Abarth-500.description: The first generation Abarth 500 was based on the Fiat 500 platform, featuring a turbocharged 1.4L engine. It was characterized by its aggressive styling, dual exhaust, and performance upgrades including sport-tuned suspension and larger brakes. Various special editions were introduced during this period, including the 595 and 695 models with increased power outputs.
Abarth-500.name: First Generation (312/223)

Abarth-500.description: The facelifted Abarth 500 maintained the same platform but received visual updates, technology improvements, and mechanical refinements. This generation featured upgraded infotainment systems, revised interior materials, and continued the performance tradition with the 595 and 695 variants offering different power levels and equipment packages. In 2020, special limited editions were introduced including the Scorpioneoro and Yamaha Monster Edition. Production continues to present.
Abarth-500.name: Second Generation (312/223 Facelift)

Abarth-595.description: The first generation Abarth 595 was introduced as a more powerful variant of the Abarth 500, featuring a 1.4L T-Jet turbocharged engine producing 160 HP in the Turismo trim and 180 HP in the Competizione trim. It offered sportier suspension, upgraded brakes, and more aggressive styling compared to the standard Abarth 500.
Abarth-595.name: First Generation

Abarth-595.description: The facelifted Abarth 595 received visual updates including revised front and rear fascias, updated interior technology, and mechanical refinements. This generation continued with various power outputs including the Turismo and Competizione variants, with the latter pushing up to 180 HP. Special editions like the Pista and Esseesse were also introduced during this period.
Abarth-595.name: Second Generation (Facelift)

Abarth-595.description: The latest generation of the Abarth 595 features further refinements to the formula with updated technology and equipment. It continues to be offered in multiple trim levels including the base 595 (145 HP), Turismo (165 HP), and Competizione (180 HP). The Esseesse variant sits at the top of the range with additional performance parts including a limited-slip differential, Sabelt seats, and a Record Monza exhaust system.
Abarth-595.name: Third Generation

Acura-CL.description: The first generation Acura CL was introduced as a replacement for the Acura Legend coupe. Available with either a 2.2L or 2.3L inline-four or a 3.0L V6 engine, this front-wheel drive luxury coupe offered a balance of performance and comfort with a focus on value in the entry-luxury segment.
Acura-CL.name: First Generation

Acura-CL.description: The second generation CL was released as a 2001 model in March 2000, featuring a completely redesigned platform. It came exclusively with a 3.2L V6 engine, with the base model producing 225 HP and the performance-oriented Type-S variant offering 260 HP. Notable for being one of the few luxury coupes with an available manual transmission option in the Type-S trim for the 2003 model year. There was no 2000 model year.
Acura-CL.name: Second Generation

Acura-ILX.description: The Acura ILX was launched for the North American market based on the ninth-generation Honda Civic platform. It was offered with multiple powertrain options including a 2.0L four-cylinder with 5-speed automatic, a 2.4L four-cylinder with 6-speed manual transmission, and a 1.5L hybrid with CVT (Acura's first hybrid variant).
Acura-ILX.name: First Generation

Acura-ILX.description: The 2016 facelift introduced the 'Jewel Eye' LED headlights, redesigned interior, and an 8-speed dual-clutch transmission option. The manual transmission was discontinued after this refresh.
Acura-ILX.name: First Generation (2016 Facelift)

Acura-ILX.description: The 2019 facelift added the 'Diamond Pentagon' grille design, revised front and rear styling, and an updated infotainment system. The ILX was discontinued in February 2022, replaced by the Acura Integra.
Acura-ILX.name: First Generation (2019 Facelift)

Acura-Integra.description: The original Acura Integra helped launch the Acura brand in North America. Available in both 3-door and 5-door hatchback body styles, it featured a 1.6L DOHC engine with 113 HP. Known for its sporty handling, practical design, and reliability, it set the foundation for the Integra's reputation.
Acura-Integra.name: First Generation

Acura-Integra.description: The second generation brought more refined styling and improved performance. Engine options included a 1.8L DOHC four-cylinder with up to 140 HP in the GS-R trim, which featured VTEC technology. This generation maintained the sporty character while improving comfort and features.
Acura-Integra.name: Second Generation

Acura-Integra.description: The third generation Integra is often considered the most iconic, particularly the Type R variant. The standard models featured a 1.8L engine producing 142 HP, while the GS-R offered 170 HP. The limited-production Type R delivered 195 HP and featured extensive weight reduction and chassis reinforcement, making it a highly sought-after collector car. The generation received facelifts in late 1994 (with new headlights) and 1998 (with updated bumpers).
Acura-Integra.name: Third Generation

Acura-Integra.description: The fourth-generation Integra was sold as the Acura RSX in North America from 2002-2006. It featured a new K-series 2.0L engine producing 160-200 HP depending on the model (RSX vs RSX Type-S). Only available as a 3-door liftback coupe, this generation marked a shift toward more powerful, turbocharged performance. Production ended in August 2006.
Acura-Integra.name: Fourth Generation (RSX Era)

Acura-Integra.description: After a 16-year hiatus, the Integra nameplate returned as a premium sport compact replacing the ILX in Acura's lineup in June 2022 for the 2023 model year. Based on the Honda Civic (eleventh generation) platform, it features a turbocharged 1.5L engine producing 200 HP and is available with a 6-speed manual transmission. The modern Integra combines sporty handling with upscale features and practicality in a five-door liftback design.
Acura-Integra.name: Fifth Generation (Rebirth)

Acura-MDX.description: The first generation MDX established itself as a luxury three-row crossover SUV with a 3.5L V6 engine producing 240-265 HP. It featured Acura's Variable Torque Management all-wheel drive system and was praised for combining car-like handling with SUV utility. Derived from Honda's Global mid-size platform, the MDX was introduced on October 5, 2000 as a 2001 model, replacing the Acura SLX.
Acura-MDX.name: First Generation

Acura-MDX.description: The second generation MDX refined the formula with more aggressive styling and improved dynamics. It featured a more powerful 3.7L V6 engine with 300 HP and Acura's Super Handling All-Wheel Drive (SH-AWD) system, which replaced the VTM-4 system. This generation added more luxury features and technology while maintaining the model's practical three-row layout.
Acura-MDX.name: Second Generation

Acura-MDX.description: The 2010 facelift brought Acura's new 'Power Plenum' grille design, a new six-speed SportShift automatic transmission with paddle shifters and downshift rev-matching, and increased compression ratio for improved performance. The Advance Package was introduced with collision mitigation braking, adaptive cruise control, active damper suspension, and blind spot monitoring. Production ended in 2013.
Acura-MDX.name: Second Generation (2010 Facelift)

Acura-MDX.description: The third generation MDX was completely redesigned and introduced a 3.5L direct-injected V6 with 290 HP, available in both front-wheel drive and SH-AWD configurations. The wheelbase increased to 111.0 inches and production moved from Canada to Lincoln, Alabama. Jewel Eye LED headlights, a 7-inch touchscreen with haptic feedback, and an 8-inch infotainment screen were standard, representing significant technology upgrades for the platform.
Acura-MDX.name: Third Generation

Acura-MDX.description: The 2017 facelift introduced a diamond pentagon front grille design, aluminum front fenders, and standard AcuraWatch safety suite including CMBS with FCW, Lane Keeping Assist, Adaptive Cruise Control, and Road Departure Mitigation. The 2017 model year also saw the introduction of the Sport Hybrid variant with a 3.0L V6 paired with three electric motors producing 321 HP combined, with standard SH-AWD and seven-speed dual-clutch transmission.
Acura-MDX.name: Third Generation (2017 Facelift)

Acura-MDX.description: The 2019 model year introduced the A-Spec appearance package with exclusive 20-inch wheels, aggressive front fascia, and sport-tuned interior with perforated leather and Alcantara trim. All 2019 models featured enhanced 9-speed automatic transmission with smoother acceleration, updated second-row seat configuration for easier third-row access, and new 20-inch wheel designs with wider tires. The Active Damper System became available on Advance package models.
Acura-MDX.name: Third Generation (2019 Facelift)

Acura-MDX.description: The fourth generation MDX was revealed as a prototype on October 14, 2020, and production began in January 2021 for the 2022 model year launch on February 2. The 2021 model year was skipped. This complete redesign featured a premium interior, sharper styling, and improved chassis with double-wishbone front suspension. The standard powertrain is a 3.5L V6 with 290 HP paired with a 10-speed automatic, while the Type-S performance variant offers a turbocharged 3.0L V6 producing 355 HP. Technology includes a 12.3-inch infotainment system with touchpad controller, 12-inch digital instrument cluster, panoramic sunroof, and advanced SH-AWD system. The fourth generation became the flagship model following the discontinuation of the Acura RLX in June 2020.
Acura-MDX.name: Fourth Generation

Acura-MDX.description: The MDX facelift was revealed on April 9, 2024 for the 2025 model year. Changes include updated exterior styling with new alloy wheel designs, a new 12.3-inch touchscreen infotainment system with Google built-in, replacement of the touchpad controller with additional storage space and wireless charging pad, and new AcuraWatch 360 safety features. The audio system was upgraded from ELS Studio 3D to a new Bang & Olufsen system with 19 speakers in non-Type-S trims and 31 speakers in Type-S variants. SiriusXM satellite radio was discontinued. Powertrain options remain unchanged.
Acura-MDX.name: Fourth Generation (2025 Facelift)

Acura-RDX.description: The first generation RDX was Acura's entry into the compact luxury SUV segment. It was powered by a turbocharged 2.3L four-cylinder engine producing 240 HP and featured Acura's Super Handling All-Wheel Drive (SH-AWD) system. The sporty RDX was notable for being one of the first luxury crossovers to use a turbocharged four-cylinder engine instead of a V6. Production began in July 2006 for the 2007 model year.
Acura-RDX.name: First Generation

Acura-RDX.description: The facelifted first generation RDX debuted in August 2009 for the 2010 model year, featuring Acura's 'power plenum' grille and the addition of a front-wheel drive option alongside the turbocharged 2.3L engine and SH-AWD system.
Acura-RDX.name: First Generation (2010 Facelift)

Acura-RDX.description: The second generation RDX was revealed in January 2012 and went on sale in April 2012 for the 2013 model year. It took a more conventional approach with a naturally aspirated 3.5L V6 engine producing 273 HP. While it still offered all-wheel drive, the complex SH-AWD system was replaced with a simpler system. This generation focused more on comfort, refinement, and fuel efficiency while increasing interior space and adding more luxury features.
Acura-RDX.name: Second Generation

Acura-RDX.description: The refreshed 2016 RDX was introduced at the 2015 Chicago Auto Show with sales beginning in mid-April 2015. It featured a more powerful 3.5L V6 producing 279 HP with updated styling including LED headlights and LED taillamps. The 2016 RDX also introduced the AcuraWatch advanced safety package with Adaptive Cruise Control and Lane Keeping Assist System (LKAS), and an updated AWD system capable of sending up to 50% torque to rear wheels.
Acura-RDX.name: Second Generation (2016 Facelift)

Acura-RDX.description: The third generation RDX debuted at the 2018 North American International Auto Show on January 15, 2018, with production beginning in May 2018. It returned to its sporty roots with a turbocharged 2.0L four-cylinder engine producing 272 HP and the return of the SH-AWD system. Built on the Honda Architecture platform, this generation features more dynamic styling, an advanced touchpad-controlled infotainment system (True Touch Pad Interface), and enhanced driving dynamics. The A-Spec trim offers sportier appearance elements, while a limited-production PMC Edition was hand-built at the same facility as the NSX.
Acura-RDX.name: Third Generation

Acura-RDX.description: The 2022 model year RDX received a facelift in September 2021 with new front and rear fascias, new exterior colors, new alloy wheel designs, and increased interior sound insulation. New features include wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration. As of the 2024 model year, SH-AWD became standard on all RDX trims, with front-wheel-drive being discontinued as an option.
Acura-RDX.name: Third Generation (2022 Facelift)

Acura-TL.description: The first generation TL replaced the Acura Vigor as the brand's mid-size luxury sedan. Available with either a 2.5L inline-five cylinder or 3.2L V6 engine, it offered a comfortable ride, premium features, and Acura's reputation for reliability in a conservatively styled package. Production began in 1995 for the 1996 model year, with assembly at Sayama Plant in Japan.
Acura-TL.name: First Generation

Acura-TL.description: The second generation TL featured more distinctive styling and came exclusively with a 3.2L V6 engine producing 225 HP. Built in Marysville, Ohio on the Honda Accord platform, this generation established the TL as a sportier alternative to competitors like the Lexus ES, offering a blend of luxury, technology, and performance.
Acura-TL.name: Second Generation

Acura-TL.description: In March 2001 for the 2002 model year, the TL received a minor facelift with a refreshed front fascia, redesigned taillights, and a 6-disc CD changer. The Type-S variant was added with 260 HP, providing enhanced performance and sportier appeal within the same platform.
Acura-TL.name: Second Generation (2002 Facelift)

Acura-TL.description: Often considered the most successful TL generation, the third-gen model featured bold styling and class-leading technology. Powered by a 3.2L V6 with 270 HP (later revised to 258 HP due to updated SAE measurement standards), it came with class-leading features including a pioneering DVD-Audio surround sound system. Assembled in Marysville, Ohio, this generation was built on the Honda Accord platform.
Acura-TL.name: Third Generation

Acura-TL.description: The 2007 Acura TL featured a slightly revised exterior with revised interior including a new steering wheel, redesigned gauges, and footwell lighting. Most notably, the Type-S variant made its return with the 3.5L V6 producing 286 HP, offering enhanced performance and distinctive styling. The base model received suspension changes for improved ride comfort.
Acura-TL.name: Third Generation (2007 Facelift)

Acura-TL.description: The final TL generation premiered for the 2009 model year with controversial styling featuring the prominent 'Power Plenum' upper grille and angular body lines. It featured a 3.5L V6 with 280 HP in the base FWD model, and the all-new SH-AWD variant with a 3.7L V6 producing 305 HP. This was the first TL to offer all-wheel drive capability.
Acura-TL.name: Fourth Generation

Acura-TL.description: For the 2012 model, Honda updated the front and rear styling, replacing the controversial 'beak' insert in the front grille with a smaller insert that flows better with the headlights. The 6-speed automatic transmission replaced the 5-speed, improving performance and efficiency. Additional features included ventilated seats, blind-spot information system, and upgraded wheels. The TL was eventually replaced by the TLX in 2015.
Acura-TL.name: Fourth Generation (2012 Facelift)

Acura-TLX.description: The first generation TLX replaced both the TL and TSX in Acura's lineup, offering a sport sedan that bridged the gap between the two previous models. Engine options included a 2.4L four-cylinder with 206 HP paired with an 8-speed dual-clutch transmission, or a 3.5L V6 with 290 HP paired with a 9-speed automatic. The V6 model was available with Acura's Super Handling All-Wheel Drive (SH-AWD) system. Model codes included UB1 (2.4L FWD), UB2 (3.5L FWD), and UB3 (3.5L AWD).
Acura-TLX.name: First Generation

Acura-TLX.description: The 2018 facelift introduced revised front fascia, fenders, and Acura's diamond pentagon grille, along with restyled wheels and new infotainment features including Apple CarPlay and Android Auto support. The A-Spec performance trim was added as a new option. The facelift maintained the same engine options as the original generation: 2.4L four-cylinder (206 HP) and 3.5L V6 (290 HP). The extended-wheelbase TLX-L variant was also introduced for the Chinese market (model code UB4).
Acura-TLX.name: First Generation (2018 Facelift)

Acura-TLX.description: The second generation TLX was built on a new Acura-exclusive platform and featured a return to performance-focused engineering with double-wishbone front suspension. The standard TLX came with a turbocharged 2.0L four-cylinder producing 272 HP paired with a 10-speed automatic. The high-performance Type S variant, reviving the Type S nameplate after a decade-long hiatus, featured a turbocharged 3.0L V6 with 355 HP, Brembo brakes, adaptive dampers, and standard SH-AWD. Model codes were UB5 (2.0T FWD), UB6 (2.0T AWD), and UB7 (Type S).
Acura-TLX.name: Second Generation

Acura-TLX.description: The 2024 facelift featured updated exterior styling with a new frameless Diamond Pentagon grille, new wheel designs, and updated rear fascia on the A-Spec model. Interior upgrades included a new 10.5-inch head-up display, new 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, larger 12.3-inch touchscreen, increased interior insulation, standard ELS STUDIO Premium Audio, and new LED ambient cabin lighting. Safety enhancements included improved AcuraWatch driver-assistance systems with new front millimeter-wave radar and updated surround-view camera. The lineup was simplified to three models: Technology (FWD), A-Spec (AWD), and Type S. Production concluded in July 2025.
Acura-TLX.name: Second Generation (2024 Facelift)

Acura-TSX.description: The first generation TSX was essentially the European/Japanese market Honda Accord adapted for the North American luxury market. It featured a high-revving 2.4L four-cylinder engine producing 200-205 HP, available with either a 6-speed manual or 5-speed automatic transmission. Known for its sharp handling, premium features, and value proposition, it established itself as an entry-level sports sedan that appealed to driving enthusiasts.
Acura-TSX.name: First Generation

Acura-TSX.description: The second generation TSX made its debut in 2009 as a larger, more refined entry-level luxury sedan. The 2.4L four-cylinder engine produced 201 HP with a 5-speed automatic or 6-speed manual transmission. For 2010, a 3.5L V6 with 280 HP became available as an option. This generation featured Advanced Compatibility Engineering body structure, xenon headlights, and a more spacious interior than its predecessor.
Acura-TSX.name: Second Generation

Acura-TSX.description: The 2011 facelift introduced a redesigned front end with horizontal-slot upper grille, new bumper cover design with body-colored sections, revised fog lamp areas, and updated taillights. Interior updates included more LED lighting and a new LED/VGA navigation screen with improved system functions. The TSX Sport Wagon was also introduced for 2011, offering a station wagon variant. This generation was eventually discontinued and replaced by the TLX, which combined the TSX and TL model lines.
Acura-TSX.name: Second Generation (2011 Facelift)

Acura-ZDX.description: The first-generation Acura ZDX was introduced as a 2010 model, representing Acura's attempt to create a luxury four-door sports coupe crossover with distinctive styling that divided opinions but established a unique identity. Built on the Honda Pilot/Acura MDX platform, the ZDX featured a dramatically sloping roofline that compromised rear headroom and cargo space in favor of coupe-like aesthetics, making it one of the first vehicles to pioneer the luxury crossover coupe segment. Powered by a 300-horsepower 3.7-liter V6 engine paired with a 6-speed automatic transmission and Acura's Super Handling All-Wheel Drive (SH-AWD) system as standard, the ZDX delivered engaging driving dynamics with precise handling and confident all-weather capability. The interior featured premium materials, advanced technology for its time including a hard drive-based navigation system, and a driver-focused cockpit design that emphasized the vehicle's sporting intentions. Despite innovative design elements and strong performance credentials, the ZDX struggled commercially due to its polarizing styling, limited practicality compared to traditional SUVs, and relatively high price point, ultimately selling fewer than 10,000 units across its four-year production run. The first-generation ZDX was notable for being the first Acura vehicle completely designed at the brand's southern California design studio in Torrance, and the production model remained remarkably faithful to the original concept car with only minor modifications to headlights and bumpers. While the ZDX failed to achieve commercial success, it established Acura's willingness to take bold design risks and laid the groundwork for the luxury crossover coupe segment that would later prove successful for other premium brands.
Acura-ZDX.name: First Generation

Acura-ZDX.description: The second-generation Acura ZDX marked the brand's entry into the electric vehicle market, representing a complete reimagining of the nameplate as Acura's first fully electric SUV after an 11-year hiatus from the ZDX name. Co-developed with General Motors and built on GM's Ultium platform at the Spring Hill, Tennessee assembly plant alongside the Cadillac Lyriq, the electric ZDX featured a more conventional SUV silhouette while maintaining distinctive Acura design language including the signature Diamond Pentagon grille and jewel-eye LED headlights. Available in three configurations including the base A-Spec with a single 358-horsepower rear-mounted motor providing 313 miles of EPA range, a dual-motor all-wheel-drive variant producing 490 horsepower with 304 miles of range, and the high-performance Type S delivering 499 horsepower and 544 lb-ft of torque with 278 miles of range and 0-60 mph acceleration in 4.3 seconds. All models utilized GM's 102 kWh Ultium lithium-ion battery pack with DC fast charging capabilities up to 190kW, allowing the single-motor model to add 81 miles of range in just 10 minutes of charging. The interior featured Acura's latest technology including a 11.3-inch touchscreen infotainment system, 11-inch head-up display, and Bang & Olufsen premium audio system, while the Type S variant included sport seats, unique styling elements, and performance-tuned suspension. Despite advanced technology, competitive range figures, and strong performance credentials, the second-generation ZDX faced significant sales challenges in the rapidly evolving EV market, leading Acura to announce its discontinuation in September 2025 after less than two years of production. The brief production run from March 2024 to September 2025 made the electric ZDX one of the shortest-lived vehicle programs in modern automotive history, though it served as an important stepping stone for Acura's electrification strategy before the brand's planned transition to the RSX electric vehicle in 2026.
Acura-ZDX.name: Second Generation (Electric)

Aiways-U5.description: The Aiways U5 is the first production model from Chinese electric vehicle startup Aiways. This all-electric compact SUV features a 63 kWh battery pack delivering approximately 400 km (250 miles) of range on the WLTP cycle. Powered by a single electric motor producing 150 kW (201 HP) and 310 Nm of torque, the U5 combines modern styling with practical interior space and contemporary technology. It was one of the first Chinese-made electric vehicles to be widely exported to European markets, beginning in 2020. The U5 features a minimalist interior with a large central touchscreen (12.3 inches), advanced driver assistance systems, and fast-charging capability that can replenish the battery from 30% to 80% in approximately 27-30 minutes.
Aiways-U5.name: First Generation

Aiways-U5.description: A styling and technology refresh of the first generation U5. The exterior styling received an update in 2021 although the dimensions remained the same. The platform, battery capacity, and electric motor remained unchanged from the pre-facelift model. The facelift included visual updates to the headlights, grille, and body panels while maintaining the same 63 kWh battery and 150 kW motor specifications.
Aiways-U5.name: First Generation (2021 Facelift)

Alfa-Romeo-Giulia.description: The modern Alfa Romeo Giulia marks the brand's return to the rear-wheel drive sports sedan segment. Built on the Giorgio platform, it features a range of engines from a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder (200-280 HP) to the high-performance Quadrifoglio's 2.9L twin-turbo V6 producing 505 HP. Unveiled in June 2015 with market launch in February 2016, the Giulia is known for its distinctive Italian styling, excellent handling characteristics, and driver-focused experience. The Quadrifoglio variant set a Nürburgring lap record for production sedans at its launch.
Alfa-Romeo-Giulia.name: First Generation (Type 952)

Alfa-Romeo-Giulia.description: The 2020 model year brought a comprehensive mid-cycle refresh with interior quality improvements and updated technology features. The redesigned center console featured an upgraded touchscreen infotainment system (with rotary dial control) and improved interior materials. For 2019, diesel engines were updated to meet Euro 6d emission standards with AdBlue technology. The Quadrifoglio received six port injectors. The trim lineup evolved with Super, Sprint, Veloce, Veloce Ti, Lusso Ti, and Quadrifoglio variants.
Alfa-Romeo-Giulia.name: First Generation (Type 952) 2020 Refresh

Alfa-Romeo-Giulia.description: The major facelift was announced in late 2022 and available for sale in 2023 (2024 model year in North America). The most significant changes include new 3+3 LED matrix adaptive headlights, revised rear combination lamps with smoked lenses, and a new 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster with three display layouts (Evolved, Relax, Heritage). For 2024, the Quadrifoglio engine power was boosted to 520 PS with a standard mechanical limited-slip differential. New variants include the Competizione trim and Super Sport variant. The lineup consists of Sprint, Ti, Veloce, Competizione, and Quadrifoglio.
Alfa-Romeo-Giulia.name: First Generation (Type 952) 2023 Facelift

Alfa-Romeo-Giulietta.description: The first generation Alfa Romeo Giulietta (Type 940) was introduced at the 2010 Geneva Motor Show. Built on the Fiat Compact platform, this front-wheel-drive compact hatchback featured distinctive Alfa Romeo styling with hidden rear door handles for a coupe-like appearance. The initial generation offered engines ranging from a 1.4L turbocharged four-cylinder to a 1.75L turbocharged four-cylinder producing 235 HP in the Quadrifoglio Verde variant. The model featured a 5-door hatchback body style and modern styling that won the 2011 European Car of the Year award (second place).
Alfa-Romeo-Giulietta.name: First Generation (Type 940)

Alfa-Romeo-Giulietta.description: The 2013 facelift was unveiled at the Frankfurt International Motor Show. This refresh included a new Uconnect infotainment system with 5" or 6.5" Radionav touchscreen, a new front grille design, chrome-plated fog light frames, redesigned and more supportive seats, new wheel designs (16, 17 and 18-inch options), and new exterior colours including Moonlight Pearl, Anodizzato Blue and Bronze. A new diesel engine variant, the 2.0-litre JTDM 2, was introduced developing 150 PS and 380 Nm of torque. All engines were upgraded to Euro 5+ emission standards.
Alfa-Romeo-Giulietta.name: First Generation (Type 940) - 2013 Facelift

Alfa-Romeo-Giulietta.description: The 2016 facelift debuted at the Geneva Motor Show with front-end styling that resembled the larger Giulia. The exterior was updated with a new Alfa Romeo brand design for lettering and logos. The trim lineup was restructured to Giulietta, Giulietta Super and Giulietta Veloce (which replaced the previous Quadrifoglio Verde while retaining the same 1.75L turbocharged engine). A new 1.6-litre JTDm diesel engine producing 120 PS with TCT transmission was introduced, along with new exterior colours and wheel designs.
Alfa-Romeo-Giulietta.name: First Generation (Type 940) - 2016 Facelift

Alfa-Romeo-Giulietta.description: For the 2019 model year, the Giulietta received updated engines all meeting Euro 6 D emission standards. The engine lineup included a 1.4-litre 120 PS turbocharged petrol, a 1.6-litre 120 PS Multijet diesel available with manual or TCT automatic transmission, and a 2.0-litre 170 PS Multijet diesel with TCT transmission. Production ended on December 22, 2020, after 469,067 units had been produced since 2010. The Giulietta was discontinued without a direct replacement.
Alfa-Romeo-Giulietta.name: First Generation (Type 940) - 2019 Facelift

Alfa-Romeo-MiTo.description: The Alfa Romeo MiTo was a three-door supermini designed to compete in the premium small car segment against vehicles like the MINI Cooper. Its name combined references to Milan (MI) and Turin (TO), the cities where it was designed and built respectively. The MiTo featured distinctive styling inspired by the 8C Competizione sports car, including teardrop headlights and Alfa's signature shield grille. The original design offered a 1.4L MultiAir turbocharged four-cylinder engine, naturally aspirated 1.4L petrol engines, and 1.3L/1.6L diesel options. The MiTo incorporated Alfa's DNA driving mode selector, allowing drivers to adjust throttle response, steering weight, and stability control settings.
Alfa-Romeo-MiTo.name: First Generation

Alfa-Romeo-MiTo.description: The 2014 model year brought significant updates including a new turbocharged 0.9L TwinAir inline-twin engine (105 PS), new chrome-plated grille, new Anthracite Grey paint colour, and burnished front light clusters. The interior was refreshed with new upholstery, three new dashboard options, and a new Uconnect 5.0 infotainment system. The updated engine range included two turbodiesel options (1.3L JTDm E5+ and 1.6L JTDm), five petrol engines, and a 1.4L Turbo LPG variant.
Alfa-Romeo-MiTo.name: First Generation (2014 Update)

Alfa-Romeo-MiTo.description: Debuting at the 2016 Geneva Motor Show, this facelift featured a reworked front fascia with a new logo badge and new lettering. The trim lineup was reorganized to MiTo, Super, and Veloce variants. The previous MiTo QV became the Mito Veloce, available with the 170 PS engine and TCT transmission. New body colours and wheel options became available. This generation was discontinued in 2020 after 293,428 total units produced across the entire MiTo production run.
Alfa-Romeo-MiTo.name: First Generation (2016 Facelift)

Alfa-Romeo-Tonale.description: The Alfa Romeo Tonale is the brand's first compact crossover SUV and marks Alfa Romeo's entry into electrification. Produced since February 2022, it is built on the FCA Small Wide 4×4 LWB platform (model code 965). Named after the Tonale mountain pass in Northern Italy, the Tonale features distinctive Alfa Romeo styling with the signature 'Scudetto' shield grille, 3+3 LED headlights inspired by the SZ and Brera, and a wraparound taillight design. It's available with various powertrain options including a 1.3L turbocharged plug-in hybrid system offering approximately 30 miles of electric-only range, as well as 1.5L and 2.0L turbocharged petrol engines, and 1.6L diesel options. The interior showcases a driver-focused cockpit with a 10.25-inch touchscreen running Uconnect 5 software and a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster. The Tonale emphasizes driving dynamics with a very quick steering rack (2.3 turns lock-to-lock), torque vectoring by braking, and frequency-selective dampers. In August 2022, a rebadged North American version was unveiled as the Dodge Hornet.
Alfa-Romeo-Tonale.name: First Generation

Aston-Martin-Vantage.description: The original Aston Martin Vantage was a performance variant of the DBS with a more powerful straight-six engine. It featured visual distinctions and performance upgrades over the standard model, though only a small number were produced during this brief production run.
Aston-Martin-Vantage.name: First Generation (1972-1973)

Aston-Martin-Vantage.description: Often referred to as 'Britain's first supercar,' the V8 Vantage featured a muscular design and a powerful 5.3L V8 engine. Performance was impressive for its era, with the ability to reach 170 mph. Later variants included the V8 Vantage Zagato with distinctive Italian coachwork.
Aston-Martin-Vantage.name: V8 Vantage (1977-1989)

Aston-Martin-Vantage.description: The high-performance Vantage variant of the Virage platform, introduced in 1993. It featured twin superchargers producing 550 HP initially (V550), with a later 600 HP upgrade (V600) available from 1998. The V8 Vantage Le Mans (1999-2000) was the final limited-production variant with 612 PS. The Vantage used wider bodywork, new suspension, and distinctive styling compared to the base Virage, with 280 coupés produced alongside 9 special Volante editions.
Aston-Martin-Vantage.name: Virage Vantage (1993-2000)

Aston-Martin-Vantage.description: The modern V8 Vantage marked Aston Martin's entry into the sports car segment to compete with the Porsche 911. Initially powered by a 4.3L V8 (later increased to 4.7L), it featured a lightweight aluminum structure and distinctive styling by Henrik Fisker. The lineup expanded to include the V12 Vantage, Roadster variants, and numerous special editions, including the track-focused GT8 and GT12 models.
Aston-Martin-Vantage.name: V8 Vantage (2005-2017)

Aston-Martin-Vantage.description: The current Vantage represents a significant departure from its predecessor with more aggressive styling and a Mercedes-AMG sourced 4.0L twin-turbo V8 producing 503 HP. Built on an all-new bonded aluminum platform, it features a more contemporary interior, sophisticated electronic systems, and improved performance capabilities. The range later expanded to include the limited-production V12 Vantage and various motorsport-inspired special editions. A major update in 2023 introduced revised styling, powertrain improvements, and chassis refinements.
Aston-Martin-Vantage.name: Current Generation (2018-present)

Audi-A1.description: The first generation Audi A1 was a premium supermini based on the Volkswagen Group PQ25 platform. Launched in August 2010, it was initially available as a three-door hatchback, followed by the five-door Sportback variant in November 2011. It featured distinctive design elements including the single-frame grille and optional contrasting roof colors. Engine options ranged from 1.0L to 1.4L TFSI petrol and 1.6L TDI diesel units. The sportier S1 variant offered a 2.0L turbocharged engine with quattro all-wheel drive. Production ended in August 2018.
Audi-A1.name: First Generation (8X)

Audi-A1.description: The second generation Audi A1 was launched in mid-June 2018 and began production in October 2018, exclusive to the five-door Sportback configuration. Built on the Volkswagen Group MQB A0 platform (shared with Volkswagen Polo Mk6 and SEAT Ibiza Mk5), it grew in size compared to its predecessor. It features a more aggressive design with styling cues inspired by the original Quattro rally car. The interior received Audi's latest technology including the Virtual Cockpit digital instrument display and improved infotainment systems. Engine options include 1.0L, 1.5L, and 2.0L TFSI petrol engines, with no diesel options offered. This generation focuses more on connectivity, technology, and sportier design while maintaining premium quality in the small car segment. Audi announced the A1 will be discontinued without a successor once this generation's lifecycle ends.
Audi-A1.name: Second Generation (GB)

Audi-A3.description: The original Audi A3 pioneered the premium compact segment, built on the Volkswagen Group A platform. Launched in September 1996 in Europe, initially available only as a three-door hatchback, it featured a range of four-cylinder engines including the 1.8T. The first-generation A3 established Audi's reputation for bringing premium quality and features to smaller vehicles. While it was replaced in Europe in 2003, Brazilian production continued until 2006.
Audi-A3.name: First Generation (8L)

Audi-A3.description: Built on the Volkswagen Group A5 (PQ35) platform, the second-generation A3 launched at the 2003 Geneva Motor Show and expanded to include a five-door Sportback variant introduced in June 2004. Engine options ranged from 1.2L to 3.2L V6 petrol and various TDI diesel units. This generation introduced the S3 and RS3 high-performance variants and received a facelift in 2008 with updated styling, modified grille, daytime running lights, and common rail 2.0 TDI engines.
Audi-A3.name: Second Generation (8P)

Audi-A3.description: Based on the Volkswagen Group MQB platform, the third-generation A3 was unveiled at the 2012 Geneva Motor Show and went on sale in September 2012. Offered in three-door hatchback, five-door Sportback, four-door sedan, and cabriolet body styles. It featured Audi's latest technology including the Virtual Cockpit digital instrument cluster and advanced driver assistance systems. Engine options included efficient TFSI petrol and TDI diesel units, plus the e-tron plug-in hybrid variant. The high-performance S3 and RS3 models continued, with the latter featuring a distinctive five-cylinder engine. The generation received a facelift in 2016 with updated styling including Matrix LED headlamps.
Audi-A3.name: Third Generation (8V)

Audi-A3.description: The 2016 facelift brought significant cosmetic updates to the A3 Saloon, including Matrix LED headlamps as seen in the A8 flagship, optional sequentially animated turn-signal treatment on rear taillights, and a refreshed front grille aligned with Audi's A4 design language. Interior updates included a fully digital 12.3-inch instrument cluster and optional Apple CarPlay and Android Auto support.
Audi-A3.name: Third Generation (8V) 2016 Facelift

Audi-A3.description: The fourth-generation A3 was unveiled on 3 March 2020 as the Sportback model, with the Saloon model unveiled on 21 April 2020. Built on the Volkswagen Group MQB Evo platform, it is offered as a five-door Sportback and four-door sedan. It features more angular design language inspired by Lamborghini, LED headlights with optional Matrix LED, and a completely redesigned interior with dual digital screens and connected services. Powertrain options include a turbocharged 1.0L 3-cylinder engine with 110 hp, 1.5L turbocharged petrol engines, 2.0L TDI diesel engines, and PHEV variants. The range continues to include S3 and RS3 performance variants with a 2.5L 5-cylinder TFSI engine. This generation focuses on digitalization, connectivity, and electrification while maintaining Audi's premium positioning in the compact segment. A 2024 refresh introduced updated styling, the AllStreet off-road variant, and further powertrain refinements.
Audi-A3.name: Fourth Generation (8Y)

Audi-A3-e-tron.description: The first Audi A3 e-tron was based on the third-generation A3 platform (8V), representing Audi's first production plug-in hybrid vehicle for many markets. Available exclusively in the Sportback (five-door hatchback) body style, it combined a 1.4-liter TFSI turbocharged gasoline engine producing 148 horsepower with an electric motor generating 101 horsepower, for a combined system output of 201 horsepower and 258 lb-ft of torque. The powertrain incorporated a six-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission with the electric motor integrated into the gearbox. An 8.8 kWh lithium-ion battery pack provided approximately 50 km of electric-only range on the NEDC cycle, with a total range of 940 km. Performance included 0-100 km/h acceleration in 7.6 seconds and a top speed of 220 km/h. Visually, the e-tron was distinguished from conventional A3 models by subtle badging, unique LED daytime running lights, and available special 'e-tron' wheel designs. The interior featured specific e-tron displays showing energy flow, charging status, and electric range, while maintaining the premium fit and finish of standard A3 models. A charging port was discreetly hidden behind the four rings logo in the front grille. The A3 e-tron offered multiple driving modes including EV (electric only), Hybrid, Hold, and Charge modes. Deliveries began in August 2014 across Europe and discontinued in November 2018.
Audi-A3-e-tron.name: First Generation (8V)

Audi-A3-e-tron.description: The A3 Sportback e-tron was briefly reintroduced at the end of 2019 for the 2020 model year, renamed to A3 Sportback 40 e-tron under Audi's new naming scheme. This version maintained the same powertrain as the original model with the 1.4-liter TFSI engine coupled to the electric motor, and the same 8.8 kWh battery pack. However, specification levels were adjusted, with the 2020 model losing previously standard LED headlights while gaining Audi's Virtual Cockpit as standard. The electric-only range was rated at 22 miles under the new WLTP test standard. This brief reintroduction represented the final production of the plug-in hybrid variant on the 8V platform before the introduction of the new TFSIe variants on the 8Y platform.
Audi-A3-e-tron.name: A3 Sportback 40 e-tron (8V Reintroduction)

Audi-A3-e-tron.description: The second-generation Audi A3 plug-in hybrid, marketed as A3 TFSIe (replacing the e-tron branding which is reserved for fully electric Audi vehicles), is based on the fourth-generation A3 platform (8Y), launched in May 2020. Available as Sportback and sedan variants in select markets outside North America, it features significantly upgraded powertrain technology and design. Two primary variants are offered: the 40 TFSIe with 0-100 km/h acceleration in 7.4 seconds, and the 45 TFSIe based on the Volkswagen Golf GTE platform with 0-100 km/h in 6.3 seconds. The powertrain combines a turbocharged gasoline engine with a permanent magnet AC synchronous electric motor (81-85 kW). A 13 kWh lithium-ion battery pack provides improved electric-only range compared to the previous generation. The exterior design adopts the more angular, aggressive styling of the latest A3 generation with distinctive LED lighting signatures, an enlarged Singleframe grille, and subtle TFSIe specific details. The interior features Audi's latest MMI infotainment system with touchscreen control, optional 12.3-inch Virtual Cockpit digital instrument cluster, and dedicated hybrid system displays. The new model offers enhanced driving modes including an efficiency-focused mode that maximizes hybrid operation. Charging capabilities include AC charging with flexible charging times. The second-generation TFSIe benefits from improved battery integration and enhanced technology for reduced cargo space compromise and optimized hybrid operation using navigation data. This generation represents a mature execution of Audi's plug-in hybrid technology on the MQB Evo platform, combining premium compact car experience with significantly improved electric capability and overall efficiency.
Audi-A3-e-tron.name: Second Generation (8Y TFSIe)

Audi-A4.description: The original Audi A4 replaced the Audi 80 and was built on the Volkswagen Group B5 platform, with production starting in November 1994. Available as a sedan and Avant (wagon), it featured a front-wheel drive layout with optional quattro all-wheel drive. Engine options included four and six-cylinder units ranging from 1.6L to 2.8L, plus diesel variants. The B5 A4 established Audi's modern design language and helped elevate the brand as a serious competitor to BMW and Mercedes-Benz in the premium compact executive segment.
Audi-A4.name: First Generation (B5)

Audi-A4.description: A significant facelift was introduced for the 1998 B5 model year at the 1997 Frankfurt Motor Show, with sales beginning in Europe in early 1998. The 2.8-litre 30-valve V6 engine replaced the 2.8-litre 12-valve, and a 2.5-litre V6 TDI diesel became available. A six-speed manual gearbox was introduced, and the high-performance Audi S4 became part of the A4 lineup. A further facelift in February 1999 as a 1999.5 model brought largely cosmetic changes including new bumpers, lights, and center console. In 1999, Audi introduced the RS4 Avant, available only in the Avant bodystyle.
Audi-A4.name: First Generation (B5) Facelift

Audi-A4.description: The B6 A4 featured a completely new design with a more sculpted body and a wider stance, launched in 2000 with model years beginning in 2001. It continued to offer sedan and Avant body styles, with the addition of the Cabriolet variant introduced in 2002. The platform was revised for improved handling and safety. Engine options expanded to include petrol and diesel units, with the high-performance S4 featuring a 4.2L V8 engine.
Audi-A4.name: Second Generation (B6)

Audi-A4.description: A significant facelift was introduced in 2003, updating the styling and technology. The B6 continued with various TFSI and TDI engine options. The Cabriolet variant production continued through 2006, becoming a popular addition to the A4 lineup.
Audi-A4.name: Second Generation (B6) Facelift

Audi-A4.description: The B7 represented a heavily revised evolution of the B6, introduced in late 2004 with model year 2005. It featured sharper styling with Audi's then-new single-frame grille and introduced new technologies and refinements to the chassis and drivetrain. The sedan and Avant variants began in 2004, while the Cabriolet was added in 2006. The B7 featured improved engines including 2.0 TFSI and 3.2L V6 FSI petrol engines. This generation saw the introduction of the RS4 variant with a high-revving 4.2L V8 FSI engine producing 420 HP. The B7 sedan continued through 2008, with the Cabriolet variant lasting through 2009.
Audi-A4.name: Third Generation (B7)

Audi-A4.description: Built on the new Volkswagen Group MLB (Modular Longitudinal Platform), the B8 A4 was unveiled in August 2007 and officially launched in October 2007, with model year 2009 for most markets. It featured a longer wheelbase and shorter overhangs compared to the B7. It introduced technologies including Audi Drive Select, adaptive dynamics, and LED daytime running lights. Engine options included efficient TFSI petrol and TDI diesel units with various power outputs.
Audi-A4.name: Fourth Generation (B8)

Audi-A4.description: A significant facelift was released in 2012 for the 2013 model year (B8.5), featuring redesigned LED headlamps and taillights, front air dam with fog lamps, and closely set twin exhausts. Interior changes included Bluetooth connectivity for audio streaming and a redesigned ignition key. The 2012 facelift also introduced new TDIe and TDI Ultra engines for improved emissions compliance. In Europe, a wide range of petrol and diesel options remained available including TFSI and TDI variants. North American B8 models continued through 2016 with this facelift specification.
Audi-A4.name: Fourth Generation (B8) Facelift

Audi-A4.description: The B9 A4 was revealed in June 2015 and officially launched at the Frankfurt Motor Show in September 2015, with production beginning in July 2015. Available in European markets as model year 2016 and North American markets as model year 2017. The B9 is slightly larger than the B8 but lighter thanks to aluminum-hybrid construction. It features the Virtual Cockpit digital instrument cluster, advanced driver assistance systems, Apple CarPlay, Android Auto, and full-color head-up display. Multiple petrol and diesel engine options were available including TFSI and TDI variants. A slight facelift was introduced in 2019 with new front and rear bumpers inspired by the Audi RS4.
Audi-A4.name: Fifth Generation (B9)

Audi-A4.description: A significant facelift (B9.5) was made available in 2020, bringing the A4's aesthetic in line with the S4, A6, A7, and A8. Nearly every body panel was altered with redesigned headlights and taillights, while the character line was removed in favor of creases on the front and rear fenders. The mechanical controls for the infotainment center were replaced with a touchscreen and larger display. Post-facelift, the A4 and S4 share their body panels with only grilles and badges distinguishing them. The 2025 model year marks the final production year for the Audi A4 nameplate after nearly three decades, with the model being discontinued and replaced by the redesigned Audi A5.
Audi-A4.name: Fifth Generation (B9) Facelift

Audi-A5.description: The original Audi A5 (Type 8T) was produced from November 2007 to November 2016 and marketed as model years 2008-2016. Unveiled at the March 2007 Geneva Motor Show, the A5 marked Audi's return to the compact executive coupe market. Designed by Walter de Silva, the A5 featured elegant proportions and was the first B8-platform vehicle released (preceding the A4 and Q5). The range included the two-door Coupe, Cabriolet convertible, and four-door Sportback liftback variants. Engine options included four and six-cylinder TFSI petrol and TDI diesel units. The S5 Coupe featured a 4.2L V8, while the S5 Cabriolet and Sportback used a supercharged 3.0L TFSI V6. The RS5 Coupe offered a high-revving 4.2L FSI V8 producing 450 HP starting in 2010. A facelift in 2012 brought revised styling and updated technology.
Audi-A5.name: First Generation (8T)

Audi-A5.description: Built on the B9 A4's MLB Evo platform (Volkswagen Group MLBevo), the second-generation A5 was unveiled on 2 June 2016 with production spanning June 2016 to 2024. The A5 continues to be offered in Coupe, Sportback, and Cabriolet body styles (Sportback model years continue through 2025). The interior features Audi's Virtual Cockpit digital instrument cluster and improved infotainment systems. Engine options include four and six-cylinder TFSI petrol and TDI diesel units, with the S5 featuring a turbocharged 3.0L V6 and the RS5 powered by a 2.9L twin-turbo V6 producing 450 HP. A facelift in 2019 refreshed the exterior design and updated the interior technology. The A5 represents the balance between elegance and sportiness in Audi's lineup.
Audi-A5.name: Second Generation (F5)

Audi-A5.description: The third-generation Audi A5 (B10) represents a significant transformation announced on 16 July 2024. As part of Audi's new strategy, the A5 replaces both the A4 sedan and the previous A5 coupe/cabriolet/sportback lineup. Production began August 2024 with model year 2025. The B10 is built on the new Premium Platform Combustion (PPC). Unlike previous generations, no coupe or cabriolet models are offered; instead, the A5 is available exclusively as a liftback sedan, Avant estate, and A5L variants (extended wheelbase for China markets). The interior features a panoramic OLED display with curved design and advanced infotainment including the Audi MMI system. Powertrains include 2.0L and 3.0L TFSI petrol engines, 2.0L TDI diesel engines, and plug-in hybrid e-hybrid variants with advanced 48V mild hybrid technology (MHEV Plus). This generation continues Audi's evolution toward a streamlined, efficient model lineup.
Audi-A5.name: Third Generation (B10)

Audi-A6.description: The original Audi A6 was essentially a rebadged and facelifted Audi 100, representing Audi's new naming convention. Available as a sedan and Avant (wagon), it featured a range of four and six-cylinder engines with front-wheel drive or quattro all-wheel drive. The C4 A6 established the foundation for Audi's mid-size luxury offering.
Audi-A6.name: First Generation (C4)

Audi-A6.description: The C5 generation marked a significant step forward with a completely new design featuring a more rounded appearance. It introduced new technologies including the aluminum-intensive 'Audi Space Frame' for the high-performance S6 and RS6 variants. Engine options ranged from efficient four-cylinders to powerful V8s, and the generation also saw the introduction of the Allroad quattro, a lifted wagon with adjustable air suspension.
Audi-A6.name: Second Generation (C5)

Audi-A6.description: The C6 A6 featured more distinctive styling with Audi's single-frame grille becoming a prominent design element. This generation saw advancements in technology including Audi's MMI (Multi Media Interface) system and adaptive air suspension. Engine options included FSI direct-injection petrol and common-rail diesel units, with the RS6 offering a twin-turbocharged V10 producing 580 HP, making it one of the most powerful sedans of its time.
Audi-A6.name: Third Generation (C6)

Audi-A6.description: Built on the MLB (Modular Longitudinal Platform), the C7 A6 featured a more athletic design with a longer wheelbase but shorter overhangs. Production began in January 2011 with the first model year arriving in 2012. This generation introduced extensive use of aluminum to reduce weight and improve efficiency. Technology advancements included full LED headlights, a head-up display, and advanced driver assistance systems. Engine options included more efficient TFSI petrol and TDI diesel units. The A6 shares its platform and interior with the Audi A7, which was released shortly after in 2011.
Audi-A6.name: Fourth Generation (C7)

Audi-A6.description: The C8 A6 was unveiled ahead of the 2018 Geneva Motor Show and went on sale in June 2018. It features Audi's latest design language with a wider, lower appearance and sharper lines. The interior represents a technological leap with a dual-touchscreen MMI system replacing most physical buttons. All engines are offered with mild-hybrid (MHEV) drivetrain as standard, featuring a 48-volt system. Technology advancements include sophisticated driver assistance systems and adaptive air suspension options. The C8 is available as a sedan and Avant (station wagon), with performance variants including the S6 and RS6 Avant. Throughout its evolution, the A6 has maintained its position as a technology leader in Audi's lineup, balancing comfort, performance, and innovation.
Audi-A6.name: Fifth Generation (C8)

Audi-A6.description: The C9 A6, officially unveiled on 4 March 2025, features a completely redesigned exterior and interior using Audi's latest design language. Built on the new Premium Platform Combustion (PPC) architecture—which debuted on the A5 (B10)—it delivers improved efficiency and driving dynamics. The Avant station wagon model was unveiled first with orders beginning in March 2025, while the sedan model followed on 15 April 2025. The C9 is the most aerodynamic Audi Avant with a combustion engine, featuring a drag coefficient of 0.25. The interior features an updated MMI technology and enhanced driver assistance systems. Powertrain options include efficient petrol engines with mild-hybrid technology and diesel options, as well as plug-in hybrid variants. Available with all-wheel steering and Quattro sport differential on Quattro all-wheel drive models, plus optional adaptive air suspension and second-generation digital OLED lighting technology. The sixth generation continues the A6's legacy as a technological leader in the executive car segment, combining luxury, performance, and sustainability.
Audi-A6.name: Sixth Generation (C9)

Audi-A7.description: The original Audi A7 pioneered the 'four-door coupe' concept in Audi's lineup, featuring a distinctive fastback design with a practical liftback tailgate. Based on the MLB platform shared with the A6, it combined elegant, flowing lines with a sporty, low-slung profile. The interior featured premium materials and advanced technology including Audi's MMI system. Engine options mirrored the A6 lineup with V6 and V8 petrol and diesel options, while the S7 featured a twin-turbo V8 and the RS7 offered significant performance. The first-generation A7 was released in autumn 2010 and became the first fastback in the Audi C-platform series since the C2 Audi 100.
Audi-A7.name: First Generation (4G)

Audi-A7.description: Audi unveiled the 2015 A7 facelift in May 2014, bringing visual and technical updates to the original design. The facelift included updated styling elements, refined MMI system features, and the introduction of Audi Connect telematics with 4G mobile internet and map updates. The interior was refreshed with new materials and controls. Engine options continued with petrol and diesel variants, and the S7 and RS7 performance models were updated with the RS7 Performance variant offering up to 605 HP. This facelift maintained the core fastback character while modernizing the vehicle's technology and styling.
Audi-A7.name: First Generation (4G) 2015 Facelift

Audi-A7.description: Built on the MLB Evo platform, the second-generation A7 features more angular styling while maintaining the distinctive fastback silhouette. Revealed in October 2017 and officially launched in Germany in February 2018, this generation represents a comprehensive redesign. The interior features a dual-touchscreen MMI system and Audi's Virtual Cockpit digital instrument cluster as standard. Engine options include 2.0L and 3.0L turbocharged petrol engines, along with 2.0L and 3.0L diesel variants, all equipped with mild-hybrid (MHEV) 48-volt technology for improved efficiency. The range includes performance-oriented S7 and RS7 Sportback variants. Advanced driver assistance systems and a more digitized interface position the A7 as a technology leader. An extended-wheelbase variant called the A7L was launched in China in 2021.
Audi-A7.name: Second Generation (4K)

Audi-Q2.description: The Audi Q2 is the brand's smallest SUV, introduced to target the growing urban compact crossover segment. Built on the Volkswagen Group MQB A1 platform (shared with the Mk7 Volkswagen Golf), it features distinctive styling with a polygon design theme and the option for contrasting C-pillar 'blades' in different colors. Despite its compact dimensions, the Q2 maintains Audi's premium interior quality with available Virtual Cockpit digital instruments and advanced infotainment systems. Engine options include three and four-cylinder TFSI petrol and TDI diesel units, with front-wheel drive standard and quattro all-wheel drive available on higher-powered variants. An electric Q2L e-tron variant was introduced in 2019 for the Chinese market, while the SQ2 performance variant launched in 2019. The Q2 is not sold in the United States or Canada.
Audi-Q2.name: First Generation (GA)

Audi-Q2.description: The 2020 facelift refreshed the exterior design and updated the technology offerings of the Audi Q2 while maintaining the same Volkswagen Group MQB A1 platform. The facelift introduced updated styling with new headlight designs, refreshed grille, and refined bumper treatments. Interior updates included enhanced infotainment systems and revised trim options. The Q2 continued with the same engine lineup and transmission options. In February 2022, Audi confirmed that the Q2 will not receive a second generation and will be discontinued without a direct successor, making this the only generation of the model.
Audi-Q2.name: First Generation (GA) - 2020 Facelift

Audi-Q3.description: The original Audi Q3 was a compact luxury crossover SUV built on the Volkswagen Group A5 (PQ35) platform, produced from June 2011 to 2014. It featured a design influenced by the larger Q5 but with more compact proportions. Engine options included four-cylinder TFSI petrol and TDI diesel units, with front-wheel drive or quattro all-wheel drive. The RS Q3 performance variant was introduced in 2013, featuring a turbocharged five-cylinder engine producing up to 367 HP in Performance trim.
Audi-Q3.name: First Generation (8U)

Audi-Q3.description: A facelift in 2014 updated the styling and technology for the first-generation Q3, including redesigned front lights with re-profiled LEDs, a wider chrome-surrounded grille, enlarged lower air vents, body-coloured wheel arch surrounds and door sills, and reshaped rear bumper design. The interior received a new steering wheel design and optional blind spot and lane departure warning systems. Engine performance was improved across the range, with the 1.4-litre TFSI gaining cylinder-on-demand technology. The RS Q3 gained 30 PS over the previous model, with torque uprated to 332 lbft (450 Nm). Production continued through 2018.
Audi-Q3.name: First Generation (8U; 2014 Facelift)

Audi-Q3.description: Built on the Volkswagen Group MQB A2 platform, the second-generation Q3 was officially unveiled on July 25, 2018 and began production in August 2018. The model grew in size with a longer wheelbase providing more interior space than its predecessor. It features more angular styling in line with Audi's latest design language. The interior represents a significant upgrade with digital instrumentation and improved infotainment systems. Engine options include four-cylinder TFSI petrol and TDI diesel units with mild-hybrid technology available on some variants. The range includes the standard Q3 and the coupe-inspired Q3 Sportback, along with the high-performance RS Q3 variant featuring a distinctive turbocharged five-cylinder engine. Production ended in June 2025, with model years spanning 2019 through 2025.
Audi-Q3.name: Second Generation (F3)

Audi-Q3.description: The third-generation Audi Q3 was unveiled on June 16, 2025, and began production in July 2025, representing a comprehensive redesign with inspiration drawn from the third-generation Q5. Built on the Volkswagen Group MQB Evo platform, it features a new design language with distinctive split headlights and updated proportions. Notable design changes include a column-mounted shifter instead of the traditional console-mounted gear selector. Powertrain options include 1.5L and 2.0L turbocharged TFSI petrol engines, a 2.0L TDI diesel engine, and a 1.5L turbocharged plug-in hybrid variant with 75 miles of electric range. The new Q3 achieves improved efficiency and performance while maintaining the model's position as a premium compact crossover. Sales commenced in late 2025 for the 2026 model year.
Audi-Q3.name: Third Generation (FJ)

Audi-Q4-e-tron.description: The Audi Q4 e-tron is the brand's first compact electric SUV, built on the Volkswagen Group MEB platform dedicated to electric vehicles. It's available in both standard SUV and Sportback body styles with the latter featuring a more coupe-like roofline. The Q4 e-tron is offered with various powertrain configurations, including single-motor rear-wheel drive (Q4 40 e-tron) producing 201 HP and dual-motor quattro all-wheel drive (Q4 50 e-tron) delivering 295 HP. Battery options include 52 kWh and 77 kWh (net capacity) packs, with the larger battery providing up to 320 miles of range (WLTP). The interior features Audi's latest technology including an available augmented reality head-up display that projects navigation instructions into the driver's field of view. The Q4 e-tron brings Audi's premium electric vehicle experience to a more accessible price point while maintaining the brand's design, quality, and technology standards.
Audi-Q4-e-tron.name: First Generation

Audi-Q5.description: The original Audi Q5 was a compact luxury crossover SUV built on the Volkswagen Group MLB platform. It featured a design that balanced sportiness with practicality, offering more cargo space than its competitors while maintaining Audi's distinctive styling. Engine options included 2.0 L TFSI I4, 3.2 L FSI V6 petrol engines, and 2.0 L and 3.0 L TDI diesel units. The high-performance SQ5 was initially offered as a diesel in Europe (making it Audi's first diesel S model) and later as a petrol model in North America. The first-generation Q5 quickly became one of Audi's best-selling models globally, with production beginning in July 2008.
Audi-Q5.name: First Generation (8R)

Audi-Q5.description: The 2012 facelift of the first generation introduced a redesigned front and rear light configuration, updated styling, and a new set of engines that increased both output and efficiency. New engine options included the 2.0 TFSI hybrid quattro, 3.0 TFSI quattro (272PS), and improved TDI diesel units. Interior updates featured 4-button MMI navigation plus system, narrow chrome trim on main controls, and large fabric-upholstered door panels with optional wood or aluminium inlays. The vehicles went on sale in summer 2012 and remained in production until 2017.
Audi-Q5.name: First Generation (8R 2012 Facelift)

Audi-Q5.description: Built on the updated MLB Evo platform, the second-generation Q5 was revealed at the 2016 Paris Motor Show with production beginning on 30 September 2016 for the 2017 model year. The Q5 was lighter than its predecessor despite increased dimensions and featured more angular styling in line with Audi's modern design language. The interior represented a significant upgrade with digital instrumentation and improved infotainment systems. Engine options included 2.0 L TFSI I4, 2.0 L TFSI MHEV I4, 2.0 L TFSIe PHEV, 2.0 L TDI I4, and 3.0 L TDI V6, with mild-hybrid and plug-in hybrid technology. The performance-oriented SQ5 continued with both diesel and petrol engines depending on market.
Audi-Q5.name: Second Generation (FY)

Audi-Q5.description: The 2021 facelift brought exterior updates including revised grille design, updated bumper side air intakes, new side sill styling, and refreshed rear trim. Interior changes featured Generation 3 MMI infotainment technologies with digital marketplace for Audi Connect plans and SiriusXM integration. New paint colors including District Green and Ultra Blue became available on PHEV and SQ5 variants. The Q5 Sportback coupe variant was introduced in January 2021, offering a sleeker body style alongside the traditional SUV. Production continued until February 2025, with the second generation remaining one of Audi's best-sellers globally, offering a balance of practicality, technology, and driving dynamics in the premium midsize SUV segment.
Audi-Q5.name: Second Generation (FY 2021 Facelift)

Audi-Q5.description: The third-generation Audi Q5 was officially unveiled on 2 September 2024 and represents the first complete redesign since 2018, built on Volkswagen Group's new Premium Platform Combustion (PPC) architecture shared with the redesigned Audi A5. Production commenced in November 2024 for the 2026 model year. The exterior styling features a raked silhouette inspired by the larger Q7, with customizable lighting signatures and available IQ.Light LED matrix headlamps providing illumination up to 500 meters. The interior features an 11.9-inch digital instrument cluster and 14.5-inch touchscreen infotainment system. Engine options include 2.0 L TFSI I4, 3.0 L TFSI V6 (SQ5), and 2.0 L TDI I4, all with 48-volt mild-hybrid systems. A Sportback coupe SUV variant was unveiled on 26 November 2024 and launched in North America in April 2025. Plug-in hybrid variants with 25.9 kWh batteries were revealed in June 2025.
Audi-Q5.name: Third Generation (GU)

Audi-Q7.description: The original Audi Q7 was the brand's first SUV, built on the Volkswagen Group PL71 platform. It was a full-size, seven-seat luxury SUV featuring Audi's quattro all-wheel drive system. Engine options included V6 and V8 TFSI petrol and TDI diesel units, plus a limited-production V12 TDI with 500 HP that was the most powerful diesel SUV of its time. The first-generation Q7 established Audi in the luxury SUV segment, combining practicality with the brand's premium quality and advanced technology.
Audi-Q7.name: First Generation (4L)

Audi-Q7.description: Built on the Volkswagen Group MLB Evo platform, the second-generation Q7 was unveiled in January 2015 at the North American International Auto Show and entered production in May 2015. It is significantly lighter than its predecessor due to extensive use of aluminum and high-strength steel. The design features sharper lines and a more imposing presence. The interior represents a significant upgrade with available virtual cockpit digital instrumentation and a dual-screen MMI touch system. Engine options include V6 and V8 TFSI petrol and TDI diesel units, plus plug-in hybrid variants (Q7 TFSI e and Q7 e-tron TDI) and the performance-oriented SQ7 with a V8 TDI or TFSI engine depending on the market.
Audi-Q7.name: Second Generation (4M)

Audi-Q7.description: The Q7 received a major facelift for the 2020 model year, introducing styling tweaks such as a redesigned grille, front and rear bumpers, new side sills, chrome trim for the tailgate and revised exhaust tips. The interior was significantly updated with a new infotainment system featuring dual touchscreens and revised dashboard and centre console. LED headlights became standard with Matrix LEDs or HD Matrix LEDs and Audi Laser Light offered as options. Air suspension was included as standard, and a new active roll-stabilisation system was introduced. Three mild-hybrid 3.0-litre V6 powertrains became available.
Audi-Q7.name: Second Generation (4M) 2020 Facelift

Audi-Q7.description: Audi announced a second facelift in January 2024 for the 2025 model year, introducing further enhancements to the front and rear headlight design. The update features HD Matrix LED headlights with Laser high-beam and OLED rear lights with a new design. This represents the final iteration of the MLB Evo platform generation.
Audi-Q7.name: Second Generation (4M) 2025 Facelift

Audi-Q7.description: The third-generation Audi Q7 represents a comprehensive redesign set to debut in early 2026. Built on the new Premium Platform Combustion (PPC), it continues the seven-seat luxury SUV segment positioning. The new Q7 will feature Audi's latest design language and technology, with enhanced efficiency and performance. Engine options will include petrol, diesel, and hybrid variants, maintaining the model's reputation as a flagship luxury SUV.
Audi-Q7.name: Third Generation (Premium Platform Combustion)

Audi-Q8.description: The Audi Q8 is the brand's first coupe-SUV and serves as its flagship SUV model. Built on the MLB Evo platform shared with the Q7, it features a more aggressive, sporty design with a sloping roofline, frameless doors, and distinctive styling elements including an octagonal single-frame grille. The initial generation launched in June 2018 with European sales beginning in July 2018. Engine options include V6 and V8 TFSI petrol and TDI diesel units with mild-hybrid technology standard. The interior features Audi's dual-touchscreen MMI system and virtual cockpit digital instruments. The SQ8 performance variant launched in June 2019 with a 4.0-litre V8 diesel engine. The RS Q8, featuring a 4.0-litre twin-turbo V8 petrol engine producing 591 HP, was unveiled at the 2019 LA Auto Show.
Audi-Q8.name: First Generation

Audi-Q8.description: The facelifted Q8 was unveiled on 5 September 2023 for the 2024 model year. Subtle exterior changes include larger air inlets in the front bumper and a new exhaust setup. The Singleframe grille now features octagonal elements flowing smoothly into the headlamps. The design of the Matrix LED headlights has been changed, with new high-tech laser lights increasing the range of high beams. Audi implemented OLED technology in the tail lamps as both an aesthetic feature and safety measure. The facelift adds three new metallic paint options (Chili Red, Ascari Blue, Sakhir Gold) and five alloy wheel designs ranging from 21 to 23 inches. The SQ8 features an increased 500 hp output from its 4.0-litre V8 petrol engine. In 2024, the RS Q8 was also facelifted with a Performance version introduced, featuring a 640 hp V8 engine.
Audi-Q8.name: First Generation (2024 Facelift)

Audi-Q8-e-tron.description: The Audi e-tron is a battery electric mid-size luxury crossover SUV produced by Audi since 2018. The e-tron was unveiled as a concept car at the 2015 Frankfurt Motor Show and the final production version was revealed on September 17, 2018. It was first delivered in May 2019, making it Audi's first battery electric mass production car. The Sportback variant, featuring a coupe-style roof, entered production in early 2020. The original e-tron featured a 95 kWh battery (83.6 kWh usable) with 50 quattro, 55 quattro, and S quattro variants available in both SUV and Sportback body styles.
Audi-Q8-e-tron.name: First Generation (Audi e-tron)

Audi-Q8-e-tron.description: In 2022, the vehicle underwent a significant facelift and was renamed to the Audi Q8 e-tron (with the performance version called SQ8 e-tron), offered in both regular and Sportback body styles. Key improvements in the facelifted Q8 e-tron include an updated design with a new enclosed Singleframe grille and revised lighting, increased battery capacity from 95 kWh to 114 kWh (106 kWh usable), and improved motor efficiency. The Q8 e-tron is available in multiple variants including 50, 55, and performance SQ8 versions. Production concluded in February 2025.
Audi-Q8-e-tron.name: First Generation (2022 Facelift / Q8 e-tron)

Audi-RS-3.description: The original Audi RS 3 was based on the second-generation A3 (8P) platform, offered exclusively in the five-door Sportback body style. It featured a turbocharged 2.5L five-cylinder engine producing 340 PS (340 HP), paired with a seven-speed S tronic dual-clutch transmission and quattro all-wheel drive. The engine delivered 450 Nm (331 lb-ft) of torque with a unique exhaust note reminiscent of Audi's rally heritage. Performance was impressive, with 0-100 km/h (0-62 mph) acceleration in 4.6 seconds and a top speed of 250 km/h. The RS 3 featured wider fenders, aggressive styling, lowered suspension by 25 mm, and 370 mm front/310 mm rear ventilated brakes. First deliveries started in early 2011.
Audi-RS-3.name: First Generation (8P)

Audi-RS-3.description: Based on the third-generation A3 (8V), the second-generation RS 3 was initially offered as a Sportback with a turbocharged 2.5L five-cylinder engine producing 367 PS (362 HP) and 465 Nm (343 lb-ft) of torque. It went on sale in the first quarter of 2015 with a 7-speed dual-clutch S-Tronic transmission and quattro all-wheel drive system. The exterior featured distinctive RS styling including flared wheel arches, aggressive bumpers, and oval exhaust tips. Performance included 0-100 km/h acceleration in 4.3 seconds with an electronically limited top speed of 280 km/h.
Audi-RS-3.name: Second Generation (8V)

Audi-RS-3.description: The RS 3 received a significant facelift in 2017, with a power increase to 400 PS (395 HP) and 480 Nm (354 lb-ft) of torque, along with improved performance figures of 0-100 km/h in 4.1 seconds (2017-2018) and later 3.8 seconds (2019-2020). The facelift coincided with the introduction of the RS 3 sedan (saloon) variant alongside the Sportback. The exterior featured updated styling with refreshed headlights and body panels, while the interior received digital displays and enhanced infotainment. The RS 3 was also introduced to the North American market in 2017. Available with fixed or adjustable magnetic dampers and various optional packages including Black Optic and Dynamic packages.
Audi-RS-3.name: Second Generation (8V) Facelift

Audi-RS-3.description: The current RS 3, based on the fourth-generation A3 (8Y), features the most powerful version of the 2.5L five-cylinder engine yet, producing 400 PS (394 HP) in standard European spec and 401 PS (395 HP) in the US market, with 500 Nm (368 lb-ft) of torque. Available in both Sportback and sedan body styles, it features the most aggressive styling with a wider track, massive air intakes, and RS-specific details. Performance is enhanced with 0-100 km/h acceleration in 3.8 seconds. The RS 3 received an RS Performance Edition variant in October 2022 with power increased to 407 PS (401 HP) and a top speed of 300 km/h (limited to 300 units). The interior features sport seats, RS-specific displays, and the latest MMI infotainment system with 10.25 or 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster.
Audi-RS-3.name: Third Generation (8Y)

Audi-RS-5.description: The original Audi RS 5 was unveiled at the 2010 Geneva Motor Show and sales began in early 2010. Based on the first-generation A5 (B8) platform, it was initially offered as a coupe. It featured a naturally aspirated 4.2L FSI V8 engine producing 450 PS (331 kW) at 8250 rpm and 430 Nm (316 lb-ft) at 4000-6000 rpm, paired with a seven-speed S tronic dual-clutch transmission and quattro all-wheel drive with a crown-gear center differential providing 40:60 front-to-rear torque split. The RS 5 featured aggressive styling with flared fenders, distinctive front bumper with large air intakes, and oval exhaust tips. Performance was impressive, with 0-62 mph (0-100 km/h) in 4.6 seconds. The naturally aspirated V8 was celebrated for its high-revving character and sonorous exhaust note.
Audi-RS-5.name: First Generation (8T)

Audi-RS-5.description: The 2012 facelift of the first-generation RS 5 was unveiled at the 2011 Frankfurt Motor Show. Changes included upgraded dampers and springs on the suspension, new electric power steering replacing engine-driven hydraulic power steering, exclusive retractable rear spoiler, red cam covers, carbon fibre intake manifold, optional piano black trim, 20-inch graphite-coloured wheels, and a sport exhaust system with black finishers. The RS 5 Cabriolet variant was added and unveiled at the 2012 Paris Motor Show, initially available as a Coupé variant with the same 4.2L FSI V8 engine. The cabriolet variant was produced from 2012-2015, while coupe production continued through 2016.
Audi-RS-5.name: First Generation (8T) 2012 Facelift

Audi-RS-5.description: Based on the second-generation A5 (B9/F5) platform, the second-generation RS 5 Coupé was unveiled on 2 June 2016, with production starting in June 2016. It represents a significant departure from its predecessor with the replacement of the naturally aspirated V8 with a 2.9L twin-turbocharged FSI V6 developing 450 PS (331 kW) and 600 Nm (443 lb-ft) of torque, paired with an 8-speed automatic transmission. The RS 5 Coupé accelerates from 0-100 km/h in 3.9 seconds with a top speed of 280 km/h (174 mph). The exterior features aggressive styling with wider fenders, honeycomb grille, and larger air intakes. The RS 5 Sportback variant was unveiled at the 2018 New York Auto Show, expanding the offering beyond the coupe. The interior features Audi's Virtual Cockpit with RS-specific displays and performance-oriented technology.
Audi-RS-5.name: Second Generation (F5)

Audi-RS-5.description: The RS 5 facelift was unveiled on 10 December 2019.
