Available in both Coupé and Sportback body styles, the facelift introduced refreshed design elements, updated styling with a wider, flatter grille and revised details. The second-generation RS 5 continues to feature the 2.9L twin-turbocharged FSI V6 engine producing 450 PS (331 kW) and 600 Nm (443 lb-ft) of torque. The facelift includes new technology updates and continued availability in both coupe and five-door Sportback variants, combining everyday usability with supercar-rivaling performance.
Audi-RS-5.name: Second Generation (F5) 2019 Facelift

Audi-RS-e-tron.description: The Audi RS e-tron GT represents the pinnacle of Audi's electric performance lineup as the first fully electric RS model, combining zero-emission operation with the performance expectations established by Audi's revered RS badge. Built on the J1 platform shared with the Porsche Taycan, the RS e-tron GT features a sleek, low-slung four-door coupe silhouette with dramatic proportions, a muscular stance, and distinctive aerodynamic elements including active vents, a rear diffuser, and an adjustable rear spoiler. Powered by a dual-motor electric powertrain delivering 590 horsepower (637 horsepower with overboost) and 612 lb-ft of torque, the RS e-tron GT accelerates from 0-60 mph in just 3.1 seconds and reaches a top speed of 155 mph. The 93.4 kWh (83.7 kWh usable) battery provides an EPA-estimated range of approximately 232 miles, supported by 800-volt architecture enabling DC fast charging at up to 270 kW—allowing a 5-80% charge in just 22.5 minutes under ideal conditions. Performance-focused features include standard adaptive air suspension, all-wheel steering, and electronic rear differential, with optional carbon-ceramic brakes for maximum stopping power. The interior combines RS sport elements with sustainable materials, featuring standard 14-way adjustable sport seats (with optional 18-way adjustable sport seats plus with ventilation and massage functions), a flat-bottomed RS steering wheel, and Audi's latest MMI touch response system with dual screens and virtual cockpit plus. A unique feature is the standard artificially generated e-tron sport sound, which can be adjusted to provide acoustic feedback proportional to driving style. As Audi's flagship electric performance vehicle, the RS e-tron GT demonstrates the brand's vision for high-performance driving in the electric era, offering exhilarating acceleration, precise handling, and sophisticated technology in a package that maintains the exclusivity and emotional appeal expected of an RS model.
Audi-RS-e-tron.name: First Generation (Audi RS e-tron GT)

Audi-S3.description: The original Audi S3 was based on the first-generation A3 platform on the Volkswagen A4 (PQ34) architecture, offered exclusively as a three-door hatchback. It featured a turbocharged 1.8L four-cylinder engine producing initially 210 HP, later increased to 225 HP (with variable valve timing added in 2001), paired with a six-speed manual transmission and quattro on-demand all-wheel drive. The S3 represented Audi's first compact performance model, featuring subtle exterior enhancements, lowered suspension, and larger brakes compared to the standard A3. A facelift in 2000 introduced one-piece headlights/indicator units and different front wings and rear light clusters.
Audi-S3.name: First Generation (8L)

Audi-S3.description: Based on the second-generation A3 on the Volkswagen A5 (PQ35) platform, the 8P S3 featured a turbocharged 2.0L four-cylinder FSI engine producing 265 HP (195 kW). Initially available only as a three-door hatchback, a five-door Sportback variant was added in 2008. Transmission options included a six-speed manual and Audi's S tronic dual-clutch automatic. The 2008 facelift brought minor updates to styling. The exterior featured distinctive S-specific styling elements including aluminum-look mirror caps and quad exhaust tips. The Haldex on-demand all-wheel drive system was standard.
Audi-S3.name: Second Generation (8P)

Audi-S3.description: The 8V generation S3 was based on the Volkswagen Group MQB platform. Presented in September 2012 with market launch in spring 2013 for the three-door hatchback (with sedan production beginning early 2014). It featured a 2.0L turbocharged TFSI four-cylinder producing 300 HP (221 kW). Body style options included three-door hatchback, five-door Sportback, four-door sedan, and cabriolet (available from July 2014). Technology advanced significantly with advanced driver assistance systems and a more sophisticated chassis. The Haldex all-wheel drive system continued as standard.
Audi-S3.name: Third Generation (8V) Pre-Facelift

Audi-S3.description: The mid-2016 facelift of the 8V S3 brought significant visual changes including more striking taillights with dynamic indicators as standard, more angular headlights, and redesigned front and rear bumpers with an updated diffuser. Engine power was increased from 300 to 310 HP. All body style options remained available: three-door hatchback, five-door Sportback, four-door sedan, and cabriolet. The Haldex all-wheel drive system and S tronic transmission continued to be standard or available.
Audi-S3.name: Third Generation (8V) Facelift

Audi-S3.description: The fourth generation based on the Audi A3 8Y platform was presented on August 11, 2020 and came to dealers at the beginning of October 2020. It features a 2.0L EA888 Evo 4 turbocharged TFSI four-cylinder producing 310 HP, paired with a 7-speed S tronic transmission and quattro all-wheel drive. Unlike the previous generation which offered four body styles, the 8Y is available only as a five-door Sportback and four-door sedan. The exterior design is more aggressive with larger air intakes and pronounced wheel arches. The interior features a completely digital environment with advanced infotainment and digital instruments. The fourth-generation S3 balances everyday usability with performance capabilities.
Audi-S3.name: Fourth Generation (8Y)

Audi-S4.description: The original Audi S4, built from August 1991 to July 1994, was based on the Volkswagen Group C4 platform and served as the performance version of the Audi 100 sedan. It featured a single turbocharged 2.2-liter inline five-cylinder engine producing 230 PS (227 HP), or optionally a 4.2L V8 engine from 1992. Available in sedan and Avant (wagon) body styles, it established the S4 nameplate before the model was temporarily discontinued when the 100 was re-badged as the A6 in 1994.
Audi-S4.name: First Generation (C4)

Audi-S4.description: The second generation Audi S4 debuted in October 1997 based on the B5 A4 platform. Featuring a 2.7-liter twin-turbocharged V6 engine producing 195 kW (261 HP) in European markets and 184 kW in US markets, it was paired with a six-speed manual transmission or five-speed Tiptronic automatic. Available in sedan and Avant body styles (wagon introduced in 1998), the B5 S4 established the blueprint for future performance A4 variants, offering impressive acceleration and handling in a practical package. Production ended in September 2001, though cars continued to be sold through 2002.
Audi-S4.name: Second Generation (B5)

Audi-S4.description: The third generation Audi S4 debuted in March 2003 based on the B6 A4 platform. It introduced the now-iconic 4.2-liter V8 engine producing 344 PS (339 HP), making it the first V8 engine in a compact executive car. Available in sedan, Avant, and cabriolet (convertible) body styles, the B6 S4 represented a major shift to naturally aspirated power compared to the turbocharged V6 predecessor. The V8 provided a distinctive exhaust note and smooth power delivery. Production ended in December 2004 for sedans and Avants, with the cabriolet ending in December 2005.
Audi-S4.name: Third Generation (B6)

Audi-S4.description: The fourth generation Audi S4 debuted in late 2004 (November 2004) based on the B7 A4 platform. Although Audi classified it as a new car, differences from the B6 were primarily cosmetic, using the same 4.2-liter V8 engine producing 253 kW (343 HP). It featured updated styling with a new single-frame grille, Bi-Xenon HID headlamps, and quad exhaust pipes. Available in sedan, Avant, and cabriolet body styles, it introduced the Torsen T-3 center differential and Bose sound system as standard. Production ended in June 2008.
Audi-S4.name: Fourth Generation (B7)

Audi-S4.description: The fifth generation Audi S4 debuted in November 2008 based on the MLB/MLP platform shared with the B8 A4. It returned to forced induction with a 3.0-liter TFSI supercharged V6 engine producing 245 kW (333 HP) and 440 Nm of torque. Available as sedan and Avant body styles only, it featured a more sophisticated quattro system with optional sports differential. The engine was paired with either a six-speed manual or seven-speed S tronic dual-clutch transmission. Technology included Audi Drive Select to adjust vehicle dynamics and LED daytime running lights.
Audi-S4.name: Fifth Generation (B8)

Audi-S4.description: The B8 S4 received a comprehensive facelift in early 2012 (European market) and early 2013 (Australasian market), designated as B8.5. The updated front end featured new headlights and grille design, while the interior received updated technology with enhanced MMI options. Mechanically, it switched to electromagnetic steering and a lighter crown gear center differential. The 3.0L TFSI supercharged V6 engine remained unchanged at 245 kW (333 HP), continuing to deliver the same performance and efficiency as pre-facelift models. Available in sedan and Avant body styles.
Audi-S4.name: Fifth Generation (B8 Facelift)

Audi-S4.description: The sixth generation Audi S4 launched in 2017 based on the MLB/MLP platform. It switched to a 3.0-liter turbocharged (rather than supercharged) V6 TFSI engine, initially producing 349 HP (later 341 HP in some markets). The transmission was exclusively an eight-speed ZF automatic, representing a shift toward focusing on everyday usability with enhanced performance. Available in sedan and Avant body styles, it featured subtle S-specific styling enhancements and Audi's Virtual Cockpit digital instrument cluster. Technology advances included updated infotainment and driver assistance features.
Audi-S4.name: Sixth Generation (B9)

Audi-S4.description: The B9 S4 received a facelift in 2019 with updated styling, including revised front and rear bumpers, new headlight and taillight designs, and refreshed interior trim. The 3.0-liter turbocharged V6 TFSI engine continued at 341 HP. The 2019 facelift introduced a 3.0L V6 TDI diesel option for European markets starting in 2019. Available in sedan and Avant body styles, the facelifted B9 S4 maintained its focus on luxury and performance, competing with the BMW M340i and Mercedes-AMG C43. Production is scheduled through 2025.
Audi-S4.name: Sixth Generation (B9 Facelift)

Audi-S5.description: The original Audi S5 was released in coupé form alongside the A5. The B8 generation featured a 4.2-litre V8 FSI engine in the coupé producing 260 kW (354 HP), while the cabriolet and sportback variants (introduced in 2009) received a supercharged 3.0-litre V6 TFSI engine producing 245 kW. The coupé offered a 6-speed manual or Tiptronic automatic, while the cabriolet and sportback had a 7-speed S-tronic dual-clutch transmission. The S5 featured distinctive aggressive styling with LED daytime running lights, bi-Xenon headlamps, and dual-tip exhausts.
Audi-S5.name: First Generation (B8/8T)

Audi-S5.description: The B8.5 facelift represented a mid-generational refresh with significant styling updates including a complete redesign of the headlights with new LED DRL's, a new grille based on the A6 design, and updated LED tail lights. Most notably, the coupé switched from the 4.2L V8 to the 3.0-litre supercharged V6 TFSI engine, unifying the powertrain across all body styles. Stop-start technology was introduced for improved fuel efficiency. Interior updates included chrome-treated dials, new Audi MMI 3G+ with Google Earth maps, and a flat-bottom steering wheel style.
Audi-S5.name: First Generation (B8.5/8.5T Facelift)

Audi-S5.description: The B9 generation, built from late 2017, introduced a completely new 3.0-litre V6 twin-scroll turbocharged engine co-developed with Porsche, producing 260 kW and mounted with the turbo within the V-angle to reduce turbo lag. Major design changes included a complete redesign of the headlights, bonnet, sharper body lines, and a new larger one-piece grille with LED front and rear lighting. The quattro system utilized a locking centre differential splitting torque 40% front/60% rear with variable distribution. Interior featured a redesigned dashboard, updated 8-inch Audi MMI, optional Virtual Cockpit, and electrically adjustable heated sport seats.
Audi-S5.name: Second Generation (B9)

Audi-S5.description: The 2019 B9.5 facelift introduced for 2020 model year featured updated styling and powertrain options. In Europe, the new 2019 S5 was exclusively offered with a diesel V6 TDI engine producing 345 HP as a mild-hybrid variant, while other markets retained the 3.0L TFSI twin-scroll turbocharged engine. This generation maintained the advanced technology features and performance credentials of the B9.
Audi-S5.name: Second Generation (B9.5 Facelift)

Audi-S5.description: The latest B10 generation is based on the new Audi A5 B10 and uses the Premium Platform Combustion (PPC). The B10 S5 introduces a new 3.0-litre V6 twin-scroll MHEV (mild hybrid electric vehicle) turbocharged engine producing 270 kW and 550 Nm of torque. For the first time, the S5 is available as a sedan and as an Avant estate/wagon in addition to the traditional coupé and cabriolet variants, significantly expanding the model's appeal and versatility.
Audi-S5.name: Third Generation (B10)

Audi-S6.description: The original Audi S6 was based on the C4 platform, featuring a 2.2L turbocharged five-cylinder engine producing 227 HP, or a 4.2L V8 with 286 HP depending on the market. Available in sedan and Avant (wagon) body styles, it featured subtle exterior enhancements, sport suspension, and larger brakes compared to the standard A6. The C4 S6 established the foundation for Audi's mid-size performance sedan and wagon offerings.
Audi-S6.name: First Generation (C4)

Audi-S6.description: The C5 S6 was exclusively powered by a 4.2L V8 engine producing 340 HP, paired with a five-speed Tiptronic automatic transmission and quattro all-wheel drive. Available in both sedan and Avant body styles, it featured more distinctive styling elements compared to its predecessor, including polished aluminum exterior mirrors and unique wheels.
Audi-S6.name: Second Generation (C5)

Audi-S6.description: The C6 S6 featured a significant powertrain upgrade with a Lamborghini-derived 5.2L V10 engine producing 435 HP, paired with a six-speed Tiptronic automatic transmission. Available in sedan and Avant body styles, it featured more aggressive styling with wider fenders, distinctive front and rear bumpers, and quad exhaust tips. The V10 engine provided a unique character and exhaust note that distinguished it from competitors.
Audi-S6.name: Third Generation (C6)

Audi-S6.description: The facelifted C6 S6 was released in late 2008 for the 2009 model year. The facelift maintained the iconic 5.2L Lamborghini-derived V10 engine but introduced updated styling elements, an upgraded MMI electronics controller (third-generation in 2010), and improved infotainment systems. The exterior retained the signature LED daytime running lights while the interior received technology enhancements and real-time traffic information capabilities.
Audi-S6.name: Third Generation (C6 Facelift)

Audi-S6.description: The C7 S6 launched as a 2013 model, a year after the C7 A6. It returned to V8 power with a twin-turbocharged 4.0L engine producing 420 HP, paired with a seven-speed S tronic dual-clutch transmission. Built on the C7 platform, it featured cylinder deactivation technology for improved fuel efficiency. The exterior continued the tradition of subtle performance enhancements while the interior offered a blend of luxury and sportiness with distinctive S elements.
Audi-S6.name: Fourth Generation (C7)

Audi-S6.description: Audi unveiled the 2015 S6 facelift in November 2014. Changes included styling tweaks to the exterior, an upgraded Multi Media Interface with faster Nvidia Tegra 3 processor and improved graphics with handwriting recognition, Audi connect telematics with 4G mobile internet and map updates, adaptive glare-free Matrix LED headlights, and an improved Night Vision Assistant. The 4.0L twin-turbo V8 was upgraded from 420 HP to 450 HP, and both TFSI petrol and all three TDI diesel engines now met the Euro 6 emission standard.
Audi-S6.name: Fourth Generation (C7 Facelift)

Audi-S6.description: The current C8 S6 represents a significant departure, with different powertrains by market. The 2.9L twin-turbocharged V6 petrol TFSI produces 331 PS (450 HP) with a 48V mild-hybrid system for global markets, while European models feature a 3.0L turbocharged diesel V6 producing 253 PS (250 HP) with an electric compressor. Both configurations are paired with an 8-speed automatic Tiptronic transmission. The exterior features more distinctive S-specific styling elements than previous generations, while the interior offers Audi's latest technology including dual touchscreens and digital instrumentation. The C8 is built on the MLB Evo platform and went on sale in summer 2019 for European models.
Audi-S6.name: Fifth Generation (C8)

Audi-SQ2.description: The Audi SQ2 is the high-performance variant of Audi's smallest SUV. Based on the Volkswagen Group MQB platform, it features a turbocharged 2.0L four-cylinder engine producing 295 HP and 400 Nm of torque, shared with other compact performance models like the Audi S3 and Volkswagen Golf R. Power is delivered to all four wheels via a seven-speed S tronic dual-clutch transmission and quattro all-wheel drive system. Performance is impressive for a compact SUV, with 0-62 mph (0-100 km/h) acceleration in 4.8 seconds. The exterior features more aggressive styling with S-specific bumpers, larger air intakes, quad exhaust tips, and unique 18 or 19-inch wheels. The suspension is lowered by 20mm compared to the standard Q2, and the interior features sport seats, stainless steel pedals, and S-specific displays.
Audi-SQ2.name: First Generation (GA)

Audi-SQ2.description: The 2021 facelift updated the SQ2's styling and technology features while maintaining the same 2.0 TFSI turbocharged engine producing 295 HP and 400 Nm of torque. The facelift introduced updated exterior styling, refreshed interior design with enhanced technology including the latest Audi MMI system, and refined infotainment features. The SQ2 represents Audi's approach to creating performance-oriented variants across all segments of its lineup, offering the practicality of a compact SUV with the performance characteristics of a hot hatchback.
Audi-SQ2.name: First Generation (GA Facelift)

Audi-SQ5.description: The original Audi SQ5 was notable for being Audi's first S-badged diesel model in many markets. The SQ5 TDI featured a 2967cc V6 twin-turbocharged TDI diesel engine producing 313 PS at 3,900-4,500 rpm with 650 Nm of torque at 1,450-2,800 rpm, paired with an 8-speed Tiptronic transmission. North American markets received a different version with a 2995cc supercharged 3.0L V6 TFSI petrol engine producing 354 HP at 5,500-6,500 rpm with 470 Nm of torque at 4,000-4,500 rpm. Both versions featured Audi's quattro all-wheel drive system with torque vectoring, sport suspension lowered by 30mm, distinctive styling with aluminum-look exterior mirrors, quad exhaust tips, and unique 20-inch wheels. The SQ5 went on sale in the first quarter of 2013 and combined impressive performance with the practicality of an SUV.
Audi-SQ5.name: First Generation (8R)

Audi-SQ5.description: Built on the MLB Evo platform, the second-generation SQ5 debuted in September 2016 for the 2017 model year. In North American markets, it features a 2995cc V6 twin-scroll turbocharged engine (EA839) producing 354 HP with 369 lb-ft (500 Nm) of torque from 1,370 rpm, paired with an 8-speed ZF automatic transmission. The SQ5 maintains the full-time rear-biased quattro AWD system with Torsen CSM self-locking center differential (40% front/60% rear distribution). European markets retained diesel options with the 3.0L V6 TDI engine. The design features aggressive styling with distinctive S design elements, an available sport differential for enhanced handling, and updated technology including digital instrument cluster and MMI infotainment. A 2021 facelift updated the styling with revised grille, bumper side air intakes, side sill, and rear trim. In January 2021, Audi introduced a Sportback variant. Production ended in February 2025.
Audi-SQ5.name: Second Generation (FY)

Audi-SQ7.description: Audi SQ7 based on second-generation Q7 platform. Powered by 4.0L V8 twin-turbo diesel engine producing 435 PS and 900 Nm of torque.
Audi-SQ7.name: First Generation

Audi-SQ7.description: Facelifted SQ7 with updated styling and new TFSI petrol engine option. Diesel version produces 429-650 BHP. TFSI petrol variant produces 500 bhp and 770 Nm of torque.
Audi-SQ7.name: First Generation (2020 Facelift)

Audi-SQ7.description: Second facelift for SQ7 with enhanced front and rear headlight design, HD Matrix LED headlights with Laser high-beam, and OLED rear lights.
Audi-SQ7.name: First Generation (2025 Facelift)

Audi-TT.description: The original Audi TT was a design icon with its distinctive, Bauhaus-inspired styling featuring a rounded, geometric shape that stood out in the automotive landscape. Available as both a 2+2 coupe and a two-seat roadster, it was built on the Volkswagen Group A4 (PQ34) platform. Engine options included 1.8L turbocharged four-cylinder units with various power outputs, topped by the 225 HP quattro variant. A 3.2L VR6 engine was added later in the production run. The TT's interior was equally distinctive with aluminum accents and minimalist design. Early models received a rear spoiler and suspension modifications following high-speed stability concerns. The first-generation TT established the model as a design-focused sports car that emphasized style alongside performance.
Audi-TT.name: First Generation (8N)

Audi-TT.description: The second-generation TT evolved the design language with sharper lines while maintaining the distinctive overall shape. Built on the Volkswagen Group A5 (PQ35) platform, it featured a steel and aluminum hybrid construction for reduced weight. Engine options expanded to include 1.8L and 2.0L TFSI petrol and 2.0L TDI diesel units, with the TTS featuring a high-output 2.0L TFSI producing 272 HP and the TT RS offering a turbocharged 2.5L five-cylinder with up to 360 HP in Plus form. The interior continued the driver-focused design with high-quality materials and the introduction of Audi's MMI infotainment system. The second-generation TT offered enhanced performance and technology while remaining true to the design-focused ethos of the original.
Audi-TT.name: Second Generation (8J)

Audi-TT.description: The third generation of the Audi TT refined the design further with a more angular and aggressive appearance. Built on the Volkswagen Group MQB platform, it featured more aluminum content for further weight reduction. Engine options included various 2.0L TFSI petrol units for standard models, while the TTS produced 306 HP and the TT RS delivered 394 HP from its award-winning 2.5L five-cylinder turbo. The interior saw a revolutionary change with the introduction of the Virtual Cockpit, which eliminated the central display in favor of a fully digital instrument cluster combining all infotainment and navigation functions. This generation offered advanced technology and strong performance while maintaining the model's focus on design and driving enjoyment.
Audi-TT.name: Third Generation (8S)

Audi-TT.description: The 2019 facelift brought significant updates to the third generation TT. Engine specifications were revised with the introduction of the TT 40 (145 kW/197 PS) and TT 45 (180 kW/245 PS) nomenclature replacing previous designations. The TTS received updated specifications with 225 kW (306 PS) and 400 Nm of torque from 2019-2021, increased to 235 kW (320 PS) from 2021 onwards. The TT RS maintained its 2.5L five-cylinder turbocharged engine with output increased to 294 kW (400 PS) and 480 Nm of torque. Visual updates included redesigned headlights and exterior styling changes. Production continued in both coupé and roadster forms until November 2023 as Audi discontinued the model to focus on electric vehicles.
Audi-TT.name: Third Generation (8S) Facelift

Audi-e-tron.description: The original Audi e-tron was the brand's first mass-produced fully electric mid-size luxury SUV, produced from 2018 with first customer deliveries in May 2019. Built on the Volkswagen Group MLB Evo platform, it featured dual electric motors providing quattro all-wheel drive with outputs ranging from 230 kW (313 hp) in the 50 quattro variant to 300-370 kW (408 hp) in boost mode for the 55 quattro variant. The battery options included a 71 kWh pack (50 quattro) or 95 kWh pack (55 quattro), delivering an EPA range of approximately 204-222 miles depending on the version. The e-tron pioneered several advanced features including optional virtual side mirrors using cameras and displays, regenerative braking contributing approximately 30% to the vehicle's range, and DC fast charging capability at 150 kW. The lineup was expanded in 2020 to include the e-tron Sportback, a coupe-style variant with a sloping roofline. In November 2022, the vehicle was facelifted and renamed to the Audi Q8 e-tron, featuring an upgraded 114 kWh battery and enhanced performance characteristics.
Audi-e-tron.name: First Generation (Audi e-tron)

Audi-e-tron.description: The facelifted Audi Q8 e-tron was revealed on November 9, 2022, as the renamed successor to the original Audi e-tron. This major update maintained the same MLB Evo platform but featured a redesigned exterior, improved efficiency, and an upgraded 114 kWh lithium-ion battery (with 106 kWh usable capacity), significantly increasing the EPA range to approximately 285 miles. The Q8 e-tron lineup includes the 50 quattro variant (183 kW/249 hp), the 55 quattro variant (220 kW/300 hp), and the performance-oriented SQ8 e-tron (370 kW/505 hp). DC fast charging speeds were increased to 170 kW for the 55 e-tron and SQ8 e-tron variants, while the 50 e-tron variant charged at 150 kW. Both standard SUV and Sportback variants were available throughout this period. Production ended in February 2025.
Audi-e-tron.name: Second Generation (Audi Q8 e-tron / Facelifted)

BMW-1-Series.description: The original BMW 1 Series was offered in hatchback (E87 five-door, E81 three-door), coupe (E82), and convertible (E88) body styles. It was notable for being the only rear-wheel drive vehicle in its class, featuring naturally aspirated and turbocharged engines ranging from four-cylinder to six-cylinder configurations. The 1 Series brought BMW's driving dynamics to the compact premium segment. This generation replaced the BMW 3 Series Compact as the entry-level model in the BMW range. The high-performance 1 Series M Coupé was also available in this generation.
BMW-1-Series.name: First Generation (E81/E82/E87/E88)

BMW-1-Series.description: The second-generation 1 Series continued as a rear-wheel drive hatchback offered in three-door (F21) and five-door (F20) body styles. The range included models from the efficient 114i to the high-performance M135i/M140i with up to 340 HP. This generation introduced turbocharged engines across the range, and added more technology including BMW's iDrive system. A facelift in 2015 significantly updated the styling and interior. The coupe and convertible models were spun off into the 2 Series.
BMW-1-Series.name: Second Generation (F20/F21)

BMW-1-Series.description: The third-generation F40 1 Series marked a significant shift for the model, adopting a front-wheel drive architecture based on BMW's UKL2 platform. Available exclusively as a five-door hatchback, it offered improved interior space and packaging efficiency compared to its predecessors. Engine options included turbocharged three-cylinder and four-cylinder units. The front-wheel drive configuration with an all-wheel drive option represented a major departure from earlier rear-wheel drive generations. BMW worked to maintain engaging driving dynamics through sophisticated chassis tuning and electronic systems.
BMW-1-Series.name: Third Generation (F40)

BMW-1-Series.description: The fourth-generation F70 1 Series was officially unveiled on 4 June 2024 and represents a heavy refresh of the F40 rather than a complete redesign. It continues to use the front-wheel drive based UKL2 platform and is available exclusively as a five-door hatchback. Engine options continue with turbocharged three-cylinder and four-cylinder units, with the M135i featuring enhanced performance. Despite its different internal codename, the F70 shares significant continuity with its F40 predecessor while incorporating modern styling updates and enhanced technology features including digital instrumentation and advanced driver assistance systems.
BMW-1-Series.name: Fourth Generation (F70)

BMW-116i.description: The first BMW 116i was part of the inaugural 1 Series generation, available in both five-door (E87) and later three-door (E81) hatchback body styles. It was powered by a naturally aspirated 1.6L inline-four engine producing approximately 115 HP, paired with either a manual or automatic transmission. As an entry-level model, it offered BMW's renowned rear-wheel drive handling dynamics in an affordable package, though with more modest performance than its higher-powered siblings. This generation was produced from 2004 to 2013.
BMW-116i.name: First Generation (E87/E81)

BMW-116i.description: The second-generation 116i featured a turbocharged 1.6L inline-four engine with power outputs ranging from 136 HP to 109 HP (in later, efficiency-focused versions). Available in both five-door (F20) and three-door (F21) body styles, it maintained BMW's rear-wheel drive layout. This generation introduced more technology including start/stop systems and BMW's EfficientDynamics suite. A facelift in 2015 brought updated styling, improved engines, and enhanced technology.
BMW-116i.name: Second Generation (F20/F21)

BMW-116i.description: The 116i is based on the F40 platform and represents BMW's shift to front-wheel drive for the 1 Series. It features a turbocharged 1.5L three-cylinder engine producing approximately 109-116 HP depending on the market. Available exclusively as a five-door hatchback, it offers improved interior space due to the transverse engine layout. The 116i benefits from BMW's latest technology including digital instrumentation options and advanced driver assistance systems, while still focusing on delivering an engaging driving experience despite the platform change.
BMW-116i.name: Third Generation (F40)

BMW-116i.description: The fourth-generation 116i is based on the F70 platform and represents a comprehensive refresh of the F40 model, rather than a complete redesign. Unveiled in June 2024 and beginning production in late 2024 for the 2025 model year, the F70 continues the front-wheel drive layout on the UKL2 platform. Available exclusively as a five-door hatchback, it features updated styling with a distinctive new grille design, improved interior technology, and enhanced driver assistance systems while maintaining the turbocharged three-cylinder efficiency and performance characteristics that define the entry-level 116i variant.
BMW-116i.name: Fourth Generation (F70)

BMW-2-Grand-Coupe.description: The BMW 2 Series Gran Coupe is BMW's first compact four-door coupe, designed to compete with vehicles like the Mercedes-Benz CLA. Built on BMW's UKL2 front-wheel drive platform (shared with the F40 1 Series), it features a sleek, coupe-like roofline combined with four doors and a traditional trunk. Revealed in October 2019, the Gran Coupe is the smallest four-door sedan offered by BMW in most markets. Engine options range from a 1.5L three-cylinder in the 218i to a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder in the range-topping M235i xDrive, which produces 306 HP and features all-wheel drive. The interior adopts BMW's latest design language with digital instrumentation, a central touchscreen featuring BMW Operating System 7.0, and ambient lighting. Despite the front-wheel drive architecture, BMW focused on delivering engaging driving dynamics through sophisticated chassis tuning and technology including ARB (actuator contiguous wheel slip limitation) for improved traction control. The 2 Series Gran Coupe represents BMW's response to growing demand for style-focused compact premium sedans.
BMW-2-Grand-Coupe.name: First Generation (F44)

BMW-2-Grand-Coupe.description: The second-generation BMW 2 Series Gran Coupé was officially unveiled on 15 October 2024. It retains the front-wheel drive UKL2 architecture and shares components with the F70 1 Series. The interior is completely redesigned and features a curved display powered by the latest BMW Operating System 9. The 2 Series comes standard with the 1.5L three-cylinder mild hybrid engine based on the B38 platform. Production at the BMW Leipzig Plant commenced in November 2024 with a scheduled market launch in March 2025.
BMW-2-Grand-Coupe.name: Second Generation (F74)

BMW-2-Series.description: The original BMW 2 Series replaced the 1 Series Coupe and Convertible, offered in two-door coupe (F22) and convertible (F23) body styles. Based on a rear-wheel drive platform and built at Leipzig, it featured longitudinally-mounted engines ranging from a 1.5L three-cylinder to a 3.0L turbocharged straight-six in the M235i/M240i producing 340 HP. The high-performance M2 (F87) was introduced in 2016 and delivered up to 410 HP in Competition form with turbocharged inline-six engines. The first-generation 2 Series was praised for its engaging handling, compact dimensions, and performance, continuing BMW's tradition of sporty compact coupes.
BMW-2-Series.name: First Generation Coupe/Convertible (F22/F23)

BMW-2-Series.description: The BMW 2 Series Active Tourer is a five-door, two-row compact MPV introduced in 2014. Built on the front-wheel drive-based UKL2 platform, it was the first BMW-branded model to not use rear-wheel drive configuration. Featuring an optional all-wheel drive (xDrive), it offered a practical, family-oriented design with versatile interiors. Engine options included three and four-cylinder petrol and diesel units, providing practicality without compromising the BMW driving experience.
BMW-2-Series.name: First Generation Active Tourer (F45)

BMW-2-Series.description: The BMW 2 Series Gran Tourer is a longer version of the Active Tourer with three-row seating, released in 2015. Built on the same front-wheel drive-based UKL2 platform, it provided a premium family vehicle with optional all-wheel drive. The Gran Tourer offered seven-seat configurations with practical sliding rear seats and a versatile interior layout, combining BMW's performance heritage with genuine family hauling capability.
BMW-2-Series.name: First Generation Gran Tourer (F46)

BMW-2-Series.description: The BMW 2 Series Gran Coupé is a four-door sedan variant revealed in October 2019 for the 2020 model year. Built on the front-wheel drive UKL2 platform shared with the Active Tourer and Gran Tourer, it serves as BMW's smallest four-door sedan in most markets. The Gran Coupé combines the practical sedan format with a sporty coupe aesthetic, offering compact executive car credentials with multiple engine options.
BMW-2-Series.name: First Generation Gran Coupé (F44)

BMW-2-Series.description: The second-generation 2 Series Coupe was revealed in July 2021 with production commencing September 2, 2021, manufactured exclusively in BMW's San Luis Potosí plant in Mexico. Maintaining its rear-wheel drive architecture, it is built on the CLAR platform with a roughly 50-50 weight distribution and shares mechanical components with the G20 3 Series and G22 4 Series. Engine options include a 2.0L four-cylinder in the 220i/230i and a 3.0L turbocharged straight-six in the M240i xDrive producing 374 HP. The second generation is not available as a convertible or with a manual transmission. A high-performance M2 (G87) variant followed, continuing the model's focus on driver engagement.
BMW-2-Series.name: Second Generation Coupe (G42)

BMW-2-Series.description: The second-generation BMW 2 Series Active Tourer was unveiled in October 2021. Built on the same front-wheel drive UKL2 platform as its predecessor, it features a completely redesigned exterior and interior adopting BMW's latest design language including a larger kidney grille and slim headlights. Available with petrol and diesel engines, a range of PHEV powertrains became available from 2022. The Gran Tourer seven-seat variant was not continued for this generation.
BMW-2-Series.name: Second Generation Active Tourer (U06)

BMW-2-Series.description: The second-generation BMW 2 Series Gran Coupé was officially unveiled on October 15, 2024. It retains the front-wheel drive-based UKL2 architecture and shares components with the F70 1 Series. The interior is completely redesigned with a curved display powered by the latest BMW Operating System 9. The 2 Series comes standard with a 1.5L three-cylinder mild hybrid engine based on the B38 platform. Production at the BMW Leipzig Plant commenced in November 2024 with a scheduled market launch in March 2025.
BMW-2-Series.name: Second Generation Gran Coupé (F74)

BMW-230e.description: The BMW 230e xDrive is a plug-in hybrid variant of the second-generation 2 Series Active Tourer (U06). It combines a 1.5L turbocharged three-cylinder petrol engine with an electric motor integrated into the 7-speed dual-clutch transmission, delivering a combined system output of approximately 326 HP and 477 Nm of torque. The xDrive system provides all-wheel drive capability with the combustion engine powering the front wheels and the electric motor driving the rear wheels. The 16.3 kWh lithium-ion battery enables an electric-only range of around 90 km (56 miles) under the WLTP cycle. Performance is impressive for its class, with 0-100 km/h acceleration in approximately 5.5 seconds. The 230e features BMW's latest interior technology, including the curved display combining digital instruments and infotainment, and offers multiple driving modes to optimize efficiency or performance as needed. This model represents BMW's commitment to electrification across its lineup while maintaining performance characteristics.
BMW-230e.name: Second Generation (U06)

BMW-3-Series.description: The original BMW 3 Series replaced the 02 Series and was initially available only as a two-door sedan/coupe. It featured engines ranging from 1.6L to 2.3L, with the fuel-injected 323i being the performance highlight with 143 HP. The E21 established the 3 Series' reputation for sporty handling and driver engagement, setting the foundation for BMW's most successful model line.
BMW-3-Series.name: First Generation (E21)

BMW-3-Series.description: The iconic E30 generation expanded the 3 Series range to include four-door sedan, wagon (Touring), and convertible body styles. Engine options ranged from economical four-cylinders to the powerful inline-six in the 325i. This generation also introduced the first M3, a homologation special with a high-revving four-cylinder engine that became one of the most celebrated driver's cars ever made. The E30 cemented BMW's position in the premium compact segment and remains highly regarded by enthusiasts.
BMW-3-Series.name: Second Generation (E30)

BMW-3-Series.description: The E36 represented a significant modernization of the 3 Series with more aerodynamic styling, improved safety features, and multi-link rear suspension. Available in sedan, coupe, convertible, wagon, and compact (hatchback) body styles, it offered a range of four and six-cylinder engines. The E36 M3 switched to a straight-six engine, offering a more refined high-performance experience. This generation helped establish BMW's global premium status.
BMW-3-Series.name: Third Generation (E36)

BMW-3-Series.description: Widely considered a high point for the 3 Series, the E46 balanced modern technology with traditional BMW driving dynamics. Available in sedan, coupe, convertible, wagon, and compact body styles, it featured refined straight-six engines and improved interior quality. The E46 M3 with its 333 HP 3.2L straight-six is particularly revered. This generation combined mechanical purity with modern comfort and technology.
BMW-3-Series.name: Fourth Generation (E46)

BMW-3-Series.description: The fifth-generation 3 Series comprised the E90 sedan, E91 wagon, E92 coupe, and E93 convertible (with a folding hardtop). It introduced run-flat tires, advanced electronic systems, and turbocharged engines on non-M models. The M3 featured a high-revving 4.0L V8. While more technologically advanced than its predecessors, some enthusiasts felt it lost some of the traditional BMW handling feel.
BMW-3-Series.name: Fifth Generation (E90/E91/E92/E93)

BMW-3-Series.description: The F30 generation separated the 3 Series sedan and wagon from the coupe and convertible (which became the 4 Series). It introduced a wider range of turbocharged engines, electric power steering, and significantly more technology. The F34 Gran Turismo offered a more practical fastback body style. The M3 returned to a straight-six engine, now twin-turbocharged with 425-450 HP. This generation focused on efficiency and technology while attempting to maintain BMW's driving dynamics.
BMW-3-Series.name: Sixth Generation (F30/F31/F34/F35)

BMW-3-Series.description: The current 3 Series features more aggressive styling, improved dynamics with a stiffer chassis, and advanced technology including partially automated driving capabilities. Engine options range from three-cylinder to six-cylinder units, with hybrid options available. The interior features BMW's latest iDrive system and digital displays. The G20 generation refocused on driver engagement following criticism of the F30. The M3 offers up to 503 HP in Competition form, with optional all-wheel drive for the first time. Throughout its evolution, the 3 Series has remained BMW's core model, embodying the brand's 'Ultimate Driving Machine' ethos while adapting to changing market demands.
BMW-3-Series.name: Seventh Generation (G20/G21/G28)

BMW-3-Series.description: The eighth generation of the BMW 3 Series lineup consists of internationally available ICE (internal combustion engine) and BEV (battery electric) versions. The G50 is the conventional gasoline/hybrid variant, while the NA0 is the battery electric variant exclusive for the Chinese market as the i3. The G50 is rumored to receive a touring bodystyle (G51), while the NA0 is rumored to receive a China-exclusive long-wheelbase variant (NA8). Performance-oriented M3 models are planned for both ICE and BEV versions. Following the 'Neue Klasse' design language introduced with the iX3, the G50 will embrace a radical and retro design makeover, new interior layout, and all-new driving technology.
BMW-3-Series.name: Eighth Generation (G50/G51/NA0)

BMW-3-Series-eDrive.description: Battery electric sedan based on G20 platform, exclusive to Chinese market. Shares powertrain with i4.
BMW-3-Series-eDrive.name: First Generation

BMW-3-Series-eDrive.description: Next-generation battery electric sedan based on G50/NA0 platform. Part of BMW's Neue Klasse generation.
BMW-3-Series-eDrive.name: Second Generation

BMW-330e.description: The first BMW 330e was based on the F30 generation 3 Series. This plug-in hybrid was unveiled at the Frankfurt International Auto Show in September 2015, with first units registered in Europe by late 2015 and North American sales beginning in 2016. The model featured a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder petrol engine combined with an electric motor integrated into the eight-speed automatic transmission. The combined system produced 252 HP (185 kW), with an all-electric range of approximately 25 miles (40 km). The battery was positioned under the trunk floor, slightly reducing cargo capacity. Performance remained strong with 0-60 mph acceleration in around 6 seconds, while offering significantly improved fuel economy compared to conventional models. The F30 330e represented BMW's first mainstream plug-in hybrid sedan, bringing electrification to the brand's core model line.
BMW-330e.name: First Generation (F30)

BMW-330e.description: Based on the G20 generation 3 Series, the current 330e features significant improvements over its predecessor. Introduced at the Geneva Motor Show in March 2019, the G20 330e combines a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder engine with a more powerful electric motor for a combined output of 292 HP (215 kW) and 420 Nm of torque. The larger 12 kWh battery (9.6 kWh usable) enables an electric range of up to 37 miles (60 km) under WLTP testing. Available in both sedan (G20) and Touring wagon (G21) body styles, with optional xDrive all-wheel drive, the second-generation 330e offers greater flexibility. The model features a newly developed 'XtraBoost' system allowing a temporary power increase from the electric motor of up to 30 kW. Performance remains impressive with 0-60 mph times of around 5.9 seconds (5.6 seconds in some earlier references). The G20 330e better integrates the hybrid components, with improved packaging for the battery and enhanced operating strategies for greater efficiency. It represents BMW's commitment to electrification while maintaining the 3 Series' driving dynamics and premium character.
BMW-330e.name: Second Generation (G20)

BMW-4-Series.description: The inaugural BMW 4 Series separated the coupe and convertible models from the 3 Series lineup, establishing a distinct identity for these sportier body styles. The range included the F32 coupe, F33 convertible (with retractable hardtop), and F36 Gran Coupe (a four-door fastback). Engine options mirrored the F30 3 Series, ranging from efficient four-cylinders to powerful six-cylinder units in the 440i. The high-performance M4 featured a twin-turbocharged 3.0L straight-six producing 425-450 HP. The first-generation 4 Series offered slightly sharper styling and dynamics compared to the 3 Series, with a lower center of gravity and wider track.
BMW-4-Series.name: First Generation (F32/F33/F36)

BMW-4-Series.description: The current 4 Series features a controversial new design direction dominated by a large, vertical kidney grille. Available as a G22 coupe, G23 convertible (now with a fabric roof instead of a retractable hardtop), and G26 Gran Coupe, it offers a more distinct visual separation from the 3 Series. The chassis has been significantly enhanced for improved dynamics, with a lower center of gravity and increased torsional rigidity. Engine options range from the 420i's four-cylinder to the M440i's 374 HP six-cylinder, with mild-hybrid technology on some variants. The M4 delivers up to 503 HP in Competition form, with optional all-wheel drive. The interior features BMW's latest technology including advanced digital displays and driver assistance systems. Despite the controversial styling, the second-generation 4 Series continues to offer engaging driving dynamics with improved refinement and technology.
BMW-4-Series.name: Second Generation (G22/G23/G26)

BMW-5-Series.description: The original BMW 5 Series replaced the New Class sedans and established BMW's numerical naming convention. Available only as a four-door sedan, it featured engines ranging from 1.8L to 3.0L, with the fuel-injected models offering the best performance. The E12 combined practical family car versatility with engaging driving dynamics, setting the template for future 5 Series models.
BMW-5-Series.name: First Generation (E12)

BMW-5-Series.description: The E28 refined the 5 Series formula with improved aerodynamics, updated technology, and enhanced comfort. Engine options ranged from economical six-cylinders to the powerful M535i. This generation also introduced the first M5, featuring a modified version of the M1's 3.5L straight-six engine producing 282 HP, creating the template for the high-performance luxury sedan segment.
BMW-5-Series.name: Second Generation (E28)

BMW-5-Series.description: The E34 represented a significant step forward in refinement, build quality, and technology. Available as a sedan and wagon (Touring), it offered a range of inline-six engines and V8 options. The E34 M5 continued as the range-topper, eventually receiving a 3.8L engine with 340 HP. This generation established the 5 Series as a technology leader with features like electronic damping control and integrated car phones.
BMW-5-Series.name: Third Generation (E34)

BMW-5-Series.description: Widely regarded as one of the finest 5 Series generations, the E39 balanced dynamic excellence with luxury and technology. It featured a sophisticated chassis with aluminum components, a range of refined straight-six and V8 engines, and elegant, timeless styling. The E39 M5 with its 400 HP V8 is particularly celebrated. This generation represented peak mechanical refinement before the introduction of more complex electronic systems.
BMW-5-Series.name: Fourth Generation (E39)

BMW-5-Series.description: The controversial E60 featured radical styling by Chris Bangle and introduced far more advanced technology, including iDrive infotainment and active steering. Available as a sedan (E60) and wagon (E61), it offered improved space and refined dynamics. The E60 M5 featured a Formula 1-inspired 5.0L V10 producing 500 HP. While initially polarizing, this generation has gained appreciation for its pioneering design and technology.
BMW-5-Series.name: Fifth Generation (E60/E61)

BMW-5-Series.description: The F10 generation returned to more conservative styling while advancing technology and refinement. Available as a sedan (F10), wagon (F11), and fastback Gran Turismo (F07), it offered a range of turbocharged engines, advanced driver assistance systems, and luxury features. The F10 M5 switched to a twin-turbocharged V8 with up to 575 HP. This generation prioritized comfort and technology, though some felt it lost some of the driver engagement of earlier models.
BMW-5-Series.name: Sixth Generation (F10/F11/F07)

BMW-5-Series.description: The G30 5 Series refined the formula with evolutionary styling, reduced weight through increased use of aluminum and high-strength steel, and advanced technology including semi-autonomous driving capabilities. Available as a sedan (G30) and wagon (G31), it offered a range of efficient turbocharged engines, plug-in hybrid options, and the M5 with up to 625 HP and all-wheel drive. This generation successfully balanced luxury, technology, and driving dynamics.
BMW-5-Series.name: Seventh Generation (G30/G31)

BMW-5-Series.description: The 2020 facelift of the G30 generation maintained the same mechanical platform and engines while introducing visual and interior updates. The facelift refreshed the exterior styling, updated infotainment systems, and refined interior design elements, continuing the G30's legacy of balancing luxury, technology, and driving dynamics through the end of the generation in 2023.
BMW-5-Series.name: Seventh Generation (G30/G31 Facelift)

BMW-5-Series.description: The latest 5 Series features a more tech-focused approach with a cleaner design language, increased electrification, and advanced digital features. It grows slightly in size while maintaining proportional elegance. Powertrain options range from mild hybrids to plug-in hybrids, with the all-electric i5 variant joining the lineup. The interior adopts BMW's latest curved display technology and minimalist design approach. Throughout its evolution, the 5 Series has maintained its position as a benchmark in the executive sedan segment, balancing luxury, technology, and driving dynamics.
BMW-5-Series.name: Eighth Generation (G60)

BMW-5-Series-xDrive.description: The F10/F11 generation 5 Series was the first to widely offer BMW's xDrive all-wheel drive system across multiple variants globally. Sales of all-wheel drive xDrive models began in June 2010. The xDrive system provided intelligent torque distribution between front and rear axles, enhancing traction in adverse conditions while maintaining the 5 Series' dynamic handling characteristics. Available on both sedan (F10) and wagon (F11) body styles, the xDrive system was offered with a range of engines from four-cylinder diesels to powerful V8s, including the M550d xDrive. This generation featured an eight-speed automatic transmission, efficient turbocharged engines, and advanced driver assistance systems.
BMW-5-Series-xDrive.name: Sixth Generation with xDrive (F10/F11)

BMW-5-Series-xDrive.description: The G30/G31 5 Series introduced refined xDrive all-wheel drive with faster response times and more sophisticated electronic control. Sales began in February 2017 following an announcement in October 2016. xDrive was available on most engine variants, including the plug-in hybrid 530e iPerformance and the performance-oriented M550i, which featured M Performance-tuned suspension and a powerful V8 engine. The G30 generation also introduced the M5 with M xDrive (F90 M5), the first M5 to employ an all-wheel drive powertrain, featuring a switchable system that could operate in rear-wheel drive mode for track driving. This generation combined exceptional comfort, advanced technology, and engaging dynamics regardless of weather conditions.
BMW-5-Series-xDrive.name: Seventh Generation with xDrive (G30/G31)

BMW-5-Series-xDrive.description: The G30/G31 5 Series underwent a comprehensive facelift and Life Cycle Impulse (LCI) reveal in May 2020. The facelift introduced redesigned front and rear bumpers with new headlights and taillights featuring simplified L-shaped daytime running lights. The kidney grille design was sharpened, and adaptive LED headlights became standard (previously optional) with options for matrix LED or laser headlamps. The engine range was revamped with twin-turbocharging for all diesel engines and optimized direct injection for petrol engines. Hybrid models received a 48-volt system adding 8 kW of power. The xDrive system continued to be refined, maintaining its position across most engine variants and providing enhanced all-weather capability through the final year of G30 production.
BMW-5-Series-xDrive.name: Seventh Generation with xDrive (G30/G31) Facelift

BMW-5-Series-xDrive.description: The latest G60 5 Series continues to offer xDrive all-wheel drive across much of the range, with further refinements to improve efficiency and dynamic response. Production commenced in summer 2023 with first deliveries beginning around October 2023 following the May 2023 reveal. xDrive is available on the 540i (standard), which features a 375-hp turbocharged inline-six engine, and the range-topping M60 xDrive model. The system is available with mild-hybrid and plug-in hybrid (550e) powertrains, providing all-weather capability without significantly compromising fuel efficiency. The xDrive system is fully integrated with the vehicle's adaptive suspension systems and driving dynamics control, allowing drivers to tailor the car's character. This generation features BMW's most advanced driver assistance systems and digital technology, maintaining the 5 Series' position as a technological flagship while providing the security and handling benefits of all-wheel drive in a luxurious executive package.
BMW-5-Series-xDrive.name: Eighth Generation with xDrive (G60)

BMW-640i-f13.description: The BMW 640i F13 was the coupe variant of the third-generation 6 Series (2011-2018), with the F13 designation specifically denoting the two-door coupe body style (F12 was convertible, F06 was Gran Coupe). The 640i featured a 3.0L turbocharged inline-six engine (N55) producing 315-320 HP depending on the market, paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission. Performance was impressive with 0-60 mph acceleration in approximately 5.3 seconds. The pre-facelift F13 6 Series (2011-2014) featured flowing, elegant styling with classic proportions and luxury grand touring characteristics. The interior offered premium materials, advanced technology including iDrive infotainment, and a driver-focused cockpit design. The 640i was positioned as a more efficient yet still powerful alternative to the V8-powered 650i model, combining strong performance with reasonable fuel economy for its class. Available with optional xDrive all-wheel drive in some markets, the 640i F13 represented BMW's approach to the luxury GT coupe segment, emphasizing long-distance comfort, style, and performance.
BMW-640i-f13.name: Third Generation 6 Series (F13)

BMW-640i-f13.description: In 2015, the BMW 640i F13 underwent a facelift, featuring design changes and minor performance and fuel economy improvements. The post-facelift F13 (2015-2017) maintained the 3.0L turbocharged inline-six engine but benefited from updated styling with revised headlights, grille, and bumpers. The refreshed interior incorporated updated infotainment and trim elements. The coupé model ended production in February 2017, making the post-facelift period relatively short but significant for its visual and technical updates.
BMW-640i-f13.name: Third Generation 6 Series (F13) 2015 Facelift

BMW-7-Series.description: The original BMW 7 Series established the brand in the full-size luxury sedan segment. Available with inline-six engines ranging from 2.5L to 3.5L, it featured advanced technology for its time including an on-board computer, climate control, and anti-lock brakes on later models. The E23 combined luxury with BMW's driver-focused philosophy.
BMW-7-Series.name: First Generation (E23)

BMW-7-Series.description: The E32 introduced V12 power to the 7 Series with the 750i/iL, alongside inline-six and V8 options. Available in standard and long-wheelbase versions, it featured innovative technology including integrated telephone and fax machine options, electronic damper control, and dual-zone climate control. The E32 enhanced BMW's reputation in the luxury segment with its combination of performance and refinement.
BMW-7-Series.name: Second Generation (E32)

BMW-7-Series.description: Often considered the most elegant 7 Series, the E38 featured classic styling combined with modern technology. Engine options included inline-six, V8, and V12 units, with five-speed automatic transmission. Notable innovations included GPS navigation, an integrated cell phone, and the introduction of side airbags. The E38 achieved cultural significance through appearances in films and maintained an ideal balance of luxury, technology, and driving dynamics.
BMW-7-Series.name: Third Generation (E38)

BMW-7-Series.description: The controversial E65/E66 represented a radical departure with its avant-garde styling and revolutionary technology. It introduced iDrive, electronic gear selection, adaptive air suspension, and active anti-roll bars. Available with six, eight, and twelve-cylinder engines in standard (E65) and long-wheelbase (E66) formats, it also offered the first hydrogen-powered production BMW in limited markets. Though initially polarizing, this generation pioneered technologies that later became industry standards.
BMW-7-Series.name: Fourth Generation (E65/E66)

BMW-7-Series.description: The F01/F02 returned to more conservative styling while advancing technology with an enhanced iDrive system, night vision with pedestrian detection, and integral active steering. Engine options ranged from efficient six-cylinders to powerful V12s, with the ActiveHybrid 7 introducing electrification to the lineup. This generation emphasized efficiency alongside luxury and performance with features like brake energy regeneration and an eight-speed automatic transmission.
BMW-7-Series.name: Fifth Generation (F01/F02)

BMW-7-Series.description: The G11/G12 introduced carbon-fiber-reinforced polymer in its structure for reduced weight, advanced semi-autonomous driving capabilities, and gesture control. Powertrain options expanded to include plug-in hybrid technology alongside conventional engines ranging from four-cylinders to the powerful V12 in the M760Li. This generation represented a technological tour de force while returning to more elegant styling.
BMW-7-Series.name: Sixth Generation (G11/G12)

BMW-7-Series.description: The latest 7 Series features a bold new design language with split headlights and an illuminated kidney grille. Available with combustion engines, plug-in hybrid technology, and as the all-electric i7, it emphasizes digital luxury with features like the BMW Theater Screen, a 31-inch rear entertainment display. Technology highlights include automated driving capabilities and an augmented reality navigation display. Throughout its evolution, the 7 Series has represented BMW's technological flagship, combining luxury, innovation, and driving dynamics in the full-size premium segment.
BMW-7-Series.name: Seventh Generation (G70)

BMW-840i.description: The first generation BMW 8 Series (E31) was introduced in 1990 and produced until 1999. It debuted at the 1989 Frankfurt Motor Show as a two-door coupe only. The E31 was powered by naturally aspirated V8 and V12 engines, establishing itself as a grand tourer with significant performance credentials. It was the first road car to offer a V12 engine mated to a 6-speed manual transmission and one of the first vehicles to feature electronic drive-by-wire throttle. The E31 was also among BMW's first cars to use a multi-link rear suspension. Despite its innovations and performance, the E31 was discontinued in 1999 due to poor sales.
BMW-840i.name: First Generation (E31)

BMW-840i.description: The second-generation BMW 8 Series was reintroduced in 2018 after a 19-year hiatus, announced on June 15, 2018, with sales commencing in November 2018. This generation introduced three body styles: coupe (G15), convertible (G14), and four-door Gran Coupe (G16), succeeding the BMW 6 Series (F06/F12/F13) lineup. Production commenced in late 2018 at BMW assembly plants in Bangkok, Thailand and Dingolfing, Germany. The generation features inline-six petrol engines and diesel options, with the high-performance M8 variant and luxury Alpina B8 also available. The 840i variant features a 3.0L turbocharged inline-six engine delivering strong performance with rear-wheel drive or all-wheel drive (xDrive) options.
BMW-840i.name: Second Generation (G14/G15/G16)

BMW-840i.description: In 2022, BMW updated the 8 Series with a mid-cycle refresh introducing the Iconic Illuminated Glow kidney grille and a larger 12.3-inch infotainment system replacing the previous 10.25-inch unit. The 840i continues with the 3.0L turbocharged inline-six engine delivering strong performance with rear-wheel drive or all-wheel drive (xDrive) options, maintaining the same body styles: coupe (G15), convertible (G14), and four-door Gran Coupe (G16).
BMW-840i.name: Second Generation (G14/G15/G16) Facelift

BMW-E91.description: The BMW E91 is the Touring (wagon) variant of the fifth-generation 3 Series, sharing its platform with the E90 sedan, E92 coupe, and E93 convertible. The E91 combined the driving dynamics of the 3 Series with enhanced practicality, offering expanded cargo capacity through its wagon body style while maintaining BMW's renowned handling characteristics. Engine options mirrored those of the sedan, ranging from efficient four-cylinder diesels to powerful six-cylinder petrol units, with many markets receiving the high-performance 335i with its twin-turbocharged 3.0L straight-six producing 306 HP. Transmission options included six-speed manual and automatic gearboxes, with later models receiving a more efficient eight-speed automatic. The E91 featured advanced technology for its time, including iDrive infotainment on higher-spec models, run-flat tires, and various electronic driving aids. A facelift (LCI - Life Cycle Impulse) in 2008 brought revised styling, updated engines including more efficient diesel options, and enhanced technology features. The E91 Touring appealed to buyers seeking the perfect balance between driving pleasure and practical versatility, establishing itself as a premium alternative to larger SUVs with better driving dynamics and efficiency.
BMW-E91.name: Fifth Generation 3 Series Touring (E91)

BMW-E92.description: The BMW E92 is the coupe variant of the fifth-generation 3 Series, introduced in July 2006 and unveiled for the MY2007 model year. It is distinguished from its E90 sedan counterpart by unique styling elements including a more aggressive front fascia, distinctive roofline, and model-specific interior details. The E92 featured a stiffer chassis than the sedan, with every body panel except the doors being unique to the coupe. Early engine options included four-cylinder diesels and naturally aspirated six-cylinder petrol units, with the twin-turbocharged N54-powered 335i producing 306 HP and the naturally aspirated 330i/328i offering refined performance. Transmission options included six-speed manual and automatic gearboxes. The range-topping M3 variant, introduced in 2007, featured a high-revving 4.0L BMW S65 V8 engine producing 414 HP, representing the only V8-powered 3 Series coupe in the model's history.
BMW-E92.name: First Generation (2006-2009)

BMW-E92.description: The 2010 facelift (LCI - Life Cycle Impulse) updated the E92's styling and introduced significant technical changes. The single-turbo N55 replaced the twin-turbo N54 in the 335i, while other engine options were revised. The facelift brought visual updates to the front and rear fascias, updated interior trim, and refreshed infotainment systems. The M3 continued with the S65 V8. Later models received a seven-speed dual-clutch transmission (DCT) option for the M3. The E92 was the last 3 Series coupe, as its successor would be renamed the 4 Series. Production continued through the 2013 model year, ending in October 2013.
BMW-E92.name: First Generation (2010 Facelift)

BMW-F34.description: The BMW F34 3 Series Gran Turismo was a unique variant in the sixth-generation 3 Series lineup, featuring a fastback body style that combined elements of sedan, wagon, and crossover designs. Unveiled at the 83rd Geneva International Motor Show in March 2013, the F34 was based on the long-wheelbase version of the 3 Series platform and was 200mm longer than the standard sedan, with a 110mm longer wheelbase, offering significantly more rear legroom and cargo space. The raised seating position provided better visibility and easier entry/exit. At launch, the engine range consisted of turbocharged petrol and diesel engines in straight-4 and straight-6 configurations, with all-wheel drive available in the xDrive models. All F34 models came standard with an eight-speed automatic transmission. Distinctive styling elements included an actively deploying rear spoiler, frameless windows, and a unique tailgate design.
BMW-F34.name: 3 Series Gran Turismo (F34)

BMW-F34.description: The F34 received a facelift (Life Cycle Impulse) in mid-2016, introducing updated styling, technology features, and an updated engine lineup. The 340i models now used the B58 engine, replacing the previous N55 engine in the 335i. Despite offering practical advantages over the standard 3 Series models, the Gran Turismo remained a niche product in BMW's lineup, appealing to buyers seeking extra space without moving to an SUV or traditional wagon. Production continued until early 2020, with no direct replacement, as BMW streamlined its model range and eventually replaced the segment with the 4 Series Gran Coupé.
BMW-F34.name: 3 Series Gran Turismo (F34) - 2016 Facelift

BMW-M2.description: The original BMW M2 built upon the legacy of the 1M Coupe, offering M performance in a compact package. Based on the F22 2 Series platform but substantially modified, it featured wider fenders, M-specific suspension, and an enhanced version of the N55 3.0L turbocharged inline-six engine producing 365 HP (370 HP in European spec). Transmission options included a six-speed manual or seven-speed dual-clutch automatic. The M2 was praised for its analog driving feel and compact dimensions reminiscent of earlier M cars. Production commenced in October 2015 with first deliveries in early 2016.
BMW-M2.name: First Generation (F87)

BMW-M2.description: The M2 Competition replaced the standard M2 as the primary variant, introducing the S55 twin-turbocharged engine from the M3/M4 detuned to 405 HP (302 kW). The Competition was introduced at the 2018 Beijing Auto Show with production beginning July 2018 and deliveries starting early 2019. It received upgraded cooling, brakes, a carbon fiber front strut brace, enlarged kidney grilles, and optional larger brake discs. The S55 engine included a closed-deck engine block, lightweight crankshaft, strengthened pistons and connecting rods, and active exhaust. It produced 405 HP at 5250-7000 rpm and 550 Nm (406 lb-ft) torque.
BMW-M2.name: First Generation (F87) M2 Competition

BMW-M2.description: The M2 CS was a track-focused variant unveiled online in November 2019 before introduction at the LA Auto Show. Production began in March 2020 with 2,200 units planned for North America and Eurasia. It used the same S55 engine as the Competition but with the F82 M4 Competition package ECU map, resulting in 450 HP (331 kW) and 550 Nm (406 lb-ft) of torque. The CS featured carbon fiber components (hood, roof, transmission tunnel, center console, trim), adaptive M suspension, electronic locking differential, carbon-ceramic brake options, unique wheel designs, active exhaust, and Alcantara interior trim with red contrast stitching. It offered 0-100 km/h in 4.2 seconds (manual) or 4.0 seconds (DCT).
BMW-M2.name: First Generation (F87) M2 CS

BMW-M2.description: The second-generation M2 (G87) was revealed in October 2022 at Motorclassica in Melbourne, Australia, and launched in April 2023. Based on the G42 2 Series platform, it shares significant components with the G80 M3/G82 M4. It features the S58 3.0L twin-turbocharged inline-six engine producing 460 HP (338 kW) at 6250 rpm and 550 Nm (406 lb-ft) torque, paired with either a six-speed manual or eight-speed automatic transmission. The G87 is 54 mm longer overall and 33 mm wider than the F87. It delivers 0-60 mph in 4.3 seconds (manual) or 4.1 seconds (automatic). For the 2025 model year, the G87 received a minor refresh with a 20 HP increase to 473 HP (355 kW), increased torque to 600 Nm (442 lb-ft) on automatic versions, and revised suspension and exhaust. The 2026 model year introduced an M2 CS variant with 523 HP, carbon fiber components, and exclusive styling. Despite being larger and heavier than its predecessor, the G87 M2 maintains its position as the most driver-focused model in BMW's M lineup, emphasizing handling precision and engagement.
BMW-M2.name: Second Generation (G87)

BMW-M3.description: The original M3 was developed as a homologation special for Group A touring car racing. Available as a two-door coupe and later as a convertible, it featured a high-revving 2.3L four-cylinder engine (later 2.5L) producing 192-235 HP depending on the version. Distinguished by its box-flared fenders, rear wing, and unique front and rear fascias, the E30 M3 was a purpose-built performance car with extensive modifications from the standard 3 Series. Its motorsport success and driving purity have made it a highly coveted collector car.
BMW-M3.name: First Generation (E30)

BMW-M3.description: The E36 M3 represented a shift towards a more refined high-performance car, available as a coupe, sedan, and convertible. Powered by a 3.0L straight-six engine (later 3.2L) producing 282-321 HP, it offered enhanced performance with greater comfort than its predecessor. European models received a more powerful engine compared to North American versions. The E36 M3 established the template for M cars combining everyday usability with exceptional performance.
BMW-M3.name: Second Generation (E36)

BMW-M3.description: Widely regarded as one of the finest M cars, the E46 M3 was powered by a 3.2L S54 straight-six engine producing 333 HP, available with a six-speed manual or SMG automated manual transmission. Offered in coupe and convertible body styles, it featured distinctive wider fenders, hood bulge, and aerodynamic enhancements. The limited-production CSL variant reduced weight through carbon fiber components and offered increased power. The E46 M3 is celebrated for its balanced handling, engaging powertrain, and timeless design.
BMW-M3.name: Third Generation (E46)

BMW-M3.description: The E9x M3 marked a significant change with the introduction of a high-revving 4.0L V8 engine producing 414 HP. Available as a sedan (E90), coupe (E92), and convertible (E93), it featured carbon fiber roof options, unique body panels, and sophisticated electronics including an adjustable differential. Special editions included the lightweight GTS, Competition Package, and Lime Rock Park Edition. This generation combined increased performance with greater refinement and technology.
BMW-M3.name: Fourth Generation (E90/E92/E93)

BMW-M3.description: The F80 M3 returned to a straight-six engine, now twin-turbocharged for the first time, producing 425-450 HP depending on the version. Available only as a sedan (the coupe became the M4), it featured increased use of lightweight materials including a carbon fiber driveshaft and optional carbon ceramic brakes. The Competition Package added power and handling enhancements, while the limited-production CS variant offered further weight reduction and track-focused upgrades. The F80 represented the transition to turbocharged engines for M cars, delivering massive torque increases over its predecessors.
BMW-M3.name: Fifth Generation (F80)

BMW-M3.description: The current M3 features controversial styling with a large vertical kidney grille but continues to offer exemplary performance. Powered by a 3.0L twin-turbocharged S58 straight-six engine producing 473 HP in standard form and 503 HP in Competition trim, it's available as a sedan (G80) and for the first time as an estate wagon (G81). The standard M3 offers a six-speed manual, while the Competition models feature an eight-speed automatic. All-wheel drive (xDrive) is available on Competition models, a first for the M3. The interior features M-specific displays, sports seats, and carbon fiber trim options. Throughout its evolution, the M3 has remained BMW's definitive performance car, combining track capability with daily usability.
BMW-M3.name: Sixth Generation (G80/G81)

BMW-M4.description: The inaugural BMW M4 separated the coupe and convertible variants from the M3 lineup, which became sedan-only. Built on the F32/F33 4 Series platform, the F82 coupe and F83 convertible featured extensive modifications including wider fenders, unique bumpers, and a carbon fiber roof on the coupe. Power came from the S55 3.0L twin-turbocharged straight-six engine producing 425 HP (later 444 HP with the Competition Package). Transmission options included a six-speed manual or seven-speed dual-clutch automatic. The M4 offered impressive performance with 0-60 mph times of around 4 seconds. Special editions included the water-injected GTS with 493 HP, the track-focused CS with 454 HP, and various limited editions. The first-generation M4 represented BMW M's transition to turbocharged engines, delivering significantly more torque than its naturally aspirated predecessors.
BMW-M4.name: First Generation (F82/F83)

BMW-M4.description: The current M4 features polarizing styling dominated by a large vertical kidney grille but builds on the performance of its predecessor. Powered by the S58 3.0L twin-turbocharged straight-six engine, it offers 473 HP in standard form and 503 HP in Competition trim. The base M4 comes with a six-speed manual transmission and rear-wheel drive, while the Competition variants feature an eight-speed automatic with optional xDrive all-wheel drive (a first for the M4). The G82 coupe and G83 convertible continue to feature model-specific body panels, suspension, and braking systems. Inside, the second-generation M4 offers a more modern interior with larger displays, advanced driver assistance options, and carbon fiber trim elements. Special models include the track-focused CSL with 543 HP, reduced weight, and rear-wheel drive only. Throughout both generations, the M4 has maintained its position as a high-performance luxury sports coupe, balancing track capability with daily usability.
BMW-M4.name: Second Generation (G82/G83)

BMW-M440i.description: The BMW M440i is the performance-oriented variant of the second-generation 4 Series, positioned between the standard 4 Series models and the full M4. Available in coupe (G22), convertible (G23), and Gran Coupe (G26) body styles, it features a 3.0L turbocharged inline-six engine (B58) producing 382 HP and 369 lb-ft of torque. The powertrain includes 48V mild-hybrid technology with an integrated starter-generator providing an additional 11 HP boost for improved efficiency and performance. All M440i models come standard with an eight-speed automatic transmission and xDrive all-wheel drive (rear-wheel drive is available in some markets). Performance is impressive, with 0-60 mph acceleration in approximately 4.3-4.5 seconds depending on body style. The M440i is distinguished from standard 4 Series models by an M Sport exterior package, larger brakes, adaptive M suspension, M Sport differential, and various visual elements including Cerium Grey accents on the kidney grille, mirrors, and exhaust tips. Inside, it features M Sport seats, steering wheel, and trim elements. Despite sharing the controversial large kidney grille design of the standard 4 Series, the M440i has been praised for its balance of performance, refinement, and daily usability, offering much of the capability of the full M4 in a more accessible package.
BMW-M440i.name: First Generation (G22/G23/G26)

BMW-M5.description: The original M5 was hand-built by BMW Motorsport and featured a modified version of the M1 supercar's 3.5L straight-six engine producing 282 HP. Available only as a four-door sedan with manual transmission, it was the fastest production sedan of its time. The E28 M5 established the blueprint for the high-performance luxury sport sedan segment, combining track-capable performance with practical four-door packaging and understated styling.
BMW-M5.name: First Generation (E28)

BMW-M5.description: The E34 M5 continued with an evolved 3.5L straight-six engine (later increased to 3.8L) producing up to 340 HP in later European models. Available as a sedan and limited-production wagon (Touring), it featured a sophisticated chassis with unique suspension tuning, larger brakes, and subtle visual enhancements. This generation maintained the hand-built quality of its predecessor while offering increased refinement and technology.
BMW-M5.name: Second Generation (E34)

BMW-M5.description: Often considered the definitive M5, the E39 introduced V8 power to the lineup with a 4.9L naturally aspirated engine producing 400 HP, paired exclusively with a six-speed manual transmission. Available only as a sedan, it featured more aggressive styling than its predecessors while maintaining the understated approach.
