Chevrolet-Aveo.description: In several Central American countries, the Aveo nameplate was used for the third-generation Chevrolet Sail sedan, which went on sale in Mexico in November 2017 for the 2019 model year to replace the first-generation Aveo sedan. The Chinese-made Sail was renamed to avoid being related to the second-generation Sail, which obtained a zero-star rating in Latin NCAP. It was marketed alongside the Sonic as a more budget offering until the latter's discontinuation. Available as a sedan, it featured a 1.5-liter engine.
Chevrolet-Aveo.name: Chevrolet Sail-based Aveo (Mexico/Central America)

Chevrolet-Aveo.description: The new generation Aveo was introduced in December 2022 and launched in February 2023 for the Mexican market for the 2024 model year. Developed and produced by SAIC-GM-Wuling under model code 310C, it is available as a 5-door hatchback and 4-door sedan. The design features modern Chevrolet styling elements with a large grille and swept-back headlights. Engine options include a 1.5L LAR straight-four engine with 73 kW (100 hp) paired with a 6-speed manual or continuously variable transmission (CVT). In Chile and other South American countries since September 2023, it is marketed as the Chevrolet Sail. The Aveo is also sold in Egypt as the Chevrolet Optra.
Chevrolet-Aveo.name: Third Generation (310C)

Chevrolet-Blazer-EV.description: The Chevrolet Blazer EV is the brand's first electric mid-size SUV, built on GM's dedicated Ultium EV platform (GM BEV3). Introduced in 2022 and going on sale in mid-2023, the model offers FWD, RWD (2023-2025), and AWD configurations across trim levels (2LT, RS, and SS). The performance-oriented SS model delivers 557 HP and 648 lb-ft of torque, enabling 0-60 mph acceleration in under 4 seconds with the WOW (Wide Open Watts) mode. Battery capacity options include 85 kWh and 102 kWh Ultium units, with EPA-estimated range from 279 miles (85 kWh AWD) to 324 miles (102 kWh RWD). The interior features a 17.7-inch infotainment touchscreen (first vehicle with GM Ultifi system) and an 11-inch driver information center. DC fast charging supports up to 195 kW, allowing approximately 78 miles of range in 10 minutes. Manufactured in Ramos Arizpe, Mexico, the Blazer EV serves as a key model in Chevrolet's electric vehicle strategy, positioned between the compact Equinox EV and larger Silverado EV pickup truck.
Chevrolet-Blazer-EV.name: First Generation

Chevrolet-Bolt-EUV.description: The Chevrolet Bolt EUV (Electric Utility Vehicle) was a compact electric crossover SUV based on the same BEV2 platform as the Bolt EV but with a longer wheelbase and overall length. The exterior design featured a more SUV-like appearance compared to the standard Bolt, with distinct styling elements including a longer hood, different front fascia, and roof rails. Powered by the same electric drivetrain as the Bolt EV, it used a 65 kWh lithium-ion battery pack and a single front-mounted motor producing 200 HP and 266 lb-ft of torque. The EPA-estimated range was 247 miles, slightly less than the standard Bolt EV due to the EUV's larger size and weight. The interior offered more rear legroom than the Bolt EV and featured a 10.2-inch touchscreen infotainment system, wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, and available features like a panoramic sunroof not offered on the standard Bolt. Most significantly, the Bolt EUV was the first Chevrolet vehicle to offer GM's Super Cruise hands-free driver assistance system. Despite its short production run, the Bolt EUV represented an important step in GM's electric vehicle strategy, offering a more spacious alternative to the standard Bolt with crossover styling cues at an accessible price point. Production ended in 2023 as GM shifted focus to vehicles built on its next-generation Ultium platform.
Chevrolet-Bolt-EUV.name: First Generation

Chevrolet-Bolt-EV.description: The first-generation Chevrolet Bolt EV represented a milestone for General Motors as the company's first mass-produced, purpose-built electric vehicle with a focus on affordability and practical range. Featuring a tall, compact hatchback design optimized for interior space within a small footprint, the Bolt EV offered seating for five and surprisingly generous cargo capacity for its external dimensions. Powered by a single electric motor producing 200 horsepower and 266 lb-ft of torque driving the front wheels, the Bolt delivered spirited performance with 0-60 mph acceleration in approximately 6.5 seconds. The 60 kWh lithium-ion battery pack provided an EPA-rated range of 238 miles (later improved to 259 miles with software updates)—unprecedented at its price point when introduced and eliminating much of the range anxiety associated with earlier affordable EVs. The interior featured a digital instrument cluster and a 10.2-inch central touchscreen, with materials that prioritized durability over luxury. Distinctive features included an electronic precision shift system using a shift-by-wire design, one-pedal driving capability through aggressive regenerative braking, and a surround-view camera system unusual for its segment. DC fast charging capability was available, though limited to a maximum of 55 kW. Despite winning numerous accolades including Motor Trend Car of the Year and North American Car of the Year, the Bolt EV faced challenges in the market including a major battery recall affecting all models due to fire risk, requiring replacement of battery modules. Nevertheless, the first-generation Bolt EV established GM's capabilities in electric vehicle development and provided a practical, affordable option for mainstream consumers ready to transition to electric mobility.
Chevrolet-Bolt-EV.name: First Generation

Chevrolet-Bolt-EV.description: The second-generation Chevrolet Bolt EV represents a comprehensive refresh rather than a complete redesign, maintaining the same basic platform and battery/motor technology while introducing significant styling updates and feature improvements at a lower starting price than its predecessor. The exterior received a more modern, mainstream design with a closed-off front fascia, new LED lighting signatures, and more streamlined proportions that reduced the somewhat awkward appearance of the original model. The powertrain carries over the single-motor front-wheel drive configuration producing 200 horsepower and 266 lb-ft of torque, paired with a 65 kWh battery providing an EPA-rated range of 259 miles. Charging capabilities remain similar with up to 11 kW Level 2 AC charging and 55 kW DC fast charging, the latter allowing approximately 100 miles of range to be added in 30 minutes. The interior saw more significant changes with a completely redesigned dashboard featuring a 10.2-inch touchscreen angled toward the driver, new seat designs with higher quality materials, and a more conventional electronic gear selector replacing the previous shift-by-wire system. New technology features include wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, an available HD surround vision camera, and enhanced driver assistance capabilities. Chevrolet addressed the previous generation's battery fire issues with new cell chemistry and manufacturing processes while backing this with an 8-year/100,000-mile battery warranty. The second-generation Bolt EV was joined by the slightly larger Bolt EUV (Electric Utility Vehicle) variant offering a more crossover-like appearance and increased rear seat space. Despite technical similarities to its predecessor, the refreshed Bolt EV's improved design, updated technology, and significantly lower starting price positioned it as one of the most affordable electric vehicles on the market, offering practical range and features at a price point competitive with many conventional compact cars after available incentives.
Chevrolet-Bolt-EV.name: Second Generation

Chevrolet-Camaro.description: The original Camaro was Chevrolet's response to the Ford Mustang, establishing the pony car rivalry that would span decades. Available as a coupe or convertible, it featured a unibody structure with a front subframe. Engine options ranged from inline-six to small and big-block V8s, with the legendary Z/28 introduced for SCCA Trans-Am racing homologation. The first-generation Camaro established the model's performance credentials and iconic styling elements.
Chevrolet-Camaro.name: First Generation

Chevrolet-Camaro.description: The longest-running Camaro generation featured a completely new design with a more aggressive, lower, and wider stance. No convertible was offered during this generation. Performance initially thrived with multiple V8 options including the Z28 and SS models, but gradually declined due to increasing emissions regulations and the 1973 oil crisis. Despite these challenges, the second-generation Camaro maintained strong sales and further cemented the model's cultural significance.
Chevrolet-Camaro.name: Second Generation

Chevrolet-Camaro.description: The third-generation Camaro represented a dramatic modernization with a sleek, aerodynamic design featuring a hatchback body style. It introduced fuel injection, four-cylinder engine options, and five-speed manual transmissions. Performance gradually returned with the IROC-Z and later models, which featured tuned port injection. This generation embraced modern technology while maintaining the Camaro's performance image during a transitional era for American muscle cars.
Chevrolet-Camaro.name: Third Generation

Chevrolet-Camaro.description: The fourth-generation Camaro featured a more rounded, aerodynamic design while returning to a more traditional performance formula. The convertible body style returned, and power came primarily from V6 and V8 engines, with the LT1 and later LS1 V8s providing impressive performance for the era. Despite strong performance credentials, changing consumer preferences toward SUVs led to declining sales and eventually the model's temporary discontinuation after 2002.
Chevrolet-Camaro.name: Fourth Generation

Chevrolet-Camaro.description: After an eight-year hiatus, the Camaro returned with retro-inspired styling that paid homage to the first generation while incorporating modern elements. Built on GM's Zeta platform, it offered V6 and V8 engines with significantly improved refinement and technology compared to previous generations. The ZL1 and Z/28 models pushed performance to new heights. This generation successfully reestablished the Camaro in the modern muscle car segment and was featured prominently in popular culture.
Chevrolet-Camaro.name: Fifth Generation

Chevrolet-Camaro.description: The current Camaro evolved the retro design language while adopting the GM Alpha platform shared with Cadillac models, resulting in a lighter, more nimble vehicle. Engine options expanded to include a turbocharged four-cylinder, alongside V6 and V8 options. The SS models featured the LT1 V8 from the Corvette, while the ZL1 offered supercharged power with track-focused capability. Despite critical acclaim for its driving dynamics, sales declined amid shrinking demand for coupes and muscle cars. Chevrolet announced 2024 would be the final production year, marking the end of the Camaro's continuous production for the second time in its history.
Chevrolet-Camaro.name: Sixth Generation

Chevrolet-Celta.description: The Chevrolet Celta was a subcompact car developed specifically for the South American market, particularly Brazil. Built on GM's 4200 platform, a simplified evolution of the Opel Corsa B architecture, it was designed to be an affordable, entry-level vehicle with low production and maintenance costs. Initially available only as a three-door hatchback, a five-door variant was added in 2002. Throughout its production, the Celta was powered by 1.0L and 1.4L gasoline engines, with flex-fuel capability (able to run on ethanol) added in 2005. The interior was basic and functional, focusing on durability rather than luxury. A significant facelift in 2006 updated the front fascia to align with Chevrolet's global design language, while additional minor updates throughout its life added features like power steering, air conditioning, and basic safety equipment. Despite its simplicity, the Celta became one of Brazil's best-selling cars due to its affordability, reliability, and low operating costs. Production ended in 2015 when it was effectively replaced by the Chevrolet Onix in GM's Brazilian lineup. The Celta represented an important strategic model for GM in developing markets, demonstrating how global platforms could be adapted and simplified for specific regional requirements and price points.
Chevrolet-Celta.name: First Generation

Chevrolet-Cobalt.description: The North American Chevrolet Cobalt was a compact car that replaced the Cavalier in Chevrolet's lineup. Built on GM's Delta platform, it was available as a two-door coupe or four-door sedan. Engine options included 2.2L and 2.4L Ecotec four-cylinders, with the performance-oriented SS models featuring either a supercharged 2.0L (2005-2007) or a turbocharged 2.0L (2008-2010) engine producing up to 260 HP in the highest-spec SS coupe. The interior was basic but functional, with materials quality that reflected its budget-friendly positioning. Safety features were gradually improved throughout its production, with side airbags and stability control eventually becoming available. Despite criticism for its interior quality and refinement, the Cobalt SS variants received praise for their performance, with the turbocharged model setting competitive lap times against more expensive sports cars.
Chevrolet-Cobalt.name: First Generation (North America)

Chevrolet-Cobalt.description: The international version of the Chevrolet Cobalt, unrelated to the North American model, was a subcompact sedan developed primarily for emerging markets in South America, Asia, and Eastern Europe. Built on GM's GEM (Global Emerging Markets) platform, it featured simple, functional styling with a focus on interior space and practicality. Typically powered by 1.4L to 1.8L four-cylinder engines depending on the market, with manual or automatic transmission options. The interior prioritized space efficiency and durability over premium materials, with basic technology features by modern standards. This Cobalt was positioned as an affordable, practical family sedan for markets where value and low operating costs were primary considerations. In some regions, it was replaced by models like the Chevrolet Onix Plus or continued to be sold alongside newer designs. The international Cobalt represented GM's strategy of developing specific, cost-effective vehicles for emerging markets rather than directly adapting North American or European models.
Chevrolet-Cobalt.name: Chevrolet Cobalt (International Markets)

Chevrolet-Colorado.description: The original Chevrolet Colorado replaced the S-10 as Chevrolet's compact/mid-size pickup truck. Developed alongside the GMC Canyon, it was available in regular cab, extended cab, and crew cab configurations with both short and long bed options. Engine choices initially included inline-four and inline-five cylinder options, with a V8 added later in the production run. The first-generation Colorado offered improved refinement compared to the S-10 but was criticized for underpowered engines in early models and interior quality. A significant refresh in 2009 addressed some concerns with revised styling, improved interior materials, and new engine options including the 5.3L V8 with 300 HP. This generation established the Colorado nameplate in North America, though it faced strong competition from the Toyota Tacoma and Nissan Frontier.
Chevrolet-Colorado.name: First Generation

Chevrolet-Colorado.description: The second-generation Colorado was initially developed by GM Brazil and Thailand for international markets before being substantially redesigned for North America, where it launched for the 2015 model year after a brief hiatus. Larger than its predecessor, it competed in the mid-size truck segment with extended and crew cab configurations. North American engine options included a 2.5L four-cylinder, 3.6L V6, and a 2.8L Duramax diesel four-cylinder that offered impressive torque and towing capability. The interior featured significantly improved materials and technology, including an available 8-inch touchscreen with smartphone integration. Off-road capability was emphasized with the Z71 package and the more extreme ZR2 variant, which featured specialized suspension, wider track width, and electronic locking differentials. This generation successfully reestablished Chevrolet in the mid-size truck segment with competitive capabilities, technology, and efficiency.
Chevrolet-Colorado.name: Second Generation

Chevrolet-Colorado.description: The current Colorado represents a complete redesign, focusing on a more aggressive appearance and enhanced capability. Now exclusively offered with crew cab and short box configuration, it features a single powertrain: a 2.7L turbocharged four-cylinder with varying output levels from 237 HP to 310 HP depending on the trim. The exterior design is more rugged and truck-like, with distinct styling differences between trims including the off-road focused Trail Boss and ZR2 models. The interior has been thoroughly modernized with a standard 11.3-inch touchscreen, digital instrument options, and improved materials. Off-road capability remains a priority, especially in the ZR2 model which features Multimatic DSSV dampers, electronic locking differentials, and increased ground clearance. This generation maintains focus on the core mid-size truck market while offering technology and features previously found only in full-size pickups, reflecting the evolving expectations and uses of mid-size trucks.
Chevrolet-Colorado.name: Third Generation

Chevrolet-Corvette.description: The original Corvette, codenamed C1, debuted in 1953 as a concept car at GM's Motorama show and quickly entered limited production. Initially available only in Polo White with a red interior, the first-year models featured a revolutionary fiberglass body—a material choice made to bypass steel shortages following World War II that would become a Corvette hallmark. Contrary to its later reputation, the C1 began life as more of a cruiser than a sports car, powered by a lackluster 150-horsepower 'Blue Flame' inline-six engine paired with a two-speed automatic transmission. Sales struggled until 1955, when Chief Engineer Zora Arkus-Duntov—who would become known as the 'Father of the Corvette'—convinced GM to install a small-block V8, transforming the car's character and trajectory. The 1956 model brought a comprehensive redesign with proper roll-up windows and optional removable hardtop. The 1957 model year introduced fuel injection, making Corvette one of the first mass-produced cars with this technology. By 1962, the final year of C1 production, the Corvette had evolved significantly, with power reaching up to 360 horsepower from the fuel-injected 327 cubic-inch V8. The first-generation Corvette established the nameplate's identity as America's sports car and laid the foundation for its future performance legacy.
Chevrolet-Corvette.name: First Generation (C1)

Chevrolet-Corvette.description: The second-generation Corvette, known as the 'Sting Ray' (written as two words until 1969), revolutionized the model with its dramatic styling and advanced engineering. Designed by Bill Mitchell and Larry Shinoda, the C2 featured distinctive split-window styling on the 1963 coupe—a controversial one-year-only design element now highly prized by collectors. For the first time, Corvette offered both convertible and coupe body styles. The C2 rode on a completely new chassis with independent rear suspension—a radical departure from the live axle of the C1—significantly improving handling and ride quality. Power came from variations of Chevrolet's small-block V8, initially displacing 327 cubic inches with outputs ranging from 250 to 360 horsepower. In 1965, a big-block V8 option was introduced, first as a 396 cubic-inch unit and later as a 427, producing up to 435 horsepower in its highest state of tune. The legendary L88 427 engine, conservatively rated at 430 horsepower but actually producing closer to 500, debuted in 1967 as a limited-production racing-oriented option. Four-wheel disc brakes became standard in 1965, further enhancing the Corvette's performance credentials. Though produced for just five model years, the C2 Corvette has become one of the most iconic and collectible American cars, representing the perfect balance of style, performance, and innovation that defined the model's golden age.
Chevrolet-Corvette.name: Second Generation (C2)

Chevrolet-Corvette.description: The third-generation Corvette, introduced in 1968, featured radical 'Mako Shark II' styling by Larry Shinoda under Bill Mitchell's design leadership. While maintaining the previous generation's chassis architecture, the C3 looked entirely different with its pronounced fender flares, long hood, and tapered rear deck. Initially offered with an array of high-performance engine options including the formidable 427 and later 454 cubic-inch big blocks, the C3 suffered from power decreases throughout its run due to tightening emissions regulations and the energy crisis. By 1975, the legendary big-block V8s had disappeared from the lineup, and the base L48 small-block output had fallen to 165 horsepower. Despite this, the C3 remained popular, with Chevrolet selling over 58,000 units in 1979—the highest annual Corvette sales up to that point. Notable developments during the extended C3 production run included the introduction of T-tops in 1968, a body-colored urethane front bumper in 1973, and a redesigned fastback rear window in 1978 with the Silver Anniversary and Pace Car editions. While the later C3 models lacked the raw power of their early counterparts, they gained improvements in build quality, refinement, and technology. The 1982 Collector Edition marked the end of the C3 era with special features including a lifting glass hatch—the first on a Corvette since 1967—and the Cross-Fire Injection fuel system that previewed the technology of the upcoming C4 generation.
Chevrolet-Corvette.name: Third Generation (C3)

Chevrolet-Corvette.description: The fourth-generation Corvette represented a complete reinvention of America's sports car after 15 years of C3 production. There was no 1983 model year Corvette, as development delays pushed the C4's introduction to 1984. The new design featured a sleek, modern shape with a clamshell hood, hideaway headlights, and a glass hatchback. The C4 introduced an entirely new chassis with a uniframe design, forged aluminum suspension components, and a digital dashboard that epitomized 1980s high-tech aesthetics. Initially powered by the 'Cross-Fire' injection 350 V8 producing 205 horsepower, the C4 quickly evolved with the introduction of Tuned Port Injection in 1985, boosting output to 230 horsepower. Performance continued to improve throughout the generation, highlighted by the introduction of the Corvette ZR-1 in 1990. Developed in collaboration with Lotus Engineering and powered by the hand-built LT5 DOHC V8 producing 375 horsepower, the ZR-1 could achieve 0-60 mph in 4.4 seconds and a top speed of 180 mph—exotic car territory for the era. The standard Corvette received its own power boost with the LT1 engine in 1992, producing 300 horsepower. The C4's final year brought the Grand Sport special edition, featuring Admiral Blue paint with a white stripe and black wheels, plus the Collector Edition. While initial C4 models emphasized handling over straight-line speed, by the end of its run, the fourth-generation Corvette had evolved into a well-rounded performance car that successfully rehabilitated the nameplate's performance image after the emissions-strangled late C3 models.
Chevrolet-Corvette.name: Fourth Generation (C4)

Chevrolet-Corvette.description: The fifth-generation Corvette debuted for 1997, introducing revolutionary changes to the model's architecture and construction. Chief Engineer Dave Hill focused on addressing the C4's shortcomings with a completely new platform featuring a hydroformed perimeter frame, a rear-mounted transmission for improved weight distribution (transaxle design), and a more rigid structure with a backbone design that reduced weight while increasing torsional stiffness by four times compared to the C4. Power came from the new LS1 all-aluminum 5.7-liter V8, producing 345 horsepower at launch and later increased to 350 horsepower. The C5 was available in three body styles: coupe with a removable roof panel, convertible, and the fixed-roof hardtop introduced in 1999, which became the basis for the track-focused Z06 model in 2001. The Z06 featured the uprated LS6 engine, initially producing 385 horsepower and later 405 horsepower, along with a titanium exhaust, lighter glass, and suspension tuned for maximum performance. The Z06 could accelerate from 0-60 mph in under 4 seconds and achieve nearly 1g of lateral grip on the skidpad. Beyond its performance capabilities, the C5 was more practical than previous Corvettes, with a real trunk in the coupe and improved ergonomics. The interior featured dual cockpit styling reminiscent of earlier generations but with modern amenities and improved build quality. The C5 represented a quantum leap forward for the Corvette, earning widespread acclaim for successfully combining world-class performance with everyday usability at a fraction of the price of exotic European competitors.
Chevrolet-Corvette.name: Fifth Generation (C5)

Chevrolet-Corvette.description: The sixth-generation Corvette, introduced for 2005, represented an evolutionary approach to the revolutionary C5 platform. The C6 maintained the same basic architecture as its predecessor while addressing many of its weaknesses. Most noticeably, the C6 eliminated the pop-up headlights that had been a Corvette signature since 1963, replacing them with fixed xenon HID projector units that improved aerodynamics and lighting performance. The exterior dimensions shrunk slightly compared to the C5, but interior space increased through more efficient packaging. Power initially came from a new LS2 6.0-liter V8 producing 400 horsepower, replaced in 2008 by the LS3 6.2-liter V8 with 430 horsepower. The Z06 model returned for 2006, now powered by the 7.0-liter LS7 V8—the largest small-block ever produced—hand-built with racing-derived features like titanium connecting rods and delivering 505 horsepower. The C6 generation reached its performance apex with the introduction of the ZR1 in 2009, featuring a supercharged 6.2-liter LS9 V8 producing 638 horsepower, extensive carbon fiber bodywork, Brembo carbon-ceramic brakes, and Magnetic Selective Ride Control suspension. With a top speed exceeding 200 mph, the ZR1 was the fastest, most powerful, and most expensive production Corvette to date. The C6 generation also saw the introduction of the Grand Sport model in 2010, combining the standard powertrain with many of the Z06's handling and visual elements. Interior quality, a longtime Corvette criticism, saw improvements throughout the generation, particularly with the 2008 refresh. The C6 Corvette further expanded the model's global credibility with multiple class victories at the 24 Hours of Le Mans in GT1 competition.
Chevrolet-Corvette.name: Sixth Generation (C6)

Chevrolet-Corvette.description: The seventh-generation Corvette debuted for 2014 with the revival of the Stingray name (now as a single word) and a bold new design language featuring angular lines, aggressive vents, and a more European-inspired appearance. While still using an evolved version of the front-engine, rear-transaxle architecture introduced with the C5, the C7 was almost entirely new, with just two parts carried over from the C6. The aluminum frame, previously reserved for Z06 and ZR1 models, became standard across the lineup, contributing to a 50:50 weight distribution. Inside, the C7 addressed longstanding criticism with a dramatically improved interior featuring quality materials, a driver-focused cockpit with high-resolution displays, and genuine carbon fiber and aluminum trim. Power came from the new LT1 6.2-liter direct-injected V8 with 455 horsepower (460 with the optional performance exhaust), utilizing Active Fuel Management cylinder deactivation technology to improve efficiency. The Z06 model returned for 2015, now featuring a supercharged LT4 V8 producing 650 horsepower, matching performance levels previously reserved for the C6 ZR1, accompanied by an aggressive aerodynamic package available in three increasingly track-focused levels. For 2019, the final year of C7 production, Chevrolet introduced the ZR1 with the 755-horsepower supercharged LT5 V8, massive cooling upgrades, and an optional High Wing package generating 950 pounds of downforce. The C7 generation also introduced the Grand Sport model that combined the Z06's wider body and suspension tuning with the base Stingray's naturally aspirated engine. Performance technology included available Magnetic Ride Control suspension, an electronic limited-slip differential, Performance Traction Management system, and a rev-matching feature for manual transmissions. The C7 represented the pinnacle of front-engine Corvette development, delivering supercar performance while maintaining the practicality and value proposition that had long defined the model.
Chevrolet-Corvette.name: Seventh Generation (C7)

Chevrolet-Corvette.description: The eighth-generation Corvette, introduced for the 2020 model year, represents the most radical reinvention in the model's history with its adoption of a mid-engine layout—fulfilling a vision Zora Arkus-Duntov had pursued since the 1960s. This fundamental architecture change positions the 6.2-liter LT2 V8 engine behind the passenger compartment but ahead of the rear axle, enabling superior weight distribution, improved traction, and a more direct connection between driver inputs and vehicle response. Even in base Stingray form, the C8 produces 495 horsepower with the Z51 performance package, enabling 0-60 mph acceleration in under 3 seconds—performance that required the top-tier ZR1 in the previous generation. The exterior design embodies the mid-engine proportions with a short, low hood, large side air intakes, and a cab-forward stance, while still incorporating traditional Corvette design cues. The interior features a driver-centric cockpit with a squared-off steering wheel, digital instrument cluster, and a distinctive row of climate controls separating driver and passenger. Technological advancements include a GPS-based front-lift system that remembers locations where additional ground clearance is needed, a digital rearview mirror, and advanced customization of performance parameters. The Z06 variant, introduced for 2023, elevates the C8's performance with the naturally aspirated 5.5-liter flat-plane crank LT6 V8 producing 670 horsepower and revving to 8,600 rpm—the most powerful naturally aspirated V8 ever in a production car. With a significantly wider body, advanced aerodynamics generating 734 pounds of downforce, and available carbon fiber wheels, the Z06 delivers track capabilities that rival dedicated racing cars. The 2024 model year introduced the hybrid all-wheel-drive E-Ray, combining the LT2 V8 with an electric motor on the front axle to produce a combined 655 horsepower. The 2024 ZR1, powered by a twin-turbocharged version of the Z06's LT6 engine, codenamed LT7, is expected to produce over 800 horsepower. The mid-engine C8 has successfully transformed the Corvette into a legitimate exotic car competitor while maintaining relative affordability compared to its European rivals.
Chevrolet-Corvette.name: Eighth Generation (C8)

Chevrolet-Cruze.description: The original Chevrolet Cruze was a globally developed compact car built on GM's Delta II platform. Initially launched in South Korea and gradually rolled out worldwide, it represented GM's first truly global compact car program. In most markets, it was available as a four-door sedan, with a five-door hatchback added later. Engine options varied by region but typically included 1.4L to 2.0L gasoline engines and various diesel options, with the turbocharged 1.4L being the most common in North America. The interior featured a dual-cockpit design with better materials than previous GM compact cars, while safety was emphasized with up to ten airbags in some markets. A significant refresh in 2015 updated the styling and technology. The first-generation Cruze was generally well-received for its solid construction, fuel efficiency, and value, helping to improve Chevrolet's reputation in the compact segment after the underwhelming Cobalt.
Chevrolet-Cruze.name: First Generation

Chevrolet-Cruze.description: The second-generation Cruze was built on GM's D2XX platform and featured more refined styling with a lower, sleeker profile. In North America, it was available as both a sedan and hatchback, powered primarily by a revised 1.4L turbocharged four-cylinder engine paired with either a six-speed manual or automatic transmission, with a 1.6L diesel option added later. The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and technology, featuring a standard 7-inch (later 8-inch) touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. Overall vehicle weight was reduced by up to 250 pounds compared to its predecessor, improving both performance and efficiency. Advanced safety features including automatic emergency braking, lane keep assist, and blind-spot monitoring became available. Despite receiving positive reviews for its refined driving experience, efficiency, and technology, the Cruze fell victim to shifting consumer preferences toward SUVs, with production for North America ending in 2019 as part of GM's restructuring. However, the model continued in other markets, particularly China, where a refreshed version remained available.
Chevrolet-Cruze.name: Second Generation

Chevrolet-D-Max.description: The first-generation Chevrolet D-Max (in markets where Chevrolet badged this model) was essentially a rebadged Isuzu D-Max, a mid-size pickup truck developed by Isuzu but sold under various brands through GM's partnership with the Japanese manufacturer. Available in single cab, extended cab, and crew cab configurations, it was designed primarily for global markets outside North America. Powertrain options typically included 2.5L to 3.0L diesel engines and occasionally gasoline options depending on the market, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. The interior was functional and durable rather than luxurious, reflecting its positioning as a work-oriented vehicle in many markets. This generation established the D-Max as a reliable, capable pickup in regions where compact and mid-size trucks were primary work vehicles rather than lifestyle products.
Chevrolet-D-Max.name: First Generation

Chevrolet-D-Max.description: The second-generation D-Max featured more modern styling and improved refinement while maintaining its robust, work-oriented character. Still based on Isuzu engineering but sold as a Chevrolet in select markets, it continued to offer single cab, extended cab, and crew cab body styles. Diesel engines remained the primary powertrain option, with improved power, efficiency, and emissions control. The interior saw notable improvements in design and material quality, with more comfort and technology features, particularly in higher trim levels intended for dual-purpose work and family use. Safety equipment was enhanced throughout the production run, with features like stability control, hill descent control, and multiple airbags becoming available. This generation maintained the model's reputation for durability while adding refinement and features expected by evolving customer preferences.
Chevrolet-D-Max.name: Second Generation

Chevrolet-D-Max.description: The current D-Max (where sold as a Chevrolet) represents a significant advancement in design, technology, and capability. Developed once again by Isuzu but with input from various badge-engineering partners, it features a more assertive exterior design with a larger grille, muscular fenders, and modern lighting elements. Powertrains continue to focus on diesel technology, typically centered around refined 1.9L and 3.0L turbodiesel engines with improved power delivery and efficiency. The interior has been thoroughly modernized with a more car-like design, improved materials, and significantly enhanced technology including larger touchscreens with smartphone integration and advanced driver assistance systems. Safety has become a major focus, with the latest models achieving impressive crash test ratings through multiple airbags, enhanced structural design, and active safety features. Where sold as a Chevrolet, the third-generation D-Max allows the brand to compete effectively in the global mid-size pickup segment with a modern, capable truck that balances work utility with passenger comfort and contemporary technology.
Chevrolet-D-Max.name: Third Generation

Chevrolet-Equinox.description: The original Chevrolet Equinox was a mid-size crossover SUV built on GM's Theta platform. Larger than many competitors in the compact SUV segment, it featured a spacious interior with a sliding rear seat that could adjust to prioritize either passenger or cargo space. Power came from a 3.4L V6 engine producing 185 HP, paired with a five-speed automatic transmission and available in front or all-wheel drive configurations. The interior was functional but featured materials that reflected its budget-friendly positioning. A Sport model with a more powerful 3.6L V6 was added later in the production run. The first-generation Equinox established the nameplate as an important part of Chevrolet's lineup during the growing transition from traditional SUVs to car-based crossovers.
Chevrolet-Equinox.name: First Generation

Chevrolet-Equinox.description: The second-generation Equinox maintained similar exterior dimensions but featured significantly improved styling, interior quality, and efficiency. Initially powered by a standard 2.4L four-cylinder or optional 3.0L V6 (later upgraded to a 3.6L), all engines featured direct injection for improved performance and fuel economy. Notable features included an available powered liftgate, advanced audio system, and a rear-seat entertainment system. Safety was enhanced with standard stability control and available forward collision alert and lane departure warning. A significant refresh in 2016 updated the exterior styling and interior technology. The second-generation Equinox became one of Chevrolet's best-selling vehicles, successfully competing in the increasingly crowded and important compact crossover segment.
Chevrolet-Equinox.name: Second Generation

Chevrolet-Equinox.description: The third-generation Equinox was downsized to more directly compete in the compact crossover segment, losing approximately 400 pounds in the process. The exterior design featured sharper styling aligned with Chevrolet's contemporary design language. Engine options included 1.5L and 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinders and briefly a 1.6L turbodiesel, all providing improved efficiency compared to the previous generation. The interior offered enhanced materials, design, and technology, including an available 8-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. Safety technology expanded to include automatic emergency braking, lane keep assist, and adaptive cruise control on higher trims. A refresh in 2022 updated the styling and feature content. This generation solidified the Equinox's position as a core model in Chevrolet's lineup, consistently ranking among the brand's best-sellers.
Chevrolet-Equinox.name: Third Generation

Chevrolet-Equinox.description: The current Equinox features a complete redesign with more modern, SUV-like styling and updated technology. Slightly larger than its predecessor, it offers improved passenger and cargo space while maintaining competitive efficiency. Powered by a turbocharged 1.5L four-cylinder engine paired with an 8-speed automatic transmission, it's available in front or all-wheel drive configurations. The interior has been thoroughly modernized with a standard 11.3-inch touchscreen, digital instrument options, and improved materials. Safety technology is comprehensive with Chevy Safety Assist standard across the lineup. The fourth-generation Equinox continues to target the heart of the compact crossover market with a balance of style, technology, and practicality, maintaining its crucial role in Chevrolet's product portfolio as consumer preferences continue to favor SUVs over traditional cars.
Chevrolet-Equinox.name: Fourth Generation

Chevrolet-Equinox-EV.description: The Chevrolet Equinox EV is an all-electric compact crossover SUV that shares only its name with the gasoline-powered Equinox. Built on GM's Ultium EV platform, it features a sleek, aerodynamic design that's distinctly different from its combustion engine namesake, with a closed-off front grille, slim LED lighting elements, and a more futuristic overall appearance. The Equinox EV is offered in both front-wheel drive and all-wheel drive configurations, with the former providing approximately 250 miles of range and the latter around 280 miles, depending on the battery pack and trim level. Power outputs range from roughly 210 HP in base front-wheel drive models to 290 HP in all-wheel drive variants. The interior showcases a modern, minimalist design centered around a standard 11-inch digital instrument cluster and 11-inch central touchscreen (upgraded to 17.7 inches in higher trims), with a floating center console providing additional storage space. Charging capabilities include DC fast charging at up to 150 kW, allowing approximately 70 miles of range to be added in 10 minutes. The Equinox EV is positioned as an affordable entry point to Chevrolet's electric vehicle lineup, with a starting price significantly lower than many competitors, making it a strategic model in GM's electrification plans. With its combination of practical size, competitive range, and accessible pricing, the Equinox EV aims to bring electric vehicles to mainstream compact SUV buyers who might otherwise consider traditional gasoline-powered alternatives.
Chevrolet-Equinox-EV.name: First Generation

Chevrolet-Express-Cargo.description: Original design for 1996 model year, first all-new design since 1971 for full-size van line. Introduced with substantial improvements including forward axle placement and increased passenger space.
Chevrolet-Express-Cargo.name: First Generation (1996-2002)

Chevrolet-Express-Cargo.description: 2003 mid-cycle revision with substantial frame and chassis upgrades. Bodywork forward of windshield revised with higher hood line. GMT610 platform continues in production through 2026 model year.
Chevrolet-Express-Cargo.name: First Generation (2003-present, Facelift)

Chevrolet-Impala.description: The original Impala was introduced as a high-end trim level of the Bel Air, featuring distinctive styling with six taillights and premium features. Available as a coupe and convertible, it established the Impala as Chevrolet's flagship full-size model. Engine options included V8s up to 348 cubic inches. Despite its short run, this generation established the Impala's reputation for combining style, luxury, and performance.
Chevrolet-Impala.name: First Generation

Chevrolet-Impala.description: The drastically redesigned 1959 Impala featured distinctive 'bat wing' rear fenders and 'cat eye' taillights. Now its own model line rather than a Bel Air trim, it was available in coupe, convertible, and sedan body styles. This iconic design, though only produced for two years, is one of the most recognizable American cars of the era and helped establish the Impala as a cultural icon.
Chevrolet-Impala.name: Second Generation

Chevrolet-Impala.description: Through the 1960s, the Impala became one of America's best-selling vehicles, with the 1965 model selling over one million units in a single year. The legendary 1961-1969 SS (Super Sport) models established the Impala's performance credentials. Subsequent generations through the 1970s and 1980s reflected changing automotive trends with downsizing, fuel efficiency focus, and evolving design language. The Impala name was temporarily retired after 1996 as Chevrolet consolidated its full-size sedan lineup.
Chevrolet-Impala.name: Third through Ninth Generations

Chevrolet-Impala.description: The Impala returned briefly as a high-performance Impala SS variant of the Caprice. Featuring a Corvette-derived 5.7L LT1 V8, sport suspension, and distinctive styling, this limited-production model became instantly collectible and maintained the Impala's performance heritage during an era when American performance cars were rare.
Chevrolet-Impala.name: Tenth Generation (Impala SS)

Chevrolet-Impala.description: After a brief hiatus, the Impala returned as a front-wheel drive sedan based on GM's W-body platform, replacing the Lumina in Chevrolet's lineup. Available with V6 engines including a supercharged variant in the SS model, this generation prioritized comfort and value over the performance focus of earlier Impalas. Despite criticism for its conservative styling and front-wheel drive layout, it sold well, particularly to fleet customers.
Chevrolet-Impala.name: Eleventh Generation

Chevrolet-Impala.description: A redesigned Impala continued on an updated version of the W-body platform with more distinctive styling. Engine options included V6s and a 5.3L V8 in the SS model (discontinued after 2009). A significant refresh in 2014 added modern technology and safety features. This generation balanced modern features with traditional full-size sedan values of space and comfort, continuing to serve both retail and fleet markets.
Chevrolet-Impala.name: Twelfth Generation

Chevrolet-Impala.description: The final Impala generation moved to GM's Epsilon II platform shared with the Cadillac XTS. Featuring sophisticated styling and dramatically improved interior quality, it received critical acclaim including Consumer Reports' highest sedan rating at its launch. Powertrain options included a 2.5L four-cylinder, 2.4L hybrid (briefly), and 3.6L V6. Advanced technology and safety features brought the Impala into the modern era, but declining sedan sales led to its discontinuation in 2020, ending over 60 years of the Impala nameplate.
Chevrolet-Impala.name: Thirteenth Generation

Chevrolet-Lacrosse.description: The Chevrolet Lacrosse, if referring to a vehicle sold under the Chevrolet brand name, would typically be a regional marketing variant of what is primarily known as the Buick LaCrosse in most markets. In Canada, the first-generation Buick LaCrosse was initially marketed as the 'Buick Allure' due to potential negative connotations of the LaCrosse name in Quebec French slang, but it was never officially sold as a Chevrolet model. In some international markets, particularly China, Buick models have occasionally been rebadged as Chevrolets for specific regional requirements, but the LaCrosse is globally recognized as a Buick product. Any Chevrolet Lacrosse would share specifications, features, and generations with its Buick counterpart of the same model years. The confusion may stem from GM's global brand strategy where vehicles are sometimes marketed under different brands in different regions. For accurate information on the mid-size to full-size sedan referred to as 'LaCrosse,' please refer to Buick LaCrosse documentation, as this represents the primary and official branding of this vehicle across global markets.
Chevrolet-Lacrosse.name: Note on Nomenclature

Chevrolet-Malibu.description: The original Malibu was introduced as a top-line trim level of the Chevrolet Chevelle, featuring more upscale appointments and styling. Available in sedan, coupe, convertible, and wagon body styles, it offered various engine options including the legendary SS performance variants with big-block V8s. This generation established the Malibu nameplate and its reputation for combining mainstream appeal with available performance options.
Chevrolet-Malibu.name: First Generation

Chevrolet-Malibu.description: Through the 1970s, the Malibu continued as a trim level of the Chevelle before eventually becoming its own model line as the Chevelle name was phased out. These generations saw the Malibu transition from a muscle car era icon to a more efficient mid-size offering in response to changing market conditions. The final rear-wheel drive generation ended production in 1983, with various sedans, coupes, and wagons offered throughout this period.
Chevrolet-Malibu.name: Second through Fourth Generations (as Chevelle Malibu)

Chevrolet-Malibu.description: After a 14-year hiatus, the Malibu returned as a front-wheel drive mid-size sedan based on GM's N-body platform. Designed to compete with the Toyota Camry and Honda Accord, it featured conservative styling and a focus on value. Initially powered by a 2.4L four-cylinder or 3.1L V6 engine, it prioritized comfort and efficiency over performance. The generation was renamed Classic from 2004-2005 after the introduction of the new Epsilon platform Malibu. Despite modest sales success, this generation helped reestablish the Malibu in the important mid-size sedan segment.
Chevrolet-Malibu.name: Fifth Generation

Chevrolet-Malibu.description: The sixth-generation Malibu moved to GM's Epsilon platform and was available as both a traditional sedan and an extended-length Maxx hatchback variant. Engine options included a 2.2L four-cylinder and 3.5L V6, with a performance-oriented SS model featuring a 3.9L V6 producing 240 HP. Interior quality improved over its predecessor, though the design was criticized for being uninspiring. This generation represented Chevrolet's continued effort to compete in the mid-size segment while the unusual Maxx variant attempted to offer a European-inspired alternative body style.
Chevrolet-Malibu.name: Sixth Generation

Chevrolet-Malibu.description: The seventh-generation Malibu featured more distinctive styling and significant improvements in refinement and quality. Available only as a sedan, it won North American Car of the Year upon its introduction. Engine options included a 2.4L four-cylinder and 3.6L V6, with a mild hybrid system briefly offered. Interior quality and design took a major step forward, with a dual-cockpit layout and improved materials. This generation successfully improved the Malibu's reputation and competitiveness in the mid-size segment.
Chevrolet-Malibu.name: Seventh Generation

Chevrolet-Malibu.description: The short-lived eighth-generation Malibu featured more aerodynamic styling and reduced weight. Initially criticized for its tight rear seat room, a quick refresh for 2014 addressed this issue with revised rear seat packaging. Powertrain options included a 2.5L four-cylinder, 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder, and a mild hybrid eAssist system. Despite technical improvements, this generation faced strong competition and was replaced after just three model years.
Chevrolet-Malibu.name: Eighth Generation

Chevrolet-Malibu.description: The ninth-generation Malibu features sleek, coupe-like styling with significantly increased interior space compared to its predecessor. Built on GM's E2XX platform, it's notably lighter than the previous generation. Engine options have included a 1.5L turbocharged four-cylinder, 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder, and for a time, a 1.8L hybrid system delivering impressive fuel economy. The interior offers modern technology including an available 8-inch touchscreen with smartphone integration. A refresh in 2019 updated the styling and technology offerings, while also introducing the sporty RS appearance package. Production ended in North America in November 2024 as the Fairfax Assembly plant was being retooled for the second-generation Chevrolet Bolt. The Malibu XL continues production in China.
Chevrolet-Malibu.name: Ninth Generation

Chevrolet-Montana.description: The original Chevrolet Montana (sold as the Tornado in some markets like Mexico) was a small unibody pickup truck developed primarily for Latin American markets. Based on the Opel Corsa/Chevrolet Corsa platform, it featured a front-wheel drive layout with a transverse engine, unusual for a pickup truck. Available only in a single cab configuration with a short bed, it was powered by small displacement engines typically ranging from 1.4L to 1.8L depending on the market. The interior was basic and car-like, sharing many components with the Corsa. This generation established the Montana as an economical, light-duty urban pickup for markets where small, affordable commercial vehicles were in demand, particularly Brazil and other South American countries.
Chevrolet-Montana.name: First Generation

Chevrolet-Montana.description: The second-generation Montana was based on the Chevrolet Agile platform, an evolution of the previous generation's architecture. It maintained the front-wheel drive, unibody construction but featured more modern styling with a more prominent grille and sculptured body lines. Still available only as a single cab, it offered improved cargo capacity and slightly more interior space. Powertrain options remained focused on economy with engines ranging from 1.4L to 1.8L depending on the market. The interior saw upgrades in design and technology, though it remained relatively basic compared to passenger cars of the same era. This generation continued to serve primarily as an affordable, efficient utility vehicle for small businesses and as a lifestyle vehicle for buyers who occasionally needed cargo-carrying capability without the size and cost of a traditional pickup.
Chevrolet-Montana.name: Second Generation

Chevrolet-Montana.description: The current Montana represents a significant departure from its predecessors, evolving from a small car-based pickup to a more substantial compact unibody truck similar in concept to the Ford Maverick and Hyundai Santa Cruz. Built on GM's GEM (Global Emerging Markets) platform shared with the Chevrolet Tracker SUV, it features a four-door crew cab design—a first for the Montana nameplate. The exterior design incorporates modern Chevrolet styling elements with a more rugged appearance suitable for its pickup classification. Power comes from a 1.2L turbocharged three-cylinder engine producing approximately 133 HP, paired with either a six-speed manual or automatic transmission, maintaining a front-wheel drive layout. The interior is significantly more advanced than previous generations, featuring a standard 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system, digital instrument display options, and contemporary safety technology. The cargo bed, while compact, offers innovative storage solutions and a multi-position tailgate. This generation transforms the Montana from a basic utility vehicle to a more versatile lifestyle pickup that balances passenger comfort with practical cargo capabilities, primarily targeting Latin American markets but with potential for wider global distribution.
Chevrolet-Montana.name: Third Generation

Chevrolet-Prizm.description: The Geo Prizm (initially sold under GM's Geo brand before being rebadged as a Chevrolet) was a compact sedan derived from the Toyota Sprinter, itself a variant of the Corolla. Built at the NUMMI joint-venture plant between GM and Toyota in California, it was essentially a rebadged Toyota with minimal styling differences. Available as a four-door sedan or five-door hatchback, it was powered by Toyota-designed 1.6L four-cylinder engines, with a more powerful 130 HP GSi performance model available. The interior was practical and durable, reflecting Toyota's influence. This generation represented GM's strategy to offer Japanese-engineered vehicles under its domestic brands to compete with rising Japanese imports, providing American buyers with Toyota reliability under a GM brand name.
Chevrolet-Prizm.name: First Generation (Geo Prizm)

Chevrolet-Prizm.description: The second-generation Prizm continued to be a rebadged Toyota Corolla/Sprinter, with the hatchback variant discontinued in favor of sedan-only configuration. Styling became more rounded and aerodynamic in line with 1990s design trends. Engine options included 1.6L and 1.8L four-cylinders from Toyota, with the larger engine producing up to 115 HP. Transmission choices included a five-speed manual or three/four-speed automatic depending on the model year. The interior maintained Toyota's quality and ergonomics with subtle changes to badging. The Geo brand was phased out during this generation, and from 1997 the model was sold as the Chevrolet Prizm. This generation continued to benefit from Toyota's engineering while wearing GM badges.
Chevrolet-Prizm.name: Second Generation (Geo/Chevrolet Prizm)

Chevrolet-Prizm.description: The final generation Prizm, now sold exclusively as a Chevrolet, continued to be mechanically identical to the Toyota Corolla. The design featured more distinct styling from its predecessor with a more conservative appearance. Powered by Toyota's 1.8L four-cylinder engine producing 120 HP, it offered impressive reliability and fuel efficiency. Available in base and LSi trim levels, the LSi added features such as power windows, locks, and optional side airbags in later models. The interior maintained Toyota's quality with improved materials and design. With the discontinuation after the 2002 model year, the Prizm represented the end of the NUMMI-produced Toyota-based compact in Chevrolet's lineup, to be replaced by the Daewoo-derived Chevrolet Cobalt. Throughout its production, the Prizm developed a reputation for reliability that was uncommon for American compact cars of the era, thanks to its Toyota engineering.
Chevrolet-Prizm.name: Third Generation (Chevrolet Prizm)

Chevrolet-S-10.description: The original Chevrolet S-10 was GM's first domestically produced compact pickup truck, developed to compete with the increasingly popular Japanese compact trucks. Available in regular and extended cab configurations with various bed lengths, it offered a range of four-cylinder and V6 engines, including a 2.8L V6 and later a 4.3L V6. Four-wheel drive was optional, making it capable in off-road conditions. Special editions included the sport-oriented Tahoe package (before Tahoe became a separate SUV model) and the high-performance S-10 Blazer. A significant refresh in 1989 updated the styling and interior. This generation established the S-10 as a major player in the compact truck market and provided the foundation for the S-10 Blazer SUV derivative.
Chevrolet-S-10.name: First Generation

Chevrolet-S-10.description: The redesigned S-10 featured more modern styling and improved engineering. Available in regular cab, extended cab, and for the first time, crew cab configurations (the latter primarily in international markets), it offered more interior space and comfort features. Engine options continued with four-cylinder and V6 choices, with the 4.3L V6 as the primary powerplant for most of its production. Special models included the sport-oriented SS variant and the off-road-focused ZR2 with increased ground clearance, wider track, and enhanced suspension. Safety features improved with the addition of driver and later passenger airbags. The second-generation S-10 continued as a popular choice in the compact truck segment until it was replaced by the larger Colorado for the 2004 model year in North America. In international markets, particularly Brazil and other South American countries, the S-10 name continued on subsequent generations developed specifically for those regions.
Chevrolet-S-10.name: Second Generation

Chevrolet-S-10.description: In many international markets, particularly South America, the S-10 nameplate continued on an entirely different vehicle than the North American Colorado. This generation was based on the Isuzu D-Max/Chevrolet Colorado developed for global markets, featuring more rugged styling and capability focused on developing markets. Available primarily in extended and crew cab configurations, it was powered by gasoline and diesel engines depending on the market, with the 2.8L Duramax diesel being popular for its torque and efficiency. Four-wheel drive variants offered significant off-road capability, important for the rural and undeveloped areas where these trucks often operated. The interior combined durability with increasingly modern technology as the generation progressed through updates. This generation maintained the S-10's position as a core model in Chevrolet's truck lineup in South America while North America used the Colorado name for its mid-size pickup offerings.
Chevrolet-S-10.name: Third Generation (International Markets)

Chevrolet-Silverado.description: The original Silverado replaced the long-running C/K pickup trucks as Chevrolet's full-size truck offering. Available in light-duty 1500, medium-duty 2500, and heavy-duty 3500 variants with various cab and bed configurations, it featured more modern styling and improved refinement compared to its predecessor. Engine options included V6 and several V8 choices, with the 5.3L V8 being particularly popular. The interior was more car-like than previous Chevrolet trucks, with improved ergonomics and comfort. This generation established the Silverado nameplate and set the foundation for it to become one of GM's most profitable and important model lines.
Chevrolet-Silverado.name: First Generation (GMT800)

Chevrolet-Silverado.description: The redesigned Silverado featured more aerodynamic styling, improved structural rigidity, and enhanced powertrains for better efficiency and capability. Engine options were updated with technologies like Active Fuel Management cylinder deactivation, while maintaining the range of V6 and V8 options. The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and technology features. New variants included luxury-oriented High Country models and off-road-focused Z71 packages. This generation continued to solidify the Silverado's position as one of the top-selling vehicles in North America, with commercial and personal-use buyers equally important to its success.
Chevrolet-Silverado.name: Second Generation (GMT900)

Chevrolet-Silverado.description: The third-generation Silverado featured more distinctive styling with squared-off fenders and a bold front fascia. Extensive use of high-strength steel and aluminum components reduced weight while increasing capability. Engine options expanded to include more efficient small-block V8s and a 4.3L V6 sharing architecture with the V8 engines. The interior offered improved technology with the introduction of the MyLink infotainment system and enhanced connectivity features. Special editions proliferated, offering various appearance and functional packages to appeal to different segments of the truck market. This generation faced increased competition from redesigned Ford and Ram trucks but maintained strong sales and brand loyalty.
Chevrolet-Silverado.name: Third Generation (K2XX)

Chevrolet-Silverado.description: The current Silverado features a complete redesign with controversial styling that maximizes size and presence. Despite being larger, it's lighter than its predecessor thanks to mixed-material construction. Engine options expanded significantly to include a 2.7L turbocharged four-cylinder, 3.0L Duramax diesel inline-six, and updated V6 and V8 options. The interior initially received criticism for not advancing as much as the competition, but a substantial update in 2022 addressed this with a completely redesigned dashboard featuring larger displays and improved materials in higher trims. Capability increased with improved towing and payload capacities, while technology advanced with features like Super Cruise hands-free driving on certain models. The fourth-generation Silverado continues Chevrolet's focus on providing a wide range of configurations and capabilities to serve diverse truck buyers, from work-focused base models to near-luxury High Country variants.
Chevrolet-Silverado.name: Fourth Generation (T1XX)

Chevrolet-Silverado-1500.description: The first-generation Silverado 1500 established the nameplate as Chevrolet's light-duty full-size pickup, replacing the C/K 1500 series. Available in regular cab, extended cab, and crew cab configurations with various bed lengths, it offered versatility for different uses. Powertrain options included a base 4.3L V6 and several V8 engines (4.8L, 5.3L, and in some cases, a 6.0L), paired with manual or automatic transmissions. The 5.3L V8 was the most popular, balancing power and efficiency. Trim levels ranged from basic Work Truck to luxurious LTZ models, with the Z71 package offering enhanced off-road capability. A significant refresh in 2003 updated the styling and interior features. This generation set the template for modern full-size trucks with improved refinement and capability compared to previous generations while maintaining the ruggedness expected of a work vehicle.
Chevrolet-Silverado-1500.name: First Generation (GMT800)

Chevrolet-Silverado-1500.description: The redesigned Silverado 1500 featured a more aerodynamic exterior, improved structural rigidity, and significantly updated interiors with better ergonomics and material quality. Engine options continued with a 4.3L V6 base model and 4.8L, 5.3L, and 6.2L V8s, all with improvements for power and efficiency including Active Fuel Management cylinder deactivation on some engines. New features included stability control, side curtain airbags, and available luxury amenities uncommon in trucks of previous eras. Special models included the economical XFE, off-road Z71, and luxury-oriented LTZ. This generation faced challenges including GM's bankruptcy and restructuring, but remained competitive through updates including a 2010 refresh that added features like USB connectivity and enhanced safety equipment.
Chevrolet-Silverado-1500.name: Second Generation (GMT900)

Chevrolet-Silverado-1500.description: The third-generation Silverado 1500 featured distinctive squared-off styling and significant weight reduction through the use of high-strength steel. Powertrain options were thoroughly updated with a new family of EcoTec3 engines, including a 4.3L V6, 5.3L V8, and 6.2L V8, all featuring direct injection, variable valve timing, and cylinder deactivation. The interior offered improved infotainment with the Chevrolet MyLink system and enhanced connectivity options. Capability increased with higher towing and payload ratings, while features like LED lighting, enhanced trailering packages, and advanced safety technology became available. High-end models like the High Country were introduced to compete with luxury trucks from competitors, featuring premium leather, advanced technology, and unique styling elements.
Chevrolet-Silverado-1500.name: Third Generation (K2XX)

Chevrolet-Silverado-1500.description: The current Silverado 1500 features bold, controversial styling with a massive grille and complex body sculpting. Built on the T1XX platform, it's larger yet lighter than its predecessor. Engine options expanded dramatically to include a 2.7L turbocharged four-cylinder, 3.0L Duramax diesel inline-six, and updated 4.3L V6, 5.3L V8, and 6.2L V8 options. Transmission choices evolved to include 8-speed and 10-speed automatics. The cargo bed, dubbed 'Durabed,' offers increased volume and innovative features like the Multi-Flex tailgate. Initial interiors received criticism, but a substantial update for 2022 brought a completely redesigned dashboard with a 13.4-inch touchscreen and 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster on higher trims. Technology advanced significantly with features like Super Cruise hands-free driving capability, Google Built-in infotainment, and enhanced trailering technologies. Special variants include the off-road-focused Trail Boss and ZR2 models, which offer factory lift kits, skid plates, and other terrain-tackling equipment. The fourth-generation Silverado 1500 continues to evolve with enhanced technology and capability while maintaining its position as one of America's best-selling vehicles.
Chevrolet-Silverado-1500.name: Fourth Generation (T1XX)

Chevrolet-Silverado-2500.description: The original Silverado 2500 (HD from 2001) replaced the C/K 2500 as Chevrolet's heavy-duty pickup truck. Available in various cab and bed configurations, it featured heavier-duty components than the 1500 series, including stronger frames, suspension, and drivetrain parts. Powertrain options included a standard 6.0L Vortec V8 gasoline engine and the optional 6.6L Duramax diesel V8 paired with an Allison transmission, the latter becoming a highly regarded combination for its power and durability. Carrying capacities significantly exceeded the light-duty 1500 series, with enhanced cooling, braking, and structural reinforcements to handle heavier loads. This generation established the Silverado HD's reputation for capability in towing and hauling while offering reasonable comfort for a heavy-duty truck.
Chevrolet-Silverado-2500.name: First Generation (GMT800)

Chevrolet-Silverado-2500.description: The redesigned Silverado 2500HD featured more aerodynamic styling, an improved structure with higher torsional rigidity, and updated powertrains. The 6.0L gasoline V8 continued as the standard engine, while the 6.6L Duramax diesel received significant updates throughout this generation, eventually reaching 397 HP and 765 lb-ft of torque. Interior comfort and features improved substantially, with better materials and design plus available luxury features uncommon in previous heavy-duty trucks. Capability increased with higher towing and payload ratings, while features like an integrated trailer brake controller and exhaust brake improved towing safety. This generation maintained clear differentiation from the light-duty models with unique styling cues indicating its heavy-duty status.
Chevrolet-Silverado-2500.name: Second Generation (GMT900)

Chevrolet-Silverado-2500.description: The third-generation Silverado 2500HD featured distinctive styling with a taller hood line and more aggressive appearance than the 1500 series. The 6.0L gasoline V8 (later updated to a 6.6L) and 6.6L Duramax diesel continued as powertrain options, with the diesel receiving updates to reach 445 HP and 910 lb-ft of torque. The interior offered similar improvements to the 1500 series with better technology including the Chevrolet MyLink infotainment system. Heavy-duty-specific features expanded to include Digital Steering Assist, enhanced cooling packages, and integrated bumper steps for easier bed access. Capability continued to increase with class-competitive towing and payload ratings, while refinement improved to make these work-focused trucks more suitable for daily driving.
Chevrolet-Silverado-2500.name: Third Generation (K2XX)

Chevrolet-Silverado-2500.description: The current Silverado 2500HD features the most differentiation from the light-duty models in the nameplate's history, with unique sheet metal and a massive grille designed to maximize cooling capacity. Powertrain options include a new 6.6L gasoline V8 producing 401 HP and 464 lb-ft of torque and an updated 6.6L Duramax diesel V8 generating 470 HP and 975 lb-ft of torque, the latter paired with a 10-speed Allison transmission. Capability increased significantly with maximum towing capacity exceeding 18,000 pounds when properly equipped. Technology advancements include an available 15-camera system with transparent trailer view, head-up display, and advanced trailering features. The interior initially shared the somewhat conservative design of the light-duty models, but a 2024 update brought a substantially improved interior with larger displays and better materials. The fourth-generation Silverado 2500HD balances increased capability and technology with improved comfort and usability, meeting the needs of customers who use their trucks for both work and personal transportation.
Chevrolet-Silverado-2500.name: Fourth Generation (T2XX)

Chevrolet-Silverado-3500.description: The original Silverado 3500 (HD from 2001) represented Chevrolet's one-ton pickup truck, replacing the C/K 3500 series. Available in single rear wheel (SRW) or dual rear wheel (DRW) configurations, it offered maximum capability in the Silverado lineup. Powertrain options mirrored the 2500 with a standard 6.0L Vortec V8 gasoline engine and the optional 6.6L Duramax diesel V8 paired with an Allison transmission. The 3500 featured the heaviest-duty components, including a strengthened frame, commercial-grade suspension, and enhanced cooling systems. Available in regular cab, extended cab, and crew cab configurations with various bed options including a chassis cab for aftermarket upfitting, it served both commercial and personal customers needing maximum hauling and towing capability. This generation established the Silverado 3500HD as a capable work truck that could also serve as personal transportation.
Chevrolet-Silverado-3500.name: First Generation (GMT800)

Chevrolet-Silverado-3500.description: The redesigned Silverado 3500HD shared its major architectural elements with the 2500HD but included upgraded components to achieve higher payload and towing ratings. The 6.0L gasoline V8 continued as the standard engine, while the 6.6L Duramax diesel received significant updates throughout this generation, eventually reaching 397 HP and 765 lb-ft of torque. Interior comfort and features improved substantially over the previous generation, making these heavy-duty trucks more suitable for dual-purpose use. Capability increased with class-competitive towing and payload ratings, while features like an integrated trailer brake controller and exhaust brake improved towing safety. The DRW models offered maximum capability for fifth-wheel and gooseneck towing applications, while SRW variants balanced capability with everyday usability.
Chevrolet-Silverado-3500.name: Second Generation (GMT900)

Chevrolet-Silverado-3500.description: The third-generation Silverado 3500HD featured distinctive styling with a taller hood line and more aggressive appearance than lighter-duty models. The 6.0L gasoline V8 (later updated to a 6.6L) and 6.6L Duramax diesel continued as powertrain options, with the diesel receiving updates to reach 445 HP and 910 lb-ft of torque. The interior offered improved technology including the Chevrolet MyLink infotainment system. Heavy-duty-specific features expanded to include Digital Steering Assist, enhanced cooling packages, and integrated bumper steps for easier bed access. Maximum towing capacity exceeded 23,000 pounds for properly equipped models, maintaining competitiveness in the one-ton segment. High-end trim levels like the High Country brought near-luxury appointments to these work-capable trucks, reflecting their increasing use as both work and personal vehicles.
Chevrolet-Silverado-3500.name: Third Generation (K2XX)

Chevrolet-Silverado-3500.description: The current Silverado 3500HD shares its design and technology with the 2500HD but with enhanced capability for the most demanding towing and hauling tasks. Powertrain options include a new 6.6L gasoline V8 producing 401 HP and 464 lb-ft of torque and an updated 6.6L Duramax diesel V8 generating 470 HP and 975 lb-ft of torque, the latter paired with a 10-speed Allison transmission. Capability increased significantly with maximum towing capacity exceeding 36,000 pounds for properly equipped dually models. Technology advancements include an available 15-camera system with transparent trailer view, head-up display, and advanced trailering features. The interior initially shared the somewhat conservative design of the light-duty models, but a 2024 update brought a substantially improved interior with larger displays and better materials. Available in single or dual rear wheel configurations with various cab and bed options including chassis cabs, the fourth-generation Silverado 3500HD represents the pinnacle of Chevrolet's truck capability while offering comfort and technology features previously reserved for luxury vehicles.
Chevrolet-Silverado-3500.name: Fourth Generation (T2XX)

Chevrolet-Silverado-EV.description: The Chevrolet Silverado EV is the brand's first purpose-built electric full-size pickup truck, utilizing GM's Ultium platform and battery technology. Unlike some competitors that offer electric versions of existing combustion engine trucks, the Silverado EV features a unique design with no shared body panels with its conventional counterpart. The exterior showcases a blend of truck functionality with aerodynamic efficiency, featuring a fixed front trunk (frunk) where a traditional engine would be, a sail pillar design connecting the cab to the bed, and available four-wheel steering for enhanced maneuverability. Power comes from a dual-motor setup producing up to 754 HP and 785 lb-ft of torque in the RST First Edition model, enabling 0-60 mph acceleration in less than 4.5 seconds. The estimated range reaches up to 450 miles on a full charge with the largest battery configuration. The truck offers up to 10.2kW of exportable power with PowerBase, allowing it to power tools, appliances, or even another EV. Innovative features include the Multi-Flex Midgate, which allows the wall between the cab and bed to fold down, extending cargo capacity to accommodate items up to 10 feet long while still seating passengers. The interior features a 17-inch diagonal infotainment screen, 11-inch driver information display, and available features like a fixed-glass roof and Super Cruise hands-free driving technology. Various versions target different markets, from the work-oriented WT (Work Truck) to the premium RST, with payload capacity up to 1,300 pounds and towing capacity up to 10,000 pounds (planned to reach 20,000 pounds in future variants). The Silverado EV represents Chevrolet's vision for the electrified future of trucks, combining traditional capability with new advantages unique to the electric powertrain architecture.
Chevrolet-Silverado-EV.name: First Generation

Chevrolet-Sonic.description: The Chevrolet Sonic (sold as the Aveo in some international markets) was a subcompact car that replaced the previous generation Aveo in North America. Available as both a four-door sedan and five-door hatchback, it featured significantly improved design, engineering, and quality compared to its predecessor. The exterior design was distinctively sporty with motorcycle-inspired headlights, hidden rear door handles on the hatchback, and an overall more aggressive stance than most subcompacts of its era. Powertrain options included a naturally aspirated 1.8L four-cylinder or a more modern 1.4L turbocharged four-cylinder, the latter offering a good balance of performance and efficiency with 138 HP. Both five-speed manual and six-speed automatic transmissions were available. The interior featured a unique instrument cluster with a combination of digital and analog displays inspired by motorcycle gauges, and materials quality was improved over the previous Aveo. A significant refresh for the 2017 model year updated the exterior styling and added technology features including standard 7-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility.
