The facelift represented the final evolution of the second-generation platform before the transition to the all-new third generation.
Dacia-Sandero.name: Second Generation (2019 Facelift)

Dacia-Sandero.description: The third generation of Dacia Sandero was launched on 29 September 2020, representing a major step forward with the switch to the Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi Alliance's CMF-B LS platform. This change brings significant improvements in refinement, safety, and technology while maintaining competitive pricing. The exterior design is more modern and sophisticated, with LED lighting and improved proportions. Engine options include a 1.0L naturally aspirated SCe, a 1.0L turbocharged TCe, and a factory-fitted LPG bi-fuel system on some models. The interior features a completely redesigned dashboard with improved ergonomics, materials, and technology, including an available 8-inch touchscreen with wireless smartphone integration. Safety features have been dramatically enhanced with standard automated emergency braking and other advanced driver assistance systems. The popular Stepway variant continues with crossover-inspired styling elements and increased ground clearance. Despite these improvements, the third-generation Sandero remains one of the most affordable new cars in Europe.
Dacia-Sandero.name: Third Generation

Dacia-Sandero.description: In June 2022, the Sandero received a slight restyling incorporating Dacia's new logo alongside other models in the brand's lineup. To accommodate the new logo, the grille was redesigned and the steering wheel was slightly modified. This refresh maintained the same CMF-B LS platform and powertrain options while updating the visual identity to align with Dacia's contemporary design language.
Dacia-Sandero.name: Third Generation (2022 Refresh)

Dacia-Sandero.description: In October 2025, the Sandero received a heavy facelift featuring a redesigned front fascia, new headlights, new fog lights, and new alloy wheel designs. The rear design remained similar to the previous refresh. This update represents the latest visual evolution of the third-generation platform, continuing Dacia's commitment to providing affordable, practical transportation with contemporary styling.
Dacia-Sandero.name: Third Generation (2025 Refresh)

Dacia-Spring.description: The Dacia Spring is a groundbreaking model that holds the distinction of being Europe's most affordable all-electric car. Based on the Renault Kwid/City K-ZE platform developed for emerging markets, it features a compact crossover-inspired design with a length of just 3.73 meters. The exterior styling incorporates SUV-like elements including increased ground clearance (151mm), roof rails, and protective body cladding, giving it a robust appearance despite its small dimensions. Powered by a modest 44 HP (33 kW) electric motor driving the front wheels, it prioritizes efficiency over performance, with 0-100 km/h acceleration taking around 19 seconds. The 27.4 kWh lithium-ion battery provides a WLTP range of approximately 230 km (143 miles) in the mixed cycle and up to 305 km (189 miles) in city driving. Charging options include standard household outlets (taking about 14 hours for a full charge), 7.4 kW wallboxes (5 hours), and DC fast charging up to 30 kW (80% in about 50 minutes). The interior is basic but functional, offering a 7-inch touchscreen infotainment system with smartphone connectivity in higher trims. Despite its compact exterior, it provides reasonable space for four adults and a 290-liter boot. Sales began in March 2021.
Dacia-Spring.name: First Generation (2021-2022)

Dacia-Spring.description: The 2023 Spring Electric, launched in June 2022, received a slight facelift on the front grille and a new badge on the rear, featuring the new Dacia logo and branding. The facelift included a redesigned front grille and updated styling cues. The vehicle retained the same 33 kW motor and 27.4 kWh battery, maintaining the 230 km WLTP range. In January 2023, Dacia launched the Spring Extreme version equipped with a 48 kW motor and a range of 220 km.
Dacia-Spring.name: First Generation (2022 Facelift)

Dacia-Spring.description: The refreshed Spring was unveiled on February 21, 2024, showcasing a revamped front and rear fascia designs, along with newly styled headlights and taillights. This generation update represents the most significant styling refresh since the model's introduction. The 2024 version was now produced in a right-hand drive format for UK and Irish markets, expanding the model's availability to left-side traffic regions. The vehicle continued to offer both the standard 33 kW motor and the Extreme variant with the 48 kW motor.
Dacia-Spring.name: First Generation (2024 Facelift)

Dodge-Challenger.description: The original Dodge Challenger was introduced as a late entrant to the pony car wars, competing with the Ford Mustang, Chevrolet Camaro, and its corporate cousin, the Plymouth Barracuda. Available as a hardtop coupe or convertible, it featured distinctive styling with a long hood, short deck, and wide stance. Engine options ranged from the base 225 cubic-inch slant-six to the legendary 426 Hemi V8 in performance-oriented models like the R/T and T/A. The first-generation Challenger gained cultural significance through its appearance in films and its competitive history in Trans Am racing, despite its relatively short production run during a period when muscle car popularity was declining due to rising insurance costs and emissions regulations.
Dodge-Challenger.name: First Generation

Dodge-Challenger.description: The second-generation Challenger was a rebadged Mitsubishi Galant Lambda coupe, bearing little resemblance to the original muscle car. This compact, four-cylinder coupe reflected the industry's shift toward fuel efficiency following the 1970s oil crises. Available with a 1.6L, 2.0L, or 2.6L engine, it prioritized economy over performance, though a modest 105 HP was available in the highest output version. This generation is generally considered a footnote in Challenger history, representing Dodge's temporary abandonment of the performance market in favor of practical, efficient transportation during a challenging period for American automakers.
Dodge-Challenger.name: Second Generation

Dodge-Challenger.description: The modern Challenger revived the nameplate after a 25-year hiatus, drawing heavy styling inspiration from the 1970 model while incorporating contemporary engineering. Built on a shortened version of the LX platform shared with the Charger sedan, it featured retro-inspired design with modern touches. Initially offered with a 3.5L V6 or 5.7L and 6.1L HEMI V8 engines, the lineup expanded over the years to include the 392 HEMI (6.4L) and the supercharged 6.2L Hellcat variants producing up to 807 HP in the Super Stock model. Unlike its competitors that evolved toward sports car handling, the Challenger maintained a focus on straight-line performance and muscle car character. A significant refresh in 2015 updated the exterior styling and interior technology while introducing more powerful engine options. Throughout its extended production run, Dodge consistently introduced special editions and performance packages that kept the aging platform relevant. The third-generation Challenger concluded production in 2023 with various commemorative Last Call editions, marking the end of the traditional HEMI-powered muscle car era as Dodge transitions toward electrification.
Dodge-Challenger.name: Third Generation (LC/LA)

Dodge-Charger.description: The original Dodge Charger was introduced mid-1966 as a fastback variant of the Chrysler B-body platform, featuring distinctive styling with hidden headlights and a full-width grille with a 'wall-to-wall' taillamp design. The interior offered four bucket seats with a center console and race-inspired instrument gauges. Engine options ranged from the 318 cubic-inch V8 to the powerful 426 Hemi. Positioned as an upscale sports-type luxury model, sales of the 1966 and 1967 Chargers were modest due to the fastback design's proportions looking tall relative to its narrow track width.
Dodge-Charger.name: First Generation

Dodge-Charger.description: The second-generation Charger was completely redesigned for 1968 with iconic curved 'Coke bottle' body lines that became widely considered one of the most beautiful American cars of its era. Production demand exceeded expectations, with 96,100 units produced in 1968 alone. Engine options continued from small-block V8s to the legendary 426 Hemi and 440 Six Pack. The Charger gained significant cultural impact through television and film appearances, most notably as the 'General Lee' in 'The Dukes of Hazzard.' Special performance variants included the more aerodynamic Charger 500 and 1970 Charger Daytona designed for NASCAR racing. The 1970 Charger won the most NASCAR races that year, helping Bobby Isaac win the championship.
Dodge-Charger.name: Second Generation

Dodge-Charger.description: The third-generation Charger was introduced for the 1971 model year based on Chrysler's modified B-platform to meet new emissions and safety regulations. Available in six different packages with cosmetic changes including a split grille, semi-fastback rear window, and ducktail spoiler. The 1973 and 1974 models featured minor differences in grille and headlamps, plus new quarter windows that were larger and shaped differently than the 1971-1972 models. Sales increased during this period primarily due to the elimination of the Dodge Coronet two-door, making the Charger Dodge's only two-door intermediate-size offering.
Dodge-Charger.name: Third Generation

Dodge-Charger.description: The 1975 Charger was restyled to move the model into the growing personal luxury car market segment, sharing its body with the new Chrysler Cordoba. For 1976, former Coronet coupes were rebranded as Charger and Charger Sport variants. A Daytona model was added featuring distinctive stripes running along the length of the car. In 1978, Dodge added the Magnum to the personal luxury segment, completing the range.
Dodge-Charger.name: Fourth Generation

Dodge-Charger.description: After a three-year absence, the Charger returned in 1981 as a front-wheel-drive subcompact hatchback coupe with five-speed manual or three-speed automatic transmission. Similar to the Dodge Omni 024 but slightly larger, it featured a 2.2L SOHC engine with optional turbocharged variant. A Shelby Charger variant was introduced starting in 1983, with the turbocharged version producing 142 hp in 1984, increased to 146 hp in 1985, and reaching 175 hp in 1987 with the Shelby-tuned GLHS model featuring an intercooler and upgraded fuel injection system. The final 1000 L-body Chargers built in 1987 were Shelby editions.
Dodge-Charger.name: Fifth Generation

Dodge-Charger.description: After a twenty-year absence, the Charger nameplate returned for the 2006 model year (introduced in 2005) as a full-size four-door sedan built on the Chrysler LX platform, incorporating some Mercedes-Benz E-Class components from the DaimlerChrysler era. The controversial four-door configuration was a significant departure from the classic coupe tradition but allowed the model to serve as both a performance vehicle and practical family car. Available in SE, SXT, R/T, and SRT8 versions with engine options from 2.7L V6 to 6.1L Hemi V8. All-wheel drive was first available only on the R/T package but expanded to SE and SXT versions from 2009 onward. The sixth generation reestablished the Charger as a modern American muscle car.
Dodge-Charger.name: Sixth Generation (LX)

Dodge-Charger.description: The seventh-generation Charger received comprehensive updates for 2011 with new exterior styling and interior quality while maintaining LX platform architecture. Updated side scoops, angular headlights, aggressive grille styling, and modern wrap-around LED tail lights improved driver visibility by over 15%. Base performance increased with a 3.6L Pentastar V6 replacing the previous 3.5L unit. The 2012 year featured a new eight-speed automatic transmission for the V6 model and the SRT-8 returned to the lineup. The Super Bee platform (later called Scat Pack 15+) was available starting in 2012, featuring a 6.4L engine rated at 470 hp.
Dodge-Charger.name: Seventh Generation (LD)

Dodge-Charger.description: The 2015 Charger received significant exterior styling updates with a new front end featuring new LED headlights, more aerodynamic nose design, and a noticeable curve around the headlight housing. Suspensions, interiors, and brakes were also redesigned. The 2017 model had an upgrade to the 8.4-inch navigation/display system. The lineup continued to include the SRT 392 and supercharged Hellcat variants. In 2020, the Charger Hellcat comes standard with the widebody package. For 2020, a new trim called the SRT Hellcat Redeye was added, producing 797 hp. In January 2022, Dodge announced that the Hemi V8 Charger would be retired at the end of the 2023 model year. Production concluded in December 2023 with Last Call special editions, marking the end of traditional HEMI-powered Chargers before the model's transition to electric power.
Dodge-Charger.name: Seventh Generation (LD, 2015 Facelift)

Dodge-Charger.description: The eighth-generation Charger was introduced in March 2024 as part of Dodge's electrification strategy for its muscle car lineup. Available as the Charger Daytona, the generation features electric vehicle variants alongside internal combustion engine models, including a version with the Stellantis Hurricane twin-turbo inline-six engine. Offered in two- and four-door hatchback body styles with R/T and Scat Pack trim levels, combining electric performance with traditional muscle car heritage.
Dodge-Charger.name: Eighth Generation (LB)

Dodge-Dakota.description: The original Dodge Dakota pioneered the mid-size pickup truck segment, positioned between compact trucks like the Ford Ranger and full-size models like the Ford F-150. Available in regular and extended (Club Cab) configurations, it featured distinctive styling with a conventional body-on-frame design. Engine options ranged from a 2.2L four-cylinder to a 5.2L V8 (added in 1991), making it the first modern mid-size truck with an optional V8. Four-wheel drive was available across most of the range. A convertible model was briefly offered from 1989-1991, representing one of the few convertible trucks in modern automotive history. The first-generation Dakota established the model's identity as a versatile, capable truck that could handle serious work while being more manageable than full-size alternatives.
Dodge-Dakota.name: First Generation

Dodge-Dakota.description: The redesigned Dakota featured more rounded styling in line with the contemporary Dodge Ram. The extended Club Cab continued, and a four-door Quad Cab model was added in 2000, offering true sedan-like rear doors. Engine options evolved to include a 2.5L four-cylinder, 3.9L V6, 4.7L V8, and 5.9L V8 in the high-performance R/T model, which could accelerate from 0-60 mph in under 7 seconds. The interior was significantly improved with better materials and ergonomics. This generation enhanced the Dakota's position as a versatile alternative to full-size trucks, offering nearly comparable capability in a more manageable package. Special models included the off-road-oriented Dakota 4×4 Sport and the performance-focused R/T.
Dodge-Dakota.name: Second Generation

Dodge-Dakota.description: The final Dakota generation featured more angular styling and shared some components with the Dodge Durango SUV. Available only in extended (Club Cab) and crew cab (Quad Cab) configurations, it grew in size to further differentiate from compact trucks. Engine options were reduced to a 3.7L V6 and 4.7L V8, both offering improved power and efficiency compared to their predecessors. The interior was substantially upgraded with better materials and available features including navigation, premium audio, and enhanced safety systems. Despite these improvements, the Dakota faced increasing competition from both improved compact trucks and more efficient full-size models. Declining sales and changing corporate priorities following Chrysler's bankruptcy and acquisition by Fiat led to the Dakota's discontinuation in 2011 without a direct replacement. The third-generation Dakota represented the culmination of the mid-size truck concept that the original model had pioneered, offering substantial capability in a package that balanced utility with daily usability.
Dodge-Dakota.name: Third Generation

Dodge-Durango.description: Introduced for the 1998 model year and produced through 2003. Based on the Dodge Dakota platform with body-on-frame construction. Built at Newark Assembly Plant in Delaware. Featured up to 7-8 passengers with various engine options including 3.9L V6 and V8 engines (5.2L, 5.9L).
Dodge-Durango.name: First Generation (DN)

Dodge-Durango.description: Introduced for the 2004 model year with production ending in December 2008. Enlarged platform with 7 inches longer, 2 inches wider, and 3 inches taller than the first generation. Maintained body-on-frame construction with new coil-spring rear suspension. Available engines included 3.7L V6, 4.7L V8, and 5.7L Hemi V8. A hybrid variant was introduced for 2009 but discontinued shortly after. Also sold as Chrysler Aspen (2007-2009).
Dodge-Durango.name: Second Generation (HB)

Dodge-Durango.description: Revived for the 2011 model year after a two-year hiatus. Built on the Jeep Grand Cherokee platform with unibody construction instead of body-on-frame. Assembled at Jefferson North Assembly Plant in Detroit, Michigan. Features three rows of seating and optional 5.7L Hemi V8 alongside the 3.6L Pentastar V6 base engine. Production began December 14, 2010 at Jefferson North Assembly Plant.
Dodge-Durango.name: Third Generation (WD)

Dodge-Durango.description: Major redesign for 2014 with sportier-looking lines, eight-speed automatic transmission, and new design trim. Updated styling including revised grille, redesigned taillights with LED 'Racetrack' tail lamps, new steering wheel, instrument cluster, and rotary shift knob. For 2016 added Pentastar V6 upgrade with Stop/Start and variable valve lift technology. For 2018, received new Uconnect radios, second-generation ZF 8-speed automatic transmission with T-grip handle, and more sporty steering wheel.
Dodge-Durango.name: Third Generation (WD) 2014 Refresh

Dodge-Durango.description: Updated exterior styling with revised bumper and headlights, three grille textures, and six new wheel designs. New interior features including new instrument panel with Uconnect 5; 8.4-inch screen standard on SXT and GT models, 10.1-inch touchscreen on R/T and Citadel models. SRT Hellcat model with 710 hp supercharged 6.2L Hemi V8 was available for 2021 only before discontinuation due to emissions requirements; returned for 2023 model year. Following discontinuation of Dodge Journey, Durango became the only SUV in Dodge lineup as of 2021.
Dodge-Durango.name: Third Generation (WD) 2021 Refresh

Dodge-Grand-Caravan.description: The original Dodge Grand Caravan was introduced as an extended wheelbase version of the revolutionary Caravan minivan. Built on Chrysler's S platform, it offered additional cargo space behind the third row of seats compared to the standard Caravan. Powered by various four-cylinder and V6 engines, including a 2.5L inline-four and 3.0L Mitsubishi V6, it provided versatile family transportation with car-like handling. The interior featured flexible seating for seven passengers and numerous storage compartments. This generation established the Grand Caravan as the more practical choice for larger families within Chrysler's minivan lineup, which had created the modern minivan segment in 1984.
Dodge-Grand-Caravan.name: First Generation (as Grand Caravan)

Dodge-Grand-Caravan.description: The redesigned Grand Caravan featured more aerodynamic styling while maintaining the practical, boxy profile necessary for maximum interior space. Built on an updated version of the S platform, it offered improved powertrains including the new 3.3L V6 engine. Interior enhancements included available anti-lock brakes, driver's side airbag, and improved seating comfort. This generation introduced integrated child safety seats as an innovative feature for family buyers. The second-generation Grand Caravan refined the successful formula of its predecessor, maintaining Chrysler's leadership in the increasingly competitive minivan segment.
Dodge-Grand-Caravan.name: Second Generation

Dodge-Grand-Caravan.description: The third-generation Grand Caravan featured more streamlined styling and substantial mechanical improvements. Based on the new NS platform, it introduced dual sliding doors—a significant innovation that was quickly adopted by competitors. Engine options included a 3.0L V6, 3.3L V6, and the new 3.8L V6, all paired with a four-speed automatic transmission. The interior offered improved ergonomics, dual front airbags, and available features like quad seating and a removable driver-side console. This generation maintained Chrysler's innovation in the minivan segment and continued the Grand Caravan's strong sales performance.
Dodge-Grand-Caravan.name: Third Generation

Dodge-Grand-Caravan.description: The fourth-generation Grand Caravan introduced power sliding doors and the innovative Stow 'n Go seating system (from 2005), which allowed the second and third-row seats to fold flat into the floor. Built on the updated RS platform, it offered refined powertrains including a 3.3L V6 and 3.8L V6. The interior featured improved materials and available features such as a DVD entertainment system, three-zone climate control, and power windows in the sliding doors. Despite increasing competition, this generation maintained the Grand Caravan's position as a value leader in the minivan segment with class-leading versatility thanks to its unique seating system.
Dodge-Grand-Caravan.name: Fourth Generation

Dodge-Grand-Caravan.description: The final Grand Caravan generation featured more squared-off styling with a focus on interior space and flexibility. The Stow 'n Go system was enhanced with easier operation and more comfortable seats, while a new Swivel 'n Go option briefly offered second-row seats that could face the third row. Initially offered with multiple engine options, the powertrain was eventually standardized to the 3.6L Pentastar V6 producing 283 HP, paired with a six-speed automatic transmission. Despite minimal updates over its extended production run, the fifth-generation Grand Caravan remained popular due to its combination of features, space, and value pricing. After the more upscale Chrysler Town & Country was replaced by the Pacifica in 2017, the Grand Caravan continued as a budget-friendly alternative until its discontinuation in 2020, marking the end of the nameplate after more than 35 years.
Dodge-Grand-Caravan.name: Fifth Generation

Dodge-Hornet.description: The Dodge Hornet is a compact crossover SUV that represents Dodge's return to the segment after more than a decade. Based on the Alfa Romeo Tonale and built alongside it in Italy, the Hornet features distinctive Dodge styling elements including a hood with integrated heat extractors, a mail-slot grille, and Rhombi logo-inspired LED taillights. Two powertrain options are available: the GT model with a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder engine producing 268 HP, and the R/T which features a plug-in hybrid system combining a 1.3L turbocharged engine with an electric motor for a total system output of 288 HP and 383 lb-ft of torque. The R/T offers approximately 30 miles of all-electric range and features PowerShot, a performance function that provides a 25 HP boost for up to 15 seconds. The interior maintains most of the Tonale's design but with Dodge-specific elements, including a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, a 10.25-inch touchscreen infotainment system with Uconnect 5, and available performance seats. A Track Pack option adds Alcantara trim, aluminum pedals, red-painted Brembo brakes, and unique 20-inch wheels. The Hornet represents Dodge's effort to bring its performance-oriented brand identity to the popular compact SUV segment while leveraging Stellantis's global platforms and electrification strategy.
Dodge-Hornet.name: First Generation

Dodge-Journey.description: The Dodge Journey was a mid-size crossover SUV that combined elements of a minivan with SUV styling. Built on Chrysler's JC platform shared with the Avenger sedan, it featured a front-wheel drive layout with available all-wheel drive. The exterior design was relatively conservative, focusing on practicality with a tall roofline and upright stance. Initially available with a 2.4L four-cylinder or 3.5L V6 (later replaced by the Pentastar 3.6L V6), the Journey offered versatile family transportation with seating for up to seven passengers across three rows. The interior was notable for its clever storage solutions, including under-floor compartments and a front passenger seat with a hidden storage bin. A significant refresh in 2011 substantially improved the interior quality and introduced the Uconnect infotainment system. Despite receiving only minor updates for the remainder of its production run, the Journey maintained steady sales by offering substantial value with competitive pricing and practical features. Production ended in 2020 without a direct replacement, as Dodge shifted focus to performance-oriented vehicles and SUVs. In some international markets, particularly China and Latin America, a second-generation Journey (based on the GAC GS5) was introduced, but this model was unrelated to the North American version and was not sold in the United States.
Dodge-Journey.name: First Generation

DongFeng-Seres-3.description: The Seres SF5 is a compact crossover SUV available in battery-electric and range-extender powertrains produced by Seres since 2019. It was introduced at Auto Guangzhou in 2019. The vehicle was initially unveiled as a concept in 2018 alongside the SF7. The SF5 features a 17-inch center console screen and is one of the first vehicles to utilize the Ali OS 2.0 infotainment system. In battery-electric form (as the A5 global variant), it uses Huawei DriveONE motors or Seres SEP200/SEP201 asynchronous motors, with single-motor (RWD) configurations producing up to 225 kW (305 hp) and dual-motor (AWD) configurations producing up to 405 kW (548 hp). The range-extended version (EREV) uses a 1.5L turbocharged engine as a generator. Battery options include 40 kWh NMC (EREV) and 88 kWh LFP (BEV) configurations, providing electric range of 180 km (EREV) to 500 km CLTC (BEV). The vehicle is manufactured in Chongqing, China and is known under various regional names including Seres A5, Seres 5 (Europe), Evolute i-Jet (Russia), and NWTN One (UAE).
DongFeng-Seres-3.name: First Generation

FIAT-500.description: The original Fiat 500, known as the Nuova 500, was a rear-engine, four-seat city car designed by Dante Giacosa. Measuring just 2.97 meters long, it epitomized the concept of the 'city car' with its compact dimensions and fuel efficiency. Powered by a tiny 479cc two-cylinder engine producing just 13 HP, it prioritized economy over performance. The design featured a distinctive bubble-like shape with suicide doors (replaced by conventional doors in later models), a canvas sunroof, and minimal interior amenities. Despite its simplicity, the original 500 became an icon of Italian design and mobility, helping to motorize post-war Italy with over 3.6 million units produced. Various versions were developed during its production, including the more powerful 500 Sport, the station wagon 500 Giardiniera, and the 500L with luxury features.
FIAT-500.name: Original (Nuova 500)

FIAT-500.description: The modern Fiat 500 was introduced on the 50th anniversary of the original model, featuring retro-inspired styling that evoked the 1957 version but with contemporary engineering and safety features. Built on Fiat's Mini platform shared with the Panda, it maintained compact dimensions but with significantly more interior space and comfort than its predecessor. Initially powered by a range of small gasoline and diesel engines, including the 1.4L 16v with 100 HP in the Sport variant, the engine lineup evolved over time to include more efficient turbocharged options like the TwinAir and MultiAir units. The interior combined vintage-inspired design elements with modern technology, featuring a body-colored dashboard panel and circular design motifs. Special variants have included the performance-oriented Abarth models, the 500C with a retractable fabric roof, and numerous limited and special editions featuring designer collaborations.
FIAT-500.name: Modern Fiat 500 (Type 312)

FIAT-500.description: The 2016 facelift brought significant visual and technical updates while maintaining the same Type 312 platform. The facelift featured a redesigned grille, reshaped headlights with integrated daytime running lights using LED technology, revised 15 and 16-inch alloy wheels, new paint colors, a rear bumper with chrome strip and integrated fog lights, and rear taillights with integrated LEDs. The interior received revised controls and a redesigned steering wheel. Available trims included Pop, Pop Star, Lounge, and S variants. The engine lineup in Europe consisted of the 1.2 petrol, 0.9 TwinAir petrol in either 85 or 105 hp setups, all Euro 6 compliant. This facelift represented the intermediate update for the single-generation vehicle.
FIAT-500.name: Modern Fiat 500 (Type 312) - 2016 Facelift

FIAT-500.description: The 2020 update introduced a new Mild Hybrid powertrain option featuring a 1.0 three-cylinder engine with combined power of 70 hp, accompanied by enhanced infotainment with a 7-inch screen, Android Auto, and Apple CarPlay compatibility. All models now featured updated technology packages. Special limited editions including the distinctive Scorpioneoro (with gold details on paintwork and wheels and scorpion patterns on seats) and the Yamaha Monster Edition (painted black and blue with Monster energy branding) were released in 2020. Production continued until August 2024 in Poland, concluding 17 years of continuous production. Throughout its production, the modern 500 maintained its essence as a fashionable, premium small car that successfully reinterpreted a classic design for contemporary consumers.
FIAT-500.name: Modern Fiat 500 (Type 312) - 2020 Update

FIAT-500X.description: The initial Fiat 500X (Type 334) is a subcompact crossover SUV that combines 500-inspired styling cues with the practicality and higher ride height of an SUV. Built on the Small Wide 4×4 platform shared with the Jeep Renegade, it represents Fiat's entry into the rapidly growing small crossover segment. The exterior design successfully translates the retro-inspired elements of the 500 city car onto a larger vehicle, featuring rounded headlights, a curved hood, and the distinctive Fiat front grille. At launch, it offered a range of engines including 1.4L MultiAir turbocharged petrol units, 1.6L and 2.0L Multijet diesels. In North America, a 2.4L Tigershark was available. The interior features a body-colored dashboard panel reminiscent of the standard 500, with a central touchscreen infotainment system. Available in front-wheel or all-wheel drive configurations, the 500X offers more off-road capability than typical city-focused crossovers, particularly in Trekking and Cross variants.
FIAT-500X.name: First Generation

FIAT-500X.description: The 2018 facelift refreshed the exterior styling of the 500X while maintaining the same platform. The refresh included updated headlights, grille, bumpers, and interior enhancements with updated infotainment systems. The powertrain lineup continued to offer the proven engine options from the initial generation.
FIAT-500X.name: First Generation (2018 Facelift)

FIAT-500X.description: A significant 2019 redesign introduced major visual and technical updates to the 500X while maintaining the Small Wide 4×4 platform. The redesign launched new turbocharged engines including downsized 1.0L and 1.3L FireFly turbo units alongside updated diesel engines. The updated styling included refreshed exterior and interior design, with new technology features and infotainment systems. The North American market received revised engine options optimized for that region.
FIAT-500X.name: First Generation (2019 Redesign)

FIAT-500X.description: The 2022 restyling brought another round of updates including the introduction of a new 1.5L FireFly mild hybrid powertrain option with a 48V electric system. Visual updates to the exterior and interior styling continued the 500X's evolution. A soft-top variant called the 500X Dolcevita, featuring a power-retractable canvas roof, was also available during this period. This represents the final iteration of the first-generation 500X before production ended in August 2024, with the 500X eventually being succeeded by the Fiat 600.
FIAT-500X.name: First Generation (2022 Restyling)

FIAT-500e.description: The original Fiat 500e was an electric variant of the conventional 500, developed primarily as a compliance car to meet California's zero-emission vehicle mandate. Despite sharing the body and most design elements with the gasoline-powered 500, it featured significant engineering modifications to accommodate the electric powertrain. Powered by a 24 kWh lithium-ion battery and an 83 kW (111 HP) electric motor driving the front wheels, it offered an EPA-rated range of 87 miles. Performance was surprisingly spirited with 0-60 mph acceleration in about 8.4 seconds. The interior maintained the retro-inspired design of the standard 500 but with model-specific instrumentation displaying charge status and energy flow. Limited primarily to California and Oregon markets, the first-generation 500e was not a commercial focus for Fiat, with then-CEO Sergio Marchionne famously asking customers not to buy it due to the significant financial losses on each unit sold. Despite this, it received positive reviews for its driving dynamics and character, often considered one of the more enjoyable early mainstream EVs to drive.
FIAT-500e.name: First Generation (Type 312)

FIAT-500e.description: The current Fiat 500e represents a complete redesign built on a dedicated electric vehicle platform rather than being converted from a gasoline model. Though visually similar to its predecessor, it features entirely new bodywork that's slightly larger in all dimensions. The design maintains the iconic 500 styling cues but with a more modern interpretation, including flush door handles, LED lighting, and a closed-off front fascia. Powered by a 42 kWh lithium-ion battery (37.3 kWh usable) and a 87 kW (118 HP) electric motor, it offers a WLTP range of up to 199 miles (320 km) and DC fast charging capability at up to 85 kW. The interior represents a significant advancement with a more premium feel, enhanced technology including a 10.25-inch infotainment screen, and improved practicality despite the car's still-compact dimensions. Unlike its predecessor, this generation was developed as a global model central to Fiat's electrification strategy rather than a compliance car. Available in multiple body styles including a hatchback, convertible, and 3+1 variant with a small rear-hinged passenger door, the second-generation 500e combines the iconic design heritage of the 500 with modern electric technology. In some markets, it's sold simply as the Fiat 500, signifying the brand's transition toward electrification.
FIAT-500e.name: Second Generation (Type 332)

FIAT-Fastback.description: The Fiat Fastback is a subcompact coupe SUV produced by Fiat mainly for the South American market, released in August 2022. It is the coupe SUV version of the Fiat Pulse and is based on the same MLA platform. In Brazil, it is positioned as a flagship Fiat model only below the imported Fiat 500e. The vehicle is assembled in Betim, Minas Gerais, Brazil. It features distinctive coupe-like styling with a sloping roofline combined with traditional SUV elements including plastic body cladding and raised ride height. Measuring approximately 4.43 meters (4,427 mm) in length and 1.77 meters (1,774 mm) in width, with a height of 1.55 meters (1,545 mm), it combines SUV practicality with coupe aesthetics. Powertrain options include a 1.0L turbocharged three-cylinder engine producing 130 HP on ethanol (125 HP on gasoline) in base models, and a more powerful 1.3L turbocharged four-cylinder delivering 185 HP on ethanol (182 HP on gasoline) in higher-end variants. Both engines are flex-fuel capable and produce 200 Nm and 270 Nm of torque respectively. Transmission options include a 6-speed automatic or CVT. The interior features a driver-focused cockpit with a 10.1-inch touchscreen infotainment system and 7-inch digital instrument display. The vehicle also comes with safety features including LED lighting, automatic high beam, tire pressure monitoring, hill holder, traction control, ESC, lane departure warning, and collision avoidance system. The Fastback is also available as the Abarth Fastback performance variant.
FIAT-Fastback.name: First Generation

FIAT-Panda.description: The original Fiat Panda was designed by Giorgetto Giugiaro as a simple, functional, and affordable small car. Featuring a distinctive boxy design with flat glass panels, it exemplified 'form follows function' with a minimalist approach. The interior was equally basic with a hammock-style rear seat, flat surfaces, and simple instruments. Initial engines included a 652cc air-cooled two-cylinder and a 903cc water-cooled four-cylinder. The Panda 4×4, introduced in 1983, was one of the first small cars to offer four-wheel drive. This generation saw numerous updates during its 23-year production run, including the introduction of the 'FIRE' engines, improved safety features, and modernized styling in the 1986 facelift. Despite its simplicity, or perhaps because of it, the first Panda achieved iconic status, selling over 4.5 million units and becoming a symbol of practical Italian motoring.
FIAT-Panda.name: First Generation (Type 141)

FIAT-Panda.description: The second-generation Panda represented a comprehensive modernization while maintaining the practical, space-efficient philosophy of its predecessor. The exterior featured a more rounded design with distinctive 'squircle' (squared circle) motifs that would become a Panda design signature. Significantly larger and safer than the original, it offered genuine four-adult accommodation despite compact external dimensions. Engine options included 1.1L and 1.2L petrol units and a 1.3L MultiJet diesel. The Panda 4×4 continued, offering impressive off-road capability for its size class. The interior was innovative with flexible seating arrangements and numerous storage solutions. This generation was highly successful, receiving the European Car of the Year award for 2004 and establishing new standards for small car design and functionality.
FIAT-Panda.name: Second Generation (Type 169)

FIAT-Panda.description: The current Panda built upon its predecessor's strengths while offering improved quality, technology, and safety. Slightly larger with a more evolved design, it maintained the 'squircle' theme throughout the interior and exterior. Engine options have included the innovative two-cylinder TwinAir turbocharged engine, conventional 1.2L four-cylinder petrol units, and 1.3L MultiJet diesels. The Panda 4×4 continued as the world's smallest off-roader with genuine capability thanks to its lightweight, electronic differential locks, and specialized traction systems. Special variants have included the Cross with enhanced off-road styling and capability, the Hybrid with mild-hybrid technology, and the City Cross offering crossover styling with two-wheel drive. The interior focuses on practicality with flexible seating, numerous storage compartments, and modern connectivity options. Despite its age, the third-generation Panda remains popular for its combination of city-friendly dimensions, practical design, and unique character, continuing as one of Fiat's core models with over 7.5 million Pandas produced across all generations.
FIAT-Panda.name: Third Generation (Type 312)

FIAT-Panda.description: The Grande Panda was introduced on 14 June 2024 as a B-segment version of the Panda, representing a larger upgrade from the classic city car size. Based on the Smart Car platform shared with the fourth-generation Citroën C3 and Opel Frontera, the Grande Panda offers a new dimension to the Panda family. It is sold with mild hybrid and fully electric powertrains, providing modern sustainable options while maintaining the Panda's iconic design language and practical philosophy.
FIAT-Panda.name: Grande Panda (Type 326)

FSO-Polonez.description: The FSO Polonez was a Polish-built hatchback developed in collaboration with Fiat and produced by Fabryka Samochodów Osobowych. It was based on the Polski Fiat 125p platform with a completely new hatchback body designed by Zbigniew Wattson, Walter de Silva and Giorgetto Giugiaro. Initially available as a five-door hatchback from 1978, with three-door versions added in 1980. Available body styles included two- and four-door hatchbacks, station wagons, pickups, vans, and ambulances. Engine options included 1.3L, 1.5L, 1.6L, and 2.0L gasoline engines plus diesel options. The Caro variant succeeded this generation in 1991.
FSO-Polonez.name: First Generation

FSO-Polonez.description: Following the fall of communism and Poland's transition to a market economy, FSO introduced the facelifted Polonez Caro in 1991. It featured new headlamps and grille, updated front and rear bumpers, improved crash safety, and a redesigned dashboard. Body styles expanded to include sedan (Atu introduced 1996), pickup, and leisure activity vehicle variants. Engine options evolved to include Rover-sourced 1.4L K-series DOHC engines (1993), Ford 2.0L engines, and Citroën-sourced 1.9L diesel. The Caro was succeeded by the Caro Plus in 1997.
FSO-Polonez.name: Second Generation (Caro)

FSO-Polonez.description: The Polonez Caro Plus was introduced in March 1997 with a new front grille, bumpers, and dashboard. A multi-point fuel injection system (Multec XM) was introduced in December 1997 for the 1.6L GSI variant. A station wagon (Kombi) version was added in 1999 with styling borrowed from the Daewoo Nubira. Production of passenger cars ended in Q1 2002, though pickup truck production continued until 2003. Despite continuous updates, the Polonez's outdated platform faced declining sales against imported used cars and new budget vehicles. The Caro Plus marked the end of Poland's most significant domestically developed passenger car.
FSO-Polonez.name: Third Generation (Caro Plus)

Ferrari-458-Italia.description: The Ferrari 458 Italia (Type F142) was introduced at the 2009 Frankfurt Motor Show as the successor to the F430. Designed by Pininfarina under the direction of Donato Coco, the Ferrari Styling Centre director during 2009, it featured flowing, aerodynamic styling with innovative aeroelastic winglets in the front grille that deformed at high speeds to reduce drag. Powered by a naturally aspirated 4.5L Ferrari F136 V8 engine producing 570 PS (562 HP) at 9,000 rpm, it was paired with a seven-speed dual-clutch transmission—Ferrari's first in a mid-engine production car. The car featured direct fuel injection and delivered exceptional performance with 0-100 km/h acceleration in 3.4 seconds and a top speed over 325 km/h. The cockpit introduced a new driver-focused layout with major controls mounted on the steering wheel, drawing input from former Ferrari Formula 1 driver Michael Schumacher. The car produced 140 kg of downforce at 200 km/h and featured advanced suspension with double wishbones and multi-link setup, E-Diff electronic differential, and F1-Trac traction control.
Ferrari-458-Italia.name: First Generation

Ferrari-458-Italia.description: The 458 Spider was introduced at the 2011 Frankfurt Motor Show as a convertible variant of the 458 Italia, featuring an innovative aluminium retractable hardtop that weighs 25 kg less than a soft roof and requires 14 seconds for operation. The Spider shared the same 4.5L V8 engine with 570 PS output, seven-speed dual-clutch transmission, and chassis as the coupe but with a redesigned engine cover to accommodate the retractable roof system. The Spider achieved the same 0-100 km/h acceleration time as the coupe (3.4 seconds) but with a slightly lower top speed of 200 mph. The Spider variant remained in production alongside the base model and Speciale variants until the end of the generation in 2015.
Ferrari-458-Italia.name: First Generation (2011 Spider)

Ferrari-458-Italia.description: The 458 Speciale was unveiled in 2013 at the Frankfurt Motor Show as the high-performance variant of the 458 Italia. Featuring enhanced aerodynamics designed by Ferrari Styling Centre in cooperation with Pininfarina, it included forged wheels, a vented bonnet, finned side sills, a taller rear spoiler, and redesigned bumpers with active aerodynamic flaps designed to balance downforce and cut drag at speed. The engine was revised with power increased to 605 PS (597 HP) at 9,000 rpm with the same 540 Nm torque at 6,000 rpm as the standard 458. Electronic systems were updated and a new Side Slip Angle Control (SSC) system was introduced to improve car control on the limit, providing instant-to-instant analysis of the car's side-slip and optimizing torque management. The Speciale accelerated from 0-100 km/h in 3.0 seconds and achieved a Fiorano test track lap time of 1:23.5 with lateral acceleration reaching 1.33 g. Only 1,309 Speciales were made during its production run.
Ferrari-458-Italia.name: First Generation (2013 Speciale)

Ferrari-458-Italia.description: The 458 Speciale A (Aperta, meaning 'open' in Italian) was unveiled at the 2014 Paris Motor Show as the convertible variant of the 458 Speciale. Limited to only 499 examples (49 right-hand drive), the Speciale A combined the Speciale's 605 PS naturally aspirated V8 engine and advanced active aerodynamics with a convertible body style. The car featured the same performance characteristics as the Speciale coupe, achieving 0-100 km/h acceleration in 3.0 seconds and a top speed of 320 km/h. At the time of its release, it was the most powerful street-legal naturally aspirated Ferrari convertible ever launched, until surpassed by the LaFerrari Aperta in 2017. The Speciale A represented the pinnacle of the 458 platform, combining track-focused performance enhancements with the open-air driving experience.
Ferrari-458-Italia.name: First Generation (2014 Speciale A)

Fiat-Grande-Punto.description: The Fiat Grande Punto represented a significant leap forward from the previous Punto, designed by Giorgetto Giugiaro in collaboration with Fiat Centro Stile. Built on the GM Fiat Small platform (later used for the Opel Corsa D), it was substantially larger than its predecessor, approaching the next segment in size. The exterior featured distinctive styling with elongated headlights, a prominent grille, and a sporty stance that gave it a more premium appearance compared to earlier Fiat small cars. Engine options included various petrol units ranging from a 1.2L 8v to a 1.4L 16v, plus the innovative 1.3L MultiJet diesel. The Abarth Grande Punto introduced in 2007 offered enhanced performance with a 1.4L T-Jet turbocharged engine producing 155 HP. The interior represented a significant improvement in quality and design over previous Fiat models, with better materials and a more modern layout. The Grande Punto achieved commercial success across Europe, helping to revitalize Fiat's reputation in the supermini segment with its combination of style, space, and value.
Fiat-Grande-Punto.name: First Generation (Project 199)

Fiat-Grande-Punto.description: The Punto Evo was a substantial facelift of the Grande Punto, featuring completely redesigned front and rear styling to align with Fiat's then-current design language. Presented in September 2009 at the Frankfurt Motor Show, the exterior changes included a more pronounced front fascia, new headlights and taillights, and revised bumpers. Engine options were updated to include the new MultiAir technology in petrol engines, offering improved efficiency and performance. The interior received a complete redesign with a new dashboard, improved materials, and the introduction of Fiat's Blue&Me connectivity system. Safety features were enhanced, allowing the model to achieve a 5-star Euro NCAP rating. This update maintained the Grande Punto's core attributes while modernizing its appearance and technology.
Fiat-Grande-Punto.name: First Generation (Project 199) 2009 Facelift (Punto Evo)

Fiat-Grande-Punto.description: Fiat introduced the 2012 Punto in September 2011 at the Frankfurt Motor Show as a facelifted version of the Punto Evo that reintroduced the Punto nomenclature (without 'Grande' or 'Evo'). This final iteration of the platform saw a return to simpler styling, with relatively minor exterior changes focusing on bumper designs, light clusters, and trim elements. The base 'Pop' trim level reverted to the older Grande Punto interior, while higher trims maintained the revised rear lights and interior of the 2009 Punto Evo. The engine lineup was rationalized to focus on more efficient options, including the 0.9L TwinAir and updated MultiJet diesels. In June 2016, Fiat introduced the new 'Techno Pack' with a 5-inch touchscreen infotainment system and cruise control. Production ended on 7 August 2018 in Europe, with the car remaining in production in India for an additional three months before ending in November 2018.
Fiat-Grande-Punto.name: First Generation (Project 199) 2012 Facelift (Punto)

Fiat-Punto.description: The original Fiat Punto was a subcompact car designed by Giorgetto Giugiaro, featuring distinctive styling with high-mounted vertical taillights. Available in three and five-door hatchback variants, it offered impressive interior space for its compact exterior dimensions. Engine options ranged from 1.1L to 1.6L petrol and a 1.7L diesel, with the GT variant featuring a turbocharged 1.4L producing 136 HP. The interior was modern for its time with good ergonomics and quality materials by class standards. This generation was highly successful, winning European Car of the Year in 1995 and becoming one of Europe's best-selling cars. The Punto established itself as a core model in Fiat's lineup, offering practicality, style, and value in the competitive supermini segment.
Fiat-Punto.name: First Generation (Type 176)

Fiat-Punto.description: The second-generation Punto codenamed Project 188 was launched in September 1999 at the Frankfurt Motor Show. The styling was all-new while retaining the original Punto's distinctive shape and design, with a completely overhauled chassis and interior featuring a new torsion beam rear suspension. Available in three and five-door hatchback forms, plus a two-door convertible (Punto Cabrio), it grew slightly in size for improved interior space. Engine options included various FIRE petrol units from 1.2L to 1.8L and improved JTD diesel engines. The performance-oriented HGT variant featured a 1.8L 16v engine with 130 HP. The interior offered improved quality, comfort, and equipment levels.
Fiat-Punto.name: Second Generation (Type 188)

Fiat-Punto.description: A significant facelift in 2003 brought further revisions to the platform, including extensive changes to the exterior styling and engines, partly due to pedestrian safety regulations. The round Fiat badge was introduced on the tailgate. Engine changes included a new 1.4L 16v engine, alongside the staple 1.2 and 1.2L 16v variants, and the introduction of two HGT versions with 1.9L MultiJet diesel and 1.8L 16v petrol engines. A new 1.3L common rail diesel MultiJet engine was also introduced. Despite the launch of the slightly larger Grande Punto at the end of 2005, the second generation Punto remained in production as 'Punto Classic' and was sold in many markets alongside the newer generation, finally ending production in Italy in November 2010.
Fiat-Punto.name: Second Generation (Type 188, 2003 Facelift)

Fiat-Punto.description: The Grande Punto, codenamed Project 199, was unveiled at the 2005 Frankfurt Motor Show and went on sale later that year. Designed by Giorgetto Giugiaro in collaboration with Fiat Centro Stile, it was based on the GM Fiat Small platform developed in joint venture with Opel. The car represented a significant size increase, approaching the next segment in dimensions with new components including chassis and body shell. Engine options included petrol units from 1.2L Fire to 1.4L with various configurations, and advanced MultiJet diesel engines. The Abarth Grande Punto, introduced in 2007, offered enhanced performance with turbocharged engines producing up to 150 HP, with further power upgrades available through the Essesse kit reaching 180 HP.
Fiat-Punto.name: Third Generation (Type 199)

Fiat-Punto.description: The Punto Evo, a substantial facelift version of the Grande Punto, was presented in September 2009 at the Frankfurt Motor Show. It received a completely new front end, revised rear lights, and a new interior. The car featured two new engines: a 1.3L second generation Multijet diesel and a 1.4L petrol engine with MultiAir technology. A new navigation system was integrated into the Blue&Me system. The Abarth Punto Evo, shown at the 2010 Geneva Motor Show, featured a 1.4L MultiAir Turbo engine producing 165 HP, with an optional Esseesse version offering 180 HP and improved performance.
Fiat-Punto.name: Third Generation (Type 199, 2009 Facelift - Punto Evo)

Fiat-Punto.description: Fiat introduced the 2012 Punto in September 2011 at the Frankfurt Motor Show as a facelifted version of the Punto Evo that reintroduced the Punto nomenclature (without 'Grande' or 'Evo'). The facelift consisted of lighter tweaks than the Grande Punto to Punto Evo transition, keeping the revised rear lights and interior of the 2009 Punto Evo but with a return to simpler styling more reminiscent of the original Grande Punto. In June 2016, a new Techno Pack was introduced with a 5-inch touchscreen infotainment system and cruise control. Production of the three-door version ended in 2015, leaving only the five-door version available in Europe. Production of the Punto ended on 7 August 2018, with no direct successor announced, concluding 25 years of production.
Fiat-Punto.name: Third Generation (Type 199, 2012 Facelift)

Fisker-Ocean.description: The Fisker Ocean is an all-electric SUV that represents the rebirth of the Fisker brand under founder Henrik Fisker after the original company's bankruptcy in 2013. Built on a dedicated EV platform developed in collaboration with Magna Steyr (who also manufactures the vehicle in Austria), it features distinctive styling that balances aerodynamic efficiency with traditional SUV proportions. The exterior design incorporates several innovative elements including a solar roof that can add up to 1,500 miles of range annually in optimal conditions, a 'California Mode' that opens all windows and the roof with a single touch, and a unique rear window that can be lowered to accommodate long items. Available in various trim levels including Sport, Ultra, and Extreme, the powertrain options range from a single-motor front-wheel drive setup producing 275 HP in the base model to a dual-motor all-wheel drive system delivering up to 564 HP in the Extreme variant. Battery capacity also varies by model, with the larger 106 kWh pack in higher trims providing an EPA-estimated range of up to 360 miles. The interior features a minimalist design focused on sustainability, using recycled materials including plastics recovered from the ocean. Technology highlights include a massive 17.1-inch central touchscreen that can rotate between portrait and landscape orientations, a digital instrument display, and comprehensive driver assistance systems. The Ocean represents Fisker's vision for sustainable mobility, combining performance, technology, and environmental consciousness in a package designed to compete with established premium electric SUVs.
Fisker-Ocean.name: First Generation

Ford-Bronco.description: The original Ford Bronco was designed as a compact off-road vehicle to compete with the Jeep CJ and International Harvester Scout. Available in wagon, pickup, and roadster body styles (though the roadster was discontinued after 1968), it featured a boxy, functional design with short overhangs for off-road capability. Initially powered by a 170 cubic-inch inline-six engine, a 289 cubic-inch V8 was added in 1967, followed by larger V8 options in later years. The first-generation Bronco featured a unique suspension system with a coil spring front axle, providing better off-road articulation and on-road comfort than its contemporaries. The simple, utilitarian interior focused on durability rather than comfort. This generation established the Bronco's reputation for off-road capability and created a dedicated following that would maintain interest in the nameplate decades after production ended.
Ford-Bronco.name: First Generation

Ford-Bronco.description: The second-generation Bronco represented a significant shift in philosophy, growing substantially in size as it moved to the F-Series truck platform. Available only as a three-door wagon with a removable fiberglass rear roof section, it featured a much larger, more truck-like appearance. Powered by either a 351 or 400 cubic-inch V8 engine, it offered substantially more power and towing capability than its predecessor. The interior was more comfortable and car-like, reflecting the growing consumer demand for practical daily-use SUVs rather than pure off-road vehicles. Despite its short two-year production run, this generation set the template for the full-size Bronco that would continue for the next three generations.
Ford-Bronco.name: Second Generation

Ford-Bronco.description: The third-generation Bronco maintained the full-size F-Series based platform but with styling updates and weight reduction measures in response to the energy crises of the 1970s. Engine options expanded to include a 300 cubic-inch inline-six and various V8s including 302 and 351 cubic-inch variants. The exterior styling was squarer and more angular than its predecessor, reflecting Ford's design language of the era. The interior offered improved comfort and convenience features, including available air conditioning, stereo systems, and more comfortable seating. Four-wheel drive systems were improved with the introduction of the Ford Twin-Traction Beam independent front suspension system on later models.
Ford-Bronco.name: Third Generation

Ford-Bronco.description: The fourth-generation Bronco received significant styling updates to match the aerodynamic redesign of the F-Series trucks. The exterior featured a more rounded front end with flush headlights and a cleaner overall design. Engine options were updated to include fuel injection across the range, improving power and efficiency. The interior was modernized with a new dashboard, improved ergonomics, and more comfort features. Safety features were enhanced with rear-wheel anti-lock brakes. This generation maintained the removable hardtop design while offering a more refined overall package.
Ford-Bronco.name: Fourth Generation

Ford-Bronco.description: The final generation of the original Bronco run featured updated styling to match the contemporary F-Series trucks, with a more rounded, aerodynamic design. Safety features were significantly enhanced with the addition of driver-side airbags, three-point seatbelts for all outboard passengers, and improved crash protection. Engine options included a 5.0L or 5.8L V8, both with electronic fuel injection. The interior offered the most car-like comfort in the model's history. Production ended in 1996 as consumer preferences shifted toward four-door SUVs, with the Ford Expedition effectively replacing the Bronco in Ford's lineup.
Ford-Bronco.name: Fifth Generation

Ford-Bronco.description: After a 25-year hiatus, the Bronco returned as a purpose-built off-road SUV available in two-door and four-door configurations. Built on a modified T6 platform with body-on-frame construction, it features retro-inspired styling that pays homage to the first-generation model while incorporating modern design elements. Power comes from either a 2.3L EcoBoost four-cylinder producing 300 HP or a 2.7L EcoBoost V6 with 330 HP, paired with a 7-speed manual (2.3L only) or 10-speed automatic transmission. The sixth-generation Bronco offers impressive off-road capability with available features including 35-inch tires, electronic locking differentials, disconnecting sway bar, and a terrain management system. Innovative features include removable doors and roof panels, washable interior with drain plugs, and modular mounting points for accessories. The interior balances ruggedness with modern technology, featuring water-resistant surfaces and an available 12-inch touchscreen with off-road navigation capability. Special variants include the desert-racing inspired Raptor with wider body, reinforced frame, and a 418 HP 3.0L EcoBoost V6. The revived Bronco has successfully captured the spirit of the original while offering modern performance, technology, and comfort, positioned as a direct competitor to the Jeep Wrangler.
Ford-Bronco.name: Sixth Generation

Ford-Bronco-Sport.description: The Ford Bronco Sport is a compact crossover SUV that shares the Bronco name and styling cues with its larger sibling but is built on Ford's C2 unibody platform shared with the Escape rather than a body-on-frame construction. Designed as a more road-friendly yet still capable off-road vehicle, it features distinctive styling with a boxy silhouette, round headlights, and 'BRONCO' lettering across the grille, clearly invoking the classic Bronco while establishing its own identity. Available exclusively as a four-door with a fixed metal roof featuring safari-style raised sections for improved headroom and cargo-carrying capability, it maintains a compact footprint suitable for urban environments. Powertrain options include a standard 1.5L EcoBoost three-cylinder producing 181 HP and an optional 2.0L EcoBoost four-cylinder with 250 HP in higher trims, both paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission and standard all-wheel drive. The Bronco Sport's off-road capability exceeds most competitors in its class, particularly in the Badlands trim which features an advanced all-wheel drive system with a twin-clutch rear differential, all-terrain tires, increased ground clearance, and underbody protection. The interior combines ruggedness with modern technology, featuring washable rubber flooring, an available 8-inch touchscreen with SYNC 3, and numerous clever storage solutions including a built-in bottle opener. A unique feature is the GOAT (Goes Over Any Terrain) mode selector, offering up to seven terrain management settings depending on the trim level. The Bronco Sport represents Ford's entry into the increasingly popular 'adventure crossover' segment, offering genuine off-road capability in a more accessible, daily-driver friendly package compared to the standard Bronco.
Ford-Bronco-Sport.name: First Generation

Ford-E-Series.description: The original Ford Econoline (later renamed E-Series) was a forward-control van based on the Ford Falcon platform. Available in van, pickup, and station wagon configurations, it featured a cab-over design with the engine placed between the front seats to maximize cargo space. Initially powered by the Falcon's 144 cubic-inch inline-six engine producing just 85 HP, the compact exterior dimensions made it ideal for urban use. The simple, functional interior focused on utility rather than comfort, with basic instrumentation and minimal amenities. This generation established Ford in the American van market as a competitor to the Volkswagen Type 2 and Chevrolet Corvair vans.
Ford-E-Series.name: First Generation (Econoline)

Ford-E-Series.description: The second-generation Econoline moved to a more conventional layout with the engine moved forward of the passenger compartment, though still partially inside the cab. This allowed for a shorter vehicle with more cargo space and improved engine access. The range expanded to include multiple wheelbase options and higher gross vehicle weight ratings for commercial applications. Engine options were significantly expanded to include larger inline-sixes and V8s up to 302 cubic inches. The interior remained utilitarian for cargo models, but passenger variants offered improved comfort with better seating, insulation, and amenities.
Ford-E-Series.name: Second Generation

Ford-E-Series.description: The third-generation E-Series (officially renamed from Econoline during this generation) adopted a complete redesign with a conventional truck-like nose that fully moved the engine ahead of the passenger compartment. Available in multiple wheelbases and roof heights, it could be configured as a cargo van, passenger wagon, or cutaway chassis for specialized applications. Engine options expanded to include larger V8s including 351, 400, and 460 cubic-inch variants, plus a 6.9L (later 7.3L) diesel option. The interior was significantly improved for passenger models, offering car-like amenities including air conditioning, improved sound systems, and more comfortable seating. This generation's extended production run saw numerous updates to styling, powertrains, and features, establishing the E-Series as America's best-selling full-size van.
Ford-E-Series.name: Third Generation

Ford-E-Series.description: The fourth-generation E-Series featured more aerodynamic styling with a sloped windshield and rounded corners, though still maintaining the truck-like front end. Available in E-150, E-250, and E-350 variants with multiple wheelbase options, it served both commercial and passenger markets. Engine options included various gasoline V8s and a 7.3L Power Stroke diesel, later updated to the 6.0L Power Stroke. The interior was gradually modernized throughout its run with improved ergonomics, safety features, and technology. This generation saw the addition of advanced features like stability control, backup sensors, and factory-installed navigation systems in later years. Despite its age, the fourth generation maintained strong sales primarily due to its established position in the commercial market and the significant costs associated with tooling for a full-size van.
Ford-E-Series.name: Fourth Generation

Ford-E-Series.description: In 2015, the E-Series passenger and cargo vans were discontinued and replaced by the Transit, but the E-Series continues in production as cutaway and stripped chassis models for commercial upfitting. These variants maintain the front-end styling and cab section of the fourth generation but are exclusively built for conversion to applications such as ambulances, shuttle buses, and motorhomes. Powertrain options were updated to include modern engines such as the 7.3L Godzilla V8 introduced in 2020. The interior of the cab section has received incremental updates to technology and safety features while maintaining the rugged, commercial-focused design. The continued production of E-Series cutaway models alongside the Transit reflects its entrenched position in the commercial vehicle market and the specialized needs of upfitters who had decades of experience with the E-Series platform.
Ford-E-Series.name: Current Generation (Cutaway Only)

Ford-EcoSport.description: The original Ford EcoSport was developed by Ford Brazil for emerging markets, particularly South America, based on the Fiesta platform. Featuring compact dimensions combined with increased ground clearance and rugged styling elements, it pioneered the now-popular subcompact crossover segment. The exterior design included a distinctive spare tire mounted on the side-hinged rear door. Powertrain options varied by market but typically included 1.0L and 1.6L petrol engines, with a focus on affordability and durability rather than performance. The interior was basic but functional, sharing many components with the contemporary Fiesta. This generation was never sold in North America or Western Europe, being primarily targeted at developing markets where its combination of small footprint, raised ride height, and affordability proved highly successful.
Ford-EcoSport.name: First Generation

Ford-EcoSport.description: The second-generation EcoSport was developed under Ford's global product development process, designated under project code B515 and model code BK in Australia. Built on the Ford Global B-car Platform (shared with the Fiesta), it was first showcased at the 2012 New Delhi Auto Expo and launched in Brazil on July 14, 2012. The vehicle was manufactured in India, Brazil, China, Thailand, Russia, and Vietnam. It entered the European market in 2014 and maintained the distinctive rear-mounted spare tire on a side-hinged rear door. Powertrain options included petrol engines (1.0L, 1.5L, 1.6L, 2.0L) and diesel engines (1.4L and 1.5L), varying by market. The interior featured improved materials and technology compared to the first generation, with Ford's SYNC infotainment system available.
Ford-EcoSport.name: Second Generation

Ford-EcoSport.description: The mid-cycle facelift of the second-generation EcoSport was announced at the 2016 Los Angeles Auto Show for the 2018 model year. Key updates included a revised front end design with a new grille and headlights, a redesigned rear bumper, and a substantially updated interior featuring an optional 8-inch floating touchscreen infotainment system supporting Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. The facelift was introduced in India and became available in the North American market in 2018, imported from India. Production continued in Romania (from 2017), Vietnam, and other markets until 2022. Regional production dates varied: Romania (2017-2022), Vietnam (2014-2022), and India/Brazil until 2021. The facelift maintained the same platform and overall concept but with modernized styling and technology to better compete in the expanding subcompact crossover segment. Production ended in North America in 2022, with the European market served from Romania until the vehicle's discontinuation after the 2022 model year without a direct replacement.
Ford-EcoSport.name: Second Generation (2017 Facelift)

Ford-Edge.description: The original Ford Edge was a mid-size crossover SUV built on Ford's CD3 platform shared with the Fusion sedan. Featuring a bold, muscular design with a prominent three-bar grille, it helped establish the crossover segment as an alternative to traditional SUVs and minivans. Introduced for the 2007 model year with production starting in January 2006, it was initially powered by a 3.5L V6 producing 265 HP, paired with a six-speed automatic transmission and available with front or all-wheel drive. A 3.7L V6 with 305 HP was added for the Sport model in 2011, while EcoBoost four-cylinder options were introduced in later years. The interior offered seating for five (with no third-row option) and emphasized passenger space and comfort with a substantial cargo area. A significant refresh in 2011 updated the styling, improved interior materials, and introduced MyFord Touch infotainment. The first-generation Edge successfully established the model as a core offering in Ford's lineup, appealing to customers seeking a practical, comfortable crossover without the size or fuel consumption of a traditional SUV.
Ford-Edge.name: First Generation

Ford-Edge.description: The redesigned Edge moved to Ford's CD4 platform shared with the Fusion, featuring more sophisticated styling with a sleeker profile, while maintaining the distinctive Edge identity. Engine options evolved to focus on EcoBoost technology, including a standard 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder, a 2.7L twin-turbo V6 for the Edge ST (replacing the Sport and producing 335 HP), and a naturally aspirated 3.5L V6 (discontinued after 2018). The interior saw significant improvements in material quality, design, and technology, featuring Ford's SYNC 3 infotainment system, available digital instrument cluster, and enhanced active safety features. A refresh in 2019 updated the styling with a wider grille and introduced the ST performance model replacing the Sport, while adding more advanced driver assistance features under the Ford Co-Pilot360 suite. For 2021, a larger 12-inch infotainment screen with SYNC 4 became standard. Production of the North American-market second-generation Edge ended on April 26, 2024, with the second-generation Edge having targeted the two-row midsize crossover segment with a focus on technology, comfort, and available performance, particularly with the ST model which introduced a more serious performance credential to the mainstream crossover segment.
Ford-Edge.name: Second Generation

Ford-Escape.description: The original Ford Escape was a compact SUV developed in partnership with Mazda (which sold its version as the Tribute). Featuring traditional SUV styling with a boxy shape and upright stance, it combined car-like handling with light off-road capability. Built on the CD2 platform with unibody construction, it was available with front-wheel or all-wheel drive. Engine options included a 2.0L four-cylinder and a 3.0L V6, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. The interior was practical and durable, with good cargo space and folding rear seats. A hybrid variant introduced in 2004 was the first hybrid SUV available in North America. The first-generation Escape established the model as a popular choice in the growing compact SUV segment, appealing to customers seeking a practical, versatile vehicle with a traditional SUV appearance but better fuel economy and handling than larger, truck-based SUVs.
Ford-Escape.name: First Generation

Ford-Escape.description: The second-generation Escape featured updated styling but maintained the boxy, traditional SUV appearance of its predecessor. Continuing on an evolved version of the CD2 platform, it offered refined powertrains including an updated 2.5L four-cylinder base engine and a more powerful 3.0L V6. The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and technology, including the introduction of Ford's SYNC system. Safety features were enhanced with standard electronic stability control and improved crash protection. The Escape Hybrid continued with improved efficiency and performance. This generation maintained the Escape's strong market position while adding refinement and technology, though it began to face increasing competition from more car-like crossover competitors.
Ford-Escape.name: Second Generation

Ford-Escape.description: The third-generation Escape represented a dramatic shift in design philosophy, adopting a sleeker, more car-like appearance aligned with Ford's kinetic design language. Built on the Ford C1 platform shared with the Ford Kuga, it featured improved aerodynamics, reduced weight, and enhanced handling. Engine options included a 2.5L naturally aspirated engine for base models and EcoBoost turbocharged four-cylinders (1.6L and 2.0L). The interior offered technology features including MyFord Touch infotainment. This generation transformed the Escape from a traditional small SUV to a modern crossover, appealing to a broader audience seeking car-like dynamics with SUV practicality.
Ford-Escape.name: Third Generation

Ford-Escape.description: The 2017 refresh introduced a mid-cycle update with an Edge-inspired front fascia, reshaped LED taillights, and a new hexagonal grille design. The refresh also added SYNC 3 infotainment system with smartphone app connectivity (Sync Connect). The 1.6L EcoBoost was replaced by a new 1.5L turbocharged four-cylinder engine. Interior refinements included reduced road and wind noise through improved insulation, acoustic glass, and enhanced seals. Driver-assist features became available including enhanced park assist, lane-keeping, forward collision warning, and adaptive cruise control. This facelift modernized the cabin and exterior styling while maintaining the same C1 platform and overall design language.
Ford-Escape.name: Third Generation (2017 Facelift)

Ford-Escape.description: The fourth-generation Escape represents a major redesign introduced in 2020, featuring a modern, sleek exterior with improved aerodynamics. Built on the Ford C2 platform, it offers significantly improved interior space while being lighter than the previous generation. Powertrain options include a turbocharged 1.5L three-cylinder EcoBoost, a turbocharged 2.0L four-cylinder EcoBoost, and both a conventional hybrid and plug-in hybrid powered by a 2.5L Atkinson-cycle engine offering approximately 37 miles of electric-only range. The interior features modern design with SYNC 3 infotainment. The fourth generation marks the unification with the Ford Kuga outside North America under Ford's One Ford strategy.
Ford-Escape.name: Fourth Generation

Ford-Escape.description: The 2023 refresh brought comprehensive updates announced in October 2022, featuring a restyled grille and headlights, updated taillights, and an optional front light bar. Both EcoBoost engines were reworked to meet current emissions standards while maintaining power output. The interior received a new digital gauge cluster as standard equipment, with an 8-inch screen and optional 12.3-inch LCD dashboard. Higher trim levels received a new 13.2-inch infotainment system with SYNC 4. The trim lineup was completely restructured, with S, SE, and Titanium replaced by Base, Active, and Platinum, plus three ST-Line variants. The plug-in hybrid became a standalone trim. Production ended in December 2025 as Ford discontinued the Escape to focus on electric vehicles and trucks.
Ford-Escape.name: Fourth Generation (2023 Facelift)

Ford-Everest.description: Ford unveiled the first-generation Everest in March 2003 at the Bangkok International Motor Show. The original Ford Everest was a mid-size SUV based on the Mazda-derived Ford Ranger pickup truck platform, developed primarily for Asian markets. It featured traditional body-on-frame construction with rugged styling and genuine off-road capability. Offering three rows of seating for up to seven passengers, it combined utility with family-friendly features. Powertrain options included a 2.6L petrol engine (Mazda G6E I4) and diesel options: 2.5L WL Duratorq I4, 2.5L WL-T Duratorq turbo I4, and 3.0L VS Duratorq turbo I4, paired with 5-speed manual, 4-speed, or 5-speed automatic transmissions and part-time four-wheel drive. The interior was basic but functional, prioritizing durability over luxury.
Ford-Everest.name: First Generation (2003-2006)

Ford-Everest.description: In November 2006, the Everest underwent a major facelift that saw the whole front and side body panels replaced to match the redesign of its base vehicle, the Ranger. The changes included an updated front fascia, new transmission, and improved engine. The redesign featured the new 5-speed automatic transmission with BorgWarner transfer case, and Active-Shift-on-the-Fly function (4x4 only).
