Despite the massive changes, it retained most mechanical parts along with its U268 project code. The visual updates included new headlights, grille, and bumpers while maintaining the basic platform.
Ford-Everest.name: First Generation (2007 Facelift)

Ford-Everest.description: A second facelift was introduced in 2009. While the changes were less prominent than the previous facelift, the Everest now featured a rounder fascia than its predecessor, similar to the facelifted Ranger. The changes were achieved by replacing the front fender assembly, front hood, front headlights, front grille, and front bumper, along with larger 18-inch polished alloy wheels, a redesigned tailgate, and new tail lamps. The platform remained unchanged with its U268 project code.
Ford-Everest.name: First Generation (2009 Facelift)

Ford-Everest.description: Another smaller update was introduced in 2012, featuring a revised front grille. In 2013, the Everest received a final facelift, featuring a redesigned front bumper in line with some other global Ford cars. The first generation continued to serve Asian markets including Southeast Asia, India, Middle East, and Central America, competing against vehicles like the Toyota Fortuner and Mitsubishi Pajero Sport in the popular truck-based SUV segment. The final years of this generation (2012-2015) represented the end of the long-running U268/UR platform.
Ford-Everest.name: First Generation (2012-2015)

Ford-Everest.description: The second-generation Everest first previewed at a 'Go Further' future product event in Sydney, Australia as a near-production concept vehicle in August 2013, with the production version unveiled in November 2014. Based on the Ford Ranger T6, this generation represented a significant advancement while maintaining its Ranger-based underpinnings. The exterior featured more sophisticated styling with rounder proportions and complex surface detailing. It was developed by Ford Australia and designated U375 (development code) and UA series (model code in Australia). Powertrain options included 2.0L EcoBoost and 2.3L EcoBoost petrol engines, and diesel options: 2.0L EcoBlue turbo, 2.0L EcoBlue twin-turbo, 2.2L Duratorq turbo, and 3.2L Duratorq turbo. The interior marked a step forward with contemporary design and improved technology including SYNC infotainment systems.
Ford-Everest.name: Second Generation

Ford-Everest.description: This model received a facelift in May 2018, coinciding with the Ranger facelift. The facelift included design tweaks, equipment list updates, a new 2.0-litre bi-turbo diesel engine, and a 10-speed automatic gearbox. Other changes included Autonomous Emergency Braking, a standard kick-activated power liftgate, and new alloy wheels. Interior changes featured more soft touch materials with an ebony dark colour scheme. Safety features were expanded to include adaptive cruise control and lane-keeping aid.
Ford-Everest.name: Second Generation (2018 Facelift)

Ford-Everest.description: Another facelift was released for the 2021 year model in November 2020 in Thailand. This version retained the T6 platform designation (U375/UA) while incorporating further refinements. The Everest continued to serve global markets including Thailand, China, South Africa, India, and Cambodia through various assembly plants. Production and sales of the Endeavour in India ended in 2021 due to the closure of all Ford manufacturing plants in the country.
Ford-Everest.name: Second Generation (2021 Facelift)

Ford-Everest.description: The third-generation Everest was revealed on 1 March 2022, developed under the U704 development code and known as the UB series in Australia. Based on the Ford Ranger P703, this generation represents the newest platform for the Everest. It shares most front end components with the P703 Ranger while maintaining increased dimensions with 50mm additional wheel track and wheelbase. The exterior features a bold, upright design with updated styling. Powertrain options include 2.3L EcoBoost turbo I4, 2.7L EcoBoost twin-turbo V6, 2.0L EcoBlue turbo I4, 2.0L EcoBlue twin-turbo I4, and 3.0L Power Stroke turbo V6 diesel engines. The interior represents a significant advancement featuring digital instrument clusters and modern touchscreen infotainment. Off-road capability remains a priority with available full-time four-wheel drive and electronic locking rear differential. Assembly is centered in Thailand at Rayong.
Ford-Everest.name: Third Generation

Ford-Expedition.description: The original Ford Expedition was introduced as a replacement for the Bronco, offering four doors and greater interior space. Known internally at Ford as the UN93, it was developed from 1993 to 1996 at a cost of US$1.3 billion. Built on the F-150 platform, it featured body-on-frame construction and a traditional SUV design. Available with either a 4.6L or 5.4L Triton V8 engine, it offered substantial towing capacity and passenger comfort. The interior provided seating for up to nine passengers across three rows with optional three-row seating and first-row captain's chair seating. The Expedition was positioned between the smaller Explorer and larger Excursion in Ford's SUV lineup, competing directly with the Chevrolet Tahoe. The 1999 model year received a facelift similar to the contemporary Ford F-150, featuring a new front grille, bumper with integrated fog lamps, and updated dashboard controls. Production ran from July 22, 1996 to March 2002.
Ford-Expedition.name: First Generation (UN93)

Ford-Expedition.description: The second-generation Expedition was developed under the U222 program code from 1996 to 2002 and launched in May 2002 for the 2003 model year. It maintained its F-150 underpinnings but featured more refined styling and improved interior quality. A major innovation was the introduction of a four-wheel independent long-travel suspension system—a first for a full-size SUV—which improved both ride quality and third-row space by reducing unsprung mass and allowing 9.4 inches of suspension travel. Power came from the 4.6L and 5.4L Triton V8 engines (2003-2004) and the 5.4L 3-valve Triton V8 (2005-2006). The Expedition received a hydroformed fully boxed frame providing 70 percent improvement in torsional stiffness and all-new steering, braking, and electronic systems. The interior was significantly upgraded with better materials and premium perforated leather seating surfaces. Production ran from March 2002 to July 2006.
Ford-Expedition.name: Second Generation (U222)

Ford-Expedition.description: The third-generation Expedition was developed under the U324 program code and launched in August 2006 for the 2007 model year. It featured updated styling and improved capabilities on the F-150 platform. The extended-length Expedition EL was introduced, adding 15 inches to the overall length for increased cargo capacity and largely replacing the Ford Excursion. Powered exclusively by the 5.4L Triton V8 initially (2007-2008), later models from 2009-2014 used the updated 5.4L V8 with E85 ethanol capability. The interior was further refined with better materials and technology features including SYNC infotainment and voice-activated controls. This generation maintained the Expedition's position in the full-size SUV market during the economic downturn and high fuel prices. In January 2009, production was relocated from Michigan Assembly Plant to Kentucky Truck Assembly in Louisville. Production ran from August 2, 2006 to July 2, 2017 for the U324 platform.
Ford-Expedition.name: Third Generation (U324)

Ford-Expedition.description: On February 18, 2014, Ford introduced a mid-cycle refresh of the Expedition (U324) for the 2015 model year, designated U3242. The refresh featured significant visual and powertrain changes while remaining on the same U324 platform. The exterior received an aggressive three-bar grille with armadillo-like stepped appearance, all-new thinner headlamps, and an all-new front bumper with oversized lower air intake and twin LED fog lamps. The most significant change was replacing the 5.4L Triton V8 entirely with the new 3.5L 24-valve DOHC Ti-VCT EcoBoost V6 engine featuring twin-turbochargers, direct injection, and producing 365 horsepower and 420 lb-ft of torque. This improved fuel economy significantly to 16 city/23 highway MPG for 2WD and 15 city/21 highway for 4WD. The interior received upgraded materials and a revised center stack derived from the 2013-2014 F-150, with the latest MyFord Touch 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system and push-button start with intelligent access. New features included optional four-wheel independent suspension with continuously controlled damping, blind-spot information system, and upgraded off-road electronics. Production ran from early 2014 to July 2017.
Ford-Expedition.name: Third Generation (U3242 Mid-Cycle Refresh)

Ford-Expedition.description: The fourth-generation Expedition featured a complete redesign with an aluminum-alloy body similar to the F-150, resulting in significant weight reduction. Launched September 25, 2017, it introduced a new U553 platform based on the Ford T3 architecture. Available in standard and long-wheelbase Max configurations, it offered seating for up to eight passengers with improved interior space. Powered exclusively by a 3.5L EcoBoost V6 producing up to 400 HP in higher trims, paired with a 10-speed 10R80 SelectShift automatic transmission. The interior represented a major advancement with higher quality materials and technology, including available SYNC 4 with a 15.5-inch vertical touchscreen in updated models. Features included active noise cancellation, panoramic sunroof, and advanced driver assistance technologies. A significant refresh for 2022 updated the exterior styling, interior technology, and added the off-road oriented Timberline and street-performance Stealth Performance packages. This generation combined the capability expected of a full-size SUV with modern technology, efficiency, and refinement. Production ran from September 25, 2017 to 2024.
Ford-Expedition.name: Fourth Generation (U553)

Ford-Expedition.description: The fifth-generation Expedition was revealed on October 3, 2024, and began production on January 6, 2025 on the Ford T3 platform as the U717. It represents the latest redesign with a reworked liftgate called the Ford Split Gate, where the top half opens like a standard liftgate while the lower half opens like a pickup truck tailgate supporting up to 500 pounds. Available in standard and long-wheelbase MAX configurations, it retains body-on-frame architecture with aluminum-alloy body construction. Powered by the 3.5L Twin-Turbo EcoBoost V6 (EcoBoost D35) producing increased output, paired with the 10-speed SelectShift automatic transmission. New trim levels include the Active as the entry-level model with the Tremor off-road variant replacing the discontinued Timberline, featuring 33-inch all-terrain tires, off-road auxiliary lighting, Raptor-inspired running boards, underbody protection, and specialized modes including Trail 1-Pedal, Rock Crawl Mode, and Trail Turn Assist. The interior features the Ford Digital Experience with a 24-inch panoramic display as instrument cluster and 13.2-inch central touchscreen, with WiFi hotspot, Alexa, Google Play, and Google Maps integration. The Flex Powered Console allows the center console to slide back nearly 8 inches for improved second-row access. The Expedition is capable of towing 7,000 pounds standard or 9,600 pounds with a weight-distributing hitch. This generation sets a new standard for full-size luxury SUVs.
Ford-Expedition.name: Fifth Generation (U717)

Ford-Explorer.description: The original Ford Explorer was introduced as a replacement for the Bronco II, built on the Ranger pickup truck platform. Available as a two-door Sport model or four-door wagon, it featured traditional body-on-frame construction with Twin I-Beam front suspension and leaf-sprung rear axle. Initially powered by a 4.0L Cologne V6 engine producing 155-160 hp, paired with either a Mazda M5OD 5-speed manual or Ford A4LD 4-speed automatic transmission. Available with rear-wheel drive or part-time four-wheel drive using the Borg Warner Touch Drive system. The interior was more family-friendly than previous Ford SUVs, featuring a dashboard shared with the Ranger but with Explorer-specific door panels and seats. This generation played a pivotal role in popularizing the SUV concept for family transportation, establishing Ford as a leader in the growing midsize SUV market.
Ford-Explorer.name: First Generation

Ford-Explorer.description: The redesigned Explorer maintained body-on-frame construction but with significant chassis upgrades, adopting a short/long-arm (SLA) wishbone front suspension replacing the Twin I-Beam setup, while retaining a leaf-sprung rear axle. The five-door model was produced from November 1994 through December 2000, while the three-door Explorer Sport continued until July 2003. Engine options expanded to include a 5.0L OHV V8 (210-215 hp) alongside the standard 4.0L Cologne V6 in both OHV (160 hp) and SOHC (210 hp) configurations. The four-wheel drive system was upgraded from Touch Drive to ControlTrac, an electronically controlled full-time system with a two-speed transfer case. A rear bench seat was available for export markets, expanding seating to seven passengers. This generation solidified the Explorer's position as America's best-selling SUV.
Ford-Explorer.name: Second Generation

Ford-Explorer.description: The third-generation Explorer marked a complete redesign, ending chassis commonality with the Ford Ranger in favor of a purpose-built SUV design (U152 platform). It introduced an independent rear suspension—a first for the mainstream American SUV segment—featuring a live axle located by two half-shafts, significantly improving ride quality and interior packaging with nearly 10 additional cubic feet of cargo space. Available exclusively as a five-door wagon, the model featured a redesigned interior with improved materials and standard dual airbags. Engine options included a 210 hp 4.0L SOHC V6 and a new 239 hp 4.6L SOHC Modular V8, paired with either a Mazda M5OD manual (2002 only) or Ford 5R55 automatic transmission. Safety features included AdvanceTrac stability control and optional side-curtain airbags. The Lincoln Aviator and Mercury Mountaineer were rebadged counterparts.
Ford-Explorer.name: Third Generation

Ford-Explorer.description: The fourth-generation Explorer maintained body-on-frame construction on a new stiffer frame from Magna International, featuring updated front and rear fascias, side profile, interior redesigns, and a new one-piece tailgate replacing the problematic two-piece design. A tire pressure monitoring system and electronic stability control became standard equipment for improved safety. Power came from a 210 hp 4.0L SOHC V6 or a 292 hp 4.6L 24-valve Modular V8, paired with a 5-speed or new 6-speed Ford automatic transmission. The 2007 model year brought minor updates including an AUX input, heated windshield option, and the Ironman Package. The XLS trim was dropped, making XLT the base model. This would be the last generation with traditional body-on-frame construction and the final one produced at the Louisville, Kentucky and St. Louis, Missouri plants.
Ford-Explorer.name: Fourth Generation

Ford-Explorer.description: The fifth-generation Explorer represented a paradigm shift, transitioning from traditional body-on-frame construction to unibody architecture based on Ford's D4 platform shared with the Flex and Lincoln MKT. This change resulted in significantly improved handling, ride quality, fuel economy, and interior space. Available exclusively as a five-door crossover SUV, it featured front-wheel drive or intelligent all-wheel drive with a variable center multi-disc differential. Powertrain options included a 290 hp 3.5L Ti-VCT V6 or a 240 hp 2.0L EcoBoost turbocharged four-cylinder (front-wheel drive only), paired with a 6-speed Ford automatic transmission. The interior offered three rows of seating for up to seven passengers with improved materials and technology including MyFord Touch infotainment system by Microsoft, SYNC connectivity, Sony audio, HD radio, and available navigation. Safety features included inflatable rear seatbelts and various driver assistance technologies.
Ford-Explorer.name: Fifth Generation

Ford-Explorer.description: The fifth-generation Explorer received a significant mid-cycle refresh for the 2016 model year, debuting at the 2014 Los Angeles Auto Show. The facelift featured a redesigned front fascia, hood, and lower bumper with standard LED low-beam headlights inspired by the thirteenth-generation F-150. The rear received restyled LED tail lamps and dual exhaust outlets. A major mechanical change upgraded the four-cylinder engine from 2.0L to a more powerful 280 hp 2.3L EcoBoost sourced from the Mustang, while the 365 hp twin-turbo 3.5L EcoBoost V6 became available beyond just the Sport trim. A new Platinum trim level was introduced, featuring enhanced luxury content including a 500-watt Sony surround sound system, hands-free liftgate, and advanced parking assist. The SYNC 3 infotainment system replaced MyFord Touch for improved usability. For 2018, the front fascia received another update with new LED fog lights and grille design.
Ford-Explorer.name: Fifth Generation (2016 Facelift)

Ford-Explorer.description: The sixth-generation Explorer debuted in January 2019, featuring a return to rear-wheel drive architecture (with available all-wheel drive) on the new CD6 platform shared with the Lincoln Aviator. The exterior design evolves the Explorer's traditional looks with more modern proportions on a 119.1-inch wheelbase. Engine options include a standard 300 hp 2.3L EcoBoost turbocharged four-cylinder, a 365-400 hp twin-turbo 3.0L EcoBoost V6 in ST and Platinum models, and a hybrid powertrain combining a 3.3L V6 with an electric motor producing 318 hp. All engines are paired with a new Ford 10-speed SelectShift automatic transmission. The interior offers three rows of seating with available captain's chairs in the second row and features a portrait-oriented 10.1-inch touchscreen in higher trims with SYNC 4 technology and a digital instrument cluster. Safety features include Ford's Co-Pilot360 suite of driver assistance technologies with standard automatic emergency braking on 2025+ models. Special variants include the off-road oriented Timberline and performance-focused ST.
Ford-Explorer.name: Sixth Generation

Ford-F-150.description: The ninth-generation F-150 featured more aerodynamic styling while maintaining its traditional truck capabilities. Available in Regular Cab and SuperCab configurations with various bed lengths, it continued Ford's dominance in the full-size pickup segment. Engine options included a 4.9L inline-six, 5.0L V8, and 5.8L V8, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. This generation introduced more comfort and convenience features as trucks began transitioning from purely work vehicles to daily transportation. The interior offered improved ergonomics and available amenities like power windows and locks, while maintaining a functional, durable design. In 1993, the SVT Lightning was introduced as a high-performance street truck variant.
Ford-F-150.name: Ninth Generation

Ford-F-150.description: The tenth-generation F-150 represented a major redesign with a more rounded, aerodynamic styling that proved somewhat controversial with traditional truck buyers. This generation introduced the SuperCrew four-door cab configuration, offering true sedan-like rear doors and passenger space. Engine options evolved to include modular overhead cam designs, with the 4.6L and 5.4L Triton V8s replacing older pushrod engines. The interior was significantly more car-like with improved materials and design. This generation enhanced the F-150's appeal as both a work vehicle and family transportation, though some critics felt it sacrificed some ruggedness in favor of style.
Ford-F-150.name: Tenth Generation

Ford-F-150.description: The eleventh-generation F-150, internally designated P2, returned to a more traditional truck appearance while maintaining modern engineering. The fully boxed frame provided improved rigidity, towing capacity, and payload ratings. Available in Regular Cab, SuperCab, and SuperCrew configurations, it offered various bed lengths and trim levels from basic work truck to the luxury King Ranch. Engine options included 4.2L V6, 4.6L V8, and 5.4L V8 powerplants. The interior offered significantly improved quality and design with materials and features approaching those of luxury vehicles in higher trims. This generation reasserted the F-150's position as the benchmark full-size pickup, balancing capability, comfort, and styling.
Ford-F-150.name: Eleventh Generation

Ford-F-150.description: The twelfth-generation F-150 featured evolutionary styling updates while introducing significant engineering innovations. Most notably, this generation received the efficient and powerful EcoBoost V6 engines, marking a shift away from the traditional V8-dominated truck market. The 3.5L EcoBoost V6 offered V8-like performance with improved fuel economy. Additional engine options included a base 3.7L V6, 5.0L V8, and 6.2L V8. The interior continued to advance in quality and features, with the introduction of SYNC technology and advanced driver information displays. Special models included the off-road Raptor, luxury Platinum, and western-themed King Ranch. This generation successfully transitioned the F-150 into the modern era of technology and efficiency while maintaining traditional truck capabilities.
Ford-F-150.name: Twelfth Generation

Ford-F-150.description: The thirteenth-generation F-150 introduced revolutionary aluminum body construction, reducing weight by up to 700 pounds compared to its predecessor. This ambitious change improved fuel efficiency, payload capacity, and towing capabilities. Engine options expanded to include a 2.7L EcoBoost V6 alongside the existing 3.5L EcoBoost, 5.0L V8, and base V6. Later in the generation, a 3.0L Power Stroke diesel was added. The interior featured improved materials, SYNC 3 infotainment, and available luxury features like massaging seats in higher trims. Innovative features included Pro Trailer Backup Assist, 360-degree cameras, and adaptive cruise control. The high-performance Raptor model continued with enhanced off-road capabilities. This generation cemented the F-150's position as a technology leader in the truck segment while delivering on traditional truck virtues.
Ford-F-150.name: Thirteenth Generation

Ford-F-150.description: The current F-150 maintains aluminum body construction while featuring evolutionary styling updates and significant powertrain innovations. Most notably, it introduced the PowerBoost full hybrid system combining a 3.5L EcoBoost V6 with an electric motor for improved efficiency and performance, plus the ability to function as a mobile power generator with Pro Power Onboard. Additional engine options include 3.3L V6, 2.7L and 3.5L EcoBoost V6s, 5.0L V8, and 3.0L Power Stroke diesel. The interior was completely redesigned with an available 12-inch touchscreen, digital instrument cluster, and innovative features like the Interior Work Surface (fold-down gear shifter and center console work table). Technology advanced with SYNC 4, over-the-air updates, and BlueCruise hands-free driving capability. The Raptor continues as the off-road performance flagship, joined by the Tremor as a more moderate off-road package. This generation advances the F-150's capabilities across all metrics while incorporating advanced technology, comfort, and efficiency features to maintain its position as America's best-selling vehicle.
Ford-F-150.name: Fourteenth Generation

Ford-F-150-Lightning.description: The Ford F-150 Lightning is a battery electric full-size pickup truck unveiled by Ford in May 2021 as part of the fourteenth generation F-Series. Based on the Ford T3 platform, it features dual permanent magnet motors providing all-wheel drive with power outputs of 452 hp for the standard battery and 580 hp for the extended-range battery, both producing 775 lb-ft of torque. Battery options include a 98 kWh usable pack offering an EPA-estimated 240 miles of range and a 131 kWh extended-range pack providing up to 320 miles. Key features include a 400-liter front trunk (frunk) with power outlets, vehicle-to-load capability providing 9.6 kW of export power for home backup or job site use, and advanced driver assistance including BlueCruise hands-free highway driving. Towing capacity reaches 10,000 pounds with a maximum payload of 2,235 pounds. Production occurred at Ford's Rouge Electric Vehicle Center in Dearborn, Michigan, from April 2022 until December 2025 when Ford discontinued the model due to profitability challenges.
Ford-F-150-Lightning.name: First Generation

Ford-F-250.description: First generation Ford Super Duty F-250 pickup truck. Produced January 1998 - 2006 (US). Featured dedicated heavy-duty chassis separate from F-150. Available with 5.4L Triton V8, 6.8L Triton V10, and Power Stroke diesel engines (7.3L 1999-2003, 6.0L 2003-2007).
Ford-F-250.name: First Generation

Ford-F-250.description: Second generation Ford Super Duty F-250 pickup truck. Production December 2006 - February 2010. Featured all-new 6.4L Power Stroke diesel engine, redesigned interior with Ford SYNC availability in 2009, and updated exterior styling. Final year for 6.8L V10 in F-250.
Ford-F-250.name: Second Generation

Ford-F-250.description: Third generation Ford Super Duty F-250 pickup truck. Production October 2010 - March 2016. Featured all-new 6.7L Power Stroke V8 diesel engine, improved towing capacity, and updated interior with MyFord Touch infotainment system. Introduced Platinum trim level in 2013.
Ford-F-250.name: Third Generation

Ford-F-250.description: Fourth generation Ford Super Duty F-250 pickup truck. Production began September 2016 for 2017 model year and continues to present. Features all-aluminum body, second-generation 6.7L Power Stroke diesel with improved output, and new Pro Trailer Backup Assist technology.
Ford-F-250.name: Fourth Generation

Ford-F-350.description: The first-generation Super Duty F-350 established Ford's dedicated heavy-duty truck platform separate from the F-150 line. Available in single rear wheel (SRW) or dual rear wheel (DRW) configurations, and in Regular Cab, SuperCab, or Crew Cab body styles with various bed options, it was designed for maximum capability. The distinctive exterior featured a bold front end with a massive grille and prominent fender flares on DRW models. Engine options included a 5.4L Triton V8, 6.8L Triton V10, and the 7.3L Power Stroke diesel (replaced by a 6.0L Power Stroke in 2003). Transmission choices included manual and automatic options, with four-wheel drive available across the range. The F-350's chassis was significantly reinforced compared to lighter-duty Ford trucks, with heavier suspension components, larger brakes, and a more robust frame. This generation set new standards for heavy-duty truck capability while offering comfort and features that made these work-focused vehicles more practical for everyday use.
Ford-F-350.name: F-Series Super Duty First Generation

Ford-F-350.description: The second-generation Super Duty F-350 featured revised styling with a larger, more prominent grille and enhanced aerodynamics. The fully boxed frame was significantly strengthened, improving towing and payload capacities. Engine options continued with the 5.4L V8 and 6.8L V10 gasoline engines, while the diesel option transitioned to the 6.4L Power Stroke with better emissions control and performance. The interior received notable improvements in design and quality, particularly in higher trim levels such as Lariat and King Ranch. New technology features included an integrated trailer brake controller and updated audio systems with available navigation. Despite its short production run, this generation continued Ford's strong position in the heavy-duty truck market while addressing increasingly stringent emissions requirements for diesel engines.
Ford-F-350.name: F-Series Super Duty Second Generation

Ford-F-350.description: The third-generation Super Duty F-350 introduced Ford's all-new 6.7L Power Stroke diesel engine, designed and manufactured in-house rather than sourced from Navistar. This new diesel offered improved power, torque, and reliability along with better fuel efficiency and quieter operation. Gasoline options evolved to a 6.2L V8 replacing the previous 5.4L V8 and 6.8L V10. The exterior design featured a larger grille and more pronounced styling elements emphasizing its heavy-duty capabilities. The interior continued to advance with improved materials, design, and technology, including SYNC infotainment systems. Towing and payload capacities increased significantly, maintaining Ford's competitive position in the capability-focused heavy-duty segment. Special editions included the luxury-oriented Platinum trim and specialized chassis packages for commercial applications.
Ford-F-350.name: F-Series Super Duty Third Generation

Ford-F-350.description: The fourth-generation Super Duty F-350 adopted aluminum body construction similar to the F-150, reducing weight while allowing for reinvestment in stronger components for improved capability. The fully boxed frame used high-strength steel for increased rigidity and durability. The 6.7L Power Stroke diesel received substantial updates, eventually reaching 475 HP and 1,050 lb-ft of torque in later model years. The 6.2L gasoline V8 continued as the standard engine, with a 7.3L gasoline V8 added in 2020 as a middle option. The interior offered premium appointments in higher trims along with advanced technology including SYNC 3, driver assistance features, and comprehensive towing aids. This generation established new benchmarks for capability while offering unprecedented levels of technology and refinement in the heavy-duty truck segment.
Ford-F-350.name: F-Series Super Duty Fourth Generation

Ford-F-350.description: The current Super Duty F-350 features evolutionary styling updates with functional improvements including enhanced lighting, more convenient bed access, and better aerodynamics. Powertrain options include a standard 6.8L V8 (replacing the 6.2L), optional 7.3L Godzilla V8, updated 6.7L Power Stroke diesel, and a new high-output diesel version producing 500 HP and 1,200 lb-ft of torque. All engines pair with a 10-speed automatic transmission. The strengthened chassis enables class-leading towing and payload capacities, with properly configured F-350 DRW models capable of towing over 35,000 pounds. The interior features significant technology updates including a 12-inch digital instrument cluster, 12-inch center touchscreen with SYNC 4, and a customizable 2-inch productivity screen. Advanced features include Pro Trailer Hitch Assist, trailer navigation, and embedded 5G connectivity. This generation continues the Super Duty tradition of maximum capability while incorporating modern technology to improve productivity, comfort, and safety for both commercial and personal use.
Ford-F-350.name: F-Series Super Duty Fifth Generation

Ford-Fiesta.description: The original Ford Fiesta was developed as a response to the 1973 oil crisis and growing demand for smaller, more fuel-efficient vehicles. Designed under the project name 'Bobcat,' it featured a front-wheel-drive layout with a transverse engine—a first for Ford Europe. Available primarily as a three-door hatchback, it was powered by a range of small displacement four-cylinder engines, from 1.0L to 1.6L depending on the market. The Fiesta quickly became a success across Europe due to its practical design, fuel efficiency, and engaging driving dynamics. While initially not sold in North America, it established the Fiesta nameplate that would become one of Ford's global small car mainstays.
Ford-Fiesta.name: First Generation (Project Bobcat)

Ford-Fiesta.description: The second-generation Fiesta maintained the three-door hatchback format but with a more angular, modern design. The mechanical layout remained similar to its predecessor with updated engines and refinements to the chassis. This generation introduced the high-performance XR2 variant with a 1.6L engine, enhanced suspension, and distinctive styling elements. Interior space and refinement were improved while maintaining the nimble handling that had made the original successful. This generation continued to strengthen the Fiesta's position in Europe's increasingly competitive supermini segment.
Ford-Fiesta.name: Second Generation (MK2)

Ford-Fiesta.description: The third-generation Fiesta featured more aerodynamic styling, improved safety with the availability of ABS brakes and side impact beams, and a more refined overall package. Five-door variants became more common alongside the traditional three-door model. Engine options expanded to include more fuel-efficient units, while the XR2i and RS Turbo versions maintained the Fiesta's performance credentials. This generation saw increased competition in the small car segment but maintained strong sales throughout its lifecycle through continuous updates and special editions.
Ford-Fiesta.name: Third Generation (MK3)

Ford-Fiesta.description: The fourth-generation Fiesta represented an evolutionary approach, refining the formula with improved safety features, better refinement, and updated styling. Available in three and five-door hatchback forms, plus a sedan variant in some markets, it offered a range of petrol and diesel engines. The performance-oriented versions continued with the ST designation replacing previous XR models. Interior quality improved notably, reflecting increasing consumer expectations in the supermini segment. This generation maintained the Fiesta's strong position in Europe while facing increased competition from rivals including the Volkswagen Polo and Opel/Vauxhall Corsa.
Ford-Fiesta.name: Fourth Generation (MK4)

Ford-Fiesta.description: The fifth-generation Fiesta featured more distinctive styling with Ford's 'New Edge' design language. Available primarily as a three or five-door hatchback, it offered improved refinement and driving dynamics. Engine options included a range of Duratec petrol and Duratorq diesel units, with the ST150 version delivering enhanced performance. Safety improved with better crash structures and the wider availability of airbags. Interior design and quality took a step forward, with better materials and available features like automatic climate control on higher trims. This generation maintained the Fiesta's strong sales in Europe and expanded its presence in other global markets.
Ford-Fiesta.name: Fifth Generation (MK5)

Ford-Fiesta.description: The sixth-generation Fiesta represented a significant advancement, with a more premium design, vastly improved interior quality, and sophisticated technology features unusual for the segment. Available globally including in North America, it featured a range of efficient petrol and diesel engines, including Ford's award-winning 1.0L EcoBoost turbocharged three-cylinder. The Fiesta ST performance model gained wide acclaim for its exceptional handling and engaging driving experience. This pre-facelift version featured the original front-end design before the 2013 refresh introduced Ford's trapezoidal grille language.
Ford-Fiesta.name: Sixth Generation (MK6)

Ford-Fiesta.description: The facelifted sixth-generation Fiesta went on sale in 2013 following its debut at the Paris Motor Show. It was the first to use Ford's new corporate front end featuring the trapezoidal grille, giving the vehicle a more mature and distinctive appearance. The interior received updates including the SYNC infotainment system with voice control and AppLink. Engine choices continued to center on the efficient 1.0L EcoBoost in various power outputs alongside diesel options. This facelift version maintained the Fiesta's critical acclaim and commercial success, becoming the UK's best-selling car for multiple consecutive years.
Ford-Fiesta.name: Sixth Generation (MK6 Facelift)

Ford-Fiesta.description: The final Fiesta generation evolved the successful formula with more mature styling, improved refinement, and enhanced technology. Available in three and five-door configurations plus crossover-inspired Active variants, it offered a wide range of customization options. Powertrain options continued to center around the 1.0L EcoBoost in various power outputs, plus diesel options in some markets. The interior made a significant leap with available features including an 8-inch touchscreen, B&O premium audio, and advanced driver assistance systems. The ST version continued as a performance benchmark in its class. Despite its critical acclaim and continued popularity in Europe, changing market demands toward SUVs and Ford's strategic shifts led to the decision to end Fiesta production in 2023 after 47 years, marking the conclusion of one of Ford's most significant global nameplates.
Ford-Fiesta.name: Seventh Generation (MK7)

Ford-Five-Hundred.description: The Ford Five Hundred was a full-size sedan introduced as a replacement for the Ford Taurus in Ford's lineup, though the Taurus name would later be revived and applied to an updated version of this very model. Built on Ford's D3 platform shared with the Volvo S80 and derived from Volvo's P2 architecture (reflecting Ford's ownership of Volvo at the time), it featured a front-wheel drive layout with optional all-wheel drive. Powered exclusively by a 3.0L Duratec V6 engine producing 203 HP, paired with either a six-speed automatic or continuously variable transmission (CVT), it prioritized fuel efficiency and interior space over performance. The exterior design was conservative with European influence, featuring a high seating position that Ford marketed as 'Command Seating' providing SUV-like visibility. The interior was notably spacious with best-in-class trunk capacity and generous rear seat room. Safety was emphasized with available features including stability control, anti-lock brakes, and optional side and curtain airbags. Production ran from July 2004 to April 2007 for model years 2005–2007. After three model years, the vehicle was significantly refreshed and renamed Taurus for the 2008 model year, ending the brief history of the Five Hundred nameplate in North America.
Ford-Five-Hundred.name: First Generation

Ford-Flex.description: The Ford Flex debuted as an all-new full-size crossover SUV with distinctive boxy, retro-modern styling inspired by the 2005 Fairlane concept. Built on Ford's D4 platform shared with the Lincoln MKT and sharing its unibody construction with the Ford Edge, the Flex offered three-row seating for up to seven passengers with exceptional interior space and cargo flexibility. Initial models featured a 3.5L Duratec V6 producing 262 horsepower paired with a six-speed automatic transmission. In 2010, Ford introduced the powerful twin-turbocharged 3.5L EcoBoost V6 option producing 355 horsepower, transforming the Flex into a surprisingly quick family hauler. Available in SE, SEL, and Limited trim levels, with front-wheel drive standard and all-wheel drive optional on SEL and Limited trims. The special Titanium edition was offered in 2011-2012, featuring blacked-out exterior styling elements including headlights, taillights, grille, and trim, along with unique Alcantara suede and leather interior appointments and exclusive colors. Notable features included available refrigerated second-row console, Sony premium audio, panoramic vista roof with MyFord Touch controls, and innovative storage solutions throughout the cabin.
Ford-Flex.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Ford-Flex.description: The 2013 model year brought a comprehensive mid-cycle refresh to the Ford Flex with a bold new face featuring the word 'FLEX' spelled across the hood brow, a single-bar upper grille design replacing the traditional Ford blue oval and three-bar grille, and redesigned headlights. The interior received significant updates including new instrument clusters, steering wheel, seats with improved foam and trim, and the latest MyFord Touch infotainment system with dual 4.2-inch instrument cluster displays and an 8-inch center touchscreen. Mechanical improvements included a more powerful base 3.5L V6 (287 horsepower, up from 262), electric power-assisted steering replacing the hydraulic system, larger front brake rotors, retuned suspension, and paddle shifters mounted on the steering wheel. The EcoBoost V6 was upgraded to 365 horsepower and became exclusively available on the Limited trim with premium equipment packages. New technology features included adaptive cruise control, active park assist, blind-spot monitoring with cross-traffic alert, inflatable rear seatbelts, ventilated front seats, and keyless ignition with push-button start. Production continued through 2019 with minimal changes in later years, as Ford shifted focus toward SUVs and away from car-based crossovers. The Flex's discontinuation marked the end of one of Ford's most distinctive and functional people movers, with its combination of retro styling, exceptional interior space, and surprising performance capability earning it a devoted following.
Ford-Flex.name: First Generation (Post-Facelift)

Ford-Focus.description: The original Ford Focus was introduced by Ford of Europe in 1998 as a replacement for the Escort, winning the 1999 European Car of the Year award. The Focus Mk 1 was available in three-door hatchback, four-door sedan, five-door estate (wagon), and five-door hatchback (from 2001) body styles. Ford of North America began marketing the Focus in September 1999 for the 2000 model year with market-specific modifications including different engines (2.0L Zetec and 2.0L/2.3L Duratec four-cylinders). A significant facelift (Mk1.5) was introduced in late 2001 featuring revised headlamps with integrated indicators, revised bumpers and grille, optional Xenon headlights, new interior trim options, and the introduction of the TDCi diesel engine. The sporty SVT Focus variant featured enhanced performance with a higher-output engine, improved suspension, and distinctive styling. The car was praised for its engaging handling and practical packaging. In 2002, the high-performance Focus RS was launched with a 2.0L turbocharged Duratec engine and was produced in limited numbers (4,501 units between 2002-2003) at the Saarlouis plant in Germany.
Ford-Focus.name: First Generation (C170; 1998)

Ford-Focus.description: The second-generation Focus had two distinct development paths. In Europe (C307), it was launched at the 2004 Paris Motor Show as a replacement for the Mk 1, available as three and five-door hatchback and estate, with a sedan added mid-2005. It featured the same basic suspension design from Mk 1 but with a stiffer bodyshell, was larger and heavier than its predecessor, and introduced new technologies including KeyFree system, solar-reflect windshield, and Bluetooth connectivity. A two-door coupé-cabriolet with retractable hardtop was added in 2007. The Focus ST debuted in 2005 with a 2.5L turbocharged five-cylinder Volvo engine producing 225 bhp. A facelift in 2007-2008 introduced Ford's Kinetic Design philosophy with a new bonnet with more creases, removal of door mouldings, sculpted pull-back headlights, and the signature trapezoidal lower grille. In 2009, the Focus RS returned with an updated 2.5L engine. For North America (C170 platform), a restyled 2008-2011 generation was introduced, available only as coupe and sedan with hatchbacks and wagons discontinued. The North American version never officially used the 'second generation' designation since it shared the same platform as Mk 1.
Ford-Focus.name: Second Generation (C307/C170; 2004)

Ford-Focus.description: The third-generation Focus represented Ford's 'One Ford' global product strategy, reuniting international and North American models. Production began in late 2010 at the Saarlouis plant in Germany, with launch in early 2011 simultaneously in North America and Europe. The previous North American version was discontinued in favor of this global platform. Available in sedan, hatchback, and wagon body styles, it featured more expressive styling and significantly improved interior quality. Powertrain options varied by market but typically included a range of efficient four-cylinder engines, including the innovative 1.0L EcoBoost three-cylinder. The high-performance ST model offered performance variants, while the RS returned in 2015 with a 2.3L EcoBoost engine and advanced all-wheel drive system that could send full power to the rear wheels. A significant facelift was previewed at the 2014 Geneva Motor Show, featuring a redesigned front end with Ford's new family grille and slimline headlights. The interior showcased improved materials and technology including SYNC 3 infotainment and later MyFord Touch systems. This generation successfully positioned the Focus as a more premium offering in the compact segment with class-leading driving dynamics.
Ford-Focus.name: Third Generation (C346; 2010)

Ford-Focus.description: The fourth-generation Focus was unveiled on April 10, 2018, to mark the brand's 20th anniversary, with European and Asian-market versions. The model is available in sedan, hatchback, and estate body styles, with a crossover-inspired 'Active' trim level available for hatchback and estate, and a 'Vignale' luxury trim level. The exterior features a sportier design while the interior is described by Ford as simpler and more minimalist with a floating touchscreen. Technology includes SYNC 3 or SYNC 4 infotainment systems, FordPass Connect, and the CoPilot360 driver assistance suite. In April 2018, Ford announced plans to discontinue all passenger vehicles except the Mustang in the North American market to focus on trucks and SUVs. The Focus Active was intended as the only version for North America, but Ford cancelled these plans in August 2018 due to tariffs on Chinese exports. The car features efficient EcoBoost petrol and EcoBlue diesel engines by market. No fourth-generation RS model was developed due to emissions standards and high development costs. A facelift was introduced in October 2021 for the European market, featuring updated styling and enhanced technology features. In 2022, Ford announced it would discontinue the Focus by 2025 as part of a pivot toward crossover vehicles and electrification. Production officially ended in November 2025 at the Saarlouis plant in Germany.
Ford-Focus.name: Fourth Generation (C519; 2018)

Ford-Focus-RS.description: The original Ford Focus RS was a limited-production, high-performance variant of the first-generation European Focus. Powered by a turbocharged 2.0L Duratec RS engine producing 212 HP and 229 lb-ft of torque, it featured a Quaife limited-slip differential to help manage torque steer through its front-wheel drive layout. The exterior was distinguished by aggressive styling with a wider track, unique front bumper with larger air intakes, rear spoiler, and blue paint as the only color option. The interior featured Sparco bucket seats, blue accents, and a unique instrument cluster. Handling was enhanced through a substantially upgraded suspension with stiffer springs, revised geometry, and larger anti-roll bars. Limited to approximately 4,500 units and never officially sold in North America, the first-generation RS established the nameplate's reputation for hardcore performance within the hot hatch segment.
Ford-Focus-RS.name: First Generation

Ford-Focus-RS.description: The second-generation Focus RS was based on the European second-generation Focus platform and featured a turbocharged 2.5L five-cylinder engine derived from Volvo, producing 301 HP and 325 lb-ft of torque. Like its predecessor, it remained front-wheel drive but utilized an innovative 'RevoKnuckle' front suspension designed to mitigate torque steer and a Quaife limited-slip differential. The aggressive exterior styling included a prominent rear wing, wide body kit, and large front air intakes, available in a wider range of colors including the signature Ultimate Green. The interior featured heavily bolstered Recaro seats, carbon fiber accents, and RS-specific gauges. With 0-60 mph acceleration in 5.9 seconds and enhanced handling through comprehensive chassis upgrades, this generation further cemented the RS as an extreme performance variant of the Focus. Production was limited to around 11,500 units, with no official North American sales.
Ford-Focus-RS.name: Second Generation

Ford-Focus-RS.description: The third-generation Focus RS represented the model's global debut, including its first official availability in North America. Built on the third-generation Focus platform, it featured a significant technical advancement with a sophisticated all-wheel drive system capable of torque vectoring across the rear axle, allowing for controlled drifts in its famous 'Drift Mode.' Powered by a turbocharged 2.3L EcoBoost four-cylinder engine producing 350 HP and 350 lb-ft of torque (with temporary overboost to 347 lb-ft), it was exclusively offered with a six-speed manual transmission. Performance was impressive with 0-60 mph acceleration in 4.7 seconds and a top speed of 165 mph. The exterior featured aggressive styling with a large rear wing, prominent diffuser, and unique front fascia, available in colors including the distinctive Nitrous Blue. The interior included heavily bolstered Recaro seats, blue accent stitching, and additional gauges. Handling was enhanced through adjustable dampers, Michelin Pilot Super Sport tires, and Brembo brakes. A special limited-edition RS500 model concluded production in 2018, featuring unique styling elements and mechanical upgrades. The third-generation RS garnered critical acclaim for its combination of everyday usability with exceptional performance capabilities, representing the ultimate expression of the Focus platform before the fourth-generation Focus moved away from the high-performance RS variant.
Ford-Focus-RS.name: Third Generation

Ford-Focus-ST.description: The original Focus ST, known as the ST170 in Europe and SVT Focus in North America, was Ford's first global performance variant of the Focus. Powered by a specially-tuned 2.0L Zetec engine producing 170 PS (168 HP) in European form and 170 HP in North American specification, it featured a 6-speed Getrag manual transmission. Chassis upgrades included stiffer suspension, larger brakes, and 17-inch wheels. Visual distinctions included unique front and rear bumpers, side skirts, and interior appointments including Recaro seats in some markets. This generation established the ST as a more accessible performance model positioned below the hardcore RS, offering enhanced driving dynamics and sportier styling while maintaining everyday practicality.
Ford-Focus-ST.name: First Generation (European MK1/MK2 ST170/SVT)

Ford-Focus-ST.description: The second-generation Focus ST was initially a European-only model based on the second-generation Focus platform. Powered by a turbocharged 2.5L five-cylinder Volvo-derived engine producing 225 HP and 236 lb-ft of torque, it offered significantly enhanced performance over the previous ST170. Available in three-door, five-door, and estate (wagon) body styles, it featured sportier suspension tuning, larger brakes, and a unique bodykit. The distinctive engine note became a hallmark of this generation. The interior included Recaro sports seats, a three-spoke leather steering wheel, and additional gauges. This generation established the ST as a serious contender in the hot hatch segment, offering an appealing blend of performance, practicality, and distinctive character.
Ford-Focus-ST.name: Second Generation (European MK2 ST)

Ford-Focus-ST.description: The third-generation Focus ST became a global model as part of Ford's 'One Ford' strategy, available in North America, Europe, and other markets. Powered by a 2.0L EcoBoost turbocharged four-cylinder engine producing 252 HP and 270 lb-ft of torque, it was offered in both hatchback and estate (wagon) body styles in Europe, but only as a hatchback in North America. Performance features included torque vectoring control, a sport-tuned suspension, and variable-ratio steering. Visually distinguished by aggressive body styling, 18-inch wheels, and a center-exit exhaust, it also featured Recaro seats and ST-specific interior trim. A diesel option with a 2.0L TDCi engine producing 185 HP was added for European markets in 2014. This generation successfully balanced everyday usability with engaging performance, establishing the ST as Ford's global hot hatch.
Ford-Focus-ST.name: Third Generation (Global)

Ford-Focus-ST.description: The current Focus ST is based on the fourth-generation Focus platform, featuring a 2.3L EcoBoost turbocharged four-cylinder engine producing 280 HP and 310 lb-ft of torque in petrol form. For the first time, the ST offers a choice between a 6-speed manual and a 7-speed automatic transmission. A diesel option continues in European markets with a 2.0L EcoBlue engine producing 190 HP. Available in five-door hatchback and estate body styles, it features an electronic limited-slip differential, continuously controlled damping, and selectable drive modes. Visually distinguished by unique bumpers, a rear spoiler, and 19-inch wheels, the interior includes heavily bolstered Recaro seats, a flat-bottom steering wheel, and ST-specific digital displays. Despite Ford's discontinuation of most car models in North America, the fourth-generation ST remains a core performance model in European and other markets, offering a sophisticated driving experience with increased technology while maintaining the engaging character that defines the ST brand.
Ford-Focus-ST.name: Fourth Generation

Ford-Fusion.description: The original North American Ford Fusion was a mid-size sedan designed to replace the aging Taurus in Ford's lineup. Built on the Mazda-derived CD3 platform shared with the Mercury Milan and Lincoln MKZ, it featured conservative but clean styling with a distinctive three-bar grille. Initially offered with a 2.3L four-cylinder or 3.0L V6 engine, a Sport model with a 3.5L V6 was added later in the generation. Transmission options included a five-speed manual and five or six-speed automatics. The interior was spacious and functional, with an emphasis on quality materials and good ergonomics. A significant refresh in 2010 updated the styling, powertrain efficiency, and technology features. This generation established the Fusion as a solid competitor in the mid-size sedan segment, known for balanced handling, good build quality, and value.
Ford-Fusion.name: First Generation (North America)

Ford-Fusion.description: The redesigned Fusion represented a dramatic shift in design philosophy, featuring sleek, European-inspired styling often compared to Aston Martin. Built on Ford's CD4 global platform, it offered a wider range of powertrains including naturally aspirated and turbocharged EcoBoost four-cylinder engines, a V6 Sport model with a twin-turbo 2.7L EcoBoost producing 325 HP, and hybrid/plug-in hybrid variants. Available with front or all-wheel drive, it emphasized both efficiency and performance. The interior featured a modern design with improved materials and technology, including the SYNC infotainment system and later SYNC 3. A refresh in 2017 updated the styling and added enhanced safety features through Ford Co-Pilot360. This generation elevated the Fusion's status, competing effectively with class leaders like the Honda Accord and Toyota Camry by offering advanced technology, engaging driving dynamics, and upscale design. Despite strong critical reception, changing consumer preferences toward SUVs led to Ford's decision to discontinue the Fusion after 2020 as part of a broader shift away from traditional passenger cars in North America.
Ford-Fusion.name: Second Generation

Ford-Fusion-Energi.description: The Ford Fusion Energi was a plug-in hybrid variant of the second-generation Fusion sedan. Based on the same CD4 platform as the standard Fusion, it combined a 2.0L Atkinson cycle four-cylinder engine with an electric motor and lithium-ion battery pack. The total system output was 188 HP, delivered through a continuously variable transmission (CVT) to the front wheels. The initial 7.6 kWh battery provided approximately 21 miles of electric-only range, later improved to 25 miles with a 9.0 kWh battery introduced in the 2019 model year. Charging took approximately 2.5 hours using a Level 2 (240V) charger or 7 hours with a standard 120V outlet. The Energi featured unique instrument cluster displays to monitor hybrid operation and energy usage, with selectable EV modes allowing drivers to choose when to use electric power. Visually similar to the standard Fusion except for charge port and badging, it maintained the sleek styling and comfortable interior of its conventional counterpart, though trunk space was reduced by the battery placement. Available in SE and Titanium (later Platinum) trim levels, it offered upscale features including leather seating, SYNC infotainment, and active safety technology. The Fusion Energi represented Ford's early commitment to electrification in mainstream vehicles, offering a balance of efficiency and practicality in a familiar package. Production ended alongside other Fusion models in 2020 as Ford shifted focus toward SUVs and fully electric vehicles.
Ford-Fusion-Energi.name: First Generation

Ford-Fusion-Hybrid.description: The original Ford Fusion Hybrid was based on the first-generation Fusion, introduced as part of the mid-cycle refresh. Utilizing a powertrain similar to the Escape Hybrid, it combined a 2.5L Atkinson cycle four-cylinder engine with an electric motor and nickel-metal hydride battery for a combined output of 191 HP. The system could operate in electric-only mode up to 47 mph, contributing to its impressive EPA ratings of 41 mpg city and 36 mpg highway—class-leading figures at the time. The Fusion Hybrid featured a unique instrument cluster called SmartGauge with EcoGuide, using dual LCD displays flanking an analog speedometer to provide customizable information about the hybrid system's operation and coaching for maximizing efficiency. Visually distinguished by specific badges and unique wheels, it maintained the refreshed styling of the standard Fusion. This generation established the Fusion Hybrid as a strong competitor in the mid-size hybrid sedan segment, offering better driving dynamics than most competitors while delivering excellent fuel economy.
Ford-Fusion-Hybrid.name: First Generation

Ford-Fusion-Hybrid.description: The second-generation Fusion Hybrid was completely redesigned alongside the conventional Fusion, featuring the sleek, European-inspired styling that characterized the platform. The hybrid powertrain evolved to combine a 2.0L Atkinson cycle four-cylinder engine with an electric motor and a more compact, lighter lithium-ion battery pack replacing the previous nickel-metal hydride unit. Total system output was 188 HP, delivered through a continuously variable transmission to the front wheels. Fuel economy improved to an EPA-rated 44 mpg city, 41 mpg highway. The SmartGauge instrument cluster was enhanced with more detailed information and coaching features. For 2017, the Fusion Hybrid received a midcycle refresh with updated styling, enhanced technology features including SYNC 3, and the addition of the premium Platinum trim level offering luxury appointments like quilted leather seating. Throughout its production, the second-generation Fusion Hybrid maintained a reputation for combining excellent fuel economy with engaging handling and premium features, differentiating it from competitors that often sacrificed driving dynamics for efficiency. Production ended in 2020 alongside other Fusion models as Ford shifted its product strategy toward SUVs and fully electric vehicles.
Ford-Fusion-Hybrid.name: Second Generation

Ford-Ka.description: The original Ford Ka was a revolutionary small city car designed by Claude Lobo and Chris Svensson, featuring distinctive 'New Edge' styling with unusual circular headlamps. Built on a shortened Mark 3 Ford Fiesta platform (BE146), it was characterized by compact dimensions (approximately 3.6 meters long) and light weight. Powered primarily by a 1.3L Endura-E engine with 60 HP, it emphasized fun handling over straight-line performance. The minimalist interior featured exposed painted metal and unique circular design elements. Body styles included a 3-door hatchback, 2-door convertible (StreetKa built by Pininfarina), and a 3-door van. Special editions like SportKa (2005-2008) added performance variants. Production ended in 2008 after a 12-year run, with over 1.4 million units produced across Spain (Almussafes), Brazil (São Bernardo do Campo), and Italy.
Ford-Ka.name: First Generation (BE146)

Ford-Ka.description: The European second-generation Ka was developed and built by Fiat in Tychy, Poland, sharing the Fiat 500/Panda platform. Unlike its predecessor, it featured more conventional styling with a 3-door hatchback body style. Engine options included a 1.2L Duratec petrol (69 PS, 102 Nm) and a 1.3L Duratorq diesel (75 PS, 145 Nm), both Fiat-sourced with CO2 emissions under 120 g/km. Interior featured improved materials with optional Bluetooth, USB port, and voice control. The suspension was retuned from the Fiat 500 with a rear antiroll bar for improved ride quality. Ford Individual packages (Tattoo/Grand Prix/Digital) offered customization options. Production ended May 20, 2016.
Ford-Ka.name: Second Generation - European (B420)

Ford-Ka.description: The Latin American second-generation Ka was a separate model developed and built in Brazil (São Bernardo do Campo), based on the first-generation Ka chassis with redesigned exterior using Ford's 'Kinetic Design' language. Longer than the European version at 3836mm, it competed in the subcompact class with a redesigned rear seat accommodating five passengers. Engines were 1.0L and 1.6L Zetec Rocam flex-fuel four-cylinder engines. A mid-cycle facelift was introduced in 2011 following the Kinect concept car. Unlike the European version, this model was not sold in Mexico.
Ford-Ka.name: Second Generation - Latin American (B402)

Ford-Ka.description: The third-generation Ka was developed by Ford Brazil as a global B-segment model, marketed in Europe as 'Ka+' to distinguish it from previous city car generations. Built on Ford's global B-car platform (shared with Fiesta), it was significantly larger at 3886-3929mm with a 2491mm wheelbase. Available as 5-door hatchback and 4-door sedan (Aspire in India). European models featured a 1.2L Ti-VCT engine (70-85 PS). The range was expanded to include the Ka+ Active crossover variant in 2018 with raised ride height and body cladding. Production in Europe ended September 2019, while Brazilian production continued until January 2021.
Ford-Ka.name: Third Generation

Ford-Kuga.description: The original Ford Kuga was a compact crossover SUV designed primarily for the European market. Built on Ford's C1 platform shared with the Focus and C-MAX, it featured sporty styling that helped differentiate it from more utilitarian competitors. Initially available with a 2.0L Duratorq diesel engine and later a 2.5L Duratec petrol, most models featured an intelligent all-wheel-drive system that could transfer torque between front and rear axles as needed. The interior offered a driver-focused cockpit with higher quality materials than many competitors. The Kuga emphasized on-road handling and driving dynamics over serious off-road capability, establishing it as one of the more enjoyable-to-drive vehicles in its segment. This generation was not sold in North America, where the similar but not identical Escape continued as Ford's compact SUV offering.
Ford-Kuga.name: First Generation

Ford-Kuga.description: The second-generation Kuga became a global model as part of Ford's 'One Ford' strategy, sold as the Escape in North America. Built on Ford's Global C platform, it featured more modern styling with improved aerodynamics and a more upscale appearance. Engine options varied by market but typically included EcoBoost petrol engines and Duratorq diesels with improved efficiency. Available technology expanded significantly to include SYNC with MyFord Touch (later SYNC 3), active park assist, and advanced safety features. This generation introduced the hands-free power liftgate activated by a foot motion under the rear bumper. Interior space improved with more room for passengers and cargo, while maintaining good driving dynamics. A significant facelift in 2016 updated the styling and technology offerings. As a global model, this generation successfully balanced the needs of different markets while maintaining the Kuga's reputation for driving enjoyment in the increasingly competitive compact SUV segment.
Ford-Kuga.name: Second Generation

Ford-Kuga.description: The current Kuga (continuing as Escape in North America) features a complete redesign with more car-like styling cues and significantly improved aerodynamics. Built on Ford's C2 platform shared with the Focus, it emphasizes improved driving dynamics and efficiency. Engine options vary by market but include EcoBoost petrol engines, EcoBlue diesels, and for the first time, hybrid and plug-in hybrid powertrains. The PHEV variant offers approximately 31 miles of electric-only range from its 14.4 kWh battery. The interior represents a major step forward with improved materials, a digital instrument cluster, and an 8-inch touchscreen running SYNC 4. Available driver assistance technology expanded to include Ford Co-Pilot360 with features like adaptive cruise control with lane centering. Despite its more car-like appearance, cargo space and practicality have improved over the previous generation. This generation balances efficiency, technology, and driving dynamics while offering multiple electrification options to meet increasingly strict emissions regulations.
Ford-Kuga.name: Third Generation

Ford-Maverick.description: The Ford Maverick is a compact pickup truck built on Ford's C2 platform shared with the Escape and Bronco Sport crossovers, representing the brand's return to the compact truck segment. Production began September 2, 2021 at Ford's Hermosillo Assembly plant in Mexico for the 2022 model year. The exterior design features boxy, purposeful styling with a relatively upright profile, creating a truck appearance despite its unibody construction. Standard power comes from a hybrid powertrain combining a 2.5L Atkinson-cycle four-cylinder engine with an electric motor for a combined 191 HP, delivering an EPA-estimated 42 mpg city—making it the most fuel-efficient pickup in America. An optional 2.0L EcoBoost turbocharged four-cylinder produces 250 HP and is available with all-wheel drive (AWD added to hybrid option for 2025). The Maverick features a 4.5-foot bed with innovative storage solutions and Ford's FLEXBED system that allows for DIY customization through slots and attachment points. The interior maintains a practical, rugged design with standard features including an 8-inch touchscreen (upgraded to 13.2-inch SYNC 4 for 2025) with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. The Maverick's maximum payload capacity of 1,500 pounds and towing capacity of up to 4,000 pounds (with the EcoBoost and tow package) make it practical for light-duty truck needs. Trim levels include XL, XLT, and Lariat, with the FX4 Off-Road Package available on all-wheel drive models. The Tremor Off-Road Package (became standalone trim in 2025) enhances capability with a twin-clutch rear differential, suspension lift, and additional terrain management modes. A 2025 refresh introduced the Lobo sport trim with lowered suspension, torque vectoring, and unique exterior styling. The Maverick has been a remarkable success for Ford, appealing to both traditional truck buyers seeking a more manageable size and efficiency-minded customers who previously wouldn't have considered a pickup.
Ford-Maverick.name: First Generation (Compact Pickup)

Ford-Mondeo.description: First generation Mondeo introduced November 1992, sales began March 1993. Replaced Ford Sierra in Europe and Ford Telstar in Asia. Front-wheel drive with optional four-wheel drive on Mk I only. Three body styles: saloon, liftback, and estate.
Ford-Mondeo.name: First Generation

Ford-Mondeo.description: Mid-cycle facelift launched October 1996. Only the doors, roof, and rear quarter panels on estate remained unchanged from original model.
Ford-Mondeo.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Ford-Mondeo.description: Second generation introduced October 2000. Larger than predecessor while maintaining CDW27 platform and suspension design. Abandoned New Edge design theme for Prodigy concept-based styling.
Ford-Mondeo.name: Second Generation

Ford-Mondeo.description: Third generation introduced late 2006. Based on EUCD platform developed with Volvo, shared with Galaxy and S-MAX MPVs. Design theme from Iosis concept shown at 2005 Frankfurt Motor Show.
Ford-Mondeo.name: Third Generation

Ford-Mondeo.description: Mid-cycle facelift introduced September 2010. Added new EcoBoost engines, LED daytime running lights, and Kinetic Design front/rear updates with improved interior materials.
Ford-Mondeo.name: Third Generation (Facelift)

Ford-Mondeo.description: Fourth generation presented at 2012 Detroit Auto Show. Global platform shared with Ford Fusion marketed in Americas. Production ended March 2022 at Valencia plant as buyer interest shifted to crossovers and SUVs.
Ford-Mondeo.name: Fourth Generation

Ford-Mondeo.description: Fifth generation released in China January 2022. Designed, built, and sold exclusively in China. Not marketed in Europe or North America. Marketed in Middle East as Ford Taurus.
Ford-Mondeo.name: Fifth Generation

Ford-Mustang.description: The original Mustang created the 'pony car' segment with its long hood, short deck proportions and affordable pricing. Available as a coupe, convertible, and fastback, it broke sales records with over 400,000 units sold in its first year. Initially based on the Ford Falcon platform, it offered a range of inline-six and V8 engines. The Mustang evolved significantly during this generation, growing larger and more powerful with performance variants including the Shelby GT350/GT500, Mach 1, and Boss 302/429. This generation established the Mustang as an American icon and defined characteristics that would influence all subsequent versions.
Ford-Mustang.name: First Generation

Ford-Mustang.description: The Mustang II was a dramatic downsizing in response to the 1973 oil crisis, based on the Ford Pinto platform. Available as a notchback coupe and fastback (hatchback), it initially offered only four-cylinder and V6 engines, with a V8 returning in 1975. Despite criticism from enthusiasts for its reduced performance, the Mustang II was commercially successful, meeting consumer demands for smaller, more efficient vehicles while retaining Mustang styling cues. Special editions included the King Cobra and Cobra II, which offered appearance packages inspired by performance Mustangs of the past.
Ford-Mustang.name: Second Generation (Mustang II)

Ford-Mustang.description: The Fox Body Mustang represented a complete redesign on Ford's Fox platform with a more angular, contemporary design. Available in coupe, hatchback, and briefly convertible body styles, it evolved substantially over its 14-year production run. Early models offered inline-four, inline-six, and V8 engines, eventually consolidating around the 5.0L V8 that became synonymous with this generation. Performance gradually returned with the Cobra, GT, and SVO variants, while special editions like the Saleen and Roush offered enhanced performance and exclusivity. The long production run and extensive aftermarket support have made the Fox Body a favorite among enthusiasts and modifiers.
Ford-Mustang.name: Third Generation (Fox Body)

Ford-Mustang.description: The fourth-generation Mustang returned to more traditional styling cues while remaining on an updated Fox platform. Available as coupe and convertible, it initially featured a 3.8L V6 or 5.0L V8, with the latter replaced by a 4.6L modular V8 in 1996. A significant styling update in 1999 (New Edge) brought sharper, more aggressive design elements. Performance variants included the Cobra with independent rear suspension, the track-focused Cobra R, and the Bullitt special edition paying homage to the famous movie car. This generation maintained the Mustang's popularity during a period when many competitors discontinued their pony cars.
Ford-Mustang.name: Fourth Generation (SN-95/New Edge)

Ford-Mustang.description: The S197 Mustang featured retro-inspired styling that strongly referenced the original 1964-1968 models, while incorporating modern engineering. Built on a dedicated platform, it offered improved handling and refinement. Base models featured a 4.0L V6 (later a 3.7L) with GT models powered by 4.6L and later 5.0L 'Coyote' V8 engines. The Shelby GT500 returned as the high-performance flagship with a supercharged engine eventually producing 662 HP. Special editions included the Boss 302, Bullitt, and various commemorative models celebrating Mustang heritage. This generation successfully revitalized the Mustang's iconic status while delivering modern performance and features.
Ford-Mustang.name: Fifth Generation (S197)

Ford-Mustang.description: The sixth-generation Mustang maintained retro-inspired styling while adopting more contemporary design elements and significantly improved engineering. Major innovations included independent rear suspension across all models and the introduction of a turbocharged four-cylinder EcoBoost engine alongside the traditional V6 (discontinued after 2017) and 5.0L V8. The interior featured higher quality materials and advanced technology including SYNC infotainment systems. Performance variants expanded to include the Shelby GT350 with a flat-plane crank 5.2L V8, the supercharged Shelby GT500 with 760 HP, and the track-focused Mach 1. A significant refresh in 2018 updated the styling and introduced advanced driver assistance features. This generation successfully broadened the Mustang's appeal globally while maintaining its performance credentials.
Ford-Mustang.name: Sixth Generation (S550)

Ford-Mustang.description: The latest Mustang features evolutionary exterior styling that maintains continuity with its predecessor while incorporating more aggressive elements, particularly in GT models. Built on an updated version of the S550 platform, it continues with the 2.3L EcoBoost four-cylinder and 5.0L Coyote V8 engines, both receiving significant updates for improved performance. The interior represents a major advancement with a fighter jet-inspired cockpit featuring a 12.4-inch digital instrument cluster that can be configured to a simplified view reminiscent of Fox Body Mustangs, and a 13.2-inch SYNC 4 touchscreen. New features include Remote Rev (allowing engine revving via key fob) and an electronic drift brake for the Performance Pack. The lineup includes the track-focused Dark Horse model with a specially tuned 500 HP version of the 5.0L V8. As competitors have discontinued their pony cars, the seventh-generation Mustang stands as the last traditional American sports car with internal combustion power, maintaining the legacy of accessible performance that has defined the nameplate for 60 years.
Ford-Mustang.name: Seventh Generation (S650)

Ford-Mustang-Mach-E.description: The Ford Mustang Mach-E is the brand's first purpose-built electric vehicle, controversially extending the Mustang nameplate to a four-door crossover SUV. Built on a dedicated EV platform, it features distinctive styling that incorporates Mustang design cues including tri-bar taillights, a long hood proportion, and aggressive headlights, while adapting them to a crossover silhouette. Available with standard or extended-range battery options (approximately 70 kWh and 91 kWh usable capacity), and in rear-wheel or all-wheel drive configurations, the lineup spans from the entry-level Select to the performance-oriented GT, with various trims including Premium and California Route 1 in between. Power outputs range from 266 HP in the base RWD model to 480 HP in the GT Performance Edition, with the latter capable of 0-60 mph acceleration in 3.5 seconds. Range varies by configuration, reaching up to 312 miles EPA-estimated in the most efficient variants. The interior showcases Ford's next-generation technology, featuring a minimalist dashboard dominated by a 15.5-inch vertical touchscreen running SYNC 4A with over-the-air update capability, and a 10.2-inch digital instrument cluster. A notable innovation is the absence of traditional door handles, replaced by electronic buttons with small emergency pull handles, and a phone-as-key feature. Charging capabilities include support for up to 150 kW DC fast charging, allowing a 10-80% charge in approximately 45 minutes. The Mach-E features Ford's BlueCruise hands-free driving system on equipped highways, and a comprehensive suite of driver assistance technologies. Since its introduction, Ford has made continuous improvements through over-the-air updates and yearly model changes, enhancing charging speeds, range, and performance while adding features. The Mach-E represents Ford's strategy to leverage its iconic nameplate while transitioning to an electric future, offering a balance of performance, practicality, and technology that competes directly with vehicles like the Tesla Model Y.
Ford-Mustang-Mach-E.name: First Generation

Ford-Puma.description: The original Ford Puma was a small sport compact coupe based on the fourth-generation Fiesta platform. Designed by Ian Callum, it featured distinctive styling with bulbous headlights and flowing curves that set it apart from its contemporaries. Primarily powered by a series of Yamaha-developed 1.4L, 1.6L, and 1.7L Zetec-SE engines producing between 90 and 155 HP, it emphasized handling and driving enjoyment over outright power. The limited-production Racing Puma, developed by Ford's Special Vehicle Engineering division, featured widened bodywork, Alcon brakes, a revised suspension, and a 155 HP 1.7L engine. The interior was driver-focused with supportive seats and a sporty instrument cluster. Despite its relatively short production run, the original Puma gained cult status among enthusiasts for its exceptional handling, distinctive design, and character, with approximately 133,000 units produced exclusively for European markets.
Ford-Puma.name: First Generation (Sport Compact)

Ford-Puma.description: The current Puma revived the nameplate for a completely different vehicle type—a subcompact crossover SUV based on the seventh-generation Fiesta platform. The exterior design incorporates some styling cues recalling the original Puma, particularly in the canoe-shaped headlights, but with a higher-riding crossover profile. Powered primarily by Ford's 1.0L EcoBoost three-cylinder engine with 48V mild-hybrid technology in various power outputs (125-155 HP), it prioritizes efficiency while maintaining engaging driving dynamics. The performance-oriented ST variant features a 1.5L EcoBoost three-cylinder producing 200 HP.
