A distinctive feature is the 'MegaBox'—an 80-liter waterproof, drainable storage compartment beneath the cargo floor, adding significant versatility. The interior shares elements with the Fiesta but with a more crossover-appropriate seating position and available 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster and 8-inch SYNC 3 touchscreen.
Ford-Puma.name: Second Generation (Crossover)

Ford-Puma.description: The Puma received a significant facelift in February 2024, with updated exterior design featuring a revamped front grille, new headlights, and slimmer bumper designs. The interior was also updated, with revised materials, a larger infotainment screen, and enhanced connectivity options. Engine choices remained efficient while innovative driver-assistance systems were added to remain competitive in its class.
Ford-Puma.name: Second Generation (Crossover, Facelift)

Ford-Ranger.description: The original Ford Ranger was introduced as a replacement for the Ford Courier, marking Ford's entry into the compact pickup segment with its own design. Available in regular cab configuration with 6 or 7-foot beds, and later extended cab (SuperCab) with a 6-foot bed. Engine options included a 2.0L or 2.3L four-cylinder, a 2.8L or 2.9L V6, and even a 2.2L diesel in early models. The Ranger featured conventional body-on-frame construction with Twin-I-Beam front suspension for 2WD models and Twin-Traction Beam for 4WD variants. This generation established the Ranger's reputation for durability and versatility while offering a more manageable size than full-size pickups.
Ford-Ranger.name: First Generation (North America)

Ford-Ranger.description: The first-generation Ranger received a significant facelift for the 1989 model year, featuring updated front styling with a more aerodynamic appearance. The interior received minor updates including revised instrumentation and trim. This facelift version maintained the same mechanical components while improving aesthetics and aerodynamics.
Ford-Ranger.name: First Generation (North America) Facelift

Ford-Ranger.description: The second-generation Ranger featured updated styling with a more aerodynamic front end while maintaining the same basic chassis architecture. Engine options evolved to include a 2.3L and 3.0L V6, with a 4.0L V6 available in higher trims. The interior was significantly improved with better ergonomics and safety features, including the eventual addition of a driver's side airbag. This generation introduced the sporty Splash variant with unique styling, stepside bed, and lowered suspension.
Ford-Ranger.name: Second Generation (North America)

Ford-Ranger.description: The third-generation Ranger received updated styling, chassis improvements, and expanded feature content. Engine options included a 2.3L four-cylinder and 3.0L and 4.0L V6 options. The SuperCab model added rear-hinged doors for improved access to the rear seats. This generation maintained the Ranger's position as one of America's most popular compact pickups.
Ford-Ranger.name: Third Generation (North America)

Ford-Ranger.description: The Ranger received its first major facelift for the 2001 model year with revised front and rear styling, updated interior materials, and improved safety features including standard side airbags. The instrument cluster was redesigned with improved visibility and functionality.
Ford-Ranger.name: Third Generation (North America) First Facelift

Ford-Ranger.description: The second facelift brought further styling updates including a revised grille, headlights, and bumper design. Interior improvements included an available in-dash CD player and updated audio system options. The 4.0L V6 received improved power output for this model year.
Ford-Ranger.name: Third Generation (North America) Second Facelift

Ford-Ranger.description: The third and final facelift for the North American Ranger featured updated front fascia, revised headlights with projector-style lenses, and a restyled tailgate. Interior updates included improved seat materials and available SYNC infotainment system in later years. Production ended after the 2011 model year, though a brief 2012 run was produced for fleet sales.
Ford-Ranger.name: Third Generation (North America) Third Facelift

Ford-Ranger.description: Following the discontinuation of Ford's Mazda-sourced Courier in most global markets, Ford introduced the Ranger name on Mazda-based pickup trucks. The first-generation Mazda-based Ranger was sold in Asia, Australasia, Europe, Africa, and several Latin American markets. Engine options varied by market but included diesel engines popular in those regions.
Ford-Ranger.name: Global Ranger (Mazda-based) First Generation

Ford-Ranger.description: The first-generation Mazda-based Ranger received a facelift with revised front styling, updated interior features, and improved safety equipment. The Courier name continued through 2006 in Australia and New Zealand alongside the Ranger branding.
Ford-Ranger.name: Global Ranger (Mazda-based) First Generation Facelift

Ford-Ranger.description: The second-generation Mazda-based Ranger was derived from the new Mazda BT-50 platform, representing a complete redesign with more modern styling and improved capabilities. Sold globally under the Ford brand while Mazda marketed its own version as the BT-50.
Ford-Ranger.name: Global Ranger (Mazda-based) Second Generation

Ford-Ranger.description: The second-generation Ranger received a facelift with updated front styling, improved interior comfort and technology features, and enhanced safety equipment. This was the final model year before Ford introduced its in-house T6 platform-based Ranger globally.
Ford-Ranger.name: Global Ranger (Mazda-based) Second Generation Facelift

Ford-Ranger.description: The T6 Ranger was developed as a global midsize pickup by Ford Australia, representing a significant advancement over the previous Mazda-sourced model. Initially not sold in North America, it featured modern styling, improved capabilities, and advanced technology. Engine options included various Duratorq diesel engines and EcoBoost gasoline engines depending on the market. The interior offered significantly improved quality, comfort, and features.
Ford-Ranger.name: Global Ranger (T6) First Generation

Ford-Ranger.description: The first-generation T6 Ranger received a comprehensive facelift around the 2015-2016 model year with revised front styling, updated interior technology including a new infotainment system, and improved safety features. The Raptor off-road variant was introduced in select markets during this period.
Ford-Ranger.name: Global Ranger (T6) First Generation Facelift

Ford-Ranger.description: The current Ranger features evolved styling with a bolder, more truck-like appearance inspired by the larger F-150. Built on a revised T6 platform designated T6.2, it offers improved capabilities and technology. Powertrain options vary by market but include a 2.3L EcoBoost four-cylinder (North America), 3.0L V6 turbodiesel, and 2.0L single and bi-turbo diesel engines. The interior represents a major advancement with available 12-inch portrait-oriented touchscreen, digital instrument cluster, and improved materials. The Raptor variant features a twin-turbo 3.0L EcoBoost V6 and sophisticated suspension with Fox dampers.
Ford-Ranger.name: Global Ranger (T6.2) Second Generation

Ford-Sierra.description: The original Ford Sierra represented a radical departure from its predecessor, the Cortina/Taunus, featuring aerodynamic 'jelly mould' styling that was initially controversial but ultimately influential. Available in hatchback and estate (wagon) body styles, the four-door Sapphire sedan was introduced alongside this generation in 1987. It was Ford's mainstream family car for Europe, primarily rear-wheel drive when competitors were largely adopting front-wheel drive. Engine options included various 'Pinto' four-cylinder petrol engines, the Cologne V6, and diesel options. Performance variants included the XR4i with its distinctive biplane rear spoiler and the limited-production RS Cosworth, which established a motorsport legacy. The bold styling initially faced consumer resistance but was later accepted for its modern approach.
Ford-Sierra.name: First Generation (Mk I)

Ford-Sierra.description: The facelifted Sierra featured completely revised styling with more conventional headlights replacing the original's flush units, a modified front end with indicators now positioned above the bumper, and larger side windows. The Sierra Sapphire four-door saloon was officially introduced at this time for the UK market alongside existing hatchback and estate models. This generation consolidated the Sierra's position as a mainstream family car while expanding its performance credentials through the RS Cosworth variant. The rear-wheel drive layout was retained on most models, with four-wheel drive available on XR4x4 variants. Interior received quality improvements and updated technology features, including the option of new engines like the 1.8-litre 'lean burn' petrol engine.
Ford-Sierra.name: Second Generation (Mk II)

Ford-Sierra.description: The final phase of Sierra production received minor updates including smoked rear lamp lenses introduced in 1990 model year, dashboard redesign with a new instrument surround mirroring the look of the new-generation Escort and Orion, updated steering wheels, and run-out special editions like 'Azure' and 'Chausseur'. The 1.6L CVH, 1.8 CVH and 2.0L DOHC petrol models became available with catalytic converter options before their adoption became compulsory at end of 1992. This marked the final usage of the venerable Pinto engine in a Ford of Europe passenger car. The Sierra Cosworth continued its motorsport success with four-wheel-drive versions from January 1990. Production ended in December 1992 as the Genk factory switched to Mondeo production, with stocks lasting into 1994. Approximately 2.7 million Sierras were sold over its lifetime, making it one of Ford Europe's most significant models.
Ford-Sierra.name: Second Generation (Mk II Facelift)

Ford-Taurus.description: The original Ford Taurus was a groundbreaking vehicle that revolutionized American car design with its aerodynamic, rounded styling that dramatically contrasted with the boxy vehicles of its era. Available as a four-door sedan and station wagon, it was a front-wheel drive midsize car built on Ford's DN5 platform. Powered by a 2.5L four-cylinder or 3.0L Vulcan V6 engine (with a high-output 3.8L V6 in the SHO performance model), it emphasized efficiency and modern engineering. The interior was equally innovative with an ergonomic, driver-focused design featuring a wraparound dashboard and convenient controls. The Taurus was a massive commercial success, becoming America's best-selling car from 1992 to 1996 and saving Ford from potential financial crisis. This generation established the Taurus as a revolutionary model that influenced automotive design throughout the industry.
Ford-Taurus.name: First Generation

Ford-Taurus.description: The second-generation Taurus featured evolutionary styling that refined the aerodynamic design of its predecessor. Continuing as a sedan and wagon, it maintained the front-wheel drive layout with updated 3.0L and 3.8L V6 engines. The high-performance SHO added a more powerful 3.2L engine paired with a manual transmission. The interior saw improvements in quality and design with a continued focus on ergonomics. Safety features expanded to include standard dual airbags and available ABS. This generation maintained the Taurus's position as America's best-selling car, though competition from Japanese manufacturers intensified. The design continued to emphasize aerodynamics and modern styling, building on the revolutionary approach of the original model.
Ford-Taurus.name: Second Generation

Ford-Taurus.description: The third-generation Taurus featured controversial oval-themed styling that extended from its exterior shape to interior elements, including the rear window, instrument panel, and even control buttons. Available in sedan and wagon body styles, it continued with V6 engines including a 3.0L Vulcan and more powerful 3.0L Duratec. The SHO variant received a 3.4L V8 developed with Yamaha but lost its manual transmission option. The oval-dominated interior polarized consumers, though it maintained good ergonomics. This generation marked the beginning of the Taurus's decline in market position as its bold styling proved too radical for many mainstream buyers, allowing the Toyota Camry to take over as America's best-selling car.
Ford-Taurus.name: Third Generation

Ford-Taurus.description: The fourth-generation Taurus represented a retreat from the oval-dominated design of its predecessor, featuring more conventional styling in response to consumer feedback. The sedan and wagon continued on an updated version of the DN101 platform with revised 3.0L V6 engines. The interior was completely redesigned with a more traditional layout and improved materials. This generation saw the Taurus gradually repositioned downmarket, eventually becoming primarily a fleet vehicle as retail focus shifted to other Ford models. The wagon was discontinued in 2005, and in 2006 Ford announced plans to discontinue the Taurus nameplate entirely, temporarily replacing it with the Ford Five Hundred and Fusion before CEO Alan Mulally reversed this decision.
Ford-Taurus.name: Fourth Generation

Ford-Taurus.description: The fifth-generation Taurus was essentially a renamed and refreshed Ford Five Hundred, representing a significant shift to a larger, more formal sedan design. Based on the D3 platform with Volvo engineering influence, it featured a higher seating position marketed as 'Command Seating' and available all-wheel drive. Powered by a 3.5L Duratec V6, it emphasized safety and space over sporty characteristics. The interior was significantly larger than previous Taurus models with a more premium design and materials. This brief generation marked CEO Alan Mulally's decision to revive the Taurus nameplate for its brand equity, applying it to the slow-selling Five Hundred as part of a broader strategy to strengthen Ford's model lineup.
Ford-Taurus.name: Fifth Generation (Former Five Hundred)

Ford-Taurus.description: The final Taurus generation featured a substantial redesign with more aggressive, muscular styling while maintaining the D3 platform architecture. Exclusively offered as a sedan, it continued with front-wheel or all-wheel drive configurations. Engine options included the standard 3.5L V6, an optional EcoBoost 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder, and a twin-turbocharged 3.5L EcoBoost V6 in the high-performance SHO model producing 365 HP. The interior offered improved materials, design, and technology, including the SYNC infotainment system. Despite these improvements, the Taurus faced declining sedan sales industry-wide and internal competition from the similarly-sized but more modern Fusion. Production ended in 2019 as part of Ford's strategic shift away from passenger cars in North America, marking the conclusion of a nameplate that had once revolutionized American car design and saved the company from financial crisis.
Ford-Taurus.name: Sixth Generation

Ford-Territory.description: The original Ford Territory was developed by Ford Australia as a mid-size crossover SUV, built on the locally designed EA169 platform shared with the Falcon. The SX series was produced from April 2004 to September 2005 and represented Ford Australia's first foray into the SUV market. Powered exclusively by a 4.0L Barra inline-six engine producing 182 kW, paired with a four-speed automatic transmission, it was available in both rear-wheel drive and all-wheel drive configurations. The interior featured Ford's innovative 'Territory Command Driving Position' with excellent visibility and theatre-style seating for five or seven passengers. Model variants included TX, TS, and Ghia trim levels.
Ford-Territory.name: First Generation (SX Series)

Ford-Territory.description: The SY series, introduced in October 2005, was primarily a mechanical upgrade with no significant visual changes from the SX. Key improvements included increased engine power to 190 kW for the naturally aspirated Barra six, and a new six-speed ZF automatic transmission for AWD models. This series introduced Australia's first factory-fitted reverse parking camera (optional on TS, standard on Ghia). A turbocharged variant of the Barra engine debuted in mid-2006, producing 245 kW and making it one of the most powerful SUVs in Australia. Ford Performance Vehicles (FPV) also introduced the F6X high-performance variant in 2008, producing 270 kW.
Ford-Territory.name: First Generation (SY Series)

Ford-Territory.description: The SY II series, revealed at the 2009 Melbourne Motor Show and launched in May 2009, represented a mid-cycle facelift for the first generation Territory. Exterior changes included a mildly restyled front end with revised bumper and grille, while interior trim received contemporary updates. A significant mechanical improvement was a revised front suspension design that addressed premature wear issues with the lower ball joints. The FPV F6X was discontinued during this series due to low sales. The SY II earned a five-star ANCAP rating when seatbelt warning chimes were added to cars produced from January 2010.
Ford-Territory.name: First Generation (SY II Facelift)

Ford-Territory.description: The SZ series marked a major generational change as the Territory migrated to Ford's E8 platform (from the FG Falcon), representing a significant investment of A$230 million in development. This facelift adopted Ford's global Kinetic Design language with a prominent lower grille, slim upper intake, and horizontal tail lights replacing the previous vertical units. A major highlight was the introduction of Ford's first locally produced diesel engine - a 2.7L Lion V6 sourced from Jaguar/Land Rover - addressing customer concerns about high fuel consumption of the petrol engines. The interior gained an eight-inch touchscreen with Ford's SYNC system, and safety was enhanced with a driver's knee airbag and updated stability control. The Ghia model was replaced by the Titanium.
Ford-Territory.name: Second Generation (SZ Series)

Ford-Territory.description: The SZ II series, introduced in December 2014 alongside the FG X Falcon, represented the final iteration of Australian-built Territory production before Ford Australia ceased manufacturing in October 2016. External styling revisions included a new fascia and alloy wheels, though the Territory lost its LED position lights in favor of traditional foglights. Interior upgrades featured updated trim colors and the SYNC2 infotainment system with voice command, Wi-Fi connectivity, DAB+ radio, and emergency call functionality. Minor mechanical refinements improved fuel efficiency by approximately 0.5%. The SZ II series was the final chapter for Australian-made Territory, with total production reaching 178,214 units over twelve years.
Ford-Territory.name: Second Generation (SZ II Facelift)

Ford-Territory.description: The Chinese-market Ford Territory, unrelated to the Australian model, was introduced in 2018 as a compact crossover SUV produced through the JMC-Ford joint venture. Based on the JMC Yusheng S330, it featured Ford's global design language with a prominent grille and sleek headlights. Powered by a 1.5L EcoBoost turbocharged inline-four engine producing approximately 138-148 hp depending on market, it was offered with manual, CVT, or automatic transmissions and front-wheel drive layout. An electric version (Territory EV) was also introduced in China in 2019 with a 120 kW motor and 360 km NEDC range. Despite being developed for the Chinese market, Ford Australia contributed to ride and handling tuning at their Geelong Proving Grounds.
Ford-Territory.name: First Generation (CX743)

Ford-Territory.description: The second-generation Territory, launched in 2022, is essentially the JMC-Ford Equator Sport marketed internationally as the Territory. Built on updated underpinnings from the first generation, it features significantly revised exterior styling aligned with Ford's global design identity. Engine options include an improved 1.5L EcoBoost producing 160 hp (up 17 hp from before) paired with a new 7-speed wet dual-clutch transmission, and for some markets a 1.8L EcoBoost. A hybrid variant with power-split drivetrain was introduced starting in 2025. Production occurs in China (Nanchang), with additional assembly in Taiwan (Ford Lio Ho) and Vietnam (Ford Vietnam). The model is exported to markets including the Philippines, Mexico, Middle East, South Africa, and Vietnam.
Ford-Territory.name: Second Generation (CX743MCA/Equator Sport)

Ford-Transit.description: The original Ford Transit revolutionized the European van market with car-like driving dynamics and styling that contrasted with forward-control designs common at the time. Introduced in October 1965 as Ford of Europe's first unified platform, it featured front engine/rear-wheel drive architecture with Essex V4 engines in the UK (1.7L and 2.0L) and Taunus V4 engines in mainland Europe (1.3L, 1.5L, and 1.7L). A diesel option from Perkins (43 hp) was offered but proved unpopular due to being underpowered; it was replaced by Ford's own York engine in 1972. The diesel version required a longer bonnet nicknamed the 'pig snout' to accommodate the engine length. Available in numerous configurations including panel van, minibus, pickup, and chassis cab, it gained a reputation for versatility and durability. A minor facelift in 1971 updated front end styling on V4 models with a safety-padded dashboard.
Ford-Transit.name: First Generation

Ford-Transit.description: In August 1977, a facelifted version codenamed 'Transit 1978½' but commonly called the Mark II debuted with a restyled, longer nose section that could properly accommodate inline engines. This allowed the Ford Pinto engine from the Cortina to become the Transit's dominant power unit (1.6L OHC and 2.0L OHC petrol options). The new frontal styling brought the Transit in line with Ford of Europe's passenger car range with square headlamps and black louvred grille. The austere dashboard was replaced with a full-width plastic fascia from the Taunus/Cortina Mk4. High-performance versions used the 3.0L Essex V6 for police and ambulance services. In 1984, a minor facelift added grey plastic front grille with integrated headlamp surrounds and multifunction rear lights. Four-wheel drive was offered from 1982 for the German market, developed with Sinpar.
Ford-Transit.name: First Generation (Mark II Facelift)

Ford-Transit.description: Codenamed VE6, the second-generation Transit featured an all-new 'one-box' bodyshell design where windscreen and bonnet are at close to the same angle. Front suspension changed to fully independent configuration on SWB versions. Initial engines carried over from the Mark II, with the high-performance 3.0L Essex V6 replaced by Cologne 2.9 EFI V6 in 1989 due to emissions regulations. Assembly plants included Genk (Belgium), Southampton (UK), and Ford Otosan (Turkey). Production continued in China until 2017 and Vietnam until 2003. The platform was also built under license by Jiangling Motors in China.
Ford-Transit.name: Second Generation

Ford-Transit.description: A major facelift in 1994 gave the Transit a new nose and dashboard along with the 2.0L DOHC 8-valve engine from the Ford Scorpio, updated to OBD II-compliant EEC-V engine control. This facelift introduced optional air conditioning, electric windows, central locking, electric mirrors, and airbags for the first time. Available engines included naturally aspirated diesels (70-76 PS) and turbodiesels (85-115 PS with intercooling from 1998). The 30th anniversary in 1995 saw a limited edition Transit Hallmark with 600 units produced. Production continued in some markets beyond European discontinuation.
Ford-Transit.name: Second Generation (1994 Facelift)

Ford-Transit.description: The third-generation Transit, introduced in July 2000, was Ford's first all-new design with 'New Edge' styling cues from the Focus and Ka. Developed in the United States, it was available in either front-wheel drive (V185) or rear-wheel drive (V184) configurations. Featured the Duratorq turbo diesel engine also used in the Mondeo and Jaguar X-Type, with petrol versions using a 2.3L 16-valve inline-four. Won International Van of the Year 2001. Production started at Ford-Otosan in Turkey, coinciding with Transit Connect introduction and ending Genk plant production. The five millionth Transit rolled off Southampton line in July 2005.
Ford-Transit.name: Third Generation

Ford-Transit.description: The third-generation Transit received a major facelift in July 2006 including new front and rear lights, new front end styling, and a new interior with dashboard-mounted gearstick and Ford's new corporate radio design. Powertrains were revised: petrol engine replaced with Ranger-sourced unit, front-wheel-drive diesel increased from 2.0L to 2.2L capacity, all diesels gained High Pressure Common Rail systems (TDCi), and CAN bus electronics were introduced for the first time. The facelift brought Ford's new nomenclature V347 (FWD) and V348 (RWD), winning International Van of the Year 2007. A five-cylinder 3.2L diesel engine (200 PS) became available. Production ended at Southampton in 2013 but continued in China with modified forms.
Ford-Transit.name: Third Generation (2006 Facelift)

Ford-Transit.description: The current Transit is a truly global vehicle, replacing both the European Transit lineage and North American E-Series as part of Ford's One Ford strategy. Built at Ford Otosan in Turkey (main global production), Kansas City Assembly in Missouri (North America), and later China. Available in multiple size categories including Transit Custom for midsize applications, offering front-wheel drive (outside North America), rear-wheel drive, and all-wheel drive configurations. Engine options include the EcoBlue diesel range in Europe (2.0L and 2.2L) and EcoBoost gasoline engines in North America, with the E-Transit electric variant introduced for 2022. Interior features significant improvements in technology, comfort and safety including SYNC infotainment systems.
Ford-Transit.name: Fourth Generation

Ford-Transit.description: A significant facelift in 2019 updated styling and technology while adding hybrid options. The Tourneo Custom plug-in hybrid was introduced featuring a 1.0L EcoBoost range-extender engine. The facelift brought updated front and rear styling in line with Ford's current design language, new interior technologies, and enhanced driver assistance features. The E-Transit electric version was added to the range for 2022, offering a fully electric powertrain while maintaining the same chassis configurations as diesel variants.
Ford-Transit.name: Fourth Generation (2019 Facelift)

Ford-Transit-Connect.description: Introduced in Europe in October 2002 as a replacement for car-derived vans (Ford Escort Van and Ford Fiesta Courier). Built on the Ford C170 platform with front-wheel-drive layout. Available in short wheelbase (SWB) and long wheelbase (LWB) variants with sliding side doors. Powered by 1.8L Duratorq TDCi diesel, 2.0L Endura-D TDDi diesel, and 2.0L Duratec gasoline engines.
Ford-Transit-Connect.name: First Generation

Ford-Transit-Connect.description: Mid-cycle facelift introduced alongside North American导入. Features restyled front grille, deeper front bumper, and new dashboard with switchgear from the C307 Ford Focus. The North American variant was introduced for 2010 model year with 2.0L Duratec gasoline engine and 4-speed automatic transmission.
Ford-Transit-Connect.name: First Generation (2009 Facelift)

Ford-Transit-Connect.description: Introduced on September 6, 2012 in Amsterdam. Built on Ford's Global C-car platform with Kinetic Design language. Produced at Valencia, Spain. Available in SWB and LWB with panel van and leisure activity vehicle (LAV) body styles. Engine options include 1.0L EcoBoost I3, 1.6L EcoBoost I4, 2.5L Duratec I4, and 1.5L Duratorq diesel.
Ford-Transit-Connect.name: Second Generation

Ford-Transit-Connect.description: Mid-life update for the 2019 model year with updated front fascia and redesigned dashboard. The 2.5L engine was replaced by a 2.0L direct-injection I4 (while remaining optional for LPG/CNG). New 1.5L EcoBlue diesel engine introduced, paired with an 8-speed automatic transmission. Production ended in North America after 2023 model year.
Ford-Transit-Connect.name: Second Generation (2019 Facelift)

Ford-Transit-Connect.description: Rebadged fourth-generation Volkswagen Caddy as part of Ford-VW commercial vehicle partnership. Built on Volkswagen Group MQB platform at VW Poznań, Poland. Engine options include 1.5L TSI petrol, 1.5L TSI plug-in hybrid (150hp combined), and 2.0L TDI diesel. Transit Connect badging released in late 2024.
Ford-Transit-Connect.name: Third Generation

GMC-Acadia.description: The original GMC Acadia was a full-size crossover SUV built on GM's Lambda platform shared with the Chevrolet Traverse, Buick Enclave, and Saturn Outlook. Featuring a unibody construction rather than the body-on-frame design of traditional GMC SUVs, it combined car-like handling with substantial interior space. Initially powered by a 3.6L V6 engine producing 275 HP (later upgraded to 288 HP), paired with a six-speed automatic transmission and available in front-wheel or all-wheel drive configurations. The interior offered three rows of seating for up to eight passengers, with flexible seating arrangements and substantial cargo capacity. A significant refresh in 2013 updated the exterior styling, interior materials, and technology features. Available in various trim levels from the base SL to the luxury Denali, this generation established the Acadia as GMC's first crossover SUV and a practical alternative to traditional truck-based models, appealing to families seeking space and versatility without the fuel consumption and ride harshness of larger, truck-based SUVs.
GMC-Acadia.name: First Generation

GMC-Acadia.description: The second-generation Acadia marked a significant change in positioning, downsizing from a full-size to a mid-size crossover. Built on GM's C1XX platform, it was approximately 7 inches shorter and 700 pounds lighter than its predecessor. Engine options expanded to include a 2.5L four-cylinder and a 3.6L V6, with a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder added in 2020. The interior maintained three-row seating but with reduced capacity for up to seven passengers, offering improved materials and technology including an 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. Special variants included the off-road-focused AT4 with enhanced capability features and the luxury Denali with premium appointments. A refresh in 2020 updated the exterior styling, transmission, and technology features. This generation repositioned the Acadia to compete in the highly competitive mid-size crossover segment, differentiating it more clearly from the larger Yukon in GMC's lineup.
GMC-Acadia.name: Second Generation

GMC-Acadia.description: The current Acadia returns to a larger size, though not as large as the original generation, positioning it more clearly in the three-row midsize SUV segment. Built on GM's VSS-S platform (C1XX-2), it features more rugged, truck-inspired styling aligned with GMC's design language. Powered exclusively by a 2.5L turbocharged inline-four engine producing 328 HP and 326 lb-ft of torque, paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission and available with front-wheel or all-wheel drive. The interior represents a significant advancement with higher quality materials, a standard 15-inch infotainment touchscreen, an 11-inch digital instrument cluster, and enhanced passenger space particularly in the third row. Seating configurations include six or seven-passenger arrangements depending on whether second-row captain's chairs are selected. Technology features include standard Super Cruise hands-free driving assistance, Google Built-in services, and comprehensive safety systems. The lineup continues to include the off-road AT4 and luxury Denali trims, with the latter featuring unique styling elements and premium appointments. This generation aims to better position the Acadia against three-row competitors like the Jeep Grand Cherokee L and Honda Pilot, offering enhanced capability and technology while maintaining GMC's professional grade identity.
GMC-Acadia.name: Third Generation

GMC-Canyon.description: The original GMC Canyon was a mid-size pickup truck developed alongside the Chevrolet Colorado, replacing the compact Sonoma in GMC's lineup. Available in regular cab, extended cab, and crew cab configurations with various bed lengths, it offered more interior space and capability than its predecessor. Engine options initially included a 2.8L four-cylinder and a 3.5L inline-five, later upgraded to 2.9L and 3.7L respectively, with a 5.3L V8 added in 2009. The first-generation Canyon featured traditional body-on-frame construction with available rear or four-wheel drive. The interior was functional though basic by modern standards, with a focus on durability over luxury. A significant refresh in 2007 updated the styling, interior, and introduced the aforementioned power increases. This generation established the Canyon as GMC's entry in the mid-size truck segment, though it faced strong competition from Japanese rivals like the Toyota Tacoma and Nissan Frontier.
GMC-Canyon.name: First Generation

GMC-Canyon.description: After a brief hiatus, the Canyon returned as a significantly more refined and capable mid-size truck. Built on GM's GMT 31XX platform shared with the Chevrolet Colorado, it featured more sophisticated styling aligned with GMC's design language. Engine options included a 2.5L four-cylinder, 3.6L V6, and a 2.8L Duramax diesel offering impressive torque and fuel efficiency. Available in extended and crew cab configurations, it targeted both work and lifestyle users with various trim levels including the luxury-oriented Denali and off-road-focused AT4. The interior offered substantially improved materials, design, and technology, including available 8-inch touchscreen infotainment with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. This generation successfully positioned the Canyon as a more premium alternative to its Chevrolet counterpart and a viable competitor to segment leaders, offering near-full-size capabilities in a more manageable package.
GMC-Canyon.name: Second Generation

GMC-Canyon.description: The current Canyon represents a complete redesign with a significantly more aggressive and distinctive appearance. Available exclusively in crew cab configuration with a single bed length, it focuses on lifestyle-oriented truck buyers rather than commercial users. Power comes solely from a 2.7L turbocharged four-cylinder engine with three output levels, topped by a high-output version with 310 HP and 430 lb-ft of torque, paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission. The interior features a more upscale design with a standard 11.3-inch touchscreen, 11-inch digital instrument cluster, and significantly improved materials. The off-road-focused AT4X serves as the flagship model with 3-inch factory lift, Multimatic DSSV dampers, front and rear electronic locking differentials, and 33-inch mud-terrain tires. This generation emphasizes technology, off-road capability, and premium features, positioning the Canyon more clearly as an aspirational lifestyle truck rather than simply a badge-engineered Colorado alternative.
GMC-Canyon.name: Third Generation

GMC-Safari.description: The original GMC Safari was a rear-wheel drive midsize van developed alongside the nearly identical Chevrolet Astro. Built on a dedicated truck-based platform with body-on-frame construction, it offered more ruggedness and capability than the front-wheel drive minivans that were becoming popular at the time. Available in cargo and passenger configurations, with the latter offering seating for up to eight passengers across three rows. Power came from various V6 engines, starting with a 4.3L carbureted version and evolving to fuel-injected variants with improved output. All-wheel drive became available in 1990, enhancing the Safari's versatility and capability in adverse conditions. The interior was functional rather than luxurious, with a focus on durability and practicality. This generation established the Safari as a versatile workhorse that bridged the gap between traditional full-size vans and more car-like minivans.
GMC-Safari.name: First Generation

GMC-Safari.description: The second-generation Safari featured a comprehensive redesign with more modern styling, including a longer front end with improved crash protection. Mechanically similar to its predecessor, it maintained the rugged body-on-frame construction and rear-wheel drive (or optional all-wheel drive) layout. Powered by an updated 4.3L Vortec V6 engine paired with a four-speed automatic transmission, it offered good towing capability for a vehicle of its size. The interior was significantly improved with better ergonomics, materials, and optional features including power accessories, enhanced audio systems, and rear air conditioning. Safety features were expanded to include driver and eventually passenger airbags, anti-lock brakes, and later optional side airbags. Though increasingly dated compared to more modern minivan designs, the Safari maintained a loyal following among those who valued its towing capability, durability, and available all-wheel drive. Production ended in 2005 without a direct replacement as GM shifted focus to full-size vans and crossover SUVs.
GMC-Safari.name: Second Generation

GMC-Sierra-1500.description: The first-generation Sierra 1500 (though the '1500' designation wasn't used until later) established GMC's full-size pickup as a distinct model from Chevrolet with more premium positioning. Built on GM's GMT400 platform, it featured more aerodynamic styling than its predecessor. Available in regular cab and extended cab configurations with various bed lengths, it offered versatility for different uses. Engine options included V6 and V8 gasoline engines, plus a 6.2L/6.5L diesel option. The interior was more car-like than previous generations, with better ergonomics and comfort features. This generation introduced many innovations including an independent front suspension for improved ride quality, and was the first American pickup to offer a third door on extended cab models in 1996.
GMC-Sierra-1500.name: First Generation (GMT400)

GMC-Sierra-1500.description: The second-generation Sierra 1500 featured more distinctive styling to differentiate it from its Chevrolet Silverado counterpart, with unique front fascia, interior trim, and available features. Built on GM's GMT800 platform, it offered regular cab, extended cab, and the new crew cab configurations. Powertrain options included various Vortec V8 engines, with a focus on improved power and efficiency. The interior was significantly more refined, with better materials and design, particularly in upscale trims like the Denali. This generation saw the introduction of the luxury-oriented Sierra Denali as a distinct model, establishing GMC's premium positioning in the truck market. A significant update in 2003 refreshed the styling and interior while adding features and technology.
GMC-Sierra-1500.name: Second Generation (GMT800)

GMC-Sierra-1500.description: The third-generation Sierra 1500 featured more sophisticated styling with better aerodynamics, while maintaining a bold, truck-like appearance. Built on GM's GMT900 platform, it offered improved structural rigidity and crash protection. Engine options evolved to include more efficient V8s with features like Active Fuel Management (cylinder deactivation). The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and technology, including available navigation and enhanced connectivity features. The luxury-oriented Denali trim expanded its prominence in the lineup, featuring distinctive styling and more premium appointments. This generation maintained the Sierra's position as GMC's flagship vehicle during a challenging period for the auto industry, including GM's bankruptcy and restructuring.
GMC-Sierra-1500.name: Third Generation (GMT900)

GMC-Sierra-1500.description: The fourth-generation Sierra 1500 featured more distinctive styling to further differentiate it from the Silverado, including unique headlights, grille, and bed features. Built on GM's K2XX platform, it offered reduced weight and improved capabilities. Engine options evolved to include more efficient V6 and V8 engines, including an EcoTec3 family with direct injection, variable valve timing, and cylinder deactivation. The interior offered improved materials, design, and technology, including the IntelliLink infotainment system. This generation introduced innovative features like the MultiPro tailgate on later Denali models and expanded use of premium materials and technology. The Sierra Denali solidified its position as a luxury truck, appealing to buyers who wanted capability with premium appointments.
GMC-Sierra-1500.name: Fourth Generation (K2XX)

GMC-Sierra-1500.description: The current Sierra 1500 features the most differentiation from its Chevrolet counterpart in the model's history, with unique styling, features, and technology. Built on GM's T1XX platform, it offers reduced weight while increasing capability and refinement. Engine options include a turbocharged four-cylinder, V6, and multiple V8 options, plus a 3.0L Duramax diesel. The interior represents a significant step forward in design and technology, particularly in higher trims, with available features including a 15-inch head-up display, digital rearview mirror, and multi-color touchscreen interfaces. Innovative features include the MultiPro tailgate with six functions, available CarbonPro carbon fiber composite bed, and transparent trailer view camera system. The Sierra Denali Ultimate introduced in 2022 established a new premium benchmark with standard adaptive suspension, open-pore wood trim, and exclusive technologies. This generation firmly positions the Sierra 1500 as GMC's technology and feature leader, with clear differentiation from the Silverado through exclusive features and more premium positioning.
GMC-Sierra-1500.name: Fifth Generation (T1XX)

GMC-Terrain.description: The original GMC Terrain was a mid-size crossover SUV that shared its platform with the Chevrolet Equinox but featured distinctive, squared-off styling with prominent fender flares and a bold front fascia. Built on GM's Theta platform, it was initially powered by either a 2.4L four-cylinder engine (182 hp) or a 3.0L V6 (264 hp), paired with a six-speed automatic transmission offering front-wheel or all-wheel drive. The interior was more upscale than its Chevrolet counterpart with higher quality materials and a premium design, particularly in the Denali trim introduced in 2013. A notable feature was the Multi-Flex fore/aft adjustable rear seat that could move nearly eight inches to prioritize either passenger or cargo space. Assembly took place in Ingersoll, Ontario at CAMI Assembly.
GMC-Terrain.name: First Generation

GMC-Terrain.description: The 2016 facelift updated the first-generation Terrain with new front and rear fascias, chrome exhaust tips on all models (first used on 2013 Denali), a power dome hood, LED daytime running lights, new wheels, and a new gear selector. The 3.0L V6 was upgraded to a more powerful 3.6L V6 producing 301 hp. For 2017, the Nightfall edition was introduced with gloss-black finish replacing chrome on grille surround, fascia accents, mirror caps, and roof rack. Production ended in 2017 with this facelift representing the final version of the first generation.
GMC-Terrain.name: First Generation (2016 Facelift)

GMC-Terrain.description: The second-generation Terrain introduced for 2018 featured more car-like styling with a floating roof design, slimmer headlights, and C-shaped LED lighting accents on all trims. Built on the GM D2XX platform in San Luis Potosí, Mexico, it moved firmly into the compact crossover segment with reduced dimensions. Engine options included a 1.5L turbocharged I4 (170 hp), a 2.0L turbocharged I4 (252 hp), and a 1.6L turbodiesel I4 (137 hp). All models featured a folding front passenger seat to accommodate items up to eight feet long and a class-exclusive switch-based transmission shifter. Trim levels included SLE, SLT, and Denali (initially only with 2.0L engine). Standard features included a seven-inch infotainment touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, four USB ports, keyless entry, and drive mode selection.
GMC-Terrain.name: Second Generation

GMC-Terrain.description: The refreshed second-generation Terrain debuted for 2022 with updated front and rear styling, exterior LED lamps, and interior improvements including an 11-inch driver information center. The low-end SL trim was discontinued. New AT4 trim introduced with rugged styling including a steel skid plate, black-painted wheels, off-road tires, and unique badging (AWD only). The diesel engine was discontinued after 2019 and the 2.0L engine after 2021, leaving only the 1.5L turbocharged I4 as the sole engine option from 2022 onward. For 2023, the 1.5L engine received an updated version with higher-pressure fuel system and slightly increased horsepower. The 2024 model year marked the final production year of this generation.
GMC-Terrain.name: Second Generation (2022 Facelift)

GMC-Terrain.description: The third-generation GMC Terrain was unveiled on August 12, 2024, with production beginning October 14, 2024. This generation features a totally redesigned interior and exterior with a more rugged, truck-like appearance aligned with GMC's larger trucks. Key exterior features include C-shaped lighting signatures in the headlights and taillights, a grille design similar to GMC's trucks, standard 17-inch wheels (20-inch optional on Denali), and available two-tone paint. The redesigned interior includes an updated 15-inch infotainment screen, an 11-inch driver information center, and relocated steering column shifter. However, the previous generation's folding front passenger seat was discontinued. This generation rides on a slightly updated version of the Delta (D2XX) platform. The powertrain consists of a 1.5L turbocharged engine producing 174 horsepower and 184-203 lb-ft of torque, paired with a CVT (FWD) or 8-speed automatic transmission (AWD). Trim levels initially include Elevation with AWD, while AT4 and Denali became available for 2026 in AWD only.
GMC-Terrain.name: Third Generation

GMC-Yukon.description: The original GMC Yukon was introduced as a two-door SUV based on the Sierra pickup truck platform, essentially replacing the Jimmy name for full-size models. A four-door version was added in 1995, significantly expanding its appeal as a family vehicle. Built on GM's GMT400 platform with body-on-frame construction, it offered genuine off-road capability and substantial towing capacity. Engine options centered around V8 powerplants, including the 5.7L small-block. The interior was relatively utilitarian by modern standards but offered good passenger and cargo space. This generation established the Yukon as GMC's premium full-size SUV, positioned as a more upscale alternative to the Chevrolet Tahoe.
GMC-Yukon.name: First Generation

GMC-Yukon.description: The second-generation Yukon featured more refined styling, improved engineering, and expanded feature content. Built on GM's GMT800 platform, it was available exclusively as a four-door with either rear-wheel or four-wheel drive. Engine options included 4.8L, 5.3L, and 6.0L Vortec V8s, all offering improved power and efficiency over their predecessors. The interior saw significant improvements in design, materials, and comfort features, particularly in the new Denali luxury trim. The Yukon Denali was initially a distinct model before becoming a trim level, featuring a unique grille, upgraded interior, and the most powerful engine options. This generation further established the Yukon's position as a versatile, capable vehicle that could serve as both a work-ready SUV and a comfortable family hauler.
GMC-Yukon.name: Second Generation (GMT800)

GMC-Yukon.description: The third-generation Yukon featured more aerodynamic styling and significant improvements in refinement, technology, and efficiency. Built on GM's GMT900 platform, it offered reduced weight and improved structural rigidity. Engine options evolved to include more efficient 5.3L and 6.2L V8s with Active Fuel Management cylinder deactivation technology. The interior was completely redesigned with better materials, design, and feature content, including navigation systems and rear-seat entertainment options. Safety features expanded to include stability control, side curtain airbags, and improved crash structures. The Denali trim became increasingly important in the lineup, offering distinctive styling and luxury features approaching those of premium brands. This generation maintained the Yukon's core capabilities while improving refinement and efficiency.
GMC-Yukon.name: Third Generation (GMT900)

GMC-Yukon.description: The fourth-generation Yukon featured more upright styling with distinctive LED lighting elements and a prominent grille. Built on GM's K2XX platform, it offered improved capabilities and refinement. Engine options included 5.3L and 6.2L EcoTec3 V8s featuring direct injection, variable valve timing, and cylinder deactivation for improved efficiency. The interior saw significant upgrades in design, materials, and technology, with available features including an 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system, head-up display, and multiple USB ports. The Denali trim expanded its premium offerings with exclusive features and design elements, accounting for a significant portion of Yukon sales. This generation enhanced the Yukon's position as a versatile, capable, and increasingly luxurious full-size SUV.
GMC-Yukon.name: Fourth Generation (K2XX)

GMC-Yukon.description: The current Yukon represents the most significant advancement in the model's history, featuring sophisticated styling and substantial mechanical improvements. Built on GM's T1XX platform, the most notable change is the adoption of an independent rear suspension, dramatically improving interior space (especially third-row comfort) and ride quality. Engine options include 5.3L and 6.2L V8s, plus a 3.0L Duramax diesel inline-six for the first time. The interior is completely redesigned with a push-button electronic shifter, available 10.2-inch touchscreen, digital instrument options, and significantly improved materials. The Denali trim received even greater differentiation with a unique interior design featuring genuine wood and hand-finished details. New to this generation is the AT4 trim with off-road focus, featuring standard four-wheel drive, all-terrain tires, skid plates, and red recovery hooks. Technology has advanced to include available features like a power-sliding center console, rear pedestrian alert, and Super Cruise hands-free driving assistance. This generation combines the traditional capability expected of a Yukon with unprecedented levels of refinement, technology, and luxury.
GMC-Yukon.name: Fifth Generation (T1XX)

GMC-Yukon-XL.description: Before becoming the Yukon XL in 2000, this vehicle was known as the GMC Suburban, sharing its platform and most components with the Chevrolet version. The Suburban established the concept of a full-size, station wagon-style body on a truck chassis, creating what would become the modern full-size SUV segment. Through multiple generations spanning over six decades, it evolved from a primarily commercial and fleet vehicle to a family-oriented people mover while maintaining its truck-based ruggedness and capability. The final generation as the Suburban (1992-1999) featured the GMT400 platform with V8 engines, available four-wheel drive, and substantial passenger and cargo capacity.
GMC-Yukon-XL.name: First Generation (as Suburban)

GMC-Yukon-XL.description: The GMC Suburban was renamed Yukon XL in 2000, aligning with GMC's naming convention while differentiating it from the Chevrolet Suburban. Built on GM's GMT800 platform, it featured more refined styling, improved engineering, and expanded feature content. Available in 1500 (half-ton) and 2500 (three-quarter-ton) variants with increased capabilities, it offered various V8 engines including 5.3L and 6.0L Vortec units. The interior saw significant improvements in design, materials, and comfort features, particularly in the Denali luxury trim introduced to the Yukon XL in 2001. This generation established the Yukon XL's position as GMC's most spacious and capable SUV, combining truck-like utility with increasing levels of refinement and luxury.
GMC-Yukon-XL.name: First Generation (as Yukon XL)

GMC-Yukon-XL.description: The second-generation Yukon XL (as named) featured more aerodynamic styling and substantial improvements in refinement and efficiency. Built on GM's GMT900 platform, it offered enhanced structural rigidity with better ride and handling characteristics. Engine options evolved to include more efficient 5.3L and 6.2L V8s with Active Fuel Management cylinder deactivation. The interior was completely redesigned with better materials, improved design, and expanded feature content including navigation systems and rear-seat entertainment. Safety features expanded to include stability control, side curtain airbags for all rows, and improved crash structures. The Denali trim gained further prominence with exclusive styling and luxury features approaching those of premium brands while maintaining the vehicle's substantial capability.
GMC-Yukon-XL.name: Second Generation

GMC-Yukon-XL.description: The third-generation Yukon XL featured more upright, distinctive styling with prominent LED lighting elements and a bold front fascia. Built on GM's K2XX platform, it offered improved capabilities and refinement. Engine options included 5.3L and 6.2L EcoTec3 V8s featuring direct injection, variable valve timing, and cylinder deactivation for improved efficiency. The interior saw significant upgrades in design, materials, and technology, with available features including an 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system, head-up display, and multiple USB ports throughout the cabin. The Denali trim expanded its premium offerings with exclusive features and design elements, accounting for a significant portion of Yukon XL sales. This generation enhanced the model's position as a versatile, capable, and increasingly luxurious extended-length SUV.
GMC-Yukon-XL.name: Third Generation

GMC-Yukon-XL.description: The current Yukon XL represents the most significant advancement in the model's history. Built on GM's T1XX platform, the most notable change is the adoption of an independent rear suspension, dramatically improving interior space (especially third-row comfort and cargo area) and ride quality. Engine options include 5.3L and 6.2L V8s, plus a 3.0L Duramax diesel inline-six. The interior is completely redesigned with a push-button electronic shifter, available 10.2-inch touchscreen, and significantly improved materials. The Denali trim received even greater differentiation with a unique interior design featuring genuine wood and hand-finished details. New to this generation is the AT4 trim with off-road focus, featuring standard four-wheel drive, all-terrain tires, and skid plates. Technology has advanced to include available features like power-sliding center console, rear pedestrian alert, and Super Cruise hands-free driving assistance. This generation maintains the traditional capabilities expected of a Yukon XL while offering unprecedented levels of refinement, technology, and luxury.
GMC-Yukon-XL.name: Fourth Generation

Genesis-G70.description: The original Genesis G70 debuted on September 15, 2017, at the global launch event in Seoul. It was designed as the brand's entry-level luxury sport sedan to compete with the BMW 3 Series and Mercedes-Benz C-Class, built on the Hyundai M2 platform (shared with the Kia Stinger). The pre-facelift G70 featured distinctive styling under Genesis's 'Athletic Elegance' design philosophy with LED headlights and athletic rear styling. It was available with a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder producing 252 HP, a 3.3L twin-turbocharged V6 delivering 365-370 HP, or a 2.2L turbodiesel with 199 HP. A six-speed manual transmission was available with the 2.0L engine, with most models featuring an eight-speed automatic. The G70 received critical acclaim for its driving dynamics, value proposition, and refinement, winning the 2019 North American Car of the Year award. The pre-facelift generation offered both rear-wheel and all-wheel drive configurations with premium interior materials and driver-focused layout.
Genesis-G70.name: First Generation

Genesis-G70.description: A comprehensive facelift was announced on September 8, 2020, going on sale in South Korea on October 20, 2020, and as a 2022 model year in North America. The facelift incorporated new corporate design cues from the Genesis GV80 crossover and second-generation G80 sedan, featuring new front and rear bumpers, headlights (adopting quad headlights), taillights, and a new grille design. While sharing the same fundamental M2 platform as the pre-facelift model, the updated design received mixed reactions, particularly in Korea where some criticized the new taillights. The facelift featured a new optional 10.25-inch touchscreen infotainment system and digital instrument cluster options. Powertrain options continued with the 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder and 3.3L twin-turbocharged V6. In 2023, the 2.0L was upgraded to a 2.5L turbocharged Smartstream engine producing 304 HP. The manual transmission was discontinued starting with the 2022 model year. A shooting brake (station wagon) variant was introduced in May 2021 for European markets. Advanced driver assistance systems were expanded with Highway Driving Assist II with machine learning capabilities.
Genesis-G70.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Genesis-G80.description: The first-generation Genesis G80 (internally designated DH) launched as the rebranded Hyundai Genesis when Genesis Motor was established as a separate luxury division in 2016. It featured distinctive styling with a hexagonal grille and Genesis's emerging design language. Available engine options included a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder, 3.3L V6, 3.3L twin-turbo V6, 3.8L V6, and 5.0L V8, with rear-wheel or all-wheel drive (HTRAC). The G80 Sport variant offered a twin-turbo 3.3L V6 with enhanced styling and dynamics. Production ran from March 2016 to 2020, with model years 2017-2020. Built on the Hyundai M2 platform at Ulsan, South Korea and Kaliningrad, Russia.
Genesis-G80.name: First Generation (DH)

Genesis-G80.description: The second-generation G80 (internally designated RG3) represents a complete redesign fully embracing Genesis's unique design language. It features the brand's signature crest grille, quad headlights and taillights, and a dramatic parabolic character line along the side profile. Built on the new Hyundai-Kia M3 platform, it offers improved dynamics and refinement. Engine options include a 2.5L turbocharged four-cylinder (Smartstream G2.5), 3.5L twin-turbo V6 (Smartstream G3.5), and a 2.2L diesel (Smartstream D2.2). All paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission. The interior showcases a minimalist luxury approach with a 14.5-inch widescreen infotainment display and digital instrument cluster. The Electrified G80 EV variant debuted in 2021 with dual motors and 87.2 kWh battery. Production began April 2020 for model years 2021-present.
Genesis-G80.name: Second Generation Pre-Facelift (RG3)

Genesis-G80.description: The facelifted G80 was revealed on December 14, 2023 for the 2024 model year. Exterior updates include micro-lens array headlight technology, a new grille pattern and front bumper, hidden exhaust outlets with V-shape chrome trim, and redesigned alloy wheels. The interior features a new 27-inch OLED display (replacing the separate digital cluster and infotainment), crystal-like shift-by-wire gear shifter, touch-based climate controls, and a new steering wheel. The G80 Sport adds a unique double-layered G-Matrix pattern grille, larger air outlets, different bumpers, D-cut steering wheel, and carbon-look interior garnishes. The Electrified G80 received an upgraded 95.4 kWh battery (up from 87.2 kWh).
Genesis-G80.name: Second Generation Facelift (RG3)

Haval-H6-HEV.description: The Haval H6 HEV is the hybrid variant of the third-generation H6, produced by Great Wall Motor since 2020 on the Lemon platform (B30). The HEV variant debuted at the 2021 Bangkok International Motor Show in March 2021. It features a 1.5-litre turbocharged GW4B15 engine producing 123 kW and 285 Nm of torque, paired with a 130 kW electric motor and 7-speed DCT hybrid transmission, delivering combined output of 243 PS (179 kW) and 530 Nm of torque. The interior features dual screens typically including a 10.25-inch digital instrument cluster and 12.3-inch central touchscreen, with minimal physical buttons. Standard technology includes wireless smartphone charging, voice control, and driver assistance systems including adaptive cruise control, lane keeping assist, and autonomous emergency braking. Production expanded globally with CKD assembly in Malaysia (2024), Thailand, and other markets. The 2024 facelift introduced a new front fascia with vertical LED daytime running lights, full-width light bar (later replaced by conventional taillights), increased length to 4703 mm, redesigned center console with 50W wireless charger, memory seats, column-style drive selector, and upgraded 14.6-inch infotainment display running Coffee OS 3.0.
Haval-H6-HEV.name: Third Generation (HEV)

Haval-Jolion.description: The Haval Jolion is a compact crossover SUV produced by Great Wall Motor's Haval marque, debuting in October 2020 at the Beijing Auto Show as a successor to the Haval H2. The first generation was launched in markets across three different regions with varying powertrains. In South Africa on 21 April 2021, it arrived with four trim levels (City, Premium, Luxury, and Super Luxury) powered exclusively by a 1.5-litre turbocharged four-cylinder petrol engine delivering 110 kW of power and 210 Nm of torque, paired with either a 6-speed manual or 7-speed dual-clutch transmission. The Australian market launch on 2 July 2021 offered three trim levels (Premium, Lux, and Ultra), also with the 1.5L turbo petrol engine and the 7-speed DCT as standard. Meanwhile, in Thailand, the Jolion launched on 25 November 2021 with three trim levels (Tech, Pro, and Ultra) exclusively with a 1.5-litre hybrid electric vehicle (HEV) powertrain featuring a 70 kW petrol engine combined with a 115 kW electric motor for a total system output of 140 kW and 375 Nm of torque. All variants were built on the L.E.M.O.N. platform (also used for the Haval Big Dog), measuring 4,472 mm long, 1,841 mm wide, and 1,574 mm tall, with a 2,700 mm wheelbase. The Jolion featured a 12.3-inch floating touchscreen infotainment system with Apple CarPlay and satellite navigation, a 7.0-inch digital instrument cluster, head-up display, comprehensive active safety features including autonomous emergency braking with pedestrian and cyclist detection, blind-spot monitoring, lane-keeping assist, rear cross-traffic alert, and other driver assistance systems. Other comfort features included a six-speaker sound system, synthetic leather upholstery, a six-way electric driver's seat with ventilation (on higher trims), dual-zone climate control, PM2.5 air filter, and wireless phone charging. The vehicle was backed by a seven-year unlimited-kilometre warranty and required servicing every 12 months or 15,000 km. The turbocharged petrol models achieved a claimed fuel consumption of 8.1 L/100 km, while hybrid models were significantly more efficient at 5.1 L/100 km.
Haval-Jolion.name: First Generation

Haval-Jolion.description: In June 2024, the Haval Jolion underwent a significant restructuring and facelift, being reorganized into two distinct model lines: the Jolion City and Jolion Pro. The City variant represents the more practical, value-oriented model available in two trim levels (City and City Plus), powered exclusively by the 1.5-litre turbocharged petrol engine paired to either a 6-speed manual or 7-speed DCT transmission. The Pro variant is the sportier model, based on the Haval Chitu platform and available in four trim levels (Premium, Super Luxury, Ultra Luxury, and S Ultra Luxury), offering customers a choice between the 1.5-litre turbocharged petrol engine or the advanced 1.5-litre HEV hybrid powertrain with Dedicated Hybrid Transmission (DHT). The hybrid system combines a 70 kW petrol engine with a 115 kW electric motor (189 hp combined system output) to deliver 375 Nm of torque with improved efficiency rated at 5.1 L/100 km. The updated Jolion includes enhanced features with a 12.3-inch central touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and satellite navigation, a 7.0-inch instrument display, and a head-up display system. The market expansion continues with the Jolion making its Indonesian debut on 17 July 2024 with deliveries commencing in October 2024, offered exclusively with the 1.5L HEV hybrid powertrain in a more limited variant range tailored to the market. Most recently, the Jolion went on sale in Vietnam on 11 March 2025 with two trim levels (Pro and Ultra), again offered exclusively with the 1.5L HEV hybrid powertrain. The facelift generation demonstrates Haval's strategy of diversifying powertrains across different markets while maintaining the vehicle's core value proposition of an affordable, well-equipped compact SUV with strong safety features. The continued global expansion, particularly the introduction of advanced hybrid technology to Southeast Asian markets, reflects the company's commitment to offering efficient, modern alternatives to conventional petrol powertrains without significant price premiums.
Haval-Jolion.name: First Generation Facelift

Haval-Jolion-HEV.description: The Haval Jolion HEV is the hybrid variant of Great Wall Motor's compact crossover SUV, representing the company's expansion into electrified powertrains for global markets. Built on GWM's L.E.M.O.N. platform (B30), it shares its modern, stylish exterior design with the conventional Jolion while featuring a distinct front-end design unique to the hybrid variant, including modified headlights, turn signals, front bumper, front grille and rear bumper. The hybrid powertrain combines a 1.5L turbocharged four-cylinder engine (GW4G15H) with an electric motor for a combined output of 140 kW (190 hp) and 375 Nm of torque, paired with a dedicated hybrid transmission (DHT115). This power-split hybrid system allows for pure electric driving at low speeds, with the gasoline engine engaging when more power is needed. The interior features a 12.3-inch central touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and satellite navigation, along with a 7.0-inch instrument display and optional head-up display. Standard technology includes wireless smartphone charging, dual-zone climate control with PM2.5 air filter, and a six-speaker sound system. The Jolion HEV delivers fuel efficiency of approximately 5.0L/100km in combined driving conditions, significantly better than its conventional counterpart. As one of the more affordable hybrid SUVs in many markets, the Jolion HEV has helped strengthen Haval's international presence, particularly in Australia, South Africa, Southeast Asia, and other export markets where production continues since 2021.
Haval-Jolion-HEV.name: First Generation

Holden-Commodore.description: The original Holden Commodore was introduced as a replacement for the larger Kingswood, representing Holden's response to the global fuel crisis with a more efficient, European-influenced design. Based on the Opel Rekord/Senator, but modified for Australian conditions, it featured a rear-wheel drive layout with either inline-six or V8 engines. Available in sedan and wagon body styles across various trim levels, it established the Commodore nameplate that would become an Australian automotive icon. Despite initial criticism for its smaller size compared to the Kingswood, the VB Commodore proved successful, combining respectable performance with improved efficiency.
Holden-Commodore.name: VB

Holden-Commodore.description: These iterations refined the first-generation Commodore concept with progressive updates to styling, engineering, and features. The VC introduced a five-speed manual transmission and improved electronics. The VH featured revised exterior styling and interior improvements. The VK received a significant facelift with a more squared-off design. The VL represented the most substantial update with new sheet metal and the controversial replacement of Holden's inline-six with a Nissan-sourced 3.0L engine (alongside the optional V8), plus the introduction of a turbocharged variant. Throughout these series, the Commodore maintained its position as a core model in Holden's lineup, offering a balance of performance, comfort, and practicality.
Holden-Commodore.name: VC, VH, VK, VL

Holden-Commodore.description: The second-generation Commodore marked a return to larger dimensions, with the VN based on a widened Opel Omega A platform. Engine options included a 3.8L V6 and a 5.0L V8, with later high-performance variants developed by Holden Special Vehicles (HSV). Through the VP, VR, and VS updates, the Commodore received progressive improvements to safety, refinement, and technology. The VR and VS in particular featured significantly improved interior quality and design. This generation firmly established the Commodore as Australia's best-selling car for much of its run, appealing to families, fleet buyers, and performance enthusiasts alike with its combination of space, capability, and value.
Holden-Commodore.name: VN, VP, VR, VS

Holden-Commodore.description: The third-generation Commodore was based on the Opel Omega B platform but extensively modified for Australian requirements. The VT introduced more sophisticated styling, improved safety, and enhanced refinement. Engine options evolved to include an upgraded 3.8L V6 and later a Gen III 5.7L V8. The VX, VY, and VZ updates brought incremental improvements to styling, technology, and powertrains, with the VZ introducing the locally developed Alloytec V6. This generation expanded to include the Monaro coupe and all-wheel drive variants, demonstrating the platform's versatility. Throughout this period, the Commodore maintained its position as a cornerstone of Australian car culture and Holden's most important model.
Holden-Commodore.name: VT, VX, VY, VZ

Holden-Commodore.description: The fourth-generation Commodore was the first to be wholly developed in Australia, using GM's global Zeta platform. The VE featured more muscular styling, improved structural rigidity, and better dynamics. Engine options included V6 and V8 powerplants, with the lineup spanning from workhorse fleet models to luxury variants and high-performance SS versions. The VF update in 2013 brought more sophisticated styling, dramatically improved interior quality, and advanced technology including MyLink infotainment. Despite its critical acclaim, this generation faced declining sales as consumer preferences shifted toward SUVs and smaller, more efficient vehicles. The locally manufactured Commodore concluded production in October 2017 with the closure of Holden's Elizabeth plant, marking the end of Australian car manufacturing.
Holden-Commodore.name: VE, VF

Holden-Commodore.description: The final Commodore was a rebadged Opel Insignia/Vauxhall Insignia, representing a fundamental shift from the traditional rear-wheel drive, Australian-built formula to an imported front-wheel drive (or all-wheel drive) platform. Available in liftback sedan and wagon body styles, it featured turbocharged four-cylinder engines in most variants, with a naturally aspirated V6 in higher-end models. While technically accomplished with modern technology, refined driving dynamics, and improved efficiency, the ZB Commodore struggled to gain acceptance among traditional Commodore buyers who valued the previous generations' rear-wheel drive performance characteristics. Following General Motors' decision to retire the Holden brand, the Commodore was discontinued in 2020, ending a 42-year nameplate that had defined Australian automotive culture for generations.
Holden-Commodore.name: ZB (Imported)

Holden-Cruze.description: The original vehicle sold as the Holden Cruze in Australia was a rebadged Suzuki Ignis, a subcompact crossover SUV. Announced as the Chevrolet YGM1 concept car at the 1999 Tokyo Motor Show, the production Cruze was derived from the Suzuki Ignis five-door hatchback. Despite Chevrolet branding, Holden executed most of the engineering work and devised the Cruze nameplate. Available with 1.3 or 1.5-liter engines coupled to five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmissions, it was marketed as a light-duty SUV rather than a conventional passenger car. From 2002 through to 2006, this generation was sold in Australia and New Zealand before being discontinued.
Holden-Cruze.name: First Generation (as rebadged Suzuki Ignis)

Holden-Cruze.description: The Holden Cruze that most consumers recognize was part of GM's global compact car program, carrying the J300 internal designation. Initially imported from South Korea before transitioning to Australian production in 2011 at Holden's Elizabeth plant, the Cruze was built on GM's Delta II platform. Available as a four-door sedan and five-door hatchback (developed specifically by Holden for Australian tastes), it featured 1.4L and 1.6L turbocharged petrol engines and a 2.0L turbodiesel, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. The Australian-built Cruze represented an important diversification of Holden's local manufacturing beyond the larger Commodore. Production ended in 2016 as part of the phased closure of Holden's Australian manufacturing operations. In 2016, the Cruze sedan was restyled and renamed for the Australasian market as the Holden Astra Sedan.
Holden-Cruze.name: Second Generation (Global Compact Car)

Honda-Accord.description: The original Honda Accord was introduced as a compact hatchback before a sedan variant was added. Measuring just 162.8 inches in length, it was significantly smaller than modern Accords. Powered by a 1.6L four-cylinder engine producing approximately 68 HP, it emphasized efficiency during the oil crisis era. The interior featured a simple, functional design with good visibility and logical controls. This generation established the Accord's reputation for quality, reliability, and efficiency, helping Honda gain a foothold in the American market as an alternative to domestic manufacturers.
Honda-Accord.name: First Generation

Honda-Accord.description: The second-generation Accord grew slightly in size and added more sophisticated styling while maintaining the hatchback and sedan body styles. Power increased with a 1.8L engine producing around 86 HP. The interior saw improvements in materials and design, with more comfort features available. This generation introduced technologies like fuel injection on higher trims and was the first Accord to be manufactured in the United States at Honda's Marysville, Ohio plant—a significant milestone for Japanese automakers. Sales increased substantially, establishing the Accord as a mainstream competitor in the American market.
Honda-Accord.name: Second Generation

Honda-Accord.description: The third-generation Accord grew again in size and sophistication, with more aerodynamic styling and retractable headlights on some models. Available in sedan, hatchback, and for the first time, coupe body styles. Power came from a 2.0L four-cylinder with output ranging from 98 to 110 HP depending on the model year and market. The interior featured a more upscale design with improved ergonomics and available luxury features like power windows, locks, and a moonroof. This generation continued to build the Accord's reputation for quality and reliability while adding more refinement and features.
Honda-Accord.name: Third Generation

Honda-Accord.description: The fourth-generation Accord featured more rounded styling and increased dimensions, transitioning from the compact to mid-size category. Available in sedan, coupe, and (in some markets) wagon body styles. Engine options included 2.0L and 2.2L four-cylinders with power ranging from 125 to 140 HP. The interior saw significant improvements in materials, design, and space utilization. This generation further solidified the Accord's position as a benchmark in the mid-size segment, becoming the best-selling car in the United States in 1991—a first for a Japanese manufacturer.
Honda-Accord.name: Fourth Generation

Honda-Accord.description: The fifth-generation Accord continued the model's growth in size and refinement, with smoother styling and increased interior space. Engine options included 2.2L four-cylinder and 2.7L V6 powerplants, the latter marking the first V6 offering in an Accord. The interior featured a more premium design with improved materials and available features including leather seating and a sophisticated audio system. This generation maintained the Accord's reputation for quality and reliability while adding more power and luxury features, keeping it competitive against increasingly sophisticated rivals.
Honda-Accord.name: Fifth Generation

Honda-Accord.description: The sixth-generation Accord featured more distinctive styling and was available in sedan and coupe body styles, with the coupes having unique, sportier sheetmetal. Engine options included improved 2.3L four-cylinder and 3.0L V6 units with up to 200 HP. The interior saw improvements in design, material quality, and technology features. This generation enhanced the Accord's driver engagement while maintaining its practical virtues, further cementing its position as a top seller in the mid-size segment and a benchmark for the competition.
Honda-Accord.name: Sixth Generation

Honda-Accord.description: The seventh-generation Accord grew substantially, approaching full-size dimensions in the North American market while remaining mid-sized in other regions. Available in sedan and coupe body styles with distinct designs, it offered 2.4L four-cylinder and 3.0L V6 engines with power up to 240 HP. The interior featured a more premium design with improved materials and technology. This generation continued the Accord's legacy of combining quality, reliability, and practicality with increasing levels of refinement and performance, maintaining its position as one of the top-selling cars in its segment.
Honda-Accord.name: Seventh Generation

Honda-Accord.description: The eighth-generation Accord grew again in size, officially classified as a full-size car in the US while other markets received a smaller, distinct model. Available in sedan and coupe body styles, it featured more angular styling and improved aerodynamics. Engine options included 2.4L four-cylinder and 3.5L V6 units with power up to 271 HP.
