The interior offered increased space with improved materials and design. Technology advanced with available navigation, Bluetooth connectivity, and advanced safety features. This generation maintained the Accord's reputation for quality and reliability while offering more space and features, though some critics felt it had strayed from the model's nimble handling heritage.
Honda-Accord.name: Eighth Generation

Honda-Accord.description: The ninth-generation Accord slightly reduced exterior dimensions while maintaining interior space, representing a focus on efficiency and maneuverability. Available in sedan and coupe body styles, it offered 2.4L four-cylinder and 3.5L V6 engines, plus new hybrid and plug-in hybrid variants. The interior featured improved materials, design, and technology, including standard rearview camera and available Apple CarPlay/Android Auto in later model years. Honda Sensing safety technology was introduced, offering features like adaptive cruise control and collision mitigation braking. This generation successfully balanced the Accord's traditional virtues with modern technology and efficiency requirements.
Honda-Accord.name: Ninth Generation

Honda-Accord.description: The tenth-generation Accord featured a complete redesign with more dramatic, fastback-inspired styling and a focus on driving dynamics. The coupe body style was discontinued, with the sedan adopting a sleeker, coupe-like profile. Traditional V6 engines were replaced by turbocharged 1.5L and 2.0L four-cylinders, plus a hybrid variant. The interior saw a significant upgrade in design, materials, and technology, including a standard 7-inch or available 8-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. Honda Sensing safety features became standard across all trims. This generation received critical acclaim for its combination of style, performance, efficiency, and technology, winning numerous awards while maintaining the Accord's reputation for quality and reliability.
Honda-Accord.name: Tenth Generation

Honda-Accord.description: The current Accord features evolutionary styling with cleaner lines and a more upright front end, built on a revised version of the previous platform with increased rigidity. Engine options include a refined 1.5L turbocharged four-cylinder and a new fourth-generation hybrid system that now forms the upper half of the lineup. The interior represents a major advancement with a simplified, horizontal dashboard design, standard 10.2-inch digital instrument display, and available 12.3-inch touchscreen infotainment system with wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. Material quality has improved with more premium touches in higher trims. Technology now includes Google Built-in services on higher trims, enhanced Honda Sensing safety features, and available head-up display. This generation focuses on refinement, efficiency, and technology while maintaining the Accord's traditional strengths of reliability and practicality, aiming to defend the sedan segment amid declining sales as consumers shift toward SUVs.
Honda-Accord.name: Eleventh Generation

Honda-Accord-Hybrid.description: The original Accord Hybrid was based on the seventh-generation Accord and took an unusual approach to hybrid technology, focusing on performance rather than maximum fuel economy. It paired a 3.0L V6 engine with an electric motor for a combined 255 HP, making it more powerful than the standard V6 model. Using Honda's Integrated Motor Assist (IMA) system, it featured a relatively small battery pack and could not operate in electric-only mode for extended periods. The exterior was distinguished by subtle hybrid badging, unique wheels, and a small rear spoiler. The interior was largely identical to high-end Accord models with leather seating and premium features as standard. While it delivered better fuel economy than the conventional V6 Accord, the modest improvement (around 25% better) and high price premium limited its appeal. This generation represented Honda's first attempt at a hybrid mid-size sedan, but its performance-oriented approach contrasted with competitors like the Toyota Camry Hybrid that prioritized efficiency.
Honda-Accord-Hybrid.name: First Generation

Honda-Accord-Hybrid.description: After a six-year hiatus, the Accord Hybrid returned based on the ninth-generation Accord with a completely different approach. This time focusing on efficiency, it featured Honda's new two-motor hybrid system combining a 2.0L Atkinson-cycle four-cylinder engine with two electric motors for a combined 196 HP. Unlike the previous IMA system, this more sophisticated setup allowed for extended electric-only driving and three distinct operating modes. Exterior differences were again subtle, with unique blue-accented grille and lights, aerodynamic wheels, and hybrid badging. The interior featured special hybrid displays and instrumentation while maintaining the comfort and quality of standard Accord models. Fuel economy was dramatically improved to an EPA-rated 50 mpg city, 45 mpg highway, making it among the most efficient mid-size sedans of its time. This generation established a more successful formula for the Accord Hybrid, though production constraints limited its availability.
Honda-Accord-Hybrid.name: Second Generation

Honda-Accord-Hybrid.description: Based on the tenth-generation Accord, this iteration refined the two-motor hybrid system with a more compact design and improved power delivery. The 2.0L Atkinson-cycle four-cylinder engine and dual electric motors produced a combined 212 HP while delivering excellent efficiency. Exterior styling was largely identical to conventional Accord models aside from hybrid badging and unique wheel designs. The interior featured the tenth-generation Accord's upscale design with hybrid-specific displays and instrumentation to monitor power flow and efficiency. Initially available in multiple trim levels from base to Touring, it offered varying levels of luxury and technology while maintaining the same hybrid powertrain. A refresh in 2021 brought updated styling, improved hybrid system refinement, and enhanced technology. This generation successfully integrated the hybrid powertrain into the critically acclaimed tenth-generation Accord platform, offering an efficient alternative without compromising the sedan's driving dynamics or practicality.
Honda-Accord-Hybrid.name: Third Generation

Honda-Accord-Hybrid.description: The current Accord Hybrid is based on the eleventh-generation Accord and features the fourth generation of Honda's two-motor hybrid system. Now positioned as the upper half of the Accord lineup rather than a separate model, it pairs a 2.0L Atkinson-cycle four-cylinder engine with upgraded electric motors for a combined 204 HP. The system is more responsive and refined than its predecessor, with smoother transitions between power sources. Exterior styling is identical to non-hybrid eleventh-generation Accords except for hybrid badging. The interior features the same horizontal dashboard design with a standard 10.2-inch digital instrument display and available 12.3-inch touchscreen, plus hybrid-specific information displays. Available in Sport, Sport-L, EX-L, and Touring trims, the hybrid now represents the premium end of the Accord range with more features and technology than the base 1.5L turbocharged models. This generation emphasizes the hybrid powertrain's refinement and performance benefits alongside its efficiency, positioning it as the preferred choice rather than merely an alternative, reflecting Honda's increased focus on electrification across its lineup.
Honda-Accord-Hybrid.name: Fourth Generation

Honda-Brio.description: The original Honda Brio was a subcompact hatchback developed primarily for emerging Asian markets including Thailand, India, Indonesia, and the Philippines. Featuring distinctive styling with a prominent glass hatchback and compact dimensions (under 3.8 meters long), it was designed for urban environments with tight spaces and congested traffic. Powered by a 1.2L i-VTEC four-cylinder engine producing around 88-90 HP depending on the market, paired with either a 5-speed manual or CVT transmission. The interior focused on maximizing space efficiency within the small footprint, offering surprising roominess for four adults despite the compact exterior. Trim levels and features varied by market, with later models receiving touchscreen infotainment systems in higher trims. A sedan variant called the Brio Amaze (or simply Amaze in some markets) was introduced in 2013, offering a conventional trunk instead of the hatchback's glass rear. A significant refresh in 2016 updated the styling with a new front fascia and revised interior. This generation established the Brio as Honda's entry-level offering in multiple Asian markets, providing the brand's reputation for quality and reliability in an affordable package.
Honda-Brio.name: First Generation

Honda-Brio.description: The current Brio features a complete redesign with more mature styling that abandons the distinctive all-glass rear hatch of its predecessor in favor of a more conventional design. Slightly larger than the first generation, it's based on a modified version of the platform used for the previous-generation Honda Jazz/Fit. Powered by the same 1.2L i-VTEC four-cylinder engine in most markets, with slight variations in output depending on region, paired with either a 5-speed manual or CVT transmission. The interior represents a significant upgrade with better materials, more modern design, and improved technology features including larger touchscreen infotainment systems with smartphone connectivity in higher trims. Safety equipment has been enhanced with features like ABS, EBD, and multiple airbags, though specifications vary by market. Unlike the previous generation, this Brio is primarily offered as a hatchback, with the sedan version (Amaze) now more significantly differentiated as a separate model. The second-generation Brio maintains its position as Honda's entry-level model in many Asian markets, competing against rivals like the Toyota Wigo/Agya, Suzuki Swift, and Mitsubishi Mirage, while offering a more refined package than its predecessor.
Honda-Brio.name: Second Generation

Honda-CR-V.description: The original Honda CR-V (RD1) was introduced in Japan in October 1995 and hit North American markets in February 1997. Designed by Hiroyuki Kawase, it was Honda's first in-house designed sport utility vehicle built on a modified Civic platform. Powered by a 2.0L B20B/B20Z four-cylinder engine paired with a five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmission, it offered practical, car-like performance. Notable for its unique externally-mounted spare tire and side-hinged rear door, removable picnic table, and Real Time AWD system that engaged automatically when slippage was detected. The 2000 model year received a facelift with an improved B20Z engine producing 147 hp, new front bumper design, and smoothed rear styling. This generation established the CR-V as a pioneer in the emerging car-based crossover SUV segment.
Honda-CR-V.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Honda-CR-V.description: The second generation CR-V went on sale November 12, 2001 (2002 model year) as a full redesign based on the seventh-generation Civic platform. It was powered by the 2.4L K24A1 engine (or K20A4 in Southeast Asia) with i-VTEC technology, producing 160 hp in North America. The exterior-mounted spare tire and side-hinged door gave way to an upward-opening tailgate and internally-stored spare tire, reflecting mainstream appeal. The new unibody design with increased torsional rigidity and improved suspension allowed for significantly more cargo space (72 cu ft). The front suspension used MacPherson struts with toe-control links, while the rear featured a reactive-link double-wishbone design. The interior saw major improvements in materials, space, and features. In 2004, the mid-cycle refresh introduced new 16-inch wheels, redesigned lights, drive-by-wire throttle, and five-speed automatic transmission. Named Car and Driver Best Small SUV for 2002 and 2003.
Honda-CR-V.name: Second Generation (Facelift)

Honda-CR-V.description: The third-generation CR-V went on sale in late September 2006 for the 2007 model year. Portions of the body structure, drivetrain, and suspension were carried over from the previous generation, while interior and exterior styling changed significantly. It introduced a rear liftgate with bottom-side spare tire mount, replacing the side-opening rear door. Powered by a 2.4L K-series inline-four engine rated at 166 hp and 161 lbft in North America, with a 2.2L i-CTDI diesel available in Europe and Asia. The European market received the 2.0L R20A gasoline engine instead. The 2010 model year featured a mid-cycle refresh with redesigned front fascia, new horizontal-slat chrome grille, honeycomb lower grille, revised tail lights, and new alloy wheels. Interior improvements included revised seat fabrics, wider armrests, and blue-backlit instruments. This generation emphasized carlike styling and driving dynamics while maintaining passenger comfort.
Honda-CR-V.name: Third Generation (Facelift)

Honda-CR-V.description: The fourth-generation CR-V went on sale December 15, 2011 (2012 model year) with evolutionary styling and significant mechanical improvements. The CR-V Concept had debuted at the Orange County International Auto Show in September 2011, followed by the production model at the 2011 Los Angeles Auto Show. Powered by a 2.4L i-VTEC inline-four engine producing 185 hp and 163 lbft of torque with an all-new Real-Time AWD with intelligent control and five-speed automatic transmission. The 2015 model year (October 2014 debut) introduced a facelifted design with direct-injected Earth Dreams engine and continuously variable transmission (CVT) offering improved fuel economy (+4/+3/+3 mpg city/highway/combined). The facelift also included modified suspension shock absorbers, springs, and anti-roll bars for improved ride performance, reduced 15.6:1 steering gear ratio, larger brake booster for sportier feel, and improved crash performance in IIHS testing. The 2.4L Earth Dreams engine rated 180-188 hp depending on market and fuel grade.
Honda-CR-V.name: Fourth Generation (Facelift)

Honda-CR-V.description: The fifth generation CR-V was unveiled October 13, 2016 in Detroit, with sales beginning December 21, 2016 as a 2017 model year. It utilized the Honda compact global platform introduced with the tenth-generation Civic. Honda began production at East Liberty, Ohio (November 2016) and Greensburg, Indiana (February 2017). It was available with an optional 7-seater variant in markets outside North America. In October 2019, Guangqi Honda in China began marketing the model as the Honda Breeze (Hàoyǐng) with different styling. A refreshed model was unveiled in September 2019 for the 2020 model year, introducing the first CR-V Hybrid variant in North America, combining a 2.0L Atkinson-cycle engine with electric motors. The refresh added Honda Sensing as standard across all trim levels, providing adaptive cruise control and collision mitigation braking. Features included floating touchscreen, digital instrument cluster, improved materials, increased passenger and cargo space, and LED lighting elements. The turbocharged 1.5L engine provided improved performance and efficiency over the previous naturally aspirated engines.
Honda-CR-V.name: Fifth Generation (Facelift)

Honda-CR-V.description: The sixth generation CR-V was unveiled July 12, 2022 in Los Angeles, with sales commencing in September 2022 as a 2023 model year. Based on the Honda Architecture platform that underpinned the eleventh-generation Civic, it features a complete redesign with more rugged styling cues including a longer hood, upright grille, and stronger horizontal elements. Available in 5 and 7-seater configurations varying by market. The CR-V is slightly larger than its predecessor in all dimensions, offering increased passenger and cargo space. Powertrain options include an enhanced 1.5L turbocharged four-cylinder and a significantly improved two-motor hybrid system (e-HEV) offering improved performance with 204 combined HP. In China, GAC Honda marketed the model as the Honda Breeze in December 2022 with different front and rear fascias. Dongfeng Honda exports its CR-V models to Europe beginning June 2023. The interior features a horizontal dashboard design with standard 7-inch touchscreen (9-inch available), 7-inch digital instrument display, and improved materials. The hybrid variant accounts for a larger market portion and comes standard with all-wheel drive. Standard Honda Sensing safety features, wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto on higher trims, and available Google built-in services enhance the appeal of this generation-leading segment vehicle.
Honda-CR-V.name: Sixth Generation

Honda-CR-V-Hybrid.description: The original CR-V Hybrid was based on the fifth-generation CR-V platform, representing Honda's first electrified SUV in many markets. Featuring the same exterior design as the standard CR-V with subtle hybrid badging and blue-accented Honda emblems, it combined a 2.0L Atkinson-cycle four-cylinder engine with two electric motors for a combined output of approximately 212 HP (varying slightly by market). Unlike many hybrid systems that use a conventional transmission, Honda's Intelligent Multi-Mode Drive (i-MMD) used a single fixed gear ratio for most driving conditions, with the electric motor providing primary propulsion and the engine acting either as a generator or providing direct drive at higher speeds. The interior was nearly identical to the standard CR-V with hybrid-specific displays in the instrument cluster to monitor power flow and efficiency. Available in front-wheel drive in some markets and standard all-wheel drive in others, it delivered significantly improved fuel economy over the conventional models, typically achieving around 40 mpg in combined driving. This generation established the CR-V Hybrid as an efficient alternative within Honda's bestselling SUV lineup, though its introduction timing varied considerably by region, arriving first in Europe and Asia before later expansion to North America for the 2020 model year.
Honda-CR-V-Hybrid.name: First Generation (Fifth-generation CR-V platform)

Honda-CR-V-Hybrid.description: The current CR-V Hybrid is built on the sixth-generation CR-V platform, featuring the same more rugged exterior styling with a longer hood, upright grille, and stronger horizontal elements. The hybrid powertrain has been significantly enhanced, now combining a refined 2.0L Atkinson-cycle four-cylinder engine with a more powerful electric motor system for a combined output of 204 HP and 247 lb-ft of torque—positioning it as the performance option in the CR-V lineup rather than just the efficiency choice. Honda's improved fourth-generation hybrid system (still using the i-MMD architecture) offers more refined operation and stronger acceleration while maintaining excellent fuel economy rated at 40 mpg combined in AWD form. The interior matches the upscale improvements of the standard sixth-generation CR-V, featuring a horizontal dashboard design with a standard 7-inch touchscreen (9-inch available) and 7-inch digital instrument display, though with hybrid-specific information screens. Unlike the previous generation where the hybrid was a niche variant, this generation positions the hybrid as a core part of the lineup, available in multiple trim levels and expected to comprise approximately 50% of CR-V sales as Honda accelerates its electrification strategy. All CR-V Hybrid models now come standard with all-wheel drive in North America, enhancing its appeal in all-weather conditions. This generation represents Honda's commitment to hybrid technology as a bridge toward full electrification, offering a no-compromise option that improves both performance and efficiency over the standard turbocharged model.
Honda-CR-V-Hybrid.name: Second Generation (Sixth-generation CR-V platform)

Honda-CR-Z.description: The Honda CR-Z was a unique hybrid sports compact that attempted to blend efficiency with driving enjoyment—marketed as the world's first hybrid sports car. Featuring distinctive wedge-shaped styling with a split-level rear glass hatch reminiscent of the Honda CRX from the 1980s, it was designed as a spiritual successor to that enthusiast favorite. Powered by a hybrid system combining a 1.5L i-VTEC four-cylinder engine with an electric motor (Honda's Integrated Motor Assist system), it produced 122 HP combined output. Uniquely for a hybrid at that time, it was available with either a six-speed manual transmission or a continuously variable transmission (CVT). The interior featured a driver-focused design with a futuristic digital instrument cluster that changed color based on driving mode and a two-seat-only configuration in North America, emphasizing its sports car aspirations. Three selectable driving modes—Sport, Normal, and Econ—altered throttle response, steering assist, and climate control operation. Production began in February 2010 in Japan.
Honda-CR-Z.name: First Generation

Honda-CR-Z.description: The 2013 facelift brought significant powertrain improvements including a more powerful electric motor (up from 10 to 15 kW) and a new higher voltage (144V) 0.6 kWh lithium-ion battery pack, increasing combined output to 130 HP at 6,000 rpm (up from 121 HP) and torque to 140 lb-ft. The Plus Sport System (S+ button) became standard, allowing drivers to access electric boost acceleration for up to five seconds when the battery is above 30% charge and traveling over 18 mph. EPA fuel economy improved by 1 mpg in both city (for CVT) and highway (for manual). Manual transmission models received a larger clutch and new lower final drive ratio. Minor cosmetic changes accompanied the technical upgrades.
Honda-CR-Z.name: First Generation (2013 Facelift)

Honda-City.description: The original Honda City was a subcompact hatchback significantly different from later models bearing the name. Featuring distinctive 'tallboy' styling that maximized interior space within a minimal footprint (under 3.4 meters long), it was designed specifically for congested Japanese urban environments. Powered by small but efficient engines including a 1.2L CVCC unit, it emphasized fuel economy and maneuverability. A notable variant was the Turbo, which added a turbocharged engine producing 100 HP—impressive for its time and size. The Motocompo, a folding scooter designed to fit in the City's trunk, was an innovative accessory. This generation established the City nameplate but bears little resemblance to the sedan models that would later use the name globally.
Honda-City.name: First Generation

Honda-City.description: The second-generation City continued as a Japan-focused model but with more conventional styling that abandoned the 'tallboy' concept for a lower, sportier profile. Available in hatchback and convertible body styles, it catered to a more youthful demographic. Engine options included various 1.2L and 1.3L units, with performance variants like the CR-i featuring more powerful DOHC engines. This generation maintained the City's focus on the Japanese market and continued to be a subcompact hatchback rather than the sedan body style that would later define the nameplate globally.
Honda-City.name: Second Generation

Honda-City.description: The third-generation marked a fundamental shift for the City nameplate, transforming from a Japan-market hatchback to a subcompact sedan designed primarily for emerging Asian markets. Developed specifically for markets like Thailand and the Philippines, it featured conventional three-box sedan styling. Powered by a 1.3L SOHC engine, it emphasized affordability, reliability, and fuel efficiency. A revised facelifted version was released in 2000, called the 'Type Z' in some markets, featuring new front end styling, tail lights, and one-piece bumpers. This generation established the template for the City as Honda's entry-level sedan for developing markets—a positioning that continues to the present day.
Honda-City.name: Third Generation

Honda-City.description: The fourth-generation City continued as a subcompact sedan for Asian markets but with more sophisticated styling and engineering. Featuring a more aerodynamic design with a distinctive front end, it grew slightly in dimensions. Engine options typically included 1.3L and 1.5L i-DSI units known for excellent fuel efficiency, with VTEC variants added in 2004. A significant mid-term facelift was introduced in September/October/November 2005, featuring a new front grille, headlamps, fog lights, tail lights, and bumpers. The front end was extended forward by 65mm while the rear was extended by 15mm, and interior updates included an armrest for the driver. The interior colour tone of VTEC variants changed to black. This generation expanded the City's market presence across Asia and parts of the Middle East, establishing it as an important global model for Honda.
Honda-City.name: Fourth Generation

Honda-City.description: The fifth-generation City adopted Honda's 'Advanced Sports Sedan' concept with more dynamic styling and increased dimensions that positioned it between the subcompact and compact segments. Powered primarily by a 1.5L i-VTEC engine, it offered improved performance along with good fuel efficiency. A major facelift was introduced in September 2011, featuring a new front grille design, front and rear bumpers, taillamps, alloy wheels, and eco driving indicator. Dual front airbags became standard on all models. Ground clearance increased to 165mm and length grew by 20mm. The interior received updates including blue optitron speedometer dials in some markets. Production continued in Pakistan until 2021 under the City Aspire nameplate with additional features including keyless entry and revised styling. This generation further established the City as an aspirational yet accessible sedan in emerging markets.
Honda-City.name: Fifth Generation

Honda-City.description: The sixth-generation City featured more sophisticated styling with Honda's 'Exciting H' design language, featuring a prominent chrome grille. Slightly larger than its predecessor with a longer wheelbase, it offered impressive interior space approaching that of compact sedans. A key engineering change was the repositioning of the fuel tank from the middle to the rear of the vehicle, allowing a lower seating position and sleeker exterior design. Powered by refined 1.5L engines including Earth Dreams technology, it offered both petrol and hybrid variants (i-DCD Sport Hybrid system in select markets). A significant mid-life facelift was launched in January 2017, featuring LED headlamps with daytime running lights, LED tail lights, and a revised chrome bar grille similar to the Civic. Honda Sensing safety suite became available on higher trims. The interior saw significant improvements in design, materials, and technology, with features like touchscreen infotainment systems and rearview cameras. This generation was also sold as Honda Grace in Japan (2014-2020), Honda Ballade in South Africa, and Honda Greiz/Gienia in China.
Honda-City.name: Sixth Generation

Honda-City.description: The current City features the most sophisticated design in the nameplate's history, with a longer, wider body and bold styling that closely resembles the larger Civic and Accord. For the first time, a hatchback variant (called City Hatchback in most markets) was introduced to replace the Jazz/Fit in some regions. Powered primarily by an updated 1.5L DOHC i-VTEC engine, with hybrid options available in select markets using Honda's compact e:HEV system. The interior represents a significant advancement with higher quality materials, a more premium design, and modern technology including an 8-inch touchscreen with smartphone connectivity and a digital instrument cluster in higher trims. Safety features have been substantially upgraded with Honda Sensing available on premium versions, offering features like adaptive cruise control and autonomous emergency braking. This generation elevates the City from its entry-level positioning to a more sophisticated offering that bridges the gap between subcompact and compact segments, reflecting increasing consumer expectations in developing markets.
Honda-City.name: Seventh Generation

Honda-Civic.description: The original Honda Civic was introduced as a fuel-efficient alternative during the 1970s oil crisis. Available as a two-door coupe, three-door hatchback, and later a five-door wagon, it featured front-wheel drive and a transverse engine layout that maximized interior space. Initially powered by a 1.2L four-cylinder engine producing just 50 HP, it emphasized efficiency over performance. The interior was basic but functional, featuring a simple instrument panel and minimal amenities. This generation established the Civic's reputation for fuel efficiency, practicality, and reliability—qualities that would define the nameplate for decades.
Honda-Civic.name: First Generation

Honda-Civic.description: The second-generation Civic grew slightly in size and offered more refined styling with better aerodynamics. Available in hatchback, sedan, and wagon body styles, it continued with front-wheel drive and transverse engine layout. Engine options expanded to include a 1.3L and 1.5L, with the introduction of the sporty S model featuring a twin-carburetor engine. The interior saw improvements in design and comfort, while maintaining a focus on efficient packaging. This generation continued to build the Civic's reputation during a period of increasing Japanese influence in the global automotive market.
Honda-Civic.name: Second Generation

Honda-Civic.description: The third-generation Civic featured more angular styling and introduced the distinctive two-level instrument panel that would become a Honda hallmark. Available in hatchback, sedan, wagon, and the new CRX variant, it continued to emphasize efficiency while adding more performance options. Engine choices included refined 1.3L and 1.5L units, with fuel injection available on higher trims. The S and Si models offered enhanced performance for enthusiasts. This generation significantly expanded the Civic's appeal, particularly in North America, establishing it as a benchmark for small cars.
Honda-Civic.name: Third Generation

Honda-Civic.description: The fourth-generation Civic featured more aerodynamic styling with increased dimensions and refinement. Available in hatchback, sedan, wagon, and CRX body styles, it offered improved handling and comfort. Engine options expanded to include more powerful and refined units, including the 16-valve engines in Si models that made the Civic a favorite among sport compact enthusiasts. The interior grew in size and quality, with better materials and more features. This generation further established the Civic as both a practical commuter car and a potential performance platform.
Honda-Civic.name: Fourth Generation

Honda-Civic.description: The fifth-generation Civic adopted a more rounded, aerodynamic design language. Available in hatchback, sedan, and coupe body styles (the latter replacing the CRX in North America), it offered improved refinement and safety features. Engine options included more efficient and powerful units, with VTEC technology bringing enhanced performance to certain models. The interior featured a more upscale design with better ergonomics and materials. This generation maintained the Civic's position as a class leader while adding more sophistication and technology.
Honda-Civic.name: Fifth Generation

Honda-Civic.description: The sixth-generation Civic continued the aerodynamic design theme with a focus on improved efficiency and refinement. Available in hatchback, sedan, and coupe body styles, it featured a more rigid body structure and enhanced safety features. Engine options varied by market but generally emphasized efficiency, with VTEC technology available on performance-oriented models. The interior offered improved comfort and quality, with better sound insulation and more premium features on higher trims. This generation further refined the Civic formula while maintaining its core virtues of efficiency and reliability.
Honda-Civic.name: Sixth Generation

Honda-Civic.description: The seventh-generation Civic featured more conservative styling but with increased interior space thanks to a flat rear floor and improved packaging. Available in sedan, coupe, and hatchback body styles (though the latter was primarily for European markets), it emphasized refinement and practicality. Engine options included improved i-VTEC units focused on balancing performance and efficiency. The interior adopted a more conventional design compared to previous generations, with better materials and feature content. This generation maintained the Civic's strong market position while appealing to a broader audience with its increased practicality.
Honda-Civic.name: Seventh Generation

Honda-Civic.description: The eighth-generation Civic featured a dramatic redesign with futuristic styling and a distinctive two-tier instrument panel. Available in sedan and coupe body styles in North America (with hatchback versions in Europe and Asia), it grew in size and refinement. Engine options emphasized efficiency, with hybrid variants available for the environmentally conscious. The interior space increased significantly, with more technology features and improved materials. This generation represented a bold design direction for the Civic and expanded its appeal, though some critics felt it had lost some of its sporty character.
Honda-Civic.name: Eighth Generation

Honda-Civic.description: The ninth-generation Civic featured more conservative styling that evolved the design language of its predecessor. Available in sedan and coupe body styles in North America, it initially received criticism for interior quality, leading to an unusually quick refresh in 2013 that improved materials and features. Engine options included efficient four-cylinders and a hybrid variant, with the Si continuing as the performance option. This generation is generally considered the most conservative modern Civic, developed during economic uncertainty following the 2008 financial crisis.
Honda-Civic.name: Ninth Generation

Honda-Civic.description: The tenth-generation Civic featured a dramatic redesign with sporty, distinctive styling that significantly departed from its predecessor. Available in sedan, coupe (until 2020), and the return of the hatchback body style to North America, it offered increased dimensions and a more premium feel. Engine options evolved to focus on turbocharged units, with the 1.5L turbo providing a balance of performance and efficiency. The interior featured improved materials, design, and technology, including available Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. Performance variants expanded to include the Si and the return of the Type R to the US market. This generation was widely acclaimed for restoring the Civic's sporty character while maintaining its practical virtues.
Honda-Civic.name: Tenth Generation

Honda-Civic.description: The current Civic features a more mature design with cleaner lines and a less complicated appearance compared to its predecessor. Available in sedan and hatchback body styles (with the coupe discontinued), it maintains similar dimensions but with a slightly longer wheelbase for improved rear passenger space. Engine options include a naturally aspirated 2.0L four-cylinder and a turbocharged 1.5L four-cylinder, both offering a balance of performance and efficiency. The interior represents a significant advancement with a horizontal dashboard design featuring a honeycomb mesh element concealing air vents, improved materials, and a standard 7-inch touchscreen (9-inch available). Performance variants include the Si sedan and Type R hatchback, the latter offering over 300 HP from its turbocharged engine. Safety and technology features have been enhanced, with Honda Sensing standard across all trims and available wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration. This generation aims to refine and mature the Civic formula while maintaining its position as a benchmark in the compact car segment.
Honda-Civic.name: Eleventh Generation

Honda-Clarity.description: The original Honda FCX Clarity was a limited-production hydrogen fuel cell vehicle that represented Honda's early commitment to fuel cell technology. Available only through a lease program in select markets with hydrogen infrastructure (primarily Southern California, Japan, and parts of Europe), it featured distinctive styling with a sloping roofline and unique proportions enabled by its purpose-built platform. Powered by Honda's V Flow fuel cell stack producing electricity to drive an electric motor with approximately 134 HP, it offered a range of about 240 miles on a full hydrogen tank. The interior featured seating for four with sustainable materials and a futuristic design befitting its advanced powertrain. As one of the first hydrogen fuel cell vehicles available to consumers (albeit in very limited numbers), the FCX Clarity served more as a technology demonstrator and real-world test platform than a mass-market vehicle. This generation established Honda's expertise in fuel cell technology while providing valuable data from real-world usage.
Honda-Clarity.name: First Generation (FCX Clarity)

Honda-Clarity.description: The second-generation Clarity expanded from a single fuel cell vehicle to a series of alternative powertrain models sharing a common body style. Available in three distinct variants: Fuel Cell (hydrogen), Electric (BEV), and Plug-in Hybrid, it represented Honda's multi-pathway approach to reducing emissions. The Fuel Cell version featured Honda's more compact, powerful fuel cell stack with approximately 174 HP and an improved range of 366 miles. The Electric version offered about 89 miles of range from its 25.5 kWh battery—limited compared to competitors but targeting specific urban markets. The Plug-in Hybrid combined a 1.5L Atkinson-cycle engine with an electric motor and 17 kWh battery for 47 miles of electric range plus gasoline backup. All variants featured distinctive styling with partially covered rear wheels for aerodynamic efficiency, though slightly more conventional than the original FCX Clarity. The interior offered premium appointments with sustainable materials, advanced technology, and seating for five. While the Fuel Cell version remained limited to areas with hydrogen infrastructure, the Plug-in Hybrid was available nationwide and became the volume seller of the lineup. Production ended in 2021 as Honda refocused its electrification strategy toward a new dedicated EV platform. This generation represented Honda's most significant effort to offer multiple zero or low-emission technologies in a single model line, providing valuable experience that would inform the company's future electrification efforts.
Honda-Clarity.name: Second Generation (Clarity Series)

Honda-Element.description: The Honda Element was a compact crossover SUV manufactured by Honda from model years 2003–2011. Produced at the East Liberty Auto Plant in Ohio, it featured distinctive boxy styling with bi-parting rear doors (no B-pillar design) and a highly versatile, washable interior designed for outdoor enthusiasts. Built on a modified second-generation Honda CR-V platform, it was available in front-wheel drive or all-wheel drive (Real Time 4WD). Power came from a 2.4L K-series i-VTEC inline-four engine producing 160 hp (2003–2006) and 166 hp (2007–2011). Transmission options included a 5-speed manual (2003–2010) and automatic transmissions—a 4-speed (2003–2006) replaced by a 5-speed (2007–2011). The interior featured removable rear seats, TPO-coated urethane flooring, and stain-resistant fabrics. A mild refresh in 2007 updated the grille, added standard side airbags and electronic stability control, and introduced the SC trim. Minor updates in 2009 included revised front fenders (metal instead of composite), squared wheel arches, and new color combinations. Trim levels included DX, LX, EX, and SC. Despite developing a cult following for its unique design and practicality, production ended in April 2011 with approximately 325,000 units produced.
Honda-Element.name: First Generation

Honda-Fit.description: The original Honda Fit (sold as the Jazz in some markets) revolutionized the subcompact category with its innovative packaging that maximized interior space within a small footprint. Built on Honda's Global Small Car platform with a central fuel tank layout, it featured the 'Magic Seat' system allowing multiple seating configurations and a flat load floor. Powered by small-displacement four-cylinder engines ranging from 1.2L to 1.5L depending on the market, paired with manual or automatic transmissions, it emphasized efficiency over performance. The interior offered surprising spaciousness for its exterior dimensions, with versatility that allowed it to accommodate items too large for many larger vehicles. This generation established the Fit's reputation for exceptional space efficiency and clever packaging, quickly becoming a global success across various markets.
Honda-Fit.name: First Generation

Honda-Fit.description: The second-generation Fit refined the successful formula with more aerodynamic styling, slightly larger dimensions, and improved refinement. The 'Magic Seat' system was enhanced with even more configurations, maintaining the model's class-leading versatility. Engine options continued with various small-displacement four-cylinders, typically ranging from 1.3L to 1.5L depending on the market, with improved fuel efficiency and slightly better performance. The interior featured higher quality materials and more technology features, including available navigation on higher trims. Safety was enhanced with standard stability control in many markets and improved crash structures. This generation further established the Fit as a benchmark in the subcompact segment, combining practicality with enjoyable driving dynamics and Honda's reputation for reliability.
Honda-Fit.name: Second Generation

Honda-Fit.description: The third-generation Fit featured more angular styling with a strong character line and a more prominent front end. While maintaining similar exterior dimensions to its predecessor, interior space improved further with class-leading rear legroom. The 'Magic Seat' system continued as a key feature, with refinements for even easier operation. Engine options varied by market but typically centered around efficient 1.3L to 1.5L four-cylinders, with hybrid variants available in some regions. The interior saw significant improvements in materials, design, and technology, featuring a touchscreen infotainment system on higher trims with smartphone connectivity. The platform employs ultra-high strength 780 MPa steel for 27 percent of the bodywork, with a shorter overall length by 4cm but a 3cm longer wheelbase and increased rear legroom by 12.2cm compared to the previous generation.
Honda-Fit.name: Third Generation

Honda-Fit.description: The facelifted third-generation Fit/Jazz received significant updates including new bumpers, revised radio with Apple CarPlay integration, and LED headlights with daytime running lights incorporated into the headlight units. The Sport trim was added for the U.S. market, featuring underbody spoiler, exhaust finisher, and orange stitching on cloth seats. Honda Sensing driver assistance features became available on higher trims following the refresh. The hybrid variants continued to be offered with Honda's Sport Hybrid i-DCD system, combining a 1.5L Atkinson-cycle engine with dual-clutch transmission for improved efficiency. Production continued through 2022 across various global markets including Japan, Europe, Thailand, Indonesia, India, and the Americas.
Honda-Fit.name: Third Generation (Facelift)

Honda-Fit.description: The current Fit/Jazz features a more rounded, friendly design compared to its predecessor, with a focus on visibility and ease of use. The 'Magic Seat' system continues as a core feature, maintaining the model's exceptional versatility. Powertrain options have evolved significantly, with many markets (particularly Europe with the Jazz nameplate) focusing exclusively on hybrid powertrains using Honda's efficient e:HEV system, which combines a 1.5L Atkinson-cycle engine with two electric motors for impressive efficiency. The interior has been completely redesigned with a more minimalist approach, featuring a digital instrument cluster, simplified control layout, and improved materials. Visibility has been enhanced with thinner A-pillars and a panoramic windshield design. Technology has advanced significantly with the latest Honda infotainment system and comprehensive Honda Sensing safety features standard on most variants. While this generation maintains the practical, space-efficient character that has defined the Fit/Jazz, it also reflects Honda's shift toward electrification as part of its environmental strategy. Note that in 2020, Honda discontinued the Fit in the North American market, focusing instead on the slightly larger HR-V crossover, though the model continues to be sold globally under both Fit and Jazz nameplates.
Honda-Fit.name: Fourth Generation

Honda-HR-V.description: The original Honda HR-V was a pioneering compact crossover SUV introduced primarily for the Japanese and European markets. Featuring distinctive boxy styling with a high roofline, it was marketed as a 'Joy Machine' that combined car-like handling with SUV versatility. Available in both three-door and five-door configurations, it was built on a modified Honda Logo platform. Powered by a 1.6L VTEC four-cylinder engine with either front-wheel drive or Honda's Real Time 4WD system, it emphasized on-road performance rather than serious off-road capability. The interior featured a car-like dashboard with a relatively high seating position providing the commanding view preferred by SUV buyers. Though not a strong seller globally, this generation was ahead of its time in anticipating the compact crossover trend that would eventually dominate the market.
Honda-HR-V.name: First Generation

Honda-HR-V.description: After a seven-year hiatus, the HR-V nameplate returned on a completely new vehicle based on the Honda Fit/Jazz platform. Featuring more dramatic styling with a coupe-like roofline and hidden rear door handles, it adopted Honda's 'Solid Wing Face' design language. The Fit's central fuel tank layout and 'Magic Seat' system were carried over, providing exceptional interior versatility with multiple seating configurations and a flat load floor when the rear seats were folded. Engine options varied by market but typically included 1.5L to 1.8L four-cylinder gasoline engines and diesel options in Europe, with hybrid variants available in Japan. The interior offered a more premium feel than the Fit, with better materials and available features including a touch-based climate control system and infotainment display. This generation established the HR-V as a global model in Honda's lineup, capitalizing on the rapidly growing subcompact crossover segment and bridging the gap between the Fit and CR-V.
Honda-HR-V.name: Second Generation

Honda-HR-V.description: The current global HR-V (known as Vezel in Japan) features a cleaner design with horizontal lines, a longer hood, and a more upright stance compared to its predecessor. Built on the latest Fit/Jazz platform, it continues to offer the 'Magic Seat' system and exceptional space efficiency. Powertrain options vary significantly by market, with many regions focused on Honda's e:HEV hybrid system that combines a 1.5L Atkinson-cycle engine with electric motors. The interior represents a significant advancement with a more minimalist design featuring a freestanding infotainment display and simplified control layout. Technology includes the latest Honda Sensing safety suite and improved connectivity options. This generation maintains the HR-V's position as a practical, efficient compact crossover while adding more sophistication and electrification options.
Honda-HR-V.name: Third Generation (Global except North America)

Honda-HR-V.description: The North American HR-V diverged from the global model with its own distinct design built on the Civic platform rather than the Fit/Jazz basis used elsewhere. Significantly larger than both its predecessor and the global model, it features more conventional SUV styling with a prominent grille and horizontal body lines. Without the Fit's 'Magic Seat' system, it offers a more traditional interior layout but with substantially more passenger and cargo space than the previous generation. Powered exclusively by a 2.0L naturally aspirated four-cylinder engine in the United States (with 158 HP) paired with a CVT transmission, it focuses on balanced performance rather than maximum efficiency. The interior shares design elements with the latest Civic, featuring a honeycomb-pattern dash accent and either a 7-inch or 9-inch touchscreen depending on trim level. Standard safety technology includes the full Honda Sensing suite across all models. This North America-specific model repositions the HR-V as a more substantial entry-level SUV, particularly important as the Fit was discontinued in this market, making the HR-V Honda's new entry point for many buyers.
Honda-HR-V.name: Third Generation (North America)

Honda-Insight.description: The original Honda Insight was the first gasoline-electric hybrid vehicle sold in the United States, beating the Toyota Prius to market by several months. Featuring radical aerodynamic styling with a teardrop shape and rear wheel skirts, it achieved a remarkable drag coefficient of 0.25. Built as a lightweight two-seater with aluminum body panels and structure, it weighed just over 1,800 pounds. Powered by Honda's first-generation Integrated Motor Assist (IMA) hybrid system combining a 1.0L three-cylinder engine with a thin electric motor sandwiched between the engine and transmission, producing a combined 67 HP. Initially available only with a manual transmission, a CVT option was added later. The interior was basic but futuristic, featuring a digital dashboard that provided feedback on the hybrid system's operation. This generation achieved exceptional fuel economy ratings of up to 61 mpg highway with the manual transmission—figures that remain impressive even by today's standards. While not a strong seller with fewer than 20,000 units sold worldwide, the first Insight established Honda's engineering credibility in hybrid technology and served as an important technical showcase.
Honda-Insight.name: First Generation

Honda-Insight.description: The second-generation Insight was completely redesigned as a five-door hatchback with styling clearly influenced by the Toyota Prius—its main competitor. Significantly more practical than its predecessor, it offered seating for five (though with somewhat tight rear accommodations) and expanded cargo space. Powered by an updated IMA hybrid system combining a 1.3L four-cylinder engine with an electric motor for a combined 98 HP, paired exclusively with a CVT transmission. The interior featured a split-level instrument panel with hybrid system information displays and feedback mechanisms to encourage efficient driving. Marketed as the most affordable hybrid on the market at launch, it sacrificed some efficiency for its lower price point, achieving EPA ratings of 40/43 mpg city/highway—good figures but well below the contemporary Prius. Despite initial sales success, particularly in Japan, the second Insight struggled to maintain momentum as competitors improved their hybrid offerings. Production ended in 2014 after disappointing global sales, with Honda refocusing its hybrid strategy.
Honda-Insight.name: Second Generation

Honda-Insight.description: The final Insight generation abandoned the dedicated hybrid vehicle approach in favor of a sedan body style based on the tenth-generation Civic platform. Featuring sophisticated styling that avoided the overtly 'hybrid' design cues of its predecessors, it positioned itself as a premium compact sedan that happened to be a hybrid. Powered by Honda's two-motor hybrid system rather than the previous IMA technology, it combined a 1.5L Atkinson-cycle four-cylinder engine with electric motors for a combined 151 HP and significantly improved driving dynamics compared to earlier Insights. The interior offered a more upscale experience with better materials and technology, including an available 8-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. Honda Sensing safety technology came standard across all trims. Fuel economy ratings of 55/49 mpg city/highway for the base model were competitive with other dedicated hybrids while offering a more conventional driving experience. Despite critical acclaim and strong efficiency, declining sedan sales led to its discontinuation after the 2022 model year, with Honda shifting its hybrid focus to the more popular Civic and CR-V models. Throughout its three distinct generations, the Insight demonstrated Honda's willingness to experiment with different approaches to hybrid vehicles, from the minimalist two-seater original to the mainstream sedan final version.
Honda-Insight.name: Third Generation

Honda-Jazz.description: The original Honda Jazz (sold as the Fit in some markets, including Japan and North America) revolutionized the subcompact category with its innovative 'Magic Seat' system and central fuel tank layout that maximized interior space. Featuring a tall, MPV-like profile, it offered exceptional interior flexibility with rear seats that could fold flat into the floor or have their seat cushions folded up to accommodate tall items. Powered by small-displacement four-cylinder engines ranging from 1.2L to 1.5L depending on the market, paired with either manual or automatic transmissions, it emphasized efficiency and practicality. The interior offered surprising spaciousness for the vehicle's external dimensions, with clever storage solutions throughout. This generation established the Jazz's reputation for exceptional space utilization and versatility, winning numerous awards globally including Japan Car of the Year.
Honda-Jazz.name: First Generation

Honda-Jazz.description: The second-generation Jazz refined the successful formula with more aerodynamic styling, slightly larger dimensions, and enhanced refinement. The 'Magic Seat' system was improved with even more configurations, maintaining the model's class-leading versatility. Engine options continued with various small-displacement four-cylinders, typically ranging from 1.2L to 1.5L depending on the market, with improved fuel efficiency and slightly better performance. The interior featured higher quality materials and more technology features, including available navigation systems on higher trims. Safety was enhanced with standard stability control in many markets and improved crash structures. This generation further established the Jazz as a benchmark in the subcompact segment, combining exceptional practicality with a surprisingly enjoyable driving experience and Honda's reputation for reliability.
Honda-Jazz.name: Second Generation

Honda-Jazz.description: The third-generation Jazz featured more angular styling with a strong character line and a more prominent front end. While maintaining similar exterior dimensions to its predecessor, interior space improved further with class-leading rear legroom. The 'Magic Seat' system continued as a key feature, with refinements for even easier operation. Engine options varied by market but typically centered around efficient 1.3L to 1.5L four-cylinders, with hybrid variants available in some regions using Honda's i-DCD system that combined a 1.5L engine with an electric motor. The interior saw significant improvements in materials, design, and technology, featuring a touchscreen infotainment system on higher trims with smartphone connectivity. Safety technology advanced with the availability of Honda Sensing driver assistance features on later models. This generation maintained the Jazz's position as a space-efficient, versatile subcompact while adding more refinement and technology to appeal to increasingly sophisticated consumers.
Honda-Jazz.name: Third Generation

Honda-Jazz.description: The current Jazz features a more rounded, friendly design compared to its predecessor, with a focus on visibility and ease of use. The 'Magic Seat' system continues as a core feature, maintaining the model's exceptional versatility. Powertrain options have evolved significantly, with many markets (particularly Europe) focusing exclusively on hybrid powertrains using Honda's e:HEV system, which combines a 1.5L Atkinson-cycle engine with two electric motors for impressive efficiency. The interior has been completely redesigned with a more minimalist approach, featuring a digital instrument cluster, simplified control layout, and improved materials. Visibility has been enhanced with thinner A-pillars and a panoramic windshield design. Technology has advanced significantly with the latest Honda infotainment system and comprehensive Honda Sensing safety features standard on most variants. A crossover-inspired 'Crosstar' variant was introduced with slightly raised ride height, roof rails, and water-resistant upholstery. While this generation maintains the practical, space-efficient character that has defined the Jazz, it also reflects Honda's shift toward electrification as part of its environmental strategy. Note that with this generation, Honda discontinued the Jazz/Fit in North America, focusing instead on the HR-V crossover in that market.
Honda-Jazz.name: Fourth Generation

Honda-M-NV.description: The Honda M-NV is a compact all-electric SUV developed specifically for the Chinese market through Honda's joint venture with Dongfeng Honda. Marketed under the Ciimo brand, it is based on the Honda XR-V (the Chinese market version of the HR-V/Vezel) but extensively modified for electric propulsion, featuring distinctive EV-specific styling elements. The exterior design incorporates a closed-off front grille typical of electric vehicles, unique LED lighting signatures, aerodynamic wheels, and blue accents signifying its electric powertrain. Powered by a single electric motor producing approximately 134 HP (100 kW) and 280 Nm of torque, it delivers adequate performance for urban and suburban use. The lithium-ion battery pack (approximately 53.6 kWh in capacity) enables a claimed range of about 400 km on the NEDC test cycle. The interior features a 12.3-inch TFT instrument cluster and push-button gear selector, with EV-specific displays and controls. Available with various driver assistance technologies including adaptive cruise control and lane keeping assistance, it offers safety features comparable to Honda's global models. The M-NV was revealed in November 2020 for the 2021 model year and represents Honda's effort to establish a presence in China's rapidly growing electric vehicle market while meeting the country's stringent NEV (New Energy Vehicle) requirements.
Honda-M-NV.name: First Generation

Honda-Odyssey.description: The original Honda Odyssey was notably different from later generations, featuring a compact design with conventional hinged rear doors rather than sliding doors. Built on an Accord platform, it combined car-like handling with minivan versatility. The interior featured three rows of seats with a unique fold-down third row that disappeared into the floor—an innovation later adopted by many competitors. Powered by a 2.2L four-cylinder engine producing 140 HP paired with a four-speed automatic transmission, it emphasized efficiency over power. This generation established the Odyssey as a practical family vehicle with Honda's reputation for reliability, though its smaller dimensions and car-like doors limited its appeal compared to more traditional minivans.
Honda-Odyssey.name: First Generation

Honda-Odyssey.description: The second-generation Odyssey represented a complete redesign that transformed it into a full-size minivan with sliding rear doors. Significantly larger than its predecessor, it competed directly with established minivans like the Dodge Caravan and Toyota Sienna. Powered by a 3.5L V6 engine producing 210 HP (later increased to 240 HP) paired with a four-speed automatic transmission, it offered competitive performance for its class. The interior featured three rows with a third-row 'Magic Seat' that could fold flat into the floor, plus innovative features like a removable center console and navigation system on higher trims. This generation established the Odyssey as a top contender in the minivan segment, winning numerous awards for its combination of practicality, quality, and driving dynamics.
Honda-Odyssey.name: Second Generation

Honda-Odyssey.description: The third-generation Odyssey featured evolutionary styling changes with a sleeker, more aerodynamic profile. Slightly larger than its predecessor, it offered enhanced interior space and flexibility. Powered by an improved 3.5L V6 engine producing 244 HP (later increased to 255 HP), paired with a five-speed automatic transmission, it maintained good performance while improving fuel efficiency through Variable Cylinder Management on certain trims. The interior featured available eight-passenger seating with a removable center seat in the second row, plus a more sophisticated 'Magic Seat' third row. New features included power sliding doors, a power tailgate, and expanded safety technology. This generation further refined the Odyssey's formula, maintaining its position as a benchmark in the increasingly competitive minivan segment.
Honda-Odyssey.name: Third Generation

Honda-Odyssey.description: The fourth-generation Odyssey featured more distinctive styling with a 'lightning bolt' belt line that added visual interest to the traditional minivan shape. Powered by an enhanced 3.5L V6 producing 248 HP paired with either a five-speed or six-speed automatic transmission (depending on trim level), it offered a good balance of performance and efficiency. The interior introduced new innovations including a 'Wide Mode' second row that could expand outward to accommodate three child seats side-by-side, a 'Cool Box' for refrigerating beverages, and an available HondaVAC built-in vacuum cleaner. Technology advanced with features like an 8-inch touchscreen, blind spot monitoring, and forward collision warning on higher trims. This generation maintained the Odyssey's reputation for driving enjoyment while adding more family-friendly features to compete in the evolving minivan market.
Honda-Odyssey.name: Fourth Generation

Honda-Odyssey.description: The current Odyssey features more sophisticated styling with a floating roof design and distinct character lines. Powered by an enhanced 3.5L V6 producing 280 HP, initially paired with a nine-speed automatic transmission and later standardized to a ten-speed, it offers refined performance with reasonable efficiency. The interior introduces further innovations including 'Magic Slide' second-row seats that can move sideways for multiple configurations, CabinWatch and CabinTalk systems that allow monitoring and communication with rear passengers, and expanded connectivity options. Technology has advanced significantly with features like a Digital Key, wireless phone charging, and the comprehensive Honda Sensing safety suite as standard equipment. A refresh in 2021 updated the styling and features, adding a more powerful infotainment system and additional safety technology. This generation continues the Odyssey's focus on family-friendly innovation while providing car-like handling that has long differentiated it from competitors, maintaining its position as a top choice in the minivan segment despite declining overall minivan sales in favor of SUVs.
Honda-Odyssey.name: Fifth Generation

Honda-Pilot.description: The original Honda Pilot was introduced as a midsize crossover SUV designed to provide minivan-like versatility with SUV styling and capability. Built on a modified Odyssey platform, it featured a boxy, upright design that maximized interior space. Powered by a 3.5L V6 engine producing 240 HP paired with a five-speed automatic transmission, it offered standard front-wheel drive or optional VTM-4 (Variable Torque Management 4-wheel drive) system. The interior provided seating for eight across three rows, with a relatively flat floor and good cargo flexibility. This generation established the Pilot as Honda's first three-row SUV and an important addition to the growing crossover segment, emphasizing practical family transportation over off-road capability.
Honda-Pilot.name: First Generation

Honda-Pilot.description: The second-generation Pilot maintained the boxy styling of its predecessor but with more rounded edges and an updated front fascia. Slightly larger than the first generation, it offered improved interior space and refinement. Powered by an enhanced 3.5L V6 producing 250 HP, paired with a five-speed automatic transmission, it introduced Variable Cylinder Management for improved fuel efficiency. The interior featured a more modern design with improved materials and technology, including an available rear entertainment system and navigation. The three-row, eight-passenger layout continued with enhanced flexibility and storage solutions. A refresh in 2012 updated the styling and features, while addressing criticisms of the original design. This generation built upon the Pilot's reputation as a practical, reliable family SUV with car-like handling and three-row versatility.
Honda-Pilot.name: Second Generation

Honda-Pilot.description: The third-generation Pilot featured significantly sleeker styling, abandoning the boxy shape of previous generations for a more aerodynamic profile. Built on a new platform shared with the Odyssey and Ridgeline, it offered improved driving dynamics and refinement. Powered by a revised 3.5L V6 producing 280 HP, paired with either a six-speed or nine-speed automatic transmission depending on trim level, it delivered improved performance and efficiency. The interior was completely redesigned with more premium materials, enhanced technology including an 8-inch touchscreen on higher trims, and available seven-passenger seating with second-row captain's chairs. Safety advanced with the available Honda Sensing suite of driver assistance features. A refresh in 2019 updated the styling and made Honda Sensing standard across all trims. This generation elevated the Pilot's position as a sophisticated three-row crossover with improved comfort and technology, competing effectively in the increasingly crowded midsize SUV segment.
Honda-Pilot.name: Third Generation

Honda-Pilot.description: The current Pilot features a complete redesign with more rugged, truck-like styling that contrasts with the sleeker previous generation. Slightly larger in nearly all dimensions, it offers improved passenger and cargo space. Built on a new light truck platform, it emphasizes capability with an available TrailSport trim featuring increased ground clearance, all-terrain tires, and skid plates for moderate off-road use. Powered by a new 3.5L V6 producing 285 HP paired exclusively with a 10-speed automatic transmission, it offers refinement with incrementally improved performance. The interior represents a major advancement with higher quality materials, a standard 7-inch digital instrument display (9-inch available), and either a 7-inch or 9-inch central touchscreen depending on trim. Available features include a panoramic moonroof, heated and ventilated front seats, and a removable second-row middle seat that can stow in the underfloor cargo area. Safety technology has been enhanced with the latest generation of Honda Sensing, including Traffic Jam Assist and Traffic Sign Recognition. This generation aims to balance family-friendly features with more adventurous styling and capability, positioning the Pilot as a versatile option in the highly competitive three-row midsize SUV segment.
Honda-Pilot.name: Fourth Generation

Honda-Prologue.description: The Honda Prologue is the brand's first volume all-electric SUV for the North American market, developed in partnership with General Motors and utilizing GM's Ultium battery and electric vehicle platform. Positioned as a midsize crossover SUV, it features clean, minimalist styling that establishes a distinct electric vehicle design language for Honda while maintaining brand recognition. The exterior incorporates aerodynamic elements including a closed-off front fascia (as no traditional grille is needed for engine cooling), flush door handles, and sculpted sides to maximize efficiency and range. Powered by a dual-motor all-wheel drive system producing 288 HP and 333 lb-ft of torque, it offers competitive performance for its class. The 85 kWh battery provides an EPA-estimated range of 296 miles in front-wheel drive configuration and 273 miles with all-wheel drive. Charging capabilities include DC fast charging at up to 155 kW, allowing a 10-80% charge in approximately 40 minutes. The interior features a minimalist, tech-focused design with a standard 11.3-inch digital instrument display and 11.3-inch infotainment touchscreen with Google Built-in services. The cabin emphasizes spaciousness with a generous 119.8 cubic feet of passenger volume and 25.2 cubic feet of cargo space behind the rear seats. Available in various trim levels including Elite, Touring, and Sport, it offers features like heated and ventilated seats, a panoramic roof, and a comprehensive suite of Honda Sensing safety technologies. As Honda's transition vehicle toward full electrification (before introducing models on its own e:Architecture platform), the Prologue represents an important strategic step for the company despite using GM's technology. The name 'Prologue' intentionally signals that this model serves as an introduction to Honda's broader electric vehicle strategy that will unfold in coming years.
Honda-Prologue.name: First Generation

Honda-Ridgeline.description: The original Honda Ridgeline reinvented the pickup truck concept with its unibody construction and transverse-mounted engine—a significant departure from traditional body-on-frame trucks. Built on a modified version of the platform underpinning the Pilot SUV and Odyssey minivan, it featured four-door crew cab configuration with a 5-foot composite bed that included a lockable in-bed trunk and dual-action tailgate that could open down or to the side. Powered by a 3.5L V6 engine producing 247 HP paired with a five-speed automatic transmission and standard Variable Torque Management all-wheel drive (VTM-4), it offered more car-like handling than conventional trucks. The interior was significantly more refined than typical pickups of the era, with better materials and comfort features. While its maximum towing capacity of 5,000 pounds and payload around 1,500 pounds were lower than traditional pickups, the Ridgeline offered a compelling compromise between utility and comfort for buyers who occasionally needed truck capabilities but preferred SUV-like driving dynamics. Production ended in early 2015, with model years running 2006-2014.
Honda-Ridgeline.name: First Generation

Honda-Ridgeline.description: The second-generation Ridgeline introduced a more conventional pickup styling to address criticism that the first generation looked too much like an SUV with a bed. Still based on Honda's global light truck platform shared with the Pilot and Passport, it features improved proportions and more traditional truck design cues. Powered by a 3.5L V6 producing 280 HP paired with a six-speed automatic transmission, it offers front-wheel drive as standard with available torque-vectoring all-wheel drive. The innovative bed features continue with a larger in-bed trunk, dual-action tailgate, and available truck bed audio system that uses exciters to turn the bed walls into speakers. The interior is essentially shared with the Pilot, offering superior comfort and refinement compared to most midsize trucks. The Ridgeline has carved out a niche for buyers prioritizing on-road comfort, interior quality, and fuel efficiency in a pickup that handles everyday truck duties with ease.
Honda-Ridgeline.name: Second Generation

Honda-Ridgeline.description: The second-generation Ridgeline received a significant refresh for 2021, introducing more rugged styling with a prominent grille and squared-off front end. The vehicle continues to use Honda's global light truck platform shared with the Pilot and Passport, maintaining its unibody construction that differentiates it from traditional body-on-frame midsize trucks. Powered by a 3.5L V6 producing 280 HP now paired with a nine-speed automatic transmission (upgraded from the previous six-speed), it offers standard front-wheel drive with available torque-vectoring all-wheel drive. The innovative bed features continue including the lockable in-bed trunk, dual-action tailgate, and available truck bed audio system. The interior is shared with the Pilot, offering superior comfort and refinement compared to most midsize trucks. While still not matching the towing or off-road capabilities of body-on-frame competitors, the facelifted Ridgeline maintains its appeal for buyers prioritizing on-road comfort and everyday practicality.
Honda-Ridgeline.name: Second Generation (2021 Facelift)

Honda-WRV.description: The first-generation Honda WR-V (GL) was a subcompact crossover SUV developed by Honda R&D Center of Brazil in collaboration with Japan. It was based on the third-generation Honda Fit/Jazz platform (Honda Global Small Car), featuring different front fascia and bonnet treatments. The model was specifically developed for emerging markets in South America (Brazil) and India, with ground clearance of 188mm. Available engines included a 1.2L i-VTEC petrol (89 HP) for India, 1.5L i-VTEC petrol (88 kW) for Brazil, and a 1.5L i-DTEC turbo diesel (99 HP) for India. The WR-V shared its body shell, doors, dashboard and instrument panel with the Fit/Jazz. It received a facelift in 2020 for both markets.
Honda-WRV.name: First Generation (GL)

Honda-WRV.description: The second-generation WR-V (DG4) was previewed by the SUV RS concept at the 2021 Indonesia International Auto Show and launched in Indonesia on November 2, 2022. Developed by Honda R&D Asia Pacific, it is based on the shortened second-generation BR-V's platform (also shared with the second-gen Honda Amaze), representing a significant shift from the Fit/Jazz-based first generation. Power comes from a 1.5L L15ZF DOHC i-VTEC engine producing 89 kW (121 PS). Ground clearance increased to 220mm. Initially available with CVT, a 6-speed manual was later added for the E trim in May 2023. It is assembled in Indonesia (Karawang) and Malaysia (Alor Gajah), with exports to Thailand, Brunei, Philippines and other markets. Honda Sensing is available on higher trims.
Honda-WRV.name: Second Generation (DG4)

Honda-ZR-V.description: The Honda ZR-V (known as the HR-V in North America but distinct from the global HR-V/Vezel) is a compact crossover SUV positioned between the smaller HR-V/Vezel and larger CR-V in Honda's global lineup. Built on the eleventh-generation Civic platform rather than the Fit/Jazz basis used for the global HR-V, it features sportier styling with a lower roofline and longer hood compared to typical compact SUVs. The exterior design incorporates a prominent hexagonal grille, sleek LED headlights, clean body sides with a single character line, and a coupe-like sloping rear with a tailgate spoiler. Powertrain options vary by market, with European models featuring Honda's e:HEV hybrid system combining a 2.0L Atkinson-cycle engine with electric motors for a combined 184 HP, while North American versions (as the HR-V) utilize a 2.0L naturally aspirated four-cylinder producing 158 HP. Japanese and Chinese markets also receive a 1.5L turbocharged option. The interior shares much of its design and technology with the latest Civic, featuring a clean, horizontal dashboard layout with a honeycomb mesh accent concealing the air vents, and either a 7-inch or 9-inch touchscreen infotainment system depending on trim level. Unlike the smaller global HR-V, it lacks the 'Magic Seat' system but offers more passenger space, particularly in the rear seats. Safety features include the comprehensive Honda Sensing suite with improved capabilities like Traffic Jam Assist on higher trims. The ZR-V/North American HR-V represents Honda's response to market fragmentation in the crossover segment, offering a sportier, more car-like alternative to the practical, space-efficient approach of the global HR-V.
Honda-ZR-V.name: First Generation

Honda-e.description: The Honda e is the brand's first purpose-built electric vehicle for the European and Japanese markets, featuring a distinctive retro-futuristic design that combines classic Honda styling elements with modern technology. Built on a dedicated EV platform with a rear-motor, rear-wheel-drive configuration unusual for its class, it emphasizes driving dynamics and urban maneuverability with a turning circle of just 4.3 meters. The exterior design is characterized by its round LED headlights and taillights, flush door handles, and camera mirrors that replace traditional side mirrors—all contributing to its unique aesthetic and improved aerodynamics. Available with either a 35.5 kWh battery paired with a 134 HP electric motor or a higher-output 152 HP version in the Advance grade, it offers a modest WLTP range of approximately 220 km (137 miles)—deliberately optimized for urban use rather than long-distance travel. The interior represents one of the most distinctive aspects of the vehicle, featuring a full-width digital dashboard comprising five screens: two 12.3-inch touchscreens in the center, two 6-inch displays for the side camera mirrors, and a digital instrument cluster. Materials and design emphasize a lounge-like atmosphere with fabric upholstery and wood-effect trim. Charging capabilities include AC charging up to 6.6 kW and DC fast charging up to 100 kW, allowing an 80% charge in around 30 minutes. The Honda e has received critical acclaim for its design, technology, and driving experience, though its limited range and relatively high price have restricted its market appeal. Rather than aiming for mass-market success, the Honda e serves as a technology showcase and brand statement, representing Honda's design-led approach to urban electric mobility as the company transitions toward electrification.
Honda-e.name: First Generation

Hyundai-Accent.description: The original Hyundai Accent was introduced as a replacement for the Excel in many markets, representing a significant improvement in quality and design. Available as a three-door hatchback or four-door sedan, it featured simple, conventional styling typical of subcompact cars of the era. Powered by a range of small four-cylinder engines, typically 1.3L to 1.5L depending on the market, with modest power outputs focused on economy rather than performance. The interior was basic but functional, with durability prioritized over luxury.
