This generation established the Accent as Hyundai's entry-level model globally, offering affordable transportation with improved reliability compared to its predecessor.
Hyundai-Accent.name: First Generation

Hyundai-Accent.description: The second-generation Accent featured more refined styling with a more aerodynamic profile. Available in three-door hatchback, four-door sedan, and in some markets, a five-door hatchback, it offered slightly increased dimensions for improved interior space. Engine options typically included 1.3L to 1.6L four-cylinders with improved efficiency and slightly better performance. The interior saw enhancements in design, materials, and available features, though still positioned as an economy car. Safety features began to receive more attention with the availability of dual front airbags in many markets. This generation continued to build Hyundai's reputation for offering good value in the subcompact segment.
Hyundai-Accent.name: Second Generation

Hyundai-Accent.description: The third-generation Accent featured more expressive styling with Hyundai's emerging design language. Available in three-door hatchback and four-door sedan body styles, it grew in size to provide more interior space. Engine options evolved to include more efficient and powerful units, typically ranging from 1.4L to 1.6L four-cylinders, with improved transmissions including a five-speed manual and four-speed automatic. The interior received significant improvements in design, material quality, and available features, including upgraded audio systems and available power accessories. Safety features expanded to include standard front and optional side airbags, antilock brakes, and improved crash structures. This generation reflected Hyundai's overall push upmarket, offering more refinement and features while maintaining competitive pricing.
Hyundai-Accent.name: Third Generation

Hyundai-Accent.description: The fourth-generation Accent adopted Hyundai's 'Fluidic Sculpture' design language, featuring more sophisticated styling with flowing lines and a distinctive hexagonal grille. In many markets, it was available in both sedan and five-door hatchback configurations. Powered primarily by improved 1.4L and 1.6L four-cylinder engines with Direct Injection in some variants, it offered a good balance of performance and efficiency. The interior saw substantial improvements in design, materials, and technology, offering features previously found only in larger vehicles. Safety technology advanced with six standard airbags, available stability control, and improved crash structures. This generation significantly elevated the Accent's position, offering near-compact levels of space and refinement in a subcompact package.
Hyundai-Accent.name: Fourth Generation

Hyundai-Accent.description: The fifth-generation Accent featured more restrained styling following Hyundai's evolved design language, with a focus on elegant simplicity over the dramatic lines of its predecessor. In many markets, it was only offered as a sedan, with the hatchback role taken by the Venue crossover or i20 depending on the region. Powered by efficient 1.6L four-cylinder engines, in some markets featuring the Gamma II MPI or GDI technology, it emphasized fuel economy while maintaining adequate performance. The interior offered improved materials, design, and technology, including an available 7-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. Safety features expanded to include available forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, and other driver assistance technologies previously uncommon in the subcompact segment. This generation maintained the Accent's value proposition while adding technology and refinement, though it was discontinued in North America after 2023 as Hyundai, like many manufacturers, shifted focus away from sedans toward crossovers in that market.
Hyundai-Accent.name: Fifth Generation

Hyundai-Avante.description: The original Hyundai Avante (codenamed J1) was launched in October 1990 as a compact sedan. It featured conservative, boxy styling typical of early 1990s vehicles and was powered by Mitsubishi-designed engines ranging from 1.5L to 1.8L four-cylinders with DOHC technology. In South Korea, it was initially sold as the Elantra nameplate until the second generation introduced the Avante name domestically. The first generation was also sold as the Bimantara Nenggala in Indonesia from 1995-1998.
Hyundai-Avante.name: First Generation

Hyundai-Avante.description: The first-generation Avante received a significant facelift in April 1993, introducing revised front and rear fascias with more organically shaped head- and taillights. The refresh also added ABS brakes, front airbags, fog lamps, power-operated side mirrors, and optional alloy wheels. For the European market in 1992, Hyundai updated the grille with its new logo while North American models retained their earlier appearance until the 1993 facelift.
Hyundai-Avante.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Hyundai-Avante.description: The second-generation Avante (codenamed RD or J2) debuted in March 1995 with more rounded, organic styling inspired by Korean blue and white pottery. It was offered as a sedan in South Korea under the Avante name and as the Lantra in Australia and Europe. A station wagon variant was introduced six months after the sedan. The platform featured MacPherson struts up front and a multi-link coil-sprung rear axle.
Hyundai-Avante.name: Second Generation

Hyundai-Avante.description: The facelifted Avante arrived in February 1998 (codenamed RD2 or J3), featuring a new grille, revised bumpers, and redesigned head- and taillights. South Korean models were marketed as the 'New Avante.' The update also introduced a 2.0L engine option replacing the earlier 1.8L in most export markets, and a PSA-built 1.9L diesel engine became available for some European markets.
Hyundai-Avante.name: Second Generation (Facelift)

Hyundai-Avante.description: The third-generation Avante (codenamed XD) was an all-new model launched in 2000 with more aerodynamic styling. The station wagon variant was replaced by a five-door liftback body style. In this generation, the 'Lantra' name was retired in European and Australian markets, replaced by 'Elantra.' The platform was shared with the Kia Spectra. Engine options included 1.5L to 2.0L petrol engines and a 2.0L CRDi diesel.
Hyundai-Avante.name: Third Generation

Hyundai-Avante.description: The XD received a significant refresh in 2004 (codenamed XD2), introducing new headlights and taillights, a new grille, updated front and rear bumpers with split lower grille, redesigned hood and trunk lid, and a completely redesigned dashboard. The 2.0L engine received continuously variable valve timing (CVVT) in 2004, improving horsepower from 135 to 138. The GT trim was discontinued for the 2006 model year, replaced by the Limited trim.
Hyundai-Avante.name: Third Generation (Facelift)

Hyundai-Avante.description: The fourth-generation Avante (codenamed HD) debuted at the 2006 New York International Auto Show for the 2007 model year. It featured a more rounded, jelly bean-like design and was sold as the Avante in South Korea. Built on the Hyundai-Kia J5 platform, it was offered with 1.6L Gamma and 2.0L Beta II petrol engines, plus a 1.6L turbodiesel. The interior received significant improvements in design and material quality.
Hyundai-Avante.name: Fourth Generation

Hyundai-Avante.description: The Avante LPI Hybrid was unveiled at the 2009 Seoul Motor Show and represented the world's first hybrid electric vehicle powered by a liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) internal combustion engine. It featured a 1.6L Gamma engine paired with a 15kW electric motor and CVT transmission, delivering exceptional fuel efficiency of 41.9 mpg. The hybrid used lithium-ion polymer batteries and qualified as a SULEV with emissions of 99 g/km CO2.
Hyundai-Avante.name: Fourth Generation (LPI Hybrid)

Hyundai-Avante.description: The fifth-generation Avante debuted at the 2010 Busan International Motor Show (codenamed MD for sedan, UD for US-manufactured sedans). It introduced Hyundai's 'Fluidic Sculpture' design language with dramatic, flowing lines and a hexagonal grille. For the U.S. market, it featured a new 1.8L Nu engine, while other markets received a 1.6L GDI direct-injection engine producing 103 kW. The Elantra won the 2012 North American Car of the Year award.
Hyundai-Avante.name: Fifth Generation

Hyundai-Avante.description: The fifth-generation Avante received a significant update for the 2014 model year. The GLS trim was changed to SE and an all-new Elantra Sport became available with a 2.0L GDI engine producing 201 hp. Exterior enhancements included new front and rear styling with tinted taillights, L-shaped fog light housings, projector headlights with LED accents on higher trims, and new wheel designs. Interior updates featured raised HVAC vents, 4.3-inch touchscreen with backup camera, and revised steering wheel design.
Hyundai-Avante.name: Fifth Generation (Facelift)

Hyundai-Avante.description: The sixth-generation Avante launched in South Korea in September 2015 (codenamed AD). The design shifted to a more conservative appearance compared to the previous generation's fluidic sculpture, adopting a fastback-like roofline with pentagonal headlights and taillights. Designed by Peter Schreyer, it featured a cockpit-style interior with controls in a single bow line across the dash. Engine options included 1.4L turbo, 1.6L Gamma II, and 2.0L Nu petrol engines.
Hyundai-Avante.name: Sixth Generation

Hyundai-Avante.description: The facelifted Avante was launched in South Korea on September 6, 2018, for the 2019 model year. The exterior received a redesigned rear with new taillights and 'ELANTRA' lettering across the trunk. Interior changes included revised HVAC controls, newly designed vents, and a new steering wheel design shared with the Kona and Veloster. Safety features were enhanced with forward collision avoidance, lane keep assist, and drive attention alert becoming standard on SEL trims and above.
Hyundai-Avante.name: Sixth Generation (Facelift)

Hyundai-Avante.description: The seventh-generation Elantra (codenamed CN7) was unveiled on March 17, 2020, for the 2021 model year. It introduced Hyundai's 'parametric dynamics' design language with dramatic creases and a return to a fastback rear end style. Designed by Luc Donckerwolke, it featured twin digital display screens and was built on the Hyundai-Kia K3 platform. The Elantra Hybrid combined a 1.6L engine with an electric motor for 141 hp. In Australia, it was badged as the i30 Sedan.
Hyundai-Avante.name: Seventh Generation

Hyundai-Avante.description: The facelifted Avante was revealed in South Korea on February 27, 2023. The North American-market Elantra was introduced on August 30, 2023, for the 2024 model year. The facelift featured a redesigned front and rear end with updated styling. New safety features included rear side-impact airbags, rear seatbelt reminder, and haptic feedback steering wheel. A new curved display screen combining two separate screens under a single pane of glass became available. The Elantra N received similar updates in April 2023.
Hyundai-Avante.name: Seventh Generation (Facelift)

Hyundai-Elantra.description: The original Hyundai Elantra (codename J1) was launched in October 1990 as a compact sedan to compete with established models like the Toyota Corolla and Honda Civic. Featuring conservative, boxy styling typical of early 1990s compact cars, it represented Hyundai's effort to expand beyond its entry-level Excel/Accent. Powered by Mitsubishi-designed 1.6L DOHC four-cylinder engines producing 113 PS, with a 1.8L option added after the April 1993 facelift. The interior was basic but functional, with a straightforward dashboard design and durable materials. This generation established the Elantra nameplate that would become one of Hyundai's global core models, though it struggled to compete with Japanese rivals in terms of refinement and quality perception. Known as the Hyundai Lantra in Australia and Europe, and the Bimantara Nenggala in Indonesia (1995-1998).
Hyundai-Elantra.name: First Generation

Hyundai-Elantra.description: The April 1993 facelift of the first-generation Elantra introduced revised front and rear fascias with new, more organically shaped head- and taillights. The vehicle gained ABS brakes, front airbags, fog lamps, power-operated side mirrors, and optional alloy seven-spoke wheels. The 1.8L inline-four engine option was added at this facelift, producing 135 PS and replacing the twin-cam 1.6L in many markets. This refresh helped modernize the vehicle's appearance and improved safety features significantly compared to the original 1990-1993 model.
Hyundai-Elantra.name: First Generation (1993 Facelift)

Hyundai-Elantra.description: The second-generation Elantra (codename J2/RD) was launched in March 1995, featuring more rounded styling inspired by Korean blue and white pottery according to Chief Designer Choi Jong-min. Available as a four-door sedan and five-door station wagon (marketed as Avante Touring in South Korea), it grew slightly in dimensions to offer improved interior space. Engine options included 1.5L to 2.0L four-cylinders with improved refinement, including the Beta II engine family producing up to 140 PS. The interior saw enhancements in design and material quality, though still positioned as a value-oriented compact car. In South Korea, it was sold as the Hyundai Avante while export markets like Australia and Europe received it as the Lantra.
Hyundai-Elantra.name: Second Generation

Hyundai-Elantra.description: The February 1998 facelift of the second-generation Elantra (codenamed J3 or RD2) introduced a new grille, revised bumpers, and redesigned head- and taillights. The 'New Avante' as it was known in South Korea received updated styling that addressed some of the earlier model's design criticisms. A 2.0L engine option became available for export markets, replacing the earlier 1.8L in most applications and producing 139 PS. The PSA-built 1.9L diesel XUD9 was also added for some European markets, producing 68 PS. The facelift variant arrived in Europe by September 1998 and continued through the end of production in 2000.
Hyundai-Elantra.name: Second Generation (1998 Facelift)

Hyundai-Elantra.description: The third-generation Elantra (codename XD) marked a significant advancement with an all-new design launched in 2000. The station wagon version was replaced by a five-door Liftback bodystyle. Built on an improved platform with a 2610mm wheelbase, it featured more sophisticated styling and improved engineering. Engine options expanded to include 1.5L to 2.0L petrol engines and 1.5L to 2.0L turbo-diesel CRDi options, with the 2.0L petrol producing up to 138 HP in North America. The interior received significant improvements in design, material quality, and feature content, reflecting Hyundai's overall push toward better quality. Safety features improved with standard front and side airbags in the US from 2001 model year. The 'Lantra' name was retired in Europe and Australia, replaced by 'Elantra' for this generation.
Hyundai-Elantra.name: Third Generation

Hyundai-Elantra.description: The 2004 facelift (codename XD2) of the third-generation Elantra introduced comprehensive visual and functional updates including new headlights, tail lights, grille, front and rear bumpers with a split lower design, redesigned hood and trunk lid. Most significantly, the interior received a completely redesigned dashboard with improved functionality and better-quality materials. The 2.0L petrol engine gained continuously variable valve timing (CVVT), improving power to 103 kW and torque to 185 Nm. Safety ratings improved with better crash structures. This facelift helped maintain the Elantra's competitiveness in its final years of production, with North American models achieving EPA ratings of 27 mpg city for manual transmission versions.
Hyundai-Elantra.name: Third Generation (2004 Facelift)

Hyundai-Elantra.description: The fourth-generation Elantra (codename HD) debuted at the 2006 New York International Auto Show for the 2007 model year, featuring more rounded 'jelly bean' styling. Built on the Hyundai-Kia J5 platform with a 2650mm wheelbase, it offered improved handling dynamics and increased interior space. Engine options included the new 1.6L Gamma and 2.0L Beta II petrol engines, plus a 1.6L U-series CRDi turbodiesel for some markets. The interior saw substantial enhancements with higher-quality materials and available features including a navigation system, leather seats, and electronic stability control. The Hyundai Avante name continued in South Korea while export markets used Elantra. North American models were classified as mid-size by the EPA due to spacious interiors.
Hyundai-Elantra.name: Fourth Generation

Hyundai-Elantra.description: The fifth-generation Elantra (codename MD/UD) adopted Hyundai's 'Fluidic Sculpture' design language with dramatic, flowing lines and a distinctive hexagonal grille. Built on the Hyundai-Kia J5 platform with a 2700mm wheelbase, it was larger than its predecessor and offered significantly improved interior space. Powered by the new Nu 1.8L engine producing 148 HP and improved Gamma 1.6L four-cylinders with direct injection options, it balanced performance with enhanced fuel efficiency of up to 40 mpg highway. The interior featured sophisticated design with higher quality materials and expanded technology options including a navigation system, premium audio, and leather seating. The Elantra Touring wagon was replaced by the Hyundai i30cw. This generation won North American Car of the Year in 2012.
Hyundai-Elantra.name: Fifth Generation

Hyundai-Elantra.description: The 2013 facelift of the fifth-generation Elantra introduced updated styling including a revised front grille, new headlights with LED accents, redesigned rear bumper, and updated wheel designs. Interior updates included a revised center console layout with enhanced infotainment system featuring a larger touchscreen, improved materials quality, and updated color options. Safety features were enhanced with additional airbags and available advanced driver assistance systems in some markets. The 1.6L Gamma engine received improvements for better fuel efficiency while maintaining performance. This mid-cycle refresh helped maintain the Elantra's competitive position in the compact sedan segment through the end of production in 2015.
Hyundai-Elantra.name: Fifth Generation (2013 Facelift)

Hyundai-Elantra.description: The sixth-generation Elantra (codename AD) featured more restrained styling compared to its dramatic predecessor, with clean lines and a focus on elegant simplicity over flourishes. Designed by Peter Schreyer (formerly of Audi), it adopted a more mature, refined appearance while maintaining the compact sedan segment's largest interior space according to Hyundai. Built on an updated platform with increased use of high-strength steel, it offered improved handling, refinement, and safety. Engine options included the 1.6L Gamma II producing 128 HP and a 2.0L Smartstream MPi engine, with a 1.4L Kappa turbocharged GDi option producing 128 HP for improved performance and efficiency. The first Elantra Sport model joined the lineup with a 1.6L turbocharged engine producing 201 HP paired with a 6-speed manual or 7-speed dual-clutch transmission.
Hyundai-Elantra.name: Sixth Generation

Hyundai-Elantra.description: The September 2018 facelift of the sixth-generation Elantra (known as Avante in South Korea and Singapore) introduced significant exterior redesign despite initial criticism of its angular 'parametric dynamics' styling. Key changes included a new rear design with 'ELANTRA' lettering across the trunk, redesigned tail lights, updated wheel designs, and a hidden trunk release integrated into the Hyundai emblem. Interior updates featured revised HVAC controls with new vent designs, a redesigned steering wheel shared with the Kona and Veloster, updated instrument cluster graphics, and a standard 5-inch touchscreen with backup camera. Safety features were significantly enhanced with Forward Collision Avoidance, Lane Keep Assist, and Drive Attention Alert now standard on SEL trim and above. The facelifted model went on sale for the 2019 model year in North America with LED headlights as an option.
Hyundai-Elantra.name: Sixth Generation (2018 Facelift)

Hyundai-Elantra.description: The seventh-generation Elantra (codename CN7) features radical styling with a 'parametric dynamics' design theme, incorporating dramatic creases, angular elements, and distinctive lighting signatures. Built on Hyundai's K3 platform with a longer 2720mm wheelbase, it offers improved dynamics, refinement, and efficiency. Powertrain options include a standard 2.0L Smartstream four-cylinder producing 147 HP, an available hybrid combining a 1.6L Smartstream engine with electric motors producing combined 139 HP, and a performance-oriented N Line with a 1.6L turbocharged engine producing 201 HP. The high-performance Elantra N joined the lineup with a 2.0L turbocharged engine producing 276 HP. The interior represents a major departure with a driver-focused cockpit design featuring an available dual-screen setup combining a 10.25-inch digital instrument cluster and 10.25-inch infotainment touchscreen under a single piece of glass. Technology advances include wireless smartphone integration, Digital Key, and Hyundai's SmartSense suite of advanced driver assistance systems. In Australia, this generation is marketed as the Hyundai i30 Sedan.
Hyundai-Elantra.name: Seventh Generation

Hyundai-Genesis-Coupe.description: The original Hyundai Genesis Coupe marked the brand's first serious entry into the sports car segment, representing a significant departure from their previous offerings. Built on a rear-wheel drive platform shared with the Genesis sedan, it featured aggressive styling with a long hood, short deck proportions, and distinctive 'Z-shaped' character line along the flanks. Initially powered by either a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder producing 210 HP or a 3.8L V6 with 306 HP, both available with six-speed manual or automatic transmissions. The interior was driver-focused with supportive seats, a simple instrument panel, and basic but functional controls. Handling was emphasized with a sport-tuned suspension, limited-slip differential on some models, and Brembo brakes available on higher trims. This early version established the Genesis Coupe as a legitimate sports car offering genuine performance at a value price point, though interior quality and refinement lagged behind some competitors.
Hyundai-Genesis-Coupe.name: First Generation (Pre-refresh)

Hyundai-Genesis-Coupe.description: The refreshed Genesis Coupe featured significant updates to both styling and powertrains. Exterior changes included a more aggressive front fascia with a larger grille, redesigned headlights, and hood heat extractors. Powertrain upgrades were substantial, with the 2.0L turbocharged engine now producing 274 HP and the 3.8L V6 increased to 348 HP, both offering more competitive performance. An 8-speed automatic transmission option replaced the previous 6-speed unit. The interior received improved materials, redesigned gauges with electroluminescent lighting, and a new multifunction steering wheel. Additional refinements included retuned suspension for better handling, reduced NVH (noise, vibration, harshness), and expanded feature content. This update addressed many of the criticisms of the original version, delivering more performance and refinement while maintaining the value proposition. The Genesis Coupe was discontinued after 2016 without a direct replacement, as the Genesis brand separated from Hyundai and repositioned as a luxury marque with its own distinct model lineup. During its production, the Genesis Coupe established Hyundai's credibility in the performance segment and helped change perceptions of the brand among enthusiasts.
Hyundai-Genesis-Coupe.name: First Generation (Refreshed)

Hyundai-IONIQ-5.description: The Hyundai Ioniq 5 is the first product marketed under the Ioniq sub-brand, and the first model developed on the Hyundai Electric Global Modular Platform (E-GMP). Introduced globally in February 2021 and production began March 2021. Features the 'Parametric Pixel' design language inspired by the original Hyundai Pony, with distinctive pixel-style headlights and tail lights. Built on a dedicated EV platform enabling a 3-meter wheelbase in a compact crossover package. Available with 58 kWh Standard Range or 72.6/77.4 kWh Long Range battery packs, in RWD (single motor) or AWD (dual motor) configurations. Notable for its 800V electrical architecture enabling ultra-fast DC charging (10-80% in 18 minutes at 350 kW), and Vehicle-to-Load (V2L) capability supplying up to 3.6 kW of power. Interior features dual 12-inch screens, sliding 'Universal Island' console, and sustainable materials including recycled PET bottles.
Hyundai-IONIQ-5.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Hyundai-IONIQ-5.description: The facelifted Ioniq 5 was revealed on March 3, 2024. Changes include the addition of a rear hatch windscreen wiper (previously absent), and an updated infotainment system. A larger battery pack option (84 kWh, up from 77.4 kWh) was introduced along with minor improvements to power efficiency and aerodynamics. An N-Line variant was added to the lineup featuring sportier styling elements. The XRT off-road trim was introduced for the 2025 model year (September 2024) featuring increased ground clearance, all-terrain tires, roof rails, and dual-motor AWD powertrain producing 320 hp with an EPA-estimated range of 259 miles. The Ioniq 5 N performance variant (introduced July 2023) continues as the top-tier model under the Hyundai N sub-brand.
Hyundai-IONIQ-5.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Hyundai-IONIQ-6.description: The Hyundai IONIQ 6 is the second dedicated electric vehicle in Hyundai's IONIQ sub-brand, built on the same Electric Global Modular Platform (E-GMP) as the IONIQ 5. Unlike its crossover sibling, the IONIQ 6 features a dramatic streamliner design inspired by the Prophecy concept car, with an extremely aerodynamic silhouette that achieves a drag coefficient of just 0.21—among the lowest of any production car. The exterior combines smooth, flowing surfaces with pixel-like lighting elements that maintain the IONIQ design language, while the elongated fastback profile maximizes efficiency and range. Like the IONIQ 5, it utilizes an 800V electrical architecture that enables ultra-fast DC charging, allowing a 10-80% charge in approximately 18 minutes at compatible charging stations. Available with either a 53 kWh or 77.4 kWh battery pack (varying slightly by market), and in single-motor rear-wheel drive or dual-motor all-wheel drive configurations, power outputs range from 149 HP to 320 HP in the performance-oriented dual-motor version. The aerodynamic design helps the IONIQ 6 achieve exceptional efficiency, with some configurations exceeding 360 miles of range—making it one of the most efficient electric vehicles on the market. The interior continues the 'living space' concept with a flat floor and spacious cabin, featuring dual 12.3-inch screens under a single piece of glass, customizable ambient lighting, and sustainable materials including recycled plastics and bio-based textiles. Advanced technology includes vehicle-to-load (V2L) functionality that allows the car to power external devices, over-the-air updates, and Hyundai's most advanced driver assistance systems. The IONIQ 6 represents Hyundai's vision for an emotional, design-focused electric sedan that prioritizes efficiency and range while offering a distinctive alternative to both conventional sedans and electric crossovers. As the second model in the growing IONIQ lineup, it further establishes Hyundai's commitment to electrification with a distinctive approach focused on design and efficiency rather than simply converting existing models to electric power.
Hyundai-IONIQ-6.name: First Generation

Hyundai-IONIQ-Electric.description: The Hyundai IONIQ Electric was the battery electric variant of the first-generation Ioniq lineup, offered alongside hybrid and plug-in hybrid variants on a single dedicated platform. Featuring aerodynamic styling with a closed grille, active air flaps, and a smooth underbody achieving a drag coefficient of just 0.24. Equipped with a 28 kWh lithium-ion polymer battery providing an EPA-rated range of approximately 124 miles. The electric motor produced 120 HP and 295 Nm of torque, with a combined EPA fuel economy rating of 136 MPGe. The interior featured a driver-focused cockpit with a digital instrument cluster, touchscreen infotainment system, and distinctive copper-colored accents to differentiate it from hybrid variants. Sold in select markets including California initially, then expanded to other states and countries like Canada, Norway, Netherlands, and Switzerland.
Hyundai-IONIQ-Electric.name: First Generation

Hyundai-IONIQ-Electric.description: The Ioniq Electric received a significant refresh for the 2020 model year, featuring a new interior design, larger battery pack, and increased performance. The lithium-ion polymer battery was upgraded from 28 kWh to 38.3 kWh, extending EPA-rated range to approximately 170 miles (311 km WLTP). Power output increased from 120 HP to 134 HP while maintaining the same 295 Nm of torque. The onboard AC charger was upgraded from 6.6 kW to 7.2 kW for faster home charging. The refresh also included updated styling cues and enhanced technology features. Production ended in July 2022 as Hyundai transitioned to its dedicated E-GMP platform for the new Ioniq sub-brand (Ioniq 5, 6, 9).
Hyundai-IONIQ-Electric.name: First Generation (2020 Facelift)

Hyundai-IONIQ-PlugIn-Hybrid.description: The Hyundai IONIQ Plug-in Hybrid was the third and final variant of the first-generation IONIQ lineup, joining the hybrid and electric versions. Featuring the same aerodynamic fastback design as its siblings but distinguished by unique headlights and grille elements, it combined the best aspects of both hybrid and electric powertrains. The system paired a 1.6L GDI four-cylinder engine producing 104 HP with a 60 HP (45 kW) electric motor for a combined output of 139 HP, delivered through a six-speed dual-clutch transmission rather than the CVT typically found in hybrid vehicles. Powered by an 8.9 kWh lithium-ion polymer battery, it offered approximately 29-32 miles of all-electric range (varying by testing standard and model year) before the gasoline engine engaged, allowing for emission-free daily commuting with the flexibility of hybrid operation for longer trips. A full battery charge took about 2.5 hours with a Level 2 charger. The interior featured a modern, clean design with a digital instrument cluster, touchscreen infotainment system, and subtle blue accents to differentiate it from other IONIQ variants. Like the rest of the IONIQ lineup, the Plug-in Hybrid was discontinued in 2022 as Hyundai transitioned to using IONIQ as a dedicated electric vehicle sub-brand. During its production, the IONIQ Plug-in Hybrid offered one of the most efficient plug-in hybrid powertrains on the market, with a total range exceeding 600 miles and combined fuel economy ratings that made it a practical stepping stone between conventional hybrids and full electric vehicles.
Hyundai-IONIQ-PlugIn-Hybrid.name: First Generation

Hyundai-Kona.description: The original Hyundai Kona was a subcompact crossover SUV that helped establish Hyundai in the rapidly growing small SUV segment. Featuring distinctive styling with a split headlight design, contrasting roof color options, and aggressive body cladding, it stood out in a crowded market. Built on a platform shared with the i20/i30, it was available with various powertrain options depending on the market, typically including 1.0L and 1.6L turbocharged gasoline engines, and in some regions, diesel options. Front-wheel drive was standard with all-wheel drive available on higher trims. The interior offered modern technology including an available 8-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility, and a range of active safety features under the SmartSense banner. A performance-oriented N Line variant was added later in the generation, featuring a more powerful engine and sportier styling. A significant facelift in 2020 updated the styling with an even more distinctive front end and enhanced technology. Electric and hybrid variants were also offered (as separate models). This generation established the Kona as one of Hyundai's global best-sellers, appealing to buyers with its combination of distinctive styling, technology, and value.
Hyundai-Kona.name: First Generation

Hyundai-Kona.description: The current Kona features a complete redesign with a more futuristic appearance inspired by the brand's 'Parametric Dynamics' design language. Significantly larger than its predecessor in nearly all dimensions, it offers improved passenger and cargo space. The exterior maintains the split headlight design but with a more refined execution, featuring a full-width LED light bar and pixelated details that echo Hyundai's IONIQ electric vehicles. Powertrain options vary by market but typically include a 2.0L naturally aspirated four-cylinder, a 1.6L turbocharged four-cylinder, and hybrid variants. For the first time, Hyundai developed the electric version first and adapted it for internal combustion engines, rather than the reverse. The interior represents a major advancement with a dual 12.3-inch panoramic display combining digital instruments and infotainment under a single piece of glass, ambient lighting, and improved materials. Technology has expanded to include advanced driver assistance systems, over-the-air updates, and digital key functionality. The sporty N Line continues as the performance-oriented option with unique styling elements and a more powerful engine. This generation elevates the Kona's position with more upscale features and design while maintaining its distinctive character in an increasingly homogenized segment.
Hyundai-Kona.name: Second Generation

Hyundai-Kona-Electric.description: The original Hyundai Kona Electric was one of the first mainstream electric crossovers, adapting the popular Kona platform for pure electric propulsion. Visually distinguished from the standard Kona by its closed-off grille, unique wheels, and slightly modified bumpers for improved aerodynamics, it maintained the distinctive split headlight design of its conventional counterpart. Initially offered with two battery options—a 39.2 kWh pack providing approximately 254 km (WLTP) range, and a more popular 64 kWh version delivering around 484 km (WLTP)—both paired with a front-mounted electric motor. The larger battery variant produced 201 HP (150 kW) and 291 lb-ft of torque, delivering surprisingly quick acceleration with 0-100 km/h times around 7.6 seconds. Charging capabilities included 100 kW DC fast charging, allowing a 10-80% charge in approximately 47 minutes on the larger battery model. The interior was largely shared with the standard Kona but with EV-specific displays and controls, featuring a digital instrument cluster with power flow and efficiency information. A significant facelift in 2021 updated the exterior styling with a smoother front end and enhanced technology features. The first-generation Kona Electric was recognized for offering among the best range-per-dollar value in the EV market, making longer-range electric mobility accessible at a more mainstream price point.
Hyundai-Kona-Electric.name: First Generation

Hyundai-Kona-Electric.description: The current Kona Electric features a complete redesign, now developed as an electric vehicle first with the internal combustion variants adapted from it—the reverse of the previous approach. Significantly larger than its predecessor, it offers improved passenger and cargo space while maintaining urban-friendly exterior dimensions. The exterior design incorporates a distinctive pixel-inspired light bar across the front, connecting the running lights (with the main headlights positioned lower in the bumper), and similar pixelated elements in the rear—styling cues shared with Hyundai's IONIQ dedicated electric vehicles. Available with either a 48.6 kWh standard-range battery offering approximately 340 km (WLTP) of range, or a 65.4 kWh long-range option providing up to 514 km (WLTP), both paired with a front-mounted electric motor. The long-range variant produces 201 HP (150 kW) and 188 lb-ft of torque, maintaining similar performance to its predecessor. Charging capabilities include up to 100 kW DC fast charging, allowing a 10-80% charge in around 41 minutes for the larger battery. The interior represents a major advancement with a dual 12.3-inch panoramic display combining digital instruments and infotainment under a single piece of glass, ambient lighting, vehicle-to-load (V2L) capability for powering external devices, and improved sustainable materials. This generation builds upon the success of the original Kona Electric with enhanced technology, range, and interior space, continuing Hyundai's commitment to making electric mobility accessible across multiple market segments.
Hyundai-Kona-Electric.name: Second Generation

Hyundai-Palisade.description: The Hyundai Palisade is the brand's flagship three-row SUV, introduced to replace the Santa Fe XL (formerly called the Santa Fe in three-row form). Built on a platform shared with the Kia Telluride, it features bold, upright styling with a massive cascading grille, vertical LED daytime running lights, and an imposing presence that signals its position at the top of Hyundai's SUV lineup. Powered by a 3.8L V6 engine producing 291 HP and 262 lb-ft of torque, paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission and available with front-wheel or HTRAC all-wheel drive systems. The interior represents one of Hyundai's most premium efforts, with available features including a 10.25-inch touchscreen infotainment system, 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, head-up display, quilted Nappa leather seating, and ambient lighting. Seating configurations include eight-passenger (with a second-row bench) or seven-passenger (with second-row captain's chairs) layouts, with impressive space in all three rows and one-touch mechanisms to ease access to the third row. Safety technology is comprehensive with Hyundai's SmartSense suite including forward collision avoidance, blind-spot collision avoidance, rear cross-traffic collision avoidance, and Highway Driving Assist. A significant refresh for the 2023 model year updated the exterior styling with a more squared-off grille, redesigned headlights, and enhanced interior technology including a larger standard infotainment screen and added features. The Palisade established Hyundai's credibility in the three-row premium SUV segment, offering near-luxury appointments and features at a mainstream price point, challenging established players like the Honda Pilot, Toyota Highlander, and Ford Explorer while also drawing comparisons to luxury-brand SUVs costing significantly more.
Hyundai-Palisade.name: First Generation

Hyundai-Santa-Cruz.description: The Hyundai Santa Cruz is the brand's first pickup truck for the North American market, though Hyundai positions it as a 'Sport Adventure Vehicle' rather than a traditional truck. Built on a unibody platform shared with the Tucson crossover rather than a body-on-frame construction typical of most pickups, it features distinctive styling with a bold parametric grille, T-shaped daytime running lights that blend into the grille pattern, and a coupe-like sloping C-pillar. The four-door crew cab configuration is the only body style offered, paired with a 4-foot bed that includes an underfloor storage compartment, integrated steps in the bumper for easier bed access, and an available lockable tonneau cover. Powertrain options include a 2.5L naturally aspirated four-cylinder producing 191 HP and a more powerful 2.5L turbocharged four-cylinder delivering 281 HP, both paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission (conventional with the base engine, dual-clutch with the turbo) and available with front-wheel or HTRAC all-wheel drive. The interior shares much of its design and technology with the Tucson, featuring a 10.25-inch digital instrument cluster, available 10.25-inch touchscreen infotainment system, and comprehensive active safety features through Hyundai SmartSense. With maximum towing capacity of 5,000 pounds (with the turbocharged engine) and payload around 1,600 pounds, the Santa Cruz offers more capability than typical crossovers while emphasizing on-road comfort and handling rather than competing directly with traditional midsize trucks. As Hyundai's entry into the growing segment of lifestyle-oriented compact trucks, the Santa Cruz targets urban and suburban buyers who occasionally need truck utility but prefer the everyday livability of a crossover, positioning it as a unique alternative to both conventional pickup trucks and SUVs.
Hyundai-Santa-Cruz.name: First Generation

Hyundai-Santa-Fe.description: The original Hyundai Santa Fe was the brand's first SUV, representing an important entry into the growing segment. Featuring somewhat awkward but distinctive styling with oversized wheel arches and unusual headlight arrangements, it was built on a car-based platform rather than the truck-based approach common for SUVs of that era. Available with a range of four-cylinder and V6 engines depending on the market, with the 2.7L V6 being the most common in North America. Offered with front-wheel drive or an optional all-wheel drive system, it positioned itself as a value alternative to established competitors like the Honda CR-V and Toyota RAV4, though slightly larger. The interior was basic but practical, focusing on durability rather than luxury. This generation established the Santa Fe nameplate and helped build Hyundai's reputation in the SUV market, offering impressive content for its price point despite some refinement shortcomings.
Hyundai-Santa-Fe.name: First Generation (SM)

Hyundai-Santa-Fe.description: The second-generation Santa Fe featured more conventional styling with improved proportions and a higher-quality appearance both inside and out. Slightly larger than its predecessor, it was available in both short-wheelbase five-passenger and long-wheelbase seven-passenger configurations in some markets. Engine options evolved to include more refined and powerful units, typically including a 2.4L four-cylinder and 3.5L V6 in North America, with various diesel options in other markets. The interior saw significant improvements in design, materials, and features, reflecting Hyundai's overall push upmarket during this period. Safety features expanded to include stability control, six airbags, and active head restraints as standard equipment. This generation elevated the Santa Fe's position in the market, offering a more refined and competitive product that helped establish Hyundai as a serious contender in the midsize crossover segment.
Hyundai-Santa-Fe.name: Second Generation (CM)

Hyundai-Santa-Fe.description: The third-generation Santa Fe adopted Hyundai's 'Fluidic Sculpture' design language, featuring more dynamic styling with bold character lines and the brand's signature hexagonal grille. Available in two distinct versions: the five-passenger Santa Fe Sport (shorter wheelbase) and the seven-passenger Santa Fe (longer wheelbase, eventually renamed Santa Fe XL in North America). Engine options varied by market but typically included a 2.4L four-cylinder and 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder for the Sport, with a 3.3L V6 for the longer version, plus diesel options in some regions. The interior featured a significant upgrade in design, materials, and technology, offering near-luxury appointments in higher trims. Safety technology advanced with the introduction of features like blind-spot detection, rear cross-traffic alert, and lane change assist. This generation further established the Santa Fe as one of Hyundai's core models globally, competing effectively with established midsize crossovers while maintaining a value advantage.
Hyundai-Santa-Fe.name: Third Generation (DM)

Hyundai-Santa-Fe.description: The fourth-generation Santa Fe featured more muscular styling with a bold front fascia incorporating split headlight design (a theme that would influence other Hyundai SUVs). Now offered exclusively in one wheelbase length as a five-passenger vehicle (with the three-row role taken by the larger Palisade), it grew slightly in overall dimensions for improved interior space. Engine options evolved to focus on efficiency, with a 2.4L four-cylinder base engine and 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder optional in North America, plus the addition of hybrid and plug-in hybrid variants in later model years. The interior represented a major step forward with a more premium design, higher-quality materials, and advanced technology including an available 10.25-inch touchscreen, digital instrument cluster, and head-up display. Safety features expanded significantly with Hyundai's comprehensive SmartSense suite including forward collision avoidance, blind-spot collision avoidance, and Highway Driving Assist. A significant facelift in 2021 substantially updated the styling with an even bolder grille and new lighting signature. This generation elevated the Santa Fe to a near-premium position in Hyundai's lineup, offering sophisticated styling, technology, and refinement while maintaining the brand's value proposition.
Hyundai-Santa-Fe.name: Fourth Generation (TM)

Hyundai-Santa-Fe.description: The current Santa Fe features a radical redesign with a boxy, upright silhouette that contrasts dramatically with its more rounded predecessor. Drawing inspiration from Land Rover and classic SUVs, it features a squared-off profile with an H-shaped lighting signature, prominent body cladding, and a more traditional SUV stance rather than the crossover styling of previous generations. Built on Hyundai's latest platform, it's slightly larger than the outgoing model with a significant focus on interior space and versatility. Engine options vary by market but center around a 2.5L four-cylinder in naturally aspirated and turbocharged forms, plus hybrid and plug-in hybrid powertrains combining a 1.6L turbocharged engine with electric motors. The interior represents a complete reinvention with a horizontal dashboard design featuring dual 12.3-inch screens, a bridge-type center console, and numerous practical storage solutions. Available with six or seven-seat configurations, it introduces unique features like fold-flat second-row seats that create a fully flat floor from the tailgate to the front seats, enhancing its utility for outdoor activities. Technology has advanced to include Hyundai's latest connectivity, assistance, and safety systems, including available features like Remote Smart Parking Assist and Digital Key 2. This generation repositions the Santa Fe as a more adventure-focused vehicle with greater emphasis on versatility and outdoor lifestyle use, while maintaining the refinement and technology expected in a modern crossover.
Hyundai-Santa-Fe.name: Fifth Generation

Hyundai-Santa-Fe-Hybrid.description: The original Santa Fe Hybrid was based on the facelifted fourth-generation Santa Fe platform, introduced as part of Hyundai's broader electrification strategy. Visually identical to the conventional Santa Fe except for hybrid badging, it featured the bold front fascia with distinctive T-shaped LED daytime running lights and a wide cascading grille that characterized the mid-cycle refresh. Powered by a hybrid system combining a 1.6L turbocharged four-cylinder engine with a 44 kW electric motor and 1.49 kWh lithium-ion battery pack, producing a combined 226 HP and 258 lb-ft of torque. Power was delivered through a six-speed automatic transmission specifically designed for hybrid applications, available with either front-wheel drive or HTRAC all-wheel drive. The interior matched the premium appointments of the standard Santa Fe, featuring an available 10.25-inch touchscreen infotainment system, 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, and Hyundai's comprehensive SmartSense safety suite. Offering approximately 30-40% better fuel efficiency than the conventional gasoline models, it maintained full five-passenger seating capacity without compromising interior space due to the compact battery placement. This generation established the hybrid powertrain as a significant option in the Santa Fe lineup, particularly appealing to buyers seeking improved efficiency without the range limitations or charging requirements of a fully electric vehicle.
Hyundai-Santa-Fe-Hybrid.name: First Generation (Fourth-generation Santa Fe platform)

Hyundai-Santa-Fe-Hybrid.description: The current Santa Fe Hybrid is built on the fifth-generation Santa Fe platform, sharing its dramatic redesign featuring a boxy, upright silhouette inspired by more traditional SUVs rather than the crossover styling of its predecessor. Distinguished by an H-shaped lighting signature, squared-off profile, and prominent body cladding, it maintains the bold styling direction of the conventional model. The hybrid powertrain has been updated but follows a similar concept, combining a 1.6L turbocharged four-cylinder engine with a more powerful electric motor and larger lithium-ion battery, producing a combined output of approximately 231 HP. The six-speed automatic transmission has been refined for improved efficiency and response, available with either front-wheel drive or HTRAC all-wheel drive systems. The interior features the same major advancements as the standard model, with dual 12.3-inch screens, horizontal dashboard design, and bridge-type center console creating an open, spacious feeling. Available in six or seven-seat configurations, it maintains the innovative folding rear seats that create a fully flat load floor when needed. Fuel efficiency remains a key selling point, with combined ratings significantly better than non-hybrid competitors while maintaining full SUV capability. This generation positions the Santa Fe Hybrid as a more adventure-focused vehicle with greater emphasis on utility and outdoor lifestyle use, while delivering the efficiency benefits of electrification without compromising on space, capability, or features.
Hyundai-Santa-Fe-Hybrid.name: Second Generation (Fifth-generation Santa Fe platform)

Hyundai-Sonata.description: The original Hyundai Sonata was a front-engine, rear-wheel-drive sedan based on the Hyundai Stellar but with updated styling. Available primarily in South Korea and limited export markets, it featured a conservative design typical of midsize sedans of its era. Powered by a range of four-cylinder engines with modest performance, it positioned itself as an affordable alternative to established competitors. The interior was basic but functional, with a focus on durability rather than luxury. This generation established the Sonata nameplate that would eventually become one of Hyundai's global core models, though it was still early in the company's development as an automaker.
Hyundai-Sonata.name: First Generation (Y1)

Hyundai-Sonata.description: The second-generation Sonata marked Hyundai's first attempt at a more globally competitive midsize sedan. Now using front-wheel drive architecture, it featured more modern styling influenced by European design trends. Available with a range of four-cylinder and V6 engines, it offered improved performance and refinement over its predecessor. The interior saw enhancements in design and materials, though still positioned as a value-oriented option. This generation began Hyundai's expansion into more international markets, including North America, though the company still struggled with quality perception compared to Japanese competitors.
Hyundai-Sonata.name: Second Generation

Hyundai-Sonata.description: The third-generation Sonata (Y3) featured evolutionary styling with a more aerodynamic design. Built on the Hyundai-Kia Y3 platform, it offered improved handling and comfort over its predecessor. Engine options included a 2.0-liter Sirius inline-four as the base engine, with a 3.0-liter Mitsubishi V6 available in some markets. The interior received significant improvements in design, materials, and features, reflecting Hyundai's efforts to move upmarket. This generation was also produced as the Hyundai Marcia between 1995 and 1998 in South Korea only, featuring restyled front and rear fascias. This generation represented an important step forward in Hyundai's global competitiveness, though the company was still establishing its reputation for quality and reliability in many markets.
Hyundai-Sonata.name: Third Generation (Y3)

Hyundai-Sonata.description: The third-generation Sonata received a significant facelift in 1996, featuring modifications to the front and rear fascias. The four-cylinder engine output was increased for that year as well. This facelifted model continued to be built in Ulsan, Korea until the end of production. The Marcia variant also continued alongside the facelifted Sonata in the South Korean market. This updated version maintained the improvements in refinement and quality while presenting a more modern appearance to compete in the increasingly competitive midsize sedan segment.
Hyundai-Sonata.name: Third Generation (Y3 Facelift)

Hyundai-Sonata.description: The fourth-generation Sonata (EF) featured more distinctive styling with a cleaner, more European-influenced design. Built on the Hyundai-Kia Y4 platform with double wishbone front suspension and independent multi-link rear suspension, it offered better handling and refinement than its predecessor. Compared to the Y3 predecessor, the EF grew slightly in size while sharing the same wheelbase. Initial engines included a 2.0-liter inline-four and a 2.5-liter V6 (G6BW Delta V6). The interior saw substantial enhancements in design, materials, and feature content, beginning to close the gap with established competitors. Quality and reliability improved significantly during this generation, helping to address one of the main concerns consumers had about the brand. This generation marked an important step in Hyundai's transition from a purely budget-oriented manufacturer to a more mainstream competitor.
Hyundai-Sonata.name: Fourth Generation (EF)

Hyundai-Sonata.description: The fourth-generation Sonata received a significant facelift in 2001 for the 2002 model year, designated as the EF-B series. Changes included a revised hood, grille, and headlights resembling those found on the second-generation Mercedes-Benz C-Class, along with updated taillights and rear license plate location moved from the fascia to the trunk lid. The interior was also revised with a new dashboard and seats. Hyundai strengthened the body shell and firewall, widened the rear track, included anti-submarining front seat pans, and added thicker front brake discs. The facelifted model featured an all-aluminum 2.7-liter Delta V6 (G6BAY) alongside the revised 2.4-liter inline-four. Production continued in various markets including China until 2017 and Russia until 2012.
Hyundai-Sonata.name: Fourth Generation (EF-B Facelift)

Hyundai-Sonata.description: The fifth-generation Sonata represented a significant leap forward in design, quality, and engineering. Featuring more sophisticated styling with a clear European influence, it announced Hyundai's ambitions to compete directly with established midsize sedans. Built on a new platform shared with Kia, it offered improved dynamics, refinement, and safety. Engine options included refined four-cylinder and V6 units with improved performance and efficiency. The interior featured a significant upgrade in design, materials, and features, approaching the level of more premium competitors. This generation established the Sonata as a legitimate contender in the competitive midsize sedan segment, helping to transform Hyundai's brand image globally.
Hyundai-Sonata.name: Fifth Generation (NF)

Hyundai-Sonata.description: The sixth-generation Sonata (YF) introduced Hyundai's 'Fluidic Sculpture' design language, featuring dramatic, flowing lines that helped it stand out in the typically conservative midsize sedan segment. Development commenced in 2005 with a cost of ₩450 billion (US$372 million). Built on an all-new platform with hot-stamped ultra high-strength steel, it offered improved handling, refinement, and safety. The vehicle was marketed as the Hyundai i45 in Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, and Colombia. Engine options included a direct-injection 2.4-liter four-cylinder Theta II engine producing 198 hp, with a 2.0L turbocharged option added in December 2010. A six-speed automatic transmission was standard, with a six-speed manual available on base models. The interior featured a modern, premium-feeling design with improved materials and technology. This generation marked Hyundai's arrival as a design leader rather than follower, with the Sonata's bold styling influencing competitors and helping to further transform the brand's image from budget option to desirable mainstream choice.
Hyundai-Sonata.name: Sixth Generation (YF)

Hyundai-Sonata.description: The sixth-generation Sonata received a mid-life facelift in 2012 for the Korean market and late 2013 for North American production (2014 model year). Exterior changes included a new grille, slimmer LED mirror indicators, front fog lights with integrated LED daytime running lamps, new alloy wheel designs, and redesigned LED taillights. Interior updates featured a new color touchscreen display for audio systems and redesigned dual-zone automatic climate controls with a small LCD. A Driver Selectable Steering Mode was standard, and front parking sensors and an electronic parking brake became available. The Sonata Hybrid continued alongside the gasoline models with improved electric motor and larger lithium-polymer battery. This facelift helped maintain the Sonata's competitive edge as consumer preferences began shifting toward SUVs.
Hyundai-Sonata.name: Sixth Generation (YF Facelift)

Hyundai-Sonata.description: The seventh-generation Sonata (LF) featured more restrained styling compared to its predecessor, with a focus on elegant simplicity over dramatic flourishes. Originally internally coded as LFA, it was unveiled in South Korea on March 24, 2014, and made its North American debut at the 2014 New York International Auto Show. Built on an updated platform with increased use of high-strength steel, it offered improved rigidity, safety, and refinement. Engine options included a 2.4L GDi inline-four, 1.6L turbocharged Gamma engine with 7-speed DCT, and 2.0L turbocharged Theta II engine. The interior saw enhancements in design, material quality, and technology, with available features including a 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system and Hyundai's Blue Link telematics. In the US, trim levels included SE, Eco, Sport, and Limited. This generation maintained the Sonata's position as one of Hyundai's core global models.
Hyundai-Sonata.name: Seventh Generation (LF)

Hyundai-Sonata.description: The seventh-generation Sonata received a significant facelift unveiled on March 8, 2017 (Korean name: 'Sonata New Rise'). The exterior received a radical redesign more in line with the sixth-generation, including new headlights, tail lights, cascading grille, and optional vertical LED lighting. The front shares characteristics of the sixth-generation Grandeur/Azera. The dashboard was reshaped with new air vents, a larger touchscreen compatible with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, a new steering wheel, gearshift, and instrument cluster. Standard features added included a wireless phone charger and USB port for rear passengers. A mid-trim SEL level was added for 2018, and the Blue Link system was upgraded for Amazon Echo and Google Home compatibility. The Sonata Plug-in Hybrid was introduced in 2015 with an all-electric range of up to 27 miles. This facelifted generation continued production through 2023, maintaining the Sonata's competitiveness in an increasingly SUV-focused market.
Hyundai-Sonata.name: Seventh Generation (LF Facelift)

Hyundai-Sonata.description: The eighth-generation Sonata (DN8) was previewed in early March 2019 and officially launched on March 21 in South Korea. It features a dramatic return to bold styling with coupe-like proportions, a fastback roofline, and distinctive lighting elements including hidden LED daytime running lights that appear chrome when off and illuminate when on. Built on Hyundai's latest N3 platform architecture with the 'Sensuous Sportiness' design language, it offers improved dynamics, refinement, and safety. Despite being classified as mid-size in North America, its cabin volume places it in the EPA's full-size classification. Engine options include a 1.5L turbo, 2.0L turbo, 2.5L naturally aspirated, and 2.5L turbo (N Line), along with hybrid and plug-in hybrid variants. The interior features a clean, horizontal dashboard design with an optional 12.3-inch digital cluster and 10.25-inch center screen. The comprehensive safety system includes three radar systems, five cameras, and thirteen ultrasonic sensors for advanced driver assistance features.
Hyundai-Sonata.name: Eighth Generation (DN8)

Hyundai-Sonata.description: The eighth-generation Sonata received a significant facelift presented on March 26, 2023, at the 2023 Seoul Mobility Show, with refreshed models reaching markets in 2024. The facelift incorporates Hyundai's updated Sensuous Sportiness design language, featuring a full-width LED light bar at the front. The main headlights are hidden above the air intakes, joined by a wider grille and sharper lines. For North American models introduced on August 30, 2023, the Sonata now offers Hyundai's H-TRAC all-wheel drive system as an option on 2.5L models, a first for Hyundai sedans in the region. A new curved display combines two separate displays under a single pane of glass, and wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto are now expanded to all models. The N Line variant continues with a turbocharged 2.5-liter engine producing 290 horsepower and paired with an eight-speed wet dual-clutch transmission. Despite its impressive features and design, this generation faces challenges as consumer preferences continue to shift away from sedans toward SUVs and crossovers.
Hyundai-Sonata.name: Eighth Generation (DN8 Facelift)

Hyundai-Tucson.description: The original Hyundai Tucson was introduced as a compact crossover SUV, positioned below the Santa Fe in Hyundai's lineup. Featuring conventional SUV styling with a boxy profile and traditional proportions, it aimed to offer SUV practicality in a smaller, more affordable package. Built on a platform shared with the Elantra, it was available with a range of four-cylinder and V6 engines depending on the market, offering front-wheel or all-wheel drive configurations. The interior was practical but basic, with a focus on durability over luxury. Safety features were relatively advanced for its price point, with standard stability control and six airbags in many markets. This generation established the Tucson nameplate in Hyundai's global lineup, offering an entry-level option for customers seeking SUV styling and versatility.
Hyundai-Tucson.name: First Generation (JM)

Hyundai-Tucson.description: The second-generation Tucson (sold as the ix35 in some markets) featured more modern, fluid styling that aligned with Hyundai's emerging design language. Built on an updated platform, it offered improved handling, refinement, and fuel efficiency. Engine options varied by market but typically included enhanced four-cylinder units in both gasoline and diesel variants, with V6 options largely dropped. The interior saw significant improvements in design, materials, and feature content, reflecting Hyundai's overall push upmarket during this period. Technology features expanded to include available navigation, backup camera, and premium audio systems. This generation elevated the Tucson's position in the competitive compact crossover segment, offering more sophisticated styling and features while maintaining Hyundai's value proposition.
Hyundai-Tucson.name: Second Generation (LM)

Hyundai-Tucson.description: The third-generation Tucson featured more premium styling with Hyundai's signature hexagonal grille and sculptured body sides. Slightly larger than its predecessor, it offered improved passenger and cargo space. Engine options evolved to focus on efficiency with improved four-cylinder units, including turbocharged variants in some markets. The interior represented a major step forward with better materials, design, and technology, featuring an available larger touchscreen infotainment system and expanded active safety features. A significant refresh in 2019 updated the styling and added more technology features. This generation further established the Tucson as one of Hyundai's global best-selling models, competing effectively with established rivals like the Toyota RAV4 and Honda CR-V.
Hyundai-Tucson.name: Third Generation (TL)

Hyundai-Tucson.description: The current Tucson features a revolutionary design with a 'parametric dynamics' theme, incorporating jewel-like surface detailing, hidden daytime running lights that blend into the grille when not illuminated, and angular wheel arches. Significantly larger than its predecessor, it offers more passenger and cargo space while maintaining compact exterior dimensions. Engine options vary by market but center around efficient four-cylinder units, with significant emphasis on electrified powertrains including hybrid, plug-in hybrid, and in some markets, fuel cell variants. The interior represents a complete reinvention with a minimalist approach featuring a 10.25-inch digital instrument cluster, 10.25-inch touchscreen infotainment system, and touch-sensitive controls. Technology has advanced significantly with features like remote smart parking assist, digital key functionality, and Hyundai's comprehensive SmartSense safety suite. This generation aims to position the Tucson as a design and technology leader in its segment rather than merely a value alternative, reflecting Hyundai's continued upmarket progression while maintaining its stronghold in the critical compact crossover market.
Hyundai-Tucson.name: Fourth Generation (NX4)

Hyundai-Tucson-Hybrid.description: The Hyundai Tucson Hybrid is based on the fourth-generation Tucson platform, sharing its revolutionary 'parametric dynamics' design with jewel-like surface details, hidden daytime running lights that blend into the grille when not illuminated, and angular styling elements. Visually nearly identical to the conventional Tucson apart from hybrid badging and minor trim differences, it maintains the dramatic styling that differentiates this generation from its competitors and predecessors. Powered by a hybrid system combining a 1.6L turbocharged four-cylinder engine with a 44.2 kW electric motor and 1.49 kWh lithium-ion battery, producing a combined 226 HP and 258 lb-ft of torque. Power is delivered through a six-speed automatic transmission specifically designed for hybrid applications, available with either front-wheel drive or HTRAC all-wheel drive. The interior features the same minimalist, technology-focused design as the standard Tucson, with a 10.25-inch digital instrument cluster, 10.25-inch touchscreen infotainment system, and touch-sensitive controls. Providing approximately 20-30% better fuel efficiency than the conventional gasoline models while delivering more power and responsive acceleration, it sacrifices no interior space due to the compact battery placement under the rear seats. The hybrid model sits in the middle of the Tucson's electrified lineup, between the conventional gasoline models and the plug-in hybrid variant which offers pure electric driving capability. As Hyundai's first hybrid compact SUV in many markets, the Tucson Hybrid represents an important part of the company's electrification strategy, offering a balance between efficiency and conventional usability that has made it a popular choice among buyers transitioning toward electrified vehicles.
Hyundai-Tucson-Hybrid.name: First Generation (Fourth-generation Tucson platform)

Hyundai-Veloster.description: The original Hyundai Veloster was a unique asymmetrical sport compact, featuring an unconventional three-door design with one door on the driver's side and two doors on the passenger side. Built on a modified Accent platform, it featured distinctive styling with a low, wide stance, aggressive front fascia, and a sloping roofline leading to a glass hatch. Initially powered by a 1.6L naturally aspirated four-cylinder producing 138 HP, with a turbocharged version added in 2012 boosting output to 201 HP. Transmission options included a six-speed manual or a six-speed dual-clutch automatic. The interior featured a driver-focused cockpit with motorcycle-inspired cues, a standard 7-inch touchscreen (large for its time), and surprising practicality given its sport compact positioning. Despite its modest base power, the Veloster earned praise for its handling, unique styling, and value, attracting younger buyers seeking something different from conventional hatchbacks. A mid-cycle refresh in 2015 updated the styling and features, while the Turbo model received a performance-oriented Rally Edition with sportier suspension tuning. This generation established the Veloster as Hyundai's distinctive sport compact entry, emphasizing individuality and fun-to-drive character over outright performance.
Hyundai-Veloster.name: First Generation

Hyundai-Veloster.description: The second-generation Veloster maintained its signature asymmetrical three-door layout but featured more refined styling with sharper lines, a more aggressive stance, and improved proportions. Built on a new platform shared with the i30/Elantra GT, it offered significantly improved driving dynamics and chassis stiffness. Engine options evolved to include a 2.0L naturally aspirated four-cylinder base engine producing 147 HP and a revised 1.6L turbocharged four-cylinder with 201 HP in Turbo models. The performance-focused Veloster N joined the lineup with a 2.0L turbocharged engine producing up to 275 HP and a comprehensive chassis, brake, and aerodynamic package developed by Hyundai's N performance division. The interior saw major improvements in material quality, design, and technology, featuring an available 8-inch touchscreen with advanced connectivity options and improved ergonomics. Despite the enhancements and critical acclaim (particularly for the Veloster N), declining sales in the sport compact segment led to most versions being discontinued after 2021, with only the N variant continuing for one additional year in the US market. This generation, particularly the N model, played an important role in transforming perceptions of Hyundai from a value-oriented brand to one capable of producing genuine performance vehicles, with the N division's expertise later expanding to other models in Hyundai's lineup.
Hyundai-Veloster.name: Second Generation

Hyundai-Venue.description: The Hyundai Venue is a subcompact crossover SUV positioned as the brand's entry-level SUV offering, below the Kona in size and price. Featuring a boxy, upright design with split headlights and Hyundai's signature cascading grille, it emphasizes practicality and urban-friendly dimensions while maintaining SUV styling cues. Built on a platform shared with the Accent sedan but with increased ride height, it's offered exclusively with front-wheel drive, positioning it as an urban crossover rather than a true off-road capable SUV. Powertrain options vary by market but typically center around a 1.6L four-cylinder engine producing approximately 121 HP in North America, paired with either a six-speed manual transmission (discontinued after 2020 in some markets) or a continuously variable transmission. The interior maximizes space efficiency with a straightforward, practical design featuring a standard 8-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility in most markets. Despite its entry-level positioning, the Venue offers Hyundai's SmartSense safety features including forward collision avoidance, lane keeping assist, and driver attention warning. A modest refresh in 2023 updated the styling with a wider grille and revised lighting elements. The Venue represents Hyundai's response to the growing demand for affordable small crossovers, effectively replacing traditional subcompact hatchbacks in many markets as consumer preferences shift toward SUV-style vehicles. By offering the styling and higher seating position of an SUV at a price point comparable to compact cars, the Venue has successfully attracted first-time buyers and those seeking an urban-friendly vehicle with a more commanding presence than a conventional small car.
Hyundai-Venue.name: First Generation

Hyundai-Verna.description: The original Hyundai Accent/Verna (X3) replaced the Excel in 1994 with conservative, boxy styling typical of 1990s compact sedans. Sold under various names including Excel in some markets and Dodge Brisa in Venezuela, it was powered by 1.3L to 1.5L Alpha series four-cylinder engines with both SOHC and DOHC options. Available as sedan, 3-door liftback, and 5-door hatchback depending on the market. The interior was basic but functional with durable materials. Production in South Korea ran until 1999, but continued in Egypt (until 2006), Indonesia (until 2005), and China (until 2006). This generation established the Verna nameplate in South Korea specifically, while most international markets retained the Accent name.
Hyundai-Verna.name: First Generation (X3)

Hyundai-Verna.description: The second-generation Accent/Verna (LC) featured more angular styling with increased dimensions over its predecessor. This was the first generation to carry the Verna nameplate in South Korea specifically. Available as 4-door sedan, 3-door liftback, and 5-door hatchback, it was built on the Hyundai-Kia TB platform. Engine options included revised 1.3L and 1.5L petrol engines plus a new 1.6L DOHC 16-valve from 2001, and notably the first Accent with a diesel option - a 1.5L three-cylinder CRDi turbodiesel. The interior saw improvements in design and material quality. Production continued in various markets including Egypt (until 2019) and Russia (as Accent until 2011), making it one of the longest-running generations.
Hyundai-Verna.name: Second Generation (LC)

Hyundai-Verna.description: The third-generation Accent/Verna (MC) introduced at the 2005 New York Auto Show featured a new exterior design, larger interior space, and CVVT (Continuously Variable Valve Timing) engines. Built on an updated platform with improved handling dynamics, it was offered as 4-door sedan and 3-door hatchback. Engine options included 1.4L Alpha I4 and 1.6L CVVT Alpha II I4 petrol, plus a 1.5L D I4 turbo-diesel CRDi with VGT. In India, this generation was marketed as Verna while the previous generation continued alongside as the Accent. Safety improvements were notable, though crash test ratings remained mixed by modern standards. Production varied by region, running until 2010 in most markets but continuing in India (until 2011) and Turkey (until 2012).
Hyundai-Verna.name: Third Generation (MC)

Hyundai-Verna.description: The fourth-generation Accent/Verna (RB for sedan, RC for China) debuted at the 2010 Beijing Auto Show with Hyundai's 'Fluidic Sculpture' design language featuring dynamic, flowing lines. Built on the Hyundai-Kia PB platform, it was offered as 4-door sedan and 5-door hatchback. Engine options expanded significantly: 1.4L and 1.6L Gamma series petrol engines with both MPI and GDI variants, plus diesel options. Transmission options included 5/6-speed manual, 4/6-speed automatic, 7-speed DCT, and CVT. Known as Solaris in Russia (where the Accent name remained for the previous generation), it achieved 5-star China NCAP rating. In India, launched as Verna in May 2011 with 1.4L and 1.6L petrol and diesel engines, it received multiple facelifts including a major update in 2015. Production continued in Egypt well beyond 2019, still ongoing as of 2025.
Hyundai-Verna.name: Fourth Generation (RB/RC)

Hyundai-Verna.description: The fifth-generation Accent/Verna (HC for sedan, YC for China) launched in late 2016/early 2017 with more mature styling and Hyundai's signature cascading grille. Built on the Hyundai-Kia K2 platform, it was offered as 4-door sedan and 5-door hatchback (hatchback not available in US). Engine options were extensive: 1.0L Kappa II T-GDi turbo (7-speed DCT), 1.4L Kappa II MPi, 1.5L Smartstream MPi (CVT), 1.6L Gamma II MPI/GDi, and 1.5L U II CRDi diesel. Notably, this generation was not sold in South Korea (replaced by Venue crossover) and was discontinued in Australia for the same reason. In India, launched as Verna in August 2017 with 1.6L petrol and diesel engines, it received a major facelift in March 2020 with new engine options including 1.5L petrol and 1.0L turbo. The Accent was discontinued in the US after 2022, replaced by the Venue.
Hyundai-Verna.name: Fifth Generation (HC/YC)

Hyundai-Verna.description: The current sixth-generation Verna (BN7) was unveiled in India on February 13, 2023, adopting Hyundai's 'Sensuous Sportiness' design language with bold parametric grille, connected LED light bar, and fastback profile. Significantly larger than its predecessor with near-midsize interior space within a compact footprint, it's built on an updated platform. Engine options include a 1.5L Smartstream G1.5 MPi (115hp, 144Nm) paired with 6-speed manual or CVT, and a 1.5L Smartstream G1.5 T-GDi turbo (158hp, 253Nm) paired with 6-speed manual or 7-speed DCT. The interior features a horizontal dashboard with dual 10.25-inch screens under one glass panel in higher trims, ambient lighting, and premium materials. Technology includes advanced driver assistance systems (ADAS), ventilated seats, Bose audio, and over-the-air updates. Launched in India on March 21, 2023, it achieved a 5-star Global NCAP rating for adult and child occupants in October 2023. Also sold in Vietnam (from May 2024), UAE (early 2025), Philippines (October 2025), and Brunei (May 2025).
Hyundai-Verna.name: Sixth Generation (BN7)

Hyundai-i10.description: The original Hyundai i10 (codenamed PA) was introduced on 31 October 2007 in New Delhi, India. Produced until 2015, it replaced the Hyundai Atos in the model line-up and was initially available only as a five-door hatchback. Built on the Hyundai-Kia SA platform, it featured simple, practical styling with a tall profile to maximize interior space. Engine options included 1.0L and 1.1L I3 petrol engines, a 1.2L Kappa I4 petrol engine (from 2008), and a 1.1L diesel CRDi option for European markets. A facelift introduced in October 2010 brought the 'Fluidic Sculpture' design language with redesigned front end, headlights, and interior updates including a new instrument cluster with gear shift indicator.
Hyundai-i10.name: First Generation (PA)

Hyundai-i10.description: The second-generation i10 (codenamed IA for Europe, BA for Grand i10 in India) debuted at the Frankfurt Motor Show in September 2013.
