Built on a new Hyundai-Kia BA platform, it was 80mm longer and 65mm wider than its predecessor. The European model arrived in showrooms in January 2014, while the Indian market received the longer Grand i10 variant (BA) with increased wheelbase. Engine options included 1.0L and 1.2L Kappa II petrol engines, an LPG variant, and a 1.1L U-II diesel CRDi. The platform was shared with the Kia Picanto (TA). A facelift introduced in 2017 updated the front and rear styling. Production continued until 2022, with sedan variants called Hyundai Xcent (India) and exported as Grand i10 sedan to emerging markets.
Hyundai-i10.name: Second Generation (IA/BA)

Hyundai-i10.description: The third-generation i10 was launched in India as the Grand i10 Nios (codenamed AI3) on 7 August 2019, followed by the European-spec i10 (AC3) at the Frankfurt Motor Show in September 2019. The new model features a more expressive design with the signature cascading grille, N Line sporty variants, and significantly upgraded technology including an 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system with Apple CarPlay/Android Auto. Built on a revised BA/K1 platform, the Euro-spec model (AC3) is manufactured in Turkey while Indian models come from Chennai. Engine options expanded to include a turbocharged 1.0L T-GDI three-cylinder engine alongside the naturally aspirated 1.2L, with Idle Stop and Go (ISG) as standard for improved fuel economy. Safety features were upgraded with Hyundai SmartSense including autonomous emergency braking and lane keep assist on higher trims. A facelift was unveiled in February 2023 bringing subtle exterior updates and additional standard technology.
Hyundai-i10.name: Third Generation (AC3/AI3)

Hyundai-i20.description: The original Hyundai i20 was introduced as a supermini (B-segment) car primarily for European and Asian markets. Replacing the Getz in Hyundai's lineup, it featured conventional styling with a focus on practicality and value. Available in three-door and five-door hatchback body styles, it offered good interior space for its external dimensions. Powertrain options varied by market but typically included small-displacement petrol engines ranging from 1.2L to 1.4L and diesel options from 1.1L to 1.4L. The interior was straightforward but well-built, with decent materials for its class and a focus on durability. A significant facelift in 2012 updated the styling and features to maintain competitiveness. This generation established the i20 as a credible competitor in the crowded European supermini segment, offering good value and reliability against established rivals like the Ford Fiesta and Volkswagen Polo.
Hyundai-i20.name: First Generation

Hyundai-i20.description: The second-generation i20 featured a significant step up in design, quality, and features. Adopting Hyundai's 'Fluidic Sculpture 2.0' design language, it offered more sophisticated styling with cleaner lines and a more premium appearance. Available in five-door hatchback, three-door coupe (i20 Coupe), and slightly raised crossover (Active) variants, it provided more options for different buyer preferences. Engine choices evolved to include more efficient units with better performance, typically ranging from 1.0L turbocharged to 1.4L naturally aspirated petrol engines, plus diesel options in many markets. The interior saw major improvements in design, material quality, and technology, featuring available touchscreen infotainment, rear-view camera, and panoramic sunroof on higher trims. Safety features expanded to include six airbags and stability control as standard in many markets. This generation elevated the i20's market position, offering near-compact levels of space and equipment in a supermini package.
Hyundai-i20.name: Second Generation

Hyundai-i20.description: The current i20 features a more angular, aggressive design with Hyundai's 'Sensuous Sportiness' design language. Built on a new platform, it offers improved dimensions with a wider stance and lowered roofline for a more dynamic appearance. Engine options focus increasingly on efficiency with a range of small displacement petrol engines, many featuring 48V mild-hybrid technology to reduce emissions and improve fuel economy. The performance-oriented i20 N variant was introduced with a 1.6L turbocharged engine producing 204 HP, establishing the model in the hot hatch segment. The interior represents a major advancement with a digital-focused design featuring a 10.25-inch digital instrument cluster and 10.25-inch infotainment touchscreen in higher trims, creating a connected, dual-screen appearance similar to premium vehicles. Safety technology has advanced significantly with Hyundai SmartSense features including lane-following assist, forward collision avoidance, and intelligent speed limit assistance as standard or available depending on trim. This generation aims to position the i20 as a more emotionally appealing choice in the segment, offering distinctive styling, advanced technology, and driving enjoyment while maintaining the practicality and value proposition that has defined the model.
Hyundai-i20.name: Third Generation

Hyundai-i30.description: The original Hyundai i30 was introduced as a compact car (C-segment) primarily for European markets, though also sold in Australia and some Asian countries (as the Elantra in some regions). Designed at Hyundai's European center in Rüsselsheim, Germany, it featured conventional but European-influenced styling to compete directly with established models like the Volkswagen Golf and Ford Focus. Available in five-door hatchback and later station wagon body styles, it offered good interior space and practicality. Engine options varied by market but typically included petrol units ranging from 1.4L to a 2.0L, plus diesel options that were particularly important for European buyers. The interior was straightforward with decent materials and build quality for its price point. This generation established the i30 as Hyundai's first serious competitor in the European C-segment, winning praise for its value, practicality, and five-year warranty.
Hyundai-i30.name: First Generation (FD)

Hyundai-i30.description: The second-generation i30 adopted Hyundai's 'Fluidic Sculpture' design language, featuring more dynamic styling with flowing lines and a distinctive hexagonal grille. Available in five-door hatchback, three-door hatchback, and station wagon body styles, it offered more options for different buyer preferences. Engine choices evolved to include more efficient units with better performance, including new turbocharged options in some markets. The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and technology, featuring a more premium appearance with soft-touch materials and available features including touchscreen infotainment and dual-zone climate control. Safety features expanded to include up to nine airbags and advanced driver assistance systems on higher trims. This generation elevated the i30's market position, offering comparable quality and features to established European competitors while maintaining a value advantage.
Hyundai-i30.name: Second Generation (GD)

Hyundai-i30.description: The current i30 features more restrained styling compared to its predecessor, adopting a cleaner, more mature design language with a cascading grille that became a Hyundai signature element. Available in five-door hatchback, station wagon (Tourer), and fastback body styles, plus the high-performance N variant, it offers more choices than ever before. Engine options increasingly focus on efficiency with a range of turbocharged petrol and diesel units, many featuring mild-hybrid technology in later years to reduce emissions. The interior represents a significant step up with higher quality materials, a more horizontal dashboard design, and improved technology including an available 8-inch touchscreen with navigation and smartphone integration. Safety technology has advanced considerably with Hyundai SmartSense features including autonomous emergency braking, lane keep assist, and driver attention warning available across the range. The introduction of the i30 N performance model with up to 280 HP also established the nameplate in the hot hatch segment, bringing driving enjoyment and emotional appeal to complement the model's traditional strengths of practicality and value. A significant facelift in 2020 updated the styling, interior technology, and engine lineup to maintain competitiveness in the challenging European C-segment.
Hyundai-i30.name: Third Generation (PD)

INFINITI-G-Sedan.description: The original Infiniti G20 was a compact luxury sedan based on the Nissan Primera, introduced to compete with entry-level European luxury cars like the BMW 3 Series and Audi 80. Featuring conservative styling typical of early 1990s Japanese sedans, it emphasized handling and driving dynamics over outright luxury. Powered by a 2.0L four-cylinder engine producing 140 HP, paired with either a five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmission, it offered modest performance with a focus on refinement. The interior featured good build quality with standard leather on most trims, though design and materials were more mainstream than truly luxurious. Notable for its multi-link front suspension that provided handling characteristics praised by automotive journalists, the G20 established itself as the driver-focused option in Infiniti's early lineup. This generation laid the groundwork for the G nameplate that would eventually become central to Infiniti's brand identity, though the original G20 achieved only modest sales success against more established luxury competitors.
INFINITI-G-Sedan.name: First Generation (P10)

INFINITI-G-Sedan.description: After a brief hiatus, the G20 returned with updated styling that maintained the conservative approach of its predecessor. Still based on the Nissan Primera, it featured improved refinement and slightly enhanced performance from the same 2.0L four-cylinder engine, now producing 145 HP. The interior saw incremental improvements in materials and features, though it remained modest by luxury standards of the era. This generation continued to emphasize handling and driving dynamics, with the 'touring' package offering sportier suspension tuning and larger wheels. Despite these enhancements, the G20 struggled against increasingly sophisticated European and Japanese competitors, leading to its discontinuation in 2002. The P11 G20 served as a transitional model in Infiniti's history, maintaining a presence in the entry-luxury segment while the brand developed the rear-wheel drive G35 that would dramatically change Infiniti's fortunes and image.
INFINITI-G-Sedan.name: Second Generation (P11)

INFINITI-G-Sedan.description: The G35 represented a complete reinvention of the G sedan, moving to Nissan's FM (Front Midship) rear-wheel drive platform shared with the Nissan 350Z sports car. Featuring distinctive styling with a long hood, short deck proportions, and flowing lines, it signaled Infiniti's new design direction and performance focus. Powered by a 3.5L VQ-series V6 engine initially producing 260 HP (later increased to 280 HP), paired with a five-speed automatic or six-speed manual transmission, it offered performance comparable to the benchmark BMW 3 Series. Available in rear-wheel or all-wheel drive configurations, it emphasized sporty handling while offering luxury amenities. The interior featured a driver-focused cockpit with good materials and a distinctive, tiered dashboard design. This generation established the G sedan as a legitimate contender in the sport-luxury segment, winning numerous awards and dramatically enhancing Infiniti's credibility and market position against established German and Japanese luxury brands.
INFINITI-G-Sedan.name: Third Generation (V35)

INFINITI-G-Sedan.description: The G37 sedan (later simply called the G sedan) evolved the successful formula of its predecessor with more muscular styling, enhanced performance, and improved luxury features. Built on an updated version of the FM platform, it featured more aggressive design elements while maintaining the athletic proportions of the G35. Powered by a larger 3.7L VQ-series V6 producing 328 HP, paired with a seven-speed automatic or six-speed manual transmission, it offered improved performance and refinement. The interior saw significant enhancements in material quality, design, and technology, featuring Infiniti's first implementation of the dual-touchscreen infotainment system in later model years. Available in various trim levels including the luxury-oriented Journey and sport-focused Sport models, plus all-wheel drive variants, it offered configurations for different buyer preferences. This generation maintained the G sedan's position as Infiniti's volume model and brand cornerstone, competing effectively against the BMW 3 Series, Mercedes-Benz C-Class, and other established luxury sport sedans. In 2014, as part of Infiniti's nomenclature change, the G sedan was renamed Q50, bringing an end to the G designation that had become synonymous with Infiniti's sport-luxury identity.
INFINITI-G-Sedan.name: Fourth Generation (V36)

INFINITI-G35.description: The original Infiniti G35 Coupe was a luxury sports coupe built on Nissan's FM (Front Midship) platform shared with the Nissan 350Z and G35 Sedan. Featuring sleek, flowing styling with a long hood and short deck proportions, it combined sports car performance with luxury appointments. Powered by a 3.5L VQ35DE V6 engine producing 280 HP (later increased to 298 HP), paired with either a five-speed automatic or six-speed manual transmission, it delivered impressive performance for its time. The rear-wheel drive layout, near-perfect weight distribution, and sophisticated suspension provided excellent handling characteristics that competed directly with established European sports coupes. The interior featured a driver-focused cockpit with good materials and distinctive styling, though some hard plastics detracted from the luxury feel. Available in base, Sport, and premium trims, it offered various equipment levels and suspension tuning options. This generation established the G35 Coupe as a genuine alternative to the BMW 3 Series Coupe and similar European offerings, winning numerous awards including Motor Trend's Car of the Year when combined with its sedan counterpart. The G35 Coupe played a crucial role in transforming Infiniti's brand image from a maker of rebadged luxury Nissans to a genuine performance-luxury manufacturer.
INFINITI-G35.name: First Generation (V35) Coupe

INFINITI-G35.description: The Infiniti G35 Sedan shared its platform and mechanical components with the coupe but featured distinctive four-door styling with more conventional proportions. Like its two-door counterpart, it was built on Nissan's FM platform offering a front-midship engine placement for optimal weight distribution. Powered by the same 3.5L VQ35DE V6 engine, initially producing 260 HP (later increased to 280 HP), it delivered sports sedan performance comparable to the benchmark BMW 3 Series. Available with a five-speed automatic or six-speed manual transmission, and in rear-wheel or all-wheel drive configurations, it offered options for different driving preferences and climates. The interior featured a driver-focused design with amenities expected in the luxury segment, though material quality was sometimes criticized compared to European competitors. The sedan version broadened the G35's appeal beyond sports car enthusiasts to include luxury buyers seeking driving enjoyment with practical four-door utility. This generation established the G sedan as a cornerstone of Infiniti's lineup, attracting buyers who previously might have defaulted to German luxury brands. The successful reception of the G35 Sedan played a crucial role in establishing Infiniti's performance-luxury identity in the early 2000s, setting the stage for the brand's subsequent growth and expanded model range.
INFINITI-G35.name: First Generation (V35) Sedan

INFINITI-G37.description: The Infiniti G37 Coupe was the successor to the G35 Coupe, featuring more aggressive styling with muscular fenders, a lower roofline, and sharper overall design. Built on an evolved version of Nissan's FM (Front Midship) platform, it maintained the front-engine, rear-wheel drive layout that defined the G series. Powered by a larger 3.7L VQ37VHR V6 engine producing 330 HP, paired with either a seven-speed automatic or six-speed manual transmission, it offered enhanced performance over its predecessor. The interior saw significant improvements in material quality, design, and technology, featuring a more premium feel with available features like a hard-drive based navigation system, Bose premium audio, and adaptive climate control. Available in multiple trims including the performance-oriented Sport and all-wheel drive models in some markets, it catered to different buyer preferences. A convertible variant (G37 Convertible) with a power-retractable hardtop was introduced in 2009, expanding the model's appeal. The G37 Coupe successfully built upon the foundation established by the G35, offering competitive performance against established luxury sports coupes like the BMW 3 Series Coupe while maintaining its value proposition.
INFINITI-G37.name: First Generation (V36) Coupe

INFINITI-G37.description: The G37 Sedan replaced the G35 Sedan in Infiniti's lineup, featuring updated styling consistent with the coupe but with a more practical four-door configuration. Sharing its platform and mechanical components with the coupe, it benefited from the same 3.7L VQ37VHR V6 engine producing 328 HP, paired with either a seven-speed automatic or six-speed manual transmission. Available in rear-wheel or all-wheel drive configurations and multiple trim levels including luxury-oriented Journey and performance-focused Sport models, it offered options for different driving preferences. The interior featured improved materials, design, and technology compared to its predecessor, with available features like dual-zone climate control, a rearview camera, and Infiniti's first implementation of the dual-touchscreen infotainment system in later years. This generation maintained the G sedan's position as a sport-luxury alternative to established European competitors, particularly appealing to buyers seeking driving enjoyment combined with Japanese reliability. In 2014, as part of Infiniti's nomenclature change, the G sedan was renamed Q50, while the coupe and convertible became the Q60, bringing an end to the G designation that had become synonymous with Infiniti's sport-luxury identity.
INFINITI-G37.name: First Generation (V36) Sedan

INFINITI-Q45.description: The original Infiniti Q45 was the brand's flagship luxury sedan, introduced when Infiniti launched in the United States. Featuring distinctive, minimalist styling that eschewed the chrome grilles and traditional luxury cues common to the segment, it took a more performance-oriented approach than most competitors. Powered by a 4.5L V8 engine producing 278 HP, paired with a four-speed automatic transmission, it offered impressive performance for its time. The rear-wheel drive platform featured an independent multi-link suspension and available active suspension system (HICAS) that delivered excellent handling for a large luxury sedan. The interior was similarly unconventional, with a minimalist design lacking wood trim and featuring a clock as the dashboard centerpiece rather than the traditional analog clock found in luxury vehicles. This generation established the Q45 as a driver-focused alternative to the more traditional Lexus LS400 and German luxury flagships, though its unconventional approach and Infiniti's low brand recognition limited its commercial success despite critical acclaim for its driving dynamics.
INFINITI-Q45.name: First Generation (G50)

INFINITI-Q45.description: The second-generation Q45 adopted a more conventional luxury approach, abandoning the minimalist styling of its predecessor for a more traditional design with a proper grille and increased chrome accents. Built on an updated platform, it was shorter but wider than the first generation, with slightly reduced interior space but improved rigidity. Powered by a new 4.1L V8 engine producing 266 HP, paired with a four-speed automatic transmission, it focused more on refinement than raw performance. The interior featured a significant shift toward traditional luxury with extensive wood trim, softer leather, and more conventional controls. This generation represented Infiniti's attempt to appeal to a broader luxury audience by adopting design elements and comfort features similar to successful competitors like Lexus. However, the more conservative approach combined with reduced power compared to its predecessor resulted in a vehicle that was less distinctive in the market, contributing to modest sales figures that fell short of Infiniti's expectations.
INFINITI-Q45.name: Second Generation (FY33)

INFINITI-Q45.description: The final generation of the Q45 returned to a more performance-oriented approach while maintaining traditional luxury elements. Featuring more aggressive styling with a distinctive grille and sharper lines, it adopted some of the sporting character that would later define Infiniti's brand identity. Powered by a new 4.5L V8 engine producing 340 HP, paired with a five-speed automatic transmission, it offered competitive performance against established luxury flagships. The interior combined luxury with technology, featuring one of the first production-car implementations of intelligent cruise control, rearview camera, voice recognition, and LED headlights. Available with an adaptive front lighting system that would swivel the headlights during turns, it showcased Infiniti's focus on innovative technology. Despite these advancements and generally positive reviews, the third-generation Q45 struggled to gain traction in a market increasingly dominated by German luxury brands and the Lexus LS. Production ended in 2006 without a direct replacement, as Infiniti shifted focus to its more successful G and M (later Q50 and Q70) models. The Q45 nameplate was eventually succeeded conceptually by the Q70, though the latter never achieved the flagship status or technological innovation that characterized the original Q45.
INFINITI-Q45.name: Third Generation (F50)

INFINITI-Q50.description: The Infiniti Q50 was introduced as the successor to the G37 sedan, representing the first model under Infiniti's new Q/QX nomenclature system. Built on Nissan's FM platform, it debuted at the 2013 North American International Auto Show and went on sale in Q3 2013. Early models featured a 3.7L VQ37VHR V6 producing 328 HP (333 PS) and a 3.5L Hybrid combining the V6 with an electric motor for 364 PS total output. Both rear-wheel drive and Intelligent All-Wheel Drive configurations were available. The interior featured a dual-touchscreen infotainment system with the upper screen for navigation and lower screen for vehicle controls. Notable innovation was the Direct Adaptive Steering (steer-by-wire) system eliminating mechanical connection between steering wheel and front wheels during normal operation. European models also included a 2.2d diesel engine (OM651) producing 168 HP. Production began May 14, 2013 at Nissan's Tochigi plant.
INFINITI-Q50.name: First Generation (V37)

INFINITI-Q50.description: A significant refresh for the 2016 model year introduced major powertrain and technology updates. The engine lineup was completely revised with the introduction of a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder (Mercedes-Benz M274) producing 211 HP, and a new 3.0L twin-turbo V6 (VR30DDTT) available in 304 HP and 400 HP (Red Sport 400) versions. The Hybrid model continued until 2018. Second-generation Direct Adaptive Steering was introduced with improved steering feel and feedback, along with Dynamic Digital Suspension. The Drive Mode Selector added a Personal mode for customization. Production continued through 2024, with Infiniti announcing cancellation of the Q50 in North America in August 2024 after eleven years on sale due to slow sales, leaving Infiniti as an SUV-only brand.
INFINITI-Q50.name: First Generation (V37) Facelift

INFINITI-Q70.description: The vehicle that would later become the Q70 was initially introduced as the Infiniti M, representing the third generation of Infiniti's mid-size luxury sedan. Built on Nissan's FM (Front Midship) rear-wheel drive platform, it featured flowing, organic styling with muscular fenders and distinctive wave-form details. Available as the M37 with a 3.7L V6 producing 330 HP or the M56 with a 5.6L V8 producing 420 HP, plus a hybrid variant (M35h) combining a 3.5L V6 with an electric motor for a combined 360 HP. All versions were paired with a seven-speed automatic transmission, with rear-wheel drive standard and all-wheel drive optional on non-hybrid models. The interior featured a distinctive, wraparound design with high-quality materials including genuine wood and semi-aniline leather on higher trims. Advanced technology for its time included available Blind Spot Intervention, Lane Departure Prevention, and a Forest Air climate control system designed to provide cleaner, more natural airflow. This generation established itself as a more distinctive and driver-focused alternative to established luxury sedans like the BMW 5 Series and Mercedes-Benz E-Class.
INFINITI-Q70.name: First Generation (as Infiniti M, Y51)

INFINITI-Q70.description: In 2014, as part of Infiniti's comprehensive nomenclature change, the M sedan was renamed Q70 without major mechanical changes. A significant expansion came with the introduction of the Q70L, featuring a 5.9-inch longer wheelbase dedicated almost entirely to increased rear passenger legroom. The powertrain lineup continued with the 3.7L V6, 5.6L V8, and hybrid system, though availability varied by market. A styling refresh in 2015 updated the exterior with a more prominent grille, revised LED headlights and taillights, and new wheel designs. The interior received minor enhancements to materials and technology features but maintained the same fundamental design. Despite these updates, the Q70 began to show its age compared to newer competitors, particularly in infotainment technology and driver assistance features. The model was discontinued in most markets after the 2019 model year without a direct replacement, as Infiniti shifted focus to SUVs and the smaller Q50 sedan. Throughout its production run, the Q70 maintained a reputation for smooth powertrains, distinctive styling, and generous interior space, though it never achieved the sales success of its German and Japanese luxury competitors, remaining a relatively niche choice in the midsize luxury sedan segment.
INFINITI-Q70.name: First Generation (as Infiniti Q70, Y51)

INFINITI-QX55.description: The INFINITI QX55 is the brand's coupe-SUV, designed as a spiritual successor to the FX series that pioneered the segment in the early 2000s. Based on the QX50 platform (second generation J55) but featuring a dramatically sloping roofline and fastback profile, it combines crossover utility with sports coupe styling. The exterior design incorporates INFINITI's signature double-arch grille, piano key LED headlights, and a distinctive character line that rises toward the rear, creating muscular proportions. Powered exclusively by a 2.0L VC-Turbo four-cylinder engine—the world's first production variable compression ratio engine—producing 268 HP and 280 lb-ft of torque. Power is delivered through a continuously variable transmission (Xtronic CVT) and standard all-wheel drive across all trim levels. The interior shares much of its design with the QX50, featuring a dual-screen infotainment system with 8-inch upper and 7-inch lower touchscreens, available semi-aniline leather seating, and open-pore wood trim in higher specifications. Despite the coupe roofline, rear headroom remains adequate for adults, though cargo space is reduced compared to the QX50. Standard safety and driver assistance technologies include forward emergency braking, predictive forward collision warning, and available ProPILOT Assist semi-autonomous driving features. As INFINITI's entry in the luxury coupe-SUV segment, the QX55 competes with models like the BMW X4 and Mercedes-Benz GLC Coupe, offering distinctive styling and the unique VC-Turbo technology as key differentiators. Production will end in 2025.
INFINITI-QX55.name: First Generation

INFINITI-QX70.description: The vehicle that would later become the QX70 was originally introduced as the INFINITI FX, pioneering the performance-focused luxury crossover segment with its 'bionic cheetah' design philosophy. Built on Nissan's FM (Front Midship) platform shared with the 350Z sports car and G35 sedan, it featured an aggressive, sports car-inspired design with a long hood, sharply raked windshield, and muscular proportions. Available as the FX35 with a 3.5L V6 producing 280 HP or the FX45 with a 4.5L V8 producing 315 HP, both paired with a five-speed automatic transmission. All models featured all-wheel drive (with rear-wheel drive later available on V6 models), sport-tuned suspension, and a rear-biased weight distribution that delivered handling dynamics more akin to sports sedans than traditional SUVs. The interior combined luxury elements with a driver-focused cockpit, featuring premium materials and advanced technology for its time including an available rear-view camera and intelligent cruise control. This generation established the FX as a distinctive alternative to conventional luxury SUVs, prioritizing on-road performance and bold styling over traditional utility.
INFINITI-QX70.name: First Generation (as INFINITI FX)

INFINITI-QX70.description: The second-generation maintained the performance-focused philosophy of its predecessor while refining the design and technology. Initially launched as the FX, it was renamed QX70 in 2014 as part of INFINITI's nomenclature restructuring. The exterior design evolved with even more aggressive styling featuring bulging fenders, a more prominent grille, and curves inspired by natural forms and athletic tension. Powertrain options expanded to include the FX35/QX70 3.7 with a 3.7L V6 producing 325 HP, the FX50/QX70 5.0 with a 5.0L V8 delivering 390 HP, and in some markets, a 3.0L V6 diesel. All engines paired with a seven-speed automatic transmission, with rear-wheel drive standard on V6 models and all-wheel drive optional (standard on V8 models). The interior featured higher quality materials, more sophisticated design, and advanced technology including INFINITI's first implementation of Around View Monitor providing a 360-degree view of the vehicle's surroundings. Available safety innovations included Lane Departure Prevention, Intelligent Brake Assist, and Distance Control Assist. A 2012 refresh updated the styling with a revised grille and front fascia, followed by the name change to QX70 in 2014. Despite its age, the QX70 maintained its distinctive character until its discontinuation in 2017, with a unique position as one of the most driver-focused SUVs on the market, sacrificing some practical considerations like rear passenger space and cargo capacity in favor of style and performance.
INFINITI-QX70.name: Second Generation (as INFINITI FX, later QX70)

JAC-EJ7.description: The JAC EJ7 is an all-electric mid-size sedan developed by Chinese automaker JAC Motors. Featuring sleek, contemporary styling with clean lines, a fastback profile, and LED lighting elements, it represents JAC's most sophisticated electric vehicle design to date. The exterior incorporates aerodynamic elements including flush door handles, a smooth underbody, and optimized airflow management, contributing to its efficiency. Powered by a permanent magnet synchronous electric motor producing approximately 190 HP (142 kW) and 340 Nm of torque, it delivers a 0-100 km/h acceleration time of around 7.5 seconds. The lithium-ion battery pack with a capacity of approximately 70 kWh enables a claimed range of up to 500 km under China's NEDC testing standard (approximately 400 km in real-world conditions). DC fast charging allows for a 30-80% charge in about 30 minutes. The interior features a minimalist, technology-focused design with a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, a large central touchscreen (approximately 12.8 inches), and touch-sensitive controls replacing many physical buttons. Advanced driver assistance systems include adaptive cruise control, lane keeping assist, and autonomous emergency braking. Positioned as JAC's premium electric offering, the EJ7 competes with domestic Chinese electric sedans like the BYD Han and Xpeng P7, as well as international models such as the Tesla Model 3, though it is primarily focused on the Chinese market with limited export availability. The EJ7 represents JAC's efforts to move upmarket and establish itself in the increasingly competitive Chinese electric vehicle segment, leveraging the company's experience as one of China's earlier entrants into the EV space.
JAC-EJ7.name: First Generation

Jaecoo-J7.description: The Jaecoo J7 (also known as Jaecoo 7) is the inaugural model from Jaecoo, a premium sub-brand of Chery Automobile launched in 2023. Built on Chery's T1X platform, this compact crossover SUV (C-segment) features rugged yet sophisticated styling with a bold front grille, matrix LED headlights, and distinctive design elements. Available powertrains include a 1.6-liter turbocharged petrol engine producing approximately 197 HP paired with a 7-speed dual-clutch transmission (available in FWD and AWD), and a 1.5-liter turbocharged plug-in hybrid system (SHS/C-DM) delivering around 326 HP with an electric range rated at approximately 80-106 km. The interior features a minimalist dashboard with a 14.8-inch touchscreen powered by a Qualcomm 8155 chip, supporting FOTA updates, facial recognition, and Level 2+ driver assistance. The Jaecoo J7 is marketed globally across Europe, UK, Australia, New Zealand, Russia, South Africa, Southeast Asia, Latin America, and the Middle East. In China, the vehicle is sold as the Chery Tansuo 06 (also known as Chery Tiggo 7 High Energy or Fulwin T6 for PHEV variants).
Jaecoo-J7.name: First Generation

Jaguar-F-PACE.description: The Jaguar F-PACE was the brand's first-ever SUV, combining sports car-inspired design with practical utility. Built on Jaguar's lightweight aluminum architecture shared with the XE and XF sedans, it features distinctive styling with a bold front grille, sleek headlights, strong shoulder line and F-TYPE-inspired rear haunches and taillights. The initial powertrain lineup varied by market but typically included a range of four-cylinder and V6 petrol and diesel engines, with the performance-oriented F-PACE S featuring a supercharged 3.0L V6 producing 380 HP. All models featured an eight-speed automatic transmission with either rear-wheel drive or all-wheel drive. The interior combined traditional Jaguar luxury elements with a more modern approach, featuring a 10.2-inch InControl Touch Pro infotainment system, configurable ambient lighting, and premium materials including leather and aluminum. Despite being an SUV, the F-PACE emphasized driving dynamics with sophisticated suspension, torque vectoring, and a rear-biased all-wheel drive system. A range-topping SVR variant with a 5.0L supercharged V8 producing 550 HP was added in 2018, establishing the F-PACE's performance credentials. This generation established Jaguar in the luxury SUV segment, becoming the brand's best-selling model and winning numerous awards including the 2017 World Car of the Year.
Jaguar-F-PACE.name: First Generation (Pre-facelift)

Jaguar-F-PACE.description: The refreshed F-PACE features significant updates to the exterior, interior, and powertrain options while maintaining the same fundamental platform. Exterior changes include slimmer LED headlights, a larger grille, redesigned bumpers, and new taillights with a double chicane signature inspired by the I-PACE. The interior received a complete overhaul with a more modern design centered around an 11.4-inch curved-glass touchscreen running Jaguar's new Pivi Pro infotainment system, a redesigned dashboard and center console, improved materials, and a new electronic gear selector replacing the rotary dial. Powertrain options were updated to include mild-hybrid technology on most engines, plus a new plug-in hybrid P400e variant combining a 2.0L four-cylinder engine with an electric motor for a combined 404 HP and an electric-only range of approximately 33 miles. The SVR model continued with an updated 5.0L supercharged V8 now producing 550 HP. Technology advancements include software-over-the-air update capability, active road noise cancellation, and enhanced driver assistance systems. The cabin air ionization system with PM2.5 filtration reflects increasing attention to air quality. This substantial refresh aimed to address criticisms of the original model's interior quality and technology while maintaining the F-PACE's position as a dynamically focused luxury SUV that combines practicality with Jaguar's sporting heritage.
Jaguar-F-PACE.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Jaguar-F-TYPE.description: The Jaguar F-TYPE was introduced as a spiritual successor to the legendary E-Type, marking Jaguar's return to the two-seat sports car segment. Initially launched as a convertible with a coupe following in 2014, it featured dramatically beautiful proportions with a long hood, short rear deck, and muscular haunches. Built on a shortened version of Jaguar's aluminum architecture, it offered exceptional structural rigidity and a near-perfect weight distribution. The initial powertrain lineup included a 3.0L supercharged V6 in two output levels (340 HP and 380 HP in the S model) and a 5.0L supercharged V8 delivering 495 HP in the V8 S convertible and later 550 HP in the R models. Transmission options initially included a six-speed manual (V6 only) and an eight-speed automatic. The interior featured a driver-focused cockpit with a distinctive passenger grab handle, premium materials, and a 'Handcrafted in Britain' approach to detailing. The F-TYPE quickly established a reputation for its visceral driving experience, particularly the crackling, popping exhaust note that became one of its signature characteristics. Various special editions and new variants were introduced throughout this period, including the range-topping SVR with 575 HP and a 200 mph top speed. This generation revitalized Jaguar's sports car heritage and provided a halo product that influenced the design and character of other Jaguar models.
Jaguar-F-TYPE.name: First Generation (Pre-facelift)

Jaguar-F-TYPE.description: The refreshed F-TYPE received substantial styling updates while maintaining the same basic platform and proportions. The exterior features slimmer, more horizontal LED headlights that dramatically altered the car's facial expression, a larger grille, and subtle revisions to the rear styling. The powertrain lineup was simplified, dropping the V6 options in most markets in favor of a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder producing 296 HP as the entry-level engine and the 5.0L supercharged V8 in two output levels: 450 HP (P450) and 575 HP (R). All engines were paired exclusively with an eight-speed automatic transmission, with the manual option discontinued. The interior received more subtle updates with improved materials, a fully digital 12.3-inch driver display, and an updated infotainment system. Chassis and suspension refinements enhanced both handling precision and ride comfort, while the active exhaust system continued to provide the distinctive sound that had become central to the F-TYPE's character. This refresh maintained the F-TYPE's position as Jaguar's flagship sports car while addressing increased competition and shifting market preferences. Production is scheduled to end in 2024 without a direct combustion-engine replacement, marking the conclusion of Jaguar's traditional sports cars as the brand transitions toward becoming an all-electric luxury manufacturer.
Jaguar-F-TYPE.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Jaguar-I-PACE.description: The Jaguar I-PACE is the brand's first all-electric vehicle, pioneering a new design language and engineering approach for Jaguar. Built on the JLR D7e electric vehicle platform, it features a distinctive cab-forward design that maximizes interior space while maintaining athletic proportions. The exterior combines SUV practicality with sports car influences, featuring a short hood, squared-off rear, and dramatic proportions enabled by the placement of batteries in the floor structure. Powered by dual permanent magnet synchronous electric motors providing all-wheel drive and a combined output of 394 HP (294 kW) and 512 lb-ft (694 Nm) of torque, it delivers 0-60 mph acceleration in 4.8 seconds with a top speed of 124 mph (electronically limited). The 90 kWh lithium-ion battery (432 pouch cells) offers an EPA-estimated range of 234 miles (WLTP: up to 292 miles), with DC fast charging capability allowing 0-80% charge in approximately 40-45 minutes at 100 kW. The interior showcases a minimalist, modern design with a floating center console, and was initially equipped with the InControl Touch Pro Duo infotainment system. The absence of a traditional drivetrain creates a flat floor and generous interior space despite relatively compact exterior dimensions. Advanced features include adaptive air suspension, active air management, and Jaguar's Adaptive Surface Response for optimizing traction in various conditions. The I-PACE has received critical acclaim, winning the 2019 World Car of the Year, European Car of the Year, World Car Design of the Year, and World Green Car awards. It was discontinued in 2024 due to slowing sales and a change in corporate vision, marking the end of Jaguar's first mass-produced electric vehicle.
Jaguar-I-PACE.name: First Generation

Jeep-Avenger.description: The Jeep Avenger is a subcompact crossover SUV (B-segment) produced by Jeep since January 2023 mainly for the European market. Based on the Common Modular Platform (CMP) shared with the second-generation Peugeot 2008, Opel Mokka, and DS 3 Crossback, it is the smallest vehicle offered by Jeep. At just 4.08 meters long, it's positioned below the Renegade in size. The Avenger is offered with mild hybrid and battery electric powertrains, using the STLA Small platform (e-CMP for the electric version). The battery electric version features a front-mounted electric motor producing 115 kW (154 HP) and 260 Nm of torque, paired with a 54 kWh battery providing up to 400 km (249 miles) of WLTP range. The mild hybrid variants use a 1.2L turbocharged three-cylinder engine with 48V mild hybrid technology. Ground clearance is 200mm with 20° approach angle and 32° departure angle, equipped with Jeep's Selec-Terrain system (Normal, Eco, Sport, Snow, Mud, Sand modes) and Hill Descent Control. The interior features a 10.25-inch touchscreen infotainment system and 10.25-inch digital instrument cluster. Designed in Italy and manufactured in Tychy, Poland, the Avenger is primarily marketed in Europe with sales also planned in Turkey, Morocco, Japan, and South Korea. It is not available in the United States, Canada, or China. The Avenger won European Car of the Year 2023—the first Jeep to receive this honor.
Jeep-Avenger.name: First Generation

Jeep-Cherokee.description: The original Cherokee was a two-door variant of the full-size Jeep Wagoneer, effectively a sportier version of the larger SUV. Built on a traditional body-on-frame truck platform with solid axles front and rear, it featured rugged construction and legitimate off-road capability. Powered by a range of inline-six and V8 engines including AMC's 258 cubic-inch six-cylinder and various 360 cubic-inch V8s, it balanced power with the durability expected of a Jeep. The interior was relatively sparse by modern standards but functional, with available amenities including air conditioning and upgraded upholstery. This generation established the Cherokee nameplate that would eventually become one of Jeep's most recognizable models, though it was considerably larger and more truck-like than later generations.
Jeep-Cherokee.name: First Generation (SJ)

Jeep-Cherokee.description: The XJ Cherokee represented a revolutionary approach to SUV design, combining traditional Jeep capability with more modern unibody construction instead of the previous body-on-frame approach. Significantly smaller and lighter than its predecessor, it featured boxy, upright styling that would become iconic. Initially available with either AMC's 2.5L four-cylinder or 2.8L V6 (later replaced by a 4.0L inline-six), it offered a choice of manual or automatic transmissions and various four-wheel drive systems including Command-Trac and Selec-Trac. The interior was practical and durable rather than luxurious, with adequate space for five passengers. Through its remarkably long production run, the XJ Cherokee received various updates to styling, powertrains, and features, but maintained its fundamental character. This generation became a benchmark for compact SUVs, combining everyday practicality with genuine off-road capability in a way few competitors could match. Its influential design and engineering approach essentially created the modern SUV segment, and its reputation for ruggedness and reliability has made it a cult classic among off-road enthusiasts.
Jeep-Cherokee.name: Second Generation (XJ)

Jeep-Cherokee.description: The third-generation Cherokee was marketed as the Liberty in North America while retaining the Cherokee name in most international markets. Featuring more rounded styling than its predecessor, it maintained traditional Jeep design elements like the seven-slot grille and trapezoidal wheel arches. Built on a new platform with rack-and-pinion steering and an independent front suspension (with solid rear axle), it attempted to balance on-road comfort with off-road capability. Powertrain options included a 2.4L four-cylinder, 3.7L V6, and in some markets, diesel engines, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. The interior offered more modern amenities and improved materials compared to the utilitarian XJ. This generation represented a more mainstream approach to the compact SUV segment, though some enthusiasts criticized it for sacrificing some of the rugged simplicity that had defined the XJ. Despite these criticisms, it maintained respectable off-road capability with available four-wheel drive systems including Command-Trac and Selec-Trac.
Jeep-Cherokee.name: Third Generation (KJ, Liberty in North America)

Jeep-Cherokee.description: The fourth-generation Cherokee (still called Liberty in North America) featured more angular styling that referenced classic Jeep design cues, with a boxier silhouette than its predecessor. Built on an updated platform, it maintained the independent front suspension/solid rear axle layout. Power came primarily from a 3.7L V6 engine in North America, with various four-cylinder and diesel options in international markets. The interior saw improvements in design and material quality, though still focused more on durability than luxury. Notable features included the Sky Slider full-length canvas roof option and an available MyGIG infotainment system. This generation continued Jeep's effort to balance daily usability with off-road capability, offering systems like Command-Trac II four-wheel drive and an available Trail Rated package. Production ended in 2012 as Jeep prepared to reintroduce the Cherokee name in North America with a completely redesigned vehicle.
Jeep-Cherokee.name: Fourth Generation (KK, Liberty in North America)

Jeep-Cherokee.description: The KL Cherokee marked a dramatic departure from previous generations, featuring polarizing styling with split headlights, a curved interpretation of the seven-slot grille, and more car-like proportions. Built on the Compact US Wide platform shared with various Fiat Chrysler products, it used a fully independent suspension for improved on-road manners. Powertrain options evolved throughout its production, initially including a 2.4L four-cylinder and 3.2L V6, later adding a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder, paired with a nine-speed automatic transmission. Available in front-wheel drive or with various four-wheel drive systems including the advanced Active Drive Lock with a rear locking differential on Trailhawk models. The interior offered significantly improved design, materials, and technology, featuring Uconnect infotainment systems and modern safety features. A substantial refresh in 2019 unified the headlights for a more conventional appearance and updated technology features. Despite its controversial styling and more road-focused platform, the Trailhawk variant maintained Jeep's off-road credibility with impressive capability for a unibody crossover. Production ended in 2023 as part of Stellantis' product portfolio realignment, with the Compass expanding to fill part of the Cherokee's former position in the lineup.
Jeep-Cherokee.name: Fifth Generation (KL)

Jeep-Commander.description: The original Jeep Commander was a full-size SUV built on a modified Grand Cherokee platform, notable as Jeep's first vehicle with standard three-row seating. Featuring squared-off, boxy styling inspired by the classic Cherokee and Wagoneer models, it presented a rugged, traditional SUV appearance despite sharing many components with the more rounded contemporary Grand Cherokee. The distinctive design included an upright windshield, squared-off sides, and an unusually tall roof to accommodate the stadium-style third-row seating. Powertrain options included a 3.7L V6, 4.7L V8, and a 5.7L HEMI V8 with Multi-Displacement System, paired with a five-speed automatic transmission and various four-wheel drive systems including Quadra-Trac I, Quadra-Trac II, and Quadra-Drive II. The interior featured three rows of seating for up to seven passengers, though the third row was criticized for limited space and accessibility. Upscale features on higher trims included leather seating, premium audio systems, and dual-zone climate control. Despite its traditional Jeep off-road capability, the Commander struggled in the marketplace due to its introduction coinciding with rising fuel prices and shifting consumer preferences toward more efficient crossovers. Production ended after just four model years without a direct replacement as Chrysler restructured following its bankruptcy and acquisition by Fiat.
Jeep-Commander.name: First Generation (XK, North America)

Jeep-Commander.description: The Jeep Commander/Grand Commander sold in China was unrelated to the North American model, instead based on an extended version of the Cherokee platform. Developed specifically for the Chinese market where three-row SUVs are highly desirable, it featured more conventional crossover styling aligned with Jeep's contemporary design language. Offered in standard Commander (five-seat) and longer Grand Commander (seven-seat) variants, it was significantly smaller than the previous North American Commander. Powertrain options centered around a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder in various output levels, paired with a nine-speed automatic transmission. The interior emphasized luxury and technology, featuring a modern design with a large touchscreen infotainment system, digital instrument cluster options, and premium materials. This China-specific model represented Jeep's effort to expand in the crucial Chinese market by developing regionally-specific products, though it was eventually discontinued as the joint venture between Stellantis and GAC struggled in an increasingly competitive Chinese automotive landscape.
Jeep-Commander.name: First Generation (K8, China)

Jeep-Commander.description: The current Commander sold in South America (particularly Brazil) is a completely different vehicle from both previous Commander models, based on the Compass platform but extended to accommodate three rows of seating. Designed specifically for Latin American markets, it features styling consistent with Jeep's modern design language, including slim LED headlights, the seven-slot grille, and a floating roof effect created by blacked-out pillars. Powertrain options include a 1.3L turbocharged gasoline engine and a 2.0L turbodiesel, paired with either a six-speed or nine-speed automatic transmission depending on the variant. Front-wheel drive is standard with four-wheel drive available on higher trims. The interior emphasizes premium features and technology, including a 10.1-inch touchscreen infotainment system, digital instrument cluster, and advanced driver assistance systems. Manufactured in Brazil, this Commander/Commander PHEV (plug-in hybrid variant added later) represents Jeep's strategy of developing market-specific products for regions like South America, where three-row SUVs at this size and price point have strong appeal. Despite sharing the Commander name, this model bears no direct relationship to either the original North American XK Commander or the Chinese K8 Commander.
Jeep-Commander.name: Second Generation (H1, South America)

Jeep-Compass.description: The original Jeep Compass was introduced alongside the Patriot as Jeep's entry into the growing compact crossover segment. Built on the GS platform shared with the Dodge Caliber, it featured more road-focused, car-like characteristics than traditional Jeep models. The exterior styling attempted to blend Jeep design cues like the seven-slot grille with a more contemporary crossover shape. Powertrain options centered around a 2.0L or 2.4L four-cylinder engine, paired with either a manual transmission, conventional automatic, or continuously variable transmission (CVT). Front-wheel drive was standard with an available Freedom Drive I all-wheel drive system. The interior was initially criticized for hard plastics and basic design, though a significant refresh in 2011 improved materials, styling, and feature content considerably. This update also brought exterior styling more in line with the Grand Cherokee, including a more traditional Jeep grille design. While the first-generation Compass offered reasonable value and fuel economy, its limited off-road capability and refinement positioned it as an entry-level option that sacrificed some of Jeep's traditional strengths in favor of affordability and on-road comfort.
Jeep-Compass.name: First Generation (MK49)

Jeep-Compass.description: The second-generation Compass debuted in September 2016 in Brazil and at the Los Angeles Auto Show, representing a complete redesign that dramatically improved the model's positioning and capability. Built on the Small Wide LWB platform shared with the Renegade, it features sophisticated styling inspired by the Grand Cherokee, with a sleeker profile and premium design elements. Powertrain options include a 2.4L Tigershark four-cylinder engine in North America paired with a nine-speed automatic transmission, with various gasoline and diesel engines available internationally. Available in front-wheel drive or with Jeep's Selec-Terrain four-wheel drive system, including the advanced Active Drive Low with a 20:1 crawl ratio on Trailhawk models. The interior offers significantly improved design, materials, and technology, featuring Uconnect infotainment systems with 7-inch or 8.4-inch touchscreens and modern safety features. A substantial refresh for 2022 updated the exterior styling, completely redesigned the interior with a more horizontal dashboard layout and larger screens, and added new technology features including a digital instrument cluster option. This generation successfully repositioned the Compass as a more premium compact SUV, bridging the gap between the smaller Renegade and larger Cherokee while offering genuine off-road capability in Trailhawk form—earning Jeep's 'Trail Rated' designation. A plug-in hybrid 4xe variant was also introduced, combining a 1.3L turbocharged engine with an electric motor for enhanced efficiency.
Jeep-Compass.name: Second Generation (MP/552)

Jeep-Compass.description: The third-generation Compass was unveiled in May 2025, representing Jeep's most advanced and versatile iteration of the compact SUV. Built on Stellantis's STLA Medium platform, it is the first Jeep offered with the choice of mild hybrid, plug-in hybrid, and battery electric powertrains, ensuring it can meet diverse customer needs. The design retains Jeep's signature seven-slot grille and trapezoidal wheel arches while introducing X-shaped LED taillights, illuminated Jeep logo, and a chrome-free exterior for ecological reasons. The interior features a 10-inch digital instrument cluster and a 16-inch touchscreen infotainment system, with most controls being touchscreen-based. Standard approach, breakover, and departure angles are 20, 15, and 26 degrees respectively, with a ground clearance of approximately 8 inches and maximum wading depth enhanced for off-road capability. Level 2 autonomous driving assistance is available. Production for North American models will begin at Belvidere Assembly Plant in Illinois starting in late 2026 or early 2027 for the 2028 model year, while European production continues at the Melfi plant in Italy.
Jeep-Compass.name: Third Generation (J4U)

Jeep-Gladiator.description: The original Jeep Gladiator (later simply called Jeep Pickup or J-Series) was a full-size pickup truck based on the Wagoneer platform. Featuring traditional body-on-frame construction with solid axles front and rear, it offered genuine capability both on and off-road. Initially available in multiple wheelbases and body configurations including Thriftside (step side) and Townside (standard) bed options, it evolved throughout its long production run. Powertrain options varied considerably over the 26-year lifespan, starting with 'Tornado' inline-six and 'Vigilante' V8 engines from Willys and later incorporating AMC powerplants after Jeep's acquisition, including the 258 cubic-inch inline-six and 360 cubic-inch V8. The interior was functional and straightforward, prioritizing utility over luxury, though more upscale features were available in later models. After a name change to J-Series in 1971, the model continued largely unchanged mechanically, though with updated styling to match contemporary Jeep vehicles. Production continued under AMC and briefly under Chrysler ownership before being discontinued when Chrysler acquired AMC and refocused the Jeep brand on SUVs. This generation established Jeep's pickup truck heritage and developed a cult following for its durability and design, maintaining influence decades after production ended.
Jeep-Gladiator.name: First Generation (as Jeep Pickup/Gladiator, SJ)

Jeep-Gladiator.description: After a 26-year absence from the pickup market, Jeep revived the Gladiator name for a midsize truck based on the Wrangler JL platform. Featuring distinctive styling that combines the Wrangler's iconic front end with a five-foot steel bed, it maintains Jeep's traditional design elements while adding pickup functionality. Built on a frame that's 31 inches longer than the Wrangler Unlimited with a wheelbase extended by 19.4 inches, it's engineered specifically for pickup duties rather than simply being a Wrangler with a bed. Initially launched with a 3.6L Pentastar V6 producing 285 HP paired with either a six-speed manual or eight-speed automatic transmission, the lineup later expanded to include a 3.0L EcoDiesel V6 option with 260 HP and 442 lb-ft of torque. Like the Wrangler, it features solid axles front and rear, with Dana 44 axles standard across the range. Available in multiple trim levels including the off-road focused Rubicon with electronic locking differentials, disconnecting sway bar, and 33-inch tires, it offers class-leading capability with 11.1 inches of ground clearance and up to 30 inches of water fording ability. The interior shares its design with the Wrangler, featuring a layout that balances ruggedness with modern technology, including available 8.4-inch Uconnect touchscreen and advanced safety features. Unique among modern midsize trucks, it offers a removable roof (soft top, hardtop, or power soft top options) and doors for an open-air experience. With a maximum towing capacity of 7,650 pounds and payload of 1,700 pounds, it balances work capability with Jeep's traditional off-road prowess, creating a distinctive offering in the pickup market that leverages the brand's heritage while expanding into a new segment.
Jeep-Gladiator.name: Second Generation (JT)

Jeep-Grand-Cherokee.description: The original Jeep Grand Cherokee was introduced as a more refined, upscale alternative to the Cherokee, targeting both off-road enthusiasts and luxury SUV buyers. Built on a unibody platform but maintaining true off-road capability with solid axles front and rear, it balanced on-road comfort with genuine Jeep ruggedness. Initially powered by AMC's 4.0L inline-six or an optional 5.2L V8, with a 5.9L V8 added later in the limited-production 5.9 Limited performance model. Available with several four-wheel drive systems including Command-Trac and the more advanced Quadra-Trac, plus rear-wheel drive in some markets. The interior was significantly more upscale than other Jeep models of the era, with available leather seating, power accessories, and premium audio. This generation established the Grand Cherokee as a versatile, capable SUV that could compete with both traditional off-roaders and emerging luxury SUVs, creating a formula that would define the model for decades.
Jeep-Grand-Cherokee.name: First Generation (ZJ)

Jeep-Grand-Cherokee.description: The second-generation Grand Cherokee featured a complete redesign with more refined styling, improved on-road handling, and enhanced interior quality. While maintaining solid axles front and rear, the suspension was redesigned for better ride comfort. Powertrain options expanded to include updated versions of the 4.0L inline-six and 4.7L PowerTech V8 replacing the previous 5.2L, with a high-output version of the 4.7L added later. Four-wheel drive systems evolved with the introduction of Quadra-Drive, which added electronic limited-slip differentials for improved traction. The interior saw significant improvements in materials, design, and feature content, with available amenities including dual-zone climate control, premium audio, and heated seats. Safety features expanded to include standard front and available side airbags. This generation further established the Grand Cherokee's position as a premium SUV that maintained serious off-road capability, increasing its appeal to luxury buyers while satisfying traditional Jeep enthusiasts.
Jeep-Grand-Cherokee.name: Second Generation (WJ)

Jeep-Grand-Cherokee.description: The third-generation Grand Cherokee featured more radical changes, adopting independent front suspension for the first time while maintaining a solid rear axle. The new design prioritized on-road comfort and handling without sacrificing off-road capability. Styling became more modern with a shorter, more rounded front end and cleaner overall design. Engine options included an updated 3.7L V6 replacing the 4.0L inline-six, a revised 4.7L V8, and the new 5.7L HEMI V8 with cylinder deactivation technology. The performance-oriented SRT8 model debuted with a 6.1L HEMI V8 producing 420 HP. The interior received a complete redesign with improved materials, more contemporary styling, and enhanced technology including available navigation, rear-seat entertainment, and upgraded audio systems. Safety features expanded to include electronic stability control, anti-roll mitigation, and side-curtain airbags. This generation represented a significant step toward making the Grand Cherokee more competitive with car-based crossovers in terms of on-road refinement while maintaining class-leading off-road capability.
Jeep-Grand-Cherokee.name: Third Generation (WK)

Jeep-Grand-Cherokee.description: The fourth-generation Grand Cherokee featured evolved styling with a more upright front end, trapezoid wheel arches, and more premium detailing. Built on a platform co-developed with Mercedes-Benz during the DaimlerChrysler era, it offered improved dynamics, refinement, and capability. The independent front suspension was refined, with a choice of three 4x4 systems and the new Quadra-Lift air suspension providing adjustable ride height. Engine options expanded to include a 3.6L Pentastar V6, updated 5.7L HEMI V8, 6.4L HEMI V8 in SRT models, and later a supercharged 6.2L Hellcat V8 in the Trackhawk producing 707 HP. A 3.0L EcoDiesel V6 was also offered for improved fuel economy and torque. The interior represented a major leap forward in quality and technology, with available features including an 8.4-inch Uconnect touchscreen, panoramic sunroof, and premium audio systems. Safety technology advanced significantly with adaptive cruise control, blind-spot monitoring, and forward collision warning. This generation elevated the Grand Cherokee's premium positioning while maintaining its off-road heritage, successfully spanning mainstream and luxury segments.
Jeep-Grand-Cherokee.name: Fourth Generation (WK2)

Jeep-Grand-Cherokee.description: The current Grand Cherokee features completely new styling with a longer hood, forward-leaning grille, and sleeker overall profile. Available in both two-row and three-row (L) configurations for the first time, it offers greater flexibility for different needs. Built on an all-new architecture with independent suspension front and rear, it maintains off-road capability with three available 4x4 systems and improved approach, departure, and breakover angles in Trailhawk models. Powertrain options include a standard 3.6L Pentastar V6, optional 5.7L HEMI V8, and for the first time, a 4xe plug-in hybrid combining a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder with electric motors for 375 HP and approximately 25 miles of electric-only range. The interior represents a dramatic advancement with available features including a 10.1-inch center touchscreen, 10.25-inch front passenger display, 10.3-inch digital gauge cluster, and McIntosh premium audio system. Luxury reaches new heights with the Summit Reserve trim featuring hand-wrapped quilted leather, open-pore waxed walnut, and 21-inch wheels. Driver assistance technology is comprehensive with hands-on Level 2 automated driving capability, night vision, and intersection collision assist. This generation combines the most refined on-road experience and luxurious interior in Grand Cherokee history with the continued off-road capability expected of a Jeep, maintaining its position as the brand's flagship SUV.
Jeep-Grand-Cherokee.name: Fifth Generation (WL)

Jeep-Liberty.description: The Jeep Liberty (sold as the Cherokee in markets outside North America) was introduced as a replacement for the Cherokee (XJ), featuring more rounded styling that departed from its boxy predecessor. Built on a new platform with rack-and-pinion steering and an independent front suspension with coil springs (while maintaining a solid rear axle), it attempted to balance improved on-road comfort with continued off-road capability. Powered primarily by a 3.7L PowerTech V6 producing 210 HP, with a 2.4L four-cylinder available as a base engine in some years, plus diesel options in international markets. Transmission options included a four-speed automatic or five-speed manual, with either Command-Trac part-time or Selec-Trac full-time four-wheel drive systems available. The interior offered more contemporary design and improved materials compared to the utilitarian Cherokee it replaced, with available features including power accessories, premium audio, and heated leather seats on higher trims. Unique features included an available sky slider roof—a large canvas sunroof that opened nearly the entire length of the roof. This generation established the Liberty as a more mainstream compact SUV while attempting to maintain enough off-road capability to satisfy traditional Jeep customers.
Jeep-Liberty.name: First Generation (KJ)

Jeep-Liberty.description: The second-generation Liberty featured more angular, aggressive styling with boxier proportions that referenced classic Jeep design cues. Built on an updated platform, it maintained the independent front suspension/solid rear axle layout but with revised geometry for improved handling. Power came primarily from the same 3.7L PowerTech V6, now producing 210 HP and 235 lb-ft of torque. Transmission options streamlined to a four-speed automatic, later replaced by a six-speed automatic, with either Command-Trac II part-time or Selec-Trac II full-time four-wheel drive systems available. The interior saw improvements in design and material quality, though still focused more on durability than luxury. Notable features included the Sky Slider full-length canvas roof and an available MyGIG infotainment system with navigation and hard drive-based music storage. Off-road capability remained a priority with the Trail Rated badge available on properly equipped models. Production ended in 2012 as Jeep prepared to consolidate its lineup, effectively replacing both the Liberty and Patriot with the new Cherokee (KL) introduced for 2014. The Liberty represented Jeep's attempt to modernize its compact SUV offerings while maintaining core brand values, serving as a transitional model between the iconic but dated Cherokee (XJ) and the more crossover-oriented Cherokee (KL) that followed.
Jeep-Liberty.name: Second Generation (KK)

Jeep-Patriot.description: The Jeep Patriot was introduced alongside the Jeep Compass as Jeep's entry-level compact SUV. Built on the GS platform shared with the Dodge Caliber, it featured traditional boxy Jeep styling referencing the Cherokee (XJ). Powered by a 2.0L or 2.4L four-cylinder engine paired with either a 5-speed manual, automatic transmission, or CVT. Front-wheel drive was standard with two four-wheel drive systems available: Freedom Drive I for light-duty capability and Freedom Drive II with low-range mode earning the 'Trail Rated' designation. The interior featured hard plastics and basic design that received criticism.
Jeep-Patriot.name: First Generation (2007-2010)

Jeep-Patriot.description: The Patriot received minor interior and exterior upgrades for 2011. Front fog lamps were shrunken and relocated, grill redesigned, and 'Patriot' lettering on rear bumper was removed. Interior materials and styling improved significantly. Three trims offered: Sport, Latitude, and Limited. In Europe, four trims were offered including an Overland version. The 2.0L Volkswagen diesel was replaced by a 2.2L Mercedes-Benz diesel for European markets. Special editions included the 70th Anniversary Edition (2011), Altitude Edition (2012), and Freedom Edition (2013).
Jeep-Patriot.name: First Generation (2011 Facelift)

Jeep-Patriot.description: For the 2014 model year, Freedom Drive I Patriots received a Hyundai 6-speed automatic transmission replacing the CVT. Despite being essentially unchanged as it entered its 11th model year and still selling well, production ended in December 2016 with the remainder marketed as '2017' model year. The Patriot was replaced by the second-generation Jeep Compass alongside the first-generation Compass.
Jeep-Patriot.name: First Generation (2014-2017)

Jeep-Renegade.description: The Jeep Renegade is the brand's first subcompact SUV, developed as a global vehicle and built in Italy on the Small US Wide platform shared with the Fiat 500X. Despite its small dimensions, it features distinctive Jeep styling with a boxy profile, trapezoidal wheel arches, and the signature seven-slot grille. The X-shaped taillights are inspired by military jerry cans, while unique design elements like the 'X' motif headlights and optional My Sky removable roof panels reference Jeep heritage. Powertrain options vary by market but typically include small-displacement turbocharged engines, with North American models featuring a 1.4L or 2.4L four-cylinder engines paired with either a six-speed manual, dual-clutch automatic, or nine-speed automatic transmission. Available in front-wheel drive or with two different four-wheel drive systems, including Active Drive Low with a 20:1 crawl ratio on Trailhawk models that earn Jeep's 'Trail Rated' badge. The interior combines rugged Jeep design cues with modern technology, featuring numerous Easter eggs (hidden design elements) throughout the cabin. Advanced features include Uconnect infotainment systems with available navigation, plus driver assistance technologies like lane departure warning and forward collision warning. The Renegade has been sold in North American, European, Brazilian, South African, Australian, Japanese, and Chinese markets, built in Melfi (Italy), Goiana (Brazil), and Guangzhou (China).
Jeep-Renegade.name: First Generation

Jeep-Renegade.description: A significant facelift for the 2019 model year introduced revised front and rear bumpers, new LED headlamps inspired by the Wrangler, and a larger front grille. The infotainment system was upgraded with a more powerful processor and larger display (7" to 8.4"), now featuring Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. In North America, the 1.3L GSE Turbo Multiair replaced the 1.4L Fire Turbo as the base engine, while the 2.4L Tigershark remained available. European models received new FireFly engine family options including a 1.0L turbocharged three-cylinder and an updated 1.3L turbo four-cylinder, along with improved diesel engines meeting Euro6D-Temp standards with SCR systems. The 2022 update standardized the U Connect 4C 8.4-inch touchscreen with integrated navigation and SiriusXM services across all models. For the US market, the 2.4L engine was discontinued in 2022, and the Sport trim was dropped for 2023, making AWD standard across the lineup. The Renegade was discontinued in the US and Canada after the 2023 model year, continuing production in Europe and Latin America.
Jeep-Renegade.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Jeep-Renegade.description: Following the discontinuation of the Renegade in the US and Canadian markets after the 2023 model year, production continues in Europe (through at least 2025), Latin America, and other markets. The 2023 refresh for the Brazilian market introduced revised front-end styling and a 1.3L 'Turbo-Flex' engine option. The Renegade continues to offer the distinctive Jeep styling and capability in a subcompact package, built on the FCA Small Wide 4×4 platform. Available trim levels include Latitude (now the entry trim in markets where it continues), Altitude, Trailhawk, and Limited, with various four-wheel drive configurations including the Trail Rated Trailhawk variant with Active Drive Low system. The model remains an important entry point for the Jeep brand in global markets.
Jeep-Renegade.name: First Generation (Continued Production)

Jeep-Wagoneer.description: The original Jeep Wagoneer was a pioneering luxury SUV that remained in production with only evolutionary changes for nearly three decades. Designed by Brooks Stevens, it featured a blend of rugged capability and upscale appointments previously unseen in four-wheel drive vehicles. Built on a traditional body-on-frame platform with solid axles front and rear, it initially offered independent front suspension in some variants—unusual for its time. Powertrain options evolved significantly throughout its long production run, beginning with overhead-cam inline-six and V8 engines from Willys and later incorporating AMC's inline-six and V8 powerplants. The interior was notably luxurious for a utility vehicle of its era, especially in later Grand Wagoneer models with wood-grain exterior trim, leather seating, power accessories, and air conditioning. The model evolved from the initial Wagoneer to the Super Wagoneer and ultimately the Grand Wagoneer as it moved increasingly upmarket. A major distinguishing feature was its four-wheel drive system designed for all-weather capability rather than just off-road use—a revolutionary concept that anticipated the modern SUV. Production continued through AMC's acquisition by Chrysler, with the Grand Wagoneer's final years positioned as a premium offering in Jeep's lineup. This generation developed a cult following for its classic design, luxury features, and capability, becoming one of the longest-produced automotive designs in American history.
Jeep-Wagoneer.name: First Generation (SJ)

Jeep-Wagoneer.description: The second-generation Wagoneer is an upscale version of the unibody-based compact XJ Cherokee produced between 1983 and 1990. The compact XJ Wagoneer was available in two trim levels: the 'Wagoneer' and the 'Wagoneer Limited'. These vehicles were intended to replace the SJ-body Wagoneer models, but high demand prompted American Motors and Chrysler after 1987 to keep the original SJ-body Wagoneer in production. This generation represented a shift toward more car-like unibody construction and smaller dimensions while maintaining the Wagoneer name's luxury positioning. It competed in the emerging compact SUV segment against vehicles like the Chevrolet Blazer and Ford Bronco II while offering more upscale appointments than its Cherokee sibling.
Jeep-Wagoneer.name: Second Generation (XJ)

Jeep-Wagoneer.description: The Wagoneer nameplate was reintroduced for one year as the top-of-the-line model of the Jeep ZJ platform that debuted on the mid-size Grand Cherokee for the 1993 model year. Called the Grand Wagoneer, it featured a long list of standard equipment, including the Magnum 5.2 L V8 engine and unique leather interior as well as the Grand Wagoneer's traditional exterior woodgrain applique. After 6,378 were produced, the model was dropped for 1994, leaving the Grand Cherokee Limited as the top-of-the-line Jeep. This brief revival brought the iconic nameplate to the modern unibody Grand Cherokee platform before the name would disappear for nearly three decades until its 2021 revival.
Jeep-Wagoneer.name: Third Generation (ZJ)

Jeep-Wagoneer.description: After a 30-year hiatus, the Wagoneer nameplate returned as Jeep's full-size premium SUV offering, positioned above the Grand Cherokee in size and luxury. Built on a body-on-frame architecture shared with the Ram 1500 but with an independent rear suspension, it combines traditional SUV capability with modern refinement. Available in standard Wagoneer and more luxurious Grand Wagoneer variants, with both offering extended-length L models starting in 2023. The exterior design is more restrained than other Jeep models, notably without the signature seven-slot grille, as the Wagoneer is positioned as a distinct premium sub-brand. Powertrain options initially included a 5.7L V8 with eTorque mild-hybrid system in the Wagoneer and a 6.4L V8 in the Grand Wagoneer, both paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission. For the 2023 model year, Hurricane twin-turbocharged inline-six engines became available, offering improved efficiency with 420 HP in the Wagoneer and 510 HP in the Grand Wagoneer. The interior showcases unprecedented luxury for a Jeep product, with the Grand Wagoneer featuring up to seven digital screens totaling nearly 45 inches of display area, including a dedicated passenger screen. Materials include real wood, aluminum, and premium leather with quilted stitching.
