Advanced technology includes Uconnect 5 infotainment, available McIntosh audio systems with up to 23 speakers, and comprehensive driver assistance features. Despite its luxury focus, the Wagoneer maintains capability with three available four-wheel drive systems, Quadra-Lift air suspension, and up to 10,000 pounds of towing capacity. This generation reestablishes the Wagoneer as a premium American SUV, competing with established full-size luxury SUVs like the Cadillac Escalade and Lincoln Navigator while offering distinctive Jeep brand heritage.
Jeep-Wagoneer.name: Fourth Generation (WS)

Jeep-Wrangler.description: The original Wrangler replaced the CJ (Civilian Jeep) series, maintaining its predecessor's open-top, off-road focus but with improved on-road comfort and safety features. Distinguished by its rectangular headlights (controversial among purists), the YJ featured a wider track, lower ride height, and leaf springs on all four corners. Powertrain options included AMC's 2.5L four-cylinder and 4.2L inline-six engines, the latter replaced by a fuel-injected 4.0L version in 1991. Transmission choices included manual and automatic options, with part-time Command-Trac four-wheel drive standard. The interior was basic but more civilized than the CJ's, with improved seats, better instrumentation, and available features like air conditioning. Notable variants included the upscale Laredo, Islander with tropical-themed graphics, and Renegade with wider fender flares and distinctive styling elements. The YJ established the Wrangler nameplate while bridging the gap between the purely utilitarian CJs and more user-friendly later generations.
Jeep-Wrangler.name: First Generation (YJ)

Jeep-Wrangler.description: The TJ Wrangler marked a significant evolution, reintroducing round headlights and adding coil spring suspension on all four corners—a major improvement for both on and off-road ride quality. The exterior maintained classic Jeep design elements while offering improved weather protection with a more substantial soft top and an available hard top. Powertrain options continued with the 2.5L four-cylinder (later replaced by a 2.4L) and the venerable 4.0L inline-six. The interior featured improved ergonomics, better safety features including dual airbags, and more comfort options. In 2003, the Rubicon model was introduced with premium off-road equipment including Dana 44 axles, 4:1 low-range transfer case, air lockers, and 31-inch tires. The Unlimited model debuted in 2004, offering a longer wheelbase with additional cargo space but still in a two-door configuration. This generation significantly improved the Wrangler's daily usability while enhancing its legendary off-road capability.
Jeep-Wrangler.name: Second Generation (TJ)

Jeep-Wrangler.description: The JK represented the most substantial Wrangler redesign in decades, introducing the four-door Unlimited model that dramatically expanded its appeal to families and everyday users. Significantly wider than its predecessor, it featured a more modern interior with improved materials, better safety features, and enhanced creature comforts. Initially powered by a 3.8L V6 (replaced by the more efficient 3.6L Pentastar V6 in 2012), it offered improved on-road performance while maintaining off-road capability. Available with Command-Trac or Rock-Trac four-wheel drive systems and electronic locking differentials on Rubicon models. The modular top design allowed for various open-air configurations, maintaining the Wrangler's signature open-top experience. Throughout its long production run, numerous special editions were offered with unique styling and equipment packages. The JK's introduction of the four-door model proved transformative for the Wrangler, dramatically increasing sales and expanding its appeal beyond hardcore off-road enthusiasts to mainstream consumers seeking an adventurous image with practical versatility.
Jeep-Wrangler.name: Third Generation (JK)

Jeep-Wrangler.description: The current Wrangler maintains its iconic design and off-road capability while offering significant improvements in refinement, technology, and efficiency. Available in two-door and four-door Unlimited models, it features improved aerodynamics, weight reduction through aluminum doors, hood, and windshield frame, and a fold-down windshield that's easier to operate. Powertrain options expanded considerably, including a standard 3.6L Pentastar V6 (available with mild-hybrid eTorque system), a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder, a 3.0L EcoDiesel V6, and the 4xe plug-in hybrid combining a 2.0L turbo with electric motors for 375 HP and approximately 21 miles of electric range. The 6.4L V8-powered Rubicon 392 delivers 470 HP and 470 lb-ft of torque. The interior represents a major advancement with higher quality materials, improved ergonomics, and modern technology including available 8.4-inch Uconnect touchscreen, forward-facing off-road camera, and comprehensive driver assistance features. Off-road capability remains paramount with up to 11.1 inches of ground clearance, improved approach and departure angles, enhanced Dana axles, and electronic sway bar disconnect. The Rubicon model continues as the factory-optimized off-road variant. Despite these modernizations, the JL maintains traditional Wrangler elements including the removable doors, roof options (soft top, hard top, or power Sky One-Touch), and fold-down windshield—preserving the open-air experience that defines the model while offering unprecedented levels of comfort, technology, and powertrain efficiency.
Jeep-Wrangler.name: Fourth Generation (JL)

Jeep-Wrangler-4xe.description: The Jeep Wrangler 4xe represents the brand's first plug-in hybrid Wrangler variant, integrating electrification into its most iconic model. Based on the four-door Wrangler Unlimited body style, it's visually distinguished by Electric Blue accents on the tow hooks, badging, and hood decal. Powered by a sophisticated plug-in hybrid system combining a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder engine with two electric motors—one replacing the conventional alternator and another integrated into the eight-speed automatic transmission—producing a combined 375 HP and 470 lb-ft of torque, making it one of the most powerful Wrangler variants available. The 17 kWh battery pack is mounted under the rear seat, protected by a sealed enclosure that maintains the Wrangler's 30-inch water fording capability. With approximately 21 miles of all-electric range and an efficiency rating of 49 MPGe, it offers significantly improved fuel economy compared to conventional Wranglers while actually enhancing off-road capability through the instant torque delivery of the electric motors. Three selectable driving modes—Hybrid (default), Electric, and eSave—allow the driver to tailor the powertrain operation to specific conditions. Available exclusively in Sahara, Rubicon, and High Altitude trim levels, it maintains all the traditional Wrangler features including removable doors, removable top (hard top or soft top), and folding windshield. The Rubicon 4xe specifically maintains the same off-road equipment as the conventional Rubicon including 33-inch tires, electronic locking differentials, electronic disconnecting sway bar, and Rock-Trac 4x4 system with a 4:1 low-range gear ratio. As the best-selling plug-in hybrid in America since its introduction, the Wrangler 4xe demonstrates how electrification can complement rather than compromise the core attributes of Jeep's most capable vehicle, combining tradition with modern powertrain technology.
Jeep-Wrangler-4xe.name: First Generation (JL)

Jeep-Wrangler-JK.description: The Jeep Wrangler JK Phase 1 (2007-2011) represents the initial production run of the third-generation Wrangler, introducing significant advancements over the previous TJ generation. This iteration marked the first use of a 3.8L EGH V6 engine producing 202 horsepower and 237 lb-ft of torque, paired with either a six-speed Chrysler NSG370 manual or four-speed 42RLE automatic transmission. The JK introduced the four-door Wrangler Unlimited with a 20.6-inch wheelbase stretch, dramatically expanding practicality while maintaining authentic off-road capability. Built on an all-new platform with a wider track and increased dimensions, it featured body-on-frame construction with rigid live axles front and rear. Standard features included off-road tuned ABS, traction control, and electronic limited-slip differential, with Rubicon models receiving electronic sway bar disconnect. Trim levels included Sport (X), Sahara, and Rubicon, with the Rubicon offering Dana 44 axles, Tru-Lok locking differentials, and Rock-Trac transfer case with 4:1 low range. The Phase 1 models represent the foundational JK design before the significant 2011 interior refresh and 2012 powertrain upgrade.
Jeep-Wrangler-JK.name: First Generation (JK) - Phase 1

Jeep-Wrangler-JK.description: The Jeep Wrangler JK Phase 2 (2011-2012) represents the mid-cycle interior refresh while retaining the original 3.8L V6 powertrain. The 2011 model year brought a comprehensive interior redesign including a new steering wheel with integrated Bluetooth voice command, cruise control, and audio system controls. The Uconnect hands-free Bluetooth phone system with voice control became available, along with Garmin-based GPS navigation and SiriusXM Satellite Radio. Interior updates included new door skins, power window control switch panel, climate controls and vents, and improved seat fabrics with optional heated front seats and leather-trimmed seating for the first time. New aluminum-alloy wheel options were introduced, and both the automatic transmission shift lever and manual four-wheel-drive system shifter were redesigned. Despite these significant interior changes, the 3.8L V6 and four-speed automatic remained in place until the 2012 model year when the Pentastar engine arrived. The Phase 2 represents a transitional period between the original JK design and the more refined later models.
Jeep-Wrangler-JK.name: First Generation (JK) - Phase 2

Jeep-Wrangler-JK.description: The Jeep Wrangler JK Phase 3 (2012-2018) represents the most refined and capable version of the JK generation, featuring the upgraded 3.6L Pentastar VVT V6 engine producing 285 horsepower and 260 lb-ft of torque. This engine replaced the 3.8L V6 and was paired with either the six-speed NSG370 manual or five-speed Mercedes-Benz W5A580 automatic transmission, significantly improving both performance and fuel efficiency. The Phase 3 also included exterior updates such as the 2014 refresh with clear park lamps and turn signal indicators replacing amber units, along with six new body colors. Special editions during this period included the Arctic, Call of Duty: MW3, Moab, Overland, Rubicon X, Dragon, Polar, Freedom, Golden Eagle, and 75th Anniversary Edition. The interior continued to receive updates including the available UConnect 6.5-inch touchscreen radio with hard drive storage. Production continued alongside the new JL generation for part of 2018, with JK models distinguished by front fender badging. Production ended April 27, 2018, after twelve years of JK production, marking the conclusion of one of the most successful Wrangler generations in terms of sales and mainstream appeal.
Jeep-Wrangler-JK.name: First Generation (JK) - Phase 3

KTM-RC.description: The first generation KTM RC series introduced the Austrian manufacturer's fully-faired sport bike lineup, sharing mechanical components with the naked Duke series but wrapped in aerodynamic bodywork with distinctive split LED headlights and aggressive styling. The RC lineup typically included the RC 125, RC 200, RC 250, and RC 390 models, varying by displacement and market availability. All featured KTM's characteristic steel trellis frame, WP suspension components, and high-performance Brembo braking systems (ByBre on smaller models). The ergonomics favored a committed sport riding position with clip-on handlebars positioned below the triple clamp, rearset footpegs, and a seat designed to lock the rider in place during aggressive cornering. Despite their sport-focused design, the RC models maintained relatively comfortable ergonomics for their class. The flagship RC 390 featured a 373.2cc single-cylinder engine producing around 43 horsepower, making it one of the most powerful bikes in the small-displacement sport bike segment. Throughout this generation, the RC series received incremental updates including improved cooling, ride-by-wire throttle, slipper clutch, and updated emissions equipment to meet evolving regulations, but the fundamental design remained consistent.
KTM-RC.name: First Generation

KTM-RC.description: The second generation KTM RC series featured a comprehensive redesign with all-new bodywork, updated ergonomics, and technological improvements. The most noticeable change was the shift from the split headlight design to a single LED headlight housed in a larger, more aerodynamic front fairing inspired by KTM's RC16 MotoGP race bike. The new generation was designed to be more practical and accessible while maintaining the sporty character, with a more relaxed riding position, larger fuel tank, increased seat padding, and improved wind protection. Technical updates included a new LCD dashboard (with TFT display on premium models), adjustable lever positions, and increased service intervals. The chassis was revised with a new frame designed to offer better flex characteristics, lighter wheels that reduced unsprung weight, and updated suspension tuning for improved handling and ride quality. The RC 390 continued as the flagship model with features like cornering ABS, traction control, quickshifter, and multiple riding modes. Engine performance remained similar to the previous generation but with improved throttle response and refinement. The new generation represented KTM's effort to broaden the appeal of their sport bikes beyond track enthusiasts to include everyday riders, with improved comfort and practical features while maintaining the brand's focus on performance and handling.
KTM-RC.name: Second Generation

KTM-RC-390.description: The first generation KTM RC 390 established itself as a high-performance entry in the small-displacement sport bike category. Powered by a 373.2cc single-cylinder engine producing approximately 43 horsepower and 35 Nm of torque, it offered exceptional power-to-weight ratio thanks to its lightweight steel trellis frame and minimalist design. The distinctive styling featured split LED headlights, sharp angular bodywork, and a compact tail section. Premium components included WP suspension, Brembo braking systems (ByBre in some markets), and Metzeler tires. Initially offered with a conventional throttle, later models received ride-by-wire throttle control, slipper clutch, and ABS. The ergonomics were sporty with clip-on handlebars mounted below the triple clamp and rearset footpegs, though less extreme than larger supersport models. Despite its track-focused design, the RC 390 gained popularity as a versatile machine suitable for both track days and daily riding. Throughout this generation, KTM made incremental improvements to address cooling issues, emissions requirements, and overall refinement, but the fundamental design remained consistent. The first-generation RC 390 established KTM as a serious contender in the sport bike segment, offering near-middleweight performance in a lightweight, affordable package.
KTM-RC-390.name: First Generation

KTM-RC-390.description: The second generation KTM RC 390 represented a comprehensive redesign focused on improving both performance and practicality. The most visible change was the new bodywork featuring a single LED headlight in a larger, more aerodynamic fairing inspired by KTM's RC16 MotoGP race bike, replacing the previous split headlight design. The revised ergonomics offered a more comfortable riding position with a larger fuel tank (now 13.7 liters, up from 10 liters), improved seat padding, and better wind protection. Technically, the new RC 390 received a significant technology upgrade with a TFT color display, cornering ABS with supermoto mode, lean-angle sensitive traction control, and an optional bi-directional quickshifter. The chassis was updated with a new frame designed to offer better flex characteristics, lighter wheels that reduced unsprung weight by 3.4 kg, adjustable suspension components, and revised geometry for improved handling stability. While the 373.2cc single-cylinder engine maintained similar power output to the previous generation at 43 horsepower, refinements improved throttle response and overall rideability. The braking system was upgraded with a larger 320mm front disc. The second generation RC 390 successfully evolved KTM's sport bike formula to balance track-focused performance with increased comfort and technology for everyday riding, making it more versatile while maintaining its position as one of the most capable and engaging small-displacement sport bikes on the market.
KTM-RC-390.name: Second Generation

Kawasaki-W800.description: The original Kawasaki W800 was introduced as a direct successor to the W650, continuing the vintage-inspired styling that paid homage to Kawasaki's W series motorcycles from the 1960s. Featuring classic design elements including a teardrop fuel tank, peashooter exhaust, and abundant chrome details, it captured the essence of British motorcycles from the 1960s while incorporating modern engineering. Powered by an air-cooled, fuel-injected 773cc parallel-twin engine with a 360-degree crankshaft and shaft-driven camshaft, producing approximately 48 HP and 49 lb-ft of torque. The engine's undersquare design prioritized low-end torque over high-RPM power, delivering a relaxed, smooth riding experience. The five-speed transmission featured a traditional gear pattern, and the final drive used a chain. The chassis featured a double-cradle steel frame, conventional telescopic front fork, and twin shock absorbers at the rear—all contributing to the classic appearance and feel. Braking was provided by a single front disc with two-piston caliper and a rear drum brake, maintaining the vintage aesthetic. Available in standard and 'Special Edition' variants with different color schemes and trim details, the W800 established itself as a refined retro alternative to other modern classics like the Triumph Bonneville. This generation maintained production until 2016 when emissions regulations led to its temporary discontinuation in many markets.
Kawasaki-W800.name: First Generation (W800)

Kawasaki-W800.description: After a brief hiatus, the Kawasaki W800 returned with comprehensive updates to meet modern emissions standards while maintaining its classic appeal. Available in several variants including the Street (standard model), Cafe (with sportier styling including a small fairing and lower handlebars), and later the Classic with more traditional styling cues. The air-cooled 773cc parallel-twin engine was updated with emissions-compliant fuel injection while retaining its distinctive character, producing approximately 47 HP and 46 lb-ft of torque. The updated engine maintains the unique bevel-gear-driven camshaft—a rare feature in modern motorcycles that provides smooth, reliable valve actuation while adding visual distinction. The chassis was refined with a new, stiffer frame, updated suspension tuning, and improved brakes with ABS as standard—the rear drum replaced by a disc brake on most models. Modern features include LED lighting, an assist-and-slipper clutch for lighter lever action and smoother downshifts, and a more refined finish with improved paint and chrome quality. The revised instrument cluster combines an analog speedometer and tachometer with a small LCD screen for additional information. Despite these modernizations, the W800 maintains its distinctive character as a meticulously crafted throwback to classic motorcycling, offering genuine vintage appeal without the maintenance challenges of an actual classic bike. As modern motorcycles increasingly adopt aggressive styling and cutting-edge technology, the W800 stands apart with its commitment to traditional aesthetics, relaxed performance, and accessible riding experience.
Kawasaki-W800.name: Second Generation (W800 Street/Cafe/Classic)

Kia-Cadenza.description: The original Kia Cadenza (known as the K7 in South Korea) was introduced as Kia's full-size sedan, positioned above the Optima and below the flagship K900. Featuring conservative yet elegant styling developed under the direction of design chief Peter Schreyer, it represented Kia's upmarket aspirations. Built on a platform shared with the Hyundai Azera, it featured a front-wheel drive layout with a transverse-mounted engine. Powered primarily by a 3.3L V6 engine producing 293 HP in the North American market, paired with a six-speed automatic transmission. The interior offered near-luxury appointments including available leather seating, wood trim, dual-zone climate control, and a premium audio system. Technology features included available navigation, backup camera, and various driver assistance systems—advanced for a mainstream brand at the time. This generation established the Cadenza as Kia's premium sedan offering in most markets, demonstrating the brand's evolution from a budget-oriented manufacturer to one capable of producing refined, well-equipped vehicles competitive with established near-luxury models.
Kia-Cadenza.name: First Generation (VG)

Kia-Cadenza.description: The second-generation Cadenza featured more sophisticated styling with a more distinctive front end featuring Kia's 'tiger nose' grille interpretation and Z-shaped LED lighting signatures. Built on an updated platform with increased use of high-strength steel and structural adhesives, it offered improved rigidity, safety, and refinement. Powered by a revised 3.3L V6 engine producing 290 HP, paired with a new eight-speed automatic transmission—Kia's first in-house developed eight-speed. The interior represented a significant advancement with higher quality materials, more sophisticated design, and enhanced technology including an available 12-speaker Harman Kardon audio system, 8-inch touchscreen interface, and head-up display. Safety technology expanded to include adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, forward collision warning with automatic emergency braking, and blind-spot detection. Available in multiple trim levels including the luxury-oriented Limited with quilted Nappa leather seating and other premium features. This generation elevated the Cadenza's positioning as a sophisticated, technology-rich alternative to both mainstream and premium full-size sedans, winning numerous awards for its combination of refinement, features, and value. Despite critical acclaim, declining sedan sales in many markets led to modest commercial success, and the model was discontinued in the North American market after the 2020 model year, though it continues as the K7 in some international markets.
Kia-Cadenza.name: Second Generation (YG)

Kia-Carens.description: The original Kia Carens was a compact MPV designed primarily for the Asian and European markets. Featuring a tall, boxy design typical of small minivans of that era, it prioritized interior space and practicality. Available with seating for five or seven passengers, it utilized a space-efficient packaging approach. Powertrain options included small-displacement four-cylinder engines, typically 1.8L and 2.0L gasoline units, with manual or automatic transmissions. The interior was basic and functional, with a focus on durability rather than luxury. This generation established the Carens nameplate in Kia's global lineup, though it had limited presence in some markets like North America where it wasn't offered.
Kia-Carens.name: First Generation

Kia-Carens.description: The second-generation Carens featured more refined styling with a smoother, more aerodynamic profile. Built on an updated platform, it offered improved handling and ride comfort. Engine options expanded to include more efficient and powerful units, with diesel options becoming particularly important in European markets. The interior saw enhancements in material quality, design, and feature content, reflecting Kia's overall push toward better quality. Seating for seven became more widely available, though the third row remained best suited for children. This generation continued to develop the Carens as a practical family vehicle that prioritized value and functionality.
Kia-Carens.name: Second Generation

Kia-Carens.description: The third-generation Carens (marketed as the Rondo in North America) featured more car-like styling and driving dynamics. Designed under the direction of Peter Schreyer, it presented a more cohesive and attractive appearance than its predecessors. Engine options varied by market but typically included improved four-cylinder gasoline and diesel units with better efficiency and refinement. The interior offered a more upscale feel with better materials and design, plus additional features including available navigation and premium audio systems. Safety features expanded to include more airbags and electronic stability control. This generation broadened the Carens/Rondo's appeal by combining its traditional practicality with improved refinement and styling.
Kia-Carens.name: Third Generation

Kia-Carens.description: The fourth-generation Carens featured more sophisticated styling with Kia's 'tiger nose' grille and sleeker proportions, despite maintaining its compact MPV packaging. Built on a platform shared with the Ceed, it offered a good balance of interior space and manageable exterior dimensions. Engine options typically included efficient four-cylinder gasoline and diesel units, with manual or automatic transmissions depending on the market. The interior represented a significant step forward with higher quality materials, modern design, and enhanced technology including touchscreen infotainment systems with connectivity features. Safety technology advanced with available features like blind spot detection and lane departure warning. This generation elevated the Carens to a more refined family vehicle that competed on more than just practicality and value.
Kia-Carens.name: Fourth Generation

Kia-Carens.description: The current Carens (marketed as the Carens in some markets and as the KY in others) has been repositioned as a three-row crossover rather than a traditional MPV, reflecting changing consumer preferences. Built on Kia's mid-size platform but adapted for markets like India where it was introduced first, it features SUV-inspired styling with a bold front end, muscular proportions, and increased ground clearance. Engine options vary by market but typically include modern four-cylinder gasoline and diesel units, some with turbocharging for improved efficiency and performance. The interior represents a major advancement with more upscale design, higher quality materials, and advanced technology including a 10.25-inch touchscreen, digital instrument cluster, and comprehensive connectivity options. Safety has been emphasized with Kia's DriveWise suite of driver assistance features available on higher trims. This generation adapts the Carens concept for the crossover-dominated modern market while maintaining its focus on practicality, value, and family-friendly features.
Kia-Carens.name: Fifth Generation

Kia-Carnival.description: The original Kia Carnival (marketed as the Sedona in some markets) was Kia's first entry into the minivan segment. Featuring a conventional minivan design with sliding rear doors and three rows of seating, it prioritized spaciousness and practicality. Powertrain options typically included V6 engines, with the 2.5L and 3.5L units being the most common depending on the market. The interior offered good space for up to seven or eight passengers, though materials and build quality were basic by today's standards. While lacking the refinement of established competitors like the Honda Odyssey and Toyota Sienna, the first-generation Carnival/Sedona offered a compelling value proposition that helped establish Kia in the family vehicle segment.
Kia-Carnival.name: First Generation

Kia-Carnival.description: The second-generation Carnival featured significantly improved styling, quality, and refinement. Built on a new platform, it offered better driving dynamics and safety performance. Powertrain options evolved to include more powerful and efficient engines, typically 2.7L V6 gasoline or 2.9L four-cylinder diesel units depending on the market. The interior saw major improvements in design, material quality, and features, offering amenities like power sliding doors, rear entertainment systems, and more comfortable seating. Safety features expanded to include more airbags and active safety technologies. This generation elevated the Carnival/Sedona from a budget option to a more competitive minivan that could be compared more directly with established market leaders.
Kia-Carnival.name: Second Generation

Kia-Carnival.description: The third-generation Carnival represented another significant step forward in design, technology, and refinement. Styling became more sophisticated under the direction of Peter Schreyer, featuring a more dynamic appearance despite its minivan proportions. Built on an updated platform with increased use of high-strength steel, it offered improved structural rigidity and safety. Powertrain options typically included a 3.3L V6 in North America and various gasoline and diesel engines in other markets, paired with six-speed or eight-speed automatic transmissions. The interior offered a more premium experience with available features including leather seating, dual sunroofs, power sliding doors, power liftgate, and advanced infotainment systems. Safety technology advanced with available features like blind spot detection, rear cross-traffic alert, and smart cruise control. This generation established the Carnival/Sedona as a serious competitor in the minivan segment, offering a compelling combination of features, styling, and value.
Kia-Carnival.name: Third Generation

Kia-Carnival.description: The current Carnival has been reimagined as a 'Grand Utility Vehicle,' adopting more SUV-like styling cues while maintaining minivan practicality. The exterior features a bold, upright front end with integrated LED headlights, a floating roof design, and distinctive C-pillar garnish. Built on Kia's N3 platform shared with the Sorento and other mid-size vehicles, it offers improved rigidity, handling, and noise isolation. Powertrain options vary by market but typically include a 3.5L V6, 2.2L diesel, or 3.5L LPG engines, paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission. The interior represents a major advancement with a sophisticated, SUV-inspired design featuring available dual 12.3-inch displays forming a panoramic digital cockpit, premium materials, and VIP second-row lounge seats with ottomans in some trim levels. Modern technology includes advanced driver assistance systems, wireless smartphone integration, and multiple USB ports throughout the cabin. This generation attempts to overcome minivan stigma by combining the segment's inherent practicality with more desirable SUV styling cues and luxury features, appealing to families who want space and versatility without sacrificing style or modern technology.
Kia-Carnival.name: Fourth Generation

Kia-Ceed.description: The original Kia Ceed (spelled cee'd until 2018) was developed specifically for the European market as Kia's first serious competitor in the crucial C-segment. Designed at Kia's European design center in Frankfurt, Germany, and manufactured in Slovakia, it represented Kia's commitment to becoming a mainstream player in Europe. Available in three body styles: five-door hatchback, three-door hatchback (pro_cee'd), and station wagon (cee'd SW). Engine options included four engines (two petrol and two diesel), with three trim levels (LX, EX, TX). A facelift in September 2009 introduced Kia's distinctive 'tiger nose' grille. Approximately 646,300 units were produced. This generation established the Ceed as Kia's European cornerstone model, helping to transform the brand's image from a budget alternative to a legitimate competitor for mainstream brands like Volkswagen, Ford, and Opel/Vauxhall.
Kia-Ceed.name: First Generation (ED)

Kia-Ceed.description: The second-generation Ceed featured more sophisticated styling under the direction of Peter Schreyer, with the distinctive 'tiger nose' grille and more dynamic proportions. Making its worldwide premiere at the 2012 Geneva Motor Show, it was significantly more expensive than the first generation and moved the Ceed out of the 'budget' market. Available in the same three body styles as its predecessor, plus the addition of the Proceed GT as a performance-oriented variant (first hot hatch from Kia, released July 2013 for 3-door, January 2014 for 5-door). A facelift was shown in June 2015 and went on sale in September 2015. Approximately 647,700 units were produced. Engine options evolved to include more efficient and refined units, including new direct-injection gasoline engines and improved diesels. The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and technology.
Kia-Ceed.name: Second Generation (JD)

Kia-Ceed.description: The current Ceed (now with simplified spelling) was announced in February 2018 and revealed at the 2018 Geneva Motor Show. Production of the hatchback started in May 2018 with availability from June 2018. Features more mature styling with clean lines and sophisticated detailing under Peter Schreyer's direction. Available in various body styles including five-door hatchback, station wagon (Ceed SW), shooting brake (ProCeed launched early 2019), and crossover-inspired variant (XCeed unveiled September 2019). Built on Kia's new K2 platform, it offers improved driving dynamics, refinement, and safety. A 48-volt mild hybrid diesel engine variant (EcoDynamics+) was added for the entire lineup in 2020. The interior represents a major step forward with a more premium design, higher quality materials, and advanced technology including a 10.25-inch touchscreen infotainment system and comprehensive connectivity features. Safety technology has advanced significantly with Kia's DriveWise suite. This generation competes directly with established European models like the Volkswagen Golf on quality and features while maintaining Kia's value proposition and industry-leading 7-year warranty.
Kia-Ceed.name: Third Generation (CD)

Kia-Cerato.description: The original Kia Cerato (sold as the Spectra in North America and Forte in some other markets) was a compact sedan and hatchback designed to compete in the global C-segment. Featuring conservative styling typical of early 2000s Korean vehicles, it represented a step forward in Kia's design and quality compared to previous models. Available with various four-cylinder engines depending on the market, typically ranging from 1.5L to 2.0L, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. The interior offered good space and practicality for its class, though materials and build quality were basic by today's standards. This generation established the Cerato/Spectra/Forte as Kia's global compact car, though it still positioned primarily as a value alternative to established competitors like the Toyota Corolla and Honda Civic.
Kia-Cerato.name: First Generation (LD)

Kia-Cerato.description: The second-generation Cerato featured more dynamic styling under the direction of Peter Schreyer, showcasing Kia's evolving design language with the early version of the 'tiger nose' grille. Available in sedan and two-door coupe (Koup) body styles in most markets, with a five-door hatchback added later. Engine options evolved to include more efficient and powerful units, typically 1.6L and 2.0L four-cylinders with improved technology including direct injection in some variants. The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and features, offering amenities like Bluetooth connectivity, better audio systems, and improved safety equipment. This generation represented a major step forward in the model's refinement, quality, and market positioning, helping to transform Kia's image from a purely budget brand to a more mainstream competitor.
Kia-Cerato.name: Second Generation (TD)

Kia-Cerato.description: The third-generation Cerato featured more sophisticated styling with a sleeker profile and more distinctive interpretation of Kia's 'tiger nose' grille. Available in sedan, five-door hatchback, and two-door coupe body styles depending on the market. Built on an updated platform with increased use of high-strength steel, it offered improved structural rigidity, safety, and handling. Engine options typically included 1.6L and 2.0L four-cylinders with direct injection technology in higher trims, paired with six-speed manual or automatic transmissions. The interior offered a more premium feel with better materials, design, and technology, including available features like a touchscreen infotainment system, rearview camera, and advanced safety systems. This generation further established the Cerato/Forte as a serious competitor in the compact car segment, offering a compelling combination of style, features, and value.
Kia-Cerato.name: Third Generation (YD)

Kia-Cerato.description: The current Cerato features more mature styling with clean lines, a fastback-inspired profile in the sedan, and sophisticated detailing. Available primarily in sedan and five-door hatchback body styles, with the coupe variant discontinued in most markets. Built on Kia's K2 platform shared with the Ceed, it offers improved driving dynamics, refinement, and safety. Engine options vary by market but typically include efficient 1.5L, 1.6L, and 2.0L four-cylinder units, with performance-oriented GT models featuring a 1.6L turbocharged engine in some regions. Transmission options include manual, conventional automatic, and continuously variable transmissions depending on configuration. The interior represents a major step forward with a more premium design, higher quality materials, and advanced technology including an available 10.25-inch touchscreen infotainment system, digital instrument cluster, and comprehensive connectivity features. Safety technology has advanced significantly with Kia's DriveWise suite including features like autonomous emergency braking, lane keeping assist, and adaptive cruise control. This generation competes directly with established compact cars on quality and features while maintaining Kia's value proposition, positioning the Cerato/Forte as a mainstream rather than budget alternative in the highly competitive compact car segment.
Kia-Cerato.name: Fourth Generation (BD)

Kia-EV3.description: The Kia EV3 is a battery electric subcompact crossover SUV (B-segment) produced by Kia. It is the fourth model in the manufacturer's 'EV' line-up after the EV5. The production version was unveiled on May 23, 2024, with sales commencing in July 2024. The EV3 is built on the K3 platform with E-GMP 400V architecture and features Kia's 'Opposites United' design philosophy, 'Digital Tiger Face' front fascia, and 'Star Map' signature vertical lighting. The interior features three displays: a 12-inch instrument cluster, a 5-inch touchscreen for HVAC controls, and a 12-inch infotainment system. It was previewed by the EV3 Concept on October 12, 2023.
Kia-EV3.name: First Generation

Kia-EV6.description: The Kia EV6 is the brand's first dedicated electric vehicle built on the Electric Global Modular Platform (E-GMP) shared with the Hyundai IONIQ 5 and Genesis GV60. Featuring a distinctive 'Opposites United' design philosophy, it combines crossover-like ground clearance with a sleek, coupe-inspired roofline and dramatic surface treatments. The exterior incorporates aerodynamic elements including a low nose, active air flaps, and a rear spoiler, contributing to a drag coefficient of just 0.28. The unique lighting signature includes a sequential LED pattern at the front and a full-width light bar at the rear. Available with either a 58 kWh or 77.4 kWh battery pack, and in single-motor rear-wheel drive or dual-motor all-wheel drive configurations, power outputs range from 167 HP to 576 HP in the performance-oriented GT model. Range varies by configuration, with up to 310 miles possible in the most efficient variants. One of the EV6's most distinctive features is its 800V electrical architecture that enables ultra-fast DC charging, allowing a 10-80% charge in as little as 18 minutes at compatible charging stations. The interior features a minimalist approach with a curved display combining a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster and 12.3-inch infotainment touchscreen under a single piece of glass, augmented reality head-up display, and sustainable materials including fabrics made from recycled plastics. Advanced technology includes Vehicle-to-Load (V2L) functionality allowing the car to power external devices or even charge other EVs, remote smart parking assist, and Highway Driving Assist 2 with lane change capabilities. As Kia's flagship electric vehicle, the EV6 represents the company's shift toward electrification while establishing a new design language for its upcoming EVs, combining striking aesthetics with practical innovation and performance. The model has received critical acclaim, winning the 2022 European Car of the Year award and establishing Kia as a serious player in the premium electric vehicle market.
Kia-EV6.name: First Generation

Kia-EV9.description: The Kia EV9 is the brand's flagship electric SUV and the second model built on the dedicated Electric Global Modular Platform (E-GMP). Featuring bold, futuristic styling inspired by Kia's 'Opposites United' design philosophy, it combines the boxy proportions of a traditional three-row SUV with distinctive futuristic elements including the 'Digital Tiger Face' front end with vertical headlights, a flat aerodynamic roofline, and distinctive 'Star Map' LED daytime running lights. With a length of approximately 5 meters, it's similar in size to the Telluride but with a significantly longer wheelbase thanks to the dedicated EV platform, maximizing interior space. Powered by a 99.8 kWh battery pack, it's available in single-motor rear-wheel drive (201 HP) or dual-motor all-wheel drive configurations (379 HP in standard dual-motor, 516 HP in GT-Line), offering up to 304 miles of range in the most efficient variant. Like the EV6, it utilizes an 800V electrical architecture enabling ultra-fast DC charging, allowing a 10-80% charge in approximately 24 minutes at compatible charging stations. The interior features a spacious three-row layout with six or seven-seat configurations, including second-row captain's chairs that can swivel to face the third row in some variants. Technology highlights include a panoramic curved display combining a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, 12.3-inch infotainment touchscreen, and 5.3-inch climate control touchscreen under a single piece of glass, a head-up display with augmented reality navigation, and comprehensive driver assistance systems including Highway Driving Pilot with conditional hands-free capability in some markets. Additional innovations include Vehicle-to-Load (V2L) functionality allowing the car to power external devices, over-the-air updates, and a comprehensive suite of connected car services. As Kia's largest and most premium electric vehicle, the EV9 challenges established luxury SUVs while pioneering the nascent three-row electric SUV segment, establishing Kia as a technology and design leader in the rapidly evolving electric vehicle market.
Kia-EV9.name: First Generation

Kia-Forte.description: The original Kia Forte (sold as the Cerato in many international markets) was introduced as a replacement for the Spectra in North America, representing a significant step forward in design, quality, and market positioning. Developed under the direction of Peter Schreyer, it featured more dynamic styling with the emerging 'tiger nose' grille. Available in sedan, five-door hatchback (Forte5), and two-door coupe (Koup) body styles, it offered versatility for different buyer preferences. Powertrain options typically included 1.6L and 2.0L four-cylinder engines, with the latter offering a more powerful SX variant in some body styles. The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and features compared to the Spectra, offering amenities like Bluetooth connectivity, satellite radio, and improved safety equipment. This generation established the Forte as a more competitive entry in the compact car segment, helping to transform Kia's image from a purely budget brand to a more mainstream competitor.
Kia-Forte.name: First Generation (TD)

Kia-Forte.description: The second-generation Forte featured more sophisticated styling with a sleeker profile and more distinctive interpretation of Kia's 'tiger nose' grille. Continuing with sedan, hatchback, and coupe body styles, it offered broad appeal across different customer preferences. Built on an updated platform with increased use of high-strength steel, it offered improved structural rigidity, safety, and handling. Engine options typically included 1.8L and 2.0L four-cylinders with direct injection technology in higher trims, paired with six-speed manual or automatic transmissions. The performance-oriented SX models featured a 1.6L turbocharged engine in hatchback and coupe variants. The interior offered a more premium feel with better materials, design, and technology, including available features like a touchscreen infotainment system, cooled glove box, heated and ventilated seats, and advanced safety systems. This generation further established the Forte as a serious competitor in the compact car segment, offering a compelling combination of style, features, and value.
Kia-Forte.name: Second Generation (YD)

Kia-Forte.description: The third-generation Forte was unveiled on January 15, 2018, and features more mature styling with clean lines, a fastback-inspired profile in the sedan, and sophisticated detailing. Available primarily in sedan and five-door hatchback body styles, with the coupe variant discontinued. Built on Kia's platform shared with the Ceed, it offers improved driving dynamics, refinement, and safety. Engine options in North America include a standard 2.0L four-cylinder and a 1.6L turbocharged unit in the GT performance model, paired with manual, conventional automatic, continuously variable transmissions, and dual-clutch transmissions depending on configuration. The interior represents a major step forward with a more premium design, higher quality materials, and advanced technology including an available 10.25-inch touchscreen infotainment system, digital instrument cluster, and comprehensive connectivity features. Safety technology has advanced significantly with features like forward collision avoidance, lane keeping assist, and driver attention warning. A refresh for the 2021 model year (marketed as 2022 in some regions) updated the styling with revised front and rear fascias and enhanced technology features. Production ended in 2024 as the Forte was succeeded by the Kia K4, marking Kia's realignment of their passenger car nomenclature with the K3 name transferred to a subcompact car segment.
Kia-Forte.name: Third Generation (BD)

Kia-K4.description: The Kia K4 is a compact car introduced in March 2024 as a replacement for the Forte/K3/Cerato, with the K3 nameplate transferred to a subcompact car. It was fully introduced at the 2024 New York International Auto Show on March 27, 2024. The K4 adopts Kia's 'Opposites United' design language with vertical headlights and taillights featuring pronounced edges in the lighting signature and hidden rear door handles. The sedan features fastback styling with a thick D-pillar, while the hatchback offers a shooting brake design. Available as both a 4-door sedan and 5-door hatchback, the K4 measures 4,705mm in length with a 2,750mm wheelbase. Engine options include a 2.0-liter MPi petrol producing 147 HP and a 1.6-liter T-GDi turbocharged petrol producing 190 HP, both paired with a CVT transmission. The interior features the Connected Car Navigation Cockpit operating system with dual 12.3-inch screens under a single piece of glass, two rows of physical controls, and a T-bar gear selector. Standard features include Digital Key 2.0 with Ultra Wideband, Over-the-Air updates, wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, and a comprehensive suite of driver assistance systems. The 2025 model year K4 was awarded 'Top Safety Pick' by IIHS. Sales began in North America in August 2024, with 33,728 units sold in the U.S. in 2024.
Kia-K4.name: First Generation

Kia-K5.description: The vehicle that would eventually become the K5 was initially introduced as the Optima (or Magentis in some markets), representing Kia's first entry into the mid-size sedan segment. Based on a platform shared with the Hyundai Sonata, it featured conservative styling typical of early 2000s Korean vehicles. Available with four-cylinder and V6 engine options depending on the market, paired with automatic or manual transmissions. The interior was spacious but featured relatively basic materials and design. This generation established Kia in the mid-size sedan segment, though primarily as a value alternative to established competitors.
Kia-K5.name: First Generation (as Optima/Magentis, MS)

Kia-K5.description: The second-generation Optima featured more distinctive styling while remaining relatively conservative compared to later models. Built on an improved platform shared with the Hyundai Sonata, it offered better handling and refinement. Engine options typically included four-cylinder and V6 units with improved efficiency and performance. The interior saw enhancements in materials, design, and feature content, reflecting Kia's push for improved quality. This generation continued to position the Optima as a value-oriented mid-size sedan, with gradually improving reputation but still not challenging segment leaders in terms of design or desirability.
Kia-K5.name: Second Generation (as Optima/Magentis, MG)

Kia-K5.description: The third-generation Optima represented a revolutionary change in design and market positioning. Styled under the direction of Peter Schreyer, it featured bold, European-influenced design with a sleek, coupe-like roofline and distinctive details. Built on an all-new platform, it offered improved dynamics, refinement, and safety. Engine options in most markets included advanced four-cylinder units, with a turbocharged 2.0L offering V6-like performance with better efficiency, plus hybrid variants introduced later. The interior featured a driver-focused cockpit with premium materials and advanced technology for its time. This generation transformed the Optima's image from practical transportation to a stylish, desirable mid-size sedan that could compete with established market leaders on more than just price.
Kia-K5.name: Third Generation (as Optima, TF)

Kia-K5.description: The fourth-generation model (called K5 in South Korea and some other markets, while retaining the Optima name in others) evolved the bold styling of its predecessor with more refined execution. Built on an updated platform with increased use of high-strength steel, it offered improved structural rigidity, safety, and NVH characteristics. Engine options varied by market but typically included efficient and powerful four-cylinder units, including turbocharged options and hybrid/plug-in hybrid variants. The interior featured improved materials, design, and technology, with available features like a panoramic sunroof, ventilated seats, and advanced driver assistance systems. This generation maintained the model's position as a stylish alternative in the mid-size sedan segment, though market preference was increasingly shifting toward SUVs.
Kia-K5.name: Fourth Generation (as Optima/K5, JF)

Kia-K5.description: The current generation adopted the K5 name globally (except in China where it remains the Optima), featuring dramatic styling with a fastback silhouette, aggressive front fascia with 'tiger face' evolution, and distinctive Z-shaped running lights. Built on Kia's N3 platform, it's lower, wider, and longer than its predecessor with improved dynamics and refinement. Engine options include a 1.6L turbocharged four-cylinder producing 180 HP, a 2.0L naturally aspirated engine, and a more powerful 2.5L turbocharged unit in the GT model producing 286 HP, paired with eight-speed automatic or dual-clutch transmissions. All-wheel drive is available for the first time in some markets. The interior features a driver-focused horizontal layout with available 10.25-inch touchscreen, 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, and premium features like a panoramic sunroof and Bose audio system. Advanced technology includes wireless Apple CarPlay/Android Auto, Digital Key, and a comprehensive suite of driver assistance systems. Despite critical acclaim for its design, performance, and features, the K5 faces challenging market conditions as consumer preferences continue to shift toward SUVs and crossovers.
Kia-K5.name: Fifth Generation (as K5, DL3)

Kia-K5.description: The facelifted K5 was revealed in October 2023 for South Korea and at the 2024 Chicago Auto Show for the 2025 model year in North America. Changes include redesigned headlights and taillights, new front bumper with larger faux vents, new exhaust pipes for non-sportier trim levels, new exterior colors, and new alloy wheel designs. The interior receives an update with a pair of screens, the traditional gear lever replaced by a rotary selector, and new technological features. The facelifted K5 also has a new base engine, dropping the 1.6-liter turbo in favor of a naturally aspirated 2.5-liter four-cylinder making 191 horsepower and 181 lb-ft of torque.
Kia-K5.name: Fifth Generation (as K5, DL3 Facelift)

Kia-Niro.description: The original Kia Niro was introduced as the brand's first dedicated hybrid crossover, designed from the ground up to accommodate electrified powertrains. Featuring a subtle crossover design with conservative styling, it prioritized efficiency over rugged SUV aesthetics. Built on a platform shared with the Hyundai Ioniq, it was available with three powertrain options: hybrid (HEV), plug-in hybrid (PHEV), and fully electric (EV) variants added later. The hybrid combined a 1.6L GDI four-cylinder engine with an electric motor for a combined 139 HP, paired with a six-speed dual-clutch transmission rather than the CVT typical of many hybrids. The PHEV added a larger battery for approximately 26 miles of electric-only range, while the EV offered around 239 miles of range from its 64 kWh battery. The interior featured a straightforward design with a focus on practicality and technology, including available features like an 8-inch touchscreen, wireless phone charging, and advanced driver assistance systems. Despite its crossover positioning, the first-generation Niro was only available with front-wheel drive. This generation established the Niro as a practical, efficiency-focused vehicle that combined crossover utility with hybrid, plug-in hybrid, or electric efficiency—offering customers a choice of electrification levels in a similar package.
Kia-Niro.name: First Generation (DE)

Kia-Niro.description: The current Niro features dramatically more distinctive styling inspired by the 2019 HabaNiro concept, with a bold two-tone design incorporating a contrasting 'Aero Blade' C-pillar, angular 'heartbeat' LED daytime running lights, and a more assertive front end. Still offered in hybrid, plug-in hybrid, and fully electric variants, it maintains its position as Kia's multi-powertrain eco-focused crossover. The hybrid and PHEV continue with an updated version of the 1.6L GDI engine and six-speed dual-clutch transmission, with combined system outputs of 139 HP and 180 HP respectively. The PHEV now offers approximately 33 miles of electric range from its larger 11.1 kWh battery. The Niro EV features a 64.8 kWh battery with around 253 miles of range and 201 HP from its electric motor. The interior represents a major advancement with a curved display combining a 10.25-inch digital instrument cluster and 10.25-inch infotainment touchscreen, ambient lighting, and sustainable materials including recycled wallpaper headliner and seat upholstery made from eucalyptus leaves. New technology includes Vehicle-to-Load (V2L) functionality in the EV model allowing it to power external devices, and an expanded suite of driver assistance features. Slightly larger than its predecessor in all dimensions, it offers improved passenger and cargo space while maintaining its urban-friendly footprint. This generation elevates the Niro's design and technology while continuing to offer customers their choice of electrification level, making it a versatile option in Kia's increasingly electrified lineup.
Kia-Niro.name: Second Generation (SG2)

Kia-Niro-EV.description: The original Kia Niro EV (sold as the e-Niro in some markets) was the all-electric variant of the first-generation Niro crossover. Sharing its basic styling with the hybrid and plug-in hybrid versions but with distinctive blue accents, a closed grille, and unique wheels for improved aerodynamics. Powered by a 201 HP (150 kW) electric motor driving the front wheels, paired with either a 39.2 kWh battery offering approximately 153 miles of range or a larger 64 kWh battery providing up to 239 miles of range (EPA rated). DC fast charging allowed an 80% charge in about 54 minutes with a 100 kW charger. The interior was largely shared with other Niro variants but featured EV-specific displays, blue accent trim, and a shift-by-wire rotary gear selector in place of the traditional shift lever. Available features included an 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system (later upgraded to 10.25 inches), wireless phone charging, heated and ventilated seats, and a suite of advanced driver assistance systems. Despite its crossover styling, the Niro EV was only available with front-wheel drive. This generation established the Niro EV as a practical, relatively affordable electric vehicle that combined crossover utility with zero-emission driving, offering impressive range for its time without the polarizing styling of some dedicated electric vehicles.
Kia-Niro-EV.name: First Generation (DE)

Kia-Niro-EV.description: The current Niro EV features dramatically more distinctive styling inspired by the 2019 HabaNiro concept, with a bold two-tone design incorporating a contrasting 'Aero Blade' C-pillar, angular 'heartbeat' LED daytime running lights, and a more assertive front end. While maintaining similar dimensions to its predecessor, the new design gives it a more substantial presence. Powered by a refined electric powertrain with the same 201 HP (150 kW) output but paired with a slightly larger 64.8 kWh battery, it offers an EPA-estimated range of up to 253 miles. Charging capabilities include up to 85 kW DC fast charging, allowing a 10-80% charge in under 45 minutes. The interior represents a major advancement with a curved display combining a 10.25-inch digital instrument cluster and 10.25-inch infotainment touchscreen, ambient lighting, and sustainable materials including recycled wallpaper headliner and seat upholstery made from eucalyptus leaves. New technology includes Vehicle-to-Load (V2L) functionality allowing the car to power external devices up to 3.6 kW, wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, and an expanded suite of driver assistance features branded as DriveWise. Slightly larger than its predecessor, it offers improved passenger space and cargo capacity. The second-generation Niro EV balances practical electric mobility with more distinctive styling and advanced technology, positioned as a versatile, feature-rich electric crossover at a more accessible price point than Kia's dedicated electric vehicles like the EV6.
Kia-Niro-EV.name: Second Generation (SG2)

Kia-Optima.description: The original Kia Optima (sold as the Magentis in some markets) was Kia's first entry into the mid-size sedan segment. Based on a platform shared with the Hyundai Sonata, it featured conservative styling typical of early 2000s Korean vehicles. Available with 2.4L four-cylinder and 2.5L V6 engine options depending on the market, paired with automatic or manual transmissions. The interior was spacious but featured relatively basic materials and design, prioritizing value over refinement. This generation established Kia in the mid-size sedan segment, though primarily as a budget alternative to established competitors like the Toyota Camry and Honda Accord.
Kia-Optima.name: First Generation (MS)

Kia-Optima.description: The second-generation Optima featured more distinctive styling while remaining relatively conservative compared to later models. Built on an improved platform shared with the Hyundai Sonata, it offered better handling and refinement. Engine options typically included 2.4L four-cylinder and 2.7L V6 units with improved efficiency and performance. The interior saw enhancements in materials, design, and feature content, reflecting Kia's push for improved quality under the leadership of Hyundai Motor Group. This generation continued to position the Optima as a value-oriented mid-size sedan, with gradually improving reputation but still not challenging segment leaders in terms of design or desirability.
Kia-Optima.name: Second Generation (MG)

Kia-Optima.description: The third-generation Optima represented a revolutionary change in design and market positioning. Styled under the direction of Peter Schreyer, it featured bold, European-influenced design with a sleek, coupe-like roofline and distinctive details that set it apart from mainstream competitors. Built on an all-new platform, it offered improved dynamics, refinement, and safety. Engine options in most markets included a 2.4L four-cylinder and a turbocharged 2.0L four-cylinder offering V6-like performance with better efficiency, plus hybrid variants introduced later. The interior featured a driver-focused cockpit with premium materials and advanced technology for its time. This generation transformed the Optima's image from practical transportation to a stylish, desirable mid-size sedan that could compete with established market leaders on more than just price, winning numerous design awards and dramatically increasing Kia's market share in the segment.
Kia-Optima.name: Third Generation (TF)

Kia-Optima.description: The fourth-generation Optima evolved the bold styling of its predecessor with more refined execution and upscale details. Built on an updated platform with increased use of high-strength steel, it offered improved structural rigidity, safety, and NVH characteristics. Engine options varied by market but typically included 2.4L and 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder units, plus hybrid and plug-in hybrid variants. The interior featured improved materials, design, and technology, with available features like a panoramic sunroof, ventilated seats, and advanced driver assistance systems including adaptive cruise control and autonomous emergency braking. This generation maintained the Optima's position as a stylish alternative in the mid-size sedan segment, though market preference was increasingly shifting toward SUVs. In 2020, Kia rebranded the Optima as the K5 globally as part of a naming strategy shift, marking the end of the Optima nameplate after 20 years.
Kia-Optima.name: Fourth Generation (JF)

Kia-Optima.description: The fifth-generation K5, launched in 2019 with North American market introduction in 2021, represents Kia's complete redesign of the mid-size sedan under the new K5 nameplate. Built on the Hyundai-Kia N3 platform, it featured a bold, sophisticated design that moved away from the Optima's long-standing visual identity. Engine options typically included a 1.6L turbocharged four-cylinder as the base engine, with an optional 2.5L turbocharged four-cylinder producing 290 hp in performance models. The new platform provided improved handling, safety features, and technology integration. All-wheel drive became available for the first time in the K5's history. This generation marked Kia's strategic shift in its global naming convention, positioning the K5 as a distinct product in the sedan segment while SUV sales continued to dominate the market. Production is ongoing with the fifth generation continuing as the sole representation of Kia's mid-size sedan offering.
Kia-Optima.name: Fifth Generation (DL3)

Kia-Picanto.description: The original Kia Picanto (sold as the Morning in South Korea) was introduced as Kia's entry-level city car. Featuring a tall, boxy design typical of small cars from that era, it emphasized interior space efficiency and ease of urban use. Available primarily as a five-door hatchback, though a three-door variant was offered in some markets. Powertrain options included small-displacement petrol engines, typically 1.0L and 1.1L units, with modest power outputs focused on efficiency rather than performance. The interior was basic but practical, with a straightforward dashboard design and durable materials. This generation established the Picanto as Kia's smallest model globally, offering affordable transportation with surprising space efficiency and practicality for its tiny footprint.
Kia-Picanto.name: First Generation (SA)

Kia-Picanto.description: The second-generation Picanto featured more sophisticated styling under the direction of Peter Schreyer, with the brand's emerging 'tiger nose' grille and more dynamic proportions. Available in both three-door and five-door body styles, it offered more visual variety than its predecessor. Engine options remained small-displacement units, typically 1.0L and 1.2L petrol engines, but with improved efficiency and refinement. Some markets also received a bi-fuel LPG variant. The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and feature content, with available options including Bluetooth connectivity, a sunroof, and LED lighting. This generation elevated the Picanto from a basic transportation device to a more refined and desirable small car that could appeal to buyers who chose the segment for its merits rather than just budget constraints.
Kia-Picanto.name: Second Generation (TA)

Kia-Picanto.description: The current Picanto features more assertive styling with a sportier stance, more pronounced character lines, and a more confident interpretation of Kia's 'tiger nose' grille. Available primarily as a five-door hatchback, with the sportier GT-Line and X-Line variants offering unique styling elements. Built on a new platform with increased use of high-strength steel, it offers improved structural rigidity, safety, and refinement. Engine options remain small-displacement units, typically 1.0L (including a turbocharged option in some markets) and 1.2L petrol engines, with manual or automatic transmission options. The interior represents a major step forward with higher quality materials, more sophisticated design, and technology features uncommon in the A-segment, including an available 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. Safety features have been enhanced with the availability of autonomous emergency braking and other driver assistance systems—rare offerings in this segment. This generation maintains the Picanto's city-friendly dimensions while offering levels of refinement, technology, and safety that challenge larger vehicles, positioning it as a premium offering in the A-segment rather than merely an entry-level option.
Kia-Picanto.name: Third Generation (JA)

Kia-Rio.description: The original Kia Rio was introduced as Kia's entry-level subcompact car, replacing the Pride/Avella in many markets. Available as a four-door sedan and five-door wagon (Rio Cinco in North America), it featured simple, functional styling. Powered by small-displacement four-cylinder engines, typically 1.3L and 1.5L units depending on the market, with modest power outputs focused on economy. The interior was basic and straightforward, with durable materials and minimal features. This generation established the Rio nameplate in Kia's global lineup, positioned as an affordable alternative to established subcompacts like the Honda Civic and Toyota Corolla, though with more basic engineering and features.
Kia-Rio.name: First Generation (DC)

Kia-Rio.description: The second-generation Rio featured more refined styling and improved engineering, available as a four-door sedan and five-door hatchback. Built on a new platform shared with the Hyundai Accent, it offered better handling and ride quality compared to its predecessor. Engine options typically included 1.4L and 1.6L four-cylinders with improved efficiency and performance, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. The interior saw enhancements in design, material quality, and feature content, though still positioned as a value-oriented offering. Safety features expanded to include standard front and available side airbags in many markets. This generation elevated the Rio's position from purely budget transportation to a more competitive subcompact offering.
Kia-Rio.name: Second Generation (JB)

Kia-Rio.description: The third-generation Rio represented a significant leap forward in design, quality, and market positioning. Styled under the direction of Peter Schreyer, it featured more sophisticated, European-influenced design with the brand's signature 'tiger nose' grille. Available in four-door sedan and five-door hatchback body styles, it offered a more premium appearance than typical in the segment. Engine options evolved to include more efficient and refined units, typically 1.4L and 1.6L four-cylinders, with direct injection technology in some markets. The interior featured a more premium design with better materials and available features including a touchscreen infotainment system, rearview camera, and heated seats on higher trims. This generation successfully repositioned the Rio as a more stylish and feature-rich subcompact that could compete on more than just price.
Kia-Rio.name: Third Generation (UB)

Kia-Rio.description: The fourth-generation Rio debuted at the 2016 Paris Motor Show, featuring more mature styling with clean lines and sophisticated detailing under designer Peter Schreyer. Unlike previous generations, this model is export-only as it is not offered in the South Korean domestic market. Available as a four-door sedan and five-door hatchback, though European markets only receive the five-door hatchback. Built on Kia's global small-car platform (Hyundai-Kia GB) with increased use of high-strength steel, it offers improved structural rigidity, safety, and refinement. Engine options vary by market: the 1.6-liter Gamma GDi engine was standard in North America initially, replaced by the 1.6-liter Gamma II MPi from the 2020 model year for improved fuel economy. The interior offers a more premium feel with better materials, improved design, and enhanced technology including an available 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system with smartphone integration. Safety features have been significantly expanded, with advanced driver assistance systems like forward collision avoidance, lane keeping assist, and driver attention warning available. This generation won the 2017 Red Dot Award for Passenger Car Design and the 2017 iF Design Award for Discipline Product. A facelift in May 2020 introduced mild-hybrid technology (1.0-liter MHEV) to replace the previous 1.0-liter T-GDi engine, along with revised front bumper design. The facelifted model went on sale in Mexico in October 2020 and in the US/Canada in December 2020 for the 2021 model year. Production ended in December 2023, succeeded by the Kia K3.
Kia-Rio.name: Fourth Generation (YB/SC)

Kia-Rondo.description: The first-generation Kia Carens (RS series) debuted in May 1999, based on the same platform as the Kia Sephia. It was marketed as a compact MPV offering practical family transportation with a focus on space efficiency and value. Available in various configurations including five-seat and seven-seat options depending on the market, it featured a straightforward, functional interior with durable materials. Engine options typically included 1.8L and 2.0L four-cylinder engines paired with manual or automatic transmissions. A facelift was issued in 2002, updating the exterior styling and interior features. The model was discontinued in Australia in 2001, but production continued elsewhere until the updated 2002 model remained on sale through approximately 2005. In Malaysia, this generation was rebadged as the Naza Citra from January 2005 onwards. This generation established the Carens as Kia's entry into the compact MPV segment, competing with other value-oriented family vehicles in global markets.
Kia-Rondo.name: First Generation (RS/FJ)

Kia-Rondo.description: The second-generation Carens, known as the UN series, was launched in 2006 following Kia's introduction of the Multi-S concept at the Frankfurt Motor Show. In North America and Australia, the model was marketed as the Kia Rondo and Rondo7 respectively. The Rondo made its public debut at the 2006 Los Angeles International Auto Show, with North American sales beginning in December 2006 in Canada and early 2007 in the United States. Available as a five or optional seven-passenger vehicle, it was powered by either a 175 hp 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine or an optional 192 hp 2.7-liter V6 engine, paired with automatic transmissions. Standard features included sixteen-inch alloy wheels, AM/FM/CD player with Sirius Satellite Radio, iPod auxiliary jack, air conditioning, power windows and door locks, front/side/full-length side curtain airbags, four-wheel disc brakes, ABS, electronic stability control, and tire pressure monitoring. Options included a moonroof, leather interior, heated front seats, cruise control, keyless entry, and Infinity ten-speaker stereo. In the United States, sales exceeded 20,000 units in each of the first two model years but declined rapidly thereafter. Kia discontinued the Rondo in the United States after August 2010, though it continued in Canada with a 2011 facelift adopting Kia's new grille design.
Kia-Rondo.name: Second Generation (UN)

Kia-Rondo.description: The third-generation Carens (codename: RP) debuted in September 2012 at the Paris Motor Show, featuring more sophisticated, European-influenced styling under the direction of Peter Schreyer. Sales began in March 2013 in South Korea. The V6 engine from the previous generation was dropped, replaced with a 2.0-liter Nu four-cylinder GDI petrol engine or a 1.7-liter U2 four-cylinder diesel engine, both available with six-speed manual or automatic transmissions. In the UK, a 1.6-liter GDI petrol engine was also offered. The Carens was offered in five-seat or seven-seat configurations. In North America, this generation was only available in Canada due to slow sales in the United States, with Canadian sales ending after the 2017 model year. A minor facelift in September 2016 brought redesigned fascias, wheels, lights, and an enlarged 'Tiger Nose' grille. The diesel engine was retuned for improved output, and the automatic transmission was upgraded to a seven-speed dual-clutch unit. The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and technology, offering features like a touchscreen infotainment system and panoramic sunroof on higher trims.
Kia-Rondo.name: Third Generation (RP)

Kia-Rondo.description: The fourth-generation Carens (codename: KY) was revealed in India on December 16, 2021, representing a significant shift in the model's positioning and design. Based on a stretched Seltos/Hyundai Creta platform, it was developed primarily for emerging markets like India rather than traditional Western markets. Unlike previous generations' compact MPV configuration, this model is configured as a compact crossover with SUV-inspired styling, marketed by Kia as a 'recreational vehicle' (RV). Available in six-seater and seven-seater configurations, it emphasizes space for third-row seat occupants. Powertrain options shared with the Indian-made Seltos include a 1.5-liter naturally aspirated petrol engine (115 hp) with six-speed manual or CVT, a 1.4-liter turbocharged petrol engine (140 hp) with six-speed manual or seven-speed dual-clutch transmission, and a 1.5-liter diesel engine (115 hp) with six-speed manual or automatic transmission. The interior features a 10.25-inch touchscreen, digital instrument cluster, and comprehensive connectivity options. Safety features include six airbags, ABS, electronic stability control, hill-hold assist, and advanced driver assistance systems on higher trims. Although not sold in North America (where the Rondo name has been retired), this generation adapts the Carens concept for the crossover-dominated modern market while maintaining its focus on practicality, value, and family-friendly features. In 2025, Kia introduced the Carens Clavis premium variant with enhanced design, technology features including dual 12.25-inch displays, and Level 2 ADAS.
Kia-Rondo.name: Fourth Generation (KY)

Kia-Seltos.description: The first generation Kia Seltos debuted as a subcompact crossover SUV positioned between the smaller Stonic/Soul and the larger Sportage in Kia's global lineup. Launched on July 18, 2019 (South Korea) and August 22, 2019 (India), the Seltos was designated as a global product with three variations: SP2 (South Korean-built, aimed at developed markets including North America and Australasia), SP2i (Indian-built for emerging markets), and SP2c/China KX3. The SP2 model shared its platform with the Hyundai Kona and Kia Soul (Hyundai-Kia B-SUV platform), while SP2i/SP2c used the Hyundai-Kia K2 platform. Engine options included 1.6L Gamma turbocharged GDI, 2.0L Nu naturally aspirated MPI, and diesel 1.5L/1.6L CRDi variants, paired with CVT, 7-speed DCT, or 6-speed automatic transmissions. A significant facelift was introduced in July 2022 (South Korea) and July 2023 (India), featuring redesigned front clip, revised dashboard with dual 10.25-inch displays, and the new Kia badge. The Seltos established itself as a strong competitor in the subcompact SUV segment, becoming Kia's second best-selling model globally. Production ended in December 2025 when the second generation was introduced.
Kia-Seltos.name: First Generation (SP2)

Kia-Seltos.description: The second generation Kia Seltos (codename SP3) represents a complete redesign built on the new Hyundai-Kia K3 platform, shared with the third-generation Hyundai Kona (SX2). Unveiled simultaneously in Korea, India, Europe, and America on December 10, 2025, the new Seltos features more modern styling with updated tiger-nose design language and a comprehensive interior upgrade. Designed by Karim Habib, the vehicle maintains its subcompact crossover positioning while offering improved technology, efficiency, and driving dynamics compared to its predecessor. All-wheel drive remains available on higher trims. Production began in December 2025 in India ahead of the January 2, 2026 launch.
Kia-Seltos.name: Second Generation (SP3)

Kia-Sonet.description: The first generation Kia Sonet was introduced as a subcompact crossover SUV positioned below the Seltos in global markets.
