Featuring Kia's signature tiger-nose grille with 'heartbeat' LED daytime running lights and a distinctive rear light bar, the Sonet aimed to bring premium styling to the entry-level segment. Depending on the market, it offered multiple powertrain options including a 1.2L naturally aspirated engine, a 1.0L turbocharged gasoline engine, and a 1.5L diesel, with transmission choices spanning from 5-speed manual to 7-speed DCT and iMT (intelligent Manual Transmission). Despite its compact dimensions, the Sonet offered surprisingly premium features like ventilated seats, Bose premium audio, ambient lighting, and a 10.25-inch touchscreen with UVO connected car technology. Safety features included six airbags, ABS, ESC, and various driver assistance systems in higher trims. The first-generation Sonet established itself as a tech-laden, feature-rich option in the highly competitive entry-level crossover segment.
Kia-Sonet.name: First Generation

Kia-Sonet.description: The facelifted Kia Sonet was unveiled on December 14, 2023, featuring significant exterior and interior updates while maintaining its subcompact crossover positioning on the Hyundai-Kia K2 platform. The exterior received redesigned front and rear fascia with new headlights and taillights, giving the vehicle a more modern appearance. The interior was upgraded with a larger 10.25-inch touchscreen infotainment system, updated dashboard layout, and enhanced materials. Safety and technology features were expanded with additional driver assistance systems. Powertrain options remained largely similar to the pre-facelift model, including 1.0L T-GDi turbocharged, 1.2L MPi, and 1.5L CRDi diesel engines paired with various transmission options including manual, iMT, DCT, and IVT. The facelifted Sonet went on sale in India in January 2024, followed by other markets throughout the year.
Kia-Sonet.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Kia-Sorento.description: The first generation Kia Sorento was a traditional body-on-frame SUV, focusing on rugged off-road capability with four-wheel drive featuring low-range gearing. Powered primarily by a 3.5L V6 engine (later a 3.8L V6 in some markets) or a 2.5L diesel engine in others, it targeted buyers seeking a capable SUV at a value price point. The interior was basic but functional, with seating for five and limited luxury features. This generation established the Sorento nameplate in the midsize SUV segment, appealing to those who wanted genuine off-road capability and towing capacity without the premium price tag of established competitors.
Kia-Sorento.name: First Generation (BL)

Kia-Sorento.description: The second generation marked a significant shift for the Sorento, moving from a body-on-frame construction to a unibody platform shared with the Hyundai Santa Fe. This transition prioritized on-road comfort, fuel efficiency, and interior space over the previous generation's off-road focus. Available in both 5 and 7-seat configurations, it offered improved interior quality and technology features. Powertrain options included 2.4L and 3.5L gasoline engines in North America, with various diesel options in other markets. The second generation represented Kia's move toward more refined, family-oriented vehicles while maintaining a value proposition in the competitive midsize crossover segment.
Kia-Sorento.name: Second Generation (XM)

Kia-Sorento.description: The third generation Sorento continued the evolution toward a more premium crossover with significantly improved interior quality, technology integration, and driving dynamics. The exterior styling became more sophisticated, reflecting Kia's design renaissance under Peter Schreyer. Slightly larger than its predecessor, it offered more comfortable seating for up to seven passengers across three rows. Powertrain options included a 2.4L four-cylinder, 3.3L V6, and a 2.2L diesel in select markets, paired with six-speed automatic transmissions and available all-wheel drive. Technology features expanded to include larger touchscreen interfaces, advanced driver assistance systems, and premium audio options. This generation firmly established the Sorento as a competitive player in the midsize crossover segment, appealing to families seeking value alongside increasingly premium features.
Kia-Sorento.name: Third Generation (UM)

Kia-Sorento.description: The fourth generation Sorento represents a dramatic advancement in design, technology, and powertrain options. Built on Kia's new N3 platform, it features a more angular, bold exterior design with distinctive vertical taillights and a more prominent grille. The interior makes a substantial leap in quality and technology, featuring available dual 10.25-inch displays, quilted leather seating, and ambient lighting. Standard seating configuration accommodates six or seven passengers with improved third-row access. Powertrain options expanded significantly to include a 2.5L four-cylinder, 2.5L turbocharged four-cylinder, a 1.6L turbocharged hybrid producing 227 HP, and a plug-in hybrid variant offering approximately 30 miles of electric range. Advanced driver assistance systems come standard across most trims, including forward collision avoidance, adaptive cruise control, and lane-keeping assist. The X-Line trim offers increased ground clearance and improved all-wheel-drive capability for light off-road use. This generation positions the Sorento as a technology showcase for Kia, bridging the gap between the compact Sportage and full-size Telluride while offering the most diverse powertrain lineup in its class.
Kia-Sorento.name: Fourth Generation (MQ4)

Kia-Soul.description: The first generation Kia Soul debuted at the 2008 Paris Motor Show and is manufactured in South Korea. Designed at Kia's design center in California, the Soul featured iconic boxy styling that defined its character. Powered by either a 1.6L or 2.0L four-cylinder engine, it offered adequate urban performance with manual or automatic transmission options. The interior featured quirky design elements and surprising space efficiency. Special editions like Denim, Ignition, Dragon, and Ghost helped establish the Soul's fun, youthful brand identity. For 2012, the Soul received upgraded powertrains including a new 6-speed manual and automatic transmission, along with the new 2.0-liter Nu engine replacing the old Beta engine. This generation earned a Red Dot design award in 2009 and established the Soul as a style-focused alternative to conventional compact cars.
Kia-Soul.name: First Generation (AM)

Kia-Soul.description: The second generation Soul is based on Kia's Track'ster concept and offers an increase in torsional rigidity of 28.7% over the previous generation. The wheelbase increased to 2,570 mm, width to 1,800 mm, maintaining the same overall height. The redesign features a wraparound greenhouse, high-mounted tail lights, large trapezoidal lower air intake, and a 'floating' body color panel on the liftgate. Built on a new platform shared with the Kia cee'd, 66% of the chassis utilizes Ultra High Strength Steel or High Strength Steel. Early models included a choice of 1.6-liter Gamma GDi or 2.0-liter Nu GDi engines, mated to 6-speed manual or automatic transmissions. The Soul EV debuted as an all-electric variant with approximately 93 miles of range, offering a 27 kWh lithium-ion polymer battery pack.
Kia-Soul.name: Second Generation (PS)

Kia-Soul.description: For model year 2017, the Soul underwent a facelift with minor body trim changes, new paint colors, and updated headlight options. The most significant change was at the top trim level, where the 2.0-liter Nu engine was replaced by a 1.6-liter turbo gasoline engine producing 201 HP and 195 lb-ft of torque, paired with a 7-speed dual-clutch transmission. This powertrain change resulted in the car becoming one of the fastest in its class, with a 0-100 km/h time of approximately 7.8 seconds. The facelift maintained the distinctive boxy styling while refining details for a more modern appearance.
Kia-Soul.name: Second Generation (PS) Facelift

Kia-Soul.description: Kia unveiled the third generation Soul at the 2018 LA Auto Show. Unlike earlier models, it features thin headlights with a large grille remaining. Built on a new platform shared with the Hyundai Kona, it has a strengthened chassis for improved crash safety. Initial models in the US included two engine options: a turbocharged 1.6-liter engine producing 201 HP or a naturally aspirated 2.0-liter engine producing 147 HP, both with improved automatic transmissions. The Soul EV (e-Soul in some markets) returned with a 64-kWh battery pack offering significantly improved range. An X-Line trim became optional, providing a rugged appearance. This generation elevated the Soul's technology with available 10.25-inch touchscreen infotainment, advanced safety features, and improved interior quality.
Kia-Soul.name: Third Generation (SK3)

Kia-Soul.description: For the 2023 model year, Kia updated the Soul with revised headlights, taillights, front bumper, and rear fascia, along with new two-tone color combinations and updated wheel designs. The rugged-looking X-Line trim was discontinued with this facelift. In the US market, the turbo version was discontinued, making the 2.0-liter Nu MPi naturally aspirated engine with CVT transmission the only available powertrain. The electric model (Soul EV/e-Soul) was discontinued in late 2023. Advanced driver assistance systems became more widely available, including forward collision avoidance, lane keeping assist, and adaptive cruise control. Despite updates, production of the Kia Soul ended in October 2025 due to declining sales and competition from newer models like the Seltos.
Kia-Soul.name: Third Generation (SK3) Facelift

Kia-Sportage.description: The original Kia Sportage was a compact SUV built on a traditional body-on-frame platform, making it one of the smaller true off-road capable vehicles in its class. Available in both three-door and five-door configurations, it featured a boxy, utilitarian design. Power came from various four-cylinder engines depending on the market, including a 2.0L gasoline engine and diesel options in some regions. Four-wheel drive with low range was available, providing genuine off-road capability. The interior was basic and functional rather than luxurious. Though it lacked refinement compared to competitors, the first-generation Sportage established the nameplate and offered affordable utility and off-road ability in a compact package.
Kia-Sportage.name: First Generation (NB-7)

Kia-Sportage.description: The second generation Sportage marked a significant shift, moving to a unibody construction shared with the Hyundai Tucson. This transition prioritized on-road comfort, handling, and fuel efficiency over off-road capability. The exterior adopted a more contemporary crossover design, abandoning the boxy look of its predecessor. Engine options expanded to include a 2.7L V6 alongside four-cylinder offerings, with both front-wheel and all-wheel drive configurations available. The interior saw major improvements in design, quality, and features. Safety equipment was substantially upgraded, helping address concerns from the previous generation. This incarnation repositioned the Sportage as a modern compact crossover competing with vehicles like the Honda CR-V and Toyota RAV4, though it still struggled to match their refinement and brand reputation.
Kia-Sportage.name: Second Generation (JE/KM)

Kia-Sportage.description: The third generation Sportage featured dramatically improved styling under the direction of design chief Peter Schreyer, with a distinctive tiger-nose grille and sleek, European-influenced design that helped differentiate it in the competitive compact crossover segment. Built on an improved platform shared with the Hyundai Tucson, it offered better driving dynamics and interior space utilization. Powertrain options included a base 2.4L four-cylinder and a more powerful 2.0L turbocharged engine in the SX trim, producing 260 horsepower. The interior quality took a significant step forward with better materials, improved ergonomics, and more technology features including available navigation and premium audio systems. This generation helped establish the Sportage as a style-focused alternative in its segment, appealing to buyers who wanted distinctive design alongside practical utility.
Kia-Sportage.name: Third Generation (SL)

Kia-Sportage.description: The fourth generation Sportage continued the bold styling direction with an even more distinctive front end featuring high-mounted headlights and a larger grille. The interior saw significant improvements in material quality, technology integration, and noise isolation. Slightly larger than its predecessor, it offered more passenger and cargo space. Powertrain options remained similar to the previous generation in most markets, with 2.4L naturally aspirated and 2.0L turbocharged engines in North America, alongside various diesel options in other regions. Technology features expanded considerably to include larger touchscreens, advanced driver assistance systems, and improved connectivity. Handling and ride quality were refined, making this generation more competitive with segment leaders. The fourth generation Sportage achieved stronger sales globally, particularly in European markets where its styling and feature set helped it stand out in the crowded compact crossover segment.
Kia-Sportage.name: Fourth Generation (QL)

Kia-Sportage.description: The fifth generation Sportage represents the most dramatic redesign in the model's history, with a bold, futuristic exterior featuring boomerang-shaped LED daytime running lights, a wide tiger-nose grille, and distinct angular lines throughout. For the first time, Kia offers market-specific versions with different dimensions, with the North American model being notably larger than its European counterpart. The interior takes a massive leap forward with a curved display panel housing dual 12.3-inch screens, touch-sensitive climate controls, and premium materials throughout. Powertrain options expanded significantly to include a 2.5L four-cylinder base engine, hybrid and plug-in hybrid variants combining a 1.6L turbocharged engine with electric motors, and a range of diesel options in global markets. The X-Pro trim targets outdoor enthusiasts with all-terrain tires, enhanced all-wheel drive modes, and rugged styling elements. Advanced driver assistance systems come standard, including forward collision avoidance, lane keeping assist, and highway driving assist. This generation positions the Sportage as a technology showcase competing with premium compact crossovers while maintaining Kia's value proposition.
Kia-Sportage.name: Fifth Generation (NQ5)

Kia-Sportage-HEV.description:
The Kia Sportage Hybrid (HEV) was introduced as part of the fifth-generation Sportage lineup, marking Kia's first hybrid offering in this popular compact crossover segment. Powered by a 1.6-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine paired with an electric motor and a 1.49 kWh battery pack, the system produces a combined 227 horsepower and 258 lb-ft of torque. This powertrain is coupled with a six-speed automatic transmission rather than the CVT often used in hybrid vehicles, delivering a more conventional driving experience. Available in both front-wheel and all-wheel drive configurations, the Sportage Hybrid achieves impressive fuel economy ratings of up to 43 mpg city for the FWD version. The HEV model features the same bold exterior design as the standard fifth-generation Sportage, with its distinctive boomerang-shaped LED daytime running lights and tiger-nose grille, while sharing the high-tech interior that includes dual 12.3-inch screens in higher trims.

The Sportage Hybrid was launched for different markets at different times: North America received it as a 2023 model in October 2021, while Australia and New Zealand added Hybrid variants in early 2024. Despite being a hybrid-only model, it shares the same NQ5 platform as conventional Sportage variants with both short-wheelbase (European/Asian markets) and long-wheelbase (North American market) configurations.

A mid-cycle facelift was introduced in November 2024 for the 2026 model year, featuring an updated front fascia with new headlights replacing the boomerang design, revised front bumper, new LED taillight graphics, new exterior colors and alloy wheel designs. Interior updates include a new 2-spoke steering wheel, updated curved digital cockpit housing the digital instrument cluster and 12.3-inch touchscreen, new air-con vents and additional interior features. Mechanical changes include an improved dampening system on the front axle, additional sound-absorbing materials, and the 7-speed dual-clutch automatic used for the 1.6 T-GDi engine was replaced with an 8-speed automatic. The Sportage Hybrid offers slightly improved acceleration compared to the standard model while maintaining all of its practicality, including generous passenger space and cargo capacity. As Kia's approach to electrification, the Sportage HEV bridges the gap between conventional internal combustion engines and fully electric vehicles, providing an efficient option for buyers not yet ready to commit to plug-in technology.
Kia-Sportage-HEV.name: First Generation (NQ5)

Kia-Stinger.description: The pre-facelift first generation Kia Stinger (2018-2020 model years) introduced Kia's entry into the sports sedan market, featuring a rear-wheel drive platform developed under former BMW M executive Albert Biermann. The fastback liftback design was a departure for Kia, competing directly with established luxury performance sedans. Available engines included the 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder Theta II producing 255 hp and 260 lb-ft of torque, and the 3.3-liter twin-turbocharged V6 Lambda II generating 365 hp and 376 lb-ft of torque. Both engines were paired exclusively with an eight-speed automatic transmission, with rear-wheel drive standard and all-wheel drive optional. The V6 model accelerated from 0-60 mph in approximately 4.6 seconds. Interior features included a driver-focused cockpit with a 7-inch infotainment screen, leather upholstery options, and available Harman Kardon audio system. The pre-facelift model was sold from 2018 to 2020 before receiving significant updates for the 2021 model year.
Kia-Stinger.name: First Generation (CK) Pre-Facelift

Kia-Stinger.description: The facelifted Kia Stinger (2021-2023 model years) retained the same platform and overall design but received significant visual and mechanical updates. Exterior changes included revised headlights and taillights, with the rear gaining a full-width LED light bar. The interior upgraded to a new 10.25-inch infotainment screen and featured the new Kia logo for 2021 models. A new optional engine was added: the 2.5-liter Smartstream turbocharged four-cylinder producing 300 hp and 311 lb-ft of torque. The 3.3-liter V6 received a power increase to 368 hp while maintaining the same 376 lb-ft of torque. A variable exhaust system became available. The Stinger Tribute Edition was released in December 2022 to mark the end of production, limited to 1,000 units worldwide with exclusive Moonscape Gray matte color and terracotta brown leather interior. Production ended in April 2023 after successfully establishing Kia as a capable manufacturer of premium performance vehicles.
Kia-Stinger.name: First Generation (CK) Facelift

Kia-Stonic.description: The first generation Kia Stonic was introduced as the brand's entry into the rapidly growing subcompact crossover segment. Built on the same platform as the Rio hatchback, the Stonic featured distinctive styling with a two-tone roof option, bold color choices, and angular design elements. The interior offered a straightforward layout with a 7-inch touchscreen featuring Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. Powertrain options varied by market but typically included small displacement engines such as a 1.0L turbocharged three-cylinder, 1.2L and 1.4L naturally aspirated four-cylinders, and a 1.6L diesel in some regions. Most models were front-wheel drive only, positioning the Stonic as an urban crossover rather than an off-road capable SUV. Despite its compact dimensions, the Stonic offered relatively practical interior space and cargo capacity for its class. Safety features included available autonomous emergency braking, lane departure warning, and driver attention warning, though specifications varied significantly by market.
Kia-Stonic.name: First Generation

Kia-Stonic.description: The refreshed Kia Stonic received design updates including revised LED headlights, updated wheel designs, and new exterior color options while maintaining its overall styling theme with the distinctive two-tone roof option. Interior improvements focused on technology, with an upgraded 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system, enhanced UVO Connect telematics, and a digital instrument display on higher trim levels. The powertrain lineup was updated to include a 48-volt mild-hybrid system paired with the 1.0L turbocharged engine in some markets, improving fuel efficiency and reducing emissions. Additional driver assistance features were added, including adaptive cruise control, blind-spot monitoring, and an improved version of the lane-keeping assist system. The refreshed model continued to target urban drivers looking for style, technology, and maneuverability in a compact package. Despite increased competition in the segment, the Stonic maintained its position through its combination of distinctive styling, improved technology, and Kia's increasingly strong brand reputation for value and reliability.
Kia-Stonic.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Kia-Stonic.description: The second facelift of the Kia Stonic was unveiled on September 1, 2025. The exterior features a redesigned front and rear fascia, updated headlights and taillights, and new alloy wheel designs, following Kia's 'Opposites United' design language. The interior receives a significant technology upgrade with a new 12.3-inch touchscreen infotainment system and a redesigned steering wheel. The powertrain continues to offer mild hybrid technology, with improvements to both the gasoline and diesel options. The 2026 model year Stonic represents a comprehensive update that keeps the subcompact crossover competitive in an increasingly crowded segment while maintaining its position as Kia's entry-level SUV offering.
Kia-Stonic.name: First Generation (Second Facelift)

Kia-Telluride.description: The first-generation Kia Telluride launched as the brand's flagship three-row midsize SUV, making a strong impression with its bold, boxy design and upscale appearance. Powered by a 3.8L naturally aspirated V6 engine producing 291 horsepower and 262 lb-ft of torque, paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission and available active on-demand all-wheel drive. The spacious interior accommodated up to eight passengers across three rows, with notable features including available premium Nappa leather, 10.25-inch touchscreen infotainment system, Harman Kardon audio, and heated/ventilated first and second-row seats. The Telluride offered comprehensive safety technology including standard forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, lane-keeping assist, and available blind-spot monitoring. Despite being Kia's first entry into the highly competitive three-row midsize SUV segment, the Telluride quickly became a sales success and earned numerous industry awards including the prestigious 2020 World Car of the Year and North American SUV of the Year. The first-generation Telluride established a reputation for offering near-luxury features and design at mainstream pricing, setting a new standard for the brand and segment.
Kia-Telluride.name: First Generation

Kia-Telluride.description: The refreshed Kia Telluride received substantial updates while maintaining the successful formula of the original model. Exterior changes included a revised front fascia with updated vertical headlights, new grille design, and reshaped bumpers. The interior saw significant technology upgrades with dual 12.3-inch displays forming a panoramic integrated display, updated center console design, and new available features such as a digital rearview mirror and 360-degree surround view monitor with 3D view. New X-Line and X-Pro trim levels were added, with the X-Line offering appearance upgrades including unique 20-inch wheels and roof rails, while the X-Pro added all-terrain tires, increased towing capacity to 5,500 pounds, and additional off-road-focused features. The powertrain remained the same trusted 3.8L V6 with an eight-speed automatic transmission. Advanced driver assistance systems were expanded to include standard forward collision avoidance with junction turning capability, navigation-based adaptive cruise control, and highway driving assist 2 with semi-autonomous lane change capability on higher trims. The refreshed Telluride built upon the original's success with enhanced technology and capability while maintaining its position as a value leader in the three-row SUV segment.
Kia-Telluride.name: Second Generation (Facelift)

Lamborghini-Huracan-evo.description: The Lamborghini Huracán Evo represents a significant mid-cycle enhancement of the original Huracán platform launched in 2014. Introduced in 2019, the Evo incorporated the more powerful 5.2-liter naturally aspirated V10 engine from the Performante variant, producing 640 horsepower and 443 lb-ft of torque, enabling 0-62 mph acceleration in just 2.9 seconds. The most significant advancement was the introduction of the Lamborghini Dinamica Veicolo Integrata (LDVI) system, a central processing unit that coordinates all aspects of the car's dynamic behavior, including all-wheel drive, all-wheel steering, torque vectoring, and stability control systems to predictively enhance performance. Exterior revisions included a new front bumper with integrated aeroblades, revised side air intakes, a redesigned rear with an integrated ducktail spoiler and prominent twin exhaust outlets positioned higher in the fascia. The interior received a new 8.4-inch touchscreen infotainment system with gesture control, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, and real-time telemetry display. The Evo was offered in both standard all-wheel drive configuration and a rear-wheel drive variant introduced in 2020 (Evo RWD), the latter providing a more purist driving experience with 610 horsepower. In 2021, the Huracán STO (Super Trofeo Omologata) joined the lineup as a road-legal track-focused variant with extensive weight reduction, aerodynamic enhancements generating 53% more downforce than the Performante, and revised suspension and braking systems. The Tecnica variant followed in 2022, positioned between the Evo RWD and STO, combining the STO's powertrain with a more road-focused setup. The Sterrato variant launched in 2023 as an all-terrain variant with increased ground clearance, widened track, and specialized off-road tires. The Huracán was succeeded by the Lamborghini Temerario in 2024.
Lamborghini-Huracan-evo.name: First Generation

Land-Rover-Defender.description: The coil-sprung Land Rover was introduced in 1983 as the Land Rover One Ten, with the Land Rover Ninety following in 1984. These models marked a significant departure from the Series III Land Rover, featuring coil spring suspension front and rear (replacing leaf springs), permanent four-wheel drive derived from the Range Rover with a two-speed transfer gearbox and lockable centre differential, and a modernized interior. The numbers 90 and 110 referred to their wheelbase lengths in inches, despite the Ninety actually having a 92.9-inch wheelbase. The One Two Seven with a 127-inch wheelbase joined in 1985 for heavier load capacity. Both models featured a separate steel ladder chassis with aluminum alloy bodywork, maintaining the rugged utility capability while offering improved ride quality and axle articulation. Engine options evolved from the Series III petrol and diesel engines to include a 2.5-litre turbo diesel (1984), enlarged 2.5-litre petrol engines (1985), and the V8 petrol engine in the Ninety for the first time. Production of these models continued until 1990 when they were renamed Defender 90, Defender 110, and Defender 130 respectively.
Land-Rover-Defender.name: Land Rover Ninety and One Ten

Land-Rover-Defender.description: In 1990, following the introduction of the Discovery, Land Rover renamed the Ninety and One Ten as Defender 90 and Defender 110, with the One Two Seven becoming Defender 130. The Defender name distinguished these utilitarian models from the more comfort-oriented Discovery within the Land Rover family. Designated as L315 from model year 1987 to 2006, this generation maintained the fundamental architecture of its predecessors while evolving continuously. The 200Tdi engine was introduced in 1990, featuring an alloy cylinder head, improved turbocharging, intercooling and direct injection, producing 111bhp and significantly improving high-speed cruising capability. This was followed by the 300Tdi in 1994, a virtually new engine despite the same capacity. In 1998, Land Rover introduced the Td5, an all-new 2.5-litre five-cylinder turbodiesel with electronic control systems producing 122bhp and improved refinement, though traditionalists criticized the increased electronic systems. The Defender retained its utilitarian design philosophy with removable doors and roof panels, fold-down windscreen, exposed door hinges, and robust mechanicals designed for field serviceability. The lineup included Defender 90 (short wheelbase), Defender 110 (long wheelbase), and Defender 130 (crew cab pickup). Special editions included the 90SV (1992), Limited Edition (1997), 50th Anniversary (1998), Heritage (1998), and Tomb Raider (2000).
Land-Rover-Defender.name: First Generation Defender (L315)

Land-Rover-Defender.description: From spring 2007, the Defender was designated L316 and received major updates to meet emissions and safety legislation. The Td5 engine was replaced by a Ford DuraTorq 2.4-litre four-cylinder diesel engine (later 2.2-litre) from the Ford Transit, producing the same power but with improved torque from a variable-geometry turbocharger. A new six-speed gearbox replaced the previous transmission. The interior was completely redesigned with a full-width fascia, instruments from the Discovery 3, and improved heating and ventilation systems. Many heritage parts dating back to the 1970s were finally replaced, though some like the Metro-sourced steering column switches and Morris Marina ignition switch were carried over. European Union legislation required the removal of inward-facing rear seats, reducing capacity from six/seven to four/five in the 90 and from nine to seven in the 110. A new bodystyle 'utility' was introduced on the 110 chassis with windowless rear panels. External changes were minimal: a reshaped bonnet for the taller engine and removal of the distinctive external air vent flaps. Minor updates in 2012 introduced the 2.2-litre engine to meet Euro V standards with a diesel particulate filter. The last Defender rolled off the Solihull production line on 29 January 2016, with the number plate H166 HUE referencing the first pre-production Land Rover. A special Defender Works V8 edition was announced in January 2018 with a 5.0-litre Jaguar V8 engine producing 405hp.
Land-Rover-Defender.name: First Generation Defender (L316)

Land-Rover-Defender.description: The all-new Land Rover Defender launched in 2020 represented a complete reimagining of the iconic nameplate, built on JLR's Premium Transverse Architecture (PTA) platform. This generation switched from body-on-chassis construction to an aluminum monocoque body and from live rigid axles to all-independent suspension, while maintaining the distinctive boxy silhouette and utilitarian design cues of its predecessor. The L663 Defender was unveiled on 10 September 2019 at the Frankfurt Motor Show and is engineered to comply with global car regulations, sold in 128 territories including China and the United States. Initially available in '90' three-door and '110' five-door configurations, an eight-seater version of the 110 named the '130' was introduced in 2022. The powertrain range includes mild-hybrid inline-four and inline-six engines: the P300 (2.0L turbo four-cylinder producing 296hp), P400 (3.0L turbo inline-six producing 355hp), and the range-topping P525 supercharged 5.0L V8 in the Defender V8 variant producing 518hp. All variants feature permanent all-wheel drive through an eight-speed automatic transmission and two-speed transfer case. The advanced Terrain Response 2 system offers multiple driving modes optimized for different surfaces and conditions. Modern features include configurable digital displays, smartphone integration, over-the-air updates, and advanced driver assistance systems, while maintaining practical elements like removable roof panels, fold-flat rear seating, and substantial towing capacity up to 3,720 kg (8,201 pounds).
Land-Rover-Defender.name: Second Generation (L663)

Land-Rover-Range-Rover.description: The original Range Rover, known as the 'Range Rover Classic'. Produced from 1970 to 1996, it was available initially as a 2-door until 1981 when the 4-door model was introduced. Featured body-on-frame design with coil springs, permanent four-wheel drive, and four-wheel disc brakes. Originally powered by various Rover V8 engines and diesel engines. The classic served as the basis for the Discovery and the second-generation Range Rover.
Land-Rover-Range-Rover.name: First Generation (Classic)

Land-Rover-Range-Rover.description: The second-generation Range Rover, model designation P38A, introduced for the 1996 model year. Based on the LWB chassis of the Classic with an updated Rover V8 engine or a 2.5-litre BMW six-cylinder turbo-diesel with Bosch injection pump - the first diesel with electronic controls in a Land Rover. This was a result of BMW's ownership of Rover Group. Last model to use the Rover V8 and interior leather supplied by Connolly.
Land-Rover-Range-Rover.name: Second Generation (P38A)

Land-Rover-Range-Rover.description: The third-generation Range Rover, model designation L322, introduced in 2001. Saw the model move further upmarket with shared components and systems from BMW 7 Series (E38) and later BMW 5 Series (E39). Three distinct periods within this generation: 2001-2005 with BMW V8, 2006-2009 with Jaguar-derived engines, and 2010-2012 with the new AJ133 5.0L engine. Received facelifts in 2006 (front fascia, lighting) and 2010 (new fascia, tail lamps, new engines).
Land-Rover-Range-Rover.name: Third Generation (L322)

Land-Rover-Range-Rover.description: The fourth-generation Range Rover, codenamed L405, exhibited at the 2012 Paris Motor Show. First production 4x4 SUV with an all-aluminium monocoque unitary body structure, reducing weight significantly compared to its steel unibody predecessor. Range Rover Hybrid (diesel) unveiled at 2013 Frankfurt Motor Show, followed by Plug-in Hybrid in 2018.
Land-Rover-Range-Rover.name: Fourth Generation (L405)

Land-Rover-Range-Rover.description: The fifth-generation Range Rover revealed on October 26, 2021. Features a range of mild hybrid diesel and petrol engines, with plug-in hybrids introduced in early 2022. First from JLR to use an engine developed under the BMW-JLR combustion and electrified powertrain partnership, including a 4.4L BMW/JLR V8 engine. All-electric model announced for 2025.
Land-Rover-Range-Rover.name: Fifth Generation

Land-Rover-Range-Rover-Velar.description: Original Range Rover Velar launched in March 2017. Built on the Jaguar Land Rover iQ[AI] (D7a) platform, sharing components with the Jaguar F-Pace, XF, and XE models. Features a new design language with smoother body lines and a interior with 3 touchscreens.
Land-Rover-Range-Rover-Velar.name: First Generation

Land-Rover-Range-Rover-Velar.description: Facelifted version introduced in 2023. Updated exterior styling and interior features including enhanced infotainment system and new engine options.
Land-Rover-Range-Rover-Velar.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Lexus-CT-200h.description: The original Lexus CT 200h pre-facelift model, launched in January 2011, marked Lexus's entry into the premium compact hybrid hatchback market. Built on the Toyota MC platform with a 1.8-liter 2ZR-FXE hybrid powertrain producing 100 kW combined output. Featured the original front fascia design before the spindle grille was introduced. Sold in Japan, Europe, and North America (from March 2011).
Lexus-CT-200h.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Lexus-CT-200h.description: The 2014 model year facelift introduced Lexus's signature spindle grille design, replacing the original front fascia. Other updates included revised interior trims and equipment options. This version continued through the 2017 model year in North America before CT 200h was discontinued in the US market.
Lexus-CT-200h.name: First Generation (First Facelift)

Lexus-CT-200h.description: The second and final facelift launched for the 2018 model year, featuring full LED headlights with new design as an option and a larger spindle grille standard on all models. Production continued globally until October 2022, when the CT 200h was discontinued and replaced by the Lexus UX crossover. This represents the final evolution of the A10 platform.
Lexus-CT-200h.name: First Generation (Second Facelift)

Lexus-ES.description: The original Lexus ES (ES 250) was introduced alongside the flagship LS 400 as part of the brand's launch lineup. Based on the Toyota Camry platform, the first ES featured conservative styling with a formal roofline and chrome accents. Powered by a 2.5-liter V6 engine producing 156 horsepower paired with a four-speed automatic transmission, it offered modest performance focused on smooth, comfortable operation rather than sportiness. The interior provided a luxurious environment with standard leather seating, wood trim, power accessories, and premium audio. While often overshadowed by the revolutionary LS 400, the ES 250 established the model's identity as Lexus's entry-level luxury sedan with an emphasis on comfort and refinement. Sales were relatively modest during this short first generation, but it laid the foundation for what would become one of Lexus's most successful models.
Lexus-ES.name: First Generation (V20)

Lexus-ES.description: The second generation ES (renamed ES 300) grew substantially in size and sophistication. Based on the Toyota Windom/XV10 Camry platform, it featured more distinctive styling with a sleeker profile and integrated design elements that better established Lexus's visual identity. Powered by a 3.0-liter V6 producing 185 horsepower (later increased to 188 hp), it offered improved performance while maintaining its focus on smooth, quiet operation. The interior was significantly upgraded with more premium materials, improved ergonomics, and additional luxury features. This generation established the ES as a strong seller in the entry-luxury segment, appealing to buyers seeking comfort and quality over sporting pretensions. A minor refresh in 1994 brought styling updates and additional features. The second-generation ES helped solidify Lexus's position in the luxury market by offering accessible luxury with the brand's growing reputation for quality and reliability.
Lexus-ES.name: Second Generation (XV10)

Lexus-ES.description: The third generation ES 300 continued its evolution as Lexus's entry-luxury sedan with more refined styling, improved performance, and additional technology features. Based on the Toyota Camry/Windom platform, it featured a more substantial appearance with a longer wheelbase and increased interior space. Powered by an updated 3.0-liter V6 producing 200 horsepower, paired with a four-speed automatic transmission (later five-speed), it delivered adequate performance for the segment with emphasis on smoothness. The interior saw significant improvements in material quality, featuring California walnut trim, upgraded leather, and improved sound insulation. Notable features included available premium Nakamichi audio system, in-dash CD changer, and automatic climate control. Safety was enhanced with standard front and side airbags. A minor refresh in 2000 brought styling updates and additional standard features. This generation further established the ES as a volume seller for Lexus, appealing to buyers seeking luxury, comfort, and reliability in a midsize sedan.
Lexus-ES.name: Third Generation (XV20)

Lexus-ES.description: The fourth generation ES 300 (renamed ES 330 in 2004) represented a more significant departure from its Toyota counterparts, with unique exterior styling and a more luxurious interior. The design featured a sleek profile with a pronounced trunk lid, chrome accents, and jewel-like headlamps. Initially powered by a 3.0-liter V6 with 210 horsepower, it was upgraded to a 3.3-liter V6 producing 225 horsepower for 2004, paired with a five-speed automatic transmission. The interior space increased significantly, with special attention paid to rear seat legroom. Luxury appointments included premium leather, genuine wood trim, available heated and ventilated seats, navigation system, and Mark Levinson audio. This generation introduced more advanced technology, including adaptive cruise control, rain-sensing wipers, and power rear sunshade. Ride quality was further refined with improved sound insulation and suspension tuning. The fourth generation ES strengthened its position as Lexus's comfort-oriented luxury sedan, distinguishing itself more clearly from the sportier IS model and providing a compelling alternative to European competitors focused on performance.
Lexus-ES.name: Fourth Generation (XV30)

Lexus-ES.description: The fifth generation ES 350 featured more distinctive styling with a sleek, modern design that better differentiated it from the Toyota Camry platform it shared. Powered by a new 3.5-liter V6 engine producing 272 horsepower paired with a six-speed automatic transmission, it offered improved performance with 0-60 mph times under 7 seconds. The interior was completely redesigned with a focus on luxury and technology, featuring semi-aniline leather, real wood trim, and improved ergonomics. New technology included keyless entry and ignition, available navigation with backup camera, Bluetooth connectivity, and USB audio input. This generation also introduced a panoramic glass roof option and improved safety features including adaptive front lighting and upgraded airbag systems. The fifth generation ES reinforced its position as a comfort-focused luxury sedan, growing sales significantly in North America and emerging markets, particularly China. A hybrid variant was notably absent from this generation, as Lexus concentrated its hybrid technology on other models in the lineup.
Lexus-ES.name: Fifth Generation (XV40)

Lexus-ES.description: The sixth generation ES marked a significant evolution, switching to the larger Toyota Avalon platform and introducing the ES 300h hybrid model alongside the V6-powered ES 350. The design featured the most aggressive implementation of Lexus's spindle grille to date on the ES, with sharper lines and a more dynamic profile. The ES 350 continued with a 3.5-liter V6, now producing 268 horsepower, while the ES 300h combined a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine with electric motors for a total system output of 200 horsepower and impressive fuel economy ratings of 40 mpg combined. The interior was significantly upgraded with higher quality materials, improved technology, and increased rear seat space (especially important for the Chinese market). Notable features included available bamboo trim, heated and ventilated seats, ambient lighting, and the second-generation Lexus Remote Touch interface. Safety technology expanded to include pre-collision system, lane departure alert, blind spot monitoring, and rear cross-traffic alert. A 2016 mid-cycle refresh brought an even more pronounced spindle grille, LED headlights, and additional safety features through the Lexus Safety System+ package. This generation solidified the ES's global importance to the Lexus brand, particularly in China where it became a top seller in the luxury segment.
Lexus-ES.name: Sixth Generation (XV60)

Lexus-ES.description: The seventh generation ES represents the most ambitious redesign in the model's history, built on the Toyota New Global Architecture (TNGA-K) platform with significant improvements in structural rigidity, handling, and overall dynamics. The exterior design features a more aggressive interpretation of the Lexus spindle grille, sleeker proportions, and F Sport availability for the first time in ES history. The ES 350 continues with a 3.5-liter V6 producing 302 horsepower, while the ES 300h hybrid combines a 2.5-liter four-cylinder with electric motors for 215 total system horsepower and up to 44 mpg combined. A new ES 250 model with a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine and all-wheel drive joined the lineup for 2021. The interior represents a major upgrade with higher quality materials including available semi-aniline leather, Japanese-inspired design elements, and improved technology featuring a 12.3-inch infotainment display with Apple CarPlay, Android Auto, and Amazon Alexa integration. The Mark Levinson PurePlay sound system with 17 speakers delivers exceptional audio quality. All models come standard with Lexus Safety System+ 2.0, including pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, dynamic radar cruise control, lane tracing assist, and road sign assist. The F Sport model offers adaptive variable suspension, sport+ driving mode, and unique interior and exterior styling elements. A 2022 refresh brought updated styling, touch-display infotainment replacing the Remote Touch controller, and additional refinements. This generation successfully balances the ES's traditional emphasis on comfort with improved driving dynamics, broadening its appeal while maintaining its position as a core model in the Lexus lineup.
Lexus-ES.name: Seventh Generation (XZ10)

Lexus-ES.description: The eighth generation ES was unveiled on 23 April 2025 at the Auto Shanghai, representing a new era for the model with electric vehicle variants and cutting-edge technology. Built on the TNGA: GA-K platform, this generation introduces the ES 350e and ES 500e electric models alongside potential hybrid variants. The exterior design is inspired by the LF-ZC concept previewed at the 2023 Japan Mobility Show, featuring Lexus' 'Clean Tech x Elegance' design concept with Twin-LED daytime running lights, spindle-shaped front graphics, and a fastback profile with a six-window design. The interior incorporates bamboo layering with 3D printing, see-through ambient lighting on door cards, a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, and a 14-inch LexusConnect touchscreen multimedia system with optional passenger touchscreen display. The steering wheel features embossed Lexus branding instead of the traditional logo, and the brand introduces Hidden Tech switches for temperature controls. Other features include a Mark Levinson surround sound system, panoramic glass roof, power forward-folding front passenger seat, and Ottoman leg support for rear passengers. All models come equipped with Lexus Safety System+ including Adaptive Cruise Control, Blind Spot Monitor, Driver Emergency Response System, High-definition Adaptive High-beam System, and Pre-Collision Safety. This generation marks Lexus' commitment to electrification while maintaining the ES's comfort-oriented character.
Lexus-ES.name: Eighth Generation (XZ20)

Lexus-ES-300h.description: The first generation Lexus ES 300h marked the introduction of hybrid technology to the ES line, coinciding with the sixth-generation ES overall. Based on the Toyota Avalon platform, it featured Lexus's distinctive spindle grille, sleek profile, and sophisticated styling elements. Powered by Lexus Hybrid Drive combining a 2.5-liter Atkinson-cycle four-cylinder engine with an electric motor for a total system output of 200 horsepower, paired with an electronic continuously variable transmission (E-CVT). This hybrid system delivered impressive fuel economy ratings of 40 mpg city, 39 mpg highway, and 40 mpg combined, nearly double the efficiency of previous ES generations. The interior maintained the ES tradition of comfort and luxury with premium materials, excellent sound insulation, and spacious accommodations, particularly for rear passengers. Available features included heated and ventilated seats, premium Mark Levinson audio system, and Lexus's Remote Touch interface for the infotainment system. A mid-cycle refresh in 2016 brought more aggressive styling with an enhanced spindle grille, standard LED headlights, and the addition of Lexus Safety System+ including pre-collision system, lane departure alert with steering assist, intelligent high beams, and high-speed dynamic radar cruise control. The first generation ES 300h successfully expanded the ES lineup to appeal to environmentally conscious luxury buyers without compromising the comfort, refinement, and quality that defined the ES brand.
Lexus-ES-300h.name: First Generation (XV60)

Lexus-ES-300h.description: The second generation ES 300h (seventh generation ES overall) represented a significant advancement in hybrid luxury performance, built on the Toyota New Global Architecture (TNGA-K) platform offering enhanced structural rigidity and improved handling dynamics. The exterior design featured a more aggressive interpretation of the Lexus spindle grille, coupe-like roofline, and premium details including intricate LED lighting. Powered by an updated hybrid system combining a more efficient 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine with improved electric motors, delivering 215 total system horsepower and achieving up to 44 mpg combined, a significant improvement over the previous generation. The fourth-generation hybrid system included a smaller, more power-dense battery that minimized intrusion into trunk space. The interior marked a substantial upgrade with higher quality materials, more advanced technology, and improved ergonomics centered around the driver. Notable features included a 12.3-inch infotainment display (touchscreen functionality added after 2022 refresh), Apple CarPlay, Android Auto, and Amazon Alexa integration, available head-up display, and a 17-speaker Mark Levinson PurePlay sound system. All models came standard with Lexus Safety System+ 2.0, featuring enhanced pre-collision system with low-light pedestrian detection, dynamic radar cruise control, lane tracing assist, and road sign assist. A 2022 refresh brought updated styling, a touch-display infotainment system replacing the Remote Touch controller, and improved driver assistance systems. The second generation ES 300h successfully balanced environmental efficiency with luxury comfort, offering a compelling alternative to both conventional luxury sedans and more utilitarian hybrid models.
Lexus-ES-300h.name: Second Generation (XZ10)

Lexus-GX.description: The first generation Lexus GX (GX 470) was introduced as a mid-size luxury SUV positioned between the RX and LX in the Lexus lineup. Based on the international Toyota Land Cruiser Prado platform, it combined genuine off-road capability with Lexus luxury. Powered by a 4.7-liter V8 engine initially producing 235 horsepower (later increased to 263 hp in 2005), paired with a five-speed automatic transmission and full-time four-wheel drive with a dual-range transfer case. Notable features included adaptive variable suspension, adjustable height control, downhill assist control, and hill-start assist control. The interior offered three rows of seating for up to eight passengers, trimmed with premium leather and wood accents. Luxury amenities included a Mark Levinson premium audio system, DVD-based navigation, and rear seat entertainment options. The GX 470 featured body-on-frame construction with an independent front suspension and solid rear axle with air springs, balancing off-road articulation with on-road comfort. A 2004 Sport package added unique wheels and roof rack, while a 2008 refresh brought styling updates and additional features. The first generation GX established the model's reputation for combining traditional SUV capability with Lexus luxury and reliability.
Lexus-GX.name: First Generation (J120)

Lexus-GX.description: The second generation Lexus GX (GX 460) continued the model's focus on combining luxury with genuine off-road capability. Based on the revised Toyota Land Cruiser Prado platform, it featured more angular styling with Lexus's signature spindle grille (more pronounced after the 2014 refresh). Powered by a 4.6-liter V8 engine producing 301 horsepower (later reduced to 292 hp with switching to SAE net ratings) paired with a six-speed automatic transmission. The full-time four-wheel drive system included a Torsen limited-slip center differential and a dual-range transfer case. Advanced off-road technology included Crawl Control (a low-speed off-road cruise control), Downhill Assist Control, and Kinetic Dynamic Suspension System that could disconnect the stabilizer bars for improved articulation. The interior featured three rows of seating for seven passengers, with premium leather, wood trim, and modern technology including an available Mark Levinson surround-sound system and wide-view front and side cameras. Safety technology expanded significantly over the generation, eventually including Lexus Safety System+ as standard with pre-collision system, lane departure alert, intelligent high beams, and high-speed dynamic radar cruise control. A significant refresh in 2020 brought an even more pronounced spindle grille, standard triple-beam LED headlights, and updated technology features. Despite minimal changes throughout its long production run, the second generation GX maintained a loyal following for its combination of luxury, reliability, and authentic off-road capability increasingly rare in the luxury SUV segment.
Lexus-GX.name: Second Generation (J150)

Lexus-GX.description: The third generation Lexus GX represents a comprehensive redesign while maintaining the model's fundamental body-on-frame construction and off-road focus. Based on Lexus's new GA-F platform shared with the Toyota Land Cruiser, it features a bold, squared-off design with a distinctive interpretation of the Lexus spindle grille, prominent fender flares, and an available blacked-out Overtrail package for a more rugged appearance. Power comes from a new twin-turbocharged 3.4-liter V6 engine producing 349 horsepower and 479 lb-ft of torque (a significant increase over the previous V8), paired with a 10-speed automatic transmission and full-time four-wheel drive with a two-speed transfer case. Advanced off-road technology includes Multi-Terrain Select, Crawl Control, Downhill Assist Control, and an available electronic-disconnect front stabilizer bar. The interior offers a significant upgrade with a modern digital cockpit featuring a 14-inch touchscreen, 12.3-inch digital instrument display, and available head-up display. Available in six or seven-passenger configurations with enhanced second-row comfort and accessibility. Luxury features include semi-aniline leather, massaging front seats, open-pore wood trim, and a 21-speaker Mark Levinson Reference surround sound system. The new platform enhances both on-road comfort and off-road capability, with improved approach, departure, and breakover angles compared to the previous generation. Advanced safety features come standard through Lexus Safety System+ 3.0. The third generation GX maintains its position as a technically capable off-roader with premium luxury appointments, now with modernized design, technology, and significantly improved performance and efficiency.
Lexus-GX.name: Third Generation (J250)

Lexus-GX-460.description: The Lexus GX 460 represented the second generation of the GX line, continuing the model's tradition of combining luxury with authentic off-road capability. Based on the Toyota Land Cruiser Prado platform, it featured distinctive Lexus styling with a bold chrome grille (updated to the spindle grille design in later refreshes). Powered by a 4.6-liter V8 engine producing 301 horsepower (later adjusted to 292 hp under revised SAE measurements) and 329 lb-ft of torque, paired with a six-speed automatic transmission. The standard full-time four-wheel drive system featured a Torsen limited-slip center differential with electronic locking capability and a dual-range transfer case with low-range gearing. Advanced off-road technology included Kinetic Dynamic Suspension System (KDSS) that could automatically disconnect stabilizer bars for improved wheel articulation, Crawl Control for low-speed off-road navigation, and Downhill Assist Control. The interior offered three rows of seating for seven passengers, wrapped in premium leather with mahogany wood trim and a comprehensive suite of luxury amenities. Early models featured a touchscreen infotainment system with available navigation, later updated to larger screens with enhanced functionality throughout the generation. A significant refresh in 2014 introduced the spindle grille design and added new safety and technology features. Another substantial update in 2020 brought even more distinctive styling with a massive spindle grille, triple-beam LED headlights, and a redesigned rear end with updated taillights. Safety technology evolved throughout the generation, culminating in the standard Lexus Safety System+ suite including pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, lane departure alert, intelligent high beams, and high-speed dynamic radar cruise control. Despite minimal mechanical changes throughout its unusually long 14-year production run, the GX 460 maintained a loyal following for its combination of luxury, reliability, and authentic off-road capability increasingly rare in the luxury SUV segment.
Lexus-GX-460.name: First Generation (J150)

Lexus-GX-470.description: The Lexus GX 470 was introduced as the first generation of Lexus's mid-size luxury SUV, positioned between the car-based RX and the full-size LX in the brand's lineup. Based on the Toyota Land Cruiser Prado platform, it featured body-on-frame construction with genuine off-road capability combined with Lexus luxury. Powered by a 4.7-liter V8 engine initially producing 235 horsepower and 320 lb-ft of torque (later increased to 263 horsepower and 323 lb-ft in 2005 with the addition of VVT-i technology), paired with a five-speed automatic transmission. The standard full-time four-wheel drive system included a center locking Torsen differential and a dual-range transfer case with low-range gearing. The suspension system featured front independent double-wishbone design and a rear four-link solid axle with air springs and adaptive variable suspension (AVS) that could adjust to different terrain conditions. Advanced off-road technology included Downhill Assist Control, Hill-start Assist Control, and adjustable height control allowing the driver to raise the vehicle for additional ground clearance. The interior offered luxurious appointments with three rows of seating for up to eight passengers, trimmed with leather and bird's-eye maple wood accents. Premium features included a Mark Levinson audio system, DVD-based navigation, and rear seat entertainment options. A Sport package was added in 2004 with special wheels and a roof rack, while a Kinetic Dynamic Suspension System (KDSS) became available in 2005, improving both on-road handling and off-road articulation. A refresh in 2008 brought revised exterior styling and interior enhancements. The GX 470 successfully established the model's reputation for blending traditional SUV capability with Lexus luxury and reliability, appealing to buyers seeking refinement without sacrificing utility and off-road performance.
Lexus-GX-470.name: First Generation (J120)

Lexus-IS.description: The first generation Lexus IS (initially sold as the Toyota Altezza in Japan) marked Lexus's entry into the compact sports sedan segment, challenging established competitors like the BMW 3 Series. Featuring distinctive styling with clear taillight housings (which spawned the 'Altezza lights' aftermarket trend) and a driver-focused interior with chronograph-style gauges. The Altezza nameplate was used in Japan from October 1998, while the Lexus IS 200 debuted in Europe in January 1999 and the IS 300 arrived in North America in 2000. Initially offered in the U.S. as the IS 300 with a 3.0-liter inline-six producing 162 horsepower, paired with either a five-speed manual or five-speed automatic transmission. A SportCross wagon variant was added in 2002, offering additional utility while maintaining the sedan's sporting character. The first generation IS established Lexus's presence in the sport sedan market with a focus on driving dynamics, though it achieved modest sales compared to European rivals, with North American sales peaking at 22,486 units in 2001.
Lexus-IS.name: First Generation (XE10)

Lexus-IS.description: The second generation IS represented a comprehensive redesign with more distinctive styling, improved performance, and additional model variants, launching globally in 2005. The lineup expanded to include the IS 250 with a 2.5-liter V6 (153 kW) and the IS 350 with a 3.5-liter V6 (228 kW), both initially paired with automatic transmissions (manual options were available on some markets). The exterior styling featured sleeker, coupé-like contours with a fastback profile and arrowhead motif, while the interior offered improved materials and more technology features including a touchscreen navigation system. The high-performance IS F joined the lineup in 2007, powered by a 5.0-liter V8 producing 310 kW, paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission and featuring track-focused suspension tuning and distinctive styling elements. A hardtop convertible IS C debuted in 2008, offering open-air motoring with a power-retractable hardtop. Safety technology expanded throughout this generation, including Lexus's Pre-Collision System. Facelifts in 2008 and 2010 brought visual and technical updates, with the 2010 refresh introducing the spindle grille design theme along with LED daytime running lights and interior enhancements. This generation broadened the IS model range and strengthened its position as Lexus's compact sport sedan, achieving significant sales growth including over 49,000 units sold globally in its first year.
Lexus-IS.name: Second Generation (XE20)

Lexus-IS.description: The third generation IS premiered in January 2013 and continues to the present, featuring progressive styling iterations centered around Lexus's signature spindle grille design. The initial 2013-2016 phase introduced sharply creased bodywork and a more muscular stance, with the interior completely redesigned with higher quality materials, enhanced technology including infotainment displays, and improved ergonomics. The powertrain lineup initially included refined versions of the 2.5L and 3.5L V6 engines, with the turbocharged 2.0L IS 200t/300 joining in 2016, plus a hybrid IS 300h model for certain markets. A significant 2017 facelift brought even more aggressive styling, standard Lexus Safety System+ with pre-collision braking and lane departure alert, and updated infotainment featuring a 10.3-inch display. The V6 engines received a 5 hp power increase in 2017. A major 2020 facelift (for 2021 model year) introduced the IS 500 F Sport Performance variant powered by a 5.0L V8 producing 346 kW as a spiritual successor to the IS F, alongside a larger spindle grille, restyled headlamps, full-width taillamps, updated interior technology with Android Auto and Apple CarPlay support, improved suspension with more rigid body structure, and enhanced driver-assistance systems. A third facelift in 2025 (2026 model year) further updated styling and technology. The high-performance IS F was discontinued after the second generation, though F Sport and F Sport Performance packages offered performance-focused variants. This generation focuses on refining the IS formula with more distinctive design, improved technology, and a better balance between sport and luxury.
Lexus-IS.name: Third Generation (XE30)

Lexus-IS-300.description: The original Lexus IS 300 introduced the IS line to North America, targeting the BMW 3 Series with its sports sedan dynamics and distinctive styling. Powered by the 2JZ-GE 3.0-liter inline-six engine (shared with the Supra but naturally aspirated) producing 215 horsepower and 218 lb-ft of torque. Debuted in July 2000 as a 2001 model year vehicle. Initially available only with a five-speed automatic transmission, a five-speed manual option was added in 2001 for the 2002 model year. The exterior featured unique styling with clear taillight housings (inspiring the 'Altezza lights' aftermarket trend) and a driver-focused interior with chronograph-inspired gauge cluster. The SportCross wagon variant was introduced in 2001 for the 2002 model year, offering additional utility while maintaining the sedan's sporting character. Handling was prioritized with double-wishbone suspension front and rear, achieving a near-perfect weight distribution. A facelift in 2003 for the 2004 model year brought redesigned 11-spoke wheels, updated fog lamps, and interior enhancements including a 2-position memory function for the driver seat. The first-generation IS 300 established Lexus's credibility in the sport sedan segment, offering Japanese reliability with engaging driving dynamics at a competitive price point.
Lexus-IS-300.name: First Generation (XE10)

Lexus-IS-300.description: The second generation IS was introduced at the Geneva Motor Show in March 2005, with sales beginning worldwide in September and October 2005 as a 2006 model. While the IS 250 and IS 350 became the primary models in most markets, the IS 300 nameplate continued in select markets with a GSE22 chassis code powered by a 3.0L V6 (3GR-FE) producing approximately 245 horsepower. The IS 300 was also available as an IS 300 C convertible from 2009-2015. This generation marked Lexus's L-finesse design philosophy with sleeker, coupé-like contours and a fastback profile. Interior improvements included memory leather seats, electroluminescent instrument display lighting, and optional advanced features like touchscreen navigation with backup camera and Mark Levinson premium sound system. A facelift in 2008 brought suspension and steering retuning for improved stability, along with the introduction of convertible variants. Another refresh in 2010 added factory-produced F Sport models and further interior updates. The high-performance IS F (USE20) was introduced in 2007, powered by a 5.0L V8 producing 416 horsepower.
Lexus-IS-300.name: Second Generation (XE20)

Lexus-IS-300.description: The third generation Lexus IS premiered at the North American International Auto Show in January 2013, with production beginning April 25, 2013 at the Tahara plant in Japan. Sales began mid-2013 as 2014 model year vehicles. The IS 300 nameplate returned in various forms: the IS 300 AWD (GSE37) used a 3.5L V6 producing 260 horsepower, while rear-wheel drive IS 300 models initially used a detuned 3.5L V6 before being replaced by the IS 200t in 2015 (2.0L turbo producing 241 horsepower). In 2017, the IS 200t was renamed IS 300 for RWD models. The hybrid IS 300h was also available in select markets. Exterior design featured Lexus's signature spindle grille with aggressive styling and angular LED lighting. The F Sport package offered enhanced handling with Adaptive Variable Suspension and Variable Gear Ratio Steering. A significant refresh in 2016 for the 2017 model year brought updated headlamps, taillamps, front fascia, and a 10.3-inch infotainment screen. Another major facelift in 2020 for the 2021 model year included a larger spindle grille, restyled headlights, full-width taillamps, and structural rigidity improvements. The IS 500 F Sport Performance was introduced in 2021 for the 2022 model year, powered by a 5.0L V8 producing 472 horsepower.
Lexus-IS-300.name: Third Generation (XE30)

Lexus-IS-300.description: The fourth generation IS 300 continues as a mid-range option in the IS lineup, representing an evolution of the third generation's platform with significant enhancements. Rear-wheel drive models are powered by a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder engine producing 241 horsepower and 258 lb-ft of torque, paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission. All-wheel drive variants retain a 3.5L V6 producing 260 horsepower and 236 lb-ft of torque, mated to a six-speed automatic. Built on a revised platform focused on handling improvements with increased structural rigidity, extra welding on radiator mount points and front side members, and new swing-valve shock absorbers. The exterior styling evolved with a larger spindle grille, slimmer headlights, and a full-width taillight bar. The interior features an updated infotainment system with standard 8-inch or available 10.3-inch touchscreen, Android Auto and Apple CarPlay compatibility, replacing the previous Remote Touch controller. Standard safety technology expanded with Lexus Safety System+ 2.5, including enhanced pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, emergency steering assist, and all-speed dynamic radar cruise control. The available F Sport package adds distinctive styling elements, sport-tuned suspension, and unique interior appointments. Dynamic Handling Package option includes Adaptive Variable Suspension and 19-inch forged alloy wheels. The IS 500 F Sport Performance continues as the flagship V8 model.
Lexus-IS-300.name: Fourth Generation (XE40)

Lexus-IS-350.description: The first-generation Lexus IS 350 debuted as the performance-oriented model in the second-generation IS lineup. Powered by a 3.5-liter V6 engine (2GR-FSE) producing 306 horsepower and 277 lb-ft of torque, featuring both direct and port injection systems—an innovative dual injection system at the time. Initially available only with a six-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters and exclusively in rear-wheel drive configuration, it could accelerate from 0-60 mph in approximately 5.3 seconds. The exterior featured sleek styling with a rising beltline and fastback-like profile, while the interior offered a driver-focused cockpit with high-quality materials and available luxury features including a Mark Levinson premium audio system, touchscreen navigation, and ventilated front seats. The double-wishbone front and multi-link rear suspension provided sporty handling characteristics, while the Vehicle Dynamics Integrated Management (VDIM) system integrated stability control, traction control, and ABS for enhanced safety. A minor refresh in 2009 brought subtle styling updates, followed by a more significant update in 2011 with the addition of Lexus's spindle grille design, LED daytime running lights, and interior improvements. Throughout its production, the first-generation IS 350 established itself as a credible performance sedan, though it maintained a more comfort-oriented character compared to some European rivals.
Lexus-IS-350.name: First Generation (XE20)

Lexus-IS-350.description: The second-generation IS 350 featured more aggressive styling with Lexus's signature spindle grille design prominently displayed, more angular headlights, and sharper body lines. Mechanically, it continued with an updated version of the 3.5-liter V6 engine maintaining 306 horsepower and 277 lb-ft of torque. Rear-wheel drive models received an eight-speed automatic transmission, while all-wheel drive versions (added to the IS 350 range for this generation) used a six-speed automatic. The chassis was significantly stiffer than its predecessor, offering improved handling dynamics, particularly with the available adaptive variable suspension. The interior saw major improvements with higher quality materials, enhanced technology including a larger infotainment display with Remote Touch controller, and a more premium feel overall. The F Sport package, especially popular on the IS 350, added unique exterior styling elements, bolstered sport seats, a special sport-tuned suspension, and an available variable gear ratio steering system. A refresh in 2017 brought even more aggressive styling, standard Lexus Safety System+ driver assistance features, and an updated infotainment system with a 10.3-inch display on navigation-equipped models. Throughout this generation, the IS 350 served as the performance model in the standard IS lineup (positioned below the limited-production IS F), appealing to buyers seeking a balance of luxury and sporting capability.
Lexus-IS-350.name: Second Generation (XE30)

Lexus-IS-350.description: The third-generation IS 350 represents an evolution of the previous model rather than a complete redesign, built on a heavily revised version of the second-generation platform with significant improvements to structural rigidity, suspension components, and overall dynamics. The exterior styling is more aggressive than ever, with an enlarged spindle grille, slimmer headlights with revised LED daytime running light signatures, and a full-width taillight design. The 3.5-liter V6 continues with 311 horsepower and 280 lb-ft of torque (a slight increase from the previous generation), maintaining the eight-speed automatic for rear-wheel drive models and six-speed automatic for all-wheel drive variants. The suspension was thoroughly retuned with lighter components and revised geometry, benefiting from expertise gained through the development of the LC coupe and flagship LS sedan. The interior features updated technology with a standard 8-inch or available 10.3-inch touchscreen that's moved closer to the driver for easier operation, replacing the previous Remote Touch controller. Safety technology was enhanced with Lexus Safety System+ 2.5, including improved pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, emergency steering assist, and all-speed dynamic radar cruise control. The F Sport package is now available in multiple tiers, with the Dynamic Handling Package adding adaptive variable suspension, a Torsen limited-slip differential (RWD only), and unique 19-inch forged alloy wheels with performance tires. This generation of the IS 350 focuses on driving dynamics and emotional engagement while updating technology and safety features to contemporary standards, positioning it as a sport sedan for enthusiast drivers within the Lexus lineup.
Lexus-IS-350.name: Third Generation (XE40)

Lexus-IS-500.description: The Lexus IS 500 F Sport Performance represents the first use of the IS 500 nameplate, introduced as a high-performance variant of the fourth-generation IS. Positioned as a spiritual successor to the IS F, it features a naturally aspirated 5.0-liter V8 engine producing 472 horsepower and 395 lb-ft of torque, paired exclusively with an eight-speed automatic transmission driving the rear wheels. This powertrain enables 0-60 mph acceleration in approximately 4.5 seconds while producing a distinctive, increasingly rare naturally aspirated V8 soundtrack enhanced by a quad exhaust system. Visually distinguished from standard IS models by a bulged hood raised by nearly two inches to accommodate the larger engine, darker window trim, a rear lip spoiler, and distinctive 19-inch split-ten-spoke Enkei alloy wheels that reduce unsprung weight. The F Sport Performance designation indicates a focus on driving dynamics beyond the regular F Sport package, featuring adaptive variable suspension, a Torsen limited-slip differential, and larger brakes with enhanced cooling. The interior features F Sport Performance badging, heated leather-trimmed steering wheel with unique center marker, and F Sport Performance pedals. Despite its high-performance credentials, the IS 500 maintains a relatively subtle exterior appearance compared to dedicated performance models from European manufacturers, embracing a 'sleeper' aesthetic that harkens back to Japanese performance car traditions. Limited-production special editions include the Launch Edition featuring distinctive Incognito paint and split-seven-spoke forged alloy BBS wheels, and the Premium with additional luxury features. The IS 500 serves as a halo model for the IS lineup and represents one of the last naturally aspirated V8 sport sedans in an era increasingly dominated by turbocharged and electrified powertrains.
Lexus-IS-500.name: First Generation (XE40)

Lexus-LC-500.description: The Lexus LC is a grand tourer manufactured by Lexus, a luxury division of Toyota. Based on the 2012 Lexus LF-LC Concept, it was revealed at the 2016 North American International Auto Show in Detroit. Series production commenced in March 2017, with the first example completed on April 23, 2017. The LC is the first Lexus model to utilize the GA-L platform, which is shared with the full-size XF50 series LS sedan. According to Lexus, the name 'LC' stands for 'Luxury Coupe'. The LC 500 is powered by a 5.0-liter 2UR-GSE V8 engine producing 471 horsepower and 398 lb-ft of torque, paired with a 10-speed Direct Shift automatic transmission and driving the rear wheels. A hybrid-electric variant, the LC 500h, was revealed in February 2016 at the Geneva Motor Show, powered by a 3.5-liter 8GR-FXS V6 engine with a hybrid transmission and lithium-ion battery pack providing a combined 354 horsepower and 500 Nm of torque. The exterior design features a variant of Lexus's spindle grille, tightly compressed mesh at the top transitioning to a wider diamond at the bottom, triple-LED headlights, and a floating roof design creating a distinctive silhouette. The chassis features mixed-material construction combining high-strength steel, aluminum, and carbon fiber, with a double-joint multi-link suspension front and rear designed to reduce necessary height while ensuring mirrored movement. The LC 500 Convertible, based on a concept vehicle, was unveiled at the LA Auto Show on November 20, 2019, with a model year of 2021, featuring a four-layer soft top that can be operated at speeds up to 50 km/h and can be stowed in approximately 15 seconds. The LC is built at Toyota's Motomachi facility, the same plant that produced the Lexus LFA, with the factory reconfigured for LC production and many of the master craftsmen who built the LFA continuing their work on the LC.
Lexus-LC-500.name: First Generation

Lexus-LS.description: The original Lexus LS 400 revolutionized the luxury sedan market, establishing the Lexus brand with its exceptional quality, refinement, and value. Developed under the top-secret F1 project ('Flagship One'), it featured a silky-smooth 4.0-liter V8 producing 250 horsepower, paired with a four-speed automatic transmission. The exterior design was intentionally conservative but elegant, with excellent aerodynamics for its time. The interior set new standards for noise isolation (famously demonstrated in the 'champagne glass' commercial), material quality, and attention to detail. Advanced features included a power-adjustable steering wheel, memory seats, and an electrochromic rearview mirror. The engineering was obsessive, with 1,400 engineers working for nearly five years to develop a vehicle that matched or exceeded established European luxury sedans in every measurable metric.
