The first-generation LS established Lexus's reputation for exceptional quality, reliability, and customer service, fundamentally changing the luxury car market.
Lexus-LS.name: First Generation (XF10)

Lexus-LS.description: The second-generation LS maintained the fundamental virtues of the original while addressing its few shortcomings. The exterior styling evolved subtly with more sculptured surfaces and improved proportions. The 4.0-liter V8 was enhanced to produce 260 horsepower, paired with a smoother five-speed automatic transmission. The interior was thoroughly revised with improved ergonomics, more luxurious materials, and additional features including a premium Nakamichi sound system and enhanced climate control. Structural rigidity increased substantially, further improving the already impressive refinement and ride quality. Safety technology expanded with front and side airbags, vehicle stability control, and enhanced braking systems. A minor revision in 1998 brought additional refinements and standard features. This generation further solidified the LS's reputation for exceptional quality and reliability while enhancing its luxury credentials, establishing it as a legitimate alternative to established European luxury sedans.
Lexus-LS.name: Second Generation (XF20)

Lexus-LS.description: The third-generation LS featured more distinctive styling, although still relatively conservative, with a slightly larger body providing increased interior space. The new 4.3-liter V8 engine produced 290 horsepower, paired with a five-speed automatic transmission (later a six-speed). Technological innovations included the first production LED taillights, adaptive cruise control, a DVD-based navigation system, and Bluetooth phone connectivity. Significant innovations included climate-controlled seats, power-closing doors, a power trunk lid, and advanced parking guidance. Safety features expanded with knee airbags, adaptive headlights, and pre-collision systems. The ultra-luxury LS 430 models featured premium Mark Levinson audio, heated and cooled rear seats, and rear-seat massage functions. This generation maintained Lexus's reputation for quality and refinement while adding significant technological innovations, further elevating the LS as a world-class luxury sedan.
Lexus-LS.name: Third Generation (XF30)

Lexus-LS.description: The fourth-generation LS represented the most significant redesign to date, with more expressive styling and advanced technology. Two models were offered: the standard wheelbase LS 460 and the long-wheelbase LS 460L, both powered by a new 4.6-liter V8 producing 380 horsepower, paired with the world's first eight-speed automatic transmission. The LS 600h L hybrid variant combined a 5.0-liter V8 with electric motors for enhanced performance and efficiency. The interior featured exceptional craftsmanship with hand-polished wood trim, semi-aniline leather, and available executive rear seating with ottoman and massage functions. Technological innovations included the Advanced Parking Guidance System for automated parallel parking, a hard-drive based navigation system, and a 19-speaker Mark Levinson Reference sound system. A significant refresh in 2013 introduced the spindle grille design and updated technology features. Throughout its long production run, this generation maintained Lexus's reputation for quality while offering unprecedented luxury features and technological sophistication, though it faced increasing competition from revitalized European rivals.
Lexus-LS.name: Fourth Generation (XF40)

Lexus-LS.description: The current LS represents the most dramatic redesign in the model's history, with expressive styling featuring a bold spindle grille, complex surfacing, and a coupe-like roofline despite its large size. Built on the new GA-L platform shared with the LC coupe, it features significantly improved structural rigidity and a lower center of gravity for enhanced handling. Initially offered as the LS 500 with a twin-turbocharged 3.5-liter V6 producing 416 horsepower and 442 lb-ft of torque, paired with a 10-speed automatic transmission, and the LS 500h hybrid combining a 3.5-liter V6 with two electric motors for a total system output of 354 horsepower. The interior showcases extraordinary craftsmanship with available hand-pleated door panels, cut glass inserts, and kiriko glass ornamentation inspired by Japanese aesthetics. Technological features include a 24-inch head-up display, 23-speaker Mark Levinson audio system, and the comprehensive Lexus Safety System+ 2.0. Executive packages offer four-zone climate control, 22-way adjustable rear seats with massage, and a rear-seat entertainment system. A refresh for 2021 brought improved suspension tuning, updated technology with a touchscreen replacing the Remote Touch controller, and enhanced driver assistance features. The fifth-generation LS embraces a more distinctive design philosophy and driving character while maintaining the model's traditional strengths in comfort, refinement, and quality, positioning it as a unique alternative to established European luxury sedans.
Lexus-LS.name: Fifth Generation (XF50)

Lexus-NX-350h.description: The first generation Lexus NX 300h was the hybrid variant of the first-generation Lexus NX compact luxury crossover SUV, introduced in late 2014. Powered by a third-generation hybrid system combining a 2.5-liter 2AR-FXE four-cylinder engine with electric motors and paired with an electronically controlled continuously variable transmission (eCVT), delivering a combined system output of 145 horsepower. This hybrid powertrain provided excellent fuel efficiency while maintaining strong acceleration for the segment. The NX 300h was positioned between the naturally aspirated NX 200 and the turbocharged NX 200t models. The first-generation NX featured Lexus's distinctive spindle grille design and compact, distinctive styling with unique suspension parts, interior, and level of luxury distinguishing it from the related Toyota RAV4. US sales began in November 2014, with production commencing on August 8, 2014 at Toyota Motor Kyushu's Miyata plant. The pre-facelift model featured the original front bumper, grille, and headlamp design that defined the NX's initial market entry.
Lexus-NX-350h.name: First Generation Pre-Facelift (AZ10)

Lexus-NX-350h.description: In September 2017, the Lexus NX received a mid-life facelift that revised the front bumper, grille, headlamps, and taillights while maintaining the core AZ10 platform. The front bumper, grille, and headlamps were significantly revised, as were the taillights and dashboard. The tailgate also received new sheetmetal, echoing Lexus's 'spindle motif' grille design. Equipment levels were boosted with a new safety package (Lexus Safety System+) and an optional head-up display becoming available. The NX 200t was renamed to NX 300 after the facelift to unify marketing efforts with the NX 300h hybrid model. The powertrain remained unchanged, with the NX 300h continuing to use the 2.5-liter hybrid system. Production continued through November 2021 before being replaced by the all-new second-generation AZ20 platform.
Lexus-NX-350h.name: First Generation Facelift (AZ10)

Lexus-NX-350h.description: The Lexus NX 350h represents the hybrid variant of the second-generation Lexus NX compact luxury crossover, replacing the previous NX 300h model with significant improvements in power, efficiency, and technology. Powered by a fourth-generation hybrid system combining a 2.5-liter A25A-FXS four-cylinder engine with electric motors for a total system output of 239 horsepower (a 45 horsepower increase over its predecessor), paired with an electronically controlled continuously variable transmission (eCVT). This powertrain delivers excellent fuel economy while offering significantly improved acceleration. Standard all-wheel drive features a dedicated rear electric motor providing seamless power distribution between front and rear wheels. The exterior design evolved with a more sophisticated interpretation of the spindle grille, sleeker overlapping L-shape daytime running lamps, and a connected taillight design. The interior represents a major advancement with the new Lexus Interface multimedia system featuring a standard 9.8-inch or available 14-inch touchscreen display with wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, cloud-based navigation, and native voice assistant capabilities. This system replaces the previous Remote Touch interface with more intuitive controls, including physical buttons for frequently used functions. Driver assistance technology expanded with Lexus Safety System+ 3.0 including enhanced pre-collision system with motorcycle detection, intersection support, and emergency steering assist. Additional features include a digital key system allowing smartphone access, wireless smartphone charging, and a digital rearview mirror. As the first hybrid model to adopt the new numerical naming convention (previous hybrid models used 'h' designations like 300h), the NX 350h positions itself as a premium hybrid crossover built on the TNGA: GA-K platform shared with the Toyota Venza/Harrier and RAV4.
Lexus-NX-350h.name: Second Generation (AZ20)

Lexus-RX.description: The original Lexus RX 300 pioneered the luxury crossover segment, combining SUV versatility with car-like handling and comfort. Based on the Toyota Harrier that debuted in Japan a year earlier, it featured unibody construction rather than the body-on-frame design common to SUVs of the era. Powered by a 3.0-liter V6 producing 220 horsepower paired with a four-speed automatic transmission, available in both front-wheel drive and all-wheel drive configurations. The exterior design blended SUV styling cues with a sleeker, more aerodynamic shape than traditional sport utility vehicles. The elevated seating position provided the commanding view drivers sought from SUVs, while the car-based platform delivered smoother ride quality and better fuel economy. The interior offered luxury amenities including leather upholstery, premium audio options, and woodgrain trim. With its practical size, comfortable ride, and Lexus quality, the RX quickly became the brand's best-selling model in the United States and established the template for the luxury crossover segment that would soon be crowded with competitors.
Lexus-RX.name: First Generation (XU10)

Lexus-RX.description: The second-generation RX grew slightly larger with more distinctive styling featuring a sleeker profile and more upscale details. Available as the RX 330 (later renamed RX 350 with a larger engine), it was powered initially by a 3.3-liter V6 producing 230 horsepower, later replaced by a 3.5-liter V6 with 270 horsepower, both paired with a five-speed automatic transmission. This generation introduced the RX 400h, the first luxury hybrid SUV, combining a 3.3-liter V6 with electric motors for improved performance and efficiency. The interior saw significant upgrades in material quality and design, with available features including a voice-activated navigation system, rear-seat DVD entertainment, and an adaptive front lighting system. Safety technology expanded with available features like adaptive cruise control, stability control, and a backup camera. The second generation refined the RX formula with improved performance, technology, and luxury features while maintaining the practical versatility that made the original a success.
Lexus-RX.name: Second Generation (XU30)

Lexus-RX.description: The third-generation RX featured more aggressive styling with sharper lines and a bolder presence. The RX 350 continued with an updated 3.5-liter V6 producing 275 horsepower, now paired with a six-speed automatic transmission. The hybrid RX 450h combined a 3.5-liter V6 with more powerful electric motors for a total system output of 295 horsepower while achieving significantly better fuel economy than the standard model. The interior was completely redesigned with higher quality materials, a new 'Remote Touch' controller for the available navigation system, and improved ergonomics. Available features included a heads-up display, wide-view side and backup monitors, and active safety technologies including pre-collision system and lane departure alert. This generation also introduced the F Sport package with sportier suspension tuning, unique exterior and interior styling elements, and enhanced driving dynamics. Throughout its production run, the third-generation RX maintained its position as the bestselling Lexus model and a benchmark in the luxury crossover segment.
Lexus-RX.name: Third Generation (AL10)

Lexus-RX.description: The fourth-generation RX featured dramatically more aggressive styling with a massive spindle grille, sharp creases, and a floating roof design created by blacked-out C-pillars. Available in both standard and extended-length L versions (added in 2018 with three-row seating), it offered more interior space and versatility. The RX 350 featured a refined 3.5-liter V6 producing 295 horsepower paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission, while the RX 450h hybrid combined the V6 with electric motors for a total of 308 horsepower. The interior showcased Lexus's contemporary design with high-quality materials, available semi-aniline leather, and laser-cut wood trim. Technology features included a 12.3-inch infotainment display, available color heads-up display, and a comprehensive suite of safety systems through Lexus Safety System+. A significant refresh in 2020 brought styling updates, improved infotainment with touchscreen functionality replacing the Remote Touch controller, and enhanced driver assistance features. The performance-oriented RX F Sport models featured adaptive variable suspension, more aggressive styling, and sport-tuned driving dynamics. This generation further refined the luxury crossover formula the RX pioneered while offering more distinctive styling, advanced technology, and improved driving dynamics.
Lexus-RX.name: Fourth Generation (AL20)

Lexus-RX.description: The fifth-generation RX represents a comprehensive redesign built on Lexus's new GA-K platform, offering improved structural rigidity, reduced weight, and enhanced driving dynamics. The exterior evolves the brand's design language with a sleeker interpretation of the spindle grille (now called "spindle body"), sharper body lines, and a connected taillight design. The powertrain lineup expanded significantly with four options: the RX 350 with a 2.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder (275 hp), the RX 350h hybrid combining a 2.5-liter four-cylinder with electric motors (246 hp), the performance-oriented RX 500h F Sport Performance with a turbocharged hybrid system (367 hp) and DIRECT4 all-wheel drive, and the plug-in hybrid RX 450h+ with approximately 38 miles of electric range. The interior features Lexus's new cockpit design philosophy centered around a standard 9.8-inch or available 14-inch touchscreen with the new Lexus Interface system, offering wireless Apple CarPlay/Android Auto, cloud-based navigation, and "Hey Lexus" voice assistant functionality. Advanced technology includes digital key capability, a panoramic view monitor, and traffic jam assist. Safety features expanded with Lexus Safety System+ 3.0 including enhanced pre-collision system, emergency driving stop system, and proactive driving assist. Available in both five-passenger configurations and F Sport variants with distinctive styling and performance enhancements. The newest RX maintains its position as a cornerstone of the Lexus lineup while embracing electrification, improved dynamics, and advanced technology to appeal to a broad spectrum of luxury crossover buyers.
Lexus-RX.name: Fifth Generation (ALA10)

Lexus-RX-350.description: The Lexus RX 350 was introduced in 2006 as a mid-cycle enhancement to the second-generation RX (XU30), replacing the RX 330 with a larger, more powerful 3.5-liter 2GR-FE V6 engine producing 270 horsepower and 251 lb-ft of torque. Paired with a five-speed automatic transmission and available in both front-wheel drive and all-wheel drive configurations, it delivered improved acceleration and overall performance compared to its predecessor. The exterior styling remained largely unchanged from the RX 330, featuring a sleek, car-like design with SUV proportions. The interior continued to offer luxury appointments including available leather seating, premium audio systems, and wood trim. Available technology included a voice-activated navigation system, rear-seat DVD entertainment, and an adaptive front lighting system. Safety features expanded with the Vehicle Stability Control system, traction control, and available adaptive cruise control. Production ended in December 2008, though some 2009 model year vehicles remained available into early 2009.
Lexus-RX-350.name: First Generation (XU30)

Lexus-RX-350.description: The second generation RX 350 (part of the third-generation RX lineup) featured more aggressive styling with sharper lines, a more distinctive grille, and a bolder presence. Powered by an updated 3.5-liter 2GR-FE V6 engine producing 275 horsepower and 257 lb-ft of torque, paired with a six-speed automatic transmission. The interior was completely redesigned with higher quality materials, improved ergonomics, and a new 'Remote Touch' controller for the available navigation system. Available features included a heads-up display, wide-view side and backup monitors, and a dual-screen rear-seat entertainment system. Safety technology expanded to include a pre-collision system, active front headrests, and available features like lane departure alert and intelligent high beam control. This generation introduced the F Sport package with sportier suspension tuning, unique 19-inch wheels, and distinctive interior and exterior styling elements. A 2012 facelift brought new headlights, taillights, grilles, and the introduction of the F Sport package with unique styling and performance enhancements. Throughout its production run, the second-generation RX 350 maintained its position as the bestselling Lexus model by offering a compelling combination of luxury, reliability, and practical utility.
Lexus-RX-350.name: Second Generation (AL10)

Lexus-RX-350.description: The third-generation RX 350 (part of the fourth-generation RX lineup) featured dramatically more aggressive styling with a massive spindle grille, sharp character lines, and a floating roof design created by blacked-out C-pillars. Offered in both standard and extended-length L versions (introduced in 2018 with three-row seating for up to seven passengers), it provided increased interior space and versatility. Powered by a refined 3.5-liter 2GR-FKS V6 engine producing 295 horsepower and 267 lb-ft of torque, paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission. The interior showcased Lexus's contemporary design approach with high-quality materials, available semi-aniline leather, and laser-cut wood trim accents. Technology features included an available 12.3-inch infotainment display, panoramic view monitor, color heads-up display, and a comprehensive suite of safety systems through Lexus Safety System+. A significant refresh in 2020 brought styling updates, touchscreen functionality replacing the Remote Touch controller, and enhanced driver assistance features including Lexus Safety System+ 2.0 with lane tracing assist. The RX 350 F Sport models featured adaptive variable suspension, more aggressive styling cues including a unique front fascia, and sport-tuned driving dynamics. Production ended in September 2022.
Lexus-RX-350.name: Third Generation (AL20)

Lexus-RX-350.description: The fourth-generation RX 350 (part of the fifth-generation RX lineup) represents a significant departure from previous models, built on Lexus's new TNGA GA-K platform offering improved structural rigidity, reduced weight, and enhanced driving dynamics. Notably, the powertrain shifts from the long-standing 3.5-liter V6 to a new 2.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine producing 275 horsepower and 317 lb-ft of torque—offering less horsepower but significantly more torque than its predecessor—paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission. Available in front-wheel drive or all-wheel drive configurations, it delivers improved fuel efficiency while maintaining strong performance. The exterior evolves Lexus's design language with a sleeker interpretation of the spindle grille (now called 'spindle body'), sharper body lines, and a connected taillight design. The interior features Lexus's new cockpit design philosophy centered around a standard 9.8-inch or available 14-inch touchscreen with the new Lexus Interface system, featuring wireless Apple CarPlay/Android Auto, cloud-based navigation, and voice assistant functionality with natural language processing. Advanced technology includes digital key capability, a panoramic view monitor, and traffic jam assist. Safety features expanded with Lexus Safety System+ 3.0 including enhanced pre-collision system, emergency driving stop system, and proactive driving assist. Available in both standard and F Sport configurations, with the latter offering distinctive styling elements, adaptive variable suspension, and performance dampers. The newest RX 350 balances the model's traditional strengths in comfort and refinement with improved driving dynamics and thoroughly modern technology.
Lexus-RX-350.name: Fourth Generation (ALA10)

Lexus-RX-450h.description: The first-generation Lexus RX 450h (part of the third-generation RX lineup) succeeded the pioneering RX 400h as Lexus's luxury hybrid SUV. Featuring a significantly improved Lexus Hybrid Drive system combining a 3.5-liter V6 engine with more powerful electric motors for a total system output of 295 horsepower, a 27 horsepower increase over its predecessor. The hybrid system utilized an Atkinson-cycle version of the V6, regenerative braking, and a nickel-metal hydride battery pack, paired with an electronically controlled continuously variable transmission (E-CVT). This powertrain delivered impressive fuel economy for a luxury SUV, with EPA ratings of 32 mpg city/28 mpg highway for front-wheel drive models and 30/28 mpg for all-wheel drive variants. The exterior styling matched the standard RX with aggressive lines and a distinctive grille, differentiated by subtle hybrid badging and blue-tinted Lexus emblems. The interior featured unique hybrid-specific displays and controls while maintaining the luxury appointments of the standard model. Available features included a heads-up display, wide-view side and backup monitors, and a Mark Levinson premium audio system. Safety technology included available features like a pre-collision system, lane departure alert, and intelligent high beam control. This generation established the RX 450h as the benchmark for luxury hybrid SUVs, offering environmentally conscious buyers a compelling combination of performance, efficiency, and Lexus refinement.
Lexus-RX-450h.name: First Generation (AL10)

Lexus-RX-450h.description: The second-generation RX 450h (part of the fourth-generation RX lineup) featured dramatically more aggressive styling with a massive spindle grille, sharp character lines, and a floating roof design created by blacked-out C-pillars. Available in both standard and extended-length L versions (introduced in 2018 with three-row seating), it offered increased interior space and versatility. Powered by an updated Lexus Hybrid Drive system combining a 3.5-liter V6 with more efficient electric motors for a total system output of 308 horsepower, paired with an electronically controlled continuously variable transmission (E-CVT). This system utilized improved power management and a more compact nickel-metal hydride battery pack that minimized intrusion into the cargo area. Fuel economy ratings were approximately 31 mpg city/28 mpg highway for the standard model and slightly lower for the L version. All-wheel drive was standard, using a dedicated electric motor for the rear wheels. The interior showcased Lexus's contemporary design with high-quality materials, available semi-aniline leather, and distinctive bamboo trim for hybrid models. Technology features included an available 12.3-inch infotainment display with Remote Touch controller, color heads-up display, and a comprehensive suite of safety systems through Lexus Safety System+. A significant refresh in 2020 brought styling updates, improved infotainment with touchscreen functionality replacing the Remote Touch controller, and enhanced driver assistance features. The F Sport package became available on the RX 450h for this generation, offering sportier suspension tuning, unique styling elements, and a more engaging driving experience while maintaining the efficiency of the hybrid powertrain. This generation continued the RX 450h's position as the benchmark luxury hybrid SUV, offering improved performance, technology, and styling while maintaining its focus on efficiency.
Lexus-RX-450h.name: Second Generation (AL20)

Lexus-RX-450h.description: For the fifth-generation RX lineup, the RX 450h nameplate has evolved into the plug-in hybrid RX 450h+, representing Lexus's first plug-in hybrid RX model. Built on Lexus's new GA-K platform offering improved structural rigidity, reduced weight, and enhanced driving dynamics. Powered by a sophisticated plug-in hybrid system combining a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine with electric motors and a lithium-ion battery pack, providing approximately 38 miles of all-electric driving range and a total system output of 304 horsepower. The system allows for electric-only operation at higher speeds than previous hybrid models, with multiple drive modes including an EV-priority mode. The exterior evolves Lexus's design language with a sleeker interpretation of the spindle grille (now called 'spindle body'), sharper body lines, and a connected taillight design, with subtle 'plug-in hybrid' badging. The interior features Lexus's new cockpit design philosophy centered around a standard 9.8-inch or available 14-inch touchscreen with the new Lexus Interface system, featuring wireless Apple CarPlay/Android Auto, cloud-based navigation, and voice assistant functionality. Advanced technology includes digital key capability, a panoramic view monitor, and traffic jam assist. Safety features expanded with Lexus Safety System+ 3.0 including enhanced pre-collision system, emergency driving stop system, and proactive driving assist. Charging capabilities include Level 1 (standard household outlet) and Level 2 (240V) compatibility, with charging status viewable remotely through the Lexus app. The RX 450h+ represents Lexus's commitment to electrification while maintaining the model's traditional strengths in luxury, refinement, and practical utility.
Lexus-RX-450h.name: Third Generation (PHEV)

Lexus-UX.description: The Lexus UX (Urban Explorer) was introduced as the brand's entry-level compact luxury crossover, positioned below the NX in size and price. Built on the Toyota New Global Architecture C (TNGA-C) platform shared with the Toyota C-HR and Corolla, it features a low center of gravity and rigid structure designed to deliver responsive handling. The UX was launched with two powertrain options: the UX 200 with a 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine producing 169 horsepower paired with a Direct-Shift CVT, and the UX 250h hybrid combining a 2.0-liter engine with electric motors for a total system output of 181 horsepower. The hybrid model features an innovative E-Four all-wheel drive system with a dedicated electric motor powering the rear wheels. The exterior design showcases Lexus's contemporary styling with an aggressive interpretation of the spindle grille, angular LED headlights, and a distinctive full-width taillight design. The interior offers a driver-focused cockpit with premium materials and available features including a 10.3-inch display with Remote Touch Interface, head-up display, and heated/ventilated seats. Advanced safety comes standard through Lexus Safety System+ 2.0 including pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, dynamic radar cruise control, and lane tracing assist. In 2020, the UX 300e became Lexus's first all-electric vehicle in select markets (not offered in North America), while a 2023 update introduced an improved infotainment system with touchscreen functionality replacing the Remote Touch controller. Throughout its production, the UX has targeted urban-dwelling luxury buyers seeking a premium compact crossover with distinctive styling, refined driving dynamics, and advanced technology in a city-friendly package.
Lexus-UX.name: First Generation

Lincoln-Aviator.description: The original Lincoln Aviator was introduced as a mid-size luxury SUV positioned between the Navigator and the smaller Mountaineer in Lincoln's lineup. Based on the Ford Explorer platform, it featured distinctive Lincoln styling cues including a prominent waterfall grille and wraparound headlights. Powered by a 4.6-liter DOHC V8 engine producing 302 horsepower and 300 lb-ft of torque, paired with a five-speed automatic transmission and available with rear-wheel or all-wheel drive. The interior offered three rows of seating for six to seven passengers with luxury appointments including standard leather upholstery, American walnut wood trim, and dual-zone automatic climate control. Available features included a DVD-based navigation system, rear-seat entertainment, and a THX-certified audio system. The vehicle was produced from 2002 to 2005, with the final vehicle produced on August 19, 2005. Despite its premium positioning and strong performance, the first-generation Aviator struggled to establish itself in the market, competing with both its Ford Explorer relative and the larger Navigator within Lincoln's own lineup. Production ended after just three model years, with Lincoln refocusing its SUV strategy on the more successful Navigator.
Lincoln-Aviator.name: First Generation (UN152)

Lincoln-Aviator.description: After a 15-year hiatus, the Lincoln Aviator returned for the 2020 model year as an all-new three-row mid-size luxury SUV, with production commencing on May 6, 2019. The second-generation model is built on the CD6 platform (derived from the Ford Explorer sixth generation U625) and represents a departure from shared platform styling with a distinctly differentiated design. The exterior features elegant styling with horizontal lines, a distinctive grille, and a sloping roofline that creates a more dynamic profile than typical SUVs. Standard power comes from a twin-turbocharged 3.0-liter EcoBoost V6 engine producing 400 horsepower and 415 lb-ft of torque, paired with a 10-speed SelectShift automatic transmission. The Grand Touring plug-in hybrid (PHEV) model combines the same twin-turbocharged engine with a permanent magnet synchronous electric motor for a total system output of 494 horsepower and 630 lb-ft of torque, equipped with a 13.6-kWh lithium-ion battery offering approximately 21 miles of electric-only range. The interior showcases Lincoln's 'Quiet Flight' design philosophy with premium materials including available 30-way Perfect Position seats with massage functionality, open-pore wood trim, and a minimalist dashboard centered around a 10.1-inch touchscreen. Advanced technology includes the Phone As A Key feature allowing smartphone control (with wireless charging for phones), a 28-speaker Revel Ultima 3D audio system, and Lincoln's Co-Pilot360 Plus suite of driver assistance features. Adaptive suspension with Road Preview uses a forward-facing camera to detect road imperfections and adjust damping accordingly. The Air Glide suspension can lower the vehicle for easier entry and loading. Notable packages include the Black Label collection offering curated interior theme options and exclusive ownership benefits.
Lincoln-Aviator.name: Second Generation (U611)

Lincoln-Aviator.description: The Lincoln Aviator received a mid-cycle refresh for the 2025 model year, revealed on February 5, 2024. The facelift features a redesigned front fascia with updated styling, a refreshed interior with new materials and technology integration, and redesigned headlights for improved visibility and aesthetic appeal. The plug-in hybrid Grand Touring trim was discontinued for 2025, leaving only the gasoline-powered variants. Despite the updates, the vehicle continues to use the CD6 platform and retains the twin-turbocharged 3.0-liter EcoBoost V6 engine with 400 horsepower and 415 lb-ft of torque, paired with the 10-speed SelectShift automatic transmission. The 2025 model year maintains Lincoln's 'Quiet Flight' design philosophy with premium interior appointments while addressing customer feedback with improved technology and comfort features.
Lincoln-Aviator.name: Second Generation (U611) [2025 Facelift]

Lincoln-Corsair.description: The Lincoln Corsair replaced the MKC as Lincoln's compact luxury SUV, aligning with the brand's shift to conventional naming rather than alphanumeric designations. Built on the Ford C2 platform shared with the fourth generation Ford Escape but substantially differentiated in design, features, and refinement to create a distinct luxury identity. The exterior features elegant proportions with horizontal lines, a distinctive Lincoln grille, and a sloping roofline, embodying Lincoln's 'Quiet Flight' design philosophy. Initially offered with two turbocharged four-cylinder engine options: a standard 2.0-liter producing 250 horsepower and an available 2.3-liter delivering 295 horsepower, both paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission. The Corsair went on sale in late 2019 with Standard and Reserve trims. The interior features an 8-inch infotainment screen running Lincoln Sync 3 software with a dashboard defined by an integrated air vent design spanning the width of the dashboard. Transmission is controlled using buttons mounted under the vents. Optional upgrades include a 12.3-inch fully digital gauge cluster with integrated navigation, 24-way 'Perfect Position' power seats, a 14-speaker Revel sound system, and a heads-up display. A driver assistance suite branded as 'Co-Pilot360' comes standard, including blind spot monitoring, automatic emergency braking and lane keep assist. The Grand Touring plug-in hybrid variant arrived in 2020, combining a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine with an electric motor for all-wheel drive and approximately 28 miles of electric-only range.
Lincoln-Corsair.name: First Generation

Lincoln-Corsair.description: The 2023 facelift brought significant updates to the Lincoln Corsair. Exterior changes include a new larger grille, LED daytime running lights, and new exterior colors. The interior receives a larger 13.2-inch touchscreen with Sync 4 software where the HVAC controls now reside, and the 12.3-inch fully digital instrument cluster is now standard across all trims. The base Standard trim has been renamed to Premiere. The 2.3-liter engine option was discontinued, while the 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder and plug-in hybrid Grand Touring remain available. The Corsair is now available with Lincoln's ActiveGlide hands-free advanced highway driving assistance system. Production concluded in December 2025 at the Louisville Assembly Plant, with Ford announcing discontinuation after the 2026 model year to make way for an all-electric pickup. The Corsair has been Lincoln's best-selling vehicle since its introduction.
Lincoln-Corsair.name: First Generation (2023 Facelift)

Lincoln-MKX.description: The first-generation Lincoln MKX was introduced as Lincoln's first entry into the mid-size luxury crossover segment, sharing its platform with the Ford Edge but differentiated with unique styling, upgraded interior materials, and additional luxury features. The exterior featured Lincoln's then-current design language with a prominent waterfall grille, distinctive headlights, and full-width taillights. Powered by a 3.5-liter V6 engine initially producing 265 horsepower (later increased to 285 hp in 2011), paired with a six-speed automatic transmission and available in front-wheel or all-wheel drive configurations. The interior offered five-passenger seating with standard leather upholstery, genuine wood trim, and a comprehensive suite of luxury amenities. Available features included a panoramic Vista Roof, heated and cooled front seats, and a THX II Certified audio system. A significant refresh for 2011 brought updated exterior styling with a split-wing grille, refined interior with improved materials and the new MyLincoln Touch infotainment system, and chassis improvements for better ride and handling. Safety features expanded throughout the generation to include blind spot monitoring, cross-traffic alert, and collision warning systems. The first-generation MKX established Lincoln in the rapidly growing luxury crossover segment, appealing to buyers seeking American luxury with practical utility in a car-based crossover format.
Lincoln-MKX.name: First Generation (U388)

Lincoln-MKX.description: The second-generation Lincoln MKX received a comprehensive redesign with more distinctive styling featuring a split-wing grille (later updated to Lincoln's new mesh grille design), more sculpted body lines, and LED lighting elements. Built on an improved platform shared with the Ford Edge, it offered enhanced ride quality, handling, and noise isolation. The standard 3.7-liter V6 engine produced 303 horsepower, while a new twin-turbocharged 2.7-liter EcoBoost V6 option delivered 335 horsepower and 380 lb-ft of torque, both paired with a six-speed automatic transmission. The interior was significantly upgraded with higher quality materials, improved design, and advanced technology including SYNC 3 infotainment with an 8-inch touchscreen. Premium features included available 22-way adjustable front seats with massage function, Revel Ultima audio system with 19 speakers, and a 360-degree camera system. Safety technology expanded with available adaptive cruise control, lane-keeping system, and pre-collision assist with pedestrian detection. A refresh for 2017 brought Lincoln's new signature grille design and additional refinements. In 2019, the MKX was renamed Nautilus as part of Lincoln's shift from alphanumeric designations to conventional names, marking the end of the MKX nameplate. The second-generation MKX represented a significant step forward in Lincoln's evolution as a modern luxury brand, offering more distinctive design, improved performance, and advanced technology.
Lincoln-MKX.name: Second Generation (U540)

Lincoln-MKZ.description: The Lincoln MKZ debuted as a rebadged and upgraded version of the Ford Fusion (initially called Lincoln Zephyr for 2006 before being renamed MKZ for 2007), marking Lincoln's entry into the mid-size luxury sedan segment. The exterior featured Lincoln's then-current design language with a prominent waterfall grille, distinctive headlights, and chrome accents. Initially powered by a 3.0-liter V6 producing 221 horsepower, it was upgraded to a 3.5-liter V6 with 263 horsepower in 2007, paired with a six-speed automatic transmission and available in front-wheel or all-wheel drive configurations. The interior offered five-passenger seating with standard leather upholstery, genuine wood trim, and a comprehensive suite of luxury amenities. A significant refresh for 2010 brought more distinctive styling with Lincoln's split-wing grille design, refined interior with improved materials, and new technology features including blind spot monitoring and the SYNC infotainment system. The MKZ Hybrid was introduced for 2011, combining a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine with an electric motor for a total system output of 191 horsepower, achieving 41 mpg city/36 mpg highway—the most fuel-efficient luxury sedan in America at the time. The first generation MKZ established Lincoln in the entry-luxury sedan segment, though it struggled to differentiate itself sufficiently from its Ford Fusion sibling.
Lincoln-MKZ.name: First Generation (CD3)

Lincoln-MKZ.description: The second-generation Lincoln MKZ represented a dramatic departure from its predecessor, featuring distinctive styling that significantly differentiated it from the Ford Fusion platform-mate. The exterior showcased Lincoln's new design direction with a split-wing grille, sleek profile, and a full-width LED taillight. Notable features included an available panoramic glass roof that retracted beyond the rear window, creating a convertible-like experience. Powertrain options expanded to include a standard 2.0-liter EcoBoost four-cylinder producing 240 horsepower, an optional 3.7-liter V6 with 300 horsepower (later replaced by a 3.0-liter twin-turbocharged V6 with 400 horsepower in 2017), and a hybrid system combining a 2.0-liter four-cylinder with an electric motor for 188 total horsepower and 41 mpg city/39 mpg highway. The interior featured a modern, flowing design with premium materials and a push-button gear selector that freed up console space. Technology included Lincoln's SYNC with MyLincoln Touch interface (later SYNC 3), available THX II Certified audio, and a suite of driver assistance features. A significant refresh for 2017 brought Lincoln's new signature grille design, the more powerful twin-turbo V6 option, and additional refinements to interior and technology features. The MKZ Reserve trim and Black Label collection offered curated design themes with premium materials and exclusive ownership benefits. The second-generation MKZ represented Lincoln's effort to establish a more distinctive luxury identity, though production ended in 2020 as Lincoln shifted focus toward its SUV lineup.
Lincoln-MKZ.name: Second Generation (CD4)

Lincoln-Nautilus.description: The first-generation Lincoln Nautilus debuted as a refreshed and renamed version of the second-generation Lincoln MKX, aligning with Lincoln's shift from alphanumeric designations to conventional names. The exterior featured Lincoln's signature mesh grille design, updated LED headlights, and revised styling elements that aligned it with newer Lincoln models like the Navigator and Aviator. Powertrain options included a standard 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder producing 250 horsepower and an available twin-turbocharged 2.7-liter V6 delivering 335 horsepower and 380 lb-ft of torque, both paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission replacing the previous six-speed. The interior maintained the same basic architecture as the MKX but received updates including a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster and new SYNC 3 infotainment system with standard Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. Premium features included available 22-way adjustable Ultra Comfort seats with massage function, Revel Ultima audio system with 19 speakers, and a panoramic sunroof. Safety technology expanded significantly with the standard Lincoln Co-Pilot360 suite including automatic emergency braking, blind spot detection, lane-keeping system, and automatic high beams, with available Plus package adding adaptive cruise control with lane centering and evasive steering assist. A refresh for 2021 brought a substantially redesigned interior with a new dashboard featuring a coast-to-coast horizontal design, a larger 13.2-inch touchscreen with SYNC 4 infotainment, and updated materials throughout the cabin. The first-generation Nautilus successfully bridged Lincoln's transition to its new design language and naming convention while competing in the highly competitive midsize luxury crossover segment.
Lincoln-Nautilus.name: First Generation (MKX Refresh)

Lincoln-Nautilus.description: The second-generation Lincoln Nautilus represents a comprehensive redesign that aligns it with Lincoln's newest design language and technology approach. The exterior features more fluid styling with a full-width LED light bar, illuminated Lincoln star emblem, and cleaner overall aesthetic compared to its predecessor. Built on a new platform, it offers improved proportions, driving dynamics, and interior space. The standard powertrain is a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine producing 250 horsepower, paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission, while a new hybrid powertrain combines a 2.0-liter four-cylinder with an electric motor for a total system output of 310 horsepower. The interior showcases Lincoln's most significant technology advancement with a massive 48-inch panoramic display spanning the entire dashboard—the largest display in Lincoln's lineup—complemented by a separate 11.1-inch touchscreen for climate, seat controls, and other vehicle functions. This curved OLED display features high-resolution graphics and can be configured to show different information based on driver preference. Premium appointments include available 24-way Perfect Position front seats with massage function, 28-speaker Revel Ultima 3D audio system, and high-quality materials throughout the cabin. Advanced driver assistance comes standard through Lincoln Co-Pilot360 2.0 with available ActiveGlide hands-free highway driving capability on pre-mapped routes. The Black Label trim offers exclusive interior themes, premium materials, and unique ownership privileges. The second-generation Nautilus elevates Lincoln's midsize luxury crossover offering with distinctive technology, refined design, and electrified powertrain options, competing directly with established luxury competitors while offering a uniquely American take on modern luxury.
Lincoln-Nautilus.name: Second Generation

Lincoln-Navigator.description: The original Lincoln Navigator established the full-size luxury SUV segment in the American market, based on the Ford Expedition but with distinctive styling and luxury appointments. Powered by a 5.4-liter V8 engine initially producing 230 horsepower (increased to 300 horsepower in 1999), paired with a four-speed automatic transmission. The exterior featured Lincoln's signature waterfall grille, complex reflector headlights, and substantial chrome accents. The interior offered three rows of leather seating for up to eight passengers, genuine wood trim, and premium audio. Notable features included power-adjustable pedals, automatic climate control, and available satellite navigation—cutting-edge technology for the time. The Navigator's success surprised Lincoln, outselling its German rivals and inspiring competition from American and Japanese manufacturers. This first generation established the Navigator as Lincoln's flagship SUV and helped reshape the American luxury vehicle market by demonstrating the viability of premium SUVs as alternatives to traditional luxury sedans.
Lincoln-Navigator.name: First Generation (UN173)

Lincoln-Navigator.description: The second-generation Navigator featured more refined styling with a larger grille, more substantial chrome accents, and improved aerodynamics. Riding on a new platform shared with the Ford Expedition, it offered better handling, improved ride quality, and the addition of an independent rear suspension—a significant upgrade providing better ride comfort and allowing for a lower, flat-folding third row. Powered by a revised 5.4-liter V8 producing 300 horsepower paired with a four-speed automatic transmission (upgraded to a six-speed in 2005). The interior was completely redesigned with higher quality materials, improved ergonomics, and advanced features including a power-folding third row—an industry first. Available technology included a DVD-based navigation system, rear-seat entertainment, and a THX-certified audio system. Safety features expanded with available safety canopy side curtain airbags, reverse sensing system, and AdvanceTrac stability control. This generation refined the Navigator's formula with improved luxury features and driving dynamics while maintaining its position as Lincoln's flagship SUV.
Lincoln-Navigator.name: Second Generation (U228)

Lincoln-Navigator.description: The third-generation Navigator featured more formal styling with Lincoln's distinctive chrome grille, complex headlight designs, and substantial chrome accents throughout. Available in standard and extended-length L versions, it offered improved interior space particularly for third-row passengers and cargo capacity. Powered by a 5.4-liter V8 engine producing 310 horsepower (updated to a more efficient 3.5-liter EcoBoost V6 with 380 horsepower in 2015), paired with a six-speed automatic transmission. The interior was significantly upgraded with higher quality materials, improved design, and advanced technology including SYNC voice command system (later MyLincoln Touch), THX II Certified audio, and a rear-seat entertainment system. Notable features included power-deployable running boards, a power liftgate, and available 20-inch chrome wheels. A significant refresh in 2015 brought revised styling, the new EcoBoost powertrain, and updated technology features. Throughout its extended production run, this generation maintained its position in the market despite increasing competition, though it gradually fell behind newer rivals in technology and efficiency toward the end of its lifecycle.
Lincoln-Navigator.name: Third Generation (U326)

Lincoln-Navigator.description: The current Navigator represents a comprehensive redesign that reestablished Lincoln as a serious contender in the ultra-luxury SUV segment. The exterior features distinctive styling with a prominent grille, full-LED lighting, and a more dynamic profile despite its substantial size. Available in standard and extended-length L versions, it offers exceptional interior space across all three rows. Powered by a twin-turbocharged 3.5-liter EcoBoost V6 producing 440 horsepower (updated to 450 hp for 2022) and 510 lb-ft of torque, paired with a 10-speed automatic transmission and available with rear-wheel or four-wheel drive. The chassis features an independent rear suspension with available adaptive damping, providing a refined ride quality despite its truck-based platform. The interior showcases Lincoln's modern luxury approach with 30-way Perfect Position front seats with massage function, genuine wood trim, and a floating center console design. Technology includes a 12-inch digital instrument cluster, 13.2-inch SYNC 4 touchscreen (updated from 10-inch SYNC 3 for 2022), standard Wi-Fi hotspot, and available rear-seat entertainment system. The Black Label trim offers curated interior themes with premium materials and exclusive ownership benefits. A refresh for 2022 brought updated exterior styling, a larger infotainment display with SYNC 4, and expanded technology including hands-free ActiveGlide driver assistance for highway driving. The fourth-generation Navigator redefined Lincoln's flagship SUV with distinctive design, advanced technology, and refined luxury, successfully competing with premium offerings from European and other American manufacturers.
Lincoln-Navigator.name: Fourth Generation (U554)

Lincoln-Navigator.description: The fifth-generation Navigator was revealed on August 15, 2024, with sales commencing in the first half of 2025. It shares styling features with the Lincoln Aviator and Nautilus, featuring an illuminated light bar on the grille and full-width LED taillights with Lincoln Embrace welcoming sequence upon vehicle approach. For the first time, the Navigator is available with 24-inch alloy wheels. The interior features Lincoln Digital Experience user interface with a revolutionary 48-inch full-width display spanning across the top of the dashboard with Google built-in integration. A 11.1-inch touchscreen serves as the primary control panel. Other interior features include a 28-speaker Revel Ultima 3D Audio System, Lincoln Digital Scent technology, Lincoln Rejuvenate wellness system, and Second-Row Power Tailored Seats with massage option. The independent rear glass opening feature has been replaced with a Split Gate featuring Open on Approach capability. A Cargo Tailgate Manager can be positioned as a bench seatback or dining table. The fifth generation features power folding third row seats with 40/20/40 split configuration. All models are powered by the twin-turbocharged 3.5-liter EcoBoost V6 gasoline engine carried over from the previous generation, with standard four-wheel drive and adaptive suspension with continuously controlled dampening. Safety features include Lincoln BlueCruise hands-free advanced safety assistance system (ADAS) as standard, alongside new driving assistance features such as Turn Signal View and Intersection Assist. The fifth-generation Navigator continues Lincoln's commitment to delivering advanced technology, refined luxury, and exceptional capability in the premium full-size SUV segment.
Lincoln-Navigator.name: Fifth Generation (U718)

Lincoln-Town-Car.description: The original Lincoln Town Car debuted as a distinct model after previously serving as a trim package for the Continental. Based on Ford's Panther platform, it exemplified traditional American luxury with its formal upright styling, vinyl roof, and substantial chrome accents. Powered by a 5.0-liter V8 engine paired with a four-speed automatic transmission, it emphasized smooth, quiet operation over performance. The spacious interior featured plush bench seating for six passengers, wood-tone accents, and luxury amenities including power features, automatic climate control, and premium sound systems. The Town Car maintained classic rear-wheel-drive, body-on-frame construction when many competitors were transitioning to front-wheel-drive platforms. This generation established the Town Car as Lincoln's flagship sedan, appealing to traditional luxury buyers and fleet operators with its comfort, durability, and imposing presence. A significant refresh in 1985 brought more modern aerodynamic styling with flush-mounted headlights and a more rounded profile while maintaining its formal luxury character.
Lincoln-Town-Car.name: First Generation (FN36/FN5)

Lincoln-Town-Car.description: The second-generation Town Car featured dramatically more aerodynamic styling with rounded edges, smoother surfacing, and a sloping trunk lid, though it maintained its formal luxury character with a chrome waterfall grille, stand-up hood ornament, and available vinyl roof treatments. Built on an updated version of the Panther platform, it continued with rear-wheel drive and body-on-frame construction. Initially powered by a 5.0-liter V8 (replaced by a more modern 4.6-liter V8 in 1991) producing 190-210 horsepower depending on the year, paired with a four-speed automatic transmission. The redesigned interior maintained its spacious six-passenger seating with front and rear bench seats, adding more modern controls, improved materials, and updated technology including available JBL audio systems, digital instrumentation, and keyless entry. Trim levels included Executive, Signature, and the top-level Cartier with exclusive features and badging. Safety advancements included standard driver and eventually passenger airbags, anti-lock brakes, and available traction control. This generation continued the Town Car's popularity with traditional luxury buyers, fleet services, and the livery industry, though it faced increasing competition from imported luxury sedans that offered more modern driving dynamics and technology.
Lincoln-Town-Car.name: Second Generation (FN36/FN5)

Lincoln-Town-Car.description: The final generation Town Car maintained its traditional full-size luxury formula while receiving more substantial updates to its styling, structure, and features. The exterior featured sharper edges, a more vertical grille design, and complex reflector headlights, with subtle styling refreshes in 2003 and 2008 to keep it current. Built on a revised Panther platform with significant structural improvements, it offered enhanced safety, better ride quality, and improved handling. Powered by a 4.6-liter V8 engine producing 200-239 horsepower depending on the year and specification, paired with a four-speed automatic transmission. The interior maintained its spacious six-passenger configuration while adding more modern appointments, improved materials, and updated technology. Available features included premium leather seating, Alpine or THX audio systems, heated seats, and dual-zone climate control. Trim levels evolved throughout this generation, with Signature and Ultimate series replacing the Executive/Signature/Cartier hierarchy in later years. The long-wheelbase L version, introduced in 2001, offered six additional inches of rear legroom specifically targeting the livery market. Despite decreasing retail sales as consumer preferences shifted toward SUVs and more modern luxury sedans, the Town Car maintained steady fleet sales until its discontinuation in 2011, ending a 30-year run as Lincoln's flagship traditional American luxury sedan. Throughout its final generation, the Town Car remained prized for its comfort, durability, and spaciousness, particularly in commercial applications.
Lincoln-Town-Car.name: Third Generation (FN145)

Lucid-Air.description: The Lucid Air represents the debut production vehicle from Lucid Motors, establishing new benchmarks for electric vehicle efficiency, performance, and luxury. Built on Lucid's proprietary Electric Advanced Platform (LEAP), it features a purpose-built EV architecture with a skateboard-style battery pack and compact powertrain components developed in-house. The exterior design achieves a remarkably low 0.21 drag coefficient while maintaining an elegant, distinctive aesthetic with its sleek profile, full-width light bars front and rear, and micro-lens array LED headlights. The spacious interior, made possible by the compact powertrain, offers executive-level rear seating and a unique glass canopy roof creating an open, airy environment. Technology showcases include a curved 34-inch 5K floating Glass Cockpit display complemented by a retractable Pilot Panel for additional controls, over-the-air update capability, and the DreamDrive Pro advanced driver assistance suite with up to 32 sensors including LiDAR. Multiple variants offer different performance levels, from the single-motor Pure (480 hp) to the dual-motor Touring (620 hp), Grand Touring (819 hp), and range-topping tri-motor Sapphire (1,234 hp) that accelerates from 0-60 mph in under 2 seconds. The Grand Touring configuration achieved an EPA-rated range of 516 miles—the longest of any electric vehicle—while 900V electrical architecture enables charging at rates up to 300 kW, adding up to 200 miles of range in just 12 minutes. The Lucid Air has received numerous accolades including 2022 MotorTrend Car of the Year, establishing Lucid Motors as a significant new player in the luxury electric vehicle market by combining exceptional engineering, performance, and refinement in a distinctive package that challenges established luxury manufacturers.
Lucid-Air.name: First Generation

MG-Comet.description: The MG Comet EV is a rebadged version of the Wuling Air EV, launched in India by MG Motor in April 2023. Based on the SGMW Global Small Electric Vehicle (GSEV) platform, it is a compact 3-door hatchback designed for urban mobility. The vehicle features a rear-motor, rear-wheel-drive layout and is marketed as an affordable electric city car targeting congested urban environments. The Comet EV represents MG's strategy to expand into emerging EV markets with accessible, city-focused electric vehicles.
MG-Comet.name: First Generation

MG-HS.description: The first-generation MG HS was introduced as MG's flagship SUV in many markets, representing the brand's push upmarket with improved quality, design, and technology. Built on the SAIC platform also used for the Roewe RX5, the HS featured European-influenced styling with a large grille featuring the iconic MG logo, sleek LED headlights, and a refined profile intended to compete with established C-segment SUVs. The exterior dimensions positioned it firmly in the compact crossover segment, with a length of approximately 4.6 meters and width of 1.9 meters. Powertrain options varied by market but typically included a 1.5-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine producing around 160-169 horsepower and 250 Nm of torque, paired with either a 6-speed manual or 7-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission. Some markets also received a 2.0-liter turbocharged variant with approximately 231 horsepower. The interior represented a significant step up for the MG brand, featuring soft-touch materials, a driver-focused dashboard design with a 10.1-inch central touchscreen, and available leather upholstery. Technology features included the MG Pilot suite of advanced driver assistance systems offering adaptive cruise control, lane keeping assist, and autonomous emergency braking. In 2020, a plug-in hybrid variant was introduced in some markets, combining the 1.5-liter turbocharged engine with an electric motor for a total system output of around 258 horsepower and an electric-only range of approximately 52 kilometers. The facelifted MG Pilot version was introduced in September 2020 at Auto China Beijing, featuring updated styling and enhanced technology. The first-generation HS helped establish MG's position in the competitive compact SUV market by offering premium features and styling at a value price point compared to Japanese and European competitors.
MG-HS.name: First Generation

MG-HS.description: The refreshed MG HS received styling updates and technology enhancements while maintaining the same fundamental platform and dimensions. Exterior changes included a revised front fascia with a larger grille featuring a new mesh pattern, updated LED headlights with a more angular design, and restyled bumpers. The rear received subtle updates including revised taillight signatures and bumper design. Inside, the most significant changes came to the technology package, with an updated infotainment system featuring improved graphics, processing power, and connectivity features including wireless smartphone integration in many markets. The center console was redesigned with a new electronic gear selector in automatic models, additional storage options, and improved material quality. The MG Pilot advanced driver assistance suite was enhanced with improved functionality and additional features in some markets. Powertrain options remained largely similar to the pre-facelift model, with the 1.5-liter turbocharged engine continuing as the primary offering, alongside the plug-in hybrid variant in select regions. Additional comfort features were added to higher trim levels, including ventilated seats, panoramic sunroof, and premium audio systems. The refreshed HS maintains the original's focus on offering near-premium features at mainstream pricing, helping MG continue its growth in competitive global markets while addressing some criticisms of the pre-facelift model regarding technology and interior design.
MG-HS.name: First Generation (Facelift)

MG-HS.description: The second-generation MG HS was unveiled on July 11, 2024 at the Goodwood Festival of Speed, representing a complete redesign based on the Chinese market second-generation Roewe RX5. The new model features enhanced design language with modern styling, expanded powertrain options including electrification, and significant improvements in technology and interior quality. The exterior design showcases a more aggressive front fascia with a prominent grille, sleek LED lighting elements, and a sportier overall profile compared to its predecessor. Inside, the cabin features a fully digital instrument cluster, a large central touchscreen with improved infotainment functionality, and higher-quality materials throughout. Powertrain options include a 1.5-liter turbocharged petrol engine (169 hp / 125 kW) paired with either a 6-speed manual or 7-speed DCT, a Hybrid+ variant producing 224 PS (165 kW) with a 2-speed DHT transmission, and a PHEV variant with 303 hp (226 kW) total output and approximately 113 km electric range. Performance figures include 0-62 mph in 6.8 seconds for the PHEV and a top speed of 190 km/h (118 mph). The second-generation HS is offered in various trim levels globally including Vibe, Excite, Essence (Australia), SE, Trophy (UK), and Comfort, Luxury (South Africa). MG continues to position the HS above the subcompact ZS in its global lineup, backed by a seven-year, 80,000-mile warranty coverage.
MG-HS.name: Second Generation

MG-Hector.description: The MG Hector marked the British brand's reentry into the Indian market under Chinese ownership (SAIC Motor), positioned as a mid-size SUV competing in the popular segment. Based on the Baojun 530 sold in China, the Hector featured distinctive styling with a large chrome-studded grille, split LED daytime running lights positioned above the main headlamp units, and prominent chrome trim. Available with multiple powertrain options including a 1.5-liter turbocharged petrol engine producing 143 horsepower, a 1.5-liter petrol with a 48V mild hybrid system for improved efficiency, and a 2.0-liter diesel engine delivering 170 horsepower. Transmission options included a 6-speed manual, a 6-speed dual-clutch automatic for petrol variants, and a 6-speed manual for diesel models. The Hector's standout feature was its technology package, dubbed 'Internet Inside,' which included a 10.4-inch portrait-oriented touchscreen infotainment system with embedded SIM for connected features, voice commands, over-the-air updates, and remote vehicle controls through a smartphone app. Interior space was generous with a focus on rear seat comfort, featuring reclining rear seats and ample legroom. Safety features included up to six airbags, electronic stability control, traction control, and a 360-degree camera on higher variants. The first-generation Hector became a significant player in the Indian market, helping establish MG as a technology-focused brand competing with established players like Hyundai and Tata.
MG-Hector.name: First Generation

MG-Hector.description: The updated MG Hector received comprehensive styling and feature upgrades while maintaining the same basic platform and dimensions. Most notably, the front fascia was redesigned with an even more prominent 'Argyle-inspired' diamond mesh grille extending across the front end, updated LED headlamps, and revised bumpers. The rear received new connected LED taillights with a chrome strip running across the tailgate. The most significant enhancements came inside, with a completely redesigned dashboard centered around a larger 14-inch portrait-oriented touchscreen infotainment system—the largest in its segment. The updated system features improved processing power, wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, and enhanced connected car features including more advanced voice commands supporting over 100 functions. New luxury features include a 7-inch digital instrument cluster, wireless phone charging, ventilated front seats, a 360-degree camera with blind spot view monitor, and a premium Infinity audio system with eight speakers. Safety technology expanded with the addition of Level 2 ADAS (Advanced Driver Assistance Systems) including adaptive cruise control, lane keep assist, forward collision warning, automatic emergency braking, and traffic sign recognition. Powertrain options remained similar to the previous generation, with 1.5-liter turbocharged petrol (with and without mild hybrid technology) and 2.0-liter diesel engines paired with manual or automatic transmissions. Interior space continues to be a strength, with the five-seater version offering generous passenger room and cargo capacity. The refreshed Hector builds on the success of its predecessor by focusing on enhanced technology, luxury features, and safety equipment to maintain its competitive position in the crowded mid-size SUV segment.
MG-Hector.name: Second Generation (Facelift)

MG-MG4.description: The MG4 Electric (known as the MG Mulan in China) represents MG's first purpose-built electric vehicle based on parent company SAIC's new Modular Scalable Platform (MSP), designed specifically for electric vehicles. This compact hatchback features distinctive, angular styling with sharp character lines, a striking two-tone roof, and a full-width LED light bar at the rear. With a length of approximately 4.3 meters and low-slung proportions, the MG4 offers a sportier stance than typical MG models. The unique battery architecture utilizes an extremely thin (just 110mm) horizontally-mounted battery pack that enables both a low center of gravity and generous interior space. Initially offered with two battery options: a 51kWh version providing approximately 217-218 miles of range (WLTP) and a 64kWh version offering up to 281 miles. The electric motor is mounted at the rear, making the MG4 MG's first rear-wheel drive passenger car in decades, producing either 168 horsepower in the standard version or 201 horsepower in the long-range variant. Later additions to the lineup included the high-performance XPower variant with dual motors, all-wheel drive, and 429 horsepower, capable of 0-62 mph in 3.8 seconds. The interior features a minimalist, modern design with a floating 10.25-inch infotainment screen, 7-inch digital instrument cluster, and a clean dashboard layout. Advanced technology includes MG Pilot driver assistance systems with adaptive cruise control, lane keeping assistance, and traffic jam assist. Charging capabilities support up to 135kW DC fast charging, enabling a 10-80% charge in approximately 35 minutes for the long-range version. The MG4 Electric represents MG's most technologically advanced vehicle to date and a significant step in the brand's evolution, offering competitive range, performance, and features at a value price point compared to established electric competitors.
MG-MG4.name: First Generation

MG-One.description: The MG One represents the British brand's (now under Chinese ownership by SAIC Motor) foray into the competitive compact crossover segment with a focus on sporty styling and modern technology. Built on SAIC's new SIGMA architecture, it features a distinctive design language with a large 'Digital Flaming Grille,' sharp LED headlights, flowing character lines, and a coupe-like roofline with contrast color options for the roof. Available in two distinct visual themes: sporty 'Fashionable' with more aggressive styling elements and 'Sporty' with additional gray trim and more rugged aesthetic touches. Dimensionally, it measures approximately 4.6 meters long by 1.9 meters wide, positioning it as a C-segment crossover. Powered by a 1.5-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine producing approximately 180 horsepower and 285 Nm of torque, paired with a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission driving the front wheels. The interior highlights technology with a minimalist design centered around a floating 10.25-inch infotainment touchscreen and a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, featuring MG's new SAIC Motor 'SOA' intelligent technology architecture supporting over-the-air updates and expanded connectivity features. Safety technology includes MG Pilot advanced driver assistance systems with various active safety features. The MG One targets younger buyers with its combination of striking design, technology focus, and accessible pricing, helping expand MG's global presence in competitive markets including Southeast Asia, Australia, South America, and the Middle East, though it's not offered in all markets where the brand operates.
MG-One.name: First Generation

MG-ZS.description: The first-generation MG ZS compact crossover SUV played a crucial role in MG's global market expansion under SAIC Motor's ownership. It featured a distinctive design with the 'London Eye' headlights, diamond-pattern grille, and flowing character lines. Dimensionally, it competed in the compact crossover segment with a length of approximately 4.3 meters. Powertrain options varied by market but typically included a 1.5-liter naturally aspirated four-cylinder producing around 106 horsepower or a 1.0-liter turbocharged three-cylinder generating approximately 111 horsepower. Transmission choices included a 5-speed manual, 6-speed manual, 4-speed automatic, or 6-speed automatic depending on engine and market. The interior offered a surprising amount of space for its class, with features uncommon at its price point including an 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system (with Apple CarPlay on higher trims), a panoramic sunroof on premium variants, and synthetic leather upholstery options. Safety features included stability control, hill-start assist, and a tire pressure monitoring system, though advanced driver assistance systems were limited. The ZS established itself as a value proposition in the competitive compact crossover segment, contributing significantly to MG's sales growth in markets such as the UK, Thailand, Australia, and India. In 2019, the ZS EV was introduced, representing MG's first all-electric vehicle, with a 44.5 kWh battery providing a WLTP range of approximately 163 miles.
MG-ZS.name: First Generation

MG-ZS.description: The refreshed MG ZS received substantial styling updates and technology improvements while maintaining the same fundamental platform. The exterior adopted a more modern design language with a larger hexagonal grille, redesigned LED headlights with new daytime running light signatures, revised bumpers, and updated taillights connected by a chrome strip. The interior saw significant enhancements including a larger 10.1-inch floating touchscreen with improved graphics and functionality, a redesigned instrument cluster with a larger digital display, and upgraded materials throughout the cabin. The powertrain lineup was updated in many markets to include a new 1.3-liter turbocharged engine producing approximately 161 horsepower and 230 Nm of torque, paired with a 6-speed automatic transmission, offering improved performance over the previous engines. The 1.5-liter naturally aspirated option continued in some markets with refinements for better efficiency. Technology features expanded to include a 360-degree parking camera system on higher trims, enhanced connected car features, and improved smartphone integration. Safety was enhanced with the addition of MG Pilot, a suite of advanced driver assistance systems including adaptive cruise control, lane keep assist, traffic jam assist, intelligent high beam control, and autonomous emergency braking on higher specifications. The ZS EV also received updates with a larger 51.1 kWh battery extending range to approximately 198 miles (WLTP) and later a 72.6 kWh Long Range version with up to 273 miles of range. The refreshed ZS continued MG's strategy of offering competitive features and technology at accessible price points, helping the model maintain strong sales performance in an increasingly crowded segment.
MG-ZS.name: Second Generation (Facelift)

MG-ZS-EV.description: Pre-facelift MG ZS EV with 44.5 kWh battery and 110 kW front motor. Introduced as EZS at the 2018 Guangzhou Auto Show, marketed as MG ZS EV globally except in China where it retained the EZS name. Available in Excite and Exclusive trim levels.
MG-ZS-EV.name: First Generation

MG-ZS-EV.description: Facelifted MG ZS EV introduced in late 2021 with updated styling, larger 72.6 kWh battery (and 51 kWh LFP option in some markets), and new trim levels. Features redesigned front fascia, updated interior with 10.1-inch infotainment screen, and enhanced autonomous safety features.
MG-ZS-EV.name: First Generation Facelift

MINI-Clubman.description: The first-generation MINI Clubman reimagined the classic Mini Traveller/Clubman Estate for the modern era, featuring an extended wheelbase compared to the standard MINI Hatch with unique split rear doors (called 'Splitdoor') and a single rear-hinged door on the driver's side (called 'Clubdoor') to aid rear passenger access. Built on the R56 MINI platform but lengthened by about 240mm, it maintained the distinctive MINI design language with round headlights, hexagonal grille, and floating roof. Powertrains mirrored the standard MINI lineup, including a 1.6-liter naturally aspirated engine in the Cooper producing 120 horsepower, a turbocharged 1.6 in the Cooper S with 175 horsepower, and various diesel options in European markets. The John Cooper Works version arrived in 2008 with 211 horsepower. The interior featured the quirky, retro-inspired design characteristic of BMW-era MINIs, with a large central speedometer, toggle switches, and unique circular design elements, while offering more cargo space than the standard Hatch—from 260 liters to 930 liters with rear seats folded. The R55 Clubman successfully expanded the MINI range beyond the basic Hardtop model, appealing to buyers who wanted MINI's distinctive character and driving dynamics but needed more practicality.
MINI-Clubman.name: First Generation (R55)

MINI-Clubman.description: The second-generation MINI Clubman underwent a significant transformation, adopting a conventional six-door layout with four traditional side doors and twin barn doors at the rear, abandoning the asymmetrical Clubdoor of its predecessor. Substantially larger than the first generation, it grew by nearly 270mm in length and 73mm in width, positioning it more clearly as a compact wagon rather than an extended hatchback. Built on BMW's UKL2 platform shared with the BMW X1 and 2 Series Active Tourer, it featured more sophisticated underpinnings with a focus on improved refinement and driving dynamics. The exterior design evolved MINI's styling language with a broader stance, elongated profile, and distinctive horizontal taillights—a departure from the vertical lights used on other MINI models. Powertrain options included three-cylinder and four-cylinder turbocharged engines, with the base Cooper using a 1.5-liter three-cylinder producing 134 horsepower, the Cooper S featuring a 2.0-liter four-cylinder with 189 horsepower (later increased to 192 hp), and the John Cooper Works model topping the range with up to 306 horsepower. Diesel options were available in European markets until later model years. All engines could be paired with either a six-speed manual or eight-speed automatic transmission, with ALL4 all-wheel drive available on higher performance models. The interior adopted MINI's more mature design approach with higher quality materials, enhanced technology including an 8.8-inch touchscreen with navigation on higher trims, and significantly improved sound insulation. A mid-cycle refresh in 2019 brought subtle styling updates, improved technology, and minor powertrain refinements. The second-generation Clubman elevated the model's premium positioning while significantly enhancing its practicality and versatility, appealing to buyers seeking a distinctive alternative to conventional compact wagons and crossovers.
MINI-Clubman.name: Second Generation (F54)

MINI-Cooper.description: The first modern MINI Cooper marked BMW's revival of the iconic British brand, reimagining the classic Mini with modern technology and safety standards while maintaining its distinctive character. The standard Cooper (R50) featured a 1.6-liter Tritec engine producing 115 horsepower, while the high-performance Cooper S (R53) utilized a supercharged version generating 163 horsepower (later increased to 170 hp). The exterior design successfully translated the original Mini's iconic styling cues—including the round headlights, floating roof, and compact dimensions—into a larger, more modern package. The interior featured a distinctive retro-futuristic design with a large central speedometer, toggle switches, and circular theme throughout.
