Despite its small footprint, the R50/R53 offered surprising interior space efficiency and engaging driving dynamics characterized by the famous 'go-kart feel.' Advanced features for the time included a CVT automatic transmission option, run-flat tires, and various luxury amenities unusual in small cars. The first-generation established the reborn MINI as a premium small car with strong emphasis on customization, offering numerous appearance packages, trim options, and accessories allowing buyers to personalize their vehicles. This generation laid the foundation for MINI's successful expansion under BMW ownership, proving that a premium small car could succeed in the modern market.
MINI-Cooper.name: First Generation (R50/R53)

MINI-Cooper.description: The second-generation MINI Cooper refined the formula established by its predecessor with evolutionary styling changes and significant mechanical updates. Introduced in July 2006, the Cooper now featured a 1.6-liter Prince engine co-developed with PSA Peugeot Citroën, producing 118 horsepower in naturally aspirated form, while the Cooper S switched from supercharging to turbocharging, generating 172 horsepower (later increased to 181 hp) with improved efficiency. Exterior styling maintained the iconic MINI aesthetic with subtle refinements including a longer front overhang to meet pedestrian safety regulations, reshaped headlights, and more pronounced wheel arches. The interior continued the quirky, retro-inspired design with an even larger central speedometer incorporating entertainment and navigation functions, improved materials, and expanded technology options. New features included keyless ignition, ambient lighting, and a more sophisticated optional navigation system. Customization options expanded further with additional paint colors, roof designs, interior trims, and special editions. Despite increasing slightly in size, the R56 maintained MINI's characteristic nimble handling while offering improved comfort, reduced noise levels, and enhanced safety features. This generation broadened MINI's appeal by balancing the brand's distinctive character with increased refinement and practicality. Production ended in November 2013 for the hatchback, with the convertible variant continuing until 2015.
MINI-Cooper.name: Second Generation (R56)

MINI-Cooper.description: The third-generation MINI Cooper represented a more substantial redesign, built on BMW's new UKL1 front-wheel-drive platform shared with several BMW models. Unveiled in November 2013 with sales beginning in early 2014, it grew in length, width, and wheelbase to improve passenger space and crash protection. Powertrains were completely revised, with the base Cooper now featuring a 1.5-liter turbocharged three-cylinder engine producing 136 horsepower, while the Cooper S utilized a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder generating 192 horsepower. Both engines incorporated BMW's TwinPower Turbo technology for improved efficiency and performance. The exterior design evolved with more rounded forms, larger headlights with optional LED rings, a more prominent grille, and more substantial proportions overall. The interior received a significant modernization with a more conventional instrument cluster positioned behind the steering wheel, a separate 6.5-inch (later 8.8-inch) infotainment display, and higher quality materials throughout. Technology advanced considerably with options including head-up display, active cruise control, collision and pedestrian warning systems, parking assistant, and enhanced connectivity features. A refreshed version was introduced in 2018 with subtle design updates, improved technology, and the addition of a dual-clutch transmission option. A battery-electric version, the Mini Electric (Cooper SE), was launched in 2020. Another refresh, the second Life Cycle Impulse (LCI), was released in 2021 with additional styling and technical updates. This generation maintained MINI's distinctive character and customization options while delivering more refinement, technology, and practicality, positioning the brand more clearly in the premium small car segment. Production ended in 2024, with the combustion-engine variant replaced by the fourth-generation F65/66/67 series.
MINI-Cooper.name: Third Generation (F56)

MINI-Cooper.description: The fourth-generation MINI Cooper introduces a new design language and platform strategy, diverging into distinct combustion-engine (F65/66/67) and battery-electric (J01) variants. The battery-electric J01 Cooper was unveiled in September 2023 with production starting in October 2023, marketed as the 2024-2025 model year. Developed and produced by Spotlight Automotive in China, the J01 features a simplified interior dominated by a fully circular OLED touchscreen display based on the OS9 operating system. Available as the Cooper E and Cooper SE, the J01 offers different battery capacities: the Cooper E with a 40.7 kWh battery (135 kW/184 hp, 305 km/190 mile range) and the Cooper SE with a 54.2 kWh battery (160 kW/218 hp, 402 km/250 mile range), plus a JCW Electric variant with 190 kW/258 hp. The combustion-engine F65/66/67 was introduced in March 2024 as a heavily refreshed version of the third generation, maintaining similar dimensions and UKL1 platform underpinnings. The F66 (3-door) is available in Cooper C and Cooper S trims with a 1.5-liter turbocharged three-cylinder (156 hp) and 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder (204 hp) respectively, paired with a 7-speed dual-clutch transmission. The F65 is the 5-door variant and the F67 is the convertible. The exterior design returns to a cleaner, more minimalist aesthetic inspired by the original Mini, featuring a rounded silhouette, more vertical front end, shorter overhangs, and simplified surfaces. The iconic circular headlights remain but are now framed in a more rectangular outline. Production of the electric J01 is set to begin at the Oxford Plant in 2026. This generation represents MINI's transition toward electrification while maintaining traditional combustion engine options, balancing the brand's heritage with modern technology and sustainability objectives.
MINI-Cooper.name: Fourth Generation (J01/F65/66/67)

MINI-Cooper-S.description: The first modern MINI Cooper S established the performance variant of BMW's reimagined MINI, featuring a supercharged 1.6-liter Tritec engine producing 163 horsepower (later increased to 170 hp) and 155 lb-ft of torque, paired with a standard six-speed Getrag manual transmission or optional six-speed automatic. Distinguished from the standard Cooper by its functional hood scoop (feeding the intercooler), more aggressive body styling, twin center-exit exhaust, and unique 16-inch or 17-inch wheel designs. Performance was brisk with 0-60 mph times of approximately 7.0 seconds and a top speed around 135 mph. The suspension was specially tuned with firmer springs, stiffer damping, and larger anti-roll bars, delivering the exceptional handling dynamics that quickly established the model's reputation. Additional performance features included larger brake discs and standard traction control. Special edition models included the Cooper S Works (with a factory-approved John Cooper Works package boosting output to 200 horsepower) and the limited-production Cooper S GP with reduced weight, aerodynamic enhancements, and exclusive features. The R53 Cooper S proved that a modern small car could deliver premium performance and character, becoming a benchmark for small sporting hatches and establishing a successful performance sub-brand within the MINI lineup.
MINI-Cooper-S.name: First Generation (R50/52/53)

MINI-Cooper-S.description: The second-generation Cooper S transitioned from supercharging to turbocharging, utilizing a new 1.6-liter turbocharged Prince engine co-developed with PSA Peugeot Citroën, producing 172 horsepower (later increased to 181 hp) and 177/192 lb-ft of torque with an overboost function. The new powerplant delivered improved efficiency alongside enhanced performance with 0-60 mph times reduced to around 6.7 seconds. Visually distinguished from the standard Cooper by its mesh grille, functional hood scoop (though now drawing air for the turbocharger rather than an intercooler), central exhaust, and unique wheels. The chassis featured performance-oriented suspension tuning, larger brakes, and enhanced stability control with an available electronic differential lock. The interior maintained MINI's distinctive retro-themed design but with improved materials, supportive sport seats, and additional performance displays. Special variants included the JCW (John Cooper Works) model becoming a full factory variant rather than a dealer-installed package, producing up to 208 horsepower, and the limited-production Cooper S GP II with 211 horsepower, adjustable coilover suspension, unique aerodynamics, and lightweight components. This generation refined the Cooper S formula with more sophisticated technology and improved daily usability while maintaining its distinctive character and engaging driving dynamics.
MINI-Cooper-S.name: Second Generation (R56/57)

MINI-Cooper-S.description: The third-generation Cooper S featured BMW's modern turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine (B48) producing 189 horsepower (later 192 hp) and 206/221 lb-ft of torque with overboost, representing a significant increase in displacement and output over its predecessor. Built on BMW's UKL1 platform, it grew slightly in all dimensions to improve passenger space and crash safety. Performance improved with 0-60 mph times of approximately 6.4 seconds for manual models. Transmission options included a six-speed manual, six-speed automatic, and later a seven-speed dual-clutch automatic. Visual differentiation included a more pronounced hood scoop, unique front bumper with larger air intakes, dual central exhaust outlets, and distinctive wheel designs. The suspension was retuned for improved comfort without sacrificing handling prowess, with available adaptive dampers offering adjustable ride characteristics. The interior featured higher quality materials, improved technology including an available 8.8-inch touchscreen, and more refined controls while maintaining MINI's distinctive design elements. The JCW version became more differentiated with up to 228 horsepower and substantial chassis modifications. A mid-cycle refresh in 2018 brought styling updates, improved technology, and enhanced efficiency, while a 2020 update standardized previously optional driver assistance features and further refined the powertrains. This generation successfully balanced MINI's distinctive sporting character with notably improved refinement, technology, and daily usability, positioning the Cooper S as a premium performance option in the compact segment.
MINI-Cooper-S.name: Third Generation (F55/56/57)

MINI-Cooper-S.description: The fourth-generation Cooper S adopts MINI's new minimalist design language, featuring a cleaner exterior with simplified surfaces, redesigned lighting elements incorporating matrix LED technology, and a more sophisticated overall appearance. Powered by an updated version of BMW's 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine now producing 201 horsepower and 221 lb-ft of torque, paired with a standard 7-speed dual-clutch transmission driving the front wheels. This powertrain enables 0-62 mph acceleration in approximately 6.6 seconds. Distinguished from the base Cooper by unique wheel designs, sportier bumpers, a subtle rear spoiler, and dual exhaust outlets integrated into the rear diffuser. The interior represents a dramatic reimagining of MINI's cabin design with a minimalist dashboard dominated by a large round 9.4-inch OLED central touchscreen that incorporates most vehicle functions, complemented by a new toggle bar for essential controls and a small digital instrument display. New technology includes augmented reality navigation, advanced driver assistance systems, and a customizable ambient lighting system that forms a complete ring around the central display. Chassis tuning emphasizes the model's sporting character with a wider track, retuned suspension, and enhanced stability control systems. For the first time, the Cooper S shares its exterior design language with the electric Cooper SE, though they utilize different platforms (the combustion models retain an evolution of the previous UKL architecture). This generation continues the Cooper S tradition of offering engaging performance in a distinctive package while incorporating modern technology, improved efficiency, and a fresh interpretation of MINI's iconic design.
MINI-Cooper-S.name: Fourth Generation (J01/F65/66/67)

MINI-Cooper-SE.description: The first MINI Cooper SE represented the brand's first mass-production all-electric vehicle, based on the F56 third-generation MINI Hardtop platform. Powered by a front-mounted electric motor producing 181 horsepower and 199 lb-ft of instant torque, enabling 0-60 mph acceleration in approximately 6.9 seconds. The 32.6 kWh lithium-ion battery provided an EPA-rated range of 110 miles (WLTP: 145-167 miles), with DC fast-charging capability allowing an 80% charge in about 35 minutes. The relatively modest battery size was a deliberate choice to maintain the MINI's characteristic handling by limiting weight increase and preserving interior space. Visually distinguished from conventional MINI models by its enclosed grille with yellow accent bar, unique wheel designs, and yellow 'S' badging. The Cooper SE featured a specially calibrated suspension to handle the additional weight of the battery while maintaining MINI's signature 'go-kart' handling characteristics. The interior retained MINI's distinctive design elements with the addition of a digital instrument cluster displaying EV-specific information. Four driving modes allowed tailoring of regenerative braking strength and throttle response, with the strongest regeneration setting enabling true one-pedal driving. Standard equipment was generous, including LED headlights, heated seats, and advanced navigation with charging station information. Despite its limited range compared to some competitors, the Cooper SE found success by offering the brand's distinctive character and driving dynamics in a zero-emission package, appealing particularly to urban drivers and MINI enthusiasts seeking an electric option.
MINI-Cooper-SE.name: First Generation (F56)

MINI-Cooper-SE.description: The second-generation Cooper SE represents a complete redesign built on a dedicated electric vehicle platform developed jointly with Chinese partner Great Wall Motor, separating it from combustion-engine MINI models for the first time. The exterior adopts MINI's new minimalist design language with cleaner surfacing, redesigned lighting elements, and a more sophisticated appearance. Available in two versions: the standard Cooper SE with a 40.7 kWh battery providing approximately 190 miles of range and 184 horsepower, and the Cooper SE with a larger battery offering around 250 miles of range and 218 horsepower. Both versions deliver improved performance compared to the previous generation, with the top variant achieving 0-62 mph in approximately 6.7 seconds. DC fast charging capability has been enhanced, allowing charging from 10-80% in under 30 minutes. The interior features a revolutionary redesign centered around a large round 9.4-inch OLED touchscreen that incorporates most vehicle functions, with minimal physical buttons remaining. This screen also serves as the primary ambient lighting element, capable of displaying various patterns and animations corresponding to different driving modes and functions. Advanced technology includes an augmented reality navigation system, sophisticated voice control, and enhanced driver assistance features. Despite the comprehensive redesign, the Cooper SE maintains similar dimensions to its predecessor, focusing on improved efficiency, range, and technology rather than increased size. This second generation represents MINI's commitment to electrification as a core part of the brand's future, with the electric Cooper SE now developed as a purpose-built EV rather than a conversion of an existing combustion-engine model.
MINI-Cooper-SE.name: Second Generation (J01)

MINI-Countryman.description: The first-generation MINI Countryman marked a significant expansion of the MINI brand, introducing the marque's first crossover SUV and first four-door model. Substantially larger than any previous MINI at approximately 4.1 meters long, it offered genuine five-passenger seating and significantly more cargo space. Built on a dedicated platform, it featured raised ground clearance, more upright styling, and available ALL4 all-wheel drive system. Powertrains mirrored the standard MINI lineup, including naturally aspirated and turbocharged 1.6-liter engines in Cooper and Cooper S models respectively, with a high-performance John Cooper Works variant added in 2012 producing 211 horsepower (later increased to 218 hp). European markets also received various diesel options. The interior maintained MINI's distinctive styling cues including the large central speedometer and toggle switches, but with a more rugged character and innovative features like the MINI Centre Rail system between the seats for adaptable storage. Despite its larger dimensions, the Countryman preserved much of MINI's characteristic handling dynamics while adding practicality and mild off-road capability. A plug-in hybrid prototype called the Countryman E was tested but never entered production. A mild refresh in 2014 brought subtle styling updates and refinements to the powertrain and features. The first-generation Countryman successfully expanded MINI's appeal to families and lifestyle-oriented buyers, becoming one of the brand's bestselling models globally.
MINI-Countryman.name: First Generation (R60)

MINI-Countryman.description: The second-generation Countryman grew significantly larger, increasing by approximately 20 cm in length and 3 cm in width, positioning it squarely in the compact crossover segment. Built on BMW's UKL2 platform shared with the BMW X1, it featured more sophisticated underpinnings and technology while maintaining MINI's distinctive design elements. The expanded dimensions provided noticeably increased passenger space and cargo capacity, with rear seats that could slide and recline. Powertrain options included a 1.5-liter turbocharged three-cylinder in the Cooper (134 hp), a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder in the Cooper S (189 hp, later increased to 192 hp), and a high-performance 2.0-liter with 228 hp (later increased to 301 hp) in the John Cooper Works model. A significant addition was the Cooper S E Countryman ALL4 plug-in hybrid, combining the 1.5-liter engine with an electric motor for a total system output of 221 horsepower and an electric-only range of approximately 12-24 miles depending on the model year. The ALL4 all-wheel drive system was available on most variants and standard on the JCW and plug-in hybrid. The interior featured a more mature design with improved materials quality, enhanced technology including an available 8.8-inch touchscreen with navigation, and a more conventional layout with the speedometer relocated to the driver's instrument cluster. Advanced safety features expanded to include automated emergency braking, adaptive cruise control, and parking assistance. A refresh in 2020 brought styling updates, improved technology, and more efficient powertrains. The second-generation Countryman successfully balanced MINI's distinctive character with increased versatility and refinement, appealing to buyers seeking a premium compact crossover with personality.
MINI-Countryman.name: Second Generation (F60)

MINI-Countryman.description: The third-generation Countryman continues its growth trajectory, increasing by approximately 13 cm in length and 6 cm in height compared to its predecessor, becoming the largest MINI model ever produced. Built on BMW's FAAR platform shared with the latest BMW X1, it offers both combustion and all-electric powertrain options for the first time. The exterior design evolves with a more angular, upright appearance featuring rectangular headlights (a departure from MINI's traditional round units), a more pronounced and squared-off grille, and a bolder overall presence while maintaining recognizable MINI design cues. Combustion engine options include a 1.5-liter three-cylinder in the Cooper C producing 168 horsepower, a 2.0-liter four-cylinder generating 215 horsepower in the Cooper S, and a 2.0-liter with 296 horsepower in the John Cooper Works model. The electric Countryman E features a single motor with 187 horsepower and approximately 250 miles of range, while the SE ALL4 offers dual motors producing 268 horsepower combined and all-wheel drive capability. The interior adopts MINI's new minimalist approach with a large circular OLED display in the center of the dashboard, reduced physical controls, and new sustainable material options including a leather-free interior. Advanced technology includes augmented reality navigation, enhanced driver assistance systems, and a sophisticated ambient lighting system that extends across the dashboard. Despite its increased size and more mainstream crossover proportions, the new Countryman maintains distinctive MINI design elements and driving character while offering significantly enhanced practicality, technology, and electrification options, positioning it to compete more directly with premium compact SUVs.
MINI-Countryman.name: Third Generation (U25)

MINI-Hardtop.description: The first-generation MINI Hardtop marked BMW's revival of the iconic British brand, reimagining the classic Mini with modern technology while maintaining its distinctive character. Available as the Cooper (R50) with a 1.6-liter Tritec engine producing 115 horsepower and the performance-oriented Cooper S (R53) with a supercharged 1.6-liter developing 163-170 horsepower. The exterior design successfully translated the original Mini's iconic styling cues—including round headlights, floating roof, minimal overhangs, and wheels pushed to the corners—into a larger, modern package that met contemporary safety standards. The interior featured a unique retro-futuristic design with a large central speedometer, toggle switches, and circular theme throughout. Despite growing significantly compared to the classic Mini, the R50/R53 maintained relatively compact dimensions by modern standards and delivered the nimble handling that became known as the 'go-kart feel.' Features unusual for a small car at the time included a multilink rear suspension, optional run-flat tires, stability control, and various luxury amenities more commonly found in premium vehicles. Extensive customization options were a hallmark of the model, with numerous color combinations, graphics packages, and accessories allowing personalization. The first-generation established the reborn MINI as a premium small car with character and performance appeal beyond its practical attributes.
MINI-Hardtop.name: First Generation (R50/R53)

MINI-Hardtop.description: The second-generation MINI Hardtop evolved the design established by its predecessor with subtle refinements to styling and significant mechanical updates. Slightly larger than the first generation, it featured a longer front overhang to meet pedestrian safety regulations, redesigned lighting elements, and refreshed interior. Powertrain options included a new 1.6-liter Prince engine co-developed with PSA Peugeot Citroën, producing 118 horsepower in naturally aspirated form for the Cooper, while the Cooper S switched from supercharging to turbocharging, generating 172 horsepower (later increased to 181 hp). The interior maintained MINI's distinctive design elements but with improved ergonomics, material quality, and technology options including an enhanced navigation system, Bluetooth connectivity, and USB integration. The chassis was retuned to preserve MINI's hallmark handling while improving ride comfort and refinement. New features included keyless ignition, ambient lighting, and an electronic limited-slip differential for improved traction. High-performance John Cooper Works models became fully integrated factory variants rather than dealer-installed packages, offering up to 208 horsepower and enhanced chassis components. A minor refresh in 2011 brought updated styling details, refined engines with improved efficiency, and expanded technology options. This generation refined the MINI formula with increased sophistication and efficiency while maintaining the brand's distinctive character.
MINI-Hardtop.name: Second Generation (R56)

MINI-Hardtop.description: The third-generation MINI Hardtop represented a more substantial redesign, built on BMW's new UKL1 front-wheel-drive platform shared with several BMW models. Notably larger than its predecessors, it grew in length, width, and wheelbase to improve passenger space and crash protection. Powertrains were completely revised, with the base Cooper featuring a 1.5-liter turbocharged three-cylinder engine producing 134 horsepower, while the Cooper S utilized a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder generating 189 horsepower. Both engines incorporated BMW's TwinPower Turbo technology for improved efficiency and performance. The exterior design evolved with more rounded forms, larger headlights with available LED technology, a more prominent grille, and more substantial proportions overall. The interior received a significant modernization with a more conventional instrument cluster positioned behind the steering wheel, a separate 6.5-inch (later 8.8-inch) infotainment display, and higher quality materials throughout. Technology advanced considerably with options including head-up display, active cruise control, collision and pedestrian warning systems, parking assistant, and enhanced connectivity features. A 4-door hardtop variant was introduced for the first time in 2015, offering improved rear passenger access and space. A refreshed version was introduced in 2018 with updated styling, improved technology including front and rear LED lights with distinctive Union Jack patterned taillights, and new customization options. The all-electric Cooper SE joined the lineup in 2020, offering 181 horsepower and approximately 110 miles of EPA-rated range. This generation maintained MINI's distinctive character while delivering more refinement, technology, and practicality.
MINI-Hardtop.name: Third Generation (F56)

MINI-Hardtop.description: The fourth-generation MINI Hardtop introduces a new design language and platform strategy, with distinct combustion-engine (internal designation J01) and electric (J01E) variants sharing styling but different underpinnings. The exterior design returns to a cleaner, more minimalist aesthetic inspired by the original Mini, featuring a rounded silhouette, shorter overhangs, simplified surfaces, and a more vertical front end. The iconic circular headlights remain but are framed in more rectangular outlines. The gasoline-powered models retain an evolution of the previous platform with updated powertrains, while the electric variants utilize a new dedicated EV architecture developed jointly with Great Wall Motor. The Cooper features a 1.5-liter turbocharged three-cylinder producing 156 horsepower, and the Cooper S utilizes a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder generating 201 horsepower, both paired with a 7-speed dual-clutch transmission. The electric Cooper SE offers two battery options with up to 250 miles of range and 218 horsepower in the higher-output version. The interior receives a dramatic reimagining with a minimalist dashboard dominated by a large round 9.4-inch OLED touchscreen that incorporates most vehicle functions, with physical controls limited to a toggle bar for essential features. New technology includes augmented reality navigation, advanced driver assistance systems, and a sophisticated ambient lighting system that extends across the dashboard. The new Hardtop represents MINI's transition toward electrification while maintaining combustion options, balancing the brand's heritage with modern technology and sustainability objectives while keeping its distinctive character and focus on driving enjoyment.
MINI-Hardtop.name: Fourth Generation (J01)

MINI-JCW.description: The original John Cooper Works offerings for MINI began as dealer-installed tuning kits developed by John Cooper Garages, bearing the name of the legendary creator of the original Mini Cooper. These kits upgraded the supercharged 1.6-liter engine in the Cooper S with a modified cylinder head, different supercharger pulley, and performance exhaust system, boosting output from 163-170 horsepower to approximately 200 horsepower. In 2006, MINI offered a limited-production factory model called the Cooper S with John Cooper Works GP Kit (commonly known as the 'GP'), restricted to 2,000 units worldwide. The GP featured a dedicated 218 horsepower engine, lightweight components including an aluminum rear suspension and carbon fiber rear spoiler, deletion of the rear seats, and exclusive chassis modifications including adjustable coilover suspension. Distinctive visual elements included unique Thunder Blue metallic paint with red mirrors, custom 18-inch wheels, aerodynamic modifications, and special badging. The GP established the ultimate expression of the JCW ethos, combining increased performance with weight reduction and focused dynamics, setting a pattern for future special JCW models. These early JCW models, particularly the GP, have become highly collectible, representing the purest expression of the first modern MINI's sporting capabilities.
MINI-JCW.name: First Generation (R53)

MINI-JCW.description: The second-generation saw John Cooper Works transformed from a tuning kit into a fully integrated model within the MINI lineup, managed entirely by MINI rather than John Cooper Garages. The JCW model launched in 2008 featured a substantially upgraded version of the Cooper S's turbocharged 1.6-liter engine, producing 208 horsepower and 192 lb-ft of torque (207 lb-ft with overboost). Enhanced with unique pistons, strengthened components, and a larger turbocharger, it was paired exclusively with a six-speed manual transmission. The chassis received comprehensive modifications including stiffer suspension tuning, larger brakes with red calipers, and an electronic differential lock system. Distinctive styling elements included aerodynamic body modifications, unique 17-inch wheels, and specific badging. The interior featured sport seats, a thicker steering wheel, and JCW-specific instrumentation. The JCW versions expanded beyond the Hardtop to include Clubman, Convertible, Coupe, and Roadster body styles. In 2013, a second-generation JCW GP model was introduced, limited to 2,000 units worldwide. The GP2 featured a 218 horsepower engine, adjustable coilover suspension, powerful braking system, lightweight 17-inch wheels, aerodynamic body kit, and rear seat deletion. Unlike the first GP, the GP2 was available in either Thunder Grey or Chili Red. This generation established JCW as MINI's dedicated performance sub-brand with a comprehensive model range rather than simply an aftermarket upgrade.
MINI-JCW.name: Second Generation (R56)

MINI-JCW.description: The third-generation JCW models represented the most substantial performance upgrades yet, transitioning to a BMW-developed 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine initially producing 228 horsepower and 236 lb-ft of torque—significantly more than previous JCW versions. This engine received a major update in 2019 for the Clubman and Countryman JCW models, increasing output to 301 horsepower and 331 lb-ft, making them the most powerful production MINIs ever at the time. The JCW was available across most MINI body styles including the Hardtop (2-door and 4-door), Convertible, Clubman, and Countryman, the latter two offering ALL4 all-wheel drive. Transmission options expanded to include an 8-speed automatic alongside the 6-speed manual, with the high-output models available exclusively with the automatic. The chassis featured model-specific suspension tuning, larger brakes with 4-piston front calipers, and enhanced cooling systems. Distinctive styling elements included aggressive aerodynamic body kits, unique wheel designs, and red accents throughout the exterior and interior. Inside, JCW models received sport seats with integrated headrests, JCW steering wheel, and performance-oriented displays. In 2020, the limited-production JCW GP3 debuted as the most extreme MINI yet, featuring a 302 horsepower engine, radical aerodynamic modifications including a distinctive rear wing, widened fenders, lightweight 18-inch wheels, and track-focused suspension. Limited to 3,000 units worldwide, the GP3 was offered exclusively with an 8-speed automatic transmission and two-seat configuration. This generation elevated the JCW sub-brand to new performance heights while expanding its appeal across the MINI model range.
MINI-JCW.name: Third Generation (F56/F55/F57/F54/F60)

MINI-JCW.description: The fourth-generation John Cooper Works models adopt MINI's new minimalist design language while maintaining the performance sub-brand's focus on enhanced sporting capability. Initially available on the Hardtop, the new JCW features the brand's cleanest styling in recent years, with simplified surfaces, more subtle aerodynamic elements, and distinctive lighting signatures. Performance comes from an updated version of BMW's 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine producing approximately 228 horsepower, paired with either a 6-speed manual or 7-speed dual-clutch transmission depending on market. The chassis receives comprehensive upgrades including stiffer suspension tuning, larger brakes with red calipers, and a mechanical limited-slip differential. Visually differentiated from standard MINI models by a model-specific body kit with larger air intakes, side skirts, rear diffuser, and optional bonnet stripes. The interior adopts MINI's new minimalist approach centered around a large circular OLED touchscreen, complemented by JCW-specific digital displays, sport seats with integrated headrests, and red accents throughout. While the new JCW maintains the brand's focus on handling and driver engagement, it introduces a more sophisticated, premium character in line with MINI's upmarket positioning. The Countryman JCW continues with a more powerful engine, producing approximately 296 horsepower and featuring all-wheel drive as standard. An electric JCW variant is expected in the future, translating the sub-brand's performance focus to MINI's expanding electric lineup. The fourth-generation JCW models aim to balance MINI's sporting heritage with contemporary design, technology, and a measured approach to performance that emphasizes driver engagement over raw statistics.
MINI-JCW.name: Fourth Generation (J01)

Maruti-Celerio.description: The first-generation Maruti Suzuki Celerio was introduced as a compact hatchback designed to combine affordability, efficiency, and practicality for urban Indian consumers. Notable for being the first car in India to offer an Automated Manual Transmission (AMT), marketed as Auto Gear Shift (AGS), providing the convenience of an automatic with the efficiency of a manual transmission at an accessible price point. Powered by a 1.0-liter K10B three-cylinder petrol engine producing approximately 67 horsepower and 90 Nm of torque, paired with either a 5-speed manual or the innovative 5-speed AMT. A CNG (Compressed Natural Gas) variant was also available in select markets for enhanced fuel economy. The exterior featured a conventional hatchback design with rounded edges and a short hood, optimized for urban maneuverability with its compact dimensions and tight turning radius. The interior was basic but functional, offering seating for five passengers with surprising interior space given its exterior dimensions. Available features (varying by market and trim) included power steering, air conditioning, power windows, central locking, and basic infotainment options. Safety equipment expanded throughout its production run to include dual front airbags, ABS with EBD, and rear parking sensors in response to evolving regulations. A minor facelift in 2017 brought styling updates including a revised grille, bumpers, and interior enhancements. The first-generation Celerio established itself as a practical, fuel-efficient city car, with its innovative AMT option helping to popularize automatic transmissions in the price-sensitive Indian small car segment.
Maruti-Celerio.name: First Generation

Maruti-Celerio.description: The second-generation Maruti Suzuki Celerio features a complete redesign with more modern styling including a rounded, droplet-themed design language with curved surfaces, a larger grille, and redesigned headlights and taillights. Built on Suzuki's newer HEARTECT platform, it offers improved structural rigidity, better safety, and reduced weight compared to its predecessor. Powered by a new K10C DualJet 1.0-liter three-cylinder petrol engine producing approximately 67 horsepower and 89 Nm of torque, featuring dual fuel injectors per cylinder for improved efficiency. Transmission options continue to include a 5-speed manual and an improved 5-speed AMT (Auto Gear Shift). The new generation claims to be India's most fuel-efficient petrol car with ratings up to 26 km/l (approximately 61 mpg). The interior received a significant update with a more contemporary design, improved materials, and enhanced technology including a 7-inch SmartPlay Studio touchscreen infotainment system with smartphone connectivity on higher trims. Available features include push-button start, electrically adjustable mirrors, height-adjustable driver's seat, and automatic climate control on premium variants. Safety equipment includes dual airbags, ABS with EBD, and rear parking sensors as standard across the range, with hill hold assist available on AMT variants. The exterior dimensions were slightly increased, providing more interior space while maintaining the car's city-friendly compact footprint and class-leading turning radius. The second-generation Celerio continues its predecessor's focus on affordability, efficiency, and practicality while offering modernized design, improved technology, and enhanced safety features for budget-conscious consumers in India and other developing markets.
Maruti-Celerio.name: Second Generation

Maruti-Suzuki-Fronx-Delta.description: The Maruti Suzuki Fronx Delta is a specific trim level of the first-generation Fronx, a subcompact crossover SUV (B-segment) produced by Suzuki through its Indian subsidiary Maruti Suzuki since 2023. The Fronx name is a portmanteau of 'Frontier Next'. Built on Suzuki's HEARTECT B platform shared with the Baleno hatchback, the Fronx features coupe-SUV styling with a sloping roofline and is positioned below the Brezza in Maruti's SUV lineup. The Delta trim is one of five variants offered in India (Sigma, Delta, Delta+, Zeta, Alpha), positioned as a mid-range option. The Delta trim is powered by the 1.2-liter K12N Dualjet petrol engine producing approximately 82-88 bhp and 113 Nm of torque, paired with a 5-speed manual or 5-speed AMT automated manual transmission. Standard features include a 7-inch Smartplay touchscreen infotainment system with wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, automatic climate control, keyless entry, push-button start, LED projector headlamps with LED DRLs, 16-inch wheels, and electrically adjustable outside mirrors. Safety equipment includes dual front airbags, ABS with EBD, rear parking sensors, and electronic stability program. The Fronx is sold exclusively through Maruti's premium NEXA dealership network in India, with exports to various global markets including Middle East, Latin America, Africa, Australia, Japan, Southeast Asia, and Mexico since July 2023.
Maruti-Suzuki-Fronx-Delta.name: First Generation

Maserati-Levante.description: The Maserati Levante marked the storied Italian manufacturer's first entry into the luxury SUV segment after several concept iterations. Built on a modified version of the platform underpinning the Ghibli and Quattroporte sedans, it features distinctively Maserati styling with an aggressive front fascia, the brand's signature triple side vents, and a coupe-like sloping roofline. Launched with a 3.0-liter twin-turbocharged V6 engine in two states of tune: approximately 345 horsepower in the base model and 424 horsepower in the Levante S, both paired with an eight-speed ZF automatic transmission and standard Q4 intelligent all-wheel drive system. European markets additionally received a 3.0-liter V6 turbodiesel option. The interior showcases Italian luxury with premium leather, available Ermenegildo Zegna silk upholstery, genuine wood or carbon fiber trim, and a driver-focused cockpit featuring an 8.4-inch touchscreen infotainment system. All models feature an adaptive air suspension with adjustable ride height and electronically controlled damping. The Levante combines Maserati's sporting heritage with SUV practicality, featuring a perfect 50:50 weight distribution, limited-slip differential, and sophisticated torque vectoring for handling dynamics uncommon in the luxury SUV segment.
Maserati-Levante.name: First Generation

Maserati-Levante.description: The 2021 facelift brought significant updates to the Levante, including revised exterior styling with a new front bumper design, updated grille, and refreshed headlight and taillight graphics. The interior received an upgraded infotainment system with a larger 10.1-inch touchscreen display featuring enhanced connectivity and over-the-air update capability. The driver assistance suite was significantly expanded, introducing Highway Assist for semi-autonomous driving, adaptive cruise control with stop-and-go functionality, lane keeping assist, and automated emergency braking. The mechanical lineup remained largely unchanged, continuing with the 3.0-liter twin-turbo V6 in various states of tune and the range-topping Trofeo variant with its Ferrari-built 3.8-liter twin-turbo V8 producing 580 horsepower. The adaptive air suspension and Q4 all-wheel drive system continued as standard features, maintaining the Levante's blend of luxury and performance SUV characteristics.
Maserati-Levante.name: First Generation (2021 Facelift)

Maserati-Levante.description: The 2023 model year brought the most significant mechanical update to the Levante lineup with the introduction of Maserati's MC20-derived 3.0-liter twin-turbocharged Nettuno V6 engine, borrowed from the MC20 supercar. In the Levante Modena, this advanced powerplant produces 550 horsepower and features technologies derived from Formula 1, including pre-chamber combustion technology. This engine replaced the previous 3.0-liter V6 in certain trim levels, offering enhanced performance and efficiency while maintaining the signature Maserati exhaust note. The exterior styling continued from the 2021 facelift, while the interior retained the 10.1-inch infotainment system with its comprehensive connectivity features. The range-topping Trofeo variant continued to offer the Ferrari-built 3.8-liter twin-turbo V8 producing 580 horsepower. Production continued through 2024, representing the final years of Levante manufacturing before the upcoming electric SUV replacement.
Maserati-Levante.name: First Generation (2023 Update)

Maxus-eDeliver-3.description: The Maxus eDeliver 3 (also marketed as the LDV eDeliver 3 in some markets) represents one of the first purpose-built electric commercial vans in its segment, rather than being an electrified conversion of an existing diesel model. Designed by the Chinese automotive manufacturer SAIC Motor and sold under their Maxus/LDV brand, it targets the urban delivery and small business market with its compact dimensions and zero-emission capabilities. Available in both van and chassis cab configurations with short and long wheelbase options, it offers versatility for various commercial applications. The exterior features a modern, clean design with a blanked-off grille, LED daytime running lights, and sliding side door. Powered by a front-mounted electric motor producing 122 horsepower and 255 Nm of instant torque, paired with either a 35 kWh or 52.5 kWh battery pack offering a WLTP-rated range of approximately 99 miles or 151 miles respectively. DC fast charging capability allows recharging to 80% in approximately 45 minutes, while a complete charge using a 7kW AC wallbox takes between 5-8 hours depending on battery size. The interior provides a functional workspace with features uncommon in commercial vehicles at this price point, including a 7-inch touchscreen infotainment system with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility, air conditioning, cruise control, and various storage solutions. The cargo area offers up to 6.3 cubic meters of volume in the long wheelbase version, with a payload capacity of up to 1,020 kg depending on the configuration. Safety features include automatic emergency braking, lane departure warning, and a rear parking camera. Three driving modes (Eco, Normal, and Power) allow drivers to prioritize either range or performance based on their needs. As one of the more affordable purpose-built electric commercial vehicles, the eDeliver 3 targets urban businesses facing increasing low-emission zone restrictions while offering operating cost advantages through reduced fuel and maintenance expenses compared to traditional diesel vans.
Maxus-eDeliver-3.name: First Generation

Mazda-2.description: The first-generation Mazda2 (known as the Demio in Japan) was introduced as Mazda's entry in the subcompact segment. Built on the Ford B3 platform shared with the fifth-generation Ford Fiesta, it featured a practical tall-boy design providing generous interior space within compact exterior dimensions. Development was led by chief engineer Kiyoshi Fujiwara. Production for the European market began on January 20, 2003 at the Almussafes Ford plant in Valencia, Spain. Powertrain options varied by market: Japanese models received 1.3L and 1.5L gasoline engines, while European models featured Ford's 1.25-liter Sigma engine and Mazda's 1.4L and 1.6L gasoline engines plus a 1.4L CDTi diesel. An innovative feature in Japan was e-4WD, a hybrid car-type system using an electric motor to power the rear wheels for traction assistance. All models were equipped with ABS and EBD, with stability control optional. Three trim levels were available in Japan: Cozy, Sport, and Casual. In Europe, trim levels were S, TS, and TS2 (later renamed Antares and Capella).
Mazda-2.name: First Generation (DY)

Mazda-2.description: The first-generation Mazda2 received a facelift on April 13, 2005. The refresh included updated exterior styling with revised front and rear bumpers, new headlights and taillights, and updated interior trim. The European version continued to use a pedal box sourced from the Ford Fiesta with their own 4x108 bolt pattern instead of 4x100. Engine and transmission options remained largely unchanged from the pre-facelift model. In 2004, Mazda introduced the Verisa in Japan, which was based on the Demio/Mazda2 but targeted further upmarket. The first generation established the Mazda2 as a practical city car focused on efficiency and maneuverability, though it lacked the sporty driving characteristics that would define later generations. It achieved moderate success in Europe and Japan but was not offered in North America.
Mazda-2.name: First Generation (DY Facelift)

Mazda-2.description: The second-generation Mazda2 marked a significant evolution with a shift to a more conventional hatchback design that emphasized sportiness over the previous model's tall-boy practicality. Launched at the 2007 Geneva Motor Show and Shanghai International Motor Show, it was built on a platform shared with the sixth-generation Ford Fiesta. The lead designer was Ikuo Maeda, who was later promoted to Head of Design at Mazda in 2009. Notably lighter than its predecessor by approximately 100 kg due to Mazda's 'gram strategy,' it achieved improved fuel efficiency and more engaging driving dynamics. Available in both 3-door and 5-door configurations, the exterior featured expressive styling with flowing lines. For the Japanese domestic market, sales began on July 5, 2007. Production reached 100,000 units by the end of January 2008. Engine choices included MZR 1.3L and 1.5L gasoline engines and MZ-CD 1.4L turbo diesel. The second-generation Mazda2 earned the 2008 World Car of the Year title.
Mazda-2.name: Second Generation (DE)

Mazda-2.description: The second-generation Mazda2 received a facelift first revealed in Thailand in October 2009 and launched in Thailand and Indonesia in November 2009. The rollout continued to Malaysia in April 2010, Australia in May 2010 (with the introduction of the sedan body style), and Europe at the end of 2010 for the 2011 model year. The North American version debuted at the 2009 LA Auto Show and became available in July 2010 with a 1.5-liter, 100 hp four-cylinder engine and 5-speed manual or 4-speed automatic transmission. In June 2011, Mazda introduced the 13-Skyactiv model featuring the first Skyactiv engine, a 1.3-liter Miller Cycle engine with i-DM intelligent driver monitoring and CVT transmission. The 13-Skyactiv was nominated for Car of the Year Japan in 2012. A limited production Demio EV with a 20 kWh lithium-ion battery was leased in Japan starting October 2012. Production ended in November 2014, with over 400,000 units sold in Europe, Australia, and Japan.
Mazda-2.name: Second Generation (DE Facelift)

Mazda-2.description: The third-generation Mazda2 embraces Mazda's Kodo 'Soul of Motion' design language and SkyActiv technology. Unveiled in July 2014, its design was previewed by the Mazda Hazumi Concept at the 2014 Geneva Motor Show. Designed under chief designer Ryo Yanagisawa, it adopted Skyactiv-branded engines, transmissions, body, and chassis loosely derived from the CX-5. While featuring greater length and wider front and rear tracks, it offers decreased interior room compared to its predecessor. Production began at Mazda's Hōfu plant in July 2014, with sales in Japan beginning in September 2014. The sedan version debuted at the Thailand International Motor Expo in November 2014. Powertrains included Skyactiv-G 1.3L and 1.5L gasoline engines and a Skyactiv-D 1.5L turbo diesel. Transmissions included Skyactiv-MT 5/6-speed manual and Skyactiv-Drive 6-speed automatic with i-STOP stop-start system and i-ELOOP brake energy regeneration. In October 2014, the Demio was awarded the 2014–2015 'Car of the Year' by Japan's Japan Car of the Year Committee.
Mazda-2.name: Third Generation (DJ)

Mazda-2.description: The third-generation Mazda2 received a significant facelift in 2019 with various exterior changes, interior trim revisions, and revised suspension tuning to improve ride quality. Changes included improved engine deceleration energy recovery system, adaptive headlights, and standard G-Vectoring Control Plus. With this facelift, the Demio nameplate for the Japanese domestic market was renamed to Mazda2 in September 2019. The facelift model went on sale in Mexico in October 2019 for the 2020 model year in i, i Touring, and i Grand Touring versions. In 2020, a 1.5L mild hybrid gasoline engine was introduced, available only with a six-speed manual transmission, as the diesel engine was discontinued in Europe. The third-generation Mazda2 has been sold in North America through Toyota as the Scion iA (2016), Toyota Yaris iA (2017–2018), and Toyota Yaris Sedan (2019–2020), as well as a Toyota Yaris Hatchback starting in October 2019 for the 2020 model year.
Mazda-2.name: Third Generation (DJ Facelift)

Mazda-2.description: The Mazda2 received its second facelift on January 27, 2023. Changes included a black or body-colored grille insert, larger Mazda logo, restyled front bumper for hatchbacks and GT sedan, and a restyled rear bumper. New colors including Aero Grey Metallic and Airstream Blue Metallic were introduced. The Evolve and GT trims added a black interior with red stitching. New seat designs and a new key fob were introduced, along with auto-folding side mirrors, dusk-sensing LED headlights, and rain-sensing windscreen wipers as standard. In February 2024, Mazda introduced the Mazda2 Grand Touring LX Carbon Edition hatchback in Colombia powered by a 2.0-liter gasoline engine producing 153 hp at 6,000 rpm and 207 Nm at 2,800 rpm. In February 2025, the gasoline-powered Mazda2 was discontinued in the UK, with the Toyota Yaris-derived Mazda2 Hybrid as its successor. A separate Toyota Yaris-based Mazda2 Hybrid (XP210) entered production in December 2021 and went on sale in Europe starting 2022 alongside the gasoline-powered DJ model.
Mazda-2.name: Third Generation (DJ Second Facelift)

Mazda-3.description: The first-generation Mazda3 replaced the Protegé/323 as Mazda's compact car offering, introducing more sophisticated styling, improved performance, and enhanced features. Available in both sedan and five-door hatchback body styles, it featured expressive design that stood out in the typically conservative compact segment. Built on the Ford C1 platform shared with the Ford Focus and Volvo S40/V50, it offered significantly improved structural rigidity and driving dynamics compared to its predecessor. Powertrain options in North America included a 2.0L four-cylinder producing 148 horsepower and a more powerful 2.3L with 160 horsepower (upgraded to 166 hp in 2006), with other markets receiving various gasoline and diesel engines. Transmission choices included four-speed automatic and five-speed manual, with a five-speed automatic added later. The sporty MAZDASPEED3 variant was introduced in 2007, featuring a turbocharged 2.3L direct-injection engine producing 263 horsepower, six-speed manual transmission, limited-slip differential, and sport-tuned suspension. The interior offered better materials and design than typical for the segment, with available features including automatic climate control, Bose audio, and navigation. This generation established the Mazda3 as a driver-focused alternative in the compact segment, emphasizing handling and engagement while providing competitive practicality and value.
Mazda-3.name: First Generation (BK)

Mazda-3.description: The second-generation Mazda3 evolved the design and driving characteristics of its predecessor while improving refinement, efficiency, and technology. The exterior styling became more expressive with a prominent 'smiling' front grille, flowing body lines, and more sculpted appearance. Available in both sedan and hatchback body styles, it maintained similar dimensions to the first generation. Powertrain options in North America included a revised 2.0L four-cylinder with 148 horsepower and a 2.5L (replacing the 2.3L) with 167 horsepower, while global markets received various gasoline and diesel engines including SkyActiv technology in later model years. Transmission choices expanded to include six-speed manual and automatic options alongside the existing five-speed manual and automatic. The MAZDASPEED3 returned with the turbocharged 2.3L producing 263 horsepower, enhanced with revised gearing and torque management to improve drivability. The interior featured improved materials, more contemporary design, and enhanced technology including an available Bose surround sound system, Bluetooth connectivity, and advanced keyless entry. A mid-cycle refresh in 2012 introduced Mazda's SkyActiv technology, including a new 2.0L SkyActiv-G engine with 155 horsepower and improved efficiency, alongside subtle styling updates. This generation continued the Mazda3's reputation for driver engagement while addressing previous criticisms regarding fuel economy and refinement.
Mazda-3.name: Second Generation (BL)

Mazda-3.description: The third-generation Mazda3 represented a significant advancement, introducing Mazda's Kodo 'Soul of Motion' design language and full suite of SkyActiv technologies. Available in sedan and hatchback body styles, it featured more premium styling with flowing lines, a prominent grille, and available LED lighting. This generation fully implemented Mazda's SkyActiv philosophy, with a lightweight but rigid platform, efficient powertrains, and a holistic approach to vehicle dynamics. Powertrain options in North America included a 2.0L SkyActiv-G with 155 horsepower and a 2.5L SkyActiv-G with 184 horsepower, both achieving significantly improved fuel economy compared to previous generations. Global markets also received SkyActiv-D diesel engines. Transmission choices included six-speed manual and automatic, both redesigned for efficiency and engagement. The interior made a substantial leap in quality, design, and technology with soft-touch materials, available leather upholstery, and Mazda Connect infotainment system controlled by a rotary commander. Advanced safety features expanded to include Smart City Brake Support, blind spot monitoring, lane departure warning, and adaptive cruise control. This generation elevated the Mazda3 to near-premium status in the compact segment, emphasizing design, driving dynamics, and quality while maintaining competitive pricing.
Mazda-3.name: Third Generation (BM)

Mazda-3.description: The third-generation Mazda3 represented a significant advancement, introducing Mazda's Kodo 'Soul of Motion' design language and full suite of SkyActiv technologies. Available in sedan and hatchback body styles, it featured more premium styling with flowing lines, a prominent grille, and available LED lighting. This generation fully implemented Mazda's SkyActiv philosophy, with a lightweight but rigid platform, efficient powertrains, and a holistic approach to vehicle dynamics. Powertrain options in North America included a 2.0L SkyActiv-G with 155 horsepower and a 2.5L SkyActiv-G with 184 horsepower, both achieving significantly improved fuel economy compared to previous generations. Global markets also received SkyActiv-D diesel engines. Transmission choices included six-speed manual and automatic, both redesigned for efficiency and engagement. The interior made a substantial leap in quality, design, and technology with soft-touch materials, available leather upholstery, and Mazda Connect infotainment system controlled by a rotary commander. Advanced safety features expanded to include Smart City Brake Support, blind spot monitoring, lane departure warning, and adaptive cruise control. A mid-cycle refresh in 2017 (BN) brought subtle styling updates, interior refinements, G-Vectoring Control for improved handling, and additional sound insulation. The third generation elevated the Mazda3 to near-premium status in the compact segment, emphasizing design, driving dynamics, and quality while maintaining competitive pricing.
Mazda-3.name: Third Generation (BN) Facelift

Mazda-3.description: The current Mazda3 represents another significant evolution, featuring a more mature interpretation of Kodo design with clean surfacing, minimal character lines, and distinctive proportions for both sedan and hatchback variants. Built on Mazda's new SkyActiv-Vehicle Architecture, it introduces a torsion beam rear suspension (replacing the previous multi-link design) to improve ride comfort and sound isolation, though the enthusiast-focused Turbo model retains a more sophisticated multi-link setup. Powertrain options include a standard 2.0L SkyActiv-G (some markets), 2.5L SkyActiv-G with 186 horsepower, and a revolutionary SkyActiv-X engine in global markets that combines spark and compression ignition for improved efficiency. For 2021, a turbocharged 2.5L engine with 250 horsepower and 320 lb-ft of torque was added, paired with standard all-wheel drive. Transmission choices include six-speed manual and automatic. All-wheel drive became available for the first time on non-turbo models as well. The interior represents a major upgrade with a minimalist design focused on driver engagement, premium materials throughout, and reduced visual distractions. Technology includes a standard 8.8-inch center display controlled by a rotary commander, available 12-speaker Bose audio, and a comprehensive suite of i-Activsense safety features including standard automated emergency braking, available adaptive cruise control with stop-and-go functionality, and driver attention alert. The fourth-generation Mazda3 continues the model's move upmarket, competing more directly with premium compact offerings through sophisticated design, refined driving dynamics, upscale interior quality, and advanced technology, while maintaining some of the driver-focused character that has defined the nameplate.
Mazda-3.name: Fourth Generation (BP)

Mazda-5.description: The first-generation Mazda Premacy was unveiled on March 9, 1999, at the Geneva Motor Show and went on sale in April 1999. It was one of the least expensive seven-seaters available at the time and was marketed as a compact multi-purpose vehicle (MPV). Available with either front or all-wheel drive, it featured four-speed automatic or five-speed manual transmissions. The second and third row seats could be folded and removed, offering flexible interior configurations. In Japan, it was sold as the Premacy, while in other markets it carried the Mazda5 name. A rebadged version was sold by Ford in some Asian markets as the Ford Ixion or Ixion MAV from 1999 until 2005 in Taiwan. The first-generation Premacy was also manufactured by China's FAW Haima Automobile as the Haima Freema until 2007. Engine options included 1.8L and 2.0L gasoline engines along with 2.0L diesel variants.
Mazda-5.name: First Generation (CP)

Mazda-5.description: The second-generation Mazda5 (known as Premacy in Japan) was introduced on February 7, 2005, in Japan and mid-2005 in export markets. Built on Ford's global C1 platform, it was larger than its predecessor and replaced the Mazda MPV in most export markets. It featured three rows of seating with six passengers in North America (using three rows of two seats each) and seven passengers elsewhere using Mazda's 'Karakuri Seating System'. The middle row seats recline, slide front-to-rear, and fold flat, while the rear row also folds flat. In North America, it was powered by a 2.3L MZR four-cylinder engine producing 157-159 horsepower, paired with either a five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmission. Other markets received 1.8L, 2.0L gasoline engines and 2.0L diesel options. A mid-cycle refresh in 2008 brought updated front bumper, wheels, rear LED lights, and interior updates including luminescent gauges and an updated radio with auxiliary input. Electronic stability control and traction control were added for 2010.
Mazda-5.name: Second Generation (CR)

Mazda-5.description: The third-generation Mazda5 debuted in Japan on July 1, 2010, with production beginning on May 13, 2010. It was the first vehicle to incorporate Mazda's new Nagare design language, featuring flowing curves along the front fender that extended past the wheel well onto the flanks. In Europe, engine options included a 1.6L turbo-diesel, 1.8L four-cylinder, and 2.0L four-cylinder gasoline with direct injection and Mazda's i-stop start/stop technology, all paired with a six-speed manual transmission. For the US market in 2012, Mazda offered a 2.5L four-cylinder engine with six-speed manual (base) or five-speed automatic (Touring and Grand Touring). A 2013 update introduced Skyactiv-G 2.0L engine and six-speed Skyactiv-Drive automatic transmission for improved fuel economy. While US sales ended after the 2015 model year due to sluggish demand and shifting consumer preferences toward crossovers, production continued in Japan until February 23, 2018. Canadian sales persisted through 2017. The vehicle was also sold as the Nissan Lafesta Highway Star in Japan on an OEM basis from 2011.
Mazda-5.name: Third Generation (CW)

Mazda-6.description: The first-generation Mazda6 (known as Atenza in Japan) replaced the 626 as Mazda's mid-size offering, introducing more distinctive styling and sportier driving dynamics to the segment. Available in sedan, hatchback, and wagon body styles (though North America received only sedan and hatchback initially, with the wagon added later), it was built on Mazda's G platform. Powertrain options in North America included a 2.3L four-cylinder producing 160 horsepower and a 3.0L V6 with 220 horsepower, paired with either a five-speed manual, four-speed automatic, or five-speed automatic depending on engine. European markets also received various diesel engines. The Mazdaspeed6 (2006-2007) featured a turbocharged 2.3L direct-injection engine producing 274 horsepower, paired with a six-speed manual transmission and all-wheel drive. The interior offered a driver-focused design with good ergonomics, available features including automatic climate control, Bose audio, and heated leather seats. This generation established the Mazda6 as a sportier alternative to mainstream mid-size sedans, emphasizing handling and driver engagement while offering competitive practicality and value.
Mazda-6.name: First Generation (GG/GY)

Mazda-6.description: The second-generation Mazda6 refined the formula of its predecessor with more sophisticated styling, improved interior quality, and enhanced technology while maintaining its focus on driving dynamics. The exterior design evolved with more fluid styling, a prominent front grille, and an overall more upscale appearance. Available in sedan, hatchback, and wagon body styles in global markets, though North America received only the sedan. Powertrain options in North America included a revised 2.5L four-cylinder replacing the 2.3L, producing 170 horsepower, and a carried-over 3.0L V6 with 272 horsepower. Transmission choices included six-speed manual and five-speed automatic with the four-cylinder, and six-speed automatic with the V6. European markets received additional engine options including several diesels. The interior saw significant improvements in material quality, design, and technology, with available features including dual-zone automatic climate control, Bluetooth connectivity, and blind spot monitoring system—one of the first mainstream mid-size sedans to offer this feature. A refresh in 2011 brought subtle styling updates and technology enhancements. This generation maintained the Mazda6's reputation for above-average driving dynamics in the mid-size segment while addressing previous criticisms regarding refinement and feature content.
Mazda-6.name: Second Generation (GH)

Mazda-6.description: The third-generation Mazda6 represented a dramatic advancement, introducing Mazda's Kodo 'Soul of Motion' design language and SkyActiv technology suite. The exterior featured striking, premium styling with flowing lines, a bold front fascia, and athletic proportions. Available as a sedan and wagon globally, though North America received only the sedan. Initially powered by SkyActiv-G engines including a 2.5L four-cylinder with 184 horsepower, paired with six-speed manual or automatic transmissions. A diesel option was available in some markets but repeatedly delayed and ultimately never offered in North America. A significant refresh in 2018 brought revised exterior styling, a thoroughly updated interior with higher quality materials, and a new turbocharged 2.5L four-cylinder engine producing 250 horsepower and 310 lb-ft of torque. The cabin featured a premium design with exceptional material quality for its class, including available Nappa leather and Japanese Sen wood trim. Technology expanded to include an 8-inch infotainment system with rotary controller, 11-speaker Bose audio, head-up display, and comprehensive safety features through i-Activsense. Further updates in 2021 added standard Apple CarPlay and Android Auto integration, along with trim and feature refinements. Throughout its production, the third-generation Mazda6 has been acclaimed for its upscale design, refined driving dynamics, and premium interior quality, positioning it as a near-luxury alternative in the mainstream mid-size sedan segment despite modest sales compared to segment leaders.
Mazda-6.name: Third Generation (GJ/GL)

Mazda-BT50.description: The first-generation Mazda BT-50 was developed alongside the Ford Ranger as part of Mazda and Ford's strategic partnership, though it featured distinctive Mazda styling cues particularly in the front fascia and interior details. Available in various body configurations including single cab, extended cab, and double cab, with both 4x2 and 4x4 drivetrain options. Powertrain options varied by market but typically included a 2.5L or 3.0L turbodiesel four-cylinder engine, with some markets also receiving a 2.6L gasoline option. Transmission choices included five-speed manual and five-speed automatic. The exterior design featured a bold front end with a prominent grille and angular headlights, though the side profile and rear were more conventional. The interior was functional and durable rather than luxurious, with varying levels of equipment depending on trim level. Designed primarily as a workhorse, the BT-50 offered payload capacity of up to approximately 1,500 kg and towing capabilities of up to 3,000 kg depending on configuration. Standard and available features varied significantly by market, ranging from basic work truck specifications to more comfortable personal-use configurations with power accessories, air conditioning, and audio systems. The first-generation BT-50 was particularly popular in Australia, Thailand, and other Asian and Pacific markets where midsize pickup trucks serve as both work vehicles and personal transportation.
Mazda-BT50.name: First Generation

Mazda-BT50.description: The second-generation Mazda BT-50 continued to share its platform with the Ford Ranger but featured a more distinctive exterior design reflecting Mazda's 'Kodo' design language of the time, with a prominent grille, swept-back headlights, and flowing body lines unusual for a pickup truck. Available in various body styles including single cab, extended cab (Freestyle), and double cab configurations, with 4x2 and 4x4 drivetrain options. Primary powertrain options included a 2.2L turbodiesel four-cylinder producing approximately 150 horsepower and 375 Nm of torque, and a more powerful 3.2L five-cylinder turbodiesel generating 197 horsepower and 470 Nm of torque. Transmission choices included six-speed manual and six-speed automatic. The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and technology compared to its predecessor, with higher trim levels offering features comparable to passenger cars including touchscreen infotainment, leather seating, dual-zone climate control, and comprehensive safety equipment. Off-road capability was enhanced with electronic locking rear differential, hill descent control, and up to 237mm of ground clearance. Maximum towing capacity increased to 3,500 kg on properly equipped models. A refresh in 2015 brought subtle styling updates, additional safety features, and infotainment improvements. Throughout its production, the second-generation BT-50 was noted for its combination of work capability and passenger car comfort, though its distinctive styling polarized opinions in the traditionally conservative pickup truck market.
Mazda-BT50.name: Second Generation

Mazda-BT50.description: The third-generation Mazda BT-50 marks a significant shift, now sharing its platform with the Isuzu D-Max rather than the Ford Ranger following the end of Mazda's product partnership with Ford. The exterior design adopts Mazda's current Kodo design language with a more refined, car-like appearance featuring the brand's signature grille, sleek headlights, and clean body lines—substantially differentiating it from its more rugged Isuzu counterpart. Available in various body styles and configurations depending on market, including 4x2 and 4x4 drivetrains. Powered primarily by an Isuzu-sourced 3.0L turbodiesel four-cylinder engine producing approximately 190 horsepower and 450 Nm of torque, with some markets also receiving a 1.9L turbodiesel option. Transmission options include six-speed manual and six-speed automatic. The interior represents a major upgrade with a modern, car-like design featuring an available 9-inch touchscreen infotainment system with wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, digital instrument cluster, soft-touch materials, and sophisticated climate control. Safety technology expanded significantly to include autonomous emergency braking, adaptive cruise control, lane-keeping assist, blind-spot monitoring, and rear cross-traffic alert—making it one of the most technologically advanced vehicles in its class. Off-road capability remains strong with selectable four-wheel drive including low range, locking rear differential on select models, and wading depth of up to 800mm. Maximum towing capacity maintains the 3,500 kg rating of its predecessor. The third-generation BT-50 repositions the model as a more refined, technology-focused option in the midsize pickup segment while maintaining the robustness and capability expected of a workhorse vehicle.
Mazda-BT50.name: Third Generation

Mazda-CX-3.description: The Mazda CX-3 is a subcompact crossover SUV based on the Mazda2 platform (model code DK), revealed on November 19, 2014, ahead of the 2014 Los Angeles Auto Show as a production vehicle for the 2016 model year. Built on a modified version of the Mazda2 platform, it featured Mazda's Kodo 'Soul of Motion' design language with sleek proportions, flowing lines, and a distinctive front fascia, offering a more premium appearance than competitors in the segment. The CX-3 was powered by multiple engine options globally: in North America, a 2.0L Skyactiv-G four-cylinder engine producing 146 horsepower was paired with a six-speed automatic transmission and available with either front-wheel drive or all-wheel drive. Global markets received additional powertrain options including 1.5L and 2.0L Skyactiv-G petrol engines and 1.5L and 1.8L Skyactiv-D diesel engines. The interior featured upscale design and materials unusual for the segment, with a driver-focused cockpit offering a standard 7-inch touchscreen with rotary controller, available head-up display, and premium materials on higher trims. Production began in Japan (Hiroshima and Hōfu plants) and Thailand (Rayong since 2015). The CX-3 established itself as one of the more engaging and premium options in the subcompact crossover segment, emphasizing style and driving dynamics.
Mazda-CX-3.name: First Generation (DK) Pre-Facelift

Mazda-CX-3.description: The Mazda CX-3 received a minor facelift in 2018 including a new split horizontal chrome grille design, fog lamps, revised tail lamps, chassis tweaks, enhanced safety features with the i-Activesense suite, a centre console armrest, and replacement of the manual handbrake with an electronic parking brake. Starting from April 2020, Mazda added a 1.5-litre four-cylinder Skyactiv-G petrol engine option for select markets including Japan, Indonesia, Egypt, Singapore, and Malaysia. Apple CarPlay and Android Auto became standard equipment for the US market from 2020. Production shifted from Japan (Hiroshima and Hōfu plants through 2022) to Mexico (Salamanca since 2022) and Thailand (Rayong). Regional market availability varies: the CX-3 was discontinued in the United States after 2021 (replaced by CX-30), Europe sales ended December 2021, while continuing in Japan, Australia, Thailand, Mexico, and other markets through 2024 and beyond.
Mazda-CX-3.name: First Generation (DK) Facelift

Mazda-CX-30.description: The Mazda CX-30 was introduced as a new model positioned between the subcompact CX-3 and the compact CX-5 in Mazda's crossover lineup. Built on the same platform as the fourth-generation Mazda3, it features sophisticated Kodo design language with clean surfacing, minimal character lines, and distinctive proportions. The exterior showcases Mazda's premium approach with sleek LED lighting, a dignified front fascia, and tasteful body cladding to enhance its crossover character. Initially powered by a standard 2.5L SkyActiv-G four-cylinder engine producing 186 horsepower and 186 lb-ft of torque, paired with a six-speed automatic transmission and available with either front-wheel drive or i-Activ all-wheel drive. For 2021, the lineup expanded to include a turbocharged 2.5L option producing up to 250 horsepower and 320 lb-ft of torque with premium fuel. The interior represents one of the most upscale offerings in its class, featuring high-quality materials throughout, minimalist design with driver-focused ergonomics, and exceptional attention to detail. Technology includes a standard 8.8-inch center display controlled by an intuitive rotary commander, available 12-speaker Bose premium audio system, and head-up display. Safety features come standard through the i-Activsense suite including automated emergency braking, lane-keeping assist, adaptive cruise control, and driver attention alert, with higher trims adding traffic sign recognition and rear cross-traffic braking. For 2022, all-wheel drive became standard on turbocharged models, and the Carbon Edition with unique styling elements was introduced. Overall, the CX-30 embodies Mazda's upmarket strategy by offering near-luxury quality, design, and driving dynamics at mainstream pricing, successfully bridging the gap between the smaller CX-3 and the larger CX-5 while providing a higher seating position and more ground clearance than the Mazda3 hatchback with which it shares much of its architecture.
Mazda-CX-30.name: First Generation (DM)

Mazda-CX-5.description: The first-generation Mazda CX-5 was the initial vehicle to fully incorporate Mazda's KODO 'Soul of Motion' design language and SkyActiv technology. This compact crossover featured a distinctive exterior with flowing lines, a prominent front grille, and sporty proportions. Powered by efficient SkyActiv engines, including a 2.0L four-cylinder producing 155 horsepower and a 2.5L four-cylinder with 184 horsepower in North America, with diesel options in other markets. Transmission choices included six-speed manual and automatic, with front-wheel or all-wheel drive configurations available. The interior offered a driver-focused layout with high-quality materials unusual for its class, featuring Mazda's first-generation infotainment system with available navigation. Standard and available safety features included blind spot monitoring, rear cross-traffic alert, and Smart City Brake Support. This generation established the CX-5 as a driver-focused alternative in the competitive compact crossover segment, combining engaging driving dynamics with practical utility and efficiency.
Mazda-CX-5.name: First Generation (KE)

Mazda-CX-5.description: The facelifted Mazda CX-5 was unveiled at the 2014 Los Angeles Auto Show as a 2016 model. Notable changes include updates to exterior styling, reductions in road noise, improvements made to the infotainment system, and a sport mode for the six-speed automatic transmission. LED headlights, LED fog lights and combination LED tail lights were also offered for higher trim levels. In the U.S. and Canada, the update was designated as a 2016.5 model year iteration.
