The Skyactiv-G 2.5 engine was made standard on all United States trim levels, except the base-level Sport equipped with the six-speed manual transmission and front wheel drive, which retained the 2.0-litre powerplant. Additional sound insulation, improved interior materials, and an electronic parking brake were also introduced.
Mazda-CX-5.name: First Generation (KE) Facelift

Mazda-CX-5.description: The second-generation CX-5 refined Mazda's approach to the compact crossover segment with more sophisticated styling, premium interior appointments, and enhanced technology. The exterior evolved Mazda's KODO design language with a cleaner, more elegant appearance featuring a longer hood, slimmer headlights, and a more prominent grille. Initially powered by carried-over 2.0L and 2.5L SkyActiv-G engines, the lineup expanded in 2019 to include a turbocharged 2.5L option producing up to 250 horsepower and 320 lb-ft of torque with premium fuel. A 2.2L SkyActiv-D diesel briefly joined the North American lineup in 2019. Six-speed automatic transmission remained standard, with manual option discontinued in most markets. The interior saw a substantial upgrade with higher quality materials throughout, including available Nappa leather and genuine wood trim on higher trims. Technology advanced with a 7-inch (later 10.25-inch) infotainment display using Mazda Connect interface, available head-up display, and expanded safety features through i-Activsense suite. G-Vectoring Control enhanced handling by subtly modulating engine torque in response to steering inputs.
Mazda-CX-5.name: Second Generation (KF)

Mazda-CX-5.description: The facelifted second-generation CX-5 was unveiled in September 2021 with updated styling and kit. Highlights include restyled bumpers and tailgate with new headlights and tail lights, larger tailpipes, a new Mi-Drive drive selector control, updated seats, and wireless charging. The dampening control structure was improved and frame rigidity was increased, helping to reduce vibrations and road noise. For the 2022 model year in North America, all models became equipped with standard all-wheel drive and horsepower for the turbo engine was increased. The 10.25-inch infotainment system became standard across all trims. Throughout its production, the second-generation CX-5 progressively moved upmarket with each update, reflecting Mazda's broader strategy to position itself as a premium alternative to mainstream brands while maintaining engaging driving dynamics.
Mazda-CX-5.name: Second Generation (KF) Facelift

Mazda-CX-5.description: The third-generation Mazda CX-5 was revealed on July 10, 2025. The wheelbase was increased by 50mm for increased interior space and handling stability, with wider opening rear doors and an optional panoramic sunroof. The exterior features an updated version of Mazda's Kodo design language with a new stacked headlight design, updated taillights, and Mazda lettering on the tailgate. The interior has a driver-first concept approach with a 10.25-inch digital instrument cluster, up to a 15.6-inch touchscreen infotainment system (the largest in a Mazda product), and the first Mazda product to use Google built-in services. Powertrains carry over the 2.5-litre SkyActiv-G engine with mild hybrid M Hybrid system in most markets, while diesel and turbocharged engines are discontinued. This generation marks a significant technological advancement for the CX-5 lineup.
Mazda-CX-5.name: Third Generation (KI)

Mazda-CX-50.description: The Mazda CX-50 is a compact crossover SUV produced by Mazda since January 2022 for the North American and Chinese markets. Built at the Mazda Toyota Manufacturing USA plant in Huntsville, Alabama alongside the Toyota Corolla Cross, it shares its Skyactiv Small Product Group platform with the Mazda3 and CX-30 but features rugged styling designed for active outdoor lifestyles. The exterior features prominent black plastic cladding, squarer styling, and increased ground clearance compared to the CX-5. Powertrain options include a standard 2.5L Skyactiv-G naturally aspirated inline-four producing 187 hp and 186 lb-ft of torque, or a turbocharged 2.5L Skyactiv-G delivering 227-256 hp and 320 lb-ft of torque depending on fuel grade. A hybrid powertrain became available for the 2025 model year using Toyota's Hybrid System with a 2.5L A25A-FXS engine and eCVT transmission. All models feature standard i-Activ all-wheel drive with Mazda Intelligent Drive Select (Mi-Drive) modes. Trim levels include Select, Preferred, Premium, and Premium Plus, with a Meridian Edition offering all-terrain tires and outdoor-oriented accessories. The CX-50 received a Top Safety Pick+ rating from the IIHS.
Mazda-CX-50.name: First Generation

Mazda-CX-60.description: The Mazda CX-60 marks a significant evolution in Mazda's lineup as the first model based on the company's new Large Product Group platform featuring a longitudinal engine layout and rear-wheel-drive-based architecture. Primarily designed for markets outside North America, including Europe, Japan, and Australia, it represents Mazda's upmarket strategy with premium design, materials, and powertrains. The exterior showcases an evolution of Mazda's KODO design language with elegant proportions highlighted by a long hood, cab-rearward stance, and muscular haunches reflecting its rear-drive platform. The CX-60 introduced Mazda's first plug-in hybrid powertrain, combining a 2.5L SkyActiv-G four-cylinder engine with an electric motor for a combined output of 323 horsepower and 369 lb-ft of torque, enabling approximately 39 miles of electric-only range. Additional powertrain options include a 3.0L inline-six SkyActiv-X gasoline engine with mild hybrid technology and a 3.3L inline-six SkyActiv-D diesel, both featuring innovative combustion technologies. All engines pair with an eight-speed automatic transmission and standard i-Activ all-wheel drive with enhanced torque distribution capabilities. The interior continues Mazda's upscale direction with higher quality materials throughout, including available Nappa leather, maple wood accents, and uniquely Japanese-inspired textiles and details. Technology features include a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, 12.3-inch central display controlled by a rotary commander, a drive personalization system that uses facial recognition to automatically adjust seat, steering wheel, mirrors, and driving mode settings to the driver's preferred positions, and Mi-Drive offering various driving modes including off-road settings. Advanced safety comes standard through the i-Activsense suite, with new features including intersection emergency braking and remote parking functionality. As Mazda's new flagship SUV in many markets, the CX-60 competes with premium mid-size crossovers while offering a uniquely Mazda approach to luxury focused on craftsmanship, driving dynamics, and Japanese-inspired design elements.
Mazda-CX-60.name: First Generation

Mazda-CX-7.description: The Mazda CX-7 was introduced as a mid-size crossover SUV with sport sedan-inspired styling, positioned below the larger CX-9 in Mazda's lineup. The exterior featured a distinctive design with a steeply raked windshield, prominent fenders, and a sloping roofline. Powered exclusively by a 2.3L turbocharged inline-four MZR L3-VDT DISI engine producing 244 hp at 5000 rpm and 258 lb-ft of torque at 2500 rpm, paired with a six-speed Aisin F21 automatic transmission. Available in front-wheel drive or all-wheel drive with Active Torque Split system that can send up to 50% torque to rear wheels. The interior featured a driver-focused cockpit with three-dial instrument cluster, three-spoke steering wheel shared with MX-5, and available leather seating, Bose audio, and navigation. Based on the Ford C1 platform shared with Ford Focus and Mazda3. Production began February 2006, sold as 2007 model year.
Mazda-CX-7.name: First Generation Pre-Facelift (ER)

Mazda-CX-7.description: The Mazda CX-7 received a significant mid-cycle refresh for the 2010 model year. Exterior updates included revised front and rear fascias with a larger five-point grille design similar to contemporary RX-8, MX-5 and Mazda3. Interior revisions featured blackout meters with 3D dials, 4.1-inch TFT color Multi Information Display, Bluetooth compatibility, and Blind Spot Monitoring System. New engine options added: a 2.5L MZR L5-VE naturally aspirated inline-four producing 161 hp for improved fuel economy, and a 2.2L MZR-CD turbo diesel available in Europe with manual transmission. The facelift was unveiled at the February 2009 Canadian International AutoShow. Production ended August 2012, replaced by the smaller but more space-efficient CX-5.
Mazda-CX-7.name: First Generation Facelift (ER)

Mazda-CX-70.description: Two-row full-size crossover SUV, the two-row variant of the CX-90. Built on Mazda's Large Product Group platform with longitudinal engine and rear-biased all-wheel-drive system. Features the same dimensions and engine options as the CX-90 with minor styling differences including unique front and rear bumper designs, black exterior accents replacing chrome, and unique wheel designs. Produced in Japan at Hōfu Plant No. 2.
Mazda-CX-70.name: First Generation

Mazda-CX-9.description: The first-generation Mazda CX-9 was introduced as Mazda's flagship three-row crossover SUV, based on the Ford CD3 platform shared with the Ford Edge but significantly modified for its larger dimensions. The exterior featured sleek styling with a prominent front grille, arched fenders, and a gently sloping roofline that gave it a more dynamic appearance than many competitors. Powered by a 3.5L V6 engine initially producing 263 horsepower (upgraded to a 3.7L V6 with 273 horsepower in 2008), paired with a six-speed automatic transmission and available in front-wheel or all-wheel drive configurations. The interior offered three-row seating for up to seven passengers with surprising second-row space and a third row usable for adults on shorter trips. Available luxury features included leather seating, three-zone automatic climate control, Bose audio system, and a power liftgate. A significant refresh in 2010 brought updated exterior styling with Mazda's five-point grille, improved interior materials, and additional technology features. Despite its size, the CX-9 maintained Mazda's reputation for engaging driving dynamics with more responsive handling than typical three-row SUVs of the era. Safety features expanded throughout its production, eventually including blind spot monitoring, rear cross-traffic alert, and forward collision warning. This generation established the CX-9 as a stylish, driver-oriented alternative in the three-row crossover segment, balancing family practicality with a more engaging driving experience than many competitors.
Mazda-CX-9.name: First Generation (TB)

Mazda-CX-9.description: The second-generation Mazda CX-9 represents a comprehensive redesign with more sophisticated styling, upscale interior, and a new turbocharged powertrain. Built on a Mazda-developed platform, it features KODO 'Soul of Motion' design language with elegant proportions, a long hood, and flowing body lines that create a more premium appearance. Significantly, Mazda replaced the previous V6 with a turbocharged 2.5L SkyActiv-G four-cylinder engine producing 227 horsepower (250 with premium fuel) and 310 lb-ft of torque, paired with a six-speed automatic transmission and available with front-wheel or i-Activ all-wheel drive. This new powertrain delivers more accessible low-end torque while improving fuel efficiency by up to 25% compared to its predecessor. The interior represents a major advance with premium materials throughout, including real aluminum and available genuine rosewood trim on the Signature trim, positioning it as a near-luxury vehicle. Despite being slightly shorter than the previous generation, improved packaging maintains interior space with comfortable seating for seven across three rows. Technology features include an available 8-inch (later 10.25-inch) infotainment display controlled by a rotary commander, 12-speaker Bose premium audio, and a comprehensive suite of i-Activsense safety features. Sound insulation was dramatically improved with acoustic glass and significantly more sound-deadening material, resulting in a notably quieter cabin. Updates throughout its production include the addition of Apple CarPlay and Android Auto capability in 2019, upgraded infotainment with a larger display in 2021, and additional refinements to interior materials and technology. Throughout its production, the second-generation CX-9 has been acclaimed for its upscale design, refined driving dynamics, and premium interior quality, positioning it as a compelling alternative to luxury-brand SUVs while maintaining Mazda's driver-focused philosophy. Production ended in 2024, with the Mazda CX-90 serving as its successor.
Mazda-CX-9.name: Second Generation (TC)

Mazda-CX-90.description: The Mazda CX-90 represents Mazda's new flagship three-row SUV in North America, based on a newly developed Large Product Group platform featuring a longitudinal engine layout and rear-wheel-drive-based architecture. As the largest and most powerful mass-production Mazda ever sold in North America, it replaces the CX-9 while offering more interior space, capability, and premium features. The exterior design evolves Mazda's KODO design language with elegant proportions emphasized by a long hood, cab-rearward stance, and clean surfacing with minimal character lines. The CX-90 debuts Mazda's new inline-six engine in North America—a 3.3L turbocharged unit with a 48-volt mild hybrid system producing 340 horsepower and 369 lb-ft of torque in its standard form, with a Performance variant producing an upgraded 280 horsepower for certain markets. A PHEV option combines a 2.5L four-cylinder engine with an electric motor for a total system output of 323 horsepower and an electric-only range of approximately 26 miles. Both powertrains pair with a new eight-speed automatic transmission and standard i-Activ all-wheel drive with expanded capability including off-road modes. The interior showcases Mazda's most premium approach to date with Nappa leather, genuine maple wood, and traditional Japanese textile inspirations like hanging stitches on the dashboard. Technology features include a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, 12.3-inch central touchscreen (that reverts to rotary controller operation while driving), available 12-speaker Bose premium audio, and a comprehensive suite of i-Activsense safety features. With three rows of seating for up to eight passengers (or seven with second-row captain's chairs), it offers significantly more interior space than the CX-9 it replaces, particularly in the third row. The CX-90 positions Mazda further upmarket, competing more directly with premium three-row SUVs while maintaining the brand's focus on driving dynamics, design, and craftsmanship.
Mazda-CX-90.name: First Generation

Mazda-MX-30.description: The Mazda MX-30 marks Mazda's first mass-produced all-electric vehicle, featuring distinctive styling and an environmentally conscious approach to materials and design. The exterior showcases a unique interpretation of Mazda's Kodo design language with a coupe-like profile, pillarless 'freestyle' rear-hinged back doors reminiscent of the RX-8 sports car, and a floating roof design. Built on a modified version of Mazda's SkyActiv platform, it's powered by a relatively modest electric drivetrain with a 35.5 kWh battery and single electric motor producing 143 horsepower and 200 lb-ft of torque, providing an EPA-estimated range of approximately 100 miles in the US market (124 miles WLTP in European markets). Mazda's 'right-sizing' philosophy deliberately uses a smaller battery to reduce environmental impact and weight while meeting the daily driving needs of urban customers. DC fast charging capability allows charging to 80% in approximately 36 minutes. The interior emphasizes sustainability with recycled materials including fabric made from plastic bottles, cork trim (honoring Mazda's origins as a cork manufacturer), and 'Heritage Cork' center console surfaces. Technology includes a 7-inch touchscreen dedicated to climate controls, an 8.8-inch center display for infotainment controlled by a rotary commander, and comprehensive safety features through i-Activsense. A 2022 addition to some markets is the MX-30 R-EV, a plug-in hybrid variant featuring a small rotary engine acting as a generator to extend range while maintaining the same electric drive motor. This rotary engine—Mazda's first production application since the RX-8—is compact and lightweight, designed specifically as a generator rather than directly driving the wheels. Available in limited markets and volumes, the first-generation MX-30 represents Mazda's unique approach to electrification, prioritizing a holistic view of environmental impact, distinctive design, and driving dynamics rather than maximum range or acceleration.
Mazda-MX-30.name: First Generation

Mazda-MX-5.description: The original Mazda MX-5, also known as the Miata in North America and Eunos Roadster in Japan, revived the classic European sports car formula with a front-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout, lightweight construction, and pure driving focus. The design featured retractable headlights, a compact footprint, and classic roadster proportions. Initially powered by a 1.6L four-cylinder engine producing 116 horsepower (increased to a 1.8L with 128-133 horsepower in later years), paired with a precise five-speed manual transmission or optional four-speed automatic. The simple fabric top could be lowered or raised manually in seconds with one hand. The minimalist interior focused on the driving experience with well-placed controls, supportive seats, and an ergonomic driving position. Special editions included the limited-production BBR Turbo, M Edition models with unique colors and equipment, and the track-focused R Package. The first-generation established the MX-5's reputation for exceptional handling, reliability, and pure driving enjoyment at an accessible price point, winning numerous awards and developing a devoted following among driving enthusiasts. With approximately 400,000 units sold, it became the bestselling two-seat sports car in history.
Mazda-MX-5.name: First Generation (NA)

Mazda-MX-5.description: The second-generation MX-5 evolved the successful formula with more modern styling, replacing the retractable headlights with fixed units to meet pedestrian safety regulations, while maintaining similar dimensions and philosophy to its predecessor. Powered by improved 1.8L engines producing 138-146 horsepower depending on market and model year, with five-speed or six-speed manual transmissions or optional four-speed automatic. The structure was significantly stiffer than the original, improving handling precision and safety. Interior improvements included better ergonomics, more supportive seats, and added passenger space despite the similar exterior dimensions. Notable variants included the 10th Anniversary Edition with six-speed transmission, Bilstein suspension, and unique blue color scheme; the high-performance Mazdaspeed/MX-5 SP featuring a factory turbocharger boosting output to 178 horsepower; and in some markets, the unique hardtop coupe NB8C Type S with a fixed roof structure. This generation maintained the original's focus on lightweight, balanced handling while addressing criticisms regarding refinement, safety, and power, further cementing the MX-5's position as the definitive modern roadster.
Mazda-MX-5.name: Second Generation (NB)

Mazda-MX-5.description: The third-generation MX-5 represented the most significant redesign to date, growing slightly in dimensions and weight but maintaining the model's focus on driving enjoyment. The styling became more angular with flared fenders and a more aggressive stance. Powered by a new 2.0L engine producing 170 horsepower (later reduced to 167 due to emissions equipment), paired with improved five-speed and six-speed manual transmissions or an optional six-speed automatic. The chassis was significantly stiffer than its predecessor, with double wishbone front and multi-link rear suspension providing more sophisticated handling characteristics. For the first time, a power retractable hardtop variant (PRHT) was offered alongside the traditional soft top, providing enhanced security and refinement with minimal weight penalty. Interior quality improved substantially with better materials, modern amenities, and improved noise isolation. Special editions included the track-focused Club Sport, luxurious Special Edition models with unique colors and equipment, and the 25th Anniversary Edition featuring exclusive design elements and premium equipment. Despite growing in size and sophistication, this generation maintained the MX-5's characteristic balanced handling and driver engagement while offering more power and refinement than its predecessors.
Mazda-MX-5.name: Third Generation (NC)

Mazda-MX-5.description: The current MX-5 returned to its roots with a focus on reduced weight and compact dimensions, shedding nearly 220 pounds compared to its predecessor while maintaining modern safety and equipment. The exterior features sharp, contemporary styling with a lower hood line, aggressive headlights, and more sculpted body lines. Initially powered by a 2.0L SkyActiv-G engine producing 155 horsepower (upgraded to 181 horsepower in 2019), paired with either a six-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission. For the first time, a retractable fastback (RF) model was introduced, featuring a power-folding hardtop that maintains the coupe-like silhouette even when open. The interior offers modern technology including available Mazda Connect infotainment with a 7-inch touchscreen and rotary controller, while maintaining the driver-focused layout and excellent ergonomics that define the model. Driver assistance features include available blind spot monitoring, rear cross-traffic alert, and lane departure warning, making this the most technologically advanced MX-5 while preserving its pure sports car character. Special editions include the 30th Anniversary model with exclusive Racing Orange paint and unique wheels, and various regional special editions with distinctive appearance packages. The fourth-generation successfully modernizes the MX-5 formula with improved efficiency, technology, and safety while recapturing the lightweight, nimble essence that made the original a driving enthusiast favorite.
Mazda-MX-5.name: Fourth Generation (ND)

Mazda-MX-5-Miata.description: The original Mazda MX-5 Miata revolutionized the affordable sports car market, reviving the classic British roadster formula with Japanese reliability. Following the principle of 'Jinba Ittai' (horse and rider as one), it featured a front-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout, double-wishbone suspension at all four corners, and a perfect 50:50 weight distribution. The compact, lightweight design (weighing just 2,150 pounds) featured pop-up headlights, a simple manual soft top, and minimalist styling. Initially powered by a 1.6L four-cylinder engine producing 116 horsepower, paired with a precise five-speed manual transmission, it prioritized handling and driving enjoyment over straight-line speed. For 1994, the engine was upgraded to a 1.8L producing 128 horsepower (later 133 hp). The simple interior focused entirely on driving, with well-placed controls, supportive seats, and an analog gauge cluster. Special editions included the limited-production BRG (British Racing Green) with tan interior, various 'M Edition' models with unique colors and equipment, and the track-focused R Package with stiffer suspension and minimal luxury features. The first-generation Miata won numerous awards including Car and Driver's '10Best' list for seven consecutive years and established the model as an iconic affordable sports car. Its simple, reliable, and endlessly enjoyable character has made it a favorite among driving enthusiasts and the most popular roadster in history with over 400,000 first-generation units sold.
Mazda-MX-5-Miata.name: First Generation (NA)

Mazda-MX-5-Miata.description: The second-generation Miata evolved the winning formula with more modern styling, replacing the pop-up headlights with fixed units while maintaining compact dimensions and light weight. The updated design featured more pronounced fenders, a more aggressive front fascia, and improved aerodynamics. Structurally, it was significantly more rigid than its predecessor, improving both handling precision and safety. Powered by a revised 1.8L engine producing 140 horsepower (142 hp from 2001), paired with an improved five-speed manual, a new six-speed manual (in higher trims), or an optional four-speed automatic transmission. The interior saw refinements including better ergonomics, more supportive seats, and additional passenger space despite similar exterior dimensions. Significant variants included the 10th Anniversary Edition featuring a six-speed transmission, Bilstein suspension, and unique blue color scheme; the high-performance Mazdaspeed Miata (2004-2005) with a factory turbocharger boosting output to 178 horsepower alongside suspension and braking upgrades; and various special editions with unique colors and equipment. The second generation successfully updated the Miata concept with enhanced performance, safety, and refinement while maintaining the original's focus on pure driving enjoyment, further cementing its position as the benchmark affordable sports car.
Mazda-MX-5-Miata.name: Second Generation (NB)

Mazda-MX-5-Miata.description: The third-generation Miata (officially marketed as the MX-5 Miata in North America) represented the most substantial redesign in the model's history, growing slightly in size and adding more modern features while remaining true to its lightweight sports car roots. The exterior design became more sculptural with flared fenders, a wider stance, and more contemporary styling. Built on an all-new platform with 47% greater torsional rigidity than its predecessor, it featured sophisticated double-wishbone front and multi-link rear suspension for improved handling and ride quality. Powered by a new 2.0L MZR engine producing 170 horsepower (later reduced to 167 hp due to emissions changes), paired with improved five-speed and six-speed manual transmissions or an optional six-speed automatic with paddle shifters. For the first time, a power retractable hardtop model (PRHT) was offered alongside the soft top, providing coupe-like refinement with open-air versatility. The interior quality improved significantly with better materials, more modern amenities, and improved noise isolation. Special editions included the track-oriented Club Sport package, luxury-focused Special Edition models, and the 25th Anniversary Edition featuring unique design elements and premium equipment. Throughout its production, the NC received several updates including revised front styling in 2009 and numerous special editions. Despite growing in size and sophistication, the third-generation maintained the Miata's engaging driving character while offering more power and refinement than previous models.
Mazda-MX-5-Miata.name: Third Generation (NC)

Mazda-MX-5-Miata.description: The current MX-5 Miata returned to its roots with a focus on lightweight design and compact dimensions, shedding nearly 220 pounds from its predecessor while incorporating modern technology and safety features. The exterior features sharp, contemporary styling with a lower hood line, aggressive LED headlights, and more sculpted body lines creating the most visually distinctive Miata to date. Initially powered by a 2.0L SkyActiv-G engine producing 155 horsepower with a focus on responsive low-end torque, it received a significant update for 2019 with power increased to 181 horsepower and a higher 7,500 rpm redline. All models feature either a precise six-speed manual transmission or an optional six-speed automatic with paddle shifters. The ND introduced the RF (Retractable Fastback) variant featuring a power-folding hardtop that maintains a coupe-like silhouette even when open. The driver-focused interior combines traditional sports car elements with modern technology, including available Mazda Connect infotainment with a 7-inch touchscreen, Bose audio system, and heated leather seats. For the first time, driver assistance features became available including blind spot monitoring, lane departure warning, and rear cross-traffic alert. Special editions include the 30th Anniversary model with exclusive Racing Orange paint and unique RAYS ZE40 forged wheels, and the Miata RF Club with available Brembo/BBS package featuring performance brakes, forged wheels, and Recaro seats. The fourth-generation successfully modernizes the Miata while maintaining its pure sports car character, once again earning critical acclaim for its exceptional handling, engaging driving experience, and accessible performance.
Mazda-MX-5-Miata.name: Fourth Generation (ND)

Mazda-Mazda3.description: The first-generation Mazda3 replaced the Protegé/323 as Mazda's compact car offering, introducing more sophisticated styling, improved performance, and enhanced features. Available in both sedan and five-door hatchback body styles, it featured expressive design that stood out in the typically conservative compact segment. Built on the Ford C1 platform shared with the Ford Focus and Volvo S40/V50, it offered significantly improved structural rigidity and driving dynamics compared to its predecessor. Powertrain options in North America included a 2.0L four-cylinder producing 148 horsepower and a more powerful 2.3L with 160 horsepower (upgraded to 166 hp in 2006), with other markets receiving various gasoline and diesel engines. Transmission choices included four-speed automatic and five-speed manual, with a five-speed automatic added later. The sporty MAZDASPEED3 variant was introduced in 2007, featuring a turbocharged 2.3L direct-injection engine producing 263 horsepower, six-speed manual transmission, limited-slip differential, and sport-tuned suspension. The interior offered better materials and design than typical for the segment, with available features including automatic climate control, Bose audio, and navigation. This generation established the Mazda3 as a driver-focused alternative in the compact segment, emphasizing handling and engagement while providing competitive practicality and value.
Mazda-Mazda3.name: First Generation (BK)

Mazda-Mazda3.description: The second-generation Mazda3 evolved the design and driving characteristics of its predecessor while improving refinement, efficiency, and technology. The exterior styling became more expressive with a prominent 'smiling' front grille, flowing body lines, and more sculpted appearance. Available in both sedan and hatchback body styles, it maintained similar dimensions to the first generation. Powertrain options in North America included a revised 2.0L four-cylinder with 148 horsepower and a 2.5L (replacing the 2.3L) with 167 horsepower, while global markets received various gasoline and diesel engines including SkyActiv technology in later model years. Transmission choices expanded to include six-speed manual and automatic options alongside the existing five-speed manual and automatic. The MAZDASPEED3 returned with the turbocharged 2.3L producing 263 horsepower, enhanced with revised gearing and torque management to improve drivability. The interior featured improved materials, more contemporary design, and enhanced technology including an available Bose surround sound system, Bluetooth connectivity, and advanced keyless entry. A mid-cycle refresh in 2012 introduced Mazda's SkyActiv technology, including a new 2.0L SkyActiv-G engine with 155 horsepower and improved efficiency, alongside subtle styling updates. This generation continued the Mazda3's reputation for driver engagement while addressing previous criticisms regarding fuel economy and refinement.
Mazda-Mazda3.name: Second Generation (BL)

Mazda-Mazda3.description: The third-generation Mazda3 represented a significant advancement, introducing Mazda's Kodo 'Soul of Motion' design language and full suite of SkyActiv technologies. Available in sedan and hatchback body styles, it featured more premium styling with flowing lines, a prominent grille, and available LED lighting. This generation fully implemented Mazda's SkyActiv philosophy, with a lightweight but rigid platform, efficient powertrains, and a holistic approach to vehicle dynamics. Powertrain options in North America included a 2.0L SkyActiv-G with 155 horsepower and a 2.5L SkyActiv-G with 184 horsepower, both achieving significantly improved fuel economy compared to previous generations. Global markets also received SkyActiv-D diesel engines. Transmission choices included six-speed manual and automatic, both redesigned for efficiency and engagement. The interior made a substantial leap in quality, design, and technology with soft-touch materials, available leather upholstery, and Mazda Connect infotainment system controlled by a rotary commander. Advanced safety features expanded to include Smart City Brake Support, blind spot monitoring, lane departure warning, and adaptive cruise control. A mid-cycle refresh in 2017 (BN) brought subtle styling updates, interior refinements, G-Vectoring Control for improved handling, and additional sound insulation. The third generation elevated the Mazda3 to near-premium status in the compact segment, emphasizing design, driving dynamics, and quality while maintaining competitive pricing.
Mazda-Mazda3.name: Third Generation (BM/BN)

Mazda-Mazda3.description: The fourth-generation Mazda3 represents another significant evolution, featuring a more mature interpretation of Kodo design with clean surfacing, minimal character lines, and distinctive proportions for both sedan and hatchback variants. Built on Mazda's new SkyActiv-Vehicle Architecture, it introduces a torsion beam rear suspension (replacing the previous multi-link design) to improve ride comfort and sound isolation, though the enthusiast-focused Turbo model retains a more sophisticated multi-link setup. Powertrain options include a standard 2.0L SkyActiv-G (some markets), 2.5L SkyActiv-G with 186 horsepower, and a revolutionary SkyActiv-X engine in global markets that combines spark and compression ignition for improved efficiency. For 2021, a turbocharged 2.5L engine with 250 horsepower and 320 lb-ft of torque was added, paired with standard all-wheel drive. Transmission choices include six-speed manual and automatic. All-wheel drive became available for the first time on non-turbo models as well. The interior represents a major upgrade with a minimalist design focused on driver engagement, premium materials throughout, and reduced visual distractions. Technology includes a standard 8.8-inch center display controlled by a rotary commander, available 12-speaker Bose audio, and a comprehensive suite of i-Activsense safety features including standard automated emergency braking, available adaptive cruise control with stop-and-go functionality, and driver attention alert. The fourth-generation Mazda3 continues the model's move upmarket, competing more directly with premium compact offerings through sophisticated design, refined driving dynamics, upscale interior quality, and advanced technology, while maintaining some of the driver-focused character that has defined the nameplate.
Mazda-Mazda3.name: Fourth Generation (BP)

Mazda-RX-7.description: The original RX-7 established Mazda's rotary-powered sports car legacy with its lightweight, compact design and distinctive front-midship engine placement. Powered by a 12A twin-rotor Wankel engine (later available with fuel injection) producing approximately 100-135 horsepower depending on market and specification, paired with either a four-speed or five-speed manual transmission or optional three-speed automatic. The sleek, elongated hood design was necessitated by the front-midship layout, which placed the compact rotary engine behind the front axle for near-perfect weight distribution. The chassis featured MacPherson strut front and semi-trailing arm rear suspension, disc brakes up front, and a curb weight under 2,500 pounds. Initially available only as a two-seat coupe, limited-production convertible and 2+2 'GLX' variants were later added. Significant updates included the Series 2 (1981) and Series 3 (1984) refreshes, bringing redesigned bumpers, interior improvements, and enhanced performance through fuel injection on GSL-SE models. The first-generation RX-7 achieved both commercial and motorsport success, winning over 100 IMSA races and establishing itself as an affordable, distinctive alternative to conventional sports cars with over 470,000 units sold worldwide.
Mazda-RX-7.name: First Generation (SA/FB)

Mazda-RX-7.description: The second-generation RX-7 evolved from a lightweight sports car to a more sophisticated grand tourer, taking styling inspiration from the Porsche 944 with pop-up headlights, wider proportions, and a more substantial presence. Initially powered by a naturally aspirated 13B rotary engine producing 146 horsepower, the lineup expanded in 1987 to include a turbocharged variant generating 182 horsepower (later increased to 200 hp in Series 5 models). The chassis featured sophisticated independent suspension all around, with dynamic tracking suspension technology that provided passive rear-wheel steering. Available in naturally aspirated, turbocharged, and convertible body styles (the latter introduced in 1988), it offered more variety than its predecessor. Interior quality and features improved significantly, with available leather upholstery, power accessories, and advanced audio systems. Performance and handling were enhanced through five distinct series updates throughout production, with the most significant being the Series 4 (1989) and Series 5 (1990) updates in the US market, bringing revised suspension tuning, improved turbos, and cosmetic refinements. Special editions included the GTU for the naturally aspirated models and anniversary editions to celebrate Mazda's rotary heritage. The second-generation RX-7 continued Mazda's motorsport success, competing successfully in IMSA GTO and GTU classes, and established itself as a more premium sports car while maintaining the unique character of the rotary engine.
Mazda-RX-7.name: Second Generation (FC)

Mazda-RX-7.description: The third-generation RX-7 represented the pinnacle of Mazda's rotary-powered sports car development, featuring striking organic styling with a curvaceous body virtually devoid of straight lines. Powered by a sequentially twin-turbocharged 13B-REW rotary engine producing 255 horsepower in the U.S. market (effortless power delivery came from its innovative sequential turbocharging system, with the primary turbo providing boost at lower RPMs before seamlessly transitioning to both turbos at higher engine speeds. Internationally, power outputs ranged up to 280 hp in the Japanese market. Paired with a five-speed manual transmission (later a Spirit R exclusive six-speed) or optional four-speed automatic. The chassis featured double-wishbone suspension front and rear, powerful four-wheel disc brakes, and a near-perfect 50:50 weight distribution achieved through the front-midship engine layout. Weighing approximately 2,800 pounds, it achieved exceptional handling balance and was widely regarded as one of the best-handling sports cars of its era. The driver-focused interior featured wraparound cockpit design, supportive seats, and minimal luxury appointments in keeping with its focused sporting intent. Various special editions throughout its production included the lightweight RS models for the Japanese market, the track-oriented R1/R2 in North America, and the final Spirit R models that marked the end of production with enhanced performance and exclusive features. While the third-generation RX-7 was discontinued in most international markets by 1995/1996 due to emissions regulations and economic factors, production continued for the Japanese domestic market until 2002. Limited production numbers (particularly in markets outside Japan) and exceptional performance have made the FD RX-7 a highly sought-after modern classic, representing the most focused and uncompromising expression of Mazda's rotary sports car philosophy.
Mazda-RX-7.name: Third Generation (FD)

Mazda-Tribute.description: First generation EP platform compact SUV, jointly developed with Ford. Offered 2.0L four-cylinder or 3.0L V6 engines with front or all-wheel drive. Conservative styling resembling the retired Mazda Navajo.
Mazda-Tribute.name: First Generation

Mazda-Tribute.description: 2004 facelift with updated 2.3L MZR inline-four engine (replacing 2.0L), new floor-mounted automatic shifter, and revised model naming (Tribute i for four-cylinder, Tribute s for V6).
Mazda-Tribute.name: First Generation (2004 Facelift)

Mazda-Tribute.description: Asia-Pacific specific facelift with bolder grille, restyled front bumper and headlights, updated dashboard with new radio, electronic climate control, and rear disc brakes replacing drums.
Mazda-Tribute.name: First Generation (Asia-Pacific Facelift)

Mazda-Tribute.description: Major revamp on CD2 platform for 2008 model year. All-new sheet metal and significantly upgraded interior with higher quality materials. New 2.5L L5-VE I4 engine in 2009 with 6-speed automatic on V6 models. Discontinued end of 2011, replaced by Mazda CX-5.
Mazda-Tribute.name: Second Generation

McLaren-Artura.description:
First generation McLaren Artura, a plug-in hybrid electric sports car featuring
an all-new M630 twin-turbocharged 120-degree V6 engine paired with an axial flux
electric motor. Available as both a 2-door coupe and 2-door roadster (Spider).
Built on the new MCLA (McLaren Carbon Lightweight Architecture) carbon fiber platform,
representing a new era for McLaren with its first V6 engine and PHEV drivetrain.
McLaren-Artura.name: First Generation

Mercedes-Benz-A-180.description: First generation A-Class introduced at Frankfurt Motor Show. Front-wheel drive layout with unusual tall but short body. The A-180 designation was not used in this generation - models included A 140, A 160, A 190, and A 210 Evolution. Facelifted in February 2001 with minor alterations to headlights, bumpers, and longer wheelbase version.
Mercedes-Benz-A-180.name: First Generation (W168)

Mercedes-Benz-A-180.description: Second generation A-Class with improved safety features including adaptive airbags and active head restraints. The A-180 was introduced as a trim level, particularly in Japan where A 170 was renamed to A 180 in August 2009. Also available as A 180 CDI diesel variant. Facelifted in 2008 with redesigned fascias and lights.
Mercedes-Benz-A-180.name: Second Generation (W169)

Mercedes-Benz-A-180.description: Third generation A-Class reclassified as subcompact executive/C-segment. Built on Mercedes-Benz MFA platform. The A-180 was available as an Urban trim level. Facelifted in Q3 2015 with updated lights and technology.
Mercedes-Benz-A-180.name: Third Generation (W176)

Mercedes-Benz-A-180.description: Fourth generation A-Class launched in March 2018, available as 5-door hatchback (W177) and 4-door sedan (V177). The A-180 is available as a Progressive trim level. First generation offered in United States and Canada.
Mercedes-Benz-A-180.name: Fourth Generation (W177)

Mercedes-Benz-A-200.description: The first generation A-Class was introduced in 1997 at the Frankfurt Motor Show. Internally coded W168, it featured a front-wheel drive layout with an unusual tall but short body design. The A-Class was marketed as the brand's entry-level vehicle with interior volume competing with larger cars. Approximately 1.1 million first generation models were sold between 1997 and 2004. A facelift was introduced in February 2001 with minor alterations to headlights, bumpers, and a new long wheelbase version.
Mercedes-Benz-A-200.name: First Generation (W168)

Mercedes-Benz-A-200.description: The second generation A-Class (W169) was introduced in September 2004, constructed with high-strength steel alloys and bonded joints. This generation featured improved safety systems including adaptive front airbags, active head restraints, and electronic stability control as standard. Seven four-cylinder engines were available including the A 200 and A 200 Turbo. A facelift in 2008 included redesigned fascias, lights, and optional stop-start function.
Mercedes-Benz-A-200.name: Second Generation (W169)

Mercedes-Benz-A-200.description: The third generation A-Class (W176) was introduced at the 2012 Geneva Motor Show as a subcompact executive C-segment model, larger than previous B-segment generations. Based on the Mercedes-Benz MFA platform, it was available only as a 5-door hatchback due to decreasing popularity of 3-door models. A facelift was presented in Q3 2015 with updated lights and technology. Production ended May 2018 in Germany.
Mercedes-Benz-A-200.name: Third Generation (W176)

Mercedes-Benz-A-200.description: The fourth generation A-Class (W177) was launched in March 2018, marking the first time the A-Class was offered in the United States and Canada. Available as a 5-door hatchback (W177), 4-door sedan (V177), and long-wheelbase sedan for China (Z177). The design featured Mercedes-Benz's 'predator face' design language. In North America, only the sedan is available in the US while both hatchback and sedan are available in Canada.
Mercedes-Benz-A-200.name: Fourth Generation (W177)

Mercedes-Benz-A-220.description: The Mercedes-Benz A-Class (W177) is the fourth and current generation of the A-Class range. The A-220 is a specific trim level featuring a 1,991cc turbocharged four-cylinder engine (M260 DE20 LA) producing 190 hp at 5,500 rpm and 300 Nm of torque from 1,800-4,000 rpm. Available with front-wheel drive or 4MATIC all-wheel drive, paired with a 7-speed automatic 7G-DCT transmission. The A-220 achieved a 0-100 km/h time of 6.9 seconds.
Mercedes-Benz-A-220.name: Fourth Generation (W177)

Mercedes-Benz-AMG-A-45.description: First generation Mercedes-AMG A45 based on the W176 platform. Powered by the M133 2.0L turbocharged inline-four engine producing 381 hp and 450 Nm of torque, making it the most powerful production four-cylinder engine at the time. Paired with AMG SPEEDSHIFT 7-speed dual-clutch transmission and AMG Performance 4MATIC all-wheel drive.
Mercedes-Benz-AMG-A-45.name: First Generation (W176)

Mercedes-Benz-AMG-A-45.description: Second generation Mercedes-AMG A45 based on the W177 platform. Features the new M139 2.0L turbocharged inline-four engine with two variants: A 45 producing 387 hp and A 45 S producing 421 hp and 500 Nm. The M139 with twin-scroll turbo was the world's most powerful four-cylinder engine in serial production at launch. Paired with 8-speed AMG SPEEDSHIFT dual-clutch transmission and fully variable AMG Performance 4MATIC+ all-wheel drive.
Mercedes-Benz-AMG-A-45.name: Second Generation (W177)

Mercedes-Benz-AMG-GT.description: First generation Mercedes-AMG GT sports car featuring the Transaxle Spaceframe platform. Available as coupe (C190) and roadster (R190). Powered by a 4.0L M178 twin-turbocharged V8 engine in 'hot inside V' configuration. The platform was an upgraded and shortened version of the SLS AMG's Transaxle Spaceframe, with 93% aluminum construction.
Mercedes-Benz-AMG-GT.name: First Generation (C190/R190)

Mercedes-Benz-AMG-GT.description: Facelift update introduced in 2017 with new GT C variant, GT R high-performance model, and Edition 50 limited edition. Key improvements include increased power output from the M178 engine for GT and GT S variants (10 kW and 9 kW respectively) and the inclusion of the 'Panamericana' grille from the GT3, GT4 and GT R variants as standard equipment for all variants.
Mercedes-Benz-AMG-GT.name: First Generation (C190/R190) - 2017 Facelift

Mercedes-Benz-AMG-GT.description: Second facelift introduced in 2020 with updated power output for GT S Coupe and Roadster. The model years continued through 2023, including special editions like the AMG GT Black Series (2021-2023) and AMG GT Track Series (2022-present). The Black Series featured a modified M178 LS2 engine with flat-plane crankshaft outputting 720 hp.
Mercedes-Benz-AMG-GT.name: First Generation (C190/R190) - 2020 Facelift

Mercedes-Benz-AMG-GT.description: Second generation AMG GT unveiled at Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance on August 19, 2023. Shares the MSA platform with the new Mercedes-AMG SL-Class (R232). Offered as a 2-door 2+2 liftback/fastback coupe. At launch, powered by 4.0L V8 in GT 55 and GT 63 variants with four-wheel drive. In 2024, added GT 43 (2.0L 4-cylinder mild hybrid RWD) and GT 63 S E Performance (plug-in hybrid V8 AWD). All variants use a 9-speed AMG Speedshift MCT automatic transmission.
Mercedes-Benz-AMG-GT.name: Second Generation (C192)

Mercedes-Benz-C-180.description: First generation C-Class sedan, replacement for the 190 (W201) range. The C180 was available as an entry-level model with inline-four engines.
Mercedes-Benz-C-180.name: First Generation (W202)

Mercedes-Benz-C-180.description: Second generation C-Class introduced in March 2000. The C180 continued as an entry-level model with improved inline-four engines.
Mercedes-Benz-C-180.name: Second Generation (W203)

Mercedes-Benz-C-180.description: Third generation C-Class introduced in January 2007. The W204 received a facelift in 2011 for the 2012 model year. The C180 was available throughout this generation with various inline-four engine options.
Mercedes-Benz-C-180.name: Third Generation (W204)

Mercedes-Benz-C-180.description: Fourth generation C-Class launched in 2014. The W205 received a mid-life update in 2018. The C180 was available with turbocharged inline-four engines.
Mercedes-Benz-C-180.name: Fourth Generation (W205)

Mercedes-Benz-C-180.description: Fifth generation C-Class unveiled in February 2021. The W206 features a new platform with extensive aluminum use. All models are equipped with four-cylinder engines coupled with an integrated starter generator (15 kW electric motor) and a 48-volt electrical system. The C180 continues as an entry-level model.
Mercedes-Benz-C-180.name: Fifth Generation (W206)

Mercedes-Benz-C200d.description: The W205 received a mid-life update at the 2018 Geneva Motor Show, introducing Mercedes' simplified naming convention with 'd' suffix for diesel engines. The C200d features a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder diesel engine (OM654) with mild hybrid assistance. The facelift included exterior changes, new dashboard design, and updated infotainment system.
Mercedes-Benz-C200d.name: Fourth Generation Facelift (W205)

Mercedes-Benz-C200d.description: The fifth generation W206 C-Class was unveiled on February 23, 2021. The C200d is equipped with an updated 2.0L four-cylinder diesel engine (OM654 m) featuring an integrated starter generator (15 kW electric motor) and 48-volt electrical system. The new platform uses extensive aluminum for weight reduction. In China, a long-wheelbase version (V206) is offered.
Mercedes-Benz-C200d.name: Fifth Generation (W206)

Mercedes-Benz-CLA-200.description: The first generation CLA is a four-door sedan based on the MFA platform, marketed as a four-door coupé. The CLA 200 features a 1.6L turbocharged I4 engine producing 156 hp and 250 Nm of torque. A Shooting Brake (station wagon) version was introduced in 2015. Production ran from 2013-2019. A facelift was introduced in 2017 with new headlights and taillights. Available with 6-speed manual or 7-speed DCT transmission.
Mercedes-Benz-CLA-200.name: First Generation (C117)

Mercedes-Benz-CLA-200.description: The second generation CLA debuted at the 2019 Consumer Electronics Show. Based on the MFA2 platform, it features updated styling inspired by the C257 CLS. The CLA 200 uses a 1.3L turbocharged I4 engine producing 163 hp and 250 Nm of torque. It features the Mercedes-Benz User Experience (MBUX) infotainment system with 'Hey Mercedes' voice control. A facelift in January 2023 brought minor updates including the discontinuation of manual transmissions. Available with 6-speed manual or 7-speed DCT (8G-DCT for 4MATIC).
Mercedes-Benz-CLA-200.name: Second Generation (C118)

Mercedes-Benz-CLA-200.description: The third-generation CLA, officially marketed as CLA with EQ Technology, debuted in March 2025. It is the first model based on the Mercedes-Benz Modular Architecture (MMA) platform. For the first time, combustion-engine and battery electric models share identical designs. The CLA 200 uses a 1.5L turbocharged I4 engine with 48V mild-hybrid system producing 163 hp combined. Features the new MB.OS operating system with MBUX Superscreen (10.25-inch instrument cluster and 14-inch touchscreen). Manual transmission fully discontinued.
Mercedes-Benz-CLA-200.name: Third Generation (C178)

Mercedes-Benz-CLA-Class.description: First generation CLA featuring sedan and Shooting Brake (station wagon) body styles. Based on the MFA platform. Known for being Mercedes-Benz's first front-wheel drive vehicle offered in the American market. Received a facelift in 2017 with restyled headlights and taillights with available bold LED lighting.
Mercedes-Benz-CLA-Class.name: First Generation (C117)

Mercedes-Benz-CLA-Class.description: Second generation CLA based on the MFA2 platform. Features the Mercedes-Benz User Experience (MBUX) infotainment system with 'Hey Mercedes' voice control. Includes sedan and Shooting Brake versions. Received a facelift in January 2023 which involved the discontinuation of the manual transmission.
Mercedes-Benz-CLA-Class.name: Second Generation (C118)

Mercedes-Benz-CLA-Class.description: Third generation CLA, officially marketed as 'CLA with EQ Technology'. First model based on the Mercedes-Benz Modular Architecture (MMA) platform. For the first time, combustion-engine and battery electric models feature identical designs. Includes both ICE (hybrid) and BEV variants, with sedan and Shooting Brake body styles.
Mercedes-Benz-CLA-Class.name: Third Generation (C178/174)

Mercedes-Benz-CLS.description: The first-generation CLS was designed by Michael Fink in 2001. Based on the W211 E-Class platform, it was marketed as a four-door coupe. Production ran from 2004 to 2010.
Mercedes-Benz-CLS.name: First Generation (C219)

Mercedes-Benz-CLS.description: The second-generation CLS was sold from 2011 to 2018. Available as a 4-door coupe and a 5-door estate (Shooting Brake). This generation introduced all-wheel drive (4MATIC).
Mercedes-Benz-CLS.name: Second Generation (C218)

Mercedes-Benz-CLS.description: The C218 received a facelift in 2014 featuring design changes, engine enhancements, and the adoption of the Mercedes 9G-Tronic automatic transmission.
Mercedes-Benz-CLS.name: Second Generation Facelift (C218)

Mercedes-Benz-CLS.description: The third-generation CLS is available only as a four-door sedan with rear-wheel or all-wheel drive. Features a 2.9L straight-six diesel and 3.0L straight-six petrol with mild hybrid on CLS 53 AMG. Production ended August 31, 2023.
Mercedes-Benz-CLS.name: Third Generation (C257)

Mercedes-Benz-E-Class.description: E-Class nameplate adopted in August 1993. Sedan (W124), Coupe (C124), Convertible (A124), and Estate (S124) body configurations. Sedans produced through 1995, estates and coupes through 1996, cabriolets finished in 1997.
Mercedes-Benz-E-Class.name: First Generation (W124)

Mercedes-Benz-E-Class.description: Launched in January 1995. Featured four large oval headlights. The sedan was replaced by the W211 in 2002, while the wagon version continued to be sold until March 2003. A facelift was introduced in September 1999.
Mercedes-Benz-E-Class.name: Second Generation (W210)

Mercedes-Benz-E-Class.description: Launched in 2002. Featured a major redesign with more aggressive, squared design language. Facelifted in June 2006 for the 2007 model year to address quality and technical issues.
Mercedes-Benz-E-Class.name: Third Generation (W211)

Mercedes-Benz-E-Class.description: Replaced the W211 in 2009 as a 2010 model. Featured new safety and convenience technologies including blind spot monitor, Lane Keeping Assist, Pre-safe with Attention Assist, and Night View Assist Plus. In 2013, received a comprehensive facelift with significant styling changes, fuel economy improvements, and updated safety features. The facelift featured singular front lights replacing twin headlamp design with integrated LED daytime running lights.
Mercedes-Benz-E-Class.name: Fourth Generation (W212)

Mercedes-Benz-E-Class.description: Unveiled at the 2016 North American International Auto Show. Design incorporates cues from the larger W222 S-Class and smaller W205 C-Class. Features a switch to inline six-cylinder engines from previous V6 engines and new generation four-cylinder diesel engines. Second-most technologically advanced Mercedes after S-Class. Includes autonomous driving capability up to 130 mph for up to 2 minutes. Received a mid-generation facelift in 2020.
Mercedes-Benz-E-Class.name: Fifth Generation (W213)

Mercedes-Benz-E-Class.description: Debuted on April 25, 2023. Body styles include sedan and wagon, while coupes and convertibles were discontinued and will slot under the new CLE nameplate. Current production generation.
Mercedes-Benz-E-Class.name: Sixth Generation (W214)

Mercedes-Benz-E180.description: Fourth generation E-Class platform. The E180 was a market-specific trim sold in Turkey, Greece, and Tunisia featuring a 1.6L turbocharged petrol engine (M270 derivative) producing 156 HP and 250 NM. This generation featured significant styling updates, improved fuel economy, and advanced safety features including driver drowsiness detection, lane departure warning, and traffic sign recognition.
Mercedes-Benz-E180.name: W212 Generation

Mercedes-Benz-EQA.description: Pre-facelift model launched February 2021. Features the original front grille design, standard LED headlights with fiber optic strip connection, and original interior layout with dual 10-inch MBUX screens. Available in EQA 250 (FWD), EQA 300 4MATIC (AWD), and EQA 350 4MATIC+ (AWD) variants.
Mercedes-Benz-EQA.name: First Generation

Mercedes-Benz-EQA.description: Facelift model available from Q1 2024. Features new front grille design, optional new front bumper, updated rear taillights with 3D light signature and tinted dark red appearance. Interior updates include new three-spoke steering wheel with capacitive controls, illuminated Mercedes logo trim pieces on dashboard and doors, larger infotainment screen, and new Plug & Charge system. New 18-, 19- and 20-inch alloy wheel designs available plus new colors including Spectral Blue Metallic.
Mercedes-Benz-EQA.name: First Generation (2024 Facelift)

Mercedes-Benz-EQB.description: The Mercedes-Benz EQB (X243) is a seven-seat battery electric mid-size D-segment crossover SUV produced by Mercedes-Benz. It is part of the EQ family and is based on the Mercedes-Benz GLB-Class using the MFA2 platform. The EQB is available in both front-wheel drive and 4MATIC branded dual motor all wheel drive configurations, with five and seven seat layouts available.
Mercedes-Benz-EQB.name: First Generation

Mercedes-Benz-EQE.description: The Mercedes-Benz EQE (V295) is a battery electric executive car produced by German automobile manufacturer Mercedes-Benz Group. It is part of the EQ family, and was presented at the Munich Motor Show 2021. Production began in 2022 using the Mercedes-Benz EVA platform. The vehicle features a 90.6 kWh lithium-ion battery with options for single motor RWD or dual motor AWD configurations.
Mercedes-Benz-EQE.name: First Generation (V295)

Mercedes-Benz-EQS.description: The Mercedes-Benz EQS (V297) is a battery electric full-size luxury liftback car produced by Mercedes-Benz. It was released in September 2021 in Germany and the fourth quarter of 2021 in the United States. The EQS is the first EQ model based on the MEA platform (Mercedes-Benz EVA platform), specifically designed for electric vehicles. It features a drag coefficient of 0.20, making it the world's most aerodynamic production car at its introduction. Available models include EQS 350, EQS 450+, EQS 450 4MATIC, EQS 500 4MATIC, EQS 580 4MATIC, and AMG EQS 53 4MATIC+.
Mercedes-Benz-EQS.name: First Generation

Mercedes-Benz-EQS.description: Mercedes-Benz released the facelifted model of the EQS on 10 April 2024. Changes include the addition of a free-standing hood ornament, an updated front fascia with a faux grille and horizontal chrome slats, interior updates with chrome accents on the B-pillar air vents and rear seat pillows featuring contrast stitching and Nappa leather piping, and increased battery capacity for model variants. The facelift maintains the same V297 platform while updating the exterior styling and improving battery technology.
Mercedes-Benz-EQS.name: First Generation (2024 Facelift)

Mercedes-Benz-EQS-Class-Sedan.description: Original production model of the Mercedes-Benz EQS (V297), a battery electric full-size luxury liftback car. Features the Mercedes-Benz EVA platform (MEA) with a drag coefficient as low as 0.20, making it the most aerodynamic production car at its introduction. Available in multiple variants including EQS 350, EQS 450+, EQS 450 4MATIC, EQS 500 4MATIC, EQS 580 4MATIC, and AMG EQS 53 4MATIC+.
Mercedes-Benz-EQS-Class-Sedan.name: First Generation

Mercedes-Benz-EQS-Class-Sedan.description: Facelifted model released on 10 April 2024. Features a free-standing hood ornament, updated front fascia with faux grille and horizontal chrome slats, interior updates with chrome accents on B-pillar air vents, rear seat pillows with contrast stitching and Nappa leather piping, and increased battery capacity for model variants.
Mercedes-Benz-EQS-Class-Sedan.name: First Generation (2024 Facelift)

Mercedes-Benz-G-Class.description: The original Mercedes-Benz G-Class was born from a collaborative agreement between Daimler-Benz and Steyr-Daimler-Puch in 1972, initially developed as a military vehicle at the suggestion of the Shah of Iran. Launched in 1979, the W460 featured austere and utilitarian design with angular, boxy styling that would become iconic. Built on a rugged body-on-frame construction with solid axles front and rear, it offered exceptional off-road capability through its three locking differentials - a rare feature that distinguished it from other passenger vehicles. The W460 was available in multiple body configurations including two-door and four-door versions, convertibles, panel vans, and pickup trucks, with both short (2,400mm) and long (2,850mm) wheelbase options. Engine choices ranged from economical diesels like the 240 GD and 300 GD to gasoline engines including the 230 G, 280 GE, and later fuel-injected variants. The interior was spartan and functional, focusing on durability over luxury. Major updates in 1981 introduced automatic transmission and air conditioning options, while 1982 brought fuel injection with the 230 GE. By 1986, over 50,000 units had been produced. A facelift in 1990 improved refinement, but the W460 remained fundamentally a working vehicle rather than a luxury SUV. Production ended in 1991 as it transitioned to the more refined W463 generation, establishing the G-Class foundation that would endure for decades.
Mercedes-Benz-G-Class.name: First Generation (W460)

Mercedes-Benz-G-Class.description: The W461 generation served as the utilitarian workhorse continuation of the original G-Class philosophy, running parallel to the more luxurious W463 from 1992 to 2022. Built on essentially the same chassis as the W460 but incorporating powertrain improvements from the W463, the W461 was specifically designed for military, government agencies, and commercial users who needed the G-Class's legendary capability without luxury appointments. Featuring a 24-volt electrical system for military compatibility, the W461 retained the solid front and rear axles with three locking differentials that made the G-Class unparalleled in off-road situations. During the 1990s, it was powered by a 2.3-liter four-cylinder gasoline engine and 2.9-liter five-cylinder diesel engine. From 2001, it received modern turbodiesel engines including the 2.7-liter five-cylinder in the G 270 CDI Worker and later the 3.0-liter V6 turbodiesel in the G 280 CDI Worker. Limited civilian editions were occasionally offered, including the G 280 CDI EDITION.30 PUR in 2009 celebrating the G-Class's 30th anniversary, and the G 300 CDI Professional from 2010-2019, available in various body configurations from panel vans to pickup trucks. These featured more basic interiors with vinyl surfaces, rubber floor coverings, and manually operated controls, emphasizing function over form. The W461 proved so successful in military applications that it was used by armed forces worldwide, earning nicknames like 'Wolf' in German service. Production finally ended in 2022 when it was replaced by the new W464 military variant.
Mercedes-Benz-G-Class.name: Second Generation (W461)

Mercedes-Benz-G-Class.description: The first-generation W463 marked the G-Class's transformation from purely utilitarian vehicle to luxury SUV, running for an remarkable 28 years from 1990 to 2018. This generation moved the G-Class upmarket to compete with vehicles like the Range Rover, featuring significantly improved interior appointments with wood trim, leather upholstery, and more sophisticated amenities while retaining the iconic boxy exterior design. The W463 introduced full-time four-wheel drive with electrically locking differentials and ABS as standard equipment. Initially offering familiar engines from the W460, the range expanded dramatically over its long production run to include everything from four-cylinder to twelve-cylinder engines, naturally aspirated to supercharged and twin-turbo configurations. Key updates included the 1997 revision with V6 engines replacing inline units, the 2002 U.S. market launch, and the 2007 major refresh with new interior, HID headlamps, and updated technology. The W463 spawned numerous special editions and variants, including the legendary 500 GE V8 (1993), G 500 Classic Special-Edition (1999), and exotic models like the G 63 AMG 6×6 (2013-2015) and Mercedes-Maybach G 650 Landaulet (2017). AMG variants became increasingly important, starting with the G 55 AMG in 2002 and evolving through supercharged and twin-turbo V8 and V12 engines producing up to 621 horsepower. By the end of production, the first-generation W463 offered the highest number of paint color options (22) of any Mercedes-Benz model and had established the G-Class as a status symbol beloved by celebrities and luxury SUV enthusiasts worldwide.
Mercedes-Benz-G-Class.name: Third Generation (W463, First Generation)

Mercedes-Benz-G-Class.description: The second-generation W463 represented the most comprehensive redesign in G-Class history while maintaining the iconic visual DNA that made it instantly recognizable. Launched in January 2018, this generation grew significantly in dimensions - 121mm wider, 53mm longer, with 6mm more ground clearance - primarily to meet new EU pedestrian safety regulations while improving interior space and driving dynamics. Despite retaining the W463 chassis designation, only three parts carried over from the previous generation: headlamp washers, door handles, and spare wheel cover. The most significant mechanical change was switching from a recirculating ball steering system to variable-ratio rack-and-pinion with electric power assistance, necessitating a move from solid front axle to independent front suspension while maintaining the solid rear axle and three locking differentials. This enabled modern safety features like active lane-keeping assist and collision avoidance systems. Interior technology leaped forward with dual 12-inch displays, smartphone integration, and 64-color ambient lighting, while build quality reached new heights with tighter panel gaps and improved materials. The initial lineup included the G 500/G 550 with a 4.0-liter twin-turbo V8 producing 416 horsepower and the Mercedes-AMG G 63 with 577 horsepower. Diesel variants followed with the G 350 d and G 400 d using clean 2.9-liter inline-six engines. Special editions included the Stronger Than Time anniversary models and the exclusive G manufaktur customization program. Notable variants included the return of the G 63 4×4² in 2022 and the Final Edition G 500 V8 in 2023, marking the end of V8 power in the non-AMG model. This generation successfully modernized the G-Class for contemporary luxury SUV buyers while preserving its uncompromising off-road capability.
Mercedes-Benz-G-Class.name: Fourth Generation (W463, Second Generation)

Mercedes-Benz-G-Class.description: The W465 generation, introduced in March 2024, represents the latest evolution of the G-Class with a focus on electrification, efficiency, and advanced technology while maintaining the model's legendary off-road prowess. This generation marks a significant powertrain transition, replacing the previous G 500's 4.0-liter V8 with a new 3.0-liter inline-six turbocharged engine featuring 48-volt mild-hybrid technology, producing 443 horsepower and enhanced efficiency. The Mercedes-AMG G 63 continues with the 4.0-liter twin-turbo V8, now also featuring mild-hybrid assistance. The diesel option evolves to the G 450 d with an upgraded 3.0-liter inline-six turbodiesel producing 362 horsepower, also with 48-volt hybrid support. Most significantly, April 2024 saw the introduction of the G 580 with EQ Technology, the first fully electric G-Class featuring four independent electric motors producing 579 horsepower and 859 lb-ft of torque, capable of 0-60 mph in 4.7 seconds. The electric variant maintains true off-road capability with the signature three locking differentials through innovative engineering, though it faces challenges with its 6,801-pound weight, limited 239-mile EPA range, and high price point compared to ICE variants. All W465 models feature updated exterior styling with improved aerodynamics inspired by the Concept EQG, enhanced interior technology, and continued availability of the G manufaktur customization program. The generation represents Mercedes-Benz's commitment to preserving G-Class heritage while advancing toward an electrified future, though early sales figures suggest consumer preference still favors traditional powertrains over the electric variant.
Mercedes-Benz-G-Class.name: Fifth Generation (W465)

Mercedes-Benz-GLA250.description: The first generation Mercedes-Benz GLA 250 was produced from December 2013 to January 2017 as a subcompact luxury crossover SUV. It featured a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder petrol engine producing 155 kW (211 PS) and 350 Nm of torque, with a 0-100 km/h acceleration of 6.7 seconds and 230 km/h top speed.
Mercedes-Benz-GLA250.name: First Generation

Mercedes-Benz-GLA250.description: The facelifted first generation Mercedes-Benz GLA 250 was produced from January 2017 to November 2019. Updates included redesigned grille, new front and rear bumpers, updated 18-inch alloy wheels, all LED bi-xenon headlamps replaced with full LED units, new LED taillights with updated design pattern, and a new 8.0-inch free-standing infotainment screen.
Mercedes-Benz-GLA250.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Mercedes-Benz-GLA250.description: The second generation Mercedes-Benz GLA 250 was introduced in December 2019 as a subcompact luxury crossover SUV. It features the MFA2 platform, with a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder petrol engine producing 165 kW (224 PS) and 350 Nm of torque, 0-100 km/h acceleration of 6.9 seconds, MBUX infotainment system, and increased interior space with 116 mm more headroom.
Mercedes-Benz-GLA250.name: Second Generation

Mercedes-Benz-GLA250.description: The facelifted second generation Mercedes-Benz GLA 250 was introduced in March 2023. Updates include redesigned headlights and taillights, latest iteration of MBUX infotainment system with wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, updated powertrain options, three new optional wheel designs, and dual 10.3-inch screen now standard as part of the Premium Package.
Mercedes-Benz-GLA250.name: Second Generation (Facelift)

Mercedes-Benz-GLB-250.description: Pre-facelift GLB 250 4MATIC. The GLB is positioned between the GLA and the larger GLC in size, equipped with optional third row seating. Uses the MFA2 platform with standard all-wheel-drive and an eight-speed dual clutch automatic transmission.
Mercedes-Benz-GLB-250.name: First Generation (X247)

Mercedes-Benz-GLB-250.description: Facelifted GLB for the 2024 model year. Features new headlights and taillights, updated MBUX infotainment system with wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, and a new 48-volt mild hybrid system (EQ Boost).
Mercedes-Benz-GLB-250.name: First Generation (X247) Facelift

Mercedes-Benz-GLC-Class.description: The first-generation GLC (X253/C253) replaced the GLK-Class. It introduced the GLC Coupé variant with a sloping roof design. Available in both SUV and Coupé body styles across multiple markets with various petrol, diesel, and hybrid powertrains. Pre-facelift models feature the original front fascia design and first-generation MBUX system.
Mercedes-Benz-GLC-Class.name: First generation (pre-facelift)

Mercedes-Benz-GLC-Class.description: The facelifted first-generation GLC (X253/C253) was unveiled at the 2019 Geneva Motor Show. Updated features include the new MBUX Operating System activated by voice command, a new steering wheel, a 12.3-inch digital cockpit, and updated engines with improved efficiency.
Mercedes-Benz-GLC-Class.name: First generation (facelift)

Mercedes-Benz-GLC-Class.description: The second-generation GLC (X254/C254) was unveiled in June 2022 with modernized styling and expanded electrified options. Features include four-cylinder engines with mild hybrid technology as standard, three plug-in hybrid variants, and is produced in Germany, China, Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia.
Mercedes-Benz-GLC-Class.name: Second generation

Mercedes-Benz-Ml63.description: First generation M-Class (W163) was a body-on-frame SUV. The ML55 AMG was introduced in 2000 as the first high-performance AMG variant of the M-Class, featuring a 5.4L V8 engine producing 342 hp. It was produced until 2003.
Mercedes-Benz-Ml63.name: W163 First Generation

Mercedes-Benz-Ml63.description: Second generation M-Class (W164) moved to a unibody platform. The ML63 AMG was introduced at the 2006 North American International Auto Show as a 2007 model, featuring a 6.2L M156 V8 engine producing 503 hp, handcrafted by AMG in Germany.
Mercedes-Benz-Ml63.name: W164 Second Generation

Mercedes-Benz-Ml63.description: Third generation M-Class (W166) was introduced in 2011 as a 2012 model. The ML63 AMG continued with a 5.5L biturbo V8 engine (M157). In 2015, the model was renamed GLE as part of Mercedes' new naming strategy, becoming the GLE 63 AMG.
Mercedes-Benz-Ml63.name: W166 Third Generation

Mercedes-Benz-Ml63.description: Fourth generation GLE (W167) was unveiled at the 2018 Paris Motor Show. The AMG GLE 63 variants feature a 4.0L biturbo V8 engine with EQ Boost mild hybrid technology, producing 571 hp in standard form and 603 hp in S form.
Mercedes-Benz-Ml63.name: W167 Fourth Generation

Mercedes-Benz-S-Class.description: First generation officially branded as S-Class, introduced with the W116 chassis code in 1972.
Mercedes-Benz-S-Class.name: W116 (First Generation)

Mercedes-Benz-S-Class.description: Second generation S-Class, premiered in September 1979, launched in March 1980, featuring improved aerodynamics and enlarged aluminum engine blocks.
Mercedes-Benz-S-Class.name: W126 (Second Generation)

Mercedes-Benz-S-Class.description: Third generation introduced in 1991, featuring two wheelbase lengths and a shorter-wheelbase W140 coupé.
Mercedes-Benz-S-Class.name: W140 (Third Generation)

Mercedes-Benz-S-Class.description: Fourth generation presented in July 1998, marketed as a sedan only, despite being smaller than the previous generation, offered more interior space.
Mercedes-Benz-S-Class.name: W220 (Fourth Generation)

Mercedes-Benz-S-Class.description: Fifth generation introduced in autumn 2005 at the Frankfurt International Motor Show, featuring a big change in design with newly developed engines.
Mercedes-Benz-S-Class.name: W221 (Fifth Generation)

Mercedes-Benz-S-Class.description: Sixth generation produced from June 2013 to September 2020 for the W222 sedan, with C217 coupé and A217 cabriolet variants produced from November 2014 to August 2020.
Mercedes-Benz-S-Class.name: W222 (Sixth Generation)

Mercedes-Benz-S-Class.description: Seventh generation unveiled on September 2, 2020, continuing production through the present.
Mercedes-Benz-S-Class.name: W223 (Seventh Generation)

Mitsubishi-ASX.description: The first-generation Mitsubishi ASX (known as RVR in Japan and Outlander Sport in North America) was introduced as Mitsubishi's entry in the rapidly growing compact crossover segment. Built on a shortened version of the Outlander platform, it featured distinctive styling with Mitsubishi's 'Jet Fighter' front grille design, a sloping roofline, and compact dimensions appealing to urban buyers. Initially powered by a range of engines including a 1.6L and 1.8L gasoline and a 1.8L diesel in European markets, while North America received a 2.0L four-cylinder producing approximately 148 horsepower. Transmission options included a 5-speed manual, CVT, and in some markets, a 6-speed automated manual. Available in both front-wheel drive and all-wheel drive configurations using Mitsubishi's All Wheel Control (AWC) system. The interior offered a straightforward, functional design with a focus on durability rather than luxury, though higher trims included features like a panoramic glass roof, touchscreen infotainment, and premium audio systems. Despite its compact exterior dimensions, the ASX provided a spacious cabin with flexible seating and cargo arrangements. The model received numerous refreshes throughout its unusually long production run, with significant facelifts in 2012, 2014, 2015 (second facelift with Dynamic Shield), and 2019 bringing updated styling, improved technology, and refined powertrains to keep it competitive. The ASX became one of Mitsubishi's most successful global models, particularly in Europe and Australia, due to its combination of practicality, value, and manageable size.
Mitsubishi-ASX.name: First Generation (GA)

Mitsubishi-ASX.description: The second-generation Mitsubishi ASX represents a dramatic shift in the model's development, now based on the Renault Captur following Mitsubishi's integration into the Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi Alliance. The exterior features Mitsubishi-specific styling elements including a distinctive interpretation of the brand's Dynamic Shield front design, though the overall silhouette and proportions closely resemble its Renault counterpart. Dimensionally similar to the outgoing model but with more modern packaging for improved interior space. Powertrain options reflect the Renault origins, including a 1.0-liter turbocharged three-cylinder engine producing approximately 90 horsepower, a 1.3-liter turbocharged four-cylinder with 140 horsepower, and a 1.6-liter hybrid system combining a gasoline engine with an electric motor for a total system output of around 145 horsepower.
