Some markets also receive a plug-in hybrid variant with approximately 30 miles of electric-only range. Transmission options include a 6-speed manual and 7-speed dual-clutch automatic depending on engine. The interior represents a significant upgrade over the previous generation with a more contemporary design featuring a 7-inch (or optional 9.3-inch) vertical touchscreen infotainment system, a digital instrument cluster, and improved materials throughout. Advanced safety technology includes lane keeping assist, traffic sign recognition, and autonomous emergency braking. Built in Spain alongside the Renault Captur, the new ASX is primarily focused on European markets where the original model achieved its greatest success. This generation marks a new approach for Mitsubishi in Europe, leveraging Alliance synergies to deliver a thoroughly modernized product while reducing development costs. A facelifted version was launched in April 2024.
Mitsubishi-ASX.name: Second Generation

Mitsubishi-Challenger.description: The original Mitsubishi Challenger (known as Pajero Sport or Montero Sport in many markets) was introduced as a mid-size SUV based on the Mitsubishi Triton/L200 pickup truck platform. Featuring body-on-frame construction with a shortened wheelbase compared to the Triton, it offered genuine off-road capability with available four-wheel drive including low-range gearing. The exterior design maintained rugged styling cues with pronounced wheel arches, substantial ground clearance, and a prominent front end. Powertrain options varied by market but typically included a 2.5L turbodiesel and a range of gasoline engines including a 3.0L V6, paired with either manual or automatic transmissions. The suspension utilized independent double wishbones at the front and leaf springs at the rear, balancing off-road articulation with reasonable on-road comfort. The interior featured straightforward, durable design with seating for five passengers in standard form, though some markets received seven-seat variants with a third row. Equipment levels varied widely by market, from basic utility-focused versions to more luxurious variants with leather upholstery, power accessories, and premium audio. Though less refined than some competitors, the first-generation Challenger/Pajero Sport built a reputation for durability and off-road capability, particularly in developing markets where these attributes were highly valued.
Mitsubishi-Challenger.name: First Generation (K90/PA)

Mitsubishi-Challenger.description: The second-generation Challenger continued its relationship with the Triton/L200 pickup, adopting more modern styling while maintaining its rugged body-on-frame construction. The exterior featured Mitsubishi's then-current design language with a bold front fascia, flared wheel arches, and distinctive character lines running along the sides. Available in both five and seven-seat configurations, it offered improved interior space and comfort compared to its predecessor. Powertrain options again varied by market, with most regions receiving a 2.5L turbodiesel engine producing approximately 178 horsepower, while some markets also offered V6 gasoline options. Transmission choices included a five-speed manual or five-speed automatic, with four-wheel drive systems featuring Super Select II or Easy Select depending on specification, both offering low-range capability for serious off-road use. The suspension was refined with a new rear multi-link setup replacing the previous leaf springs, significantly improving on-road ride quality while maintaining off-road articulation. The interior saw substantial improvements in design, material quality, and features, with higher trim levels offering touchscreen navigation, leather upholstery, and advanced safety equipment. Despite these refinements, the second-generation maintained its focus on durability and off-road capability, positioning it as a more rugged alternative to increasingly road-focused crossover SUVs. The model achieved particular success in Southeast Asia, Australia, the Middle East, and Latin America, markets where its combination of toughness, practicality, and reasonable comfort was especially valued.
Mitsubishi-Challenger.name: Second Generation (KH)

Mitsubishi-Challenger.description: The third generation, now universally known as the Pajero Sport/Montero Sport with the Challenger name discontinued in most markets, represents a significant advancement in design, technology, and refinement while maintaining its body-on-frame construction and off-road focus. Built on an updated version of the Triton/L200 platform, it features dramatically different styling with Mitsubishi's 'Dynamic Shield' front design, distinctive vertical taillights extending from the rear pillars, and a more sculpted overall appearance. Powertrain options center around a 2.4L MIVEC turbodiesel producing approximately 180 horsepower and 430 Nm of torque in most markets, paired with a new 8-speed automatic transmission (replacing the previous 5-speed), though some regions receive alternative engine options including gasoline variants. The four-wheel drive system was upgraded to Super Select 4WD-II with improved off-road electronics including hill descent control, terrain selection modes, and an off-road traction control system. Available in both five and seven-seat configurations, the third generation offers significantly improved interior quality with soft-touch materials, piano black and silver accents, and available leather upholstery. Technology features include an 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system, multi-around view monitor, and on later models, a digital instrument cluster. Safety technology expanded substantially with the addition of Forward Collision Mitigation, Blind Spot Warning, and Ultrasonic Misacceleration Mitigation System. A facelift in 2019 brought updated styling, enhanced technology including smartphone integration, and additional driver assistance features. This generation successfully bridges the gap between rugged capability and everyday refinement, maintaining the model's appeal in developing markets while offering a more sophisticated package to compete with increasingly premium competitors.
Mitsubishi-Challenger.name: Third Generation (QF/QG)

Mitsubishi-Eclipse-Cross.description: The original Mitsubishi Eclipse Cross was introduced as a compact crossover SUV positioned between the smaller ASX/Outlander Sport and larger Outlander in Mitsubishi's lineup. Built on a modified version of the GS platform shared with the Outlander, it featured distinctive styling with a coupe-like roofline, split rear window design, and Mitsubishi's 'Dynamic Shield' front fascia. The name 'Eclipse' revived a nameplate previously used on Mitsubishi's sporty coupe, though the Eclipse Cross shared nothing with its namesake beyond the badge. Primarily powered by a new 1.5-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine producing approximately 152 horsepower and 184 lb-ft of torque, paired with a continuously variable transmission (CVT) featuring eight simulated gears. Some markets also received a 2.2-liter diesel option. Available in both front-wheel drive and all-wheel drive configurations using Mitsubishi's Super All-Wheel Control (S-AWC) system derived from the Lancer Evolution. The interior introduced new design elements including a touchpad controller for the infotainment system and a head-up display, though the split rear window design compromised rearward visibility and cargo space was modest for the class. Standard and available features included heated front and rear seats, adaptive cruise control, forward collision mitigation, and lane departure warning. The first iteration of the Eclipse Cross represented Mitsubishi's attempt to offer a more style-focused crossover alongside its more practical offerings, though the unconventional rear styling proved controversial with consumers and critics.
Mitsubishi-Eclipse-Cross.name: First Generation

Mitsubishi-Eclipse-Cross.description: The substantially refreshed Eclipse Cross received significant exterior styling changes, most notably abandoning the controversial split rear window design in favor of a more conventional tailgate with redesigned taillights, improving both aesthetics and rearward visibility. The front fascia was also updated with revised lighting elements and bumper design, while the overall dimensions increased slightly, adding about 5.5 inches to the overall length. The interior received more subtle updates focused on usability, with an updated infotainment system featuring a larger 8-inch touchscreen positioned closer to the driver and redesigned with improved functionality, eliminating the previous touchpad controller. The powertrain remained largely unchanged with the 1.5-liter turbocharged four-cylinder continuing as the primary offering, though refinements improved overall drivability. A significant addition was the plug-in hybrid (PHEV) powertrain in select markets, adapting the system from the Outlander PHEV with a 2.4-liter gasoline engine combined with electric motors at both axles, providing all-wheel drive capability and approximately 22 miles of electric-only range. The chassis received minor refinements to improve ride quality and handling precision, while additional sound insulation enhanced overall refinement. Safety technology expanded to include improved driver assistance features and additional airbags. The updated Eclipse Cross addressed many of the criticisms of the original model while maintaining its position as a style-focused alternative in Mitsubishi's crossover lineup, bridging the gap between mainstream compact crossovers and more premium offerings.
Mitsubishi-Eclipse-Cross.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Mitsubishi-Eclipse-Cross-PHEV.description: The Mitsubishi Eclipse Cross PHEV (Plug-in Hybrid Electric Vehicle) was introduced as part of the Eclipse Cross facelift, adopting and refining the plug-in hybrid technology first deployed in the larger Outlander PHEV. Based on the refreshed Eclipse Cross with its revised exterior styling, the PHEV variant is visually distinguished by unique badging, specific wheel designs, and in some markets, exclusive color options. The sophisticated hybrid powertrain combines a 2.4-liter gasoline engine producing approximately 126 horsepower with two electric motors—a 82 hp motor at the front and a 95 hp motor at the rear—creating a unique all-wheel drive system without needing a traditional driveshaft. Total system output is approximately 188 horsepower, providing more responsive performance than the standard turbocharged model. A 13.8 kWh lithium-ion battery enables an electric-only driving range of approximately 22 miles (45 kilometers on the WLTP cycle) with a top speed of about 80 mph in EV mode. This battery can be charged using a standard household outlet, Level 2 charging station, or DC fast charging capable of an 80% charge in approximately 25 minutes. Multiple drive modes include EV Priority (using only electric power), Series Hybrid (where the engine acts as a generator), Parallel Hybrid (where both the engine and motors power the vehicle), and a Battery Save mode to maintain charge for later use. The system also offers selectable regenerative braking strength via paddle shifters. The interior features specific displays for monitoring the hybrid system's operation and energy flow, while the S-AWC (Super All-Wheel Control) system benefits from the precise torque control enabled by the electric motors. A unique feature is the vehicle's bi-directional charging capability, allowing it to function as a mobile power source for outdoor activities or emergency situations. The Eclipse Cross PHEV combines Mitsubishi's expertise in both SUVs and electrification.
Mitsubishi-Eclipse-Cross-PHEV.name: First Generation

Mitsubishi-Lancer.description: The original Mitsubishi Lancer was introduced as a compact car positioned between the company's Minica kei car and the larger Galant. Available in sedan and wagon body styles, it featured conventional boxy styling typical of the era. Powered by various inline-four engines ranging from 1.2 to 1.6 liters depending on the market. The performance-oriented 1600 GSR variant gained fame through rally victories, establishing the Lancer's motorsport heritage early in its history. This generation was largely sold in Asian markets with limited distribution elsewhere, though it was marketed in some regions as the Dodge Colt through Chrysler's partnership with Mitsubishi.
Mitsubishi-Lancer.name: First Generation (A70)

Mitsubishi-Lancer.description: The second-generation Lancer adopted more angular styling with improved aerodynamics. Available in sedan, wagon, and three-door hatchback body styles depending on the market. Engine options included a broader range of four-cylinder units ranging from 1.2 to 1.8 liters, with the introduction of the first diesel Lancer in some markets. This generation expanded global distribution with rebadged versions sold as the Dodge Colt, Plymouth Champ, and Chrysler Lancer in various markets. The performance variant, known as the Lancer EX2000 Turbo, featured a turbocharged engine producing approximately 168 horsepower, further cementing the model's sporting credentials.
Mitsubishi-Lancer.name: Second Generation (EX)

Mitsubishi-Lancer.description: The third-generation Lancer featured more modern styling with a taller profile for improved interior space, available in sedan and station wagon body styles. Engine options varied by market but typically ranged from 1.3 to 1.8 liters, with both naturally aspirated and turbocharged variants. This generation saw the introduction of the Lancer Fiore, a front-wheel drive variant sold alongside the original rear-wheel drive model in some markets. The high-performance variant, now branded as the first Lancer Turbo, continued the model's motorsport success with advanced features for the time including electronic fuel injection and intercooling.
Mitsubishi-Lancer.name: Third Generation (C10/C30)

Mitsubishi-Lancer.description: The fourth-generation Lancer represented a significant shift with all models now utilizing front-wheel drive architecture. Styling became more rounded in line with automotive trends of the late 1980s. Body styles included sedan, wagon, and in some markets, a five-door hatchback. The engine lineup was refreshed with improved four-cylinder units, including multi-valve technology in higher specifications. This generation is notable for introducing the GTi variant with a 1.8-liter DOHC engine producing approximately 136 horsepower, providing an accessible performance option below the more extreme Evolution models that would later emerge.
Mitsubishi-Lancer.name: Fourth Generation (C50/C70)

Mitsubishi-Lancer.description: The fifth-generation Lancer featured more rounded, aerodynamic styling and grew slightly in all dimensions. Available primarily as a sedan and wagon, with a coupe version in some markets. This generation is particularly significant for introducing the first Lancer Evolution in 1992, a high-performance variant developed for World Rally Championship competition, featuring a turbocharged 2.0-liter engine, all-wheel drive, and sophisticated suspension. Standard Lancers continued with a range of four-cylinder engines, with improved safety features including available ABS and driver airbags in higher trim levels. Regional variations were substantial, with different styling and equipment depending on the market.
Mitsubishi-Lancer.name: Fifth Generation (CB/CD/CE)

Mitsubishi-Lancer.description: The sixth-generation Lancer continued the model's evolution with more refined styling and improved interior quality. Available in sedan, wagon, and in some markets, coupe body styles. Engine options were updated with improved efficiency and emissions compliance, ranging from 1.3 to 1.8 liters in standard models. The Lancer Evolution continued through iterations IV, V, and VI during this generation, each offering increased performance and handling capabilities, with the Evo VI producing up to 280 horsepower in some specifications. This generation saw expanded global distribution with the Lancer now available in more markets under the Mitsubishi brand rather than through rebadging arrangements.
Mitsubishi-Lancer.name: Sixth Generation (CK/CM)

Mitsubishi-Lancer.description: The seventh-generation Lancer featured more distinctive styling with a prominent grille and sharper lines. Available primarily as a sedan and wagon, with the Cedia name used in some markets. The interior saw significant improvements in materials and design, with more modern amenities including available navigation systems in higher trims. Engine options were refreshed with improved four-cylinder units ranging from 1.3 to 2.4 liters depending on the market. The Evolution series continued with the Evo VII, VIII, and IX, featuring increasingly sophisticated technology including active yaw control and more advanced all-wheel drive systems, with power outputs maintained at Japan's voluntary 280 horsepower limit but with improved torque and response. This generation diversified the Lancer lineup with variants including the Ralliart model offering a middle ground between standard models and the extreme Evolution.
Mitsubishi-Lancer.name: Seventh Generation (CS/LS/KS)

Mitsubishi-Lancer.description: The eighth-generation Lancer, marketed as the Cedia in Japan, represented a significant step up in size and sophistication, moving from the subcompact to compact segment. Built on the CS2A-CS9W platform, it was available in sedan and station wagon body styles. The design featured more modern styling with a prominent front grille and improved interior quality compared to its predecessor. Engine options varied by market, ranging from 1.3 to 2.4 liters, with improvements in efficiency and emissions compliance. This generation continued the tradition of the Lancer Evolution (VII, VIII, IX) during its production run, featuring advanced technology including active yaw control and sophisticated all-wheel drive systems. In Japan, it continued to be sold alongside the later generation model (marketed as Galant Fortis) until 2010. Production of this platform continued in various markets through 2007 when it was replaced by the new ninth-generation Lancer globally.
Mitsubishi-Lancer.name: Eighth Generation (CS/Cedia)

Mitsubishi-Lancer.description: The ninth-generation Lancer featured aggressive styling with a distinctive 'shark nose' front end incorporating Mitsubishi's trapezoidal grille design. Built on the Mitsubishi GS platform, it was offered as a sedan and five-door hatchback (marketed as the Lancer Sportback). The platform was shared with the Outlander SUV, bringing benefits in rigidity and crash protection. Engine options varied by market but typically included 1.5 to 2.4-liter four-cylinders, with a focus on improved efficiency. The Evolution X continued the high-performance tradition with a new aluminum block, variable valve timing, and a sophisticated S-AWC (Super All-Wheel Control) system, though it would be the final Evolution model, discontinued in 2016. A Ralliart variant offered a detuned version of the Evolution's turbocharged engine with all-wheel drive and a dual-clutch transmission. The mainstream Lancer received a series of minor updates throughout its extended production run including a significant facelift in 2015-2016. Production was gradually phased out across different markets by 2017, with Mitsubishi ending global production in August 2017 without a direct successor. Despite its age, it maintained popularity in certain regions due to its reputation for reliability, value, and distinctive styling.
Mitsubishi-Lancer.name: Ninth Generation (CY/GS)

Mitsubishi-Lancer.description: The tenth-generation Lancer, marketed as the Grand Lancer, was a Taiwan-exclusive model developed by China Motor Corporation (CMC) with design collaboration from Pininfarina Shanghai. Built on the same platform as the ninth generation (CS8A), it represented an extensive facelift rather than a completely new platform. The exterior received a complete redesign including the new Mitsubishi Dynamic Shield grille, redesigned front hood, bumpers, fenders, door panels, and rear bumper. The interior was also significantly updated with new styling and enhanced features. This generation maintained the Lancer nameplate in the Taiwanese market after global production ended in 2017, with sales continuing due to strong local demand for the Lancer nameplate. Production of the Grand Lancer ended in April 2024, marking the end of the Mitsubishi Lancer nameplate after 51 years of production.
Mitsubishi-Lancer.name: Tenth Generation (Grand Lancer/Taiwan)

Mitsubishi-Mirage.description: Mitsubishi launched the Mirage as a front-wheel drive three-door hatchback in March 1978, as a response to the 1973 oil crisis. A five-door hatchback on a longer wheelbase arrived in September. The first generation featured four-wheel independent suspension, rack and pinion steering, plus front disc brakes. Power initially came from 1,244 and 1410 cc iterations of the Orion engine. A facelift arrived in February 1982 with flusher fitting headlamps and updated styling. In October 1982, a four-door sedan variant was introduced in Japan under the names Mirage Saloon and Lancer Fiore. Japanese manufacture ended in October 1983.
Mitsubishi-Mirage.name: First Generation

Mitsubishi-Mirage.description: Mitsubishi launched the second generation Mirage to Japan in 1983, again splitting the range into Mirage (three- and five-door hatchback, plus four-door sedan) and Lancer Fiore (four-door sedan) models. A station wagon version of the Mirage was added in 1985, with a four-wheel drive wagon available from fall 1986. Uprated engines were deployed including 1.3- and 1.5-liter Orion gasoline engines replacing previous units, plus 1.6 and 1.8-liter Sirius gasoline powerplants and for the first time a 1.8-liter Sirius diesel. The car received a very mild facelift in early 1986. The second generation Mirage hatchback was replaced in October 1987; the sedans were replaced in January 1988. The Wagon and Van versions were kept in production with some minor updates until 1991.
Mitsubishi-Mirage.name: Second Generation

Mitsubishi-Mirage.description: Mitsubishi introduced the more rounded, third-generation Mirage to Japan in October 1987. The basic model was a three-door hatchback with upright tailgate and large glasshouse. The sedan, released to Japan in January 1988 was stylistically distinct with almost vertical rear glass, influenced by the larger Galant. The range was complemented by a five-door liftback in June 1988. Engines available were 1.3- and 1.5-liter Orion gasoline inline-fours and 1.8-liter Saturn gasoline inline-four, plus a 1.8-liter Sirius diesel carrying over. Four-wheel-drive versions were also available in Japan. The third generation received a minor facelift in September 1989, with late models receiving the same modernized engines as were seen in the subsequent generation.
Mitsubishi-Mirage.name: Third Generation

Mitsubishi-Mirage.description: In October 1991, the fourth generation Mirage made its debut for the Japanese market alongside the related Lancer. Departing from the previous series, the new Mirage adopted a much rounder body shape. The Japanese Mirage lineup comprised the three-door hatchback (now called Mirage Cyborg) and sedan (now with a six-window glasshouse), plus a new coupé body type suffixed Asti. Lancer variants sold in Japan offered unique body variants—a four-windowed sedan and, from May 1992, a station wagon named Mitsubishi Libero. A turbocharged model named Libero GT was also available. The US specification with longer bumpers has drag coefficient of 0.33 (coupe) and 0.32 (sedan) respectively.
Mitsubishi-Mirage.name: Fourth Generation

Mitsubishi-Mirage.description: The release of the fifth generation Mirage to Japan in October 1995 introduced a rationalized lineup as a result of the fragile post-bubble economy in Japan. Three body types were issued: first, the three-door hatchback and sedan, then in December 1995, the two-door coupé (Asti). While the sedan grew slightly in size, the coupé shrunk modestly. It was bumped from the subcompact class to compact in the United States. A minor facelift arrived in 1997 with new grille and reshaped inner-portions of the headlamps. Although a new, substantially larger and more expensive generation of Lancer sedan arrived in 2000, many export markets retained the Mirage-derived model up until 2003 when Japanese manufacture concluded. Production dates varied by region: 1995–2003 (Japan), 1997–2002 (Indonesia), 1998–2012 (India), 2003–2019 (China).
Mitsubishi-Mirage.name: Fifth Generation

Mitsubishi-Mirage.description: Mitsubishi resurrected the Mirage name internationally for a new sixth generation model in 2012. The current Mirage model is a subcompact hatchback and sedan that replaces the Mitsubishi Colt sold between 2002 and 2012. The sixth generation shares its platform with the Nissan March/Micra and is manufactured at Mitsubishi's plant in Laem Chabang, Thailand. The Mirage competes in the subcompact segment with fuel efficiency as a primary selling point. The sedan version was added to the lineup in 2013. A facelift was applied in 2017 with updated front and rear styling, new interior features, and improved safety equipment. The model continues in production as of 2024.
Mitsubishi-Mirage.name: Sixth Generation

Mitsubishi-Outlander.description: The original Mitsubishi Outlander was introduced as a compact crossover SUV, initially marketed as the Airtrek in Japan before adopting the global Outlander name. The Airtrek was first introduced to the Japanese market on June 20, 2001, as a car-like unibody crossover with available all-wheel drive. Built on the GS platform shared with the Lancer, it offered both front-wheel drive and four-wheel drive configurations. The Outlander nameplate arrived in North America in 2003, replacing the Mitsubishi Montero Sport with modified front grille and headlights that increased overall length. Powertrain options included a 2.0L 4G63 turbo engine (producing 240 PS in Japan, 202 PS in export markets), a 2.0L GDI engine, and a 2.4L four-cylinder engine. Transmission choices included four-speed and five-speed automatic transmissions and five-speed manual. The interior offered seating for five passengers with flexible cargo arrangements. This first generation established the Outlander nameplate as a compact crossover competitor against the Toyota RAV4 and Honda CR-V.
Mitsubishi-Outlander.name: First Generation (CU/ZE/ZF)

Mitsubishi-Outlander.description: The second-generation Outlander was launched on October 17, 2005, and featured more distinctive styling with Mitsubishi's 'Jet Fighter' inspired design. Production began in 2006, with North American model years starting in 2007 and running through 2013. Larger than its predecessor, it moved into the mid-size crossover category and introduced an available third-row seat for seven-passenger capability. Built on the Mitsubishi GS platform, it offered improved handling and refinement. Powertrain options included a 2.0L DOHC MIVEC four-cylinder, 2.4L MIVEC four-cylinder, 3.0L V6, and in some markets, diesel engines including VW's 2.0L TDI and PSA's 2.2L DW12 HDi units. An electronically controlled all-wheel drive system called Super All-Wheel Control (S-AWC) was available on higher trims. The second generation introduced the first Outlander PHEV in January 2013 (launched at the 2012 Paris Motor Show), combining a 2.0L gasoline engine with electric motors and lithium-ion battery, with limited initial availability. Interior quality improved significantly with better materials and available features. Facelifts in 2008 and 2010 kept the model current. PSA's Peugeot 4007 and Citroën C-Crosser were badge-engineered versions manufactured by Mitsubishi in Japan.
Mitsubishi-Outlander.name: Second Generation (CW/ZG/ZH)

Mitsubishi-Outlander.description: The third-generation Outlander was unveiled at the 2012 Geneva Motor Show with production beginning in Russia in July 2012, followed by European markets in September 2012. Model years started in 2013 for export markets. This generation featured refined styling with Mitsubishi's 'Dynamic Shield' design language introduced in the 2016 facelift. Built on an updated version of the GS platform, it maintained seven-seat seating in most markets while offering improved noise isolation and ride quality. Powertrain options included 2.0L and 2.4L four-cylinder engines and a 3.0L V6. The Outlander PHEV became significantly more available during this generation, featuring a 2.0L or 2.4L petrol engine with electric motors. Three facelifts occurred: the first in 2014, the second in 2016 (introducing Dynamic Shield styling and CVT8 transmission), and the third in 2019 with updated grille and bumper designs. The battery capacity for the PHEV increased from 12 kWh to 13.8 kWh in 2019, extending electric range to 65 km. Production continued through 2024, representing one of the longest-running generations. The third-generation Outlander, particularly in PHEV form, became the world's best-selling plug-in hybrid, helping establish Mitsubishi's reputation in electrified vehicles.
Mitsubishi-Outlander.name: Third Generation (GF/GG/ZJ/ZK/ZL)

Mitsubishi-Outlander.description: The fourth-generation Outlander debuted on February 16, 2021, representing the most substantial redesign in the model's history. Developed after Mitsubishi became part of the Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi Alliance, it was based on the Nissan Rogue/X-Trail (T33) and uses the CMF-CD platform shared within the alliance. Production began in 2021 for 2022 model year introduction. The design features a bold interpretation of the 'Dynamic Shield' front design with complex surface detailing and floating roof effect. Substantially larger than its predecessor, it offers improved passenger space particularly in the standard third row. The primary powertrain is the 2.5L Nissan PR25DD four-cylinder engine producing 181 horsepower, paired with a Jatco CVT8 transmission and available with the updated Super All-Wheel Control (S-AWC) system. The PHEV variant, released in Japan in October 2021 and arriving in North America for the 2023 model year, features the 2.4L 4B12 engine with upgraded electric motors and a larger 20 kWh lithium-ion battery providing 87 km of electric-only range. The interior represents a major leap forward with higher quality materials, a modern design featuring a 9-inch touchscreen infotainment system with wireless Apple CarPlay, 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, and available head-up display. Safety technology includes forward collision mitigation, lane departure warning, adaptive cruise control, and blind-spot monitoring. Starting in 2026, the Outlander will also be rebadged as the Nissan Rogue PHEV in North America. The fourth-generation Outlander demonstrates the benefits of the Alliance partnership while preserving Mitsubishi's distinctive character and all-weather capability focus.
Mitsubishi-Outlander.name: Fourth Generation (GM/GN/ZM)

Mitsubishi-Outlander-PHEV.description: The original Mitsubishi Outlander PHEV (Plug-in Hybrid Electric Vehicle) pioneered accessible plug-in hybrid technology in the SUV segment, based on the third-generation Outlander platform. The innovative powertrain combined a 2.0L MIVEC gasoline engine with two electric motors—one at each axle—creating a unique all-wheel drive system without needing a traditional driveshaft. A 12 kWh lithium-ion battery provided an electric-only range of approximately 32 km (20 miles) under the New European Driving Cycle. Total system output was approximately 200 horsepower, with the ability to operate in three distinct modes: EV Drive (using only electric power), Series Hybrid Mode (where the engine generates electricity for the motors), and Parallel Hybrid Mode (where both the engine and motors power the vehicle). Unlike many competing hybrids, the Outlander PHEV offered DC fast-charging capability via CHAdeMO, allowing an 80% battery charge in approximately 25 minutes. The system also featured Vehicle-to-Home power supply functionality in some markets. Visually distinguished from conventional Outlander models by subtle PHEV badging, unique wheels, and additional charging port. A significant update in 2016 brought refined 'Dynamic Shield' styling, improved electric motors, and a more efficient 2.4L gasoline engine, while a 2018 revision increased battery capacity to 13.8 kWh and introduced updated powertrain software, improving both performance and efficiency. The Outlander PHEV became the world's best-selling plug-in hybrid SUV, finding particular success in European markets where incentives favored its combination of electric capability and practical utility.
Mitsubishi-Outlander-PHEV.name: First Generation (ZJ/ZK/ZL)

Mitsubishi-Outlander-PHEV.description: The second-generation Outlander PHEV is based on the fourth-generation Outlander platform, sharing its architecture with the Nissan Rogue/X-Trail on the Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi CMF-CD platform. The plug-in hybrid system received a comprehensive upgrade, combining the proven 2.4L MIVEC gasoline engine with more powerful electric motors—85 kW at the front and 100 kW at the rear—and a significantly larger 20 kWh battery pack. This system delivers approximately 84 km (52 miles) of electric-only range under WLTP/NEDC testing and a combined 248 horsepower. The seven-mode drive selector includes Power, Eco, and Normal settings that adjust system response and efficiency, along with an innovative one-pedal driving mode. The new platform enables a full seven-seat configuration, making it one of the few plug-in hybrids to offer three-row seating. DC fast-charging capability continues with CHAdeMO, now providing up to 80% charge in approximately 38 minutes. The interior features a 9-inch touchscreen infotainment system with wireless Apple CarPlay, a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster with PHEV-specific displays, and available head-up display. Advanced safety features include MI-PILOT Assist with adaptive cruise control and lane-keeping assistance. The second-generation Outlander PHEV builds on the success of its predecessor with substantially improved electric capability, performance, and refinement, positioning it as one of the most versatile plug-in hybrid SUVs on the market.
Mitsubishi-Outlander-PHEV.name: Second Generation (GM/GN/ZM)

Mitsubishi-Outlander-Sport.description: The Mitsubishi Outlander Sport (known as the ASX or RVR in other markets) was introduced for the 2011 model year as a compact crossover positioned below the standard Outlander in size and price. Built on a shortened version of the Outlander's GS platform shared with the Lancer, it featured distinctive styling with Mitsubishi's 'jet fighter' front grille design, a sloping roofline, and compact dimensions appealing to urban buyers. In North America, it was powered by a 2.0L four-cylinder engine (4B11) producing 148 horsepower, with a larger 2.4L option (4B12) added in 2015 generating 166-168 horsepower. Transmission options included a five-speed manual (later discontinued) and continuously variable transmission (CVT), with both front-wheel drive and all-wheel drive configurations available using Mitsubishi's All Wheel Control (AWC) system. The interior offered straightforward design with a focus on functionality, though higher trims included features like a panoramic glass roof, push-button start, and available navigation. The model received numerous facelifts throughout its long production run: first facelift in April 2012 with revised front fascia, 2015 model year updates with LED daytime running lamps and new wheels, November 2015 introducing the 'Dynamic Shield' design language, and a third facelift unveiled in February 2019 for the 2020 model year with updated front styling, new 18-inch alloy wheels, and an upgraded infotainment system with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. Standard safety features expanded over time to include seven airbags, stability control, and advanced driver assistance systems. Despite its compact exterior dimensions, the Outlander Sport provided a relatively spacious cabin with flexible seating and cargo arrangements. Production for the North American market continued through 2023, making it one of Mitsubishi's longest-running models in the region.
Mitsubishi-Outlander-Sport.name: First Generation (GA)

Mitsubishi-Outlander-Sport.description: The second-generation Mitsubishi Outlander Sport represents a significant step forward, built on the Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi Alliance CMF-B platform shared with the second-generation Renault Captur. This new platform brings substantial improvements in ride quality, interior space, and efficiency compared to the previous GS-platform vehicle. The exterior features Mitsubishi's latest interpretation of the Dynamic Shield design language with a bold front fascia, distinctive LED lighting signatures, and more contemporary proportions while maintaining the compact crossover identity. The vehicle is slightly larger than its predecessor but remains positioned below the standard Outlander in Mitsubishi's lineup. Powertrain options include a 1.5-liter turbocharged three-cylinder engine (TCe 130) producing approximately 158-161 horsepower, paired with a continuously variable transmission (CVT) or a 6-speed manual transmission in some markets. A mild hybrid (MHEV) version is also available in European markets, offering improved fuel efficiency and reduced emissions. All-wheel drive continues to be available through an updated version of Mitsubishi's All Wheel Control (AWC) system with improved torque vectoring capabilities. The interior represents a significant advancement with higher quality materials, a driver-focused cockpit featuring a 10.25-inch touchscreen infotainment system with wireless smartphone integration (Apple CarPlay and Android Auto), a fully digital instrument cluster on higher trims, and greatly improved connectivity options. Safety technology expands substantially with Mitsubishi's latest driver assistance systems including adaptive cruise control, lane keeping assist, automatic emergency braking with pedestrian and cyclist detection, blind spot monitoring, rear cross traffic alert, and a 360-degree camera system. The second-generation Outlander Sport maintains its position as Mitsubishi's entry-level crossover while offering substantially improved refinement, technology, and efficiency compared to its predecessor, benefiting from the shared development resources of the Alliance partnership.
Mitsubishi-Outlander-Sport.name: Second Generation

Mitsubishi-Pajero.description: The first generation Pajero was launched in May 1982 as a luxury, rugged SUV with three-door short-wheelbase and five-door long-wheelbase body styles. It featured ladder frame chassis and options for 2.0-litre 4-cylinder petrol, 2.6-litre 4-cylinder petrol, turbocharged variants, and later a 3.0-litre V6 engine.
Mitsubishi-Pajero.name: First Generation

Mitsubishi-Pajero.description: The second generation debuted in 1991 with a more modern design. It continued production through 1999 in Japan, though continued in some markets like Philippines until 2008, Colombia until 2012, and China until 2021. Featured improvements in comfort and performance over the first generation.
Mitsubishi-Pajero.name: Second Generation

Mitsubishi-Pajero.description: The third generation was introduced in August 1999 in Japan and late 2000 (as 2001 model) in international markets. It featured monocoque construction instead of body-on-frame design, Mitsubishi's RISE reinforcement system, and the Super Select 4WD II system. Received a minor facelift in 2003.
Mitsubishi-Pajero.name: Third Generation

Mitsubishi-Pajero.description: The fourth generation debuted at the 2006 Paris Motor Show and was produced from September 2006 to March 2021. It featured revised interior and exterior styling, dual-stage front airbags, and side-impact and curtain airbags. The final generation was discontinued in March 2021, ending the Pajero's 40-year production run.
Mitsubishi-Pajero.name: Fourth Generation

Mitsubishi-RVR.description: The original Mitsubishi RVR was introduced in Japan as a compact multi-purpose vehicle (MPV) with a tall wagon-like body style. The name RVR stood for 'Recreation Vehicle Runner.' Available in both front-wheel drive and all-wheel drive configurations, it offered versatile interior space despite relatively compact exterior dimensions. Powertrain options included various four-cylinder engines, with performance variants featuring the turbocharged 4G63 engine shared with the Lancer Evolution, producing up to 240 horsepower in the RVR Hyper Sports Gear R trim. The first generation evolved through several updates, with the 'New RVR' from 1997-2002 featuring revised styling and updated powertrains. This generation was marketed in some export markets as the Mitsubishi Space Runner or Expo LRV, though with limited distribution outside Japan and select Asian markets. The original RVR established Mitsubishi's presence in the recreational vehicle segment in Japan, offering a combination of utility, performance options, and compact dimensions ideal for urban use.
Mitsubishi-RVR.name: First Generation

Mitsubishi-RVR.description: After an eight-year hiatus, the RVR nameplate was revived for a completely different vehicle—a compact crossover SUV marketed globally under various names including ASX in Europe and Outlander Sport in North America. Built on a shortened version of the Outlander's GS platform, it featured distinctive styling with Mitsubishi's 'jet fighter' front grille design and a more conventional crossover silhouette compared to the MPV-style original. In Japan, it was primarily powered by a 1.8L MIVEC four-cylinder engine, with later updates adding smaller displacement options and improved efficiency. Transmission choices included CVT and manual options depending on the market, with both front-wheel drive and electronically controlled all-wheel drive available. The interior offered straightforward functionality with a focus on practicality, featuring flexible seating and cargo configurations. The second-generation RVR received several significant updates throughout its unusually long production run, with refreshes in 2013, 2016, and a more substantial redesign in 2020 bringing elements of Mitsubishi's Dynamic Shield design language, updated technology, and refined powertrains. Despite its age compared to competitors, the RVR maintained popularity in Japan and global markets due to its combination of compact dimensions, practical utility, value pricing, and available all-wheel drive capability.
Mitsubishi-RVR.name: Second Generation

Mitsubishi-Triton.description: The first generation model of Mitsubishi's compact pickup truck was first sold in Japan as the Mitsubishi Forte in September 1978 and continued until late 1986. In export markets, it was known as the L200, Forte, or other names depending on the region. The Dodge Ram 50 and Plymouth Arrow Truck were badge-engineered versions sold by Chrysler Corporation from 1979. The vehicle was available with various engine options including 1.6L, 2.0L petrol, 2.3L diesel, and 2.6L engines. Four-wheel drive was added in 1981.
Mitsubishi-Triton.name: First Generation (L200)

Mitsubishi-Triton.description: The second generation model was introduced in 1986 for most markets. In Australia, this model launched in October 1986 as the low-cost Triton. In Japan the pickups made their return as the Strada in March 1991. A facelift took place for the 1993 model year, with a new grille and new plastic bumpers. The truck usually has a 2.5 litre diesel or turbo diesel engine. Production continued until 1996, with Japanese domestic market sales continuing into the middle of 1997. In the US it was known as the Mitsubishi Mighty Max or Dodge Ram 50.
Mitsubishi-Triton.name: Second Generation (K00/K10/K20/K30)

Mitsubishi-Triton.description: In 1996, a new generation model was introduced with 2.5-litre turbodiesel engines developing 85 kW. Other engine options include two sixteen-valve fuel injected gasoline engines and a naturally aspirated diesel. The previous 2.6-litre unit was replaced with a new, considerably more powerful 2.4-litre engine with 112 kW. Production ended in 2006, built in Laem Chabang, Thailand. In late 2001 the third generation pickup underwent a facelift with new headlights and other changes. An SUV model developed from this generation was called the Mitsubishi Challenger or Montero Sport.
Mitsubishi-Triton.name: Third Generation (K50/K60/K70)

Mitsubishi-Triton.description: The fourth generation Triton was released in 2005. Designed by Akinori Nakanishi, it was built exclusively by Mitsubishi's subsidiary in Thailand and was exported to 140 global markets. It was mostly known as L200 except for Japan and its subsidiary countries' markets. The car had a 2.5-litre turbo-diesel engine developing 100 kW. In Japan, the Triton was exclusively equipped with 3.5-litre petrol engine and 4-speed automatic transmission and was sold from 2006 to 2011. A facelift occurred in 2011 with new front fascia and other updates.
Mitsubishi-Triton.name: Fourth Generation (KA/KB)

Mitsubishi-Triton.description: In 2014, Mitsubishi unveiled the fifth-generation Triton/L200/Strada which went on sale in early 2015 (Asia-Pacific) and late 2015 (Europe and the Caribbean). Since 2015, it shares underpinnings with the rebadged Fiat Fullback for European and Middle East markets. The Triton was refreshed for the 2019 model year at the 2018 Thailand International Motor Expo with new front fascia inspired from the Pajero/Montero Sport, Eclipse Cross and Xpander, new teardrop taillight design, and slight interior changes. This generation received 4 stars from Euro NCAP in 2015.
Mitsubishi-Triton.name: Fifth Generation (KJ/KK/KL)

Mitsubishi-Triton.description: The sixth-generation Triton was unveiled on 26 July 2023, featuring the 'Beast Mode' design concept previewed as the XRT Concept at the 2023 Bangkok International Motor Show. The interior follows the 'Horizontal Axis' concept with geometric shapes and Mitsubishi Touch approach. It features a new 4N16 turbocharged diesel engine with three power output options: 150 PS, 184 PS (Hyper Power), and 204 PS (Hyper Power X2). It received 4 stars from ASEAN NCAP in 2023. Production began in 2023 and continues to present.
Mitsubishi-Triton.name: Sixth Generation (LC/MV)

Nissan-ARIYA.description: The Nissan ARIYA represents the brand's first dedicated electric crossover SUV, built on a new CMF-EV platform (now called AmpR Medium) developed within the Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi Alliance specifically for electric vehicles. The exterior showcases Nissan's evolved design language with a sleek, coupe-like silhouette, distinctive 'shield' interpretation of the V-motion grille that incorporates sensors for driver assistance systems, ultra-slim LED headlights, and a continuous light blade across the rear. The minimalist yet premium interior features a horizontal 'wave' dashboard with integrated dual 12.3-inch displays, haptic touch controls that provide feedback when activated, and a power-sliding center console that can be repositioned based on driver preference. The flat floor enabled by the dedicated EV platform provides exceptional interior space relative to the vehicle's exterior dimensions. Multiple powertrain configurations are available, including a 63 kWh or 87 kWh battery paired with either front-wheel drive or 'e-4ORCE' all-wheel drive utilizing dual motors. Power output ranges from 214 horsepower in the base configuration to 389 horsepower in the high-performance version, with driving range varying from approximately 216 to 304 miles depending on configuration. DC fast charging capability allows adding up to 175 miles of range in 30 minutes under optimal conditions. Advanced technology includes ProPILOT Assist 2.0 with hands-off highway driving capability, a head-up display, Amazon Alexa integration, and wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto.
Nissan-ARIYA.name: First Generation

Nissan-ARIYA.description: The Nissan ARIYA received a mid-cycle facelift for the 2026 model year, debuting at the Japan Mobility Show in November 2025 and unveiled in Japan on December 23, 2025. The facelift includes updated exterior styling elements while maintaining the overall design language of the original generation. The Ariya Nismo high-performance variant was introduced in January 2024, delivering up to 430 horsepower. The platform continues to use the AmpR Medium (formerly CMF-EV) architecture with the same powertrain options: front-wheel drive or all-wheel drive (e-4ORCE) with 63 kWh or 87 kWh battery capacities. Advanced driver assistance features continue to include ProPILOT 2.0 hands-free driving capability on select trims.
Nissan-ARIYA.name: First Generation (2026 Facelift)

Nissan-Altima.description: The original Nissan Altima was introduced as a replacement for the Stanza in Nissan's lineup, positioned between the compact Sentra and flagship Maxima sedans. Built at Nissan's Smyrna, Tennessee plant, it featured a rounded, conservative design typical of early 1990s Japanese sedans. Powered by a 2.4L KA24DE four-cylinder engine producing 150 horsepower, paired with either a 5-speed manual or 4-speed automatic transmission driving the front wheels. The interior offered seating for five with standard amenities including air conditioning, power windows, and a stereo system. Trim levels ranged from the base XE to the luxury-oriented GLE with leather seating, alloy wheels, and additional power accessories. The first-generation Altima established itself as a value-oriented midsize sedan with a focus on reliability and comfort, though it lacked the refinement and features of some competitors.
Nissan-Altima.name: First Generation (U13)

Nissan-Altima.description: The second-generation Altima maintained similar dimensions to its predecessor but featured updated styling with a more aerodynamic profile and refined details. The 2.4L four-cylinder engine continued with minor improvements, still producing 150 horsepower, paired with the same transmission options. Interior space was slightly improved, with better materials and enhanced ergonomics. New features included available side airbags, an improved audio system, and refined suspension tuning for better ride quality. Special editions included the sporty SE and luxury-oriented GLE models, offering distinctive appearance elements and additional features. This generation represented an evolutionary approach, maintaining the Altima's position as a value alternative in the midsize sedan segment while addressing some refinement issues from the first generation.
Nissan-Altima.name: Second Generation (L30)

Nissan-Altima.description: The third-generation Altima marked a significant advancement, growing substantially in size and moving firmly into the midsize sedan category. Built on Nissan's new FF-L platform shared with the Maxima, it featured more aggressive styling with a distinctive front fascia and athletic proportions. Engine options expanded to include a base 2.5L four-cylinder producing 175 horsepower and an optional 3.5L VQ35DE V6 generating 240 horsepower, paired with either a 5-speed manual or 4-speed automatic transmission (later a 5-speed automatic for V6 models). The interior offered significantly more space with improved materials and design, including available features such as a Bose audio system, leather seating, and a power sunroof. The SE-R performance variant joined the lineup in 2005, featuring a 260 horsepower version of the V6, sport-tuned suspension, 18-inch wheels, and unique interior and exterior styling elements. This generation established the Altima as a more distinctive, performance-oriented alternative to competitors like the Honda Accord and Toyota Camry, dramatically increasing its market presence and sales volume.
Nissan-Altima.name: Third Generation (L31)

Nissan-Altima.description: The fourth-generation Altima refined the successful formula of its predecessor with evolutionary styling updates, enhanced technology, and improved efficiency. Available in both sedan and coupe body styles (the latter introduced in 2008), it maintained similar dimensions to the third generation but with more sophisticated design elements. Powertrain options continued with refined versions of the 2.5L four-cylinder (175 hp) and 3.5L V6 (270 hp), now paired with either a 6-speed manual or continuously variable transmission (CVT) that helped improve fuel economy. The interior featured higher quality materials, improved sound insulation, and available technology including Bluetooth connectivity, push-button ignition, and a backup camera. Safety features expanded to include stability control, traction control, and available features like blind spot monitoring. The Altima Hybrid joined the lineup from 2007-2011, combining the 2.5L engine with an electric motor and technology licensed from Toyota for a total system output of 198 horsepower and substantially improved fuel economy. This generation maintained the Altima's strong market position with its balance of performance, efficiency, and value, consistently ranking among the bestselling midsize sedans in the United States.
Nissan-Altima.name: Fourth Generation (L32)

Nissan-Altima.description: The fifth-generation Altima featured more dramatic styling with a bold front grille, sculpted body sides, and a coupe-like roofline, though it was offered only as a sedan with the coupe discontinued. Built on a revised version of the previous platform, it was lighter and more aerodynamic while maintaining similar dimensions. The 2.5L four-cylinder was heavily revised, now producing 182 horsepower, while the 3.5L V6 continued with 270 horsepower, both paired exclusively with an improved continuously variable transmission. The interior received a significant upgrade with higher quality materials, a more contemporary design, and advanced technology including NissanConnect infotainment system with navigation and mobile apps capability. Available features expanded to include remote engine start, dual-zone climate control, and heated steering wheel. Safety technology advanced substantially with the introduction of Nissan Safety Shield including forward collision warning, blind spot monitoring, and rear cross-traffic alert. A mid-cycle refresh in 2016 brought updated exterior styling, enhanced interior materials, and expanded availability of active safety features. The fifth-generation Altima continued as a strong competitor in the midsize segment, particularly appealing to those seeking a combination of expressive styling, good fuel economy, and value pricing.
Nissan-Altima.name: Fifth Generation (L33)

Nissan-Altima.description: The current Altima represents a comprehensive redesign featuring more sophisticated styling with a lower, wider stance, Nissan's V-motion grille design, and sleeker proportions. Built on a new platform, it offers improved structural rigidity, reduced noise, and enhanced handling dynamics. A significant powertrain innovation is the introduction of Nissan's variable compression turbo (VC-Turbo) 2.0L four-cylinder engine generating 248 horsepower as the V6 replacement on higher trims, while the base 2.5L four-cylinder was redesigned to produce 188 horsepower. Both engines pair with a continuously variable transmission. For the first time, all-wheel drive became available, though only with the 2.5L engine. The interior features a more premium design with a 'gliding wing' dashboard housing an 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. Advanced safety technology includes standard Nissan Safety Shield 360 with automatic emergency braking, pedestrian detection, lane departure warning, and automatic high beams, with available ProPILOT Assist providing semi-autonomous driving capability on highways. Special variants include the sporty SR with unique styling elements and the premium Platinum trim with upgraded leather upholstery and additional luxury features. A minor update for 2023 brought revised styling and feature adjustments. The sixth-generation Altima competes in the declining midsize sedan segment by offering distinctive technology, optional all-wheel drive, and comprehensive safety features, helping maintain its relevance as consumer preferences shift toward crossovers and SUVs.
Nissan-Altima.name: Sixth Generation (L34)

Nissan-Armada.description: First generation Nissan Armada (TA60), originally badged as Pathfinder Armada. Built on the Nissan F-Alpha platform shared with the Nissan Titan. Powered by a 5.6L VK56DE V8 engine mated to a 5-speed automatic transmission.
Nissan-Armada.name: First Generation

Nissan-Armada.description: Facelifted first generation Armada introduced for the 2008 model year. Updated VK56DE V8 engine with increased power and improved towing capacity. New front and rear fascia, updated interior, 8-inch infotainment screen, and electronic third-row seats.
Nissan-Armada.name: First Generation (2008 Facelift)

Nissan-Armada.description: Second generation Nissan Armada (Y62) based on the Nissan Patrol platform. Powered by a 5.6L VK56VD Endurance V8 engine producing 390 hp and 394 lb-ft of torque, paired with a 7-speed automatic transmission. Offered in SV, SL, and Platinum trims.
Nissan-Armada.name: Second Generation

Nissan-Armada.description: Facelifted second generation Armada revealed in December 2020. Features redesigned front end with larger grille and C-shaped LED headlights, updated taillights, new center console with 12.3-inch infotainment screen, wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, and standard Safety Shield 360.
Nissan-Armada.name: Second Generation (2021 Facelift)

Nissan-Armada.description: Third generation Nissan Armada (Y63) unveiled September 3, 2024. Features a 3.5-liter twin-turbocharged V6 producing 425 hp and 516 lb-ft of torque paired with a 9-speed automatic transmission. Available in SV, SL, Platinum, Pro-4X, and Platinum Reserve trims. Includes ProPilot Assist 2.1 hands-free driving capability.
Nissan-Armada.name: Third Generation

Nissan-Frontier.description: The original Nissan Frontier (replacing the Nissan Hardbody in North America) was introduced in 1997 as a compact pickup truck available in Regular and King Cab configurations, with a Crew Cab variant added in 2000. Power came from a 2.4L four-cylinder engine producing 143 horsepower, with a 3.3L V6 option generating 170 horsepower added in 1999. Transmission choices included 5-speed manual and 4-speed automatic, with both rear-wheel and four-wheel drive available. The design featured rugged, angular styling with flared fenders resembling those of the larger Titan pickup. Notable variants included the Desert Runner offering the look and raised suspension of the 4x4 with rear-wheel drive. The interior was basic but functional, focusing on durability rather than luxury, though higher trims offered amenities including air conditioning, power accessories, and upgraded audio systems. This pre-facelift model established the Frontier's reputation for durability and off-road capability at a value price point, competing primarily with the Toyota Tacoma and Ford Ranger in the compact truck segment.
Nissan-Frontier.name: First Generation (D22)

Nissan-Frontier.description: The 2001 facelift introduced bolder styling to make the Frontier more appealing to younger buyers in its second generation. Changes included a new grille, bumper, headlights, taillights, and built-in fender flares. The regular cab was discontinued after the 2001 model year. A supercharged version of the V6 engine became available, boosting output to 210 horsepower. The Crew Cab and King Cab versions continued with updated styling details. This facelifted model maintained the same mechanical specifications as the pre-facelift, with the 2.4L four-cylinder and 3.3L V6 engines, while offering improved aesthetics and updated interior touches. The first generation concluded its run in 2004, having established the Frontier's reputation for durability and value in the competitive compact truck segment.
Nissan-Frontier.name: First Generation (D22 Facelift)

Nissan-Frontier.description: The second-generation Frontier grew substantially, moving from the compact to mid-size pickup category. Based on Nissan's F-Alpha platform shared with the full-size Titan, it featured more aggressive styling with pronounced fender flares and a bolder grille. Offered in King Cab and Crew Cab configurations, powertrain options included a 2.5L four-cylinder with 152 horsepower and a 4.0L V6 producing 261 horsepower, paired with either a 5-speed automatic, 6-speed manual, or 5-speed manual transmission depending on engine and configuration. The interior offered improved materials and design, with available features including leather seating, Rockford Fosgate audio system, and navigation in higher trims. Off-road capability was enhanced in the NISMO (later PRO-4X) models with Bilstein shocks, skid plates, and an electronic locking rear differential. Towing capacity reached up to 6,500 pounds with proper equipment. A significant update in 2009 brought refreshed styling including new wheels, updated headlights, a revised grille, rounder bumper, and improved interior materials with better quality surfaces. The NISMO model was replaced by the PRO-4X trim during this update. This pre-powertrain-update generation maintained steady sales throughout its run, appealing to buyers seeking a capable midsize truck with traditional truck values.
Nissan-Frontier.name: Second Generation (D40)

Nissan-Frontier.description: The 2020 model year update marked a significant powertrain overhaul for the second-generation Frontier, introducing a new 3.8L V6 engine producing 310 horsepower and 281 lb-ft of torque, paired exclusively with a 9-speed automatic transmission. This update replaced both the outgoing 4.0L V6 and 2.5L I4 engines, representing a substantial increase in power and refinement. The manual transmission was discontinued except for the PRO-4X model in Canada. The lineup was revised: King Cab models offered both rear-wheel-drive and four-wheel-drive configurations on S and SV models; Crew Cab models extended configurations to SV short bed and SV long bed trims, while PRO-4X remained four-wheel-drive exclusively. Power windows and locks became standard on all trim levels. This update effectively bridged the gap to the upcoming third generation while maintaining the proven D40 platform and frame structure, offering customers improved performance and modern powertrain technology in a familiar package.
Nissan-Frontier.name: Second Generation (D40 Update)

Nissan-Frontier.description: The third-generation Frontier represents the first dedicated model for the North American market, not shared with the global Nissan Navarra. Unveiled on February 4, 2021 for the 2022 model year, it features a comprehensive redesign while retaining a revised high-strength steel ladder frame chassis carried over from the outgoing D40 with substantial reinforcements for improved rigidity. The exterior adopts much more modern, aggressive styling inspired by the classic Nissan Hardbody trucks of the 1980s and early '90s, with a bold grille, distinctive LED lighting signatures, and prominent fender flares. Available in King Cab and Crew Cab configurations with 5-foot and 6-foot bed lengths, it is powered by the 3.8L V6 engine producing 310 horsepower and 281 lb-ft of torque—the most standard horsepower in the midsize truck class at introduction—paired exclusively with a 9-speed automatic transmission. Available with rear-wheel or part-time four-wheel drive with low range. The interior represents a dramatic improvement with contemporary design, higher quality materials, and modern technology including an available 9-inch touchscreen infotainment system with wireless smartphone integration, 360-degree camera system, and enhanced driver assistance features. The off-road-focused PRO-4X trim continues with Bilstein shocks, electronic locking rear differential, and additional underbody protection. Maximum towing capacity reaches 6,720 pounds, with payload up to 1,610 pounds. Trim levels include the base S, SV, and Pro-4X.
Nissan-Frontier.name: Third Generation (D41)

Nissan-Frontier.description: The 2025 model year brought a mid-cycle refresh to the third-generation Frontier, featuring a revised front fascia with updated grille and bumper design for a more refined appearance. Technology upgrades include a standard 12.3-inch touchscreen with wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto on all trims, replacing the previous 9-inch unit. A telescoping steering wheel became standard on SV and higher trims for improved driver comfort and adjustability. New 17-inch alloy wheel designs were introduced, along with an exclusive Afterburn Orange paint color option. The long-wheelbase Crew Cab with 6-foot bed became available on SV, Pro-4X, and SL trims, expanding cargo flexibility. Safety features such as Lane Departure Warning and Blind Spot Warning were made standard across all grades. Maximum towing capacity increased to 7,150 pounds. The PRO-4X trim continues to offer off-road capability with Bilstein shocks, electronic locking rear differential, and underbody skid plates. The Hardbody Edition trim was introduced for 2024, featuring retro-inspired seventeen-inch aluminum wheels painted white and exterior details inspired by the 1980s Nissan Pickup, but the 2025 refresh represents the most comprehensive update to the D41 generation.
Nissan-Frontier.name: Third Generation (D41 Facelift)

Nissan-Juke.description: The original Nissan Juke introduced a distinctively polarizing design to the emerging subcompact crossover segment, featuring bulbous fenders, a coupe-like roofline, raised ground clearance, and unusual split front lighting with round headlights below LED daytime running lights at the hood level. Built on Nissan's B-platform shared with the Versa/Micra, it offered compact exterior dimensions with a more car-like driving position than many crossovers. In North America, power came exclusively from a 1.6L turbocharged four-cylinder engine producing 188 horsepower, paired with either a CVT or 6-speed manual transmission and available with front-wheel or torque-vectoring all-wheel drive. The interior featured a motorcycle-inspired console, distinctive circular gauges, and available colored trim accents, though rear seat and cargo space were limited by the dramatic styling. A high-performance NISMO variant was introduced in 2013 with increased power output (up to 215 hp in the NISMO RS), sport-tuned suspension, and unique styling elements. The limited-production Juke-R featured the GT-R's powertrain and running gear in a modified Juke body. A mild refresh in 2015 brought updated styling and features. The first-generation Juke helped establish the subcompact crossover segment and attracted younger buyers to the Nissan brand with its unconventional design and engaging driving dynamics, though its polarizing styling and practical compromises limited its mainstream appeal.
Nissan-Juke.name: First Generation (F15)

Nissan-Juke.description: The second-generation Juke maintains its predecessor's distinctive character but with a more refined interpretation of its unique styling. Built on the Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi Alliance's CMF-B platform shared with the Renault Captur, it features a coupe-like silhouette with slim LED headlights, prominent circular running lights, hidden rear door handles, and a floating roof design. Despite similar exterior dimensions to its predecessor, interior space is significantly improved with increased rear seat legroom and cargo capacity. In most markets, power comes from a 1.0L turbocharged three-cylinder engine producing approximately 117 horsepower, paired with either a 6-speed manual or 7-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission, primarily in front-wheel drive configuration with all-wheel drive available in select markets. Some regions also offer a hybrid powertrain combining a 1.6L gasoline engine with an electric motor. The interior represents a major upgrade with higher quality materials, more conventional ergonomics, and modern technology including an 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility, available Bose Personal Plus audio system with headrest speakers, and a comprehensive suite of Nissan Safety Shield driver assistance features. The second-generation Juke refines the model's formula with more mainstream appeal through improved practicality and technology while maintaining distinctive styling to stand out in the increasingly crowded subcompact crossover segment. Unlike the first generation, this model is not offered in North America, where it's effectively replaced by the more conventional Kicks.
Nissan-Juke.name: Second Generation (F16)

Nissan-Kicks.description: The first-generation Nissan Kicks was introduced as a global subcompact crossover, initially for emerging markets before expanding to North America in 2018 as an indirect replacement for the quirky Juke. Built on Nissan's V-platform shared with the Versa, it featured a more conventional crossover design than the Juke with a practical focus on interior space, efficiency, and value. The exterior design incorporated Nissan's V-motion grille, floating roof aesthetic, and available two-tone color schemes. Power came from a naturally aspirated 1.6L four-cylinder engine producing 122 horsepower (North American specification), paired exclusively with a continuously variable transmission (CVT) and front-wheel drive—notably, all-wheel drive was not offered. The interior emphasized practicality with surprisingly spacious seating for its compact dimensions, straightforward controls, and respectable cargo capacity. Standard and available features included a 7-inch touchscreen infotainment system, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility, Bose Personal Plus audio system with headrest speakers, and Nissan Safety Shield 360 driver assistance technology. The Kicks established itself as a value-oriented entry point to the rapidly growing subcompact crossover segment, offering crossover styling and a higher seating position than a traditional hatchback, but with more emphasis on efficiency and affordability than off-road capability or performance.
Nissan-Kicks.name: First Generation (P15)

Nissan-Kicks.description: The refreshed Nissan Kicks received a significant update focusing on styling and technology while maintaining the same fundamental platform and powertrain. Exterior changes incorporated Nissan's latest design language with a larger, more prominent V-motion grille identical to the Kicks e-Power variant, redesigned LED headlights and taillights, a more substantial rear bumper, and new wheel designs. The interior saw technology upgrades including a standard 7-inch touchscreen (8-inch on higher trims) with improved functionality, a new electronic parking brake, redesigned center console, and enhanced connectivity options including standard Apple CarPlay and Android Auto across all trims. New available features included a Wi-Fi hotspot, wireless charging pad, and expanded USB ports. The powertrain continued unchanged with the 1.6L four-cylinder (122 hp) and CVT, maintaining its focus on efficiency rather than performance, still exclusively with front-wheel drive. Safety technology expanded with Nissan Safety Shield 360 becoming standard across all trim levels, including automatic emergency braking with pedestrian detection, rear automatic braking, blind spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, lane departure warning, and high beam assist. The updated Kicks went on sale in North America in February 2021 and in the Middle East in July 2021.
Nissan-Kicks.name: First Generation (P15 Facelift)

Nissan-Kicks.description: The second-generation Nissan Kicks debuted in the U.S. on 22 March 2024 for the 2025 model year, representing a complete redesign on Nissan's CMF-B HS platform. The new model is 1.7 inches longer, 3.5 inches wider and 0.6 inches taller, with approximately 2.3 inches longer wheelbase compared to its predecessor. The U.S. market model is powered by a larger 2.0-liter four-cylinder petrol engine producing 141 horsepower, which is 19 more horsepower than the previous 1.6L engine. An Xtronic branded CVT is the only available transmission choice in the US market, but for the first time outside of Japan, the Kicks is also available with optional all-wheel drive. The interior features twin 7-inch screens that serve as the gauge cluster and infotainment system, which can be optionally upgraded to 12.3-inch screens with wireless Android Auto and Apple CarPlay support. An available 10-speaker Bose sound system features speakers integrated into the front passenger seats' headrests. A front wireless charging pad is optional along with up to four USB type-C ports. Cloth seating is standard with optional heated front seats, while higher trims receive leatherette seating surfaces featuring Nissan's Zero Gravity design. The 2025 model year Kicks was awarded 'Top Safety Pick' by IIHS, equipped with Nissan Safety Shield 360 as standard across all trims. Production is handled at Nissan's plant in Aguascalientes, Mexico.
Nissan-Kicks.name: Second Generation (P16)

Nissan-Leaf.description: The first-generation Nissan Leaf was the world's first mass-market battery electric vehicle from a major manufacturer, unveiled on 1 August 2009. Production began on 22 October 2010 at the Oppama facility in Yokosuka, Japan, with European and US models initially imported from this plant until early 2013. Battery production began at the Smyrna plant on 12 December 2012, with official US production starting on 9 January 2013. UK manufacturing began on 28 March 2013. The Leaf featured a distinctive 5-door hatchback design with a 24 kWh lithium-ion battery pack (192 flat, laminated cells developed with NEC) providing approximately 73 miles of EPA-rated range, powering an 80 kW electric motor. The battery pack was located under the floor and between the wheels, optimizing handling and interior space. Recharging took 16 hours on 120V or 8 hours on 230V, with fast charging restoring 80% capacity in approximately 30 minutes. The first generation garnered praise for its spacious cargo area and standard heated seats, but criticism for inexpensive interior materials and battery degradation concerns in hot climates due to the lack of active thermal management. Despite challenges, it became the world's best-selling electric vehicle from 2011 to 2014 and again in 2016, establishing Nissan as a pioneer in mass-market EVs.
Nissan-Leaf.name: First Generation (ZE0)

Nissan-Leaf.description: The second-generation Nissan Leaf launched in October 2017 for the 2018 model year, with deliveries beginning in North America and Europe in February 2018. Stylistically, it marked a major departure with more conventional design language including the V-motion grille, boomerang-shaped lights, and floating roof. Initially offered with a 40 kWh battery pack (39 kWh usable) providing an EPA-rated range of approximately 150 miles, powering an 110 kW electric motor producing 236 lb-ft of torque. Charging options included a 6.6 kW regular plug (SAE J1772 in US/Japan, Type 2 in EU) and 50 kW CHAdeMO fast charging. The interior added Android Auto and Apple CarPlay compatibility. From 2019, the Leaf e+ (Leaf Plus in North America) variant offered a larger 62 kWh battery (59 kWh usable) providing approximately 226 miles of EPA range, paired with a more powerful 160 kW motor and up to 100 kW CHAdeMO fast charging. ProPILOT Assist, a lane-centering system with automatic parking capability, was available on higher trims. The e-Pedal system enabled one-pedal driving through enhanced regenerative braking. In June 2022, the Leaf received a facelift for the 2023 model year, with EPA range slightly reduced to 149 miles for the 40 kWh version and 212 miles for the 62 kWh version. UK production ceased in March 2024 after 270,000 units produced at the Sunderland plant across both generations. Global production ended in June 2025.
Nissan-Leaf.name: Second Generation (ZE1)

Nissan-Leaf.description: The June 2022 facelift for the 2023 model year brought exterior and interior updates to the second-generation Leaf. The EPA range was slightly reduced compared to pre-facelift models, with the 40 kWh version rated at 149 miles and the 62 kWh Leaf Plus at 212 miles. The facelift maintained the same mechanical layout and powertrain options while introducing updated styling elements consistent with Nissan's then-current design language. Production continued alongside the third-generation ZE2 model for a brief overlap period before concluding in June 2025.
Nissan-Leaf.name: Second Generation (ZE1) Facelift

Nissan-Leaf.description: The third-generation Nissan Leaf was unveiled on 17 June 2025, representing a significant departure from its predecessors by adopting a subcompact crossover-style body built on the Renault-Nissan AmpR Medium platform (formerly CMF-EV), shared with the Nissan Ariya. This generation marks the first time the Leaf features active liquid-cooled battery packs instead of the passive air-cooled systems used previously. Two NMC lithium-ion battery options are available: a 52 kWh battery paired with a motor producing 174 hp, and a 75 kWh battery paired with a 214 hp motor. EPA-rated range is estimated up to 303 miles on select configurations, with European versions offering approximately 285 miles at steady speeds. Charging capabilities include 150 kW DC fast charging, making it the first Nissan vehicle to adopt the North American Charging System (NACS) for Tesla Supercharger compatibility. In North America, the J1772 port is on the driver's side front fender for Level 2 charging, while the NACS port is on the passenger side. The drag coefficient is reduced to 0.25 (0.26 in North America) compared to the previous generation's 0.29. The Leaf retains a single-motor, front-wheel-drive layout without dual-motor AWD options. Availability is confirmed for North America, Europe, Japan, and Australia, with manufacturing in Japan at Kaminokawa, Tochigi and the UK at Sunderland.
Nissan-Leaf.name: Third Generation (ZE2)

Nissan-Maxima.description: The original Maxima wasn't yet a separate model but a trim level of the Datsun 810 (later badged as the Nissan 810 Maxima), featuring a 2.4L inline-six engine. This generation established the model's focus on being a sporty alternative to mainstream family sedans.
Nissan-Maxima.name: First Generation (G910)

Nissan-Maxima.description: The first standalone Maxima model, featuring front-wheel drive and powered by a 3.0L V6 engine. Available in sedan and wagon body styles, it emphasized technology with a digital instrument cluster, optional electronic adjustable suspension, and a talking voice warning system. This generation established the Maxima's position as Nissan's flagship sedan in North America, offering a combination of performance, luxury, and technology.
Nissan-Maxima.name: Second Generation (U11)

Nissan-Maxima.description: Often considered a high point in the model's history, the third-generation Maxima featured sleek styling and earned the nickname '4-Door Sports Car' (4DSC).
