Powered by a 3.0L V6 producing 160 horsepower (190 hp in SE trim), it was available with a 5-speed manual or 4-speed automatic transmission. The SE model offered a sport-tuned suspension, limited-slip differential, and distinctive alloy wheels. The interior featured a driver-focused cockpit with straightforward ergonomics and available leather upholstery. This generation cemented the Maxima's reputation for offering sports sedan performance in a practical package at a mainstream price point.
Nissan-Maxima.name: Third Generation (J30)

Nissan-Maxima.description: The fourth-generation Maxima grew in size and refinement, featuring more rounded styling and improved interior quality. Powered by a revised 3.0L V6 now producing 190 horsepower (upgraded to 200 hp in 1999), it maintained available 5-speed manual transmission in SE trim—unusual for its class. This generation introduced a sophisticated multi-link rear suspension improving both handling and ride quality. The interior offered increased space and luxury amenities including available Bose audio system, leather seating, and a power sunroof. This generation successfully balanced increased refinement with engaging driving dynamics, winning Motor Trend's Import Car of the Year award for 1995.
Nissan-Maxima.name: Fourth Generation (A32)

Nissan-Maxima.description: The fifth-generation Maxima featured evolutionary styling with a more upright greenhouse and formal roofline. Powered by a new 3.0L V6 (VQ30DE) producing 222 horsepower, paired with either a 5-speed manual or 4-speed automatic transmission. This generation introduced a more upscale interior with improved materials, available navigation system, and expanded safety features including side airbags. The Maxima's flagship position in Nissan's sedan lineup was reinforced with premium features and performance that compared favorably to entry-level luxury brands, though competition from the redesigned Altima began to challenge its position within Nissan's lineup.
Nissan-Maxima.name: Fifth Generation (A33)

Nissan-Maxima.description: The sixth-generation Maxima moved to Nissan's FF-L platform shared with the Altima, featuring distinctive styling with high-mounted taillights and a more aggressive front fascia. Powered by a 3.5L V6 (VQ35DE) producing 265 horsepower, paired with a continuously variable transmission (CVT) or 6-speed manual. This generation faced challenges in distinguishing itself from the increasingly powerful and refined Altima, leading to a stronger emphasis on luxury features including available SkyView fixed glass roof panels, heated steering wheel, and premium audio. The SkyView roof and unusual interior styling with a 'wave' dashboard represented attempts to differentiate the model through distinctive design elements.
Nissan-Maxima.name: Sixth Generation (A34)

Nissan-Maxima.description: The seventh-generation Maxima featured more dramatic styling with a bold front grille, sculpted body sides, and coupe-like roofline. Powered by a revised 3.5L V6 now producing 290 horsepower, paired exclusively with a CVT optimized for both performance and efficiency. This generation emphasized sport sedan characteristics with a driver-focused cockpit, paddle shifters, and available sport-tuned suspension. Interior quality saw significant improvements with soft-touch materials, available premium leather, and advanced technology including Nissan Hard Drive Navigation with 9.3GB Music Box hard drive. This generation attempted to recapture the '4-Door Sports Car' identity with more distinctive styling and focus on driving engagement.
Nissan-Maxima.name: Seventh Generation (A35)

Nissan-Maxima.description: The eighth and final Maxima generation featured dramatically aggressive styling with a floating roof design, boomerang-shaped lighting elements, and deeply sculpted body sides. Powered by a revised 3.5L V6 producing 300 horsepower, paired exclusively with a retuned CVT featuring simulated shift points and available paddle shifters. The chassis featured increased use of high-strength steel and aluminum components for improved rigidity and reduced weight. The interior represented a significant upgrade with premium materials, NASA-inspired 'Zero Gravity' front seats, and advanced technology including an 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system. Later model years added Nissan Safety Shield 360 with comprehensive driver assistance features and ProPILOT Assist semi-autonomous driving capability. Special editions in the final years included the 40th Anniversary Edition commemorating the model's history. Production ended in 2023 as Nissan consolidated its sedan lineup and consumer preferences shifted toward crossovers and SUVs.
Nissan-Maxima.name: Eighth Generation (A36)

Nissan-Murano.description: The original Nissan Murano was introduced as a mid-size crossover featuring distinctive styling that departed from traditional boxy SUV designs of the era. The exterior showcased a sleek, aerodynamic profile with a distinctive grille, wraparound headlights, and seamlessly integrated rear liftgate. Built on Nissan's FF-L platform shared with the Altima and Maxima, it offered car-like handling with SUV versatility. Powered by a 3.5L VQ35DE V6 engine producing 245 horsepower, paired with a continuously variable transmission (CVT)—one of the first applications of a CVT in a V6-powered vehicle. Available in front-wheel or all-wheel drive configurations using an intuitive on-demand system. The interior featured a driver-focused cockpit with a floating center console, modern design elements, and premium materials unusual for a mainstream brand at the time. Available features included a navigation system, Bose audio, leather seating, and a power sunroof. The first-generation Murano helped establish the premium mid-size crossover segment, offering more sophisticated styling and driving dynamics than traditional SUVs while maintaining practical utility. It significantly influenced crossover design trends with its emphasis on style alongside functionality.
Nissan-Murano.name: First Generation (Z50)

Nissan-Murano.description: The second-generation Murano evolved the distinctive styling of its predecessor with a more sculpted exterior featuring an aggressive front fascia, pronounced wheel arches, and complex surface detailing. Continuing on a revised version of the FF-L platform, it grew slightly in all dimensions. Powered by an updated 3.5L V6 now producing 260-265 horsepower (depending on model year), again paired with an improved continuously variable transmission (CVT), available in front-wheel or all-wheel drive configurations. The interior offered increased refinement with higher quality materials, more sophisticated design, and enhanced technology including an available hard-drive based navigation system, rearview camera, and dual-panel moonroof. A novel addition was the Murano CrossCabriolet introduced in 2011—a two-door convertible variant with a power-folding soft top that was the first crossover convertible from a mainstream manufacturer, though its unconventional design achieved limited commercial success. The Murano LE trim offered near-luxury appointments including wood trim, premium leather, and additional convenience features. This generation maintained the model's position as a style-focused alternative to more conventional crossovers, emphasizing refinement and distinctive design over maximum utility or off-road capability.
Nissan-Murano.name: Second Generation (Z51)

Nissan-Murano.description: The third-generation Murano features bold, futuristic styling based on Nissan's 'V-Motion' design language with a prominent V-shaped grille, boomerang-shaped lighting elements, floating roof design achieved through blacked-out D-pillars, and complex sculpted body sides. Built on the evolved D platform shared with other Nissan and Infiniti products, it prioritizes comfort and refinement. Powered by a 3.5L V6 engine producing 260 horsepower, paired with a continuously variable transmission (CVT) and available with front-wheel or intuitive all-wheel drive. The interior represents a significant advancement with premium materials including available semi-aniline leather, 'Zero Gravity' seats designed to reduce fatigue, ambient lighting, and a sweeping, layered dashboard design. Technology features include an 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system (later upgraded to include Apple CarPlay and Android Auto), available Bose premium audio, 360-degree Around View Monitor, and an expanding suite of driver assistance features eventually encompassing Nissan Safety Shield 360 and ProPILOT Assist semi-autonomous driving capability. A significant refresh in 2019 brought additional safety features, updated technology, and subtle styling refinements. Throughout its production, the third-generation Murano has maintained its position as Nissan's premium five-passenger crossover, emphasizing sophisticated design, comfort, and technology over sportiness or off-road capability.
Nissan-Murano.name: Third Generation (Z52)

Nissan-Murano.description: The fourth-generation Murano was unveiled in October 2024 for the 2025 model year, featuring bold new styling inspired by the Nissan Ariya electric crossover. Built on the evolved D platform, it represents a major departure from the CVT-only powertrain of previous generations, replacing the iconic 3.5L V6 and CVT with a 2.0L turbocharged KR20DDET four-cylinder engine paired with a 9-speed automatic transmission. The vehicle offers a modern, sophisticated interior with dual 12.3-inch displays for the instrument cluster and infotainment system, wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto connectivity, ventilated and massaging front seats, and an enhanced suite of driver assistance technologies including Nissan ProPilot Assist. The fourth generation emphasizes comfort, technology, and efficiency while maintaining Nissan's focus on premium appointments and refined driving dynamics in the mid-size crossover segment.
Nissan-Murano.name: Fourth Generation (Z53)

Nissan-Navara.description: First generation compact pickup truck, successor to the Datsun 720. Available worldwide in two body styles - 'A' body designed in Japan and 'S' body King Cab designed in the United States. The name 'Navara' was used in some markets such as Australia and New Zealand.
Nissan-Navara.name: D21 Series

Nissan-Navara.description: Compact size pickup truck. Originally planned to be designed by Nissan Design International in California, but design was given to Japan during 1994-1995 period. In North America, it was marketed as the Nissan Frontier.
Nissan-Navara.name: First Generation (D22)

Nissan-Navara.description: Facelifted D22 introduced in February 2000 at the Chicago Auto Show. Featured bolder styling with new grille, bumper, headlights, taillights, and built-in fender flares. The regular cab was discontinued after 2001 MY. In Australia, Series 2 released in 2001 with ZD30 Diesel engine and updated front end.
Nissan-Navara.name: First Generation (D22 Facelift)

Nissan-Navara.description: Mid-size pickup truck introduced at the 2004 North American International Auto Show. Uses the new Nissan F-Alpha platform with fully boxed ladder frame. Exterior styling resembles the full-size Nissan Titan. In North America marketed as Frontier, elsewhere as Navarra.
Nissan-Navara.name: Second Generation (D40)

Nissan-Navara.description: Facelifted D40 introduced for 2009/2010 model years. Added new 3.0L V9X V6 turbodiesel engine and revised 2.5L dCi unit. Updated headlights, bonnet, V-shaped grille shell, rounder bumper, new alloy wheels, and improved interior materials. In North America, updated for 2020 MY with new 3.8L V6 and nine-speed automatic.
Nissan-Navara.name: Second Generation (D40 Facelift)

Nissan-Navara.description: Third generation Navarra, codenamed D23 and released as NP300 Navarra. Series production commenced in Thailand in July 2014. Not available in US or Canada (favoring the larger D41 Frontier). Features Nissan Intelligent Mobility technology including Around View Monitor and blind-spot monitoring.
Nissan-Navara.name: Third Generation (D23)

Nissan-Navara.description: Facelifted D23 Navarra unveiled on November 5, 2020, with introduction of Pro-4X trim level. Active safety equipment added including additional airbags and stability control. Pre-facelift model production in Barcelona continued until December 16, 2021 due to declining European sales.
Nissan-Navara.name: Third Generation (D23 Facelift)

Nissan-Navara.description: Fourth generation Navarra unveiled in Australia and New Zealand on November 19, 2024. Developed from the sixth-generation Mitsubishi Triton platform and manufactured by Mitsubishi Motors.
Nissan-Navara.name: Fourth Generation (D27)

Nissan-Pathfinder.description: The original Nissan Pathfinder was introduced as a two-door SUV based on Nissan's compact pickup truck platform, later adding a four-door variant in 1990. Featuring boxy, utilitarian styling with a prominent front grille and angular wheel arches, it emphasized rugged capability over comfort. Initially powered by a 2.4L four-cylinder or 3.0L V6 engine, with a 3.3L V6 replacing both in later years. Transmission options included a five-speed manual or four-speed automatic, with part-time four-wheel drive featuring a two-speed transfer case for genuine off-road capability. The interior was basic but functional, focusing on durability rather than luxury, though later model years added more comfort features. This generation established the Pathfinder as a competitor to the Jeep Cherokee, Toyota 4Runner, and Ford Explorer in the growing SUV market, combining truck-based durability with increasing refinements to appeal to family buyers.
Nissan-Pathfinder.name: First Generation (WD21)

Nissan-Pathfinder.description: The second-generation Pathfinder made a significant transition to a unibody construction while maintaining body-on-frame ruggedness with its MonoFrame design. Available exclusively as a four-door, it featured more rounded styling, improved aerodynamics, and expanded interior space. Initially powered by a 3.3L V6 producing 168 horsepower, later upgraded to a more powerful 3.5L V6 generating 240 horsepower. Transmission options included a four-speed automatic or five-speed manual, with available part-time or all-time four-wheel drive systems. The interior saw substantial improvements in material quality, design, and features, with available amenities including leather seating, premium audio, and a sunroof. This generation balanced off-road capability with improved on-road comfort, offering a more sophisticated driving experience while maintaining adequate trail capability. Unique variants included the rugged-looking Pathfinder LE with body-colored fender flares and special interior appointments.
Nissan-Pathfinder.name: Second Generation (R50)

Nissan-Pathfinder.description: The third-generation Pathfinder returned to a traditional body-on-frame construction based on the Nissan F-Alpha platform shared with the Frontier and Titan, signaling a shift back toward ruggedness and towing capability. The exterior featured more angular styling with pronounced fender flares and an upright stance. Initially powered by a 4.0L V6 producing 270 horsepower, with a 5.6L V8 generating 310 horsepower added as an option in 2008. Both engines paired with a five-speed automatic transmission, with available part-time four-wheel drive featuring a two-speed transfer case and electronic locking rear differential in some configurations. The interior offered three rows of seating for up to seven passengers, with improved materials and technology including an available navigation system, Bluetooth connectivity, and rear-seat entertainment. This generation emphasized utility with up to 7,000 pounds of towing capacity, adjustable cargo organization systems, and substantial ground clearance, positioning it as a more capable alternative to increasingly car-based crossover competitors.
Nissan-Pathfinder.name: Third Generation (R51)

Nissan-Pathfinder.description: The fourth-generation Pathfinder represented a dramatic shift in philosophy, transitioning to a unibody crossover platform shared with the Nissan Murano and emphasizing on-road comfort and efficiency over off-road capability. The exterior featured more aerodynamic styling with flowing lines and a less aggressive stance. Powered exclusively by a 3.5L V6 engine initially producing 260 horsepower (later increased to 284 hp), paired with a continuously variable transmission (CVT) and available with front-wheel or all-wheel drive lacking the low-range transfer case of previous generations. The interior prioritized family-friendly features with easy access to the third row via innovative sliding and tilting second-row seats, expanded cargo flexibility, and available premium features including a panoramic sunroof, Around View Monitor camera system, and Bose premium audio. A refresh in 2017 brought updated styling, enhanced technology including Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility, and additional active safety features. This generation repositioned the Pathfinder as a mainstream three-row crossover competing with vehicles like the Toyota Highlander and Honda Pilot rather than traditional body-on-frame SUVs.
Nissan-Pathfinder.name: Fourth Generation (R52)

Nissan-Pathfinder.description: The current Pathfinder returns to a more rugged aesthetic while maintaining unibody construction, featuring bold, squared-off styling with a prominent V-motion grille, bluff front end, and muscular proportions that reference the original model's design ethos. Built on an updated version of Nissan's D platform, it prioritizes improved driving dynamics and capability without reverting to body-on-frame construction. Powered by a carried-over 3.5L V6 producing 284 horsepower but now paired with a conventional nine-speed automatic transmission replacing the previous CVT, available with front-wheel drive or an enhanced Intelligent 4WD system with seven drive and terrain modes. The interior features a completely redesigned dashboard with available 9-inch touchscreen, 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, and head-up display, alongside thoughtful family features like captain's chairs with a removable center console and one-touch folding seats providing easy third-row access. Seating capacity increases to eight passengers with the standard second-row bench. Technology advances significantly with standard Nissan Safety Shield 360, available ProPILOT Assist with Navi-link semi-autonomous driving capability, wireless Apple CarPlay, and enhanced connectivity features. Towing capacity increases to 6,000 pounds, and the more sophisticated all-wheel drive system provides improved all-weather performance. The fifth-generation Pathfinder balances a return to rugged styling and improved capability with modern technology and refinement, repositioning the model as a more adventurous option in the three-row crossover segment.
Nissan-Pathfinder.name: Fifth Generation (R53)

Nissan-Pulsar.description: The original Nissan Pulsar (known as the Datsun Cherry in some markets) was introduced as a subcompact car available in three-door and five-door hatchback, four-door sedan, and three-door van/wagon body styles. Powered by a range of small displacement four-cylinder engines, typically 1.0L to 1.4L depending on market. The design featured conventional, boxy styling typical of the era. This generation established the Pulsar nameplate in certain markets and was notable for its emphasis on fuel efficiency during a period of rising fuel costs.
Nissan-Pulsar.name: First Generation (N10)

Nissan-Pulsar.description: The second-generation Pulsar featured more angular styling with improved aerodynamics. Available in a range of body styles including three-door and five-door hatchbacks, four-door sedan, and a unique cabriolet version in some markets. Engine options expanded to include a wider range of four-cylinder units, with the introduction of the EXA/Pulsar NX sport coupe variant featuring pop-up headlights and available t-top roof panels. This generation saw technical innovations including the introduction of an electronically controlled variable geometry suspension system on certain models.
Nissan-Pulsar.name: Second Generation (N12)

Nissan-Pulsar.description: The third-generation Pulsar offered more rounded styling compared to its predecessor, aligning with changing design trends of the late 1980s. Available in hatchback, sedan, and coupe body styles, with significant market variations—in North America, the Pulsar NX featured unique modular bodywork with interchangeable hatch configurations (Sportbak and Canopy). Engine options included various four-cylinder units, with performance-oriented models featuring the SR20DE engine in certain markets. This generation introduced more sophisticated multi-link rear suspension on some variants, improving handling and ride comfort.
Nissan-Pulsar.name: Third Generation (N13)

Nissan-Pulsar.description: The fourth-generation Pulsar featured more aerodynamic styling with smoother contours and integrated bumpers. Available primarily as three-door and five-door hatchbacks and a four-door sedan, it shared its platform with the European Nissan Sunny/Sentra. Engine options ranged from economical 1.3L and 1.4L units to the more powerful 2.0L SR20DE found in the GTI-R variant—a homologation special featuring 227 horsepower, all-wheel drive, and distinctive rally-inspired styling with a prominent hood scoop. The interior offered improved ergonomics and quality compared to previous generations. This generation is particularly notable for the limited-production GTI-R model that competed in World Rally Championship events.
Nissan-Pulsar.name: Fourth Generation (N14)

Nissan-Pulsar.description: The fifth-generation Pulsar continued with evolutionary styling updates while maintaining the same basic body configurations. The design featured softer contours and a more conservative appearance than its predecessor. Engine options were similar to the previous generation but with refinements for improved efficiency and emissions compliance. Notable variants included the VZR with the SR20VE NEO VVL variable valve timing engine producing up to 190 horsepower in certain markets. This generation was not widely distributed globally, with the Pulsar name being phased out in many regions in favor of other Nissan model names.
Nissan-Pulsar.name: Fifth Generation (N15)

Nissan-Pulsar.description: The sixth-generation Pulsar, primarily sold in Australia and Asian markets, shared its platform with the global Nissan Sunny/Sentra. The styling became more conventional with less distinctive elements compared to earlier generations. Available in sedan and hatchback body styles, it featured a range of four-cylinder engines focused on economy rather than performance. The interior emphasized practicality with improved space utilization and straightforward controls. This generation represented a shift toward more mainstream design and positioning within Nissan's global strategy.
Nissan-Pulsar.name: Sixth Generation (N16)

Nissan-Pulsar.description: After a period of absence in many markets, the Pulsar name was revived for a compact hatchback specifically designed for the European market. Built on the Renault-Nissan Alliance CMF platform shared with the Qashqai and X-Trail, it featured contemporary styling with Nissan's V-motion grille design and boomerang-shaped light signatures. Powertrain options included small displacement turbocharged gasoline and diesel engines, with a focus on efficiency and emissions compliance for European regulations. The interior offered class-competitive technology including NissanConnect infotainment system, Around View Monitor, and various driver assistance features. This generation was positioned as a conventional compact hatchback competitor to the Volkswagen Golf and Ford Focus, but achieved limited commercial success in the highly competitive European C-segment, leading to its discontinuation after a relatively short production run.
Nissan-Pulsar.name: C13 Generation (European Market)

Nissan-Qashqai.description: The original Nissan Qashqai (pronounced 'kash-kye' and marketed as the Dualis in Japan and Australia) pioneered the compact crossover segment in Europe, combining SUV styling cues with hatchback dimensions and driving dynamics. Built on Nissan's C platform shared with the X-Trail, it featured a relatively high seating position and available all-wheel drive while maintaining car-like handling characteristics. The exterior design blended smooth curves with subtle SUV elements including black lower body cladding and increased ground clearance compared to conventional hatchbacks. Powertrain options varied by market but typically included 1.6L and 2.0L gasoline engines and 1.5L and 2.0L diesel options, paired with manual or CVT transmissions. The interior emphasized practicality with flexible seating configurations, good visibility, and straightforward controls. A seven-seat variant called the Qashqai+2 was introduced in 2008, featuring an extended wheelbase and rear overhang to accommodate the additional row. A significant refresh in 2010 brought updated styling, improved interior materials, and enhanced technology features. The first-generation Qashqai proved tremendously successful, particularly in Europe, establishing a new vehicle category that combined the appeal of an SUV with the efficiency and driving dynamics of a conventional hatchback.
Nissan-Qashqai.name: First Generation (J10)

Nissan-Qashqai.description: The second-generation Qashqai featured more sophisticated styling with sharper lines, a more pronounced V-motion grille, and LED lighting elements. Built on the Renault-Nissan Alliance CMF-CD platform, it grew slightly in size while reducing weight through increased use of high-strength steel and aluminum components. Powertrain options continued with improved versions of the 1.2L, 1.3L, 1.6L and 2.0L gasoline engines and 1.5L, 1.6L and 1.7L diesel engines in most markets, with efficiency enhancements including start-stop technology. Transmission choices included a 6-speed manual, an improved Xtronic CVT, and a 7-speed dual-clutch transmission, with front-wheel drive standard and all-wheel drive available on select variants. The interior represented a significant upgrade with higher quality materials, improved design, and enhanced technology including an available 7-inch NissanConnect touchscreen infotainment system, Around View Monitor, and an expanding suite of driver assistance features eventually encompassing autonomous emergency braking, lane departure warning, and traffic sign recognition. The seven-seat +2 variant was discontinued with that role taken by the larger X-Trail/Rogue. A significant update in 2017 brought revised exterior styling, interior refinements, and the addition of ProPILOT semi-autonomous driving capability on higher trims. In North America, this generation was marketed as the Nissan Rogue Sport from 2017 to 2022. The second-generation Qashqai continued the model's strong sales success, particularly in Europe where it frequently ranked among the bestselling vehicles overall, not just in the crossover segment it helped establish.
Nissan-Qashqai.name: Second Generation (J11)

Nissan-Qashqai.description: The current Qashqai features a more dramatic evolution of Nissan's design language with a bold interpretation of the V-motion grille, slim LED headlights, floating roof effect, and more muscular proportions. Built on an updated version of the CMF-CD platform with increased use of lightweight materials, it offers improved rigidity and refinement. For the first time, the Qashqai has fully embraced electrification, with European models featuring either the innovative e-Power system (where a gasoline engine functions solely as a generator for an electric motor that drives the wheels) or mild hybrid technology paired with a 1.3L turbocharged gasoline engine. Traditional diesel engines have been eliminated from the lineup. The interior represents a substantial upgrade with higher quality materials throughout, a more contemporary design, and significantly enhanced technology including an available 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, 9-inch central touchscreen with wireless Google services, and a 10.8-inch head-up display. Safety technology has expanded with an improved Around View Monitor featuring a 200-degree front camera and enhanced semi-autonomous driving capabilities via ProPILOT Assist. A facelift introduced in 2024 brought redesigned headlights and taillights, a new front fascia, new alloy wheels, and the addition of Google built-in services to the infotainment system. Practicality remains a focus with increased passenger and cargo space, though the model maintains its compact exterior dimensions. Globally, the Qashqai uses the Qashqai name in all markets, with production established in the United Kingdom and later in China starting May 2023, representing Nissan's continued commitment to the compact crossover segment it pioneered.
Nissan-Qashqai.name: Third Generation (J12)

Nissan-Rogue.description: The original Nissan Rogue was introduced as a compact crossover SUV, sharing its platform with the Nissan Sentra but with increased height and available all-wheel drive. The exterior featured relatively conservative styling with smooth contours and a conventional SUV silhouette. Powered exclusively by a 2.5L four-cylinder engine producing 170 horsepower, paired with a continuously variable transmission (CVT) and available in front-wheel or all-wheel drive configurations. The interior offered seating for five with no third-row option, featuring straightforward design and controls. Available features included a premium audio system, navigation, rearview camera, and Bluetooth connectivity. Standard safety features included stability control, anti-lock brakes, and six airbags. Despite being Nissan's entry in the rapidly growing compact crossover segment, the first-generation Rogue was notable for its car-like handling, comfortable ride, and value proposition rather than distinctive styling or off-road capability.
Nissan-Rogue.name: First Generation (S35)

Nissan-Rogue.description: The second-generation Rogue featured more distinctive styling with Nissan's V-motion grille design, LED daytime running lights, and more sculpted body lines. Built on the jointly developed Renault-Nissan Common Module Family (CMF) platform, it offered improved rigidity and refinement. Continued with the 2.5L four-cylinder engine now producing 170-175 horsepower (depending on model year) paired with an improved continuously variable transmission (CVT) featuring simulated gear ratios for more natural acceleration feel. Interior space and flexibility improved substantially with the innovative EZ Flex seating system and Divide-N-Hide cargo management. Available features expanded to include a 360-degree Around View Monitor camera system, power liftgate, dual-zone climate control, and NissanConnect infotainment with navigation and mobile apps capability. A significant addition was the available third-row seat on certain trims, though this feature was discontinued after 2017. Safety technology advanced considerably throughout this generation, eventually including Nissan Safety Shield technologies such as automatic emergency braking, blind spot warning, and rear cross-traffic alert. A hybrid variant was briefly offered from 2017-2019, combining a 2.0L four-cylinder engine with an electric motor for improved efficiency. A significant refresh in 2017 brought updated styling, interior refinements, and additional safety features. The second-generation Rogue became Nissan's bestselling model in the United States, appealing to families with its combination of practicality, technology, and value pricing.
Nissan-Rogue.name: Second Generation (T32)

Nissan-Rogue.description: The current Rogue features dramatically more sophisticated styling with a bold interpretation of Nissan's V-motion grille, split-level lighting with slim upper LED daytime running lights separated from the main headlights, floating roof design, and more squared-off proportions creating a more substantial presence. Built on an updated version of the CMF platform with increased use of high-strength steel and aluminum components, it offers improved structural rigidity and reduced weight. Initially powered by an updated 2.5L four-cylinder engine producing 181 horsepower, paired with a continuously variable transmission (CVT) with improved efficiency and responsiveness. For 2022, a new 1.5L variable-compression turbocharged three-cylinder engine producing 201 horsepower and 225 lb-ft of torque became available, delivering improved performance and efficiency. The interior represents a significant upgrade with higher quality materials, more sophisticated design including a 'floating' center console, and advanced technology including an available 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, 10.8-inch head-up display, and 9-inch touchscreen infotainment system with wireless Apple CarPlay. Safety technology has expanded substantially with standard Nissan Safety Shield 360 including automatic emergency braking with pedestrian detection, blind spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, lane departure warning, high beam assist, and rear automatic braking, with available ProPILOT Assist with Navi-link offering enhanced semi-autonomous driving capability. The third-generation Rogue maintains its focus on family-friendly features with improved rear seat space, tri-zone climate control, and thoughtful storage solutions throughout the cabin, positioning it as a technology-forward, premium-feeling option in the highly competitive compact crossover segment.
Nissan-Rogue.name: Third Generation (T33)

Nissan-Rogue-Sport.description: The Nissan Rogue Sport, the North American rebadged version of the second-generation Qashqai (J11), was introduced to fill the gap between the Juke and the larger Rogue in Nissan's crossover lineup. Built on the same CMF platform as the Rogue but approximately 12 inches shorter overall and with a 2.3-inch shorter wheelbase, it featured Nissan's V-motion grille design, boomerang-shaped lights, and floating roof aesthetic. Powered exclusively by a 2.0L four-cylinder engine producing 141 horsepower, paired with a continuously variable transmission (CVT) and available with front-wheel or all-wheel drive. The interior offered seating for five with no third-row option, featuring a straightforward design with available features including a 7-inch touchscreen infotainment system, Around View Monitor 360-degree camera system, and heated front seats. Safety technology included available automatic emergency braking, blind spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, and lane departure warning. The Rogue Sport established itself as a more city-friendly alternative to the standard Rogue, appealing to buyers seeking crossover styling and a higher seating position in a more compact package. Trim levels included S, SV, and SL.
Nissan-Rogue-Sport.name: First Generation (J11; Pre-Facelift)

Nissan-Rogue-Sport.description: The 2020 model year brought a significant refresh to the Rogue Sport, featuring updated exterior styling with a more pronounced grille, new front bumper cover and hood, redesigned headlights and tail lights, and new alloy wheel designs. The interior received refinements including improved materials and updated technology features. Safety features were expanded with the inclusion of Nissan Safety Shield 360 as standard on higher trims, which includes automatic emergency braking with pedestrian detection, blind spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, lane departure warning, high beam assist, and rear automatic braking. The powertrain remained unchanged: a 2.0L four-cylinder engine producing 141 horsepower paired with a CVT, available in front-wheel or all-wheel drive configurations. Production for the North American market ended in December 2022, making 2022 the final model year for the US Rogue Sport, though the Qashqai continues in other global markets.
Nissan-Rogue-Sport.name: First Generation (J11; Facelift)

Nissan-Sentra.description: The original Nissan Sentra (known as the Sunny in other markets) was introduced as Nissan's entry-level compact car in North America, replacing the Datsun 210. Available in two-door sedan, four-door sedan, five-door wagon, and three-door hatchback body styles. Powered by a 1.5L or 1.6L four-cylinder engine paired with either a four or five-speed manual transmission or a three-speed automatic. The design featured boxy, clean styling typical of early 1980s Japanese compact cars. The interior emphasized simplicity and fuel economy during an era of rising gas prices, with minimal luxury features. This generation established the Sentra nameplate in North America and helped transition the brand from Datsun to Nissan branding during this period.
Nissan-Sentra.name: First Generation (B11)

Nissan-Sentra.description: The second-generation Sentra maintained a boxy design but with more refined styling, better aerodynamics, and improved interior space. Available in coupe, sedan, hatchback, and wagon body styles. Engine options included 1.6L and 1.8L four-cylinders, with the introduction of a sport-oriented SE-R model featuring a 140-horsepower GA16DE engine in some markets. Transmission options included four and five-speed manuals and a three or four-speed automatic depending on trim level. Safety features expanded to include passive restraints to meet evolving regulations. This generation continued to emphasize value and efficiency while adding more comfort features and improved performance options.
Nissan-Sentra.name: Second Generation (B12)

Nissan-Sentra.description: The third-generation Sentra featured more aerodynamic styling with rounded edges and smoother contours. Available primarily as a two-door coupe or four-door sedan in North America. Engine options included a standard 1.6L four-cylinder, with the performance-oriented SE-R featuring the acclaimed SR20DE engine producing 140 horsepower—making it one of the most engaging compact cars of its era. Interior quality improved with better materials and design, though still focusing on value rather than luxury. This generation is particularly remembered for the SE-R variant, which developed a cult following among enthusiasts for its combination of performance, reliability, and affordability.
Nissan-Sentra.name: Third Generation (B13)

Nissan-Sentra.description: The fourth-generation Sentra grew slightly in size and featured more substantial styling with a three-box design for sedan models. Available as a four-door sedan and two-door coupe (the latter marketed as the 200SX in North America). Powered by a 1.6L four-cylinder engine in base models, with the SE and SE-R variants featuring a 2.0L engine producing up to 140 horsepower. Transmission options included a five-speed manual or four-speed automatic. Interior quality continued to improve with more comfort features available including power accessories, improved audio systems, and optional sunroof. Safety features expanded to include dual airbags and improved structural design. This generation maintained the Sentra's position as a practical, affordable compact car with sporty variants appealing to enthusiast drivers.
Nissan-Sentra.name: Fourth Generation (B14)

Nissan-Sentra.description: The fifth-generation Sentra featured more substantial styling with a taller profile providing improved interior space. Available exclusively as a four-door sedan in North America. Engine options included a base 1.8L four-cylinder producing 126 horsepower or a 2.5L four-cylinder generating 165-175 horsepower in the SE-R Spec V performance model. Transmission choices included a five or six-speed manual (the latter in Spec V) or four-speed automatic. The interior offered improved materials, design, and available features including side airbags, a Rockford Fosgate audio system, and enhanced convenience features. The SE-R returned to the lineup with this generation, offering performance-oriented suspension tuning, larger brakes, and sportier appearance elements. This generation moved the Sentra slightly upmarket as the Versa later assumed the entry-level position in Nissan's lineup.
Nissan-Sentra.name: Fifth Generation (B15)

Nissan-Sentra.description: The sixth-generation Sentra grew substantially in size, moving into the upper end of the compact segment. Featuring more upright styling with a higher beltline and larger greenhouse, available exclusively as a four-door sedan. Powered by a 2.0L four-cylinder producing 140 horsepower in standard models, with the SE-R variants featuring a 2.5L engine generating up to 200 horsepower in the Spec V. Transmission options included a six-speed manual, continuously variable transmission (CVT), or a six-speed manual for the Spec V. The interior offered significantly more space with improved materials and available technology including navigation, Bluetooth connectivity, and Intelligent Key keyless entry and start. Safety features expanded to include standard side and curtain airbags, anti-lock brakes, and available electronic stability control. This generation positioned the Sentra as a more substantial compact sedan targeting buyers seeking space and comfort alongside value.
Nissan-Sentra.name: Sixth Generation (B16)

Nissan-Sentra.description: The seventh-generation Sentra featured more premium styling influenced by the larger Altima, with flowing lines, chrome accents, and LED lighting elements. Available exclusively as a four-door sedan, it maintained similar dimensions to its predecessor but with improved interior space and trunk capacity. Powered primarily by a 1.8L four-cylinder engine producing 130 horsepower, paired with either a six-speed manual or continuously variable transmission (CVT), with the SR Turbo and NISMO variants later adding a 1.6L turbocharged engine generating 188 horsepower. The interior emphasized quality with improved materials, straightforward ergonomics, and available features including NissanConnect infotainment, navigation, dual-zone climate control, and Bose premium audio. Safety technology expanded throughout the generation, eventually including automatic emergency braking, blind spot warning, and rear cross-traffic alert. A significant refresh in 2016 brought updated styling, improved interior materials, and additional technology features. This generation positioned the Sentra as a value-oriented compact sedan with increasingly premium features, though it faced criticism for modest performance in standard configurations compared to some competitors.
Nissan-Sentra.name: Seventh Generation (B17)

Nissan-Sentra.description: The current Sentra represents a comprehensive redesign featuring dramatically more distinctive styling with a lower, wider stance, floating roof design, and more aggressive interpretation of Nissan's V-motion grille. Built on a new platform with independent rear suspension replacing the previous torsion beam setup, it offers significantly improved driving dynamics and refinement. Powered by a new 2.0L four-cylinder engine producing 149 horsepower and 146 lb-ft of torque, paired exclusively with a continuously variable transmission (CVT) with simulated shift points. The interior represents a substantial upgrade with higher quality materials, more sophisticated design including a 'floating' center console, and improved technology including an available 7-inch digital driver display, 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system, and Android Auto and Apple CarPlay compatibility. Safety technology expanded significantly with standard Nissan Safety Shield 360 including automatic emergency braking with pedestrian detection, blind spot warning, rear cross-traffic alert, lane departure warning, high beam assist, and rear automatic braking. The eighth-generation Sentra re-establishes the model's competitiveness in the compact sedan segment through improved styling, driving dynamics, and technology, positioning it as a more premium offering despite maintaining value pricing relative to competitors.
Nissan-Sentra.name: Eighth Generation (B18)

Nissan-Titan.description: The first generation Nissan Titan was produced from 2004 to 2015, featuring a 5.6L V8 engine with 317-385 hp depending on model year. Available in King Cab (extended cab) and Crew Cab configurations with 2WD or 4WD. An intermediate refresh occurred in 2008 with styling and dimensional updates.
Nissan-Titan.name: First Generation (A60)

Nissan-Titan.description: The second generation Titan was produced from 2016 to 2024 (ended November 2024). Available in three cab styles: regular cab (2016-2019), King Cab, and Crew Cab. Featured a 5.6L V8 gasoline engine (390-400 hp), and a 5.0L Cummins turbo-diesel option (2016-2019). An intermediate refresh in 2020 introduced a 9-speed transmission, updated styling, and the discontinuation of the regular cab and diesel engine. The lineup transitioned from heavy-duty (XD) to standard configurations.
Nissan-Titan.name: Second Generation (A61)

Nissan-Versa.description: The original Nissan Versa was introduced as Nissan's new entry-level subcompact, positioned below the Sentra in both size and price. Available as both a sedan and hatchback (the latter called the Versa Hatchback or Versa Note in some markets), it offered exceptional interior space for its class due to its tall roof and long wheelbase. Powered by a 1.8L four-cylinder engine producing 122 horsepower, paired with either a six-speed manual, four-speed automatic, or continuously variable transmission (CVT) depending on trim level. The exterior featured tall, practical proportions with clean, simple styling, while the interior emphasized spaciousness with surprising rear seat legroom for the segment. Standard features were minimal on base models to achieve a competitive starting price, with higher trims adding power accessories, cruise control, and upgraded audio systems. Safety features included front, side, and curtain airbags, though electronic stability control was initially optional. The first-generation Versa established itself as a value leader emphasizing practicality and interior space over styling or driving dynamics.
Nissan-Versa.name: First Generation (C11)

Nissan-Versa.description: The second-generation Versa split into two distinct models: the Versa sedan based on the global Nissan Sunny, and the Versa Note hatchback based on the global Nissan Note, though both shared mechanical components. The sedan featured conservative styling with a three-box design, launched in 2012, while the more distinctively styled Versa Note hatchback arrived for 2014 with a more dynamic appearance and added versatility. Both were powered by a 1.6L four-cylinder engine producing 109 horsepower, paired with either a five-speed manual or continuously variable transmission (CVT), with the four-speed automatic discontinued. The interior maintained impressive space efficiency but with improved materials and design compared to the first generation, particularly in the Versa Note. Available features expanded to include NissanConnect infotainment, navigation, Around View Monitor 360-degree camera system, and keyless entry with push-button start on higher trims. Safety technology evolved throughout the generation, eventually adding available automatic emergency braking. The sedan received a styling refresh in 2015, while the Note was updated in 2017. The second-generation Versa continued the model's focus on affordability and practicality, with the sedan often positioned as the lowest-priced new car available in the United States.
Nissan-Versa.name: Second Generation (N17 sedan/E12 hatchback)

Nissan-Versa.description: The current Versa features dramatically improved styling with proportions and design elements shared with larger Nissan sedans, including a lower and wider stance, floating roof design, and V-motion grille. Available exclusively as a sedan (with the Versa Note hatchback discontinued), it grows in width and length while reducing height compared to its predecessor. Powered by an updated 1.6L four-cylinder engine now producing 122 horsepower and 114 lb-ft of torque, paired with either a five-speed manual or continuously variable transmission (CVT). The interior represents a substantial upgrade with higher quality materials, more sophisticated design including a 'floating' touchscreen, and improved technology including an available 7-inch driver information display, 7-inch touchscreen infotainment system, and Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. Safety technology expanded significantly with standard Nissan Safety Shield 360 on higher trims including automatic emergency braking with pedestrian detection, rear automatic braking, lane departure warning, high beam assist, blind spot warning, and rear cross-traffic alert. Despite significant improvements in design, features, and technology, the third-generation Versa maintains competitive pricing, continuing its value proposition while offering much more premium appearance and features than previous generations. The new Versa positions itself as a compelling alternative for buyers seeking sedan styling and driving dynamics in an increasingly crossover-dominated market.
Nissan-Versa.name: Third Generation (N18)

Nissan-X-Trail.description: The original Nissan X-Trail was introduced as a compact SUV featuring distinctive boxy styling with emphasis on genuine off-road capability unusual in its segment. Built on Nissan's FF-S platform, it offered a capable all-mode 4x4 system with selectable 2WD, Auto, and Lock modes using an electronic coupling to distribute torque between the front and rear axles. The exterior design featured squared-off proportions with prominent wheel arches and upright greenhouse providing excellent visibility. Powertrain options varied by market but typically included 2.0L and 2.5L gasoline engines and a 2.2L diesel, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. The interior emphasized durability with water-resistant surfaces, removable and washable seat covers on some variants, and practical features including multiple storage compartments and a wet storage area in the cargo floor. Notable for its combination of car-like on-road manners with respectable off-road capability, the first-generation X-Trail became particularly popular in Europe, Asia, and Australia, though it wasn't offered in North America where Nissan instead sold the more road-focused Murano.
Nissan-X-Trail.name: First Generation (T30)

Nissan-X-Trail.description: The second-generation X-Trail maintained the boxy, functional design ethos of its predecessor but with smoother contours and a slightly larger footprint. Built on Nissan's C platform shared with the Qashqai/Rogue, it continued to offer capable all-wheel drive systems with electronic hill descent control and an intelligent ESP system that incorporated understeer control. Powertrain options again varied by market but typically included improved versions of the 2.0L and 2.5L gasoline engines and 2.0L diesel, with transmission choices including manual and continuously variable transmission (CVT) options. The interior featured a more refined design while maintaining practical elements including water-resistant surfaces in some variants, fold-flat rear seats, and the innovative Utili-Track cargo system with movable tie-down points. Technology features expanded to include available navigation, Bluetooth connectivity, and a panoramic sunroof. This generation continued to balance on-road comfort with off-road capability, though with increased emphasis on interior refinement and technology, maintaining strong sales in global markets while the North American market continued to receive the separate Rogue model.
Nissan-X-Trail.name: Second Generation (T31)

Nissan-X-Trail.description: The third-generation X-Trail adopted a significantly more modern and aerodynamic design while maintaining some of the model's traditional boxiness. For the first time, platform sharing with the North American Rogue became explicit, with the X-Trail and Rogue essentially the same vehicle with market-specific adjustments. Built on the Common Module Family (CMF) platform developed within the Renault-Nissan Alliance, it offered improved rigidity, refinement, and safety. Powertrain options varied substantially by market, including various gasoline and diesel four-cylinder engines, with transmission choices typically including manual and continuously variable options. The all-wheel drive system evolved to include multiple terrain modes. A significant addition was the optional third-row seat, allowing for seven-passenger capacity, though with limited space in the rearmost row. The interior featured a more premium design with higher quality materials, improved technology including NissanConnect infotainment, Around View Monitor camera system, and expanded driver assistance features as the generation progressed. A refresh in 2017 brought styling updates, interior refinements, and additional safety technology. The third-generation X-Trail balanced its traditional SUV appeal with crossover comfort, continuing its global popularity while maintaining separate branding from the mechanically similar Rogue in markets where both were sold.
Nissan-X-Trail.name: Third Generation (T32)

Nissan-X-Trail.description: The current X-Trail features bold, modern styling sharing many design elements with the North American Rogue but with market-specific adjustments. Built on an updated version of the CMF platform with increased use of high-strength steel and lightweight materials, it offers improved structural rigidity and refinement. The exterior design incorporates Nissan's V-motion grille, split-level headlight arrangement, and more muscular proportions than its predecessor. Powertrain options vary by market but include conventional gasoline engines and, notably, Nissan's innovative e-Power system in some regions—where a gasoline engine functions solely as a generator for an electric motor that drives the wheels, providing EV-like driving characteristics without requiring external charging. Advanced driver assistance expands with Nissan's ProPILOT system offering semi-autonomous driving capability on highways. The interior represents a significant upgrade with a more premium design, higher quality materials, and advanced technology including an available 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster and 10.8-inch head-up display. Available in five and seven-seat configurations, it maintains the model's focus on family practicality while offering improved refinement and technology. The fourth-generation X-Trail positions itself as a more sophisticated, electrified offering while maintaining the versatility and capability that have defined the nameplate, continuing its global significance as one of Nissan's core models outside North America.
Nissan-X-Trail.name: Fourth Generation (T33)

Nissan-Xterra.description: The original Nissan Xterra was introduced as a rugged, affordable SUV positioned below the Pathfinder in Nissan's lineup, targeting younger, active buyers seeking off-road capability without luxury pretensions. Built on the Frontier pickup truck platform, it featured distinctive styling with a raised rear roofline, externally mounted first aid kit, and prominent roof rack with integrated storage box. Initially powered by either a 2.4L four-cylinder (143 hp) or a 3.3L V6 (170 hp, later increased to 180 hp), paired with either a five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmission. Available in rear-wheel drive or part-time four-wheel drive configurations with a two-speed transfer case for low-range off-road capability. The interior emphasized durability and functionality over luxury, with wash-out flooring, stadium-style rear seating for improved visibility, and numerous storage solutions for outdoor gear. Trim levels included the base XE and more feature-rich SE, with later additions including the rugged SE Supercharged featuring a supercharged version of the 3.3L V6 producing 210 horsepower. The first-generation Xterra established a distinctive niche in the SUV market, appealing to outdoor enthusiasts with its combination of authentic off-road capability, practical design features, and value pricing.
Nissan-Xterra.name: First Generation (WD22)

Nissan-Xterra.description: The second-generation Xterra featured more aggressive styling with a muscular stance, distinctive stepped roofline, and pronounced fender flares. Built on Nissan's F-Alpha platform shared with the Frontier and Titan, it grew larger and more capable than its predecessor. Powered exclusively by a 4.0L V6 engine producing 265 horsepower (later revised to 261 hp), paired with either a six-speed manual or five-speed automatic transmission. Available in rear-wheel drive or part-time four-wheel drive configurations with a two-speed transfer case and available electronic locking rear differential on off-road-oriented models. The chassis featured a fully boxed ladder frame, independent front suspension, and solid rear axle with leaf springs optimized for off-road durability. The interior maintained its focus on functionality with easy-clean surfaces, adjustable cargo organization system, and available built-in first-aid kit. Trim levels evolved throughout the generation but typically included the base X, volume-selling S, luxury-oriented SE, and off-road-focused Pro-4X (initially called Off Road), the latter featuring Bilstein shocks, skid plates, all-terrain tires, and additional off-road equipment. A refresh in 2009 brought updated styling, refined interior, and additional features. Despite minimal changes in its later years, the second-generation Xterra maintained a loyal following among off-road enthusiasts seeking a legitimate SUV with true off-road capabilities in an era of increasingly car-based crossovers. Production ended in 2015 as Nissan consolidated its SUV lineup and stringent emissions and safety standards made updating the platform financially challenging.
Nissan-Xterra.name: Second Generation (N50)

Omoda-Omoda-5-EV.description: The Omoda E5 (also known as Omoda C5 EV or Chery Omoda E5 depending on the market) is the all-electric variant of the Omoda 5 compact crossover from Chery Automobile's premium-oriented Omoda sub-brand. Unveiled at Auto Shanghai in April 2023, it entered production in February 2024 and first went on sale in Indonesia in February 2024, followed by Australia in September 2024. Featuring Chery's 'Art in Motion' design language with a distinct front end styling compared to the petrol version, it lacks any Chery logo and branding. It is built on the T1X platform and powered by a front-mounted permanent magnet synchronous motor producing 150 kW (204 PS/201 hp) and 340 Nm of torque. The original battery option was a 61.06 kWh LFP battery pack, capable of 0-100 km/h acceleration in 7.2 seconds. Driving range varies by market certification but is approximately 430 km under NEDC standards. DC fast charging allows 30-80% charge in approximately 30 minutes. The interior features dual integrated 10.25-inch high-definition digital screens for driving, climate and entertainment controls. Available technology includes wireless smartphone charging, a Sony sound system, and advanced driver assistance systems including adaptive cruise control, lane keeping assistance, and autonomous emergency braking. The E5 represents Omoda's expansion into international markets including Australia, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Singapore, Brazil, and various European countries.
Omoda-Omoda-5-EV.name: First Generation

Perodua-Bezza.description: The original Perodua Bezza was a significant milestone as Perodua's first sedan model, designed and developed primarily for the Malaysian market. Launched on 21 July 2016, it was built on the platform shared with the Axia hatchback but featured a four-door sedan body style. The design emphasized maximizing interior space and fuel efficiency, with Perodua claiming up to 95% local content. Powered by either a 1.0L three-cylinder 1KR-VE VVT-i engine producing 67 horsepower or a 1.3L four-cylinder 1NR-VE Dual VVT-i engine generating 94 horsepower, paired with either a 5-speed manual or 4-speed automatic transmission. The interior prioritized practical features including multiple storage compartments, flexible 60:40 split-folding rear seats, and a spacious trunk. Available features included push-button start on higher trims, touchscreen infotainment with Bluetooth, reverse camera (Advance variant), and Vehicle Stability Control on the range-topping model. The Bezza achieved 5-star ASEAN NCAP safety rating for the Advance variant, with all models featuring dual airbags, ABS with EBD, and ISOFIX child seat anchors. This first generation positioned the Bezza as an affordable yet well-equipped entry-level sedan focused on value, fuel efficiency, and practicality for urban Malaysian families.
Perodua-Bezza.name: First Generation

Perodua-Bezza.description: The refreshed Perodua Bezza received substantial styling updates while maintaining the same fundamental platform and dimensions. Launched in early January 2020, the facelift featured a redesigned front and rear bumper with gloss black finish on the rear chrome strip and side skirts, upgraded LED headlamps for all variants, and new 14-inch turbine design or 15-inch double-tone alloy wheels. Two new exterior colors were added: Garnet Red and Granite Grey. Interior updates included a revised speedometer with white illumination and removal of the pre-facelift's gloss black dashboard trim in favor of silver. The most significant update came in safety technology, with Perodua's Advanced Safety Assist (ASA) 2.0 suite becoming standard on the Advance variant, offering features unusual in the budget sedan segment including Pedestrian Detection, Pre-Collision Warning, Pre-Collision Braking, Front Departure Alert, and Pedal Misoperation Control. Vehicle Stability Control (VSC) was added to the Premium X variant. Mechanical specifications remained largely unchanged with the same 1.0L and 1.3L engine options, though the manual transmission was discontinued for 1.3L variants. The facelifted Bezza maintained its position as one of Malaysia's bestselling vehicles, with sales reaching 100,814 units in 2024 alone.
Perodua-Bezza.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Peugeot-2008.description: The original Peugeot 2008 was introduced at the 2013 Geneva Motor Show as a subcompact crossover SUV based on the PF1 platform shared with the 208 hatchback. Positioned below the 3008, it replaced the 207 SW as Peugeot did not release a station wagon version of the 208. The design featured increased ride height, plastic body cladding, roof rails, and distinctive front grille with rugged styling elements. Powertrain options included various gasoline engines from 1.2L to 1.6L PureTech and diesel options from 1.4L to 1.6L BlueHDi, paired with manual or automatic transmissions driving front wheels only. The interior showcased Peugeot's i-Cockpit design with a small steering wheel positioned below the instrument cluster, high-mounted dashboard, and premium materials. Available features included Grip Control enhanced traction system for light off-road capability, touchscreen infotainment system, and panoramic glass roof.
Peugeot-2008.name: First Generation (A94) Pre-Facelift

Peugeot-2008.description: The facelifted first-generation 2008 was released in February 2016, featuring a more vertical grille design, additional body cladding, and expanded equipment offerings. The update coincided with the revised 208 platform and brought styling updates to align with Peugeot's evolving design language. The Grip Control system remained available for enhanced traction on various surfaces. In Brazil, the 2008 received a unique facelift in 2019 to maintain competitiveness until the new generation arrived. Production in Brazil continued until November 2023 for South American markets, but the platform/generation effectively ended with the second-generation launch in 2020 for European and global markets.
Peugeot-2008.name: First Generation (A94) Facelift

Peugeot-2008.description: The second-generation Peugeot 2008 was announced on June 19, 2019, featuring dramatically more distinctive styling with bold LED 'fang' daytime running lights and a muscular stance. Built on PSA's Common Modular Platform (CMP) shared with the 208, DS 3 Crossback, and Opel Corsa F, it grew significantly in all dimensions. Powertrain options included PureTech gasoline engines (100-155 hp), BlueHDi diesel options in some markets, and the fully electric e-2008 with 50 kWh battery providing 310 km range. The interior featured the latest i-Cockpit evolution with a 3D digital instrument display, 10-inch touchscreen on higher trims, and distinctive piano-key style toggle switches. Advanced technology included adaptive cruise control, lane positioning assist, automated parking, and driver assistance features.
Peugeot-2008.name: Second Generation (P24) Pre-Facelift

Peugeot-2008.description: The facelifted second-generation 2008 was officially unveiled on May 4, 2023, featuring visual changes including new headlights, front apron, grille with body-colored elements, and updated tail lights. LED headlights and lights became standard across all trims. The e-2008 received a larger 54 kWh battery and new motor, increasing range from 345 km to 406 km under WLTP testing. Internal combustion engines carried over with minor refinements. The updated model incorporates Peugeot's new brand identity and offers additional color options. The e-2008 charging capability remains up to 100 kW where supported. Production continues at various PSA plants including El Palomar factory in Argentina for Latin American markets launched August 2024 with Fiat-sourced FireFly 1.0L turbo engine.
Peugeot-2008.name: Second Generation (P24) Facelift

Peugeot-205.description: The Peugeot 205 was a revolutionary small car that transformed Peugeot's image and financial fortunes. Designed by Gerard Welter (with Pininfarina styling the cabriolet), it featured clean, timeless styling that aged remarkably well throughout its production run. Available in three and five-door hatchback body styles, plus a unique two-door cabriolet created in collaboration with Pininfarina. The fully independent suspension used MacPherson struts at the front and trailing arms with torsion bars at the rear. Early models used the X petrol engine from the older Peugeot 104, later replaced with newer XU and TU-series engines. Engines ranged from 954cc to 1905cc, in carbureted or fuel-injected versions. The diesel models employed the PSA XUD engine, lifted from the Citroën BX, offering petrol-like performance with diesel economy. The interior was simple but well-designed, with good visibility and space utilization despite compact exterior dimensions. Dashboard redesign occurred for the 1988 model year. Notable variants included the GTI performance models launched in 1984, the Rallye stripped sports version, and numerous special editions. The 205 T16 Group B rally car shared little more than styling with the road car but cemented the model's sporting credentials with two World Rally Championships (1985-1986).
Peugeot-205.name: First Generation

Peugeot-205.description: In late 1990, the 205 received a significant facelift introducing new door design with updated cards, clear front indicators replacing amber units, new 'smoked' rear light clusters, single-point petrol injection (Bosch Mono-Jetronic), and catalytic converters to meet 1992 emissions standards. The styling evolution was subtle but distinct, maintaining the car's timeless appeal while updating it for the new decade. The XU and TU engines continued with improvements, including the introduction of the turbocharged 1.8 diesel dTurbo in 1991 delivering enhanced performance in the diesel segment. The STDT (Special Trim Diesel Turbo) was introduced in 1993, offering GTI-like handling in a diesel package with bucket seats, power steering, and alloy wheels. The GTI continued through 1994, though the 1.6 was discontinued in 1992 due to emissions regulations while the 1.9 continued with catalytic converter. Special editions included the Miami Blue and Sorrento Green limited GTIs (1989-1990), the Gentry luxury variant with leather interior, and the 1FM UK-exclusive 25th anniversary edition. Production ended in the UK in 1996, with the final 'Sacré Numéro' and 'Génération' models sold until 1998 in Argentina and France. Over 5.2 million units were produced during its remarkable 15-year run.
Peugeot-205.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Peugeot-206.description: The original Peugeot 206 was introduced in September 1998 as the successor to the legendary 205, representing a new generation of Peugeot superminis. Built on the PSA PF1 platform, it featured distinctive styling with large headlights and a rounded design. Available initially as 3-door and 5-door hatchbacks, the range expanded to include the 206 CC coupe-cabriolet with a folding steel roof (2000), the 206 SW station wagon (2002), and the 206 SD sedan for developing markets like Iran (2005). Engine options ranged from 1.1L to 2.0L petrol and 1.4L to 2.0L diesel, with the high-performance GTi (130hp) and later GTi 180/RC (180hp) variants becoming modern classics. A minor cosmetic facelift in 2003 brought updated headlights, rear clusters, and interior revisions. The 206 achieved motorsport success, winning the World Rally Championship manufacturers' and drivers' titles in 2000 and 2002. Replaced by the 207 in European markets in April 2006, but continued production globally until 2008.
Peugeot-206.name: First Generation

Peugeot-206.description: The facelifted Peugeot 206, marketed as the 206+ in Europe (2009-2013) and 207 Compact/207 Brasil in South America (2008-2017), featured a significant restyle with a new front end and styling similar to the Peugeot 207. The redesign included revised headlights, bumper, grille, and interior appointments bringing it in line with Peugeot's newer design language. Production continued at the Mulhouse plant in France for European markets, while South American production (Argentina, Brazil) extended well beyond 2012. The facelifted model was offered in hatchback, station wagon, and sedan body styles. In Iran, a related version called the 207i was produced under license by Iran Khodro (IKCO), with a second series launched in 2017 using locally sourced parts. This extended production run made the 206 one of Peugeot's longest-lived single generation models, with over 8.3 million units produced globally by 2012.
Peugeot-206.name: First Generation (Facelift/206+)

Peugeot-207.description: The Peugeot 207 was introduced as the successor to the highly successful 206, growing significantly in size and moving upmarket with improved quality and safety features. Based on PSA's Platform 1 (shared with Citroën C3), it featured more aggressive styling with an enlarged grille, distinctive headlights, and a more substantial overall appearance. Available in a wide range of body styles including three and five-door hatchbacks, the 207 CC with a folding metal roof (launched December 2006), and the 207 SW station wagon, with a sedan variant (207 Passion) offered in some markets. Powertrain options included various gasoline engines from 1.4L to 1.6L, including new turbocharged units co-developed with BMW (EP6 engines such as the 1.6 THP producing 175 hp in the GTi/RC), and diesel options from 1.4L to 1.6L HDi, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. The interior featured improved materials and a more modern design compared to the 206, with available features including a panoramic glass roof, dual-zone climate control, and upgraded audio systems. Safety was significantly enhanced with a stronger structure and increased standard safety equipment, earning a 5-star Euro NCAP rating. Production began in April 2006 at plants in Poissy (France), Madrid (Spain), and Trnava (Slovakia). The 207 was replaced by the Peugeot 208 in April 2012.
Peugeot-207.name: First Generation

Peugeot-207.description: The Peugeot 207 received a significant facelift in July 2009, featuring a slightly smaller grille and revised front lighting with new fog lamp housings, along with LED lights on the rear. Some engine management software changes were also made, boosting the power of the GTi from 150 to 175 hp. The refreshed model continued alongside the newly launched 208 until April 2012, when the 208 became the primary successor. However, production of the facelifted 207 continued in certain markets until 2014 to meet ongoing demand. The facelift maintained the same platform and mechanical lineup but offered updated styling both inside and out, with revised dashboard materials and enhanced equipment levels. Despite mixed reviews regarding interior quality and gearbox refinement, the 207 achieved strong sales, ranking as the sixth best-selling car in Britain in 2007 with over 67,000 units sold that year.
Peugeot-207.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Peugeot-208.description: The first-generation Peugeot 208 represented a significant redesign compared to its predecessor, the 207, with a focus on reduced weight, improved efficiency, and a more premium feel. Available in three and five-door hatchback body styles, it featured distinctive styling with a 'floating' front grille, cat's-eye headlights, and 'claw' taillights that would become signature Peugeot design elements. Powertrains included a range of efficient PureTech gasoline engines (1.0L to 1.6L) and BlueHDi diesel options (1.4L to 1.6L), with the performance-oriented GTi variant featuring a 1.6L turbocharged engine producing up to 208 horsepower in the GTi by Peugeot Sport special edition. The interior introduced Peugeot's new i-Cockpit design philosophy with a small steering wheel positioned below the instrument cluster, a high-mounted dashboard, and a touchscreen infotainment system on most variants. Despite being smaller externally than the 207, clever packaging maintained interior space while reducing weight by approximately 110 kg, improving both performance and efficiency. A mid-cycle refresh in 2015 brought subtle styling updates, improved infotainment with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, and enhanced safety features. The 208 successfully repositioned Peugeot's supermini as a more upscale offering in the segment, winning multiple awards and performing well in European markets where its combination of style, efficiency, and perceived quality helped distinguish it from volume competitors.
Peugeot-208.name: First Generation

Peugeot-208.description: The second-generation Peugeot 208 features a bold evolution of Peugeot's design language with a more aggressive front end, distinctive LED lighting including 'fang' daytime running lights, and a black rear panel with LED 'claw' taillights spanning the width of the car. Built on PSA's new CMP (Common Modular Platform), it's offered exclusively as a five-door hatchback. A significant innovation is the availability of multiple powertrain options on the same platform: traditional PureTech gasoline engines (75-130 hp), BlueHDi diesel options in some markets, and the fully electric e-208 with a 50 kWh battery providing approximately 217 miles (350 km) of range. The interior represents a major advancement of the i-Cockpit concept with 3D holographic-effect digital instruments, a larger central touchscreen with piano-key shortcut buttons, and higher quality materials throughout. Available technology includes semi-autonomous driving features, adaptive cruise control, automatic parking, and a suite of connected services. Performance models moved away from the GTi badge tradition, with the GT and GT-Line trims offering sportier styling and equipment but less performance focus than previous GTi models. The e-208 electric variant shares most styling elements with combustion models but offers distinctive color accents and dedicated displays. This generation positions the 208 further upmarket with improved refinement, technology, and design sophistication while maintaining competitive pricing, winning European Car of the Year 2020 and establishing Peugeot's position at the premium end of the mainstream supermini segment.
Peugeot-208.name: Second Generation

Peugeot-3008.description: The original Peugeot 3008 was introduced as a compact crossover with distinctive MPV influences, featuring a relatively tall body, practical interior, and innovative features. The exterior design blended elements of both SUVs and minivans with a rounded profile, distinctive Peugeot family face, and a unique split tailgate that could function as both a conventional hatch and a small pickup-style dropgate. Powertrain options varied by market but typically included gasoline engines from 1.2L to 1.6L and diesel options from 1.6L to 2.0L, with manual and automatic transmission options. A innovative diesel-electric Hybrid4 variant was introduced in 2011, featuring a 2.0L diesel engine powering the front wheels and an electric motor for the rear wheels, creating a through-the-road all-wheel drive system. The interior showcased a cockpit-like design with a high center console, aircraft-style handbrake, and a driver-oriented layout. Notable features included the Grip Control enhanced traction system offering various terrain modes without the complexity and weight of a traditional AWD system, a Head-Up Display, and an available panoramic glass roof. A significant refresh in 2013 brought updated styling with LED signature lighting, improved interior materials, and enhanced technology features. The first-generation 3008 established the model as a practical, innovative option in the growing crossover segment, with strong sales particularly in European markets where its combination of MPV practicality with crossover styling and features appealed to family buyers.
Peugeot-3008.name: First Generation (T84)

Peugeot-3008.description: The second-generation Peugeot 3008 represented a dramatic reinvention, transforming from a MPV-crossover hybrid into a fully-fledged SUV with bold, contemporary styling. Built on PSA's new EMP2 platform, it features a more muscular stance, distinctive front end with an aggressive grille design, and numerous SUV styling cues including pronounced wheel arches and protective body cladding. Powertrain options expanded to include various PureTech gasoline engines (1.2L to 1.6L), BlueHDi diesel options (1.5L to 2.0L), and plug-in hybrid variants introduced in 2019 offering either front-wheel drive (225 hp combined) or all-wheel drive (300 hp combined) with up to 36 miles of electric-only range. The interior showcases an evolved version of Peugeot's i-Cockpit with a compact steering wheel, 12.3-inch digital instrument display, and 8-inch (later 10-inch) touchscreen, complemented by distinctive toggle switches and high-quality materials. Advanced technology includes semi-autonomous driving features, automated parking, and a comprehensive suite of driver assistance systems. A significant refresh in 2020 brought updated exterior styling with a frameless grille, redesigned lighting elements, and enhanced technology including night vision capabilities on higher trims. The second-generation 3008 achieved critical acclaim, winning European Car of the Year 2017 and numerous other awards, successfully repositioning the model as a premium-feeling offering in the highly competitive compact SUV segment and becoming one of Peugeot's global bestsellers.
