Peugeot-3008.name: Second Generation (P84)

Peugeot-3008.description: The third-generation Peugeot 3008 represents another significant evolution, transforming into a fastback-SUV with a dramatically more futuristic design. Built on Stellantis's new STLA Medium platform designed specifically for electrification, it features a sleeker, more aerodynamic profile with a steeply raked rear window, distinctive front-end with Peugeot's new light signature, and more angular overall aesthetic. For the first time, the 3008 lineup includes a fully electric e-3008 variant as the flagship, offering multiple battery options (73 kWh or 98 kWh) providing ranges up to approximately 435 miles in the Long Range version. Hybrid and plug-in hybrid powertrains are also available, maintaining powertrain flexibility while shifting focus toward electrification. The interior introduces Peugeot's new Panoramic i-Cockpit featuring a curved 21-inch screen combining the instrument cluster and infotainment functions, complemented by a minimalist dashboard design with few physical controls. Advanced technology includes upgraded driver assistance systems, augmented reality navigation, and sophisticated connected services. Passenger space is enhanced despite the sleeker roofline, with a focus on premium materials and sustainable options including recycled fabrics. The third-generation 3008 positions itself as a technological showcase for Peugeot, bridging the gap between traditional SUVs and electric vehicles while maintaining the distinctive design philosophy and premium positioning established by its predecessor, targeting increasingly electrification-focused European markets with a forward-looking design and technology approach.
Peugeot-3008.name: Third Generation (P64)

Peugeot-307.description: The Peugeot 307 was introduced as a replacement for the successful 306, representing a significant shift in design philosophy with a taller, more MPV-influenced profile offering improved interior space. Available in multiple body styles including three and five-door hatchbacks, a station wagon (SW), a sedan (in select markets), and the innovative 307 CC featuring a folding metal hardtop. The exterior design featured Peugeot's distinctive front fascia with a prominent grille between the headlights and swept-back headlights, while the overall proportions emphasized interior volume rather than sporty aesthetics. Powertrain options varied by market but typically included gasoline engines ranging from 1.4L to 2.0L and diesel options from 1.4L to 2.0L HDi, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. The interior offered significantly more headroom than its predecessor, with flexible seating configurations particularly in the SW version which could be ordered with an optional third row. Notable features included dual-zone climate control, a panoramic glass roof on the SW, and improved safety equipment earning it the European Car of the Year award for 2002. The 307 WRC competed in the World Rally Championship starting in 2004, though with some transmission problems. Despite early build quality concerns noted by German Automobile Club statistics, the 307 proved popular with over 3.7 million units sold globally during its lifetime.
Peugeot-307.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Peugeot-307.description: In June 2005, the 307 was revised to meet the competition of improved rivals which had been launched since the introduction of the 307 four years earlier. The facelift brought significant exterior changes including restyled headlights, a new bonnet, updated instrument cluster, and most notably the removal of the trademark Peugeot grille between the headlights. The new front design featured a larger air intake as first established on the Peugeot 407, establishing Peugeot's new grille language. Reliability improved significantly with the facelift models becoming more popular and trustworthy according to reviews. Production continued in Europe until 2008, though the model was also built in China through 2014 and Argentina through 2010. The 307 WRC achieved its greatest success during this period with Marcus Grönholm winning Rally Finland in both 2004 and 2005, plus Rally Japan in 2005. Overall the facelifted 307 maintained its position as a practical small family car with improved quality while continuing to offer multiple body styles and efficient powertrains including the 1.6 BioFlex ethanol-capable engine introduced in 2007.
Peugeot-307.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Peugeot-308.description: The original Peugeot 308 was introduced as a replacement for the 307, featuring more conventional styling compared to its MPV-influenced predecessor, with a focus on improved quality and refinement. Available in multiple body styles including three and five-door hatchbacks, a station wagon (SW), and the 308 CC featuring a folding metal hardtop. The exterior design showcased a more sophisticated aesthetic with a prominent grille, flowing lines, and improved aerodynamics. Powertrain options varied by market but typically included gasoline engines ranging from 1.4L to 1.6L (the latter co-developed with BMW and featuring turbocharging in higher performance variants) and diesel options from 1.6L to 2.0L HDi, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. The high-performance GTi variant featured a 1.6L turbocharged engine producing 200 horsepower. The interior represented a significant improvement in material quality and design compared to the 307, with a more driver-focused layout and improved ergonomics. A significant facelift in May 2011 brought updated styling including a smaller grille and revised front fascia more aligned with Peugeot's evolving design language, along with improved engines offering better efficiency and reduced emissions. A second facelift in 2015 was applied to South American markets where the EMP2 platform was not industrialized, featuring updated front bumper design inspired by the second-generation 308. While European production ended in 2013 when the second generation launched, first-generation 308 continued manufacture in Argentina until 2021, sold alongside the imported second-generation model locally named 308 S. The first-generation 308 successfully repositioned Peugeot's compact offering with a more premium feel and conventional styling, improving the brand's quality perception while maintaining competitive pricing in the European C-segment.
Peugeot-308.name: First Generation (T7)

Peugeot-308.description: The second-generation Peugeot 308 marked a substantial leap forward in design, quality, and technology, built on PSA's new EMP2 platform offering reduced weight and improved efficiency. Unveiled in May 2013 and awarded the 2014 European Car of the Year, it was available as a five-door hatchback and station wagon (SW), featuring more sophisticated styling with a smaller, more upright grille, sleeker headlights, and a more athletic stance. The exterior design won praise for its elegant proportions and premium appearance. Powertrain options expanded to include improved PureTech gasoline engines (1.2L to 1.6L) and BlueHDi diesel options (1.5L to 2.0L), with the performance-oriented GTi by Peugeot Sport featuring a 1.6L turbocharged engine producing up to 270 horsepower with advanced features including an electronic limited-slip differential and Alcon brakes. The interior introduced Peugeot's innovative i-Cockpit design concept with a small steering wheel positioned below the instrument cluster, minimalist dashboard, and high-mounted controls centered around a touchscreen infotainment system—a design that proved polarizing but became a signature Peugeot element. A facelift in 2017 brought a new bonnet, front bumper design with scrolling indicators, updated grille featuring the new Peugeot Lion logo, and improved infotainment with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. An eight-speed automatic transmission replaced the previous six-speed unit. The 2020 update introduced the digital i-Cockpit first seen on the 3008. Production of the second-generation 308 ended in May 2021, successfully repositioning the model as a more upscale alternative to mainstream competitors like the Volkswagen Golf and Ford Focus.
Peugeot-308.name: Second Generation (T9)

Peugeot-308.description: The current Peugeot 308 represents another significant advancement, featuring bold, distinctive styling with an aggressive front end showcasing Peugeot's new lion-head logo, slimmer headlights, and the brand's signature 'fang' LED daytime running lights. Built on the third-generation EMP2 platform (EMP2 V3) with an increased wheelbase, it's available as a five-door hatchback and station wagon (SW). Unveiled in March 2021 and launched in May 2021, with production beginning September 29, 2021, it was the first vehicle to bear Peugeot's new logo. The design features a sleeker silhouette with reduced height and a drag coefficient of 0.28. Powertrain options diversified significantly to include traditional PureTech gasoline and BlueHDi diesel engines alongside new plug-in hybrid variants (308 Hybrid and Hybrid 180/225) combining a 1.6L gasoline engine with an electric motor for total system outputs of either 180 or 225 horsepower and approximately 60km of electric-only range under WLTP testing. A fully electric e-308 was introduced in September 2022 with a 54 kWh battery pack (80% nickel, 10% manganese, 10% cobalt) providing approximately 400km of range. The interior features Peugeot's evolved i-Cockpit concept with a 10-inch digital instrument display, 10-inch central touchscreen with customizable i-toggle shortcut buttons, and an overall more premium design with high-quality materials. Advanced technology includes semi-autonomous driving capabilities (Drive Assist pack with adaptive cruise control, lane keeping assistance, and semi-automatic lane change), matrix LED headlights on GT and GT Premium variants, and enhanced connectivity features. The station wagon version was released in June 2021, while a crossover derivative (408) was unveiled in June 2022. A facelift in August 2025 brought design updates and improved EV range for the e-308. The third-generation 308 positions itself as a technology-forward, premium-feeling alternative in the compact segment.
Peugeot-308.name: Third Generation (P5)

Peugeot-308-Hybrid.description: The Peugeot 308 Hybrid represents the plug-in hybrid variant of the third-generation 308, built on the EMP2 V3 platform specifically optimized for electrification. Available in both five-door hatchback and SW (station wagon) body styles, it features identical exterior styling to conventional 308 models with subtle Hybrid badging, distinctive 'fang' LED daytime running lights, and the new Peugeot emblem prominently displayed on its bold grille. The vehicle was unveiled in March 2021 and production began on September 29, 2021. Offered in two power levels: Hybrid 180 combining a 150 hp 1.6-liter PureTech turbocharged gasoline engine with an 81 kW electric motor for a combined 180 horsepower, and Hybrid 225 with an uprated 180 hp gasoline engine for a total system output of 225 horsepower. Both versions utilize the same 12.4 kWh lithium-ion battery providing electric-only range under WLTP testing. The powertrain is paired with an e-EAT8 eight-speed automatic transmission with the electric motor integrated into the gearbox. The interior features Peugeot's latest i-Cockpit design with a 10-inch digital instrument cluster, 10-inch central touchscreen with customizable i-toggle shortcut buttons, and compact steering wheel positioned below the instruments. Dedicated hybrid system displays show energy flow, battery status, and charging information. Driving modes include Electric, Hybrid, and Sport, with a specific 'e-Save' function to preserve battery charge for later use. Charging capabilities include support for up to 7.4 kW AC charging, allowing a full charge in under 2 hours. Despite the addition of hybrid components, clever packaging minimizes the impact on interior space, with only a slight reduction in cargo capacity compared to conventional models. The 308 Hybrid maintains the model's focus on distinctive design, driving engagement, and premium feel while adding significant efficiency benefits and electric driving capability.
Peugeot-308-Hybrid.name: Third Generation (P5)

Peugeot-407.description: The Peugeot 407 was introduced as a replacement for the successful 406, featuring dramatically more distinctive styling with a prominent front overhang, large grille opening, and sleek profile. Available in three body styles: a four-door sedan, a five-door station wagon (SW), and the elegant two-door coupe designed by Pininfarina. Built on PSA's Platform 3, it featured double-wishbone front suspension and a multi-link rear setup providing improved handling and ride comfort. Powertrain options varied by market but typically included gasoline engines ranging from 1.8L to 3.0L V6, and diesel options from 1.6L to 3.0L V6 HDi, paired with manual, automated manual (2.0 HDi only), or conventional automatic transmissions. The interior featured a driver-focused cockpit with a prominent center console, available features including dual-zone climate control, high-end JBL audio, and satellite navigation system with a pop-up screen. Safety was emphasized with up to nine airbags, electronic stability control, and available lane departure warning system—advanced for its time. A significant refresh in 2008 brought subtle styling updates, improved interior materials, and enhanced efficiency across the engine range. The 407 represented a more dynamic, design-focused approach compared to its predecessor, though its bold styling proved somewhat polarizing. Over its production run, approximately 1.1 million units were sold, making it less commercially successful than the 406 it replaced, but it remained an important model in Peugeot's lineup until succeeded by the 508 in 2011.
Peugeot-407.name: First Generation (D2)

Peugeot-505.description: The Peugeot 505 was introduced as a replacement for the successful 504, officially unveiled on May 16, 1979. Designed by Pininfarina in collaboration with Peugeot's internal styling department, featuring clean, elegant lines that would age remarkably well throughout its long production run. Available as a four-door sedan with the station wagon (Break) and eight-passenger Familiale version introduced at the 1982 Geneva Motor Show. The front-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout differentiated the 505 from many marketplace competitors. Early models featured MacPherson struts at front and semi-trailing arms at rear, with station wagons using a live-axle rear suspension. Initial engine offerings included the 1.8L XM7 and 2.0L XN1 gasoline engines with carburetor or fuel injection, along with the 2.3L XD2 diesel inherited from the 504. The interior designed by Paul Bracq emphasized comfort with supportive seats and logical control layout. Right-hand drive became available from October 1979 for RHD markets. The 505 was praised by contemporary journalists for its ride and handling, especially on rough roads, contributing to its popularity in less developed countries. Dangel offered a four-wheel drive version of the Break with turbodiesel or 2.2L petrol engines.
Peugeot-505.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Peugeot-505.description: The 505 received a significant facelift in 1986, featuring an all-new interior while maintaining the proven rear-wheel drive platform. The estate/wagon model continued production until 1992, while sedan production ended in 1989 with the launch of the new Peugeot 605 flagship. The V6 model using the 2.8-liter PRV engine was added during 1986, priced identically to the 505 Turbo but targeting a different clientele. The Turbo models received increased power to 130 PS thanks to an intercooler and slight boost increase, with ABS brakes also added. The 505 STI introduced the new 2165cc Douvrin engine developed with Renault. The turbodiesel XD3T and XD3TE with intercooler became available from 1985 onwards. North American markets received unique body styling with different headlamps, taillights, and bumpers, with turbocharged station wagons unique to the US. The 505 was one of the last Peugeot models sold in the United States, with sedan sales ending in 1990 and wagon sales in 1991. In Argentina, production continued until 1995 by Sevel. The 505 became one of Peugeot's most globally successful models, with over 1.3 million units produced between 1978 and 1992.
Peugeot-505.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Peugeot-508.description: The original Peugeot 508 was introduced as a joint replacement for both the 407 and larger 607, representing a more streamlined approach to Peugeot's sedan lineup. Available as a four-door sedan (with a fastback-like profile) and a five-door station wagon (SW), it featured relatively conservative but elegant styling with balanced proportions. Built on PSA's Platform 3, it offered improved efficiency and refinement compared to its predecessors. Powertrain options varied by market but typically included gasoline engines ranging from 1.6L to 2.0L and diesel options from 1.6L to 2.2L HDi, with a diesel-electric HYbrid4 variant added in 2012—introducing a through-the-road hybrid system with diesel engine powering the front wheels and electric motor driving the rear wheels. Transmission choices included manual, automated manual, and conventional automatic options. The interior represented a significant improvement in quality and design, with premium materials, a driver-focused layout, and available technology including a color head-up display, four-zone climate control, and a JBL premium audio system. A significant refresh in 2014 brought updated styling with a more vertical grille design aligned with newer Peugeot models, improved interior materials, and enhanced technology features. A long-wheelbase version was produced exclusively for the Chinese market. The first-generation 508 successfully established itself as Peugeot's flagship sedan, offering a compelling combination of comfort, efficiency, and premium features, though it faced the challenges of a declining sedan market as consumer preferences shifted toward SUVs.
Peugeot-508.name: First Generation (W23)

Peugeot-508.description: The current Peugeot 508 features dramatically more distinctive styling departing from conventional sedan norms, with a sleek fastback design, frameless doors, and aggressive styling elements including fang-like LED daytime running lights and a bold front fascia. Built on PSA's EMP2 platform, it's available as a five-door fastback (technically a liftback rather than a conventional sedan) and a station wagon (SW). The exterior design prioritizes style over maximum practicality, with a low coupe-like roofline and muscular stance. Powertrain options include various PureTech gasoline engines (1.6L) and BlueHDi diesel options (1.5L to 2.0L), with the range later expanded to include a plug-in hybrid variant combining a 1.6L gasoline engine with an electric motor for a combined output of up to 225 horsepower and approximately 30-35 miles of electric-only range. The interior showcases Peugeot's i-Cockpit design philosophy with a small steering wheel positioned below the instrument panel, high-mounted digital displays, and distinctive toggle-style switches. Material quality represents Peugeot's most premium offering with advanced technology including Night Vision, adaptive cruise control with stop-and-go functionality, and a comprehensive suite of driver assistance systems. The high-performance Peugeot Sport Engineered (PSE) variant introduced in 2020 features a more powerful plug-in hybrid system combining a 1.6L turbocharged engine with two electric motors (one per axle) for a total system output of 355 horsepower, creating Peugeot's most powerful production car. The second-generation 508 positions itself as a design-focused alternative to conventional D-segment competitors and premium brand offerings, emphasizing style, technology, and driving dynamics while acknowledging the segment's declining sales by focusing on distinction rather than maximum market share.
Peugeot-508.name: Second Generation (R83)

Peugeot-Expert.description: The original Peugeot Expert was developed as part of a joint venture between PSA (Peugeot-Citroën) and Fiat, sharing its platform and most components with the Citroën Jumpy and Fiat Scudo. Available in panel van, combi (mixed passenger and cargo), and minibus configurations with standard and long wheelbase options. The design featured a relatively compact footprint for urban maneuverability while maximizing interior cargo volume, with sliding side doors and rear barn doors or an available tailgate. Powertrain options included various gasoline and diesel engines, with the latter predominating in most markets, typically ranging from 1.9L to 2.0L, paired with manual transmissions. The interior prioritized functionality with durable materials and straightforward controls, though passenger variants offered improved comfort features. A significant refresh in 2004 brought updated styling, improved engines including a new 2.0L HDi diesel, and enhanced equipment levels. Over its 11-year production run, the first-generation Expert established itself as a versatile commercial vehicle for small businesses and fleet operators, offering a balance of cargo capacity, driving dynamics, and operating costs between smaller car-derived vans and larger full-size commercial vehicles.
Peugeot-Expert.name: First Generation

Peugeot-Expert.description: The second-generation Expert continued the collaboration between PSA and Fiat, sharing its platform with the Citroën Jumpy, Fiat Scudo, and newly added Toyota ProAce. Featuring more modern styling with a car-like front end, improved aerodynamics, and a more substantial overall presence. Available in multiple body configurations including panel van, crew van, combi, and platform cab versions, with various length and height options providing increased versatility. The cargo capacity expanded to up to 7 cubic meters with a payload capacity of up to 1,200 kg depending on configuration. Powertrain options centered around HDi diesel engines ranging from 1.6L to 2.0L with various power outputs, all paired with manual transmissions, with later models receiving improved e-HDi engines featuring start-stop technology for enhanced efficiency. The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and available technology, with an emphasis on creating a more car-like driving environment while maintaining commercial vehicle durability. Advanced features for the segment included available navigation, Bluetooth connectivity, and improved safety equipment including ESP stability control. This generation successfully modernized the Expert formula, increasing its appeal to both commercial users and private buyers seeking a versatile people carrier, while improving efficiency, refinement, and technology to meet evolving market expectations.
Peugeot-Expert.name: Second Generation

Peugeot-Expert.description: The current Peugeot Expert is built on PSA's EMP2 platform, shared with passenger cars but adapted for commercial use, and jointly developed with other brands in the group plus Toyota (Citroën Jumpy/SpaceTourer, Opel/Vauxhall Vivaro, Toyota ProAce). Available in three length variants (Compact at 4.6m, Standard at 4.95m, and Long at 5.3m) without height variations, providing flexibility while maintaining a relatively low overall height of 1.9m, enabling access to most height-restricted parking structures. The exterior design features a more assertive front end with higher-mounted headlights, pronounced wheel arches, and an overall more contemporary appearance. Payload capacity increased to up to 1,400 kg with cargo volume ranging from 4.6 to 6.6 cubic meters depending on configuration. Powertrain options centered on BlueHDi diesel engines ranging from 1.5L to 2.0L with various power outputs (95-180 hp), paired with manual or automatic transmissions. In 2020, an all-electric e-Expert was introduced, featuring a 50 or 75 kWh battery pack providing up to 211 miles (340 km) of range on the larger battery version, with 100 kW DC fast charging capability. The interior combines commercial vehicle practicality with passenger car features, including available 7-inch touchscreen infotainment, head-up display, and advanced driver assistance systems. Innovative features include hands-free sliding side doors operated by a foot sensor and Moduwork flexible front passenger seat that can be raised to create additional cargo space with a flat load-through capability. The third-generation Expert significantly advances the model's capabilities in terms of versatility, technology, and efficiency, while the addition of the electric e-Expert variant positions it at the forefront of the commercial vehicle electrification trend.
Peugeot-Expert.name: Third Generation (K0)

Peugeot-e-208.description: The Peugeot e-208 was introduced as the all-electric variant of the second-generation 208 supermini, unveiled at the Geneva Motor Show in March 2019 and going on sale that summer. Built on PSA's multi-energy CMP (Common Modular Platform), the e-208 shares its chassis with conventional petrol/diesel versions, allowing assembly on the same production line at the Trnava plant in Slovakia. Visually almost identical to its combustion-engine siblings but distinguished by specific styling elements and the absence of a traditional grille. Powered by a 100 kW (136 hp) electric motor producing 260 Nm of instant torque, with a 50 kWh lithium-ion battery providing approximately 211-217 miles (340-350 km) of range under WLTP testing. Performance was brisk with 0-62 mph acceleration in 8.1 seconds and a top speed of 93 mph. Three driving modes were available: Eco, Normal, and Sport. Regenerative braking offered adjustable settings controlled via the gear selector. Charging capabilities included a CCS Combo Type 2 connector supporting up to 100 kW DC fast charging (70 kW up to 40% state of charge, then decreasing to 50 kW), with an onboard charger limited to 7.4 kW (optional 11 kW three-phase available). The interior featured Peugeot's i-Cockpit design with a small steering wheel positioned below the instrument panel, digital instrument cluster, and 7 or 10-inch central touchscreen depending on trim level. The e-208 was approximately 300 kg heavier than conventional versions due to the battery pack, but maintained the same 311-liter cargo capacity. Demand was strong at launch, with over 60% of pre-orders initially for the e-208 variant.
Peugeot-e-208.name: First Generation

Peugeot-e-208.description: The refreshed Peugeot e-208 was introduced in July 2023 alongside the facelifted second-generation 208 lineup, featuring updated exterior styling aligned with Peugeot's evolving design language. The exterior updates include a new front end with redesigned headlights, front apron and grille, while the rear receives new tail lights. LED headlights and partial LED tail lights became standard, with full LED options available. The grille maintains its proportions but features new designs with body-colored elements and incorporates three vertical lines as the new light signature and DRLs. The interior receives an upgraded infotainment system with a 10-inch display as standard (up from 7-inch), while the base trim retains an analogue cockpit. New interior fabrics are also available. The most significant technical change for the e-208 is a more powerful electric motor now producing 115 kW (156 hp), providing increased performance and efficiency. The WLTP range increases accordingly, representing an improvement over the pre-facelift model. Charging capabilities remain similar with support for up to 100 kW DC fast charging. The refreshed e-208 maintains the model's approach of offering electric propulsion without compromise to style or practicality, now with improved performance and range that helps maintain competitiveness against newer rivals in the rapidly evolving electric supermini segment.
Peugeot-e-208.name: First Generation (Refresh)

Polestar-2.description: The Polestar 2 is the first all-electric volume model from Polestar, Volvo's performance and electrification sub-brand. Built on Volvo's Compact Modular Architecture (CMA) platform, it features distinctive fastback styling that blends elements of sedans, hatchbacks, and crossovers with minimalist Scandinavian design principles. Initially launched as a high-performance dual-motor AWD variant with 408 horsepower (300 kW) and 487 lb-ft (660 Nm) of torque, a single-motor FWD version with 231-299 horsepower (depending on model year and battery) was added later. Battery options include a 64 kWh standard-range pack (made by CATL) and a 78 kWh long-range pack, providing EPA-rated ranges from approximately 220-270 miles depending on configuration. Performance is brisk with 0-60 mph acceleration in as little as 4.2 seconds for dual-motor variants. The interior showcases minimalist design with high-quality sustainable materials including available WeaveTech vegan upholstery. Technology is centered around an 11.2-inch portrait-oriented touchscreen powered by Android Automotive OS—the first production car to feature Google's automotive operating system natively integrated, including Google Maps, Google Assistant, and Google Play Store. Safety features include Volvo's comprehensive suite of driver assistance systems. The Performance Pack option adds Öhlins dual-flow valve dampers, Brembo brakes, and distinctive 20-inch forged wheels for enhanced handling capabilities. The Polestar 2 established itself as a compelling alternative to Tesla and traditional premium brand electric vehicles.
Polestar-2.name: First Generation

Polestar-2.description: An updated Polestar 2 was revealed in January 2023 for the 2024 model year, representing a significant facelift with major mechanical and visual changes. Rear-wheel drive became the standard drivetrain for the entry-level single-motor model instead of the previous front-wheel drive configuration, improving efficiency and driving dynamics. The single motor was upgraded to produce 295 hp and 361 lb-ft of torque, an increase of 68 hp and 44 lb-ft, resulting in faster acceleration (0-60 mph in 5.9 seconds). The long range trim's battery was upgraded to 82 kWh capacity (79 kWh usable) from the previous 78 kWh. The dual-motor model's output was increased to 421 hp and 546 lb-ft, enabling 0-60 mph in 4.3 seconds. Dual-motor models now use an asynchronous motor in the front that can disengage to increase efficiency and range. The front end received a major visual update, exchanging the grid-like grille for a more covered version with a 'SmartZone' panel housing sensors and a camera array. The interior continues with minimalist Scandinavian design and Android Automotive OS integration. This facelift represents a substantial evolution of Polestar's first mass-production electric vehicle.
Polestar-2.name: First Generation (2024 Facelift)

Polestar-3.description: The Polestar 3 is the brand's first purpose-built SUV, representing a significant expansion of the Polestar lineup beyond the performance-oriented Polestar 1 and the fastback Polestar 2. Built on Volvo's SPA2 (Scalable Product Architecture) platform, it features distinctive aerodynamic styling with a sloping roofline, muscular proportions, and Polestar's minimalist design language. The exterior incorporates unique elements including a 'SmartZone' front panel housing various sensors, aerodynamic optimization through the front aero wing integrated into the hood, rear aero wings, and distinctive split headlights with Polestar's signature 'Thor's Hammer' daytime running lights. Initially available exclusively with a dual-motor all-wheel drive powertrain producing 489 horsepower and 620 lb-ft of torque in standard form, with an optional Performance Pack increasing output to 517 horsepower and 671 lb-ft. Power comes from a 111 kWh battery pack (107 kWh usable) providing approximately 300 miles of EPA-rated range, with 250 kW DC fast-charging capability allowing a 10-80% charge in approximately 30 minutes. The spacious five-seat interior features sustainable materials including bio-attributed MicroTech upholstery, recycled polyester, and FSC-certified wood. Technology is centered around a 14.5-inch portrait-oriented touchscreen running Android Automotive OS, complemented by a 9-inch driver display and an available 25-speaker Bowers & Wilkins audio system. Advanced driver assistance is provided through a comprehensive suite of radar, camera, and ultrasonic sensors, plus a standard LIDAR system from Luminar that enables enhanced future autonomous capabilities. The Polestar 3 positions itself as a performance-oriented, technology-forward electric SUV competing with premium offerings from established luxury brands and other electric vehicle specialists, with manufacturing taking place both in China and the United States.
Polestar-3.name: First Generation

Polestar-4.description: The Polestar 4 is a battery electric compact luxury crossover SUV marketed by Polestar since 2023. Positioned between the smaller Polestar 2 and larger Polestar 3, it belongs to the D-segment size segmentation. Unveiled in April 2023 at Auto Shanghai, production began in November 2023 at Geely's factory in Hangzhou Bay, China. The vehicle is built on Geely's Sustainable Experience Architecture (SEA) platform, shared with the Volvo EX30 and Zeekr 001. Most notably, the Polestar 4 eliminates the traditional rear window entirely, using a roof-mounted camera system instead. Available in two powertrain options: Single Motor RWD with 272 horsepower, and Dual Motor AWD with 544 horsepower and 506 lb-ft of torque, capable of 0-62 mph in 3.8 seconds. Both variants use a 102 kWh nickel manganese cobalt battery with 200 kW DC fast-charging (10-80% in under 30 minutes) and 22 kW AC charging. The interior features a 15.4-inch Android Automotive touchscreen, 10.2-inch digital instrument cluster, and available head-up display. A full-length glass roof and digital rear-view mirror are standard. Interior materials use 100% recycled polyester. The vehicle became available in Europe, Canada, and Asia-Pacific from 2024, with additional production starting in South Korea (Busan) from H2 2025 via Renault Korea.
Polestar-4.name: First Generation

Pontiac-Vibe.description: First generation Pontiac Vibe produced from 2002-2006. The Vibe was a badged variant of the Toyota Matrix, jointly developed by GM and Toyota at NUMMI in Fremont, California. Base trim with 1.8L engine producing 130hp, AWD model with 118hp (automatic only), and GT sport trim with VVTL-i producing 170hp (6-speed manual only). Front grille resembles Pontiac Aztek styling.
Pontiac-Vibe.name: First Generation

Pontiac-Vibe.description: Facelifted first generation with revised front fascia restyled to resemble the Pontiac Solstice, part of Pontiac's convergence design language. GT and AWD trims discontinued for 2007 model year due to poor sales and new emissions standards. Base trim continued with 1.8L engine.
Pontiac-Vibe.name: First Generation (2005 Facelift)

Pontiac-Vibe.description: Redesigned second generation debuted at December 2007 L.A. Auto Show for 2009 model year. Return of GT trim and AWD options with new 2.4L 158hp engine, plus updated 1.8L 132hp 2ZR-FE standard on base. Last new model from Pontiac brand before discontinuation. Production ended August 17, 2009.
Pontiac-Vibe.name: Second Generation

Porsche-718.description: The Porsche 718 nameplate was revived in 2016 for the fourth generation of the Boxster and Cayman models, paying homage to the successful Porsche 718 race car from the late 1950s and early 1960s. This generation marked a significant powertrain shift, replacing the naturally aspirated flat-six engines with turbocharged flat-four engines. The base models received a 2.0-liter turbocharged flat-four producing 300 horsepower, while the S variants featured a 2.5-liter turbocharged flat-four with 350 horsepower. The GTS models, introduced in 2017, initially used an uprated version of the 2.5-liter turbo-four with 365 horsepower before reverting to a naturally aspirated 4.0-liter flat-six with 394 horsepower in 2020. The track-focused Cayman GT4 and Boxster Spyder models retained naturally aspirated flat-six engines. Although the switch to four-cylinder engines was controversial among purists, the 718 generation delivered improved torque, better fuel economy, and enhanced performance figures. The chassis was refined with technology derived from the 911, including retuned suspension, upgraded brakes, and more responsive steering. The interior was modernized with Porsche's latest PCM infotainment system, while the exterior design was updated with more aggressive styling, revised lighting, and refreshed bumpers. Despite initially facing criticism for its engine note compared to the previous flat-six, the 718 generation has earned respect for its exceptional handling dynamics, precise steering, and impressive performance capabilities.
Porsche-718.name: 982 Generation

Porsche-911.description: The original Porsche 911, initially designated as the 901 until Peugeot objected to the name, established the iconic rear-engine sports car formula that continues to define the model today. Designed by Ferdinand 'Butzi' Porsche, it featured a rear-mounted air-cooled 2.0-liter flat-six engine initially producing 130 horsepower. Throughout this generation, displacement increased to 2.4 liters and power up to 190 horsepower in the Carrera RS version. The distinctive silhouette, round headlights, and sloping rear deck became 911 hallmarks. Despite challenging handling characteristics due to its rear weight bias, the car quickly developed a devoted following for its unique driving experience and versatility as both a daily driver and competition vehicle.
Porsche-911.name: Original 911 (901)

Porsche-911.description: The G-Series 911 introduced significant safety and modernization updates while maintaining the core rear-engine, air-cooled formula. Most visibly, it added impact-absorbing bumpers to meet US regulations. Engine displacement grew from 2.7 to 3.2 liters by the end of production, and the high-performance 911 Turbo (Type 930) was introduced, becoming the brand's flagship with its distinctive wide body and whale tail rear spoiler. Electronic fuel injection replaced mechanical systems, improving reliability and emissions. The model range expanded significantly, including Targa and Cabriolet variants alongside the coupe. This generation's 15-year production run made it the longest-lived 911 series and cemented the model's place in automotive culture.
Porsche-911.name: G-Series

Porsche-911.description: The 964 generation represented the most significant technological update to the 911 in its history to that point, with Porsche claiming 85% new components while maintaining the classic silhouette. Key innovations included coil springs replacing torsion bars, ABS brakes, power steering, and available all-wheel drive in the Carrera 4 model. The air-cooled flat-six grew to 3.6 liters producing 250 horsepower in standard form, while the Turbo initially carried over the 3.3-liter engine before receiving a 3.6-liter unit in its final years. A new Tiptronic automatic transmission option broadened appeal. The 964 maintained the core 911 driving experience while significantly improving refinement, handling precision, and everyday usability.

The 993 generation, designed by Englishman Tony Hatter, is widely regarded as the pinnacle of air-cooled 911 development and the last of the air-cooled models. Its redesigned body featured a more integrated bumper design, smoother curves, and a wider stance. Mechanical improvements included a new multi-link rear suspension that dramatically improved handling and tamed the 911's tendency for lift-off oversteer. The standard 3.6-liter engine produced 272 horsepower initially, while the twin-turbocharged variant made up to 450 horsepower in ultimate Turbo S form. The 993 introduced all-wheel drive across Carrera models in addition to the Turbo. Particularly prized for its combination of classic 911 character with modern refinement and reliability, the 993 has become highly collectible as the final expression of the original air-cooled concept.

The 996 marked the most radical redesign in 911 history, adopting water-cooled engines and a completely new body design sharing components with the less expensive Boxster. Breaking with tradition, the iconic round headlights were replaced with 'fried egg' shaped units, and the interior was completely modernized. The new 3.4-liter (later 3.6-liter) flat-six engines were more powerful, efficient, and environmentally friendly than their air-cooled predecessors. Despite initial resistance from purists, the 996 broadened the 911's appeal with improved comfort, refinement, and daily usability. The GT3 model was introduced as a more track-focused variant, while the Turbo utilized a completely different engine derived from the GT1 race car. Though controversial when new, the 996 has been reassessed as a pivotal transition model that secured the 911's future in an era of increasing regulatory requirements.

The 997 generation represented an evolution of the water-cooled concept introduced with the 996, but with styling that returned to traditional 911 design cues, most notably with the return of circular headlights. Available in Carrera (rear-wheel drive) and Carrera 4 (all-wheel drive) variants, with either 3.6-liter or 3.8-liter engines in standard and S models respectively, power ranged from 325 to 385 horsepower in non-specialized models. The first generation (997.1) used essentially refined 996 engines, while the second phase (997.2) introduced direct fuel injection and dual-clutch PDK transmission options. The model range expanded significantly with numerous special editions and the introduction of the GT2 RS and GT3 RS 4.0 as ultimate performance variants. The 997 is widely considered to have successfully modernized the 911 while recapturing the traditional character somewhat diluted in the 996 generation.

The 991 generation grew slightly in size but actually reduced weight through increased use of aluminum in its construction. For the first time, it utilized electric power steering instead of hydraulic systems. The standard 3.4-liter and 3.8-liter engines in Carrera and Carrera S models respectively were upgraded to turbocharged 3.0-liter units in the 991.2 mid-cycle refresh, marking the end of naturally aspirated engines in standard 911 models. Performance reached new heights across the range, with even base Carrera models capable of sub-4.5 second 0-60 mph times. Technology integration increased significantly with advanced infotainment systems and driver assistance features. The GT3 models maintained naturally aspirated engines and offered both PDK and manual transmission options after enthusiast feedback. The 991 successfully evolved the 911 concept with increased everyday refinement while maintaining its sports car credentials and achieving new performance benchmarks.

The current 992 generation builds upon the 991's foundation with evolutionary styling changes including a more pronounced rear light bar, flush door handles, and wider fenders applied across all models rather than just all-wheel drive variants. The 3.0-liter twin-turbocharged flat-six engines produce 379 horsepower in base Carrera models and 443 horsepower in Carrera S versions, paired with an 8-speed PDK dual-clutch transmission or optional 7-speed manual in select models. Notable innovations include a 'Wet Mode' that detects water on the road and adjusts vehicle systems accordingly, plus significantly enhanced digital interfaces inside the cabin while maintaining some traditional 911 elements like the center tachometer. The 992 GT3 continues with a naturally aspirated 4.0-liter engine producing 502 horsepower. This generation prepares the 911 for potential hybridization while maintaining the distinctive driving character that has defined the model for nearly 60 years.

Porsche-981-Cayman.description: The Porsche 981 Cayman represented the second generation of Porsche's mid-engine coupe, introduced in 2013 following the redesign of its convertible sibling, the Boxster. Built on a new platform featuring increased use of aluminum, the 981 Cayman was approximately 66 pounds lighter than its predecessor while offering 40% greater torsional rigidity. The wheelbase was extended by 2.4 inches, creating a more stable platform and increasing interior space. The standard Cayman featured a 2.7-liter flat-six producing 275 horsepower, while the Cayman S employed a 3.4-liter flat-six with 325 horsepower. The top-tier Cayman GTS, introduced in 2014, produced 340 horsepower from its 3.4-liter engine. The ultimate expression of the 981 Cayman was the GT4, featuring a 3.8-liter engine derived from the 911 Carrera S producing 385 horsepower, aggressive aerodynamics, and track-focused suspension tuning. All variants were available with either a 6-speed manual or 7-speed PDK dual-clutch transmission. The redesigned exterior featured more sculptural styling with larger side air intakes, a steeper windshield angle, and a distinctive spoiler edge integrated into the taillights. The interior quality was significantly upgraded with a design inspired by the Panamera, featuring a sloping center console and improved materials. The 981 Cayman was praised for its near-perfect balance, communicative steering, and exceptional handling dynamics, cementing its reputation as one of the purest sports car experiences available before the transition to turbocharged four-cylinder engines in the succeeding 718 generation.
Porsche-981-Cayman.name: 981 Generation

Porsche-Boxster.description: The original Porsche Boxster (986) debuted as a 1997 model year vehicle after being previewed as a concept in 1993. Developed during a financially challenging period for Porsche, the Boxster shared approximately 40% of its components with the 996-generation 911 to reduce costs. Powered by a water-cooled 2.5-liter flat-six engine initially producing 201 horsepower (later enlarged to 2.7 liters with 217-228 horsepower), the mid-engine roadster offered balanced handling and a more accessible price point than the 911. The Boxster S variant was introduced in 2000 with a 3.2-liter engine producing 250-258 horsepower. The 986 featured a power-operated soft top, a front trunk and a rear trunk straddling the mid-mounted engine, and styling that recalled the iconic 550 Spyder. With its mid-engine layout and near-perfect weight distribution, the Boxster helped reestablish Porsche's financial stability while offering driving dynamics that some enthusiasts considered superior to the higher-priced 911.
Porsche-Boxster.name: First Generation (986)

Porsche-Boxster.description: The second-generation Boxster (987) refined the original concept with more distinctive styling that less closely resembled the 911. The interior was significantly upgraded with higher quality materials and a more sophisticated design. Initially powered by a revised 2.7-liter flat-six producing 240 horsepower in the base model and a 3.2-liter (later 3.4-liter) engine making 280-310 horsepower in the S variant, performance improved across the board. A limited-slip differential became available, and transmission options included a 5-speed manual (later 6-speed) or Tiptronic automatic, with Porsche's PDK dual-clutch transmission arriving with the 2009 update. The 987 received a significant refresh (sometimes called 987.2) for the 2009 model year, with direct fuel injection engines delivering more power and improved efficiency. The range was expanded with the lightweight, performance-focused Boxster Spyder in 2010, featuring a simplified manual top, reduced sound insulation, and a 320-horsepower engine. The 987 generation built upon the dynamic excellence of its predecessor while addressing initial quality concerns and elevating the model's premium positioning.
Porsche-Boxster.name: Second Generation (987)

Porsche-Boxster.description: The third-generation Boxster (981) represented a more comprehensive redesign, featuring a new lightweight body structure with extensive use of aluminum, resulting in improved rigidity and reduced weight despite slightly larger dimensions. The exterior design became more aggressive and sculptural, with larger side air intakes and a more distinctive stance. The base model received a new 2.7-liter flat-six producing 265 horsepower, while the S variant featured a 3.4-liter engine with 315 horsepower. The GTS model, introduced in 2014, extracted 330 horsepower from the 3.4-liter powerplant. The most extreme variant was the Boxster Spyder, featuring a 3.8-liter engine from the 911 Carrera S producing 375 horsepower, a specialized lightweight manual top, and track-focused suspension tuning. The 981's interior quality took another step forward with a design influenced by the Panamera and Carrera GT. This generation was widely praised for its dynamic excellence, with many reviewers considering it among the best-handling cars available at any price. The 981 Boxster represented the pinnacle of the naturally aspirated flat-six Boxster before the transition to turbocharged four-cylinder engines in the succeeding 718 generation.
Porsche-Boxster.name: Third Generation (981)

Porsche-Boxster.description: The fourth and current generation Boxster adopted the 718 nomenclature, paying homage to Porsche's successful four-cylinder racing cars from the 1950s and 1960s. This name change signaled the most significant powertrain shift in the model's history: replacing the naturally aspirated flat-six engines with turbocharged flat-four engines. The base 718 Boxster features a 2.0-liter turbocharged flat-four producing 300 horsepower, while the S model uses a 2.5-liter turbocharged flat-four with 350 horsepower. The GTS initially used an uprated version of the 2.5-liter engine with 365 horsepower before reverting to a naturally aspirated 4.0-liter flat-six with 394 horsepower in 2020. The limited-production 718 Spyder also features this 4.0-liter naturally aspirated engine. While the switch to four-cylinder engines improved torque, acceleration figures, and fuel efficiency, some enthusiasts criticized the change in engine character and sound. Visually, the 718 Boxster features more angular styling with revised front and rear designs, while the interior received updated technology including Porsche's latest infotainment system. Despite the controversial powertrain change, the 718 Boxster maintains the model's reputation for exceptional handling balance, precise steering, and driver engagement.
Porsche-Boxster.name: Fourth Generation (982/718)

Porsche-Cayenne.description: The first-generation Porsche Cayenne (9PA) represented Porsche's controversial but ultimately successful entry into the luxury SUV market. Developed in partnership with Volkswagen (which produced the related Touareg), the Cayenne maintained distinctive Porsche styling and driving characteristics despite its size and weight. Initially available with a 3.2-liter VR6 engine in the base model, a 4.5-liter V8 in the Cayenne S, and a twin-turbocharged version of the V8 producing 450 horsepower in the Turbo, the range later expanded to include the 520-horsepower Turbo S and more efficient V6 diesel and hybrid variants. The Cayenne featured permanent all-wheel drive with a low-range transfer case, offering genuine off-road capability alongside its on-road performance. The GTS variant, introduced in 2008, focused on sporty on-road dynamics with a lowered suspension and 405-horsepower naturally aspirated V8. The interior featured traditional Porsche design elements with a center-mounted tachometer and a button-heavy center console. Despite initial skepticism from Porsche purists, the Cayenne quickly became the brand's best-selling model, providing financial stability that enabled continued development of sports car models.
Porsche-Cayenne.name: First Generation (9PA)

Porsche-Cayenne.description: The second-generation Cayenne (92A) refined the formula with sleeker styling, reduced weight, and improved efficiency while maintaining its predecessor's versatility. Though sharing its platform with the Volkswagen Touareg and Audi Q7, Porsche further differentiated the Cayenne with bespoke powertrains and tuning. Engine options included a 3.6-liter V6, 4.8-liter V8, twin-turbocharged 4.8-liter V8 (in Turbo and Turbo S variants producing up to 570 horsepower), diesel V6 and V8 options, and a new S Hybrid model combining a supercharged V6 with an electric motor. This was later upgraded to a plug-in hybrid system in the S E-Hybrid. The transmission was standardized to an 8-speed Tiptronic automatic across the range. The interior was completely redesigned with influences from the Panamera, featuring higher quality materials and a more cohesive design. The center console incorporated many more physical buttons in a distinctive layout. The second-generation Cayenne introduced more advanced chassis systems, including Porsche Dynamic Chassis Control (PDCC) which utilized active anti-roll bars to reduce body roll. The GTS model continued as the driver-focused naturally aspirated V8 variant until the 2015 facelift, when it switched to a twin-turbocharged V6. The second-generation Cayenne expanded the model's appeal with improved dynamics and efficiency while maintaining its position as a uniquely sporting luxury SUV.
Porsche-Cayenne.name: Second Generation (92A)

Porsche-Cayenne.description: The third and current generation Cayenne (9YA) builds upon the success of its predecessors with evolutionary styling changes concealing a new platform shared with other Volkswagen Group luxury SUVs. Weight reduction was a key focus, with increased use of aluminum and a lighter, more rigid structure. The base model features a 3.0-liter turbocharged V6 producing 335 horsepower, the S variant uses a 2.9-liter twin-turbocharged V6 with 434 horsepower, and the GTS employs a 4.0-liter twin-turbocharged V8 making 453 horsepower. The Turbo variants extract up to 631 horsepower from the 4.0-liter twin-turbo V8 in the Turbo GT model. Hybrid options expanded with the E-Hybrid (455 horsepower) and Turbo S E-Hybrid (670 horsepower), both offering plug-in capability and extended electric range. All models utilize an 8-speed Tiptronic automatic transmission. The exterior design features a wider, more horizontal emphasis with a continuous light strip across the rear. For the first time, the Cayenne is also available in a 'Coupe' body style featuring a more steeply raked roofline and unique rear styling. The interior has been thoroughly modernized with the Porsche Advanced Cockpit concept, reducing physical buttons in favor of touch-sensitive surfaces and larger digital displays. Chassis technology has advanced with options including rear-wheel steering, active anti-roll bars, and three-chamber air suspension. This generation further refines the Cayenne's balance of luxury, versatility, and performance that has made it a cornerstone of Porsche's lineup.
Porsche-Cayenne.name: Third Generation (9YA)

Porsche-Cayenne.description: The fourth-generation Porsche Cayenne was officially unveiled on November 19, 2025, and will commence production in 2026. This generation marks a significant shift as it is exclusively available with a battery-electric powertrain as the Cayenne Electric, built on the Volkswagen Group Premium Platform Electric (PPE). The electric Cayenne features a 113 kWh battery pack (108 kWh net) with support for rapid charging at up to 400 kW. The dual-motor Turbo model produces over 804 horsepower (600 kW) with surge power capabilities reaching 938 horsepower (700 kW) and up to 1,072 horsepower (800 kW) with launch control. The interior has been modernized with a 14.25-inch OLED instrument display and a curved 12.25-inch OLED infotainment screen. Regenerative braking can reach 600 kW, supporting deceleration exceeding 0.5 Gs. While no fourth-generation internal combustion engine Cayenne has been confirmed, Porsche has announced another upgrade to the third-generation model that will extend its lifecycle beyond 2030.
Porsche-Cayenne.name: Fourth Generation (E4)

Porsche-Cayman.description: The first-generation Porsche Cayman (987) was introduced as a coupe companion to the second-generation Boxster, positioned between the Boxster and 911 in Porsche's lineup. Based on the Boxster's architecture but with added structural rigidity from its fixed roof, the Cayman offered enhanced handling dynamics. Initially available as the Cayman S with a 3.4-liter flat-six producing 295 horsepower, a base model with a 2.7-liter 245-horsepower engine was added in 2007. In 2009, as part of the 987.2 update, both engines received direct fuel injection, boosting power to 265 horsepower in the base model and 320 horsepower in the S. Transmission options included a five or six-speed manual, or Porsche's new PDK dual-clutch automatic from 2009. The interior was shared with the Boxster, featuring traditional Porsche styling cues and high-quality materials. A limited-production Cayman R was introduced in 2011 as a lightweight, performance-focused variant with 330 horsepower, reduced sound insulation, and optional deletion of air conditioning and radio. The first-generation Cayman established the model's reputation for exceptional balance and handling precision, with many enthusiasts and reviewers considering it the purest expression of Porsche's sports car philosophy.
Porsche-Cayman.name: First Generation (987)

Porsche-Cayman.description: The second-generation Cayman (981) represented a more comprehensive redesign, featuring a new lightweight body structure with extensive use of aluminum, resulting in a 66-pound weight reduction despite slightly larger dimensions. The chassis rigidity increased by 40%, further enhancing the Cayman's already exceptional handling. The standard Cayman featured a 2.7-liter flat-six producing 275 horsepower, while the Cayman S employed a 3.4-liter flat-six with 325 horsepower. The Cayman GTS, introduced in 2014, extracted 340 horsepower from the 3.4-liter powerplant. All were available with either a six-speed manual or seven-speed PDK dual-clutch transmission. The crowning achievement of the 981 generation was the Cayman GT4, which utilized a 3.8-liter engine derived from the 911 Carrera S producing 385 horsepower, paired exclusively with a six-speed manual transmission. The GT4 also featured aggressive aerodynamics and suspension components shared with the 911 GT3. The exterior design became more aggressive and sculptural, with larger side air intakes and a more distinctive stance, while the interior quality was significantly upgraded with a design influenced by the Panamera. The 981 Cayman was widely praised for its dynamic excellence, with many reviewers considering it among the best-handling cars available at any price. This generation represented the pinnacle of the naturally aspirated flat-six Cayman before the transition to turbocharged four-cylinder engines in the succeeding 718 generation.
Porsche-Cayman.name: Second Generation (981)

Porsche-Cayman.description: The third and current generation Cayman adopted the 718 nomenclature, paying homage to Porsche's successful four-cylinder racing cars from the 1950s and 1960s. This name change signaled the most significant powertrain shift in the model's history: replacing the naturally aspirated flat-six engines with turbocharged flat-four engines. The base 718 Cayman features a 2.0-liter turbocharged flat-four producing 300 horsepower, while the S model uses a 2.5-liter turbocharged flat-four with 350 horsepower. The GTS initially used an uprated version of the 2.5-liter engine with 365 horsepower before reverting to a naturally aspirated 4.0-liter flat-six with 394 horsepower in 2020. The track-focused GT4 also features a naturally aspirated 4.0-liter flat-six producing 414 horsepower. The GT4 RS, introduced in 2022, uses a modified version of the GT3's 4.0-liter flat-six, producing 493 horsepower. While the switch to four-cylinder engines improved torque, acceleration figures, and fuel efficiency, some enthusiasts criticized the change in engine character and sound. Visually, the 718 Cayman features more angular styling with revised front and rear designs, while the interior received updated technology including Porsche's latest infotainment system. Despite the controversial powertrain change, the 718 Cayman maintains the model's reputation for exceptional handling balance, precise steering, and driver engagement.
Porsche-Cayman.name: Third Generation (982/718)

Porsche-Macan.description: The first-generation Porsche Macan (95B) was introduced as a compact luxury crossover SUV positioned below the Cayenne in Porsche's lineup. Based on the Volkswagen Group MLB platform shared with the Audi Q5, the Macan was extensively modified by Porsche with unique powertrains, suspension tuning, and exterior design. Initially available in three variants—the base Macan with a turbocharged 2.0-liter inline-four, the Macan S with a twin-turbocharged 3.0-liter V6, and the Macan Turbo with a twin-turbocharged 3.6-liter V6—the range later expanded to include the GTS (a sportier version of the S) and Turbo with Performance Package. Power outputs ranged from 252 horsepower in the base model to 440 horsepower in the Turbo with Performance Package. All models featured a seven-speed PDK dual-clutch transmission and all-wheel drive. A significant facelift in 2019 updated the exterior styling with a full-width rear light bar and redesigned front fascia, while the interior received Porsche's latest infotainment system and revised dashboard design. The V6 engines were also updated to newer, more efficient units. The first-generation Macan was praised for its exceptional driving dynamics that belied its SUV classification, with handling and performance that rivaled many sports cars. It quickly became Porsche's best-selling model, appealing to buyers seeking a practical luxury vehicle with genuine sporting credentials. The first generation continues in production alongside the electric second-generation model.
Porsche-Macan.name: First Generation (95B)

Porsche-Macan.description: The second-generation Porsche Macan (XAB) represents a significant technological departure from its predecessor as Porsche's first all-electric compact SUV. Built on the Premium Platform Electric (PPE) architecture co-developed with Audi, the electric Macan features an 800-volt electrical system enabling extremely fast charging capabilities of up to 270 kW, allowing a 10-80% charge in under 25 minutes. Initially available in multiple variants—Macan Electric, Macan 4 Electric, Macan 4S Electric, and Macan Turbo Electric—all utilize dual electric motors providing all-wheel drive. The Macan 4 produces 402 horsepower and 479 lb-ft of torque, while the Turbo delivers 630 horsepower and 833 lb-ft. Both feature a 95 kWh usable battery pack delivering approximately 380 miles of range on the European WLTP cycle. Performance is impressive, with the Turbo capable of 0-60 mph in 3.3 seconds. The exterior design maintains recognizable Macan proportions while introducing new electric-specific elements including a more aerodynamic front end without traditional cooling grilles. The interior features a fully digital cockpit with three screens: a 12.6-inch curved instrument cluster, 10.9-inch central infotainment screen, and optional 10.9-inch passenger display. Driver assistance systems have been significantly upgraded, including remote parking capability and enhanced adaptive cruise control. Despite the transition to electric power, Porsche has maintained its focus on driving dynamics with standard adaptive air suspension, optional rear-axle steering, and Porsche Torque Vectoring Plus. The second-generation Macan is produced alongside the first-generation model at Porsche's Leipzig plant.
Porsche-Macan.name: Second Generation (XAB)

Porsche-Macan-Electric.description: The Porsche Macan Electric represents Porsche's second-generation Macan and the brand's first fully electric compact luxury SUV, launched in 2024 as a complete redesign built on the Premium Platform Electric (PPE) architecture co-developed with Audi. Production began in May 2024 at the Leipzig plant alongside the older internal combustion engine version. The electric Macan is offered in multiple variants: Macan Electric (single rear motor, RWD), Macan 4 Electric (dual motors, AWD), Macan 4S Electric, and Macan Turbo Electric. Performance ranges from 5.7 seconds for the base single-motor variant to 3.3 seconds for the Turbo Electric. The vehicle features a 95 kWh lithium-nickel-manganese-cobalt (Li-NMC) battery pack with 270 kW DC fast charging capability, allowing 10-80% charge in approximately 22 minutes. The interior showcases Porsche's latest digital cockpit with three screens: a curved 12.6-inch instrument cluster, a 10.9-inch central infotainment system, and an optional 10.9-inch screen for the front passenger. The Macan Electric shares its PPE platform with the Audi Q6 e-tron, maintaining Porsche's signature driving dynamics while offering zero-emission mobility with an estimated range of up to 381 miles (WLTP) depending on the variant.
Porsche-Macan-Electric.name: Second Generation (XAB)

Porsche-Panamera.description: The first-generation Porsche Panamera (970) marked Porsche's entry into the four-door luxury sports sedan segment. Designed as a grand tourer with 911-inspired styling cues adapted to a four-door format, the Panamera offered 2+2 seating in a hatchback body style. Initially available with naturally aspirated 4.8-liter V8 (Panamera S/4S) and twin-turbocharged 4.8-liter V8 (Panamera Turbo) engines, the range later expanded to include V6 models, diesel variants, and the hybrid Panamera S E-Hybrid. Power outputs ranged from 300 horsepower in the base V6 to 570 horsepower in the Turbo S. Most models featured a seven-speed PDK dual-clutch transmission, though some markets received manual and conventional automatic options. Despite controversial styling—particularly its bulbous rear end designed to accommodate rear passenger headroom—the Panamera was praised for combining sports car handling with luxury sedan comfort. The interior featured a distinctive center console design with a wide array of physical buttons and controls, premium materials, and advanced technology for its time. A facelift in 2013 refined the exterior design, particularly improving the rear-end styling, while adding the long-wheelbase Executive model for markets prioritizing rear-seat comfort. The first-generation Panamera successfully created a new segment for Porsche, appealing to buyers seeking Porsche driving dynamics without sacrificing practicality.
Porsche-Panamera.name: First Generation (970)

Porsche-Panamera.description: The second-generation Panamera (971) represented a comprehensive redesign addressing the styling criticisms of its predecessor while advancing the model's technology and performance. Revealed on 28 June 2016 in Berlin, Germany, it was built on the MSB platform shared with Bentley and featured more cohesive styling with a lower, longer profile and a more elegant fastback design. The interior was thoroughly modernized with the Porsche Advanced Cockpit concept, featuring touch-sensitive surfaces replacing many physical buttons, a 12.3-inch touchscreen, and dual 7-inch displays flanking an analog tachometer. Powertrains were completely revised, with a new range of engines including a 2.9-liter twin-turbocharged V6 in the 4S (440 horsepower), a 4.0-liter twin-turbocharged V8 in the Turbo/Turbo S (550-620 horsepower), and various plug-in hybrid combinations producing up to 680 horsepower in the Turbo S E-Hybrid. All engines were paired with an eight-speed PDK dual-clutch transmission. The model range expanded to include the Sport Turismo wagon variant, offering increased cargo capacity and a more distinctive design. The 971 Panamera introduced advanced chassis technologies including rear-wheel steering, electronic anti-roll bars, and three-chamber air suspension, further enhancing the sedan's ability to balance sports car handling with luxury comfort. A mid-cycle facelift in 2021 refined the design and introduced the optional Porsche Active Ride suspension. Performance capabilities reached new heights, with the Turbo S model capable of 0-60 mph in under 3 seconds while maintaining its grand touring character. The second-generation Panamera reinforced the model's position as one of the most dynamically capable luxury sedans on the market.
Porsche-Panamera.name: Second Generation (971)

Porsche-Panamera.description: The third-generation Porsche Panamera (976) was officially presented on 24 November 2023 for the 2024 model year, featuring evolutionary exterior styling changes concealing significant technical advancements. Built on an updated version of the MSB platform, the new Panamera retains similar proportions to its predecessor but features refined design elements including a new frontal air inlet above the license plate bracket and a redesigned rear light strip. The interior receives Porsche's latest digital interface with a curved 12.6-inch digital instrument cluster, 12.3-inch central touchscreen, and an optional front passenger display. Physical controls remain for key functions, balancing modern technology with usability. Powertrain options have been thoroughly updated, starting with a 2.9-liter turbocharged V6 producing 353 horsepower in the base model and a twin-turbocharged V6 with higher output in the 4S variant. The Turbo E-Hybrid and Turbo S E-Hybrid combine a 4.0-liter twin-turbocharged V8 with an electric motor for combined outputs of 680 and 782 horsepower respectively. All hybrid variants benefit from a 25.9 kWh (gross) or 21.8 kWh (net) battery that provides up to 90 kilometers of all-electric range under WLTP cycle. The chassis features Porsche's new Active Ride suspension system with electrohydraulic actuators for independent wheel control, which uses dual-valve dampers and active anti-roll bars to provide both exceptional ride comfort and sporting dynamics. This system can counteract body roll, dive, and squat, keeping the body virtually level during aggressive driving maneuvers. The shooting brake Sport Turismo body style was discontinued for the third generation. The third-generation Panamera aims to further refine the model's dual character as both a luxury grand tourer and a high-performance sports sedan, with particular emphasis on the electrified variants that will play an increasingly important role in Porsche's lineup during the transition toward electric mobility.
Porsche-Panamera.name: Third Generation (976)

Porsche-Taycan.description: The Porsche Taycan represents Porsche's first fully electric production vehicle, debuting in 2019 after being previewed by the Mission E concept. Built on a dedicated electric vehicle platform (J1), the Taycan features an 800-volt electrical architecture—double the voltage of most electric vehicles—enabling faster charging and better performance consistency. Initially launched in Turbo and Turbo S variants (despite having no actual turbochargers, maintaining Porsche's traditional nomenclature for performance hierarchy), the range later expanded to include the base Taycan with rear-wheel drive, Taycan 4S with less powerful dual motors, and the GTS offering a balance of performance and value. Power outputs range from 402 horsepower in the base model to 750 horsepower in the Turbo S, with the latter capable of 0-60 mph acceleration in as little as 2.6 seconds. All variants except the base model feature dual electric motors providing all-wheel drive with torque vectoring. The Taycan incorporates a two-speed transmission on the rear axle—unusual for EVs—to balance low-end acceleration with high-speed efficiency. Driving range varies by model and battery size (Performance Battery or larger Performance Battery Plus), typically delivering between 200-300 miles depending on configuration and testing methodology. The exterior design maintains recognizable Porsche design elements while introducing new electric-specific features like the horizontal light bar and aerodynamically optimized body. The interior features a distinctive curved digital instrument cluster and up to four additional screens. In 2021, two additional body styles joined the original sedan: the Cross Turismo, a more rugged wagon with increased ground clearance, and the Sport Turismo, a conventional wagon without the Cross Turismo's body cladding and off-road pretensions. The Taycan has been praised for its exceptional driving dynamics that successfully translate Porsche's sports car DNA to an electric platform, offering precise handling, communicative steering, and performance capabilities that rival or exceed its conventional counterparts.
Porsche-Taycan.name: First Generation (J1)

Porsche-Taycan.description: The 2024 model year brought a significant mid-cycle update to the Porsche Taycan, focusing on improved performance, efficiency, and technology while maintaining the original design ethos. While exterior changes were minimal—limited to revised headlights, new wheel designs, and updated color options—the technical updates were substantial. The powertrain received comprehensive upgrades including new pulse inverters with higher switching frequencies, improved thermal management, a more efficient heat pump, and revised battery charging algorithms. These changes resulted in significant performance improvements, with the Turbo S accelerating from 0-60 mph in just 2.3 seconds when equipped with the launch control feature of the Sport Chrono package. Efficiency also improved, with up to 35% more driving range on a single charge compared to previous models. All Taycan variants received larger battery packs, with the Performance Battery Plus now offering 105 kWh of gross capacity and faster 320 kW charging capability, allowing a 10-80% charge in approximately 18 minutes under ideal conditions. The suspension was retuned with new damper calibration and revised air spring rates, while the Porsche Active Ride suspension became optional on top-tier models, providing both improved comfort and dynamic capabilities. Inside, the Taycan adopted the latest PCM 6.0 infotainment system with a redesigned interface, improved voice control functionality, and better integration of charging planning into the navigation system. The updated Taycan lineup demonstrates Porsche's commitment to continuous improvement of its electric flagship, addressing initial criticisms regarding range while further enhancing the performance capabilities that distinguished the model from its inception.
Porsche-Taycan.name: First Generation Refresh

Ram-1500.description: The fourth-generation Ram 1500 was introduced at the 2008 North American International Auto Show in Detroit and launched as the 2009 Dodge Ram 1500 in Fall 2008. This generation marked a pivotal transition, with Ram separated from Dodge starting in 2010 for the 2011 model year. The fourth generation featured a distinctive coil-spring five-link rear suspension—the first traditional full-size pickup truck with rear coil springs since 1972—replacing leaf springs and significantly improving ride comfort and handling. Engine options included the 3.7L PowerTech V6, 4.7L PowerTech V8, and 5.7L HEMI V8. Notable features included the RamBox cargo management system, Uconnect infotainment with available navigation, and available air suspension. Various trim levels ranged from the work-oriented Tradesman to the luxury-focused Laramie Limited and off-road specialized Power Wagon. This generation was produced at Warren Truck Assembly in Michigan and Saltillo Truck Assembly in Mexico, and was sold as both the Dodge Ram (2009-2010) and Ram 1500 (2011-2012).
Ram-1500.name: Fourth Generation (DS) - Pre-Facelift

Ram-1500.description: The 2013 model year brought a significant refresh to the fourth-generation Ram 1500, featuring a new front fascia, optional projector-beam halogen headlamps with LED turn signals/parking lamps, and a completely restyled interior that replaced the 'DODGE' dashboard badge with 'RAM'. The engine lineup was updated with the introduction of Chrysler's 3.6L Pentastar V6 coupled to the new ZF 8-speed TorqueFlite automatic transmission, achieving best-in-class fuel efficiency. The 4.7L V8 replaced the 3.7L V6 as the base engine, while the 5.7L HEMI V8 gained 5 horsepower through a new electric power steering system. New infotainment options included the Uconnect 5.0BT and top-of-the-line Uconnect ACCESS 8.4A/8.4AN with 8.4-inch touchscreens, GPS navigation, and mobile app compatibility. Air suspension became available offering four ride height settings, and the Ram became the first North American pickup truck to offer keyless ignition. The High Fuel Efficiency (HFE) model was introduced for 2013, offering 18/25 MPG with the Pentastar V6 and eight-speed transmission on 2WD regular cab configurations. This generation continued production through 2018 before being replaced by the Ram 1500 Classic (2019-2024) and the all-new fifth-generation platform.
Ram-1500.name: Fourth Generation (DS) - Facelift

Ram-1500.description: The fifth-generation Ram 1500 (codenamed DT) debuted at the 2018 North American International Auto Show and began sales in early 2019 as a 2019 model year vehicle. This comprehensive redesign focused on weight reduction (approximately 225 pounds less than the previous generation), increased capability, and advanced technology. The frame utilizes 98% high-strength steel for improved rigidity and durability, with additional weight savings through aluminum components including the tailgate, engine mounts, and suspension parts. Engine options include the 3.6L Pentastar V6 with optional eTorque mild hybrid system, the 5.7L HEMI V8 with or without eTorque, and the 3.0L EcoDiesel V6. The interior features available 12-inch vertical touchscreen infotainment, active noise cancellation, premium audio systems, and luxury appointments rivaling premium sedans. The five-link rear coil suspension was further refined with available air suspension providing automatic load leveling and height adjustment. Advanced driver assistance features include adaptive cruise control, blind-spot monitoring, and 360-degree camera systems. The high-performance Ram TRX model, introduced for 2021, targets the off-road performance market with a supercharged 6.2L HEMI V8 producing 702 horsepower, Bilstein adaptive dampers, 35-inch tires, and 13 inches of wheel travel. The fifth-generation Ram 1500 has won Motor Trend Truck of the Year a record four consecutive times (2019, 2020, 2021, and 2025).
Ram-1500.name: Fifth Generation (DT) - Pre-Facelift

Ram-1500.description: For the 2025 model year, the Ram 1500 received a mid-cycle refresh introducing significant changes. The most notable was the discontinuation of the 5.7L HEMI V8 in favor of the new 3.0-liter Hurricane twin turbo inline-six engine, offering improved power and efficiency. The interior received updates with enhanced technology features and material upgrades. The Ram TRX continues as the high-performance off-road variant. Production continues at the Sterling Heights Assembly Plant in Michigan.
Ram-1500.name: Fifth Generation (DT) - Facelift
