Ram-2500.description: The fourth generation Ram 2500 Heavy Duty established the model as part of the standalone Ram brand after splitting from Dodge. Built on a stronger, fully boxed frame with hydroformed front frame rails, this generation offered significant capability improvements while focusing on comfort and refinement uncommon in the heavy-duty segment. Powertrain options included a 5.7L HEMI V8, 6.4L HEMI V8 (introduced in 2014), and the renowned 6.7L Cummins inline-six turbo diesel producing up to 800 lb-ft of torque in later years. Transmission options included six-speed automatics and six-speed manuals (for diesel models until 2018). Unlike the Ram 1500, the 2500 retained rear leaf springs, though with improved tuning for better ride quality. The interior shared much with the 1500, offering luxury features like heated and ventilated leather seats, premium audio systems, and the Uconnect infotainment system. Maximum towing capacity reached approximately 18,000 pounds for properly equipped models, while payload capacity approached 4,000 pounds. Available in regular cab, crew cab, and Mega Cab configurations with various bed lengths, the Ram 2500 offered configurations for work, family, and recreational use. The fourth generation received updates throughout its run, with notable refreshes in 2013 and 2016 introducing more modern styling, improved interiors, and enhanced capability.
Ram-2500.name: Fourth Generation

Ram-2500.description: The fifth generation Ram 2500 Heavy Duty debuted for the 2019 model year with a comprehensive redesign focusing on increased capability, improved technology, and enhanced comfort. Built on a redesigned frame utilizing 98.5% high-strength steel, the new generation offers significantly improved torsional rigidity and durability. Engine options include a standard 6.4L HEMI V8 producing 410 horsepower and 429 lb-ft of torque paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission, and the optional 6.7L Cummins turbo diesel inline-six generating up to 370 horsepower and a class-leading 850 lb-ft of torque (later increased to 370 hp and 1,000 lb-ft), mated to a six-speed automatic transmission. Maximum towing capacity exceeds 19,000 pounds with payload capacity approaching 4,500 pounds for properly equipped models. The interior represents a significant upgrade, mirroring many of the premium features from the Ram 1500 including the available 12-inch vertical touchscreen, active noise cancellation, and luxury appointments that rival many premium sedans. Available driver assistance features include adaptive cruise control, forward collision warning, and a 360-degree camera system with trailer reverse guidance. The suspension was completely reengineered with frequency response damping shocks and progressive rear springs to improve both ride comfort and load-handling capability. Available in regular cab, crew cab, and Mega Cab configurations with various bed lengths and trim levels ranging from work-oriented Tradesman to ultra-luxury Limited, the fifth-generation Ram 2500 has been widely praised for bringing unprecedented refinement and technology to the heavy-duty pickup segment while maintaining the capability expected for serious work applications.
Ram-2500.name: Fifth Generation

Ram-3500.description: The fourth generation Ram 3500 Heavy Duty represented the pinnacle of Ram's work-focused trucks after the brand's separation from Dodge. Built on a fully boxed frame with enhanced strength for maximum capability, this one-ton truck was designed for serious towing and hauling applications. Available in single rear wheel (SRW) or dual rear wheel (DRW) configurations, the Ram 3500 offered a standard 5.7L HEMI V8 engine, with a 6.4L HEMI V8 added in 2014. However, the powertrain most associated with the Ram 3500 was the 6.7L Cummins turbo diesel inline-six, which saw continuous improvement throughout this generation, eventually reaching 385 horsepower and 900 lb-ft of torque by 2018. When properly equipped, towing capacity exceeded 30,000 pounds, placing it among the most capable consumer trucks available. The Ram 3500 was available in regular cab, crew cab, and Mega Cab body styles with various bed lengths. Inside, the 3500 offered surprising refinement for a work truck, with top trim levels featuring premium leather, wood accents, heated and ventilated seats, and advanced infotainment systems. The available Auto-Level Rear Air Suspension was unique among heavy-duty pickups, allowing for automatic load-leveling when towing or hauling. The fourth generation received updates throughout its run, with significant refreshes in 2013 and 2016 bringing more modern styling, improved interiors, and enhanced capability.
Ram-3500.name: Fourth Generation

Ram-3500.description: The fifth generation Ram 3500 Heavy Duty launched for the 2019 model year with a comprehensive redesign focused on setting new benchmarks for capability, technology, and comfort in the one-ton truck segment. Built on a redesigned frame utilizing 98.5% high-strength steel, the new generation offers significantly improved rigidity and durability to handle extreme towing and hauling demands. Engine options include a standard 6.4L HEMI V8 producing 410 horsepower and 429 lb-ft of torque paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission. The optional 6.7L Cummins turbo diesel is available in two variants: a standard output version with 370 horsepower and 850 lb-ft of torque and a high-output version producing 400 horsepower and an industry-first 1,000 lb-ft of torque (later increased to 420 hp and 1,075 lb-ft), mated to a six-speed automatic transmission. This immense power enables properly equipped models to tow more than 35,000 pounds with fifth-wheel/gooseneck hitches, with conventional towing exceeding 20,000 pounds. Available in single or dual rear wheel configurations and in regular cab, crew cab, and Mega Cab body styles with various bed lengths, the Ram 3500 offers configurations suited for diverse heavy-duty applications. Despite its work-focused nature, the interior mirrors the premium appointments of the light-duty Ram 1500, featuring the available 12-inch vertical touchscreen, active noise cancellation, and luxury features previously unheard of in the heavy-duty segment. Advanced technology extends to towing assistance, with available features including a 360-degree camera system, trailer reverse guidance, and tire pressure monitoring for trailer tires. The suspension system features upgraded components including progressive springs and frequency response damping shocks to balance load capacity with improved ride quality. From the work-oriented Tradesman to the ultra-luxury Limited and off-road-capable Power Wagon trims, the fifth-generation Ram 3500 continues to set the standard for American heavy-duty pickups.
Ram-3500.name: Fifth Generation

Renault-Captur.description: The first generation Renault Captur J87 is a subcompact crossover SUV based on the fourth-generation Clio's B platform, debuted at the 2013 Geneva Motor Show and went on sale in April 2013. Designed under Laurens van den Acker, it features a distinctive two-tone color scheme with a floating roof design. Measuring approximately 4.12 meters in length, it offers compact dimensions for urban use with a practical interior including sliding rear seats. Engine options include petrol engines (0.9L TCe 90, 1.2L TCe 120, 1.3L TCe 150) and diesel options (1.5L dCi 90/110), paired with manual or EDC dual-clutch transmissions. A facelift was introduced in May 2017 with revised interior/exterior designs and improved equipment. The Captur achieved a five-star Euro NCAP rating in 2013 and won the What Car? 2014 'Best Small SUV Less Than £16,000' award.
Renault-Captur.name: First Generation (J87)

Renault-Captur.description: The second-generation Renault Captur debuted in July 2019 for the 2020 model year, built on the Renault-Nissan-Mitsubishi Alliance's new CMF-B platform (JB/JE) also used by Clio V and Nissan Juke. Growing to 4.23 meters in length with a longer wheelbase, it maintains the two-tone floating roof while adopting more pronounced SUV styling and C-shaped LED lighting. Interior upgrades include digital instrument clusters (7 or 10 inches) and a 9.3-inch portrait touchscreen with Renault's Easy Link infotainment. A sliding rear bench offers 16cm of adjustment. Powertrains include petrol engines (1.0L TCe 90-100hp, 1.3L TCe 130-155hp), diesel (1.5L Blue dCi 95-115hp), and a plug-in hybrid E-Tech delivering 160hp with up to 65km electric range. Safety features include adaptive cruise control, lane keeping assist, and 360-degree camera. A facelift was revealed in April 2024 with restyled front fascia, new taillights, and updated interior technology.
Renault-Captur.name: Second Generation (JB/JE)

Renault-Clio.description: The first generation Renault Clio, introduced as the successor to the Renault 5, was designed by Patrick Le Quément and marked a significant step forward in Renault's supermini offerings. Initially available as a three or five-door hatchback, the Clio featured a rounded, aerodynamic design that helped earn it the European Car of the Year award in 1991. Engine options included small gasoline units ranging from 1.1 to 1.8 liters and diesel variants, with power outputs between 55 and 137 horsepower in the sporty Clio Williams edition that was created to homologate variants for rally competition. The interior was relatively spacious for its class and featured more modern design elements than its predecessor. Throughout its production, this generation received several updates, including additional engine options, improved safety features, and minor styling revisions. The performance-oriented models, particularly the Clio Williams with its 2.0-liter 16-valve engine, helped establish Renault's reputation for producing engaging small performance cars. The first-generation Clio was instrumental in cementing Renault's position in the European supermini market with over 4 million units sold worldwide.
Renault-Clio.name: First Generation

Renault-Clio.description: The second generation Renault Clio built upon the success of its predecessor with a more mature design and improved quality. Again penned by Patrick Le Quément, the new Clio grew in size and took on a more substantial, rounded appearance with distinctive oval headlights. Available in three or five-door body styles, this generation also saw the introduction of the Clio Sport Tourer estate variant in some markets. Engine options expanded to include more efficient and powerful units, ranging from 1.0-liter to 2.0-liter gasoline engines and improved diesel options including the 1.5 dCi. The performance-oriented Clio RS (Renault Sport) featured a naturally aspirated 2.0-liter engine producing up to 182 horsepower in later versions. The interior quality improved significantly with better materials and modern features like satellite navigation becoming available on higher trim levels. Safety was enhanced with the inclusion of more airbags and improved structural design, earning the car a 4-star Euro NCAP safety rating—impressive for its time. A facelift in 2001 introduced the 'new face of Renault' with a revised front-end design featuring a prominent emblem and reshaped headlights. The second-generation Clio continued Renault's strong presence in the supermini segment, particularly in Europe, with approximately 4.5 million units sold globally.
Renault-Clio.name: Second Generation

Renault-Clio.description: The third generation Renault Clio, unveiled at the 2005 Frankfurt Motor Show, represented a significant shift upmarket for Renault's supermini. Built on the Renault–Nissan B platform co-developed with Nissan (which Renault has a stake in), this generation was considerably larger and heavier than its predecessor, nearly outgrowing the supermini class. The Clio III was voted European Car of the Year 2006, becoming the first car to win this award twice (also winning in 1991). Sales began throughout Europe in October 2005. The platform was shared with the Renault Modus, Nissan Micra, and Nissan Note. Engine options included a range of petrol (1.2L, 1.4L, 1.6L, 2.0L) and diesel (1.5 dCi) units. The high-performance Clio Renault Sport featured a naturally aspirated 2.0L engine producing approximately 197 horsepower with a 6-speed manual gearbox. An estate version called Sport Tourer was introduced in March 2007, built in Turkey by Oyak-Renault. A facelift in May 2009 introduced higher quality interior materials, more equipment, and a new expressive front fascia. Following the launch of the Clio IV in 2012, the Clio III remained on sale in France and Spain as the 'Clio Collection' until 2014, marking the complete cessation of production.
Renault-Clio.name: Third Generation

Renault-Clio.description: The fourth generation Renault Clio marked a significant design departure under the direction of Laurens van den Acker, featuring more emotional styling with pronounced curves, hidden rear door handles creating a coupe-like profile, and distinctive LED daytime running lights. Built on the new CMF-B platform, this Clio was offered exclusively as a five-door hatchback, though the hidden rear door handles maintained a sportier appearance. The dimensions were actually slightly smaller than its predecessor in length and height, but offered more interior space through improved packaging. Engine options included a range of small efficient gasoline engines (0.9 TCe and 1.2 TCe) and diesel variants (1.5 dCi) with power outputs ranging from 75 to 200 horsepower in the Clio RS. Transmission options included manual and dual-clutch automatics, with the RS model exclusively offering the latter. The interior saw a dramatic improvement in quality, design, and technology, featuring a tablet-like touchscreen infotainment system on higher trims with Renault's R-Link system. Safety features expanded to include electronic stability control as standard, multiple airbags, and available driver assistance features. The high-performance Clio RS 200 featured a 1.6-liter turbocharged engine, firmer suspension, and sportier styling elements but was controversial among enthusiasts for switching from a naturally aspirated engine and manual transmission to a turbocharged engine with only a dual-clutch automatic option. A facelift in 2016 introduced refined styling, updated interior technology, and improved engines. The fourth-generation Clio was a commercial success for Renault, consistently ranking among Europe's best-selling vehicles.
Renault-Clio.name: Fourth Generation

Renault-Clio.description: The fifth generation Renault Clio was unveiled at the 2019 Geneva Motor Show, representing the first model to use the CMF-B HS platform, shared with the second-generation Renault Captur and Nissan Juke among others. This generation features an interior that uses higher quality materials and finishes (for higher trim levels) than the previous one, sporty seats and a redesigned, more compact steering wheel. On higher trim levels it can be equipped with a 9.3-inch touchscreen (with Easy Link system, compatible with Android Auto and Apple CarPlay), a customizable instrument cluster that uses a TFT LCD, an electric parking brake, wireless smartphone charger, hands-free parking, a 360-degree camera system, and advanced driver assistance features including lane keeping assistant, adaptive cruise control, blind spot warning and automatic emergency braking. The CMF-B modular platform enables improved efficiency and offers the option of a hybrid powertrain for the first time. Available from 2020, the E-Tech hybrid drivetrain combines a new generation 1.6-liter petrol engine with two electric motors, a multi-mode gearbox and a 1.2 kWh battery. Engine options include petrol units (0.9 TCe, 1.0 SCe, 1.2 TCe) and the E-Tech hybrid system. A significant facelift debuted in April 2023, featuring a completely redesigned front bumper with slimmer headlights and a wider checkerboard grille. The R.S. Line trim level was replaced with the Esprit Alpine trim level. The Mitsubishi Colt was introduced in June 2023 as a rebadged version of the facelifted Clio, featuring a hybrid powertrain option.
Renault-Clio.name: Fifth Generation

Renault-Clio-III.description: The Renault Clio III represented a significant step up in size, quality, and refinement compared to its predecessors. Designed under Patrick Le Quément's direction, the third-generation Clio adopted a more mature and substantial appearance with a focus on improved perceived quality. Unveiled at the 2005 Frankfurt Motor Show, the Clio III was built on the Nissan B platform shared with the Nissan Micra and Renault Modus. Available in both three and five-door hatchback body styles, its dimensions increased significantly, pushing it toward the upper end of the supermini segment and approaching the size of some small family cars. Engine options included gasoline units ranging from 1.2 to 2.0 liters and diesel engines, primarily the efficient 1.5 dCi in various power outputs between 65 and 106 horsepower. The performance-oriented Clio Renault Sport featured a naturally aspirated 2.0-liter engine producing 197 horsepower, receiving widespread acclaim for its handling dynamics and performance. Interior quality was substantially improved with better materials and construction, while safety features were enhanced, earning the car a 5-star Euro NCAP safety rating—one of the first superminis to achieve this score. Sales began throughout Europe in October 2005, and it was voted European Car of the Year 2006, becoming the first car to win this award twice.
Renault-Clio-III.name: First Generation

Renault-Clio-III.description: A facelifted version of the Clio III went on sale in the United Kingdom on 15 May 2009, featuring higher quality interior materials, more equipment, and Patrick Le Quément's third and final interpretation of the Renault family face. This more expressive look signaled a move away from individual model styling, towards a unified, familial approach. New for 2009 was the Clio GT variant, a 'warm hatch' intended to slot between the regular Clio and the Clio 197 R.S., featuring a new aggressive front bumper, black grille, extended side sills, stiffer suspension, twin-tailpipe design, and sporty lip spoiler. The Renault Clio Gordini 200 limited edition was introduced in the UK in 2010, equipped with a 2.0L F4R engine. Following the launch of the Clio IV in 2012, the Clio III range was scaled back but remained on sale alongside its successor in France and Spain as the 'Clio Collection,' positioned as a value-centric alternative to the new Clio IV. Production of the Clio Collection lasted until 2014, marking the complete cessation of Clio III production.
Renault-Clio-III.name: First Generation (2009 Facelift)

Renault-Clio-V.description: The fifth-generation Renault Clio, unveiled at the 2019 Geneva Motor Show, represents an evolutionary approach to exterior design but a revolutionary leap in interior quality and technology. Built on the CMF-B HS platform shared with the second-generation Captur, the Clio V is actually slightly shorter and lower than its predecessor but offers more interior space through improved packaging. The exterior design, under the direction of Laurens van den Acker and Pierre Sabas (exterior), maintains the previous generation's sporty silhouette with hidden rear door handles but features more refined lines, C-shaped LED signature lighting, and a more assertive front grille. The most significant changes are found inside, where a completely redesigned dashboard features significantly improved materials and finishes, a digital instrument cluster (7 to 10 inches depending on trim), and a portrait-oriented touchscreen (up to 9.3 inches) housing Renault's new Easy Link infotainment system with enhanced connectivity features including Android Auto and Apple CarPlay. Engine options include small gasoline units such as the 0.9 TCe and 1.2 TCe in various power outputs (75-130hp), a 1.5 Blue dCi diesel (75-115hp), and notably, the introduction of Renault's E-Tech hybrid system combining a 1.6-liter gasoline engine with two electric motors for a combined output of 140 horsepower and the ability to drive on electric power alone for short distances. Transmission options include 5/6-speed manual, 7-speed Getrag EDC dual-clutch automatic, and E-TECH multi-mode automatic transmission. Safety and driver assistance technology saw a significant expansion with available features including adaptive cruise control, lane keeping assist, traffic sign recognition, blind spot warning, and automated emergency braking. The interior design was led by Magali Gouraud and features sporty seats and a redesigned steering wheel. Despite market shifts toward crossovers and SUVs, the fifth-generation Clio continues to be one of Europe's best-selling vehicles, appealing to buyers seeking a sophisticated small car with modern technology and efficient powertrains.
Renault-Clio-V.name: Fifth Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Renault-Clio-V.description: A significant facelift debuted on 18 April 2023, featuring a completely redesigned front bumper with slimmer headlights and a wider checkerboard grille. The R.S. Line trim level was replaced with the Esprit Alpine trim level, marking a shift in Renault's performance-oriented branding. The exterior updates include a more aggressive front fascia with the new grille design that echoes Renault's current design language. Inside, the facelifted Clio retains the high-quality materials and technology features of the original fifth-generation model while receiving incremental updates to keep it competitive in the supermini segment. The E-Tech hybrid system continues to be available, offering improved efficiency and the signature benefit of electric-only driving capability. The facelift helps maintain the Clio's position as one of Europe's top-selling vehicles, competing against newer rivals while leveraging Renault's established reputation for combining style, technology, and efficiency in the B-segment. In 2024, the Clio received an updated steering wheel with Renault's new logo, taken from the Symbioz model.
Renault-Clio-V.name: Fifth Generation (Facelift)

Renault-Duster.description: The first-generation Renault Duster (also marketed as Dacia Duster in many markets) was developed as an affordable compact SUV for global markets, built on the B0 platform shared with the Logan and Sandero. Designed with a focus on simplicity, ruggedness, and value, the Duster measured approximately 4.3 meters in length and featured a relatively high ground clearance of 210mm in four-wheel-drive variants. The exterior design emphasized utilitarian SUV elements with black plastic body cladding, roof rails, and skid plates. Powertrain options varied significantly by market but typically included 1.6-liter and 2.0-liter gasoline engines as well as Renault's 1.5-liter dCi diesel in various states of tune, with power outputs ranging from 85 to 150 horsepower. Available in both front-wheel-drive and four-wheel-drive configurations, the all-wheel-drive system featured three modes: 2WD, Auto (which distributed torque as needed), and Lock (which fixed torque distribution for challenging conditions). The interior was basic but functional, with durable materials and straightforward controls. Equipment levels were modest, though higher trims offered features like air conditioning, power windows, and basic infotainment systems. A facelift in 2013 introduced subtle styling updates, improved interior materials, and additional equipment options. Despite its simplicity, the first-generation Duster proved enormously successful globally, particularly in emerging markets and price-sensitive European regions, selling over two million units worldwide and establishing itself as one of the most accessible compact SUVs available.
Renault-Duster.name: First Generation

Renault-Duster.description: The second-generation Renault Duster (or Dacia Duster in many markets) debuted in late 2017 for the 2018 model year, maintaining the model's philosophy of affordable robustness while improving quality, design, and technology. While still based on the B0 platform, the architecture was significantly updated to improve refinement and safety. The exterior design represents an evolution of its predecessor with more modern styling elements including C-shaped LED signature lighting, a more muscular stance, and improved aerodynamics, while maintaining similar dimensions at approximately 4.3 meters in length. Ground clearance remains generous at 210mm for 4WD versions, with approach and departure angles suitable for legitimate off-road use. Engine options again vary by market but typically include a 1.0-liter TCe and 1.3-liter TCe gasoline engines (developed with Mercedes-Benz), the familiar 1.5-liter dCi diesel, and in some markets, bi-fuel petrol/LPG options. Power outputs range from 100 to 150 horsepower, with transmission choices including manual, automated manual (Easy-R), and dual-clutch automatic (EDC) depending on engine and market. The four-wheel-drive system was refined with a new 4x4 monitor that displays the vehicle's angle in real-time. Interior quality improved significantly with a redesigned dashboard featuring better materials, a higher-mounted infotainment screen (up to 8 inches), and more comfortable seating. New technology includes multi-view camera systems, blind-spot warning, automatic climate control, and keyless entry on higher trims. Safety was enhanced with reinforced structure, additional airbags, and electronic stability control as standard. A facelift in 2021 introduced updated lighting front and rear, new steering wheel design, and simplified grille pattern. Production ended in June 2024 due to GSR 2 safety regulations, with the third generation already underway.
Renault-Duster.name: Second Generation

Renault-Duster.description: The third-generation Renault Duster (marketed as Dacia Duster in Europe) debuted in November 2023 for the 2024 model year, representing a complete redesign built on the Renault-Nissan CMF-B LS platform, replacing the B0 platform used by previous generations. This new architecture brings significant improvements in safety, refinement, and technology while maintaining the Duster's core value proposition of affordable ruggedness. The exterior features a more boxy and rugged design with a distinctive Y-shaped light signature, increased use of recycled plastic materials including the unpainted Starkle composite for body panels, and improved approach and departure angles for off-road capability. The interior is completely redesigned with a new steering wheel, 10.1-inch central touchscreen infotainment system with wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, and for the first time a 7-inch digital instrument cluster. The cargo volume increased to 472 liters, 6% more than the previous generation. Powertrain options now include a mild-hybrid 1.2-liter turbocharged three-cylinder engine, a full hybrid 1.6-liter four-cylinder, and the return of the bi-fuel LPG option. For the first time, diesel engines are being phased out, available only in select markets like Morocco, Moldova, and Ukraine. The all-wheel-drive system now features five driving modes (Auto, Snow, Mud/Sand, Off-Road, and Eco). Advanced safety features include automatic emergency braking with pedestrian and cyclist detection, traffic sign recognition with overspeed alert, lane keep warning, and drowsiness monitoring to comply with GSR 2 regulations. The third-generation Duster is marketed as Renault in India, Ukraine, South America, Australia, New Zealand, Turkey, and Egypt, while retaining the Dacia name in Europe.
Renault-Duster.name: Third Generation

Renault-Kadjar.description: The Renault Kadjar was introduced in 2015 as Renault's entry into the popular compact crossover segment, positioned above the smaller Captur and sharing its platform with the successful Nissan Qashqai through the Renault-Nissan Alliance. Designed under the direction of Laurens van den Acker, the Kadjar featured flowing, organic styling consistent with Renault's contemporary design language, with prominent LED daytime running lights and a bold front grille carrying the large Renault diamond emblem. Measuring 4.45 meters in length, the Kadjar offered generous interior space with a flexible cabin featuring sliding and folding rear seats and a cargo capacity of 472 to 1,478 liters. Engine options included 1.2-liter and 1.6-liter TCe gasoline units and 1.5-liter and 1.6-liter dCi diesel engines, with power outputs ranging from 110 to 165 horsepower. Transmission options included 6-speed manual and 7-speed dual-clutch automatic (EDC), with both front-wheel drive and all-wheel drive configurations available depending on the engine. The interior featured Renault's R-Link 2 infotainment system with a 7-inch touchscreen, navigation, smartphone connectivity, and various driver assistance systems such as lane departure warning, traffic sign recognition, and automatic emergency braking on higher trim levels. A facelift in 2018 introduced revised styling with C-shaped LED lighting signatures, updated dashboard design with improved ergonomics, and new, more efficient engines including 1.3-liter TCe gasoline units co-developed with Mercedes-Benz. The Kadjar provided a comfortable, practical alternative in the crowded compact crossover segment, with particular strengths in ride comfort, interior space, and efficient diesel engines, though it faced increasingly strong competition throughout its lifecycle from both established competitors and newer entrants to the segment.
Renault-Kadjar.name: First Generation

Renault-Kadjar.description: The Renault Kadjar's second generation was effectively renamed and reborn as the Renault Austral in 2022, representing a comprehensive redesign and repositioning of Renault's compact crossover offering. Built on the CMF-CD platform shared with the Nissan Qashqai, the Austral features more angular, assertive styling aligned with Renault's new design direction under Gilles Vidal, including the reinterpreted 'nouvel'R' logo, distinctive LED lighting with the brand's new light signature, and a more upright, SUV-like stance. Measuring 4.51 meters in length, the Austral maintains similar exterior dimensions to the Kadjar but offers improved interior space and flexibility. The powertrain lineup marks a significant shift toward electrification, centered around E-Tech full hybrid technology combining a 1.2-liter turbocharged three-cylinder engine with electric motors for a combined output of 200 horsepower, as well as mild-hybrid options based on the 1.3-liter TCe engine with outputs ranging from 140 to 160 horsepower. Notably, diesel engines are absent from the range, reflecting the market shift away from this fuel type. The interior represents a dramatic technological advancement featuring Renault's new OpenR digital environment with a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster and 12-inch portrait-oriented touchscreen powered by Google Automotive Services, offering integrated Google Maps, Assistant, and Play Store access. The Austral introduces Renault's multi-sense driving modes and 4CONTROL Advanced four-wheel steering system on higher trims, enhancing both maneuverability and high-speed stability. Safety and driver assistance technology expanded substantially with up to 32 driving aids including adaptive cruise control with stop-and-go functionality, lane centering, and automated parking. Though the Kadjar name was discontinued, the Austral effectively serves as its second generation, representing a significant step forward in design, technology, and electrification while maintaining the practical, family-friendly approach of its predecessor.
Renault-Kadjar.name: Second Generation (Renamed as Austral)

Renault-Koleos.description: The first-generation Renault Koleos represented Renault's initial entry into the compact SUV segment, developed in collaboration with Nissan and manufactured by Renault Samsung Motors in South Korea. Built on the Nissan C platform shared with the Nissan X-Trail, the Koleos featured a conventional SUV silhouette with Renault's corporate styling of the period. Measuring 4.52 meters in length, it offered five seats and cargo space up to 1,380 liters with rear seats folded. Engine options included a 2.0-liter gasoline engine (140 hp) and 2.0-liter dCi diesel (150-175 hp), available with six-speed manual or CVT transmissions and front-wheel or all-wheel drive. The all-wheel drive system featured 2WD, Auto, and Lock modes. A facelift in July 2011 brought revised front styling, interior enhancements, and equipment upgrades. Production ended in March 2015, with the model withdrawn from the UK in 2010 due to poor sales.
Renault-Koleos.name: First Generation

Renault-Koleos.description: The second-generation Renault Koleos, introduced at the 2016 Beijing Motor Show, marked a significant step up in size and quality, growing to 4.67 meters in length on the Renault-Nissan CMF-CD platform shared with the Nissan X-Trail and Renault Kadjar. Designed by Alexis Martot under Laurens van den Acker, it adopted Renault's design language with C-shaped LED lighting. Engine options included a 2.0-liter dCi diesel (130-175 hp), 2.5-liter gasoline (170 hp), and 1.6 dCi diesel, paired with six-speed manual or X-Tronic CVT transmissions. The interior featured a 7-inch touchscreen standard and optional 8.7-inch R-Link 2 system, with available features including heated leather seats, Bose audio, and panoramic sunroof. Safety features expanded to include adaptive cruise control, blind-spot monitoring, emergency braking, and around-view camera. A 2019/2020 facelift brought styling updates and improved technology. Production continued in Korea until April 2023, while other markets ended earlier.
Renault-Koleos.name: Second Generation

Renault-Koleos.description: The third-generation Renault Koleos, marketed as the Renault Grand Koleos, was introduced on June 27, 2024 at the Busan International Mobility Show. Built on Geely's Compact Modular Architecture platform (same as Geely Xingyue L/Monjaro) through the Renault-Geely partnership in South Korea, it represents a significant size increase over its predecessor. The design features redesigned front and rear fascias, a borderless grille, and body panels unique to Renault. The interior shares the Geely platform's dashboard with a 12.3-inch digital instrument display, 12.3-inch infotainment screen, and another 12.3-inch passenger touchscreen, all powered by Qualcomm hardware and marketed as openR. Powertrains include a 2.0-liter turbocharged engine with 7-speed dual-clutch or 8-speed automatic transmission, and an E-Tech Hybrid system combining a 1.5-liter turbo engine with a 1.64 kWh battery. Production began July 2024 at Renault Korea's Busan plant, with plans to expand to Middle East, Mexico, Colombia, and other markets.
Renault-Koleos.name: Third Generation

Renault-Kwid.description: The Renault Kwid is a subcompact crossover-styled hatchback primarily developed for emerging markets, first launched in India in 2015. Built on the CMF-A platform (Common Module Family - Affordable), the Kwid was designed to offer SUV-inspired styling in an ultra-affordable package. The car measures just under 3.7 meters in length but features relatively high ground clearance (180mm), plastic body cladding, and roof rails to create a crossover aesthetic that distinguishes it from traditional budget hatchbacks. Initially offered with a 0.8-liter three-cylinder engine producing 54 horsepower, the range later expanded to include a more powerful 1.0-liter option with 68 horsepower. Transmission options include a standard 5-speed manual and an automated manual transmission (Easy-R) introduced in 2016. The interior is surprisingly spacious for its segment and features a distinctive digital instrument cluster and, on higher trims, a 7-inch touchscreen infotainment system—unusual features for the ultra-budget segment when introduced. A significant facelift in 2019 brought revised styling with LED daytime running lights, reshaped bumpers, and interior refinements. Safety features were also enhanced to meet stricter regulations with the addition of driver airbag, ABS, and seatbelt reminders as standard across the range. The Kwid has been particularly successful in India, Brazil, and other emerging markets where its combination of affordable pricing, crossover styling, and reasonable equipment levels made it an attractive entry-level option. While not marketed in most European markets, the Kwid has been adapted for Europe as the Dacia Spring Electric, featuring the same basic design but with an electric powertrain and additional safety equipment to meet European standards.
Renault-Kwid.name: First Generation

Renault-Megane.description: The first-generation Renault Megane replaced the Renault 19 as the company's entry in the compact car segment. Designed by Patrick Le Quément, it introduced a distinctive design language that would influence Renault's lineup through the late 1990s. Initially available as a three-door and five-door hatchback, the range later expanded to include a four-door sedan (Classic), a coupe, a convertible, and an estate (Grandtour) variant. Engine options ranged from 1.4-liter to 2.0-liter gasoline units and several diesel options, primarily the 1.9 dTi and 1.9 dCi. The performance-oriented 2.0 16v version offered 150 horsepower, while the limited Megane Maxi kit car homologation version produced 280 horsepower. The interior was conventional for its era with a focus on practicality rather than style. The Megane achieved a 4-star Euro NCAP safety rating in 1997—impressive for its time—and was the first car in its class to offer curtain airbags. A facelift in 1999 updated the styling with revised headlights, bumpers, and interior details. This generation established the Megane as a key competitor in the European compact car market, combining practicality with a distinctive design.
Renault-Megane.name: First Generation

Renault-Megane.description: The second-generation Renault Megane marked a bold styling departure with its distinctive rear end featuring a prominent window and tailgate design often referred to as the 'bustle-back.' Designed under Patrick Le Quément, this generation continued Renault's design renaissance with unique styling that polarized opinion but certainly stood out in the crowded compact segment. Available in three-door (Sport Hatch) and five-door hatchback, sedan (in some markets), coupe-cabriolet (featuring a folding metal roof), and estate (Grandtour) body styles. Engine options expanded to include gasoline units from 1.4 to 2.0 liters, including the 2.0-liter turbocharged engine in the Renault Sport versions producing up to 225 horsepower in the R26.R special edition. Diesel options were a major focus, with the 1.5 dCi and 1.9 dCi engines gaining popularity for their efficiency. The interior featured improved quality with a more driver-focused design, digital speedometer displayed in the center of the dashboard, and keyless entry and start on higher trim levels—innovative for its segment at the time. Safety was a priority with the car achieving a 5-star Euro NCAP rating. The Renault Sport variants, particularly the R26.R which featured extensive weight reduction measures including polycarbonate windows and eliminated rear seats, earned acclaim for their handling and performance, cementing Renault's reputation for producing excellent hot hatchbacks.
Renault-Megane.name: Second Generation

Renault-Megane.description: The third-generation Renault Megane adopted a more conventional but elegant design compared to its distinctive predecessor, focusing on perceived quality and refinement. Designed under Patrick Le Quément, this Megane featured more flowing lines and a premium appearance. Available as a five-door hatchback, three-door coupe, estate (Sport Tourer), and a coupe-cabriolet with a folding metal roof. Engine options included gasoline units from 1.2 TCe to 2.0-liter, and diesel engines from the efficient 1.5 dCi to the more powerful 1.6 dCi and 2.0 dCi. The Renault Sport versions featured a 2.0-liter turbocharged engine producing 250 horsepower initially, later increased to 265 hp and ultimately 275 hp in the Trophy-R variant, which set a front-wheel-drive Nürburgring lap record in 2014. The interior quality saw significant improvement with soft-touch materials, ambient lighting, and a more cohesive design. Technology features expanded to include a hands-free card key system, TomTom-based navigation, and the introduction of Renault's R-Link infotainment system in later models. A significant facelift in 2012 updated the front end with Renault's new design identity featuring a prominent diamond logo and sleeker headlights. The third-generation Megane further developed Renault's position in the competitive compact segment, with particular strengths in ride comfort, fuel efficiency with the diesel engines, and exceptional handling in the Renault Sport variants.
Renault-Megane.name: Third Generation

Renault-Megane.description: The fourth-generation Renault Megane, designed under Laurens van den Acker, featured a more distinctive and dynamic design with pronounced shoulders, C-shaped LED daytime running lights, and connected rear lights creating a horizontal signature. Built on the Common Module Family (CMF-C/D) platform shared with the Nissan Pulsar and Renault Kadjar, the Megane grew slightly in size while adopting a wider, lower stance for a more athletic appearance. Available as a five-door hatchback and estate (Sport Tourer), though coupe and convertible variants were discontinued. Engine options included the 1.2 TCe and 1.6 TCe gasoline engines, a hybrid option added later, and the 1.5 dCi and 1.6 dCi diesel engines, with power outputs ranging from 110 to 205 horsepower in standard models. The performance GT variant featured 4Control four-wheel steering—unique in the segment. The Renault Sport model came exclusively with a 1.8-liter turbocharged engine producing 280 horsepower, available with either a 6-speed manual or dual-clutch automatic transmission. The interior represents a significant technological leap with the portrait-oriented 8.7-inch R-Link 2 touchscreen infotainment system on higher trims, customizable ambient lighting, and a digital instrument cluster. A comprehensive suite of driver assistance systems was available including adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, and automated parking. The fourth-generation Megane faced increasing competition from both traditional rivals and the growing SUV segment, leading Renault to focus more on the crossover variants in many markets while transitioning the Megane nameplate toward electrification.
Renault-Megane.name: Fourth Generation

Renault-Megane.description: The fifth-generation Renault Megane represents a fundamental reinvention of the nameplate, transitioning it fully into the electric era with the Megane E-Tech Electric. Designed under Laurens van den Acker, this generation abandons internal combustion entirely and adopts a compact crossover-hatchback form factor, blending traditional hatch proportions with SUV-inspired cues such as a higher beltline and larger wheels. Built on the dedicated CMF-EV platform developed by the Renault–Nissan–Mitsubishi Alliance, the Megane E-Tech features a flat battery pack integrated into the floor, enabling a long wheelbase, short overhangs, and a low center of gravity. Powertrain options include a single front-mounted electric motor producing either 130 or 220 horsepower, paired with battery capacities of 40 kWh or 60 kWh, delivering WLTP ranges of up to approximately 470 km (292 miles). The interior marks a major technological leap, highlighted by the OpenR cockpit—a dual-screen layout combining a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster with a vertical 12-inch infotainment display running Android Automotive OS with native Google services. Material quality and sustainability are emphasized through recycled fabrics and minimalist design. Advanced driver assistance systems are standard or optional depending on trim, including adaptive cruise control, lane centering, and hands-free highway driving capabilities. With this generation, Renault repositions the Megane as a technology-forward, electric-focused model aimed at competing with vehicles such as the Volkswagen ID.3 and Cupra Born, signaling the brand’s broader shift away from traditional compact hatchbacks toward electrified mobility solutions.
Renault-Megane.name: Fifth Generation

Renault-Megane-E-Tech.description: The Renault Megane E-Tech Electric represents Renault's first purpose-built electric vehicle based on the Alliance CMF-EV platform dedicated to electric vehicles, marking a significant evolution of the Megane nameplate into the EV era. Despite carrying the Megane name, the E-Tech Electric features a completely distinct crossover-inspired design with a higher stance than traditional Megane models but a relatively low height (1.50m) for an electric crossover, prioritizing aerodynamic efficiency. The exterior design, developed under Gilles Vidal, features distinctive full-LED lighting including Renault's new light signature, flush door handles that deploy automatically, and a contrasting roof. Available with two battery options—a 40 kWh pack providing approximately 186 miles of range and a 60 kWh pack offering up to 292 miles (WLTP)—paired with electric motors producing either 130 or 218 horsepower, with the more powerful version delivering 0-62 mph acceleration in 7.4 seconds. The interior represents Renault's most advanced cabin design to date, centered around the new OpenR display combining a 12.3-inch digital instrument panel and 12-inch portrait-oriented touchscreen powered by Google's Android Automotive OS with built-in Google services. This system incorporates over 40 apps and can receive over-the-air updates. The cabin emphasizes sustainability with extensive use of recycled materials, while clever packaging of the battery (just 11cm thick) enables a spacious interior despite compact exterior dimensions. Advanced driver assistance systems include level 2 autonomous driving capability, automatic emergency braking, rear cross-traffic alert, and a 3D surround-view camera. Charging capabilities include up to 130 kW DC fast charging, allowing for up to 186 miles of range to be added in 30 minutes. The Megane E-Tech Electric represents Renault's significant investment in electrification as part of its 'Renaulution' strategy, offering a modern, technology-focused alternative to both traditional compact cars and larger electric SUVs.
Renault-Megane-E-Tech.name: First Generation

Renault-Symbol.description: The first-generation Renault Symbol (also known as the Renault Clio Symbol, Renault Thalia, or Renault Clio Sedan in different markets) was essentially a sedan version of the second-generation Renault Clio. Developed primarily for markets where sedans were preferred over hatchbacks, particularly Eastern Europe, Turkey, Latin America, and North Africa, the Symbol featured a conventional three-box design extending the Clio's platform and styling. Measuring around 4.15 meters in length, it offered a spacious 510-liter trunk—a significant advantage over the hatchback version. Engine options typically included small gasoline units ranging from 1.0 to 1.6 liters and the 1.5 dCi diesel, with power outputs between 60 and 107 horsepower. Transmission options were primarily 5-speed manual with some markets receiving a 4-speed automatic option. The interior was largely identical to the Clio hatchback, offering straightforward controls and reasonable equipment levels for its price point. A facelift in 2002 aligned the front-end styling more closely with the updated Clio, while maintaining the distinctive rear section. The first-generation Symbol established itself as a value-focused sedan offering reliable transportation and generous cargo space at an accessible price point, becoming particularly popular in markets where sedan body styles were traditionally preferred and where low purchase and operating costs were primary considerations.
Renault-Symbol.name: First Generation

Renault-Symbol.description: The second-generation Renault Symbol, launched in 2008, was based on the Renault-Nissan B platform shared with the third-generation Renault Clio but featured more distinctive styling that differentiated it more clearly from its hatchback sibling. Designed specifically for emerging markets where sedans remained popular, the second-generation Symbol offered improved quality, safety, and equipment levels while maintaining its value positioning. Measuring approximately 4.26 meters in length, it provided a slightly larger cabin and a generous 506-liter trunk capacity. Engine options included 1.2-liter and 1.6-liter gasoline units and the 1.5 dCi diesel, with power outputs ranging from 75 to 105 horsepower. Transmission options included 5-speed manual and 4-speed automatic depending on the engine and market. The interior featured a more modern design with improved materials and available equipment including air conditioning, power windows, and basic audio systems, with higher trims offering features like fog lights, alloy wheels, and more comprehensive infotainment options. Safety features included dual front airbags and ABS braking, though these sometimes varied by market. The second-generation Symbol continued to appeal to budget-conscious buyers seeking the practicality of a sedan with low running costs, particularly in regions like Eastern Europe, Russia, North Africa, and Latin America.
Renault-Symbol.name: Second Generation

Renault-Symbol.description: The third-generation Renault Symbol (still marketed as Thalia in some regions) was based on the second-generation Dacia Logan but adopted Renault's then-current design language with the prominent diamond logo and more flowing lines compared to the utilitarian Logan. This generation continued the model's focus on providing affordable, practical transportation in a three-box sedan format for markets where such vehicles remained popular. Measuring approximately 4.35 meters in length, the third-generation Symbol offered increased interior space and a capacious 510-liter trunk. Engine options varied by market but typically included 1.2-liter and 1.6-liter gasoline engines and the 1.5 dCi diesel, with power outputs ranging from 75 to 105 horsepower. Transmission options included 5-speed manual and 4-speed automatic depending on the engine. The interior represented a significant step forward in design and perceived quality compared to its predecessors, with a more contemporary dashboard layout and improved materials. Available equipment expanded to include features like the Media Nav infotainment system with a 7-inch touchscreen, cruise control, rear parking sensors, and automatic climate control on higher trim levels. Safety features were enhanced with up to four airbags, electronic stability control, and emergency brake assist, though specific features varied by market. A facelift in 2016 introduced Renault's updated design language with C-shaped LED daytime running lights and minor interior refinements. The third-generation Symbol continues to serve as an important value-focused sedan in Renault's global portfolio, particularly in markets like Turkey, North Africa, and parts of Latin America and Eastern Europe where it competes in the budget sedan segment.
Renault-Symbol.name: Third Generation

Renault-ZOE.description:
The Renault Zoe (stylized ZOE), known as Renault Zoe E-Tech Electric since 2021, is a five-door supermini electric car produced by the French manufacturer Renault from 2012 to 2024. The Zoe was based on the platform of the Renault Clio and represented one of the first mass-market electric vehicles from a mainstream European manufacturer. Retail customer deliveries began in France in December 2012, followed by other European countries in 2013. The Zoe became Europe's best-selling electric vehicle for multiple years and ranks as one of the all-time best-selling plug-in electric cars in Europe. Production ended on March 30, 2024 after nearly twelve years, with a total of 426,706 units manufactured. The Zoe was replaced by the retro-styled Renault 5 E-Tech.

The Zoe underwent several significant updates during its production run:

**Initial Production (2012-June 2015)**: Powered by a 22 kWh lithium-ion battery providing an NEDC range of 130-150 miles, driven by a synchronous electric motor (Q90/R90) producing approximately 88 horsepower. Featured the innovative 'Chameleon' charger allowing AC charging at any level up to 43 kW.

**ZE 40 Update (October 2016-September 2019)**: Introduced a new 41 kWh lithium-ion battery developed with LG Chem, increasing the NEDC range to approximately 250 miles. The battery weighed 305 kg and was mounted on Zoes using the R75/90 motor. Older Zoes could also be upgraded to this battery.

**ZE 50 Facelift (June 2019-2024)**: A comprehensive update featuring a new 52 kWh battery (55 kWh total capacity) providing up to 245 miles of WLTP range. Paired with more powerful electric motors: the R110 producing 107 horsepower or the R135 with 134 horsepower. For the first time, DC fast charging capability via CCS2 was introduced (up to 50 kW). The exterior received updated styling with LED headlights, while the interior was overhauled with improved materials and Renault's Easy Link infotainment system. Advanced driver assistance systems were also added including lane-keeping assist and automatic emergency braking.

The Zoe was produced at Renault's Flins plant in France alongside the Clio and Nissan Micra. It was available with various battery ownership models including full purchase or battery leasing options depending on the market.
Renault-ZOE.name: First Generation

Rivian-R1S.description: The Rivian R1S is an all-electric, seven-passenger, full-size off-road SUV manufactured by Rivian. Built on the same skateboard platform as the R1T pickup truck (sharing 91% of components), the R1S debuted as a prototype at the Los Angeles Auto Show in November 2018 and entered production in 2021, with customer deliveries beginning in late August 2022 after 10 years of development. The R1S features a distinctive design with a full-width horizontal light bar at the front, vertical oval headlights, and clean minimalist body panels. It measures 200.8 inches in length with a 121.1-inch wheelbase and offers a turning circle nearly 4 feet smaller than the R1T due to its shorter wheelbase and rear overhang. Initially launched with a quad-motor powertrain (one motor per wheel) developed by Bosch, delivering 835 horsepower and 908 lb-ft of torque, enabling 0-60 mph acceleration in approximately 3 seconds. The lineup expanded to include dual-motor variants starting in 2024 using Rivian's in-house 'Enduro' motors, with a Performance Dual-Motor option added in April 2023 that raises output through software modification. Battery options include a 105 kWh Standard pack (LFP chemistry, delayed until 2024), 135 kWh Large pack, and a 149 kWh Max pack (delayed until 2023). EPA-rated range is up to 410 miles with the Max pack and quad-motor configuration. The adaptive air suspension provides up to 14.9 inches of ground clearance with a maximum wading depth of 3 feet, and includes a Camp Mode for leveling on irregular terrain. Interior features include a 16-inch central touchscreen, 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, panoramic glass roof (without sunshade), sustainable vegan leather seats, and a gear tunnel behind the rear seats with an integrated air compressor. Trim levels include the Adventure package with heated/cooled perforated vegan leather seats and a Meridian Audio sound system, while the base Explore package was discontinued in August 2022 citing low demand. The R1S achieved IIHS TOP SAFETY PICK+ status for the 2023 model year.
Rivian-R1S.name: First Generation

Rivian-R1T.description: The first generation Rivian R1T launched in 2022 as the first mass-produced electric pickup truck to reach the market. Built on Rivian's skateboard platform, it featured a domain-based architecture with 17 ECUs. The Gen 1 model was initially offered exclusively with a quad-motor powertrain delivering approximately 835 horsepower and 908 lb-ft of torque, providing precise torque vectoring control with one motor per wheel. The quad-motor version could accelerate from 0-60 mph in approximately 3 seconds. Battery options included 105 kWh (Standard), 135 kWh (Large), and 180 kWh (Max) packs. The adaptive air suspension provided up to 14.9 inches of ground clearance and could ford water up to 3.3 feet deep. Unique features included the 'gear tunnel' pass-through storage space and a premium interior with sustainable materials, panoramic glass roof, and a 16-inch central touchscreen. Towing capacity was up to 11,000 pounds.
Rivian-R1T.name: First Generation (Gen 1)

Rivian-R1T.description: The second generation R1T introduced in 2024 features a new zonal wiring architecture that reduces total wiring length by 1.6 miles and weight significantly, cutting material costs by 20% and carbon footprint by 15%. The new architecture uses only four main ECUs (infotainment, autonomy, vehicle access, drive units, and battery management) plus three additional ECUs for remaining functions, compared to 17 ECUs in Gen 1. The dual-motor powertrain became more prevalent, with the Performance Dual-Motor option offering approximately 665 horsepower and 829 lb-ft of torque. Battery options were updated to 105 kWh (Standard), 135 kWh (Large), and 149 kWh (Max). The Gen 2 model continued to offer the gear tunnel, premium interior with sustainable materials, and advanced Driver+ assistance system. The 2024 model year R1T was awarded 'Top Safety Pick+' by IIHS.
Rivian-R1T.name: Second Generation (Gen 2)

Saab-9-3.description: The first-generation Saab 9-3, internally designated as the 9-3 Type 1 (body style 9400), was launched in 1998 for the 1999 model year as a significant development of the Saab 900 (New Generation) introduced in 1994. Built on the GM2900 platform, it received over 1,100 improvements including enhanced safety features, chassis refinements, and interior upgrades. Available as a three or five-door hatchback and a two-door convertible, the 9-3 featured distinctive Saab styling elements like the hockey stick-shaped C-pillar, aircraft-inspired dashboard, and center console-mounted ignition switch. Engine options included naturally aspirated and turbocharged versions of Saab's 2.0-liter and 2.3-liter four-cylinder engines, with power outputs ranging from 130 to 225 horsepower in the Viggen performance model. The high-performance Viggen (named after the Saab 37 Viggen fighter jet) featured unique styling elements, sport suspension, and a 225 horsepower turbocharged engine. Production ended on 8 May 2002 at the Trollhättan plant, with Valmet continuing production until 25 April 2003. A total of 326,370 first-generation 9-3s were built.
Saab-9-3.name: First Generation (9-3 Type 1)

Saab-9-3.description: The second-generation Saab 9-3, internally designated as the 9-3 Type 2, represented a significant departure from Saab tradition by abandoning the hatchback body style in favor of a conventional sedan when it launched in July 2002 for the 2003 model year. Built on GM's Epsilon platform shared with vehicles like the Opel Vectra and Chevrolet Malibu, the new 9-3 featured a more mainstream design while retaining distinctive Saab elements such as the wraparound windshield effect, aircraft-inspired cockpit, and center console-mounted ignition. The model range initially included a four-door sedan and two-door convertible, with a five-door SportCombi wagon added in 2005. Power came primarily from turbocharged four-cylinder engines ranging from 1.8 to 2.8 liters, with outputs from 150 to 280 horsepower in the Turbo X performance model. Despite General Motors' financial troubles and eventual sale of Saab to Spyker Cars in 2010, the 9-3 continued in production until Saab's bankruptcy in 2011. Very limited production resumed under NEVS (National Electric Vehicle Sweden) ownership from December 2013 to May 2014, with the MY14 model featuring updated styling and a 2.0-liter turbocharged engine.
Saab-9-3.name: Second Generation (9-3 Type 2)

Saab-9-3.description: The 2008 model year marked a significant facelift for the second-generation Saab 9-3, with over 2,000 changes introduced. The new frontal styling was inspired by the Saab Aero-X concept car, featuring the first use of LED 'signature' lighting in revised headlamps, a new clamshell bonnet, and clear tail lamps dubbed 'ice block'. Other changes included new door panels, a new rear bumper, and black replacing charcoal gray as an interior color choice. The 2.8T V6 received a mild power boost. The Turbo X performance model was introduced at the 2007 Frankfurt Motor Show, featuring Saab's first production XWD all-wheel drive system, an electronic limited-slip differential, and unique styling in metallic jet black with matte grey trim. A new twin-turbo diesel engine (1.9 TTiD) with 180 PS was also introduced. For the 2012 model year, the car was badged 'Griffin' in most markets with further revisions including improved fuel efficiency, rear badging changes, and new interior trim options. This facelift version continued in production until final NEVS production ended in May 2014.
Saab-9-3.name: Second Generation Facelift (2008)

Saab-9-5.description: The first-generation Saab 9-5 replaced the long-running Saab 9000 as the company's flagship model. Developed while Saab was partially owned by General Motors, the 9-5 was built on the GM2900 platform but extensively modified and engineered to meet Saab's standards for safety and driving dynamics. Initially available as a four-door sedan, with an estate (wagon) variant called the SportWagon added in 1999, the 9-5 featured distinctive Saab styling elements including a sweeping aircraft-inspired dashboard, center console-mounted ignition switch, and night panel function that dimmed all non-essential gauges. Engine options were exclusively turbocharged, ranging from a 2.0-liter four-cylinder in various states of tune to a 3.0-liter V6, with power outputs from 150 to 260 horsepower. Transmission choices included five-speed manual and four-speed automatic, with a five-speed automatic added later. The 9-5 showcased Saab's commitment to safety innovation with active head restraints, side impact protection, and a comprehensive array of airbags, earning it top safety ratings. The model received a significant facelift in 2001 with updated exterior styling, an enhanced chassis, and revised powertrains featuring Saab's Direct Ignition system. A second refresh in 2006 brought further styling updates with influences from the 9X concept car. Throughout its 12-year production run, the 9-5 was offered in various trim levels, with the sporty Aero model featuring enhanced performance, sport suspension, and aerodynamic exterior elements. Special editions included the Anniversary and BioPower variants, the latter designed to run on ethanol-blended fuel. The first-generation 9-5 represented Saab's unique approach to premium vehicles, emphasizing safety, turbocharged performance, and practical Nordic design while maintaining the brand's aircraft heritage and distinctive character.
Saab-9-5.name: First Generation

Saab-9-5.description: The second-generation Saab 9-5 was introduced just as Saab was experiencing its most tumultuous period, with parent company General Motors selling the brand to Spyker Cars shortly after the model's launch. Built on GM's Epsilon II platform shared with vehicles like the Buick LaCrosse and Opel Insignia, the new 9-5 was significantly larger than its predecessor, particularly in wheelbase and overall length. The exterior design, led by Simon Padian, featured distinctive elements including ice-block themed lighting, a wraparound windshield effect extending into the A-pillars, and a sleek, fastback-like profile despite being a traditional three-box sedan. The interior maintained several Saab trademarks including the driver-oriented dashboard and center console-mounted ignition (now a start button), while introducing a head-up display and Saab's largest ever infotainment screen. Engine options included turbocharged four and six-cylinder gasoline engines and a turbo-diesel, with power outputs ranging from approximately 160 to 300 horsepower. The most powerful variant featured Saab's XWD all-wheel drive system with an electronic limited-slip differential. The second-generation 9-5 was initially launched only as a sedan, with a SportCombi wagon prototype developed but never reaching production due to Saab's bankruptcy. Despite critical acclaim for its design, driving dynamics, and technology, the second-generation 9-5 had an extremely short production life, with only about 11,000 units built before Saab ceased operations in 2011 following the company's bankruptcy. This makes it one of the rarest modern production cars from a mainstream manufacturer. The second-generation 9-5 represented both the culmination of Saab's design philosophy and, tragically, the final chapter for the storied Swedish automaker as a volume manufacturer.
Saab-9-5.name: Second Generation

Scion-FR-S.description: The Scion FR-S was Toyota's North American market variant of the jointly developed sports car project with Subaru, known as the Toyota 86/GT86 in other markets and the Subaru BRZ for Subaru's version. Designed as a return to Toyota's sports car heritage, the FR-S (which stood for Front-engine, Rear-wheel drive, Sport) was built around the principle of an affordable, lightweight sports coupe focused on handling and driver engagement rather than outright power. Powered by Subaru's naturally aspirated 2.0-liter flat-four 'boxer' engine with Toyota's D-4S direct and port injection system, the FR-S produced 200 horsepower and 151 lb-ft of torque, delivered to the rear wheels via a six-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission. The lightweight chassis (curb weight around 2,800 pounds) featured a low center of gravity thanks to the flat-four engine design, with a near-perfect weight distribution of 53/47 front to rear. The suspension utilized MacPherson struts up front and a double-wishbone setup in the rear, tuned for responsive handling and controlled oversteer. The minimalist interior focused on the driving experience with supportive sport seats, a small-diameter steering wheel, and simple controls. Technology was limited compared to many contemporaries, maintaining the car's focus on driving purity and keeping the price point accessible. Over its short lifespan, the FR-S received minimal changes beyond special edition models with unique colors and minor equipment variations. When Toyota discontinued the Scion brand after the 2016 model year, the FR-S was rebranded as the Toyota 86 for the North American market, continuing the model's legacy under the parent company's nameplate.
Scion-FR-S.name: First Generation

Scion-iQ.description: Single generation of the Scion iQ, marketed in North America from 2012-2015. The Scion iQ was the North American variant of the Toyota iQ city car, featuring a 1.3L 1NR-FE engine paired with CVT automatic transmission. Known for its compact size seating four occupants despite being only 9.8 feet long, the iQ maximized interior space through innovative engineering including a differential mounted further forward than usual and a flat fuel tank positioned underneath the cabin floor.
Scion-iQ.name: First Generation

Scion-tC.description: The first-generation Scion tC was introduced as a compact sport coupe aimed at younger buyers, embodying Scion's mission to attract a new generation to the Toyota brand. Based on the European Toyota Avensis platform, the tC featured a sleek two-door hatchback design with a standard panoramic glass moonroof, giving it a premium feel unusual for its price point. Toyota debuted the production tC at the January 2004 North American International Auto Show with sales beginning in May 2004 as a 2005 model year. Powered by a 2.4-liter 2AZ-FE inline-four engine producing 160 horsepower and 163 lb-ft of torque, the tC offered respectable performance for an entry-level coupe, with power delivered to the front wheels through either a five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmission. The interior was designed to appeal to younger buyers with premium-for-its-class materials, a driver-oriented cockpit, and a 160-watt Pioneer audio system with CD player. A key aspect of the tC's appeal was its extensive customization potential, with Scion offering numerous dealer-installed accessories and a thriving aftermarket. The tC also featured surprising practicality for a sport coupe with 60/40 split folding rear seats that reclined up to 45 degrees and generous cargo capacity through the hatchback design. Safety features included standard front, side, and curtain airbags—comprehensive for its time and class. The tC quickly became Scion's best-selling model, with 79,125 units sold in 2006.
Scion-tC.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Scion-tC.description: The first-generation Scion tC received a minor refresh in 2007 for the 2008 model year that included a revised grille and new 'Altezza'-styled head and taillights. The 2.4-liter 2AZ-FE engine received updated tuning for the 2007 model year, increasing power slightly. Safety features were enhanced for 2008 models with the addition of front seat-mounted side torso airbags, front and rear side curtain airbags, and a driver's knee airbag becoming standard. The Spec Package option was discontinued after the 2008 model year, leaving only the fully-equipped trim. Scion continued to offer 'Release Series' special editions throughout this period, including RS 4.0 (2008) in Galactic Gray Mica, RS 5.0 (2009) in Gloss Black, and RS 6.0 (2010) in Speedway Blue. Sales declined significantly by the end of this generation, dropping to 15,204 units in 2010.
Scion-tC.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Scion-tC.description: The second-generation Scion tC debuted with a more angular and aggressive design than its predecessor, featuring a thicker, flat-bottomed steering wheel inspired by the Lexus LFA supercar, more bolstered seats, and an overall more muscular stance. The replacement model debuted at the April 2010 New York International Auto Show and appeared in U.S. dealerships in October 2010. Built on a revised Toyota New MC platform shared with the Avensis, the new tC grew slightly in dimensions while maintaining its coupe-hatchback body style with panoramic moonroof. Power came from an updated 2.5-liter 2AR-FE inline-four engine producing 180 horsepower and 173 lb-ft of torque—a significant increase over the previous generation—paired with either a six-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission. The interior received a substantial upgrade with better materials, an 8-speaker 300-watt Pioneer audio system with standard Bluetooth connectivity and HD radio. The tC maintained its practical nature with 60/40 split folding rear seats and good cargo capacity for a sport coupe. Scion offered 'Release Series' special editions including RS 7.0 (2012) in High Voltage Yellow and RS 8.0 (2013) in Absolutely Red.
Scion-tC.name: Second Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Scion-tC.description: The second-generation Scion tC received a significant facelift for the 2014 model year, coinciding with the launch of the Scion FR-S. Inspired by the FR-S design language, the 2014 tC received updated headlamps, grille, LED taillights, 18-inch alloy rims, body kit, sport-tuned suspension, reworked faster shifting transmission, sport-tuned shocks, and a new 6.1-inch touchscreen audio system. Scion offered a Series 10 anniversary edition for the first model year, limited to 3,500 units, featuring silver color, silver seat belts, a solar-powered illuminated shift knob, and sequentially numbered interior badge. For the 2016 model year, minor changes included a standard rear windshield wiper, silver interior door handles, center console tray cover, and leather-wrapped shift knob. The tC ended production in August 2016 after a final Release Series 10.0 edition in Barcelona Red with 1,200 units produced, as part of the phasing out of the Scion brand. The tC was Scion's best-selling model, constituting almost 40% of total Scion sales.
Scion-tC.name: Second Generation (Facelift)

Scion-xB.description: The first-generation Scion xB was a lightly modified and rebadged version of the Japanese-market subcompact Toyota bB. It was based on the Toyota Echo/Yaris platform and featured a 1.5L 1NZ-FE I4 engine producing 108 hp. Available with both 5-speed manual and 4-speed automatic transmissions, it was one of two launch models for the Scion marque alongside the xA.
Scion-xB.name: First Generation (XP30)

Scion-xB.description: The second-generation Scion xB was retooled as a compact car based on the E150 series Corolla platform (Toyota New MC platform). It featured a larger, rounder design with a 2.4L 2AZ-FE I4 engine rated at 158 hp. This model was also sold internationally as the Toyota Corolla Rumion in Japan and Toyota Rukus in Australia.
Scion-xB.name: Second Generation Pre-Facelift (E150)

Scion-xB.description: The facelifted second-generation xB received revised front and rear bumpers, new front grille, headlights, and tail lights for the 2012 model year. Additional updates included a revised gauge cluster, center console, and new driver and front passenger seats. For 2013, there were further interior upgrades including the optional BeSpoke radio and remodeled bumpers. The 2015 model added a standard backup camera as the final model year before the xB was replaced by the Scion iM.
Scion-xB.name: Second Generation Facelift (E150)

Seat-Alhambra.description: The first-generation SEAT Alhambra was a full-size MPV (Multi-Purpose Vehicle) developed as part of a joint venture between the Volkswagen Group and Ford, resulting in three nearly identical vehicles: the SEAT Alhambra, Volkswagen Sharan, and Ford Galaxy. Built at the AutoEuropa plant in Portugal, the Alhambra featured a conventional minivan design with sliding rear doors and seating for up to seven passengers in a 2-3-2 configuration. Engine options varied throughout its long production run but typically included gasoline options ranging from 1.8 to 2.8 liters (including a 1.8T turbocharged variant) and diesel engines from 1.9 to 2.0 liters with various power outputs, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. The Alhambra underwent a significant facelift in 2000, receiving updated exterior styling, improved interior materials, and enhanced safety features. Despite being one of the older designs in its segment by the end of its run, the first-generation Alhambra maintained popularity thanks to its spacious interior, practical sliding doors, and relative value compared to its Volkswagen sibling. Throughout its 14-year production span—unusually long for a modern vehicle—the Alhambra received numerous minor updates to keep it competitive, including improved engines, additional equipment, and enhanced safety features. As SEAT's first and only MPV, the Alhambra established the Spanish brand's presence in the family vehicle segment across European markets.
Seat-Alhambra.name: First Generation

Seat-Alhambra.description: The second-generation SEAT Alhambra represented a complete redesign, now based on the Volkswagen Group's more modern PQ46 platform shared with the contemporary Volkswagen Sharan but no longer related to Ford's offerings. The new Alhambra maintained the practical sliding rear door design of its predecessor while adopting SEAT's more angular styling language. Slightly larger than the outgoing model in all dimensions, the new Alhambra offered improved interior space with a flexible seating system accommodating up to seven passengers, with the third row suitable for adults—uncommon in the segment. Engine options centered around the Volkswagen Group's 1.4 TSI and 2.0 TSI gasoline engines and the 2.0 TDI diesel in various power outputs ranging from 140 to 220 horsepower, paired with six-speed manual or DSG dual-clutch automatic transmissions. The interior featured a significant upgrade in material quality and technology, with available features including three-zone climate control, panoramic sunroof, and later SEAT's Full Link infotainment system with smartphone integration. Safety technology expanded to include optional adaptive cruise control, lane-keeping assist, automatic emergency braking, and various parking assistance systems. The second generation achieved a 5-star Euro NCAP safety rating in 2010.
Seat-Alhambra.name: Second Generation

Seat-Alhambra.description: The second-generation SEAT Alhambra received a significant facelift in September 2015, bringing updated styling, improved engines meeting Euro 6 emissions standards, LED taillights, and enhanced infotainment options. The diesel models were revised to meet Euro 6 standards with increased power outputs. Despite the market shift toward SUVs and crossovers, the second-generation Alhambra maintained steady sales thanks to its practical design, spacious interior, and strong value proposition. Production ended in March 2020 without a direct replacement, reflecting the declining MPV market as family buyers increasingly favored SUV-style vehicles. The facelifted model continued to offer the same practical sliding doors, seven-seat capacity, and flexible interior layout that made the Alhambra popular with families.
Seat-Alhambra.name: Second Generation Facelift

Seat-Altea.description: Original SEAT Altea compact MPV launched in March 2004. Based on Volkswagen Group's A5 (PQ35) platform. Designed by Walter de Silva as the first example of SEAT's new corporate look. Five trim levels: Essence, Reference, Reference Sport, Stylance, Sport and FR.
Seat-Altea.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Seat-Altea.description: Facelifted SEAT Altea introduced in 2009 with updated exterior styling, interior improvements and new engine options including the 1.2 TSI and 1.6 TDI. Production continued until August 21, 2015 when SEAT announced discontinuation. The Altea XL and Altea Freetrack variants were also produced during this period.
Seat-Altea.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Seat-Arona.description: The SEAT Arona is the Spanish brand's first subcompact crossover SUV, introduced to capitalize on the rapidly growing small SUV segment in Europe. Built on the Volkswagen Group's MQB A0 platform shared with the SEAT Ibiza, Volkswagen Polo, and Volkswagen T-Cross, the Arona features a raised ride height and SUV-inspired styling while maintaining compact dimensions suitable for urban driving. Named after a municipality in Tenerife, Spain, the Arona measures approximately 4.14 meters in length, positioning it as one of the more compact offerings in its class. Engine options at launch included 1.0 TSI three-cylinder turbo gasoline engines in 95 or 115 horsepower variants, a 1.5 TSI four-cylinder with 150 horsepower, and 1.6 TDI diesel options producing between 95 and 115 horsepower. Transmission choices include five or six-speed manuals and seven-speed DSG dual-clutch automatics depending on engine selection. The interior features SEAT's driver-focused design with a central 8-inch touchscreen for infotainment functions, and practical storage solutions.
