Despite its crossover positioning, the Arona is exclusively front-wheel drive across all variants, focusing on city-friendly maneuverability and efficiency rather than genuine off-road capability.
Seat-Arona.name: First Generation

Seat-Arona.description: The facelifted SEAT Arona was revealed on 15 April 2021, bringing significant updates to the popular subcompact crossover SUV. The exterior received updated styling with all exterior lighting now using LED technology, including new LED headlights, revised grille, and modified bumpers. The interior received a free-standing touchscreen infotainment system (now up to 9.2 inches), improved connectivity, voice control, and new advanced driving safety features. The rugged-looking Xperience trim was introduced with additional body cladding and styling elements suggesting enhanced off-road capability. The Arona continues to be built on the Volkswagen Group's MQB A0 platform and remains one of SEAT's most successful models, appealing to buyers seeking the elevated driving position and style of an SUV with the manageable dimensions and running costs of a supermini.
Seat-Arona.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Seat-Ateca.description: The SEAT Ateca marks the Spanish brand's first entry into the compact SUV segment, strategically launched to capitalize on the growing demand for crossovers in European markets. Named after a village in Spain, the Ateca is built on the Volkswagen Group's MQB A1 platform shared with vehicles like the Volkswagen Tiguan and Škoda Karoq. Measuring approximately 4.36 meters in length, the Ateca combines compact exterior dimensions with a spacious interior offering 510 liters of cargo capacity (485 liters in all-wheel drive variants). The exterior design features SEAT's sharp, angular styling language with triangular headlights, a prominent grille, and sculpted body panels creating a more dynamic appearance than many competitors. Engine options at launch included 1.0 TSI and 1.4 TSI (later replaced by 1.5 TSI) gasoline engines and 1.6 TDI and 2.0 TDI diesel variants with power outputs ranging from 115 to 190 horsepower. Transmission options include six-speed manual and seven-speed DSG dual-clutch automatic, with 4Drive all-wheel drive available on selected higher-powered models. The interior features a driver-oriented dashboard with an 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system, available digital cockpit, and practical storage solutions. The pre-facelift model was awarded 5 stars by Euro NCAP in 2016 for safety.
Seat-Ateca.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Seat-Ateca.description: The facelifted SEAT Ateca was revealed in June 2020, bringing significant visual and technological updates while maintaining the MQB A1 platform. Exterior revisions include a modified front bumper, a new rear bumper, a revised radiator grille, new LED headlamps and tail lights with sequential indicators on higher trim levels. The traditional block-capital SEAT badge was replaced with the new hand-written script logo. Interior updates include a new leather steering wheel, updated door cards, new upholstery designs, an eight-way electrically adjustable driver's seat, USB-C ports, and a multi-colour ambient lighting system. The infotainment system was upgraded to an 8.25-inch unit as standard with a larger 9.2-inch unit as an option. The model range continues to include the Xcellence, FR, and entry-level trims, with the performance-oriented Cupra Ateca also receiving corresponding updates featuring the copper-tinted Cupra badge and a 2.0 TSI engine producing 300 horsepower.
Seat-Ateca.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Seat-Ibiza.description: The first-generation SEAT Ibiza (codenamed 021A) was introduced at the 1984 Paris Motor Show, marking SEAT's first car developed as an independent company after separating from Fiat. Designed by Giorgetto Giugiaro at Italdesign with mechanical components developed in collaboration with Porsche (advertised as 'System Porsche'), the Ibiza featured Italian styling and German engineering. Based on the SEAT Ronda (which was derived from the Fiat Ritmo), it was larger than typical superminis like the Ford Fiesta and Opel Corsa. Available in three and five-door configurations, it offered a 320-liter boot expanding to 1,200 liters with rear seats folded. Engine options included 0.9-liter, 1.2-liter, 1.5-liter, and 1.7-liter gasoline units plus a 1.7-liter diesel, with power outputs from 44 to 100 horsepower. A light facelift in early 1989 brought a new grille and interior, while the 1991 'New Style' version offered more thorough updates. The first-generation Ibiza proved highly successful, selling 1,342,001 units before the second generation arrived in 1993. Production continued in China until 2008 as the Nanjing Yuejin Soyat.
Seat-Ibiza.name: First Generation (021A)

Seat-Ibiza.description: The second-generation SEAT Ibiza (Typ 6K) was the first developed entirely under Volkswagen Group ownership, utilizing a platform shared with the Volkswagen Polo Mk3 and Golf Mk3. Again designed by Giorgetto Giugiaro, the new Ibiza featured more rounded styling while maintaining a sporty character. Available in three and five-door hatchback configurations, with saloon and estate variants sold as the SEAT Córdoba. Engine options expanded significantly, including 1.0-liter to 2.0-liter gasoline units and 1.9-liter diesel variants, with the range-topping Cupra producing up to 156 horsepower. A minor facelift in 1996 added smoother bumpers and new headlights, while the more substantial 1999 facelift (6K2) brought revised front and rear styling, a new dashboard, and the tailgate-mounted SEAT badge that doubled as a boot release. The sporty Cupra and Cupra R variants became icons of SEAT's performance image. The second generation achieved significant success, winning 'Car of the Year 1994' in Spain and Portugal, and selling 1,522,607 units before production ended in 2002.
Seat-Ibiza.name: Second Generation (6K)

Seat-Ibiza.description: The third-generation SEAT Ibiza (Typ 6L) was built on the Volkswagen Group PQ24 platform shared with the VW Polo Mk4 and Škoda Fabia. Styled by Walter de Silva to emphasize sportiness and performance, the Mk3 Ibiza was larger than its predecessors with improved interior space. Available in three and five-door hatchbacks, with the Córdoba saloon continuing until 2009. Engine options ranged from 1.2-liter to 1.8-liter gasoline engines (including a 180-horsepower 1.8T in the Cupra) and 1.4-liter to 1.9-liter TDI diesel variants, with the FR and Cupra R representing top performance models. A 2006 facelift brought cosmetic updates to the interior and exterior plus enhanced equipment. The third-generation Ibiza received critical acclaim, winning 'Car of the Year 2003' and 'Supermini of the Year' for three consecutive years from What Car? magazine. Euro NCAP awarded it a 4-star safety rating. Production continued until 2008, with the 2.0-liter engine variant lasting until 2009 in Latin American markets.
Seat-Ibiza.name: Third Generation (6L)

Seat-Ibiza.description: The fourth-generation SEAT Ibiza (Typ 6J) was the first in its segment to use Volkswagen Group's PQ25 platform, later shared with the VW Polo Mk5 and Audi A1. Styled by Luc Donckerwolke featuring a distinctive 'arrow design' language previewed by the 2008 Bocanegra concept, the Mk4 Ibiza marked a bold departure from previous generations. Available as a five-door hatchback, three-door Sport Coupé (SC), and five-door estate (Ibiza ST introduced in 2010). Engine options included 1.0-liter to 1.8-liter gasoline units (including innovative TSI turbocharged engines) and 1.2-liter to 2.0-liter TDI diesels, with the high-performance FR and Cupra variants using a 1.4-liter TSI twincharger producing up to 180 horsepower. A 2012 facelift brought exterior and interior refreshments, while a more thorough 2015 update introduced full LED headlights, improved quality materials, and enhanced connectivity via Full Link technology. Euro NCAP awarded a 5-star safety rating in both 2008 and 2011 assessments. The fifth-generation model debuted in 2017, ending production of this generation.
Seat-Ibiza.name: Fourth Generation (6J)

Seat-Ibiza.description: The fifth-generation SEAT Ibiza (Typ 6F) was introduced at the 2017 Geneva Motor Show as the first Volkswagen Group model to use the MQB A0 platform, later shared with the VW Polo Mk6, Škoda Fabia Mk4, and Audi A1. Available exclusively as a five-door hatchback (discontinuing the SC and ST variants), it was designed under Julio Lozano with sharper, more angular styling. Despite similar exterior dimensions to its predecessor, the MQB A0 platform enabled significantly improved interior space and cargo capacity (355 liters). Engine options included 1.0-liter MPI and TSI three-cylinder gasoline engines, a 1.5-liter TSI EVO, a 1.0-liter TSI CNG variant, and a 1.6-liter TDI diesel, with power outputs ranging from 75 to 150 horsepower. The interior featured an available 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, plus comprehensive driver assistance systems. A 2021 facelift brought minimal exterior changes but significant interior upgrades including a larger screen, new steering wheel, and soft-touch materials. A second facelift in October 2025 introduced redesigned lights, bumpers, and SEAT's new hexagonal grille design. The fifth-generation Ibiza continues production to present day.
Seat-Ibiza.name: Fifth Generation (6F)

Seat-Leon.description: The first-generation SEAT Leon was introduced as the Spanish brand's entry into the compact hatchback segment, effectively replacing the SEAT Toledo as the brand's C-segment contender. Built on the Volkswagen Group's PQ34 platform shared with contemporaries like the Volkswagen Golf Mk4, Audi A3 Mk1, and Škoda Octavia, the original Leon featured distinctive styling by Giorgetto Giugiaro with a sleeker, more dynamic appearance than its Volkswagen Group siblings. Available exclusively as a five-door hatchback, the Leon measured approximately 4.18 meters in length. Engine options included a wide range of Volkswagen Group powertrains, from 1.4-liter to 2.8-liter gasoline units (including the 1.8T in various states of tune) and 1.9-liter diesel engines in both naturally aspirated SDI and turbocharged TDI forms, with power outputs ranging from 68 to 180 horsepower in standard models. The range-topping Leon Cupra R featured a 210-horsepower (later 225-horsepower) version of the 1.8T engine, making it the most powerful production SEAT at the time. The interior shared components with other Volkswagen Group products but featured unique styling elements and sportier appointments, particularly in FR and Cupra models. A mild facelift in 2004 brought subtle exterior updates and equipment improvements. The first-generation Leon established the nameplate as a sportier, more distinctively styled alternative to the Golf, particularly appealing to younger buyers looking for a more expressive design without sacrificing the solid engineering and reliability associated with Volkswagen Group products.
Seat-Leon.name: First Generation

Seat-Leon.description: The second-generation SEAT Leon (internally designated 1P) was built on the Volkswagen Group's PQ35 platform shared with contemporaries like the Volkswagen Golf Mk5 and Audi A3 Mk2. Designed under Walter de'Silva, the new Leon featured more radical styling with dramatic character lines, distinctive headlights, and a sloping roofline giving it a more coupe-like appearance than most competitors despite remaining a practical five-door hatchback. Measuring approximately 4.32 meters in length, the second-generation Leon grew slightly compared to its predecessor. Engine options expanded to include gasoline units ranging from 1.4 to 2.0 liters, including TSI turbocharged engines, and diesel options centered around the 1.9 TDI and later 2.0 TDI in various states of tune, with power outputs ranging from 85 to 240 horsepower in the Cupra R. Transmission options included five and six-speed manuals, conventional automatics, and DSG dual-clutch automatics depending on engine selection. The interior featured improved quality with better materials and more technology, including available dual-zone climate control, upgraded audio systems, and later, touchscreen navigation. A facelift in 2009 brought revised exterior styling with new headlights incorporating LED daytime running lights, modified bumpers, and interior refinements including a new steering wheel design and updated materials. The performance-oriented FR and Cupra models continued as the sportier variants, with the limited-production Cupra R featuring a 265-horsepower 2.0 TSI engine. The second-generation Leon further developed the model's reputation for combining practicality with a distinctly sporty character and more expressive styling than its Volkswagen Group siblings, particularly appealing to younger buyers seeking a more dynamic compact hatchback.
Seat-Leon.name: Second Generation

Seat-Leon.description: The third-generation SEAT Leon (internally designated 5F) was built on the Volkswagen Group's MQB platform, which it shared with the Volkswagen Golf Mk7, Audi A3 Mk3, and Škoda Octavia Mk3. Designed under Alejandro Mesonero-Romanos, the new Leon featured sharper, more angular styling with defined character lines, triangular headlights, and a more sophisticated overall appearance. For the first time, the Leon was available in three body styles: the standard five-door hatchback, a three-door 'SC' (Sport Coupé), and a 'ST' estate variant, expanding the model's appeal to a broader audience. The third-generation Leon was approximately 4.26 meters long in five-door form, with the ST estate stretching to 4.54 meters. Engine options included gasoline units ranging from 1.2 to 2.0 liters, almost all turbocharged, and diesel options centered around the 1.6 TDI and 2.0 TDI, with power outputs ranging from 86 to 300 horsepower in the Cupra variants. Transmission options included six-speed manuals and six or seven-speed DSG dual-clutch automatics depending on engine selection. The interior saw significant improvements in quality, design, and technology, with an available 5.8-inch (later 8-inch) touchscreen infotainment system, optional full-LED headlights (a first in its segment), and a comprehensive suite of driver assistance systems in later models. A facelift in 2017 brought updated exterior styling, new engine options including a 1.5 TSI, improved technology with gesture control for the infotainment system, and additional driver assistance features. The third-generation Leon was also the first to offer alternative powertrains with the Leon TGI running on compressed natural gas (CNG) and the plug-in hybrid eHybrid version introduced near the end of the generation. The high-performance Cupra models became increasingly distinct, eventually leading to the creation of the separate Cupra brand in 2018, with the Cupra Leon featuring unique styling elements, bespoke suspension tuning, and up to 300 horsepower in the range-topping models. The third-generation Leon became SEAT's bestselling model, successfully competing with class leaders through its combination of distinctive styling, engaging driving dynamics, practical features, and competitive pricing.
Seat-Leon.name: Third Generation

Seat-Leon.description: The fourth-generation SEAT Leon (internally designated KL1) continues on the Volkswagen Group's MQB platform, now in its evolved 'Evo' form shared with models like the Volkswagen Golf Mk8 and Škoda Octavia Mk4. Designed under Alejandro Mesonero-Romanos, the new Leon features a more evolutionary styling approach than previous generations but with a distinctly more technological appearance, highlighted by full LED lighting including a coast-to-coast light bar connecting the taillights and dynamic indicators. Available in five-door hatchback and estate (Sportstourer) body styles—with the three-door version discontinued—the fourth-generation Leon measures approximately 4.37 meters long in hatchback form and 4.65 meters as an estate, slightly larger than its predecessor in both configurations. Engine options include gasoline units ranging from 1.0 to 2.0 liters, diesel options centered around the 2.0 TDI, a compressed natural gas (CNG) 1.5 TGI variant, and for the first time, electrified powertrains including mild hybrid (eTSI) and plug-in hybrid (eHybrid) versions producing between 204 and 245 horsepower with up to 60km of electric-only range. Conventional engines offer power outputs ranging from 90 to 300 horsepower in the Cupra variant (now a separate brand but based on the Leon). Transmission options include six-speed manuals and seven-speed DSG dual-clutch automatics depending on engine selection. The interior represents a significant technological leap with a minimalist approach featuring a 10.25-inch digital cockpit and a 10-inch centrally mounted touchscreen infotainment system controlling most vehicle functions, with physical buttons largely eliminated. Connectivity is enhanced with SEAT Connect services offering remote features via a smartphone app, while driver assistance systems expanded to include adaptive cruise control with predictive speed regulation, emergency assist, and travel assist for semi-autonomous driving capabilities. The fourth-generation Leon continues SEAT's trajectory of combining distinctive styling and engaging driving dynamics with increasingly advanced technology and a broader range of powertrain options to meet evolving emissions regulations and consumer preferences.
Seat-Leon.name: Fourth Generation

Seat-Mii-Electric.description: The SEAT Mii Electric was not a new vehicle design but rather an all-electric version of the existing SEAT Mii city car, which had been available with gasoline engines since 2011. When SEAT discontinued all internal combustion engine versions of the Mii in 2019, the Electric variant became the sole offering, marking SEAT's first all-electric production vehicle. Built on the Volkswagen Group's NSF (New Small Family) platform shared with the Volkswagen e-up! and Škoda Citigo-e iV, the Mii Electric maintained the standard Mii's compact dimensions at just 3.56 meters long, making it ideal for urban environments. Propulsion came from an 82 horsepower (61 kW) electric motor producing 156 lb-ft (212 Nm) of torque, powered by a 36.8 kWh lithium-ion battery pack providing a WLTP-rated range of up to 161 miles (260 km). Performance was modest but adequate for its city car positioning, with 0-62 mph (0-100 km/h) acceleration in approximately 12.3 seconds and a top speed limited to 80 mph (130 km/h). Charging capabilities included AC charging at up to 7.2 kW (allowing a full charge in about 4 hours) and DC fast charging at up to 40 kW (providing 0-80% charge in approximately one hour). The exterior design was nearly identical to the gasoline-powered Mii, with minor changes including 'Electric' badging, unique 16-inch alloy wheels, and slightly revised front-end styling. The interior similarly maintained the gasoline Mii's straightforward design but featured specific electric vehicle instrumentation, a leather-wrapped steering wheel and gear knob, heated seats, and a unique dashboard finish. Standard equipment was generous compared to the previous gasoline models, with all Mii Electric versions featuring air conditioning, lane assist, traffic sign recognition, rear parking sensors, and a smartphone integration system that allowed a mounted smartphone to serve as the primary infotainment display. The Mii Electric was positioned as an affordable entry point into electric mobility, significantly undercutting many competitors on price while offering practical urban transportation with zero emissions. Production ended in 2021 without a direct replacement, as SEAT shifted focus to larger electric vehicles developed on dedicated EV platforms.
Seat-Mii-Electric.name: First Generation

Seat-Tarraco.description: The SEAT Tarraco is the Spanish brand's first large SUV, positioned above the compact Ateca and subcompact Arona in the lineup. Named after the ancient name for the Spanish city of Tarragona, the Tarraco is built on the Volkswagen Group's MQB-A2 platform shared with the Volkswagen Tiguan Allspace and Škoda Kodiaq. Measuring approximately 4.74 meters in length, the Tarraco offers seven seats as standard in most markets (with a five-seat configuration available in some regions), positioning it as SEAT's flagship family vehicle. The exterior design features sharp, angular styling consistent with SEAT's design language but with a more premium, sophisticated appearance befitting its flagship status. Engine options at launch included 1.5 TSI and 2.0 TSI gasoline engines and 2.0 TDI diesel variants with power outputs ranging from 150 to 190 horsepower. Transmission options include six-speed manual and seven-speed DSG dual-clutch automatic, with 4Drive all-wheel drive available on higher-powered variants. The interior combines SEAT's driver-focused design with premium materials and advanced technology, including a 10.25-inch Digital Cockpit instrument display and an 8-inch floating touchscreen for the infotainment system. A comprehensive suite of driver assistance systems includes adaptive cruise control, lane assist, traffic sign recognition, and emergency assist. In 2021, the range expanded to include a plug-in hybrid eHybrid variant combining a 1.4 TSI gasoline engine with an electric motor for a combined output of 245 horsepower and an electric-only range of approximately 30 miles. The Tarraco was designed to appeal to growing families seeking a versatile, technology-rich vehicle with a more dynamic driving experience than typically offered in the seven-seat SUV segment. The Tarraco represents SEAT's move upmarket, competing with established seven-seat SUVs while offering distinctive styling and a more engaging driving experience than many rivals, consistent with SEAT's sportier positioning within the Volkswagen Group.
Seat-Tarraco.name: First Generation

Skoda-Elroq.description: All-electric compact crossover SUV, the first fully electric model in Škoda's small SUV segment. Based on the Volkswagen Group MEB platform. Positioned below the Enyaq in the electric vehicle lineup.
Skoda-Elroq.name: First Generation

Skoda-Enyaq.description: The Škoda Enyaq (originally introduced as Škoda Enyaq iV) is the Czech automaker's first purpose-built electric vehicle, representing a significant milestone in the brand's history. Built on the Volkswagen Group's MEB (Modularer E-Antriebs-Baukasten) platform dedicated to electric vehicles and shared with models like the Volkswagen ID.4 and Audi Q4 e-tron, the Enyaq features a distinctive SUV design that balances contemporary Škoda styling cues with aerodynamic efficiency. Measuring approximately 4.65 meters in length, the Enyaq positions itself as a C-segment SUV with interior space comparable to larger vehicles thanks to the packaging advantages of the dedicated electric platform. The name is derived from the Irish name Enya, originating from the Gaelic word 'eithne', meaning 'essence, spirit or principle'. Production commenced in November 2020 at the Škoda plant in Mladá Boleslav, Czech Republic. Available in multiple powertrain configurations, the Enyaq lineup includes rear-wheel drive single-motor variants (Enyaq 50, 60, 80) and all-wheel drive dual-motor versions (Enyaq 80x, RS), with battery capacities ranging from 52 kWh to 77 kWh (usable) providing WLTP ranges between approximately 340 and 510 kilometers depending on configuration. Power outputs range from 109 kW in the base model to 225 kW in the performance-oriented RS variant. Charging capabilities include AC charging at up to 11 kW and DC fast charging at up to 125 kW. The interior features a minimalist, modern design centered around a 13-inch central touchscreen complemented by an optional head-up display with augmented reality functionality. A unique feature is Škoda's 'Design Selection' approach, which replaces traditional trim levels with interior themes inspired by modern living environments.
Skoda-Enyaq.name: First Generation

Skoda-Enyaq.description: Škoda released the facelift models of both the Enyaq and Enyaq Coupe on 8 January 2025. Changes include a redesigned front fascia featuring the 'Modern Solid' face debuted on the smaller Elroq, an improved drag coefficient for both models, new exterior colors, and interior features more sustainable materials. The facelift also introduced updated powertrains including the new Enyaq 85 and 85x variants with the latest-generation APP550 electric motor (initially introduced on the Volkswagen ID.7), delivering enhanced performance and improved efficiency compared to its predecessor. The naming convention also evolved, with 'iV' suffix dropped and the RS variant receiving updated power outputs. The Sportline variant continues to offer distinct interior and exterior styling with extended standard features, while the Laurin & Klement (L&K) variant joins the lineup with premium appointments. The Enyaq Coupé continues alongside the standard SUV, featuring a sloping roofline, panoramic glass roof, and enhanced aerodynamics. Both body styles continue to be produced at the Mladá Boleslav plant for the European market.
Skoda-Enyaq.name: First Generation (2025 Facelift)

Skoda-Fabia.description: The first-generation Škoda Fabia, based on the Volkswagen Group's PQ24 platform shared with the Volkswagen Polo and SEAT Ibiza, marked a significant evolution for the Czech brand under Volkswagen ownership. Available as a five-door hatchback, estate (Combi), and later a four-door sedan (Sedan), the Fabia showcased substantially improved quality compared to pre-Volkswagen Škoda models. Measuring approximately 3.96 meters in length (4.22 meters for the Combi), the Fabia offered generous interior space for its compact exterior dimensions. Engine options included gasoline units ranging from 1.0 to 2.0 liters and diesel options centered around the 1.4 and 1.9 TDI, with power outputs ranging from 54 to 130 horsepower in the vRS performance model. The vRS, available exclusively with a 1.9 TDI diesel engine producing 130 horsepower, established a unique position as a performance diesel at a time when such combinations were uncommon. The interior featured straightforward, functional design with solid build quality and Škoda's emerging 'Simply Clever' features. A facelift in 2004 brought revised styling with updated headlights, grille, and improved interior materials. The first-generation Fabia established the model as a practical, reliable, and value-focused alternative to its Volkswagen Group siblings and competitors, helping to transform Škoda's market perception and achieve significant sales success across Europe.
Skoda-Fabia.name: First Generation (Type 6Y)

Skoda-Fabia.description: The second-generation Škoda Fabia, built on an updated version of the PQ24 platform, featured more distinctive styling with a taller, more upright profile emphasizing interior space and practicality. Available as a five-door hatchback and estate (Combi), with the sedan variant discontinued, the new Fabia maintained similar exterior dimensions to its predecessor at approximately 4.0 meters long (4.24 meters for the Combi). Engine options included gasoline units ranging from 1.2 to 1.6 liters, including the new 1.2 TSI turbocharged engine, and diesel options centered around the 1.4 and 1.6 TDI, with power outputs ranging from 60 to 132 horsepower in the vRS models. Unlike the diesel-only predecessor, the second-generation vRS was offered with a 1.4-liter twin-charged (supercharged and turbocharged) gasoline engine producing 180 horsepower, paired exclusively with a seven-speed DSG dual-clutch automatic transmission. The interior featured improved materials, more equipment options, and expanded 'Simply Clever' practical solutions. A facelift in 2010 brought updated styling with Škoda's new corporate grille design and additional equipment. The second-generation Fabia further developed the model's reputation for offering excellent value, practicality, and reliability, continuing its strong sales performance particularly in European markets where efficient small cars are popular.
Skoda-Fabia.name: Second Generation (Type 5J)

Skoda-Fabia.description: The third-generation Škoda Fabia was built on the Volkswagen Group's MQB-A0 platform shared with models like the Volkswagen Polo and SEAT Ibiza. With sharper, more angular styling aligned with Škoda's evolving design language, the new Fabia featured a wider stance and lower roofline than its predecessor, creating a more dynamic appearance. Available as a five-door hatchback and estate (Combi), the third-generation Fabia grew slightly to approximately 4.06 meters long (4.26 meters for the Combi). Engine options included gasoline units ranging from 1.0 MPI naturally aspirated to 1.0 and 1.2 TSI turbocharged engines, and diesel options including the 1.4 TDI, with power outputs ranging from 60 to 110 horsepower. Notably, no vRS performance variant was offered in this generation. Transmission options included five and six-speed manuals and a seven-speed DSG dual-clutch automatic. The interior featured a more modern design with improved materials, a central infotainment display with available smartphone connectivity, and expanded 'Simply Clever' features including umbrella storage under the passenger seat and a waste bin in the door pocket. A facelift in 2018 brought subtle exterior updates, LED lighting options, and additional technology including available blind-spot detection and rear traffic alert—advanced features for the segment. The third-generation Fabia continued the model's success by combining practicality and value with more sophisticated styling and technology, maintaining its position as one of Škoda's best-selling models.
Skoda-Fabia.name: Third Generation (Type NJ)

Skoda-Fabia.description: The fourth-generation Škoda Fabia represents the most comprehensive redesign in the model's history, now fully utilizing the Volkswagen Group's MQB-A0 platform that underpins models like the current Volkswagen Polo and SEAT Ibiza. Significantly larger than its predecessor, the new Fabia grows to approximately 4.11 meters in length, approaching the size of earlier Škoda Octavia models, while the estate (Combi) variant was initially discontinued before returning in 2023. The exterior design features sharper lines, a more assertive front with a larger grille, and improved aerodynamics with a drag coefficient of 0.28. Engine options are exclusively gasoline, centered around the 1.0 MPI naturally aspirated and 1.0 TSI turbocharged three-cylinder engines, plus a 1.5 TSI four-cylinder in higher-spec models, with power outputs ranging from 65 to 150 horsepower. Transmission options include five and six-speed manuals and a seven-speed DSG dual-clutch automatic depending on engine selection. The interior represents a significant advancement with a more modern design featuring a free-standing infotainment screen up to 9.2 inches, an optional 10.25-inch digital instrument cluster, and improved materials throughout. Technology options expanded to include features previously reserved for larger vehicles, such as dual-zone climate control, heated steering wheel, and advanced driver assistance systems including adaptive cruise control and lane-keeping assist. The 'Simply Clever' features that Škoda is known for are more numerous than ever, with up to 43 different practical solutions including a folding front passenger backrest, smartphone pockets on the front seatbacks, and a removable cupholder. The fourth-generation Fabia offers substantially more interior space, particularly rear legroom and cargo capacity, which increases to 380 liters (up 50 liters from the previous generation). This generation elevates the Fabia's position in the supermini segment, offering near-compact car space and features while maintaining competitive pricing, strengthening its appeal as a practical, value-focused choice with fewer compromises than typically associated with small cars.
Skoda-Fabia.name: Fourth Generation (Type PJ)

Skoda-Kamiq.description: The Škoda Kamiq is the Czech brand's entry into the subcompact crossover SUV segment, positioned as the smallest SUV in Škoda's lineup below the Karoq and Kodiaq. Built on the Volkswagen Group's MQB A0 platform shared with models like the Volkswagen T-Cross, SEAT Arona, and Škoda Scala, the Kamiq combines city-friendly dimensions with an elevated driving position and crossover styling. The name 'Kamiq' comes from the language of the Inuit people of northern Canada and Greenland, meaning 'something that fits perfectly.' Measuring approximately 4.24 meters in length, the Kamiq is designed to appeal to urban dwellers seeking practicality and versatility without excessive exterior dimensions. The exterior design features Škoda's contemporary styling language with split headlight design (a first for a European Škoda model), where LED daytime running lights are positioned above the main headlight units, creating a distinctive front-end appearance. Engine options include 1.0 TSI three-cylinder and 1.5 TSI four-cylinder gasoline engines, plus a 1.6 TDI diesel in some markets, with power outputs ranging from 95 to 150 horsepower. Transmission options include five and six-speed manuals and a seven-speed DSG dual-clutch automatic depending on engine selection. Unlike some competitors, the Kamiq is exclusively front-wheel drive across all variants, focusing on on-road dynamics rather than off-road capability. The interior showcases Škoda's modern design approach with a free-standing infotainment screen (up to 9.2 inches), optional 10.25-inch Virtual Cockpit digital instrument display, and distinctive materials and textures. Consistent with Škoda's 'Simply Clever' philosophy, the Kamiq features numerous practical touches including an umbrella in the driver's door, an ice scraper in the fuel filler cap, and a removable LED flashlight in the cargo area. Despite its compact exterior dimensions, the Kamiq offers generous interior space with 400 liters of cargo capacity.
Skoda-Kamiq.name: First Generation

Skoda-Kamiq.description: The facelifted Škoda Kamiq was unveiled in August 2023 alongside the Scala. The updates include redesigned front and rear fascias with new L-shaped rear reflectors and the availability of matrix LED headlights, new exterior colours and alloy wheel designs. Inside, there is a redesigned HVAC control panel, more recycled materials used for the interior, improved standard equipment across the lineup, and additional Simply Clever features borrowed from other Škoda models. The trim structure has been updated and diesel engines are no longer available for the facelift model. The Kamiq continues to be built on the Volkswagen Group MQB A0 platform and remains a subcompact crossover SUV with front-wheel drive layout.
Skoda-Kamiq.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Skoda-Kodiaq.description: The first-generation Škoda Kodiaq is a mid-size crossover SUV representing the Czech brand's first large SUV, named after the Alaskan Kodiak bear. Built on Volkswagen Group's MQB A2 platform shared with VW Tiguan Allspace and SEAT Tarraco, the Kodiaq offered five or seven-seat configurations. Measuring approximately 4.7 meters in length, it featured crystalline design elements inspired by Czech glass art in the headlights and taillights. Engine options included 1.4 TSI (125-150 HP) and 2.0 TSI (180-220 HP) petrol units, plus 2.0 TDI diesel variants (150-240 HP). Transmission options included 6-speed manual and 6/7-speed DSG dual-clutch, with front-wheel drive standard and all-wheel drive available on higher trims. The interior featured an 8-inch infotainment system with capacitive buttons (first in VW Group MQB), Virtual Cockpit option, and 'Simply Clever' features like door-edge protection and integrated umbrella. Variants included Scout (raised ground clearance), Sportline (black trim, sport seats), and RS performance model with 240 HP bi-turbo diesel. The Kodiaq GT coupe variant was sold only in China.
Skoda-Kodiaq.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Skoda-Kodiaq.description: The facelifted first-generation Kodiaq launched in April 2021 introduced subtle but significant visual and functional updates. Exterior changes included a redesigned hood, more upright front grille, and slimmer LED headlights with optional matrix technology for improved aerodynamics. Bumpers were revised and a new roof-mounted spoiler enhanced efficiency. High-performance RS model received a 245 HP 2.0 TSI petrol engine replacing the previous bi-turbo diesel. New 20-inch polished wheels in metallic black with aero shields were exclusive to RS variants. The Kodiaq maintained its position as Škoda's flagship SUV with continued success in European and Asian markets, winning multiple awards including 'Best Family Car' accolades. Production of the first generation continued through 2024.
Skoda-Kodiaq.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Skoda-Kodiaq.description: The second-generation Škoda Kodiaq, introduced October 4, 2023 for the 2024 model year, builds on its predecessor's success with advanced technology, electrified powertrains, and refined design. Built on the updated Volkswagen Group MQB Evo platform, the new Kodiaq maintains similar dimensions (~4.76m length) but with improved interior packaging. Available in five and seven-seat configurations, features include evolutionary styling with more upright front end, redesigned LED headlights with optional Matrix technology, and new C-shaped rear light signature. Powertrains include a new plug-in hybrid (1.5 TSI + electric motor, 25.7kWh battery, ~100km range, 50kW DC charging), alongside 1.5 TSI and 2.0 TSI petrol engines with mild hybrid, and 2.0 TDI diesel. The RS variant delivers 265 HP. Interior advances include a 10-inch digital display (upgradeable to 13 inches), 13-inch central touchscreen, and innovative 'Smart Dials' combining physical controls with digital displays. Sustainable materials include recycled seat coverings. The Kodiaq II continues Škoda's 'Simply Clever' philosophy with enhanced practicality.
Skoda-Kodiaq.name: Second Generation

Skoda-Octavia.description: The first-generation Škoda Octavia represented a pivotal model for the Czech brand following its acquisition by the Volkswagen Group. Built on the Volkswagen Group's PQ34 platform shared with the Volkswagen Golf Mk4 and Audi A3 Mk1, the Octavia cleverly positioned itself as a halfway point between compact and mid-size segments. Available as a five-door liftback sedan (despite its conventional three-box appearance) and later as an estate (Combi), the Octavia measured approximately 4.5 meters in length, offering substantially more interior space and cargo capacity than most compact cars of the era. Engine options included gasoline units ranging from 1.4 to 2.0 liters, including a 1.8-liter turbocharged variant, and diesel options centered around the 1.9 TDI in various states of tune, with power outputs ranging from 60 to 180 horsepower in the high-performance RS model introduced in 2000. The interior featured straightforward Germanic design with a focus on functionality and durability rather than style, but with materials and build quality that represented a quantum leap over pre-Volkswagen Škoda products. A facelift in 2000 brought updated styling and technology. The first-generation Octavia established the model's reputation for offering exceptional value by essentially providing mid-size car space and capability at compact car prices, a formula that would define the Octavia through subsequent generations and play a key role in transforming Škoda's brand image.
Skoda-Octavia.name: First Generation (Type 1U)

Skoda-Octavia.description: The second-generation Škoda Octavia, built on the Volkswagen Group's PQ35 platform shared with the Volkswagen Golf Mk5 and Audi A3 Mk2, continued the successful formula of its predecessor while growing in size, refinement, and feature content. Again available as a five-door liftback sedan and estate (Combi), the second-generation Octavia grew to approximately 4.57 meters in length, further emphasizing its positioning between compact and mid-size segments. Engine options expanded to include gasoline units ranging from 1.4 to 2.0 liters, including TSI turbocharged engines later in the production run, and diesel options centered around the 1.9 TDI and later 2.0 TDI, with power outputs ranging from 80 to 200 horsepower in the RS performance variants. Transmission options included five and six-speed manuals, conventional automatics, and DSG dual-clutch automatics depending on engine selection. The interior featured improved materials, more sophisticated design, and expanded technology options including available navigation systems. A significant facelift in 2008 brought updated exterior styling with new headlights and grille design, along with interior refinements. The range expanded to include specialty variants such as the Scout, a rugged, raised-height estate with all-wheel drive and off-road styling elements, and the GreenLine, focusing on maximum efficiency with aerodynamic improvements and engine modifications to reduce fuel consumption and emissions. The second-generation Octavia further established the model as Škoda's cornerstone product, successfully competing with cars from more prestigious brands by offering superior space and equipment for the price point.
Skoda-Octavia.name: Second Generation (Type 1Z)

Skoda-Octavia.description: The third-generation Škoda Octavia was built on the Volkswagen Group's MQB platform shared with models like the Volkswagen Golf Mk7 and Audi A3 Mk3. Continuing the trend of its predecessors, the new Octavia grew again to approximately 4.66 meters in length, placing it firmly in mid-size territory despite often being marketed and priced as a compact car. Available in the traditional five-door liftback sedan and estate (Combi) body styles, the third-generation Octavia featured more distinctive styling with sharper lines and, initially, controversial split headlight design that was revised in a 2017 facelift. Engine options included gasoline units ranging from 1.0 to 2.0 liters, almost all turbocharged, and diesel options centered around the 1.6 TDI and 2.0 TDI, with power outputs ranging from 86 to 245 horsepower in the RS performance variants. Alternative powertrains expanded to include the G-TEC compressed natural gas (CNG) variant and, for the first time, a plug-in hybrid version in the later years of production. Transmission options included six-speed manuals, seven-speed DSG dual-clutch automatics, and, in some markets, a traditional automatic. The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and technology, featuring an available 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system, digital instrument cluster option, and expanded driver assistance systems including adaptive cruise control and lane-keeping assist. The 'Simply Clever' features that became a Škoda hallmark expanded to include numerous practical touches like an ice scraper mounted inside the fuel filler cap, a waste bin in the door pocket, and an umbrella under the passenger seat. Specialty variants continued with the Scout (later renamed Octavia Scout) offering raised ride height, all-wheel drive, and off-road styling elements, and the RS performance model available in both body styles with gasoline or diesel power. The third-generation Octavia became Škoda's global bestseller, successfully entering new markets including Australia and establishing itself as a rational alternative to both mainstream and premium compact and mid-size offerings.
Skoda-Octavia.name: Third Generation (Type 5E)

Skoda-Octavia.description: The fourth-generation Škoda Octavia continues on the Volkswagen Group's MQB platform, now in its evolved 'Evo' form shared with models like the Volkswagen Golf Mk8 and SEAT Leon Mk4. Growing yet again to approximately 4.69 meters in length, the latest Octavia offers interior space comparable to many full-size sedans despite its lower market positioning. Available in the traditional five-door liftback sedan and estate (Combi) body styles, the fourth-generation Octavia features more sophisticated styling with a coupe-like roofline for the liftback, standard LED lighting, and a more premium overall appearance. Engine options include gasoline units ranging from 1.0 to 2.0 liters, diesel options centered around the 2.0 TDI (now using twin-dosing SCR technology for reduced emissions), and a significantly expanded range of alternative powertrains including mild hybrid (eTSI), plug-in hybrid (iV), and compressed natural gas (G-TEC) variants. The plug-in hybrid combines a 1.4 TSI engine with an electric motor for a combined output of 204 horsepower and an electric-only range of up to 60 kilometers. Power outputs across the range span from 110 to 245 horsepower in the RS models, which for the first time include a plug-in hybrid option alongside the traditional gasoline variant. The interior represents a complete redesign with a more minimalist approach, featuring a free-standing central display up to 10 inches, an available 10.25-inch digital instrument cluster, and a new two-spoke steering wheel design (three-spoke for RS models). Physical buttons have been largely replaced by touch-sensitive controls and sliders, while material quality has improved throughout. Technology has advanced significantly with available features including a head-up display, wireless smartphone connectivity, and enhanced driver assistance systems providing Level 2 semi-autonomous driving capability. The 'Simply Clever' features have expanded further to include USB-C ports mounted on the rear-view mirror for dashboard cameras, a funnel built into the windshield washer fluid cap, and smartphone pockets on the seatbacks. Specialty variants continue with the Octavia Scout offering increased ground clearance, standard all-wheel drive, and rugged styling elements. The fourth-generation Octavia aims to bridge the gap between mainstream and premium segments more convincingly than ever, offering considerable space, technology, and refinement at competitive price points while expanding its appeal through greater powertrain electrification.
Skoda-Octavia.name: Fourth Generation (Type NX)

Skoda-Rapid.description: The Škoda Rapid revived a historical nameplate for the Czech brand, positioning itself as a budget-friendly model bridging the gap between the Fabia and Octavia in Škoda's European lineup. Built on the Volkswagen Group's PQ25 platform shared with models like the Volkswagen Polo Mk5, the European Rapid was available in two distinct body styles: the Rapid 'Spaceback,' a conventional five-door hatchback, and simply 'Rapid,' a sedan-like five-door liftback with a unique design featuring a separate trunk lid and window, though the entire tailgate opened as a hatch. Measuring approximately 4.48 meters in length (4.30 meters for the Spaceback), the Rapid offered generous interior space and cargo capacity relative to its class, continuing Škoda's tradition of providing larger-car practicality at smaller-car prices. Engine options included gasoline units ranging from 1.0 to 1.6 liters, including TSI turbocharged variants, and diesel options centered around the 1.4 and 1.6 TDI, with power outputs ranging from 75 to 125 horsepower. Transmission options included five and six-speed manuals and seven-speed DSG dual-clutch automatics depending on engine selection. The interior featured a straightforward, functional design prioritizing space and practicality over style, though material quality was improved in a 2017 facelift that also brought updated exterior styling and enhanced technology including a new infotainment system with smartphone connectivity. True to Škoda's 'Simply Clever' philosophy, the Rapid incorporated numerous practical features such as an ice scraper mounted inside the fuel filler cap and a ticket holder on the windshield. Positioned as a value-focused offering, the European Rapid found success in markets where practicality and affordability were prioritized over driving dynamics or luxury features, though it was eventually replaced by the more sophisticated Scala model as Škoda moved upmarket.
Skoda-Rapid.name: First Generation (European model)

Skoda-Rapid.description: Distinct from the European version, the Škoda Rapid developed for emerging markets like India and China was based on the Volkswagen Group's PQ25 platform but featured unique styling and positioning. Designed as a conventional three-box sedan rather than the liftback design of the European model, the Asian Rapid measured approximately 4.39 meters in length. In the Indian market, it competed in the highly competitive compact sedan segment, strategically sized just under 4.4 meters to qualify for lower tax rates. Engine options varied by market but typically included 1.2 TSI and 1.6 MPI gasoline units and a 1.5 TDI diesel in India, with power outputs ranging from 90 to 110 horsepower. Transmission options included five and six-speed manuals and a six-speed automatic or seven-speed DSG depending on market and engine. The interior featured a straightforward design with a focus on durability and space efficiency, with equipment levels tailored to market expectations, generally including features like air conditioning, power windows, and basic infotainment systems even in lower trims. A significant facelift in 2016 brought the model more in line with Škoda's contemporary design language, featuring an updated front end with wider headlights and the brand's signature grille. The Indian/Chinese Rapid was developed with local market requirements in mind, including enhanced ground clearance for poor road conditions, more robust suspension components, and simplified electronics for easier maintenance in regions with less developed service infrastructure. The model was eventually replaced by market-specific vehicles such as the Škoda Slavia in India, as the brand moved to more precisely tailored products for different regions based on the MQB-A0-IN platform developed specifically for emerging markets. Production continued until 2023 in China, longer than initially expected.
Skoda-Rapid.name: First Generation (Indian/Chinese Market)

Skoda-Scala.description: The Škoda Scala represents a new direction for the Czech brand in the compact hatchback segment, effectively replacing both the Rapid Spaceback and serving as a more direct competitor to established models like the Volkswagen Golf and Ford Focus. The name 'Scala,' derived from the Latin word for 'ladder' or 'stairs,' signals Škoda's ambition to move upmarket with this model. Built on the Volkswagen Group's MQB A0 platform shared with models like the Volkswagen Polo and SEAT Ibiza, the Scala maximizes the platform's potential by stretching it to its limits, resulting in a vehicle measuring approximately 4.36 meters in length—significantly larger than most MQB A0-based vehicles. The exterior design, led by Oliver Stefani, features more emotional styling than previous Škoda models, with a distinctive front end, sharp character lines, and extended glass area on the tailgate where the Škoda name is spelled out in individual letters rather than using the logo—a first for the brand in Europe. Engine options include 1.0 TSI three-cylinder and 1.5 TSI four-cylinder gasoline engines, plus a 1.6 TDI diesel in some markets, with power outputs ranging from 95 to 150 horsepower. Transmission options include five and six-speed manuals and a seven-speed DSG dual-clutch automatic depending on engine selection. The interior represents a significant step forward for Škoda, featuring a free-standing infotainment screen up to 9.2 inches, an optional 10.25-inch Virtual Cockpit digital instrument display, and higher quality materials than the Rapid it replaces. Consistent with Škoda's 'Simply Clever' philosophy, the Scala incorporates numerous practical features including an ice scraper in the fuel filler cap, an umbrella in the driver's door, and a ticket holder on the windshield.
Skoda-Scala.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Skoda-Scala.description: A facelift was unveiled in August 2023 alongside the Kamiq. The changes include redesigned front and rear fascias with the availability of matrix LED headlights, a sportier bodykit inspired from the Vision RS concept, new exterior colours and new alloy wheel designs. Inside, there is a redesigned control panel used to operate the HVAC system, more recycled materials used for the interior improvised standard interior equipment across the line-up, and extra Simply Clever features borrowed from other Škoda models. Škoda has also updated the trim structure and diesel engines are no longer available for the facelift model. The Scala continues to be built on the MQB A0 platform and offers the same practical interior space with class-leading rear legroom and a 467-liter cargo capacity.
Skoda-Scala.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Skoda-Superb.description: First generation Škoda Superb based on the Volkswagen Group B5 (PL45+) platform. Produced from 2001 to 2008 with a pre-facelift period from 2001-2006. Featured longitudinal front-engine, front-wheel-drive layout. The base model included 1.9 litre TDI or 2.0 litre petrol engines.
Skoda-Superb.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Skoda-Superb.description: Facelifted first generation Superb introduced in August 2006. Updated with Škoda's new radiator grille, headlights, side repeater indicators integrated into door mirrors, and C-shaped tail lights. Interior redesign included real wood trim in some models. Top of range 'Laurin & Klement' model introduced.
Skoda-Superb.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Skoda-Superb.description: All new second generation Superb unveiled at Geneva Motor Show March 2008. Based on stretched A5 Octavia platform (Volkswagen Group A6 PQ46). Features transverse engine layout and innovative 'TwinDoor' trunk lid. Estate version (Superb Combi) introduced in 2009.
Skoda-Superb.name: Second Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Skoda-Superb.description: Facelifted second generation Superb unveiled in Shanghai April 2013, released June 2013. Updated exterior design with new Škoda design language. Headlights fitted with integrated LED daytime running lights. TwinDoor mechanism updated for easier operation.
Skoda-Superb.name: Second Generation (Facelift)

Skoda-Superb.description: Third generation Superb based on Volkswagen Group MQB platform, unveiled February 2015 at Geneva Motor Show. Larger than second generation. Available as sedan and estate (Combi). Dealer deliveries began June 2015 for sedan, September for estate.
Skoda-Superb.name: Third Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Skoda-Superb.description: Facelifted third generation Superb unveiled in Bratislava May 2019. Added matrix full-LED headlights, Predictive Cruise Control and Emergency Assist. First plug-in hybrid variant (Superb iV) introduced with 1.4 litre petrol engine and 13 kWh battery.
Skoda-Superb.name: Third Generation (Facelift)

Skoda-Superb.description: Fourth generation Superb officially unveiled November 2, 2023. Based on stretched version of MQB Evo platform. Offered as estate (Combi) and liftback. Features new 'Modern Solid' design language with crystalline styling. First vehicles delivered in 2024.
Skoda-Superb.name: Fourth Generation

Smart-Smart-1.description: The Smart #1 (stylised as 'smart #1') is a battery electric subcompact crossover SUV developed and produced by Smart Automobile, a joint venture between Mercedes-Benz Group and Geely Holding. It is the first vehicle produced by the joint venture, based on the Sustainable Experience Architecture (SEA) electric vehicle platform developed by Geely. The production version was unveiled on 7 April 2022, with prices for the European market announced in September 2022. The exterior design features smooth, rounded forms with distinctive elements including a floating halo roof, concealed door handles, and frameless doors. Powered by a rear-mounted electric motor producing 200 kW (268 hp) and 343 Nm of torque in standard form, the #1 can accelerate from 0-100 km/h in 6.7 seconds. A performance-oriented Brabus variant adds a front motor for all-wheel drive, producing a combined 315 kW (422 hp) and enabling 0-100 km/h in just 3.9 seconds. A 66 kWh NMC battery provides WLTP range, with charging capability of up to 22 kW AC and 150 kW DC. The interior features a 12.8-inch touchscreen with customizable user interface, ambient lighting, and AI-based voice control. Available in multiple trim levels including Pure, Pure+, Pro, Pro+, Premium, Pulse, and Brabus.
Smart-Smart-1.name: First Generation

Subaru-Ascent.description: The Subaru Ascent represents the Japanese automaker's largest vehicle and its re-entry into the three-row midsize crossover SUV segment after the discontinued Tribeca. Developed specifically for the North American market where larger family vehicles are in high demand, the Ascent is built on Subaru's global platform that underpins most of its modern lineup. Measuring approximately 196 inches in length, the Ascent offers seating for up to eight passengers (or seven with optional second-row captain's chairs) and up to 86.5 cubic feet of cargo space with rear seats folded. Powered exclusively by a 2.4-liter turbocharged flat-four 'boxer' engine producing 260 horsepower and 277 lb-ft of torque, the Ascent comes standard with Subaru's Symmetrical All-Wheel Drive system and a continuously variable transmission (CVT) with an eight-speed manual mode. Towing capacity is rated at up to 5,000 pounds—competitive for the segment. The exterior design incorporates Subaru's familiar styling cues including the hexagonal grille and hawk-eye headlights, but scaled up to suit the vehicle's larger proportions. Inside, the Ascent offers a practical, family-focused interior with standard three-zone climate control, up to eight USB ports, 19 cup and bottle holders, and available features like a panoramic moonroof, heated and ventilated front seats, and second-row climate controls. Technology includes Subaru's Starlink infotainment system with standard Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility on a 6.5-inch or available 8-inch touchscreen. All models come standard with Subaru's EyeSight driver assistance package, which includes adaptive cruise control, pre-collision braking, lane departure warning, and lane-keeping assist. A significant update for the 2023 model year brought refreshed exterior styling, a larger 11.6-inch vertical touchscreen, wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, and the addition of Subaru's latest driver assistance technology, including a wide-angle mono camera to enhance the EyeSight system's field of view. The Ascent has positioned itself as a practical, safety-focused alternative in the competitive three-row crossover segment, appealing particularly to families who value all-weather capability, reliability, and safety over styling flair or performance dynamics.
Subaru-Ascent.name: First Generation

Subaru-BRZ.description: The first-generation Subaru BRZ was developed as a joint venture between Subaru and Toyota (which sold its version as the GT86, Scion FR-S, or Toyota 86 depending on market), designed as a back-to-basics, lightweight sports coupe emphasizing handling balance and driver engagement over outright power. The name 'BRZ' stands for Boxer engine, Rear-wheel drive, and Zenith. Built on a unique platform with the engine placed low and far back in the chassis to achieve an exceptionally low center of gravity and near-perfect weight distribution, the BRZ featured Subaru's naturally aspirated 2.0-liter FA20 flat-four 'boxer' engine with Toyota's D-4S direct and port injection system, producing 200 horsepower and 151 lb-ft of torque. Available with either a six-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission, the BRZ delivered 0-60 mph times of approximately 6.4 seconds—respectable but deliberately not class-leading, as the focus was on balanced handling rather than straight-line speed. The chassis featured MacPherson strut front suspension and double-wishbone rear suspension, with relatively narrow 215-width tires chosen specifically to allow controllable oversteer and enhance driver involvement. Weighing approximately 2,800 pounds, the BRZ was notably lighter than most contemporary sports cars. The exterior design featured classic sports car proportions with a long hood, low roofline, and short rear deck, while the 2+2 interior prioritized the driver with supportive sport seats, a small-diameter steering wheel, and simple, performance-oriented controls. A mid-cycle refresh in 2017 brought minor styling updates, revised suspension tuning, slight power increases for manual transmission models, and additional features including full-LED headlights. Special editions throughout the production run included the Series.Blue, Series.Yellow, and tS (tuned by STI) variants with unique styling elements and chassis refinements. The first-generation BRZ earned widespread acclaim from enthusiasts and automotive journalists for its pure driving experience in an era of increasingly computerized, high-horsepower sports cars, though some criticized its relative lack of torque and unchanging formula throughout its production run.
Subaru-BRZ.name: First Generation (ZC6)

Subaru-BRZ.description: The second-generation Subaru BRZ maintains the fundamental philosophy of its predecessor—a lightweight, affordable rear-wheel-drive sports coupe emphasizing handling balance and driver engagement—while addressing key criticisms and modernizing the package. Still developed jointly with Toyota (whose version is now exclusively called the GR86), the new BRZ features more distinctive styling with a larger grille, functional side vents, and a more aggressive overall appearance while maintaining similar proportions to the original. Addressing the most common complaint about the first generation, the BRZ now features a larger 2.4-liter FA24 naturally aspirated flat-four 'boxer' engine producing 228 horsepower and a more substantial 184 lb-ft of torque, with the torque peak occurring at a more accessible 3,700 rpm compared to the high-revving character of the previous engine. Available again with either a six-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission, the new BRZ offers improved acceleration with 0-60 mph times reduced to around 5.8 seconds for manual transmission models. Despite the larger engine, curb weight increases only marginally to approximately 2,815-2,881 pounds depending on configuration, thanks to the use of aluminum for the roof, hood, and fenders. The chassis features increased rigidity, with front lateral bending rigidity improved by 60 percent for more responsive handling. The interior has been modernized with a 7-inch digital instrument cluster featuring a unique track-focused display mode, an 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system with standard Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility, and improved materials while maintaining the driver-focused layout. For the first time, automatic transmission models include Subaru's EyeSight driver assistance system with adaptive cruise control, pre-collision braking, and lane departure warning, though this is not available with the manual transmission. The second-generation BRZ continues to offer a relatively rare proposition in the modern automotive landscape: an affordable, purpose-built sports car that prioritizes driver involvement over outright performance figures or luxury features, now with enough additional power and refinement to address the main criticisms of its well-regarded predecessor.
Subaru-BRZ.name: Second Generation (ZD8)

Subaru-Baja.description: The Subaru Baja is an all-wheel-drive, four-passenger coupé utility manufactured from 2002 to 2006. It combines the handling and passenger carrying characteristics of a traditional passenger car with the open-bed versatility and load capacity of a small pickup truck. The unibody design is based on the Subaru Legacy/Outback wagon platform. Production began at the Subaru of Indiana Automotive factory in Lafayette, Indiana on July 18, 2002 as a 2003 model. The name 'Baja' derives from the Baja California peninsula, home to the Baja 1000 off-road race. Model years include 2003 (launch), 2004 (turbocharged model introduction), 2005 (ride height updates), and 2006 (final model year with enhanced optional packages). Production ended in April 2006, but dealers sold remaining 2006 inventory through February 2008.
Subaru-Baja.name: First Generation

Subaru-Crosstrek.description: The first-generation Subaru Crosstrek (initially called the XV Crosstrek in North America until 2015) was essentially a lifted and ruggedized version of the Impreza hatchback, positioned as a compact crossover SUV. Built on the same platform as the fourth-generation Impreza, the Crosstrek featured a raised suspension providing 8.7 inches of ground clearance (3.7 inches more than the standard Impreza), unique 17-inch wheels, more aggressive body cladding, and roof rails as standard equipment. Powered by a naturally aspirated 2.0-liter flat-four 'boxer' engine producing 148 horsepower and 145 lb-ft of torque, the Crosstrek came standard with Subaru's Symmetrical All-Wheel Drive system paired with either a five-speed manual or Lineartronic continuously variable transmission (CVT). In 2014, a gas-electric hybrid variant was introduced in select markets, combining the 2.0-liter engine with a 13.4 horsepower electric motor for marginally improved fuel economy but limited electric-only operation. The interior was largely identical to the Impreza, featuring a straightforward, functional design with cloth or optional leather seating, a multi-function display atop the center stack, and available features including navigation, heated seats, and a power moonroof. The cargo area offered 22.3 cubic feet of space behind the rear seats, expanding to 51.9 cubic feet with the rear seats folded—modest for a crossover but practical for its compact exterior dimensions. Standard safety features included seven airbags, anti-lock brakes, and stability control, with Subaru's EyeSight driver assistance system becoming available later in the generation. The first-generation Crosstrek successfully captured buyers looking for light off-road capability and all-weather performance in a compact, efficient package, appealing particularly to outdoor enthusiasts and those living in regions with challenging weather conditions.
Subaru-Crosstrek.name: First Generation

Subaru-Crosstrek.description: The second-generation Subaru Crosstrek was built on the Subaru Global Platform first introduced with the fifth-generation Impreza, offering increased rigidity, improved crash protection, and enhanced ride quality. Following the same formula as its predecessor, the new Crosstrek maintained its lifted stance with 8.7 inches of ground clearance but featured more refined styling with a more prominent grille, hawk-eye headlights, and more sophisticated body cladding, while maintaining clear visual connections to the Impreza hatchback upon which it was based. Initially powered by the same 2.0-liter flat-four 'boxer' engine as before, now producing 152 horsepower and 145 lb-ft of torque, the Crosstrek was offered with either a six-speed manual or a continuously variable transmission (CVT), both paired with Subaru's Symmetrical All-Wheel Drive system. Responding to feedback that the previous model was underpowered, Subaru added an optional 2.5-liter flat-four producing 182 horsepower and 176 lb-ft of torque for higher trim levels beginning in 2021. A plug-in hybrid variant called the Crosstrek Hybrid (or Crosstrek e-Boxer in some markets) combined a 2.0-liter engine with electric motors and a small battery enabling approximately 17 miles of electric-only operation. The interior saw significant improvements with higher quality materials, a more modern design, and enhanced technology including a standard 6.5-inch or available 8-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. Cargo capacity increased slightly to 20.8 cubic feet behind the rear seats, expanding to 55.3 cubic feet with the seats folded. Safety features expanded substantially with Subaru's EyeSight driver assistance system becoming standard on all CVT-equipped models, offering adaptive cruise control, pre-collision braking, lane departure warning, and lane-keeping assist. The second-generation Crosstrek built upon the success of its predecessor with improved refinement, enhanced capability, and a more modern feature set.
Subaru-Crosstrek.name: Second Generation

Subaru-Crosstrek.description: The third-generation Subaru Crosstrek, introduced for the 2023 model year, continues the model's successful formula as a lifted, ruggedized compact crossover based on the latest Impreza platform, but with more distinctive styling and features to further differentiate it from its hatchback sibling. The exterior design features a more aggressive appearance with a larger grille, redesigned headlights, more prominent wheel arch cladding, and an overall more substantial presence, though the basic shape and dimensions remain similar to the previous generation. Ground clearance remains a class-leading 8.7 inches, maintaining the model's off-road capability. Engine options include a revised 2.0-liter flat-four 'boxer' producing 152 horsepower and 145 lb-ft of torque in base models, and a 2.5-liter flat-four developing 182 horsepower and 178 lb-ft of torque in higher trim levels. Both engines are paired with Subaru's Lineartronic continuously variable transmission (CVT) and Symmetrical All-Wheel Drive system, with the manual transmission option eliminated in the North American market. A hybrid variant continues in select markets. The interior features a more upscale design with improved materials, a standard 7-inch or available 11.6-inch vertical touchscreen infotainment system, and expanded connectivity options including wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. Cargo space remains practical at approximately 20 cubic feet behind the rear seats and 55 cubic feet with the seats folded. Safety technology has been enhanced with the latest version of Subaru's EyeSight driver assistance system now standard across all models, featuring improved cameras with a wider field of view and enhanced processing for more natural-feeling operation in various driving conditions. New available features include a 360-degree camera system, wireless smartphone charging, and dual-zone automatic climate control. The third-generation Crosstrek has evolved to more clearly establish its own identity separate from the Impreza while maintaining the core values of capability, reliability, and all-weather performance that have made it a success.
Subaru-Crosstrek.name: Third Generation

Subaru-Forester.description: The first-generation Subaru Forester pioneered the crossover SUV concept, blending station wagon practicality with SUV capability before the term 'crossover' was widely used. Built on the Impreza platform but with a raised ride height and more rugged styling, the original Forester was marketed as a 'SUV-tough, car-easy' vehicle. Measuring approximately 175 inches in length, the Forester featured a boxy, utilitarian design with large windows for excellent visibility. Powered by a 2.5-liter flat-four 'boxer' engine producing 165 horsepower and 162 lb-ft of torque in most markets, the Forester came standard with Subaru's symmetrical all-wheel-drive system paired with either a five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmission. In Japan and some other markets, turbocharged variants were available with up to 240 horsepower. Ground clearance of 7.5 inches provided capability on unpaved roads and in adverse weather conditions without the compromised on-road handling of traditional truck-based SUVs. The interior was straightforward and functional, prioritizing practicality over style, with standard features including air conditioning, power windows, and a four-speaker stereo. Higher trim levels added amenities like leather upholstery, a power moonroof, and upgraded audio systems. Safety features were advanced for the time, with standard dual front airbags, antilock brakes, and side-impact door beams. The cargo area offered 26.9 cubic feet of space behind the rear seats, expanding to 64.6 cubic feet with the seats folded. The first-generation Forester established a winning formula that would define the model through subsequent generations: combining car-like handling and efficiency with SUV versatility and all-weather capability.
Subaru-Forester.name: First Generation (SF)

Subaru-Forester.description: The second-generation Subaru Forester maintained the successful formula of its predecessor while refining the package with improved space, performance, and features. Still based on the Impreza platform, the new Forester grew slightly in all dimensions but preserved its compact, boxy proportions with practicality and visibility as priorities. The exterior featured more refined styling with smoother lines and better integration of the traditional SUV elements. Engine options in most markets centered around a revised 2.5-liter flat-four 'boxer' engine, now producing 173 horsepower in naturally aspirated form, while the turbocharged XT variant offered 210 horsepower (later increased to 224 horsepower) and a more performance-oriented character. All models featured Subaru's symmetrical all-wheel drive system, paired with either a five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmission. Ground clearance increased to 8.1 inches, enhancing off-road capability. The interior saw significant improvements in material quality and design, with a more modern dashboard layout, enhanced sound insulation, and additional features including available heated seats and mirrors, automatic climate control, and a premium audio system. Safety features expanded to include side-impact airbags and available stability control. Cargo capacity increased to 30.7 cubic feet behind the rear seats and 68.6 cubic feet with the seats folded. A facelift in 2006 brought updated styling with a new grille and headlights, along with interior refinements and expanded feature availability. The second-generation Forester built upon the strengths of the original, offering enhanced refinement and performance while maintaining its position as a practical, capable alternative to both conventional wagons and traditional SUVs, appealing particularly to buyers in regions with challenging weather and road conditions.
Subaru-Forester.name: Second Generation (SG)

Subaru-Forester.description: The third-generation Subaru Forester represented a more significant evolution, growing substantially in size and adopting more traditional SUV proportions while still maintaining car-like handling characteristics. Built on a new platform with a longer wheelbase and wider track, the new Forester measured approximately 179 inches in length and featured a taller, more upright design with increased ground clearance of 8.7 inches. Engine options remained centered around the 2.5-liter flat-four 'boxer' engine, producing 170 horsepower in naturally aspirated form, while the turbocharged XT variant offered 224 horsepower, both paired with Subaru's symmetrical all-wheel drive system. Transmission options included a five-speed manual or four-speed automatic, with the latter replaced by a more modern continuously variable transmission (CVT) in later model years. The interior grew significantly in all dimensions, particularly rear seat legroom and cargo capacity, which increased to 33.5 cubic feet behind the rear seats and 68.3 cubic feet with the seats folded. Design and material quality improved with a more contemporary dashboard layout, available leather upholstery, and enhanced technology including an available navigation system and premium Harman Kardon audio. Safety features expanded to include standard electronic stability control, front side airbags, and side curtain airbags, with a backup camera becoming available on higher trim levels. A notable new feature was an optional panoramic moonroof that extended over both front and rear seats, providing an open, airy feeling to the cabin. This generation marked a shift toward a more mainstream crossover SUV positioning for the Forester, moving away from its wagon-like origins while maintaining Subaru's core values of all-weather capability, practicality, and safety, helping the model achieve broader appeal in the rapidly growing crossover segment.
Subaru-Forester.name: Third Generation (SH)

Subaru-Forester.description: The fourth-generation Subaru Forester continued the model's evolution toward a more conventional crossover SUV while maintaining its distinctive Subaru characteristics. Built on a revised version of the previous platform with a slightly longer wheelbase, the new Forester maintained similar exterior dimensions but featured a more aerodynamic design with smoother lines, a more steeply raked windshield, and better integration of the increased ground clearance, which remained at 8.7 inches. Engine options included an updated 2.5-liter naturally aspirated flat-four 'boxer' engine producing 170 horsepower and 174 lb-ft of torque, now featuring more efficient timing for improved fuel economy, while the XT model received a new 2.0-liter turbocharged flat-four producing 250 horsepower and 258 lb-ft of torque. A six-speed manual transmission was available on base models, but most Foresters were equipped with Subaru's Lineartronic continuously variable transmission (CVT), which now featured simulated gear steps in the XT model to provide a more conventional driving feel. All models continued to feature Subaru's symmetrical all-wheel drive system as standard. The interior saw significant improvements in both design and material quality, with reduced noise levels, more supportive seats, and expanded technology offerings including a touchscreen infotainment system with available navigation, a premium Harman Kardon audio system, and a power rear liftgate. Passenger space increased in all dimensions, while cargo capacity expanded to 34.4 cubic feet behind the rear seats and 74.7 cubic feet with the seats folded. Safety features grew to include Subaru's EyeSight driver assistance system on higher trim levels, offering adaptive cruise control, pre-collision braking, and lane departure warning. The fourth-generation Forester found success by balancing increased refinement and technology with the practical, capable characteristics that had defined the model from its inception, helping it become one of Subaru's best-selling vehicles globally.
Subaru-Forester.name: Fourth Generation (SJ)

Subaru-Forester.description: The fifth-generation Subaru Forester represents an evolutionary approach to the successful formula, now built on the Subaru Global Platform that underpins most of the company's modern lineup. Exterior dimensions remain similar to the previous generation, but with a longer wheelbase providing enhanced interior space, particularly for rear passengers. The design maintains the practical, somewhat boxy proportions that have defined the Forester, prioritizing visibility, interior space, and functionality over trendy styling. Ground clearance remains a class-leading 8.7 inches, supporting the vehicle's all-weather, all-terrain capability.
