Powertrain options were initially streamlined to a single 2.5-liter naturally aspirated flat-four 'boxer' engine producing 182 horsepower and 176 lb-ft of torque, paired exclusively with a continuously variable transmission (CVT) and Subaru's symmetrical all-wheel drive system, with the turbocharged XT variant dropped from the lineup. However, a new hybrid model called the Forester e-Boxer was introduced in some markets, combining a 2.0-liter engine with an electric motor for improved efficiency. For the 2022 model year, a wilderness-focused trim level was introduced, featuring increased ground clearance (9.2 inches), all-terrain tires, and revised gearing for enhanced off-road capability. The interior showcases a more premium design with higher quality materials, reduced noise levels, and enhanced technology including a standard dual-screen infotainment system with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. Cargo capacity remains generous at 35.4 cubic feet behind the rear seats and 76.1 cubic feet with the seats folded. Safety technology expanded with Subaru's EyeSight driver assistance system now standard across all trim levels, offering adaptive cruise control, pre-collision braking, lane departure warning, and lane-keeping assist, while the available DriverFocus system uses facial recognition technology to identify signs of driver fatigue or distraction. A facelift for the 2022 model year brought updated styling with a more prominent grille, redesigned headlights, and expanded feature content. The fifth-generation Forester continues the model's tradition of blending practical design, all-weather capability, and value with increased refinement and technology, maintaining its position as one of Subaru's core models.
Subaru-Forester.name: Fifth Generation (SK)

Subaru-Forester.description: The sixth-generation Subaru Forester represents a dramatic update for 2025, offering more passenger space and a quieter ride than the previous model. The new generation features a completely redesigned exterior with more defined styling while maintaining the Forester's practical dimensions and capabilities. The 2025 Forester is powered by an updated version of its 2.5-liter four-cylinder flat-four 'boxer' engine producing 180 horsepower and 178 lb-ft of torque, which is essentially the same as the previous generation. For the first time, the Forester lineup offers a new series-parallel hybrid powertrain that integrates a 2.5-liter Subaru Boxer engine and electric motors with Subaru Symmetrical All-Wheel Drive. The hybrid model delivers 194 total system horsepower, coupling Subaru's legendary off-road capability with up to 40 percent better fuel efficiency compared to the non-hybrid counterpart. The redesigned exterior maintains the vehicle's characteristic boxy proportions while incorporating more contemporary styling elements, and ground clearance remains competitive for the class. The interior features updated technology and materials consistent with Subaru's design evolution, continuing to prioritize practicality, visibility, and all-weather capability. The sixth-generation Forester maintains the model's tradition of blending practical design, all-weather capability, and increasing electrification with advanced technology, positioning it for future market demands.
Subaru-Forester.name: Sixth Generation (SL)

Subaru-Impreza.description: The first-generation Subaru Impreza established many of the model's defining characteristics, including compact dimensions, standard all-wheel drive, and horizontally opposed 'boxer' engines. Available in four-door sedan (GC), five-door wagon (GF), and two-door coupe (GM) body styles, the original Impreza featured conservative styling with a focus on functionality rather than aesthetics. Engine options varied by market but typically included 1.6, 1.8, and 2.2-liter naturally aspirated flat-four engines, with the performance-oriented WRX variant (primarily available outside North America) featuring a turbocharged 2.0-liter unit producing up to 250 horsepower. The interior prioritized practicality with straightforward controls, good visibility, and reasonable space efficiency for its compact footprint. The introduction of the rally-derived WRX and later STI performance variants helped establish Subaru's motorsport pedigree, with the Impreza winning multiple World Rally Championship titles during this generation. While the standard Impreza competed with mainstream compact cars like the Honda Civic and Toyota Corolla, its standard all-wheel drive system and unique boxer engine layout gave it distinct advantages in adverse weather conditions and helped establish a loyal following, particularly in regions with challenging climates.
Subaru-Impreza.name: First Generation (GC/GF/GM)

Subaru-Impreza.description: The second-generation Subaru Impreza evolved the formula established by its predecessor, maintaining the core characteristics of all-wheel drive and boxer engines while updating the styling and technology. Available again in sedan (GD) and wagon (GG) body styles, with the coupe variant discontinued, the new Impreza featured more distinctive styling with prominent round headlights (often referred to as 'bug eyes') in its initial form, later revised in 2003 and 2005 facelifts. Engine options continued to include various displacements of naturally aspirated flat-four engines, while the WRX and STI performance models became officially available in North America for the first time, featuring turbocharged 2.0 or 2.5-liter engines producing between 227 and 300 horsepower depending on market and specification. All models featured Subaru's symmetrical all-wheel drive system, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. The interior saw improvements in material quality and design compared to the first generation, though it maintained a focus on functionality over luxury. This generation coincided with increased awareness of the Impreza in popular culture, particularly through rally racing, motorsports video games, and films. The wagon body style's practicality combined with the performance potential of the WRX and STI variants helped the Impreza develop a cult following among enthusiasts seeking everyday usability alongside performance capabilities. A special feature of the STI variant was the Driver Controlled Center Differential (DCCD), allowing manual adjustment of power distribution between front and rear axles.
Subaru-Impreza.name: Second Generation (GD/GG)

Subaru-Impreza.description: The third-generation Subaru Impreza represented a significant redesign, with a focus on broadening the model's appeal beyond its core enthusiast base. Available in four-door sedan (GE) and five-door hatchback (GH) body styles—with the traditional wagon replaced by a more compact hatchback design—the new Impreza featured more mainstream styling and improved interior space efficiency. Engine options in most markets centered around a 2.5-liter naturally aspirated flat-four producing approximately 170 horsepower in standard models, while the WRX and STI variants (which began to be marketed as separate models in some regions) continued with turbocharged power plants producing up to 305 horsepower. All models maintained Subaru's symmetrical all-wheel drive system as standard, paired with manual or automatic transmissions, with the WRX STI featuring the sophisticated Driver Controlled Center Differential (DCCD) system. The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and feature content, with available amenities including navigation, premium audio, and enhanced safety features. This generation marked a shift toward more refined road manners and everyday usability, somewhat at the expense of the raw, rally-derived character that defined earlier generations—a change that received mixed reactions from traditional enthusiasts but helped broaden the model's appeal to a wider audience. Notable changes during this generation's run included the introduction of a redesigned WRX for the 2009 model year with wider bodywork and more aggressive styling to differentiate it from the standard Impreza.
Subaru-Impreza.name: Third Generation (GE/GH/GR/GV)

Subaru-Impreza.description: The fourth-generation Subaru Impreza continued the model's evolution toward the mainstream compact car segment while maintaining the distinctive Subaru characteristics of standard all-wheel drive and boxer engines. Available in four-door sedan (GJ) and five-door hatchback (GP) body styles, the new Impreza featured more aerodynamic styling with smoother lines and a more cohesive overall design compared to its predecessor. Engine options were streamlined in most markets to a single 2.0-liter naturally aspirated flat-four producing approximately 148 horsepower, representing a decrease in displacement and power compared to the previous generation but offering improved fuel efficiency. All models continued to feature Subaru's symmetrical all-wheel drive system as standard, paired with either a five-speed manual or continuously variable transmission (CVT). The interior saw improvements in material quality, design, and technology integration, with available features including touchscreen infotainment systems with smartphone connectivity, advanced safety features, and premium audio. This generation marked the further separation of the standard Impreza from its high-performance WRX and STI variants, which continued on the previous platform for several years before transitioning to their own distinct models while maintaining the mechanical DNA established by the Impreza. A key focus of this generation was improved fuel economy and emissions performance, achieved through reduced weight, more efficient powertrains, and aerodynamic enhancements, addressing one of the traditional criticisms of all-wheel drive vehicles. Safety became a more prominent selling point, with the Impreza achieving top ratings in crash tests and offering Subaru's EyeSight driver assistance system on higher trim levels.
Subaru-Impreza.name: Fourth Generation (GJ/GP)

Subaru-Impreza.description: The fifth-generation Subaru Impreza represented a significant advancement, being the first model built on the Subaru Global Platform that would eventually underpin most of the company's lineup. Available in four-door sedan (GK) and five-door hatchback (GT) body styles, the new Impreza featured evolutionary styling that maintained family resemblance to its predecessor while incorporating more sophisticated design elements. The platform provided improved structural rigidity, contributing to enhanced handling, ride quality, and crash protection. Engine options continued to center around a revised 2.0-liter naturally aspirated flat-four producing approximately 152 horsepower, paired with either a six-speed manual or continuously variable transmission (CVT) and standard symmetrical all-wheel drive across all models. The interior saw substantial improvements in material quality, design, and technology, featuring a standard touchscreen infotainment system with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility, available harman/kardon premium audio, and expanded comfort features. Safety technology became a key selling point, with Subaru's EyeSight driver assistance system available across most of the lineup, offering adaptive cruise control, pre-collision braking, and lane-keeping assist. This generation marked a more pronounced separation from the WRX and STI performance models, which were now marketed as entirely separate vehicles despite sharing the Impreza's basic engineering philosophy. The fifth-generation Impreza continued to appeal to buyers seeking the all-weather capability and safety of all-wheel drive in a compact, efficient package, particularly in regions with challenging climate conditions where Subaru traditionally enjoyed strong market presence.
Subaru-Impreza.name: Fifth Generation (GK/GT)

Subaru-Impreza.description: The sixth-generation Subaru Impreza, introduced for the 2023 model year, represents a focused refinement of the model with some significant strategic changes. Available exclusively as a five-door hatchback in the North American market (with the sedan body style discontinued), the new Impreza maintains its compact dimensions while featuring more expressive styling with sculpted body panels, a broader stance, and more distinctive lighting elements. Built on an enhanced version of the Subaru Global Platform, the new Impreza benefits from increased rigidity and improved noise reduction. Engine options in most markets include a carried-over 2.0-liter naturally aspirated flat-four producing 152 horsepower and a new RS trim featuring a 2.5-liter flat-four with 182 horsepower, marking the return of the RS designation not seen on the Impreza since the early 2000s. All models continue to feature Subaru's symmetrical all-wheel drive system as standard, now paired exclusively with a continuously variable transmission (CVT) with simulated gear steps, as the manual transmission option has been eliminated in most markets. The interior features a modernized design with a standard 7-inch or available 11.6-inch vertical touchscreen infotainment system, improved materials, and enhanced connectivity options including wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. Safety technology remains a priority with Subaru's EyeSight driver assistance system standard across all trim levels, now featuring enhanced cameras with a wider field of view and improved processing for more natural operation in various driving conditions. The sixth-generation Impreza continues to appeal to buyers seeking the security of all-wheel drive and Subaru's reputation for reliability and safety in a compact, practical package, though the elimination of the sedan body style and manual transmission option represents a streamlining of the lineup to focus on the configurations most popular with customers.
Subaru-Impreza.name: Sixth Generation (G50)

Subaru-Legacy.description: The first-generation Subaru Legacy established the model as the brand's mid-size flagship, designed to compete with mainstream offerings like the Honda Accord and Toyota Camry while featuring Subaru's distinctive boxer engines and available all-wheel drive. Available in four-door sedan (BC) and five-door wagon (BF/BJ) body styles, the Legacy featured clean, conservative styling typical of Japanese sedans of the era. Engine options included 2.0 and 2.2-liter naturally aspirated flat-four engines, with some markets receiving a turbocharged 2.0-liter variant in performance-oriented RS models. Transmissions included five-speed manual and four-speed automatic options, with front-wheel drive standard on base models in some markets and all-wheel drive either optional or standard depending on trim and region. The interior prioritized functionality with straightforward controls, good visibility, and reasonable space for its exterior dimensions. The Legacy made its mark in motorsport, particularly in long-distance rally events like Australia's Tasmanian Rally, helping establish Subaru's competition credentials before the brand's later World Rally Championship success with the Impreza. This generation established the Legacy's reputation for offering a unique combination of all-weather capability, practical design, and reliability that would define the model through subsequent iterations.
Subaru-Legacy.name: First Generation (BC/BF/BJ)

Subaru-Legacy.description: The second-generation Subaru Legacy built upon the foundation established by its predecessor, maintaining the combination of mid-size dimensions, boxer engines, and all-wheel drive capability while introducing more refined styling and enhanced features. Available again in four-door sedan (BD) and five-door wagon (BG) body styles, the new Legacy featured a more aerodynamic design with smoother lines and improved proportions. Engine options expanded to include 2.0, 2.2, and 2.5-liter naturally aspirated flat-four engines, with turbocharged variants available in performance models like the GT and RS in various markets. All-wheel drive became standard across most of the lineup globally, paired with either five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmissions. The interior saw improvements in material quality, design, and feature content, offering a more premium feel than the previous generation. This era introduced the Legacy GT with the 2.5-liter turbocharged engine, establishing the performance-oriented variant that would become a mainstay of the lineup. In Japan and some other markets, a specialized variant called the Legacy Touring Wagon GT-B featured unique styling, upgraded suspension by Bilstein, and enhanced performance. The second-generation Legacy further developed the model's distinctive positioning as a more capable alternative to mainstream mid-size cars, attracting buyers seeking all-weather performance and practicality, particularly in regions with challenging climate conditions.
Subaru-Legacy.name: Second Generation (BD/BG/BK)

Subaru-Legacy.description: The third-generation Subaru Legacy represented a significant evolution in design and refinement, moving the model upmarket while maintaining its core characteristics of boxer engines and all-wheel drive capability. Available in four-door sedan (BE) and five-door wagon (BH) body styles, the new Legacy featured more distinctive styling with flared fenders, quad headlights, and a more substantial overall presence. Engine options centered around 2.0, 2.5, and 3.0-liter flat-four and flat-six engines, with naturally aspirated and turbocharged variants depending on market and trim level. The H6 (six-cylinder boxer) engine was introduced in this generation as a smooth, powerful option for higher-end models. All-wheel drive was standard across the lineup globally, now with more advanced systems featuring variable torque distribution on some models. Transmission options included five-speed manual and four or five-speed automatic transmissions. The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and feature content, with a focus on creating a more premium environment to compete with entry-level luxury offerings. Performance variants like the B4 and GT models continued, offering turbocharged engines with up to 280 horsepower in some markets. Special editions included the Blitzen, developed in collaboration with Porsche Design, featuring unique styling elements and premium equipment. The third-generation Legacy successfully elevated the model's positioning, offering a compelling blend of performance, all-weather capability, and refinement that helped differentiate it from mainstream competitors while establishing it as a credible alternative to entry-level luxury offerings.
Subaru-Legacy.name: Third Generation (BE/BH)

Subaru-Legacy.description: The fourth-generation Subaru Legacy continued the model's evolution toward increased refinement and premium positioning while maintaining the distinctive characteristics of boxer engines and all-wheel drive. Available in four-door sedan (BL) and five-door wagon (BP) body styles, the new Legacy featured more sophisticated styling with a sleeker profile, prominent fenders, and a more upscale overall appearance. Engine options varied by market but typically included 2.0, 2.5, and 3.0-liter naturally aspirated and turbocharged flat-four and flat-six engines, with power outputs ranging from approximately 165 to 250 horsepower in mainstream variants and up to 280 horsepower in specialized performance models. All-wheel drive remained standard across the lineup, now with more advanced electronic control systems on higher-end models. Transmission options included five-speed manual, four and five-speed automatic, and continuously variable transmissions depending on market and engine. The interior featured a significant redesign with improved materials, more sophisticated styling, and enhanced technology including available navigation systems, premium audio, and expanded safety features. Performance variants like the GT and spec.B models offered enhanced handling through sport-tuned suspensions, larger brakes, and more aggressive styling. This generation saw the introduction of SI-Drive on some models, allowing drivers to select different engine response profiles. Special editions included the GT spec.B with Bilstein suspensions, unique interior appointments, and performance enhancements. The fourth-generation Legacy successfully balanced increasing luxury and refinement with the performance capabilities that had defined earlier generations, establishing a distinct identity in the competitive mid-size segment.
Subaru-Legacy.name: Fourth Generation (BL/BP)

Subaru-Legacy.description: The fifth-generation Subaru Legacy marked a more mainstream approach for the model, with increased dimensions, more conservative styling, and a greater focus on comfort and interior space. Available in four-door sedan (BM) and, in markets outside North America, five-door wagon (BR) body styles (with the wagon marketed as the Outback in North America regardless of ride height), the new Legacy grew significantly in size to compete more directly with mid-size segment leaders. Engine options were streamlined in many markets to focus on a 2.5-liter naturally aspirated flat-four and a 3.6-liter flat-six, with turbocharged options reduced or eliminated in some regions. All-wheel drive remained standard across the lineup, paired with either a six-speed manual (in some markets) or Subaru's Lineartronic continuously variable transmission (CVT). The interior saw the most dramatic changes, with substantially increased passenger space, particularly in rear seat legroom, and a more conventional design focused on mainstream appeal rather than the sporty character of previous generations. Technology features expanded to include available touchscreen infotainment systems, advanced safety features like Subaru's EyeSight driver assistance system, and enhanced connectivity options. This generation represented Subaru's effort to capture a larger share of the mainstream mid-size sedan market, particularly in North America, by offering more competitive interior space and comfort features while maintaining the all-weather capability and safety focus that distinguished the brand. While this approach broadened the model's appeal to family sedan buyers, some enthusiasts lamented the reduction in performance variants and the more conservative overall character compared to previous generations.
Subaru-Legacy.name: Fifth Generation (BM/BR)

Subaru-Legacy.description: The sixth-generation Subaru Legacy refined the mainstream approach established by its predecessor, with evolutionary styling changes and a continued focus on interior space, comfort, and safety. Available primarily as a four-door sedan in most markets (with the wagon version marketed exclusively as the Outback), the new Legacy maintained similar exterior dimensions to the fifth generation but featured more refined styling with a sleeker profile, more pronounced character lines, and updated lighting elements. Engine options in most markets included a revised 2.5-liter naturally aspirated flat-four and a 3.6-liter flat-six, both paired with Subaru's Lineartronic continuously variable transmission (CVT) and standard symmetrical all-wheel drive. The interior saw improvements in material quality, design, and technology integration, featuring a large central touchscreen (up to 7 inches) in the dashboard, improved connectivity options, and enhanced active safety features including Subaru's more advanced EyeSight driver assistance system. A key focus of this generation was improved refinement, with enhanced sound insulation, more rigid body structure, and revised suspension tuning providing a quieter, more composed ride quality. Safety became an even more prominent selling point, with the Legacy achieving top ratings in crash tests and offering an expanded suite of driver assistance features. This generation continued the Legacy's transition from a somewhat niche offering with a focus on performance and all-weather capability to a more mainstream mid-size sedan competing directly with segment leaders like the Honda Accord and Toyota Camry, while maintaining the all-wheel drive advantage that distinguished it from most competitors.
Subaru-Legacy.name: Sixth Generation (BN/BS)

Subaru-Legacy.description: The seventh-generation Subaru Legacy, built on the Subaru Global Platform that underpins most of the company's modern lineup, represents an evolutionary approach to styling with a revolutionary improvement in structural rigidity, technology, and refinement. Available exclusively as a four-door sedan (with the wagon body style reserved for the Outback crossover), the new Legacy maintains similar exterior dimensions to its predecessor but features more confident styling with cleaner lines, a more prominent grille, and enhanced detailing. Engine options have been revamped to include a standard 2.5-liter naturally aspirated flat-four producing 182 horsepower and, replacing the old flat-six, a 2.4-liter turbocharged flat-four delivering 260 horsepower, both paired with a continuously variable transmission (CVT) and Subaru's symmetrical all-wheel drive system. The interior represents the most significant advancement, featuring a more premium design with higher quality materials and, on most trim levels, a portrait-oriented 11.6-inch touchscreen infotainment system dominating the center stack, offering improved connectivity, navigation, and vehicle controls. Passenger space remains generous, with a focus on long-distance comfort through improved seating, reduced noise levels, and enhanced ride quality. Safety technology has been further expanded with the latest version of Subaru's EyeSight driver assistance system now standard across all models, offering adaptive cruise control, lane-keeping assist, and pre-collision braking, with higher trim levels adding driver monitoring systems that can detect driver fatigue or distraction. The seventh-generation Legacy continues to appeal to buyers seeking the security of all-wheel drive and Subaru's reputation for reliability and safety in a traditional sedan format, offering a compelling alternative in a segment increasingly abandoned by competitors as the market shifts toward crossovers and SUVs. Subaru of America announced that 2025 will be the last model year for the Legacy, with production ending in Japan in June 2020 for the worldwide market.
Subaru-Legacy.name: Seventh Generation (BW)

Subaru-Outback.description: The first-generation Subaru Outback pioneered what would become the crossover segment, essentially created by adding raised suspension, body cladding, and a more rugged appearance to the Legacy wagon. Initially marketed as the 'Legacy Grand Wagon' in Japan and 'Legacy Outback' elsewhere, the model featured 7.3 inches of ground clearance, protective lower body cladding, larger tires, and a more outdoors-oriented image than the standard Legacy. Powered by either a 2.2-liter or 2.5-liter flat-four 'boxer' engine depending on market and model year, with power outputs ranging from 135 to 165 horsepower, the Outback came standard with Subaru's all-wheel drive system paired with either a five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmission. The interior was largely identical to the Legacy wagon, featuring practical design with reasonable space for passengers and cargo. The model was famously promoted by Australian actor Paul Hogan of 'Crocodile Dundee' fame, establishing the rugged, adventurous image that would define the Outback through subsequent generations. This innovative 'world's first sport utility wagon' approach provided much of the capability and practicality of the increasingly popular SUVs of the era but with better fuel economy, handling, and ride comfort due to its car-based platform—a formula that would eventually be adopted by numerous manufacturers as the crossover segment exploded in popularity.
Subaru-Outback.name: First Generation (BG)

Subaru-Outback.description: The second-generation Subaru Outback built upon the successful formula established by its predecessor, growing slightly in size and capability while maintaining the core concept of a Legacy wagon with increased ground clearance and rugged styling elements. Now more distinctly positioned as its own model rather than simply a trim level of the Legacy, the Outback featured more aggressive styling differentiation with larger fog lights, more substantial body cladding, and unique interior treatments. Ground clearance increased to 7.9 inches, enhancing off-road capability without significantly compromising on-road handling. Engine options expanded to include a 2.5-liter flat-four as the standard offering in most markets, with the introduction of a more powerful 3.0-liter flat-six (H6) in higher-end models providing 212 horsepower—the first six-cylinder engine in a Subaru passenger vehicle. All-wheel drive remained standard across the lineup, with more advanced systems featuring variable torque distribution on some models. Transmission options included five-speed manual and four-speed automatic, with the H6 exclusively paired with the automatic. The interior saw improvements in material quality, design, and feature content, with available amenities including leather upholstery, premium audio, and enhanced safety features. A sedan version, the Outback SUS (Sport Utility Sedan), was offered in North America, applying the same raised ride height and rugged styling to the Legacy sedan body style. Special editions included the VDC (Vehicle Dynamics Control) model with advanced stability control and the L.L.Bean edition featuring unique styling and premium features. The second-generation Outback further established the model's reputation for offering a compelling blend of all-weather capability, light off-road performance, and car-like driving dynamics in an era when traditional truck-based SUVs dominated the market.
Subaru-Outback.name: Second Generation (BH)

Subaru-Outback.description: The third-generation Subaru Outback continued to refine the raised wagon formula while growing in size, capability, and feature content. Styling became more distinctive with pronounced fender flares, a larger grille, and more substantial overall presence, further differentiating the Outback from the Legacy wagon on which it was based. Ground clearance maintained a generous 8.4 inches, supporting the vehicle's 'go-anywhere' positioning. Engine options varied by market but typically included a 2.5-liter naturally aspirated flat-four, a turbocharged version of the same engine in XT models, and a revised 3.0-liter flat-six in higher-end variants, with power outputs ranging from approximately 165 to 250 horsepower. All-wheel drive remained standard across the lineup, now with more sophisticated electronic control systems in some models. Transmission options included five-speed manual, four and five-speed automatic, and the introduction of SI-Drive on some models, allowing drivers to select different engine response profiles. The interior featured improved materials, more sophisticated design, and enhanced technology including available navigation systems, premium audio, and expanded safety features. This generation was the last to be offered in both wagon and sedan body styles in some markets, though the wagon was by far the more popular choice, reinforcing the outdoor, adventure-focused image of the Outback brand. Special editions included the XT Limited with the turbocharged engine and premium features, and in some markets, the Outback 3.0R with the six-cylinder engine and sport-tuned suspension. The third-generation Outback successfully built upon the model's reputation for versatility and capability, finding particular success in regions with challenging weather conditions and among buyers seeking an alternative to traditional SUVs.
Subaru-Outback.name: Third Generation (BP)

Subaru-Outback.description: The fourth-generation Subaru Outback represented a significant evolution, growing substantially in size and adopting a more SUV-like appearance while maintaining its wagon body style and car-based platform. In North America, this generation marked the complete separation of the Outback from the Legacy wagon, which was discontinued in that market, with the Outback effectively replacing it. The exterior design featured more upright proportions, increased ground clearance of 8.7 inches, and a taller overall height, creating a more commanding presence. Engine options were streamlined in many markets to focus on a 2.5-liter naturally aspirated flat-four and a 3.6-liter flat-six, with turbocharged options eliminated in most regions. All-wheel drive remained standard across the lineup, paired with either a six-speed manual or Subaru's Lineartronic continuously variable transmission (CVT). The interior grew significantly in all dimensions, particularly rear seat legroom and cargo capacity, with a more conventional design focused on mainstream appeal and practicality. Technology features expanded to include available touchscreen infotainment systems, backup cameras, and enhanced safety features. A key innovation was the introduction of Subaru's EyeSight driver assistance system on higher trim levels, offering adaptive cruise control, pre-collision braking, and lane departure warning. This generation marked a shift toward positioning the Outback more directly as an alternative to mid-size SUVs rather than as a niche all-wheel drive wagon, particularly in the North American market, a strategy that proved successful as the model achieved record sales. While this approach broadened the model's appeal to family SUV buyers, some enthusiasts lamented the loss of the turbocharged XT variant and the more car-like driving dynamics of previous generations.
Subaru-Outback.name: Fourth Generation (BR)

Subaru-Outback.description: The fifth-generation Subaru Outback refined the formula established by its predecessor, maintaining similar dimensions but featuring more sophisticated styling, improved refinement, and enhanced technology. The exterior design evolved with more fluid lines, updated lighting elements, and a sleeker overall appearance while preserving the model's characteristic raised ride height of 8.7 inches and protective body cladding. Engine options in most markets continued to include a revised 2.5-liter naturally aspirated flat-four and a 3.6-liter flat-six, both paired with Subaru's Lineartronic continuously variable transmission (CVT) and standard symmetrical all-wheel drive. The interior saw significant improvements in material quality, design, and technology integration, featuring a large central touchscreen (up to 7 inches) in the dashboard, improved connectivity options, and enhanced active safety features including Subaru's more advanced EyeSight driver assistance system, which became available across more of the model line. A key focus of this generation was improved refinement, with enhanced sound insulation, more rigid body structure, and revised suspension tuning providing a quieter, more composed ride quality. Capability remained a priority with standard features like X-Mode, which optimized the AWD system, engine output, and braking for challenging conditions. Special editions included the Touring model with premium features like Java Brown leather upholstery and the Outback Wilderness with increased ground clearance, all-terrain tires, and enhanced off-road capability. The fifth-generation Outback continued the model's success as a versatile alternative to traditional SUVs, particularly appealing to outdoor enthusiasts and families seeking all-weather capability combined with car-like driving dynamics and fuel efficiency.
Subaru-Outback.name: Fifth Generation (BS)

Subaru-Outback.description: The sixth-generation Subaru Outback, built on the Subaru Global Platform that underpins most of the company's modern lineup, represents an evolutionary approach to styling with revolutionary improvements in structural rigidity, technology, and refinement. Exterior dimensions remain similar to the previous generation, but with more rugged styling elements including more prominent body cladding, redesigned roof rails with integrated tie-down points, and an overall more substantial presence. Ground clearance remains 8.7 inches (9.5 inches in the Wilderness variant introduced in 2021), supporting the vehicle's off-road capability. Engine options have been revamped to include a standard 2.5-liter naturally aspirated flat-four producing 182 horsepower and, replacing the old flat-six, a 2.4-liter turbocharged flat-four delivering 260 horsepower, both paired with a continuously variable transmission (CVT) and Subaru's symmetrical all-wheel drive system. The interior represents the most significant advancement, featuring a more premium design with higher quality materials and, on most trim levels, a portrait-oriented 11.6-inch touchscreen infotainment system dominating the center stack, offering improved connectivity, navigation, and vehicle controls. Cargo capacity remains generous at 32.5 cubic feet behind the rear seats, expanding to 75.7 cubic feet with the seats folded. Safety technology has been expanded with the latest version of Subaru's EyeSight driver assistance system now standard across all models, offering adaptive cruise control, lane-keeping assist, and pre-collision braking, with higher trim levels adding driver monitoring systems that can detect driver fatigue or distraction. The Outback Wilderness, introduced in 2021, features increased ground clearance, all-terrain tires, strengthened roof rails, and revised gearing for enhanced off-road capability, catering to the growing overlanding trend. The sixth-generation Outback continues the model's successful positioning as a versatile, capable alternative to conventional SUVs, appealing to outdoor enthusiasts and families seeking all-weather performance, practicality, and safety in an increasingly crowded crossover market.
Subaru-Outback.name: Sixth Generation (BT)

Subaru-Outback.description: The seventh-generation Subaru Outback, revealed on April 16, 2025, and released in North America on August 22, 2025, marks a significant design shift from the raised station wagon format to a full crossover SUV body style. Built on the Subaru Global Platform, this generation features a more boxy, SUV-like shape with increased height, squared-off wheel arches, and a taller roofline that provides more headroom for both front and rear occupants. The discontinuation of the Subaru Legacy sedan in 2025 meant the Outback was no longer constrained by sedan proportions, allowing Subaru designers to create a more spacious, capable vehicle. Ground clearance is 8.7 inches on regular models and 9.5 inches on the Wilderness variant, comparable to the previous generation. Engine options include a naturally aspirated 2.5-liter flat-four boxer engine producing 180 horsepower as the base unit, and a turbocharged 2.4-liter flat-four (2.4T) delivering 260 horsepower on XT and Wilderness trims, both paired with continuously variable transmission (CVT) and standard symmetrical all-wheel drive. The interior features a 12.1-inch touchscreen infotainment system with Google Android Automotive operating system, a 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, and improved climate control with physical buttons rather than touchscreen-based controls. Cargo space increases to 34.3 cubic feet, an improvement over the previous generation. The Wilderness variant returns with enhanced capability, featuring all-terrain tires, copper-colored accents, water-resistant upholstery, electronically controlled dampers, and additional Snow/Dirt and Deep Snow/Mud modes for the X-Mode system. Safety features include Subaru's EyeSight driver assistance system with hands-free driving capability at speeds up to 85 mph, lane-keeping assist, adaptive cruise control, pre-collision braking, and the new Emergency Stop Assist with Safe Lane Selection feature. The seventh-generation Outback represents a bold shift toward the growing crossover segment while maintaining the adventure-oriented philosophy that has defined the model since its inception.
Subaru-Outback.name: Seventh Generation (BU)

Subaru-Solterra.description: The Subaru Solterra represents the Japanese automaker's first all-electric vehicle, developed jointly with Toyota (which sells its version as the bZ4X) on a dedicated EV platform called e-SUBARU Global Platform. The name 'Solterra' combines the Latin words for 'sun' and 'earth,' reflecting the vehicle's environmentally conscious positioning while maintaining a connection to Subaru's nature-oriented brand image. Measuring approximately 184.6 inches in length, the Solterra adopts a crossover SUV form with distinctive styling elements including sharp, angular headlights, prominent black wheel arch cladding, and a coupe-like roofline with a split rear spoiler. Ground clearance of 8.3 inches maintains Subaru's traditional focus on off-road capability, supported by a new dual-motor all-wheel drive system dubbed 'Symmetrical All-Wheel Drive e-SUBARU,' with one electric motor powering each axle for a combined output of 215 horsepower and 248 lb-ft of torque. Powered by a 72.8 kWh lithium-ion battery, the Solterra offers an EPA-estimated range of approximately 220-230 miles depending on trim level, with DC fast-charging capability allowing for an 80% charge in about an hour under ideal conditions. The interior features a minimalist design centered around a high-mounted 12.3-inch touchscreen infotainment system and a digital instrument cluster positioned far forward on the dashboard, creating a unique spatial arrangement. Standard equipment includes heated front seats, a heat pump system for efficient climate control in cold weather, and Subaru's EyeSight driver assistance technology offering adaptive cruise control, pre-collision braking, and lane-keeping assistance. Off-road oriented features include X-Mode with Grip Control, which optimizes the electric motors' output for varying terrain, and Downhill Assist Control for controlled descents on steep gradients. While sharing its fundamental architecture with Toyota's bZ4X, the Solterra features distinct tuning and design elements. Sales began in mid-2022 across Japan, US, Canada, Europe, and China.
Subaru-Solterra.name: First Generation

Subaru-Solterra.description: The 2025 facelift for the Subaru Solterra, unveiled at the New York Auto Show for the 2026 model year, introduced significant updates including a new front end design, 25 percent range improvement over the pre-facelift model, and increased power output to 375 horsepower thanks to stronger front and rear motors. The battery size was increased to 74.7 kWh, improving overall efficiency and range. A new Solterra XT trim was added, featuring more powerful dual electric motors producing a combined 375 horsepower output for enhanced performance. The updated model also features improved DC fast charging capabilities, allowing the vehicle to charge from 10% to 80% in approximately 30 minutes. Interior updates include a larger 14-inch infotainment display replacing the earlier 12.3-inch screen, with physical knobs for volume and climate control that were notably absent in the previous model. Exterior changes include revised styling with Toyota's new 'Hammerhead'-style front fascia and color-matched wheel arch panels replacing the previous black plastic overfenders. The vehicle continues to use the e-SUBARU Global Platform (e-SGP) and maintains Subaru's signature Symmetrical All-Wheel Drive system with X-Mode for off-road capability.
Subaru-Solterra.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Subaru-Tribeca.description: The Subaru B9 Tribeca, as it was initially named, represented Subaru's first entry into the mid-size crossover SUV segment and its first vehicle to offer seating for up to seven passengers. Built on a modified version of the Subaru Legacy/Outback platform, the Tribeca featured highly distinctive styling with a controversial front end design incorporating a triangular grille and swept-back headlights inspired by Subaru's aviation heritage. Measuring approximately 189.8 inches in length, the Tribeca was significantly larger than any previous Subaru model. Powered exclusively by a 3.0-liter flat-six 'boxer' engine producing 245 horsepower and 215 lb-ft of torque, the Tribeca came standard with Subaru's symmetrical all-wheel drive system paired with a five-speed automatic transmission. The interior featured an avant-garde design with a flowing, wave-like dashboard, a central information display, and available features including leather upholstery, heated seats, a navigation system, and a rear-seat DVD entertainment system. Available in five and seven-seat configurations, the Tribeca offered reasonably spacious accommodations in the first and second rows, though the optional third row was suitable mainly for children or short trips. Safety features included standard stability control, anti-lock brakes, and a comprehensive array of airbags. Despite its innovative design and capable all-wheel drive system, the initial Tribeca faced criticism for its polarizing styling, relatively modest power for its size, and tight third-row accommodations compared to competitors, leading to sales figures that fell short of Subaru's expectations.
Subaru-Tribeca.name: First Generation (Initial Release)

Subaru-Tribeca.description: Following lukewarm reception to the original design, Subaru implemented a comprehensive facelift for the 2008 model year, dropping the 'B9' prefix and simply calling the vehicle 'Tribeca.' The most significant change was a complete redesign of the front end, replacing the distinctive but controversial triangular grille with a more conventional design featuring a chrome bar and hexagonal opening more consistent with other Subaru models. The rear styling was also updated with revised taillights and bumper design. Mechanically, the 3.0-liter flat-six engine was replaced by a new 3.6-liter version producing 256 horsepower and 247 lb-ft of torque, addressing criticism of the original model's modest power while maintaining similar fuel economy. The five-speed automatic transmission was revised for smoother operation and better responsiveness. Interior changes were more subtle, focusing on improved materials and minor ergonomic refinements, while maintaining the distinctive wave-like dashboard design. The seating configuration continued to offer five and seven-passenger options, with slight revisions to improve third-row access and comfort, though space remained tight compared to many competitors. Throughout the remainder of its production run, the Tribeca received only minor updates to equipment and features, gradually falling behind the rapidly evolving mid-size crossover segment in technology and design. Despite the improvements, the Tribeca never achieved the sales success Subaru had hoped for, leading to its discontinuation after the 2014 model year without an immediate replacement. The experience gained from the Tribeca, however, would later inform the development of the more successful Subaru Ascent, which would return the brand to the three-row SUV segment in 2019 with a more conventional design and feature set better aligned with market expectations.
Subaru-Tribeca.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Subaru-WRX.description: The first-generation Subaru WRX, based on the Impreza platform, was introduced in Japan and other global markets (but not North America) as a high-performance variant developed from Subaru's rally racing experience. Available in four-door sedan (GC) and five-door wagon (GF) body styles, the original WRX featured subtle but functional performance modifications including a turbocharged 2.0-liter flat-four 'boxer' engine producing approximately 240 horsepower, enhanced suspension, larger brakes, and standard all-wheel drive. Visually distinguished from standard Impreza models by wider body panels, a hood scoop to direct air to the top-mounted intercooler, and unique wheels, the WRX established the template for the rally-inspired road car that would define the model through subsequent generations. The interior maintained the basic layout of the standard Impreza but added sport seats, a three-spoke steering wheel, and additional gauges in some versions. Performance was impressive for the era, with 0-60 mph times of approximately 5.8 seconds and handling that benefited from the low center of gravity provided by the boxer engine and the traction of the all-wheel drive system. Special variants included the limited-production 22B with widened bodywork, a 2.2-liter engine, and unique styling elements commemorating Subaru's World Rally Championship success. This generation established the WRX's reputation for offering supercar-rivaling performance and all-weather capability in a practical, relatively affordable package, developing a devoted enthusiast following and contributing significantly to Subaru's performance image.
Subaru-WRX.name: First Generation (GC/GF)

Subaru-WRX.description: The second-generation Subaru WRX continued to evolve the rally-bred performance formula while expanding to new markets, including North America where it was officially introduced for the 2002 model year. Available in four-door sedan (GD) and five-door wagon (GG) body styles, the new WRX featured more aggressive styling with prominent round headlights (often referred to as 'bug eyes') in its initial form, later revised in 2003 ('blob eye') and 2005 ('hawk eye') facelifts. Powered by a turbocharged 2.0-liter flat-four 'boxer' engine in most global markets or a 2.5-liter version in North America, the WRX produced between 227 and 280 horsepower depending on market and model year. All versions featured Subaru's symmetrical all-wheel drive system, paired primarily with a five-speed manual transmission with an automatic option available in some markets. The interior offered improved materials and design compared to the first generation, though still focused on functionality over luxury, with sport seats, a MOMO steering wheel in many versions, and aluminum pedal covers. This generation coincided with increased awareness of the WRX in popular culture, particularly through rally racing, motorsports video games, and films, helping establish the model as a performance icon. Special variants included the WRX STI, which became a separate model line with more substantial performance upgrades, and various limited editions with unique colors and equipment. The second-generation WRX significantly expanded the model's global reach and enthusiast following, cementing its reputation for offering accessible performance with practical everyday usability.
Subaru-WRX.name: Second Generation (GD/GG)

Subaru-WRX.description: The third-generation Subaru WRX, initially marketed as part of the Impreza line before becoming a separate model later in this generation, represented a significant redesign with a focus on broadening appeal while maintaining performance capabilities. Available in four-door sedan (GE/GV) and five-door hatchback (GH/GR) body styles, the new WRX featured more mainstream styling than its predecessor, particularly in the early years of this generation. Powered by a turbocharged 2.5-liter flat-four 'boxer' engine in most markets, the WRX produced approximately 265 horsepower, delivered through Subaru's symmetrical all-wheel drive system paired with a five-speed manual transmission, with an automatic option available in some regions. In 2011, the WRX received a significant update that more clearly differentiated it from the standard Impreza, featuring widened body panels, a more aggressive front end, and unique quad exhaust outlets. The interior saw improvements in material quality and design, with available features including navigation systems, premium audio, and enhanced safety equipment. This generation marked a period of transition for the WRX, evolving from its raw, rally-derived character toward a more refined, accessible performance car, though still maintaining the turbocharged boxer engine and all-wheel drive formula that defined the model. Special editions included the limited-production WRX STI spec C and spec R in Japan, featuring reduced weight and track-focused upgrades. The third-generation WRX continued to build the model's enthusiast following while appealing to a broader audience with improved daily usability and comfort, though some purists felt it had lost some of the raw character that defined earlier versions.
Subaru-WRX.name: Third Generation (GE/GH/GR/GV)

Subaru-WRX.description: The fourth-generation Subaru WRX marked the model's complete separation from the Impreza line, becoming a distinct model with its own platform modifications and styling, though still sharing some underlying architecture with the Impreza. Available exclusively as a four-door sedan in most markets, the new WRX featured more aggressive, distinctive styling with a prominent hood scoop, flared fenders, and quad exhaust outlets. Powertrain saw a significant change with the introduction of a new 2.0-liter direct-injection turbocharged flat-four 'boxer' engine (FA20) replacing the previous 2.5-liter unit in most markets, producing 268 horsepower and 258 lb-ft of torque, paired with either a six-speed manual transmission or a continuously variable transmission (CVT) marketed as the 'Sport Lineartronic' with simulated gear steps. All models continued to feature Subaru's symmetrical all-wheel drive system, with different versions depending on the transmission choice. The interior represented a significant upgrade from previous generations, with improved materials, a more modern design, and enhanced technology including a central touchscreen infotainment system with available navigation and smartphone integration. A key focus was improving refinement and daily usability without compromising performance capabilities, with revised suspension tuning, a more rigid chassis, and reduced interior noise. This generation introduced more advanced driver assistance features on CVT-equipped models, including Subaru's EyeSight system offering adaptive cruise control and pre-collision braking. Special variants included the limited-production Series.Gray with unique styling elements and the WRX STI, which maintained the older EJ25 2.5-liter engine but with increased output and substantial chassis upgrades. The fourth-generation WRX successfully balanced improved refinement and technology with the performance characteristics expected of the nameplate, maintaining its position as a benchmark for affordable all-weather performance cars.
Subaru-WRX.name: Fourth Generation (VA)

Subaru-WRX.description: The fifth-generation Subaru WRX represents the most comprehensive redesign in the model's history, built on the Subaru Global Platform that underpins most of the company's modern lineup but with extensive performance-focused modifications. Available exclusively as a four-door sedan, the new WRX features more aggressive styling with prominent fender flares, functional air vents on the front fenders and rear bumper, a larger hood scoop, and distinctive rear diffuser with quad exhaust tips. A significant change is the addition of contrasting black plastic cladding around the wheel arches and lower body, a controversial design element that polarized enthusiast opinion. Powered by a new 2.4-liter turbocharged flat-four 'boxer' engine producing 271 horsepower and 258 lb-ft of torque (a modest increase in horsepower but across a broader rev range), the WRX is available with either a six-speed manual transmission or a new Subaru Performance Transmission (SPT)—a specially tuned continuously variable transmission with faster shift responses than the previous generation. All models continue to feature Subaru's symmetrical all-wheel drive system, with different versions depending on transmission choice. The interior has been completely redesigned with a more modern, technology-focused approach featuring an available 11.6-inch portrait-oriented touchscreen infotainment system, improved materials, and more supportive front seats. For the first time, the WRX is available in a GT trim that combines the SPT with electronically controlled dampers offering Comfort, Normal, and Sport settings—the first adaptive suspension ever offered on a WRX. Safety technology has been expanded with Subaru's EyeSight driver assistance system standard on all SPT-equipped models, offering adaptive cruise control, lane-keeping assist, and emergency braking. Notably, for this generation, there is no STI variant planned, with Subaru announcing that it would not produce an STI version of the VB platform as it focuses on electrification strategies for future performance models. The fifth-generation WRX continues to target enthusiast drivers seeking all-weather performance with everyday practicality, now with enhanced technology and refinement, though its styling and the absence of an STI variant have proven controversial among the model's traditional fan base.
Subaru-WRX.name: Fifth Generation (VB)

Subaru-WRX-STI.description: The first-generation Subaru Impreza WRX STI (Subaru Tecnica International) was introduced in Japan as the ultimate expression of Subaru's rally technology in a road car, building upon the already-capable WRX with more power, enhanced handling, and distinctive styling elements. Available in four-door sedan (GC) and five-door wagon (GF) body styles, the original STI featured a more powerful version of the turbocharged 2.0-liter flat-four 'boxer' engine, producing up to 280 horsepower in later versions—adhering to Japan's 'gentleman's agreement' limiting advertised power output. Performance upgrades over the standard WRX included a stronger transmission, front and rear limited-slip differentials, revised suspension with STI-tuned dampers and springs, and larger brakes. Visual distinctions included a larger rear wing, more aggressive body kit, gold-painted BBS wheels that became a signature STI element, and pink STI badges. The interior featured more heavily bolstered Recaro seats, a MOMO steering wheel, and additional gauges. This generation introduced the innovative Driver Controlled Center Differential (DCCD), allowing manual adjustment of torque distribution between front and rear axles. Special variants included the legendary 22B, produced in limited numbers to celebrate Subaru's World Rally Championship success, featuring widened bodywork, a 2.2-liter engine, and unique styling elements. The first-generation STI established the blueprint for the ultimate Subaru performance car and created a devoted enthusiast following, though it was not officially imported to North America during this generation.
Subaru-WRX-STI.name: First Generation (GC/GF)

Subaru-WRX-STI.description: The second-generation Subaru Impreza WRX STI continued to evolve the high-performance formula while expanding to new markets, including North America where it was officially introduced for the 2004 model year. Available in four-door sedan (GD) and five-door wagon (GG) body styles, though North America initially received only the sedan, the new STI featured more aggressive styling with prominent round headlights in its initial form, later revised in 2003 and 2005 facelifts. Powered by a turbocharged 2.0-liter flat-four 'boxer' engine in Japan and most global markets, producing up to another Japanese-market limited 280 horsepower, while North American models received a 2.5-liter version with 300 horsepower, both paired exclusively with a six-speed manual transmission. Performance technology advanced with refined versions of the Driver Controlled Center Differential (DCCD), front and rear limited-slip differentials, and more sophisticated stability control systems that could be fully disabled for track use. Braking performance improved with larger Brembo calipers and rotors, while suspension received STI-specific tuning with upgraded components. Visual distinctions from the standard WRX included a more aggressive body kit, larger rear wing, and gold BBS wheels continuing the STI tradition. The interior featured more heavily bolstered seats, STI-branded gauges and trim elements, and a smaller-diameter steering wheel. Special editions included the limited-production Spec C with reduced weight and track-focused upgrades, and the S203/S204 in Japan with even more power and performance refinements. This generation significantly expanded the STI's global presence and enthusiast following, establishing it as a performance icon capable of competing with sports cars costing much more.
Subaru-WRX-STI.name: Second Generation (GD/GG)

Subaru-WRX-STI.description: The third-generation Subaru Impreza WRX STI represented a more significant departure from the standard Impreza, with unique bodywork and performance features further distinguishing it as a specialized performance model. Initially available only as a five-door hatchback (GR) in most markets before adding a four-door sedan (GV) option for the 2011 model year, the new STI featured an aggressive wide-body design with flared fenders, a large rear wing on sedan models, and distinctive quad exhaust outlets. Powered by a carried-over turbocharged 2.5-liter flat-four 'boxer' engine producing 305 horsepower in most markets, the STI continued to be offered exclusively with a six-speed manual transmission and Subaru's advanced all-wheel drive system featuring the Driver Controlled Center Differential (DCCD), allowing manual adjustment of torque distribution between front and rear axles. Performance technology expanded to include Subaru Intelligent Drive (SI-Drive) with three driver-selectable engine response modes and a multi-mode Vehicle Dynamics Control system allowing varying levels of stability control intervention. The suspension featured inverted struts derived from rally racing experience, aluminum lower control arms for reduced unsprung weight, and more aggressive tuning than standard WRX models. Braking was provided by Brembo calipers with cross-drilled rotors. The interior featured more heavily bolstered seats, STI-branded instrumentation with a center-mounted tachometer, aluminum pedals, and a thick-rimmed steering wheel. Special editions included the STI Spec C in Japan with reduced weight and track-focused upgrades, and the U.S.-market STI Special Edition with JDM suspension components. The third-generation STI continued to build the model's reputation for offering supercar-rivaling performance and all-weather capability in a practical package, though some enthusiasts felt it had lost some of the raw character that defined earlier versions as it became more refined and accessible.
Subaru-WRX-STI.name: Third Generation (GR/GV)

Subaru-WRX-STI.description: The fourth-generation Subaru WRX STI marked the model's complete separation from the Impreza line, becoming a distinct model with its own platform modifications and styling, though still sharing some underlying architecture with the Impreza. Available exclusively as a four-door sedan in most markets, the new STI featured even more aggressive styling than the standard WRX with a larger rear wing, unique front bumper design, and more pronounced aerodynamic elements. Unlike the standard WRX, which received a new 2.0-liter direct-injection turbocharged engine, the STI maintained the previous generation's EJ25 2.5-liter turbocharged flat-four 'boxer' engine with only minor updates, producing 305 horsepower and 290 lb-ft of torque in most markets, paired exclusively with a reinforced six-speed manual transmission. The all-wheel drive system featured further refinements to the Driver Controlled Center Differential (DCCD), now using electronic control rather than the previous mechanical and electronic combined system, along with front and rear limited-slip differentials. Suspension was significantly upgraded with inverted front struts, aluminum lower control arms, and more aggressive tuning, while braking performance improved with larger Brembo calipers and cross-drilled rotors. The interior received upgrades over the standard WRX with more heavily bolstered seats featuring STI embroidery, a leather-wrapped flat-bottom steering wheel, and additional performance displays in the instrument cluster. A key focus was improving refinement without compromising performance capabilities, with a more rigid chassis, improved sound insulation, and higher quality interior materials. Special editions included the limited-production STI Type RA with reduced weight, a carbon fiber roof, enhanced engine components, and unique styling elements, and the STI S209 for the U.S. market—the first S-line STI sold outside Japan—featuring 341 horsepower and comprehensive chassis upgrades. As the last generation to use the legendary EJ25 engine that had powered STI models for nearly two decades, the fourth-generation STI maintained its position as a benchmark for affordable all-weather performance cars while offering improved daily usability and refinement.
Subaru-WRX-STI.name: Fourth Generation (VA)

Suzuki-Alto.description: The first generation (SS30V/40V), introduced in May 1979, is a three-door cargo version of the Fronte passenger car. Initially equipped with a T5B two-stroke three-cylinder engine, it was later available with the F5A four-stroke engine from January 1981. The model was exported as the Suzuki Hatch in Australia and as the Alto/Fronte in other markets. Production ended in 1984.
Suzuki-Alto.name: First Generation

Suzuki-Alto.description: The second generation (CA71) was introduced in September 1984, featuring design elements from the GM M-platform. It continued with the F5A engine but added turbocharged and multi-valve variants. The Alto Works performance version was introduced in February 1987, being the first kei car to reach the legal power limit. A five-door body became available in October 1985, and a facelift arrived in July 1986 with new wraparound headlights and updated suspension. Production continued until 1994, though it remained in production in Pakistan as the Mehran until 2019.
Suzuki-Alto.name: Second Generation

Suzuki-Alto.description: The third generation (CL/CM11) replaced the CA71 in September 1988, featuring angular styling with an unusual glazed C-pillar on the five-door. It offered a unique sliding door version called 'Slide Slim'. When kei car standards changed in 1990, the engine was upgraded to the F6A and the model codes changed to CL/CM/CN/CP21. The Fronte name was discontinued in October 1989, making the Alto the sole nameplate. This generation was successful at home but not widely exported.
Suzuki-Alto.name: Third Generation

Suzuki-Alto.description: The fourth-generation Alto (HA11) appeared in November 1994, marked by simplicity as Suzuki returned to making a more basic car. The Slide Slim and column-shift Regina models were discontinued to cut costs. The Wagon R took over much of the Alto's market share at the higher end. New K6A engines joined the F6A, with the Works RS/Z model receiving the high-performance version. A facelift in April 1997 added side impact protection and new front design.
Suzuki-Alto.name: Fourth Generation

Suzuki-Alto.description: The fifth-generation Alto (HA12/22) was introduced in October 1998 with more rounded styling. Weight was minimized and four-wheel drive models shared the same bottom plate as front-wheel drive versions. A thorough facelift in December 2000 (becoming HA23) brought updated styling and naturally aspirated K6A engines. The Works models were discontinued. This generation entered production in India as the Maruti Suzuki Alto and was exported to Europe until 2009.
Suzuki-Alto.name: Fifth Generation

Suzuki-Alto.description: The sixth-generation Alto (HA24) was introduced in September 2004 with a distinctive front design featuring curved bonnet and headlamps. The Alto was repositioned as a less costly model, with more powerful engines moving to the Cervo and Alto Lapin. No three-door variant was offered, returning the five-door Van for the first time since 1989. The model was also sold as the Mazda Carol and Nissan Pino in Japan. Production continued until December 2009.
Suzuki-Alto.name: Sixth Generation

Suzuki-Alto.description: The seventh-generation Alto was introduced at the 2009 Tokyo Motor Show. In Japan, it featured the K6A engine with manual, automatic, or CVT transmission options. An Eco variant launched in 2011 featured the new R06A engine with idling stop function, achieving excellent fuel economy. Internationally, a different model was sold as the Maruti Suzuki A-Star (also known as Suzuki Celerio), manufactured exclusively in India. In 2012, the Alto 800 was introduced as a low-cost model for India and export markets.
Suzuki-Alto.name: Seventh Generation

Suzuki-Alto.description: The eighth-generation Alto was introduced in Japan in December 2014 as the first Suzuki built on the lightweight HEARTECT platform. It features torsion beam rear suspension (except AWD models) and improved fuel efficiency with 'Suzuki Green Technology'. Sporty variants included the Turbo RS (2015) and Works (2015). The VP commercial van was discontinued in August 2021, marking the end of the Alto commercial vehicle. In Pakistan, local manufacturing began in 2019 with three variants (VX, VXR, VXL).
Suzuki-Alto.name: Eighth Generation

Suzuki-Alto.description: The ninth-generation Alto was introduced in Japan in December 2021, continuing on the HEARTECT platform with the R06A engine for conventional models. A new R06D engine with mild hybrid system was added for hybrid variants. CVT is the only transmission option, making this the first Alto without a manual gearbox. The Auto Gear Shift (AGS) automated manual was also discontinued. Styling by Alessandro Di Gregorio features softer, friendlier lines with a more vertical windscreen for increased interior space. Four trim levels are available: A and L for conventional, S and X for hybrid.
Suzuki-Alto.name: Ninth Generation

Suzuki-Baleno.description: The first-generation Suzuki Baleno is a subcompact hatchback produced from September 2015, built on Suzuki's new HEARTECT B platform. Unveiled at the 66th IAA Frankfurt Motor Show on 15 September 2015, it was previewed by the iK-2 concept car shown at the Geneva Motor Show in March 2015. Unlike previous Baleno models which were sedans and wagons, this generation is exclusively a 5-door hatchback. Engine options varied by market including a 1.0-liter Boosterjet turbocharged three-cylinder producing approximately 111 horsepower, a 1.2-liter Dualjet four-cylinder with approximately 90 horsepower, and a 1.4-liter naturally aspirated four-cylinder. A mild hybrid SHVS (Smart Hybrid Vehicle by Suzuki) system was available on some variants. Transmission options included five-speed manual, six-speed automatic, and CVT depending on market. The interior offered class-leading passenger space with a 7-inch touchscreen infotainment system on higher trims featuring Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. Safety features included six airbags, ABS with EBD, electronic stability program, and available autonomous emergency braking. The Baleno was marketed as a spacious alternative to the Swift, positioned above it in Suzuki's global lineup. Production took place in India at Maruti Suzuki's Manesar and Ahmedabad plants for global markets including Europe, Japan, Australia, and Asia.
Suzuki-Baleno.name: First Generation

Suzuki-Baleno.description: The facelifted first-generation Baleno was launched in India on 28 January 2019, introducing significant exterior and interior updates while retaining the same HEARTECT B platform. The exterior received a remodeled front bumper with a new grille design and new 16-inch alloy wheels with dual-tone coloring. The interior was upgraded with a dual-tone black-and-blue color scheme, and improvements were made to noise reduction and ride comfort. The Baleno RS performance variant was discontinued in January 2020 due to emission standards non-compliance. A new 1.2-liter K12N Dualjet dual-injector petrol engine with mild hybrid technology producing approximately 90 horsepower was introduced in April 2019, available for Delta and Zeta trims without CVT option. The 1.25-liter turbodiesel engine was discontinued in May 2020 due to stricter emission standards. The facelifted model was not available in Europe, Japan, and several other markets after Suzuki decided to discontinue the Baleno in those regions in 2020 to focus on the more popular Swift. Toyota began selling the facelifted Baleno as the Glanza in India from June 2019. Despite these updates, this remained the same WB1 platform generation.
Suzuki-Baleno.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Suzuki-Baleno.description: The second-generation Suzuki Baleno hatchback was released in India on 23 February 2022, marketed as the 'New Age Baleno.' While continuing to use Suzuki's HEARTECT platform, it features major body shell revisions with new exterior panels, headlights, LED fog lights, tail lights, smaller C-pillar window, and redesigned wheels. The interior received a complete redesign with a floating 9-inch LCD display, new gauge cluster, refreshed steering wheel, rear air conditioning vents, fast charging USB ports, head-up display, 360-degree view camera, and Amazon Alexa voice assistant support. Handling was improved with an all-new suspension system, new hydraulic clutch, and larger front disc brakes. Engine options include a 1.2-liter K12N Dualjet petrol engine producing approximately 90 horsepower, with a CNG variant introduced in October 2022 for the Indian market. Transmission options include a 5-speed manual or new 5-speed AMT 'AGS' automatic which replaced the previous CVT. Export markets receive a larger 1.5-liter K15B petrol engine. Safety features were enhanced with up to 6 airbags, electronic stability control, and the model achieved a 4-star rating in Bharat NCAP (2025). Toyota continues to sell the Baleno-based Glanza with differentiated styling. Production continues in India for export to Asia, Africa, Middle East, and Latin America.
Suzuki-Baleno.name: Second Generation

Suzuki-Ignis.description: First series of the Ignis, manufactured as a three- and five-door hatchback. Powered by M family 1.3L (M13A) and 1.5L (M15A) inline-four petrol engines with DOHC, four valves per cylinder and variable valve timing. Model codes: HT51S (1.3L) and HT81S (1.5L). Transmission options included five-speed manual and four-speed automatic, with both FWD and AWD layouts available. Minor facelift in 2003 featured new wheel trims, revised grille insert and clear headlamp-mounted turn signal lenses.
Suzuki-Ignis.name: First Generation (FH)

Suzuki-Ignis.description: Facelifted European version based on the Chevrolet Cruze platform. Suzuki extended the length by 200mm behind the rear axle to improve interior room and luggage space. Manufactured in Esztergom, Hungary by Magyar Suzuki. Also sold as Subaru G3X Justy in Europe. Engine options included 1.3L and 1.5L petrol, plus a Fiat 1.3L Multijet diesel. Available with FWD or AWD (manual transmission only for AWD).
Suzuki-Ignis.name: First Generation (MH) Facelift

Suzuki-Ignis.description: Crossover-styled city car launched January 2016. Built on the HEARTECT A platform with styling cues from the Suzuki Cervo SS20 (1977). Powered by 1.25L K12C inline-four engine with optional mild hybrid system (SHVS) using 3Ah lithium-ion battery. Engine produces 91 PS and 118 Nm of torque. Transmission options: 5-speed manual or CVT, available in FWD or AWD (AllGrip) configuration.
Suzuki-Ignis.name: Second Generation (MF)

Suzuki-Ignis.description: Facelifted version launched February 2020. Received new front and rear bumpers, revised grille with four slots flanking Suzuki logo, updated gauge cluster colour and fabric seats design. European models received new 1.2L K12D Dualjet mild hybrid engine producing 83 PS and 107 Nm, with enlarged 10Ah battery. AGS automated manual transmission replaced with CVT.
Suzuki-Ignis.name: Second Generation (MF) Facelift

Suzuki-Jimny.description: The first-generation Suzuki Jimny established the model's identity as a lightweight, minimalist off-roader designed to provide genuine four-wheel drive capability in a compact, affordable package. Initially known as the LJ (Light Jeep) series, the original Jimny featured a simple, boxy design with an open body style, though hardtop variants were later added. Measuring just 3 meters in length and weighing approximately 600 kg, the Jimny was exceptionally compact even by kei car standards. Early models were powered by a tiny 359cc two-stroke, two-cylinder engine producing just 25 horsepower to comply with Japanese kei car regulations, later upgraded to a 539cc version for export markets and eventually to a 797cc four-cylinder for the LJ80 variant. All models featured part-time four-wheel drive with a two-speed transfer case and leaf spring suspension front and rear. The interior was utterly basic with minimal comfort features, emphasizing function over form. Despite its modest power and simple construction, the first-generation Jimny established a reputation for remarkable off-road capability relative to its size, able to navigate challenging terrain thanks to its light weight, good ground clearance, and proper four-wheel drive system with low-range gearing. This generation laid the foundation for what would become one of the world's longest-running small 4×4 nameplates, finding particular success in rural and mountainous regions globally where its compact dimensions and off-road prowess proved invaluable.
Suzuki-Jimny.name: First Generation (LJ10/20)

Suzuki-Jimny.description: The second-generation Suzuki Jimny, often known as the SJ series or Samurai in some markets, refined the concept established by its predecessor while broadening its appeal and capabilities. Available in various body styles including convertible soft top, hardtop, pickup, and long-wheelbase variants depending on market, this generation featured more angular styling with a distinctive slatted grille and rectangular headlights. Engine options expanded significantly, including 539cc and 657cc three-cylinder engines for Japanese kei car versions, with larger 1.0-liter and 1.3-liter four-cylinder engines for export markets, and even 1.9-liter turbodiesel options in some regions. All retained the part-time four-wheel drive system with a two-speed transfer case, though mechanical refinements improved reliability and capability. The suspension continued with leaf springs but with improved articulation and ride quality. The interior remained basic but offered more comfort features than the previous generation, particularly in later years and higher trim levels. This generation achieved global popularity, establishing the Jimny as a cult vehicle among off-road enthusiasts who appreciated its remarkable capability despite its humble origins. The SJ410/413 variants, in particular, developed a reputation for being able to follow much larger, more expensive 4×4s in challenging off-road situations while offering superior maneuverability in tight trails. Though controversy in some markets regarding rollover risk affected its image, the second-generation Jimny's lengthy production run and widespread global sales cemented its position as an iconic small off-roader.
Suzuki-Jimny.name: Second Generation (SJ30/40/410)

Suzuki-Jimny.description: The third-generation Suzuki Jimny represented a significant modernization of the model while maintaining its core identity as a compact, capable off-roader.
