Featuring more rounded styling than its predecessors but retaining the boxy, upright profile and short overhangs essential for off-road performance, this generation was available primarily as a three-door hardtop, with some markets also receiving convertible variants in early years. In Japan, the kei car version (JB23) featured a 658cc turbocharged three-cylinder engine producing 63 horsepower to comply with regulations, while international models (JB33/43/53) received a larger 1.3-liter four-cylinder producing approximately 80-85 horsepower depending on market and emissions regulations. The most significant mechanical change was the switch from leaf springs to coil springs at all four corners, improving on-road ride quality and off-road articulation, while a switch to a ladder frame chassis provided improved rigidity. The part-time four-wheel drive system with low-range transfer case remained, now enhanced with electronic aids including ABS that could be switched off for off-road use, and in later models, limited-slip differential functionality through brake intervention. The interior offered significantly improved comfort, ergonomics, and safety compared to previous generations, though still maintaining a utilitarian character with hard-wearing materials and straightforward controls. Throughout its remarkably long 20-year production run, the third-generation Jimny received only modest updates to styling, equipment, and powertrains, a testament to the enduring appeal of its fundamental design. This generation further enhanced the Jimny's cult status among off-road enthusiasts who appreciated its combination of genuine capability, compact dimensions, mechanical simplicity, and distinctive character in an era of increasingly car-like crossovers.
Suzuki-Jimny.name: Third Generation (JB23/33/43/53)

Suzuki-Jimny.description: The fourth-generation Suzuki Jimny marks a return to more angular, retro-inspired styling while thoroughly modernizing the mechanical package and technology. The distinctive exterior design incorporates elements reminiscent of earlier generations, including a simple rectangular grille with vertical slats, circular headlights, and an upright, boxy silhouette with similarly minimalist dimensions to its predecessor. In Japan, the kei car version (JB64) features a 658cc turbocharged three-cylinder engine producing 63 horsepower to comply with regulations, while the global model (JB74) receives a naturally aspirated 1.5-liter four-cylinder producing 100-102 horsepower depending on market, both significant improvements in performance over the previous generation. Both variants maintain the traditional Jimny formula of body-on-frame construction, rigid axles front and rear with coil springs, and part-time four-wheel drive with a proper low-range transfer case, now enhanced with electronic aids including brake LSD traction control, hill descent control, and hill hold assist. The interior represents the most significant advancement, featuring modern design with enhanced ergonomics, improved materials, and significantly updated technology including a 7-inch touchscreen infotainment system with smartphone connectivity on higher trim levels. Safety equipment has been comprehensively upgraded with the addition of autonomous emergency braking, lane departure warning, and six airbags as standard in most markets. Despite these modernizations, the fourth-generation Jimny maintains its focus on off-road capability with exceptional approach, breakover, and departure angles, good ground clearance, and a lightweight structure enhancing performance in challenging terrain. The new model has achieved unprecedented global demand, often exceeding production capacity, thanks to its distinctive design, genuine capability, and unique positioning as one of the few remaining small, purpose-built off-roaders in an era dominated by car-based crossovers. Regulatory challenges in some markets, particularly concerning emissions, have led to creative solutions including a commercial vehicle variant with rear seats removed in European markets.
Suzuki-Jimny.name: Fourth Generation (JB64/74)

Suzuki-SX4.description: First generation Suzuki SX4 introduced December 2005 at Geneva Motor Show. Available as five-door hatchback crossover and sedan. Designed by Giorgetto Giugiaro at Italdesign. Built on Suzuki A-Segment Platform. Joint development with Fiat (sold as Sedici). Standard features include intelligent All Wheel Drive (iAWD) system with three modes.
Suzuki-SX4.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Suzuki-SX4.description: Facelift updates including new grille, instrument cluster, climate controls, and door trim. Restructured cargo hold with 'arena seating' raised rear seat layout. Updated engines meeting Euro 5 emissions. New SportBack model offered with sport-tuned suspension and body kit.
Suzuki-SX4.name: First Generation (2010 Facelift)

Suzuki-SX4.description: Second facelift with new front bumper and wider grille. New RC1 variant launched in Indonesia with accessories, bumpers, rear spoiler, twin mufflers, 17-inch wheels and LED headlamps. Stability control and rear disc brakes became standard on US models.
Suzuki-SX4.name: First Generation (2012 Facelift)

Suzuki-SX4.description: Final production year for first generation in most markets except China. Redesigned front fascia and navigation added as optional feature on US models. Last model year for US and Canada sales.
Suzuki-SX4.name: First Generation (Final Facelift)

Suzuki-SX4.description: All-new second generation SX4 S-Cross unveiled at Geneva Motor Show 2013. Larger subcompact crossover SUV built on Suzuki Global C platform. Standard FWD with optional AllGrip AWD system. Five-star Euro NCAP safety rating. Produced alongside first generation until 2014.
Suzuki-SX4.name: Second Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Suzuki-SX4.description: Facelifted SX4 S-Cross with new front-end design, LED daytime running lights, updated interior with soft-touch dashboard. New Boosterjet turbo engines introduced: 1.0L K10C and 1.4L K14C. Mild hybrid (SHVS) system added in 2020 with 48V lithium-ion battery and Integrated Starter Generator.
Suzuki-SX4.name: Second Generation (2016 Facelift)

Suzuki-SX4.description: Third generation SX4 S-Cross unveiled November 2021. Heavily based on previous generation with major exterior makeover and updated interior dashboard. Carried over 1.4L K14D Boosterjet mild hybrid engine with 48V ISG system. Continues to be manufactured by Magyar Suzuki in Hungary for European and global markets.
Suzuki-SX4.name: Third Generation

Suzuki-Splash.description: Pre-facelift model introduced in 2008. Jointly developed by Suzuki and Opel, marketed as Opel Agila/Vauxhall Agila in European markets. Powered by 1.0L and 1.2L petrol engines, plus 1.3L Fiat MultiJet diesel.
Suzuki-Splash.name: First Generation

Suzuki-Splash.description: Facelifted version with updated front fascia, new grille, headlamps, bumpers, and interior updates. Launched in Europe in 2013, Indonesia in April 2013 with automatic transmission option. Indian market Ritz received similar updates in 2015 model year.
Suzuki-Splash.name: First Generation Facelift

Suzuki-Swift.description: The first vehicle to bear the Swift name globally (though initially marketed as the Cultus in Japan and some other markets) established Suzuki's presence in the subcompact segment with a focus on simplicity, affordability, and efficiency. Available in three-door and five-door hatchback body styles, the SA310/AA Swift featured compact dimensions, light weight, and straightforward styling characteristic of early 1980s Japanese small cars. Engine options varied by market but typically included 1.0-liter and 1.3-liter gasoline engines, with power outputs ranging from approximately 50 to 70 horsepower. Transmission options included four and five-speed manuals and a three-speed automatic, with front-wheel drive standard and all-wheel drive available in some markets and variants. The interior prioritized functional simplicity over comfort or style, with basic materials and minimal features by modern standards. This generation was also marketed under various names through global alliances, including as the Chevrolet Sprint, Pontiac Firefly, and Geo Metro in North America. While modest in its specifications and capabilities, the first-generation Swift/Cultus established the nameplate in global markets and laid the foundation for its reputation as an economical, reliable subcompact.
Suzuki-Swift.name: First Generation (SA310/AA/Cultus)

Suzuki-Swift.description: The second-generation Suzuki Swift/Cultus refined the formula established by its predecessor with more rounded styling reflecting automotive design trends of the late 1980s. Available in three-door and five-door hatchback body styles, plus sedan variants in some markets (sometimes called Swift Sedan or Cultus Esteem), this generation maintained compact dimensions but offered improved space efficiency and slightly more sophisticated styling. Engine options expanded to include a broader range of displacements from 1.0 to 1.6 liters, with the introduction of 16-valve technology in some variants and even a turbocharged GTi performance model producing up to 100 horsepower—impressive for a lightweight subcompact of the era. Transmission options included five-speed manual and three or four-speed automatic, with front-wheel drive standard and all-wheel drive available on certain models, particularly in the Japanese domestic market. The interior saw improvements in design, material quality, and feature content, though still focusing on functional simplicity rather than luxury. This generation continued to be marketed under various badges globally, including as the Geo Metro and Pontiac Firefly in North America and the Holden Barina in Australia. The second-generation Swift/Cultus further developed the model's reputation for offering economical, reliable transportation with a broader range of variants catering to different segments of the subcompact market.
Suzuki-Swift.name: Second Generation (Cultus/SF310/EA/MA)

Suzuki-Swift.description: The third-generation Suzuki Swift/Cultus continued the model's evolution with more aerodynamic styling and improved refinement. Available in three-door and five-door hatchback body styles, with sedan variants in some markets, this generation featured softer, more rounded styling in keeping with 1990s design trends. Engine options again varied by market but typically included 1.0-liter, 1.3-liter, and 1.6-liter gasoline engines, with the performance-oriented Swift GTi continuing in some regions. Transmission options included five-speed manual and three or four-speed automatic, with front-wheel drive standard and all-wheel drive available on certain variants. The interior saw further improvements in design, material quality, and feature content, including available amenities such as power windows, central locking, and improved audio systems on higher trim levels. Safety features expanded to include available driver and passenger airbags and ABS brakes on some models. This generation maintained the Swift's global presence through various rebadging arrangements, though with decreasing prominence in some markets as the small car segment became increasingly competitive. The third-generation Swift/Cultus reinforced the model's positioning as a practical, economical subcompact, though without significant innovations to distinguish it in an increasingly crowded segment.
Suzuki-Swift.name: Third Generation (Cultus/HT51/81)

Suzuki-Swift.description: The fourth-generation Suzuki Swift represented a transitional model with limited global distribution, as Suzuki's small car strategy fragmented across different models and markets during this period. In many regions, the Swift nameplate was temporarily retired or applied to rebadged versions of other Suzuki models like the Ignis, while this generation—sometimes referred to as the Swift 'Classic'—continued in select markets including Japan and China. Featuring evolutionary styling from the previous generation with a focus on practicality and economy, this Swift was available in three-door and five-door hatchback body styles. Engine options typically included 1.0-liter, 1.3-liter, and 1.5-liter gasoline units with modest power outputs, paired with five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmissions. The interior maintained a straightforward, functional approach with minimal luxury features. This generation had a relatively short production run and limited impact on global markets compared to both its predecessors and successor, serving primarily to maintain Suzuki's presence in the subcompact segment while the company developed a completely new approach for the fifth generation that would revitalize the Swift nameplate internationally.
Suzuki-Swift.name: Fourth Generation (HT)

Suzuki-Swift.description: The fifth-generation Suzuki Swift marked a complete reinvention of the nameplate with distinctive styling, improved dynamics, and a renewed global market presence. Featuring a distinctive, sporty design with a wide stance, flared wheel arches, and a wraparound windshield creating a 'helmet visor' look, this generation established a strong visual identity that would influence Swift design for years to come. Available in three-door and five-door hatchback body styles, with a sedan variant (Swift DZire) in some markets, the fifth-generation Swift was larger than its predecessors but still compact by segment standards. Engine options varied by market but typically included 1.3-liter and 1.5-liter gasoline engines, with a 1.3-liter diesel option in some regions, and power outputs ranging from approximately 75 to 100 horsepower. Transmission choices included five-speed manual and four-speed automatic, with front-wheel drive standard and all-wheel drive available in select markets. The interior featured a more design-conscious approach than previous generations, with a sporty three-spoke steering wheel, motorcycle-inspired gauges, and improved materials. Higher trims offered features including climate control, keyless entry, and enhanced audio systems. The performance-oriented Swift Sport, featuring a 1.6-liter engine producing 125 horsepower, reintroduced a genuinely fun-to-drive variant to the lineup. The fifth-generation Swift achieved significant global success, earning numerous awards and establishing itself as a stylish, enjoyable alternative in the subcompact segment, effectively resetting public perception of both the model and the Suzuki brand in many markets.
Suzuki-Swift.name: Fifth Generation (ZC11/21/31/71/RS series)

Suzuki-Swift.description: The sixth-generation Suzuki Swift evolved the successful formula established by its predecessor with refined styling, improved efficiency, and enhanced technology. Maintaining the distinctive design language but with more sophisticated detailing including a more prominent grille, complex headlight designs, and hidden rear door handles on five-door models, this generation preserved the Swift's newfound identity as a stylish, youthful subcompact. Available in three-door and five-door hatchback body styles, with sedan variants (Swift DZire) in some markets, the sixth-generation Swift maintained similar dimensions to its predecessor but with improved interior space efficiency. Engine options varied significantly by market but typically included 1.2-liter and 1.4-liter gasoline engines, a 1.2-liter Dualjet with enhanced efficiency in later years, and 1.3-liter diesel options in some regions, with power outputs ranging from approximately 75 to 94 horsepower in standard models. The Swift Sport continued as the performance flagship, now with a 1.6-liter engine producing 136 horsepower. Transmission options included five and six-speed manuals, continuously variable transmission (CVT), and conventional automatics depending on market and engine, with front-wheel drive standard and all-wheel drive available on certain variants. The interior saw improvements in material quality, design, and technology, with available features including keyless entry and start, automatic climate control, and more sophisticated infotainment systems. Safety features expanded to include up to seven airbags, electronic stability control, and available crash mitigation systems in some markets. This generation further developed the Swift's reputation for combining style, driving enjoyment, and efficiency in a practical package, continuing its global success while facing increasingly tough competition in the subcompact segment.
Suzuki-Swift.name: Sixth Generation (ZC72/82/32/AZG series)

Suzuki-Swift.description: The seventh-generation Suzuki Swift refines the established design language while introducing significant advances in platform technology, efficiency, and features. Built on Suzuki's new HEARTECT platform, which reduces weight while improving rigidity and crash performance, the current Swift maintains its distinctive styling with an evolution of the 'helmet visor' windshield, floating roof effect enhanced by blacked-out pillars, concealed rear door handles, and more complex surface detailing. Available primarily as a five-door hatchback (with the three-door now discontinued in most markets), the seventh-generation Swift is slightly shorter but wider than its predecessor, with improved interior space efficiency. Engine options vary by market but center around a 1.2-liter Dualjet naturally aspirated four-cylinder and a 1.0-liter Boosterjet turbocharged three-cylinder, with the innovative 1.2-liter SHVS mild hybrid system available in many regions, providing improved efficiency through regenerative braking and electric assist. Transmission options include five and six-speed manuals, continuously variable transmission (CVT), and conventional automatics depending on market and engine, with front-wheel drive standard and all-wheel drive available on certain variants. The Swift Sport continues as the performance model, now featuring a 1.4-liter Boosterjet turbocharged engine producing up to 140 horsepower in a lighter package, improving the power-to-weight ratio. The interior features a more premium design with a driver-focused dashboard, 7-inch touchscreen infotainment system with smartphone integration on higher trims, and improved materials. Safety technology has advanced significantly with Suzuki Safety Support offering features including autonomous emergency braking, lane departure warning, and adaptive cruise control—sophisticated technology for the subcompact segment. This generation continues the Swift's trajectory as a stylish, fun-to-drive subcompact with improved efficiency and safety features.
Suzuki-Swift.name: Seventh Generation (ZC13/33/43/53/83/93/A2L series)

Suzuki-Swift.description: The eighth-generation Suzuki Swift builds upon the successful formula established by its predecessor while introducing significant updates in design, technology, and efficiency. The hatchback is still underpinned by the same Heartect platform, but redesigned to appeal to Generation Z with more aerodynamic styling claimed to be 4.6% more efficient through features including back door side spoilers, optimized front strake, front bumper and wheel shape. The hidden rear door handle on the rear door frame is reverted to the original position to blend with the side body lines, bringing back older Swift design identity. The Japanese market Swift received slightly different exterior details such as a different grille mesh design with chrome garnish and an additional rear bumper cover for top models. The interior features a new multi-layered dashboard design similar to SX4 S-Cross or Baleno, redesigned door panels and a bigger 9-inch LCD screen for the top model. Safety and convenience features were also revamped with additional front parking sensors, electronic parking brake, driver monitoring system and an advanced collision avoidance system Dual Sensor Brake Support II (DSBS II) which added wider detection range for bicycles and motorcycles. A brand new 1.2-liter three-cylinder engine called Z12E was introduced, replacing the older K12D/N Dualjet four-cylinder engines and available in conventional or mild hybrid versions. It is mated to a 5-speed manual transmission or a newly developed lightweight CVT, available for both front or all-wheel drive configurations. A CNG variant of the Z12E engine was introduced in India in September 2024.
Suzuki-Swift.name: Eighth Generation (AOL series)

Suzuki-Vitara.description: The first-generation Suzuki Vitara (marketed as the Escudo in Japan and Sidekick in some markets) pioneered the compact SUV segment with a design that combined off-road capability with more car-like dimensions and handling than traditional utility vehicles. Initially available as a short-wheelbase three-door convertible or hardtop, with a longer five-door variant added later, the original Vitara featured a distinctive boxy design with round headlights and a spare tire mounted on the rear door. Built on a proper ladder frame chassis with part-time four-wheel drive featuring a two-speed transfer case, the Vitara offered genuine off-road capability uncommon in its size class. Engine options varied by market and over the production run but typically included 1.6-liter and later 1.8-liter and 2.0-liter gasoline engines, with some markets also receiving diesel options. Transmission choices included five-speed manual and four-speed automatic, with selectable four-wheel drive. The interior was functional and straightforward with a focus on durability rather than luxury, though higher trim levels offered improved materials and additional features. This generation established the Vitara as a practical compromise between traditional off-roaders and passenger cars, appealing to buyers seeking outdoor lifestyle capabilities without the size, cost, and compromised on-road manners of larger SUVs. The model achieved particular success in developing markets where its combination of durability, off-road capability, and relatively accessible pricing proved especially valuable.
Suzuki-Vitara.name: First Generation (ET/TA)

Suzuki-Vitara.description: The second-generation Suzuki Vitara, often marketed as the Grand Vitara to distinguish it from the continuing first-generation model in some markets, represented a significant evolution with more sophisticated styling, improved on-road performance, and enhanced refinement. Available in three-door and five-door body styles, this generation featured more rounded, contemporary styling while maintaining clear visual connections to its predecessor. A key mechanical change was the adoption of a monocoque body with integrated ladder frame, combining elements of both unibody and body-on-frame construction to balance on-road refinement with off-road durability. Engine options expanded to include 1.6-liter, 2.0-liter, and 2.5-liter V6 gasoline engines in most markets, with 1.9-liter and 2.0-liter diesel options in some regions. All variants maintained a proper four-wheel drive system with low-range gearing, though now with permanent four-wheel drive on many models rather than the selectable system of the previous generation. The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and feature content, with available amenities including climate control, improved audio systems, and leather upholstery on higher trim levels. Safety features expanded to include dual front airbags, ABS brakes, and greater crash protection through improved body structure. This generation further developed the Vitara's positioning as a more premium compact SUV offering genuine off-road capability uncommon in its segment, finding particular success in markets where challenging road conditions or recreational off-roading were common considerations for buyers.
Suzuki-Vitara.name: Second Generation (FT/GT)

Suzuki-Vitara.description: The third-generation Suzuki Grand Vitara (with the 'Grand' prefix now standard in most markets) continued the model's evolution toward increased refinement and on-road performance while maintaining more off-road capability than most competitors in the compact SUV segment. Available in three-door and five-door body styles, though with the three-door discontinued in many markets before the end of the generation, the new Grand Vitara featured more upscale, sophisticated styling with a prominent chrome grille and integrated body cladding. This generation marked a return to a full unibody construction but with an integrated ladder frame for rigidity, maintaining a compromise between on-road comfort and off-road durability. Engine options varied by market but typically included 1.6-liter, 2.0-liter, and 2.4-liter four-cylinder and 2.7-liter V6 gasoline engines, with diesel options in some regions. All variants featured a full-time four-wheel drive system with a locking center differential and proper low-range gearing on most models, distinguishing it from the increasingly car-based competition. The interior represented a significant step forward with improved design, material quality, and technology, featuring available amenities including touchscreen navigation, premium audio systems, keyless entry and start, and enhanced safety features including multiple airbags, stability control, and improved crash structures. Throughout its long production run, this generation received various updates to styling, equipment, and powertrains, helping maintain its competitiveness in an increasingly crowded segment. The third-generation Grand Vitara successfully balanced improved on-road manners and comfort with continued off-road capability beyond most rivals, though as the market shifted increasingly toward car-based crossovers with limited off-road pretensions, it gradually became a more niche offering for buyers specifically seeking its combination of compact dimensions and genuine off-road ability.
Suzuki-Vitara.name: Third Generation (JT)

Suzuki-Vitara.description: The fourth-generation Suzuki Vitara (dropping the 'Grand' prefix) represents a significant repositioning of the nameplate, transitioning from a compact off-road capable SUV to a more mainstream crossover focused primarily on on-road use. This strategic shift reflects broader market trends toward car-based crossovers with limited off-road aspirations but improved efficiency, driving dynamics, and technology. Available exclusively as a five-door model, the current Vitara features more contemporary, stylish design with a distinctive clamshell hood, two-tone paint options, and more aerodynamic proportions than its predecessors. Built on Suzuki's new-generation platform, this Vitara adopts a full unibody construction without the integrated ladder frame of previous generations, significantly reducing weight while improving rigidity, handling, and efficiency. Engine options vary by market and model year but typically include 1.0-liter and 1.4-liter Boosterjet turbocharged gasoline engines, 1.6-liter naturally aspirated gasoline engines in earlier years, and in some markets, 1.6-liter diesel options (discontinued in later years). A key innovation is the available mild hybrid system (SHVS) added in later model years, incorporating an integrated starter generator and lithium-ion battery to improve efficiency. Transmission options include five and six-speed manuals and six-speed automatic or CVT depending on market and engine. While standard models feature front-wheel drive, Suzuki's AllGrip four-wheel drive system is available on higher trim levels, offering multiple selectable modes but without the low-range gearing of previous generations. The interior offers a more modern design with a 7-inch touchscreen infotainment system supporting Apple CarPlay and Android Auto on higher trims, improved materials, and available features including panoramic sunroof, adaptive cruise control, and various driver assistance systems. A 2018 facelift brought updated styling and new engine options including a mild hybrid system, while a 2024 facelift introduced further design updates and enhanced safety features.
Suzuki-Vitara.name: Fourth Generation (LY)

Tata-Harrier.description: The Tata Harrier is a five-seater, diesel-engined compact crossover SUV produced by the Indian automaker Tata Motors Limited. Launched on 23 January 2019, it is positioned between the subcompact Tata Nexon and the mid-size Tata Safari. Based on the OmegaArc platform (an essentially re-engineered version of the Jaguar Land Rover D8 platform), the Harrier features distinctive styling based on Tata's Impact Design 2.0 philosophy with split headlamp configuration, a prominent grille, flared wheel arches, and a floating roof effect. Powered by a 2.0-liter Multijet/Kryotec turbocharged diesel engine producing 140 horsepower and 350 Nm of torque, paired with a six-speed manual transmission. The interior features an 8.8-inch touchscreen infotainment system with Android Auto and a 7-inch TFT instrument cluster display. Safety features include six airbags, ESP stability control, and traction control. Three driving modes (Eco, City, Sport) and a Terrain Response System with Normal, Wet, and Rough modes are offered. In October 2019, the Dark edition was launched with black interiors and exteriors. Production started in October 2018 at Tata's Pune plant.
Tata-Harrier.name: First Generation

Tata-Harrier.description: The Tata Harrier facelift was revealed alongside the Safari facelift on 6 October 2023. The updated model features exterior and interior design revisions along with enhanced technology features including a new 10.25-inch touchscreen infotainment system, 7-inch digital instrument cluster, 360-degree surround view camera, and ADAS semi-autonomous driving functionalities. A new Red Dark edition was introduced with red interior and red accents on the front grille. The mechanical specifications remain unchanged, continuing with the 2.0-liter turbo diesel engine and front-wheel drive layout. The Harrier continues to be built on the OmegaArc platform derived from the Jaguar Land Rover D8 architecture. An all-electric Harrier EV version was showcased and is set to go into production.
Tata-Harrier.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Tata-Tiago.description: Original Tata Tiago hatchback launched in 2016, successor to the Tata Bolt. Built on the modified Tata X1 platform with 1.2L Revotron petrol and 1.1L Revotorq diesel engines.
Tata-Tiago.name: First Generation

Tata-Tiago.description: Facelifted Tiago unveiled in 2020 with cosmetic changes and BS6-compliant engines. Introduced Tiago i-CNG version in 2022.
Tata-Tiago.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Tata-Tiago.description: Second facelift unveiled on January 10, 2025 featuring a redesigned front fascia.
Tata-Tiago.name: Second Generation (Facelift)

Tata-Tiago.description: Electric version of the Tiago launched in 2022. Available in Medium Range (19.2 kWh battery, 61 hp) and Long Range (24 kWh battery, 74 hp) variants.
Tata-Tiago.name: Tiago.ev (Electric)

Tesla-Cybertruck.description: The Tesla Cybertruck is a battery-electric full-size pickup truck manufactured by Tesla since 2023. It was first unveiled as a prototype in November 2019, featuring a distinctive angular design composed of flat, unpainted stainless steel body panels. After multiple delays, production began at Gigafactory Texas in November 2023, with initial customer deliveries occurring that same month. The Cybertruck is offered in three variants: a single-motor rear-wheel drive (RWD) 'Long Range' model, a dual-motor all-wheel drive (AWD) model, and a tri-motor AWD model marketed as the 'Cyberbeast'. The vehicle features an exoskeleton construction using 30X cold-rolled stainless steel, eliminating the need for traditional body stamping. Measuring approximately 223.7 inches long, 79.8 inches wide, and 70.5 inches tall, it features adjustable air suspension (on AWD and Cyberbeast trims) with up to 17 inches of ground clearance. Power outputs range from approximately 600 hp in the Long Range to 845 hp in the Cyberbeast, enabling 0-60 mph acceleration as quick as 2.6 seconds. The 123 kWh structural battery pack provides an estimated EPA range of 250-340 miles depending on configuration. Notable features include steer-by-wire with a yoke-style steering wheel, four-wheel steering with up to 10 degrees of rear-wheel articulation, and up to 9.6 kW of vehicle-to-load power output. The Cybertruck represents Tesla's entry into the pickup truck market, with a claimed towing capacity of up to 11,000 pounds and a payload capacity of approximately 2,500 pounds.
Tesla-Cybertruck.name: First Generation

Tesla-Model-3.description: The Tesla Model 3 represented the company's long-promised 'affordable' electric vehicle, designed to bring Tesla technology and performance to a broader market segment than the more expensive Model S and Model X. Unveiled in March 2016 and introduced in 2017, the Model 3 established a unique visual identity with its minimalist exterior design, clean lines, distinctive glass roof extending from windshield to rear window, and a near-grille-less front fascia. Initially available in rear-wheel drive single-motor and all-wheel drive dual-motor configurations, with various battery capacities offering ranges from approximately 220 to 310 miles depending on variant, the Model 3 delivered impressive performance with 0-60 mph times ranging from 5.6 seconds in base models to 3.1 seconds in the Performance variant. The interior introduced Tesla's ultra-minimalist approach with almost all controls relegated to a central 15.4-inch landscape-oriented touchscreen and nearly no physical buttons, creating a uniquely clean, futuristic cabin aesthetic. Standard features included Autopilot driver assistance capabilities, over-the-air software updates, and access to Tesla's Supercharger network, while premium features like improved audio systems and heated seats were included in higher trim levels. Manufacturing challenges during the initial production ramp in 2017-2018, dubbed 'production hell' by CEO Elon Musk, gradually resolved as Tesla mastered the challenges of mass production. In November 2020, the Model 3 received exterior and interior styling changes carried over from the Model Y, including black-finished door handles, side mirror trim, window trim, and camera covers, along with a heat pump with octovalve for improved climate control, a power-operated trunk, and a redesigned center console with Qi wireless charging pads. In June 2021, the Model 3 became the first electric car to pass global sales of 1 million units, and from July 2017 through 2023, it was the world's top-selling electric vehicle until briefly superseded by the Tesla Model Y crossover.
Tesla-Model-3.name: First Generation

Tesla-Model-3.description: Tesla announced a major design refresh of the Model 3 on September 1, 2023, bringing a longer driving range, lower production costs, technical improvements, and a restyled exterior and interior. During development, the refresh was codenamed 'Project Highland' and was exhibited at the 2023 Munich Motor Show. The refreshed Model 3 improved range by approximately 10%, largely from a lower and more aerodynamic nose along with a better rear diffuser and more aerodynamic wheels. The drag coefficient improved from 0.225 Cd. Exterior changes included redesigned tail lights that eliminated the vertical break between trunk and side, new headlights, taillights, and wheels. Interior additions included an 8-inch touchscreen for rear seat passengers with Bluetooth audio capability, ventilated front seats, up to a 17-speaker sound system (up from 14), customizable interior accent lighting, and a new steering wheel without turn signal and gear selector stalks (controls moved to steering wheel buttons and touchscreen). The upgrade featured Frequency Selective Damping shock-absorbing technology. Gigafactory Shanghai was the first to begin making the refreshed Model 3, with availability in China and export markets including Europe, the Middle East, Australia, and Japan. The refreshed Model 3 became available for order in North America on January 10, 2024, with these models produced at the Tesla Fremont Factory. The update came equipped with HW4 camera and processing technology, which permitted a wider field of view and improved Autopilot's cross-traffic emergency braking.
Tesla-Model-3.name: Second Generation (Highland)

Tesla-Model-S.description: The original Tesla Model S (2012-2016) represented a watershed moment for electric vehicles, being the first purpose-built EV from the company and establishing a new benchmark for long-range, high-performance electric motoring. Designed from the ground up as an electric vehicle rather than a conversion of an existing platform, the Model S featured a distinctive fastback sedan profile with clean, aerodynamic styling achieving a remarkably low 0.24 drag coefficient. The aluminum-intensive body structure housed a floor-mounted battery pack (available in 60, 70, 85, or 90 kWh capacities) providing ranges from approximately 208 to 270 miles—unprecedented for production EVs of the era. The AC induction motor in base models produced 362 hp, with performance variants including the P85 and P85D delivering supercar-rivaling acceleration. Early models featured a minimalist interior centered around a pioneering 17-inch vertical touchscreen controlling most vehicle functions. Distinctive features included an available third-row rear-facing jump seat for children, a front trunk ('frunk') providing additional storage, and over-the-air software updates—a revolutionary concept in the automotive industry at the time. Tesla's proprietary Supercharger network, launched alongside the Model S, addressed the critical issue of long-distance travel for EVs. The first-generation Model S received numerous updates throughout its production, including the introduction of dual-motor all-wheel drive ('D' variants) in 2014 with the P85D, and Autopilot driver assistance technology. The vehicle earned unprecedented acclaim, including Motor Trend's 2013 Car of the Year award and the highest score ever recorded by Consumer Reports at the time, while establishing Tesla as a significant player in the premium automotive market.
Tesla-Model-S.name: First Generation (2012-2016)

Tesla-Model-S.description: The facelifted Tesla Model S introduced in 2016 featured significant visual and technological updates while maintaining the same fundamental platform. The most obvious exterior change was the elimination of the faux grille, replaced with a smoother nose section more similar to the Model X, along with revised headlights and minor rear styling tweaks. Interior updates included new front seats and additional finish choices. Technical improvements encompassed a new HEPA air filtration system, faster charging capabilities, and improved standard equipment. During this period (2016-2019), Tesla continually enhanced the Model S with more efficient electric motors, improved battery management for increased range, and enhanced Autopilot hardware. Battery capacities were rationalized to 75 and 100 kWh variants, with the P90D continuing to offer extreme performance. The cabin technology received regular updates through over-the-air software improvements. The dual-motor P100D achieved 0-60 mph acceleration in approximately 2.4 seconds with Ludicrous Plus mode. While maintaining its position as Tesla's flagship sedan, this generation of Model S faced increasing competition from Tesla's own more affordable Model 3 and other premium electric vehicles.
Tesla-Model-S.name: First Generation (2016-2019 Facelift)

Tesla-Model-S.description: In mid-2019, Tesla streamlined its Model S lineup by replacing the previous 75D, 100D, and P100D models with Standard Range, Long Range, and Performance models. This represented a simplification of nomenclature while continuing the same fundamental platform architecture. The Long Range variant featured a 100 kWh battery with dual motors generating 469 hp and 730 Nm of torque, providing up to 375 miles of range. The Performance variant produced 754 hp and 687 lb-ft of torque with the same 100 kWh battery and a range of 365 miles. A new motor technology was introduced for dual-motor models: a permanent magnet synchronous reluctance motor at the front and an AC induction motor at the rear, improving efficiency by approximately ten percent. For 2020, the Long Range Plus model was introduced with 100 kWh battery, dual motors producing 417 hp and 485 lb-ft of torque, and an EPA-rated range of 400 miles. This period maintained the original interior design philosophy with the portrait-oriented 17-inch touchscreen before the comprehensive redesign of 2021.
Tesla-Model-S.name: First Generation (2019-2021 Simplified Naming)

Tesla-Model-S.description: The 2021 redesign of the Tesla Model S represents the most comprehensive update to the vehicle since its introduction, featuring an entirely new interior architecture and the introduction of the high-performance Plaid variant. Exterior changes were relatively subtle with minimal alterations to the car's distinctive silhouette. The interior received a dramatic overhaul, replacing the portrait 17-inch touchscreen with a new landscape-oriented 17-inch display, eliminating the traditional gear selector in favor of automatic gear selection via touchscreen controls, and introducing a 'yoke' steering wheel design lacking a conventional rim (though a conventional wheel became optional later). Performance saw revolutionary advances with the tri-motor Plaid variant, producing 1,020 horsepower and achieving 0-60 mph acceleration in under 2 seconds with rollout—making it among the quickest production cars ever made regardless of powertrain type. The Plaid achieved 359 miles EPA range despite its extreme performance focus. The standard dual-motor Long Range variant achieved up to 405 miles EPA range. Technical updates included a new heat pump climate system for improved efficiency in cold weather and completely revised computing hardware powering the infotainment and driver assistance systems. A Plaid+ variant with 520+ miles of range was announced but canceled before production. The second-generation Model S maintains Tesla's position at the forefront of electric vehicle performance and technology, with all-wheel drive standard across configurations and access to Full Self-Driving capability.
Tesla-Model-S.name: Second Generation (2021-Present Redesign)

Tesla-Model-X.description: The original Tesla Model X represented a pioneering entry in the electric SUV segment, combining the company's battery and powertrain technology with a distinctive crossover design featuring dramatic falcon-wing rear doors that articulated upward on dual hinges. These unique doors, while visually striking and providing excellent access to the second and third rows, presented significant engineering and production challenges that contributed to the vehicle's delayed launch. Built on a modified version of the Model S platform, the Model X featured a floor-mounted battery pack (available in 60, 75, 90, or 100 kWh capacities depending on model year and variant) providing ranges from approximately 237 to 325 miles. Performance was exceptional for a vehicle of its size, with the P100D variant capable of 0-60 mph acceleration in approximately 2.9 seconds when equipped with Ludicrous Mode. The interior offered seating configurations for five, six, or seven passengers across three rows, with the second-row seats mounted on single posts that allowed them to move forward and tilt independently even with child seats installed. The minimalist dashboard centered around a 17-inch vertical touchscreen controlling most vehicle functions. Distinctive features included a massive panoramic windshield extending far into the roof, automatically opening front doors, and a bioweapon defense mode air filtration system. The Model X included Tesla's developing Autopilot driver assistance technology, with hardware evolving through several generations during this production period. Despite its groundbreaking technology and performance, the early Model X faced criticism for reliability issues, particularly related to the complex falcon-wing doors and automatic front doors, though many of these concerns were addressed through design refinements and over-the-air software updates throughout its production run.
Tesla-Model-X.name: First Generation (Pre-Refresh)

Tesla-Model-X.description: The refreshed Tesla Model X, sometimes referred to as the second generation though technically still based on the same platform, received its most substantial update in 2021 alongside the Model S. Exterior changes were modest, maintaining the vehicle's distinctive silhouette with falcon-wing rear doors but incorporating slightly revised front and rear styling with new wheel designs. The interior saw a dramatic transformation, replacing the portrait touchscreen with a new 17-inch landscape-oriented display, adding a second screen for rear passengers, and most controversially, replacing the conventional steering wheel with a 'yoke' design lacking an upper rim (though a conventional wheel later became optional). Seating configurations continued to offer five, six, or seven-passenger arrangements with improved comfort and materials. Performance reached new heights with the introduction of the tri-motor Plaid variant, producing 1,020 horsepower and achieving 0-60 mph acceleration in approximately 2.5 seconds—extraordinary figures for a three-row SUV weighing over 5,000 pounds. Range improved with the Long Range variant EPA-rated at up to 352 miles as of 2024. Technical updates included a new heat pump climate system for improved efficiency in cold weather, updated battery architecture, and completely revised computing hardware powering the infotainment and driver assistance systems. Tesla's Autopilot and Full Self-Driving capabilities continued to evolve through over-the-air updates, though still requiring active driver supervision. A further update was introduced in June 2025 with new front bumper styling, updated camera arrangements, new wheel designs, increased third-row space, dynamic ambient lighting, and adaptive headlights. The refreshed Model X maintained its position as one of the most capable electric SUVs on the market, though at a significantly higher price point than the previous generation, reflecting both its more premium positioning and the broader market shifts in electric vehicle pricing. The Model X continues to stand out for its unique combination of distinctive design, exceptional performance, long range, and access to Tesla's mature Supercharger network, though it faces increasing competition from new electric SUV entrants from established luxury manufacturers.
Tesla-Model-X.name: Second Generation (Refresh/Plaid)

Tesla-Model-Y.description: The original Tesla Model Y, introduced in March 2019 and entering production in January 2020. Based on the Model 3 sedan with approximately 75% parts commonality, featuring a taller body, increased cargo space, and optional third-row seating. The design includes a minimalist exterior with clean lines, panoramic glass roof, and lack of traditional grille. Initial configurations included Long Range AWD and Performance variants, with a Standard Range RWD that was briefly offered then discontinued. Production occurred at Fremont Factory (California), Giga Shanghai (China from December 2020), Gigafactory Texas (late 2021), and Gigafactory Berlin-Brandenburg (March 2022). Technical features include a heat pump system with Octovalve, single-piece rear casting (Giga Press), and radar-based driver assistance. Range varies from approximately 279 to 330 miles depending on configuration.
Tesla-Model-Y.name: First Generation

Tesla-Model-Y.description: A significantly refreshed Model Y, internally codenamed 'Juniper', revealed in January 2025. Exterior changes include a full-width light bar as daytime running lights and tail light, sleeker front design with more streamlined nose, thin light bar across the hood, redesigned wheels, and rear diffuser to reduce drag. Interior adopts design cues from the updated Model 3, including wraparound ambient lighting, 15.4-inch central touchscreen, ventilated seats, and an 8-inch rear touchscreen for second-row passengers. Additional upgrades include powered rear seats, improved suspension, double-layer acoustic glass on all windows, and silver-coated panoramic glass roof. The Long Range variant was rebranded as 'Model Y Premium' in North America in October 2025. A Model Y Performance variant debuted in August 2025 for Europe/Middle East/Africa and October 2025 for North America, featuring carbon fiber rear spoiler, gloss black trim, red brake calipers, and Performance 4DU dual-motor system producing 456 hp. A Model Y L long-wheelbase variant with three-row six-seat configuration was introduced in June 2025, produced at Gigafactory Shanghai.
Tesla-Model-Y.name: Second Generation (Juniper Refresh)

Toyota-4Runner.description: The first-generation Toyota 4Runner essentially began as a modified Toyota pickup truck (Hilux) with a fiberglass shell covering the bed and rear seats added, evolving Toyota's presence in the growing sport utility vehicle market. Available initially only as a two-door model with a removable fiberglass top over the rear section, the original 4Runner featured a solid front axle and leaf spring suspension emphasizing off-road capability over on-road comfort. Engine options in the US market included a 2.4-liter four-cylinder gasoline engine (22R, later the fuel-injected 22RE) and, briefly, a 2.4-liter turbodiesel option, paired with either manual or automatic transmissions and part-time four-wheel drive with a two-speed transfer case. The interior was spartan by modern standards, with basic amenities and a utilitarian design reflecting the vehicle's truck-based origins. A notable and controversial feature was the removable rear seat that faced sideways, a configuration that would later be deemed unsafe and discontinued. Throughout its production, the first-generation 4Runner gained additional comfort features and refinements, including an available SR5 package with upgraded interior materials and features. This generation established the 4Runner's reputation for durability and off-road capability, though with significant compromises in terms of on-road comfort, interior space, and safety compared to more car-like SUVs that would later dominate the market.
Toyota-4Runner.name: First Generation (N60)

Toyota-4Runner.description: The second-generation Toyota 4Runner marked a significant evolution from its pickup-based predecessor, featuring a completely unique body design (though still sharing much of its underpinnings with the Hilux/Pickup). Available in both two-door and four-door configurations, this generation transitioned the model toward greater comfort and versatility while maintaining serious off-road capability. A key mechanical change was the switch from a solid front axle to an independent front suspension on four-wheel drive models, improving on-road handling and ride quality while still providing good off-road articulation. Engine options expanded to include a 2.4-liter four-cylinder and a more powerful 3.0-liter V6, both available with manual or automatic transmissions. All models featured a proper steel roof (no more removable fiberglass top) with either a standard steel roof or an optional power moonroof or removable rear section on some variants. The interior saw significant improvements in design, materials, and features, offering a more car-like environment while maintaining utility with fold-down rear seats for expanded cargo capacity. Safety features improved with the introduction of available anti-lock brakes and four-wheel disc brakes on higher trim levels. The second-generation 4Runner successfully balanced the rugged capability expected of the nameplate with increased refinement and practicality, broadening its appeal beyond the hardcore off-road enthusiasts who embraced the first generation. This model established the 4Runner's position in Toyota's lineup as a versatile SUV suitable for both daily driving and weekend adventures.
Toyota-4Runner.name: Second Generation (N120/N130)

Toyota-4Runner.description: The third-generation Toyota 4Runner continued the model's evolution toward increased refinement and versatility while maintaining its reputation for off-road capability and durability. Featuring a more aerodynamic exterior design with smoother lines and a more integrated appearance compared to the boxy previous generations, this model grew in size, offering increased interior space for passengers and cargo. Mechanically, the third-generation 4Runner retained a body-on-frame construction but switched all models to independent front suspension for improved on-road handling and comfort. Engine options initially included a 2.7-liter four-cylinder and a 3.4-liter V6, both offering improved power and efficiency compared to their predecessors, paired with either manual or automatic transmissions and two-wheel or four-wheel drive. Interior quality saw significant improvements with more car-like amenities, improved noise insulation, and available features including power windows, locks, and seating, premium audio, and leather upholstery on higher trim levels. Safety features expanded to include dual front airbags, available ABS, and improved crash protection through a reinforced body structure. Toyota's off-road technology advanced with this generation, introducing features like Active Traction Control (A-TRAC) and optional rear differential lockers on some variants, enhancing the vehicle's capability in challenging terrain while making it more accessible to drivers of varying skill levels. Positioned between the smaller RAV4 and the larger Land Cruiser, the third-generation 4Runner found success by balancing everyday usability with weekend adventure capability, appealing to families, outdoor enthusiasts, and anyone seeking a durable, versatile SUV.
Toyota-4Runner.name: Third Generation (N180)

Toyota-4Runner.description: The fourth-generation Toyota 4Runner represented a significant redesign, growing larger and more powerful while introducing more sophisticated technology and comfort features. Exterior styling became more aggressive and angular, with pronounced fender flares, a bold front fascia, and an overall more imposing presence. Based on Toyota's new 4×4 platform shared with the Land Cruiser Prado (and Lexus GX), this generation featured a stronger, more rigid frame and updated suspension geometry for improved handling both on and off-road. Engine options in the North American market included a standard 4.0-liter V6 producing 245 horsepower and an optional 4.7-liter V8 making 270 horsepower, both paired with automatic transmissions—the first time a V8 was offered in the 4Runner. Advanced off-road technology expanded with the introduction of Toyota's Downhill Assist Control (DAC), Hill-start Assist Control (HAC), and a more sophisticated four-wheel drive system with electronic terrain controls on higher trim levels, including a center locking differential on some variants. The interior size increased significantly with more passenger space in all dimensions and expanded cargo capacity, while quality and feature content reached new levels with available amenities including a premium JBL audio system, DVD navigation, leather upholstery, and heated seats. Safety advanced with the addition of side and curtain airbags, electronic stability control, and improved crash structures. During this generation, Toyota positioned the 4Runner more clearly as an off-road capable SUV as consumer preferences began shifting toward more car-like crossovers, setting the stage for the model's continued focus on capability rather than following market trends toward increasingly road-oriented SUVs.
Toyota-4Runner.name: Fourth Generation (N210)

Toyota-4Runner.description: The fifth-generation Toyota 4Runner doubled down on rugged capability at a time when many competitors were transitioning to car-based crossover platforms, solidifying the model's position as one of the few remaining body-on-frame, trail-capable SUVs in its segment. Featuring muscular, angular styling with a prominent front grille, bulging fenders, and an upright greenhouse, this generation projected a purposeful, adventurous image. Powered exclusively by a 4.0-liter V6 producing 270 horsepower and 278 lb-ft of torque paired with a five-speed automatic transmission, the fifth-generation 4Runner was available in rear-wheel drive or with one of two four-wheel drive systems: a part-time system with a two-speed transfer case or, on Limited models, a full-time system with a Torsen center differential. Off-road technology reached new heights with the introduction of the TRD Pro trim in 2015, featuring Bilstein shocks with remote reservoirs, TRD-tuned springs, aggressive all-terrain tires, and distinctive styling elements, while other models offered Toyota's Multi-Terrain Select system allowing drivers to tailor traction control settings to different surfaces. Despite its focus on capability, the interior provided reasonable comfort with available features including navigation, premium audio, heated and ventilated seats, and a power-sliding rear cargo deck on some variants. Throughout its exceptionally long production run, the fifth-generation 4Runner received modest updates to styling, technology, and features, including improved infotainment systems, additional USB ports, and enhanced safety equipment, though its fundamental mechanical package remained largely unchanged. This generation became known for exceptional reliability and longevity, maintained strong resale values, and developed a devoted following among outdoor enthusiasts, off-road adventurers, and consumers seeking a rugged alternative to increasingly car-like crossovers, with annual sales actually increasing in the later years of its production despite its aging design.
Toyota-4Runner.name: Fifth Generation (N280)

Toyota-4Runner.description: The sixth-generation Toyota 4Runner, unveiled on April 9, 2024 and entering production in December 2024 for the 2025 model year, continues the model's legacy as a capable body-on-frame SUV while comprehensively modernizing its technology, efficiency, and design. Built on Toyota's GA-F platform (TNGA-F) shared with the latest Tacoma, Tundra, and Sequoia, the new 4Runner features more angular, upright styling with distinctive LED lighting signatures, bold fender flares, and a muscular overall presence that pays homage to earlier generations while looking thoroughly contemporary. The most significant mechanical change is the replacement of the long-running 4.0-liter V6 with a new 2.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine producing 278 horsepower and 317 lb-ft of torque, paired with an eight-speed Direct Shift ECTi automatic transmission—a major upgrade from the previous five-speed. A hybrid i-FORCE MAX powertrain combining the turbocharged engine with an electric motor integrated into the transmission is also available, delivering 326 horsepower and 465 lb-ft of torque along with improved efficiency. Four-wheel drive systems include both part-time and full-time options depending on trim level, all with a standard electronic locking rear differential and Multi-Terrain Select system. Off-road capability remains a core focus with the TRD Pro and new Trailhunter variants featuring specialized suspension with increased travel, skid plates, all-terrain tires, and rock rails, while ground clearance and approach/departure angles improve across the lineup. The interior represents a complete redesign with a standard 8-inch or available 14-inch touchscreen running Toyota's latest infotainment system, an available 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, and significantly improved materials and design. Cargo capacity increases slightly while a power-folding third-row seat becomes available for the first time on non-hybrid models. Toyota Safety Sense 3.0 is standard across the range, offering advanced driver assistance features including pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, dynamic radar cruise control, lane departure alert, and automatic high beams. The sixth-generation 4Runner is available in nine trim levels including the new Platinum luxury trim and Trailhunter overlanding trim, continuing Toyota's commitment to offering a vehicle for every adventure while maintaining its unique position in the market.
Toyota-4Runner.name: Sixth Generation (N500)

Toyota-Alphard.description: The first-generation Alphard was launched by Toyota on 22 May 2002. Developed under the lead of chief engineer Hideyuki Iwata, it is based on the second-generation Previa/Estima. Available with 2.4L and 3.0L petrol engines, plus a hybrid option introduced in MY 2003. The model features optional electric-powered tailgate and roll-down rear side windows. Refreshed in April 2005 with updated front grille, bumper, headlamps, and rear combination lamps.
Toyota-Alphard.name: First Generation (AH10)

Toyota-Alphard.description: Facelifted version of the first-generation Alphard introduced in April 2005. The 3.0L model received a 5-speed automatic transmission replacing the 4-speed unit. Royal Lounge version introduced in 2006 as a more upmarket four-seater variant.
Toyota-Alphard.name: First Generation (AH10) Facelift

Toyota-Alphard.description: Second-generation Alphard launched in May 2008. Developed under chief engineer Yuzo Nakagoshi, it shares design cues with the first generation. Available with 2.4L (ANH20/25), 3.5L (GGH20/25) petrol engines, and 2.4L hybrid (ATH20). Twin model Vellfire introduced as successor to Alphard V, sold through Netz Store dealership chain.
Toyota-Alphard.name: Second Generation (AH20)

Toyota-Alphard.description: Facelifted second-generation Alphard announced September 27, 2011 and released November 1, 2011. Hybrid version reintroduced with THS2 system including Eco Mode and EV mode. Styling updates across all models with improved interior trim materials and Nanoe air purifiers available.
Toyota-Alphard.name: Second Generation (AH20) Facelift

Toyota-Alphard.description: Third-generation Alphard released January 26, 2015 on the Toyota New MC platform. Features completely redesigned exterior with new 2.5L 2AR-FE petrol and 2.5L 2AR-FXE hybrid engines, plus carryover 3.5L 2GR-FE V6. New double wishbone rear suspension replaces torsion beam setup. Executive Lounge grade added as top-of-line variant.
Toyota-Alphard.name: Third Generation (AH30)

Toyota-Alphard.description: Facelifted third-generation Alphard unveiled December 25, 2017 and released January 8, 2018. Updated 2GR-FKS V6 engine replaces the 2GR-FE. New Direct-Shift 8-speed automatic introduced for V6 variants. Toyota Safety Sense 2 becomes standard across all variants. Production ended in June 2022.
Toyota-Alphard.name: Third Generation (AH30) Facelift

Toyota-Alphard.description: Fourth-generation Alphard released June 21, 2023 on the TNGA-K platform. Features improved rigidity with straight rockers and V-shaped rear brace, plus MacPherson struts front and updated double wishbone rear suspension. Insignia moved to front door window frames. New 2.5L A25A-FXS hybrid and 2.4L T24A-FTS turbo engines available alongside carryover 2.5L 2AR-FE petrol.
Toyota-Alphard.name: Fourth Generation (AH40)

Toyota-Aqua.description: The first-generation Toyota Aqua, marketed as the Prius c in North America and some other markets, was developed as a compact hybrid vehicle aimed at urban drivers seeking maximum efficiency in a smaller package than the standard Prius. Built on a modified Yaris platform but featuring Toyota's Hybrid Synergy Drive system, the Aqua measured just 4 meters in length while offering four-door practicality with a five-door hatchback configuration. Powered by a 1.5-liter Atkinson cycle four-cylinder engine paired with an electric motor for a combined output of 99 horsepower, the Aqua achieved remarkable fuel economy figures of approximately 35-40 km/L (82-94 mpg) in the Japanese JC08 test cycle. The powertrain utilized a continuously variable transmission (CVT) and a nickel-metal hydride battery pack positioned under the rear seat to maintain cargo space. The interior featured a centrally mounted digital speedometer and hybrid system monitor above a conventional dashboard layout, with equipment levels ranging from basic to relatively well-appointed in higher trim levels. Despite its compact dimensions, the Aqua offered reasonable passenger space with a flexible rear seat that could fold to expand the cargo area. Throughout its production run, the Aqua received several updates including a facelift in 2015 that introduced more aggressive styling, improved interior materials, and enhanced equipment options. The model achieved significant success, particularly in the Japanese domestic market where it frequently ranked among the top-selling vehicles overall, appealing to buyers seeking an affordable, practical hybrid for urban environments.
Toyota-Aqua.name: First Generation (P10)

Toyota-Aqua.description: The second-generation Toyota Aqua builds upon the successful formula of its predecessor while introducing significant technological advancements and quality improvements. Continuing as a compact five-door hybrid hatchback, the new Aqua maintains similar dimensions but features more sophisticated styling with smoother lines, LED lighting, and a more premium overall appearance. The most notable technical innovation is the world's first high-output bipolar nickel-hydrogen battery for a production hybrid vehicle, which delivers approximately twice the output of the previous generation's battery despite similar physical dimensions, enabling more responsive acceleration and increased electric-only driving capability. The powertrain combines a more efficient 1.5-liter Dynamic Force engine with Toyota's latest hybrid system for a combined output of 91 horsepower, achieving a class-leading fuel economy of 35.8 km/L (84.3 mpg) in the WLTC Japanese test cycle. A new electronic four-wheel drive system (E-Four) is available for the first time, using an additional rear-mounted electric motor to provide enhanced traction when needed. The interior represents a significant upgrade with a standard 7-inch or optional 10.5-inch touchscreen infotainment system, digital instrument cluster, and improved materials throughout. Safety technology advances with the Toyota Safety Sense package including pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, lane tracing assist, and dynamic radar cruise control as standard equipment. An innovative feature is the power supply delivery system that can convert the Aqua's DC battery power to AC, allowing the vehicle to serve as a mobile power source during emergencies—an increasingly valued capability in disaster-prone Japan. The second-generation Aqua continues the model's mission of providing accessible hybrid technology in a practical compact package, now with enhanced performance, technology, and versatility that help maintain its position as one of Japan's most popular hybrid vehicles.
Toyota-Aqua.name: Second Generation (P15)

Toyota-Auris.description: The first-generation Toyota Auris was introduced as a replacement for the Corolla hatchback in European and some Asian markets, though the Corolla nameplate continued in sedan form and in other regions. Designed specifically to appeal to European tastes and compete with popular hatchbacks like the Volkswagen Golf, the Auris featured more dynamic styling than the Corolla it replaced, with a shorter, taller body profile and distinctive character lines. Available as a five-door hatchback (with a three-door variant added later in some markets), the Auris was built on Toyota's MC platform shared with the contemporary Corolla. Engine options varied by market but typically included 1.4-liter and 1.6-liter gasoline engines, a 1.8-liter in higher trim levels (including a hybrid variant introduced in 2010), and 1.4-liter and 2.0-liter diesel options popular in European markets. The hybrid version, known as Auris Hybrid, was notable as the first mass-produced hybrid vehicle in the compact segment from a mainstream manufacturer. A facelift in 2010 brought revised exterior styling, improved interior materials, and enhanced equipment levels.
Toyota-Auris.name: First Generation (E150)

Toyota-Auris.description: The second-generation Toyota Auris featured more distinctive, angular styling as part of Toyota's effort to create more emotionally appealing designs under the direction of President Akio Toyoda. Built on an updated version of the MC platform, the new Auris adopted a lower, wider stance with a more aggressive front end featuring sharper headlights and a prominent grille. Available in five-door hatchback and wagon (Touring Sports) body styles, the latter being a new addition to the lineup, the Auris grew slightly in length while reducing height for improved proportions and aerodynamics. Engine options continued to include small-displacement gasoline and diesel units, with the hybrid powertrain becoming increasingly important to the model mix. The interior saw improvements in design and material quality, adopting a more horizontal dashboard layout with softer touch surfaces. A facelift in 2015 brought revised exterior styling, new engine options including a 1.2-liter turbocharged gasoline unit, and further interior refinements.
Toyota-Auris.name: Second Generation (E180)

Toyota-Auris.description: The third-generation Auris is based on the Toyota New Global Architecture (TNGA) platform, representing a significant step forward in driving dynamics and refinement. Unveiled as a pre-production model in March 2018 at the Geneva Motor Show, this generation marked the first use of TNGA for the C-segment hatchback. The Auris nameplate was discontinued across Europe with this generation, replaced by the Corolla nameplate starting January 2019. However, the Auris name continued in Taiwan from September 2018 to July 2020. The Taiwanese market version was powered by a 2.0-liter M20A-FKS petrol engine mated to a simulated 10-speed Direct Shift CVT, equipped with Toyota Safety Sense (TSS), vehicle stability control, traction control, hill-start assist, head-up display, push start, and smart entry systems. The E210 platform offered improved driving dynamics, a lower center of gravity, and enhanced safety features compared to its predecessors.
Toyota-Auris.name: Third Generation (E210)

Toyota-Avalon.description: The first-generation Toyota Avalon was introduced as Toyota's flagship sedan for the North American market, positioned above the Camry as a larger, more premium offering. Designed specifically with American consumers in mind, the Avalon featured conservative, understated styling with a formal roofline and traditional three-box sedan proportions. Built on an extended version of the Camry platform, the Avalon offered a spacious interior with a focus on comfort, particularly for rear passengers who enjoyed nearly limousine-like legroom for a mainstream sedan. Powered by a 3.0-liter V6 engine producing 192 horsepower, paired with a four-speed automatic transmission, the Avalon delivered smooth, quiet performance in keeping with its near-luxury positioning. The interior emphasized comfort and convenience with features including a front bench seat option (allowing six-passenger seating), power amenities, available leather upholstery, and premium audio. Suspension tuning prioritized ride comfort over handling dynamics, creating a plush, floating ride quality that appealed to buyers seeking a comfortable highway cruiser. Though the Avalon didn't carry a luxury badge, its size, equipment, and refinement positioned it as a value alternative to entry-level luxury sedans while offering typically excellent Toyota reliability. The first-generation Avalon established the model's identity as Toyota's interpretation of traditional American large car values—comfortable, spacious, and well-equipped—while incorporating Japanese engineering for improved quality and efficiency compared to domestic competitors of the era.
Toyota-Avalon.name: First Generation (XX10)

Toyota-Avalon.description: The second-generation Toyota Avalon maintained the model's position as Toyota's flagship sedan for North America while introducing more sophisticated styling and enhanced features. The exterior design evolved with more rounded forms, a sleeker greenhouse, and improved proportions, creating a more upscale appearance while remaining conservative and understated. Slightly larger than its predecessor, the new Avalon continued to offer exceptional interior space, particularly for rear-seat passengers, cementing its reputation as a comfortable alternative to more expensive luxury sedans. The 3.0-liter V6 engine was revised to produce 210 horsepower and paired with a more responsive four-speed automatic transmission, delivering improved performance while maintaining the smooth, quiet character expected of the model. The interior saw significant improvements in design and material quality, offering a more premium environment with available features including dual-zone climate control, improved audio systems, and enhanced convenience features. Safety technology expanded to include standard front side airbags and available side curtain airbags—advanced features for the era. The second-generation Avalon continued the model's focus on comfort-oriented driving dynamics with a plush ride quality and light steering, though with marginally improved handling compared to its predecessor. This generation further developed the Avalon's position as a 'stealth luxury' option for consumers who valued comfort, space, and reliability over badge prestige, serving as a bridge between mainstream sedans and true luxury offerings while demonstrating Toyota's ability to create a convincing premium product.
Toyota-Avalon.name: Second Generation (XX20)

Toyota-Avalon.description: The third-generation Toyota Avalon represented a more significant evolution of Toyota's flagship sedan, featuring more distinctive styling with a sleeker, more modern silhouette while maintaining the model's focus on comfort and refinement. The exterior design incorporated more character lines, a more pronounced grille, and overall more presence than its understated predecessors, signaling Toyota's desire to attract younger buyers to what had been perceived as a car for older demographics. Interior space remained a key selling point with class-leading rear seat room, while material quality and design took another step upmarket with available features including Smart Key entry, push-button start, navigation, JBL premium audio, and heated/ventilated seats. Power came from a new 3.5-liter V6 engine producing 268 horsepower—a significant increase—paired with a five-speed automatic transmission (later upgraded to six-speed), providing both improved performance and efficiency. The driving experience remained comfort-focused with a smooth, quiet ride, though with more composed handling than previous generations and available stability control for enhanced safety. A facelift in 2008 brought refreshed styling, enhanced interior features, and additional safety technology. The third-generation Avalon successfully maintained its position as a value-oriented alternative to luxury sedans while offering a more contemporary, slightly more engaging package than its predecessors. This generation helped expand the model's appeal somewhat beyond its traditional older buyer base, though still primarily attracting consumers who prioritized comfort and quality over sporty driving dynamics or flashy design.
Toyota-Avalon.name: Third Generation (XX30)

Toyota-Avalon.description: The fourth-generation Toyota Avalon marked the most dramatic reinvention of the model to date, featuring bold, assertive styling with a large, distinctive grille, complex surfacing, and a more coupe-like roofline. This significant design departure reflected Toyota's determination to shed the Avalon's staid image and attract younger buyers to their flagship sedan. Built on a new platform shared with the contemporary Lexus ES, the Avalon maintained generous interior dimensions while featuring a more driver-focused cockpit with a standard touchscreen infotainment system, capacitive touch controls, and ambient lighting creating a more premium atmosphere. For the first time, a hybrid variant joined the lineup, combining a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine with electric motors for a total system output of 200 horsepower and impressive EPA-rated fuel economy of 40 mpg combined. The standard powertrain remained a refined 3.5-liter V6 producing 268 horsepower, now paired with a six-speed automatic transmission. Driving dynamics received increased attention with a more rigid chassis, revised suspension tuning, and selectable drive modes, creating a more engaging experience while maintaining the comfort expected of the nameplate. Available features expanded to include advanced safety technology like pre-collision warning, blind-spot monitoring, and rear cross-traffic alert alongside luxury amenities including ventilated seats, three-zone climate control, and premium audio. A mid-cycle refresh in 2016 brought minor styling updates and technology improvements. The fourth-generation Avalon successfully evolved the model's formula with more distinctive styling and improved driving dynamics while maintaining its core values of comfort, space, and quality, helping it remain relevant in a market increasingly dominated by crossovers and SUVs.
Toyota-Avalon.name: Fourth Generation (XX40)

Toyota-Avalon.description: The fifth-generation Toyota Avalon represented the model's most ambitious iteration, featuring dramatic styling with an enormous front grille, complex creases, and an overall more athletic stance that pushed Toyota's design language to new extremes for a flagship sedan. Built on Toyota's TNGA-K platform shared with the Camry and Lexus ES, the new Avalon benefited from a lower center of gravity, increased rigidity, and improved suspension geometry for enhanced handling without compromising the comfortable ride quality that defined previous generations. The standard powertrain remained a 3.5-liter V6, now producing 301 horsepower and paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission, while the hybrid variant combined a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine with electric motors for a combined 215 horsepower and exceptional fuel economy of up to 44 mpg combined. For the first time, the Avalon added a TRD (Toyota Racing Development) sport variant featuring a track-tuned suspension, larger brakes, more aggressive styling, and a sport exhaust—a surprising addition for a model traditionally focused on comfort. The interior maintained exceptional passenger space while featuring Toyota's most premium execution in a mainstream model, with available features including a 14-speaker JBL audio system, head-up display, 9-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility, and a full suite of Toyota Safety Sense driver assistance technologies as standard equipment. All-wheel drive became available for the first time in 2021, paired with a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine.
