Despite its technical excellence and striking design, the fifth-generation Avalon arrived as sedans were increasingly challenged by the market shift toward SUVs and crossovers, leading Toyota to announce the model's discontinuation after the 2022 model year, ending a nearly 30-year run as Toyota's full-size flagship sedan in North America.
Toyota-Avalon.name: Fifth Generation (XX50)

Toyota-Aygo.description: The first-generation Toyota Aygo was developed as part of a joint venture between Toyota and PSA Peugeot Citroën (now Stellantis), resulting in three nearly identical city cars: the Toyota Aygo, Peugeot 107, and Citroën C1. Produced at a shared factory in the Czech Republic, the Aygo was designed specifically for European urban environments, featuring compact dimensions of just 3.4 meters in length, making it exceptionally maneuverable in tight city streets and easy to park in limited spaces. Available in three and five-door hatchback configurations, the Aygo featured distinctive styling with circular themes in its headlights and taillights, while maintaining an overall minimalist, functional design. Powered by a 1.0-liter three-cylinder VVT-i engine producing 68 horsepower, paired with either a five-speed manual or optional automated manual transmission, the Aygo prioritized efficiency over performance with low emissions and fuel consumption as key selling points. A 1.4-liter diesel engine was also available from 2005-2007. The interior was simple and cheerful, with body-colored panels adding visual interest to an otherwise basic cabin, though space was predictably limited, particularly for rear passengers and cargo. Equipment levels were modest in base models, with features like air conditioning, power windows, and audio systems either optional or reserved for higher trim levels. The first facelift in 2009 (AB20) replaced the front bumper shape and changed rear lights to a transparent appearance. A second facelift in 2012 (AB30) incorporated a more angular bumper with daytime running lights. The first-generation Aygo successfully established Toyota in the European A-segment (city car) market, appealing to first-time buyers, urban dwellers, and those seeking maximum efficiency and low running costs.
Toyota-Aygo.name: First Generation (AB10/AB20/AB30)

Toyota-Aygo.description: The second-generation Toyota Aygo continued the collaborative development with PSA Peugeot Citroën, again resulting in three related models, though with more distinctive styling for each brand compared to the first generation. The Aygo adopted a bold, expressive design centered around an X-shaped front fascia that became the model's signature element, available in contrasting colors to enhance its visual impact. This focus on personalization extended throughout the vehicle, with customizable exterior and interior elements allowing buyers to create a more individualized car—an important feature for appealing to younger consumers in the competitive city car segment. Still compact at approximately 3.45 meters in length, the new Aygo maintained its predecessor's urban-friendly dimensions while offering slightly improved interior space. Powered by an updated version of the 1.0-liter three-cylinder engine, now producing 69-72 horsepower depending on market and emissions regulations (1KR-FE from 2014-2018, then 1KR-B52 from 2019), the Aygo continued to emphasize efficiency with reduced CO2 emissions and improved fuel economy. Transmission options remained a five-speed manual or x-shift automated manual. The interior saw significant improvements in both design and material quality, featuring a central 7-inch touchscreen infotainment system on higher trim levels (x-touch), offering features like a backup camera, Bluetooth connectivity, and smartphone integration. Safety features expanded to include standard stability control (VSC), ABS, hill start assist, and six airbags. A facelift in 2018 brought a new front bumper, headlights, tail lights and the updated engine. The second-generation Aygo was produced until February 2022.
Toyota-Aygo.name: Second Generation (AB40)

Toyota-Aygo.description: The third-generation Toyota Aygo, renamed Aygo X (pronounced 'Aygo Cross'), represents a significant reinvention of the model, developed solely by Toyota rather than as part of the previous joint venture with PSA/Stellantis. Built on Toyota's GA-B platform shared with the larger Yaris, the Aygo X adopts a crossover-inspired design with increased ride height, wheel arch cladding, and a more substantial overall presence while maintaining compact dimensions at approximately 3.7 meters in length—still among the smallest cars in the European market. The exterior design features a distinctive front end with LED lighting elements, a contrast-color roof option, and up to 18-inch wheels on higher trims—unusually large for the segment. Power comes exclusively from a 1.0-liter three-cylinder engine producing 72 horsepower, paired with either a five-speed manual or continuously variable transmission (CVT), prioritizing urban efficiency over performance. The interior offers a more premium environment than previous generations, with higher quality materials and increased space for both passengers and cargo. Technology takes a significant step forward with a standard 7-inch or optional 9-inch touchscreen infotainment system featuring wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, alongside available amenities including wireless phone charging, intelligent parking sensors, and a premium JBL audio system. Safety technology is comprehensive for the segment, with Toyota Safety Sense bringing advanced features like pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, adaptive cruise control, and lane trace assist as standard equipment across the range. This generation reflects Toyota's strategy to maintain presence in the shrinking A-segment by creating a more distinctive, premium-feeling product.
Toyota-Aygo.name: Third Generation (Aygo X)

Toyota-C-HR.description: The first-generation Toyota C-HR (Compact High-Rider or Coupe High-Rider) represented Toyota's bold entry into the competitive subcompact crossover segment, featuring radical styling that departed significantly from the brand's typically conservative design language. With its dramatic coupe-like roofline, prominent character lines, bulging wheel arches, and concealed rear door handles, the C-HR prioritized distinctive style over traditional SUV practicality. Built on Toyota's TNGA-C platform shared with the Corolla and Prius, the C-HR offered car-like handling with a higher seating position and slightly increased ground clearance. Powertrain options varied by market but typically included a 1.2-liter turbocharged four-cylinder in Europe, a 1.8-liter hybrid system shared with the Prius in some regions, and a naturally aspirated 2.0-liter four-cylinder producing 144 horsepower in North America. Most markets received either a continuously variable transmission (CVT) or six-speed manual, with front-wheel drive standard and all-wheel drive available in select regions. The interior featured a driver-focused asymmetrical dashboard design with a soft-touch upper section and diamond pattern motifs echoing the exterior styling, though rear seat space and visibility were compromised by the dramatic roofline and small windows. Equipment levels were generally good with standard features including dual-zone climate control, touchscreen infotainment, and Toyota Safety Sense active safety systems. A facelift in 2020 brought subtle styling revisions, an improved infotainment system with smartphone integration, and in some markets, a more powerful 2.0-liter hybrid system. The first-generation C-HR successfully attracted younger buyers to the Toyota brand with its distinctive styling and driving dynamics that prioritized handling over off-road capability, though its form-over-function design polarized opinions and limited its appeal to more practically-minded consumers.
Toyota-C-HR.name: First Generation

Toyota-C-HR.description: The second-generation Toyota C-HR continues the model's focus on distinctive styling while refining the formula with more sophisticated design, enhanced technology, and an increased emphasis on electrification. Though still featuring a coupe-like silhouette with a sloping roofline and angular character lines, the new C-HR adopts more mature, cohesive styling with flush door handles, seamless LED light bars front and rear, and a less busy overall appearance despite maintaining its bold character. Built on an updated version of the TNGA-C platform, the C-HR is available exclusively with hybrid powertrains in most markets, including a 1.8-liter hybrid system producing 140 horsepower and a more powerful 2.0-liter hybrid generating 196 horsepower, with a plug-in hybrid variant added in some regions offering approximately 60 kilometers of electric-only range. All powertrains utilize an electronically controlled continuously variable transmission (e-CVT) with front-wheel drive standard and all-wheel drive available on selected variants through the addition of a rear electric motor. The interior represents a significant advancement with higher quality materials, a streamlined design featuring ambient lighting, and Toyota's latest technology including dual 12.3-inch displays for instrumentation and infotainment, wireless smartphone integration, and cloud-based navigation. While rear seat space remains somewhat compromised by the sloping roofline, access has improved through larger door openings and slightly increased dimensions. Safety technology has expanded with the latest generation of Toyota Safety Sense, offering enhanced autonomous emergency braking, adaptive cruise control with stop-and-go functionality, lane tracing assist, and new features including safe exit assist and rear seat reminder. A key focus for this generation is sustainability, with extensive use of recycled and bio-based materials throughout the interior. The second-generation C-HR maintains the original's focus on distinctive styling and car-like dynamics while offering a more refined package with improved efficiency through its hybrid-only powertrain strategy, positioning it as a design-focused alternative in the increasingly crowded compact crossover segment.
Toyota-C-HR.name: Second Generation

Toyota-Camry.description: The first-generation Toyota Camry was introduced as a replacement for the Corona in Toyota's lineup, initially available as a four-door sedan and five-door liftback. This generation established the Camry nameplate that would eventually become one of the world's best-selling cars, though this original version was significantly smaller than later models. Featuring front-wheel drive—a departure from the rear-wheel drive Corona—the first Camry emphasized fuel efficiency, practicality, and reliability. Engine options varied by market but typically included 1.8-liter and 2.0-liter gasoline four-cylinders, with diesel options available in some regions. The interior was straightforward and functional, focusing on quality construction rather than luxury. Though modest by later standards, this first generation began establishing the Camry's reputation for dependability and value that would define the nameplate for decades to come.
Toyota-Camry.name: First Generation (V10)

Toyota-Camry.description: The second-generation Toyota Camry grew in size and refinement, more clearly targeting the mid-size sedan segment that would become its core market. Available in sedan and wagon body styles (with the liftback discontinued), this generation featured more rounded styling than its predecessor, following automotive design trends of the late 1980s. The Camry's size increase improved interior space, making it more competitive with American and European mid-size offerings. Engine options expanded to include more powerful four-cylinders and, for the first time, a V6 option in some markets. The interior saw significant improvements in design, materials, and features, with higher trim levels offering amenities that pushed the Camry toward near-luxury territory. This generation began the Camry's ascent in the North American market, where it would eventually become the benchmark for the mid-size sedan segment, appealing to buyers seeking reliability, comfort, and value in a practical package.
Toyota-Camry.name: Second Generation (V20)

Toyota-Camry.description: The third-generation Toyota Camry represented a significant evolution, growing substantially in size and adopting different designs for different markets—the wider, larger XV10 for North America and Australia, and the narrower V30 for Japan and some other markets. This split reflected the Camry's increasing importance in the North American market, where the larger version was tailored to American preferences for roomier interiors and smoother rides. In North America, the Camry was available as a sedan or wagon, powered by either a 2.2-liter four-cylinder or a 3.0-liter V6, both offering improved refinement and performance. The interior quality took another step forward with better materials, more features, and increased sound insulation creating a quieter cabin. This generation solidified the Camry's reputation for reliability while adding a higher level of comfort and refinement, helping it become the best-selling car in the United States for the first time—a position it would frequently reclaim in subsequent decades. The third-generation Camry established the template of smooth, quiet performance, comfortable ride, and trouble-free ownership that would define the model's appeal for years to come.
Toyota-Camry.name: Third Generation (V30/XV10)

Toyota-Camry.description: The fourth-generation Toyota Camry continued the model's evolution toward greater refinement and comfort, with North America now clearly established as its primary market. Featuring more elegant, rounded styling than its predecessor, this generation maintained similar exterior dimensions but offered improved interior space through better packaging. Available as a sedan or wagon (though the wagon would be discontinued during this generation in North America), the Camry continued with refined versions of the 2.2-liter four-cylinder and 3.0-liter V6 engines, the latter now producing up to 200 horsepower. The interior saw significant improvements in material quality and design, with a focus on ergonomics and comfort that helped position higher trim levels as credible alternatives to entry-level luxury cars. This generation further refined the Camry's reputation for smooth, quiet operation, reliable performance, and hassle-free ownership—attributes that resonated strongly with mainstream American consumers seeking practical transportation without drama or compromise. The fourth-generation Camry solidified the model's position as the benchmark for the mid-size sedan segment, forcing competitors to measure their offerings against Toyota's combination of quality, reliability, and value.
Toyota-Camry.name: Fourth Generation (XV20)

Toyota-Camry.description: The fifth-generation Toyota Camry featured more substantial styling with a taller, more upright greenhouse providing improved visibility and interior space. Available exclusively as a sedan in most markets (with the wagon discontinued), this generation grew slightly in most dimensions, reinforcing its position in the heart of the mid-size segment. Engine options included an updated 2.4-liter four-cylinder replacing the previous 2.2-liter, and a revised 3.0-liter V6, both offering improved performance and efficiency. The interior design emphasized user-friendly controls and improved materials, particularly in higher trim levels like the luxury-oriented XLE. Safety features expanded to include available side and curtain airbags, stability control, and improved crash structures. This generation maintained the Camry's focus on comfortable, trouble-free transportation while improving driving dynamics somewhat compared to its predecessors. The fifth-generation Camry continued the model's strong sales performance, particularly in North America, as it effectively delivered on consumer expectations for a practical, reliable mid-size sedan while adding incremental improvements in refinement, features, and value.
Toyota-Camry.name: Fifth Generation (XV30)

Toyota-Camry.description: The sixth-generation Toyota Camry featured more angular styling and a focus on improved interior space and comfort. Available as a sedan in most markets, this generation maintained similar exterior dimensions to its predecessor while offering a more efficient interior package. A key development was the introduction of the Camry Hybrid, combining a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine with Toyota's Hybrid Synergy Drive system, significantly improving fuel economy for the mid-size sedan. Conventional powertrains included an updated 2.4-liter four-cylinder and a new 3.5-liter V6 producing 268 horsepower—a substantial increase from the previous generation. The interior featured improved materials in most areas, though some critics noted instances of cost-cutting compared to earlier models. Safety technology expanded with standard stability control, multiple airbags, and improved crash structures resulting in strong safety ratings. This generation continued the Camry's reputation for reliability and practicality, maintaining its position as one of the best-selling vehicles in North America despite increasing competition in the mid-size sedan segment. The addition of the hybrid variant proved prescient as fuel economy became an increasingly important consideration for consumers, broadening the Camry's appeal to more environmentally and economically conscious buyers.
Toyota-Camry.name: Sixth Generation (XV40)

Toyota-Camry.description: The seventh-generation Toyota Camry received a more comprehensive redesign with an emphasis on improved driving dynamics and more expressive styling to address criticism that previous generations had been too conservative and uninspiring to drive. Available exclusively as a sedan, this Camry featured more aggressive exterior styling with a bolder front fascia, pronounced character lines, and a more athletic stance. Powertrains carried over with updates, including the 2.5-liter four-cylinder, 3.5-liter V6, and hybrid system combining a 2.5-liter engine with electric motors, all offering improved performance and efficiency. The interior saw significant upgrades in design and material quality, with a focus on more premium soft-touch surfaces in most areas and improved technology including available touchscreen infotainment systems. A substantial mid-cycle refresh in 2015 brought even more aggressive styling with almost every exterior panel redesigned, representing an unusual investment for a mid-cycle update. This generation successfully maintained the Camry's traditional strengths of reliability, comfort, and practicality while adding more emotional appeal through styling and improved driving dynamics, helping the model maintain its sales leadership in an increasingly competitive segment facing pressure from the growing popularity of crossovers and SUVs.
Toyota-Camry.name: Seventh Generation (XV50)

Toyota-Camry.description: The eighth-generation Toyota Camry represents the most dramatic reinvention of the model in its history, featuring bold, aggressive styling with a low-slung silhouette, a two-tone roof option on some trims, and significantly different design treatments across trim levels—particularly the sport-focused SE and XSE compared to the more traditional LE and XLE. Built on Toyota's TNGA-K platform providing a lower center of gravity and increased structural rigidity, this generation emphasizes improved driving dynamics without compromising the comfort that has defined the Camry. The standard powertrain is a 2.5-liter Dynamic Force four-cylinder producing up to 206 horsepower, with an available 3.5-liter V6 generating 301 horsepower in higher trim levels. The hybrid variant combines a 2.5-liter engine with electric motors for a combined 208 horsepower while achieving up to 52 mpg combined in some configurations. The interior features a more driver-focused design with higher quality materials, improved technology including an available 9-inch touchscreen, and enhanced safety through the standard Toyota Safety Sense suite of driver assistance features. A 2021 refresh brought subtle styling revisions and updated infotainment with standard Android Auto joining Apple CarPlay. Despite the industry-wide decline in sedan sales as consumers shift to crossovers and SUVs, the eighth-generation Camry has maintained its position as one of the best-selling passenger cars in North America by successfully balancing its traditional virtues of quality, reliability, and value with more emotional design and engaging driving dynamics, broadening its appeal beyond its traditional practical-minded customer base.
Toyota-Camry.name: Eighth Generation (XV70)

Toyota-Camry-Hybrid.description: The first-generation Toyota Camry Hybrid marked Toyota's expansion of its successful hybrid technology from the Prius into its mainstream mid-size sedan, creating a more conventional-looking alternative for hybrid buyers while offering Camry customers a more efficient powertrain option. Based on the sixth-generation Camry, the hybrid variant featured subtle exterior distinctions including unique badging, a slightly different grille design, and specific wheels, but otherwise maintained the standard Camry's conservative styling and proportions. The hybrid powertrain combined a 2.4-liter Atkinson-cycle four-cylinder engine with an electric motor and nickel-metal hydride battery pack, producing a combined 187 horsepower while achieving approximately 34 mpg combined—a significant improvement over the conventional four-cylinder Camry's 25 mpg. The system utilized Toyota's Hybrid Synergy Drive technology shared with the Prius, featuring a continuously variable transmission (CVT) and the ability to operate in electric-only mode at low speeds for short distances. The battery pack was positioned in the trunk, reducing cargo capacity somewhat compared to the conventional model. The interior was largely identical to the standard Camry, though with hybrid-specific instrumentation including a power flow display and efficiency monitor. Equipment levels generally aligned with higher trim conventional Camrys, reflecting the hybrid's premium position in the lineup. This first generation established the Camry Hybrid as a practical, mainstream hybrid option for consumers who wanted improved efficiency without the distinct appearance and potential stigma associated with dedicated hybrid models like the Prius, successfully expanding Toyota's hybrid presence while capitalizing on the Camry's reputation for reliability and value.
Toyota-Camry-Hybrid.name: First Generation (XV40)

Toyota-Camry-Hybrid.description: The second-generation Toyota Camry Hybrid, based on the seventh-generation Camry, featured more expressive styling and significant improvements in the hybrid powertrain's performance and efficiency. Exterior design maintained subtle differentiation from conventional Camry models, with hybrid-specific badges, unique wheels, and minor trim differences while sharing the standard model's more aggressive styling that characterized this Camry generation. The hybrid system was thoroughly updated, now combining a more efficient 2.5-liter Atkinson-cycle four-cylinder engine with a more powerful electric motor and improved power control unit, producing a combined 200 horsepower while achieving significantly better fuel economy—up to 41 mpg combined in earlier models, improved to 42 mpg after a 2015 update, representing nearly a 30% improvement over the previous generation. The nickel-metal hydride battery pack was redesigned to be more compact, reducing its impact on cargo space, while the electric motor could now propel the vehicle at higher speeds on electricity alone compared to the previous generation. The interior featured the same design improvements as the conventional Camry, with better materials and more technology, plus hybrid-specific displays and instrumentation. Available in LE and XLE trim levels—with SE added later in the generation—the Camry Hybrid offered varying levels of equipment ranging from practical to near-luxury, though all versions included features like dual-zone automatic climate control and a power driver's seat as standard. A significant mid-cycle refresh in 2015 brought updated exterior styling, minor interior improvements, and additional features. This generation successfully built upon the foundation established by its predecessor, offering improved efficiency and performance while maintaining the Camry's reputation for comfort, reliability, and practicality, helping to further normalize hybrid technology in the mainstream mid-size sedan segment.
Toyota-Camry-Hybrid.name: Second Generation (XV50)

Toyota-Camry-Hybrid.description: The third-generation Toyota Camry Hybrid, based on the eighth-generation Camry, represents the most advanced and efficient iteration of Toyota's mid-size hybrid sedan to date, benefiting from the comprehensive platform and design reinvention of the conventional model. Built on Toyota's TNGA-K architecture featuring a lower center of gravity and increased structural rigidity, this generation emphasizes improved driving dynamics alongside exceptional efficiency. The hybrid powertrain combines a 2.5-liter Dynamic Force four-cylinder engine operating on the Atkinson cycle with dual electric motors and a continuously variable transmission, producing a combined 208 horsepower while achieving remarkable fuel economy—up to 52 mpg combined in the LE trim, or 46 mpg in the heavier SE and XLE trims with their additional equipment. For the first time, the hybrid battery was positioned under the rear seat rather than in the trunk, eliminating the cargo capacity penalty that affected previous generations. Available in multiple trim levels including LE, SE, XLE, and later XSE, the Camry Hybrid offers configurations ranging from value-focused to sport-oriented to luxury-equipped, all featuring hybrid-specific instrumentation and distinctive but subtle exterior badges and trim elements. Standard equipment across all hybrid variants includes dual-zone automatic climate control, smart key access, and Toyota Safety Sense 2.0 or 2.5 (depending on model year) with advanced driver assistance features including adaptive cruise control, lane-keeping assist, and pre-collision warning with pedestrian detection. A mid-cycle refresh for 2021 brought subtle styling updates, enhanced infotainment with Android Auto joining the previously available Apple CarPlay, and minor equipment adjustments. This generation has successfully positioned the Camry Hybrid as not merely an efficiency-focused variant but a compelling option in its own right, offering an excellent balance of performance, economy, and value while reducing the compromises traditionally associated with hybrid vehicles.
Toyota-Camry-Hybrid.name: Third Generation (XV70)

Toyota-Celica.description: The first-generation Celica was introduced in December 1970 as a two-door hardtop coupé. It featured 'coke bottle styling' and was based on the Toyota Carina platform. Available in notchback coupe and liftback body styles with various four-cylinder engines including the 2T, 2T-G, 18R, and 20R. Rear-wheel drive layout throughout this generation.
Toyota-Celica.name: First Generation

Toyota-Celica.description: The second-generation Celica was released for the 1978 model year in August 1977. Designed by David Stollery at Toyota's Calty Design Research studio in California. Available in notchback coupe and liftback forms with frameless door glass. Switched to larger 20R and later 22R engines. Rear-wheel drive layout continued.
Toyota-Celica.name: Second Generation

Toyota-Celica.description: Third-generation Celica introduced in August 1981 with significantly changed styling. Available in notchback coupe and liftback forms. Featured fully retractable headlights after August 1983 facelift. First turbocharged Celica (GT-T) introduced in September 1982 for Japan. Rear-wheel drive with various engines including 4A, 2T, 3T, 1S, 2S, 18R-G, and 21R.
Toyota-Celica.name: Third Generation

Toyota-Celica.description: Major redesign in August 1985 introduced front-wheel drive and a rounded, flowing body style. Switched from Toyota A platform to Toyota T platform. Introduced the GT-Four (ST165) with all-wheel drive and turbocharged 3S-GTE engine in October 1986. Available in coupe, liftback, and convertible forms.
Toyota-Celica.name: Fourth Generation

Toyota-Celica.description: Fifth-generation Celica introduced in September 1989 for the 1990 model year featuring 'Super Round' organic styling. Available with front-wheel drive or all-wheel drive (GT-Four). Japanese market offered four-wheel steering (4WS) models. Facelifted in August 1991 for the 1992 model year.
Toyota-Celica.name: Fifth Generation

Toyota-Celica.description: Sixth-generation Celica introduced in August 1993 for the 1994 model year with more aerodynamic styling. Available in coupe and liftback body styles. Front-wheel drive as standard, GT-Four continued with all-wheel drive. Variable valve timing became standard from 2000 model year.
Toyota-Celica.name: Sixth Generation

Toyota-Celica.description: Seventh and final generation Celica introduced in August 1999 for the 2000 model year. Featured a more angular design compared to previous generations. Available as a liftback only. Front-wheel drive with 1ZZ-FE or 2ZZ-GE engines. Production ended in April 2006 after 35 years of production.
Toyota-Celica.name: Seventh Generation

Toyota-Corolla.description: The first-generation Toyota Corolla established what would become the world's best-selling automotive nameplate, introduced as a small, economical car designed to meet the needs of Japan's growing middle class. Available in sedan, coupe, and wagon body styles, the original Corolla featured compact dimensions, a simple design, and straightforward mechanicals including a 1.1-liter engine producing just 60 horsepower, paired with either a 4-speed manual or 2-speed automatic transmission driving the rear wheels. By modern standards the first Corolla was extremely basic, with minimal amenities and a focus on affordability and reliability rather than comfort or performance. Despite its simplicity, the Corolla quickly gained popularity in Japan and began expanding to international markets, laying the groundwork for Toyota's global growth through an efficient, dependable product that delivered on its promises—a formula that would define the Corolla nameplate for decades to come.
Toyota-Corolla.name: First Generation (E10)

Toyota-Corolla.description: The second-generation Toyota Corolla grew slightly in all dimensions while maintaining its focus on simplicity and reliability. Available in an expanded range of body styles including sedan, coupe, wagon, and hardtop, this generation featured more rounded styling than its predecessor with a slightly more upscale appearance. Engine options expanded to include 1.2-liter and 1.6-liter units with modest increases in power, while maintaining the rear-wheel drive layout. Interior space improved through the increased dimensions, though amenities remained basic by modern standards. This generation saw significantly expanded global distribution, particularly in North America where the Corolla began building its reputation for trouble-free operation and value, attributes that would become core to the nameplate's identity. The second-generation Corolla helped establish Toyota as a legitimate competitor in international markets through a product that emphasized practical transportation with minimal fuss—a straightforward approach that resonated with pragmatic consumers worldwide.
Toyota-Corolla.name: Second Generation (E20)

Toyota-Corolla.description: The third-generation Toyota Corolla continued the model's evolution with increased dimensions, more modern styling, and expanded capabilities while maintaining its focus on reliable, economical transportation. Available in sedan, coupe, wagon, hardtop, and liftback body styles, this generation featured more distinctive styling with expanded glass areas, a longer hood, and more defined character lines. Engine options ranged from 1.2 to 1.6 liters depending on market, with the model maintaining its rear-wheel drive configuration. Interior comfort improved with better seats, more insulation, and additional convenience features on higher trim levels. A significant development was the introduction of emissions control equipment to meet increasingly stringent regulations in key markets like the United States. This generation coincided with the 1973 oil crisis, which increased demand for fuel-efficient vehicles and helped accelerate the Corolla's growth in international markets. The third-generation Corolla further solidified the model's reputation for providing practical, economical transportation with minimal ownership hassle, contributing to Toyota's growing global presence.
Toyota-Corolla.name: Third Generation (E30/E40/E50/E60)

Toyota-Corolla.description: The fourth-generation Toyota Corolla featured more angular styling reflecting automotive design trends of the late 1970s, while growing slightly in size and refinement. Available in a wide range of body styles including sedan, coupe, liftback, wagon, and hardtop, this generation maintained the rear-wheel drive layout that had defined previous Corollas. Engine options expanded to include more efficient and powerful units, topped by the 1.8-liter engine in some markets. Interior quality improved with better materials and more features, particularly in higher trim levels. This generation saw the introduction of the sporty Levin and Trueno models in Japan, which would eventually evolve into the iconic AE86 in the fifth generation. The fourth-generation Corolla continued the model's global expansion, with production beginning in additional countries as Toyota implemented its strategy of building vehicles closer to their markets. As with previous generations, the fourth-generation Corolla emphasized reliability and value, attributes that were increasingly recognized by consumers worldwide as the model continued its trajectory toward becoming the world's best-selling car nameplate.
Toyota-Corolla.name: Fourth Generation (E70)

Toyota-Corolla.description: The fifth-generation Toyota Corolla represented a significant transition, with most models switching to front-wheel drive while performance variants retained the rear-wheel drive layout—most notably the AE86 coupe and liftback that would later achieve cult status through motorsport, initial D manga/anime, and the drifting scene. This generation featured more modern, aerodynamic styling with a lower hood line made possible by the more compact front-wheel drive powertrain. Available in sedan, coupe, liftback, wagon, and hatchback body styles, the model lineup expanded to serve an increasingly diverse global market. Engine options ranged from fuel-efficient 1.3-liter units to more powerful 1.6-liter options, with fuel injection becoming more common. Interior space improved through better packaging enabled by the front-wheel drive layout, while features and comfort continued their gradual improvement. The fifth-generation Corolla successfully managed the challenging transition to front-wheel drive while maintaining the reliability and value proposition that had defined previous generations, further cementing the model's global popularity and influence.
Toyota-Corolla.name: Fifth Generation (E80)

Toyota-Corolla.description: The sixth-generation Toyota Corolla completed the transition to front-wheel drive across all mainstream variants, featuring more rounded styling with improved aerodynamics. Available in sedan, coupe, hatchback, liftback, and wagon body styles, this generation grew slightly in size while offering improved interior space through better packaging. Engine options expanded to include more powerful and efficient 1.6-liter and new 1.8-liter units in some markets, with technology like electronic fuel injection becoming more prevalent. Interior quality continued its steady improvement with better materials and more features, including air conditioning and power accessories becoming more common in middle and upper trim levels. Safety features improved with the wider availability of features like ABS brakes on some variants. This generation saw the introduction of the sporty Corolla GT-S in North America with the 4A-GE engine, maintaining a performance presence in the lineup. The sixth-generation Corolla reinforced the model's reputation for practical, reliable transportation with slightly more style and refinement than its predecessors, continuing its strong market position globally as consumers increasingly viewed the Corolla as the definitive compact car benchmark.
Toyota-Corolla.name: Sixth Generation (E90)

Toyota-Corolla.description: The seventh-generation Toyota Corolla featured more aerodynamic styling with softer lines and improved interior space despite maintaining similar exterior dimensions to its predecessor. Available in sedan, coupe, hatchback, liftback, and wagon body styles (though the selection varied significantly by market), this generation continued with front-wheel drive across all variants. Engine options typically included 1.3, 1.5, 1.6, and 1.8-liter gasoline units, with the introduction of lean-burn technology in some markets for improved efficiency. Interior quality saw another incremental improvement with more comfortable seats, improved ergonomics, and expanded feature availability including passenger airbags in some markets. This generation saw significant design and equipment divergence between Asian, European, and North American models as Toyota increasingly tailored the Corolla to regional preferences. Notable variants included the sporty AE101 Levin/Trueno in Japan with the 4A-GE 20-valve engine, maintaining the model's performance heritage. The seventh-generation Corolla continued the model's successful formula of reliability, efficiency, and value while gradually adding more refinement and features, further solidifying its position as one of the world's most popular cars.
Toyota-Corolla.name: Seventh Generation (E100)

Toyota-Corolla.description: The eighth-generation Toyota Corolla featured more distinctive styling with a slightly more upscale appearance, continuing the model's gradual evolution toward greater refinement and feature content. Regional differentiation increased further, with European, North American, and Asian variants featuring significant design and engineering differences to better target local preferences. Body styles included sedan, hatchback, coupe, and wagon, though availability varied by market. Engine options expanded to include more advanced units with improved efficiency and power, including VVT-i (Variable Valve Timing with intelligence) technology on some variants. Interior quality improved noticeably with better materials, more sophisticated design, and expanded feature availability including side airbags, antilock brakes, and enhanced audio systems in higher trim levels. This generation saw the introduction of the Corolla Spacio mini-MPV in some markets, expanding the nameplate's reach into different vehicle categories. Despite increasing competition and the growing popularity of SUVs, the eighth-generation Corolla maintained strong global sales through its proven combination of reliability, efficiency, and value, while the incremental improvements in refinement and features helped the model appeal to a broader range of consumers.
Toyota-Corolla.name: Eighth Generation (E110)

Toyota-Corolla.description: The ninth-generation Toyota Corolla featured more distinctive styling and a significant step up in interior quality and refinement, reflecting the model's gradual upmarket progression. Regional differentiation reached its peak with this generation, as the Japanese, European, and North American models featured substantially different designs and engineering, though sharing the same basic platform and mechanical components. Body styles included sedan, hatchback (primarily in Europe and Japan), and wagon (in some markets). Engine options typically included improved 1.4, 1.6, 1.8, and 2.0-liter gasoline units with VVT-i technology, and diesel options in some regions. Interior quality improved substantially with more premium materials, more sophisticated design, and expanded feature availability including navigation systems, automatic climate control, and enhanced safety features like stability control and additional airbags on higher trim levels. This generation saw the North American Corolla grow to nearly mid-size proportions, while European and Japanese models maintained more compact dimensions. Performance variants continued with models like the Corolla T-Sport in Europe and the XRS in North America, featuring more powerful engines and sport-tuned suspensions. The ninth-generation Corolla successfully balanced its traditional strengths of reliability and value with enhanced refinement and features, maintaining its position as one of the world's best-selling cars despite its increasing age by the end of the generation.
Toyota-Corolla.name: Ninth Generation (E120/E130)

Toyota-Corolla.description: The tenth-generation Toyota Corolla continued the trend of regional differentiation with distinct designs for different markets, though with more shared components than the previous generation. The sedan grew in most dimensions across all markets, offering improved interior space, while hatchback models (branded as Auris in Europe and Corolla in other regions) adopted a more distinctive design separate from the sedan. Engine options typically included refined versions of the 1.4, 1.6, 1.8, and 2.0-liter gasoline units with dual VVT-i on some variants, plus diesel options in markets where they were popular. Continuously Variable Transmission (CVT) options began replacing conventional automatics in some markets. Interior quality saw another improvement with better materials, more mature design, and expanded feature availability including touchscreen infotainment, keyless entry and start, and comprehensive safety features on higher trims. This generation also saw the introduction of the first Corolla hybrid models in some markets, reflecting the industry's gradual shift toward electrification. The tenth-generation Corolla maintained the model's reputation for reliability and practicality while continuing its gradual evolution toward greater refinement and technology, though it faced increasing criticism for relatively uninspired driving dynamics compared to some competitors.
Toyota-Corolla.name: Tenth Generation (E140/E150)

Toyota-Corolla.description: The eleventh-generation Toyota Corolla maintained significant regional differentiation, with the most notable division between the larger North American/Chinese model (E170/E180) and the more compact Japanese/European version (E160). The sedan featured more expressive styling than its predecessor with sharper lines and a more distinctive front fascia, while the Auris/Corolla hatchback (depending on market) continued as a separate design. Engine options typically included refined versions of previous powertrains, with the 1.8-liter remaining the mainstay in many markets, plus new smaller turbocharged options and improved hybrid powertrains in some regions. Continuous Variable Transmissions became more common across the range. Interior quality improved again with more premium materials in most areas, more contemporary design with available touchscreen infotainment systems, and expanded connectivity options. Safety technology saw significant advancement with the introduction of Toyota Safety Sense on many variants, offering features like pre-collision braking, lane departure alert, and adaptive cruise control—advanced technology for the compact segment at the time. Despite the continued trend toward crossovers and SUVs, the eleventh-generation Corolla maintained strong sales globally through its combination of reliability, efficiency, and steadily improving refinement and features, though with a driving experience still focused more on comfort than engagement.
Toyota-Corolla.name: Eleventh Generation (E160/E170/E180)

Toyota-Corolla.description: The twelfth-generation Toyota Corolla represents the most significant redesign in the model's recent history, transitioning to the TNGA-C (Toyota New Global Architecture) platform shared with the Prius and C-HR, with a focus on improved driving dynamics without compromising the traditional Corolla virtues of reliability and practicality. Available in sedan, hatchback, and wagon (primarily in Europe) body styles, this generation features more cohesive global design than its predecessors, though with regional variations in features and powertrains. The exterior design is significantly more expressive with a lower, wider stance, a more aggressive front fascia, and distinctive LED lighting signatures, while maintaining recognizable Corolla proportions. Engine options vary by market but typically include a 1.8-liter gasoline engine, a more powerful 2.0-liter option in some regions, and notably, a much-expanded hybrid lineup that has become the volume seller in many markets, offering up to 50+ mpg efficiency. Interior quality reaches new heights with soft-touch materials in most areas, a standard 7 or 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility, and available features including a digital instrument cluster, wireless charging, and premium audio. Safety technology is comprehensive with Toyota Safety Sense 2.0 or later standard across most markets, offering advanced driver assistance features including adaptive cruise control with stop-and-go functionality, lane tracing assist, and road sign assist. Driving dynamics are significantly improved through the new platform's lower center of gravity, increased rigidity, and revised suspension tuning, creating a more engaging experience without sacrificing comfort. The twelfth-generation Corolla successfully balances the model's traditional strengths with modern design, technology, and driving dynamics, helping maintain its position as one of the world's best-selling cars despite the continued market shift toward crossovers and SUVs.
Toyota-Corolla.name: Twelfth Generation (E210)

Toyota-Corolla.description: The 2023 refresh of the twelfth-generation Toyota Corolla introduced updated styling, new infotainment software, and further refined hybrid systems while maintaining the TNGA-C platform foundation. The facelift brought revised exterior styling with refreshed bumpers, updated LED lighting signatures, and refined body panels. Interior updates included enhanced infotainment systems with improved software and connectivity features. The hybrid powertrains received refinements for improved efficiency and performance. All body styles (sedan, hatchback, and wagon) received the updates, which were phased in across different markets throughout 2023 and into 2024. The facelifted Corolla continues Toyota's commitment to balancing traditional compact car reliability and practicality with contemporary design, technology, and driving dynamics in an increasingly crowded market segment.
Toyota-Corolla.name: Twelfth Generation (E210) 2023 Facelift

Toyota-Corolla-Cross.description: The Toyota Corolla Cross represents the iconic nameplate's expansion into the rapidly growing subcompact/compact crossover segment, leveraging the Corolla's strong brand recognition while offering the higher riding position and versatility that have driven SUV popularity. Built on Toyota's TNGA-C platform shared with the Corolla sedan and hatchback, the Corolla Cross features more conventional SUV-like styling compared to the swoopier C-HR, with a practical upright profile, pronounced wheel arches, and a recognizable family resemblance to Toyota's larger RAV4 and Highlander SUVs. Measuring approximately 175.6 inches in length and 64.8 inches in height, the Corolla Cross slots between the C-HR and RAV4 in Toyota's lineup. Powertrain options vary by market but typically include a 2.0-liter Dynamic Force four-cylinder producing 169 horsepower paired with a continuously variable transmission (CVT) in standard models, with front-wheel drive standard and all-wheel drive optional. A hybrid variant introduced for the 2023 model year combines a 2.0-liter engine with three electric motors (two in front, one in rear for AWD models) for a combined 196 horsepower and significantly improved fuel economy. The interior features straightforward, practical design shared with other Corolla models but with a more commanding seating position and increased cargo space—up to 25.5 cubic feet behind the rear seats, expanding to 65.5 cubic feet with seats folded. Technology includes standard Toyota Safety Sense 2.0 driver assistance features, a standard 7-inch or available 8-inch (later up to 10.5-inch) touchscreen infotainment system with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility, and available features including a power liftgate, wireless charging, and a 9-speaker JBL premium audio system. The Corolla Cross successfully targets the sweet spot in the market between the smaller, style-focused C-HR and the larger, more expensive RAV4, offering Corolla's reputation for reliability and value in a package that meets current consumer preferences for crossover styling and practicality.
Toyota-Corolla-Cross.name: First Generation

Toyota-Corolla-Hybrid.description: The twelfth-generation Toyota Corolla Hybrid is based on the TNGA-C (GA-C) platform, introduced in 2018. The hybrid powertrain combines a 1.8-liter 2ZR-FXE Atkinson-cycle four-cylinder engine with Toyota's Hybrid Synergy Drive system, producing a combined 121 horsepower. Power is delivered through an electronically controlled continuously variable transmission (E-CVT). The Corolla Hybrid was first available in the US market for the 2020 model year, unveiled at the November 2018 LA Auto Show. Available in sedan, hatchback, and estate (Touring Sports) body styles depending on the market. Fuel economy is exceptional at up to 53 mpg combined for front-wheel drive models. Standard features include Toyota Safety Sense 2.0, 4.2-inch multi-information display, and Entune 3.0 infotainment with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto (Android Auto added for 2021). The hybrid uses a nickel-metal hydride battery pack in most markets. All-wheel drive became available on hybrid models for the 2023 model year.
Toyota-Corolla-Hybrid.name: First Generation (E210)

Toyota-Corolla-Hybrid.description: The mid-cycle facelift for the Toyota Corolla Hybrid was introduced in 2022 for the 2023 model year. Key updates include updated exterior styling inspired by the GR Corolla, Toyota Safety Sense 3.0 with improved driver assistance features, and an 8-inch touchscreen with Toyota Audio Multimedia system capable of Over-the-Air (OTA) updates. The hybrid powertrain was enhanced with a more powerful electric motor-generator and a smaller lithium-ion battery that sits under the rear seat, increasing luggage space. In North America, hybrid availability expanded from a single LE trim to include SE and XLE/XSE trims. All-wheel drive became available on hybrid models in North America for the 2023 model year. The 2.0-liter M20A-FXS Dynamic Force hybrid engine (138 hp combined) became available in some markets alongside the 1.8-liter engine. European market discontinued all non-hybrid powertrains, offering only hybrid variants with 1.8L or 2.0L hybrid engines.
Toyota-Corolla-Hybrid.name: First Generation Facelift (E210)

Toyota-Corolla-iM.description: The Toyota Corolla iM represented a brief but significant chapter in the Corolla lineage in North America, originally introduced as the Scion iM before being rebranded as a Toyota after the discontinuation of the Scion brand. Essentially the North American version of the European Toyota Auris (itself a Corolla hatchback variant in other markets), the Corolla iM offered a sportier, more practical alternative to the Corolla sedan. Built on the same platform as the eleventh-generation Corolla but with different styling, the iM featured a distinctive five-door hatchback design with more aggressive lines, standard 17-inch alloy wheels, and a generally more youthful appearance than the sedan. Powered by a 1.8-liter four-cylinder engine producing 137 horsepower and 126 lb-ft of torque, the iM was available with either a six-speed manual transmission or a continuously variable transmission (CVT) with manual mode and seven simulated gear steps. The interior featured a more modern design than the contemporary Corolla sedan, with piano black accents, a leather-wrapped steering wheel, and a 7-inch touchscreen infotainment system as standard equipment. In keeping with the former Scion brand's 'mono-spec' philosophy, the iM was offered in a single well-equipped trim level with a limited number of dealer-installed options. Standard safety features included Toyota's Safety Sense C with pre-collision system, lane departure alert, and automatic high beams—advanced technology for its price point at the time. The Corolla iM successfully bridged the gap between Scion's discontinuation and the introduction of the twelfth-generation Corolla hatchback, offering North American consumers a more European-flavored compact hatchback experience wearing the trusted Corolla badge, though with somewhat compromised performance due to its relatively modest power output compared to some competitors.
Toyota-Corolla-iM.name: First Generation

Toyota-Crown.description: The first-generation Toyota Crown established what would become Toyota's flagship sedan, representing the company's first true luxury offering. Featuring formal, somewhat American-influenced styling with pronounced fenders and substantial chrome accents typical of 1950s design, the original Crown was available in sedan, wagon, and commercial vehicle variants. Powered by a 1.5-liter (later 1.9-liter) four-cylinder engine with modest output, the Crown emphasized build quality and comfort over performance. The interior featured upscale appointments by Japanese standards of the era, with a focus on passenger comfort and premium materials. The first Crown also became Toyota's first export model to the United States in 1958, though it struggled in that market due to its modest power and size. Nevertheless, this generation established the Crown nameplate as Toyota's domestic flagship and began the model's long history as a conservative, well-built luxury car favored by executives, government officials, and taxi companies in Japan.
Toyota-Crown.name: First Generation (RS)

Toyota-Crown.description: The fifteenth-generation Toyota Crown, the final iteration of the traditional Crown sedan, represented the pinnacle of Toyota's sedan development in its home market of Japan. Featuring elegant, conservative styling with a distinctive fastback-like silhouette, long hood, and short deck, this Crown maintained its position as a prestigious executive sedan. Available with multiple powertrains including a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, a 2.5-liter hybrid, and a 3.5-liter V6 hybrid delivering up to 359 combined horsepower, this Crown prioritized refined performance and efficiency. Built on the TNGA-N platform shared with the Lexus LS, the Crown offered a sophisticated double-wishbone front and multi-link rear suspension system for a premium ride quality. The interior featured high-quality materials throughout, with wood trim, leather upholstery, and advanced technology including a large center display, digital instrument cluster, and a comprehensive suite of driver assistance features. This generation maintained the Crown's traditional values of quality, comfort, and prestige while incorporating modern technology and efficiency, serving as the final chapter of the traditional Crown sedan before the nameplate's radical reinvention for its sixteenth generation.
Toyota-Crown.name: Fifteenth Generation (S220)

Toyota-Crown.description: The sixteenth-generation Toyota Crown represents the most dramatic reinvention in the nameplate's history, transforming from a traditional sedan into a distinctive crossover sedan with elevated ride height and unique fastback proportions. This radical departure reflects shifting global market preferences while maintaining the Crown's premium positioning. Measuring 194 inches long with a 112.2-inch wheelbase, the new Crown features a polarizing design with a sloping roofline, bulging fenders, and an elevated stance (approximately 4 inches higher than a typical sedan), creating what Toyota calls a 'crossover sedan' that combines attributes of both body styles. Available globally—including the United States for the first time since 1972—this Crown is offered exclusively with hybrid powertrains. The standard system combines a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine with electric motors for a combined 236 horsepower and all-wheel drive through a rear-mounted electric motor. The premium HYBRID MAX powertrain pairs a 2.4-liter turbocharged engine with an electric motor for 340 combined horsepower, featuring a direct-shift six-speed automatic transmission instead of the planetary continuously variable transmission used in the base system. The interior emphasizes premium comfort with standard heated front seats, dual-zone climate control, panoramic moonroof, and an 11-speaker JBL audio system on higher trims. Technology includes standard 12.3-inch touchscreen and digital instrument displays, wireless smartphone integration, and Toyota Safety Sense 3.0 with enhanced driver assistance features. This generation expands into a family of Crown-badged vehicles in some markets, including the Crown Sport, Crown Sedan, and Crown Estate, though only the crossover sedan variant is offered globally. The sixteenth-generation Crown attempts to maintain the model's traditional values of quality and prestige while adapting to contemporary market trends, appealing to consumers who desire a premium vehicle with distinctive styling that transcends traditional vehicle categories.
Toyota-Crown.name: Sixteenth Generation (Crown Crossover)

Toyota-Crown-Signia.description: The Toyota Crown Signia represents an expansion of the reimagined Crown lineup, offering a more practical wagon-like crossover variant alongside the elevated Crown sedan introduced in 2022. Based on the same TNGA-K platform as the standard Crown and sharing its front-end styling, the Crown Signia differentiates itself with a distinctive fastback/liftgate design replacing the sedan's traditional trunk, creating a silhouette reminiscent of luxury European sport wagons but with a slightly elevated ride height. Measuring approximately 190.6 inches in length—about 4 inches shorter than the Crown sedan—the Signia features the same 112.2-inch wheelbase but with a more practical rear configuration offering up to 25.5 cubic feet of cargo space behind the rear seats. Powered exclusively by Toyota's fourth-generation hybrid system combining a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine with front and rear electric motors for a combined 243 horsepower and standard electronic all-wheel drive, the Crown Signia prioritizes efficiency alongside premium positioning. The interior mirrors the Crown sedan's upscale approach with standard leather seating, a 12.3-inch digital instrument panel, 12.3-inch central touchscreen with wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto connectivity, heated and ventilated front seats, and a panoramic moonroof. Advanced technology includes Toyota Safety Sense 3.0 with pre-collision system, dynamic radar cruise control, lane departure alert with steering assist, and proactive driving assist. Available in XLE and Limited trim levels, the Crown Signia targets buyers seeking the premium character of the Crown with enhanced versatility, competing in the niche space between luxury SUVs and traditional wagons. As part of Toyota's strategy to reinvent the Crown nameplate for modern preferences while maintaining its premium position in the lineup, the Signia represents the North American version of what is sold as the Crown Estate in some other markets.
Toyota-Crown-Signia.name: First Generation

Toyota-FJ-Cruiser.description: The Toyota FJ Cruiser represented a nostalgic yet thoroughly modern take on Toyota's legendary FJ40 Land Cruiser, combining retro styling cues with contemporary engineering for serious off-road capability. Built on a modified version of the 120-series Land Cruiser Prado/4Runner platform, the FJ Cruiser featured distinctive retro-inspired styling with a short, boxy profile, white roof, wrap-around rear windows, and round headlights flanking a 'TOYOTA' branded grille—all clear homages to the iconic FJ40. The unusual body configuration featured rear-hinged half doors providing access to the rear seats, similar to extended cab pickup trucks. Powered by a 4.0-liter V6 producing 239 horsepower (later increased to 260 horsepower) and 278 lb-ft of torque, the FJ Cruiser was available with either rear-wheel drive or part-time four-wheel drive with a two-speed transfer case, the latter featuring either a five-speed automatic or six-speed manual transmission with a locking rear differential. Off-road credentials were impressive with 9.6 inches of ground clearance, 34-degree approach and 31-degree departure angles, and available features like Active Traction Control (A-TRAC) and Crawl Control on some variants. The interior emphasized durability with water-resistant materials, rubber flooring, and drain plugs for easy cleaning, though with modern amenities including an available premium JBL audio system, power accessories, and cruise control. Throughout its production run, the FJ Cruiser received minor updates including improved engines, additional convenience features, and special editions like the Trail Teams models with enhanced off-road equipment. Despite its niche appeal and relatively short production run in North America (continuing longer in other markets like the Middle East and Australia), the FJ Cruiser developed a devoted following and strong resale values due to its unique character, genuine capability, and Toyota's reputation for reliability.
Toyota-FJ-Cruiser.name: First Generation

Toyota-Fortuner.description: The first-generation Toyota Fortuner was developed as a mid-size SUV based on the Hilux pickup truck platform, targeting emerging markets across Asia, the Middle East, South America, and Australia (where it was initially known as the HiLux SW4). Featuring traditional body-on-frame construction with a design that emphasized ruggedness and utility, the Fortuner offered three rows of seating for up to seven passengers and genuine off-road capability, distinguishing it from the more car-like crossovers that were becoming increasingly common. Powertrain options varied by market but typically included a range of diesel and gasoline engines, with the most common being 2.5-liter and 3.0-liter turbo-diesel four-cylinders, and a 2.7-liter gasoline option, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. All variants featured selectable four-wheel drive with a low-range transfer case for off-road use. The interior prioritized durability and practicality over luxury, though higher trim levels offered features like leather seating, climate control, and upgraded audio systems. This original version established the Fortuner's reputation for rugged reliability.
Toyota-Fortuner.name: First Generation (AN50/AN60)

Toyota-Fortuner.description: The first facelift of the Toyota Fortuner was launched in July 2008, featuring updated projector headlamps and grille, new rear lights with LED elements, Bluetooth connectivity, and a new light sand interior color. The 4×4 V model received an electronic adjustable driver's seat, and the rear air conditioning was relocated from the sides to the ceiling for second and third row passengers. Electronic Brake Force Distribution with Brake Assist was introduced on select models. This facelift also marked the introduction of variable nozzle turbocharger (VNT) technology on the 2.5-liter diesel engine, improving power output by approximately 60% while reducing fuel consumption by up to 30%.
Toyota-Fortuner.name: First Generation (AN50/AN60) - First Facelift

Toyota-Fortuner.description: The second facelift of the Toyota Fortuner was introduced in July 2011, bringing a comprehensive exterior redesign with a new front fascia, fender, hood, grille, headlamps, tail lamps, bumper, and fog light housing, styling cues similar to the J200 Land Cruiser. The rear bumper and garnish plate were also revised. Side changes included new sharper fender flares, LED-integrated side view mirrors, and redesigned wheels similar to the 2012 Hilux. Interior upgrades included a new center console, steering wheel, and upgraded audio/video system. The VNT (Variable Nozzle Turbo) intercooled engine became standard across the range, further improving performance and efficiency. This facelift version continued production until December 2015.
Toyota-Fortuner.name: First Generation (AN50/AN60) - Second Facelift

Toyota-Fortuner.description: The second-generation Toyota Fortuner was unveiled simultaneously on 16 July 2015 in Australia and Thailand. Developed under executive chief engineer Hiroki Nakajima, it features the 'Keen Look' design language shared with the new Hilux. While sharing bonnet panels, front pillar area, windscreen glass, and front doors with the Hilux, the Fortuner has a more slim-looking exterior with slim headlights featuring bi-beam LED projector options and blacked-out D-pillars for a 'floating roof' look. Toyota designers drew inspiration from the Land Cruiser and Land Cruiser Prado heritage to differentiate the Fortuner from competitors. The interior no longer shares design with the Hilux, featuring an upright dashboard with synthetic leather trims, a three-spoke steering wheel, and a modern instrument cluster with a large color TFT LCD multi-info display. Powertrains include newly developed GD series diesel engines (2.4L and 2.8L), updated 2.7L and 4.0L petrol engines with Dual VVT-i, paired with six-speed manual or automatic transmissions. The body-on-frame construction features larger cross-section ladder frame, double wishbone front suspension, and five-link rear suspension with coil springs. A part-time 4×4 system replaced the full-time system of the previous generation.
Toyota-Fortuner.name: Second Generation (AN150/AN160)

Toyota-Fortuner.description: The facelifted second-generation Toyota Fortuner debuted in June 2020 for the Thai market alongside the facelifted Hilux. The Legender flagship sub-model (known as VRZ in Indonesia and Malaysia, LTD in the Philippines, Diamond in South America, and Black Onyx in Russia) was introduced to replace the TRD Sportivo model. The Legender grade features different headlight units, unique front and rear bumper designs aligned with Toyota crossover SUVs, 20-inch wheels, interior ambient lighting, two-tone leather seats, JBL sound system, and Toyota Safety Sense active safety systems. The 2.8-liter 1GD-FTV diesel engine received an upgrade, producing increased power and torque. The Legender-based GR Sport variant was launched in August 2021, offering sportier styling and features. Additional updates across markets include improved safety features, updated infotainment systems with wireless smartphone connectivity, and in some regions, the introduction of 48V mild hybrid technology on the 2.8-liter diesel engine.
Toyota-Fortuner.name: Second Generation (AN150/AN160) - Facelift

Toyota-GR-Corolla.description: The Toyota GR Corolla represents the first high-performance variant of the Corolla developed by Toyota's Gazoo Racing division for the North American market, bringing serious performance credentials to the traditionally practical compact car. Based on the twelfth-generation Corolla hatchback but with substantial performance modifications, the GR Corolla features aggressive styling with widened fenders, functional air vents, a large rear wing, and triple exhaust outlets—visual clues to its performance-focused nature. Powered by a turbocharged 1.6-liter three-cylinder G16E-GTS engine producing 300 horsepower and 273 lb-ft of torque, the GR Corolla delivers impressive performance with a 0-60 mph time of approximately 5.0 seconds. A defining feature is the GR-FOUR all-wheel drive system offering three driver-selectable torque distribution settings (60:40, 50:50, or 30:70 front-to-rear), paired exclusively with a six-speed manual transmission featuring rev-matching functionality. The chassis features significant reinforcement with additional welds and structural adhesive, while the suspension has been completely retuned with unique springs, dampers, and stabilizer bars for optimized handling. Available in Core, Circuit Edition (2023 only), and limited-production Morizo Edition variants, the latter featuring increased torque (295 lb-ft), reduced weight, and additional chassis reinforcement. The interior combines the standard Corolla's basic layout with sport-specific enhancements including heavily bolstered front seats, a GR-specific steering wheel and shifter, and unique instrumentation including all-wheel drive mode indicators. Standard features include Toyota Safety Sense 3.0 driver assistance suite.
Toyota-GR-Corolla.name: First Generation

Toyota-GR-Corolla.description: The facelifted GR Corolla was revealed on August 1, 2024, for the 2025 model year. The most significant change is the addition of an 8-speed Direct Automatic Transmission (DAT) option with Formula One-style paddle-shifters for semi-automatic mode, marking the first automatic transmission available in the GR Corolla. All trims now produce increased torque and come with front and rear Torsen limited-slip differentials standard. The restyled front bumper was designed for better cooling and aerodynamics, with a sub-radiator standard on Premium Plus or optional on Premium models. The transmission fluid cooler for the 8-speed DAT is housed in the left-hand side of the bumper. US market model grades are Core, Premium, and Premium Plus—with the Premium Plus featuring the forged carbon roof, hood bulge with vents, and sub-radiator as a successor to the Circuit Edition. The interior received upgrades including suede-trimmed upholstery, heated seats and steering wheel, and JBL Premium sound system on higher trims.
Toyota-GR-Corolla.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Toyota-GR-Supra.description: The first-generation Toyota Supra began as a premium variant of the Celica, known as the Celica Supra or Celica XX in some markets, featuring distinctive styling with quad headlights, a longer wheelbase to accommodate the inline-six engine, and more luxurious features. Powered by a 2.6-liter (later 2.8-liter) inline-six engine producing approximately 110-116 horsepower depending on market and model year, the original Supra positioned itself as a comfortable grand tourer rather than an outright sports car. Available with either a five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmission driving the rear wheels, the Supra offered modest performance but with more refinement than the standard Celica. The interior featured a driver-oriented dashboard with a comprehensive gauge package, and equipment levels were upscale for the era with available leather upholstery, power windows, and air conditioning. This generation established the Supra nameplate (derived from the Latin prefix meaning 'above' or 'beyond') and its initial positioning as a premium sports coupe, though it remained closely tied to its Celica origins while adding the straight-six engine configuration that would become a defining characteristic of subsequent Supra generations.
Toyota-GR-Supra.name: First Generation (A40/A50)

Toyota-GR-Supra.description: The second-generation Toyota Supra continued as a derivative of the Celica but with more distinctive styling, featuring angular lines, pop-up headlights, and a more aggressive overall appearance reflecting automotive design trends of the early 1980s. Still marketed as the Celica Supra in many regions, this generation further distinguished itself from the standard Celica with a longer wheelbase, wider track, and more comprehensive performance enhancements. Powered by a 2.8-liter inline-six engine (5M-GE) with dual overhead cams, producing approximately 145-175 horsepower depending on market and model year, paired with either a five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmission, the second-generation Supra offered improved performance while maintaining its grand touring character. The introduction of independent rear suspension improved handling significantly over its predecessor, while four-wheel disc brakes provided enhanced stopping power. The interior featured a more driver-focused design with deeply bolstered seats, a comprehensive gauge cluster, and available luxury features including leather upholstery, power windows, and an upgraded audio system. Later models offered a Performance Package with sport suspension, limited-slip differential, and wider tires. This generation began shifting the Supra's positioning more toward performance while maintaining premium features, establishing it as Toyota's flagship sports coupe and laying the groundwork for its eventual evolution into a dedicated high-performance vehicle separate from the Celica.
Toyota-GR-Supra.name: Second Generation (A60)

Toyota-GR-Supra.description: The third-generation Toyota Supra marked a significant evolution, separating completely from the Celica to become a distinct model on its own platform, signifying its elevated status in Toyota's lineup. Featuring more rounded, contemporary styling with a prominent rear spoiler on Turbo models, pop-up headlights, and wider, more aggressive proportions, this generation embraced the performance focus that would come to define the nameplate. Engine options varied by market but were centered around the 3.0-liter inline-six in naturally aspirated (7M-GE) and, most significantly, turbocharged (7M-GTE) forms, the latter producing up to 232 horsepower—a substantial figure for the era. Transmission options included a five-speed manual, optional six-speed manual on later models, or four-speed automatic. The chassis featured double-wishbone suspension at all four corners, providing a sophisticated foundation for impressive handling capabilities, while innovations like available electronically controlled shock absorbers (TEMS) showcased Toyota's investment in performance technology. The interior continued the driver-focused theme with a wraparound cockpit design, comprehensive gauges including a boost meter on Turbo models, and available luxury features such as power-adjustable seats, leather upholstery, and a premium sound system. This generation firmly established the Supra as a serious performance car capable of competing with more expensive European and American sports coupes, particularly in turbocharged form, while maintaining reasonable practicality as a daily driver. The A70 Supra developed a strong following among performance enthusiasts, particularly for its robust engine design that proved highly receptive to aftermarket modifications and tuning.
Toyota-GR-Supra.name: Third Generation (A70)

Toyota-GR-Supra.description: The fourth-generation Toyota Supra represents the pinnacle of the nameplate's original run, featuring radical styling with a rounded, organic form, distinctive circular taillights, and an optional large rear wing that created one of the most recognizable sports car silhouettes of the 1990s. Significantly lighter than its predecessor through extensive use of aluminum and reduced equipment in certain models, this Supra prioritized performance above all else. Powered by the legendary 3.0-liter 2JZ inline-six engine in naturally aspirated (2JZ-GE, 220 horsepower) or twin-turbocharged (2JZ-GTE, 276 horsepower in Japan, 320 horsepower in export markets) forms, the latter featuring sequential turbochargers to virtually eliminate lag, paired with either a six-speed manual (Turbo only) or four-speed automatic transmission. The sophisticated chassis utilized double-wishbone suspension at all four corners, large brakes, and variable power steering, creating exceptional handling capabilities that could challenge much more expensive sports cars. The interior focused on the driver with a wraparound cockpit design, excellent ergonomics, and a relatively simple layout emphasizing function over luxury. This generation achieved legendary status for its extraordinary performance potential, with the twin-turbocharged variant in particular demonstrating exceptional durability and capacity for aftermarket modifications, with many examples reliably producing double or triple the factory horsepower rating with appropriate upgrades. The A80 Supra was discontinued in most markets by 1998 due to declining sales of sports cars, tightening emissions regulations, and rising production costs, though production continued for the Japanese market until 2002. Its cultural impact was amplified through prominent appearances in movies, video games, and racing series, maintaining enthusiast interest during the two decades between its discontinuation and eventual revival, with well-preserved examples commanding extraordinary prices on the collector market.
Toyota-GR-Supra.name: Fourth Generation (A80)

Toyota-GR-Supra.description: The fifth-generation Toyota Supra marks the revival of the iconic nameplate after a 17-year hiatus, developed as part of a joint venture with BMW that also produced the Z4 roadster. Designed with input from Toyota's Gazoo Racing motorsport division (hence the 'GR' prefix used in some markets), the new Supra features dramatic styling with a double-bubble roof, prominent front fenders, integrated ducktail rear spoiler, and numerous functional air vents and aerodynamic elements that create a distinctive appearance while honoring the heritage of previous generations, particularly the fourth-generation A80. The underlying chassis and powertrain are largely BMW-sourced, with the Supra initially launching with a 3.0-liter turbocharged inline-six engine (maintaining the straight-six tradition) producing 335 horsepower and 365 lb-ft of torque, paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission driving the rear wheels. This initial production period featured the first version of the B58 engine with 11:1 compression ratio and two-port turbo manifold. The chassis features adaptive variable suspension, an electronically controlled limited-slip differential, and a near-perfect 50:50 weight distribution. The two-seat interior combines BMW switchgear and infotainment with Toyota-specific instrumentation and trim, featuring a driver-focused cockpit design with high-quality materials. Production began in March 2019 with model year 2020, going on sale in May 2019 in Japan and July 2019 in the United States. Special editions during this period included the Launch Edition with unique colors and features.
Toyota-GR-Supra.name: Fifth Generation (A90) - Initial Production
