Toyota-GR-Supra.description: The fifth-generation Toyota Supra received significant updates for the 2021 model year (effective from late 2020), including a power increase for the 3.0-liter turbocharged inline-six engine from 335 to 382 horsepower and 365 to 368 lb-ft of torque, achieved through revised engine tuning, a 10.2:1 compression ratio, and a six-port cylinder head and turbo manifold. The 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine was introduced for the US market in 2021, producing 255 horsepower and 295 lb-ft of torque. In 2022 for the 2023 model year, Toyota responded to enthusiast demand by adding a six-speed manual transmission option (ZF S6-53) for the six-cylinder model, featuring rev-matching and a shorter final drive ratio. Chassis updates included revised rear suspension bushings and added engine bay stiffening bars for improved handling. Special editions have included the A91 Edition (2021, 1,000 units), A91-CF Edition with carbon fiber body kit (2022, 600 units), A91-MT Edition with manual transmission (2023, 500 units), and the 45th Anniversary Edition (2024, 900 units) celebrating 45 years since the first Celica Supra in 1978. In late 2024, Toyota announced the A90 Final Edition as the final variant of the current generation, limited to 300 units worldwide with significant performance upgrades including carbon fiber body components, KW suspension, Brembo brakes, and increased power output. The 2.0-liter engine was discontinued for the 2025 model year.
Toyota-GR-Supra.name: Fifth Generation (A90) - Facelift

Toyota-GR86.description: The first generation of Toyota's compact sports car was developed jointly with Subaru and sold under various names depending on the market: Toyota 86 (Asia, Australia, North America from 2016), Toyota GT86 (Europe), Scion FR-S (United States and Canada, 2012-2016). This lightweight rear-wheel-drive sports coupe featured a naturally aspirated 2.0-liter FA20 boxer engine producing 200 horsepower at 7,000 rpm and 151 lb-ft of torque at 6,400 rpm. The car was praised for its excellent handling balance, low center of gravity, and driver engagement, with a 53/47 front/rear weight distribution. Production began in February 2012 at Subaru's Gunma plant in Japan. The first generation received a facelift in 2016 for the 2017 model year, which included suspension upgrades increasing power to 205 horsepower and torque to 156 lb-ft for manual transmission models, along with a revised final drive ratio. Various special editions were produced throughout its lifecycle, including the TRD GT86, 14R-60, Style Cb, and numerous regional variants. While Subaru BRZ production ended in July 2020, Toyota 86 production continued through at least the third quarter of 2020.
Toyota-GR86.name: First Generation (ZN6/ZC6)

Toyota-GR86.description: The second generation, marketed as the GR86 under Toyota's Gazoo Racing performance division, represents a significant evolution of the original platform while maintaining its core philosophy of being a lightweight, affordable rear-wheel-drive sports coupe. Jointly developed with Subaru (which continues to sell the BRZ), the new model addresses the most common criticism of its predecessor by featuring a larger 2.4-liter FA24D naturally aspirated boxer engine producing 228 horsepower at 7,000 rpm and 184 lb-ft of torque at 3,700 rpm—a significant increase in both power and torque delivered at a more accessible rpm. The exterior design features more aggressive styling with functional air intakes, a distinct matrix grille pattern, more pronounced fenders, and a ducktail rear spoiler. Available with either a six-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission, the GR86 delivers improved acceleration with 0-60 mph times of approximately 5.4 seconds for automatic models and 6.1 seconds for manual models. Despite the larger engine, curb weight increases only marginally thanks to aluminum roof and fender panels, maintaining the car's nimble character. The chassis features increased rigidity with 50 percent more torsional rigidity than its predecessor, adopting elements from the Subaru Global Platform. The interior has been modernized with a 7-inch digital instrument cluster featuring a track-focused display mode, an 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system with standard Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility, and improved materials throughout while maintaining the driver-focused layout. Special editions include the 10th Anniversary Special Edition, Trueno Edition (celebrating 40 years of the AE86), Hakone Edition, and Yuzu Edition.
Toyota-GR86.name: Second Generation (ZN8/ZD8)

Toyota-Grand-Highlander.description: The Toyota Grand Highlander represents a strategic expansion of Toyota's SUV lineup, positioned between the standard Highlander and the larger, more premium Sequoia. Addressing feedback that the regular Highlander's third-row space was insufficient for families needing room for adults or teenagers, the Grand Highlander adds approximately 6.5 inches of overall length and 4 inches of wheelbase, resulting in significantly improved third-row accommodations and cargo capacity. Exterior styling is distinct from the standard Highlander with a more upright, squared-off design featuring a prominent front grille, horizontal-themed lighting elements, and a floating roof effect created by blacked-out pillars. Available with three powertrain options: a 2.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder producing 265 horsepower, a conventional hybrid system combining a 2.5-liter four-cylinder with electric motors for 243 total horsepower, and a Hybrid MAX performance-oriented system pairing a 2.4-liter turbocharged engine with electric motors for 362 combined horsepower and 400 lb-ft of torque. All configurations feature an eight-speed automatic transmission, with front-wheel drive standard and all-wheel drive optional (standard on Hybrid MAX). The interior emphasizes premium comfort with features including heated and ventilated first and second-row seats, a panoramic moonroof, and a power-folding third row, while technology includes a standard 12.3-inch touchscreen with wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, an available 12.3-inch digital instrument cluster, and a full suite of Toyota Safety Sense 3.0 driver assistance features. Practical features include up to seven USB ports throughout the cabin, a refrigerated center console on higher trims, and a maximum cargo capacity of 98 cubic feet with all seats folded. With towing capacity of up to 5,000 pounds, seating for up to eight passengers, and significantly improved space for both passengers and cargo compared to the standard Highlander, the Grand Highlander aims to address the needs of growing families seeking three-row versatility without stepping up to the larger, truck-based Sequoia.
Toyota-Grand-Highlander.name: First Generation

Toyota-Grand-Highlander-Hybrid.description: The Toyota Grand Highlander Hybrid offers electrified powertrain options within the larger Grand Highlander lineup, featuring two distinct hybrid systems to balance efficiency and performance needs. Available in standard hybrid and performance-oriented Hybrid MAX configurations, the Grand Highlander Hybrid maintains the same enlarged proportions as its conventional counterpart, providing enhanced third-row space and cargo capacity over the standard Highlander. The conventional hybrid system combines a 2.5-liter Atkinson-cycle four-cylinder engine with electric motors for a combined 243 horsepower, delivering an EPA-estimated 36 mpg in front-wheel drive configuration—impressive efficiency for a vehicle of this size—while offering up to 600 miles of driving range on a single tank. The Hybrid MAX system, available exclusively on the Platinum grade with standard all-wheel drive, pairs a 2.4-liter turbocharged engine with more powerful electric motors to produce 362 total system horsepower and 400 lb-ft of torque, enabling 0-60 mph acceleration in approximately 6.3 seconds at the expense of some efficiency (27 mpg combined). The standard hybrid uses an electronic continuously variable transmission (e-CVT) system, while the Hybrid MAX features a more conventional 6-speed automatic. Both hybrid variants maintain the same interior appointments, technology features, and cargo capacity as the conventional Grand Highlander, including the 12.3-inch touchscreen infotainment system, available digital instrument cluster, and Toyota Safety Sense 3.0 driver assistance suite. The conventional hybrid configuration particularly emphasizes value, offering class-leading fuel economy without compromising the three-row utility and comfort that define the Grand Highlander's mission. With its combination of spaciousness, efficiency, and available performance, the Grand Highlander Hybrid appeals to families seeking a practical three-row crossover with reduced fuel consumption.
Toyota-Grand-Highlander-Hybrid.name: First Generation

Toyota-Highlander.description: The first-generation Toyota Highlander pioneered Toyota's car-based midsize crossover segment, based on the Camry platform rather than traditional truck underpinnings. Featuring a unibody construction, front-wheel drive architecture with optional all-wheel drive, and a focus on on-road comfort over off-road capability, the original Highlander represented Toyota's response to growing consumer demand for more car-like SUVs. Available in five or seven-passenger configurations (the latter added mid-generation), the Highlander featured conservative, mainstream styling with a practical, upright profile prioritizing interior space and visibility. Engine options included a 2.4-liter four-cylinder producing 155 horsepower and a 3.0-liter V6 generating 220 horsepower (later upgraded to a 3.3-liter with 230 horsepower), both paired with a four-speed automatic transmission. The interior emphasized practicality with straightforward controls, reasonable material quality, and flexible seating arrangements, though without the luxury touches found in its Lexus RX cousin. A mild refresh in 2004 brought updated styling and the optional third row, though the rearmost seats were suitable mainly for children. This generation established the Highlander's reputation for reliability, practicality, and no-fuss ownership experience, appealing to families transitioning from sedans to more versatile vehicles while seeking Toyota's known quality and value.
Toyota-Highlander.name: First Generation (XU20)

Toyota-Highlander.description: The second-generation Toyota Highlander grew substantially in size, emphasizing improved passenger space particularly in the now-standard third row, while adopting more distinctive styling with a prominent grille and more substantial overall presence. Built on an enhanced version of the Camry/Avalon platform, this Highlander offered front-wheel drive standard with optional all-wheel drive, maintaining its car-based crossover approach. Engine options included a base 2.7-liter four-cylinder producing 187 horsepower (new to the lineup) and a 3.5-liter V6 generating 270 horsepower, paired with either a six-speed (I4) or five-speed (V6) automatic transmission. This generation also introduced the Highlander Hybrid, combining the V6 with electric motors for improved efficiency while maintaining strong performance. Interior space expanded significantly, with a clever second-row center seat that could be stowed in a console between the outboard seats or installed to accommodate an eighth passenger. Materials and design improved over the previous generation, with more soft-touch surfaces and available features including a premium JBL audio system, three-zone climate control, and a backup camera on higher trims. A mid-cycle refresh in 2011 brought revised exterior styling with a more aggressive front end and interior refinements. This generation built upon the Highlander's reputation for practical, family-friendly transportation with enhanced space, features, and refinement, further establishing it as a benchmark in the increasingly competitive midsize crossover segment.
Toyota-Highlander.name: Second Generation (XU40)

Toyota-Highlander.description: The third-generation Toyota Highlander featured more aggressive, truck-inspired styling with a prominent trapezoidal grille, pronounced fender flares, and a more muscular overall appearance while maintaining its car-based underpinnings. Built on Toyota's revised K platform, this Highlander grew slightly larger again, offering improved interior space particularly for third-row passengers and cargo. Engine options initially carried over, including the 2.7-liter four-cylinder and 3.5-liter V6, though the four-cylinder was discontinued mid-generation as the vast majority of buyers opted for the V6. In 2017, the V6 was paired with a new eight-speed automatic transmission replacing the previous six-speed, while gaining direct injection for improved power (295 horsepower) and efficiency. The Highlander Hybrid continued with its Atkinson-cycle V6 and electric motor combination, now achieving up to 28 mpg combined. Interior quality took another step forward with more premium materials, particularly in higher trim levels, while technology expanded to include features like an 8-inch touchscreen, Driver Easy Speak (using the microphone to amplify the driver's voice to rear passengers), and an expanded suite of safety features including standard Toyota Safety Sense P from 2017 onward. Seating for up to eight passengers was available with a second-row bench, while seven-passenger configurations featured second-row captain's chairs. A refresh in 2017 brought the aforementioned powertrain updates along with revised styling featuring an even larger grille and expanded feature content. This generation further refined the Highlander's position as a practical, feature-rich family vehicle combining SUV versatility with car-like comfort and driving dynamics.
Toyota-Highlander.name: Third Generation (XU50)

Toyota-Highlander.description: The fourth-generation Toyota Highlander represents a comprehensive redesign built on Toyota's TNGA-K platform, featuring more distinctive styling with a mix of sharp character lines and curved surfaces, a more cohesive overall design, and improved proportions including a longer, more SUV-like hood line. Slightly larger than its predecessor at 194.9 inches in length, this Highlander emphasizes improved dynamics and refinement alongside its traditional strengths of practicality and reliability. The standard powertrain is now a 3.5-liter V6 producing 295 horsepower and 263 lb-ft of torque paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission, with front-wheel drive standard and three different all-wheel drive systems available depending on trim level. A significant change for the 2023 model year replaced the V6 with a 2.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder producing 265 horsepower and 309 lb-ft of torque. The Highlander Hybrid combines a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine with electric motors for a total system output of 243 horsepower while achieving up to 36 mpg combined with front-wheel drive—a significant efficiency improvement over previous generations. Interior quality reaches new heights with more premium materials throughout, standard three-zone climate control, and enhanced technology including a standard 8-inch or available 12.3-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. Safety technology is comprehensive with Toyota Safety Sense 2.5+ standard across all trims, offering features including pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, full-speed dynamic radar cruise control, lane tracing assist, and automatic high beams. Available in L, LE, XLE, XSE, Limited, and Platinum trim levels, the Highlander offers configurations ranging from practical to near-luxury, all sharing the model's focus on family-friendly design with features including seven USB ports throughout the cabin, available second-row captain's chairs, and a power liftgate on most trims. The fourth-generation Highlander builds upon the model's reputation for practical, reliable family transportation while offering enhanced style, efficiency, and technology to maintain its position in the highly competitive midsize crossover segment.
Toyota-Highlander.name: Fourth Generation (XU70)

Toyota-Hilux.description: The first-generation Toyota Hilux established what would become one of the world's most enduring pickup truck nameplates, replacing the earlier Toyota Stout as the company's compact pickup offering. Featuring simple, functional styling with a separate cab and bed on a ladder frame chassis, the original Hilux was powered by a 1.5-liter inline-four engine producing a modest 70 horsepower, later supplemented by a 1.6-liter option. Available only with rear-wheel drive and emphasizing utility over comfort, this initial Hilux laid the groundwork for Toyota's reputation for building durable, reliable workhorse vehicles. The design prioritized practicality with a focus on commercial applications, though with somewhat more refinement than the typical pickup of its era. This generation introduced the Hilux nameplate (combining 'High' and 'Luxury') that would eventually become synonymous with tough, dependable trucks in markets worldwide, though its global distribution was still limited compared to later generations.
Toyota-Hilux.name: First Generation (N10)

Toyota-Hilux.description: The second-generation Toyota Hilux featured updated styling with a more modern appearance, increased dimensions, and improved comfort while maintaining its focus on durability and utility. Engine options expanded to include 1.6, 2.0, and 2.2-liter gasoline units with modestly increased power outputs, though still focused on reliability and efficiency rather than performance. This generation maintained the body-on-frame construction with leaf spring rear suspension that would define the Hilux throughout its history. Interior comfort improved with better materials and more features, though still basic by modern standards. A significant development was the introduction of the first long-wheelbase variant, offering increased bed length and payload capacity. Still primarily available as a rear-wheel drive model, this generation began to expand the Hilux's global footprint as Toyota's international presence grew, establishing the model's reputation in developing markets where its durability and simplicity proved especially valuable. The second-generation Hilux further developed the model's core identity as a tough, practical pickup that prioritized functionality and reliability over luxury or excessive refinement.
Toyota-Hilux.name: Second Generation (N20)

Toyota-Hilux.description: The third-generation Toyota Hilux marked a significant evolution with more modern styling featuring a wider body, square headlights, and a more substantial overall appearance. Engine options varied by market but typically included 1.6, 1.8, 2.0, and 2.2-liter gasoline units, with diesel options beginning to appear in some regions. A crucial development was the introduction of four-wheel drive variants, substantially expanding the Hilux's capability and appeal, particularly in markets with challenging terrain or weather conditions. This generation offered both standard and long-wheelbase configurations with varying bed lengths, and introduced the first extended cab (Xtra Cab) body style in some markets, providing additional interior storage space behind the front seats. Interior comfort continued to improve with better seating, more sound insulation, and additional features, though still maintaining a straightforward, durable design. The third-generation Hilux significantly expanded its global presence, appearing in more markets worldwide and beginning to build the legendary reputation for toughness and reliability that would define the nameplate, particularly in developing regions where its combination of durability, simplicity, and four-wheel drive capability proved invaluable for both commercial and personal use.
Toyota-Hilux.name: Third Generation (N30/N40)

Toyota-Hilux.description: The fourth-generation Toyota Hilux featured more aerodynamic styling with softer lines and a less boxy appearance than its predecessors, reflecting broader automotive design trends of the 1980s. Available in standard and long-wheelbase variants with multiple cab configurations including regular, extended (Xtra Cab), and in some markets, the first double cab (four-door) Hilux models providing seating for up to five passengers, this generation significantly expanded the model's versatility. Engine options varied widely by market but typically included 1.6, 2.0, 2.2, and 2.4-liter gasoline units and 2.2 and 2.4-liter diesel options, the latter becoming increasingly important in many markets. Four-wheel drive continued as an option alongside standard rear-wheel drive, with improved off-road capability through better approach and departure angles, increased ground clearance, and more sophisticated transfer cases on 4WD variants. Interior comfort improved noticeably with better materials, more supportive seats, and enhanced noise insulation, though still designed for durability over luxury. This generation further cemented the Hilux's global reputation for exceptional reliability and durability, expanding its appeal beyond purely utilitarian applications to include recreational and lifestyle users, particularly with four-wheel drive and double cab variants.
Toyota-Hilux.name: Fourth Generation (N50/N60/N70)

Toyota-Hilux.description: The fifth-generation Toyota Hilux continued the model's evolution with more refined styling featuring rounded edges, flush surfaces, and integrated bumpers for improved aerodynamics and a more modern appearance. Available in an expanded range of configurations including regular cab, extended cab (Xtra Cab), and double cab body styles, with both rear-wheel drive and four-wheel drive options, this generation further diversified the Hilux's appeal across different user types. Engine options again varied significantly by market but typically included 1.8, 2.0, 2.4, and 2.7-liter gasoline units and 2.4 and 2.8-liter diesel engines, with the first turbodiesel variants appearing in some regions. Suspension design was refined with independent front suspension on some variants for improved on-road comfort without sacrificing durability or off-road capability. Interior quality took another step forward with more car-like design, improved ergonomics, and expanded feature content, particularly on higher-trim double cab models targeting personal use customers. This generation saw significant expansion of the Hilux's global manufacturing footprint with production facilities in multiple countries, cementing its position as a truly global vehicle. The fifth-generation Hilux built upon the model's reputation for exceptional reliability and durability while offering increased refinement and features, broadening its appeal beyond purely utilitarian applications to serve as both workhorses and lifestyle vehicles depending on configuration and market.
Toyota-Hilux.name: Fifth Generation (N80/N90/N100/N110)

Toyota-Hilux.description: The sixth-generation Toyota Hilux featured more substantial, muscular styling with flared wheel arches, a higher hood line, and an overall more imposing presence, reflecting the global trend toward more SUV-like aesthetics in pickup trucks. Available in an expanded range of cab and bed configurations, this generation continued with both rear-wheel drive and four-wheel drive options, the latter now with more sophisticated systems including shift-on-the-fly capability on some variants. Engine options varied by market but typically included 2.0, 2.4, 2.7, and 3.4-liter gasoline units and 2.4, 2.5, 2.8, and 3.0-liter diesel options, with diesel engines becoming increasingly dominant in many markets, particularly with the improved performance and efficiency of turbodiesel variants. Suspension design continued to evolve with a focus on balancing off-road capability, durability, and improved on-road comfort, the latter becoming increasingly important as double cab variants gained popularity as personal vehicles. Interior design and quality improved significantly with more car-like features, better materials, and enhanced comfort, particularly in higher-trim models targeting the growing lifestyle pickup segment. Safety features expanded with the introduction of driver and passenger airbags on some variants. This generation further expanded the Hilux's global presence and reputation, with its legendary durability showcased in various extreme demonstrations including by the BBC's Top Gear program, which unsuccessfully attempted to destroy a high-mileage example through a series of extraordinary abuses—a testament that significantly enhanced the model's already formidable reputation for toughness.
Toyota-Hilux.name: Sixth Generation (N140/N150/N160/N170)

Toyota-Hilux.description: The seventh-generation Toyota Hilux featured more sophisticated styling with complex surfacing, integrated bumpers, and larger dimensions, continuing the trend toward more passenger-car-like refinement while maintaining the model's renowned durability. Available in single cab, extra cab, and double cab configurations with various bed lengths and both rear-wheel drive and four-wheel drive options, this generation expanded the model's versatility across work and lifestyle applications. Engine options varied by market but centered around a range of gasoline units including 2.0, 2.7, and 4.0-liter options, plus increasingly important diesel engines including 2.5 and 3.0-liter turbodiesel variants, the latter becoming the predominant choice in many markets due to their combination of power, torque, and efficiency. Chassis engineering focused on increased rigidity for improved safety and handling, while suspension design continued to balance off-road capability with better on-road comfort. Interior quality took another significant step forward with more sophisticated design, higher quality materials, and enhanced technology including available touchscreen infotainment systems, automatic climate control, and comprehensive safety features on higher trim levels. This generation introduced advanced active and passive safety elements including stability control, traction control, and multiple airbags on many variants. The seventh-generation Hilux further cemented the model's global reputation for exceptional durability while offering significantly improved refinement, comfort, and technology, broadening its appeal to serve both as rugged work vehicles and comfortable personal transportation, particularly in double cab 4×4 configuration where it effectively functioned as an SUV with a bed.
Toyota-Hilux.name: Seventh Generation (AN10/AN20/AN30)

Toyota-Hilux.description: The eighth-generation Toyota Hilux features more aggressive, contemporary styling with a prominent hexagonal grille, complex LED lighting elements, and muscular body sculpting, reflecting the global trend toward more assertive pickup truck aesthetics. Available in the established range of single cab, extra cab, and double cab configurations with various bed lengths, this generation continues with both rear-wheel drive and four-wheel drive options with enhanced off-road capability on the latter. Engine options vary significantly by market but generally include a 2.7-liter gasoline option in some regions and a range of diesel engines centered on the new 2.4 and 2.8-liter 'GD' series turbodiesel units, offering improved refinement, efficiency, and emissions performance compared to previous generations. Transmission options include six-speed manual and automatic, with the latter becoming increasingly popular even in markets traditionally favoring manual transmissions. Chassis rigidity improved significantly, contributing to enhanced safety, handling, and towing capability, while suspension design continues to balance off-road performance with improved on-road comfort. Interior quality advanced considerably with a more car-like dashboard design, higher quality materials throughout, and significantly enhanced technology including a central touchscreen infotainment system with smartphone connectivity, multi-camera viewing systems on higher trims, and a comprehensive suite of driver assistance features on many variants. Safety technology expanded dramatically with the Toyota Safety Sense package available on higher trim levels, offering features like pre-collision system, lane departure alert, and dynamic radar cruise control—advanced technology for the pickup segment. A significant facelift in 2020 brought revised styling, improved refinement, and increased power for the 2.8-liter diesel engine, now producing up to 201 horsepower and 500 Nm of torque. Special models include the off-road focused Hilux GR Sport with unique suspension tuning and styling elements developed with input from Toyota's Gazoo Racing division. The eighth-generation Hilux continues the model's dual role as both a rugged work vehicle and an increasingly refined lifestyle pickup, maintaining its legendary reputation for durability while offering features and comfort approaching passenger car levels, particularly in higher-specification double cab variants.
Toyota-Hilux.name: Eighth Generation (AN120/AN130)

Toyota-Innova.description: The first-generation Toyota Innova was developed as a more passenger-focused MPV (Multi-Purpose Vehicle) replacement for the more utilitarian Kijang/Revo/Unser models that had been popular in Southeast Asian markets. Built on the IMV (Innovative International Multi-purpose Vehicle) platform shared with the Hilux pickup and Fortuner SUV, the Innova combined truck-based ruggedness with improved comfort and features suitable for family transportation. Featuring three rows of seating for seven or eight passengers depending on configuration, the Innova adopted a tall wagon-like design with conventional hinged doors rather than the sliding doors typical of minivans in other markets. Engine options varied by market but typically included 2.0 and 2.7-liter gasoline and 2.5-liter diesel units, paired with manual or automatic transmissions driving the rear wheels. The interior prioritized space and flexibility with multiple seating configurations, though material quality and features were relatively basic in lower trims. Higher specifications offered amenities like automatic climate control, leather seating, and enhanced audio systems to appeal to more affluent buyers. A significant facelift in 2008 updated the styling and interior, followed by another refresh in 2011 that further modernized the appearance. The first-generation Innova established itself as a versatile family vehicle particularly suited to developing markets across Asia, offering a combination of durability, practicality, and relative affordability that made it a popular choice for both private owners and commercial operators in the taxi and shuttle service industries.
Toyota-Innova.name: First Generation (AN40)

Toyota-Innova.description: The second-generation Toyota Innova featured a more upscale, contemporary design with a prominent trapezoidal grille, complex headlight shapes, and more sophisticated surface detailing, marking a significant step up in perceived quality and presence. Still built on an updated version of the IMV platform shared with the Hilux and Fortuner, this generation maintained its body-on-frame construction while offering improved refinement and dynamics. Available with seven or eight-passenger seating across three rows, the Innova grew slightly in all dimensions, providing enhanced interior space particularly for third-row passengers. Engine options varied by market but typically centered around improved 2.0 and 2.7-liter gasoline engines and a new 2.4-liter GD-series turbodiesel replacing the previous 2.5-liter unit, all offering better performance, efficiency, and refinement than their predecessors. Transmission options included manual and automatic, both with additional gears compared to the previous generation. The interior saw a dramatic improvement in design and material quality, with a more car-like dashboard layout, higher grade plastics, and enhanced feature content including available ambient lighting, automatic climate control with rear controls, and a touchscreen infotainment system on higher grades. Safety technology expanded significantly with available features including multiple airbags, stability control, and hill-start assist. The second-generation Innova positioned itself as a more premium offering than its predecessor while maintaining the durability and practicality that had made the original successful, appealing to buyers seeking a robust family vehicle with enhanced comfort and features in markets across Asia, the Middle East, and parts of Africa.
Toyota-Innova.name: Second Generation (AN140)

Toyota-Innova.description: The third-generation Toyota Innova, marketed as Innova Hycross or Zenix depending on region, represents a revolutionary change for the nameplate, transitioning from the traditional body-on-frame IMV platform to Toyota's TNGA-C unibody architecture shared with vehicles like the Corolla Cross. This fundamental shift creates a more car-like driving experience while maintaining the spacious three-row layout that defined previous generations. The exterior design evolves to a more SUV-inspired appearance with a prominent grille, muscular wheel arches, and an overall more premium presence. For the first time, the Innova adopts front-wheel drive instead of rear-wheel drive, enabling improved interior packaging and a lower, flatter floor. Also revolutionary is the powertrain lineup, centered around a 2.0-liter naturally aspirated gasoline engine in base models and, most significantly, Toyota's highly efficient hybrid system combining a 2.0-liter gasoline engine with electric motors for improved performance and substantially better fuel economy than previous diesel options. Transmission options include CVT for standard models and an e-CVT for the hybrid variants. The interior represents a complete reinvention with a horizontally-themed dashboard featuring a freestanding infotainment touchscreen (up to 10.1 inches), digital instrument cluster in higher grades, and much-improved materials throughout. Available luxury features include ventilated front seats, captain's chairs with ottomans in the second row, a panoramic sunroof, powered tailgate, and ambient lighting—features unprecedented in the Innova lineup. Safety technology takes a major leap forward with Toyota Safety Sense 3.0 bringing pre-collision system, dynamic radar cruise control, lane tracing assist, and automatic high beams on higher trim levels. While maintaining the Innova's core identity as a spacious and practical three-row family vehicle, this generation elevates the model's refinement, efficiency, and technology to unprecedented levels for the nameplate.
Toyota-Innova.name: Third Generation (Innova Hycross/Zenix)

Toyota-Ist.description: The first-generation Toyota ist was introduced in Japan as a compact hatchback with distinctive boxy styling targeting young urban buyers, later exported to North America as the Scion xA and to China as the Toyota Zelas. Based on the same platform as the contemporary Yaris/Vitz but with a more substantial body design, the ist featured a tall, upright profile maximizing interior space within compact exterior dimensions. Powered by a 1.3-liter or 1.5-liter VVT-i engine in the Japanese market, paired with either a five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmission, the ist offered modest but adequate performance for urban environments. The interior emphasized versatility with rear seats that could slide, fold, or be removed entirely, creating a flat cargo floor when needed. Despite its compact dimensions, the ist provided relatively spacious accommodations for passengers due to its efficient packaging and tall roof. Equipment levels were good for its segment, with features like automatic climate control, power accessories, and a premium audio system available. The ist established itself in the Japanese market as a practical, stylish compact car appealing particularly to younger buyers seeking versatility and distinctive design in a small package, while serving as one of the initial offerings for Toyota's youth-oriented Scion brand in North America.
Toyota-Ist.name: First Generation (XP60)

Toyota-Ist.description: The first-generation Toyota ist received a significant facelift on May 30, 2005, introducing revised exterior styling with updated front and rear bumper designs, new headlights, and an updated grille. The interior received minor revisions including new trim options and updated equipment availability. After the facelift, the ist was only available through Toyota's Netz Store dealerships, replacing the previous availability at both Netz and Toyopet stores. The mechanical specifications remained largely unchanged, continuing with the 1.3-liter and 1.5-liter VVT-i engine options paired with manual or automatic transmissions. The facelifted model maintained its position as Toyota's youth-oriented compact hatchback, serving as the basis for the Scion xA in North America. The distinctive boxy styling was softened slightly while maintaining the tall, space-efficient profile that maximized interior volume within compact exterior dimensions.
Toyota-Ist.name: First Generation (XP60 Facelift)

Toyota-Ist.description: The second-generation Toyota ist featured more refined styling with a less boxy, more dynamic appearance while maintaining the practical, space-efficient design philosophy of its predecessor. Based on an updated version of Toyota's small car platform shared with the contemporary Yaris, the new ist grew slightly in all dimensions offering improved interior space and comfort. Engine options in the Japanese market continued with 1.5-liter and 1.8-liter VVT-i units, paired with a Super CVT-i (Continuously Variable Transmission) replacing the previous conventional automatic, providing improved efficiency and smoother operation. The interior saw significant improvements in design and material quality, with a more upscale appearance and enhanced feature content including available smart key entry and start, automatic climate control, and enhanced audio systems. Safety features expanded with standard ABS, multiple airbags, and available stability control on higher grades. The versatile rear seating arrangement continued with 60:40 split folding capability, though without the removable function of the previous generation. This generation was exported to North America as the Scion xD, replacing the xA, though with some design and equipment differences from the Japanese ist. The second-generation ist continued to appeal to urban buyers seeking a practical, versatile compact car with distinctive styling and good feature content, remaining in production in Japan until 2016 when it was effectively replaced by the more crossover-oriented Toyota C-HR, reflecting the market shift toward SUV-like vehicles even in the compact segment.
Toyota-Ist.name: Second Generation (XP110)

Toyota-Land-Cruiser.description: The Toyota Land Cruiser FJ40 series is among the most iconic generations of Toyota's legendary off-road vehicle, featuring distinctive boxy styling, exceptional durability, and formidable off-road capability. Available in short and medium wheelbase configurations, plus the long-wheelbase FJ45 variants, this generation established the Land Cruiser's global reputation as a vehicle capable of conquering the most challenging terrain while maintaining remarkable reliability. Most models featured the virtually indestructible F-series inline-six gasoline engines ranging from 3.9 to 4.2 liters, though some markets received diesel options in later years. The spartan interior emphasized function over comfort with simple controls, durable materials, and minimal luxury features, reflecting the vehicle's focus on practicality and durability. Key elements included solid front and rear axles, leaf spring suspension, and a part-time four-wheel drive system with a two-speed transfer case. While the basic design remained consistent throughout its long production run, the FJ40 series gradually evolved with improved engines, enhanced safety features, and minor comfort improvements. This generation established the Land Cruiser's legendary reputation for durability in the most challenging environments worldwide, from African deserts to Arctic tundra, particularly in regions with undeveloped infrastructure where reliability was paramount. The FJ40's iconic status and enduring popularity have made well-preserved examples highly sought after by collectors and enthusiasts, with values appreciating significantly in recent decades.
Toyota-Land-Cruiser.name: FJ40 Series

Toyota-Land-Cruiser.description: The Toyota Land Cruiser FJ60/FJ62 series evolved the model into a more practical family vehicle while maintaining serious off-road capability, featuring a longer wagon body with four doors and significantly more interior space than its FJ40 predecessor. The exterior design maintained a boxy, functional aesthetic but with more modern elements including rectangular headlights and larger glass areas for improved visibility. Powertrain options included the carbureted 4.2-liter 2F inline-six in the FJ60 (1980-1987) and the fuel-injected 4.0-liter 3F-E in the FJ62 (1988-1990), with diesel options available in some markets. Transmission choices included four and five-speed manuals and a four-speed automatic in later FJ62 models, paired with a part-time four-wheel drive system featuring a two-speed transfer case. While still employing a body-on-frame design with solid axles front and rear, the FJ60/62 offered improved on-road comfort through better interior appointments, enhanced sound insulation, and available amenities like power windows, air conditioning, and improved audio systems—though still emphasizing durability over luxury. This generation successfully broadened the Land Cruiser's appeal beyond specialized utility applications to include family use, recreational off-roading, and overland travel, establishing the model's dual identity as both a highly capable off-road vehicle and a practical, if somewhat spartan, everyday transportation option. The FJ60/62's combination of increased practicality and maintained capability helped expand the Land Cruiser's global presence and reputation, particularly in North America where it began to develop a following beyond hardcore off-road enthusiasts.
Toyota-Land-Cruiser.name: FJ60/FJ62 Series

Toyota-Land-Cruiser.description: The Toyota Land Cruiser FJ80 series (officially designated as the 80 Series) represented a significant modernization of the iconic nameplate, combining enhanced comfort and on-road performance with maintained off-road prowess. Featuring softer, more aerodynamic styling with rounded edges replacing the sharp lines of its predecessors, the 80 Series grew in all dimensions, offering substantially increased interior space and improved ergonomics. Powertrain options varied by market but included the 4.0-liter 3F-E and 4.5-liter 1FZ-FE gasoline inline-six engines in North America, with various gasoline and diesel options in other regions. Transmission choices included five-speed manual and four-speed automatic, paired with a full-time four-wheel drive system on most variants—a significant change from the part-time systems of previous generations. While maintaining body-on-frame construction and solid axles front and rear, the 80 Series incorporated coil springs at all four corners (replacing leaf springs) for improved articulation off-road and better ride quality on pavement. Interior quality and features took a major step forward with available amenities including leather upholstery, power accessories, improved climate control, and enhanced audio systems, reflecting the model's evolution toward a more premium positioning in many markets. Safety features expanded with the introduction of anti-lock brakes, airbags in later models, and improved crash structures. The 80 Series successfully balanced significant improvements in comfort, refinement, and on-road performance with maintained or enhanced off-road capability, aided by features like triple differential locks on some models including the Lexus-badged variants (LX450) in North America. This generation further established the Land Cruiser's global reputation as the ultimate go-anywhere vehicle while broadening its appeal to luxury SUV buyers, particularly in developed markets.
Toyota-Land-Cruiser.name: FJ80 Series

Toyota-Land-Cruiser.description: The Toyota Land Cruiser FJ100 series (officially designated as the 100 Series) continued the model's evolution toward increased luxury and refinement while maintaining impressive off-road capability. Featuring more sophisticated styling with a prominent grille, complex headlight designs, and an overall more upscale appearance, the 100 Series grew slightly larger than its predecessor, offering enhanced interior space and comfort. A significant chassis change was the introduction of independent front suspension (IFS) on some variants, primarily those destined for developed markets like North America and Australia, while solid front axle models continued for markets prioritizing maximum off-road capability. Powertrain options varied significantly by market but included a 4.7-liter V8 (2UZ-FE) in North America and Australia, with various gasoline and diesel inline-six and V8 options in other regions. Transmission choices included manual in some markets and four or five-speed automatic, paired with full-time four-wheel drive systems featuring a center differential with locking capability. The interior reached new heights of luxury with high-quality leather upholstery, premium wood trim, enhanced climate control systems, and improved noise insulation, particularly in higher trim levels and Lexus-badged variants (LX470) sold in some markets. Safety features expanded significantly with multiple airbags, stability control, and enhanced braking systems. Off-road technology advanced with systems like Active Traction Control (A-TRAC), Downhill Assist Control (DAC), and adjustable height suspension on some models. The 100 Series successfully balanced the Land Cruiser's traditional strengths of durability and off-road capability with significantly enhanced comfort, refinement, and technology, allowing it to compete more directly with luxury SUVs while maintaining its core identity as an exceptionally capable vehicle for challenging environments.
Toyota-Land-Cruiser.name: FJ100 Series

Toyota-Land-Cruiser.description: The Toyota Land Cruiser J200 series represented the nameplate's most luxurious and technologically advanced iteration to date, featuring sophisticated styling with a commanding presence, chrome accents, and complex surfacing that balanced traditional Land Cruiser design cues with modern luxury SUV aesthetics. Based on a strengthened body-on-frame platform with independent front suspension and a solid rear axle, the J200 grew larger in all dimensions, offering expanded interior space particularly for third-row passengers. Powertrain options varied by market but included a 5.7-liter V8 (3UR-FE) in North America producing 381 horsepower, a 4.6-liter V8 (1UR-FE) in some regions, and various diesel options including the twin-turbocharged 4.5-liter V8 diesel (VD) that became the predominant choice in many markets due to its exceptional torque and reasonable efficiency. Transmission options centered around five, six, and later eight-speed automatics paired with sophisticated full-time four-wheel drive systems featuring a Torsen center differential and a two-speed transfer case. Interior quality reached unprecedented levels with premium leather, real wood and metal accents, four-zone climate control, heated and ventilated seats, and enhanced technology including large infotainment screens with advanced connectivity options. Off-road capability remained exceptional despite the increased luxury, aided by systems like Crawl Control, Multi-Terrain Select, and Kinetic Dynamic Suspension System (KDSS) allowing automated disconnection of the stabilizer bars for improved articulation. Safety technology expanded dramatically throughout this generation's long production run, eventually including Toyota Safety Sense with pre-collision system, dynamic radar cruise control, lane departure alert, and automatic high beams. A significant refresh in 2015 brought updated styling, improved interior technology, and enhanced safety features. The J200 successfully combined genuine all-terrain capability with increased luxury and technology, maintaining the Land Cruiser's position as the ultimate go-anywhere vehicle while offering comfort and refinement approaching that of dedicated luxury SUVs.
Toyota-Land-Cruiser.name: J200 Series

Toyota-Land-Cruiser.description: The Toyota Land Cruiser J300 series represents a comprehensive redesign of Toyota's flagship SUV, featuring more angular, modern styling with prominent wheel arches, a bold grille, and a generally more muscular yet sophisticated appearance. Built on Toyota's new TNGA-F body-on-frame platform shared with the latest Tundra and Sequoia, the J300 maintains similar exterior dimensions to its predecessor but is approximately 440 pounds lighter thanks to increased use of high-strength steel and aluminum. A significant mechanical change is the replacement of the traditional V8 engines with a twin-turbocharged 3.5-liter V6 producing 409 horsepower and 479 lb-ft of torque in gasoline form (available in most global markets), or a 3.3-liter twin-turbocharged diesel V6 generating 304 horsepower and 516 lb-ft of torque (primarily for markets outside North America), both paired with a 10-speed automatic transmission and full-time four-wheel drive system. Off-road capability remains exceptional with systems like Multi-Terrain Select now featuring Auto mode that automatically detects surface conditions, an improved Crawl Control function, and available E-KDSS (Electronic Kinetic Dynamic Suspension System) that provides improved wheel articulation off-road while reducing body roll on pavement. The interior combines traditional Land Cruiser durability with modern luxury, featuring a 12.3-inch touchscreen infotainment system, digital instrument cluster, and enhanced materials throughout, though maintaining a somewhat more utilitarian approach than luxury-branded competitors. Advanced safety technology is comprehensive with Toyota Safety Sense 2.0 standard across the range, offering pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, dynamic radar cruise control, lane tracing assist, and road sign assist. Though the J300 was initially not offered in the North American market (where the more luxury-oriented Lexus LX600 serves as its replacement), it returned for the 2024 model year as the Land Cruiser 250 with unique styling and a hybrid-only powertrain. The J300 series continues the Land Cruiser's dual mission of providing exceptional off-road capability while offering increased refinement, technology, and efficiency, maintaining its position as the benchmark for combining luxury and all-terrain prowess in challenging global environments.
Toyota-Land-Cruiser.name: J300 Series

Toyota-Land-Cruiser-Hybrid.description: The Toyota Land Cruiser J200 series introduced limited hybrid variants in select markets, primarily Japan, representing Toyota's first exploration of electrifying its flagship SUV. The J200 hybrid utilized Toyota's established hybrid technology, pairing a 5.0-liter V8 gasoline engine with an electric motor to create a sophisticated parallel hybrid system, producing combined outputs around 430 horsepower while achieving notable improvements in fuel efficiency and emissions—critical factors in markets with stringent environmental regulations and high fuel costs. The hybrid system employed Toyota's proven technology from the Lexus LS600h, adapted for the Land Cruiser's body-on-frame platform and four-wheel drive requirements. An electric motor was integrated with the transmission, providing electric-only driving capability at low speeds for urban environments and seamless transitions to hybrid and engine-only modes based on driving conditions and power demands. The nickel-metal hydride battery pack was positioned to maintain the Land Cruiser's ground clearance and protect it during off-road use, with additional underbody protection and sealed components ensuring reliability in challenging conditions. Despite the added complexity of the hybrid system, the J200 hybrid maintained full four-wheel drive capability with Torsen center differential and two-speed transfer case, along with all off-road systems including Crawl Control, Multi-Terrain Select, and KDSS. The interior featured hybrid-specific displays and controls integrated into the premium cabin, showing energy flow, regenerative braking status, and optimized climate control that could pre-condition the cabin using battery power. Toyota Safety Sense features were standard, including pre-collision system, dynamic radar cruise control, and lane departure alert. While the J200 hybrid had limited global availability and relatively low production volumes, it served as an important proving ground for Toyota's development of hybrid technology in body-on-frame SUVs, informing the engineering decisions that would shape the more widespread hybrid adoption in the J300 series. The J200 hybrid demonstrated that Toyota's legendary reliability and durability could extend to hybrid powertrains even in demanding applications, laying the groundwork for the Land Cruiser's electrified future.
Toyota-Land-Cruiser-Hybrid.name: J200 Series Hybrid (Limited Markets)

Toyota-Land-Cruiser-Hybrid.description: The Toyota Land Cruiser J300 series introduced hybrid technology to the global Land Cruiser lineup, representing a significant shift toward electrification while maintaining the model's renowned off-road capability. Built on Toyota's TNGA-F body-on-frame platform, the J300 hybrid is available in multiple variants across different markets. In select international markets, the primary hybrid option features a 3.5-liter twin-turbocharged V6 gasoline engine paired with an electric motor and 10-speed automatic transmission, delivering combined outputs exceeding 400 horsepower while providing improved fuel efficiency—a critical consideration in markets with high fuel costs or strict emissions regulations. The North American market received the Land Cruiser 250 starting in 2024, featuring distinctive retro-modern styling with a bold vertical grille, prominent round headlights, and squared-off body lines that pay homage to classic Land Cruiser designs. This variant utilizes a turbocharged 2.4-liter inline-four gasoline engine with an electric motor integrated into an 8-speed automatic transmission, producing a combined output of 326 horsepower and 465 lb-ft of torque, positioned as a more accessible and efficient alternative to the luxury-focused Lexus LX. All hybrid variants feature sophisticated full-time four-wheel drive systems with two-speed transfer cases, with battery placement carefully engineered to maintain ground clearance and protect hybrid components during extreme off-road use through enhanced underbody protection and water-resistant sealing. The hybrid systems provide instant torque delivery for enhanced low-speed off-road performance, improved throttle response for rock crawling, and better on-road acceleration while maintaining exceptional fuel efficiency. Off-road technology includes Multi-Terrain Select with Auto mode that automatically detects surface conditions, enhanced Crawl Control leveraging the electric motor's precise torque control, Downhill Assist Control, and available E-KDSS (Electronic Kinetic Dynamic Suspension System) providing exceptional wheel articulation. Interior appointments vary by market, with global variants emphasizing premium materials and the Land Cruiser 250 focusing on durability and practicality with water-resistant materials, though all feature advanced technology including 12.3-inch touchscreen infotainment systems, digital instrument clusters with hybrid-specific displays showing energy flow and regenerative braking status, and comprehensive Toyota Safety Sense suites. Seating configurations include five-passenger layouts standard with optional third-row seven-passenger configurations available in certain markets. Build quality emphasizes Toyota's legendary durability with enhanced corrosion protection and robust construction suitable for challenging global environments, from tropical regions to arctic conditions. The J300 hybrid successfully demonstrates that hybrid technology and extreme capability are not mutually exclusive, continuing Toyota's strategy of electrifying its lineup while preserving the fundamental characteristics that have made the Land Cruiser indispensable in demanding applications worldwide, from United Nations relief operations to remote tourism ventures, while offering improved efficiency and a more attainable price point that maintains the core values that have defined the Land Cruiser for over six decades.
Toyota-Land-Cruiser-Hybrid.name: J300 Series Hybrid

Toyota-MR2.description: The first-generation Toyota MR2 represented Toyota's pioneering entry into the affordable mid-engine sports car segment, featuring a distinctive wedge-shaped design with angular lines, pop-up headlights, and compact dimensions. The name MR2 derived from 'Midship Runabout 2-seater,' reflecting its mid-engine, rear-wheel drive configuration that was unusual in its price range. Weighing approximately 2,300 pounds, the W10 MR2 emphasized handling precision over outright power, with a naturally aspirated 1.6-liter 4A-GE inline-four engine (shared with the Corolla GT-S) producing 112-128 horsepower depending on market and model year, paired with a five-speed manual or optional four-speed automatic transmission. A supercharged version was added later in some markets, increasing output to 145 horsepower. The interior featured a driver-focused cockpit with well-bolstered seats, a three-spoke steering wheel, and distinctive features like a center console angled toward the driver. Despite its compact exterior, the cabin offered reasonable space for two occupants, while storage was provided in both front and rear trunks, albeit with limited capacity. Handling was the MR2's standout characteristic, with its mid-engine layout, fully independent MacPherson strut suspension, and lightweight construction creating a nimble, responsive driving experience that earned it acclaim from automotive journalists and driving enthusiasts. The first-generation MR2 successfully demonstrated that an affordable, reliable mid-engine sports car was viable, establishing the model's reputation for delivering exotic car driving dynamics at a fraction of the price.
Toyota-MR2.name: First Generation (W10)

Toyota-MR2.description: The second-generation Toyota MR2 evolved the model with more rounded, exotic styling reminiscent of contemporary mid-engine supercars, particularly Ferrari designs—earning it the nickname 'baby Ferrari' in some circles. Significantly larger and heavier than its predecessor, the W20 MR2 offered enhanced performance, refinement, and features while maintaining the mid-engine, rear-wheel drive layout that defined the nameplate. Base models featured a naturally aspirated 2.0-liter 3S-GE inline-four producing approximately 165 horsepower, while the performance-oriented Turbo variant (available in North America and Japan) used a turbocharged 3S-GTE engine generating up to 200 horsepower in early models and up to 242 horsepower in later Japanese versions. Transmission options included a five-speed manual and a four-speed automatic, with the latter not available on Turbo models. The interior offered improved comfort and equipment compared to the first generation, with better materials, more adjustability in the seating position, and enhanced noise insulation. The driving experience balanced sharper performance with improved refinement, though early models gained a reputation for challenging handling at the limit—an issue Toyota addressed with suspension revisions in 1993 that improved predictability. The second-generation MR2 demonstrated Toyota's commitment to the sports car segment during Japan's economic bubble period, delivering genuine performance and exotic styling at a relatively accessible price point, though still facing the same practical limitations inherent to the mid-engine, two-seater format. This generation's long production run—a full decade—spoke to its success and enduring appeal, with the turbocharged variants in particular developing a strong following among tuning enthusiasts.
Toyota-MR2.name: Second Generation (W20)

Toyota-MR2.description: The third-generation Toyota MR2, marketed as the MR2 Spyder in North America and MR-S in Japan, represented a dramatic reimagining of the nameplate, downsizing to a lightweight, open-top roadster format clearly inspired by the successful Mazda Miata/MX-5. Significantly smaller and approximately 700-800 pounds lighter than its predecessor, the W30 MR2 returned to the first generation's philosophy of prioritizing handling agility over outright power. Available exclusively as a convertible with a manual folding soft top, the MR2 Spyder featured clean, minimalist styling with smooth curves, fixed headlights (replacing the pop-ups of previous generations), and a distinctive appearance with the top either up or down. Powered by a naturally aspirated 1.8-liter 1ZZ-FE inline-four mounted transversely behind the seats, the MR2 produced a modest 138 horsepower but offered lively performance due to its approximately 2,200-pound curb weight. Transmission options included a five-speed manual and later a six-speed sequential manual transmission (SMT) with paddle shifters—one of the first such transmissions in an affordable sports car. The interior was simple and focused on the driving experience, with minimal luxury features but supportive seats and well-placed controls. Storage space was extremely limited, with only a small compartment behind the engine and tiny bins behind the seats. The driving experience emphasized immediate response, exceptional agility, and the visceral connection between driver and machine rather than straight-line speed. While less powerful than its predecessors, the third-generation MR2 captured the pure sports car essence that had defined the original, providing an affordable mid-engine experience focused on driving enjoyment rather than practicality or specs. The model was discontinued after the 2005 model year in North America and 2007 globally without a direct replacement, marking the end of Toyota's mid-engine sports car era until the introduction of the GR Supra and eventual GR Corolla.
Toyota-MR2.name: Third Generation (W30)

Toyota-Matrix.description: First generation Toyota Matrix, introduced as a 2003 model year vehicle. Based on the Toyota Corolla platform with compact hatchback body style. Featured 1ZZ-FE and 2ZZ-GE I4 engine options. Relatively unchanged from 2003 to 2004.
Toyota-Matrix.name: First Generation

Toyota-Matrix.description: Facelifted first generation Matrix with updated styling and features. The 2ZZ-GE engine was discontinued after 2006, ending the XRS trim line. Replaced by limited M-Theory edition in 2007.
Toyota-Matrix.name: First Generation

Toyota-Matrix.description: Completely redesigned second generation Matrix unveiled at SEMA show on October 31, 2007. Built on the new E140 platform with updated Corolla-based architecture. Featured new 2ZR-FE and 2AZ-FE I4 engines.
Toyota-Matrix.name: Second Generation

Toyota-Matrix.description: Updated second generation Matrix with redesigned exterior and interior elements for 2011 model year. Added Bluetooth capability, new fascias, wheels, and seat fabrics. XRS trim discontinued in US after 2010.
Toyota-Matrix.name: Second Generation

Toyota-Mirai.description: The first-generation Toyota Mirai represented Toyota's pioneering entry into hydrogen fuel cell vehicles available to the general public, though in limited markets with hydrogen refueling infrastructure. Featuring distinctive, polarizing styling with sharp character lines, prominent air intakes required for the fuel cell system cooling, and an overall futuristic aesthetic, the Mirai clearly announced its technological differentiation from conventional vehicles. Powered by a hydrogen fuel cell stack producing electricity that drives a 151 horsepower electric motor, the Mirai offered approximately 312 miles of range and could be refueled in about five minutes—advantages over battery electric vehicles of the era. The fuel cell system combined hydrogen stored in two carbon-fiber-reinforced tanks with oxygen from the air to produce electricity, emitting only water vapor as a byproduct. The interior featured a premium-focused design with an unusual split-level center console, multiple digital displays, and advanced technology including adaptive cruise control, lane departure alert, and pre-collision system—advanced features for 2014. Seating was limited to four passengers due to the center placement of the rear hydrogen tank. Initially available only in Japan, California, and select European markets with hydrogen infrastructure, the first-generation Mirai served as both a technology showcase and a practical zero-emission vehicle for early adopters, establishing Toyota's position in hydrogen fuel cell technology while providing valuable real-world data about the ownership experience. Despite limited production volumes and infrastructure challenges, the first-generation Mirai demonstrated Toyota's commitment to hydrogen as part of its electrification strategy, positioning the technology as complementary to battery electric vehicles rather than competing with them.
Toyota-Mirai.name: First Generation (JPD10)

Toyota-Mirai.description: The second-generation Toyota Mirai represents a dramatic reinvention of Toyota's hydrogen fuel cell vehicle, transitioning from the eco-car aesthetic of the first generation to a premium, luxury-focused sedan with striking proportions and elegant styling. Built on Toyota's rear-wheel drive TNGA-L platform shared with Lexus models, the new Mirai features a long hood, sweeping roofline, and a significantly more conventional yet sophisticated appearance compared to its predecessor. This fundamental platform change enables improved packaging with the hydrogen tanks now distributed more efficiently throughout the vehicle structure, allowing for five-passenger seating (up from four) and a more balanced weight distribution. The fuel cell stack is smaller yet more powerful, working with a larger battery buffer to power a rear-mounted electric motor producing 182 horsepower and 221 lb-ft of torque. Range increases substantially to approximately 402 miles in the base XLE trim (357 miles in the heavier Limited), representing a nearly 30% improvement over the first generation. The interior takes a significant step upmarket with a design and material quality approaching Lexus levels, featuring a 12.3-inch touchscreen infotainment system, digital instrument cluster, available semi-aniline leather upholstery, and a panoramic roof on higher trims. Technology is comprehensive with Toyota Safety Sense 2.5+ offering enhanced driver assistance features, a JBL sound system, and a digital rearview mirror among the available amenities. By repositioning the Mirai as a premium sedan with cutting-edge technology rather than simply an alternative-fuel vehicle, Toyota aims to broaden the appeal of hydrogen technology while continuing to advance fuel cell development. Though still limited to markets with hydrogen infrastructure (primarily California in the US), the second-generation Mirai makes a more compelling case for hydrogen as part of the zero-emission vehicle landscape, offering luxury, long range, and quick refueling as its key advantages over battery electric alternatives.
Toyota-Mirai.name: Second Generation (JPD20)

Toyota-Prius.description: The first-generation Toyota Prius made history as the world's first mass-produced hybrid electric vehicle, though initially available only in Japan before expanding to limited international markets in 2000. Featuring a conventional sedan design that didn't visually announce its revolutionary powertrain, this original Prius established Toyota's hybrid technology leadership. Powered by what would become known as the Hybrid Synergy Drive system, it combined a 1.5-liter gasoline engine with an electric motor for a combined 70 horsepower, achieving approximately 41 mpg combined—exceptional efficiency for the time. The nickel-metal hydride battery pack was positioned behind the rear seats, limiting cargo space somewhat but allowing for a traditional sedan profile. The interior was relatively conventional with a center-mounted digital instrument display being the main visual clue to its unique technology. This pioneering generation served primarily as a technology demonstration and early adopter vehicle, with modest sales volumes but enormous significance in establishing hybrid technology as viable for everyday transportation.
Toyota-Prius.name: First Generation (XW10)

Toyota-Prius.description: The second-generation Toyota Prius transformed the nameplate from a niche technology showcase into a mainstream success and cultural icon, adopting a distinctive liftback design with a high tail and split-window rear that optimized aerodynamics while creating an instantly recognizable silhouette that clearly differentiated it from conventional vehicles. This distinctive styling, which prioritized aerodynamic efficiency (achieving a drag coefficient of just 0.26) over traditional aesthetics, became emblematic of eco-conscious motoring. The Toyota Hybrid Synergy Drive system was significantly improved, now producing a combined 110 horsepower while achieving approximately 46 mpg combined—a substantial improvement over both its predecessor and conventional alternatives. The interior adopted a futuristic theme with a center-mounted digital information display, small electronic shift lever, and unconventional dashboard layout further emphasizing the Prius's technological differentiation. Interior space expanded significantly through the more efficient liftback design, offering improved passenger room and cargo capacity enhanced by folding rear seats. The second-generation Prius achieved breakthrough market success, particularly as rising fuel prices and growing environmental awareness increased consumer interest in fuel-efficient vehicles. Its distinctive appearance allowed owners to visibly demonstrate their environmental consciousness, creating a cultural phenomenon that extended beyond the car's practical attributes. This generation established the Prius as the defining hybrid vehicle in the public consciousness, with sales exceeding one million units worldwide.
Toyota-Prius.name: Second Generation (XW20)

Toyota-Prius.description: The third-generation Toyota Prius evolved the iconic liftback design with a more refined, elongated silhouette that maintained the distinctive triangular profile while improving aerodynamics further to achieve a 0.25 drag coefficient. The Hybrid Synergy Drive system was extensively updated with a larger 1.8-liter engine replacing the previous 1.5-liter unit, combined with more powerful electric motors to produce 134 total system horsepower while achieving approximately 50 mpg combined—setting a new benchmark for mass-market fuel efficiency. The interior featured a more conventional instrument position in front of the driver but maintained the distinctive center information display, minimalist gear selector, and futuristic design elements that had become Prius hallmarks. Interior space and comfort improved with better materials, enhanced sound insulation, and more supportive seating. This generation expanded the Prius into a family of vehicles with the introduction of the compact Prius c, larger Prius v, and the Prius Plug-in Hybrid offering limited electric-only operation through external charging—the latter previewing Toyota's eventual expansion into plug-in vehicles. Safety and technology features advanced significantly with available pre-collision warning, lane departure alert, and enhanced infotainment options. The third-generation Prius further cemented the model's position as the definitive hybrid vehicle, achieving strong global sales despite increasing competition as other manufacturers introduced their own hybrid models.
Toyota-Prius.name: Third Generation (XW30)

Toyota-Prius.description: The fourth-generation Toyota Prius featured the most dramatic styling departure in the model's history, adopting sharply creased bodywork, complex angular headlights and taillights, and an overall more aggressive appearance that polarized opinion after the more understated design of its predecessors. Built on Toyota's TNGA (Toyota New Global Architecture) platform providing a lower center of gravity and increased structural rigidity, this generation offered improved driving dynamics with a more connected feel and better handling without compromising the efficiency that defined the nameplate. The Hybrid Synergy Drive system was thoroughly updated with enhanced thermal efficiency, reduced friction, and improved electric components, maintaining the 1.8-liter engine displacement but with comprehensive internal refinements, achieving up to 56 mpg combined in the base Eco model—again setting new standards for non-plug-in efficiency. For the first time, the Prius offered an all-wheel drive option (AWD-e) using an additional electric motor to power the rear wheels at low speeds and in slippery conditions. The interior design became more conventional with the instrument display moved in front of the driver and overall ergonomics more closely aligned with traditional Toyota models, while maintaining distinctive hybrid-specific displays and controls. Technology advanced significantly with Toyota Safety Sense becoming standard, offering pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, lane departure alert with steering assist, and adaptive cruise control across all trim levels. A mid-cycle refresh in 2019 toned down some of the more controversial styling elements while adding additional technology features. This generation maintained the Prius's efficiency leadership while attempting to broaden its appeal through improved driving dynamics and the available AWD-e system, though facing increased competition from both hybrid versions of mainstream models and the growing electric vehicle market.
Toyota-Prius.name: Fourth Generation (XW50)

Toyota-Prius.description: The fifth-generation Toyota Prius represents the most dramatic reinvention in the nameplate's history, trading the overtly eco-conscious image of previous generations for a sleek, sporty design with a lower, wider stance, coupe-like roofline, and clean, flowing lines that prioritize style alongside aerodynamic efficiency. Built on an improved version of the TNGA-C platform, this Prius is approximately 2 inches lower, 1 inch wider, and slightly shorter in length than its predecessor, creating more athletic proportions while maintaining the liftback configuration. The hybrid system is completely redesigned around a larger 2.0-liter gasoline engine combined with a more powerful electric motor and improved lithium-ion battery, producing 194 horsepower in front-wheel drive models and 196 horsepower with the available all-wheel drive system (which continues to use a rear-mounted electric motor)—a nearly 60% increase over the previous generation. This substantial power increase improves acceleration to 7.2 seconds 0-60 mph (FWD) or 7.0 seconds (AWD), addressing a long-standing criticism of the Prius's modest performance. Despite the performance focus, efficiency remains impressive at up to 57 mpg combined for the LE FWD model. The interior features a more driver-oriented design with a standard 8-inch or available 12.3-inch touchscreen infotainment system positioned high on the minimalist dashboard, a digital instrument display located directly in the driver's line of sight, and improved materials throughout. Technology is comprehensive with Toyota Safety Sense 3.0 standard across all trim levels, offering enhanced versions of pre-collision system, dynamic radar cruise control, lane departure alert, and new features like proactive driving assist and traffic jam assist on higher trims. Additionally, the Prius Prime plug-in hybrid variant offers 44 miles of electric-only range (up from 25) and a total system output of 220 horsepower. This generation represents Toyota's recognition that hybrid technology has become mainstream, allowing the Prius to evolve beyond its purely efficiency-focused roots to offer style and performance alongside class-leading fuel economy, appealing to a broader range of consumers as the market shifts increasingly toward fully electric vehicles.
Toyota-Prius.name: Fifth Generation (XW60)

Toyota-Prius-Prime.description: The first-generation Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid (known as the Prius PHV in some markets) represented Toyota's initial entry into the plug-in hybrid vehicle segment, based on the third-generation Prius liftback but with enhanced electric capabilities. Visually distinguished from the standard Prius by subtle styling cues including chrome door handles, unique wheels, and specific badging, the Prius Plug-in maintained the familiar silhouette while incorporating the technology needed for extended electric-only operation. The powertrain combined the same 1.8-liter gasoline engine as the standard Prius with more powerful electric motors and a larger 4.4 kWh lithium-ion battery that could be recharged from an external power source, enabling approximately 11 miles of electric-only range at speeds up to 62 mph before operating as a conventional hybrid. Charging from a standard 120V outlet took approximately 3 hours, or 1.5 hours with a 240V Level 2 charger. When the battery was depleted, the vehicle operated like a standard Prius hybrid, achieving approximately 50 mpg combined. The interior was nearly identical to the standard Prius with the addition of specific displays for the plug-in system's state of charge and energy flow. Available in limited markets and volumes, this generation served primarily as Toyota's first step into plug-in technology while gauging market demand, providing useful real-world data while allowing the company to enter the segment without the development costs of a completely new vehicle.
Toyota-Prius-Prime.name: First Generation

Toyota-Prius-Prime.description: The second-generation Toyota Prius Prime (continuing the Prius PHV name in some markets) represented a much more distinct and purposeful plug-in hybrid design compared to its predecessor, featuring unique styling that differentiated it significantly from the standard fourth-generation Prius on which it was based. The exterior design incorporated model-specific elements including quad LED headlights, a double-bubble rear glass, carbon-fiber-reinforced polymer rear hatch, and distinctive front and rear fascias creating a more futuristic, technologically advanced appearance.
