The powertrain combined Toyota's 1.8-liter Atkinson-cycle gasoline engine with dual motor-generators and a substantially larger 8.8 kWh lithium-ion battery pack, enabling an EPA-rated 25 miles of electric-only range at speeds up to 84 mph—more than double the capability of the previous generation. When operating as a hybrid after battery depletion, the Prius Prime achieved 54 mpg combined. Charging time from a standard 120V outlet was approximately 5.5 hours, reduced to about 2 hours with a 240V Level 2 charger. The interior featured model-specific elements including an available 11.6-inch portrait-oriented touchscreen inspired by tablet computers, a four-seat configuration (rather than the standard Prius's five seats) to accommodate battery packaging, and enhanced technology features. Driving modes allowed the user to prioritize electric operation, save battery charge for later use, or let the system automatically determine the most efficient operation. The second-generation Prius Prime represented a more serious commitment to plug-in hybrid technology from Toyota, offering a distinct product with meaningful electric capability rather than simply a variant of the standard Prius, achieving significantly higher sales than its predecessor and establishing the Prime sub-brand that would later expand to other Toyota models.
Toyota-Prius-Prime.name: Second Generation

Toyota-Prius-Prime.description: The third-generation Toyota Prius Prime, based on the fifth-generation Prius platform, continues the nameplate's evolution with dramatically improved styling, performance, and electric capability. Sharing the standard Prius's sleek, sporty redesign but with distinctive Prime-specific elements including unique lighting signatures, front and rear fascias, and aerodynamic enhancements, this generation abandons the overtly futuristic aesthetic of its predecessor for a more conventionally attractive yet still distinctive appearance. The powertrain represents a significant advancement, combining a larger 2.0-liter gasoline engine with more powerful electric motors and a substantially enlarged 13.6 kWh lithium-ion battery pack, creating a combined system output of 220 horsepower—a nearly 100 horsepower increase over the previous generation—while enabling an EPA-rated 44 miles of electric-only range, a 76% improvement. Performance improves dramatically with 0-60 mph acceleration in just 6.6 seconds, addressing a long-standing criticism of previous Prius models. When operating as a hybrid after battery depletion, the Prius Prime achieves 52 mpg combined. The interior features a more driver-focused design with a standard 8-inch or available 12.3-inch touchscreen infotainment system, digital driver's display, and improved materials throughout, now accommodating five passengers rather than the previous generation's four. Advanced technology includes a solar roof option that can generate enough electricity for up to 750 miles of electric driving annually in optimal conditions, while Toyota Safety Sense 3.0 provides comprehensive driver assistance features including traffic jam assist with hands-free capability in certain conditions. The third-generation Prius Prime successfully combines the practical efficiency expected of the nameplate with considerably enhanced performance, style, and electric capability, positioning it as a compelling plug-in hybrid at a time when the automotive market is increasingly transitioning toward full electrification.
Toyota-Prius-Prime.name: Third Generation

Toyota-Prius-v.description: The Toyota Prius v (known as Prius α in Japan and Prius+ in Europe) represented the first expansion of the Prius into a family of vehicles, offering a more practical wagon-like body style with substantially increased cargo capacity and interior space compared to the standard Prius liftback. Based on a modified version of the third-generation Prius platform but with a longer, taller body, the Prius v featured a more upright, practical design prioritizing interior volume while maintaining the distinctive Prius aerodynamic profile and hybrid identity. Powered by Toyota's Hybrid Synergy Drive system combining a 1.8-liter Atkinson-cycle gasoline engine with electric motors for a combined 134 horsepower—the same powertrain as the standard Prius—the Prius v delivered an EPA-rated 42 mpg combined, lower than the standard Prius due to increased weight and less favorable aerodynamics but still exceptional for a vehicle of its size and capacity. The interior focused on family practicality with flexible seating for five (North American models) or seven (European and Japanese models), sliding and reclining rear seats, and up to 67.3 cubic feet of cargo space with rear seats folded—providing approximately 60% more cargo room than the standard Prius. Technology and features were similar to the contemporary Prius, with a central information display, available navigation, and Toyota's reputation for reliability, though with an emphasis on practical features like multiple storage compartments throughout the cabin. The Prius v successfully addressed the needs of environmentally conscious families requiring more space than the standard Prius could provide, offering a compelling alternative to small crossovers and wagons while maintaining much of the efficiency that defined the Prius nameplate. The model was discontinued in North America after the 2017 model year as consumer preferences shifted increasingly toward crossover SUVs, though it continued longer in some international markets.
Toyota-Prius-v.name: First Generation

Toyota-RAV4.description: The first-generation Toyota RAV4 (Recreational Activity Vehicle: 4-wheel drive) pioneered the compact crossover SUV segment, combining car-like unibody construction and handling with available four-wheel drive capability and SUV styling. Initially available in two-door and later four-door configurations, with both hardtop and convertible variants in some markets, the original RAV4 featured compact dimensions, a relatively low ride height compared to traditional SUVs, and spirited handling thanks to its passenger car-derived platform. Powered by a 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine producing approximately 120 horsepower in most markets, paired with either a five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmission, the RAV4 prioritized on-road dynamics over serious off-road capability, though its available all-wheel drive system provided competent performance on unpaved roads and in adverse weather conditions. The interior was compact but well-designed, featuring a car-like driving position, decent materials for its price point, and a rear seat that could be folded to expand cargo capacity. The RAV4's combination of fuel efficiency, maneuverability, versatility, and a more dynamic driving experience compared to traditional truck-based SUVs resonated strongly with consumers, particularly in urban and suburban environments where its compact dimensions proved advantageous. This pioneering model established both the RAV4 nameplate and the compact crossover SUV segment that would eventually become one of the largest and most competitive in the global automotive market.
Toyota-RAV4.name: First Generation (XA10)

Toyota-RAV4.description: The second-generation Toyota RAV4 evolved the successful formula of its predecessor with increased dimensions, more refined styling, and enhanced practicality while maintaining the car-based crossover approach that had defined the original. Available primarily as a four-door model (though a two-door variant continued in some markets), the new RAV4 featured more rounded, contemporary styling with improved aerodynamics and a slightly more substantial presence. Engine options expanded to include a range of more powerful and efficient four-cylinder units, including a 2.4-liter option in some markets producing up to 161 horsepower, paired with improved manual and automatic transmissions. The chassis maintained its unibody construction but with a more rigid structure, improved suspension tuning, and better noise insulation, resulting in enhanced ride quality and reduced interior noise. The interior grew more spacious with improved materials, more comfort features, and enhanced cargo capacity, particularly in longer-wheelbase variants offered in some markets. Safety features expanded with available side airbags and anti-lock brakes. The second-generation RAV4 successfully built upon the strengths of the original while addressing some of its limitations regarding space and refinement, continuing to appeal to buyers seeking a practical, efficient alternative to larger SUVs while maintaining reasonable off-pavement capability through its available all-wheel drive system.
Toyota-RAV4.name: Second Generation (XA20)

Toyota-RAV4.description: The third-generation Toyota RAV4 grew substantially in size and capability, reflecting the segment's evolution from niche to mainstream. Available exclusively in a four-door configuration but with both short and long-wheelbase variants in some markets, this generation featured more traditional SUV styling with a side-hinged rear door (including externally mounted spare tire in some markets) and a more upright stance. Engine options expanded significantly to include larger four-cylinder units and, for the first time in the RAV4, a V6 option in North America producing 269 horsepower—creating one of the quickest vehicles in its class. Transmission options included improved manual and automatic units, with the latter gaining additional gears throughout the generation. The all-wheel drive system became more sophisticated with electronic control systems enhancing stability and traction. The interior grew considerably more spacious with available third-row seating in long-wheelbase models (primarily for North American and Asian markets), significantly increased cargo capacity, and more premium features including available leather upholstery, dual-zone climate control, and enhanced audio systems. Safety features expanded to include stability control, traction control, and multiple airbags as standard equipment. A Sport appearance package offered unique styling and suspension tuning for a more dynamic character. The third-generation RAV4 successfully expanded the model's appeal beyond its original compact crossover niche to compete more directly with traditional SUVs in terms of space and capability, while maintaining the car-like driving dynamics and efficiency that had defined the nameplate.
Toyota-RAV4.name: Third Generation (XA30)

Toyota-RAV4.description: The fourth-generation Toyota RAV4 returned to a more car-like approach after the relatively SUV-oriented third generation, featuring sleeker styling with a sloping roofline, unified body design (eliminating the externally mounted spare tire), and a conventional liftgate replacing the side-hinged door of its predecessor. Built on Toyota's MC platform shared with numerous other models, the new RAV4 adopted front-wheel drive as standard with optional all-wheel drive, the latter featuring a sophisticated electronic control system with various terrain modes on higher trims. Engine options were streamlined in most markets to focus on a 2.5-liter four-cylinder producing 176 horsepower, with smaller engines available in some regions and hybrid variants joining the lineup mid-generation. Transmission options centered around a six-speed automatic, with CVT used for hybrid models. The V6 option was eliminated, creating a more efficiency-focused lineup. The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and technology, with available features including a touchscreen infotainment system, power liftgate, and enhanced safety technology like blind-spot monitoring and rear cross-traffic alert. The third-row seating option was discontinued, returning the RAV4 to a dedicated five-passenger configuration. This generation introduced the RAV4 Hybrid, combining the 2.5-liter engine with electric motors to produce 194 total system horsepower while achieving approximately 32 mpg combined—establishing a variant that would eventually become a cornerstone of the lineup. A mild refresh in 2016 brought updated styling with LED headlights, additional safety features, and improved infotainment options. The fourth-generation RAV4 successfully balanced everyday practicality with improved refinement and efficiency, helping it become one of the best-selling vehicles in its segment and establishing the groundwork for the hybrid's eventual prominence in the model line.
Toyota-RAV4.name: Fourth Generation (XA40)

Toyota-RAV4.description: The fifth-generation Toyota RAV4 represents a bold redesign with more rugged, angular styling inspired by Toyota's truck lineup, robust fender flares, and a more upright, muscular stance that departs significantly from the more car-like appearance of its predecessor. Built on Toyota's TNGA-K platform, this generation benefits from a more rigid structure, lower center of gravity, and improved suspension geometry resulting in enhanced handling and ride quality. The standard powertrain in most markets is a 2.5-liter four-cylinder producing 203 horsepower paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission, while the hybrid variant combines the same engine with electric motors for a total system output of 219 horsepower and significantly improved fuel economy of up to 40 mpg combined. A plug-in hybrid (RAV4 Prime) joined the lineup for 2021, offering 302 horsepower and approximately 42 miles of electric-only range. Various all-wheel drive systems are available depending on trim and powertrain, including a sophisticated torque-vectoring system on Adventure and TRD Off-Road models designed for enhanced capability on unpaved surfaces. The interior features a more premium design with higher quality materials, improved ergonomics, and enhanced technology including a standard 7-inch (later 8-inch or 10.5-inch) touchscreen with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility. Safety technology is comprehensive with Toyota Safety Sense 2.0 standard across all trim levels, offering features like pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, full-speed dynamic radar cruise control, lane departure alert with steering assist, and road sign assist. Distinct visual and functional variations are offered through different trim levels, ranging from the efficiency-focused LE Hybrid to the more rugged TRD Off-Road to the premium Limited. The fifth-generation RAV4 successfully builds upon the model's practical foundation while offering more distinctive styling, improved driving dynamics, enhanced technology, and a range of powertrain options to suit different priorities, helping it maintain its position as one of the world's best-selling SUVs.
Toyota-RAV4.name: Fifth Generation (XA50)

Toyota-RAV4.description: The sixth-generation Toyota RAV4 was revealed on May 20-21, 2025, representing the first RAV4 generation to have a fully electrified lineup, offering either a fifth-generation hybrid (HEV) or sixth-generation plug-in hybrid (PHEV) drivetrain. Built on the TNGA: GA-K platform with additional structural improvements including reinforced sub-frames, braced suspension towers, and revised sub-frames for improved rigidity and NVH, this generation maintains similar exterior dimensions to the XA50 while introducing three distinct design themes: Core (LE, XLE, Limited), Adventure (Woodland), and Sport (SE, XSE, PHEV-only GR Sport). Production began in late 2025, with deliveries starting for the 2026 model year. The powertrain lineup includes hybrid variants producing 222 horsepower in FWD and 232 horsepower in AWD configurations, while plug-in hybrids deliver 302 horsepower with an estimated EPA range of 50 miles. All PHEVs include silicon-carbide inverters, V2H capability, and 50 kW CCS fast charging that replenishes 10-80% in roughly 30 minutes. Technology upgrades include a standard 10.5-inch touchscreen with an optional 12.9-inch unit running Toyota's Arena software platform, while safety features are enhanced with Toyota Safety Sense 4.0 adding front cross-traffic alert, lane-change assist, and predictive curve speed control delivered via over-the-air updates.
Toyota-RAV4.name: Sixth Generation (XA60)

Toyota-RAV4-Hybrid.description: The first-generation Toyota RAV4 Hybrid represented Toyota's expansion of its proven hybrid technology into the popular compact crossover segment, based on the fourth-generation RAV4 platform but with an electrified powertrain. Visually differentiated from conventional RAV4 models by subtle styling cues including unique badges, blue-tinted Toyota emblems, and hybrid-specific wheel designs, the RAV4 Hybrid maintained the standard model's practical crossover design while incorporating the technology needed for hybrid operation. The powertrain combined a 2.5-liter Atkinson-cycle gasoline engine with three electric motors (one serving as a starter/generator, one driving the front wheels, and one driving the rear wheels), creating a total system output of 194 horsepower. This arrangement provided standard all-wheel drive through the dedicated rear electric motor, offering improved traction in slippery conditions. Fuel economy was significantly improved over the conventional RAV4, achieving an EPA-rated 32 mpg combined compared to the standard AWD model's 24 mpg. The nickel-metal hydride battery pack was positioned under the rear seats to minimize intrusion into passenger and cargo space. The interior was nearly identical to non-hybrid RAV4 models with the addition of hybrid-specific displays showing energy flow, battery state of charge, and efficiency information. Available in XLE, SE, and Limited trim levels, the RAV4 Hybrid offered a range of features from basic to near-luxury, all with the added benefit of improved efficiency and reduced emissions. Despite a price premium over equivalent non-hybrid models, the RAV4 Hybrid found success by combining the popular crossover format with significant fuel savings, particularly appealing to urban and suburban drivers with longer commutes who could more quickly recoup the additional upfront cost through reduced fuel expenses.
Toyota-RAV4-Hybrid.name: Fourth Generation (XA40)

Toyota-RAV4-Hybrid.description: The second-generation Toyota RAV4 Hybrid, based on the fifth-generation RAV4 platform, features the same bold, angular styling and robust stance as its conventional counterpart but with hybrid-specific elements including unique badges, blue-tinted Toyota emblems, and distinct wheel designs on some trim levels. Built on Toyota's TNGA-K platform providing improved rigidity, lower center of gravity, and better handling dynamics, this generation offers a more engaging driving experience alongside its efficiency advantages. The hybrid powertrain combines an updated 2.5-liter Atkinson-cycle gasoline engine with more powerful electric motors and a more advanced power control unit, delivering a combined 219 horsepower—a 25 horsepower increase over its predecessor and 16 more than the contemporary non-hybrid RAV4. Fuel economy sees a dramatic improvement to 40 mpg combined in most trim levels, representing a 25% increase over the first-generation RAV4 Hybrid. The nickel-metal hydride battery (switched to lithium-ion in later model years for most trim levels) is positioned under the rear seats to preserve interior space. The Electronic On-Demand AWD system with a dedicated rear electric motor provides more sophisticated control of power distribution to enhance both efficiency and capability. The interior maintains the same design and features as equivalent non-hybrid RAV4 models with the addition of hybrid-specific displays and a drive mode selector offering EV (limited electric-only operation), Eco, Normal, and Sport modes. Available in most of the same trim levels as the conventional RAV4—from basic LE to premium Limited to the off-road-oriented XSE—the hybrid variant offers virtually no compromises compared to the standard model. A significant development for this generation is that the hybrid has become the volume seller in many markets, accounting for over 40% of RAV4 sales in North America and even higher percentages in some regions, reflecting both its efficiency appeal and competitive pricing.
Toyota-RAV4-Hybrid.name: Fifth Generation (XA50)

Toyota-RAV4-Prime.description: The Toyota RAV4 Prime (known as RAV4 PHEV in other markets and renamed RAV4 Plug-in Hybrid for the 2025 model year in North America) is the plug-in hybrid electric vehicle (PHEV) variant of the fifth-generation RAV4 compact crossover SUV. Unveiled at the December 2019 Los Angeles Auto Show and sales beginning in June 2020, the Prime shares its bold, angular styling with conventional and hybrid RAV4 models but features subtle distinguishing elements including a unique front fascia, model-specific badging, and charging port integration. The powertrain combines a specially-tuned 2.5-liter A25A-FXS Atkinson-cycle four-cylinder engine producing 177 hp with two electric motors—one driving the front wheels (40 kW) and another powering the rear (54 kW)—fed by an 18.1 kWh lithium-ion battery pack. This configuration delivers a total system output of 302 horsepower (83 hp more than the standard RAV4 Hybrid) and 227 lb-ft of torque, enabling acceleration from 0-60 mph in just 5.8 seconds and making it the second-quickest vehicle in Toyota's lineup behind the GR Supra. The Prime offers an EPA-rated 42 miles of all-electric range—the highest of any plug-in hybrid SUV at its introduction—allowing many commuters to operate primarily on electric power for daily driving. When depleted, it functions as a conventional hybrid achieving 38 mpg combined. Charging from a 120V outlet takes approximately 12 hours, reduced to 4.5 hours with a 240V Level 2 charger (or 2.5 hours with the optional 6.6 kW onboard charger). Standard Electronic On-Demand AWD provides all-weather capability through the rear electric motor. Available in SE and XSE trim levels (North America), the Prime features standard heated seats, Toyota Safety Sense 2.0, and available premium amenities including a head-up display, panoramic moonroof, and JBL audio. A September 2021 facelift brought updated LED projector headlights, new alloy wheel designs, and USB-C charging ports. The Prime is imported to North America from Toyota's Nagakusa plant in Japan.
Toyota-RAV4-Prime.name: First Generation

Toyota-Rush.description: The first-generation Toyota Rush was launched in January 2006 as a compact SUV developed through Toyota's collaboration with Daihatsu, which sold its version as the Terios (Japan: Be‣go). Built on a built-in ladder frame monocoque body structure, the Rush offered a balance between lighter weight, higher body rigidity, and comfort. Available in both short-wheelbase (J200/J210/J211) and long-wheelbase (F700/F710) configurations, the Rush was sold in five or seven-seat layouts depending on market preference. The design featured a boxy, upright profile with a rear-mounted spare tire emphasizing its SUV identity. Power came from 1.3-liter K3-VE or 1.5-liter 3SZ-VE four-cylinder engines, paired with five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmissions. While rear-wheel drive was standard, select markets offered four-wheel drive with a lockable central differential. The Rush received its first facelift in November 2008 with revised bumpers, tail lamps, and improved fuel economy. A second facelift in March 2015 added projector headlamps with LED positioning lamps, LED tail lights, and a wider grille. In Japan, the Rush was exclusive to Toyopet dealerships and was discontinued in March 2016, succeeded by the Rocky/Raize crossover in November 2019. Production continued in other markets until 2017, with strong sales in Indonesia, Malaysia, South Africa, and various developing markets.
Toyota-Rush.name: First Generation (J200/F700)

Toyota-Rush.description: The second-generation Toyota Rush was unveiled alongside the Daihatsu Terios in Indonesia on 23 November 2017, with sales commencing on 3 January 2018. Unlike its predecessor, this generation is offered exclusively in long-wheelbase configuration with no short-wheelbase or four-wheel drive options. The design transitioned to a more crossover-like appearance with streamlined styling influenced by the FT Concept, featuring a rear liftgate instead of the traditional side-opening door and eliminating the externally mounted spare tire. Model codes are F800 for the international market Rush/Terios and F850 for the Malaysian market version. Power comes from a 1.5-liter four-cylinder engine producing approximately 103 horsepower and 136 Nm of torque, paired with five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmissions, with rear-wheel drive the sole configuration. The interior features modern styling with improved materials and a touchscreen infotainment system on higher trims. Safety features include vehicle stability control, hill-start assist, and up to six airbags. In Indonesia, grades include X, R, and TRD Sportivo (later renamed GR Sport in August 2021). A facelift was launched in June 2023 with updated styling. The Rush continues to target Southeast Asian, Middle Eastern, South African, and Latin American markets where it competes in the compact SUV segment.
Toyota-Rush.name: Second Generation (F800/F850)

Toyota-Sequoia.description: The first-generation Toyota Sequoia was introduced as Toyota's entry into the full-size SUV segment in North America, positioned above the 4Runner and Land Cruiser in size and focused on competing directly with domestic offerings like the Ford Expedition and Chevrolet Tahoe. Based on the same platform as the Tundra pickup truck, the Sequoia featured traditional body-on-frame construction, robust dimensions, and three rows of seating accommodating up to eight passengers. Powered initially by a 4.7-liter V8 engine producing 240 horsepower (later increased to 282 horsepower), paired with a four-speed automatic transmission (later upgraded to five-speed), the Sequoia offered both rear-wheel drive and part-time four-wheel drive configurations with a two-speed transfer case. The exterior featured conservative styling with a prominent grille, squared-off wheel arches, and an overall boxy profile emphasizing its truck-based origins. The interior was spacious and practical, focused on passenger comfort and cargo versatility with split-folding second and third-row seats, though material quality was modest compared to more premium offerings. A mid-cycle refresh in 2005 brought updated styling, enhanced power, the aforementioned five-speed transmission, and additional features including available side curtain airbags, stability control, and a DVD entertainment system. The first-generation Sequoia established Toyota's presence in the lucrative full-size SUV market by offering the brand's reputation for reliability and quality in a larger package capable of towing up to 6,500 pounds while accommodating large families and their cargo, though it faced challenges competing with more established domestic competitors that offered greater power, towing capacity, and feature content.
Toyota-Sequoia.name: First Generation (XK30/XK40)

Toyota-Sequoia.description: The second-generation Toyota Sequoia grew significantly larger than its predecessor, featuring more aggressive styling with a massive front grille, pronounced fender flares, and an imposing overall presence. Based on an enhanced version of the second-generation Tundra pickup platform, the new Sequoia offered improved passenger space across all three rows and increased cargo capacity. Powered initially by a 4.7-liter V8 engine, and shortly thereafter by a more modern 5.7-liter V8 producing 381 horsepower and 401 lb-ft of torque, paired with a six-speed automatic transmission, the Sequoia delivered stronger performance and increased towing capacity of up to 7,400 pounds. Available in rear-wheel drive or part-time four-wheel drive configurations, with a multi-mode system on higher trim levels adding a full-time all-wheel drive option, the Sequoia maintained its focus on utility while adding more sophisticated features. The interior offered significant improvements in design, material quality, and technology, with available features including a power-folding third row, navigation system, premium JBL audio, and rear entertainment system. Safety features expanded to include multiple airbags, stability control, and traction control as standard equipment. A notable engineering advancement was the adoption of an independent rear suspension replacing the previous solid axle, significantly improving ride quality and interior packaging. The Sequoia received periodic updates throughout its unusually long production run, including enhanced infotainment systems, additional safety features like blind-spot monitoring, and special editions such as the TRD Sport and TRD Pro offering unique styling and enhanced off-road capability. Despite its age in later years, the second-generation Sequoia maintained appeal through its combination of robust capability, massive interior space, proven reliability, and strong resale value, particularly for buyers prioritizing durability and utility over the latest features and technology.
Toyota-Sequoia.name: Second Generation (XK60)

Toyota-Sequoia.description: The third-generation Toyota Sequoia represents a comprehensive redesign of Toyota's largest SUV, featuring bold, blocky styling with a massive front grille, muscular fender flares, and an upright, imposing presence. Built on Toyota's new TNGA-F body-on-frame platform shared with the latest Tundra pickup and global Land Cruiser, the new Sequoia maintains similar exterior dimensions to its predecessor but with significantly improved interior packaging, technology, and efficiency. The most dramatic change is the powertrain, with the previous V8 engine replaced by a standard hybrid system combining a 3.5-liter twin-turbocharged V6 engine with an electric motor integrated into the transmission (branded as i-FORCE MAX), producing a combined 437 horsepower and 583 lb-ft of torque—substantial increases over the outgoing model. This powertrain is paired with a 10-speed automatic transmission and either rear-wheel drive or part-time four-wheel drive with a two-speed transfer case. The hybrid system delivers significantly improved fuel economy while enhancing performance and capability, with towing capacity increasing to 9,520 pounds when properly equipped. The interior features a complete redesign with a more horizontal dashboard layout, standard 8-inch or available 14-inch touchscreen infotainment system, digital driver's display, and significantly improved materials throughout. A sliding second-row seat and improved third-row accommodations enhance passenger comfort, while a new feature allows the third row to slide fore and aft to balance passenger and cargo space as needed. Available in multiple trim levels ranging from the more basic SR5 to the luxury-oriented Capstone with semi-aniline leather and open-pore wood trim, the Sequoia offers configurations to suit various preferences and budgets. The TRD Pro variant continues as the off-road flagship with FOX internal bypass shocks, a front skid plate, all-terrain tires, and unique styling elements. Standard safety technology is comprehensive with Toyota Safety Sense 2.5 offering pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, dynamic radar cruise control, lane tracing assist, and automatic high beams. The third-generation Sequoia successfully modernizes Toyota's largest SUV with improved efficiency, technology, and capability while maintaining the robust, utility-focused character that has defined the nameplate.
Toyota-Sequoia.name: Third Generation (XK80)

Toyota-Sienna.description: The first-generation Toyota Sienna was introduced as Toyota's entry into the North American minivan market, replacing the underperforming Previa with a more conventional front-wheel drive design better aligned with market preferences. Based on an extended version of the Camry platform, the original Sienna featured conservative, rounded styling with a focus on practicality rather than visual excitement. Available in three trim levels (CE, LE, and XLE), the Sienna offered seating for seven passengers across three rows, with the third row capable of folding flat into the floor—an innovative feature at the time. Powered by a 3.0-liter V6 engine producing 194 horsepower paired with a four-speed automatic transmission, the Sienna delivered adequate performance for family hauling duties while achieving reasonable fuel economy for its class. The interior emphasized practicality with numerous storage compartments, cup holders, and convenience features, though material quality varied significantly between base and higher trim levels. Safety was a priority with standard dual front airbags and available side airbags—advanced features for minivans of this era. A mid-cycle refresh in 2001 brought minor styling updates, additional convenience features, and a slightly more powerful engine. The first-generation Sienna established Toyota in the competitive North American minivan segment by offering the brand's reputation for reliability and quality in a practical family vehicle format, though with more conservative design and slightly smaller dimensions than class leaders like the Honda Odyssey and Chrysler minivans.
Toyota-Sienna.name: First Generation (XL10)

Toyota-Sienna.description: The second-generation Toyota Sienna represented a significant advancement over its predecessor, growing substantially in size to compete more directly with segment leaders. The exterior featured more distinctive styling with a prominent grille, sculpted sides, and an overall more substantial presence, while the interior volume expanded to accommodate up to eight passengers with the optional second-row center seat. A key innovation was the introduction of available all-wheel drive—a first for a Toyota minivan and rare in the segment—though with the tradeoff of eliminating the spare tire well and fold-flat third-row capability in AWD models. Powered by a 3.3-liter V6 (later upgraded to 3.5-liter) producing up to 266 horsepower paired with a five-speed automatic transmission, the Sienna offered strong performance for its class. The interior saw significant improvements in both design and material quality, with available luxury features including dual power sliding doors, a power liftgate, tri-zone climate control, and a rear entertainment system. Practical innovations included a split-and-stow third-row seat that folded flat into the floor in front-wheel drive models, second-row seats that could be positioned together or apart, and numerous storage compartments throughout the cabin. Safety features expanded to include standard stability control, traction control, anti-lock brakes, and available side curtain airbags for all three rows. The second-generation Sienna successfully elevated Toyota's position in the minivan segment by offering a compelling combination of space, versatility, safety, and reliability, with the option of all-wheel drive providing a notable advantage over many competitors, particularly in regions with severe winter weather.
Toyota-Sienna.name: Second Generation (XL20)

Toyota-Sienna.description: The third-generation Toyota Sienna featured more expressive styling with a prominent front grille, distinctive character lines, and a more aggressive overall appearance compared to its predecessors. Continuing on an enhanced version of the previous platform, the new Sienna maintained its generous dimensions while improving aerodynamics and interior packaging. Powered by a refined 3.5-liter V6 engine initially producing 266 horsepower (later updated to 296 horsepower with the addition of direct injection), paired with a six-speed automatic transmission (later eight-speed), the Sienna offered competitive performance while maintaining the segment-exclusive option of all-wheel drive. The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and features, with an available dual moonroof, premium JBL audio system, and lounge-style second-row seats with extendable footrests on higher trim levels. Practical innovations included a widescreen rear entertainment system that could display two different sources simultaneously, Driver Easy Speak (using the microphone to amplify the driver's voice to rear passengers), and an expanding array of USB ports and power outlets throughout the cabin. A sporty SE trim with unique styling, 19-inch wheels, and sport-tuned suspension offered a more dynamic appearance and driving experience unusual for the minivan segment. Safety technology expanded throughout the generation's lifecycle, eventually including the Toyota Safety Sense suite with pre-collision system, lane departure alert, and adaptive cruise control as standard equipment. A significant refresh in 2018 brought updated styling, improved infotainment with Apple CarPlay (and later Android Auto), and additional convenience features. The third-generation Sienna successfully balanced practical family transportation with increased style, comfort, and technology, maintaining Toyota's strong position in the shrinking but still significant minivan market as many competitors exited the segment.
Toyota-Sienna.name: Third Generation (XL30)

Toyota-Sienna.description: The fourth-generation Toyota Sienna represents the most dramatic reinvention in the model's history, transitioning to a hybrid-only powertrain while featuring bold, SUV-inspired styling with a massive front grille, muscular wheel arches, and distinctive side character lines creating a far more adventurous appearance than traditional minivans. Built on Toyota's TNGA-K platform shared with vehicles like the Highlander and Camry, the new Sienna prioritizes efficiency alongside practical family transportation. The exclusive powertrain combines a 2.5-liter four-cylinder gasoline engine with electric motors for a combined 245 horsepower, paired with an electronically controlled continuously variable transmission (eCVT). While this represents less power than the previous V6, the hybrid system delivers substantially improved fuel economy of 36 mpg combined in front-wheel drive models—a nearly 50% increase over the previous generation. All-wheel drive remains available through the addition of a third electric motor powering the rear wheels. The interior features a bridge console design with raised center section, creating a more car-like driving position while maintaining minivan practicality with available features including built-in vacuum cleaner, refrigerator, digital rearview mirror, and a rear entertainment system. The sliding second-row captain's chairs in higher trims feature an extraordinary 25 inches of travel to maximize legroom or cargo flexibility, though they cannot be removed entirely. Available in multiple trim levels from the basic LE to the luxury-oriented Platinum to the more rugged Woodland Edition with increased ground clearance, the Sienna offers configurations to suit various preferences. Standard safety technology is comprehensive with Toyota Safety Sense 2.0 offering pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, full-speed dynamic radar cruise control, lane departure alert with steering assist, and automatic high beams. The fourth-generation Sienna boldly reimagines the minivan formula with its standard hybrid powertrain, SUV-inspired styling, and continued practicality innovations, aiming to maintain relevance in a market increasingly dominated by crossovers and SUVs while delivering significant efficiency improvements that benefit both family budgets and environmental impact.
Toyota-Sienna.name: Fourth Generation (XL40)

Toyota-Sienna-Hybrid.description: The Toyota Sienna Hybrid represents Toyota's comprehensive approach to electrification by making a hybrid powertrain standard across the entire fourth-generation Sienna lineup, rather than offering it as a separate variant like many other models. Built on Toyota's TNGA-GA-K platform, the Sienna Hybrid features the same bold, SUV-inspired styling as all fourth-generation Siennas, with a massive front grille, muscular wheel arches, and distinctive side character lines creating a far more adventurous appearance than traditional minivans. The hybrid powertrain combines a 2.5-liter four-cylinder gasoline engine with electric motors for a combined 245 horsepower, paired with an electronically controlled continuously variable transmission (eCVT). While this represents less power than the previous generation's V6, the hybrid system delivers substantially improved fuel economy of 36 mpg combined in front-wheel drive models—a nearly 50% increase over the previous generation and exceptional for a vehicle of this size and capacity. The hybrid system uses a nickel-metal hydride battery positioned under the front seats to avoid intrusion into passenger or cargo space. All-wheel drive is available through the addition of a third electric motor powering the rear wheels, reducing combined fuel economy only slightly to 35 mpg. The interior features a bridge console design with raised center section, creating a more car-like driving position while maintaining minivan practicality with available features including built-in vacuum cleaner, refrigerator, digital rearview mirror, and a rear entertainment system. The sliding second-row captain's chairs in higher trims feature an extraordinary 25 inches of travel to maximize legroom or cargo flexibility. Available in multiple trim levels from the basic LE to the luxury-oriented Platinum to the more rugged Woodland Edition with increased ground clearance, the Sienna Hybrid offers configurations to suit various preferences while delivering class-leading fuel efficiency and standard hybrid capability across the entire lineup.
Toyota-Sienna-Hybrid.name: First Generation (XL40)

Toyota-Supra.description: The first-generation Toyota Supra began as a premium variant of the Celica, known as the Celica Supra or Celica XX in some markets, featuring distinctive styling with quad headlights, a longer wheelbase to accommodate the inline-six engine, and more luxurious features. Powered by a 2.6-liter (later 2.8-liter) inline-six engine producing approximately 110-116 horsepower depending on market and model year, the original Supra positioned itself as a comfortable grand tourer rather than an outright sports car. Available with either a five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmission driving the rear wheels, the Supra offered modest performance but with more refinement than the standard Celica. The interior featured a driver-oriented dashboard with a comprehensive gauge package, and equipment levels were upscale for the era with available leather upholstery, power windows, and air conditioning. This generation established the Supra nameplate (derived from the Latin prefix meaning 'above' or 'beyond') and its initial positioning as a premium sports coupe, though it remained closely tied to its Celica origins while adding the straight-six engine configuration that would become a defining characteristic of subsequent Supra generations.
Toyota-Supra.name: First Generation (A40/A50)

Toyota-Supra.description: The second-generation Toyota Supra continued as a derivative of the Celica but with more distinctive styling, featuring angular lines, pop-up headlights, and a more aggressive overall appearance reflecting automotive design trends of the early 1980s. Still marketed as the Celica Supra in many regions, this generation further distinguished itself from the standard Celica with a longer wheelbase, wider track, and more comprehensive performance enhancements. Powered by a 2.8-liter inline-six engine (5M-GE) with dual overhead cams, producing approximately 145-175 horsepower depending on market and model year, paired with either a five-speed manual or four-speed automatic transmission, the second-generation Supra offered improved performance while maintaining its grand touring character. The introduction of independent rear suspension improved handling significantly over its predecessor, while four-wheel disc brakes provided enhanced stopping power. The interior featured a more driver-focused design with deeply bolstered seats, a comprehensive gauge cluster, and available luxury features including leather upholstery, power windows, and an upgraded audio system. Later models offered a Performance Package with sport suspension, limited-slip differential, and wider tires. This generation began shifting the Supra's positioning more toward performance while maintaining premium features, establishing it as Toyota's flagship sports coupe and laying the groundwork for its eventual evolution into a dedicated high-performance vehicle separate from the Celica.
Toyota-Supra.name: Second Generation (A60)

Toyota-Supra.description: The third-generation Toyota Supra marked a significant evolution, separating completely from the Celica to become a distinct model on its own platform, signifying its elevated status in Toyota's lineup. Featuring more rounded, contemporary styling with a prominent rear spoiler on Turbo models, pop-up headlights, and wider, more aggressive proportions, this generation embraced the performance focus that would come to define the nameplate. Engine options varied by market but were centered around the 3.0-liter inline-six in naturally aspirated (7M-GE) and, most significantly, turbocharged (7M-GTE) forms, the latter producing up to 232 horsepower—a substantial figure for the era. Transmission options included a five-speed manual, optional six-speed manual on later models, or four-speed automatic. The chassis featured double-wishbone suspension at all four corners, providing a sophisticated foundation for impressive handling capabilities, while innovations like available electronically controlled shock absorbers (TEMS) showcased Toyota's investment in performance technology. The interior continued the driver-focused theme with a wraparound cockpit design, comprehensive gauges including a boost meter on Turbo models, and available luxury features such as power-adjustable seats, leather upholstery, and a premium sound system. This generation firmly established the Supra as a serious performance car capable of competing with more expensive European and American sports coupes, particularly in turbocharged form, while maintaining reasonable practicality as a daily driver. The A70 Supra developed a strong following among performance enthusiasts, particularly for its robust engine design that proved highly receptive to aftermarket modifications and tuning.
Toyota-Supra.name: Third Generation (A70)

Toyota-Supra.description: The fourth-generation Toyota Supra represents the pinnacle of the nameplate's original run, featuring radical styling with a rounded, organic form, distinctive circular taillights, and an optional large rear wing that created one of the most recognizable sports car silhouettes of the 1990s. Significantly lighter than its predecessor through extensive use of aluminum and reduced equipment in certain models, this Supra prioritized performance above all else. Powered by the legendary 3.0-liter 2JZ inline-six engine in naturally aspirated (2JZ-GE, 220 horsepower) or twin-turbocharged (2JZ-GTE, 276 horsepower in Japan, 320 horsepower in export markets) forms, the latter featuring sequential turbochargers to virtually eliminate lag, paired with either a six-speed manual (Turbo only) or four-speed automatic transmission. The sophisticated chassis utilized double-wishbone suspension at all four corners, large brakes, and variable power steering, creating exceptional handling capabilities that could challenge much more expensive sports cars. The interior focused on the driver with a wraparound cockpit design, excellent ergonomics, and a relatively simple layout emphasizing function over luxury. This generation achieved legendary status for its extraordinary performance potential, with the twin-turbocharged variant in particular demonstrating exceptional durability and capacity for aftermarket modifications, with many examples reliably producing double or triple the factory horsepower rating with appropriate upgrades. The A80 Supra was discontinued in most markets by 1998 due to declining sales of sports cars, tightening emissions regulations, and rising production costs, though production continued for the Japanese market until 2002. Its cultural impact was amplified through prominent appearances in movies, video games, and racing series, maintaining enthusiast interest during the two decades between its discontinuation and eventual revival, with well-preserved examples commanding extraordinary prices on the collector market.
Toyota-Supra.name: Fourth Generation (A80)

Toyota-Supra.description: The fifth-generation Toyota Supra marks the revival of the iconic nameplate after a 17-year hiatus, developed as part of a joint venture with BMW that also produced the Z4 roadster. Designed with input from Toyota's Gazoo Racing motorsport division (hence the 'GR' prefix used in some markets), the new Supra features dramatic styling with a double-bubble roof, prominent front fenders, integrated ducktail rear spoiler, and numerous functional air vents and aerodynamic elements that create a distinctive appearance while honoring the heritage of previous generations, particularly the fourth-generation A80. The underlying chassis and powertrain are largely BMW-sourced, with the Supra initially launching with a 3.0-liter turbocharged inline-six engine (maintaining the straight-six tradition) producing 335 horsepower and 365 lb-ft of torque (later increased to 382 horsepower and 368 lb-ft for 2021), paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission driving the rear wheels. In 2021, a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine option was added to the lineup, producing 255 horsepower and 295 lb-ft of torque. After considerable enthusiast demand, a six-speed manual transmission became available for the six-cylinder model in 2023. Performance is impressive with the six-cylinder achieving 0-60 mph in approximately 3.9 seconds (later 3.8 with the power increase). The chassis features adaptive variable suspension, an electronically controlled limited-slip differential, and a near-perfect 50:50 weight distribution. The two-seat interior combines BMW switchgear and infotainment with Toyota-specific instrumentation and trim, featuring a driver-focused cockpit design with high-quality materials. Special editions have included the Launch Edition, A91 Edition, and various market-specific special models offering unique colors and equipment. While the BMW collaboration generated some controversy among purists, the fifth-generation Supra has generally received acclaim for its engaging handling, strong performance, and striking design, successfully reviving one of Toyota's most storied performance nameplates while providing a modern interpretation of the front-engine, rear-wheel drive sports car formula.
Toyota-Supra.name: Fifth Generation (A90)

Toyota-Tacoma.description: The first-generation Toyota Tacoma was introduced as Toyota's compact pickup truck for North America, replacing the previous Toyota Pickup (Hilux in other markets) with a design more specifically tailored to American preferences. Available in regular cab, extended cab (Xtracab), and eventually crew cab (DoubleCab) configurations, the original Tacoma featured more car-like comfort, handling, and safety features than its more utilitarian predecessor. Engine options included a 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 2.7-liter four-cylinder, and a 3.4-liter V6, paired with manual or automatic transmissions and either rear-wheel drive or part-time four-wheel drive with a two-speed transfer case. The interior offered improved comfort and features compared to previous Toyota trucks, though still maintaining a relatively utilitarian character with durable materials. Specialized variants included the PreRunner offering the styling and stance of a four-wheel drive model with rear-wheel drive mechanicals, and the off-road oriented TRD packages featuring upgraded suspension, tires, and appearance elements. Safety features expanded during this generation to include driver and passenger airbags and ABS. This generation established the Tacoma as a leader in the compact truck segment (later reclassified as midsize), known for its reliability, off-road capability, and strong resale value—attributes that would define the nameplate through subsequent generations. The first-generation Tacoma struck a successful balance between the rugged durability expected of a pickup truck and the more civilized driving experience increasingly demanded by American consumers using trucks as daily transportation.
Toyota-Tacoma.name: First Generation (N140/N150/N160/N170)

Toyota-Tacoma.description: The second-generation Toyota Tacoma grew significantly larger than its predecessor, reflecting the general market trend toward bigger vehicles and the reclassification of this segment from compact to midsize trucks. Available in regular cab, access cab (extended), and double cab (crew) configurations with both short and long bed options, this generation featured more aggressive styling with a prominent grille, flared fenders, and an overall more substantial presence. Engine options included a 2.7-liter four-cylinder and a 4.0-liter V6 producing 236 horsepower, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. The interior saw improvements in design, material quality, and features, including available touchscreen navigation, premium audio, and enhanced comfort options, though maintaining a relatively utilitarian character appropriate for a work vehicle. Off-road capability remained a priority with multiple four-wheel drive system options, including the advanced TRD Off-Road and TRD Pro packages featuring specialized suspension, all-terrain tires, locking rear differential, and terrain-specific driving modes. Safety features expanded to include side and curtain airbags, stability control, and traction control. A notable innovation was the Composite-Reinforced Cargo Bed made of fiber-reinforced Sheet-Molded Composite (SMC) on the inner bed walls and floor, providing enhanced durability and corrosion resistance while reducing weight. A minor refresh in 2012 brought updated styling with a revised grille and headlights. This generation further cemented the Tacoma's reputation for reliability, capability, and exceptional resale value, helping it dominate the midsize truck segment in North America despite relatively few updates over its extended production run, as most competitors temporarily withdrew from the segment during this period.
Toyota-Tacoma.name: Second Generation (N220/N240/N250/N260/N270)

Toyota-Tacoma.description: The third-generation Toyota Tacoma featured more aggressive, angular styling with a bold hexagonal grille, muscular fender flares, and a higher hood line, maintaining its rugged identity while adopting more modern design elements. Available exclusively in access cab and double cab configurations (the regular cab was discontinued), with short and long bed options, this generation continued to target both work and recreational users. Engine options included a 2.7-liter four-cylinder and a more advanced 3.5-liter V6 with direct and port injection producing 278 horsepower, paired with six-speed manual or automatic transmissions. The interior saw significant improvements in design, material quality, and technology, featuring a standard GoPro mount on the windshield (reflecting the active lifestyle focus of many owners), touchscreen infotainment system with smartphone integration, and improved ergonomics, though maintaining a purposeful, function-oriented character. Off-road capability remained a key selling point with the TRD Off-Road and flagship TRD Pro models offering specialized suspensions, terrain management systems, and enhanced underbody protection. The composite bed continued as a distinctive feature, with the addition of a 120V outlet and adjustable tie-down cleats in many models. Safety technology expanded dramatically with the Toyota Safety Sense P suite becoming standard across the range in 2018, offering pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, lane departure alert, automatic high beams, and dynamic radar cruise control—advanced features for the midsize truck segment at the time. Throughout its production run, this generation received periodic updates including enhanced infotainment with Apple CarPlay, Android Auto and Amazon Alexa capability, additional special editions including the Trail and Nightshade variants, and revised color and package options. The third-generation Tacoma maintained the model's dominance in the revitalized midsize truck segment despite strong new competition, continuing to attract buyers with its proven reliability, exceptional off-road capability, strong resale value, and balanced approach to combining work utility with lifestyle-oriented features.
Toyota-Tacoma.name: Third Generation (N300)

Toyota-Tacoma.description: The fourth-generation Toyota Tacoma represents the most comprehensive redesign in the model's history, built on Toyota's TNGA-F platform shared with the full-size Tundra and global Land Cruiser series. Available in extended cab and crew cab configurations with multiple bed lengths, the new Tacoma features evolutionary styling that maintains its muscular, off-road ready appearance while incorporating more modern elements including C-shaped LED signature lighting, a larger grille, and more pronounced fender bulges. A significant engineering change is the transition from leaf springs to a coil spring rear suspension across all models, providing improved ride quality and handling without compromising capability. Powertrain options include a new 2.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder in multiple states of tune, from 228 horsepower in base models to 278 horsepower in mid-grade variants, while the higher-end configurations feature a hybrid-assisted i-FORCE MAX version producing 326 horsepower and 465 lb-ft of torque—the most powerful Tacoma ever offered. Transmission options include an eight-speed automatic or six-speed manual in certain trims, maintaining an option increasingly rare in modern trucks. The interior represents a dramatic improvement with higher quality materials, more sophisticated design, and significantly enhanced technology including a standard 8-inch or available 14-inch touchscreen infotainment system, digital gauge cluster, and wireless smartphone integration. Off-road capability remains a core focus with up to seven distinct off-road focused grades including the Trail, TRD Off-Road, TRD Pro, and new Trailhunter, the latter developed specifically for overlanding enthusiasts with factory-installed features like high-performance Fox internal bypass shocks, a high-mounted air intake, and integrated recovery points. Safety technology is comprehensive with Toyota Safety Sense 3.0 standard across all trims, offering pre-collision system with motorcycle detection, dynamic radar cruise control, lane departure alert, and proactive driving assist. The fourth-generation Tacoma aims to maintain the model's leadership in the midsize truck segment by significantly improving refinement, technology, and efficiency while preserving the reliability, durability, and off-road capability that has defined the nameplate.
Toyota-Tacoma.name: Fourth Generation (N400)

Toyota-Tundra.description: The first-generation Toyota Tundra marked Toyota's entry into the full-size pickup truck segment in North America, though with dimensions slightly smaller than domestic competitors, positioning it initially as an 'almost full-size' offering. Available in regular and extended cab (Access Cab) configurations with multiple bed lengths, the original Tundra featured relatively conservative styling that didn't stray far from established pickup truck design conventions. Engine options included a 3.4-liter V6 (later a 4.0-liter) and a 4.7-liter V8 producing 245 horsepower, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. The interior focused on durability and practicality, with straightforward controls and relatively modest materials even in higher trim levels. Four-wheel drive models featured a part-time system with a two-speed transfer case, providing reasonable off-road capability though not specifically focused on extreme terrain. A notable milestone occurred in 2003 when Toyota began producing the Tundra in a new plant in San Antonio, Texas—a strategic move to strengthen the truck's American credentials. This generation established Toyota in the full-size truck market, capitalizing on the brand's reputation for reliability and quality while laying the groundwork for its future expansion in this lucrative segment, though it struggled to capture significant market share from established domestic competitors due to its somewhat undersized proportions and lower towing and payload capacities.
Toyota-Tundra.name: First Generation (XK30/XK40)

Toyota-Tundra.description: The second-generation Toyota Tundra represented Toyota's full commitment to the traditional full-size truck segment, growing substantially in size, capability, and power to compete directly with domestic offerings from Ford, Chevrolet, and Ram. Available in regular cab, double cab, and CrewMax configurations with multiple bed lengths, this generation featured bold, imposing styling with a massive grille, pronounced fender flares, and an overall more substantial presence clearly targeting American truck buyers' preferences. Engine options initially included a 4.0-liter V6, 4.7-liter V8, and a new 5.7-liter V8 producing 381 horsepower and 401 lb-ft of torque, the latter providing competitive performance and towing capacity of up to 10,400 pounds when properly equipped. Transmission options centered around a five-speed automatic for smaller engines and a six-speed automatic for the 5.7-liter. The interior saw significant improvements in design, space, and material quality, particularly in higher trim levels like the luxurious Platinum and 1794 Edition (named after the founding date of the ranch where the San Antonio plant was built), which offered premium leather, wood trim, and enhanced technology features. Off-road capability was addressed with the TRD Off-Road package and later the more comprehensive TRD Pro model featuring specialized suspension, all-terrain tires, and unique styling elements. Safety features expanded throughout the long production run, eventually including the Toyota Safety Sense-P suite with pre-collision system, lane departure alert, automatic high beams, and dynamic radar cruise control. Despite receiving relatively modest updates over its 14-year production run—a remarkably long lifecycle for a modern vehicle—the second-generation Tundra maintained respectable sales through its reputation for exceptional reliability and durability, with many examples surpassing 250,000 miles with minimal issues. This generation established the Tundra as a legitimate, full-size competitor in the truck market, though it never approached the sales volumes of the dominant domestic players.
Toyota-Tundra.name: Second Generation (XK50)

Toyota-Tundra.description: The third-generation Toyota Tundra represents a comprehensive redesign, featuring bold, highly angular styling with an enormous grille, squared-off wheel arches, and an overall more assertive presence than its predecessor. Built on Toyota's new TNGA-F body-on-frame platform shared with the latest Land Cruiser and Lexus LX, the new Tundra adopts a coil spring rear suspension replacing the previous leaf springs—a significant change improving ride quality and handling while maintaining competitive payload and towing capabilities. Available in extended cab (Double Cab) and crew cab (CrewMax) configurations with multiple bed lengths, the third-generation Tundra notably eliminates the regular cab option, reflecting shifting market preferences. The most dramatic change is the powertrain lineup, with the previously offered V8 engines replaced by a standard 3.5-liter twin-turbocharged V6 (branded as i-FORCE) producing 389 horsepower and 479 lb-ft of torque, and an optional hybrid variant (i-FORCE MAX) adding an electric motor integrated into the transmission for a combined 437 horsepower and 583 lb-ft of torque. Both engines pair with a 10-speed automatic transmission, with rear-wheel drive standard and part-time four-wheel drive optional. Towing capacity reaches up to 12,000 pounds when properly equipped, while payload capacity tops out at 1,940 pounds. The interior features a complete redesign with a horizontally oriented dashboard, standard 8-inch or available 14-inch touchscreen infotainment system, and significantly improved materials throughout. Available in multiple trim levels ranging from the work-oriented SR to the luxury-focused Platinum and 1794 Edition to the off-road-capable TRD Pro, the Tundra offers configurations to suit various preferences and requirements. Technology includes an available 360-degree camera system, wireless Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, and a virtual display rearview mirror. Standard safety features are comprehensive with Toyota Safety Sense 2.5 offering pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, dynamic radar cruise control, lane tracing assist, and automatic high beams. The third-generation Tundra aims to combine the legendary reliability that defined its predecessor with significantly improved refinement, technology, and efficiency while maintaining competitive capability in the fiercely contested full-size truck segment.
Toyota-Tundra.name: Third Generation (XK70)

Toyota-Venza.description: The first-generation Toyota Venza was introduced as a mid-size crossover wagon targeting the North American market, positioned between the RAV4 and Highlander in Toyota's lineup. Based on the Camry platform but with unique styling and higher ride height, the Venza featured a distinctive design with a sleek roofline, prominent grille, and substantial proportions that blended elements of both wagon and SUV. Available with either a 2.7-liter four-cylinder engine producing 182 horsepower or a 3.5-liter V6 generating 268 horsepower, both paired with a six-speed automatic transmission and either front-wheel drive or all-wheel drive, the Venza prioritized on-road comfort over off-road capability. The five-passenger interior emphasized space and practicality with a wide center console, generous cargo capacity of up to 70.2 cubic feet with rear seats folded, and a focus on versatility for active lifestyles. Feature content was relatively generous even on base models, with higher trims offering leather upholstery, panoramic glass roof, power liftgate, and advanced infotainment options. A minor refresh in 2012 brought updated styling elements and enhanced technology features. The first-generation Venza represented Toyota's attempt to create a segment-blending vehicle appealing to buyers seeking the practicality of an SUV with the driving dynamics and efficiency of a car, though it struggled to establish a clear identity in the marketplace amidst increasing competition from more conventional crossovers. Production ended for the U.S. market in 2015 as Toyota reorganized its crossover lineup, leaving a five-year gap before the nameplate would be revived.
Toyota-Venza.name: First Generation (AV10)

Toyota-Venza.description: The second-generation Toyota Venza was reintroduced after a five-year hiatus, now as a distinctly more upscale, style-focused crossover SUV based on the Japanese-market Harrier. Built on Toyota's TNGA-K platform shared with vehicles like the RAV4 and Camry, the new Venza features elegant, almost Lexus-like styling with a sleek silhouette, tapered roofline, and sophisticated design details creating a more premium appearance than most Toyota crossovers. Available exclusively with a hybrid powertrain combining a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine with three electric motors (one serving as a starter/generator, one driving the front wheels, and one driving the rear wheels) for a combined 219 horsepower, the Venza delivers an impressive 40 mpg combined fuel economy while providing standard electronic all-wheel drive through its dedicated rear electric motor. The five-passenger interior emphasizes premium materials and technology, with standard features including an 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system (12.3-inch available), multi-zone climate control, and power-adjustable front seats, while higher trims offer a unique Star Gaze electrochromic glass roof that can switch between transparent and frosted states. Safety technology is comprehensive with Toyota Safety Sense 2.0 standard across all trim levels, providing features like pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, full-speed dynamic radar cruise control, lane departure alert with steering assist, and automatic high beams. Cargo capacity is modest for the segment at 28.8 cubic feet behind the rear seats, reflecting the Venza's focus on style over maximum utility. The second-generation Venza occupies a specific niche in Toyota's lineup as a more premium, efficiency-focused alternative to the more utilitarian RAV4, appealing to buyers seeking upscale design and technology in a mid-size crossover package without stepping up to the luxury-branded Lexus RX.
Toyota-Venza.name: Second Generation (XU80)

Toyota-Venza-Hybrid.description: The Toyota Venza Hybrid represents the second-generation Venza, which unlike its predecessor is offered exclusively with a hybrid powertrain, making the Venza Hybrid designation somewhat redundant but reflective of Toyota's hybrid-centric strategy for this model. Based on the Japanese-market Harrier and built on Toyota's TNGA-K platform, the Venza Hybrid features sophisticated styling with a coupe-like roofline, smooth body surfaces, and premium design elements creating an upscale appearance that bridges the gap between mainstream Toyota and luxury Lexus offerings. The hybrid powertrain combines a 2.5-liter four-cylinder Atkinson-cycle engine with three electric motors—one serving as a starter/generator, one driving the front wheels, and one driving the rear wheels—producing a combined 219 horsepower while delivering an impressive 40 mpg combined in EPA testing. The Electronic On-Demand AWD system provides all-wheel drive capability through the dedicated rear electric motor, enhancing both all-weather traction and efficiency by engaging the rear wheels only when needed. The nickel-metal hydride battery is positioned under the rear seats to minimize intrusion into passenger and cargo space. The interior emphasizes premium appointments with standard features including power-adjustable front seats, soft-touch materials throughout, and an 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system (12.3-inch available), while higher trims offer heated and ventilated front seats, a digital rearview mirror, and the innovative Star Gaze electrochromic glass roof that can switch between transparent and frosted modes at the touch of a button. Safety technology is comprehensive with Toyota Safety Sense 2.0 standard across all trim levels, including pre-collision system with pedestrian detection, full-speed dynamic radar cruise control, lane departure alert with steering assist, and automatic high beams. Available in LE, XLE, and Limited trim levels, the Venza Hybrid offers varying levels of luxury and technology while maintaining the same efficient powertrain across the lineup. The Venza Hybrid successfully carves out a specific niche in Toyota's crossover portfolio as a more premium, efficiency-focused alternative to the RAV4 Hybrid, appealing to buyers seeking upscale design and comfort features combined with the proven reliability and efficiency of Toyota's hybrid technology.
Toyota-Venza-Hybrid.name: First Generation (XU80)

Toyota-Yaris.description: The first-generation Toyota Yaris (marketed as the Echo in North America and the Vitz in Japan) was introduced as Toyota's new global subcompact car, replacing the Tercel/Starlet in various markets. Featuring distinctive, somewhat polarizing styling with a tall, rounded profile maximizing interior space within minimal exterior dimensions, the original Yaris established a design philosophy prioritizing interior packaging efficiency. Available in three-door and five-door hatchback configurations plus a sedan variant (primarily for North America), the Yaris was powered by a range of small-displacement engines including 1.0, 1.3, and 1.5-liter units, paired with either manual or automatic transmissions. The interior featured an unconventional center-mounted instrument cluster and surprisingly spacious accommodations given the compact exterior, with clever storage solutions and flexible seating arrangements. Safety features were relatively advanced for the segment and era, with available ABS and multiple airbags. This generation successfully established the Yaris/Echo/Vitz as Toyota's entry-level global offering, appealing to buyers seeking efficiency, value, and Toyota's reputation for reliability in a compact package, though the North American Echo variant faced criticism for its unconventional styling and sparse standard equipment.
Toyota-Yaris.name: First Generation (XP10)

Toyota-Yaris.description: The second-generation Toyota Yaris featured more conventional, mainstream styling compared to its somewhat quirky predecessor, with smoother lines and a more substantial appearance while maintaining compact dimensions suitable for urban environments. Available in three-door and five-door hatchback configurations in most markets, with a sedan variant in some regions (particularly North America), this generation grew slightly in all dimensions, offering improved interior space and comfort. Engine options varied by market but typically included 1.0, 1.3, and 1.5-liter gasoline units, with diesel options available in some regions, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. The interior design was more conventional than the previous generation, relocating the instruments from the center to a traditional position in front of the driver in most markets, while improving material quality and feature content. Safety advanced with standard stability control in many markets and up to nine airbags available in some configurations. This generation successfully refined the Yaris formula with more mature styling and enhanced refinement while maintaining the model's focus on efficiency, reliability, and value, broadening its appeal beyond first-time buyers to include a wider range of consumers seeking a practical, economical small car.
Toyota-Yaris.name: Second Generation (XP90)

Toyota-Yaris.description: The third-generation Toyota Yaris continued the model's evolution with more dynamic styling featuring sharp character lines, a prominent trapezoidal grille, and a more aggressive overall appearance. Available primarily as a three-door and five-door hatchback (with the sedan discontinued in many markets), this generation maintained similar exterior dimensions to its predecessor while offering improved interior packaging and enhanced safety features. Engine options varied significantly by market but typically included 1.0, 1.3, and 1.5-liter gasoline units and a 1.4-liter diesel in some regions, with hybrid variants introduced for the first time in select markets, combining a 1.5-liter engine with an electric motor for improved efficiency. Transmission options included manual, conventional automatic, and continuously variable transmissions depending on market and engine. The interior saw improvements in design, material quality, and technology, with available features including touchscreen infotainment systems, keyless entry and start, and enhanced connectivity options. Safety technology advanced substantially with Toyota Safety Sense becoming available on higher trim levels in later years, offering features like pre-collision system, lane departure alert, and automatic high beams—advanced technology for the subcompact segment. This generation further established the Yaris as a key player in the global subcompact segment, offering a compelling combination of efficiency, safety, technology, and Toyota's reputation for reliability, though with increasing differentiation between variants sold in different global markets.
Toyota-Yaris.name: Third Generation (XP130)

Toyota-Yaris.description: The fourth-generation Toyota Yaris represents a comprehensive redesign, now based on Toyota's TNGA-B (Toyota New Global Architecture) platform providing improved rigidity, lower center of gravity, and enhanced driving dynamics. Available primarily as a five-door hatchback (with three-door variants largely discontinued), this generation features dynamic styling with a more aggressive front end, muscular wheel arches, and a sporty overall appearance—particularly in the performance-oriented GR Yaris variant. Notably, the North American Yaris became a rebadged Mazda2 in 2016 and was subsequently discontinued entirely in 2020, making this fourth generation primarily relevant to European, Asian, and other global markets. Engine options vary by market but center around an improved 1.5-liter three-cylinder gasoline engine available in both conventional and hybrid forms, the latter now using a lithium-ion battery for reduced weight and improved performance. For the first time, all-wheel drive is available in the GR Yaris performance variant, which features a turbocharged 1.6-liter three-cylinder producing up to 261 horsepower—a radical departure from the Yaris's economy car roots. The interior adopts a more driver-focused design with improved materials, a standard 7-inch or optional 10-inch touchscreen infotainment system, digital instrument cluster on higher trims, and enhanced connectivity options. Safety technology is comprehensive with Toyota Safety Sense standard across most trim levels, offering features including pre-collision system with pedestrian and cyclist detection, adaptive cruise control, lane trace assist, and road sign assist. This generation elevates the Yaris's position in the subcompact segment with significantly improved driving dynamics, sophisticated hybrid technology, comprehensive safety features, and the addition of a genuine performance variant, broadening its appeal beyond the efficiency and value focus of previous generations while maintaining the model's reputation for reliability and practicality.
Toyota-Yaris.name: Fourth Generation (XP210)

Toyota-Yaris-Cross.description: The XP210 series Yaris Cross is Toyota's subcompact crossover based on the TNGA-B platform, sharing its architecture with the fourth-generation Yaris hatchback. Originally unveiled in April 2020 after the Geneva Motor Show cancellation, it went on sale in Japan in August 2020, Australia in November 2020, and Europe in mid-2021. Positioned between the Aygo X/C-HR and above the Raize in Toyota's crossover lineup, it features SUV-inspired styling with increased ground clearance, black wheel arch cladding, and roof rails. The XP210 measures approximately 4.18 meters in length and offers optional all-wheel drive (AWD-i) on hybrid variants—a rare feature in the B-segment SUV class. Powertrains include a 1.5L three-cylinder petrol engine (M15A-FKS) producing 118 hp, and a hybrid system (M15A-FXE) combining the same engine with an electric motor for 116 hp total output.
