Interior features a 7-inch or optional 10.5-inch touchscreen with Apple CarPlay/Android Auto, digital instrument cluster, and Toyota Safety Sense standard across most trims. The vehicle is manufactured in Japan (Toyota Motor East Japan) and France (Toyota Motor Manufacturing France). In November 2023, updates included a new Premiere Edition trim, improved power output to 130 hp, new Toyota Smart Connect multimedia system with 12.3-inch instrument panel, and enhanced safety features.
Toyota-Yaris-Cross.name: First Generation (XP210)

Toyota-Yaris-Cross.description: The AC200 series Yaris Cross is a larger subcompact crossover based on the Daihatsu New Global Architecture (DNGA-B), developed by Toyota's Emerging-market Compact Car Company joint venture with Daihatsu. Unveiled in Indonesia on May 15, 2023, with production starting June 13, 2023, this version is marketed primarily in Southeast Asia, Latin America, Taiwan, and other emerging markets. Unlike the XP210, the AC200 is larger and positioned as a more affordable option in these regions. It shares its platform with the AC100 series Vios/Yaris sedan and the Daihatsu Avanza/Veloz. Powertrains include a 1.5L four-cylinder petrol engine (2NR-VE) producing 106 hp, and a hybrid system (2NR-VEX) rated at 103 hp from the engine plus 82 hp from the electric motor. The hybrid uses a smaller 0.7 kWh lithium-ion battery compared to the XP210's system. Available with 5-speed manual, Dual Mode CVT (D-CVT), or eCVT depending on market and trim. Toyota Safety Sense is standard on higher trims. The vehicle is produced at Toyota Motor Manufacturing Indonesia in Karawang for export to 25 countries, and also assembled in Taiwan by Kuozui Motors. In Malaysia, it is sold as the Perodua Traz (petrol only).
Toyota-Yaris-Cross.name: Second Generation (AC200)

Toyota-Yaris-iA.description: The Toyota Yaris iA represented a unique product in Toyota's North American lineup—a subcompact sedan that was actually a rebadged Mazda2 sedan (known as the Mazda Demio in some markets), initially sold under Toyota's now-discontinued Scion brand as the Scion iA before transitioning to Toyota badging for the 2017 model year when the Scion brand was eliminated. Featuring distinctly Mazda-derived styling with Toyota/Scion badges added, the Yaris iA stood apart from the Toyota-designed Yaris hatchback sold alongside it, creating a somewhat confusing situation where two different vehicles shared the Yaris nameplate in North America. Powered by Mazda's 1.5-liter Skyactiv-G four-cylinder engine producing 106 horsepower, paired with either a six-speed manual or six-speed automatic transmission driving the front wheels, the Yaris iA offered more engaging driving dynamics than typical for the segment, reflecting its Mazda engineering. The interior was similarly Mazda-derived, featuring a driver-focused cockpit with a standard 7-inch touchscreen that could also be controlled via a rotary knob, higher quality materials than the Toyota-designed Yaris, and a more premium overall feel. In an unusual approach for Toyota, the Yaris iA was offered in a single, well-equipped trim level with minimal options, reflecting its origins as a Scion product where the 'mono-spec' approach was standard practice. Standard features included forward collision warning with low-speed automatic emergency braking, a rearview camera, keyless entry, and cruise control—a generous equipment level for an entry-level vehicle of this era. The Yaris iA found modest success by offering the reliability reputation of the Toyota brand combined with Mazda's strengths in driving dynamics and interior quality, providing an alternative for subcompact sedan buyers seeking a more engaging driving experience than typical economy cars.
Toyota-Yaris-iA.name: First Generation

Toyota-Yaris-iA.description: For the 2019 model year, the rebadged Mazda2 sedan was rebranded as the Toyota Yaris Sedan and received a minor facelift. The facelift introduced new trim levels (L, LE, XLE) with a variety of interior and exterior options, replacing the previous monospec approach. The vehicle retained its Mazda-derived 1.5-liter Skyactiv-G engine producing 106 horsepower, paired with a six-speed automatic transmission (the manual transmission was discontinued). Exterior changes included subtle but noticeable updates to the front and rear styling, while interior enhancements included updated trim materials and additional convenience features across the higher trim levels. Safety features continued to be comprehensive for the segment, with forward collision warning and automatic emergency braking standard. Despite these updates, the model was discontinued after the 2020 model year when Toyota withdrew from the subcompact sedan segment in North America entirely.
Toyota-Yaris-iA.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Toyota-bZ4X.description: The Toyota bZ4X represents Toyota's first dedicated battery-electric vehicle built on the e-TNGA platform co-developed with Subaru. Launched in April 2022 for the 2023 model year, the bZ4X marked the beginning of Toyota's bZ (beyond Zero) sub-brand. Available in single-motor front-wheel drive producing 201 hp or dual-motor all-wheel drive generating 214 hp combined. Powered by a 71.4 kWh (FWD) or 72.8 kWh (AWD) lithium-ion battery pack, offering an EPA-estimated range of approximately 252 miles for FWD models and 228 miles for AWD variants. DC fast-charging capability of up to 150 kW for FWD and 100 kW for AWD models. The interior features a 12.3-inch touchscreen, optional solar roof, and Toyota Safety Sense 3.0 safety features. The vehicle faced a recall in June 2022 due to loose wheel bolts, which was resolved by October 2022.
Toyota-bZ4X.name: First Generation

Toyota-bZ4X.description: The 2025 facelift brought major updates to the bZ4X, including a name change to 'Toyota bZ' for the North American market. Key improvements include significantly faster DC fast charging (10-80% in approximately 30 minutes), an upgraded 11 kW onboard AC charger, and a larger 74.7 kWh battery with manufacturer-estimated range of up to 320 miles. Powertrain enhancements include updated BluE Nexus eAxle motors using silicon carbide semiconductors, producing up to 233 kW combined in AWD models (a 50% increase) and up to 165 kW in FWD models. Interior updates include a larger 14-inch infotainment display with physical knobs for volume and climate control, and removal of the plastic frame separating the steering wheel from the gauge cluster. Exterior changes feature Toyota's new 'Hammerhead' front fascia and color-matched wheel arch cladding. The model also adopted the NACS charging port for North American markets with Plug & Charge functionality.
Toyota-bZ4X.name: First Generation Facelift

Toyota-iQ.description: The Toyota iQ represented a groundbreaking approach to city car design, offering exceptional space efficiency in an ultra-compact package. Measuring just 2.98 meters in length—shorter than most microcars—the iQ nevertheless provided seating for up to four passengers through innovative packaging, including an asymmetric dashboard design, ultra-thin seatbacks, and a compact differential that allowed the front wheels to be pushed to the extreme corners of the vehicle. The exterior featured distinctive, chunky styling with minimal overhangs, a wide stance, and high beltline creating a substantial appearance despite its tiny footprint. Power came from small displacement engines including 1.0-liter and 1.33-liter gasoline units in most markets, paired with either manual or continuously variable transmissions driving the front wheels. The interior emphasized quality over typical city car expectations, with premium materials and available features including leather upholstery, navigation, and automatic climate control—unusual amenities in this segment. Safety was a priority with up to nine airbags including the world's first rear window curtain airbag, helping the iQ achieve a five-star Euro NCAP rating despite its diminutive size. The innovative '3+1' seating arrangement allowed three adults and one child (or small adult) to fit within the minimal footprint, though the space behind the driver was suitable only for small children or cargo. While never achieving the same iconic status as competitors like the Smart Fortwo, the iQ earned recognition for its clever design, premium approach to the city car segment, and sophisticated engineering solutions to maximize interior space. The model also served as the basis for the Aston Martin Cygnet, a luxury city car created to help the British sports car manufacturer meet European fleet emissions requirements. Production ended in December 2015 globally, with Japanese market continuing until April 2016.
Toyota-iQ.name: First Generation

VW-Golf.description: The first-generation Volkswagen Golf (known as the Rabbit in North America) replaced the iconic Beetle as Volkswagen's core model. Designed by Giorgetto Giugiaro, it pioneered the modern hatchback configuration with front-wheel drive, a transverse engine layout, and fold-down rear seats. Initially offered with 1.1L and 1.5L gasoline engines and later a 1.5L diesel, it prioritized efficiency and practicality. The performance-oriented GTI variant, introduced in 1976 with a fuel-injected 1.6L engine producing 110 horsepower, essentially created the hot hatchback category. The first-generation Golf established a formula of practical, efficient transportation with engaging driving dynamics that would define the model for decades to come.
VW-Golf.name: First Generation (Mk1)

VW-Golf.description: The second-generation Golf grew in size and sophistication while maintaining the fundamental principles of its predecessor. The exterior featured more rounded styling while preserving the recognizable Golf silhouette. Engineering improvements included increased body rigidity and more refined suspension, contributing to better ride and handling characteristics. Engine options expanded to include more powerful and efficient variants, including 16-valve versions in GTI models. This generation also saw the introduction of the Golf syncro with all-wheel drive and continued the performance tradition with the GTI G60 featuring a supercharged engine. The Mk2 successfully evolved the Golf formula with improved quality, comfort, and performance while maintaining the practical versatility that made the original so popular.
VW-Golf.name: Second Generation (Mk2)

VW-Golf.description: The third-generation Golf represented a significant advance in safety, refinement, and technology. The body structure incorporated enhanced crash protection, while the exterior design featured softer, more aerodynamic styling. This generation introduced the VR6 engine option, a compact narrow-angle V6 that delivered impressive performance in the range-topping models. Other innovations included the first TDI diesel Golf, utilizing direct injection turbo diesel technology for improved efficiency, and the first Golf Cabriolet based on the new platform. The Mk3 also saw the introduction of standard dual airbags, ABS brakes, and improved environmental considerations in manufacturing and recycling. Though sometimes considered less charismatic than its predecessors, the Mk3 represented an important evolution in making the Golf more sophisticated and safer.
VW-Golf.name: Third Generation (Mk3)

VW-Golf.description: The fourth-generation Golf set new standards for build quality and refinement in the compact class. The exterior featured clean, sophisticated styling with tight panel gaps and impressive attention to detail. The interior quality took a significant step forward with soft-touch materials, damped switches, and a solid feel previously associated with more expensive vehicles. Engine options ranged from basic petrol and diesel variants to the powerful VR6 and the new 1.8T turbocharged four-cylinder. This generation expanded the Golf portfolio further with the R32, featuring a 3.2L VR6 engine and 4MOTION all-wheel drive, establishing a new performance flagship above the GTI. Technological advances included the option of DSG dual-clutch transmission, electronic stability control, and improved safety features. The Mk4 successfully elevated the Golf's position in the market, bridging the gap between mainstream and premium compact cars.
VW-Golf.name: Fourth Generation (Mk4)

VW-Golf.description: The fifth-generation Golf returned to the model's sportier roots while maintaining the quality improvements of its predecessor. The exterior design was more dynamic and distinctive, while the chassis featured a sophisticated multilink rear suspension that improved both handling and ride comfort. The GTI variant regained its performance credibility with a 2.0L turbocharged direct-injection engine, while the R32 continued as the all-wheel drive flagship. This generation introduced adaptive chassis control, bi-xenon headlights, and improved infotainment options. The TDI diesel engines gained common-rail injection technology for better refinement and efficiency. The Mk5 successfully balanced driver engagement with practical considerations, reconnecting with enthusiasts while continuing to serve as versatile family transportation.
VW-Golf.name: Fifth Generation (Mk5)

VW-Golf.description: The sixth-generation Golf was more of an extensive redesign of the Mk5 rather than a completely new model. The exterior featured sharper styling with influences from other Volkswagen models like the Scirocco, while the interior quality and refinement were further improved with better materials and sound insulation. Engine choices continued to evolve with more efficient TSI petrol and TDI diesel options, including the introduction of BlueMotion technology focused on maximum efficiency. The GTI continued with an improved 2.0L turbocharged engine, while the range-topping variant changed from R32 to simply 'R', now powered by a 2.0L turbocharged four-cylinder rather than the VR6. Safety technology advanced with features like adaptive cruise control and park assist becoming available. Despite its relatively short production run, the Mk6 successfully refined the Golf formula with a focus on quality and efficiency.
VW-Golf.name: Sixth Generation (Mk6)

VW-Golf.description: The seventh-generation Golf moved to Volkswagen's versatile MQB platform, enabling significant advances in technology, efficiency, and safety while reducing weight by up to 100 kg compared to its predecessor. The exterior design evolved subtly but incorporated sharper lines and more precise detailing. Engine options were thoroughly updated, with downsized turbocharged petrol and diesel engines focused on improved efficiency without sacrificing performance. This generation expanded the Golf family significantly with the introduction of the full-electric e-Golf, plug-in hybrid GTE, compressed natural gas TGI, and high-performance Golf R with up to 310 horsepower in later iterations. Technology features took a major step forward with available digital instrument clusters, advanced infotainment systems with gesture control, and expanded driver assistance systems including semi-autonomous capabilities. A facelift in 2017 (sometimes called Mk7.5) updated the styling and technology further. The Mk7 successfully modernized the Golf with class-leading technology and efficiency while maintaining its fundamental appeal.
VW-Golf.name: Seventh Generation (Mk7)

VW-Golf.description: The eighth-generation Golf, introduced in late 2019 as a 2020 model, represents a digital revolution for Volkswagen's core model while maintaining evolutionary exterior styling. Built on an updated version of the MQB platform, the exterior features refined aerodynamics and a distinctive front end with standard LED lighting. The interior marks the most radical change, with almost all physical buttons replaced by touch-sensitive surfaces and screens, including a standard 10.25-inch digital instrument cluster and 10-inch center touchscreen. Powertrain options include updated TSI petrol and TDI diesel engines, now featuring 48-volt mild hybrid technology on many variants, plus expanded plug-in hybrid offerings with increased electric range. The GTI continues as the core performance model, while the GTD (diesel) and GTE (plug-in hybrid) offer alternative performance flavors, and the Golf R remains the all-wheel drive flagship. Connected services and driver assistance systems are significantly expanded, with Car2X communication enabling the vehicle to exchange information with infrastructure and other vehicles. The Mk8 maintains the Golf's position as a technology leader in its segment, though the digital-focused interior has received mixed reception from traditional Golf enthusiasts.
VW-Golf.name: Eighth Generation (Mk8)

Vauxhall-Astra.description: The Vauxhall Astra Mark 1 was the UK-badged version of the Opel Kadett D, launched in March 1980 as Vauxhall's first front-wheel drive model, replacing the Viva. Initially offered in hatchback, saloon, and estate body styles, with engines ranging from 1.2 to 1.8 liters including the fuel-injected GTE introduced in 1983. This generation established Vauxhall's entry into the competitive small family car segment, competing against the Ford Escort and Volkswagen Golf. The 1.8 GTE became a notable hot hatch rival to the Ford XR3i and Golf GTI, featuring the first 'colour-coded' body trim in the UK. Awarded What Car?'s Car of the Year for 1980.
Vauxhall-Astra.name: First Generation

Vauxhall-Astra.description: The Vauxhall Astra Mark 2, launched on 17 October 1984, featured completely restyled aerodynamics while sharing the previous generation's engines and running gear. This long-lived generation was available in hatchback, estate, saloon (badged as Vauxhall Belmont), and cabriolet versions, with Bertone building 6,764 convertibles between 1987-1993. The Mark 2 was voted 1985 European Car of the Year. Performance variants included the GTE with 1.8 and 2.0-liter engines, culminating in the legendary 20XE 'red top' twin-cam engine producing approximately 150 bhp. The special edition GTE 'Leather Edition' launched in 1990 featured Recaro seats and Connolly leather interior. The Mark 2 became Britain's second most popular small family car, though it never matched the Ford Escort's sales success.
Vauxhall-Astra.name: Second Generation

Vauxhall-Astra.description: The Vauxhall Astra Mark 3, released in October 1991, was the first generation sold as Astra by Opel (succeeding the Kadett E) and also by Holden in Australia and New Zealand. Available as three or five-door hatchback, saloon, estate, and cabriolet (Bertone-built), this generation introduced significant safety improvements including twin side impact bars, collapsible steering column, and pre-tensioner seatbelts—ahead of competitors like the Volkswagen Golf and Ford Monde. The range was revised in late 1994 with new Ecotec engines and subtle exterior styling updates including Vauxhall's corporate 'V' grille. The top performance model was the three-door only GSi with 1.8 or 2.0 16v engines, later replaced by Sport models with Lotus suspension. Trim levels included Merit, LS, GLS, CD, CDX, Si, SRi, and special editions such as Sport, Expression, California, and Arizona.
Vauxhall-Astra.name: Third Generation

Vauxhall-Astra.description: The Vauxhall Astra Mark 4, launched at the London Motor Show in October 1997 and released in Spring 1998, addressed criticism of the Mark 3 with greatly improved ride and handling. Built on GM's T-platform, it achieved a Euro NCAP 4-star crash test rating—excellent for its time. Available in hatchback, estate, saloon (poor seller), and popular coupé and convertible variants released in 2000. Engine options included 1.2, 1.4 16v, 1.6 (8v and 16v including Twinport), 1.8, 2.0, and 2.2 liters, plus diesel 1.7 DTi and CDTi variants. The high-performance GSi Turbo produced approximately 200 bhp. The Astravan continued production until 2006, while five-door hatchbacks remained available until mid-2005. Police forces widely adopted the Mark 4 as a panda car, with 54 constabularies using the model.
Vauxhall-Astra.name: Fourth Generation

Vauxhall-Astra.description: The Vauxhall Astra Mark V (codenamed H), launched in May 2004 as a five-door hatchback, expanded to include estate, three-door Sport Hatch (with optional panoramic windscreen), and TwinTop convertible from 2006. This generation achieved Vauxhall's first Euro NCAP 5-star crash test rating. Trim levels ranged from Life and Club to SRi, Elite, and the high-performance VXR Sport Hatch producing 240 bhp. Engine options included petrol 1.4, 1.6 (105-177 bhp), 1.8, and 2.0 turbo (197-236 bhp), plus diesel 1.3, 1.7, and 1.9 CDTi variants. Special editions included Active, Energy, Breeze, and VXR Nurburgring. The five-door was replaced in late 2009 (available through 2010-2011), while the Sport Hatch continued until late 2011. This was the last Astra to include an Astravan variant, with production ending in 2013 and effectively replaced by the Fiat Doblo-based Combo van.
Vauxhall-Astra.name: Fifth Generation

Vauxhall-Astra.description: The Vauxhall Astra Mark 6 (codenamed J), officially unveiled at the 2009 Frankfurt Motor Show and available from late 2009, was designed under GM's Australian subsidiary with significant influence from the Vauxhall Insignia's design language. The main manufacturing plant at Ellesmere Port benefited from sterling depreciation. Available as five-door hatchback and estate (Sports Tourer, debuted Paris Motor Show 2010), the Mark 6 was a strong sales success—Britain's best-selling car in June 2010 with over 10,000 sales, outselling the Ford Focus by nearly 50%. The model served as BBC2 Top Gear's 'Reasonably Priced Car' in the Tech Line trim. Engine options included efficient petrol and diesel units, with the 1.0-liter three-cylinder engine introduced later in the generation. The 'OnStar' system provided integrated assistance calling. The sixth generation was Britain's second-best selling new car in 2010 with 80,646 units, finally outselling the Ford Focus and ending Ford's 37-year lead in the small family car segment.
Vauxhall-Astra.name: Sixth Generation

Vauxhall-Astra.description: The Vauxhall Astra Mark 7 (codenamed K), also sold as the Opel Astra in continental Europe, represented the seventh generation of Vauxhall's compact family car. Launched at the Frankfurt Motor Show in September 2015, it was built on GM's D2XX platform before the brand's acquisition by PSA Group (later Stellantis). Significantly lighter than its predecessor—up to 200 kg (440 lbs) reduction—the Astra K offered improved efficiency and driving dynamics. Available in five-door hatchback and estate (Sports Tourer) body styles with sharp creases, floating roof effect on some models, and more athletic stance. Engine options included 1.0, 1.4, and 1.6-liter turbocharged petrol engines (105-200 horsepower) and 1.6/2.0-liter diesel units (110-160 horsepower). Transmission choices included six-speed manual, automated manual, and conventional automatic. The interior featured a driver-focused cockpit with 7-inch or optional 8-inch touchscreen infotainment, available OnStar connectivity (until 2019), and improved materials. Advanced features included optional IntelliLux LED matrix headlights, adaptive cruise control, and automated parking assistance. The Astra K won the European Car of the Year award in 2016 and maintained strong sales through to 2021.
Vauxhall-Astra.name: Seventh Generation (Astra K)

Vauxhall-Astra.description: The Vauxhall Astra Mark 8 (codenamed L), also sold as the Opel Astra in continental Europe, represents the eighth generation of Vauxhall's compact family car and the first developed under Stellantis ownership after PSA Group's acquisition of Vauxhall/Opel from General Motors. Unveiled on 13 July 2021 and on sale from 12 November 2021, it is built on the Stellantis EMP2 platform shared with the Peugeot 308. The Astra L features Vauxhall's new 'Vizor' front end design—a blacked-out panel integrating headlights and grille—and more angular, assertive proportions. Available in five-door hatchback and estate (Sports Tourer) body styles, it maintains similar dimensions while offering improved interior space. Powertrains reflect Stellantis's electrification strategy: 1.2-liter turbo petrol (110-130 hp), 1.5-liter diesel (130 hp), plug-in hybrid combining 1.6-liter petrol with electric motor (up to 225 hp, approximately 35-mile electric range), and Astra Electric (2023) with 156 hp motor and 54 kWh battery providing approximately 258 miles range. The interior features the Pure Panel digital cockpit with dual 10-inch screens, wireless smartphone integration, and improved materials. Advanced driver assistance includes semi-automated lane changing, adaptive cruise control, and 360-degree cameras.
Vauxhall-Astra.name: Eighth Generation (Astra L)

Vauxhall-Mokka-e.description: The Vauxhall Mokka-e (branded as Opel Mokka-e in continental Europe) represents the fully electric variant of the second-generation Mokka subcompact crossover, the first developed under PSA Group (now Stellantis) ownership after the acquisition of Vauxhall/Opel from General Motors. Built on the Stellantis CMP (Common Modular Platform) architecture designed to accommodate multiple powertrain types, the Mokka-e features distinctive styling with Vauxhall's new 'Vizor' front end design—a blacked-out panel spanning the width of the vehicle integrating headlights and brand logo—and a more angular, assertive appearance compared to its predecessor. Dimensionally smaller than the first-generation Mokka but with improved interior packaging, the Mokka-e emphasizes style and technology over maximum utility. Powered by a 136 horsepower (100 kW) electric motor driving the front wheels and drawing energy from a 50 kWh battery pack, the Mokka-e delivers a WLTP-rated range of approximately 209 miles (338 km) on a full charge. DC fast charging at up to 100 kW allows for an 80% charge in about 30 minutes. The interior features Vauxhall's Pure Panel digital cockpit combining dual widescreens (up to 12 inches combined) for instruments and infotainment, creating a minimalist, high-tech environment with physical controls limited to essential functions. Standard equipment is generous across all trim levels, including LED headlights, a 7-inch touchscreen, cruise control, and multiple driver assistance systems, with higher trims adding features like adaptive cruise control, heated seats, and a larger 10-inch touchscreen. As one of the first fully electric models launched under Vauxhall's commitment to electrify its entire lineup, the Mokka-e plays a key role in the brand's transition toward zero-emission vehicles while offering the higher seating position and crossover styling increasingly preferred by European consumers.
Vauxhall-Mokka-e.name: First Generation

Vauxhall-Mokka-e.description: A facelift was unveiled on 23 October 2024. There are minimal exterior changes but there are updated lighting graphics, the brand's visor front fascia features the new logo, and new black exterior accents replaced the chrome inserts. Inside, there is a new steering wheel, updated software for the infotainment system, some functions that were previously controlled by buttons are integrated into the touchscreen, a new matte silver centre console and all fabrics are made from recycled content.
Vauxhall-Mokka-e.name: First Generation (Facelift)

VauxhallOpel-Ampera.description: The Vauxhall/Opel Ampera was the European variant of the Chevrolet Volt, representing General Motors' first extended-range electric vehicle (E-REV) or series plug-in hybrid. Featuring distinctive, futuristic styling with a unique front fascia, aerodynamic profile, and special lighting elements that differentiated it from conventional Vauxhall/Opel models, the Ampera was designed to showcase GM's advanced electric propulsion technology. Powered by a 16 kWh lithium-ion battery pack and an electric motor producing 149 horsepower and 273 lb-ft of torque, the Ampera could travel approximately 25-50 miles on electricity alone depending on conditions. Once the battery reached a predetermined depletion level, a 1.4-liter gasoline engine functioned primarily as a generator to produce electricity for the motor, extending the total range to around 300 miles. This powertrain architecture differed from traditional hybrids by using the electric motor for propulsion in almost all driving scenarios, with the gasoline engine rarely providing direct mechanical drive to the wheels. The interior featured a futuristic design with two 7-inch displays providing comprehensive information about the powertrain's operation, energy flow, and efficiency metrics, alongside practical features including seating for four passengers (with the battery tunnel limiting the vehicle to four seats) and a reasonable 300-liter luggage capacity. The Ampera won numerous accolades including European Car of the Year 2012, but faced challenges in the European market due to its relatively high price compared to conventional alternatives. Despite its technical sophistication and favorable reviews, sales remained modest, and the model was discontinued in 2015 without a direct replacement as GM reconsidered its European product strategy, ultimately leading to the sale of Vauxhall/Opel to PSA Group in 2017.
VauxhallOpel-Ampera.name: First Generation

VauxhallOpel-Ampera.description: The Vauxhall/Opel Ampera-e represented a complete reconceptualization of the Ampera nameplate, abandoning the extended-range hybrid approach of its predecessor in favor of a pure battery-electric vehicle based on the North American Chevrolet Bolt EV. A compact five-door hatchback with crossover-inspired styling elements, the Ampera-e featured a more conventional exterior design than its predecessor but with distinctive elements including a blanked-off grille, unique light signatures, and aerodynamic optimizations appropriate for an electric vehicle. Powered by a 60 kWh lithium-ion battery pack and a single electric motor producing 204 horsepower and 266 lb-ft of torque driving the front wheels, the Ampera-e delivered impressive performance with 0-62 mph acceleration in 7.3 seconds alongside a WLTP-rated range of approximately 240 miles—class-leading for its time and price point. DC fast charging capability allowed for approximately 90 miles of range to be added in 30 minutes under ideal conditions. The interior emphasized technology and space efficiency, featuring a 10.2-inch touchscreen infotainment system, digital instrument cluster, and surprisingly generous passenger and cargo accommodation considering the vehicle's compact exterior dimensions—a benefit of the purpose-built electric architecture with the battery positioned under the floor. Despite its technical merits and positive reception, the Ampera-e faced a challenging existence in Europe. Shortly after its introduction, General Motors announced the sale of Vauxhall/Opel to PSA Group, creating uncertainty about the model's future. Limited supply and allocation issues further complicated its market presence, and production for European markets ended in 2019 as the new PSA ownership focused on developing electric vehicles based on their own platforms rather than continuing with GM-derived products. The Ampera-e thus had a brief but significant tenure as Opel/Vauxhall's first mainstream pure electric vehicle, demonstrating the capabilities of battery-electric technology before the brand's more comprehensive electrification strategy under Stellantis ownership.
VauxhallOpel-Ampera.name: Second Generation (Ampera-e)

VauxhallOpel-Astra.description: The Opel Astra F was the first generation of the Astra nameplate, launched in September 1991 as a direct replacement for the Opel Kadett E. Built on the T-body platform, it was offered as a three- or five-door hatchback, four-door sedan, and five-door estate (Caravan). The Astra F grew slightly in all dimensions compared to the Kadett, with a windshield moved forward by 33mm and roof extended at the rear, significantly increasing interior volume. The model received a cosmetic facelift in 1994 with improved rust protection, new grille with larger Opel badge, clear front turn signals, and updated door mirrors. While production in Germany ended in 2000, Polish-built Astras continued as the Astra Classic until 2003 in Central and Eastern European markets. Engine options ranged from 1.4 to 2.0 liters in petrol (including the high-performance 2.0L 16V GSi with DOHC C20XE engine) and 1.7 liters in diesel. A cabriolet version was designed and built by Bertone in Italy. The Astra F won the Semperit Irish Car of the Year in 1992 and South African Car of the Year in 1994 and 1995.
VauxhallOpel-Astra.name: Astra F

VauxhallOpel-Astra.description: The Opel Astra G was launched in Spring 1998, representing the second generation built on the updated T-body platform. Available as a three or five-door hatchback, four-door sedan, five-door estate (Caravan), and two special versions from 2000: the Astra Coupé and Astra Cabrio, both designed and built by Bertone. The Astra G introduced a natural gas-powered engine option and its chassis, tuned by Lotus, formed the basis for the Opel Zafira A compact MPV co-developed with Porsche. Approximately 90,000 coupés were produced. Production continued at Opel's Gliwice plant in Poland after the debut of the Astra H, with the older model branded as Astra Classic II (2004-2009). The Astra G was also built as Chevrolet Astra in Brazil, receiving a facelift in 2003 and sold until 2011. Engine options included petrol units from 1.2 to 2.0 liters and diesel engines from 1.7 to 2.2 liters, with the high-performance OPC version powered by a 2.0L turbocharged engine producing 192 kW (260 PS). The Astra G was used for DTM racing cars featuring gull-wing doors and purpose-built 4.0L V8 engines.
VauxhallOpel-Astra.name: Astra G

VauxhallOpel-Astra.description: The Opel Astra H was launched in March 2004 as a five-door hatchback, with the estate following late 2004 and the sporty three-door GTC launching in 2005. Built on an updated GM T platform with increased dimensions, the Astra H featured innovative options including a panoramic windscreen on the GTC and digital radio availability. The range included a retractable hardtop convertible TwinTop (2006-2010) built by Magna Steyr. Production continued until end of 2009 for most models, with TwinTop continuing until November 2010. The Astra H received a facelift in January 2007 with updated front and rear styling. The high-performance OPC version of the GTC featured a 2.0L turbocharged engine producing 177 kW (240 PS). The model was sold as Chevrolet Astra in Brazil, Saturn Astra in North America (2008-2009), and Holden Astra in Australia/New Zealand. Engine options spanned 1.3 to 2.0 liters in both petrol and diesel, with transmissions including 5/6-speed manual, Easytronic automated manual, and 4/6-speed automatic. Production continued alongside the new Astra J as the Astra Classic III in Eastern European markets until 2014.
VauxhallOpel-Astra.name: Astra H

VauxhallOpel-Astra.description: The Opel Astra J debuted at the 2009 Frankfurt Motor Show, built on General Motors' Delta II platform and featuring styling inspired by the Opel Insignia with 'sculptural artistry meets German precision' design language. Deliveries began in December 2009, with full production at Vauxhall's Ellesmere Port Plant. The station wagon Sports Tourer debuted at the 2010 Paris Motor Show, replacing Opel's traditional 'Caravan' nomenclature. A three-door GTC version introduced in July 2011 featured the HiPerStrut front suspension from the Insignia OPC and Watt's link rear suspension. The high-performance OPC version offered a 2.0L turbocharged engine producing 206 kW (280 PS). A facelift in June 2012 brought revised bumpers, grilles, headlights, rear lights, and new driver assistance systems including lane-departure warning and forward-collision alert. A four-door sedan variant was introduced in 2012 for various markets including China (Buick Excelle GT), North America (Buick Verano), and others, with production continuing until 2018. Engine options included 1.4 to 2.0 liter petrol and 1.3 to 2.0 liter diesel units, with the new 1.6L 'whisper diesel' CDTI introduced in 2014. The Astra J came third in the European Car of the Year 2010 award.
VauxhallOpel-Astra.name: Astra J

VauxhallOpel-Astra.description: The Vauxhall/Opel Astra K represented the fifth generation of the popular European compact car, built on General Motors' D2XX platform before the brands' acquisition by PSA Group (later Stellantis). Officially unveiled on 1 June 2015 and premiered at the Frankfurt Motor Show, the Astra K is 5cm smaller but offers more interior space than its predecessor. Significantly lighter—up to 200 kg (440 lbs) in some configurations—the weight reduction came from a bodyshell reduced by 20% from 357 to 280 kilograms using high-strength and ultra-high-strength steels. Available in five-door hatchback and estate (Sports Tourer) body styles, the Astra K featured more dynamic styling with sharp creases and a floating roof effect on some models. Engine options included 1.0-liter three-cylinder and 1.4-liter four-cylinder petrol engines (1.2L and 1.3L from 2019) or 1.6-liter 'whisper diesel', with turbocharged petrol engines using direct injection. Transmission choices included five or six-speed manual, the new 5-speed EasyTronic 3.0 automated manual, and 6-speed automatic. The interior featured a standard 7-inch or optional 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system with Android Auto and Apple CarPlay connectivity, available OnStar services (until 2019), and improved materials throughout. Advanced features included optional IntelliLux LED matrix headlights, adaptive cruise control, and automated parking assistance. The Astra K won the European Car of the Year award in 2016.
VauxhallOpel-Astra.name: Astra K

VauxhallOpel-Astra.description: The Vauxhall/Opel Astra L represents the sixth generation of the compact family car and the first developed under Stellantis ownership after the PSA Group's acquisition of Vauxhall/Opel from General Motors. Built on the Stellantis EMP2 platform shared with vehicles like the Peugeot 308, the Astra L features bold, distinctive styling adopting the new 'Vizor' front end design—a blacked-out panel integrating the headlights and grille into a single visual element—and more angular, assertive proportions. Available in five-door hatchback and estate (Sports Tourer) body styles, the Astra L maintains similar dimensions to its predecessor while offering improved interior space and technology. Powertrain options reflect Stellantis's electrification strategy, including traditional petrol and diesel engines alongside plug-in hybrid variants. Petrol options include 1.2-liter three-cylinder turbocharged engines with 110 or 130 horsepower, while diesel is represented by a 1.5-liter four-cylinder producing 130 horsepower. The plug-in hybrid combines a 1.6-liter petrol engine with an electric motor for a combined output of up to 225 horsepower, offering approximately 35 miles of electric-only range. A fully electric Astra Electric variant joined the lineup in 2023, featuring a 156 horsepower motor and 54 kWh battery providing approximately 258 miles of range. The interior demonstrates a significant technological leap with the Pure Panel digital cockpit combining dual 10-inch screens for instruments and infotainment, wireless smartphone integration, and improved materials throughout. Advanced driver assistance systems include semi-automated lane changing, adaptive cruise control, and 360-degree parking cameras.
VauxhallOpel-Astra.name: Astra L

VauxhallOpel-Corsa-e.description: The Vauxhall/Opel Corsa-e represents the fully electric variant of the sixth-generation Corsa supermini (Corsa F), the first developed under PSA Group (now Stellantis) ownership after the acquisition of Vauxhall/Opel from General Motors. Built on the Stellantis CMP (Common Modular Platform) architecture designed to accommodate multiple powertrain types, the Corsa-e shares its fundamental electric drivetrain with other Stellantis group vehicles including the Peugeot e-208. Visually similar to the conventional petrol and diesel Corsa models but with subtle distinctive elements including unique alloy wheel designs, model-specific blue accents, and 'e' badging, the Corsa-e maintains the sixth-generation Corsa's more restrained styling compared to some competitors. Powered by a 136 horsepower (100 kW) electric motor driving the front wheels and drawing energy from a 50 kWh battery pack, the Corsa-e delivers a WLTP-rated range of approximately 209 miles (337 km) on a full charge. DC fast charging at up to 100 kW allows for an 80% charge in about 30 minutes. Performance is sprightly with 0-62 mph acceleration in 8.1 seconds, actually making it the quickest model in the Corsa lineup. The interior maintains the conventional Corsa's layout with a driver-oriented cockpit featuring a 7-inch or optional 10-inch touchscreen infotainment system, digital instrument cluster, and intuitive physical controls for essential functions. Three driving modes (Eco, Normal, and Sport) allow users to prioritize range or performance as needed. Standard equipment is generous across all trim levels, including automatic climate control, navigation, and multiple driver assistance systems.
VauxhallOpel-Corsa-e.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

VauxhallOpel-Corsa-e.description: The facelifted Vauxhall/Opel Corsa-e was unveiled on 24 May 2023, featuring a comprehensive update to the sixth-generation Corsa F platform. The exterior redesign introduces Opel's new 'Visor' front end design language, giving the Corsa-e a more distinctive and modern appearance with a bold single-piece grille treatment and refined lighting elements. Inside, the facelift brings a new steering wheel design, updated seat designs with improved comfort and support, and a new gear shifter for automatic transmission variants. Technology upgrades include an enhanced infotainment system with improved connectivity features, larger touchscreen options, and advanced driver assistance systems. The Corsa-e continues to utilize the proven 50 kWh battery pack and 136 horsepower (100 kW) electric motor, though efficiency improvements may extend the real-world range. In December 2023, Opel expanded the Corsa lineup with 48V mild-hybrid versions, though the fully electric Corsa-e remains the flagship zero-emission model. The facelift represents Vauxhall/Opel's commitment to keeping their electric supermini competitive in an increasingly crowded market while maintaining the practical range and accessible price point that made the original successful.
VauxhallOpel-Corsa-e.name: Second Generation (Facelift)

VauxhallOpel-Crossland.description: The Vauxhall/Opel Crossland X was introduced as a compact crossover SUV replacing the Meriva MPV, representing the brand's response to shifting consumer preferences from traditional people carriers toward SUV-styled vehicles. Developed under General Motors ownership but launched just as PSA Group acquired Vauxhall/Opel, the Crossland X was actually based on the PSA PF1 platform shared with the Peugeot 2008 and Citroën C3 Aircross—foreshadowing the full transition to PSA architecture that would follow. Featuring a relatively conventional crossover design with a high roofline, raised seating position, and practical proportions, the Crossland X prioritized interior space and versatility over dynamic styling or off-road pretensions. Engine options included PSA-sourced petrol and diesel units, with the petrol lineup featuring 1.2-liter three-cylinder engines in naturally aspirated (81 horsepower) or turbocharged (110 or 130 horsepower) forms, while diesel options comprised 1.5-liter four-cylinders with either 102 or 120 horsepower. Transmission choices included five and six-speed manuals or a six-speed automatic, all driving the front wheels only—all-wheel drive was not offered. The interior emphasized practicality with a flexible rear seat that could slide forward and back to prioritize either passenger or cargo space, a relatively high seating position providing good visibility, and straightforward controls. Technology features included a 7-inch or 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility, and available safety systems such as lane departure warning, traffic sign recognition, and forward collision alert. The Crossland X represented Vauxhall/Opel's entry into the booming small crossover segment, offering a practical alternative for families seeking more style than a traditional MPV but with similar levels of versatility.
VauxhallOpel-Crossland.name: First Generation (Crossland X)

VauxhallOpel-Crossland.description: The Vauxhall/Opel Crossland (dropping the 'X' suffix from its name) received a comprehensive facelift for 2020, adopting the brand's new 'Vizor' front end design—a blacked-out panel spanning between the headlights—that would become a signature element across the Vauxhall/Opel range. Beyond the significant front-end redesign, the updated Crossland received revised rear styling with darkened taillight surrounds, new wheel designs, and the introduction of a more dynamic-looking 'GS Line' trim level. Mechanically, the vehicle remained largely unchanged, continuing to offer the same range of PSA-sourced petrol and diesel engines, though with minor efficiency improvements to meet evolving emissions standards. Petrol options included 1.2-liter three-cylinder engines in naturally aspirated (83 horsepower) or turbocharged (110 or 130 horsepower) forms, while diesel choices comprised 1.5-liter four-cylinders with either 110 or 120 horsepower. The interior saw more modest updates with new trim options, improved technology including a standard 7-inch or optional 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system, and enhanced connectivity. The sliding rear seat remained a key practical feature, allowing owners to prioritize either passenger legroom or cargo capacity as needed. Under full Stellantis ownership (following the merger of PSA Group and FCA), the refreshed Crossland continued to serve as Vauxhall/Opel's entry in the competitive small crossover segment, appealing primarily to buyers seeking a practical family vehicle with a raised driving position and relatively compact exterior dimensions, though facing increased competition from newer competitors offering more distinctive styling, enhanced technology, or electrified powertrain options. Production ended in 2024, with the Frontera succeeding the Crossland.
VauxhallOpel-Crossland.name: First Generation (Crossland facelift)

VauxhallOpel-Grandland-X.description: The Vauxhall/Opel Grandland X was introduced as the largest crossover SUV in the manufacturer's lineup, replacing the Antara and competing in the crowded compact SUV segment. Developed following PSA Group's acquisition of Vauxhall/Opel from General Motors, the Grandland X was based on the PSA EMP2 platform shared with the Peugeot 3008, representing one of the first new models launched under PSA ownership. Featuring relatively conventional SUV styling with a high beltline, pronounced wheel arches, and contrasting roof options, the Grandland X prioritized mainstream appeal over distinctive design flourishes. Engine options included PSA-sourced petrol and diesel units, with the petrol lineup featuring a 1.2-liter turbocharged three-cylinder producing 130 horsepower and a 1.6-liter turbocharged four-cylinder with 180 horsepower, while diesel options comprised 1.5 and 2.0-liter four-cylinders with outputs ranging from 120 to 177 horsepower. In 2019, a plug-in hybrid variant was introduced, combining a 1.6-liter petrol engine with electric motors for either 225 horsepower in front-wheel drive form or 300 horsepower with all-wheel drive capability through an additional rear electric motor. Transmission choices included six-speed manual and eight-speed automatic options. The interior featured a driver-oriented cockpit with a standard 7-inch or optional 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system, traditional analog instruments, and a straightforward control layout. Practical features included generous passenger space, up to 514 liters of cargo capacity, and numerous storage compartments throughout the cabin. Safety technology was comprehensive with available features including adaptive cruise control, lane keeping assist, blind spot monitoring, and automated parking assistance. The Grandland X represented Vauxhall/Opel's entry into the highly competitive compact SUV segment, offering a balance of practicality, technology, and moderate styling that appealed to m...
VauxhallOpel-Grandland-X.name: First Generation (Grandland X)

VauxhallOpel-Grandland-X.description: The Vauxhall/Opel Grandland (dropping the 'X' suffix from its name) received a substantial facelift in June 2021, adopting the brand's new 'Vizor' front end design—a blacked-out panel spanning the width of the vehicle integrating headlights and brand logo—creating a much more distinctive and modern appearance than its predecessor. Beyond the dramatically redesigned front end, the updated Grandland featured revised rear styling with darkened taillight surrounds, new wheel designs, and enhanced trim options including a more dynamic GSe electrified performance variant. The engine lineup continued with the same range of petrol, diesel, and plug-in hybrid powertrains, though with minor efficiency improvements to meet evolving emissions standards. The most significant interior update was the introduction of the Pure Panel digital cockpit combining a 12-inch digital instrument cluster with a 10-inch central touchscreen under a single curved housing, creating a more high-tech, contemporary ambiance. Additional technology improvements included the availability of Night Vision (a segment first), 360-degree parking cameras, and enhanced driver assistance systems. The plug-in hybrid variants remained a key part of the lineup, offering up to 39 miles of electric-only range (WLTP) and serving as a stepping stone in the brand's electrification strategy. Under full Stellantis ownership (following the merger of PSA Group and FCA), the refreshed Grandland continued as Vauxhall/Opel's flagship SUV, appealing to family buyers seeking a practical, technology-rich crossover with distinctive styling and the option of electrified powertrains.
VauxhallOpel-Grandland-X.name: First Generation (Grandland facelift)

VauxhallOpel-Grandland-X.description: The second generation Vauxhall/Opel Grandland was officially revealed on 22 April 2024 and is the third vehicle based on Stellantis' STLA Medium platform. The new generation represents a significant step forward in design and technology, borrowing elements from the Experimental concept car including the '3D Visor' front fascia with an illuminated logo, Intelli-Lux Pixel HD lighting system, and illuminated brand lettering in the center of the full-width taillights. Beyond versions powered by an internal combustion engine, an all-electric variant became available for the first time in the Grandland lineup. The interior uses 100% recyclable materials for the fabric and upholstery and features a 16-inch central touchscreen infotainment system, a small fully digital instrument cluster, Intelli-HUD head-up display, and the Pure Mode which reduces content on displays to eliminate distractions. Electric variants offer up to 82 kWh battery capacity with a range of over 300 miles, while plug-in hybrid and mild hybrid options continue to be available. AWD versions of the electric Grandland were announced in June 2025, becoming the most powerful models in Opel's lineup at that time. The second generation Grandland shares its Euro NCAP results with the Peugeot 3008 and 5008.
VauxhallOpel-Grandland-X.name: Second Generation

VauxhallOpel-Insignia.description: The first-generation Vauxhall/Opel Insignia replaced the Vectra as the brand's mid-size offering, representing a significant step upmarket in terms of design, technology, and perceived quality. Built on General Motors' Epsilon II platform, the Insignia was available in sedan (saloon), hatchback (fastback), and estate (Sports Tourer) body styles, with the distinctive appearance winning European Car of the Year honors in 2009. The exterior featured flowing, aerodynamic lines with a coupé-like silhouette even on four-door variants, contributing to a class-leading drag coefficient of 0.27. Engine options varied extensively depending on market and model year, including petrol units ranging from 1.4 to 2.8-liter displacement and diesel options from 1.6 to 2.0-liters, with power outputs spanning from 110 to 325 horsepower in the high-performance OPC/VXR variants. Transmission choices included six-speed manual, six-speed automatic, and later six-speed automated manual options, with front-wheel drive standard and all-wheel drive (marketed as Adaptive 4x4) available on higher-powered variants. The interior represented a significant advance over the Vectra, featuring a driver-oriented cockpit with a 'wraparound' dashboard design, higher quality materials, and advanced technology including an available 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system, adaptive cruise control, and the sophisticated FlexRide adaptive chassis system with three driving modes adjusting damping, steering, and throttle response. A substantial facelift in 2013 (sometimes referred to as Insignia B in some markets) brought updated styling, enhanced technology, and improved efficiency, helping to maintain competitiveness in the shrinking mid-size segment increasingly challenged by the rise of crossovers and SUVs. The first-generation Insignia proved a successful model for Vauxhall/Opel, elevating the brand's image with its combination of style, technology, and refinement, though facing the same market headwinds affecting all traditional sedans as consumer preferences shifted toward higher-riding vehicles.
VauxhallOpel-Insignia.name: First Generation (Insignia A)

VauxhallOpel-Insignia.description: The second-generation Vauxhall/Opel Insignia, marketed as the Insignia Grand Sport (hatchback), Insignia Sports Tourer (estate), and Insignia Country Tourer (raised estate with SUV styling cues), represented the last model developed under General Motors ownership before PSA Group (later Stellantis) acquired Vauxhall/Opel. Built on GM's E2XX platform and sharing components with the North American Buick Regal, the new Insignia grew significantly in length and wheelbase while being up to 175 kg (386 lbs) lighter than its predecessor thanks to more extensive use of high-strength steel and other weight-saving measures. The exterior design evolved with more taut, sculptural surfaces, a lower, wider stance, and a longer, more elegant silhouette emphasizing the increased dimensions. Engine options at launch included 1.5 and 2.0-liter turbocharged petrol units and 1.6 and 2.0-liter diesel engines, with power outputs ranging from 110 to 260 horsepower, though the lineup has evolved following the transition to PSA/Stellantis ownership to include more PSA-sourced powertrains. Transmission choices initially included six-speed manual, six-speed automatic, and eight-speed automatic options, with front-wheel drive standard and all-wheel drive with torque vectoring available on high-end models. The interior featured a more horizontal dashboard design with reduced button count, a standard 7-inch or optional 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system, and enhanced materials throughout. Technology advanced significantly with new features including a head-up display, adaptive LED matrix headlights (IntelliLux), and enhanced driver assistance systems including adaptive cruise control and automated emergency braking. Following PSA's acquisition, the Insignia received updates to align with the new corporate direction, though remaining on its GM-developed platform. The second-generation Insignia continued the model's positioning as a value-oriented alternative to premium mid-size offerings, providing generous space, equipment, and refinement at competitive price points, though facing the ongoing challenge of competing in a segment with declining popularity as buyers increasingly favor SUVs and crossovers.
VauxhallOpel-Insignia.name: Second Generation (Insignia B)

VauxhallOpel-Mokka.description: The first-generation Vauxhall/Opel Mokka was introduced as the brand's entry into the rapidly growing subcompact crossover segment, developed under General Motors ownership and sharing its Gamma II platform with other GM small vehicles including the Chevrolet Trax. Featuring a relatively boxy, upright design with traditional SUV styling cues including pronounced wheel arches, skid plates, and roof rails, the original Mokka combined compact exterior dimensions suitable for urban environments with a higher riding position appealing to buyers seeking an SUV-like experience in a smaller package. Engine options varied by market but typically included 1.4 and 1.6-liter petrol engines and 1.6 and 1.7-liter diesel units, with power outputs ranging from approximately 115 to 140 horsepower, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. While front-wheel drive was standard, all-wheel drive was available on select variants—an unusual feature for the segment at that time. The interior featured a somewhat cluttered dashboard design with numerous buttons and controls, though offering good visibility and a relatively high seating position. Technology included a 7-inch touchscreen infotainment system, available navigation, and safety features like a rearview camera and blind-spot monitoring on higher trims.
VauxhallOpel-Mokka.name: First Generation (Mokka A)

VauxhallOpel-Mokka.description: The first-generation Mokka received a significant mid-cycle refresh in April 2016, marketed as the Mokka X for model year 2017. The facelift introduced new headlights with LED daytime running lights, restyled bumpers with a more horizontal front-end design, new LED tail lights, and a completely redesigned interior featuring an all-new dashboard, instrument cluster, and centre stack with reduced button count. A more powerful 1.4-liter direct injection turbo petrol engine (B14XFT) was introduced with the facelift. The updated model maintained the same GM Gamma II platform and mechanicals while offering enhanced technology and a more refined appearance. The Mokka X continued to offer both front-wheel drive and all-wheel drive configurations, along with the same range of petrol and diesel engines including the new 1.6-liter CDTI diesel that replaced the older 1.7-liter unit.
VauxhallOpel-Mokka.name: First Generation (Mokka X - Facelift)

VauxhallOpel-Mokka.description: The second-generation Vauxhall/Opel Mokka represents a radical departure from its predecessor, developed under PSA Group (now Stellantis) ownership after the acquisition of Vauxhall/Opel from General Motors. Built on the Stellantis CMP (Common Modular Platform) architecture shared with vehicles like the Peugeot 2008, the new Mokka features a bold, distinctive design introducing Vauxhall/Opel's new 'Vizor' front end—a blacked-out panel spanning the width of the vehicle incorporating headlights and brand logo. Marginally shorter but wider than its predecessor, the Mokka presents more dynamic proportions with a strong character line along the sides, available two-tone roof, and a more expressive overall aesthetic that significantly distinguishes it from the more conventional first generation. Powertrain options reflect Stellantis's diversified approach, including 1.2-liter three-cylinder turbocharged petrol engines with either 100 or 130 horsepower, a 1.5-liter diesel producing 110 horsepower, and most significantly, a fully electric Mokka-e (later renamed Mokka Electric) variant featuring a 136 horsepower electric motor and 50 kWh battery providing approximately 209 miles (338 km) of WLTP-rated range. All versions are front-wheel drive only, with no all-wheel drive option offered. The interior represents a complete redesign with the Pure Panel digital cockpit combining dual widescreens (up to 12 inches combined) for instruments and infotainment, creating a minimalist, high-tech environment with physical controls limited to essential functions. Advanced driver assistance systems include adaptive cruise control, automatic emergency braking, and lane-keeping assistance.
VauxhallOpel-Mokka.name: Second Generation (Mokka B)

VauxhallOpel-Zafira-B.description: The Vauxhall/Opel Zafira B represented the second generation of the popular European compact MPV (Multi-Purpose Vehicle), building upon the success of its predecessor with enhanced practicality, technology, and refinement. Built on General Motors' Delta platform shared with the contemporary Astra H, the Zafira B featured more modern, aerodynamic styling while maintaining the boxy, high-roof silhouette required for maximum interior space. The defining feature remained the innovative Flex7 seating system allowing for various configurations from seven-seat people carrier to two-seat cargo hauler, with the third row of seats that could fold flat into the floor—a feature that continued to distinguish the Zafira from many competitors. Engine options varied by market and model year but typically included 1.6, 1.8, and 2.0-liter petrol units and 1.9-liter diesel engines, with power outputs ranging from approximately 105 to 200 horsepower in the performance-oriented OPC/VXR variants. Transmission choices included five and six-speed manual and four and six-speed automatic options. The interior featured a driver-oriented cockpit with a notably high-mounted gear lever, improved materials compared to the first generation, and enhanced technology including an available navigation system and panoramic glass roof. A significant innovation was the optional FlexFix integrated bicycle carrier that could slide out from the rear bumper—a unique feature in the segment. Safety features expanded to include up to six airbags, stability control, and active head restraints. A substantial facelift in 2009 brought updated styling with elements from Opel's then-new design language, interior refinements, and additional equipment options. The Zafira B successfully continued the model's formula of combining compact exterior dimensions with maximum interior versatility, achieving strong sales particularly in European markets where MPVs remained popular family vehicles before the subsequent shift toward crossover SUVs.
VauxhallOpel-Zafira-B.name: Zafira B

Volkswagen-Amarok.description: The first-generation Volkswagen Amarok represented the German automaker's entry into the global mid-size pickup truck market, combining traditional truck capability with Volkswagen's reputation for build quality and refinement. Featuring relatively clean, straightforward styling with a squared-off exterior emphasizing strength and functionality rather than aggressive design flourishes, the Amarok maintained VW's recognizable design language while adapting it to pickup truck proportions. Available in single cab and double cab body styles (the latter dominating sales in most markets), the Amarok was built on a conventional ladder frame chassis with leaf spring rear suspension. Engine options varied by market but centered around TDI diesel powerplants including 2.0-liter four-cylinder engines in single and bi-turbo configurations, producing between 122 and 180 horsepower, plus a 3.0-liter V6 TDI added in 2016 with up to 258 horsepower, though some markets received a 2.0-liter petrol option. Transmission choices included six-speed manual and eight-speed automatic, with rear-wheel drive, part-time four-wheel drive, or permanent all-wheel drive (4MOTION) available depending on variant. The interior quality surpassed most pickup competitors, featuring car-like design elements, superior materials, and available technology including touchscreen infotainment and comprehensive driver assistance systems on later models. Cargo capacity was class-competitive with a payload of up to 1,154 kg and towing capacity of up to 3,500 kg when properly equipped. A significant facelift in 2016 brought exterior styling updates, the aforementioned V6 diesel option, and enhanced technology features. The first-generation Amarok established Volkswagen in the global pickup segment by offering a more refined, premium-feeling alternative to mainstream competitors, particularly appealing to users who valued driving comfort alongside utility, though it faced challenges in some markets including the absence of a North American variant due to import restrictions and differing market requirements.
Volkswagen-Amarok.name: First Generation

Volkswagen-Amarok.description: The second-generation Volkswagen Amarok represents a significant evolution of VW's pickup offering, developed in partnership with Ford and sharing its underlying platform and much of its engineering with the latest Ford Ranger—though with distinctive Volkswagen design, technology, and tuning. Featuring more muscular, imposing styling with pronounced wheel arches, C-shaped LED signature lighting, and an overall more commanding presence, the new Amarok has grown in length and width compared to its predecessor while maintaining similar height. Available primarily as a double cab (with single cab offered in select markets), the Amarok continues with a conventional ladder frame chassis and leaf spring rear suspension optimized for load-carrying capability. Engine options vary by market but typically include Ford-sourced 2.0-liter four-cylinder and 3.0-liter V6 diesel units plus a 2.3-liter turbocharged petrol option in some regions, with power outputs ranging from approximately 170 to 250 horsepower depending on configuration. Transmission choices include six-speed manual and ten-speed automatic, with rear-wheel drive, part-time four-wheel drive, or permanent all-wheel drive available depending on variant. The interior features a distinctly Volkswagen design despite the Ford partnership, with a standard 10-inch or optional 12-inch portrait-oriented touchscreen infotainment system, digital instrument cluster on higher trims, and improved materials throughout. Practicality has been enhanced with increased payload capacity of up to 1,160 kg and maintained maximum towing capacity of 3,500 kg when properly equipped. Advanced driver assistance systems are comprehensive with up to 20 different systems available including adaptive cruise control, lane-keeping assist, and 360-degree cameras. The second-generation Amarok aims to build on its predecessor's reputation for combining workhorse capability with passenger car refinement, now with enhanced technology and capability through the Ford partnership, enabling Volkswagen to maintain a competitive offering in the global pickup segment while sharing development costs in this challenging market sector.
Volkswagen-Amarok.name: Second Generation

Volkswagen-Arteon.description: The Volkswagen Arteon was introduced in March 2017 at the Geneva Motor Show as a premium fastback sedan positioned above the Passat, effectively replacing the discontinued CC. Built on Volkswagen's modular MQB platform, the Arteon featured dramatic, coupe-like styling with a sloping roofline, frameless doors, and a wide horizontal front end. At launch in Europe, it offered three turbocharged engines: a 2.0L 280 PS TSI petrol and two diesel options with 150 PS and 240 PS. Additional engines including a 1.5L TSI Evo (150 PS) and both petrol and diesel 190 PS variants were introduced shortly after. The interior featured an 8-inch or optional 9.2-inch touchscreen infotainment system with available digital instrument cluster. The Arteon was built in Emden, Germany, and positioned as a more upmarket model than the CC it replaced. Front-wheel drive was standard with Volkswagen's 4MOTION all-wheel drive available on higher-powered models. Transmission options included six-speed manual and seven-speed dual-clutch automatic.
Volkswagen-Arteon.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Volkswagen-Arteon.description: The Arteon received a significant facelift in 2020, bringing substantial updates across exterior styling, interior technology, and model range. A new shooting brake (estate/wagon) body style was introduced alongside the existing liftback. The performance-oriented Arteon R debuted, featuring Volkswagen's 2.0L TSI turbocharged petrol engine producing 320 PS (235 kW) and 420 Nm of torque, paired with a seven-speed DSG gearbox and all-wheel drive with a rear torque-splitting differential. A plug-in hybrid e-Hybrid variant was also launched, combining a 1.4L petrol engine with an electric motor for a combined output of 215 PS and approximately 50 km electric-only range. Interior updates included a completely revised dashboard with touch-sensitive climate controls, new digital instrument panel, and enhanced infotainment touchscreen. Advanced driver assistance features including Travel Assist semi-automated driving capability were added. The facelifted model continued with updated powertrains including a 300 PS version for the US market. Production of the sedan body style ended in 2023, while the shooting brake continues through 2026.
Volkswagen-Arteon.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Volkswagen-Atlas.description: The original Volkswagen Atlas (marketed as Teramont outside North America) was introduced at the LA Auto Show in November 2016 for the 2018 model year. Built on Volkswagen's MQB platform, it was developed specifically for the North American market as Volkswagen's largest SUV offering, addressing the three-row midsize segment. The original design featured a bold rectangular grille, angular headlights, squared-off SUV styling with pronounced wheel arches. Available engines included a 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder (EA888) producing approximately 235 horsepower and a 3.6-liter VR6 generating 276 horsepower, both paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission and optional 4MOTION all-wheel drive. The seven-passenger interior featured a straightforward horizontal dashboard with a standard 6.5-inch or optional 8-inch touchscreen infotainment system, offering Android Auto and Apple CarPlay connectivity. The Atlas distinguished itself with genuine adult-sized third-row seating, accommodating passengers up to 6 feet tall. Cargo capacity reached up to 96.8 cubic feet with all rear seats folded.
Volkswagen-Atlas.name: First Generation

Volkswagen-Atlas.description: The 2021 facelift introduced at the Chicago Auto Show brought significant exterior styling updates aligned with the Atlas Cross Sport, including a new front end design, redesigned wheels, and new rear lights. The interior received a new steering wheel design while maintaining the practical horizontal dashboard layout. Technology features were enhanced with the availability of VW Digital Cockpit digital gauge cluster on higher trims. The engine lineup remained unchanged with the 2.0 TSI four-cylinder and 3.6 VR6 options both available throughout this period. This refresh helped maintain sales momentum, with the Atlas and Cross Sport combined reaching over 115,000 units sold in the US in 2021.
Volkswagen-Atlas.name: First Generation (2021 Facelift)

Volkswagen-Atlas.description: The 2024 model year refresh, revealed in February 2023, represented the most significant update to the first-generation Atlas. Exterior changes included a completely redesigned front clip and rear section with updated lighting elements and bumper designs. The interior received a heavily revised design featuring an electronic shift-by-wire gear selector, a 10.3-inch digital gauge cluster (Digital Cockpit), and a larger 12.0-inch touchscreen infotainment system. Perhaps most significantly, the VR6 engine was discontinued due to stricter EPA emissions standards, leaving the turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder as the sole engine option. Towing capacity remained unchanged at 5,000 pounds. The Peak Edition trim was introduced as a special edition for this model year.
Volkswagen-Atlas.name: First Generation (2024 Facelift)

Volkswagen-Atlas.description: The second-generation Volkswagen Atlas was launched in 2025, representing a complete redesign of the midsize crossover SUV. Built on an updated platform, the new generation features contemporary exterior styling with the latest Volkswagen design language. The vehicle continues to be produced at Volkswagen's Chattanooga, Tennessee plant for North American markets while maintaining the Teramont naming for other global markets including China. Details on powertrain options and specific feature content were being finalized at launch, with the new model representing Volkswagen's continued commitment to the three-row SUV segment in North America.
Volkswagen-Atlas.name: Second Generation

Volkswagen-Beetle.description: The original Volkswagen Beetle, officially the Volkswagen Type 1, represents one of the most iconic automobile designs in history. Conceived in the 1930s as the 'people's car' (Volkswagen in German) under Ferdinand Porsche's direction, the Beetle featured a distinctive rounded silhouette, rear-mounted air-cooled flat-four engine, and simple, robust engineering focused on affordability and reliability. Production began in 1938 but was largely interrupted by World War II, resuming in earnest after 1945 and continuing remarkably with only evolutionary changes until 2003, when the last original Beetle rolled off the production line in Mexico. The rear-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout with torsion bar suspension proved surprisingly adaptable, with engine displacement gradually increasing from 1.1 to 1.6 liters and power rising from 25 to 50 horsepower over the decades. The basic shape remained instantly recognizable throughout production, though countless detail changes occurred including larger windows, revised front and rear styling, improved safety features, and enhanced comfort amenities. The interior maintained a spartan, functional approach with a simple flat dashboard, basic instrumentation, and minimal luxury features even in later models. Beyond its practical transportation role, the Beetle became a cultural phenomenon, symbolizing everything from post-war German industrial recovery to 1960s counterculture to Disney's 'Herbie' films. Over 21.5 million units were produced during its 65-year production run—a testament to the fundamental soundness of its design and its global appeal across generations and social boundaries. This remarkable longevity established the Beetle as not merely a car but a cultural icon whose influence extended far beyond the automotive world.
Volkswagen-Beetle.name: Original Beetle (Type 1)

Volkswagen-Beetle.description: The Volkswagen New Beetle represented a modern reinterpretation of the iconic original, built on the Volkswagen Group A4 platform shared with the contemporary Golf and featuring front-engine, front-wheel-drive architecture rather than the rear-engine layout of its predecessor. Styling was deliberately retro-futuristic, maintaining the distinctive rounded silhouette, circular headlights, and separate fenders of the original Beetle but with modern proportions including a dramatically arched roofline, creating a cheerful, nostalgic appearance that capitalized on the strong emotional connection many consumers had with the original model. Engine options varied by market but typically included a range of gasoline four-cylinders from 1.4 to 2.5-liters plus diesel options in some regions, with power outputs ranging from approximately 75 to 170 horsepower in the turbocharged variants. Transmission choices included five and six-speed manuals and four and six-speed automatics. The interior featured a playful design with a dashboard-mounted flower vase, circular theme elements, and body-colored panels, though with significantly more comfort and features than the spartan original Beetle, including modern amenities such as air conditioning, power accessories, and later navigation and premium audio options. A convertible variant introduced in 2003 further expanded the model's appeal by recalling the popular Cabriolet version of the original. Special editions including the Turbo S, RSi (in Europe), and various appearance packages helped maintain interest throughout the production run. The New Beetle succeeded in its primary mission of creating a distinctive, emotionally appealing model that strengthened Volkswagen's brand image, particularly in the crucial North American market, though it was always more of a style statement than a volume seller, appealing primarily to those drawn to its unique blend of nostalgia and modern features rather than buyers seeking maximum practicality or performance for their money.
Volkswagen-Beetle.name: New Beetle (A4)

Volkswagen-Beetle.description: The final generation of the Volkswagen Beetle (dropping the 'New' prefix) was built on the company's A5 (PQ35) platform shared with the Golf VI, featuring a lower, wider stance and a flatter roofline than its predecessor, creating a more masculine, sporty appearance that moved away from the 'cute' aesthetic of the New Beetle toward a design more closely resembling the proportions of the original Type 1. Available in both hardtop and convertible body styles, this generation aimed to broaden the Beetle's appeal beyond the predominantly female buyer base of the previous model. Engine options varied by market but typically included 1.2, 1.4, 1.8, and 2.0-liter turbocharged petrol units and 1.6 and 2.0-liter diesel options in some regions, with power outputs ranging from approximately 105 to 220 horsepower in the performance-oriented R-Line and GSR variants. Transmission choices included five and six-speed manuals and six and seven-speed dual-clutch automatics. The interior maintained distinctive Beetle elements including body-colored dashboard panels and circular themes but adopted a more conventional layout with higher quality materials and enhanced technology including a standard infotainment system, available navigation, and comprehensive connectivity options on later models. Special editions were numerous throughout the production run, including the Dune with raised ride height and off-road styling cues, the performance-focused GSR with its distinctive yellow and black color scheme recalling a 1970s special edition, and various decade-themed models celebrating design elements from the 1950s, 60s, and 70s. Despite these efforts to reinvigorate interest in the model, the Beetle faced declining sales as consumer preferences shifted increasingly toward SUVs and crossovers, leading Volkswagen to announce the end of production in 2019 with no direct replacement planned. This final chapter of the Beetle story marked the end of one of the most recognizable automotive nameplates in history, concluding a legacy that spanned more than eight decades and three distinct generations.
Volkswagen-Beetle.name: Beetle (A5)

Volkswagen-CC.description: The Volkswagen CC, initially sold as the Passat CC, is a premium four-door coupé derivative of the Passat sedan, featuring more stylish, swooping bodywork with frameless doors and a lower, sleeker roofline. Built on the same PQ46 platform as the contemporary Passat B6, the CC shared much of its mechanical architecture while offering a distinctly more upscale appearance and positioning.
