Seven seats came as standard. Engine lineup included updated 1.8T (150 hp), 2.0 (115 hp), 2.8 VR6 (204 hp), and 1.9 TDI diesel engines (100-130 hp). Some 1.9 TDI variants offered 4motion all-wheel drive with 6-speed manual transmission. Won Auto Express New Car Honours – Best MPV in 2000. The cooperation between Volkswagen and Ford ended in 2006, with Ford going alone to build the second generation Galaxy.
Volkswagen-Sharan.name: First Generation Mark 1A/Phase 1.5 (Type 7M)

Volkswagen-Sharan.description: A minor cosmetic facelift was implemented in September 2003 for model year 2004, primarily changing the grille and tail lights. More standard equipment was added including air conditioning and curtain side airbags. Ford introduced an independently developed new Galaxy in 2006, not based on Sharan/Alhambra designs. The first generation Sharan continued production until August 2010 at the AutoEuropa plant in Portugal. New engines included 2.0 TDI (136-140 hp). A BlueMotion variant was introduced in 2008 with lower CO2 emissions (159g/km). An LPG version launched in June 2006 with a flexible fuel engine working with petrol or autogas. Total production reached nearly 670,000 units across all first generation variants, making it one of the longest-running car models in Europe.
Volkswagen-Sharan.name: First Generation Mark 1B/Phase 1.75 (Type 7M)

Volkswagen-Sharan.description: The second-generation Volkswagen Sharan was launched at the 2010 Geneva Motor Show, based on the Volkswagen Passat B7 platform. Unlike its predecessor, this was developed independently by Volkswagen rather than as a joint venture with Ford. It grew longer (by 22mm), wider (by 92mm) and lower (by 22mm) with a wheelbase lengthened by 124mm. Weight was reduced by up to 75kg compared to the first generation. The most significant change was the adoption of sliding rear doors as standard on both sides. Initial engine range comprised 1.4-litre TSI (148 hp) and 2.0-litre TSI (197 hp) petrol options, plus two 2.0-litre TDI diesel engines rated at 115 and 140 hp. Paired with manual or DSG dual-clutch automatic transmissions driving the front wheels. The interior featured Volkswagen's 'EasyFold' seating system allowing all five rear seats to fold flat into the floor.
Volkswagen-Sharan.name: Second Generation Pre-Facelift (Type 7N)

Volkswagen-Sharan.description: A facelifted Sharan was unveiled at the 2015 Geneva Motor Show with new electronic systems and engines with reduced fuel consumption. The 2.0 litre TSI engine was upgraded to produce 217-220 hp and paired with the same six-speed direct-shift gearbox as the 2016 Golf GTI. The Sharan continued to be built at the AutoEuropa factory in Portugal, remaining popular for its unmatched interior flexibility and car-like driving dynamics. Production continued in Europe despite the market shift toward SUVs and crossovers. The Sharan was discontinued in the UK in 2021 but continued elsewhere in Europe until October 2022 when production finally ended after more than a decade of the second generation model. No direct replacement was planned as the market moved toward crossovers and SUVs like the Volkswagen Tiguan.
Volkswagen-Sharan.name: Second Generation Facelift (Type 7N)

Volkswagen-T-Cross.description: The Volkswagen T-Cross is the brand's smallest SUV, sitting below the T-Roc in the lineup. Launched in 2018, this subcompact crossover is built on the MQB A0 platform shared with the Polo. The T-Cross features distinctive styling with a wide grille, optional two-tone paint schemes, and a full-width reflector bar at the rear. Inside, it offers a practical cabin with sliding rear seats that can increase either passenger legroom or cargo space as needed. The dashboard houses Volkswagen's infotainment system with an 8-inch touchscreen on most models. Powertrain options typically include a range of efficient TSI petrol and TDI diesel engines, with power outputs ranging from approximately 95 to 150 horsepower, paired with either manual or DSG automatic transmissions. The T-Cross is front-wheel drive only, focusing on urban practicality rather than off-road capability. Safety features are comprehensive, earning it a five-star Euro NCAP rating, with available driver assistance systems including automatic emergency braking and lane-keeping assist.
Volkswagen-T-Cross.name: First Generation

Volkswagen-T-Roc.description: The first generation Volkswagen T-Roc is a subcompact crossover SUV built on the Volkswagen Group MQB A1 platform. Unveiled at the 2017 Frankfurt Motor Show and launched in November 2017, it is positioned between the Tiguan and T-Cross. The model features distinctive coupe-like styling with a sloping roofline, bold character lines, and available two-tone paint schemes. A high-performance T-Roc R variant was launched in February 2019, featuring a 2.0-liter turbocharged engine producing 300 horsepower with 4Motion all-wheel drive. A convertible T-Roc Cabriolet debuted in April 2020 as VW's first convertible SUV, featuring a fabric roof that opens/closes at speeds up to 30 km/h. The T-Roc Cabriolet is assembled at Volkswagen's Osnabrück plant in Germany.
Volkswagen-T-Roc.name: First Generation (A1)

Volkswagen-T-Roc.description: The T-Roc received a significant facelift unveiled in November 2021, featuring updated exterior styling with revised front and rear bumpers, new headlights, and an improved interior with better quality materials and a new infotainment system. The facelift also introduced enhanced technology features and updated powertrains including the new 1.5-litre TSI Evo2 engine. The cabriolet variant also received the facelift updates. This updated model continued production until the launch of the second generation in 2025.
Volkswagen-T-Roc.name: First Generation Facelift (A1)

Volkswagen-T-Roc.description: The second-generation Volkswagen T-Roc is built on the MQB Evo platform, which it shares with the Golf Mk8.5. The production version was officially presented on August 27, 2025, featuring updated styling, improved technology, and enhanced efficiency compared to its predecessor. The new generation continues Volkswagen's commitment to the compact crossover segment while offering more advanced features and improved performance.
Volkswagen-T-Roc.name: Second Generation (A2)

Volkswagen-T5.description: The Volkswagen Transporter T5 launched on October 6, 2002, with full production beginning April 25, 2003, replacing the T4. This fifth generation marked a significant evolution with front-mounted engines and more car-like handling while maintaining the versatility of a commercial vehicle. Available in over 100 configurations including panel van, kombi, caravelle, multivan, and the California campervan. Engine options included 2.0L and 3.2L VR6 petrol engines, 1.9L TDI, and 2.5L TDI diesel engines with power outputs from 85 to 235 horsepower. Transmission options included 5-speed and 6-speed manual, and 6-speed automatic, with front-wheel drive or 4MOTION all-wheel drive. The pre-facelift model featured a distinctive front grille design and was marketed across Europe, Asia, and Latin America but not in the US due to the 'chicken tax' tariff.
Volkswagen-T5.name: First Generation Pre-Facelift (2003-2009)

Volkswagen-T5.description: The facelifted T5 launched in late 2009/2010 featuring significant visual and technical updates. Exterior changes included a revised front grille, updated headlights with optional Bi-Xenon units with LED daytime running lights, and refreshed bumper designs. The major technical advancement was the introduction of a world-first 7-speed Direct-Shift Gearbox (DSG) for light commercial vehicles. All engines were replaced with new 2.0L inline-four-cylinder designs featuring common rail fuel injection, replacing the previous Pumpe Düse unit injector system. New safety and technology features included Side Lane Assist blind spot monitoring, tyre pressure monitoring, touchscreen Radio Navigation System (RNS), and a reversing camera. The facelifted T5 continued to be available in all variants including the California campervan, maintaining its reputation for quality, durability, and versatility until being replaced by the T6 in 2015.
Volkswagen-T5.name: First Generation Facelift (2010-2015)

Volkswagen-Taigo.description: The Volkswagen Taigo is essentially a coupe-SUV version of the Volkswagen T-Cross, introduced to European markets in 2021 (previously launched in South America as the Nivus in 2020). Built on the MQB A0 platform, the Taigo features a distinctive sloping roofline that differentiates it from its more upright T-Cross sibling. Despite the sportier silhouette, it maintains reasonable rear headroom and cargo space. The front fascia incorporates LED headlights connected by a light bar on higher trims, while the interior features Volkswagen's digital cockpit and infotainment system with a standard 8-inch or optional 9.2-inch touchscreen. Powertrain options include 1.0-liter three-cylinder and 1.5-liter four-cylinder TSI petrol engines, with power outputs ranging from approximately 95 to 150 horsepower, paired with manual or DSG automatic transmissions. The Taigo is front-wheel drive only, focusing on style and on-road dynamics rather than off-road capability. Standard and available safety features include lane-keeping assist, adaptive cruise control, and autonomous emergency braking. The Taigo represents Volkswagen's entry into the compact coupe-SUV segment, appealing to style-conscious buyers wanting something more distinctive than a conventional crossover.
Volkswagen-Taigo.name: First Generation

Volkswagen-Taos.description: The Volkswagen Taos is a compact crossover SUV that debuted in October 2020 for the North American market as a 2022 model year vehicle. Built on the Volkswagen Group MQB A1 platform, it is positioned below the Tiguan in the lineup and serves as an indirect replacement for the discontinued Golf. For the North American market, power comes from a 1.5-liter turbocharged four-cylinder TSI Evo engine producing 158 horsepower and 184 lb-ft of torque at 1,750 rpm. Front-wheel-drive models feature an 8-speed automatic transmission, while the 4Motion all-wheel drive variants use a 7-speed DSG dual-clutch transmission. The Mexican-built Taos features Volkswagen's Digital Cockpit system with a reconfigurable 12.3-inch display, MIB3 infotainment with either a 6.5-inch or 8.0-inch touchscreen, and available wireless charging. Standard safety features include forward collision warning, autonomous emergency braking, blind-spot monitoring, and adaptive cruise control. The Taos offers over 28 cubic feet of cargo space behind the rear seats and is available in S, SE, and SEL trim levels.
Volkswagen-Taos.name: First Generation

Volkswagen-Taos.description: For the 2025 model year, the Volkswagen Taos received a significant mid-cycle refresh. The exterior features updated bodywork including revised front and rear bumpers, new headlights, and a restyled grille. The 1.5-liter turbocharged engine has been revised and now produces 174 horsepower while maintaining 184 lb-ft of torque. Most notably, the 7-speed DSG transmission has been replaced with an 8-speed automatic transmission now standard across all models, including both front-wheel-drive and all-wheel-drive variants. The interior continues to feature the Digital Cockpit display and MIB3 infotainment system with available 8.0-inch touchscreen. The refreshed Taos maintains its position as the entry-level compact SUV in Volkswagen's North American lineup, slotting below the Tiguan.
Volkswagen-Taos.name: First Generation (2025 Facelift)

Volkswagen-Tiguan.description: The first-generation Volkswagen Tiguan was introduced as the brand's entry into the compact SUV segment. Built on the PQ46 platform (not PQ35 as commonly believed), it combined the practicality of an SUV with car-like handling characteristics. The exterior featured Volkswagen's then-current design language with a squared-off appearance and distinctive grille. Engine options varied by market but generally included various TSI petrol and TDI diesel engines ranging from 1.4 to 2.0 liters, with power outputs from approximately 120 to 200 horsepower. Transmission options included manual and automatic, with both front-wheel drive and 4MOTION all-wheel drive configurations available. The interior offered a functional, well-built cabin with high-quality materials for its class. A facelift in 2012 updated the styling to align with Volkswagen's newer models, featuring revised front and rear fascias, bolder headlights, and updated interior trim. The first-generation Tiguan proved popular globally, establishing Volkswagen as a competitor in the rapidly growing compact SUV segment. Production continued until 2018 globally, and until 2020 in China where it was sold as the Tiguan Silk Road.
Volkswagen-Tiguan.name: First Generation

Volkswagen-Tiguan.description: The second-generation Tiguan represented a significant evolution, growing in size and moving upmarket. Built on Volkswagen's modular MQB A2 platform, it offered both standard short-wheelbase and long-wheelbase (sold as Tiguan Allspace or Tiguan L depending on market) versions, with the latter providing optional third-row seating. The design featured sharper lines, a wider stance, and more premium detailing than its predecessor. Engine options again varied by market but typically included 1.4 to 2.0-liter TSI petrol and TDI diesel engines, with power ranging from approximately 125 to 245 horsepower. Most markets received a choice of manual or DSG dual-clutch automatic transmissions and front or 4MOTION all-wheel drive. The interior offered significant improvements in material quality, technology, and space, featuring available digital instrumentation, larger infotainment screens, and enhanced driver assistance systems. A facelift in 2020 brought styling updates including new headlamps, radiator grille, and a new multifunction digital steering wheel, along with updated MIB3 infotainment software and the IQ.Drive safety suite. Variants include the performance-oriented Tiguan R (2020+) and the coupe-style Tiguan X (China, 2020+). This generation successfully positioned the Tiguan as one of Volkswagen's global best-sellers and the best-selling SUV in Europe.
Volkswagen-Tiguan.name: Second Generation

Volkswagen-Tiguan.description: The third-generation Tiguan, unveiled in June 2023 and launched in 2024 for the 2024 model year, builds upon the success of its predecessor while incorporating Volkswagen's latest design language and technology. Based on the MQB Evo platform, it maintains similar dimensions to the second generation but features a more streamlined, aerodynamic exterior with a sloping hood, sleeker LED lighting elements, and a more sophisticated overall appearance. The interior represents a significant upgrade with a minimalist dashboard dominated by a standard 12.9-inch or optional 15-inch central touchscreen and a 10.25-inch digital instrument cluster, with most physical buttons replaced by touch surfaces. Powertrain options include upgraded versions of familiar TSI and TDI engines, plus new plug-in hybrid options with electric ranges of up to 100 kilometers. Advanced driver assistance systems have been expanded to include Travel Assist with swarm data capabilities and improved automated parking features. In China, this generation is marketed as the Tiguan L Pro with longer wheelbase and body length. In North America, it's nearly identical to the Chinese-market Tayron L. The third-generation Tiguan aims to maintain its position as a cornerstone of Volkswagen's global lineup by offering premium technology and features in a versatile compact SUV package.
Volkswagen-Tiguan.name: Third Generation

Volkswagen-Touareg.description: The first-generation Volkswagen Touareg was developed as a joint project with Porsche (Cayenne) and Audi (Q7), establishing Volkswagen's entry into the luxury SUV segment. Launched in 2002, it featured a robust body-on-frame construction with unibody elements, providing both off-road capability and on-road comfort. The exterior design was characterized by a bold front end, flared wheel arches, and an overall imposing presence. Engine options were extensive, ranging from V6 and V8 petrol and diesel engines to a flagship W12 petrol and innovative V10 TDI diesel, with power outputs spanning from approximately 220 to 450 horsepower. All models featured permanent all-wheel drive and a sophisticated air suspension system on higher trims. The interior offered premium materials, including wood and aluminum accents, with a focus on luxury and comfort. A facelift in 2007 brought updated styling, improved electronics, and refined powertrains. The first-generation Touareg established itself as a technically advanced luxury SUV with genuine off-road capabilities, distinguishing it from many competitors.
Volkswagen-Touareg.name: First Generation

Volkswagen-Touareg.description: The second-generation Touareg debuted at the 2010 Geneva Motor Show and began production for the 2011 model year. Built on the Volkswagen Group PL71 platform shared with the Porsche Cayenne and Audi Q7, it was lighter yet larger than its predecessor, with an emphasis on improved efficiency and on-road dynamics without sacrificing off-road capability. The exterior featured more streamlined styling with a prominent chrome grille integrated with the headlights. Engine options were streamlined but still included various V6 and V8 petrol and diesel options, with the addition of a hybrid variant combining a supercharged V6 petrol engine with an electric motor. All models featured 4MOTION all-wheel drive and either traditional steel spring suspension or advanced air suspension on higher trims. The interior saw significant upgrades in design, materials, and technology, including a larger infotainment screen and enhanced driver assistance systems. A facelift in 2014 brought subtle styling updates and improved efficiency. This generation further refined the Touareg's position as Volkswagen's flagship SUV, offering luxury features and technology comparable to premium competitors at a relatively more accessible price point.
Volkswagen-Touareg.name: Second Generation

Volkswagen-Touareg.description: The third-generation Touareg, introduced in 2018 as a 2019 model, represents Volkswagen's most advanced and luxurious SUV to date. Built on the Volkswagen Group MLB Evo platform shared with premium SUVs like the Audi Q7 and Porsche Cayenne, it features a more elegant, sophisticated design with a wider grille, sleeker LED lighting, and a more dynamic profile. Despite being larger than its predecessor, extensive use of aluminum in the body structure has reduced weight. Engine options vary by market but typically include V6 and V8 TDI diesel engines, V6 TSI petrol engines, and a plug-in hybrid variant combining a V6 petrol engine with an electric motor. All versions feature 4MOTION all-wheel drive and advanced air suspension with electronic damping control. The interior represents a quantum leap forward with the optional Innovision Cockpit, which combines a 15-inch central touchscreen with a 12-inch digital instrument cluster under a single glass panel. Available luxury and technology features include night vision, head-up display, four-wheel steering, active roll stabilization, and semi-autonomous driving capabilities. This generation positions the Touareg as a true luxury SUV that rivals premium brands in technology and refinement while maintaining Volkswagen's characteristic understated elegance.
Volkswagen-Touareg.name: Third Generation

Volkswagen-Touran.description: The first-generation Volkswagen Touran was introduced as a compact MPV (multi-purpose vehicle) built on the Golf's PQ35 platform. Launched in 2003, it offered generous interior space with three rows of seating in a relatively compact footprint. The exterior featured a practical, boxy design prioritizing interior volume over style. Engine options typically included a range of TSI petrol and TDI diesel engines, with power outputs ranging from approximately 100 to 170 horsepower, paired with manual or automatic transmissions. The interior's highlight was its flexible seating system, featuring individually folding and removable second and third-row seats. A facelift in 2006 updated the styling with revised front and rear ends, along with interior refinements. A second update in 2010 aligned the front styling with the Golf VI, including new features like DCC adaptive suspension and improved Park Assist. The first-generation Touran established itself as a practical family vehicle, particularly popular in Europe.
Volkswagen-Touran.name: First Generation

Volkswagen-Touran.description: The second-generation Touran was introduced at the 2015 Geneva Motor Show, built on Volkswagen's modern MQB platform shared with the Golf VII. The exterior features more sophisticated styling with sharper character lines, a prominent grille, and available LED lighting, while maintaining the practical MPV silhouette. Engine options focus on efficiency, with various TSI petrol and TDI diesel engines offering improved fuel economy. The interior provides a significant upgrade in design, materials, and technology, featuring a modern dashboard with infotainment touchscreen, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto compatibility, and enhanced connectivity options. The seating system remains highly flexible with up to 47 configurations possible. Safety systems were comprehensively upgraded with driver assistance features including autonomous emergency braking, adaptive cruise control, and lane-keeping assist. This generation successfully modernized the Touran concept while maintaining its practical, family-friendly focus.
Volkswagen-Touran.name: Second Generation

Volkswagen-Up.description: The Volkswagen Up (stylized as 'up!') is a city car produced from 2011 to 2023 by the Volkswagen Group. Built on the NSF (New Small Family) platform, it features a space-efficient design with a length of just 3.54 meters while maximizing interior space through a 2.42-meter wheelbase and wheels pushed to the corners. Initially available as a three-door, a five-door variant was added in 2012. The exterior design is characterized by clean, simple lines with a distinctive glass tailgate and minimalist detailing. Engine options center around small, efficient petrol engines, primarily 1.0-liter three-cylinder units with power outputs ranging from 60 to 90 horsepower, with a turbocharged TSI variant producing 115 hp. A fully electric e-Up was introduced in 2013, offering zero-emission urban mobility. The interior features a surprisingly spacious cabin for its exterior dimensions, with a straightforward dashboard design, and clever storage solutions. A significant facelift in 2016 updated the styling, technology, and powertrains. The Up GTI performance variant with 115 horsepower arrived in January 2018. The Up was produced at Volkswagen's Bratislava Plant in Slovakia from December 2011 to October 2023. Production also occurred in Brazil from February 2014 to 2021. The Up shares its platform with the Škoda Citigo and SEAT Mii, which are rebadged variants. The vehicle was discontinued in various markets at different times, including Europe and Latin America by 2023.
Volkswagen-Up.name: First Generation

Volkswagen-Virtus.description: The Volkswagen Virtus is a subcompact sedan primarily designed for emerging markets, including South America, India, and parts of Asia. Introduced in 2018, it's essentially the sedan version of the sixth-generation Polo, built on Volkswagen's MQB A0 platform. The exterior features a clean, sophisticated design with a flowing roofline that transitions smoothly into a short deck lid, giving it more attractive proportions than many sedan derivatives of hatchbacks. The front end shares styling cues with the Polo, while the rear features distinctive wraparound taillights. Engine options vary by market but typically include 1.0-liter three-cylinder engines in naturally aspirated and turbocharged forms, plus a 1.6-liter naturally aspirated four-cylinder in some regions, with power outputs ranging from approximately 85 to 115 horsepower. Transmission options generally include 5 or 6-speed manuals and 6-speed automatics or 6-speed DSG dual-clutch units. The interior is largely shared with the Polo, featuring a modern dashboard design centered around a touchscreen infotainment system, with digital instrumentation available on higher trims. A significant selling point is the spacious cabin and class-leading trunk space, making it practical as a family vehicle despite its compact exterior dimensions. In 2022, an updated version was introduced in some markets with refreshed styling and enhanced technology features. The Virtus has been particularly successful in Brazil and India, where it competes in the premium subcompact sedan segment.
Volkswagen-Virtus.name: First Generation

Volkswagen-e-Golf.description: The original Volkswagen e-Golf represented the brand's first mainstream all-electric passenger vehicle, based on the seventh-generation Golf (MQB platform). Powered by an 85 kW (115 hp) electric motor driving the front wheels and a 24.2 kWh lithium-ion battery providing approximately 83 miles of EPA-rated range, the e-Golf was visually nearly identical to the standard Golf apart from model-specific LED daytime running lights, subtle blue accents, unique wheels, and the absence of exhaust pipes. DC fast charging capability was available at 40 kW via the Combined Charging System (CCS), allowing an 80% charge in approximately 30 minutes. The interior maintained the high-quality design and materials of the standard Golf while adding electric-specific displays, blue accent stitching, and a modified instrument cluster showing power flow, regenerative braking levels, and remaining range. Regenerative braking could be adjusted through multiple levels using the shift paddles. Standard features included LED headlights, heated seats, and Car-Net connected services with specific EV functions like remote charging control and climate pre-conditioning. Production began in March 2014 for European markets, with U.S. sales starting in November 2014 for the 2015 model year.
Volkswagen-e-Golf.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Volkswagen-e-Golf.description: The facelifted e-Golf (Mk7.5) received significant updates including a larger 35.8 kWh lithium-ion battery increasing EPA-rated range to approximately 125 miles, and a more powerful 100 kW (134 hp) electric motor improving acceleration from 0-60 mph to approximately 9.6 seconds. The onboard charger was upgraded to accept AC power at up to 7.2 kW as standard, while DC fast charging capability was made standard on higher trims. Visually, the facelift featured updated headlights with full LED technology as standard across the range, revised front and rear bumpers, and an enlarged infotainment touchscreen with enhanced connectivity options. The e-Golf was the last hatchback version of the Golf Mk7 produced in Europe, with production continuing until late December 2020 due to high demand, well after other powertrain variants which were discontinued in 2019. The successor ID.3 took over the e-Golf's Transparent Factory production line in Dresden starting at the end of January 2021.
Volkswagen-e-Golf.name: First Generation (Mk7.5 Facelift)

Volvo-C30.description: The Volvo C30 was a three-door, front-engine, front-wheel-drive premium compact hatchback manufactured by Volvo Cars from 2006 to 2013. This pre-facelift model was built on the Ford C1/Volvo P1 platform shared with the S40 sedan, V50 wagon, and C70. The C30 drew styling inspiration from the classic Volvo P1800 ES with its distinctive frameless glass rear hatch and four individual seats. Engine options varied by market, including four and five-cylinder petrol and diesel engines, with power ranging from approximately 100 horsepower in the 1.6L engines to 230 horsepower in the T5 turbo variant. The interior featured Volvo's floating center console design, premium materials, and Scandinavian minimalism aesthetic. Throughout its production, the C30 positioned itself as a stylish, safety-focused premium hatchback alternative to competitors like the Audi A3 and BMW 1 Series.
Volvo-C30.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Volvo-C30.description: The Volvo C30 received a significant facelift in early 2010 that redesigned the front fascia with a new grille and bumper, giving it a more modern appearance. New interior color combinations like Espresso/Blond were introduced, and optional features like an advanced start/stop function became available. The C30 continued to be built on the Ford C1/Volvo P1 platform with the same range of four and five-cylinder petrol and diesel engines. Despite winning the IIHS Top Safety Pick award, its unusual positioning as a premium three-door hatchback with limited practicality meant it remained a niche product. Production ended in 2013 without a direct replacement, though its design philosophy influenced later models including the C40 electric crossover coupe.
Volvo-C30.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Volvo-EX30.description: The Volvo EX30 is Volvo's smallest electric SUV, introduced in 2023 as part of the brand's ambitious electrification strategy. Built on Geely's Sustainable Experience Architecture (SEA2), the same platform underpinning the Smart #1 and Zeekr X, it combines Volvo's Scandinavian design philosophy with compact dimensions and full electric power. The exterior features a distinctive interpretation of Volvo's design language, including Thor's Hammer headlights, a closed-off grille, and a boxy yet modern silhouette, measuring just over 4.2 meters in length. The EX30 is offered with multiple powertrain options, including single-motor rear-wheel drive variants with either a 51 kWh LFP battery (approximately 344 km WLTP range) or a 69 kWh NMC battery (approximately 480 km WLTP range), and a dual-motor all-wheel drive performance version producing around 428 horsepower with a 0-100 km/h time of 3.6 seconds, making it the fastest accelerating Volvo ever made. The interior presents a minimalist approach with a single 12.3-inch central touchscreen controlling most functions, no traditional instrument cluster, and a focus on sustainable materials including recycled plastics, denim, flax, and wool blend fabrics. Notable features include a Harman Kardon audio system, advanced driver assistance systems with semi-autonomous lane-changing capability, and bidirectional charging capability on some variants. The EX30 represents Volvo's entry point into pure electric mobility, offering the safety, quality, and design expected from the brand in a more compact and accessible package, with a claimed carbon footprint that's the lowest of any Volvo vehicle to date. Production began in China in 2023, with European production starting in Ghent, Belgium in 2025.
Volvo-EX30.name: First Generation

Volvo-S40.description: The first-generation Volvo S40 was developed jointly with Mitsubishi and shared its platform with the Mitsubishi Carisma. Built at the Nedcar factory in Born, Netherlands, it replaced the 440/460 series as Volvo's entry into the compact executive car segment. The S40 (saloon) and V40 (estate) were introduced in 1995, named after Volvo's naming convention conflict with Audi's S4. The design featured Peter Horbury's signature styling—characteristically Volvo but with softer, more rounded lines than previous models. Power came from four-cylinder engines including 1.6L, 1.8L, and 2.0L petrol options plus a Renault-sourced 1.9L turbodiesel. The T4 high-performance variant offered up to 200 horsepower. Safety was paramount with dual front airbags, SIPS (Side Impact Protection System), and curtain airbags. A major facelift in 2000 (Phase II) brought improved engine management, diesel direct injection, larger brakes, revised suspension, and updated styling. Another update in late 2002 introduced the distinctive 'egg crate' grille, new steering wheel, and enhanced safety features. The S40 was the first Volvo to earn a four-star Euro-NCAP safety rating and achieved notable motorsport success, including Rickard Rydell's 1998 BTCC championship.
Volvo-S40.name: First Generation

Volvo-S40.description: The second-generation Volvo S40 marked a complete redesign using the Volvo P1 platform (also used by Ford Focus and Mazda3), built at Volvo's Ghent, Belgium factory. Unveiled at the September 2003 Frankfurt Motor Show with production starting October 2003, it went on sale as a '2004.5' model year vehicle. The design featured a more aerodynamic and modern aesthetic while maintaining Volvo's identity, with designer Fedde Talsma leading the exterior development. Inside, the innovative 'floating' center console became a Volvo signature, creating clever storage space. Engine choices expanded to include five-cylinder units alongside four-cylinders—the T5 turbocharged five-cylinder produced up to 227 horsepower. Front-wheel drive was standard, with optional all-wheel drive on certain variants. The S40 received a facelift in April 2007 featuring improved audio systems, increased storage, emergency brake lights, and optional active bi-xenon headlights and BLIS blind-spot monitoring. Production ended in May 2012, replaced by the V40 hatchback. Total production across both generations reached 602,910 units. The S40 earned the 2005 Canadian Car of the Year Best New Sport Compact and South African Car of the Year awards.
Volvo-S40.name: Second Generation

Volvo-S60.description: The first-generation Volvo S60 was a compact executive sedan introduced to replace the S70. Built on Volvo's P2 platform, it featured a swooping, coupe-like roofline that distinguished it from the boxier Volvos of the past. This generation offered a range of five-cylinder engines, from 2.4-liter naturally aspirated units to high-performance turbocharged T5 and R variants, the latter producing up to 300 horsepower. The interior maintained Volvo's reputation for excellent ergonomics and comfort, with exceptionally supportive seats. Safety equipment was comprehensive, including Volvo's Side Impact Protection System, Whiplash Protection System, and multiple airbags. A significant facelift in 2004 updated the exterior styling, improved the interior, and introduced new technology features. The sporty S60 R, produced from 2003 to 2007, featured a sport-tuned chassis with Volvo's Four-C active suspension, Brembo brakes, and all-wheel drive. The first-generation S60 successfully blended traditional Volvo values with more dynamic styling and driving characteristics.
Volvo-S60.name: First Generation

Volvo-S60.description: The second-generation S60 continued Volvo's evolution toward more dynamic and emotional design while retaining the brand's core values of safety and practicality. Built on Ford's EUCD platform (later owned by Geely after their acquisition of Volvo), the S60 featured sculpted bodywork and a more aggressive stance. Engine options varied by market but included various four, five, and six-cylinder petrol and diesel engines, with power outputs ranging from approximately 150 to 350 horsepower in the high-performance Polestar models. The interior showcased Volvo's Scandinavian design aesthetic with a floating center console, high-quality materials, and intuitive controls. This generation marked a significant advancement in safety technology, introducing features like Pedestrian Detection with full auto brake, City Safety collision avoidance, and various driver assistance systems. A facelift in 2013 refreshed the styling and updated the technology, while a more comprehensive update in 2016 introduced new Drive-E four-cylinder engines focused on efficiency. The second-generation S60 elevated Volvo's position in the premium sedan segment, offering a distinctive alternative to German competitors with a focus on safety, comfort, and increasingly, performance.
Volvo-S60.name: Second Generation

Volvo-S60.description: The third-generation S60 represents Volvo's thoroughly modern take on the premium sports sedan, built on the company's Scalable Product Architecture (SPA) shared with the V60, XC60, and larger 90-series models. Notably, it became the first Volvo to be manufactured in the United States at the company's South Carolina plant. The exterior design features clean, minimalist lines with distinctive Thor's Hammer LED headlights and a confident stance. A significant departure from previous generations is the exclusive use of four-cylinder engines across the range, with various levels of electrification. Options include turbocharged T5, turbo- and supercharged T6, and plug-in hybrid T8 twin-engine variants with the latter producing over 400 horsepower in Polestar Engineered form. The interior exemplifies Scandinavian luxury with premium materials, a tablet-style Sensus infotainment system, and minimal physical buttons. Safety and driver assistance technology reached new heights with Pilot Assist semi-autonomous driving capabilities, cross-traffic alert with autobrake, and numerous other advanced features. Production ended in June 2024 in the US, with sales ending in late 2024 in North America and Europe, though production continued in China for Asian markets. The third-generation S60 has further refined Volvo's unique position in the market, offering distinctive design, progressive electrification technology, and class-leading safety in the competitive premium sedan segment.
Volvo-S60.name: Third Generation

Volvo-S70.description: The Volvo S70 was essentially a significantly facelifted and renamed continuation of the Volvo 850 sedan, introduced in late 1996 as a 1997 model. While sharing the same core platform and mechanical components with the 850, the S70 featured smoother, more rounded exterior styling that moved away from the distinctly boxy design of its predecessor. The interior was also comprehensively redesigned with improved ergonomics, updated materials, and enhanced safety features. Powertrains carried over from the 850, consisting of various five-cylinder engines in naturally aspirated and turbocharged forms, with outputs ranging from approximately 126 to 250 horsepower. Transmission options included 5-speed manual and 4-speed automatic gearboxes, with front-wheel drive standard and all-wheel drive available on certain turbo models (badged as S70 AWD). The S70 maintained Volvo's reputation for safety innovation, featuring the Side Impact Protection System (SIPS), Whiplash Protection System (WHIPS), and side airbags. Despite its relatively short production run before being replaced by the S60, the S70 represented an important transitional model that helped modernize Volvo's design language while maintaining the brand's core values of safety, durability, and practicality.
Volvo-S70.name: First Generation

Volvo-S90.description: The modern Volvo S90, introduced in 2016, represents Volvo's flagship luxury sedan and a key component of the brand's upmarket repositioning under Geely ownership. Built on the Scalable Product Architecture (SPA) platform shared with the XC90 SUV and V90 wagon, the S90 features distinctive Scandinavian design with clean lines, elegant proportions, and signature Thor's Hammer LED headlights. The interior showcases premium materials including wood, leather, and metal accents, centered around a 9-inch portrait-oriented Sensus touchscreen that controls most vehicle functions. Initially launched with a range of Drive-E four-cylinder engines, including turbocharged T5, turbo- and supercharged T6, and plug-in hybrid T8 twin-engine variants with up to 400 combined horsepower. Advanced safety and driver assistance systems are comprehensive, including Pilot Assist semi-autonomous driving capability, City Safety collision avoidance, and numerous other features that continue Volvo's safety leadership. The S90 Excellence, offered in select markets, provides an ultra-luxury experience with a four-seat configuration featuring exceptional rear-seat amenities.
Volvo-S90.name: First Generation

Volvo-S90.description: The 2020 facelift of the first-generation S90 introduced several design and technology updates. Exterior changes included new sequential LED taillight indicators and chrome garnish on the front bumper for Inscription variants. Mild-hybrid powertrains became more widespread across the range, with Volvo phasing out conventional engines in favor of electrified options. The T8 plug-in hybrid variant received enhanced electric motor output, while advanced safety features and driver assistance systems continued to set benchmarks in the segment. The S90 successfully positions Volvo as a distinctive alternative to established German luxury brands, offering a uniquely Scandinavian interpretation of premium automotive design and technology. The vehicle was discontinued in Western markets (US, Australia, Canada, Europe, India) in 2024 due to poor sales and tariff concerns on Chinese-built vehicles.
Volvo-S90.name: First Generation (2020 Facelift)

Volvo-V50.description: The Volvo V50 was the station wagon version of the Volvo S40 small family car, first unveiled at the 2003 Bologna Motor Show. Built on the Ford Global C-car Platform shared with the second-generation European Ford Focus and Mazda3, the V50 featured Volvo's innovative 'floating' center console design and interior 'theatre' lighting. The pre-facelift model featured the original front styling with a more traditional Volvo grille design. Powertrain options included four-cylinder petrol engines (1.6L, 1.8L, 2.0L, 2.4L) and five-cylinder units including the naturally aspirated 2.4i and the turbocharged T5 producing approximately 220 horsepower. Diesel options were available in Europe, including the 2.0D and D5 turbocharged diesel engines. All-wheel drive was available on T5 models. Safety remained a Volvo hallmark with the Side Impact Protection System and Whiplash Protection System. The pre-facelift V50 represented a complete redesign from the previous V40, offering more modern styling while maintaining Volvo's family wagon heritage.
Volvo-V50.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Volvo-V50.description: For the 2008 model year, the Volvo V50 received a significant facelift with revised front styling featuring a more modern grille and bumper design, along with minor interior modifications. The T5 engine received increased power and torque output. New options included active xenon headlights and updated audio systems. A six-speed manual transmission became available along with a new 1.8 Flexifuel engine capable of running on E85 ethanol. The D5 diesel engine became available with this update. In North America, the 2011 model year was the last for the V50, with production continuing in Belgium until December 2012. Total production reached 519,007 units from 2003 to 2012. The facelifted V50 maintained its reputation for safety while offering updated technology and more refined styling, appealing to families seeking a premium compact wagon with contemporary design.
Volvo-V50.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Volvo-V60.description: The first-generation Volvo V60 was introduced in autumn 2010 as a sporty, lifestyle-oriented wagon alternative to the more practical V70, sharing its platform and most components with the S60 sedan. Built on Ford's EUCD platform (later owned by Geely after their acquisition of Volvo), it featured a dynamic silhouette with a dramatically sloping roofline and an emphasis on style over maximum cargo capacity. Engine options varied by market but included various four, five, and six-cylinder petrol and diesel engines, with power outputs ranging from approximately 115 to 350 horsepower in the high-performance Polestar models. The interior showcased Volvo's Scandinavian design philosophy with a floating center console, high-quality materials, and intuitive controls. This generation pioneered several safety innovations, including Pedestrian Detection with full auto brake, City Safety collision avoidance, and various driver assistance systems. The V60 was available in various trim levels including R-Design for a sportier appearance and Ocean Race Edition with unique detailing.
Volvo-V60.name: First Generation

Volvo-V60.description: The facelifted first-generation Volvo V60 was introduced in 2014 with refreshed styling, updated technology, and an emphasis on efficiency. The exterior received revised front and rear bumpers, updated headlights, and new alloy wheel designs. A more significant update in 2016 introduced Volvo's new Drive-E four-cylinder engine family, replacing the older five and six-cylinder engines while improving fuel efficiency and reducing emissions. The plug-in hybrid variant (V60 Plug-in Hybrid/D6) was introduced, combining a five-cylinder diesel engine with an electric motor to achieve exceptional fuel economy and low CO2 emissions. The V60 Polestar performance variant received updates including a new four-cylinder turbo engine in 2016. The Cross Country variant was introduced in 2015 with increased ground clearance and standard all-wheel drive. This facelifted generation maintained Volvo's position as a leader in safety technology while offering progressive electrification options in the premium wagon segment.
Volvo-V60.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Volvo-V60.description: The second-generation Volvo V60 represents Volvo's thoroughly modern take on the premium mid-size wagon, built on the company's Scalable Product Architecture (SPA) shared with the S60, XC60, and larger 90-series models. The exterior design features clean, minimalist lines with distinctive Thor's Hammer LED headlights and more balanced proportions than its predecessor, offering increased interior space despite maintaining a sporty silhouette. A significant departure from the previous generation is the exclusive use of four-cylinder engines across the range, with various levels of electrification. Options include turbocharged B3/B4/B5 mild hybrid variants, turbo- and supercharged T6, and plug-in hybrid T8 twin-engine variants with the latter producing over 400 horsepower in Polestar Engineered form. The interior exemplifies Scandinavian luxury with premium materials, a tablet-style Sensus infotainment system (later Google-based), and minimal physical buttons. The more rugged Cross Country variant offers increased ground clearance, standard all-wheel drive, and body cladding for light off-road capability. Safety and driver assistance technology reached new heights with Pilot Assist semi-autonomous driving capabilities, cross-traffic alert with autobrake, and numerous other advanced features. The second-generation V60 has further refined Volvo's unique position in the market, offering distinctive design, progressive electrification technology, and class-leading safety in the increasingly niche premium wagon segment.
Volvo-V60.name: Second Generation

Volvo-V70.description: The first-generation Volvo V70 was essentially a significantly facelifted and renamed continuation of the Volvo 850 wagon, introduced in late 1996 as a 1997 model. While sharing the same core platform and mechanical components with the 850, the V70 featured smoother, more rounded exterior styling that moved away from the distinctly boxy design of its predecessor. The interior was also comprehensively redesigned with improved ergonomics, updated materials, and enhanced safety features. Powertrains carried over from the 850, consisting of various five-cylinder engines in naturally aspirated and turbocharged forms, with outputs ranging from approximately 126 to 250 horsepower. The high-performance V70 R featured a turbocharged five-cylinder engine producing up to 250 horsepower, available front-wheel drive or all-wheel drive, and unique styling elements. The V70 Cross Country (later XC70) variant introduced in 1997 added increased ground clearance, all-wheel drive, and body cladding for light off-road capability. The first-generation V70 maintained Volvo's reputation for safety innovation, featuring the Side Impact Protection System (SIPS), Whiplash Protection System (WHIPS), and side airbags. This generation helped modernize Volvo's design language while maintaining the brand's core values of safety, durability, and practicality.
Volvo-V70.name: First Generation

Volvo-V70.description: The second-generation V70 represented a complete redesign, moving to Volvo's P2 platform shared with the S60 sedan and XC90 SUV. The exterior featured a more refined evolution of Volvo's design language with smoother lines and a more upscale appearance. Interior space increased compared to its predecessor, with improved materials and build quality. Powertrains continued to center around Volvo's five-cylinder engines in various configurations, including naturally aspirated 2.4-liter units and turbocharged variants ranging from light-pressure turbo models to the high-performance T5 and R versions, the latter producing up to 300 horsepower. This generation saw significant advances in safety technology, including available features like Blind Spot Information System (BLIS), adaptive cruise control, and enhanced structural protection. The XC70 cross-country variant continued with increased ground clearance, standard all-wheel drive, and rugged body cladding. A facelift in 2004 updated the styling, interior features, and technology. The second-generation V70 successfully built upon Volvo's wagon heritage with increased refinement, performance, and technology, maintaining its position as a practical yet premium alternative to the growing SUV segment.
Volvo-V70.name: Second Generation

Volvo-V70.description: The third-generation V70 moved to Ford's EUCD platform shared with the S80 sedan, marking a further step upmarket in size, refinement, and technology. The exterior design featured a more distinctive front end with angled headlights and a sculpted hood, while maintaining the traditional wagon silhouette. The interior offered increased passenger and cargo space, with a floating center console design, premium materials, and advanced technology features. Engine options evolved throughout this generation, beginning with a range of inline-five and inline-six cylinder engines, later transitioning to Volvo's new Drive-E four-cylinder engines focusing on efficiency without sacrificing performance. Safety innovation continued with features like City Safety automatic braking, Driver Alert Control, and Lane Departure Warning. The XC70 cross-country variant again offered increased ground clearance and all-wheel drive capability. A significant update in 2013 refreshed the styling and interior technology while introducing the new family of Drive-E engines. The third-generation V70 was the final iteration of Volvo's mid-size wagon under this nameplate, as it was replaced by the V90 in 2016. Throughout its run, it maintained Volvo's reputation for safety, practicality, and understated luxury, appealing to discerning buyers seeking an alternative to both premium sedans and increasingly popular SUVs.
Volvo-V70.name: Third Generation

Volvo-V90-Cross-Country.description: The Volvo V90 Cross Country is the rugged, adventure-oriented variant of the V90 luxury wagon, continuing Volvo's Cross Country tradition that began with the V70 XC in 1997. Launched in 2017 as part of Volvo's revitalized 90-series lineup, it's built on the Scalable Product Architecture (SPA) platform shared with the standard V90, S90, and XC90. The Cross Country features increased ground clearance (approximately 65mm higher than the standard V90), standard all-wheel drive, and protective body cladding around the wheel arches, side sills, and bumpers. The exterior design shares the elegant, clean lines of the V90 but with a more robust, adventure-ready appearance. The interior is nearly identical to the standard V90, showcasing Scandinavian luxury with premium materials including wood, leather, and metal accents, centered around a 9-inch portrait-oriented touchscreen that controls most vehicle functions. Powertrain options included various Drive-E four-cylinder engines, primarily the T5 turbocharged and T6 turbo- and supercharged variants. Advanced safety and driver assistance systems are comprehensive, including Pilot Assist semi-autonomous driving capability, City Safety collision avoidance, and numerous other features that continue Volvo's safety leadership. The V90 Cross Country successfully combines luxury, versatility, and all-road capability, appealing to outdoor enthusiasts who prefer wagons to traditional SUVs.
Volvo-V90-Cross-Country.name: First Generation

Volvo-V90-Cross-Country.description: The facelifted Volvo V90 Cross Country debuted in February 2020 with updated styling and technology. The exterior changes include taillights with sequential LED indicators, while Inscription variants received a chrome garnish on the front bumper. Inside, the 9-inch portrait-oriented touchscreen continued to control most functions with updated software and connectivity features. The powertrain lineup evolved significantly: 2022 introduced mild hybrid technology replacing the belt-driven supercharger with an electric one and adding a Belt Alternator Starter (BAS) unit for improved fuel economy. By 2023, Volvo removed conventional engines as options entirely, making mild hybrids the standard. The T8 plug-in hybrid continued throughout this period. Advanced safety systems remained comprehensive, including Pilot Assist semi-autonomous driving capability and City Safety collision avoidance. The V90 Cross Country continued to offer elevated ground clearance, standard AWD, and rugged body cladding for adventure-ready capability while maintaining its luxury wagon character.
Volvo-V90-Cross-Country.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Volvo-V90CC.description: The Volvo V90 Cross Country is the rugged, adventure-oriented variant of the V90 luxury wagon, continuing Volvo's Cross Country tradition that began with the V70 XC in 1997. Launched in 2017 as part of Volvo's revitalized 90-series lineup, it's built on the Scalable Product Architecture (SPA) platform shared with the standard V90, S90, and XC90. The Cross Country features increased ground clearance (approximately 65mm higher than the standard V90), standard all-wheel drive, and protective body cladding around the wheel arches, side sills, and bumpers. The exterior design shares the elegant, clean lines of the V90 but with a more robust, adventure-ready appearance. The interior is nearly identical to the standard V90, showcasing Scandinavian luxury with premium materials including wood, leather, and metal accents, centered around a 9-inch portrait-oriented touchscreen that controls most vehicle functions. Powertrain options included various Drive-E four-cylinder engines, primarily the T5 turbocharged and T6 turbo- and supercharged variants. Advanced safety and driver assistance systems are comprehensive, including Pilot Assist semi-autonomous driving capability, City Safety collision avoidance, and numerous other features that continue Volvo's safety leadership. The V90CC successfully combines luxury, versatility, and all-road capability, appealing to outdoor enthusiasts who prefer wagons to traditional SUVs.
Volvo-V90CC.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Volvo-V90CC.description: The facelifted Volvo V90 Cross Country debuted in early 2020 with updated styling and technology. Key exterior changes included new taillights with sequential LED indicators and chrome garnish on the front bumper for Inscription variants. Interior technology updates improved connectivity and user experience. In 2022, Volvo introduced updated mild hybrid powertrains that replaced the belt-driven supercharger with an electric one and added a Belt Alternator Starter (BAS) unit for improved fuel economy. By 2023, Volvo removed conventional engines entirely from the lineup, making mild hybrids the standard powertrain option. The facelifted V90CC continued to offer the same blend of luxury, versatility, and all-road capability while benefiting from improved efficiency and updated technology features.
Volvo-V90CC.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Volvo-XC40.description: The Volvo XC40 is Volvo's first compact luxury crossover SUV, unveiled on September 21, 2017 as the smallest member of Volvo's SUV lineup below the XC60. Built on the Compact Modular Architecture (CMA) platform developed with parent company Geely, it features distinctive styling that maintains Volvo's design language while incorporating youthful, urban elements like an available contrasting roof, bold character lines, and the signature Thor's Hammer LED headlights. The interior offers a modern, minimalist approach with high-quality materials, clever storage solutions throughout the cabin, and a 9-inch Sensus touchscreen infotainment system. Initially launched with a range of engines including 1.5-liter three-cylinder and 2.0-liter four-cylinder engines in both diesel (D3/D4) and petrol variants (T3, T4, T5). In the US market, engine choices were limited to the 2.0-liter four-cylinder petrol-powered T4 and T5 models. The plug-in hybrid T5 Twin Engine was introduced in 2019, combining a 180 hp petrol engine with a 74 kW electric motor. The XC40 Recharge pure electric model was added in late 2020, marking Volvo's first all-electric production vehicle with a 78 kWh battery pack. Safety features are comprehensive, including City Safety collision avoidance, Pilot Assist semi-autonomous driving capability, and numerous advanced driver assistance systems. The XC40 won European Car of the Year 2018 and Car of the Year Japan for 2018/2019.
Volvo-XC40.name: First Generation (Pre-Facelift)

Volvo-XC40.description: The XC40 received a significant facelift for the 2023 model year. The refreshed model features aesthetic changes that bring it more into line with the C40 Recharge, including updated headlights, bumpers, and integration of Android Automotive for the mild hybrid models. Diesel-powered models were dropped from the lineup entirely. In 2023, Volvo made mild hybrids the base engine option in the US market, removing conventional engines as an option. The single-motor electric version was revised to adopt a rear-wheel drive layout instead of front-wheel drive, making it the first rear-wheel-drive Volvo vehicle in 25 years. The electric version received improved range and efficiency with a new motor. In 2024, Volvo renamed the battery electric XC40 to the Volvo EX40, aligning it with newer battery electric models such as the EX30 and EX90. The facelift also introduced a new ADAS sensor platform for enhanced safety features.
Volvo-XC40.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Volvo-XC40-Recharge.description: The Volvo XC40 Recharge is Volvo's first all-electric vehicle, based on the conventional XC40 compact luxury crossover. Introduced in 2020, it represents a pivotal step in Volvo's commitment to electrification and sustainability. While sharing the basic exterior and interior design with the standard XC40, the Recharge features distinctive elements including a closed-off front grille (as no traditional radiator is needed), unique wheel designs, and model-specific color options. Initially launched as the P8 AWD model, it features a dual-motor electric powertrain producing 402 horsepower (300 kW) and 486 lb-ft of torque, enabling a 0-60 mph time of approximately 4.7 seconds. Power comes from a 78 kWh battery pack providing an EPA-rated range of around 223 miles (later improved in subsequent model years). The interior offers the same practical and stylish cabin as the standard XC40 but was among the first Volvo models to feature the Google-based infotainment system with built-in Google Maps, Google Assistant, and access to the Google Play Store. The lack of an internal combustion engine creates additional front storage space (frunk). Safety features remain comprehensive, including all of Volvo's advanced driver assistance systems. In 2022, a single-motor front-wheel drive variant was added to the lineup, offering increased range and a lower entry price. In 2023, a rear-wheel drive variant was introduced as an alternative to the front-wheel drive option. The XC40 Recharge was renamed to the EX40 in 2024 as part of Volvo's new naming strategy for electric vehicles. The XC40 Recharge successfully combines Volvo's premium qualities and safety leadership with zero-emission electric propulsion, appealing to environmentally conscious luxury buyers.
Volvo-XC40-Recharge.name: First Generation

Volvo-XC40-T4-Recharge.description: The Volvo XC40 T4 Recharge is a plug-in hybrid (PHEV) variant of Volvo's compact luxury crossover, introduced in 2020 as part of the company's electrification strategy. Based on the conventional XC40, it combines a 1.5-liter three-cylinder turbocharged petrol engine (B3154T10) with an electric motor for a combined output of approximately 211 horsepower. The T4 Recharge is front-wheel drive only, distinguishing it from the more powerful T5 Recharge PHEV which offered all-wheel drive. The electric motor is powered by a 10.7 kWh lithium-ion battery pack enabling an electric-only range of approximately 27-28 miles (44-45 km) on the WLTP cycle. Visually, the T4 Recharge is distinguished from conventional XC40 models by specific badges and the addition of a charging port on the front fender. The interior features Volvo's distinctive Scandinavian design with high-quality materials, a 9-inch touchscreen infotainment system, and numerous clever storage solutions. Safety features are comprehensive, including City Safety collision avoidance, Pilot Assist semi-autonomous driving capability, and numerous advanced driver assistance systems. The XC40 T4 Recharge served as an entry point to Volvo's electrified lineup, offering reduced emissions and the ability to complete short commutes on electric power alone. Production ended in 2023 as Volvo shifted focus to fully electric models like the EX40.
Volvo-XC40-T4-Recharge.name: First Generation

Volvo-XC60.description: The first-generation Volvo XC60 was introduced as a compact luxury crossover SUV positioned between the XC70 and XC90 in Volvo's lineup. Built on Volvo's P3 platform (shared with S60, V60), it featured distinctive styling with a coupe-like roofline and Volvo's signature shoulder line. Powertrain options included various five and six-cylinder petrol and diesel engines, with the T6 model featuring a turbocharged inline-six producing around 300 horsepower. All-wheel drive was standard or optional. The interior showcased Scandinavian design with Volvo's floating center console and high-quality materials. Safety was a major selling point, with City Safety low-speed automatic braking system as standard—a first in the industry. A significant facelift in 2013 updated exterior styling, grille, front lights, and introduced new materials and dashboard trims with a 7-inch display. The first-generation XC60 proved to be Volvo's most popular model globally since 2009, successfully blending practicality, safety, and premium features.
Volvo-XC60.name: First Generation

Volvo-XC60.description: The second-generation Volvo XC60, built on Volvo's Scalable Product Architecture (SPA) platform shared with the 90-series models, was unveiled at the 2017 Geneva Motor Show. The exterior design evolved Volvo's language with refined proportions, distinctive Thor's Hammer LED headlights, and a more athletic stance. The interior represents a significant upgrade with premium materials, minimalist Scandinavian design centered around a 9-inch portrait-oriented touchscreen. A key departure is the exclusive use of four-cylinder engines with various electrification levels: T5 (turbocharged), T6 (turbo and supercharged), D4/D5 diesels, and T8 Twin Engine plug-in hybrids producing up to 400 combined horsepower. Mild hybrid technology was introduced in 2020. Safety reached new heights with Pilot Assist semi-autonomous driving and advanced collision avoidance. A 2021 facelift introduced Google-based infotainment systems, with another facelift in August 2025 bringing a redesigned grille, larger 11.2-inch touchscreen, and updated digital instrument cluster. The second-generation XC60 has continued as Volvo's best-selling model, winning 2018 World Car of the Year.
Volvo-XC60.name: Second Generation

Volvo-XC90.description: The first-generation Volvo XC90 was Volvo's pioneering entry into the luxury SUV market, introduced at the 2002 North American International Auto Show and built on the P2 platform shared with the S80 sedan. Production began in August 2002 at Volvo's Torslandaverken in Sweden. The exterior featured traditional Volvo design elements adapted to an SUV form, with a boxy yet refined silhouette, distinctive tail lamps, and a practical seven-seat configuration. Initially offered with a range of engines including five-cylinder turbocharged petrol (2.5T, 3.2L) and diesel options, a 2.9L twin-turbocharged inline-six (T6), and a Yamaha-developed 4.4L V8 introduced in 2005, the XC90 provided varied performance options across different markets. The interior emphasized versatility with three rows of seats, the second and third of which could fold flat to create a substantial cargo area. Safety innovations were numerous, including Roll Stability Control (industry-first in 2003), a reinforced roof structure marketed as ROPS, and advanced side-impact protection (SIPS) that helped the XC90 achieve class-leading safety ratings including IIHS Top Safety Pick. The XC90 won Motor Trend's 2003 SUV of the Year and North American Car of the Year. Production continued in China as the XC Classic from 2014-2016 after Swedish production ended.
Volvo-XC90.name: First Generation (2002)

Volvo-XC90.description: The 2007 facelift brought significant updates to the first-generation XC90. The exterior received a redesigned front and rear fascia, giving the vehicle a more modern appearance while maintaining its distinctive Volvo identity. The interior was revised with updated materials and technology offerings. For the US market, the base 2.5L five-cylinder engine was replaced by a new 3.2L straight-six SI6 engine. The facelifted XC90 debuted at the New York Auto Show in April 2006 for the 2007 model year. The 2009 model year introduced a new rear logo with larger lettering and wider spacing between 'VOLVO' letters, along with a new circular Volvo logo on the front grille. For 2010, painted wheel arches became standard (previously optional). This facelift period maintained the same P2 platform but offered improved refinement and updated technology throughout.
Volvo-XC90.name: First Generation (2007 Facelift)

Volvo-XC90.description: The 2012/2013 facelift introduced more significant visual updates to the first-generation XC90. New LED tail-lights became available on higher trim levels, while entry-level models retained the previous style. For the 2013 model year, the XC90 received a cosmetic refresh that included standard LED daytime running lights and taillights, along with exterior revisions including body-color bumpers, rocker panels, and silver trim replacing the previous black plastic trim. This facelift represented the final iteration of the first-generation XC90 before the transition to the second generation in 2015. The updated model went on sale during late spring 2012 with improved standard features and technology while maintaining the versatile seven-seat configuration and robust safety credentials that defined the first-generation XC90.
Volvo-XC90.name: First Generation (2012 Facelift)

Volvo-XC90.description: The second-generation Volvo XC90, introduced for the 2015 model year, represented a complete reinvention and served as the flagship for Volvo's transformation under Geely ownership. Unveiled in Stockholm on August 26, 2014, it was built on the new Scalable Product Architecture (SPA) platform featuring stronger construction, weight reduction, and improved safety. The exterior featured a distinctive design with Thor's Hammer LED daytime running lights, a bold new grille, and the company's prominent iron mark. The interior showcased Scandinavian luxury with premium materials including wood, leather, and metal accents, centered around a 9-inch portrait-oriented Sensus touchscreen controlling most vehicle functions. All engines were 2.0-liter four-cylinder Drive-E powertrains including turbocharged T5, twincharged T6, diesel D4 and D5, with an eight-speed Geartronic automatic transmission. The T8 Twin Engine plug-in hybrid combined a turbo- and supercharged petrol engine with electric motors for nearly 400 horsepower. Safety technology included City Safety with auto brake at intersections, Run-off-road protection, and Pilot Assist semi-autonomous driving. The First Edition of 1,927 numbered cars sold out in 47 hours. The XC90 won Motor Trend's 2016 SUV of the Year and 2016 North American Truck/Utility of the Year.
Volvo-XC90.name: Second Generation (2015)

Volvo-XC90.description: The mid-cycle facelift for the 2020 model year brought significant updates to the second-generation XC90. The exterior received revised front and rear fascias with a new front grille design, new exterior colors, and updated wheel designs. The Sensus infotainment system became compatible with Android Auto, and a new kinetic energy recovery braking system (B5/B6 MHEV) was added. For the 2021 model year, the T8 powertrain was renamed 'XC90 Recharge' with updated electric motor delivering more power and increased battery capacity. The trim structure evolved in 2022, replacing Momentum/R-Design/Inscription with Core/Plus/Ultimate naming while adding more standard features. The powertrain lineup included B5 (MHEV), B6 (MHEV), T5, T6, and T8 Recharge (PHEV) variants. This facelift maintained the distinctive Thor's Hammer headlights and premium interior while improving efficiency through mild hybridization across most variants. The T8 Recharge plug-in hybrid continued to offer strong performance with improved all-electric range.
Volvo-XC90.name: Second Generation (2020 Facelift)

Volvo-XC90.description: The September 2024 facelift for the 2025 model year brought comprehensive updates to the second-generation XC90. The exterior features a redesigned front fascia with new headlights and grille design, a modified front bumper, and updated tinted LED taillights. The interior received a new 11.2-inch touchscreen infotainment system, increased storage spaces with a repositioned wireless charging pad, redesigned air vents, and decorative materials made from recycled materials. Sound insulation was improved for a quieter cabin. For 2025, the Ultimate trim was renamed Ultra. The powertrain lineup continues with mild hybrid B5 and B6 variants, T5/T6 engines, and the T8 Recharge plug-in hybrid. Volvo confirmed in March 2024 that the XC90 was the final Volvo car built with a diesel engine. Despite the introduction of the all-electric EX90 as a potential successor, Volvo stated both models would be sold together for the foreseeable future. This facelift represents the most technologically advanced version of the second-generation XC90, with enhanced connectivity and refined comfort while maintaining Volvo's safety leadership.
Volvo-XC90.name: Second Generation (2025 Facelift)

Voyah-Free.description: The original Voyah Free was the first production model from Voyah, the premium electric vehicle brand of Chinese state-owned Dongfeng Motor Corporation. Introduced in Q3 2021, the Free is a mid-size luxury SUV designed to compete with established premium electric vehicles. The exterior styling was led by Italian design house Italdesign Giugiaro, resulting in a sleek, modern appearance with a distinctive front light bar, floating roof design, and flush door handles. The vehicle was offered in both pure electric (EV) and extended-range electric vehicle (EREV) configurations. The EV version featured a dual-motor all-wheel-drive setup producing approximately 510 horsepower with an 88 kWh battery pack, while the EREV variant combined a smaller battery with a 1.5-liter turbocharged petrol engine acting as a generator (Dongfeng C15TDR series engine with 41.07% thermal efficiency), extending the total range. The interior offered a premium experience with high-quality materials, a minimalist design centered around a large central touchscreen and digital instrument cluster, and extensive ambient lighting. Advanced technology features included facial recognition, augmented reality head-up display, level 2+ driver assistance systems with three millimeter wave radars, 9 cameras, and 12 ultrasonic radars. Series production began in late January 2021. The electric model was discontinued in August 2023.
Voyah-Free.name: First Generation

Voyah-Free.description: The 2023 facelift of the Voyah Free brought updated specifications while maintaining the same platform. The pure electric version was discontinued, leaving only the extended-range (EREV) model available. The battery capacity increased to 39 kWh for the EREV variant. Voyah also introduced the high-performance limited edition model called Voyah Free DNA, featuring even higher power output (4.3 second 0-100 km/h acceleration), a dual motor AWD system with comprehensive maximum power of 360/490 kW/ps, and a special body kit with exterior modifications. The facelifted models retained the premium interior with air suspension, comprehensive driver assistance features including active night vision system effective up to 150 meters, and the signature Italian-designed exterior styling.
Voyah-Free.name: First Generation (Facelift)

Voyah-Free.description: The Voyah Free+ is a completely new generation that replaced the original Free in 2025. Unveiled at Auto Shanghai 2025, the Free+ features the 'City Light and Shadow Aesthetics' design language with increased dimensions - length and width have grown while the wheelbase increased by 70mm. The interior features a 10.25-inch digital instrument cluster, a 29-inch AR-HUD, and a 15.6-inch 2K central infotainment touchscreen running Huawei's HarmonySpace 5 cockpit system, plus a rear control touchscreen for passengers. All seats have heating and ventilation functions, with the front passenger seat reclining up to 163 degrees. The center console includes 50-watt active cooled wireless charging and a refrigerator. It features a 22-speaker Huawei Sound system and a panoramic sunroof. The Free+ is one of the first vehicles equipped with Huawei's ADS 4.0 system, featuring a 29-sensor suite including one 192-line LiDAR, three 4D mmWave radars, and 11 cameras for L2 semiautonomous driving. The Free+ is available exclusively with a range-extender powertrain using a 1.5-liter turbocharged inline-four engine generator combined with a 43.2 kWh LFP battery capable of 3C charging (20-80% in 20 minutes). Both RWD (318 variant) and AWD configurations are available.
Voyah-Free.name: Second Generation (Free+)

Zeekr-009.description: The Zeekr 009 is a battery electric luxury minivan from Zeekr, the premium electric vehicle brand owned by Geely Automobile Holdings. Presented in early 2022 and deliveries beginning in Q1 2023, the 009 is built on Geely's Sustainable Experience Architecture 1 (SEA1) platform. The vehicle features a distinctive design with an illuminated grille, split headlight arrangement, and power-operated sliding doors. Available in multiple configurations including 4-seat Grand (launched April 2024), 6-seat Platinum (2+2+2), and 7-seat Premium/Deluxe (2+2+3) layouts with luxury amenities such as captain's chairs, heating, ventilation, massage functions, and premium materials including Nappa leather. The 009 is offered with dual-motor all-wheel-drive producing 400-580 kW, enabling 0-100 km/h acceleration in approximately 4.5 seconds. Battery options include 108 kWh, 116 kWh CATL NCM, and 140 kWh CATL Qilin batteries with ranges from 582 to 900 km depending on cycle testing. Technology features include Qualcomm Snapdragon processors (8155 and 8295), 15.4-inch central touchscreen, 17-inch rear LCD screen, digital instrument cluster, and Yamaha 30-speaker audio system. The 009 has sold over 41,800 units in China (19,210 in 2023, 22,631 in 2024) and represents Geely's commitment to premium electric vehicle design and technology.
Zeekr-009.name: First Generation

smart-fortwo.description: The first-generation smart fortwo (originally marketed simply as the 'smart city-coupé' until 2004) revolutionized urban mobility with its ultra-compact dimensions, measuring just 2.5 meters in length. Developed as a joint venture between Swatch and Mercedes-Benz (later fully acquired by Daimler-Benz), the fortwo featured a distinctive two-tone color scheme with a visible 'Tridion' safety cell surrounding the passenger compartment. The rear-engined, rear-wheel-drive layout maximized interior space within the minimal footprint, with a 599cc three-cylinder turbocharged engine initially producing 45 or 55 horsepower, later expanded to a 698cc version with up to 61 horsepower. Transmission was provided by a six-speed automated manual, which was notoriously jerky in early models but improved with successive updates. Available in closed coupé or semi-convertible 'cabrio' body styles, the fortwo offered surprisingly practical features including interchangeable body panels, a split tailgate, and a relatively spacious interior for two occupants despite the car's tiny exterior dimensions. Safety was addressed through the robust Tridion cell, crumple zones, and standard ABS, though early models received mixed crash test results. A facelift in 2002 brought improved quality, refined transmission operation, and additional features. While initially met with skepticism and frequently the subject of jokes, the first-generation fortwo successfully established itself as a pioneering urban vehicle particularly suited to congested European cities with limited parking, eventually selling over 770,000 units worldwide and spawning a new category of ultra-compact urban cars.
smart-fortwo.name: First Generation (W450)

smart-fortwo.description: The second-generation smart fortwo maintained the revolutionary concept of its predecessor while addressing many of its shortcomings. Still built around a visible Tridion safety cell, the new fortwo grew slightly to 2.69 meters in length, improving crash protection and ride quality without compromising its city-friendly dimensions. The design evolved with more mature styling and improved aerodynamics while maintaining the distinctive smart aesthetic. Powertrain options expanded to include naturally aspirated and turbocharged versions of a 1.0-liter three-cylinder gasoline engine with power outputs ranging from 61 to 102 horsepower (in the Brabus performance version), along with a 0.8-liter diesel in some markets. The problematic transmission from the first generation was replaced with an improved five-speed automated manual, though shifts remained less refined than conventional automatics. The model range again included coupé and cabrio body styles, with the cabrio featuring a power-operated canvas roof that could be opened partially or fully. Interior quality improved significantly with better materials and more sophisticated design, while safety enhancements included standard ESP electronic stability control across the range. For the first time, a fully electric version (ED - Electric Drive) was offered in limited markets beginning in 2009, with a second-generation ED arriving in 2012 featuring improved range and performance. Special editions like the 'Passion,' 'BRABUS,' and 'Edition Limited Three' offered unique styling and equipment combinations. The second-generation fortwo expanded into new markets including the United States, where it offered the highest fuel economy of any gasoline-powered vehicle at the time, though its specialized nature limited appeal in regions where parking and congestion were less problematic than in European urban centers.
smart-fortwo.name: Second Generation (W451)

smart-fortwo.description: The third-generation smart fortwo represented the most comprehensive redesign in the model's history, now developed as a joint project with Renault (which used the same platform for its Twingo). While maintaining the iconic proportions and Tridion safety cell, the new fortwo grew marginally to 2.7 meters in length but featured significantly improved engineering, notably a wider track that enhanced both stability and interior space. The distinctive rear-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout continued, but with all-new powertrains: a 1.0-liter naturally aspirated three-cylinder producing 71 horsepower or a 0.9-liter turbocharged three-cylinder with 90 horsepower. Most significantly, the much-criticized automated manual transmission was replaced with either a five-speed manual or a much smoother dual-clutch automatic (twinamic). The turning circle was further reduced to just 6.95 meters curb-to-curb, making it unrivaled for urban maneuverability. Available again in coupé and cabrio body styles, the third-generation fortwo featured more modern styling with a more prominent front grille, larger headlights, and a more substantial appearance despite its tiny dimensions. The interior saw major improvements with higher quality materials, a more contemporary design, and improved technology including a touchscreen infotainment system with smartphone integration. Safety systems expanded to include Crosswind Assist as standard, with forward collision warning and lane-keeping assist available as options. In March 2018, electric versions were rebranded as the 'smart EQ fortwo' to align with Mercedes-Benz's electric vehicle branding strategy. A facelift in late 2019 introduced updated styling and technology features while maintaining the same platform. The electric version featured an 80 horsepower electric motor and a 17.6 kWh battery providing approximately 100 miles of range. This generation introduced a new level of sophistication to the fortwo formula, making it a more viable everyday car while maintaining its unique positioning as the ultimate urban mobility solution. Production ended in 2024 after 26 years of continuous production across three platform generations.
smart-fortwo.name: Third Generation (C453)
